title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVEE, JOHN CHRISTOPHER
description: BOVEE-John Christopher. Jan. 31, 1997, at home from complications due to AIDS. Survived by his mother, Doris Abeel Bovee, his maternal grandfather, Joseph Abeel and his companion, David R. McGehean. He was pre-deceased by his father, Eugene Leon Bovee and his brother Eugene Joseph Bovee. Friends may call at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Monday, February 3, 24PM and 7-9PM. Funeral service on Tuesday, Febuary 4, 11:30AM. Interment at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Sixth Ave., New York, New York 10013 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, ELI
description: BLOOM-Eli. Loving friend of Chan Jones. Adored father of Edward and Laura. Cherished grandfather of Molly and Max Bloom, and Miles Chandler. Dear brother of Jeanette Bronstein. He was a mentor to many and a friend to all. An icon in the automotive industry. Oh how we miss you, Dear Eli. Memorial service at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 7PM, Wed. 2/5/97.

title: Simpson Juror Is Dismissed; Deliberations to Start Anew
description: A new element of surprise and doubt was suddenly injected into O. J. Simpson's civil trial today when the only black woman on the jury was dismissed for failing to disclose that her daughter worked for the prosecutors who had tried Mr. Simpson on criminal charges.

title: Thomas Belk, 71, Retailing Executive At Family Chain
description: Thomas M. Belk, the president of Belk Stores Services, a quietly run department store chain in Charlotte, N.C., died at Presbyterian Hospital there last Saturday. Mr. Belk, who was 71, suffered complications following gallbladder surgery, according to his secretary, Susan Blount.

title: Schubert, Vast or Intimate, Doesn't Show His Age: 200
description: When Kurt Masur was making plans for the New York Philharmonic's commemoration this weekend of Schubert's 200th birthday, he knew that his program must include the ''Great'' Symphony in C. This sprawling work, Schubert's last completed symphony, is the pinnacle of the composer's achievement in the symphonic genre, and on Thursday night Mr. Masur and the orchestra performed it compellingly.

title: States Given More Latitude In Following Welfare Law
description: The Clinton Administration told state officials today that they could generally spend state money as they wished under the new welfare law, provided that they did not ''circumvent the work requirements'' imposed by Congress.

title: OSHMAN'S PLANS TO CLOSE 50 STORES IN COST-SAVING MOVE
description: Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. said yesterday that it would close 50 smaller stores this year, causing an unspecified number of layoffs. The retailer operates 115 stores in 16 states. The company said it would take an $11 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the closings, but expected the move to save $3.5 million annually. Oshman's said it expected to report that fourth-quarter sales fell to $112 million, from $117.3 million the year before. The lower sales, combined with the loss on the store closings, would cause Oshman's to lose $10 million to $12 million, or $1.72 to $2.06 a share, in the fourth quarter. In American Stock Exchange trading, Oshman's shares rose 31.25 cents yesterday , to close at $5.1875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, KATHLEEN BRENNAN
description: HUGHES-Kathleen Brennan. On Jan. 30, 1997. Former Executive Secretary to the Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, Secretary to Mayor Vincent Impellitari, active member of Saint Emeric's Altar and Rosary Society and Ladies of Charity, New York City. Loving mother of Donald and Joan Hughes. Proud grandmother of Christopher Barry and Victoria Hughes. Dear great grandmother of Kathleen Elizabeth. Wake Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 Street, New York City. Funeral Monday 10AM, Saint Emeric's Church.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: A Test for Christ the King

title: 46-Month Sentence in Internet Stock Fraud
description: The former chairman of Systems of Excellence Inc. was sentenced to 46 months in prison yesterday for his role in a multimillion-dollar stock fraud that used the Internet to promote his company's shares.

title: Swap Carries Price the Jets Cannot Afford
description: Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, has presented the Jets with the choice of the lady or the tiger: if the Jets want Bill Parcells as their coach, the price is their No. 1 pick over all.

title: Giuliani Says He Feels Bad For Dinkins, But No Anger
description: If there were any remaining doubts that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would love to run against his predecessor, David N. Dinkins, Mr. Giuliani appeared to put them to rest yesterday.

title: SAP Says Net Was Up 40% in 1996
description: SAP A.G., a maker of business management software, said yesterday that 1996 net profit rose 40 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, CELIA
description: FRIEDMAN-Celia. February 16, 1908-January 10, 1997. Devoted wife of David Friedman (previously deceased). Loving mother of Paula, Ben and Eleanor. Adoring grandmother of Russell Goldberg. Homemaker. Remembered for her personal qualities and natural beauty, she will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELVERNE, MARTIN M.
description: SELVERNE-Martin M. Remembered and remembered and rememberedalways with love.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Challenging Orthodoxies

title: C. E. Inniss, 61; Was a Leader In Many Causes
description: Charles E. Inniss, a retired vice president of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the chairman of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, died on Thursday at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Mr. Inniss, who lived in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, was 61.

title: EGGHEAD TO CLOSE 77 STORES AND CUT WORK FORCE
description: Egghead Inc. said yesterday that it would close 77 of its 156 stores and cut its work force 44 percent as part of a reorganization. Terence M. Strom, chief executive, would step down, along with two senior vice presidents, Kurt Conklin and Ron Smith. The chairman, George P. Orban, would take on the additional duties of chief executive. Egghead also said that sales at stores open a year fell 8 percent in the three months that ended Dec. 28. In its 1996 fiscal year, which ended March 29, the company posted a net loss of $10.7 million, or 62 cents a share. Egghead said it would lay off 800 of its 1,800 employees. Restructuring costs are expected to reduce earnings by about $30 million in the fiscal fourth quarter. In the corresponding period last year, the company posted a loss of $3.1 million, or 19 cents a share. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Egghead fell 62.5 cents, to $5.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRANTE DI RUFFANO, GIOVANNI
description: FERRANTE di RUFFANO-Giovanni, age 68. Died on January 27 in Cazenovia, New York. He is survived by his stepchildren: Genevieve H. Swanson, Ward and Robert Hewins, all children of his beloved wife, Jane Gellert Hewins Ferrante di Ruffano, who predeceased him. Also survived by children of his first wife, Georgette Davis: Giaff, Cam, Gray, Francesca, Catherine, Virginia and Philip, their families and seventeen grandchildren. Also survived by siblings: Mse. Antonio Ferrante di Ruffano, Virginia MacVeagh, Bssa. Gloria Gasparini and Roberto Ferrante di Ruffano. Mr. Ferrante, a Technical Advisor, had recently retired from Johnson & Johnson's Worldwide Group, after twenty-one years employment.

title: Fujimori Softens Tone Before Talks in Canada
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori flew today to Toronto, where he is to meet on Saturday with the Japanese Prime Minister to discuss Peru's handling of the hostage siege at the Japanese Embassy residence in Lima.

title: Ex-Guard Holds 5 Hostages for Hours Before Surrender
description: A former security guard, distraught over his relationship with his former girlfriend, took the woman, their two children and members of her family hostage yesterday, threatening to kill them and holding the police at bay for six hours outside a Brooklyn apartment building.

title: A Fraternity Of Officers Is Divided
description: VICTOR ORTIZ longs for his youth. There was a time, recalled Mr. Ortiz, a 72-year-old retired police detective, when he could speak off the cuff and ''create a little fire.'' He walks with a cane, slightly stooped and slowed by terminal spinal cancer.

title: Toy Makers Win Restrictions In Lawsuit Over Trade Show
description: A Federal judge has given at least a partial victory to a toy-manufacturers group in its battle with its landlord over the American International Toy Fair, the industry's premier trade show.

title: Isles' Canadian Bust Ends With 1-0 Defeat
description: The Islanders may sometimes play as though they are from outer space, but they do not defy the laws of gravity. For the Islanders, what goes up must indeed come down.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about a writing workshop for early-stage Alzheimer's patients misspelled the given name of a participant. She is Sarita Stein, not Serita.

title: Take This TV Talk Show Host. Please.
description: One thing can certainly be said for Rodney Dangerfield's frantic new comedy, ''Meet Wally Sparks.'' In its goofy adolescent way, this spoof of television talk shows and the pious politicians who hate them addresses a subject that is very much on people's minds. Mr. Dangerfield's character, Wally Sparks, happens to be the most tasteless (and popular) talk-show host on television. He is a folk hero whose notion of uplifting entertainment is to plant a banana in a woman's cleavage and then try to consume it while remaining, as he leeringly puts it, ''a gentleman.''

title: SINCLAIR BROADCAST TO ADD TV AND RADIO STATIONS
description: The Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a Las Vegas, Nev., television station for $87 million and two Buffalo radio stations for $1.5 million. The company did not disclose the seller or sellers. Sinclair will buy KUPN-TV, an affiliate of the UPN network, and WGR-AM and WWWS-AM, for which the company already sells advertising time as part of a joint sales agreement. Sinclair owns or provides programming to 28 television stations in 20 markets and owns, has options to buy or provides sales and programming to 33 radio stations in 8 markets. In Nasdaq trading, Sinclair rose 25 cents, to $25.50 yesterday.

title: Mayor Rebuts Criticism Of Budget Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani staunchly defended his new preliminary budget yesterday against criticism that he had not done enough to address New York City's long-term financial ills, maintaining that he had devoted a significant portion of a $1.2 billion windfall in tax revenues to whittling down future deficits.

title: Teen-Agers Charged In Son's Death Return Home
description: As two hovering news helicopters chattered overhead, Amy S. Grossberg and Brian C. Peterson Jr. returned to their suburban homes here today to begin a 7 1/2-month wait for their trial on charges of murdering their newborn son last Nov. 12 at a Delaware motel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEPRIN, SYLVIA LEAH (NEE BROD)
description: WEPRIN-Sylvia Leah (nee Brod). Beloved daughter of Harry and Bessie E. Brod. Devoted wife to Louis Weprin and loving mother to Joel, Ruth, Natalie, Barry and Earle. Proud grandmother to Julie, Peter, Eric, Angela and David. Mrs. Weprin achieved a fullness of life, dedicated to service and love to her family and community.

title: Caltex to Dismiss 50 on Singapore Staff
description: Caltex Petroleum said it would dismiss 50 employees, or about 15 percent of its staff in Singapore, as part of a revamping plan.

title: Another Tie, but No Panic for Devils
description: Tying the team with the worst record in the National Hockey League should be disturbing for the Devils. But it was not to Coach Jacques Lemaire.

title: Preserve America's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Ruling Rejects Banning of Cult
description: The religious cult accused of masterminding a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system in 1995 won a new lease on life today, when the Public Security Commission rejected a Government proposal that it be outlawed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DOROTHY C.
description: WEINSTEIN-Dorothy C. We mourn the loss of Dorothy Weinstein, beloved mother of Barbara Perless, Florence Weinstein and Dr. Lionel A. Winston; grandmother of Jaime, Gary, and David Perless & Jonathan Winston and great grandmother of Leo. Services Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Sunday, February 2 at 11:30 A.M.

title: One Violinist, Two Views
description: There are at least two ways to view the playing of Pinchas Zukerman on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. The program was the second of two recitals presenting the complete Brahms sonatas for violin and piano, and for viola and piano, part of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's ''Celebration of Titans'' series devoted to music of Schubert and Brahms.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about campaign contributions by American subsidiaries of foreign companies referred incorrectly to a company that asked the Democratic Party to refund $15,000. The company, Pasteur Merieux Connaught of Swiftwater, Pa., is a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc of Lyons, France. Pasteur Merieux Connaught is not itself a French company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFELL, JOHN P.
description: DUFFELL-John P. On January 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Dowling). Loving father of Eileen, Father John P., Carolanne, Richard, Stephen, Rita, Denise, Anne and Suzette. Also survived by sixteen grandchildren and his sister Rita Albert. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street. Viewing Saturday 7-9, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 11AM, Ascension Church, 221 West 107th Street, NYC. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Missing Woman Found Dead
description: The body of a woman who had been missing for more than two weeks was found yesterday wrapped in plastic and hidden under debris in a parking lot in Fort Lee, near the George Washington Bridge, the authorities said. Jong Moon Choe of Little Ferry was charged with murdering his wife, Tok Sun Pae, who had filed for divorce, said Charles R. Buckley, the Acting Bergen County Prosecutor.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Campaign Finance 'Reforms' Don't Work
description: As good-government groups display indignation that would make a Southern revival preacher proud, Congress is nearly hysterical about reforming campaign finance laws, regardless of the consequences. If lawmakers are not careful, they may get what they're asking for.

title: Tuition Aid Cuts Will End New York Compact to Educate Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''There's unparalleled peace and quiet. If you shut your machine off.''

title: Union to Pay Ex-Leader's Salary
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Hidden Cameras Find the Truth
description: The multimillion-dollar legal and public relations battle Food Lion has waged against ABC News is really a war against investigative reporting.

title: Court Rules House Site Intrudes on Indian Reservation
description: After more than 350 years of land deals and treaties that reduced their holdings on the South Fork to little more than 300 acres, the Shinnecock Indians won a victory in court today that may help them preserve what is left of their dwindling heritage.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES TO BUY FRENCH COMPANY
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a closely held French maker of bench-top clinical chemistry laboratory analyzers. The drug and medical supply maker said it would acquire Alcyon Analyzer S.A., a company with 1996 revenues of less than $50 million. Alcyon makes a family of three low-volume automated diagnostic test instruments. Abbott stock rose 25 cents, to $54.50.

title: Cowboys to Keep Mum
description: The Dallas Cowboys' owner, JERRY JONES, is preventing anyone in the organization, including Coach BARRY SWITZER, from discussing football-related matters with the news media.

title: In Congress, the Plush Life Goes On
description: Remember when the House and Senate approved new rules banning gifts to lawmakers in 1995, renouncing all those ritzy vacations with lobbyists? Well, those cozy gatherings are still very much alive, thanks to a large loophole in the law that both parties are happy to march through.

title: Rodman Meets With Stern and Is Likely to Start Second Half
description: Although Commissioner David Stern will not make an announcement until next week, it appears likely that Dennis Rodman, the Chicago Bulls forward who was suspended last month for kicking a cameraman, will be back in uniform after the All-Star Game break as Rodman had hoped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIPIPPO, LEONARD, JR.
description: diPIPPO-Leonard, Jr. It is with deep sorrow that we note the passing of Leonard diPippo, Jr., Vice President of Real Estate for Loehmann's. Len's dedication and tenacity helped fuel our recent growth and future expansion. His warmth and sense of humor will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Debra, their children Jake and Brooke and his entire family. Robert N. Friedman, Chairman and CEO Philip Kaplan, President Senior Management Committee and his friends and colleagues at Loehmann's

title: VOLUNTARY RULES ON APPAREL LABOR PROVE HARD TO SET
description: In a groundbreaking effort to set minimum standards at apparel factories both in the United States and abroad, a Presidential task force that includes representatives of labor unions, human rights groups and industry powerhouses like Liz Claiborne, L. L. Bean and Nike has agreed on child-labor and anti-harassment practices but remains badly split over wages and hours.

title: Getting Past the Busy Signal
description: The attorneys general of 36 states may be satisfied with the settlement they reached with America Online, but customers who have met with busy signals for weeks will be less convinced that the problem of network congestion has been solved.

title: Small-Town Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FRANK
description: BERNSTEIN-Frank, died of natural causes after a very brief illness. Beloved husband of Marcia, devoted father of Abby Gostein and Brenda Bernstein, father-in-law of Michael Gostein, dear brother of Ann Burnstine and Philip Bernstein. Memorial service 11:30 A.M. at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street, NYC. Wife severely allergic to flowers, ''don't even think about it!''. In lieu of flowers, donations to Osteogenesis Imperfecta Foundation or Yale University would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, EMMA M.
description: McGRATH-Emma M., 93, of Medford, NJ, formerly of Madison, CT. Wife of the late James Edward McGrath, who was formerly advertising manager of the Wall Street Journal. Survived by two daughters and two sons-in-law, Mary and Dr. Karl Franzoni of Ewing Township, NJ, and Mary Elizabeth and Hubert Lacroix of Evanston, IL. Funeral will be held Monday at 10 A.M. at the Church of the Incarnation, Pennington Road, Ewing, New Jersey. Family will receive friends from 9:30 A.M until the time of Mass at the church. Donations to Martin House Learning Center, PO Box 1025, Trenton, New Jersey 08606 or to charity of donor's choice.

title: Axa Sells Stake In the Reinsurer Scor
description: Axa, the world's second-largest insurer, said yesterday that it sold its minority stake in the reinsurer Scor as part of a string of share sales totaling 2.16 billion French francs ($390 million) this week.

title: Nissan Motor Cutting Jobs in U.S. Marketing Unit
description: Faced with stagnant sales and worried about what the consolidation of car dealerships will mean for auto makers, the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. is eliminating several hundred jobs in its 2,500-member marketing staff through early retirements, incentives to leave and dismissals.

title: Bridge
description: Study the diagramed deal and try to decide whether six hearts can be made after the lead of the spade queen. Would another lead be better?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENKRON, IAN
description: LOWENKRON-Ian. Temple BethEl of Great Neck deeply mourns the tragic passing of Ian Lowenkron, son of Nancy and Allan Lowenkron and grandson of our former Temple President Marjorie Kurcias and Michael Kurcias. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Kids Thank Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Spotlight on Public Liaison Office
description: When President Clinton's re-election campaign needed suggestions for political and civic leaders to invite to coffees with him, it called members of a small White House office charged with building public support for his policies.

title: Ex-I.R.S. Agent Took Bribes
description: In the 1970's, John F. Mancini, an Internal Revenue Service agent, began auditing several construction companies owned by Ralph M. Cestone of West Orange. In 1983, prosecutors said, Mr. Cestone offered Mr. Mancini a used station wagon in exchange for the agent's official approval of some illegal tax deductions Mr. Cestone had claimed.

title: Parcells Keeps It Coy While Patriots Talk Tough
description: Five days after he coached them in Super Bowl XXXI, Bill Parcells resigned as coach of the New England Patriots yesterday while deflecting questions about his future. Minutes later, Robert K. Kraft, the Patriots' owner, reiterated that Parcells's future with the Jets depended on their willingness to part with the No. 1 pick in the college draft.

title: At California Library, a 'Freeway Revolt' Builds
description: To the Editor:

title: CONRAIL POSTPONES MEETING TO AVOID COUP
description: Conrail Inc. said late yesterday that it would hold its annual shareholders meeting on Dec. 19, 1997, seven months later than normal. Pushing the meeting date back is seen as a defensive tactic should the Norfolk Southern Corporation, a hostile bidder for the railroad, and dissident shareholders, seek to win control of the board. Norfolk Southern's chief executive, David R. Goode, warned earlier this week that his company would try to replace Conrail's board if a friendly resolution to the three-month battle for Conrail could not be reached. The Conrail meeting would be held only if a friendly merger with a rival railroad company, the CSX Corporation, does not go through. The announcement by Conrail came after chief executives of the three companies ended a meeting without indicating whether any progress had been made. ''No further details on this meeting or timing of future meetings will be announced,'' a statement from the executives said.

title: Woods Gets Spotlight; Mickelson Gets a Break
description: It isn't easy to escape the eclipse caused by the phenomenon known as Tigermania.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HECK, ALICE HILLMAN
description: HECK-Alice Hillman. February 1, 1994. Love and memory, Charles

title: Unocal Signs Burmese Gas Deal; U.S. May Ban Such Accords
description: As the Clinton Administration weighs whether to impose a ban on new American investment in Myanmar because of its human rights abuses, the Unocal Corporation has signed a deal with the Burmese Government to greatly expand its rights to explore and develop gas fields off the coast.

title: For a Man Born Scarred by Drugs, a Job Is a Victory
description: In May, Eric Ortiz, 27, began working part time at a Pathmark supermarket on the Lower East Side, bagging, collecting shopping carts from the parking lot, cleaning and helping elderly women to their cars. If the tasks seem menial, they are no small feat for Mr. Ortiz, who less than a decade ago could barely muster the courage to look for a job.

title: Tough Line By Secretary Of Defense
description: In his first news conference as Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen today condemned hazing and sexual harassment in the armed forces and promised that officers would be held responsible for incidents occurring in their commands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, MOLLY
description: HESS-Molly. Beloved sister of Bess and Philip Rosenberg, and sister-in-law of Bathami Rosenberg. Cherished aunt and great aunt. Services Sunday, 11:00AM, at Beth-Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: U.S. ECONOMY RISES BY A STRONG 4.7% AS INFLATION DIPS
description: Powered by a surge in exports, the economy grew at a surprisingly vigorous 4.7 percent pace during the final 1996 quarter, more than twice as fast as during the summer, the Government reported today.

title: A Trio's Quiet Spontaneity
description: In an appearance at the Village Vanguard occasioned by his second album, ''The Art of the Trio, Vol. I'' (Warner Brothers), the pianist Brad Mehldau is demonstrating that he's a curious anti-phenomenon. The excitement around the album, as visible as anything in jazz recently, is based on an indwelling, retracting-from-light sensibility. With the drummer Jorge Rossy and the bassist Larry Grenadier, Mr. Mehldau creates time that gently collapses and then reconstitutes itself; the band is aiming at an intuitive spontaneity within old-fashioned, romantic song structures.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy Grows Rapidly, Paced By Strong Exports

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESSAR, THEODORE, M.D.
description: PESSAR-Theodore, M.D. It is with deep sorrow that we record the untimely passing of our esteemed member, Dr. Theodore Pessar, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Mildred, and his children, Gregory, Marc and Dennis. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President Barry Swidler, Secretary

title: John Mohr, 86, Hoover Confidant and Ally at F.B.I., Dies
description: John P. Mohr, the crusty, poker-playing F.B.I. official who became a member of J. Edgar Hoover's inner circle and later played a central role in the mysterious disappearance of Hoover's legendary files on politicians, died last Saturday at a hospital near his home in Arlington, Va. He was 86 and had retired in 1972 as assistant to the director.

title: The Roar of Cold Cash on Snowy Maine Trails
description: Snow draped the evergreen boughs of the spruce and balsam fir trees in fresh white. Here in the Great North Woods, hundreds and hundreds of square miles of remote forest, home to moose, beaver, lynx and the wily, rarely seen fisher cat, the only sound you can hear is---- vroooom.

title: P.G.&E. to Buy Valero Energy, A Marketer Of Natural Gas
description: Seeking to strengthen itself in the face of new competition, the P.G.&E. Corporation the nation's largest utility, announced yesterday that it would acquire most of the Valero Energy Corporation for $722.5 million in stock.

title: In a Poor Land, a Classic Swindle Leaves Rage and Emptier Pockets
description: Life was hard enough for Shpresa Rinxhi before she and her husband scraped together $500 and put it into one of the most dizzying of Albania's dream machines, a so-called charity foundation that was promising a quick 300 percent return on their money.

title: Hidden Cameras Find the Truth
description: The multimillion-dollar legal and public relations battle Food Lion has waged against ABC News is really a war against investigative reporting.

title: HARVEST TO SELL ASSETS TO GROUP INCLUDING KROGER
description: Harvest Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of its assets to a group including the Kroger Company supermarket chain for about $50 million. Harvest also said that Harry J. Janson, its president and chief executive, had resigned and would be succeeded in both posts by David F. Hendrix, the company's director of operations. Harvest, a grocery chain, said the sale is subject to approval by the Federal Bankruptcy Court; the company filed for bankruptcy protection in June.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Jan. 20 reproducing criticisms of America Online's service that were posted on an Internet bulletin board referred incorrectly to a comment by Jeffrey Ray Roberts of Kansas City, Mo., who said he was disconnected while trying to reserve airlines tickets. The comment did not relate an actual experience; it was intended as a parody.

title: Debt Crisis Adds to Woes Of Car Lender
description: A bookkeeping scandal at the Mercury Finance Company pushed the used-auto-loan giant further into financial straits today as banks balked at providing new short-term financing to cover $17 million in the company's debt that is coming due.

title: Home Is Where the Victories Are for Manhattan
description: On the cover of Manhattan's basketball media guide, ''Home Sweet Home'' appears above a photo of the Jaspers' new head coach, John Leonard. Those words apparently have a double meaning.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in some editions on Thursday about an Air China jetliner that skidded off a runway at Kennedy International Airport Wednesday night after landing misstated the flight's origin. It was from Beijing, not from Taipei.

title: Plight of the Sioux
description: To the Editor:

title: The Grave Robbers
description: You have probably seen the TV commercial in which John Wayne finds his misplaced beer in an Army barracks. Unless you're one of the 17 Americans who did not watch the Super Bowl, you surely saw the commercial in which Fred Astaire danced up and down the walls wielding some sort of vacuum cleaner.

title: PROGRESSIVE FOOD INVESTS IN HARRY'S FARMERS MARKET
description: Harry's Farmers Market Inc. said yesterday that it had received $23 million in new capital from Progressive Food Concepts Inc., an affiliate of Boston Chicken Inc. Progressive could get up to a 43 percent stake in Harry's as a result of the investment, which includes a long-term loan that is exchangeable into common stock and warrants to buy more stock. Harry's, which operates grocery stores and food markets, said it would use the proceeds to pay bank debt and refine and expand its Harry's In A Hurry restaurant concept. Investors sent Harry's stock rising 63 percent, or $2.4375, to close at $6.3125 a share in Nasdaq trading. Boston Chicken stock fell $1 to close at $34.625.

title: Leaders of I.R.S. Panel Urge Sweeping Overhaul of Agency
description: The most sweeping reorganization of the Internal Revenue Service since 1952, when it was a patronage agency riddled with corruption, was proposed today by the co-chairmen of a bipartisan panel investigating the agency's bungled effort to modernize its computers.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on Thursday about the direction to be taken by the balloon Dymocks Flyer on a planned trip around the world was published in error. The diagram in Science Times on Tuesday was correct: the balloon will fly from east to west. While most balloons fly eastward on such flights, the Dymocks Flyer is to ascend to more than 100,000 feet, where air currents will carry it west.

title: German Concern To Pay Ex-Chief
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said today that it would pay its former chief executive, Heinz Schimmelbusch, 1.5 million marks ($920,000) as part of an out-of-court settlement concerning his dismissal in December 1993.

title: Umpires and Players to Meet
description: Players and umpires are scheduled to hold a so-called summit meeting with Major League Baseball officials Tuesday, but players are reluctant to attend for fear of retaliation by the umpires, people familiar with the planning of the meeting said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAVEN, MARGARET CRAY
description: RAVEN-Margaret Cray, 65, North Palm Beach, FL., on January 28, 1997. Mother of Edward ''Ned'', Margaret ''Meg''. Sister of John J. Cray, Jr.; Thomas P. and Charles M. Cray. Funeral Mass Friday, January 31, 1997, North Palm Beach. Donations to Connor's Nursery, 2309 Ponce de Leon Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONOFRIO, MICHAEL T
description: DONOFRIO-Michael T. Dearest dad, we love you and miss you more with every passing year. Love, Mom, Michael, Bob and Gay

title: I.R.A., Not Britain, Sabotages Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: REED ELSEVIER TO SELL BOOK UNIT TO RANDOM HOUSE
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a division of its Reed Books publishing unit to Random House Inc. The division includes the publishing labels William Heinemann, Mandarin Paperbacks, Methuen and Minerva and the authors Umberto Eco, Graham Greene and George Orwell. The British-Dutch media company had been trying since July 1995 to sell the division to focus on businesses like its Lexis-Nexis data base. Reed International P.L.C. of Britain and Elsevier N.V. of the Netherlands each own 50 percent of Reed Elsevier. Random House is part of Advance Publications Inc.

title: A Law Against Peeping Toms
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill into law yesterday that makes it a crime to spy on someone through the window of a private home. The new law was prompted by the 1994 sexual assault and murder of 6-year-old Amanda Wengert of Manalapan Township. She was killed by a man who had been caught peering into the girls' bathroom at a local school, but had not been arrested because there was no law against peeping Toms, said Pete McDonough, a spokesman for the Governor. A law later made peering into school windows a crime. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, ZILLA SARAH
description: SUSSMAN-Zilla Sarah, of West Orange, NJ. Donations in her memory may be sent to Scleroderma Federation, Peabody Office Building, 1 Newbury St, Peabody, MA 01960. Information Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ.

title: POP
description: Finding the Cosmic Side

title: Metro Digest
description: Major Developments: News Summaries, Page 2

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELLICE, CLARA B.
description: ELLICE-Clara B. Beloved mother. Remembered with love. Joan

title: Bernardin Memoir Suggests Priest Urged Accuser
description: Before he died of pancreatic cancer last November, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Archbishop of Chicago, wrote a memoir of his last years, spiritual reflections on how he coped with the disease and with an accusation of sexual abuse against him.

title: Trouble in the F.B.I. Lab
description: For decades the Federal Bureau of Investigation's high-tech crime laboratory has been considered the ultimate in forensic sleuthing, world-famous for its ability to solve hard cases from a piece of fiber, a sliver of paint or a speck of blood. But that reassuring image was shattered this week by reports of astonishing incompetence and possible dishonesty in the handling of evidence in some of the Government's most important criminal cases.

title: Bernard Johnson, 60, Dancer, Choreographer and Designer
description: Bernard Johnson, a dancer, choreographer and fashion and costume designer, died on Jan. 22 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Profits at Coca-Cola Rose By 18% During 4th Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its profits soared 18 percent during the fourth quarter, buoyed by growth in international soft-drink shipments and by an increase in market share throughout most of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOHN CAMPBELL
description: HENRY-John Campbell. Passed away January 30, 1997. Survived by his wife Elizabeth. Brother of Louise Clark. Father of Margaret Smith and John C. Henry, Jr. Grandfather of Malcolm and Bradley Smith. A private service will be held for the family at Woodlawn Cemetery on Monday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the N.Y. Metropolitan Opera and Fraunces Tavern Museum, New York.

title: Small Savings For Customers In Lilco Deal, Some Testify
description: Customers of the Long Island Lighting Company and Brooklyn Union Gas would initially save only 2 to 3 percent on their bills from the proposed merger of the two utilities, witnesses said at two days of public hearings that concluded yesterday.

title: More Fuel Aid for the Poor
description: New Jersey families who need help paying their winter heating bills will receive a total of $7.1 million in emergency Federal money, in addition to the $37.8 million that has already been allocated, the White House announced yesterday.

title: Aches, Flu Bugs and Next, the Hornets
description: Patrick Ewing's sore left groin is improving, but there is no guarantee he will play this weekend. Chris Childs has the flu and Charles Oakley's swollen right ankle bothered him enough to curtail his practice time today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBBINS, SIM
description: ROBBINS-Sim, 1918-2/1/82. ''And when he shall die, take him and cut him out in little stars, and he will make the face of Heaven so fine that all the world will be in love with night.'' Your loving family: Rose, Dana, Karen and Steffie

title: VEBA SELLS 20 PERCENT STAKE IN PENN VIRGINIA
description: Veba A.G., a German utility company, sold a 20 percent stake in the Penn Virginia Corporation for $36 million to various buyers, including Penn Virginia board members and senior managers, Penn Virginia said yesterday. Penn Virginia, based in Radnor, Pa., owns oil, coal and timber properties. Veba sold 868,258 shares for $41.50 each. Penn Virginia board members and senior managers bought an unspecified portion of the shares. The company bought 210,308 shares. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Penn Virginia fell $1.75, to $43.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, JUDIE
description: BURROWS-Judie. You have been a light, an inspiration and a love to us. We will always love you. Myrna and Mike

title: France Reports Decline In Number of Job Seekers
description: The number of French job seekers unexpectedly fell 29,000, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, in December, the first decrease since October, economists said yesterday.

title: Two Mouths Running
description: It was a scene most Broadway producers can only fantasize about. On a snowy Monday night in January, people were all but rioting to enter a theater adjacent to Times Square -- with neither a falling chandelier nor a fallen Liza Minnelli anywhere in sight. And unlike most Broadway audiences, this one was mixed in age, race and class, with suburbanites joined by college students and a snazzy cultural contingent as various as William Styron, George C. Wolfe, Helen Mirren and Arthur Schlesinger Jr.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Growth Exceeds Forecasts As Expansion Starts 7th Year : Low U.S. Inflation Fuels Market Hopes
description: NEW YORK  The American economy is entering its seventh fat year with few worries that inflation will threaten what is seen as sustainable growth of 2 percent to 3 percent a year, data released Friday showed.

title: Has a State Tried Too Hard to Deregulate?
description: With its white-clapboard houses set against pine-covered hills, this New England village of 5,300 might seem a piddling conquest for a $13.2 billion energy company trying to make a name for itself as a national supplier of low-cost gas and electricity to homes and businesses.

title: Pataki Bolsters State's Pursuit Of Air Polluters
description: After two years of criticism from Federal environmental officials, Gov. George E. Pataki has announced plans to strengthen New York State's enforcement of environmental laws, particularly those limiting air pollution from large sources like factories and power plants.

title: Congress Is Asked to Speed Money for Family Planning Overseas
description: President Clinton formally asked Congress today to speed its financing of overseas family-planning programs, setting up what abortion opponents call the first abortion-related vote in the new Congress. The vote must be held by Feb. 28.

title: INSIDE
description: A Burmese Policy Tangle

title: Chip Sales Were Down 1% in December
description: Worldwide sales of computer chips fell 1 percent in December from November and 17 percent from December 1995, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.

title: Mandela Rival Takes Over (At Least for a Few Days)
description: In an announcement that provoked uncertain laughter in the Senate, President Nelson Mandela today appointed his archrival, Chief Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi, to stand in as Acting President when he leaves the country this weekend.

title: Mother Held in Support Case
description: The mother of 4 of the 10 children found abandoned last week in an Atlantic City row house was ordered yesterday to remain in county jail for at least three more weeks for not paying child support, The Associated Press reported.

title: State Defends Education Law
description: Whether the new school financing law is judged by the education standards it imposes or the money it allocates to school districts, the statute meets the constitutional test of providing a ''thorough and efficient'' education for New Jersey students, state officials argued in a brief filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTZEL, MURRAY N.
description: WORTZEL-Murray N. Passed away Jan. 30, 1997 after a heart attack. Cherished brother of Bertha Belmar and Esther Friedfeld. He was a professor of Library Science at Lehman College and founder of Leonard Eisner Memorial Foundation. He devoted his time and efforts to the Special Libraries Association and Kurt Weill Foundation. Services Sunday, 10 AM ''Kirschenbaum's'', 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Donations may be made to the Leonard Eisner Memorial Foundation.

title: 60 Subscriptions, and No Grand Prize
description: It was a dull day at the post office: a supermarket flier with specials on red snapper, the water bill, a letter inviting me to a wellness seminar -- and a ''check'' for $5 million. I passed on the snapper, paid the bill, considered the seminar. The ''check'' I tore up angrily.

title: Friendlier, Trimmer Police
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir's announcement that New York City police officers had received high marks for politeness, based on the way they treated undercover questioners posing as confused tourists, carried promotional overtones. But the politeness test, and its positive results, suggest that a new campaign to improve relations between police officers and the community may ultimately pay important dividends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGALL, CAROL B. (NEE BERKOWITZ)
description: SEGALL-Carol B. (nee Berkowitz) of Short Hills, NJ on Friday, Jan. 31, 1997. Devoted wife of Jack W. Segall. Loving mother of Wendy Achtel, Cathy Schaffer and Ken Amron. Dear sister of Bill Berkowitz and the late Larry Berkowitz. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Joshua, Alison, Rachel and Zachary. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Sun, Feb. 2, 1997 at 11:30 AM. Interment in the B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ.

title: Lawyers Say Bloody Pants Will Not Fit A Defendant
description: Hoping to show that the police planted incriminating evidence on the chief defendant in the Crown Heights trial, lawyers for Lemrick Nelson Jr. said yesterday that he would try on the blood-stained pants that the police said he was wearing when he was arrested and that the pants would not fit him.

title: The Role of Partisans in a Neutral Business
description: George Stephanopoulos has settled comfortably into his new line of work at ABC News. He has already been seen on ''Good Morning, America'' and ''This Week'' and at the inauguration, contributing, as one of his new colleagues announced, to ''the political dialogue in America.'' Soft-spoken and well-spoken, he told America that the reprimand to Newt Gingrich would hurt him and that Democrats had committed ''tactical blunders.''

title: Sad Ending for Unbridled's Song's Brief Melody
description: Unbridled's Song broke a bone in his right foreleg during a gallop at Gulfstream Park this morning and was promptly retired from a career that spun a soap-opera's saga of injuries, delayed decisions and great but unfulfilled expectations.

title: POP
description: A Diva Who Has Lived Hard

title: Dow Off a Bit As a Volatile Month Ends
description: If January is any indication of the season ahead, the stock market is in for a wild ride.

title: Casino Isn't Benign
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy in Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. The Board of Trustees, the Central Administration, the College Presidents, the faculty, students and staff of The City University of New York deeply mourn the passing of Trustee Charles E. Inniss. Appointed to the Board by the Governor in 1992, he served with great distinction and honor, chairing the Fiscal, Facilities, and Presidential Search Committees and the CUNY Construction Fund. His dedication to the University's mission, his love of education, and his extraordinary service to the community will have an enduring impact. He will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. James P. Murphy, Chairman Board of Trustees W. Ann Reynolds, Chancellor

title: At the Met, Deborah Voigt And a Kingly Pavarotti
description: Luciano Pavarotti has not been giving colleagues and listeners his full attention in recent times. Reports from the 61-year-old tenor's recital at the Metropolitan Opera a few weeks ago describe a man indifferent to his material and content with the easy acquisition of good will from a host of uncritical partisans. The description will be familiar to anyone who observed Mr. Pavarotti's casual approach to the much-advertised ''Three Tenors'' concert last summer at Giant Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, SYLVIA
description: KLEIN-Sylvia. The Congregation of the Malverne Jewish Center mourns the passing of our longtime member, Sylvia Klein. Condolences to her husband Arthur and children. Barry J. Chesler, Rabbi Murray Greenspan, President

title: Rangers Working Up a Broad Street Mood
description: Ulf Samuelsson seemed a little antsy this afternoon. It was Day 4 without a game, and with the Philadelphia Flyers more than 24 hours away, he had only his teammates to take on.

title: THEATER
description: Trying to Save a Nephew

title: The Tale of a Tree, in Which Science Meets Soul
description: Ever since he took overnine years ago as director of the Botanical Garden at the University of British Columbia, Bruce Macdonald has known there was something unusual about the two scrawny spruce trees with needles that are golden, like sunlight itself.

title: Germany Says It Will Press On With Scientology Investigations
description: With remarks ranging from the frosty to the outraged, German officials today brushed aside United States Government criticism of Germany's attitude toward the Scientology movement. The officials said they would not be deterred from inquiries to see whether the organization should be placed under surveillance or outlawed.

title: In Police Pay, New York City's Top Ranking Is History
description: As New York City and its largest police union head into arbitration over a new contract, the Giuliani administration contends that its officers are compensated better than any urban police department in the country.

title: Bond Prices Rally as Inflation Stays Low
description: Treasury prices gained yesterday as a flurry of economic reports failed to persuade bond investors that inflation had become a problem.

title: North Korea Links Talks to Grain Deal
description: North Korea indicated today that it would not take part in talks with the United States and South Korea about the possibility of peace negotiations until it reached an agreement to buy grain from an American company.

title: Researcher Made Profit After Study
description: A Cleveland researcher whose study showed that zinc lozenges might be an effective cold treatment said yesterday that he had invested in the company that makes the lozenges before the paper announcing the results was published. Once the paper appeared, the company's stock soared, and he sold some shares for a profit of about $145,000, he said.

title: To Palestinian, Israel Is Better Than U.S. Cell
description: When Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook abruptly agreed this week to Israel's request to extradite him for trial on terrorism charges, it stunned the United States, Israel and the fledgling Palestinian Authority.

title: Ever True, Despite the Consequences
description: When at last Marius Byleveld, the obstinate pastor of Athol Fugard's ''Road to Mecca,'' surrenders in his fight to have the town eccentric, Miss Helen, separated from her disquieting sculpture garden and sent to a nursing home, it is with the knowledge that he has been vanquished by a power greater than any at his command.

title: Parcells Seeking New Kitchen
description: WHILE poor unemployed Bill Parcells shuffles home to New Jersey to sit by the phone and see if he has a future, he should know he has the philosophical blessing of many chefs around the world.

title: Canada, Cuba and Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Lobbying Firm Gets a D'Amato Connection
description: Among the knot of lobbying firms here, one has long stood out not because of its size but because its chief lobbyist, Mel Miller, has an unusually useful credential: He was once the Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly.

title: At a New School, No Boys, Less Fussing, and a Freer Spirit
description: They have been together for only five months, but the students in the pioneering seventh-grade class at the all-girls public school in East Harlem have already begun to leave their marks on their surroundings.

title: At 20, Pompidou Center Seeks a Lift
description: The Georges Pompidou Center is putting on a cheerful face for its 20th birthday this weekend. A new replica of Constantin Brancusi's studio has opened at the northern edge of the center's sloping plaza. Eight ''metamechanical'' sculptures by Jean Tinguely welcome visitors into the building's forum. And on its third and fourth floors, a show called ''Made in France'' displays hundreds of works of art created in France between 1947 and 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUNNELL, ANTHONY LEWIS
description: FUNNELL-Anthony Lewis, 65, of Kent, CT on 28 January of cardiac arrest. Born in Stanford, CT., 31 October 1931 to Mary and Walter Lewis Funnell. Educated at South Kent School, Bowdoin and Columbia. Served as a Corporal in the US Army and worked for many years in the air travel industry in NYC, most recently as a consumer action affairs officer with Pan American World Airways. In retirement he lived in Millbrook, NY pursuing his interest in travel, animals and nature studies and moved to Kent, CT. in 1993 joining the South Kent teaching faculty for the '94-5 school year. Survived by his brother William Brewster Funnell of South Orleans, MA., his nephew, niece and three great nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to South Kent School or to any charity serving the interest of nature and animal life.

title: Yankees and Their Fans Are Full of Want
description: Yankee General Manager Bob Watson wants to sign Bernie Williams to a three- or four-year contract, but not a two-year deal. Manager Joe Torre wants to finish his career with the Yankees. Rebecca Maher simply wants Derek Jeter's autograph.

title: Italy Detains Ex-Wife In Gucci's Slaying
description: Almost two years after Maurizio Gucci was shot to death outside his office here, the police today took into custody Mr. Gucci's former wife, Patrizia Reggiani Martinelli, and three other people on suspicion of murder.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAFFEL, ALEXANDER
description: TAFFEL-Alexander, Sunday, February 2nd, 2:30PM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., NYC.

title: George W. Mitchell, 92, Ex-Official at the Fed
description: George W. Mitchell, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and tireless promoter of electronic banking, died last Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 92 and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about bookkeeping irregularities at the Mercury Finance Company referred incorrectly to work done for the company by Salomon Brothers. Salomon had planned to syndicate a $750 million loan, which was not completed. The firm has not handled the issuance of Mercury securities.

title: Suit Says 'Cats' Character Was Much Too Frisky
description: Bill Maher, the host of the ABC talk show ''Politically Incorrect,'' says crime may be down in New York, but nobody can do anything about ''Cats.'' Well, someone is trying.

title: Hilton Hotels Finally Makes A Bid for ITT
description: As promised, the Hilton Hotels Corporation formally made a $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid yesterday for 50.1 percent of the ITT Corporation.

title: A Jilted Mistress, a Clairvoyant, a Plot
description: Last Oct. 9, federal prosecutors unearthed a body on a ranch belonging to Raul Salinas de Gortari and triumphantly predicted that the cadaver would implicate him in one of Mexico's most infamous murders.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5

title: Police Applaud Ruling to Allow Restrictions on Gang Suspects
description: Law-enforcement officials in California today praised a State Supreme Court decision that allows cities to prohibit suspected gang members from standing together on street corners, climbing trees, wearing beepers and doing any number of other things that are legal for ordinary citizens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINER, BERNARD
description: FEINER-Bernard. To our dear uncle, a man who was always there when needed, a man who will be missed and a man who will always be loved. Love, Liz and Irwin, Steven, Andrea and Scott

title: Swedes and Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: B12 Deficiency May Hasten Onset of AIDS, Study Finds
description: Men who are infected with the virus that causes AIDS appear to progress to the full-blown disease much more quickly if they are deficient in vitamin B12, researchers said today.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: HOME DETENTION -- Two New Jersey teen-agers returned to their homes to await trial on charges of murdering their newborn. Page 22.

title: Company Briefs
description: AETNA INC., Hartford, the insurance company, said it had formed a joint venture with a Brazilian insurer, Sul America Seguros S.A., to offer life and health insurance in Brazil.

title: Out of the Din of Madness, the Music of Words
description: WHEN FIRST SEEN IN ''The Steward of Christendom,'' Sebastian Barry's play now at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, the Irish actor Donal McCann is a half-crazed old man wearing dirty long johns and confined to the county home in Baltinglass, County Wicklow. He looks possessed, like a character out of an early Samuel Beckett play, but he rages with something of the splendor of the prose of James Joyce's ''Dubliners'' and ''Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man.'' Perhaps only Ireland, where rich language still seems to be as commonplace as peat, could give birth to a theater work quite so grandly and ripely word-driven, and to an actor who, like Mr. McCann, has the mind, talent and technical facility necessary to deliver it.

title: Town Turmoil Over Condemned Dog
description: There is a dog on death row here.

title: Why Music From New Movies Is Outselling Other Albums
description: VARIETY magazine doesn't carry the Billboard charts. But maybe the publishers of the leading movie and music trade magazines ought to think about collaborating.

title: Caseworkers Aren't Sabotaging Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRACTENBERG, LILLIAN
description: FRACTENBERG-Lillian. Though the love of my life, Lillian, left me eleven years ago, I have the same feeling of love for her now that I had before. Harry

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about philanthropists who make donations anonymously misstated the ranking of a precept from the 12th-century philosopher Maimonides. He taught that anonymous giving was second on the scale of ''Eight Levels of Charity.'' The highest form was that which let someone become self-supporting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONATI, HONORABLE ALFRED, JR.
description: DONATI-Honorable Alfred, Jr. On February 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Bonnie (nee White). Devoted brother of John and Stacy, Teresa. Beloved uncle of John Edward and Melissa. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72nd St, NYC, 212-877-9700. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment Moravian Cemetery, SI, NY. Viewing Sunday 4-8, Monday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: Echoes of the Cuban Cultural Experience
description: TEN Cuban-American artists -- nine exiles and one who was born in the United States -- are featured in ''Past Cuba'' at the Walsh Art Gallery, in the Quick Center at Fairfield University. Especially striking about the exhibition is that the artists don't dwell bitterly on their estrangement. They are imbued with Cuba's long cultural history and many incorporate it effectively into their work.

title: No Ax to Grind?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Power Behind the Play Emerges Into the Light
description: THEATER IS A GROUP ENTERPRISE. It represents the joint labor of playwrights, actors, directors, set designers, costume designers and a long list of more or less anonymous foot soldiers celebrated only in the fine print of Playbill. Perhaps the most mysterious of these is the dramaturge.

title: Lumberyard Can Remain Park's Unlikely Center
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit challenging the Port Authority's decision to allow a lumberyard to operate in the center of the proposed Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: Gay Couples and the Law, at Odds Over the Right to Marry
description: THE gym brought them together, but it took six weeks of courting on the phone to reach the first date. Old relationships still haunted them, including one marriage, and there was a great fear of rushing things.

title: Opposite Views On Cross-Island Bridge
description: Congratulations to John Waldman. Resurgence in interest in a Long Island Sound crossing is long overdue.

title: What's New
description: She strolls into the studio, her sweater dragging across the floor, and pulls her book out of a tapestry knapsack. ''Where are you from,'' the designer asks, as he thumbs through the pages of color prints. ''Romania,'' she mumbles, and slouches. ''How old are you?'' quizzes the stylist. She chews on her still-tender nails and twirls her baby-fine hair. ''Fourteen.'' ''Who else have you worked for?'' they demand in unison. ''No one,'' she squeaks. Glee fills the room: they have found a New Girl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACK, ROSE G.
description: MACK-Rose G., 88, of Lauderhill, Florida, on January 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Eric Mack and mother-in-law of Mary Sirridge. Cherished grandmother of Joshua and Rebekah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, JEAN
description: LONDON-Jean, 83, formerly of 68th Rd., Forest Hills, died January 25, 1997. Wife of the late Harry London. Survived by 2 sons, Peter and Ross, a daughter, Tsurah August, six grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A son, Richard, died previously. Graveside services were held in United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, DIANE (NEE STRELL)
description: KAUFMAN-Diane (nee Strell), on Jan. 31, 1997. Beloved wife of Justus Kaufman. Beloved mother of Bonnie and Howard Heneson and Billy Kaufman. Beloved grandmother of Susie and Steve Moskowitz and Sandee and Keith Walker. Beloved great-grandmother of Shira and Ari Moskowitz and Ryan Walker. Beloved sister of Ruth Mosberg and Leo Strell; beloved sister-in -law of Leon Sussman and Vivian Strell. Funeral services today, at Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79th St, 12:30 PM.

title: An Answer to a Mystery
description: When it happened, back in 1986, it seemed almost too bizarre to be credible. ''Kenneth, what is the frequency?'' an assailant was supposed to have grilled Dan Rather, the CBS news anchor, while punching and kicking him on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. As the months passed, and the attacker was never apprehended, skepticism about Mr. Rather's version only increased.

title: Trent Lott and His Fierce Freshmen
description: YOU'D THINK THE MAJORITY LEADER OF THE UNITED States Senate would have better things to do. But Trent Lott likes order so much that he often irons his cotton shirts after they have come back from the cleaners to remove any remaining wrinkles. ''He criticized the way I ironed shirts one day,'' recalls Patricia Lott, his wife of 32 years. ''I said, 'Fine, you do it.' So when the shirts come home from the cleaners and he doesn't like the way they're ironed, he does it. I don't.''

title: In Tokyo Scandal, Profits Were for the Birds
description: The arrest of a member of Parliament this week in connection with a bogus banking scheme is embarrassing Japan's main opposition party and adding to the general public sourness toward politics.

title: In Yosemite, Nature May Have Its Way Yet
description: Beneath the imperious granite faces that stare out at one another across this fabled valley, the signs of devastation are everywhere.

title: A Busy Week on the Baltic
description: CAN a cruise passenger find happiness in a cabin of less than 60 square feet, including space given over to sink, toilet and shower? Can the attractions of fabled Baltic seaports compensate for a lack of the luxury normally associated with Continental cruising? Is a nine-day basic Baltic package at about $2,500 with air fare (not including optional shore trips) a bargain? These were a few of my questions last July when I booked passage on the Kristina Regina, a Finnish ship that has been taking travelers on visa-free tours to ports in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania, as well as to St. Petersburg and Gdansk, for the last five years.

title: Crew Enlists Army's Help in Exploring Idea for Military School
description: A proposal by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to establish what could be New York's first public military high school has found a predictably eager partner -- the United States Army.

title: Hype, Hope and Hurt on the AIDS Front Lines
description: AFTER early years of panic and a decade of almost unbroken despair, the AIDS landscape has gained a startling, unexpected new feature: real hope.

title: How to Find a Fit in the New Job Market
description: MICHAEL GORDON was unemployed when he signed up for Eugene Hodge's career class at Quinnipiac College in Hamden. Mr. Hodge offered this solution: Go discuss it with 10 or more people a week. With few alternatives, Mr. Gordon went to the New Haven green and started talking to strangers about sports, gradually steering the conversation his way: He had certain skills, he wanted to work with computers, what did the person think about it?

title: What if Two Giants Met Just One More Time?
description: JUST once, on a March afternoon in 1964, two earthshaking lives, soon to be cut short, intersected. That moment -- a handshake between the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X, captured in one of history's great photo ops -- graces the cover of the Crossroads Theater Company's program.

title: Black Past, Black Present
description: February is Black History (Herstory) Month, celebrating the achievements of African-Americans. It is also a time when African-Americans in New Jersey are under attack, specifically in a bill on affirmative action introduced by two Republican members of the state Assembly, Kevin O'Toole and Michael Carroll.

title: Fast Ship Steered With a Joy Stick
description: The traditional big Coast Guard cutter is steered with a wheel, has a crew of 70 and, if it tends buoys, does not even try to work when the wind and the seas are too rough. By contrast, the Juniper is steered with a joy stick or a keystroke, has a crew of 40, and on a recent January day, was off the Connecticut coast on Long Island Sound, where heavy seas had buoys whipping back and forth in menacing karate chops.

title: The Groucho Marxist
description: For the Hell of It

title: THE LAPTOP COLONIALISTS
description: Your article about the young American expats in Ho Chi Minh City's Apocalypse Now bar reads like a neocolonialist sequel to ''The Heart of Darkness,'' devoid of the moral ambiguity of Conrad's vision. Their ''work and drink, money and sex, 'I'm here to make money,' '' attitude looks like a yuppie version of the colonial exploitation Conrad pilloried.

title: Elizabeth Stein, Stephen Thurer
description: Elizabeth Jennifer Stein, the daughter of Joanne Seblatnigg of Cologne, Germany, and Dr. Gilbert Stein of Memphis, was married last evening to Stephen Michael Thurer, the son of Diane and Dr. Gerald Thurer of Dix Hills, L.I. Dr. Harry Danzinger, the senior rabbi of Temple Israel in Memphis, officiated at the Peabody Hotel there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. The Board of Trustees and staff of the City University Construction Fund mourn the death of our beloved chairman, Charles E. Inniss. He was a man of great intelligence, compassion and dignity, whose visionary leadership guided the design and construction of several major educational facilities which offered greater opportunities for The City University's students, and enhanced the New York City community. We will miss him and thank him for his many years of dedicated service to the City University. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Marjorie, and the Inniss family. Harvey Auerbach, Vice Chair Emma E. Macari, AIA, Exec Dir.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Children's Books
description: IMAGINARY ANIMALS

title: Great-Grandma's House
description: THE ghost of Rosanna Zuckerman's great-grandmother is watching. ''I hope she'll be happy with the garden,'' said Mrs. Zuckerman, a handsome, gray-haired widow in her ''early 70's'' who has embarked on a total renovation of the two bottom floors of her great-grandmother's house at 491 West 22d Street. Ms. Zuckerman, who charmingly related the saga of the old house in Chelsea, lives in another family house two doors down.

title: Loews Details Plans for White Plains Movie Palace
description: WITH the announcement last month of the decision by Regal Cinemas to drop out of the competition to build this city's first multiplex movie complex, the path is now clear for Loews Theaters to go ahead with its plans to build a mega-movie palace similar in style to its flagship Lincoln Square theater in Manhattan.

title: New Budget: A Primer For Investors
description: WHEN he lays out his vision for the nation during his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton will no doubt speak in sweeping terms of the country's problems and his solutions. But when he sends his budget to Congress two days later, he will include detailed proposals that could affect investors in many ways.

title: Wild Bison Dispute Deepens as Montana Governor Faults U.S.
description: The Governor of Montana says a new plan by the Federal Government to stop shipping bison to slaughter and instead herd them back into Yellowstone National Park will not work.

title: P.B.A. and Its Lawyers in a Tangle of Money and Mixed Roles
description: The lawyers at the center of the emerging scandal over kickbacks in a police union have been like a trusty sidearm to the powerful Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: It Is Money Battles Like These that Make The Dead Truly Grateful
description: JERRY GARCIA did not lead a tidy life. Followers of his band, the Grateful Dead, might not have expected a 401(k) from the man whose fondness for hallucinogens earned him the nickname ''Captain Trips.'' But only after he died in a drug-rehabilitation center in 1995 did the image of smiling 1960's idealism that Mr. Garcia personified onstage give way to a more troubling picture of financial problems, tangled relationships and a long struggle with heroin addiction.

title: Renata Zajkowski, Stephen Kelly
description: Renata Zajkowski, the daughter of Regina Kiper of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Edward Zajkowski, was married yesterday to Stephen John Kelly, a son of Anny Kelly of Wayne, N.J., and the late Robert Kelly. The Rev. Damian O'Connell officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: The True Balance Of Power
description: The success of President Clinton's agenda for the next four years will be determined largely by whether he can govern from the center. That agenda recognizes that government is not the solution to all problems, nor the cause, but must be a tool to provide opportunity to those willing to accept responsibility. This is the essence of the ''vital center,'' from which most Americans want the President and Congress to govern.

title: One Man's War
description: CHANGING ENEMIES

title: Curtain Up
description: The love of a married couple is threatened in Francois Truffaut's drama of a theater company in Nazi-held Paris, THE LAST METRO (1980) -- TUES. at 8 P.M., TUES.-WED. at 2 A.M. and WED. at 3:30 P.M. on BRAVO. The beautiful leading actress (Catherine Deneuve) who guides the company resists a growing attraction to her passionate leading man (Gerard Depardieu). Her husband is in hiding in the theater, away from watchful eyes, some spiteful, some deadly. To top it all, business is rocky. The wartime ambiance and Truffaut's attention to the details of human nature flavor the drama. Ms. Deneuve is stunningly compelling in a characterization of grit, bravery, loyalty and feeling. Vive Deneuve and (of course) Truffaut! Howard Thompson

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SOHO

title: Fireworks Ban May Send the Ox in Quietly
description: They have been known to start fires and blow off fingers. But firecrackers have been an integral part of the Chinese New Year celebration for thousands of years, charged with chasing away evil spirits.

title: Opposite Views On Cross-Island Bridge
description: I am appalled at John Waldman's faulty logic and lack of respect for nature in his article $(''Still Needed: A Cross-Island Bridge,'' Dec. 29$) calling for a bridge to connect Long Island with Westchester or Southern Connecticut.

title: The Arrow of Time
description: Every year, on June 17, the Argentine photographer Diego Goldberg assembles the members of his family and takes their pictures, one by one. ''It started a year after I went to live together with my future wife, Susy,'' says Goldberg of the ritual he inaugurated 20 years ago. ''Her mother said, 'I would like to have a portrait of you.' A year later, I saw the picture hanging in her bedroom, and I said to my wife, 'Why don't we do it again?' The next time I thought, 'We'll include our son.' '' In the years since, Goldberg has made the family photo sessions an annual event, adding children as they arrived: Nicolas and Matias were born in Paris when he was working for the photo agency Sygma, and Sebastian after the family relocated to New York. ''It's always a little ceremony,'' says Goldberg, now the photo editor at Clarin, a newspaper in Buenos Aires. ''The problem is that I can't stop. It has a life of its own. I've got to fee the monster.'' Goldber's photographs are a kind of human time-lapse photography: they catch his subjects in the act of change. And they put a frame around the often haphazard experience of growing up - a bid, as Goldberg puts it, ''to stop for a fleeting moment the arrow of time as it passes by.''

title: It Happened One Day
description: It was while languishing in a Roman prison (circa A.D. 316) that Blaise, Bishop of Sebastia in Armenia, miraculously healed a boy who was choking on a fish bone. History doesn't record whether he waved his hands or simply whomped the lad, but tomorrow, the Feast of St. Blaise commemorates the man whose medieval Heimlich made him famous as ''the patron saint of throat sufferers.'' Supplicants go to church to have their February-embattled esophagi blessed by a priest who crosses two candles under the chin and asks God to preserve them from ''throat troubles and every other evil.'' Oddly enough, this really packs 'em in. ''It's a popular day,'' says Msgr. Donald Sakano of Manhattan. ''Which defies any kind of analysis.'' Blaise, alas, couldn't save his own neck. He was beheaded after his flesh was shredded with iron combs (normally used to brush out sheepskins), thus making him the patron saint of wool combers as well.

title: Tax Breaks and Bodegas
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Panel Votes to End Rights Laws In Hong Kong
description: In the face of widespread opposition here, a Beijing-appointed committee overseeing this British colony's return to Chinese rule voted today to repeal several key laws protecting Hong Kong's civil liberties.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 40'S MOVIELAND

title: The Thing That Mocked The Movies
description: CHEESE, the campy aesthetic of cool 1990's irony, is notorious for a short shelf life. Whatever is hip at first about cheesy television shows like ''Baywatch'' or ''Melrose Place'' usually isn't as funny by the 150th episode.

title: RETURN ENGAGEMENT
description: Sometimes you can't keep a good transvestite play down. Three years ago, ''In Betweens'' -- a drama by Bryan Goluboff about a lowlife co-dependency triangle involving an ex-con, his cross-dressing brother and a drifter -- was scheduled for a big Off-Broadway opening with name stars (John Heard, Bruno Kirby). The money people didn't like what they saw -- ''It was miscast,'' Goluboff says -- so they pulled out at the 11th hour, taking a $400,000 loss. Enter Dante Alberti of the Belmont Italian-American Playhouse (situated above a Bronx supermarket), who mounted a production with unknown actors and scored a hit. The run proved so successful, in fact, that the producers have reinvested and moved the play downtown -- with the Bronx cast. It opens Tuesday at the Cherry Lane.

title: 'GATE 25
description: 1. June 17 marks the 25th anniversary of the Watergate break-in, but the commemorative fun starts Friday. The American Bar Association has assembled the ultimate all-star panel -- including Bob Woodward and John Dean -- for a rehash in Boca Raton, Fla. 2. Not invited: John Ehrlichman, a Watergate revisionist who now says it's ''likely'' that Dean instigated the break-in. 3. This theory is central to ''Silent Coup,'' a 1991 book (by Len Colodny and Robert Gettlin) that drew a still-unresolved libel suit from Dean. 4. Dean's alleged motive for the burglary? To expose a Democrat-run call-girl ring. 5. Whatever their take, many revisionists agree that the Boca Raton panelists represent an outmoded Watergate orthodoxy. ''Frankly,'' says Jim Hougan, whose book ''Secret Agenda'' claims Watergate was a C.I.A. operation, ''it sounds like a bore.''

title: Suit Threatens '98 Track Games
description: PLANS for the Goodwill Games, a major athletic competition similar to the Summer Olympics, next year on Long Island are generating hearty enthusiasm among business and government leaders.

title: Jennifer Abramson, Jeffrey Rosenberg
description: Jennifer Leigh Abramson, the daughter of the late Lois Abramson and the late Oscar Abramson, was married last evening to Dr. Jeffrey S. Rosenberg, a son of Maxine and Dr. Dan Rosenberg of West Chester, Pa. Rabbi David Glandsberg-Kranin performed the ceremony at the Mendenhall Inn in Mendenhall, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, JOHN
description: MARSHALL-John, age 79, on January 30, 1997, after several years battle with cancer. John was the great-great-grandson of the former Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, John Marshall. John is survived by his brother Walton of Silver Springs, MD, his nephews Walton and Bob, and niece Sally of New Mexico, and by his late wife Anna's brother and wife, Dr. Jack Silk and Jean Silk. John will be buried with Anna in Orange, VA. John served as President of the Amateur Astronomers Association from 1978 to 1985, and as Executive Director for the past twelve years. A memorial service will be held at the Park Avenue Christian Church (85th Street and Park Avenue) at 3 P.M., Saturday, February 8, 1997. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Amateur Astronomers' Association, 1010 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10028 would be appreciated.

title: A Place to Practice Their Craft
description: To the Editor:

title: Conical Hats And Visual Messages
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Breaks On Selling A House
description: IT is hardly a secret that homeowners enjoy special benefits under Federal tax laws -- but there are important exceptions.

title: Remembering
description: To the Editor: Your article brings up the central issue of ''preserving'' ruins -- particularly concentration camps -- as historic monuments and memorials to the atrocities of World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEARY, MATTHEW
description: NEARY-Matthew. The entire John Jay Community mourns the death of our colleague, Professor of Law and Police Science and Criminal Justice Administration and former Dean of Administration. He will be remembered for his exemplary service to the NYPD and his dedication to the students of John Jay College. Gerald W. Lynch, President

title: France Takes a New Look At Property Looted From Jews
description: Confronting its collaborationist past under Nazi occupation, France announced last week that it was forming a committee to identify and locate property stolen from Jewish families during World War II. The property is believed to include buildings now owned by the city of Paris and nearly 2,000 works of art -- among them paintings by Courbet, Picasso and Sisley -- now in French museums.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: From Religious Roots to the Pop Charts
description: THE spirit is flowing through the church. The organ is pumping, and the choir is swaying and clapping to the backbeat. Down in the pews, the congregation is shouting ''Yes, Jesus!'' each time the choir gets to the refrain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, BURTON.
description: FISHMAN-Burton. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Janis and Steven Kamin, Robert and Jill Fishman, and Amy and Jay Schwartzberg. Cherished grandfather of Melissa, Jessica, Julie and Max. Dear uncle and good friend. Services ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 12:45 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, MARY
description: FINK-Mary. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Martin Fink. Cherished sister of Jean Kelvin. Devoted aunt and great-aunt. Service today 1:30PM at Temple Israel, Central Avenue, Lawrence, Long Island.

title: The State of Queens
