description: In her annual State of the Borough address delivered last week at the Queens Theater in the Park, Borough President Claire Shulman said unemployment in the county was down, infrastructure and library projects were under way and thousands of new seats had been created to ease overcrowding in the public schools -- although that remains one of Queens's most troubling problems.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, JOSEPH ABRAHAM
description: COOPER-Joseph Abraham. February 2, 1907-July 4, 1996. Happy 90th Birthday, dearest Dad. How I love and miss you and Mom.

title: But What About the Tax Bill?
description: Investors' thoughts about inflation will naturally drive their decisions about buying the Treasury's new inflation-indexed bonds. In a very unusual feature among fixed-income investments, the 10-year bonds auctioned on Wednesday will pay a ''real'' interest rate, of 3.375 percent. That means investors who hold them to maturity will be guaranteed that return, above and beyond inflation no matter how high it goes.

title: A Theater Where Women Are in the Director's Chair
description: Just as Barbara Krajkowski was talking about expanding opportunities for women's independence in the theater, a voice boomed from the wings: ''Go change the set.''

title: Vinny's Girlfriend, Climbing Back After Success
description: MARISA TOMEI KEEPS HER Oscar on the dressing table in the bathroom of her Greenwich Village apartment, right next to the Vavoom hair gel and vanilla body mist. ''It was a peak moment in my life, definitely,'' says the 32-year-old actress.

title: U.N. and U.S. Pressed on Rights Stance
description: With a new Secretary General here and with President Clinton entering his second term, human rights groups are stepping up pressure on both leaders to make protection of people around the world against violence and abuse a higher priority.

title: Jets Won't Give Up the Top Draft Pick. Next Question.
description: The Jets may look foolish on the football field, but the point men in the negotiations for Bill Parcells are not considered to be fools, despite their ragged results in recent years. They will not yield their overall No. 1 draft pick to get Bill Parcells from the Patriots, say people familiar with the plans of the Jets' president, Steve Gutman, and the owner, Leon Hess.

title: A Quest for Peace That Offers None
description: CRAVING a lack of communication, Katherine Samuel, once a teacher in an urban school, retreats to a ranch in search of silence. Ideas, insights, books, words: those are the fundamentals of Katherine's suddenly renewed interior life, and she means to indulge.

title: Isles Go West and Fall Off the Map
description: The first two losses were difficult enough, but the third one was a crusher. In the space of four days this week in Western Canada, the Islanders lost three games, all by one goal, once in overtime, and by 1-0 in their coup de grace. This wasn't a road trip, it was torture.

title: Iona Lures Recruits And Plays for Success
description: IN college basketball, the game is played on the floor, but the real game begins months and often years before, when a coaching staff recruits players. So important is recruiting that over a season, assistant coaches often spend more time calling prospects, mailing letters to them and visiting them than they do coaching. Every once in a while, though, if they are lucky, a recruit whom they miss coming out of high school falls back into their lap. That is the case with Iona and John McDonald.

title: Masked Ball to Celebrate 100th Anniversary of Castle
description: THE Castle at Tarrytown, restored to its turn-of-the-century grandeur, will celebrate its official opening as a luxury inn with a masked ball on March 1. The black-tie gala, which marks the 100th anniversary of the building of the Castle, will benefit two charities, Historic Hudson Valley and the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts.

title: Sold for Slaughter
description: The Federal Bureau of Land Management is supposed to protect America's wild horses. But a Justice Department inquiry found that the bureau had, in effect, looked the other way while many of the animals were sold for slaughter.

title: Three For the Show
description: Honors for Isaac Stern and Cy Coleman; WNYC celebrates its independence.

title: From Achebe to Zydeco
description: The Dictionary

title: Frustrated Gaza Increasingly Faults Its Rulers
description: It was just one more aggravation, the kind that people here recount in describing life these days in the Gaza Strip more than 30 months after Israel yielded control to the Palestinian Authority.

title: Landmark Idea Applauded, but Columbia Is Cautious
description: Many residents of the streets and avenues surrounding Columbia University's campus view their neighborhood as an under-recognized architectural treasure.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WENDER, LEONARD L.
description: WENDER-Leonard L. 2/5/94. Miss you more each day. Always loved. Sylvia, Stephen, Toby

title: Plain in Life, Wildly Ornamental In Their Works
description: REBECCA SCATTERGOOD SAVERY, an affluent Quaker living in Philadelphia in the early 19th century, made some pretty fancy quilts, not quite in keeping with what one might expect today from the drab-looking, plain-speaking Quakers. In the most dazzling one of all, she stitched together 6,700 diamond-shaped pieces of printed cotton cloth into a gloriously colorful mosaic, a design aptly called Sunburst. The fabrics she used were not exactly ordinary scraps but English prints -- costly imports in the 1820's.

title: School Bus Has 1 Seat, Many Diners
description: When the owner of a popular Bronx diner decided recently to move his restaurant, he did not waste time with realtors or moving companies. He just drove it up the block, parked it and reopened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIPIPPO, LEONARD, JR.
description: diPIPPO-Leonard, Jr. It is with deep sorrow that we note the passing of Leonard diPippo, Jr., Vice President of Real Estate for Loehmann's. Len's dedication and tenacity helped fuel our recent growth and future expansion. His warmth and sense of humor will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Debra, their children Jake and Brooke and his entire family. Robert N. Friedman, Chairman and CEO Philip Kaplan, President Senior Management Committee and his friends and colleagues at Loehmann's

title: Open Space Plan A Benefit to Few
description: Your report on open space $(''Open Space Plan Starts in Pine Area'' Jan. 19$) is the latest of various programs going back 25 years which have served to enrich politically connected landowners at taxpayers' expense. In 1972, with great fanfare, a plan to purchase farmland development rights was initiated which paid landowners over 80 percent of the value of their land for development rights alone. Now it's a plan to purchase development rights to protect the water supply. Part of this plan involves credits to be traded to developers.

title: Hartsdale Fights to Reopen Doors of Once-Thriving Stores
description: YOU can have your nails done, choose new wallpaper, plan a vacation and eat sushi in the shopping district that everyone here calls Hartsdale Village, although Hartsdale is really a hamlet in the town of Greenburgh.

title: Churchill's Switzerland
description: To the Editor:

title: 1999 or 2000
description: To the Editor: After reading the Travel section of Dec. 29, with its articles about millennial observances, I wrote this vers de societe for you:

title: Trying to Dust Off Historical Societies
description: DAVID M. KAHN thinks that historical societies are inclined to dwell too much on the past.

title: A SHARP DECREASE IN WELFARE CASES IS GATHERING SPEED
description: The steep decline in welfare caseloads that began nearly three years ago has accelerated in recent months, offering states a larger-than-expected financial windfall and a head start in carrying out the nation's newly restrictive welfare law.

title: Lending a Hand to Fellow New Yorkers
description: Here is a list of some organizations around the five boroughs that can use your help.

title: Frank Tejeda, 51, Congressman From Texas and Former Marine
description: Representative Frank Tejeda of Texas, a high school dropout who used the Marine Corps as a springboard out of the San Antonio slums and into an eventual seat in Congress, died on Thursday at the home of his former wife, Cecelia, in San Antonio. He was 51 and had represented the heavily Hispanic 28th District of south Texas as a Democrat since its creation in 1992.

title: Westchester Firm Becoming Part of Jersey REIT
description: FOR 40 years, the company created by Robert Weinberg and Martin Berger was a major factor in the two counties immediately north of New York City, with their Robert Martin Company eventually owning 4.1 million square feet of office, mixed-use and industrial space in Westchester and in Fairfield County, Conn.

title: Dollywood
description: Where Cindy and the gang pickup an Oscar and get to wear very tight clothes.

title: Home Depot Fighting a Stay in Smithtown
description: WHEN the Smithtown Board of Zoning Appeals voted to let Home Depot build a store on 13 acres, the Town Board went to court and obtained a stay.

title: Crime
description: Where's the beef? That's a fair question to put to Patricia Cornwell, who has written a long (377 pages), detailed and exceedingly dull police procedural that inexplicably lacks a major criminal investigation to give it focus. Having ditched her designated series sleuth, the forensic pathologist Kay Scarpetta, for more conventional crimebusters in HORNET'S NEST (Putnam, $25.95), Ms. Cornwell fixes her attention on Judy Hammer, Chief of Police in Charlotte, N.C.; her deputy, Virginia West; and a 22-year-old cub reporter named Andy Brazil, who, in defiance of all police protocol (and rudimentary common sense), is given the extraordinary assignment of tagging along on the job with Deputy West and playing cop.

title: The Latest Steps in a Ballroom Contest
description: A month ago, it seemed that the long-held desire of the Rev. Calvin O. Butts and a group of Harlem investors to own and renovate the Renaissance Ballroom had been foiled. Although the group, led by the Abyssinian Development Corporation, held the mortgage on the property, it was narrowly outbid at a foreclosure auction in December by Michael Berman, a business associate of the building's former owner, Baruch Singer, a real-estate investor.

title: Imbued With Love, Imbued With Effort
description: WHAT happens when practitioners of musical comedy schtick take charge of an ineffable 18th-century French comedy? In the case of ''Triumph of Love'' at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, something tres charmless.

title: Hill Is Still Double Trouble For Nets
description: The waifish Kerry Kittles was nothing more than a windbreaker on Detroit's Grant Hill, flimsy protection against a player who can slice through anyone's best intentions.

title: Tapping Maples, Making Syrup. Vermont? No, Short Hills.
description: Maple syrup isn't tapped just in Vermont, and the mall is hardly the only family attraction in Short Hills.

title: THE LAPTOP COLONIALISTS
description: Many's the night I've cranked ''Madame Butterfly'' on the stereo, curled up with a single-malt Scotch and a copy of the latest Cigar Aficionado magazine, and wept bitterly, mourning the fact that there aren't any more places where American boys can live like kings, having their way with a smorgasbord of exotic native women. So, needless to say, I booked a flight to Vietnam the moment I finished ''The Laptop Colonialists,'' by Michael Paterniti (Jan. 12). Miss Saigon is alive and well, quietly freshening our drinks as we go about the important business of saving the Vietnamese from their primitive noncapitalist ways.

title: In a Bronx Neighborhood, Moderate-Income Choices
description: IN an active node of residential construction in the Baychester section of the northeast Bronx, two home builders are providing new two-family houses for moderate-income buyers.

title: Where Bad Golf Can Anger The Gods
description: DURING the months of picking, pondering and discarding like gin rummy cards various destinations for our upcoming Asia trip, my friend Harvey and I had only one firm requirement: that we have time to play on some of the region's fine golf courses. With devastating logic, our wives disputed our need to travel halfway around the world to do exactly what we do here at home. Our reply was immediate: This was not about a game, but about the special insight golf would provide into each country's culture.

title: Heat Subsidies Are Arriving
description: To the Editor:

title: 60's-Style Heroics for the 90's
description: PROBABLY THE MOST common put-down of contemporary pop music by baby boomers and classic-rock lovers comes in the form of a question: ''Can you name one musician today who can compare to Jimi Hendrix or Eric Clapton or Led Zeppelin?'' An easy answer is to ask them to name a musician of the 60's who can compare to Dr. Dre or Kurt Cobain or the Aphex Twin. A better answer is that there are musicians just as great as Hendrix and Jimmy Page out there today. But we live in a rock culture that in part because of the success of these musicians has grown more adept at turning an art form -- especially one built on youth, nonconformity and protest -- into an industry. It is the canny plagiarists and the genre synthesists who tend to rise to prominence in a business that makes money by turning meaningful music into a disposable trend.

title: Connie Connors, Michael Fleisher
description: Cornelia Kathleen Connors, the president of Connors Communications, a New York public relations company, was married last evening to Michael David Fleisher, the president of the emerging-businesses division of the Gartner Group, a technology research firm in Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the couple's home in New York.

title: Honoring Cow College Tradition At UConn
description: TO walk into the auditorium of the Radcliffe Hicks Building in Storrs is to step backward in time. One of the largest classrooms on the main campus of the University of Connecticut looks less like a bastion of academia than a rodeo ring. Several rows of chairs surround an earthen pit some 90 feet in diameter. The floor's sawdust covering is redolent with the odor of the barnyard.

title: Railroads Should Play Bigger Role in Future
description: Your article $(''County's Rails Tell of Past and Future,'' Dec. 22$) told of some of the past, but to my dismay, incorporated little about the future. While it was enjoyable, it did not make any reference to the inequalities in public policy that almost brought the railroads to extinction.

title: A Chance to Try to End an Agony
description: JANUARY was the cruelest month in Algeria. Cruel in its violence, including a car-bombing that killed 42 people in central Algiers; cruel in the cynicism of the assassination of Abdelhak Benhamouda, an influential union leader who had wanted to forge a new political party. And cruel, above all, for the promise of yet more killing that was contained in a ranting speech by the President in which he blamed foreign plots for all of Algeria's woes and vowed to ''eradicate'' the terrorists.

title: Compromise Recipe at Feuding Food Co-op
description: Debate grew heated at times, but a meeting of the Park Slope Food Cooperative last week was dominated by a mood members say has been missing for months: conciliation.

title: Golden Oldies
description: WHEN New Jersey became ''the Garden State'' no one had any idea there were 90-million-year-old fusainized flowers hidden beneath the ground in Sayreville, near the mouth of the Raritan River.

title: With Show, Cosby Acts On His Vow To Move On
description: Bill Cosby managed to get back to the business of stand-up comedy tonight, telling an audience of 2,200 people here at his first concert performance since the murder of his son: ''This is not difficult for me because a part of my lifetime has been with you all.''

title: Living, and Selling, In New York City
description: Over breakfast, Donna Hanover will tell residential sales agents and brokers why she opted to live, raise a family and work in Manhattan even before the television and movie personality's husband, Rudolph W. Giuliani, became Mayor. During the cocktail hour, Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter will offer insight into the city's fiscal health, job growth and the quality of life in the new residential sections of the city, especially Wall Street.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: STUDIO AFFAIRS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEPRIN, SYLVIA LEAH (NEE BROD)
description: WEPRIN-Sylvia Leah (nee Brod). Beloved daughter of Harry and Bessie E. Brod. Devoted wife to Louis Weprin and loving mother to Joel, Ruth, Natalie, Barry and Earle. Proud grandmother to Julie, Peter, Eric, Angela and David. Mrs. Weprin achieved a fullness of life, dedicated to service and love to her family and community.

title: It's the Demand, Stupid
description: Every week somewhere in washington, I am certain, Al Gore steals a few hours from his Vice-Presidential duties to check on the progress of his campaign to raise hundreds of millions for his Presidential race in 2000. Burden though it is to beg for money and to promise future favors, Gore is the luckiest of the potential candidates. He at least can entertain media fat cats in a Government mansion and fly Air Force Two to the Buddhist temple in California that proved so generous to him and Bill Clinton last year.

title: Low Flow, High Overflow
description: Two years ago, when Barbara George's co-op building in Greenwich Village enrolled in a city program that offered rebates to landlords and apartment owners who installed water-saving toilets, Ms. George championed the program as a stroke of environmental genius.

title: The F.B.I. Takes a Second Look At Its Model Crime Lab
description: Ever since J. Edgar Hoover created it, the Federal Bureau of Investigation's crime lab has been considered a model in the field of forensic science -- that is, until a two-year internal Justice Department investigation uncovered an array of complaints. Much of the criticism came from lab employees themselves; they described sloppy, improper and unscientific practices in important cases like the Oklahoma City bombing investigation. In one instance in that case, lab examiners sent the prime suspect's jeans to the lab in a brown paper sack instead of a sealed evidence bag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRADKIN, BENJAMIN
description: FRADKIN - Benjamin. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Stephen and Judy. Loving brother of Helen Friedman. Proud grandfather of Jon, Jill, Wendy, Hilary Hotchkiss, Kathy and Neil Fradkin. Services were held.

title: Corporate Welfare's New Enemies
description: REPRESENTATIVE JOHN R. KASICH, one of the standard-bearers in the Republican war on the welfare state, tells a story about an encounter he had recently with a business executive in Texas.

title: Where Eyesores and the Economy Collide
description: PETER B. DORRAM, dapper in vest and bow tie, tapped his pointer at a chart propped on an easel in Eddie Goldberg's office. The office is a remodeled trailer at Tri-Way Kars, the used-car lot Mr. Goldberg has run for almost 30 years on Route 46 in South Hackensack.

title: Casting a Wider Net For Web Site Workers
description: COMPANIES are still struggling to find ways to profit from the Internet, but many people who set up and run corporate Web sites are not having the same problem.

title: BEST SELLERS: February, 2, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARD COVER

title: Shaking Up the World, or Shaped by It?
description: HAS THERE BEEN ANY MOVIE that like a branch thrown in a river changed, however slightly, the course of history? A movie that turned the tide of opinion because it so enlightened, shocked or dismayed its viewers? Or are films like silt, constantly settling to the bottom of the river, doing their work invisibly, if at all?

title: Inspired by Citrus, From Salad to Dessert
description: THIS is the season for citrus. Oranges, lemons, grapefruit, tangerines, blood oranges and some unusual fruit, like big thick-skinned green pomelos and scarlet blood oranges, are in season. These fruits can inspire any number of dishes, from first courses to desserts. And if you believe that vitamin C helps ward off colds, these fruits enhance the supply of vitamin C.

title: Questions About a Professional's Standing? An Answer's on the Web
description: In the belief that knowledge is power, the New York State Board of Regents has placed licensing information for 610,000 professionals, including any disciplinary action, on the Internet. Now, with the click of a computer mouse, a consumer can learn who is in good standing -- from the psychologist recommending more sessions to the interior decorator insisting on a Viking theme for every room in the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDAHL, BRADLEY M.
description: UNDAHL-Bradley M., of NYC, age 34. Born in Baudett, MN. Survived by companion William Barry of NYC, parents Burnell and Dorothy, and siblings Barbara and Steve. Brad was a Minnesota State 1980 graduate, majoring in Wind Instruments and played with several orchestras including Big Apple Corp. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Cabrini Medical Center in Brad's name. A memorial mass will be offered Monday, February 3, at 6 P.M., at St. Veronica's R.C. Church.

title: The E.P.A. May Extend the Debate on Tougher Air Standards
description: Facing opposition from some of the nation's governors to proposals for toughening air quality standards, the Environmental Protection Agency is moving to extend the period for public debate before the final rules are issued.

title: This Takes the Cake: Lyle to Manage
description: Lou Piniella saw it in his morning newspaper and said, ''They can have a cheeseburger before they pitch.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSAN, WILLIAM C.
description: HASSAN-William C. of Moraga, CA on January 23, 1997. After retiring from the US Marine Corps. he was an executive of Bechtel Corporation in San Francisco. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Jenco). Devoted father of Patricia Newhart and Georgiana Andersen. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Will and Kyle. Contributions to Hospice of Contra Costa County, CA.

title: Next Front: Animals That Aren't So Cute
description: BIG brown eyes, furry coats, playful quirks. Most animals hunted and ranched for their fur have another thing going for them: they're cute. Judging by the species of animals that have won sympathy points with the public and those that have not -- lizards, alligators, cows and pigs -- Darwin's treatise might need an update, like survival of the furriest.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Inspecting the Inspectors
description: IN 1992, a State Police sting secretly recorded inspectors from the Atlantic City Mercantile Office soliciting bribes from Timothy Daley, who pushes a rolling chair on the Boardwalk. That sting resulted in dismissals of seven of the dozen employees. Now, the office is once again drawing attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, BENJAMIN HARRY
description: BARON-Benjamin Harry. Born February 16, 1909, (nee Baronofsky). Passed away on January 28, 1997. He resided in Brooklyn, NY most of his life, and West Palm Beach, Fla. He is survived by his beloved children, Ruth Herz and Carl Baron; grandchildren: Nicole, Justin and Julia; sister Mildred Halpert and brother Leon. After graduating CCNY in 1929, Ben became a dedicated foreign language teacher in the NYC High Schools and an active member of The Teachers Union. He was devoted to promoting the survival of Yiddish through his work on behalf of the Kings Highway Jewish School, had a deep love for classical music and tennis. A memorial will be held at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUCCIO, VINCENT
description: PUCCIO-Vincent. Of Northport, LI. Graphic artist and partner with Walsh, Reinhart and Puccio. Husband of Gloria. Father of James, Christopher and Victor. Brother of Sal. Grandfather of Laura. Fatherin-law of Diane Puccio and Lynn Schulte. Reposing Nolan & TaylorHowe Funeral Home, Northport, LI, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. Interment Northport Rural Cemetery.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TCHAIKOVSKY'S LAST DAYS

title: The Secrets of Winter Fishing in the Florida Keys
description: A man in his 60's wearing shorts and a T-shirt gazed almost defiantly at the windswept South Atlantic as Marathon Key's noontime temperature refused to budge higher than 52 degrees. The day before, an Alberta Clipper had roared down like Sherman's Army, sending much of South Florida into near panic with words like ''wind chill'' and ''hard freeze'' being used for the first time in years.

title: Three Cheers For Music's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: The Syracuse Defense Works for Others, Too
description: When a guard brings the ball up the floor against the Syracuse defense, way before he reaches the halfcourt line, he will often find the Orangemen set in their staple 2-3 defense. Syracuse guards out front, bent over, hands on knees. Syracuse back line of three standing tall, denying layups.

title: When Plant Fans Gather, a Harvest of Obsessions
description: Plant fanatics abandoned themselves to the first annual Plant-O-Rama at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden last week with a wild euphoria that was ''Reefer Madness'' in the perennial bed.

title: Neutral Ireland Posed the Greatest Threat to an Allied Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACTER, BARBARA CAMERON
description: SCHACTER-Barbara Cameron, on January 26, 1997. A beautiful person both inside and out, who touched everyone in her own very special way. A devoted and wonderful friend who will live on not only in my heart, but also in the hearts of all those who knew and loved her. Barbara, I will miss you and I will always love you. Gail Jeffee Cohen

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: CIRCLE VIEW By Brad Barkley. Southern Methodist University, cloth, $22.50; paper, $12.95.

title: Renaissance Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mother's Name
description: When I was five months pregnant with my son, I went to a dinner party in Florence, where my husband, Luca Passaleva, is from. The conversation briefly left politics when someone suggested that I name my child Silvio, after Berlusconi, the Italian Prime Minister at the time.

title: Programs Salute Those With African Roots
description: THE arrival of February marks the start of African-American History Month. Today at 1:30 P.M. youngsters can attend a performance of the Okra Dance Company, presented by Playtime Productions in the Chappaqua Library Auditorium. The guest ensemble will take the family on ''a fast-paced, rousing journey of American dance as it evolved from African roots to its European influences with tap, minstrel, soft-shoe, Broadway, hip-hop and even the 'hot' club dances of today.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH
description: BERGER-Ruth. The New York Women's Bar Association extends its condolences to Director and immediate Past President Andrea Berger, on the death of her beloved mother, Ruth.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: New Year's Eve

title: Festivals and Focuses
description: THERE ARE MORE than 1,000 film festivals every year, but only a small number are truly important. Cannes is still the most highly regarded, followed in Europe by Venice and Berlin. But at least four North American festivals have international significance.

title: Pay Us in Advance
description: To the Editor:

title: Where They're Sailing
description: TITIAN'S plump beauties come to mind when viewing today's ships. On the inside, these outsized vessels are more like apartment buildings with corridors stretching to infinity. At least five enter service this year, including the Rotterdam VI, weighing 62,000 tons and carrying 1,320 passengers to replace the 38-year-old Rotterdam, retiring as Holland America's flagship.

title: State Grants Helping Open School Clinics
description: FRUSTRATED in reaching students who have a high risk of disease, health officials are trying a more direct approach -- setting up clinics in the schools.

title: His Work, Her Valentines, Their 32 Years of Celebration
description: MEL CASSON, the creator of Redeye, a comic strip about an American Indian tribe that appears in 350 newspapers, also makes valentines. ''It has to do with my marriage of over 30 years,'' he explains. ''Every year for Valentine's Day I have drawn a valentine for my wife, Mary Lee.''

title: The Mets' Future Will Have to Wait
description: The morning stillness is punctuated only by a few grunts and the occasional crack of a baseball being whacked by a bat. Spring training is still officially almost three weeks away for the Mets, but not for three of the club's brightest pitching hopes.

title: Truth Be Told, Louganis Must Be Free to Speak
description: A FLORIDA state senator, John Grant of the 13th District, recently wrote a letter to the president of the University of South Florida in Tampa to bar Greg Louganis from speaking at the school.

title: 1996 Was a Big Year, but Maybe Not the Biggest
description: AS everyone knows by now, 1996 was a record year for the mutual fund industry. Or was it?

title: The Naked Manatee Did It
description: THERE had been talk of beers and snacks squeezed in between their appearances on ''The Charlie Rose Show'' and at a book signing at the Union Square Barnes & Noble. But events conspired against them: Mr. Rose talked too long to his previous guest, Jacqueline Bisset, the actress. Then he showed an update on something called the O. J. Simpson trial, which two of the nation's top crime novelists, Carl Hiaasen and Elmore Leonard, with the humorist Dave Barry in tow, claimed to know nothing about.

title: Sugar Hill Sours On Plan for Subway Ventilation Pipe
description: After working as a maid for most of her life, Nancy Dixon saw a dream of home ownership come true when she bought the five-story limestone row house at 731 St. Nicholas Avenue in 1977. The round gray facade sets it apart from the other houses on the block with plain brick fronts. And there are views of Yankee Stadium to the north and the midtown skyline to the south.

title: Cold Comfort
description: CLASS TRIP

title: HOW FOOTBALL GOT SACKED
description: Barra's explanation of the deteriorating interest of fans in TV football can be summed up in one word: Boredom. To cover the millions of dollars they plunk down each year for the privilege of broadcasting the games, the networks expose us to more and more commercials, so that it now takes upward of three and a half hours to see a 60-minute game. Not content with the normal interruptions of an athletic contest, they have created the monstrosity known as the TV timeout, which only prolongs the agony.

title: Ms. Buchinskas And Mr. Forsythe
description: Marianne Buchinskas, a daughter of Claire and Dr. Edmund J. Buchinskas of West Falmouth, Mass., was married in New York yesterday to Wayne J. Forsythe, a son of Mildred and Daniel Forsythe of Boca Raton, Fla. Justice David B. Saxe of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Penn Club.

title: Not Just Cruise Ships Anymore
description: HEAVY bookings for millennium cruises, including cruises whose price and itinerary are not yet established, promise to jump-start the cruise business for the year 2000. But right now the industry is perplexed about 1996, worried about 1997, and wondering whether any of those heady projections about the growing popularity of cruising will be realized before the next century.

title: Trails and Gardens, A Woods And Pond
description: THINGS are perking at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center in Stamford. After what appeared to be a dormant period, the landscape has started to sprout with dramatic additions -- the most compelling and original being Nature's Playground.

title: I've Kicked The Tires. Now I'll Kick Myself.
description: FOR me, the phrase ''used car'' has always conjured up the image of a slick-talking, cigar-chomping salesman clad in plaid and stuffing bananas into a car's innards to muffle the whine from a damaged differential.

title: Many Unhappy Returns at I.R.S.
description: For once, we can do something about government waste and I.R.S. ineptitude, quickly and cheaply.

title: Reviving Music and Culture in a Town That Time Forgot
description: This town seat of the state's poorest, least populous county -- is set in the middle of miles of fields, an hour's drive from Philadelphia and three hours from New York City. The few outsiders who have heard of it usually know only that its nuclear power plant -- closed since 1995 -- is ranked as one of the nation's most troubled.

title: CBS and King Video
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Keys: Soaring Free Of the Piano
description: THERE'S A MOMENT AT THE END OF THE first chapter in ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' when the protagonist jumps out of the window of the widow Douglas's house. It's one of the more exhilarating events in American literature: Huck is set free; the continent is his to explore, and the narrative has nowhere to go but onward and outward.

title: Using 'Trimulcast,' Station Switches to Country
description: IN 1938 Orson Welles shocked the radio audience with his realistic adaptation of ''The War of the Worlds.''

title: Role of Jail Advisory Committee
description: As a member of the Jail Advisory Committee I am disturbed that ''Nassau Moving Juveniles to New Detention Center at County Jail'' $(Jan. 5$) suggests that the committee makes decisions or sets policy concerning jail or county matters. This is not the case at all.

title: The Little Rubber Dress, Among Others
description: At some point, Helmut Lang decided how he would look. Long hair, white skin that could easily go brown but is always, always pale and stiff blue jeans. In 10 years of photographs, his appearance does not change. It is not so much a uniform as a deliberate choice, an extension of his stylistic vision. Lang has that certainty -- a hem should hit here; silk will drape better than rayon; lime green will be more interesting than forest -- and he has always stuck by the same spare but surprisingly detailed silhouette. While other designers dash from decade to decade for inspiration, doing warmed-over revisions of fashions past, Lang has remained, rather stubbornly and brilliantly, modern.

title: Song Will Always Remain the Same for Williams
description: He was in Charlotte with the Knicks and his ailing father was at home in Rocky Mount. That night after the game, he had planned to drive four hours east through North Carolina. It was perhaps the last time they would talk.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on page 3 of the Travel section today, about direct flights to Colorado skiing areas, misspells the surname of the president of Mountain Air Express. He is Tom McClain, not McCain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, YVONNE
description: ROSEN-Yvonne. On January 28,1997. Beloved mother of Roxane and Ronald. Adoring grandmother of Shira, Jaron and Rose. Devoted mother-in-law of Paul. Cherished friend of the children and grandchildren of her dear late husband, George Rosen. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Her life touched all those who knew her. She will be missed. Funeral private. A memorial to celebrate her life will be held at a later date.

title: Group Helps Students Develop Job Skills
description: THE only thing certain about the future is change, and nowhere is that more evident than in the workplace. Educators and employers agree that students will need more than the basics to compete in the labor market in the 21st century.

title: UConn Struggles Again Before Taking a Step Forward
description: Connecticut was without its heart and soul. Seton Hall's heart and soul, meanwhile, went without a field goal in the final 19 minutes.

title: Legal Euthanasia: Australia Faces a Grim Reality
description: The last meal of sandwiches and beer seems to have been more agonizing for Dr. Philip Nitschke than for the cancer-ridden patient whose life he was about to take.

title: Barbara Corvino, Michael Malone
description: Barbara Anne Corvino and Michael James Malone were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Very Rev. Michael G. Ryan performed the ceremony.

title: Hard Times at the Chapel Square Mall
description: WHEN Terry Cranville opened Zab's Backyard Hots in the Chapel Square Mall in 1984, downtown New Haven was a much different place.

title: A Model of a Good Teacher Tells How
description: WHEN the Governor of North Carolina, James B. Hunt Jr., wrote a book last year titled ''What Matters Most: Teaching for America's Future,'' it was Evelyn Jenkins Gunn, an English teacher at Pelham Memorial High School whom he held up as a model of a good teacher.

title: Yesterday's Soda Can, Today's Swiss Watch
description: WHAT Rewatch, a wristwatch made from beer cans, soda cans and recycled Mercedes-Benz seats, with works by Eta, the Swiss company that also supplies Swatch, Omega and Tissot. For $69 at Watch World stores throughout the city, or by mail; (888) 928-2496; also sold in Germany, Austria and New Zealand.

title: Where East Meets Tex-Mex
description: LIKE most customers lined 11 deep at Fresco Tortilla shortly after noon last Tuesday, the man in the Armani suit uses the fish face. First, his eyes squint up at the huge 54-item Tex-Mex menu, then his mouth forms an ''o.'' He begins to order an item, then goes back to the ''o'' again. Finally, he orders ''Number 10,'' a grilled chicken taco, to go.

title: Peru Pledges to Reopen Talks With Rebels
description: Under pressure from the Government of Japan, Peru agreed today to reopen formal talks with rebels to find a peaceful solution to the six-week hostage crisis in Lima, but it again ruled out meeting demands for a release of rebel prisoners in Peruvian jails.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FRANK
description: BERNSTEIN-Frank. With deep sorrow the Board of Directors of River Point Towers mourns the passing of our devoted Secretary and fellow Director. His ability to offer practical solutions to complex problems in a most professional and good natured way will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies are with his wife Marcia, daughters Brenda and Abigail, son-in-law Michael and all of his loving family members. Edward L. Scharf, President For the Board of Directors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, HELEN BANDOW
description: LAZAR-Helen Bandow, 79. Adoring wife of Jack. Mother and mother-in-law of Bill and Anne, Jeanne and Michael. Grandmother of Jack, Rebecca, Cooper, Rita and Matthew. She, with her husband Jack, cofounded Kimberly Knitwear, Inc., and she served as the head designer. They built a wonderful company together and had a great time doing so. The memorial service was held in Teaneck, NJ, on Jan. 31. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: An Elegant Flower In a Modest Garden
description: IN THE WINTER, YELLOW JASMINE trees decorate the Venetian courtyard of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, their masses of blooms like golden halos. Just behind that courtyard, the museum's intimate temporary exhibition space has been painted with pilasters and capitals to suggest the measured opulence of 15th-century Florence.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Eric Bogosian
description: Eric Bogosian's movie ''Suburbia'' opens Friday.

title: Why Praise a Failure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mikel Cardinal Koliqi of Albania Dies at 94
description: Mikel Cardinal Koliqi of Albania, who spent decades in confinement during the rigidly Stalinist era of his homeland, died on Tuesday in Shkoder. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, TESS
description: LIPTON-Tess, on January 24, 1997. Resident of Las Vegas, Nevada. Formerly of New York City, Shrub Oak Park, Century Village, Deerfield Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Koppel Lipton. Loving mother to Howard, Paul and Daughter-in-law Elaine. Missing her will be grandchildren: Ross, Jeffrey and his wife Randi. Nieces and nephews Barbara Leonard, Marilyn and Ike Hazan. Edward and Chris Gitelson, Paul and Nancy Gitelson. Sister-in-law Bertha Givertzman and other cousins and their children. She was quick with a smile, generous and a very caring member of her family. She leaves a painful void, but will always be remembered with love, admiration and respect. Services were held Sunday, January 26, 1997, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Landscape Visionary for a New American Dream
description: THE VIEW FROM Garrett Eckbo's house high in the Berkeley Hills is one of the most dazzling in the United States, a panorama encompassing San Francisco, its bay and its bridges. Yet to Mr. Eckbo, the 86-year-old dean of West Coast landscape architects, the outlook is less than enthralling. ''I know this is controversial,'' he said with a sly grin, ''but I'm so tired of the Bay Area congratulating itself on what a marvelous place this is when it's really a bloody mess.''

title: The Magic of Fine French Cooking, as Performed by a Master
description: THE husband is late. Not so late that I'll miss the cooking demonstration at the Kings supermarket in Short Hills, but late enough that I won't have time to stop for dinner. And that's unfortunate. Famished is not the way you want to be while watching one of the world's great chefs produce one of the world's great dinners. (At cooking exhibitions, you get to taste, not to eat.)

title: New Calm in Balanced-Budget Quest
description: When Republicans pushed unsuccessfully for a steep reduction in the capital gains tax in the late 1980's, their proposals were attacked by Democrats as ''a tax break for the wealthy paid for by the middle class,'' as George J. Mitchell of Maine, then the majority leader in the Senate, put it.

title: More Than Just Food, It Offers Camaraderie
description: REMEMBER when someone in a Technicolor musical like Judy Garland or Jane Powell would say, ''Hey kids, I've got an idea, let's put on a show.'' The show was usually not slick or commercial, but it was always endearing, even lovable. That line comes to mind at the tiny, 40-seat Crescent City Coffee House in Floral Park. It generates a similar spirit.

title: Church v. State: Landmark Case
description: WHAT can be done with a house of worship that is treasured by the public but no longer wholly suited to the needs of its congregation? Must it be maintained? For whom? And by whom? Since the beginning of the century, and the early stirrings of the historic preservation movement, Americans have wrestled with the question of where to draw the line when religious freedom and civic responsibility collide.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE TWILIGHT OF COMMON DREAMS: Why America Is Wracked by Culture Wars

title: HOW FOOTBALL GOT SACKED
description: As a self-described ''football fan'' who hasn't watched more than five consecutive minutes of a game in over 10 years, I found it a relief to read Allen Barra's ''How Football Got Sacked'' (Jan. 12). So I'm not the only one who can't tell which new cat team is from what sunshine city, or who the heck the Ravens are, or were!

title: Remembering
description: To the Editor: I commend Oradour-sur-Glane for preserving the results of the Nazi atrocity.

title: Roll Over Hawks and Doves
description: The Times Mexico correspondent Julia Preston recently told me an intriguing story about the Zapatista guerrillas, the peasant group that has been fighting the effects of free trade and globalization on Mexico. Last year, the Zapatistas held a convention in the jungles of southern Mexico, entitled ''The Intercontinental Forum in Favor of Humanity and Against Neo-Liberalism.'' The closing session met in a steamy, mud-hole amphitheater and was led by Zapatista leader ''Sub-Commander Marcos'' -- a Mexican combination of Robin Hood and Ralph Nader. The session ended with the Zapatistas doing a kind of drum roll and announcing the most evil, dangerous institution in the world today. To a standing ovation, the Zapatistas declared the biggest enemy of mankind to be the W.T.O. -- the World Trade Organization in Geneva, which promotes global free trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, MARY (NEE TARTELL)
description: JACOBSON-Mary (nee Tartell). Of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Brooklyn. On Thursday, January 30. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Services at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' on Monday, at 12 Noon.

title: 'They Love You. Watch Out.'
description: RIGHT IN THE

title: Peru to Reopen Talks With Hostage-Takers
description: Insisting Peru will never give in to demands that 300 rebels be freed, President Alberto K. Fujimori said he would resume talks to release 72 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima. He made the commitment after meeting the Japanese Prime Minister, who has grown nervous about aggressive tactics by Mr. Fujimori's troops.

title: College Offers Readings With Tea
description: ESPRESSO, tea and lively talk are what the organizers have in mind for a new series at Manhattanville College to begin today. The programs, ''Tea at Three: The Manhattanville College Current Author Series,'' will bring writers to the campus in Purchase for book readings and general conversation.

title: Not About Eve
description: Race and HUMAN Evolution

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOHN CAMPBELL
description: HENRY-John Campbell. On January 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Whitmel Powers Henry. Survived also by a daughter, Margaret Smith, a son, John Campbell Henry, Jr., a stepson, Eric Knaus, two grandsons and a sister, Louise Henry Clark. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Another Simpson Jury Gets Its Chance
description: The jury in the O. J. Simpson civil case began deliberating last week whether to find Mr. Simpson financially liable for the deaths of his wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald L. Goldman.

title: HE'S NOT HEAVY, HE'S MY BABY
description: I cringe when I read stories written by married people with children in the apologetic tone they use to justify their existence. Matson's single life style seemed more interesting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH FANSHEL
description: BERGER-Ruth Fanshel. Died at 69 of cancer on February 1, 1997. Beloved wife of Wallace for 51 years. Daughter of the late Hyman and Clara Fanshel. Devoted mother of Andrea and Adam (Katharine). Loving grandmother of Beth, Louisa and Clara. Sister of David (Florence), Jack (Beatrice) and the late Sol (Florence). Retired Professor of Social Work at Lehman College, CUNY. A woman of integrity and compassion, she devoted her life to issues concerning social justice and peace.

title: Swimming in Smaller Pools
description: Mutual fund managers who pick stocks of big companies have not kept pace with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the last couple of years, and investors have taken note. The Vanguard Index 500 Portfolio, which tracks the index, has supplanted Fidelity Magellan as the top-selling mutual fund.

title: Asian American Group Took Advocacy to the Next Level
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERA, DOLORES (NEE DIBBLEE)
description: SILVERA-Dolores (nee Dibblee). On January 30, 1997. Of Rosemont, PA. Wife of Alain Silvera and mother of David D. Also survived by two grandchildren. Memorial service Monday, February 3 at 11 AM, chapel of West Laurel Hill Cemetery, Belmont Ave, Bala Cynwyd, PA. Interment in cemetery.

title: Where Even the Ghosts Give Encouragement
description: UNTIL THE NEW DANCE Group Arts Center on West 47th Street in Manhattan installed a new elevator last month, the 85-year-old choreographer Sophie Maslow climbed the six-story building's steep, well-worn marble staircase several times a week to teach a class, hold an audition or prepare a concert. Over the years, she was not the only luminary to avoid the original, creaky elevator. Martha Graham, Agnes de Mille, Alvin Ailey, Jose Limon, Merce Cunningham and Jerome Robbins often went up and down the same narrow passageway. More recently, Ben Vereen, Tommy Tune, Gelsey Kirkland, Madonna and Savion Glover did, too.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Many H.M.O.'s Easing Rules On Seeking Specialists' Care
description: They are known as gatekeepers, and they are what many Americans dislike most about their health maintenance organizations. They are the primary-care doctors who must say yes before a patient can see a specialist.

title: Safir Shifts 500 Detectives to Aid Precincts
description: Seeking to relieve police investigators' caseloads, Commissioner Howard Safir is reassigning 500 detectives from administrative duty to detective squads in New York City's 76 precinct station houses, police officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOSHPITZ, JOSEPH D., M.D.
description: NOSHPITZ-Joseph D., M.D. On Tuesday, January 28, 1997. Dr. Joseph D. Noshpitz of Washington, D.C. Beloved husband of Charlotte Noshpitz. Devoted father of Claude Noshpitz. Loving brother of Ruth Kellman and Rose Bennett. Adoring grandfather of Jonathan Cummings. Services at the Danzansky-Goldberg Memorial Chapel, Inc., 1170 Rockville Pike, Rockville, MD., Sunday, February 2, 1997 at 11 A.M. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. The family will be in mourning at the late residence. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to The Joseph Dov Noshpitz Memorial Fund, The American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, 3615 Wisconsin Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: INSIDE
description: Grip Tightens on Hong Kong

title: On 2 Streets, 2 Different Views of a Dinkins Candidacy
description: In the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, Helen Maharaj, a 49-year-old homemaker picking over breakfast at a diner on Fulton Street, lit up when the subject turned to the news that David N. Dinkins might return to public life. ''I just love the idea,'' she said, nearly rising out of her seat. ''I would vote for him. And I would tell all my friends to vote for him.''

title: Richter Turns Back the Flyers With a Goaltending Exhibition
description: How does a hockey team get outplayed for long stretches by a younger, bigger, much more physical team -- one that outshoots you by 41-17 -- and still win by two goals?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, MICHAEL D.

description: FOR those seeking romantic inspiration in the kitchen, Valentine's Day celebrations at the Tarrytown Hilton and the Rye Town Hilton will focus on how to make culinary delights.

description: Many cruise lines have pages on the World Wide Web.; many more travel agencies and services emphasizing cruises are also on line.

title: From Soup to Litchi Nuts
description: ''MONA IN THE PROMISED LAND'' IS THE story of a second-generation Chinese-American girl whose version of adolescent rebellion was to convert to Judaism. Revolted by her mother's home-style Chinese cooking -- that's gross, she says of a certain stir-fry -- Mona took her comfort from matzoh ball soup.

description: The White House acknowledged today that it had never reviewed the backgrounds of any of the hundreds of visitors who saw President Clinton in scores of intimate White House meetings arranged by the Democratic National Committee.

description: To the Editor:

title: Alone, in a Crowd
description: William S. Cohen, the new Secretary of Defense, stands alone. He is the only Republican in the Cabinet of a Democratic President. Do you stand alone in your office? Are you the only woman in an office full of men, or the only man in an office of women? Are you the only parent in an office full of childless Generation X'ers? Or maybe you're a liberal surrounded by conservatives. Has your unique status caused any interesting situations in your office? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Education of a Health Care Customer
description: DARRIN JACKSON-WEEKS got his Medicaid card two years ago. He had been an H.I.V. counselor, a member of a private health plan. Suddenly he was an H.I.V. client on public assistance. As smart, informed and assertive as he still was, he felt the difference right away. He had been walked around the desk. He was looked upon as a poor person now. What could he possibly know?

title: Listening Is Either/Or. Or Is It?
description: AN ADVERTISING MAN WITH A SALES campaign on his mind called this office not long ago wanting to know what music we listen to while reading our favorite newspaper. At the time, I couldn't bring myself to call him back, but I hope this makes amends.

title: To Foster Family Activities, Turn Off the TV
description: IF some determined parents and educators have their way, children here will be clueless about television shows on Wednesday nights for the next few weeks.

title: Don Imus's Finance Forum
description: It is alarming but true that the discussion of campaign finance last week on Don Imus's radio show was more honest and useful than President Clinton's comments on the same subject at his news conference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, BENJAMIN
description: ADLER-Benjamin, age 89, of Delray Beach, FL, passed away on Jan. 31, 1997. He is surived by sons Joseph and Robert, and grandchildren Michele, Felicia and Noah Adler, of Miami, FL; and wife, Rebecca, her daughter, Ann, and children, Stacy and Susan. Graveside services will be held next week at Mt. Nebo Cemetery, NY.

title: Judy Adams and Ralph Archangel
description: BEFORE it fills up with brides and bridegrooms, the Marriage Chapel at City Hall seems about as romantic as the passport office.

description: After 45 years, the country's oldest Acme supermarket, a Lambertville landmark, closed its doors and pulled out of town.

title: Saturn V Displayed At Kennedy Center
description: The Apollo-Saturn V Center, featuring an actual 363-foot Saturn V rocket, the most powerful rocket ever built, producing more than 7.5 million pounds of thrust upon blastoff, opened Dec. 17 at the Kennedy Space Center near Cape Canaveral, Fla.

description: When John and Marsha Drury moved here 20 years ago, they asked around about recreational opportunities for their sons Ted, 6, and Jimmy, 4. There is the rink, they were told, the nearby Wonderland of Ice. ''We were just lucky,'' John said.

title: Timely Trimming for Brilliant Blooms
description: THERE probably is an extra calendar sitting around somewhere. Gardeners can put it to good use for a specific reason: to record the days when particular things happen outdoors. In a year's time, these records will be useful as a guide to when certain chores should be done.

title: For '96, a Slow, Steady Commercial Market Upturn
description: THE state's commercial market ran a relatively smooth course of slow but steady improvement last year.

title: Still No Progress
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Touring the Tip Of Baja California, On Paved Road And Dirt
description: THE bell ringer at the Todos Santos church, on a hilltop overlooking the Pacific Ocean at the south end of Mexico's Baja Peninsula, is an old cowboy who chain-smokes on a bench between services. When I pulled into town one Saturday evening in mid-December (behind the wheel of my rather gaseous-smelling rented VW bug), he was getting ready to sound the call to Mass. The sun was setting in a pink wave on the horizon, and soon the little town filled with song emanating from the custard-yellow church. There could be no better welcome to Todos Santos or sweeter reward for making the long, hard, occasionally unnerving trip 1,000 miles south from the Mexican border at Tijuana to the tip of the Baja Peninsula.

title: Union Square: Discreet to Loud
description: ANGELO AND MAXIE'S STEAKHOUSE * $(rating: one star$)

title: Topics of The Times
description: An Undeserved Star

title: Is It Going to Be a Smaller World, After All?
description: ENGINEERS for the Xerox Corporation last week unveiled their plans for what their micro-electromechanical systems will be able to create -- self-guiding airplane wings with sensors no thicker than peach fuzz and a paint that repaints itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JOHN F.
description: McIntyre-John F. Age 57, Vice President, Secretary, and General Counsel of Alcon Laboratories Inc., died Thursday, January 30, 1997, in Arlington, TX. John McIntyre was born September 8, 1939, in Detroit, MI. He graduated from Gilmore Academy and received his bachelor of arts degree from Dartmouth College. He was a first lieutenant, US Army Intelligence and retired a captain before attending University of Michigan Law School. He later completed the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program. He was employed as an attorney for McClintock, Donovan & Waterman, and for United Airlines. He then became an international attorney at the Upjohn Company. He was awarded the W.E. Upjohn Prize for Outstanding Accomplishments and served as Chairman of the International Legal Committee, Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. He joined Alcon Laboratories, Inc., in 1983, as Vice President, Secretary and General Counsel with managment responsiblitiy for Corporate, International, Trademark, and Patent Law. He will be greatly missed.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: VICTORY AT ANY COST

title: Caseworkers Aren't Sabotaging Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Overpay For a Muni Fund
description: If you had $100 to invest, and could buy a diversified portfolio of municipal bonds worth $93, or one worth $112, which would you choose?

title: State of the Speech: Reading Between the Lines
description: REMEMBER how Bill Clinton electrified a joint session of Congress in 1993 by brandishing a prototype of a national health care card and calling for ''health care that can never be taken away, health care that is always there''?

title: Fishermen Worry: How Many Will Get Away This Year?
description: There may be plenty of fish in the sea, but some New Jersey fishermen object to the way species are counted, which is used to determine the number that may legally be caught. Recreational fishermen recently expressed concern about the number of striped bass that may be caught in some areas along the Eastern Seaboard, and commercial fishermen question the quotas likely to be set for fluke fishing this summer.

title: Moving Pictures
description: In CAPTURING THE MOMENT: The Sports Photography of Barton Silverman (Penguin Studio, $34.95), Barton Silverman takes the reader on a tour through the last 30 years of professional and nonprofessional athletic competition. The moments Mr. Silverman, a sports photographer at The New York Times since 1964, has captured run the gamut from the ridiculous (Tonya Harding tearfully showing the judges a broken lace on her ice skate during the Lillehammer Olympics) to the sublime (Cal Ripken Jr. enthusiastically greeting fans after breaking Lou Gehrig's streak of consecutive baseball games played). Mr. Silverman captures the artistry as well as the athleticism of sport. His shot of the Chinese diver Sun Shuwei performing a dive during the Barcelona Olympics looks surreal, depicting him suspended in midair above the city with the Church of the Sagrada Familia looming ominously in the background. No photograph better shows Mr. Silverman's ability to depict the meaning of an event than his famous shot of Muhammad Ali sitting dazed in the boxing ring, unable to come out of his corner for the 11th round against Larry Holmes in the world heavyweight title match in Las Vegas on Oct. 2, 1980. The haunted look in the eyes of the former champion is a study in dejection and brings home to the reader that even the mightiest figures in sports are all too mortal. Carolyn T. Hughes

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETTY, SCOTT W.
description: PETTY-Scott W. January 26, 1997. Mark, Dad, Marjan, Brent, Mom, Chuck, Sara, Eric, Oma, John, Jim, Elzie, Chris, Clifford. We love you very much.

title: On Ice
description: Peter LaSalle's HOCKEY SUR GLACE: Stories (Breakaway/Lyons & Burford, $20) brims with affection for hockey -- more accurately, for skating and winter. It's full of fond memories of searching for good ice as you tramp through the woods with your friends after school, of taking a breakaway and tucking the puck into a homemade goal on a frozen lake while young women watch, of skating defense while your wife watches. As the main character in ''Hockey'' observes, ''He had never liked anything in the world, loved anything, as much as to hear his blades cutting over the ice, to be skating.'' This is the small-''h'' hockey of mill towns and pickup games on pond ice, played by past-their-prime skaters with their old jerseys and old gloves and boys' hearts for the game. Stories like ''Hockey Angels,'' ''Wellesley College for Women, 1969'' and ''Van Arsdale's Pond'' all take weight from a powerful retrospect, from lost times that were both troubled and blessed, rife with the smell of winter air or the refrigeration of old rinks. ''The Injury'' is an 11-page sentence about the moment a young professional hockey player's life is changed forever, and ''Additional Consideration'' starts out as a mock-academic examination of the ''sleep shot,'' then twists deeper to become a love letter to the narrator's dying father. For good measure, Mr. LaSalle includes four poems (among them ''Goalies Are Weird'') and closes his book with ''Two Great Quotes.'' But the seven stories are plenty to convince us of his regard for, and personal acquaintance with, a life on the ice. Ron Carlson

title: Cindy Frumkes And John Campoli
description: Cindy Joy Frumkes, a corporate-bond broker, was married yesterday to John Peri Campoli, a lawyer. The Rev. Cynthia Heller, an interfaith clergywoman, officiated at the Equitable Tower in New York.

title: Maturity Diminishes Drug Use, a Study Finds
description: Young adults who used illegal drugs or alcohol as teen-agers tend to cut down or quit when confronted by the responsibilities of marriage and family. But divorce can drive them back to their old habits, according to a new study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN
description: PERLMAN-Julian. The Directors of the Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Julian Perlman. A man of deep integrity, high intelligence, and generosity of spirit, he was dedicated to the culture of our time, the city of New York, and the future of Israel. Julian was fair, compassionate, wise, idealistic. Always considerate and caring, he enriched our lives with warmth, humor, and most of all, loyalty. We are deeply grateful for having known and worked with him. Richard A. Rifkin, Laurie Friedland, Arthur Levitt, Jr. Dir. Emeritus

title: 2 Sought Help From Hospital Before a Death
description: Hours before an elderly woman was found poisoned to death by carbon monoxide fumes in her Upper East Side apartment on Thursday, paramedics responded to a 911 call reporting that a child was having difficulty breathing in the same building, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Philip Chasin, 87, Professional Fund-Raiser
description: Philip Chasin, a professional fund raiser for Jewish causes and Israel, died on Monday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: District 26 to Defer Gifted Program to Give More a Chance
description: Should an intelligence test given to 4-year-olds be the sole criterion for getting into -- and staying in, through sixth grade -- a school's coveted gifted program?

title: It's an Era of Limits; Bolt Upright in the Car, Please
description: FOR baby boomers and their parents, the American love affair with cars was at least in part about love affairs in cars. Whether driving hip to hip down the highway or making out in the back seat, millions of Americans went looking for love in Fords and Chevys.

title: The Customs of the Country
description: LE DIVORCE By Diane Johnson. 309 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/Dutton. $23.95.

title: Jill Rosenberg and Edward Nord
description: Jill Stecher Rosenberg and Dr. Edward Philip Nord are to be married today in Jericho, L.I. Rabbi Paul Kaplan is to perform the ceremony at Temple Or-Eloheim.

title: Q and A
description: Cooking in Vienna

title: Grant to Bring Commuters Information by Phone
description: By year's end, commuters should be able to call an 800 number for information about traffic delays and road conditions anywhere along their routes to work, even out of state, transportation officials announced last week.

title: Paul Reiser's Balancing Act
description: AT 39, the comedian and actor Paul Reiser has achieved a level of success in the television industry attained by very few. As the co-star, co-creator and one of the executive producers of the NBC sitcom ''Mad About You,'' he has seen his series become one of the most popular and critically praised prime-time series of the 1990's.

title: Virtual Tales From the Cybercouch
description: Adam could be a great jazz trumpeter; instead, he's a drugged-out backup player for pickup gigs at The Knitting Factory. Celeste, a divorced baby boomer, dates via personal ads and fantasizes about getting a Guggenheim grant to finish her novel. Mike is on parole, having assaulted someone on a subway platform.

title: Bookshelf
description: BONJOUR, LONNIE. Written and illustrated by Faith Ringgold. Hyperion. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9) In a dream the Love Bird takes Lonnie to Paris, and the ambitious story addresses the 20th-century experiences of African-Americans in France. There is a helpful bibliography for young readers who want to learn more about the artists and writers, the 369th Infantry Division or Josephine Baker.

title: Saving Natural Sites
description: The United Nations has added five natural sites to its list of places of ''outstanding universal value'' that should be preserved. The sites are the Belize Barrier Reef Reserve System, the Volcanoes of Kamchatka and Lake Baikal, both in the Russian Federation, the W National Park in Niger and the Okapi Faunal Reserve in Zaire.

title: Felicia Kaplan, Andrew Waldman
description: Felicia Stacey Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour A. Kaplan of Danbury, Conn., was married last evening to Andrew Lawrence Waldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Waldman of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Phillip Aronson performed the ceremony at the Jupiter Beach Resort in Jupiter, Fla.

title: Van Gundy Feels Johnson Is Better Than Stats Show
description: The trade of Anthony Mason for Larry Johnson appears to be a statistical bust for the Knicks. Mason is shining, Johnson is struggling and Mason's Charlotte Hornets have won two of their three meetings with New York.

title: The Journey to the Derby Starts Today on Two Coasts
description: They stood a continent apart today and they were embarking on different routes, but they were aiming for precisely the same place: the starting gate at Churchill Downs for the Kentucky Derby in three months.

title: Losing Pounds and Raising Self-Esteem
description: IN 1971, a new psychologist at a hospital in Durham, N.C., wondered why the other psychologists ignored certain patients. ''They're those fat people from New York,'' a staff worker confided. Well, the young doctor, thought: I'm fat. I'm from New York. And I'm going to treat those people.

title: Mischief Afoot: Murder With an M.B.A.
description: IT'S the season for contemplating the mysteries of business. Not because you're wondering why those Super Bowl advertisers paid $1.2 million for 30 seconds of access to viewers wearing foam-rubber cheese wedges on their heads. But because it's winter, and these dark-by-the-time-you-leave-the-office evenings are just right for cozying up to a mystery novel. Pick one with finance in the plot and you might not even feel guilty.

title: A Hard Life to the Hardwoods: An Ex-Inmate Tries to Justify His Reprieve
description: File all of Dan Buie's baskets under second-chance points. The 25-year-old Buie is a 6-foot-8-inch forward for Washburn, a Division II university in Topeka, Kan. When he graduated from high school in 1991, he had been recruited by Kentucky, Duke and Cincinnati. But the wiry scorer who seemed to have the world at his fingertips was also having them repeatedly dipped into the precinct house ink pad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTZEL, MURRAY N.
description: WORTZEL-Murray N. Passed away Jan. 30, 1997 after a heart attack. Cherished brother of Bertha Belmar and Esther Friedfeld. He was a professor of Library Science at Lehman College and founder of Leonard Eisner Memorial Foundation. He devoted his time and efforts to the Special Libraries Association and Kurt Weill Foundation. Services today, 10 AM, ''Kirschenbaum's'', 1153 Coney Island Ave., Bklyn. Donations may be made to the Leonard Eisner Memorial Foundation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Herb Caen, 80, San Francisco Voice, Dies
description: Herb Caen, whose 60-year journalism career was devoted to doting on San Francisco and whose affections were more than amply requited by legions of ardent readers, died this morning at the California Pacific Medical Center here. Mr. Caen, who was 80, told readers in May that he had inoperable lung cancer.

title: Unlimited? Not Quite.
description: Cyberspace, it turns out, is a lot like the restaurant business. Offer all-you-can-eat pricing, and many people will indeed consume more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDDER, ESTHER KOBLENZ
description: RUDDER-Esther Koblenz, age 92, of Aventura, FL, passed away January 30, 1997. Cherished and adored mother of Gail Rudder Kent, of South Orange, NJ, and Neal Rudder of Hollywood, FL. Beloved sister of Ethel Lau, Rose Koblenz Goldberg and Herbert Koblenz. Beloved grandmother of Debra, Ives, David, Stacey, Erin, and Penelope and great grandmother of Jessica and Spencer. Former New York City school teacher for more than 40 years. Hospital volunteer in Florida during her retirement. A truly extraordinary woman of elegance and grace who will be missed forever. Donations may be made to the American Humane Society. Interment to take place at King Solomon in Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIRTI, ROSE ANN (NEE RUSSO)
description: MIRTI-Rose Ann (nee Russo) on January 30, 1997 of New Canaan, CT. Beloved wife of Anthony E. Mirti. Devoted children Carol Runge Mirti of Manassas, VA. Anthony Mirti of Marlborough, MA and Mark Mirti of Westport, CT. Adored by daughter-in-laws Frances and Debbie Mirti. Grandmother of Catherine Runge. Loving sister of Mrs. Barron (Velia) Castellano. Aunt of Elaine Grillo. Sister-inlaw of Mary Dent and Gilda O'Brien. Also survived by loving nieces, nephews, and cousins. Rose Ann lit up all of our lives. Funeral Monday 9:30 AM from the Megaro Memorial Home, 503 Union Ave, Belleville, NJ. Funeral Mass Church of St. Francis Xavier, Newark, NJ, 10:30 AM. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. Visitation Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Mystery of 104 Bronze Statues of Mercury
description: WHAT happened to the bronze statues of Mercury that used to adorn the tops of the traffic lights on Fifth Avenue?'' writes John Morrin, an art collector who has lived in midtown since the 1950's. ''Those bronzes were worth a lot of money.''

title: Dueling Decibels
description: I HAD just come home from a South American tour of my one-piano show ''Carreno,'' and I was looking forward to a few days of R. and R.

title: The Nominee Chosen, the Charges Still Fly
description: Two weeks ago, 330 Brooklyn Democrats named Joan L. Millman, a retired teacher, to be their candidate in a special election to complete the term of the late Assemblywoman Eileen C. Dugan. Last week, the political fallout came.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Remembering
description: To the Editor: ''The Village That Hasn't Forgotten'' brought back poignant memories of my visit there in 1984, the 40th anniversary of the Normandy invasion and the awful events in that village.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: LOVE casts its magic spell in the movies this week over London, during World War II, a British hospital in Burma, a small Pacific isle, and in a Paris office building.

title: The Basics of Building a Birdhouse
description: BUILDING a birdhouse may seem like a frivolous project to the serious homeowner. There are, however, a number of reasons to make the project. It's a good way for a beginning woodworker to practice using tools and learn the fundamentals of shaping wood. A simple birdhouse is also a good beginning project to introduce a youngster to the pleasures of woodworking. Also the completed project will serve as a nesting place for wild birds and can perhaps kindle an interest in ornithology.

title: Forging Bonds Between Nature and Culture
description: OUTSIDE his work as a composer, Jerod Sheffer Tate doesn't use his Chickasaw name, Taloa Ikbi. The braid down his back is blondish, in fact, and his eyes -- from his mother, whose family came from the Isle of Man -- are blue. But he is committed to his father's American Indian linage, and to creating for it a new musical stream unsullied by Hollywood and tourist stereotypes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSELGOFF, LEA M.
description: KISSELGOFF-Lea M. On January 31, 1997. Beloved mother of Anna, cherished wife of the late Avram. A Sinologist, she was an admiring disciple of Professor Marcel Granet in Paris and of Professor L. Carrington Goodrich at Columbia University.

title: By Sternwheeler Along the Columbia
description: LAUNCHED in 1995, the Queen of the West is a sternwheeler in the tradition of those that plied the Columbia River from 1855 to 1917. In those days, three sets of boats worked three distinct sections of the river, separated by impassable falls around which passengers and freight had to be portaged. Used for freight and, later, for passengers, these shallow-draft boats were eventually made obsolete by the railways and the highway system. Today, a series of locks and dams has eliminated the obstacles, transforming the mighty Columbia into a series of placid, very large pools.

title: Flood Damage Closes Much of Yosemite Valley
description: The storms that hit California in January washed out much of Yosemite National Park's winter season. Flood damage has forced the park to close access to most of its peaks, waterfalls and forests at least until March, and some areas will be off-limits even longer.

title: Inventing a Charter School
description: The state recently approved 17 charter schools. If you could set up a school, what would it be like?

title: The New Wilhelmina Wears a T-Shirt
description: ASK anyone who runs a New York modeling agency what generates buzz, and the answer is definitive: female superstars. Ask whether an agency can survive without them, and the answer will not be so definitive.

title: DIARY
description: SOCIAL SECURITY

title: Remembering
description: To the Editor: Gillian Tindall wrote a truly moving article. When my husband was stationed in France in 1962, we visited there several times. This was only 18 years after the atrocity and memories still burned strongly. The village was much less tidy then than it is today. In one badly charred car in the town square, fresh flowers were placed on the steering wheel regularly. Perhaps it was some family member or friend.

title: Queuing Up
description: ''AMID THE QUOTIDIAN TRIALS OF suburban life,'' wrote Newsweek in appreciation of Erma Bombeck, ''she found a way to make us laugh.''

title: Traders Want Some Space, Too
description: THE battle for Wall Street's desktops has always been fierce. Now the jostling among the major competitors has become so intense that it is hard to tell who's winning. The short answer: no one.

title: The Hermitage Exhibits More 'Hidden' Art
description: The State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, has recently opened its second exhibition of ''hidden'' art, treasures taken by Soviet troops from Germany at the end of World War II. In 1995, the museum mounted a show of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings from German collections that broke attendance records. The new exhibition, ''Master Drawings Rediscovered: Treasures from Prewar German Collections,'' opened in December and will run at least through the end of March. The exhibit includes 89 works by such artists as Goya, Daumier, Delacroix, Cezanne and Van Gogh.

title: Governors Split Over Need for Changes to New Welfare Law
description: Governors said today that they were deeply divided over whether to seek substantial changes in the new Federal welfare law, passed just six months ago at the urging of governors from both parties.

title: Another Dimension
description: DEFINING VISION The Battle for the Future of Television. By Joel Brinkley. Illustrated. 402 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $27.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Mollie Panter-Downes, 90, New Yorker Correspondent
description: Mollie Panter-Downes, whose quiet, compelling accounts of everyday British life brought England alive for two generations of readers of The New Yorker, died on Jan. 22 in a nursing home near her longtime home in Surrey. She was 90 and had written The New Yorker's ''Letter from London'' from 1939 to 1984.

title: Defenders of a Kingdom Long Swept Aside
description: WHEN THE PHOTOGRAPHER Peter Beard was trampled, almost fatally, by an elephant while on safari in Kenya last September, Africa might have been delivering payback for the intrusion of countless camera safaris to the world's wildlife mecca. Mr. Beard's 1965 photo essay, ''The End of the Game,'' is one reason so many amateurs and professionals roam the veldt with everything from point-and-shoots to 4-by-5's, often carrying Rover-loads of lenses as big as cannon barrels.

title: Q. & A.
description: Retirees Getting Mortgages

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRAY, LILLA
description: GRAY-Lilla. Feb. 1, 1897-Aug. 13, 1972. On the centennial of her birth, the children and grandchildren of Lilla Schwartz Gray remember her with love & respect.

title: Landmark Churches Before High Court
description: Are religious institutions -- whose buildings are often among the most beautiful and historic in a community -- bound by the same land-use rules as others?

title: Making a Stand Against Sterility
description: ''WHY DID THEY DO IT?'' Czeslaw Milosz wants to know. ''What were they thinking?''

title: Correction
