description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Jan. 12 about plans for an exhibit of Keith Haring sculptures on the Park Avenue mall misstated recent history of sculpture exhibits there. The most recent was not the plump nudes, by Fernando Botero, in 1993; bronze rabbits, by Barry Flanagan, appeared from September 1995 through March 1996.

title: Peter Soros and Flora Fraser
description: Flora Fraser, a writer and historian, and Peter R. Soros, an investment banker, were married on Wednesday at the Chelsea Registry Office in London.

title: Where Seafood Overshadows the Steak
description: SOME names say it all. Cattleman's Harbor does. This Freeport newcomer, with its logo of a steer at the wheel of a ship, tries to please everyone. There are steakhouse headliners for red meat lovers; lobsters, fish and oysters on the half shell for seafood aficionados plus a lineup of interesting specialties like grilled chicken with flying shrimp and potato-crusted scallops with Jack Daniels cream sauce for the adventurous.

title: Indian Tradition and a Need for Recognition
description: CHIEF BIG EAGLE, also known as Aurelius H. Piper Sr., is chief of the Golden Hill Paugussett and the leader of the White Buffalo Society, an organization with members from Maine to Florida dedicated to helping people through traditional American Indian spiritualism and educating people in the ways and traditions of the American Indian.

title: Deflating an Inflation Worry
description: IN testimony before Congress two weeks ago, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed his worries about the danger of wage inflation. Specifically, Mr. Greenspan is concerned that shortages of qualified people for job openings may lead to excessive wage offers to fill those jobs. Some people take this uneasiness to suggest that a rise in interest rates may be in the offing -- if not at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting starting on Tuesday, then sometime later this year.

title: Atheists Don't 'Despise' Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmers Cultivating Suburban Neighbors
description: As the suburban frontier seeps across the countryside, officials here in Howard County are trying to convince farmers that their new neighbors are an untapped market rather than the ushers of doom.

title: HOW FOOTBALL GOT SACKED
description: I had to chuckle when I read Barra's article. There may be empty seats at the Meadowlands, but that is certainly not a problem at Green Bay's Lambeau Field. Three days after giving birth to my son last March, I requested Packers season tickets for him. He is No. 23,272 on the waiting list! He'll be lucky to get his tickets by the time he's 30, in the year 2026.

title: Duncan, Deacons Get Their Revenge
description: Fifth-ranked Maryland had defeated Wake Forest on its homecourt less than two weeks ago, the only loss this season for the Demon Deacons. And for one half today, before 14,500 delighted fans at Cole Field House, it appeared that the Terrapins and their trapping defense would again prove more than second-ranked Wake Forest could handle.

title: Providing Help To Battered Women
description: Any one of a number of 40's, fabulous and female heroines who strive against all odds to keep their families intact could be portrayed by Kathleen Turner $(''Real Life Role Helping Battered Woman,'' Jan. 12$) if a screenwriter who is looking for a project adapted the stories of bettered women for the screen. Until a screenwriter comes along, Ms. Turner might consider the role of the mother in Roddy Doyle's brilliant book, ''The Woman Who Walked Into Doors.'' If the public experienced these women as heroines, not victims, the focus of domestic violence would be turned to the causes, and their context, and away from the women as victims.

title: Inn's Ghost Liked Smoke, but Fire?
description: It was the quick glimpse of a top hat and a waistcoat reflected in a mirror that finally turned Maria Ennes into a believer. ''I knew I had always felt a presence in the inn,'' she recalled last week, ''but actually seeing an image of him let me know all the years of hearsay were for a reason.''

title: Repair Work On Bridge Spans Years
description: Like most Bedford Park residents, Patricia L. Newland instinctively avoids the bridge over the subway tracks when she drives to the corner car wash or the Lehman College library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGG, HILDA M.
description: BRAGG-Hilda M., 94, of Greenwich, CT, on January 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edward H. Bragg. Devoted mother of Edward, Jr., and mother-in-law of Margaret. Dear grandmother of Philip, James and Winston Bragg. Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 4th at 12:30PM at Christ Episcopal Church Chapel, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Greenwich Hospital Endowment Fund would be appreciated. For information, the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: Lone Rangers Of Charity Are Losing Their Masks
description: WHEN R. Champlin Sheridan decided to make a sizable gift to his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University, he wanted to do it quietly. His goal, he said, was to ''change other people's lives -- I didn't want it to change mine.''

title: Skiers Fly Directly To Colorado Slopes
description: EVERY afternoon this winter, as an American Airlines jet wings its way from Newark to Vail, a concierge walks the aisles, taking reservations for everything from dinners out to dogsled rides. By the time the Boeing 757 taxis up to a new Rocky Mountain lodge-style terminal, passengers have confirmed reservations in hand.

title: Ex-Addicts Find Methadone More Elusive Than Heroin
description: Every morning before dawn, Omere Luneau climbs into his sport utility vehicle and drives south for two hours to a private clinic in Lawrence, Mass., where he swallows a cherry-red liquid and, upon demand, produces a urine sample. Then he drives for another two hours back to New Hampshire to start the day's work as a builder and restorer of old houses.

title: Egypt Mustn't Waver
description: To the Editor:

title: Sallie Dinkel, Mark Giordano
description: Sallie Camp Fitch Dinkel, a daughter of Mrs. Ridgely Manning Foster of Palm Beach, Fla., and Edward John Dinkel 3d of Tampa, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark Victor Giordano, a son of John Carl Giordano Jr. of New York and the late Kay Meyer. The Rev. Steven E. Woolley performed the Episcopal ceremony yesterday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Dinkins, From Afar, Is Talk of Forum
description: A prominent group of black elected officials held a forum yesterday on the next mayoral race, but the potential candidate that almost everyone was talking about was thousands of miles away.

title: Mediterranean Style, Mediterranean Menu
description: SWEET TOMATO is the name of a restaurant that has taken over a sizable two-story building not far from the railroad station in Westport. The space is attractively configured, and there is ample parking. And now the low-ceilinged dining room suggests the Mediterranean, with white-plastered walls, red aprons over white tablecloths and banquettes around the sides. These touches of color provide a warmth that works well with the Italian-Mediteranean menu. (There is a Spanish cook as well as an Italian one in the kitchen, we were told.)

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Park Advocates Oppose Drop-Off Area
description: A deeply held dream for park-starved Chelsea residents has been to see an expanse of green space emerge from the blueprints for Hudson River Park, which is planned for a stretch of shoreline between Battery Park City and 59th Street. One of the biggest opportunities for this is in a relatively wide piece of land off the West Side Highway between 22d and 23d Streets that residents have nicknamed the ''great lawn.''

title: Elizabeth Painter, Paul Ricciardelli
description: Elizabeth Hunt Painter, the daughter of the Rev. Abigail Wootton Hamilton of West Orange, N.J., and Alan Sproul Painter of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Emmanuel Ricciardelli, a son of Rosemarie and Dr. Orlando Paul Ricciardelli of Maplewood, N.J. Jack M. McKelvey, Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J. The Rev. Richard Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Dolls, Darling, Dolls

title: WESTCHESTER WEEKLY DESK
description: PHOTO EXHIBITION

title: Duval's Got the Torch, But His Back Is Burning
description: David Duval knows he is a winner. On Sunday, with the shimmering Pacific Ocean as a backdrop for what could be the most satisfying walk of his 25 years, he will attempt to prove it.

title: No Sales Tax Spurs Discounts and Sprees
description: HERE on the border things can get rough the border of Connecticut, that is. Although Rye is not contiguous to the Nutmeg State, when it comes to business, its downtown merchants say they definitely experience border bleed out -- shoppers traveling a few extra miles into Greenwich or Stamford to get clothing under $500 and children's apparel tax free.

title: Picking Up the Mantle
description: To the Editor:

title: Affirmative Action Is KO'd in the Sports Section, Too
description: Affirmative Action, the heavyweight plan that was to conquer inequality in the workplace, now lies beaten on the canvas, thoroughly thrashed and humiliated. It has the jelly legs of a tomato can that had the temerity to climb into the ring with an underrated but determined champion, and is now bleeding uncontrollably from both eyes.

title: Reviewer's Block
description: To the Editor:

title: Family-Centered First Home of the U.N.
description: THERE could be few more suitable places to study the evolution of the Long Island ranch house than Lake Success, an expensive, family-centered village in western Nassau County where the expanded ranch is something of an art form.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot

title: Do Checks Need 3 Days To Clear?
description: SINCE 1990, Federal law has required banks to clear local checks within two business days, giving consumers quicker access to their money. Before the 1987 law that phased in this change, the waiting period was a week or more.

title: Very Preventive Medicine
description: The dangers of being an abortion doctor are well known, but according to a 1993 report by the American College of Surgeons' Task Force on Clinical Safety, cosmetic surgeons face plenty of risks themselves. Since 1993, for example, three have been killed by men who didn't like their nose jobs.

title: Remembering
description: To the Editor: While traveling in Europe last summer our family decided to take a side trip to Oradour-sur-Glane, not knowing what we would find.

title: Black-and-White Photographs of Americans by Americans
description: All Americans

title: An Experience With Frustration
description: ''Encounters'' $(''Decades After Silence, a Voice Is Recognized,'' by Erika Duncan, Jan. 19$) tells so movingly the story of Julia Tavalaro, a stroke victim, and her release from the imprisonment she suffered at the expense of her own body and its inability to communicate. How terrible the frustrations Ms. Tavalaro must have experienced as her world evolved beyond her control. The loss of control of one's body is a tragedy difficult to conceive, but to have one's mind entrapped within that body is beyond conception.

title: Watch Out, New York City. Here Come the Girls of Yardley, Pa.
description: Walking dogs and reading books are popular pastimes in the Watch Out Neighborhood -- Here We Come Club of Yardley, Pa., but recently the organization expanded its agenda when its four members mailed a $50 contribution to the 85th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Restaurant Is Second In a Chain of Two

title: The Matatu Conjecture
description: THE OUT-OF-TOWNERS PRESENTED THE challenge shortly before Christmas: Could I possibly get them tickets to ''Chicago'' for an upcoming Friday night? I wasn't optimistic. The musical had just opened to phenomenal reviews, selling $1 million in tickets the first weekend. Broadway insiders accustomed to snagging house seats were complaining they couldn't get tickets before spring. Ticket brokers were being shut out; the first several I called wouldn't even bother looking for tickets. Eventually I found a broker who was offering $70 orchestra seats -- for $175. I was about to call the out-of-towners and confess that I had no better Broadway connections than they did.

title: Pros of College
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HOW FOOTBALL GOT SACKED
description: In seeking reasons for the failure of professional football to maintain its dominance as a vital cultural form, perhaps we need to look more closely at the international geopolitical situation.

title: Love Potion No. 9, in the Water Cooler
description: Love, your magic spell is everywhere, but it seems to be particularly potent in the office. There, the smitten suffer agonies of longing, overcome shyness, undertake impetuous acts and sometimes, just as in the happiest of tales, overcome all obstacles and find enduring romance.

title: An Artist in Many Dimensions
description: IN THE HEART OF West Hollywood, nestled among the gay bars and tiny, Russian grocery stores, stands an outwardly unassuming edifice that might best be described as David Hockney Inc. Mr. Hockney, the puckish English-born artist who has made Southern California his year-round home since 1978, breezily refers to the building as ''just a storage space.'' Don't be fooled; that's British understatement.

title: Waiting to Explode
description: To the Editor:

title: Even If You Build It (Big 'If'), Will They Come?
description: THE FUTURE OF HOME entertainment is manifestly digital. That much understood, a slumping and impatient consumer electronics industry wants to proclaim the future now, the golden age of digital technology dawned. But if it has dawned, the sky is barely red with intimation of the high noon to come; and as much as the clamorous industry might wish otherwise, that period of maturation cannot be forced.

title: From Selling Toys to 'Edu-tainment'
description: IT'S hard to imagine that the head of a retail distribution company that once owned several toy store chains could have trouble finding toys for his own children. Well, Stanley Greenman did. While searching for toys that were both exciting and educational, he found most of the stores he appproached carried an overwhelming supply of video games, action toys and figures, and relatively few had products designed to expand a child's horizons and stimulate his imagination.

title: At Issue: Spending Per Pupil
description: WHEN the State Education Department released its school-by- school report cards last month, parents pored over the statistics to evaluate their district's performance. In Westchester, not only did the range of reading performances gain notice, but also the disparity in spending for each student.

title: Fire Island Losing Battle to Save Plovers
description: WITH all its precautions over the last 10 years to protect the piping plover from extinction, the Fire Island National Seashore has found that the bird is not faring well on Fire Island.

title: South Africa
description: To the Editor: The Bushmen in South Africa were probably not driven out by the Xhosas, as Donald G. McNeil Jr. asserts (''South Africa Begins to Memorialize Its Past,'' Dec. 15). In fact, the adoption of clicking sounds into Xhosa speech suggests a high level of interaction between the cultures.

title: Whitman Budget May Spell Diesel Buses' Retirement
description: Making good on a promise to environmentalists, Governor Whitman this week pledged to put about $35 million of her $16.4 billion budget toward moving the state's aging diesel bus fleet toward more environmentally sound fuels. Under the proposal, New Jersey Transit would spend $26 million to buy 50 new buses that burn compressed natural gas while phasing out an equal number of diesel-burning ones.

title: A Neighborhood Lives Again
description: THE decaying colonial houses, illuminated against a backdrop of night sky, called to mind the set for an opera. I was wandering after dark with my husband and two friends visiting from the United States about a year ago through the unrenovated section of the Pelourinho neighborhood, in the city of Salvador de Baia de Todos os Santos (Saviour of the Bay of All Saints), the unofficial capital of Afro-Brazil.

title: An Extra Mortgage Cost May Last Far Too Long
description: IT would be foolish to pay for insurance on a car you no longer own, right? Well, many homeowners are doing something akin to that, without knowing it, by paying for mortgage insurance they no longer need.

title: A Danbury Landfill Plagues Its Neighbors
description: FOR the last five months many Danbury area residents have waked up praying the wind blows the other way -- and holding their noses if it doesn't.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KUPERMAN, JOSHUA
description: KUPERMAN-Joshua. October 17, 1953-February 2, 1993. Our role model of courage. Lovingly remembered. Mother, Dad and Jay

title: Optimism Drives New-Home and Resale Markets
description: WHEN Joseph D. Simon, a Garden City lawyer, and his wife, Dana, signed a contract on Dec. 26 to buy a new house in the Villages at Huntington, a Melville development, they did so without making the $340,000 purchase contingent on finding a buyer for their three-bedroom town house in Wantagh.

title: Scenes Little Noticed but Long Remembered
description: ESPECIALLY in cold weather, New Yorkers do not take the time to look at the world around them, focusing on where they are coming from or where they are going. The Museum of the City of New York is displaying little-noticed moments from the last 100 years in an exhibition that opens Wednesday titled ''The Streets and Beyond: New York Photographs.''

title: First, Park Place . . .
description: THE man who could be the next king of Atlantic City's Boardwalk says he gets his best business ideas while running.

title: Retrospective Reflects Artist's Eye to Nature
description: LARGE though it is, the gallery at Rockland Center for the Arts here can barely contain its present attraction, a show by Hugh Mesibov, which covers 60 years and numbers almost 100 works. The congestion is spiritual as well as physical and small wonder, given the political, economic and esthetic turbulence of the period.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Wind Breaker

title: Hip-Hop's New Find: Old Soul
description: A DECADE AGO, a gum-snapping teen-age clerk in a record store ridiculed a customer in his 20's for buying a vintage Marvin Gaye album. ''That's for old folks,'' she snorted. In many ways, her dismissal perfectly anticipated the divide that was to come in black pop with young fans gravitating to hip-hop and older listeners clinging to melodic rhythm-and-blues.

title: John E. Tobin, 73, a Corporate Lawyer
description: John E. Tobin, a retired corporate lawyer and founding partner in the New York office of Dorsey & Whitney of Minneapolis, died on Jan. 19 at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 73 and lived in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: BENEFITS
description: For Pets, at the Plaza

title: Sex, Drugs and Slivovitz
description: Blue Mondays

title: Mammograms and Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: More on a Fresco
description: To the Editor: Another note on ''A Fresco Saved,'' the letter of Robert B. Wolcott Jr. on Nov. 24, in which he described the actions of the British that saved the ''Resurrection'' fresco from bombardment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DOROTHY C.
description: WEINSTEIN-Dorothy C. We mourn the loss of Dorothy Weinstein, beloved mother of Barbara Perless, Florence Weinstein and Dr. Lionel A. Winston; grandmother of Jaime, Gary, and David Perless & Jonathan Winston and great grandmother of Leo. Services Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Sunday, February 2 at 11:30 A.M.

title: The Hoyas Extinguish St. John's Fire
description: With Patrick Ewing working their corner, and Victor Page providing the heartbreaking knockout blow in the closing seconds, the Georgetown Hoyas sent St. John's sprawling to the bottom of the Big East deck yesterday, defeating the Red Storm, 71-68.

title: A Master Organist's Music to Dunk By
description: In a recent basketball game in their cramped gym on Flatbush Avenue, the Long Island University Blackbirds were trailing the Monmouth College Hawks by 6 points with five minutes left to play. Ray Haskins, the L.I.U. coach, shook his head, called a timeout and tried to motivate his shaken squad. The crowd, numbed by a late scoring spurt by the Hawks, seemed impervious to the rallying cries of a school band and a deejay spinning hip-hop records.

title: HE'S NOT HEAVY, HE'S MY BABY
description: I related well to Suzanne Matson's Lives column ''He's Not Heavy, He's My Baby'' (Jan. 12). When I was first married, and 25 years old, my wife and I packed up our clothes, in two suitcases, and went to Europe, North Africa and Israel. We lived there for nine months, bought a car and came back poor materially, but wealthy culturally.

title: Actor Finds That His Roles Walk on the Darker Side of Life
description: AS an actor, Mitchell Lichtenstein has many psychos to his credit. In ''Ratchet,'' written and directed by John Johnson, which had its United States premiere at the Hampton International Film Festival in October, Mr. Lichtenstein plays a psychotic screenwriter, fresh out of a nervous breakdown, who takes revenge on a fellow writer after he sleeps with his girlfriend.

title: BLACK HISTORY MONTH
description: February is Black History Month. Here is a sampling of events and activities scheduled in New Jersey.

title: Retro and Retractable
description: AUTOMOTIVELY speaking, I was born a generation too late.

title: Michael Braun, Producer, 60
description: Michael Braun, one of the producers of the musical ''Titanic,'' scheduled to open at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater in April, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: Asian American Group Took Advocacy to the Next Level
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESCHHOFF, VIRGINIA GRAVES
description: WIESCHHOFF-Virginia Graves. Age 91, on January 30, Newton, MA. Longtime resident of Bronxville, NY. Guidance counselor at Rye High School, Director Herald Tribune World Youth Forum. Wife of the late Heinrich, former Director of Political and Security Council Affairs of the United Nations. Mother of Eugenia Pitts, Virginia Miller and Hynrich Wieschhoff.

title: A Low-Key Fund Group Nears a Limelight Level
description: COMING off one of its best years ever, the mutual fund industry is approaching yet another milestone, this one in a nook of the business that has attracted far less attention than stock funds and their persistent waves of cash.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: YESTERDAY'S TRAIN

title: A.A.R.P. Is Adding Some Spice To Its Menu
description: THERE'S conservative -- and then there's conservative.

title: Jurassic Baubles
description: Attention, slightly creepy celebrity buffs. This month, Star Gene Inc., a company based in San Rafael, Calif., is rolling out the first item in a new line of jewelry with a unique additive: DNA harvested from the rich, famous and larger-than-life. On the $195 Abraham Lincoln commemorative watch (pictured), the crucial stuff, replicated from a lock of hair removed the night Lincoln died, is housed inside a small, amber-like dot -- the ''genestone'' -- just below his craggy visage.

title: Reservations Most Definitely Required
description: If you weren't invited to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last week -- and unless you're at the pinnacle of business or politics, forget it -- you'd better not try to crash the party. (Andy Mettler for The New York Times)

title: Marilyn Mercer, Charles Bell
description: Marilyn Lawes Mercer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Mercer Jr. of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Robert Bell, a son of Mrs. Alfonso Palmon of Rome, N.Y., and the late Robert C. Bell. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River in Rumson.

title: Super Bowl of Science?
description: To the Editor:

title: Unmasking the Twin Problems of Race and Class in the Athletic Elite
description: Green Bay won the Super Bowl because a naturally endowed black runner made the difference in a battle of brainpower between two brilliant white coaches and their determined white quarterbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFMAN, JEROME
description: DORFMAN-Jerome. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Jerome Dorfman, on January 29, 1997. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Private services were held. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec. Dir.

title: An Election Year Budget, Not One for the Ages
description: Governor Whitman presented a $16.4 billion election year budget last week that brims with modest but politically important initiatives aimed at bolstering her standing with voters beyond her Republican strongholds.

title: Joseph Jablow, Anthropology Professor, 82
description: Joseph Jablow, professor emeritus of anthropology at Brooklyn College and chairman of the department from 1971 to his retirement in 1977, died on Jan. 20 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, ELI
description: BLOOM-Eli. Loving friend of Chan Jones. Adored father of Edward and Laura. Cherished grandfather of Molly and Max Bloom, and Miles Chandler. Dear brother of Jeanette Bronstein. He was a mentor to many and a friend to all. An icon in the automotive industry. Oh how we miss you, Dear Eli. Memorial service at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC, 7PM, Wed. 2/5/97.

title: Defending Your Lies
description: Is a university doing the right thing when it defends the free-speech rights of a professor who says the Holocaust was a hoax? Officials at Northwestern think so. For years, the campus has wrestled with the nettlesome presence of Arthur Butz, a tenured associate professor of engineering who is also a notorious Holocaust revisionist. Recently, Northwestern dropped Sheldon Epstein, an adjunct professor in the engineering department who criticized Butz in class. Epstein says he was silenced. School officials deny it, but admit that the episode highlights a deeply held commitment to, essentially, protecting Butz's right to be a crank. ''His ideas are odious,'' says Henry S. Bienen, Northwestern's president. ''But I don't want to say he can't have them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOSHPITZ, JOSEPH D.
description: NOSHPITZ-Joseph D. The International Society for Adolescent Psychiatry mourns the loss of one of its officers and most eloquent spokesman, Joseph D. Noshpitz, MD. With his brilliance, wit and profound wisdom, Joe never failed to enrich the life of anyone he touched. On behalf of our Executive Committee, I extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Revered by all who were priveleged to know him, he will be sorely missed. Michael G. Kalogerakis, MD President

title: Old and New Being Honored
description: In a mixture of current and nostalgic events, the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America will honor past and present members of the Yankees and the Mets at its annual dinner tonight in Manhattan.

title: Cochran Stays Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Home for the Elderly To Get 8-Story Glass Tower
description: An eight-story glass tower is to be a major component of a $33 million expansion and renovation at the Jewish Home and Hospital at West Kingsbridge Road and University Avenue in the West Bronx.

title: Modest Tunnel Turns Out High Yields
description: LITTLE was left of a recent snow; the landcape was mostly gray and brown. But the world was fresh and green inside Carol Hanby's tunnel house, where young plants poked up everywhere.

title: THE LAPTOP COLONIALISTS
description: Thank God someone with the wit and intelligence of Michael Paterniti can expose the charade that is the expatriate experience in the late 1990's.

title: Africa's Culture War: Old Customs, New Values
description: FOR 16 years, Mark Wisdom, a 54-year-old Baptist preacher and a native Ghanaian, has been waging a lonely campaign to end a form of slavery here as old as the culture of the Ewe peasants inhabiting the dusty villages of this poor corner of Ghana.

title: County's Reaction To the Report Cards
description: IN Mount Vernon last month, irate black leaders called for a better education for the city's schoolchildren, many of whom come from families living below the poverty level. In Scarsdale, there was a similar demand for improved schooling, only in that section of Westchester it came from a mostly white group of parents with above- average incomes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINS, EDWIN F. (TED)
description: ATKINS-Edwin F. (Ted), devoted husband of Elaine, loving father of Ned, Robert, Katherine and William and grandfather of nine, died January 31 at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL.

title: India's War on Polio Met With Superstition
description: To the Editor;

title: An Experience With Frustration
description: Although I do not know Julia Tavalaro personally, I am her daughter Judy's best friend since childhood and feel I must respond to the negative portrayal of Julia's husband George in the article. Ms. Duncan says ''laughingly Julia and Richard tell me how when they were trying to find ways to make her feel more powerful they came upon the idea of suing for a divorce from the husband who had hardly come to see her at all.'' What she neglects to say is that the only way George Tavalaro could feel powerful in an incredibly tragic and powerless situation was by protecting and ensuring that his suddenly motherless daughter would always have a warm, supportive and loving home.

title: Jury Award Voided in Scientific Research Case
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned a jury's finding that the University of Alabama and four researchers there stole the work of another scientist.

title: The Great Exception
description: THE STATE OF THE NATION

title: Black Workers Bear Big Burden As Jobs in Government Dwindle
description: In a better, fairer world, Wallace Riddle would have been a carpenter. He could build anything, his daughter Donna said.

title: Hollywood Breathes In The Spirit of Sundance
description: AT THE SUNDANCE FILM FESTIVAL, it was hard to walk down the street or negotiate your way through a party without being mowed down by a camera crew. Park City was full of them, but they weren't making movies; they were trying to mint new celebrities.

title: A Dissident Returns
description: After Natan Sharansky was expelled from the Soviet Union in 1986, he settled in Israel and never looked back. He learned fluent Hebrew, founded a party of Russian Jewish emigrants, became a minister of the government. And when he came back to Russia last week, he said it was mainly to promote trade with Israel.

title: Making Book on Oprah
description: LAST fall Oprah Winfrey, the queen of talk television, started an on-air reading club and the book business hasn't been the same since. For 10 years publishers had watched as self-help, inspirational and celebrity titles rose to best-seller status on the tides of telegenic emotion flooding each day across the screens of Ms. Winfrey's 14 million American viewers. Think of ''Simple Abundance,'' ''The Soul's Code,'' ''Don't Block the Blessings,'' ''Down in the Garden'' and Ms. Winfrey's own ''Make the Connection,'' written with Bob Greene. They all got their sales starts from her.

title: Now, Batting Leadoff for The Bronx...
description: THOUGH crowning victory was achieved at Yankee Stadium, the hardware earned by the Yankees' winning the World Series remains at City Hall. And in the rancorous civic spirit Bobby Bonilla once demonstrated in vowing to ''show the Bronx'' to a reporter he did not like, Fernando Ferrer has delivered the following brushback pitch to the principal owner of the Yankees, as well as the Mayor of New York, whom he wishes to unseat.

title: Designer's Invisibility Act
description: Helmut Lang, 40, the Austrian designer and minimalist pioneer, has an influence on fashion that far exceeds his cult following. Top designers in New York and Europe have already appropriated ideas from his Paris shows to give their own collections a cutting-edge look.

title: Mommy, What's a Classroom?
description: I LOVED GRADE SCHOOL. I mean, every September I just loved getting back to it. I loved sharpening those pencils and putting grocery-bag covers on my textbooks. I loved my teachers unquestioningly -- those towering, unbenign presences -- and shrank before them. I loved the games at recess, the bullying danger of the blacktop, the qualmy allure of the off-limits forest at the far end of the playground. I loved the checker games in the back of the classroom when recess got rained out. I loved snow days, because then there was time to play at home and time to read whatever grown-up book I wanted to read. Best of all, I loved staring out the school room windows in spring, watching the maples bud and leaf and fill out. And man, come to think of it, there was nothing -- nothing -- like the last day of school when you roared off the bus and leapt on your bike and rode away into summer. Even if you loved school, there was nothing better than not going, nothing better in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCELROY, MARJORIE LEBOUTILLIER
description: McELROY-Marjorie LeBoutillier, who broke new ground as a female athlete in the 1930's, died on Sunday, January 26, in the Jupiter (FL) Medical Center. She was 80. Her husband of 49 years, David Brown McElroy, said the cause was complications following surgery. A native of Old Westbury, Long Island, NY, Mrs. McElroy was considered the best woman polo player in the country. An 8goaler, she captained the Long Island Freebooters in the famous 1937 East-West Series. Her team won every match including one played in front of 6000 spectators at Long Island's Bethpage State Park. She was also one of the first women ice hockey players, often holding her own with her male contemporaries. She was a 6-handicap golfer and a champion squash player. In addition to her husband, she is survived by two sons, John LeB. McElroy of Hinsdale, IL and Stewart B. Iglehart of Delray, FL; and six grandchildren.

title: Will the Bulls' Arrival Provide Wake-Up Call?
description: Halfway through their season, the Seattle SuperSonics are certain of one thing. Winning the Western Conference again will not be easy.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: A LITTLE LONDON British Airways has a London for Less package starting at $399, including round-trip air fare from New York and three nights' hotel accommodation with Continental breakfast. The price is per person, based on double occupancy, with accommodations at the Tavistock Hotel; upgrades are available at an additional cost. Departures are on Thursday from Feb. 20 to March 13 or Tuesday or Wednesday from Feb. 4 to March 19. Tickets are nonrefundable and must be paid for at the time reservations are made. Information or reservations: (800) 359-8722.

title: Carlton Goodlett, 82, Doctor And a Campaigning Publisher
description: Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett, a family doctor who built a small San Francisco weekly tabloid into an influential newspaper chain and used his power as publisher to campaign for civil rights, died at his home in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on Saturday. He was 82.

title: Biko's Case Now Offers Justice From a Travesty
description: MANY of those who sat in the old synagogue in Pretoria nearly 20 years ago, when it served briefly as one of apartheid's most infamous courtrooms, must have paused at the news from South Africa last week. According to the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, five white security officers involved in the detention and killing of the black leader Steve Biko in 1977 have indicated a readiness to admit their part in his death, and begun the process of applying for amnesty for their crimes.

title: Judge Orders Last Call At Dance Club
description: Pierre Clerk can get back to his sculpture. He and the other SoHo artists fighting the proliferation of bars and night spots in their neighborhood recently won a nine-month legal battle when a State Supreme Court judge ruled that the State Liquor Authority had violated the law in granting a license to a proposed dance club on Grand Street.

title: Lisbon
description: This luminous city sprawled over seven hills or more is in the throes of a building boom the likes of which hasn't been seen since the Marques de Pombal rebuilt the entire downtown after the great earthquake of 1755. With round-the-clock construction, the Portuguese capital prepares for its biggest show in years: Expo 1998, marking the 500th anniversary of Vasco da Gama's journey to India.

title: When Olympic Champions Moved In, They Put Simsbury on the World Map
description: Among the dozen or so young girls executing double salchows, axels and camels at the rink here on a typical afternoon, a visitor would be hard-pressed to find one who actually came from this wealthy New England town.

title: Everything Up to Date in 1948
description: DEWEY DEFEATS TRUMAN

title: Meet Some Buyers of the New Inflation Bonds
description: SALLY HEINEMANN has been going to Treasury auctions for nearly two decades. She remembers those inflationary days, in the early 1980's, when the prime rate hovered near 21 percent and people flocked to the Federal Reserve Bank near Wall Street to snap up bonds paying 15 percent interest.

title: Woman Slain By Officers After Chase
description: Police officers on Friday night shot and killed a woman who first tried to run them down and then drew a gun that turned out to be a toy, the authorities said.

title: Potus Aurelius
description: Ever since Jimmy Carter went up the mountain with tomes on leadership and came down with malaise, it has made me nervous to see Presidents fooling around with books.

title: Finding French Food in Mamaroneck
description: AFTER short durations, quite a few eateries have fled this space, an unwieldy trapezoid near the vertex of a triangular lot. Finally, Le Provencal has taken over, and this winning little restaurant seems to have come with the right stuff, a winning script for a long and prosperous run. The place has been open only three months, and although flowers and candlelight have given it a certain charm, mirrors on dead wall space and cloth instead of paper table covers would be welcome improvements.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D., M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. Ten long years since you left us, but your love and dynamic spirit pervade our lives. Your family

title: Youngsters Get on Board
description: AMERICAN Family Cruises, designed specifically for families with children, began sailing in December 1993. Bruce I. Nierenberg, who founded the company in partnership with Costa Cruises, believed there were enough pupils in the United States attending year-round schools -- six weeks on, six weeks off -- to keep a cruise ship busy all year. The two young girls I took on an American Family cruise that winter thought it was cool or at least neat, and made me promise to take them again. But in September 1994, American Family Cruises ceased operation, citing inadequate year-round business.

title: A Mozart Serenade, a Rutter Suite
description: AFTER a fairly quiet January, the orchestral scene is springing back to life. Today, at 3 o'clock, James Humphreville conducts the Danbury Concert Chorus and Orchestra in the world premiere of ''Jefferson's Letter,'' by Harry Simeone, the Southbury composer of the Christmas classic ''Do You Hear What I Hear?''

title: The New Mercenaries of Africa
description: Mercenaries have returned to Africa. The new group, led by whites who once fought in South Africa's notorious counterinsurgency units, is called Executive Outcomes and advertises its military services in fancy brochures. The organization, formed in 1989, has little in common with the ragtag band of coup-plotters Africa has seen in recent years. But it threatens to be just as destructive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTNICK, GARY H.
description: PLOTNICK-Gary H. Passed away on February 1, age 56. Beloved husband of Margaret Ellen (Harris). Devoted father of Jennifer. Loving son of Ruth and the late Murray Plotnick. Dear brother of Karen Goldman and Sondra Robinson. Services at GuttermanMusicant, 402 Park, Hackensack, NJ, 2 PM today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, BERYL CLARKE
description: JAMES-Beryl Clarke. The Greater New York Links regrets to announce the passing of their sister Link, Beryl Clarke James, on Thursday, January 30, 1997. We will miss her sorely. We offer our sincere condolences to her daughter and members of the family. Wake Tuesday, February 4, 1997, 3PM-8PM, Granby's Funeral Home, White Plains Road and 226th St., Bronx, NY. Funeral service Wednesday, Feburary 5, 11 AM, Christ Church, 252nd St. and Henry Hudson Parkway, Bronx.

title: Monster in the Woods
description: MY DROWNING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, LAURA
description: GREENBERG - Laura. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Anita Wengrover, Dr. Gary Greene, Robert Greene. Mother-in-law of Bernard, Susan and Laura. Cherished grandmother of ten and great-grandmother of seventeen.

title: Overcrowded, Schools 'Create' New Classrooms
description: UNABLE to spare a single room for its art class, one Long Island school district has developed a program called ''art on a cart,'' a movable feast that brings the teacher to the students.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 20 of The Times Book Review today, with a brief review of ''Capturing the Moment: The Sports Photography of Barton Silverman,'' includes an erroneous identification from the book for the New York Islanders hockey team member holding the Stanley Cup. He is John Tonelli, not Clark Gillies.

title: The Diagnosis: H.I.V.-Positive
description: LIKE many gay men of a certain age, Matthew Hamilton, 35, feels lucky to be alive. Over the last 16 years, as AIDS claimed a dozen of his close friends, Mr. Hamilton came to consider himself a survivor. ''I always followed the rules on safe sex and somehow steered clear of H.I.V.,'' he said.

title: A Poor Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Dept. Assigns Second Chief To Help With Queens Problems
description: A new deputy chief has been assigned to train, guide and supervise firefighters who battle fires in southeastern Queens. The appointment adds a second division command to Queens, the city's largest borough and the one with the highest number of deaths by fire last year.

title: Quotation on Food Co-op Unduly Inflamed Passions
description: To the Editor:

title: The States Offer A Model for Washington
description: While the Federal Government struggles toward balancing its budget sometime after the new millennium begins, the states are proving models of fiscal caution. In all but Hawaii, Tennessee and Idaho, revenues are running ahead of budget projections, letting most pour extra cash into rainy-day funds. The torrent of surplus cash is especially strong in the Midwest, where just a few years ago states were slashing spending and raising taxes. Minnesota anticipates a $1.4 billion surplus this year, meaning each of its 4.6 million residents is giving the state almost a dollar a day more than the state needs to pay its bills. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

title: For Mohawks, Casino Dream Is Still Alive
description: A STEADY stream of cars and four-by-fours pours in and out of the Bear's Den gas station, as though it offers some sort of wonder everyone must experience. And in a way, of course, it does.

title: Jamie Nicholls, Ottavio Biondi Jr.
description: Jamie Carter Nicholls, the daughter of Judy Carter Cormier of New York and Richard Hall Nicholls of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Ottavio Francis Biondi Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Biondi of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Endangered Beetle Sets Off a Furor on Fire Island
description: THE image of a tiny gray beetle that would colonize along the Fire Island shore and spread to other beaches would not usually cause a stir, especially when the beetle is known for eating the gnats that gnaw at beachgoers' ankles.

title: A Master Of the Small Chuckle
description: HE WHIMPERED. HE WHINED. SOMETIMES he actually cried. In short, Jack Paar was a television natural. And, fittingly, the Museum of Television and Radio is celebrating his distinguished career with a black-tie gala at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan on Thursday. This is for a man who, years after he inexplicably walked away from NBC's ''Tonight Show'' in 1962, paving the way for a new host named Johnny Carson, insisted to one interviewer that he was in bed most nights by 7 o'clock. He has never been exactly the kind of guy advertisers crave.

title: Bridge
description: It is 71 years since Harold Sterling Vanderbilt introduced ''contract bridge'' to three friends on a cruise through the Panama Canal on the liner Finland. Since that time, many clubs have been named for him, one of them in Lake Sucess, L.I. Another is in Nashville, where the name is perhaps due more to Vanderbilt University's being there than to the origins of the game.

title: Yes to Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSER, TESSIE
description: LASSER-Tessie, on February 2, 1997, age 96 years. Wife of the late Milton Lasser, mother, by birth and marriage, of Arnold, Ruth, Joseph, Ruth, Howard and Barbara Lasser, and Judith and Mark Litt. Grandmother by birth and marriage of 18 grandchildren and 19 great-grandchildren. Her focus was her family. Funeral service Monday 11:30 AM, Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd, New Rochelle. Memorial contributions to Temple Israel of New Rochelle Religious School or Nursery School would be her wish. For further information contact The George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle.

title: W. C. Patton, 84, Alabama Voice for Black Voters
description: W. C. Patton, an Alabama civic leader who worked for voter registration among blacks well before it moved to the forefront of the civil rights movement, died on Jan. 16 at University of Alabama Hospital in Birmingham. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, CELIA THOMASHOWER
description: LEVINE - Celia Thomashower. Age 93, of Forest Hills, NY, passed away peacefully on Feb. 1, 1997. She is survived by her loving son Marvin Thomashower, daughter Ruth Silverman, son Sidney Thomashower, brothers, grandchildren, great-grandchidlren, relatives and friends. We will remember her all the days of our lives. Graveside service.

title: After Years of Fighting, a Family Is Finding Itself
description: After 17 years together, most spent in a haze of drugs and anger, Robert and Evelyn R. are getting to know each other. The drugs were his, the anger was hers and the suffering belonged to everyone, especially the children, Chris and Melissa.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: U.S.-China Textile Trade Pact Signed in Time for Albright Trip
description: A broad agreement reached by China and the United States today on textile trade is likely to further increase a sector of cross-Pacific commerce already worth billions, American officials said.

title: No Headline
description: ''You have seen these kids after they leave school in the neighborhoods they live in and you sometimes wondered how they made it through anyway. Now you're amazed, every day, how good they are in spite of it all.''

title: Israeli Peace Guidelines
description: To the Editor:

title: But Who Will Enforce a Budget Amendment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENKES, BRAD
description: MENKES-Brad. Professor Emeritus, City College of New York. Beloved husband of Bette (nee Kaplan). Devoted father of Holly Freedman, Laurie Hollman, Jill Kushner and the late Peter K. Menkes. Father-in-law of Alan Freedman, Jeffrey Hollman and Robb Kushner. Loving grandfather of Jon and Michael Freedman, David and Richard Hollman, and Matthew and Liz Kushner. Shiva will be observed at the Menkes residence. Contributions may be made to the Peter K. Menkes Memorial Fund at the Teaneck Library, Teaneck Rd., Teaneck, NJ, 07666. For information ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 800-522-0588.

title: Danger at the N.R.A.
description: Weakened by declining membership, financial problems and an abysmal public image, the National Rifle Association is facing a takeover by a far-right faction known for courting armed militias and other extremists. The showdown is expected at a board meeting later this month, when the current executive vice president, Wayne LaPierre Jr., could be ousted by his longtime rival, Neal Knox, a troubling figure if ever there was one.

title: An Inventive Los Angeles Music Station Will Change Format, a Casualty of Radio Economics
description: Junior Wells, a Chicago harmonica legend known as the godfather of the blues, was never a regular on the pop charts. But his remake of the singer Tracy Chapman's ''Give Me One Reason'' in the gut-bucket Mississippi Delta blues style, his harmonica wailing over an acoustic slide guitar, was a regular on the play list of KSCA-FM (101.9) in Los Angeles.

title: Fasting to Protest a Hunt
description: These are not easy times for New Jersey's wild canines.

title: English Is Fundamental
description: To the Editor:

title: In Reversal, White House Says Guests Were Vetted
description: Partly reversing itself, the White House said this evening that the backgrounds of the hundreds of visitors who saw the President at small gatherings arranged by the Democratic National Committee had been reviewed by Secret Service officials to determine whether the visitors might have posed a security threat to Mr. Clinton.

title: Lea Kisselgoff, 88, Classical China Scholar
description: Lea M. Kisselgoff, a Sinologist who specialized in classical Chinese texts, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: Victim's Dog Foils Attack in Central Park
description: A 43-year-old woman who was attacked in Central Park yesterday afternoon was saved when one of her dogs frightened off the assailant, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTERS, ELIZABETH
description: BASTERS-Elizabeth, 86, an employee of the Catholic Medical Mission Board for 32 years, died Dec. 21, 1996. A former member of the Carroll Club and a longtime resident of Stuyvesant Town. A Memorial Mass will be held at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th Street, Wednesday, February 5, 1997 at 11 A.M.

title: Church's Role in Serbia Protests May Block Reforms
description: The Rev. Stevo Vlacic, his deep baritone voice reciting a liturgy that has changed little in the last millennium, stood in his gold embroidered vestments today and began a two-hour Mass for his standing congregation.

title: All About the Telephone Long Before 'Press 1'
description: ''The American Experience'' has its eye on inventors. Tonight it's Alexander Graham Bell, whom everybody knows about, and next week it's Philo T. Farnsworth, whom almost nobody knows about. One became famous enough to be played by Don Ameche; the other sounds like a character invented by W. C. Fields. But both were homegrown tinkerers of genius who came up with world-changing inventions and ran up against corporate power and money.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT INDIANA's familiar painting of the word Love has been transformed into all sorts of reproductions over the years: sculpture, stamps, greeting cards and jewelry.

title: Clinton's Agenda and Budget Will Test Tone of Amity
description: After months of invoking bipartisanship, President Clinton this week formally presents his legislative agenda and his budget, beginning the long struggle that will determine whether the Republican-controlled Congress and the Democratic President can really enter a season of cooperation.

title: For Nets, A 20-Point Cushion Is Too Thin
description: There was no need for hyperbole to make Kendall Gill's day more dramatic than it was, no extra topping required.

title: Naked Truth
description: The problem with ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' is its fundamental dishonesty. It's a cowardly movie that keeps trying to tell us how brave it is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOHN CAMPBELL
description: HENRY-John Campbell. On January 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Whitmel Powers Henry. Survived also by a daughter, Margaret Smith, a son, John Campbell Henry, Jr., a stepson, Eric Knaus, two grandsons and a sister, Louise Henry Clark. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ANNA
description: GREENBERG-Anna, on February 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham (Al). Devoted mother of Beverly Van Dyne and Shelley Korn. Cherished grandmother of Paul Van Dyne, Ali Hoffman, Aimee Van Dyne Tillem, Caren Marder, Brett Mufson, and Beth Mufson. Adored great-grandmother of six. Services today 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HADDAD, MOYSH
description: HADDAD-Moysh. It's been so many years, but I think about you and miss you so much. You left me too soon. Freda

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, CELIA (CELE) NEE KISLAH
description: COHEN-Celia (Cele) nee Kislah. In her 89th year, beloved wife of Samuel, loving mother of Elaine Krasna (Alvin) and Ruth Wiener (Jerry), devoted grandmother of five and great-grandmother of eleven.

title: Interpublic Unit Gets AST Account
description: There have been developments in reviews for two computer accounts.

title: Dr. Ian A. H. Munro, 73, Editor Of The Lancet Medical Journal
description: Dr. Ian A. H. Munro, a crusading editor of the British medical journal The Lancet for 12 years, died in a hospital in Kent, England, on Jan. 22. He was 73.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: The Old Star Wars Gets Some New Looks
description: In case you have been on the ice planet Hoth and out of touch, a tuned-up version of ''Star Wars'' opened in theaters across the country Friday, taking in $36 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISTER, MORRIS
description: MEISTER-Morris of Elizabeth, NJ. Husband of the late Florence. Devoted father of Rabbi Dr. Gerald M. Meister of Fresh Meadows Jewish Center, Elaine Sacks, daughter-in-law Audrey, adored grandfather of Jonathan A. Loving brother. Services at ''Kreitzman's Memorial Home'' 1055 E. Jersey St., Elizabeth, on Monday 10:30 AM.

title: Long-Term Debt
description: Professionally neutral Switzerland, and especially its secretive banking system, has come under fire for committing the greatest sin a banker can be charged with: not protecting the assets of its depositors, in this case the money of European Jews entrusted to Swiss safekeeping during the Holocaust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLES, CHANDLER R.
description: COWLES-Chandler R. On Feb. 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Pavlina Dokovska-Cowles. Loving father of Matthew and Christopher, and grandfather of Isabel and Lily. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, Feb. 5, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84th St, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: Missing Stars, U.S. Faces Climb at Worlds
description: The world Alpine ski championships begin Monday. Time for American sports fans to dust off their long-term memories and become reacquainted with their 1994 Winter Olympic heroes.

title: Vladimir A. Yamnikov, 56, Premium Russian Vodka Maker
description: Vladimir A. Yamnikov, manager of the Kristall distillery, one of the largest vodka makers in Russia, died in Moscow on Jan. 20. He was 56.

title: But Are They Better Than Al Roker?
description: For 15 years, Staten Island Chuck has been summoned from his den to do battle with Punxsutawney Phil on Feb. 2, Groundhog Day. At least three groundhogs have played the role of Chuck, and many more have played Phil; the lifespan for the species, Marmota monax, is only four or five years.

title: Hello Makes Quick Work Of Last Year's Champion
description: Boston Harbor, last year's champion 2-year-old colt, took his first step down the path toward the Kentucky Derby today and stubbed his toe.

title: Thurber, Wry Minimalist, Joins a Literary Pantheon
description: James Thurber was, by his own description, a ''short-piece writer'': 10 pages or less, and on to the next work. Once he collaborated (with Elliott Nugent) on a full-length play, ''The Male Animal,'' but he was not about to write a Jamesian novel or a tell-all-through-the-night autobiography. His memoir, ''My Life and Hard Times,'' is briefer than a breviary.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an entry on Friday in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page about an advertising assignment for Titan Auto Insurance, won by the Dallas office of Publicis/Bloom, referred incompletely to the scope of the assignment. In addition to the Spanish-speaking consumer market, it covers the general market.

title: GOVERNORS LIMIT REVISIONS SOUGHT IN WELFARE LAW
description: Under pressure from Congressional Republicans, leaders of the National Governors' Association today decided not to seek wholesale changes in the new Federal welfare law. Instead they issued a cautious appeal to Congress and the Clinton Administration to work with them to meet the needs of a relatively small group of legal immigrants who will lose Federal benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERLIN, NATHAN J., M.D.
description: SERLIN-Nathan J., M.D. Died January 28, 1997 in Mt. Vernon, NY where he practiced internal medicine and hematology for 50 years. He is survived by his beloved wife Hilde, daughters Patricia Helsing and Nancy Pine, sonin-law Richard Pine, sister Ruth Towers and two adored grandsons. He will be sorely missed.

title: I.R.A. Leader Denies Talk of Killing Rival
description: Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, denied today as ''rubbish'' reports in London newspapers that a former I.R.A. guerrilla said Mr. Adams once discussed murdering John Hume, the most prominent mainstream Roman Catholic leader in Northern Ireland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN
description: PERLMAN-Julian, on February 1, 1997. Loving father to Tom and the late Jane Elizabeth. Husband of the late Jane. Brother to Murray Perlman and Charlotte Walsh. Son-in-law of Anne Norris. Friend to Sylvia Wolf. A kind and devoted uncle. Services Tuesday 12 PM at Temple Israel of the City of NY, 112 East 75th St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGG, HILDA M.
description: BRAGG-Hilda M., 94, of Greenwich, CT, on January 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edward H. Bragg. Devoted mother of Edward, Jr., and mother-in-law of Margaret. Dear grandmother of Philip, James and Winston Bragg. Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 4th at 12:30PM at Christ Episcopal Church Chapel, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Greenwich Hospital Endowment Fund would be appreciated. For information, the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: Hospital Problems Beyond the E.R.
description: Now in its third season on CBS, ''Chicago Hope,'' created by David E. Kelley (''Picket Fences''), got off to one of the more memorably unfortunate starts in prime time. Suddenly there were two new major hospital shows, and two major networks, with typically shaky programming wisdom, decided to compete head-to-head on Thursday nights. NBC's ''E. R.,'' more finely attuned to blood, guts and sex, quickly ran off with the reviews and ratings. It still does.

title: Police Residency Rule Will Deplete the Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANE, VINCENT J.
description: VANE-Vincent J. Age 65, of Lake Barrington Shores, IL. Husband of the late Marilyn. Father of Terry, Cullen, Lisa, Chris, Jennifer and MarySara. Grandfather of eight. Brother of Sr. Imnaculata and Edwin. Funeral Mass at St. Francis de Sales Church, 10 AM, Tuesday, Lake Zurich, IL. For information call 847-540-8871.

title: Deep Scars Are Expected in Senate Hearings on Nominee for C.I.A. Chief
description: President Clinton's nomination of Anthony Lake as the Director of Central Intelligence is turning into a political bloodletting that could leave both Mr. Lake and the C.I.A. damaged.

title: Roger Tayler, 67; Briton Advanced Knowledge of Stars
description: Roger John Tayler, who helped advance modern understanding of stellar evolution and served for 18 years as secretary, treasurer and finally president of the Royal Astronomical Society in Britain, died on Jan. 23 in a London hospital. He was 67 and lived in Lewes, England.

title: One Camera That Offers Many Views
description: Imagine a teleconference in which every attendee, whether a few feet or a thousand miles away, can use a computer mouse to ''move'' around the main conference room, stopping at each participant's face or zooming in on notes being taken.

title: TV Film About Teen-Ager's Murder Draws Protests on Network's Timing
description: The killing took place in December 1995; two suspects were arrested last September. One of them is to go on trial next September; no trial date has been set for the other. The television movie is on next Monday night.

title: Fallon McElligott drops McDonald's and Leap moves deeper into the Los Angeles market.
description: TWO prominent Midwestern agencies surprised Madison Avenue with significant moves late last week.

title: Americans by Birth
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Will Receive Two-Year Extension
description: The Yankee owner, George Steinbrenner, said last night that Manager Joe Torre will be given a two-year contract extension, through the 1999 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICHETTO, STEPHEN
description: PICHETTO-Stephen. Died on Feb. 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Maura. Brother of the late Audrey Andrepont. Uncle of Paul, Cherie and John. Visiting hours on Tuesday, Feb. 4, from 2-4 PM, and 7-9 PM, at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, at West 261st St, Riverdale, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, Feb. 5, at 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, 6000 Riverdale Ave. Interment at the Pichetto family mausoleum at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MORTIMER
description: COHEN-Mortimer, on February 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Nina and Mark Reisman, and the late Paul Cohen. Cherished grandfather of Paul and Collin. Services Tuesday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Pentagon to Help Peru Stop Drug Traffic on Jungle Rivers
description: With President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru in Washington this weekend, the Defense Department is planning a major new military aid program for Peru to intercept shipments of coca base on jungle rivers before they reach Colombia for processing into cocaine.

title: Back in Jail, Again
description: A woman who had claimed falsely that she was raped by an inmate at the Union County jail was sentenced on Friday to serve six months at the jail for contempt and false swearing. The woman, Alveda Torrado of Elizabeth, admitted in December that her sexual experience with a male inmate had been consensual and that she had fled to Puerto Rico to avoid appearing before a grand jury investigating the rape charge she had filed.

title: Dear Mother England, Don't Cut the Apron Strings
description: This place relishes its status as one of the last outposts of the British Empire and has never hesitated to fight to keep things that way. So when the Foreign Office back in London issued a policy statement in December that the people here interpreted as a none-too-subtle shove toward independence, it was no surprise that a ruckus ensued.

title: New TV Law in Colombia Provokes Complaints of Censorship
description: The Colombian Congress has granted a regulatory commission broad authority to take television news programs off the air on the basis of their content. Many journalists see the move as an attempt to punish programs that have investigated suspected ties between drug traffickers and prominent politicians, including President Ernesto Samper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEEHAN, WILLIAM
description: MEEHAN-William, on January 26. Beloved husband of Dee Dee, loving father of Billy and Brian. Your love and generosity enriched our lives beyond compare. We will love you always.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Accord Is Seen to Fuel Textile Trade With China

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, misidentified the company developing an interactive video communications network for the forum. It is Advanced Video Communications Inc., the commercial arm of the forum, not Hewlett-Packard.

title: Executive Changes At 3 Agencies
description: Three agencies are making executive appointments.

title: Music in Review: Jazz
description: Audience Gets the Jokes, As Well It Should

title: Canada Called Haven for Nazi Criminals
description: Recent news accounts of Canada's lax pursuit of accused war criminals after World War II have stirred painful memories and raised troubling questions about the Canadian Government's policies in the post-war period.

title: INSIDE
description: President to Stress 'Unfinished Business'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TULCHINER, SEMON
description: TULCHINER-Semon. The Jewish Center of Jackson Heights mourns the pasing of our esteemed President, Semon Tulchiner. We offer our heartfelt sympathies to his family, wife Rita, their children Michael and Jill, and son-in-law Selwyn, grandchildren Scott, Anthony, Christina, David; and his mother Raye and sister Judy Horowitz. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Board of Directors

title: Kwan Wants It All, In and Out of the Rink
description: When she won the world figure skating championship last March at age 15, Michelle Kwan slept with her gold medal. But her teen-age exuberance was tempered by a more grown-up revelation: ''It was like, 'I won, get on with life,' '' she said.

title: The Empire That Henry Luce Built Now Works at Bolstering the Bottom Line
description: There is no other way to put it: Time Inc. is on a roll.

title: Now Refashion U.S.-Caribbean Economic Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOANNA SIMON, the mezzo-soprano, does not shy away from taking her career in dramatic new directions.

title: Land of Opportunity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSMAN, PHILIP
description: ISSMAN-Philip. On January 27, in Boca Raton, FL. Son of the late Anne and Irving Issman; beloved husband of Thelma; father of Matthew (Susan), Andrew (Sharon) and Claudia (David); grandfather; and brother of Helen Mintz, Ruth Fisherman and the late Jules. He will always be remembered.

title: Thinking Small Paying Off Big In Gene Quest
description: Working in the shadow of the vast project to decode human genes, biologists are rapidly deciphering the genetic makeup of much smaller organisms, including microbes that cause disease.

title: Auto Lender Is Scrambling For Financing
description: The Mercury Finance Company remained in financial limbo over the weekend as auditors pored over its books and bankers refused to extend new loans to cover short-term obligations that began coming due Friday.

title: Wiring the Spread of Technology
description: A generation ago, the people who built and maintained America's digital plumbing often spent their days on telephone poles. But with the wires within buildings multiplying and becoming as important as the wires leading to the curb, many of the plumbers have moved indoors, trading their bright orange telephone testers for hand-held digital crosstalk and delay skew analyzers.

title: Cyberspace Resumes Fit the Modern Job Hunt
description: A recent help-wanted newspaper advertisement instructed job seekers to send their resumes to hireme@concretemedia.com. Ads like this are proliferating and suggest it is time to dust off the electronic resume -- or hurry and write one. Many places on the World Wide Web offer simple forms for just that purpose.

title: Telemarketing Finds a Ready Labor Market in Hard-Pressed North Dakota
description: The driving on the Lawrence Welk Highway had deteriorated into whiteout conditions as another blizzard scoured the North Dakota plains. But in a well-heated former tractor showroom, Susan Horner was booking vacations to Hawaii and Florida.

title: Music in Review: Classical Music
description: A Move Across Town

title: City Ballet's 'Schubertiad' as a Birthday Present
description: The New York City Ballet gave Franz Schubert a birthday present on Friday night at the New York State Theater. Schubert was born on Jan. 31, 1797, and in honor of the 200th anniversary of his birth, the company revived ''A Schubertiad,'' the ballet to Schubert piano music that Peter Martins created in 1984.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, LAWRENCE A.
description: FLEISCHMAN-Lawrence A. The Friends and Patrons of the Arts of the Vatican Museums record with deep regret the death of its founding member, the architect of its major successes in acquisition and conservation, and a dear personal friend. His work and generosity also led to the construction of the Cardinal Cooke Conservation Laboratory at the Vatican Museums. He was created a Knight of St. Sylvestre of the Holy See for his leadership and care of the fine arts at the Museums. Lucy F. McGrath, Chairman Monsignor Eugene V. Clark

title: Serenity, Not Giddiness, From Whirling
description: The Whirling Dervishes of Turkey presented meditation in motion on Saturday night at City Center.

title: The Long, Slow Climb From the Bottom
description: IT was supposed to have been the afternoon when University of Miami basketball took its great leap forward. A leap from obscurity, from years of being a doormat, to being in the thick of a Big East race. The ingredients were all there: a winning streak, a national television audience and -- most important of all -- Rutgers.

title: Iran's Central Bank Chief HailsCooperation From 'Partners,'Citing Failure of U.S. Sanctions : Europe and Japan Are Guaranteeing $5 Billion in Loans Tehran Reports
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Despite U.S. anti-terrorism sanctions, Iran has managed to obtain offers of more than $5 billion in government-backed loan guarantees from Europe and Japan over the last 18 months, according to the governor of Tehran's central bank

title: New Twist By Miami On Toeing The Line
description: The difference between Rutgers and Miami today was about the length of a sneaker's toe.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today, in a market that has swung sharply in recent sessions. At the end of the Tokyo Stock Exchange's trading session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 244.06 points, or 1.33 percent, to stand at 18,085.95. On Friday, the Nikkei index gained 465.97 points, or 2.67 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSCHEL, JEAN F.
description: NEUSCHEL-Jean F. Formerly of Brookville, NY, on January 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Richard F. Loving mother of Robin Reeves (Ross C.) and Debra Jones (Robert). Dear grandmother of Cameron and Peter Reeves; Samantha and Peyton Jones. Interment service 12 noon, Monday, Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, NY.

title: A Good Guy Still Feels Left Out
description: Last night, Todd Hundley of the Mets experienced yet another example of the affection New York City lavishes on a winner.

title: It's What They Like
description: The chance to buy a painting that once hung in Newark International Airport or the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan does not come along every day. So perhaps the big crowd at yesterday's opening of a pre-auction display of artworks owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should not be surprising. ''We're mobbed,'' said Carol Deutsch, the publicity agent for Dawson's Auctioneers and Appraisers in Morris Plains, estimating the crowd at more than 400. ''People are liking the sculptures, people are looking for Picassos.'' Robert Motherwell's ''Elegy No. 116,'' a nine-foot-long black and white tapestry, attracted many inquiries, Ms. Deutsch said.

title: A Call to Account Issued by Giuliani
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani urged yesterday that municipal unions be required to disclose in greater detail how they spend their money -- much of which comes from taxpayers -- in the wake of indictments last month against lawyers who received millions in fees from the city police union.

title: Is Bhutto Good, Bad or Ugly? Pakistanis Will Decide Today
description: At her final rally over the weekend for Monday's general election, Benazir Bhutto offered a crowd grown damp from drizzling rain a last, hoarse rendition of what has been her battle cry for re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, YVONNE
description: ROSEN-Yvonne. On January 28,1997. Beloved mother of Roxane and Ronald. Adoring grandmother of Shira, Jaron and Rose. Devoted mother-in-law of Paul. Cherished friend of the children and grandchildren of her dear late husband, George Rosen. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Her life touched all those who knew her. She will be missed. Funeral private. A memorial to celebrate her life will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, RACHEL
description: RIFKIN-Rachel. Beloved sister of Arthur, Irving and Bernard. Loving aunt of Beth, Terry and Leah, Bryna. Adoring sisters-in-law Lois and Fran. Great-aunt of Judah, Alana and David. Retired NYC school principal, past President of ZOA Women's Division, lover of Zion, member of Greystone Jewish Center in Yonkers. Shiva will be observed in Riverdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSEL, STANLEY P.
description: KUSEL-Stanley P., 83, of Virginia Beach, VA, died February 1, 1996, in a local hospital. Mr. Kusel was a native of New York, NY. Survivors include his wife, Eleanor Kahn Kusel of Virginia Beach, a daughter, Barbara K. Fried of Virginia Beach, a son, Donald R. Kusel of Pleasantville, NY, and his four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. A graveside service will be conducted at 1 PM, Monday, February 3, 1997, in Forest Lawn Cemetery, Norfolk by Rabbi Elliott Marmon. For information, contact H.D. Oliver Funeral Apartments, Laskin Road Chapel.

title: 'The British Genius'
description: In the run-up to the British election, now likely to take place in May, it seems increasingly difficult to tell the two major parties apart. Two weeks ago Labor's shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, went so far as to promise that Labor would not raise income-tax rates for five years if it won, or increase public spending for two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANHALT, HERBERT, M.D.
description: ANHALT-Herbert, M.D. On February 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Lenore. Father of Evan and Todd. Grandfather of Dana, Alaine, Emily and David. A compassionate, intelligent and artistic man.

title: Private Help for Public Woes
description: Despite America's robust economy, unemployment remains stubborn in the inner cities. Millions of urban residents are not only jobless. They are growing increasingly out of touch with potential employers. At a time of reduced government spending, salvation lies increasingly with the private sector. Two recent developments offer glimmers of hope.

title: Rice Puts On His Act, And the Knicks Fall for It
description: The Knicks climb over bodies and knock down 3-pointers in the fourth quarter, conniving a few thousand people into staying and supporting them. Glen Rice does his part by missing a few shots and acting as if his confidence is gone -- before burying yet another demoralizing 20-foot jump shot.

title: When Foreign Aid Makes a Difference
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and the Republican leadership in Congress have expressed hope for renewed bipartisanship in foreign policy. One place to start is foreign aid, which has been much maligned and misunderstood.

title: Lewis H. Gann, 72, Expert on Colonialist Africa
description: Dr. Lewis Henry Gann, a writer, an editor and an archivist steeped in the intersecting histories of Africa and Europe, died on Jan. 17 in his adopted hometown of Palo Alto, Calif. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, MILTON S.
description: SAMUELS-Milton S. of Park Ridge, NJ on January 31, 1997. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Carrigan). Devoted father of Deidre and David, M.D. Dear grandfather of Kevin and Owen. Memorial Service 11 AM Tuesday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, PA or the American Cancer Society.

title: Parking Attendant Dies as Car Falls in Shaft
description: A parking garage attendant was killed last night on the Upper West Side of Manhattan when the car he was driving rolled backward into an open freight elevator shaft and plunged at least two stories, the police said.

title: White House Had Ended System of Checking Foreign Guests
description: Ten years ago the Reagan White House adopted a rule about foreign businessmen, lobbyists and consultants who wanted to get in to see the President without the blessing of their embassies: they shouldn't.

title: Global Phone Pact Appears Near But U.S. Conditions May Block It
description: Trade negotiators from more than 100 countries are close to reaching an agreement on opening up government-protected telecommunication monopolies to competition, but the United States is still threatening to block the pact if it does not go as far as American officials would like.

title: A Stricter Belt Law
description: New Jersey drivers could soon have an extra incentive to buckle up. Although seat belts have been mandatory in New Jersey since 1985, a police officer cannot issue a ticket to a motorist driving without one unless the driver is stopped for another reason, like speeding. Under a bill to be considered by the Assembly Transportation and Communications Committee today, the police would be able to stop and ticket drivers simply for not using a seat belt. Violations carry a $20 penalty but would still not result in points against a driver's license.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Judge Rejects Plea Bargain In Bribe Case
