description: In a rare courtroom reversal, a judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan has rescinded her approval of a plea bargain by a former union business agent accused of extortion and bribery, saying she agreed with dissident union members who had protested his proposed sentence as too lenient.

title: Does National Public Radio feel pressure when foundation donors specify topics?
description: THE credit lines at the end of National Public Radio's news broadcasts are a familiar part of the radio soundscape: the news is brought by this foundation for coverage of education, another for the environment, yet another for coverage of news about children's issues.

title: Rangers Can't Recover From Woeful Start
description: The Rangers played one horrible period in Philadelphia on Saturday -- the second -- and not only survived, but won by a pair of goals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEBY, DR. FREDERICK
description: APPLEBY-Dr. Frederick. On February 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Barbara Kessler. Devoted father of Kenneth and Micki, Paul and Robin. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Alexander, Melanie and Lauren. Stepfather of Ronni and Michael, Jon and Asti, and Richard. Grandfather of Madeline, Juliette and Abraham. Brother of Dr. Joseph and brother-in-law of Doris. Funeral services will be held today at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Inc., 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens.

title: Dozens of Chinese From 1993 Voyage Still in Jail
description: The freighter Golden Venture, loaded with a human cargo of 286 smuggled Chinese immigrants, shuddered to a halt on a sandbar off Queens one drizzly night in 1993. With the twinkling promise of America close enough to touch, many leaped into the black, pounding surf to make a desperate swim for freedom.

title: Gay Scholarship's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Have a Wild Card: Belichick
description: Although they still plan to offer a package to the New England Patriots that would bring them Bill Parcells, the Jets have come up with a Plan B -- as in Bill Belichick. According to people with both teams, the Jets will offer their head coaching job to Belichick, Parcells's defensive coordinator and the former head coach of the Cleveland Browns, if they are unable to make a deal with the Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVINE, ANNA
description: LEVINE-Anna. Remembered always with love by her family. Dear mother, grandma, and great grandma.

title: New Video-Conferencing Unit Aims for the Middle Market
description: For years, companies that wanted to bring face-to-face video-conferencing into their offices have themselves faced an ugly picture.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSTON, W. ELBERT III
description: JOHNSTON-W. Elbert III. May 25, 1963-February 3, 1978. So long as we remember, you live. Love, Mom and Wilvena

title: An inventor tries to bring snowboarding to a screeching halt, or a gradual stop. Your choice.
description: SNOWBOARDERS have become just about as common as skiers at many downhill resorts. But snowboarding -- surfing down a mountain slope on what is essentially a skateboard minus the wheels -- is more popular among young daredevils than middle-aged folks.

title: Recall Move in Atlantic City
description: Some citizens cannot wait for a chance to vote Mayor James F. Whelan of Atlantic City out of office. His second term expires in May 1998, but the Committee to Recall James Whelan From the Office of Mayor said last week that it had gathered more than enough signatures to force a recall election and that it planned to submit them early this week. The committee's chairwoman, Michelle Sobolewski, criticized Mr. Whelan for raising taxes, for giving Mirage Resorts 168 acres of waterfront property for a casino and for trying to abolish the post of police chief, which she said has hurt police morale. Mr. Whelan said a drop in taxable property caused the tax increase and that the other acts would help to attract jobs and control the police.

title: New Rules for H.M.O.'s
description: Changes are coming soon for the two million New Jersey residents who belong to health maintenance organizations. New H.M.O. regulations, which consumer groups call some of the strongest in the country, will be announced tomorrow by the State Health Department, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOERFLER, WILLIAM G.
description: DOERFLER-William G. The Stephen Wise Free Synagogue and its Women's Organization record with profound sorrow the passing of a longtime benefactor and the cherished husband of many years to Annette (Toddy), who has served with great distinction as a Board member and Officer of the Women's Organization. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Board of Trustees Women's Organization Gary Bretton-Granatoor, Rabbi Ellen Stettner, Cantor

title: Absent Arab Peace Partners
description: The first weeks of 1997 brought clear evidence that the political leaders and people of Israel are ready to push ahead with the next moves toward building a Middle East peace. So too are the Palestinians and their leader, Yasir Arafat. The question now is whether Egypt and Syria have the courage and wisdom to join them.

title: Music in Review: Classical Music
description: A Powerful Voice Goes From Opera to Recital Stage

title: Sidney W. Dean Is Dead at 91; Served as Trustee of City Club
description: Sidney W. Dean Jr., a longtime trustee of the City Club of New York and a strong advocate of free speech who fought for years to make cable television a positive force for the city, died on Jan. 24 at his Greenwich Village apartment.

title: With America Online Demand Come New Rules of Supply
description: When America Online Inc. began its all-you-can-eat pricing policy in December, the company was making a number of risky bets at once -- not only with its own business, but also with the cyberspace fortunes of the 300 companies, large and small, that supply everything from news to fashion tips on the big on-line service.

title: Cosby and His Audience Return to Business of Laughter
description: Bill Cosby managed to get back to the business of stand-up comedy tonight, telling an audience of 2,200 people here at his first concert performance since the murder of his son: ''This is not difficult for me because a part of my lifetime has been with you all.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, HERBERT G.
description: LANE-Herbert G. Loving husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Kenneth and Nancy, Donna and Simon Swaap. Cherished ''Poppy'' of Ryan and Allison. Dear brother of Robert, Arthur and Richard. And dear Mitzi. Service today February 3, 11:30 AM at Temple Israel of the City of New York, 112 East 75th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to Temple Israel would be appreciated.

title: Family Killings Jolt a Tranquil Town
description: Just across Lake Washington from the funk and grunge of Seattle, Bellevue is a staid suburban city of two-computer households and mini-vans, most notable for the rocketing of its real-estate prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ERNA
description: LEVINE-Erna. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Carol L. Cohen and Lynn Levine and mother-in-law of Michael Cohen and Cliff Adler. Cherished grandmother of Gregg and Brook. Devoted sister of Harry Hirschmann, Richard Hirschmann, Ilsa Rosenbaum and Lotte Koesten. Services today, 10 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Avenue J). Donations may be made to Linden Lodge, 75 Linden St., Brattleboro, VT 05301

title: All hail Jules Verne, patron saint of cyberspace.
description: AS an Internet wag once noted, there are some things about modern life that not even Jules Verne predicted: things like Post-It notes and televangelists, Velcro and Minoxidil, Orville Redenbacher and ''The Bridges of Madison County.''

title: O'Meara Manages to Escape Yet Another Rush by Woods
description: It is a common notion that Tiger Woods has a better passing gear than a Ferrari. Perhaps that's because golf's comeback kid has chased down so many Hyundais in his brief but illustrious career.

title: For D'Amato, A Quest to Be Mr. Sensitive
description: NO one seemed to be able to explain exactly what Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was doing there.

title: Sleepwalkers, Awake! What We Need Is a Little Menace
description: What's a mystery story without mystery? Ever since its premiere in 1946, theatergoers have called ''La Sonnambula'' the sort of ballet Edgar Allan Poe might have created if his art had been dance rather than literature. In this work to a score by Vittorio Rieti, George Balanchine choreographically tells an eerie tale about an idealistic Poet who attends a party given by a decadent Baron. There he encounters an alluring Coquette and an apparently spellbound Sleepwalker. The plot rushes to a violent conclusion and, as in many works by Poe, events are infused with a totally irrational, yet very real, sense of menace.

title: Bill Sale Today Is Only Offering Listed by Treasury This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Apple Plan to Cut Costs 25% Might Include Significant Layoffs
description: Apple Computer Inc. will disclose the details of its restructuring plan this week as the struggling company tries to cut its costs by 25 percent. The plan is expected to include substantial layoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, GOLDIE
description: GOODMAN-Goldie. Age 91 years. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Beverly Diamond. Dearest grandmother of Harold and Judy, Elise and Allen and Judy. Loving great-grandmother of Alyssa. For further information call Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Inc., 800-468-3232.

title: The Bill That Fell From Grace
description: Almost a year ago, the Rev. Tom Grey recalled, a rumpled, gruff-voiced man approached him at a convention of evangelical Christians in Rochester and gave him his card. ''We have a common interest,'' the man said.

title: Offerings of Equity and Debt Expected to Be Made This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Now It's Pataki's Turn: $15,000 for Out-of-State Speeches
description: Engaging in the same practice that his own campaign advisers criticized former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a contract early last year to give speeches across the country for $15,000 each.

title: Politics and Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. The Board and staff of The South Forty Corporation mourn the passing of their longtime former Board member, Charles Inniss, who served the agency with dedication and deep personal interest in its mission of providing meaningful rehabilitation programs and job opportunities for men and women ex-offenders released from the New York State and City correctional systems. We extend our sympathy to his wife and family. Charlie will be missed but not forgotten. Anthony Schulte, President John Rakis, Executive Director

title: Johnson Will Just Play And Stop Worrying
description: He has passed up shots often this season, some of them only a few feet from the basket. But given the chance to make a statement off the floor yesterday, Larry Johnson did not hesitate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 21 about the killing of bison suspected of carrying brucellosis characterized the disease incorrectly. While all but eliminated in humans in the United States, brucellosis -- often called undulant fever, or Malta fever -- can affect people, not just animals.

title: Hope and Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Brodeur Sits, and the Devils Make Do
description: For the second time this season, Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire has disturbed and embarrassed Martin Brodeur by keeping him out of a game he wanted and expected to play.

title: The Road to the Derby Begins With a Stunner
description: The horse was 105-1, and for good reason: he had won only one of his seven starts, and that was six months ago. He had never won a stakes race, or even run in one. His trainer put him in the race, the season's first major test for the Kentucky Derby, because ''he had been training well.'' And his jockey had won only 2 of 40 races in his first month as a regular rider at Gulfstream Park.

title: This Time, Diversity In Crown Heights Jury
description: When the racially charged Crown Heights case first went to trial in 1992, the state court jury was made up only of Brooklyn residents, six of whom were black, and there were no Jews on the panel.

title: Clevelanders' Three Nights Of Reveling In Schubert
description: We were in safe hands at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, Friday and Saturday with Christoph von Dohnanyi and the Cleveland Orchestra. Schubert was in safe hands. The three concerts, celebrating his bicentenary, were beautifully prepared and beautifully accomplished; they were also beautifully programmed, around two finished symphonies and two unfinished, though with the underlying message that all symphonies are unfinished until realized in performance. Even then life goes on. But these performances, so definite, won't be forgotten.

title: Heroics (and Special Effects) Strike a Chord
description: Several days ago George Lucas, the creator of ''Star Wars,'' joined an office pool betting on how much money the reissue of his film would earn over the weekend. Mr. Lucas said the movie, which opened on Friday, would earn a substantial $10 million.

title: '95 Data Show Sharp Drop in Reported Rapes
description: The number of rapes reported to the police nationwide in 1995 dropped to 97,000, the lowest number since 1989 and the lowest rate per capita in a decade, according to a major report released by the Justice Department yesterday.

title: Hispanics Suffer Loss of Health Care, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: From 'Doormat Wife' to a Pioneer in the Boardroom and the Newsroom
description: PERSONAL HISTORY

title: Teen-Ager Held in Slaying of Friend at Party
description: A small house-warming party in Staten Island turned deadly Saturday night when a teen-ager fiddling with a gun apparently shot his sometime girlfriend by accident, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHBERG, JOSEPH
description: EICHBERG-Joseph. Age 90, died in Atlanta, Feb. 1, 1997. He was President of the American Lecithin Company for over 60 years. Predeceased by wives Lucille Rosenfeld Eichberg and Florence May Eichberg, and daughter Susan Eichberg Whitfield. Survivors include son Joseph Eichberg, Jr., son-in-law Larry Whitfield and five grandchildren.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about advances in the field of quantum computing misstated the nature of a discovery announced by scientists at the City College of New York, the University of Barcelona and the Xerox Corporation. The scientists discovered that a magnetic material under study exhibited the properties necessary for quantum computing. They did not discover the material itself, which was first synthesized in 1980.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, IVAN HARVEY
description: SCHWARTZ-Ivan Harvey. Happy Birthday, Cookie. Deeply missed today and every day. I will always love you. Your J Z

title: Top Institutions Heat Up Drives For Arts Funds
description: Though it has not been officially announced, the New York Public Library is embarking on a $430 million capital campaign to refurbish its structures, expand its programs and create a new $12 million humanities center, the largest fund-raising drive in the library's 102-year history.

title: Group Aims to Build Chain of Latin Banks
description: An investor group that includes units of the Blackstone Group and the Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had committed $350 million to a venture that will invest in financial services companies throughout Latin America.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A JURY'S MAKEUP -- Unlike in the first trial, the second Crown Heights jury is a diverse group spanning racial and religious lines. B3.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Patents column of Business Day on Jan. 20 about a new drug delivery system reversed two words in a quotation from Dr. Larry R. Brown, executive director of research at Epic Therapeutics Inc. Describing differences between Epic's drug delivery technology and others, he said: ''With other processes the final microsphere is generally 85 percent polymer and 15 percent drug. Ours is about 80 percent drug and 20 percent polymer.'' He did not say 80 percent polymer and 20 percent drug.

title: A Well-Matched Pair, Giving Money With an Intellectual Fervor
description: Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman, who have quietly pledged more than $80 million, mostly to civic and cultural institutions in New York City, are known as ''dream'' patrons.

title: Accounts
description: * C. B. Fleet Co., Lynchburg, Va., to Euro RSCG Tatham, Chicago, a unit of Havas Advertising, to handle Summer's Eve feminine-hygiene products, previously at Compton Partners, Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: Nettled Jordan Stings The Sonics
description: It was another vintage day in the career of Michael Jordan. The court was his stage. His jump shot was like radar. And another opponent was at his mercy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, JULIA
description: SPERLING-Julia. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Bernard and Gery. Adored grandmother of Andrea, Eugene, Caryn, Amy and Valerie. Services 10A M Monday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Vanishing Breed of Teacher: Ex-Police Officers
description: One wind-whipped Brooklyn morning, Francis Musto bundled up his third and fourth graders and ferried them out the door of Public School 345 for a carefully planned field trip. Not Ellis Island or the Museum of Natural History. Not Radio City Music Hall. Nothing like that.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Major Developments:

title: Mild-Mannered Comics Lover or Businessman of Steel?
description: While Ronald Perelman and Carl Icahn bicker over control of Marvel Entertainment in bankruptcy court, a comic-book titan from Baltimore has been soaring like Superman. Sidestepping the wreckage left by the predations of financially muscular outsiders, Steve Geppi has become a leading figure in the melodramatic world of comics by consolidating the lucrative distribution end of the industry.

title: Barry Offers Budget (Some See Politics Between Lines)
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today unveiled his proposed budget for 1998, a $3.3 billion spending plan that he said would balance the capital's budget for the first time in years while still invigorating the local economy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the legal difficulties of James J. Lysaght, a lawyer for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, referred incorrectly to records subpoenaed by the Federal authorities. While agents seized records from the union's law firm, Lysaght, Lysaght & Kramer, they have not seized any from the union itself.

title: People
description: * Adam Krumwiede was named vice president and media planning director at North Castle Partners, Stamford, Conn., assuming responsibilities from William P. Tucker, who left to join N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, a unit of MacManus Group, as senior vice president and media director. Mr. Krumwiede had been vice president and associate media director at DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, part of Omnicom Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, LOUIS H
description: KAUFMAN-Louis H. On February 2, at the age of 84. A lifelong New York City resident. Graduate of New York University School of Law and founding partner of the legal firm of Schneider, Kaufman & Sherman, P.C. He is survived by his beloved companion Liselotte (Judy) Langholtz, daughter Jaymee Brandt, grandchildren Adam and Keri Brandt, and sister Gussie. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, on Wednesday, February 5, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the National Asphia Association, PO Box 1887, Murray Hill Station, New York, NY, 10156.

title: Arrest in Endangerment
description: Three sisters between 2 and 5 years old were found yesterday morning wearing no coats and crying on a sidewalk in Flushing, Queens. The police arrested their grandmother on charges of endangering the welfare of a minor, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYNT, J. HOWARD III
description: JOYNT-J. Howard III on Saturday, February 1, 1997 of Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Carol Ross Joynt, father of Spencer Ross Joynt, J. Howard Joynt, IV and Christopher Michael Joynt. Brother of Martha Joynt Kumar. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, Inc, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue at Harrison Street, N.W. on Wednesday, February 5 from 6-9 PM. Memorial services will be held at Christ Church Georgetown, Episcopal, 31st and O Streets, N.W. on Thursday, February 27th, at 11:00 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Circle of the National Gallery of Art, 4th and Constitution Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20565 or the Medical Intensive Care Unit of the Washington Hospital Center, 110 Irving Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20010.

title: Musings and Digressions on Life's Absurdities
description: A SUPPOSEDLY FUN THING I'LL NEVER DO AGAIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORCH, WILLIAM (BILL)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGAN, ANNA
description: PAGAN-Anna. Beloved wife of the late Juan. Devoted mother of Muriel, Anne Macaluso and the late John. Loving grandmother of John, Patrica, Michael, Christopher, Daniel, Elisa and James Chrysanthis. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue, until 9 A.M. Mass of Christian Burial, Holy Rosary Church at 10 A.M. Farenga Bros. Inc, Directors.

title: Icahn Names His Advisers In RJR Battle
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn named his investment advisers yesterday for a proxy assault on the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, reiterating his intent to seek an immediate spinoff of the company's food business.

title: Stringer's Son to N.C. State
description: DAVID STRINGER, the son of the Rutgers women's basketball coach, C. VIVIAN STRINGER, announced yesterday that he has accepted a scholarship to play football at North Carolina State next season. Stringer, a 6-foot, 200-pound wide receiver and defensive back, played at North Brunswick High School in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWLES, CHANDLER R.
description: COWLES-Chandler R. On Feb. 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Pavlina Dokovska-Cowles. Loving father of Matthew and Christopher, and grandfather of Isabel and Lily. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, February 5, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84th Street, 11 AM. Interment private.

title: Building New Ideas From Familiar Songs
description: In the last few years, the nature of the remix has changed. No longer do these studio-altered versions of pop songs simply offer a way to dance longer to a tune. Instead, remixes often suggest new ways of listening to a song, challenge ideas about authorship and completion or create a completely new piece of music solely using sounds from the original. One in-demand musician, the Aphex Twin, says he only remixes only music that he doesn't like, so he can turn it into a song that he likes. On these four new albums, remixers breathe new life into familiar songs as well as creating provocative introductions to the work of lesser-known musicians.

title: Another Comeback? Gooden Thinks So
description: Every time Dwight Gooden hears himself referred to as a question mark for this season because of a suspect right shoulder, he either ignores the comments or uses them as motivation. Although Yankee Manager Joe Torre has conceded that the forecast for Gooden is hazy until he proves his shoulder is fine, Gooden sees things more clearly.

title: Giuliani Sees Tuition Plan Set for Fall
description: Just a few months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested that public school students could benefit from a private school education, his idea is on the verge of becoming reality. In September, at least 1,000 New York City public school students are expected to enter private schools, on scholarships raised from private sources. All that remains is the selection of the students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, HERBERT
description: LANE-Herbert. Our cherished uncle Herb-the kindest, most gentle and thoughtful man in the world. You were a special gift to all who knew you. We cannot believe that you are gone, but we will remember you and all our special times together forever. We love you now and always. Your nieces and nephews Robyn and Ken, Laurie and Charles

title: Juror's Service Challenged
description: Defense lawyers for the man accused of killing Megan Kanka in 1994 filed an appeal yesterday of a judge's decision to allow a man with close ties to United States Representative Richard A. Zimmer to remain in the jury pool.

title: Pogorelich Cancels
description: The pianist Ivo Pogorelich has canceled his concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Feb. 16, citing medical problems. Tickets may be exchanged or turned in for a refund at the box office. Information: (212) 875-5030.

title: 2 Firms Seeking Approval Of Lyme Disease Vaccines
description: Two drug companies are racing to get Federal approval to market a vaccine to fight Lyme disease, after they reported that separate human trials showed sufficiently positive results.

title: Stiffer Prison Terms Sought
description: Through work programs and credit for good behavior, prison inmates can reduce their sentence by as much as two-thirds. Yesterday, after hearing emotional appeals from crime victims, the Assembly Law and Public Safety Committee unanimously approved a plan to require people who commit the most serious offenses to serve 85 percent of their sentences before becoming eligible for parole.

title: Executive In Westchester Leaving Post After 14 Years
description: With characteristic banter but also some moments of sadness, Andrew P. O'Rourke announced today that he would not seek re-election as Westchester County Executive, a job he has held for 14 years.

title: Metro Digest
description: Major Developments: News Summaries, Page A2

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUBAREZ, RASHID A
description: MUBAREZ-Rashid A. February 4, 1962 to February 25, 1992. The light from your life continues to illuminate our lives. Love, Breck Joey and Waulene

description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Lenin's Palace Survives to Serve the Fittest
description: The Palace of Young Pioneers was one of those ideas that could have been born only in the brain of a Bolshevik.

title: Agencies Dissolve G.M. Partnership
description: A partnership formed in May between Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston and units of McCann-Erickson Worldwide to work on direct marketing assignments for the General Motors Corporation has been dissolved.

title: 3 Companies to Jointly Develop a Powerful Computer Chip
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Company, Hitachi Ltd. and Texas Instruments plan to jointly develop a computer memory chip capable of storing one billion bits of information, a spokesman for Mitsubishi said today.

title: Job Search Lures Mexicans to Far Corners of U.S.
description: Few places in the United States would seem less likely to attract Mexican migrant workers than Alaska.

title: ITT HARTFORD GROUP (HIG, NY)
description: The company said it earned $205 million, or $1.75 a share, in the quarter, up 45 percent, from $141 million, or $1.20 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELLIOTT ASSOCIATES L.P. New York, and its affiliates acquired a 6.46 percent stake in Envirodyne Industries of Oak Brook, Ill., for $6.2 million.

title: Less Invasive Biopsy
description: To the Editor:

title: PLASTECH ENGINEERED PRODUCTS IN DEAL FOR UNITED SCREW
description: The United Screw and Bolt Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Plastech Engineered Products Inc. for $128 million in cash. United Screw, of North Olmsted, Ohio, makes injection-molded plastic and metal stampings. Plastech, based in St. Clair Shores, Mich., makes plastic automotive parts. United Screw said completion of the deal was subject to a further study of its financial results by Plastech, the negotiation of a definitive agreement and certain government filings.

title: Umpires Pitching for Peaceful Coexistence
description: Where's the beef? Major league baseball's umpires say theirs is with the league presidents, not with the players. But it will become us versus them, umpires versus players, if the umpires prevail in their arguments at baseball's tripartite meeting today in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Clinton Praises Peru's Stand Over Hostages
description: After meeting with President Clinton at the White House, President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru said today that he was prepared to offer ''very narrow'' concessions to the rebels holding 72 diplomats and businessmen hostage in the Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima. But he said he would not discuss a larger peace agreement with them.

title: Incredible Shrinking Transistor Nears Its Ultimate Limit: The Laws of Physics
description: IT was just before Christmas in 1947 that a team of scientists at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., created the first transistor. Neither they nor anyone else knew where it would go. When the invention was unveiled publicly in 1948, it received scant attention. The New York Times ran a four-paragraph article saying the half-inch device had ''several applications in radio where a vacuum tube ordinarily is employed.''

title: AT&T Suffers Another Defection From Its Executive Ranks
description: In yet another high-level defection, Richard W. Miller, the chief financial officer of AT&T and an architect of its three-way split, resigned unexpectedly yesterday to pursue other interests.

title: In Her 19th Millrose, Clark Is Still Clicking
description: Joetta Clark, as fast as ever at age 34, remembers watching her first Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden.

title: China Eastern looks good on the surface, but look deeper.
description: WHEN a modern airline company pays its 18 most-senior executives an average of $5,500 a year, what does it get?

title: Rangers Are Not Prepared, Frustrated Campbell Says
description: Colin Campbell was desperate.

title: Facing Rough Times, Charles Wang Tries a New Style
description: Charles B. Wang, the chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates International, a man who at 52 is worth more than a billion dollars, has a pretty good jump shot. He always keeps the basketball low on his right side, as if poised to make a pass, then suddenly catapults the ball skyward. The ball often arcs neatly through the net.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: TENSIONS IN NEWARK -- 18 months after it began, the state takeover of Newark schools has left behind an increasingly divided system. B2.

title: Debt
description: * Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, is selling $250 million of medium-term notes due in 2002 through Bear, Stearns & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes, which are callable in three years, carry an interest rate of 6.500 percent and are priced at par.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAIRMONT, MAURICE M.
description: CLAIRMONT-Maurice M. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University note with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed friend, Maurice Clairmont of Geneva, Switzerland, on January 17, 1997. He was a member of the AFTAU Founders Circle of Friends and the International Board of Governors of Tel Aviv University. Dedicated to the development and education of Israeli musicians, he was a major supporter of the University's Samuel Rubin Academy of Music and recently established The Clairmont Hall, a new music auditorium. Through the Clairmont family's support of scholarships and competitions, countless musicians, performers and conductors have and will receive professional training at the worldrenowned Rubin Academy. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Angela, and his son, George, and family. Melvin S. Taub Chairman, Board of Directors Robert J. Topchik, President Jules Love Executive Vice President

title: To Forget No Cranny, Filigree or Flourish
description: It is hardly unusual for a singer to seduce a recital audience with a beautifully produced tone; that is, after all, a crucial part of the job, and it yields a purely visceral thrill that is enough to satisfy a great many concertgoers. A truly moving performance, though -- the kind a listener mentally retraces on the way home in the hope of holding onto it for a while longer -- works its magic by making the connections between the poet's text, the composer's setting and the singer's phrasing seem both surprising and inevitable.

title: Accounts
description: * Saab Japan, Tokyo, a unit of Saab Automobile A.B., to McCann-Erickson Tokyo, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account had been handled by the Nippo Agency, Tokyo, when Saab distributed cars in Japan through local dealers; the company now works through the Japanese arm of the General Motors Corp., a mainstay McCann client. McCann also handles Saab in other Asian-Pacific markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUBRY, CHARLES GEORGES
description: AUBRY-Charles Georges. Age 82. Of Greenwood, VA, formerly of Yonkers, NY and Greenwich, CT. Died February 2, 1997. Funeral services Wednesday, 12 Noon, Emmanuel Episcopal Church, Greenwood. Contributions may be made to Cardwell Cancer Care Center, Martha Jefferson Hospital, Charlottesville, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, HARRY
description: WACHTEL-Harry. With profound sorrow we mark the passing of a man whose life was dedicated to freedom, justice and civil rights for all and was filled with pleasures shared with family and friends. His warmth and caring will be deeply missed by his wife Lucy; children Alan, Susanna and Bill; daughtersin-law Ellen and Katherine; grandchildren Carly, Nicholas, Jesse, Jonathan, Madeline, Branden; family, friends and colleagues. The memorial service will be on Wednesday, February 5, 4 PM at Unitarian Universalist Congregation, 48 Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset. Contributions may be made to the Harry Wachtel Fund for the Study of Non-Violent Social Change at Hofstra University.

title: A Vast Journey on a Single Keyboard
description: Sometimes a jazz musician need only gain special mastery of one element in the triad of melody, harmony and rhythm, and the rest falls into place. Such is the case with the pianist Randy Weston, who gave a solo concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center on Friday night. Mr. Weston has created his own rhythm-based idiom encapsulating much of jazz history, including elements from Africa and the Caribbean.

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column in the Styles pages on Sunday, about ''city hall'' weddings, misidentified the site of such ceremonies in New York City. It is actually the Municipal Building, not City Hall.

title: January Car Sales Up 2.3%; Foreign Makers Have Surge
description: Foreign auto makers showed the biggest sales gains in the American auto market last month as the strong dollar continued to help them offer generous lease deals and low prices.

title: Couture Skips the Revolution
description: It could be argued that nearly every major designer breakthrough of the last 50 years has been based on a new take on the suit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, ESTHER
description: WEINBERGER - Esther, died peacefully Feb. 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Loving mother to Lucienne and Jonathan (Jane). Cherished grandmother to David. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, 16th Street and First Avenue, New York, New York 10003.

title: MOTOROLA COMPUTER BUSINESS SPLITS INTO TWO DIVISIONS
description: The computer unit of Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it had reorganized into two divisions, one of which will sell Macintosh clones, portables and servers, while the other will sell components to other manufacturers. The computer unit said each division would be responsible for its own profitability and each would have its own engineering, sales, marketing, finance and human resource operations, effective immediately. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., is a maker of semiconductors, advanced electronics systems and wireless communications equipment. The company would not disclose current sales for the computer group. Shares of Motorola fell $1.50 yesterday, to $66.75.

title: UConn Guard's Return Is Not Quite Enough
description: Connecticut's sophomore point guard, Ricky Moore, returned from a five-game suspension to a standing ovation from a capacity crowd of 15,842 at the Hartford Civic Center tonight. But during the first half, Connecticut fans at the Huskies' home away from home had little to cheer about as UConn shot 25 percent and fell behind, 28-19.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, DAVID
description: BERGER-David. On February 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Mali. Loving father of Myron (Mike) and Roger. Father-in-law of Sumie and Gail. Beloved grandfather of Matthew, Paul and Mai. Brother of Ralph and Thea. Services today 1:30 P.M., at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, ELI
description: BLOOM-Eli. The directors and members of the Greater New York Automobile Dealers Association mourn the loss of director and past-president Eli Bloom. We will all miss his companionship, as well as his leadership as chairman of the long range planning committee. Eli was an extraordinary and giving member of the community who dedicated many years to the service of the Association, and to the greater community. We will miss his warmth, his intellect, and his humanity. We extend our most sincere condolences to his family, friends, and associates. Douglas Callahan, President Mark Schienberg, Executive V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, MARGARET
description: DEUTSCH-Margaret. The family of Margaret Deutsch mourns her passing on February 2. Beloved wife of the late David Deutsch, beloved mother of Gerald, the late Ronald, and Robert. Beloved grandmother of Gayle, Daniel, Jonathan, and Stacey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEXAUER, JAMES MONROE
description: SEXAUER-James Monroe, of West Palm Beach, Florida, died on Friday, January 24, 1997, at his home, following an extended illness. Mr. Sexauer had been a resident of the Palm Beach area since 1991, coming here from Harrison, NY. Born July 21, 1896 in Belvidere, IL, he was one of seven children born to John and Lena Bleiler Sexauer. On July 15, 1935 he married Dorothy Bohan at the Church of the Transfiguration in NYC. Mr. Sexauer was a graduate of the University of Illinois and a member of Sigma Chi Fraternity. He joined the J.A. Sexauer Manufacturing Company in 1923, which was founded by his brother John A. Sexauer in 1921. He succeeded his brother as President and Chairman of the Board of Directors in 1971. In 1976 he sold the Company to the Dyson-Kissner Corporation. At the time of his death, Mr. Sexauer was President and Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Sexauer Foundation. He was a member of St. John Episcopal Church in Larchmont, NY and was a member of the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, New York from 1929 until 1992. Survivors include his wife, Dorothy B. Sexauer of West Palm Beach, FL; a daughter, Nancy Sexauer Walsh of Palm Beach, FL and his grandson, James R. Walsh of NYC. A Memorial Service will be held at 2:00 PM on Thursday, February 6, 1997 at St. John Episcopal Church in Larchmont, New York, with the Reverend Thomas Nichols, Rector, officiating. Inurnment will follow in the Columbarium at St. John's Church. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to the Sexauer Foundation, c/o Mr. Wesley G. Cawley, Palm Beach National Bank & Trust Company, 125 Worth Avenue, Palm Beach, FL 33480. For information, Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVA, MARX
description: LEVA-Marx, Sunday, February 2, 1997, of Bethesda, MD. Beloved husband of Shirley Pearlman Leva, M.D. Father of Lloyd Leva Plaine of Bethesda, MD and the late Leo Marx Leva, M.D. Brother of Isabelle Leva Sterne of Birmingham, AL. He is also survived by his nephew, Marx Sterne and his family of Arlington, VA. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, Inc., 5130 Wisconsin Avenue at Harrison Street, N.W., Tuesday from 4-8 PM. Interment private. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to: So Others Might Eat, 71 O Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20001 or Jewish Social Service Agency Community Hospice, 22 C Montgomery Village Avenue, Gaithersburg, MD. 20879 or the Nature Conservancy, 1815 North Lynn Street, Arlington, VA. 22209.

description: Esprit Shifts Its Focus

title: Top Enlisted Man in the Army Stands Accused of Sex Assault
description: A 22-year Army veteran has accused her former boss, who is the Army's top-ranking enlisted soldier and a member of the commission charged with reviewing the Army's sexual harassment policies, of sexually assaulting her in her hotel room during an official trip to Hawaii in April. She says at least one senior Army officer then tried to cover up the incident.

title: Frustrated, The Jets Interview Belichick
description: As the Patriots introduced their new coach, Pete Carroll, yesterday, the Jets became increasingly frustrated by the refusal of the New England owner Robert K. Kraft to soften his demand for their No. 1 draft pick in exchange for his old coach, Bill Parcells.

description: To the Editor:

description: Albright and Her Heritage

title: Unneeded Lab Chimps Face Hazy Future
description: Hands and feet gently slapping concrete, Chandra and Shasta come loping down their sunny outdoor run at the complex operated by the Coulston Foundation here. The little apes do not look up when the black triangle of a Stealth fighter knifes across the sky above them and banks for a landing at a nearby runway.

title: Theodoros Stamos, 74, Abstract Painter, Dies
description: Theodoros Stamos, a precocious member of Abstract Expressionism's first generation and a prominent figure in a trial that rocked the art world in the 1970's, died on Sunday at the Hatsikosta Hospital in Yiannina, Greece, which he entered 12 days ago. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan and on the island of Lefkada, Greece.

title: Investing in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Move for Simpson Mistrial Is Rejected Again
description: Arguing that the case had been tainted beyond repair by the lies of a dismissed juror, the defense in the wrongful-death civil suit against O. J. Simpson moved for a second time today for a mistrial, only to be turned down again by the court.

title: Padilla Fights to Recover After Being Hit by a Car
description: Last June 19, Doug Padilla left his home here in late afternoon for a five-mile run. He would have preferred to be in Atlanta, at the Olympic trials, but he had missed the qualifying time for 5,000 meters. So he had turned his attention to masters competitions, in which he could compete when he turned 40 in four months.

title: On-Line Guide to New York Is Bought by Internet Giant
description: In a continuing consolidation of startup Internet companies in Manhattan, WP Studio, producers of Total New York, a popular on-line guide to the city, has been bought by a company that is 80 percent owned by America Online and that offers similar guides in more than a dozen cities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: A Pole's Work on Its Own Terms
description: Most talk about recent composers ends up a search for connections. What are the models? Where do the methods come from? What schools of style embrace or expel this music or that? Witold Lutoslawski's Fourth Symphony is a little different. It inspires personal words: confidence, patience, the self-assurance that music laid out at its own pace will lengthen the short attention span and deeply satisfy the longer one. Regardless of the style in use -- and Lutoslawski used a lot of different ones -- it is a composer we are hearing, not a unit of historical progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, STANLEY
description: GORDON-Stanley. Combining a huge heart, gentle irreverence and a gift for forming lasting relationships, he provided guidance, hope and opportunity to hundreds of students and colleagues. After a successful career in business he worked for the pure pleasure of helping students he treated as family members. Unrestrained by long standing health problems he was a tireless presence at school, community meetings and each venue where new resources for students could be found. His legacy will be an unparalleled standard for supporting young adults with wisdom, energy and love. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held at the school on Thursday, March 13 at 4 P.M. Howard Friedman, Principal Faculty, Staff and Students of Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School

title: Pamela Harriman Ill, Paris Embassy Says
description: Pamela Harriman, the United States Ambassador to France, collapsed on Monday night in Paris and was hospitalized, an Embassy spokesman said.

title: Company to Leave Mercer
description: Mercer County, which has lost thousands of jobs since four companies announced two years ago that they were shutting down, was dealt another blow yesterday when Delphi Interior and Lighting Systems, a division of General Motors, said it would close next year.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, GERRY
description: MORRIS-Gerry. The Officers, Governors and Members of The New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Gerry Morris on February 2, 1997. He was a dedicated contributor to the Friars Epistle. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be at a later date. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Exec. Dir.

title: Executive Changes
description: STATEWIDE FINANCIAL CORP., Jersey City, named Michael J. Griffin president and chief operating officer of its Statewide Savings Bank unit, succeeding Clifford Adams, who resigned.

title: Honor for Haskins and Carril
description: Don Haskins of Texas-El Paso and Pete Carril of Princeton, two college coaches who have left major imprints on the sport, were elected yesterday to the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass.

title: The Truth About Steve Biko
description: When South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission began work last April, the widow of Steve Biko feared it could grant amnesty to the people who murdered her husband in 1977. Last week five policemen said they had killed Mr. Biko, and they will probably get amnesty in return. But Mrs. Biko got something she had long been denied -- the truth. For decades the apartheid Government insisted that her husband had committed suicide or died accidentally in a struggle with police. His killers will now confess on national television to this and several other notorious murders.

title: Rancor Over Newark Schools
description: After 18 months of operating New Jersey's largest school district, Dr. Beverly Hall, the state-appointed superintendent, and her advisory board are viewed by some parents and teachers as an occupying army whose promises of liberating the Newark district from two decades of mismanagement, corruption and unresponsiveness have turned sour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, PHILIP
description: CHASIN-Philip. The Board of Directors and the staff of the City College Fund record with deep regret the passing of Philip Chasin. A member of the Class of 1931, Mr. Chasin was an honorary member of The Board of Directors and one of the founders of the City College Fund. An authority in his profession, he will be missed by all who knew him. Stanley H. Kaplan '39 Chairman Seymour L. Gartenberg '52 President Gerald C. Crane '59 Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCQUAID, JAMES A
description: McQUAID-James A. On February 2, 1997. Retired V.P. of U.S. Lines. Devoted husband of the late Margaret, beloved father of Peter and Maureen, dear brother of Ellen Cundari and Ann Capone. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 65 East 89th St, Thursday, 11 AM. Interment to follow at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Lupus Foundation, 149 Madison Avenue, Suite 205, NYC 10016.

title: Germ War, a Current World Threat, Is a Remembered Nightmare in China
description: When the history of the 20th century is written and the great terrors, exterminations and genocides are fully documented, a grisly footnote will have to be appended from this tiny hamlet in southeastern China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICHETTO, STEPHEN
description: PICHETTO-Stephen. Died Feb. 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Maura. Brother of the late Audrey Andrepont. Uncle of Paul, Cherie and John. Visiting hours on Tuesday, Feb. 4, from 2-4 PM, and 7-9 PM, at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, at West 261st St, Riverdale, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, Feb. 5, at 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, 6000 Riverdale Avenue. Interment at the Pichetto family mausoleum at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

description: ALLEN-Jared David. We will love you forever. We will miss you for always. Grandma Fay, Grandpa Allen, Aunt Sheila, Uncle Jeff, Gregory and Greer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILDNER, BENJAMIN
description: BILDNER-Benjamin. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the loss of a beloved, colorful figure in the annals of the Weizmann Family, often remembered as the founder of the ''Big Ben'' supermarket chain in Long Island. After a lifetime of generous support of the Institute & of many American and Israeli philanthropic causes, he died in retirement in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, at the age of 104. Benjamin Bildner was proud to share his devotion to the Weizmann Institute with his son, Albert, distinguished member of the Board of Governors of the Institute and of its Executive Council and Honorary Vice Chairman of its American Committee. We extend heartfelt condolences to Benjamin Bildner's dear son Albert and daughter-in-law Lin Ilusorio Bildner, and his cherished sister Rebecca Shulman. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Insitute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Robert G. Begam, President Fran Ginsburg, Exec Director Bernard N. Samers, Exec VP Emeritus

title: For 'Sunset Boulevard,' It's the End of the Road
description: A theatrical titan has toppled. ''Sunset Boulevard,'' the $12 million Andrew Lloyd Webber musical that won a Tony for best musical in 1995 and made a musical star of Glenn Close, will close on March 22 after 977 regular performances and 17 previews at the Minskoff Theater.

title: Dutch Food Concern Buys Illinois Baker
description: CSM N.V., a Dutch food and food ingredients maker, said yesterday that it had bought Karp's Inc., which specializes in bakery products, for an undisclosed sum. The deal was first announced in December.

title: Fordham Falls Victim to Travieso and Co.
description: Three guards were one too many for Fordham last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, SYLVIA (NEEDLEMAN)
description: LERNER-Sylvia (Needleman). Of Freehold, NJ, on February 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herman (1989), devoted mother of Barbara Kopel (Marlboro, NJ), and Ellen Glass (Richmond, VA.). Dear mother-in-law of Brian Glass and Steve Kopel, loving grandmother of Jeff, Seth and Kathy Tieger, Tara and Hera Kopel and adored great-grandmother of Chad Michael Tieger. Services ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffers Memorial Chapel'', 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday 12 Noon. The period of Shiva will be observed at the Kopel residence Marlboro, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFFRICH, STOCKTON
description: HELFFRICH-Stockton. A wise, principled man and concerned citizen. witty and warm, he will be sorely missed by his wife Maxie, children Richard H., Richard K., Jackie, Scott, John and grandchildren Glenn, Preston, Jeffrey and Jean. Memorial gathering Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 Street, Thursday, Feb 6, 5PM.

title: Let Mammography Debate Be Guided by Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Phenomenon Walks
description: The burghers smile and bow as he strides the street, the urban peasantry on their way to work or already at it digging holes shout merry greetings, coachmen stand in their carriages to wave and the very horses nod respectfully.

title: King Family Seeks Trial for Ray Before He Dies With His Secrets
description: Twenty-nine years is a long time to wonder. Yet how much worse, for the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., if the mystery stretches into forever.

title: Top Systems, Not Saviors, Save Teams
description: PETE CARROLL was named coach of the New England Patriots yesterday and announced himself not as a cook who must purchase the groceries but as a relationship kind of guy who doesn't mind pushing the cart the way he does for his wife.

title: Sunday's Upsets Prompt Second Looks
description: On both coasts today, the trainers of Kentucky Derby candidates victimized in Sunday's two upsets tended to excuse their colts' performances, but it was clear they were distressed at the setbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDAH, JUDGE SABRI
description: KANDAH-Judge Sabri. Husband of the late Margot. Service Thursday, 6:30PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial will follow in Israel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Imported Cars Show Gains, But Domestic Models Ebb

title: Privatization's Perils: Grounded in Venezuela
description: The future of Venezuela's flagship, and currently grounded, airline is awaiting a vote by its workers on a $55 million effort by the majority owners, the Venezuelan Government and Iberia Air Lines of Spain, to rescue it from bankruptcy.

title: Mr. Pataki's Moonlighting
description: New York's Governor, George Pataki, is following the bad example of his predecessor, Mario Cuomo, by supplementing his state income with speaking fees. This lecture sideline, no matter how it is organized, invites conflict-of-interest problems and distracts the state's highest official from his primary duties. Moreover, by failing to make his moonlighting public, Mr. Pataki has made an undesirable practice worse.

title: Netanyahu Sees Pope, Looking To Jerusalem
description: After meeting for the first time, Pope John Paul II and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel promised today in the Vatican to meet again ''as soon as possible'' in Jerusalem.

title: Albany Democrats Want to Put Campaign Records on Computer
description: For years, New York State's system of filing campaign contribution records has been considered one of the most cumbersome and archaic in the country. Every several months, thousands of typed or hand-scribbled pages are filed with the state, creating a mountain of paperwork that defies efforts by state auditors, government watchdog groups, reporters and even candidates themselves to track the flow of money through the state's political system.

title: In Address to Governors, Lott Opposes Medicaid Plan
description: Even while pledging to work with President Clinton in a bipartisan spirit, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said today that he opposed Mr. Clinton's proposal to set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending. He also said there was little money available to fix the new welfare law in ways sought by the President.

title: Unlock Family Planning Funds
description: Responding to pressure from anti-abortion activists, Congress has put so many restrictions on spending for international family planning programs that, according to the Clinton Administration, millions of people in developing countries are being denied access to contraceptives. America's role in population planning has thus been transformed from generous benefactor to parsimonious scold. The new Congress has a chance to turn matters around.

title: Hun Lacks Seriosity
description: These are serious times. On every side we are beset by serious people being extremely serious about serious matters. Last week, for example, I had a call from Attila the Hun's press agent. I said cut the kidding.

title: UNITED STATES FILTER TO ACQUIRE A WHEELABRATOR UNIT
description: The United States Filter Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.'s EOS unit for stock valued at $77.4 million, expanding its waste-water treatment systems and services business. Wheelabrator EOS Inc., which manages water, waste-water and groundwater treatment operations, had 1996 revenue of $55 million. The two companies also agreed to a joint marketing agreement between United States Filter and the Wheelabrator Bio Gro business. Shares of United States Filter, based in Palm Desert, Calif., fell $1.25 yesterday, to $37.125. Wheelabrator declined 25 cents, to $16.625. Wheelabrator Technologies, a subsidiary of WMX Technologies Inc., is based in Hampton, N.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLINOFF, JEANNE L.
description: GELLINOFF-Jeanne L., February 3, in her 93rd year. Beloved wife of the late Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff, cherished mother of Judy and Fred Levy and Joan and David Masket, adored grandmother of Jane (Alan) Neustadter, Steven (Elaine) Masket, Mary-Ellen (David) Stein, Nancy (Richard) Conti, Elizabeth (Jonathan) Sommer, Dr. Andrew (Lisa) Levy, and proud great-grandmother of 15, devoted sister of Ruth (Barney) Cohen and Dr. Morton Lepler (Trude) and sister-in-law of Silvia (Michael) Brodzinsky. A beautiful and gentle woman, truly loved by all who knew her. Service 12:30 PM, Tuesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam.

title: Quirks, Oddities May Be Illnesses
description: THEY may sound like nothing more than personality quirks -- a working mother who is competent and controlled at her job but explodes at home when small things go wrong or a computer programmer who is the ultimate loner, sitting hunched over his terminal night and day.

title: Outsider Put At the Helm Of Mercury
description: The job of leading the Mercury Finance Company's struggle to avoid bankruptcy was handed over today to William A. Brandt Jr., an outside corporate turnaround specialist who was brought in last week after the auto loan company disclosed that its reported earnings had been improperly inflated for several years.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES TO PURCHASE GERSTENSLAGER
description: Worthington Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Gerstenslager Company from JMAC, an investment company controlled by John H. McConnell, Worthington chairman emeritus, for about $113 million in stock. Gerstenslager, of Wooster, Ohio, makes automotive body panels, and has annual sales of about $120 million. Worthington Industries, of Columbus, Ohio, makes metal and plastics products. Its shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $18.75.

title: Taco Bell joins the industry shake-up with a review, and there's nothing ordinary about it.
description: THE changes in the volatile realm of fast-food advertising are coming faster than burgers or burritos pushed out double drive-through windows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONATI, JUDGE ALFRED, JR.
description: DONATI-Judge Alfred, Jr. We are deeply saddened and mourn the loss of our dear friend and former colleague, Judge Alfred Donati, Jr. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Bonnie and members of his family The Robert M. Morgenthau Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURT, WILLIAM C.
description: BURT-William C. Kane Lodge #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONNER, GLADYS
description: RONNER-Gladys. On February 3, 1997. Beloved wife of Irving. Cherished mother of Madeleine Kaufman and Dr. Hilary Ronner. Devoted mother-in-law of Dr. Stephen Kaufman and Ron Feiman. Adored Nana of Justin, Craig, Kimberly and Jed. Graveside service.

title: Benazir Bhutto Loses Badly To Longtime Pakistan Rival
description: A 47-year-old industrialist who last headed Pakistan's Government from 1990 to 1993 appeared today to be headed for a landslide victory in elections on Monday, substantial returns indicated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DITCHIK, FLORENCE LEDER (DIXON)
description: DITCHIK-Florence Leder (Dixon), 92, died peacefully at home on February 2, 1997, surrounded by loved ones. Survived and beloved by sons: Donald, Richard and Stephen Dixon; daughters Marguerite (Bunny) Franco and Pat Dixon. Daughters-in-law Gerald, Irma and Anne; dear friend Sonia Sealey; fifteen grandchildren and thirteen great grandchildren all of whom loved her and were loved by her. She was predeceased by her husband Dr. Abraham M. Ditchik and children James and Carole Dixon. Services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, SY
description: WEISSMAN-Sy. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses sincere condolences to our member, Marilyn Weissman, and family on the loss of her beloved husband. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mark Spund, President Yehudah Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Mutual Fund Concern Feels Impact of Lender's Default
description: Strong Capital Management last week repurchased millions of dollars of short-term commercial paper issued by the Mercury Finance Company, the troubled consumer auto lender, from three of its popular money market funds to keep the funds from losing money on the notes.

title: Judgment Against ABC for Use Of Hidden Cameras Is Reversed
description: ABC News, which has lost several court cases related to hidden camera investigative reports, had one of those judgments overturned in its favor yesterday.

title: Baggy Jeans Are Last Issue In Rights Trial
description: In a theatrical finale to the defense's case, the man accused in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew in the Crown Heights racial violence paced before a Brooklyn jury yesterday in the baggy jeans the authorities say he wore during the attack, only to have the pants slide down below his knees.

title: Sweaters of Spring
description: Sweaters are a year-round fashion. They just get smaller and lighter in weight for spring.

title: Supervision of Troopers Faulted In Evidence-Tampering Scandal
description: Concluding a four-year investigation into the worst scandal in state police history, a special prosecutor said today that troopers were able to plant evidence routinely in criminal cases across a broad swath of rural New York because they had no fear of detection by supervisors, who maintained a willful ignorance.

title: Oratory vs. Really Talking About Culture
description: These are some of the words that were used and abused at Town Hall last week in that much-publicized discussion between a prominent critic and a prominent playwright: art, culture, race, ideology, Europeans, Africans, slavery and freedom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, NORMAN A.
description: JACKSON-Norman A., February 3, 1997, of West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Edith. Devoted father of Ruth Albert, Lois Scheir, Judith Beckwith and Roger. Cherished grandfather of thirteen and great-grandfather of four. Loving brother of Louis. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer,'' Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York. Interment in Mount Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The last time Capt. MARK PHILLIPS was married, in 1973, it was to Princess Anne, in Westminster Abbey. That ceremony was watched by television viewers around the world. On Saturday, Captain Phillips, 48, wed again, this time on a beachfront in Hawaii. The bride: SANDY PFLUEGER, 47, an equestrian member of the 1984 United States Olympic team, who became a British citizen last year. Captain Phillips is a horse trainer who manages the United States equestrian team.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, ROBERT J.
description: DAVIS-Robert J., on Thursday, February 6, 4 P.M., at the Parish House, 12 West 11th Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRIAM, LOUIS T., JR.
description: MERRIAM-Louis T., Jr. of Darien, CT., on February 1, 1997. Husband of Marjorie H. Merriam. Father of Frances Marsillio, Anne Jones, Thayer Sifers, Julie Kamp, and Dr. Louis T. Merriam III. Brother of Robert L. Merriam. Grandfather of twelve. Memorial services will be held at Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT., on Friday, February 7, 1997 at 11:00 AM. Contributions may be made to Darien Public Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: Mets Hire Keith Hernandez
description: The former All-Star first baseman Keith Hernandez, a winner of 11 Gold Gloves, ended a seven-year retirement from baseball yesterday when he rejoined the Mets as an instructor.

title: California Floods Change Thinking on Need to Tame Rivers
description: NOW that the raging floodwaters that made California's Central Valley an inland sea last month have largely receded, a debate about the lessons of the floods is under way among scientists, environmentalists, planners and politicians.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY WALLACE AUTOMOTIVE
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wallace Automotive Group for about $55 million in stock, the latest acquisition by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga, who has created the nation's largest chain of new-car dealerships. Wallace operates six dealerships in southeast Florida: two for Lincoln-Mercury and one each for Ford, Nissan, Dodge and Mitsubishi. Wallace could add about $300 million in revenue to a new-car dealership group that is expected to have revenue of $2.8 billion this year. Shares of Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., fell 50 cents yesterday, to $41.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORENBERG, DAVID
description: GORENBERG-David, Feb. 2, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Mary and Lee. Father of Alvin Goren and Eli Gorenberg. Grandfather of 6. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, Tuesday, 11:30 A.M.

title: Dole Looks Back, Asking What If They Knew More?
description: In his first extensive interview since losing the Presidential race, Bob Dole said today that his wife, Elizabeth, might run for President in 2000 and that if more details about Democratic fund raising had come out before the election, he might have won.

title: Albright Learns That She Lost 3 Ancestors in the Holocaust
description: In the weeks since President Clinton nominated her to be Secretary of State, the history of Madeleine K. Albright's early life in Czechoslovakia amid the tumult of World War II has become a familiar one. And the story of how her family came to America, fleeing first the Nazis and then the Communists, has been invoked from the White House to Capitol Hill as an inspiration and a metaphor.

title: CKS Group Buys McKinney & Silver
description: CKS Group in Cupertino, Calif., said yesterday that it had acquired McKinney & Silver, a midsize creatively focused agency in Raleigh, N.C., for about $24 million in stock.

title: Four A's Nominates Officers for 1997-98
description: Two executives have been nominated to serve as the 1997-98 leaders of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELL, HERBERT H.
description: ZELL-Herbert H., age 74, beloved husband of Carol, devoted father of Judy and Michael. Dear brother of Frances Horn and the late Edward Zell. He was a Vice President of design and merchandising for his own company, in addition to various other mens' sportswear companies. He retired December, 1994 at the age of 72. Services are today, 1:00 PM at Schoem Chapel, 150 Route 4E, Paramus. Mourning period observed at the Zell residence through Sunday, February 9. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Association or the American Cancer Society.

title: Far From Quiet on the Computer Game Front
description: LET'S play a game.

title: Narrator of Mailer's Next Novel: Jesus
description: The newest offering from Norman Mailer, a writer who is nothing if not ambitious, is a 225-page novel in the first person about Jesus Christ. The novel, called "The Gospel According to the Son," is to be published in May.

title: MetroStars Improve Their Midfield
description: The MetroStars will fly to Italy today, for five weeks of training and exhibition games, with an improved midfield.

title: More Jobs, More Seekers
description: New York City's unemployment rate rose to 8.7 percent in December, up from 8.5 percent in November, the State Department of Labor said. The state's unemployment rate also inched up, climbing from 5.7 to 5.8 percent over the same period.

title: Mix Comedy and Politics With Strange Bedfellows, Then Hope for Sparks
description: Bill Maher grew up wanting to be his generation's Johnny Carson. Now, at age 41, he has made it into the late-night spotlight. His topical talk show, ''Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher,'' just moved to ABC.

title: Falsely Accused in Death Of Son, Man Fights Back
description: For 18 months, Edward Lauer, a subway conductor, walked around his neighborhood in Maspeth, Queens with hot coals burning in his heart. His only child, 3-year-old Andrew, was dead. A city medical examiner had ruled the death a homicide from injuries to the brain and neck. And the chief suspect was Mr. Lauer.

title: A Wash of Impressionism For a Visit by the French
description: Hearing the Cleveland Orchestra on three consecutive evenings may not have been the kindest way to prepare for the concert by the Orchestre National de France at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon. Almost any ensemble would have suffered by comparison; what was fascinating was how this one did, with so many qualities stereotypically deemed French -- grace, elegance, refinement, sophistication, precision, clarity -- falling to the Cleveland side of the equation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SYLVIA
description: MILLER-Sylvia, 97, on February 2, 1997 at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. Formerly a resident of Great Neck, beloved wife of the late Irving Miller, devoted mother of Jack and his wife Gladys, Alfred and his wife Joan, Arnold and his wife Linda, loving grandmother of David, Barbara, Wendy, Paul and his wife Donna, Asher and Tamara, and adoring great-grandmother of Marc. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 5, at 2 P.M., at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 15 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR Station.

title: Lawrence A. Fleischman, 71, an Art Dealer
description: Lawrence A. Fleischman, chairman and chief executive officer of Kennedy Galleries in Manhattan, an authority on American art from the 18th through 20th centuries and a major collector of antiquities, died on Friday at his home in London. He was 71 and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Sanford Meisner, a Mentor Who Guided Actors and Directors Toward Truth, Dies at 91
description: Sanford Meisner, one of the most influential American acting teachers of this century and for decades the director of the celebrated Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theater in Manhattan, died on Sunday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 91.

title: Trader Sentenced in China Bond Scandal
description: Two years ago, the same week that Barings P.L.C. was brought down by huge losses attributed to a rogue trader, an eerily similiar fate befell Shanghai's leading securities firm at the time, Shanghai International Securities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEFING, HENRY O.
description: WEFING-Henry O., on Saturday, Feb. 1, 1997, of Kearny, NJ. A former writer, editor and assistant news director with CBS News, NYC. Loving husband of Freda (Heiart). Beloved father of Henry O., Jr. and John B. Dear brotherin-law of Jane Heiart. Grandfather of 5. Funeral Wednesday, Feb. 5, 8:30 AM from the E.T. Reid Home for Funerals, 585 Belgrove Drive, Kearny, New Jersey, with a 9:30 AM, Mass St. Stephen's Church, Kearny, NJ. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, N. Arlington, New Jersey. Visitation Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Peter's Preparatory School, 144 Grand Street, Jersey City, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH
description: BERGER-Ruth. Child Development Research mourns the untimely passing of a beloved, dedicated volunteer. Drs. Judith Kestenberg, Eva Fogelman, Helene BassWichelhaus, Edith Laufer, Joe Glick and Susan Charney

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREYER, DOROTHY JENSEN
description: DREYER-Dorothy Jensen, on February 2, 1997 of Manhattan, NY. Beloved wife of the late John Jensen and the late Leo Dreyer. Dear sister of Claire Rollins, John H. Hoertz, M.D. & Paul G. Hoertz. Cherished niece of Barbara Byrne, Jean Delaney, Sr. Grace Regina, O.P. and Mary Ferrar. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons East Islip Funeral Home, 200 East Main Street (1/2 mile west of S.S. Parkway, exit 45W). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Queen of the Rosary, 555 Albany Ave, Amityville, LI, on Wednesday 10:30 AM. Interment Saint John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. Visiting Tuesday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30.

title: Despite a World-Class Economy, a Nation Senses Decline
description: During the dirt-poor years after the Korean War, South Koreans were exhorted to extend the lives of pencils by attaching sticks to stubs that had become too short to grip.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: St. John's

title: Rancor Grows Over State's Role in Schools
description: After 18 months of operating New Jersey's largest school district, Dr. Beverly Hall, the state-appointed superintendent, and her advisory board are viewed by some parents and teachers as an occupying army whose promises to liberate the district from two decades of mismanagement, corruption and unresponsiveness have turned sour.

title: False Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, BRIAN R.
description: GREENE-Brian R., of New City, New York, on February 3, 1997. Husband of Arline. Father of Michael and Gregory Greene, Carolyn McGoldrick, Diane Faranetta, and Linda Greene. Grandfather of Jake Faranetta. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 AM, St. Augustine's Church, New City, NY. Burial Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY. Visiting Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main Street, New City, NY, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E
description: INNISS-Charles E. The members of the Board of Trustees of the Catholic Interracial Council are deeply saddened by the death of Charles E. Inniss, our devoted and spirited leader for more than 15 years, serving both as President and a member of the Board. His sophisticated understanding, quiet manner, humanitarian concern and generosity profoundly influenced the scope of the Council. He was an inspiration to all of us as he worked tirelessly to promote justice, social equality and racial harmony. His warmth and kindness will be remembered always. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved Marjorie and family. Gerald W. Lynch, President The Catholic Interracial Council

title: America Online Cutting Off Inactive Users
description: In an attempt to clear up network delays, America Online Inc. has begun monitoring individual subscribers and disconnecting those who do not appear to be using the service.

title: Dinkins, in Africa, Says He'll Decide Soon on Mayoral Bid
description: Former Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City said today that he would probably decide within two weeks whether he would challenge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in this year's election.

title: Still No Cases In Arbitration
description: Baseball clubs and players, doing their best to avoid salary arbitration hearings, reached two more settlements yesterday.

title: 3 NATIONS AGREE ON FREEZING GOLD LOOTED BY NAZIS
description: The United States, Britain and France have agreed to freeze the distribution of $68 million in gold bars that were looted by the Nazis from European central banks, and Clinton Administration officials say the gold could form the core of a fund to compensate Holocaust victims.

title: Californian Is Charged With Leading Bomb Plot
description: A small-time rap music promoter surrendered to the police this afternoon and was charged here with hiring two men to bomb a county court building and a police evidence room, in an apparent attempt to block his pending trial in a drug case that could have brought him a life prison term under California's three-strikes sentencing law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRICKLER, JACK
description: STRICKLER-Jack. Beloved husband of Maya. Devoted father of Miriam Cybul and father-in-law of Martin Cybul. Dear brother of Cyla Brudner and David. Loving grandfather of Brandt, Mathew and Katie. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Wednesday about the newly formed Doris Duke Charitable Foundation misstated the amount of money it will give out each year. While it will dispense at least $17.3 million this year, that figure will rise to at least $50 million beginning next year.

title: B.C. and B.U. Advance In a Combative Beanpot
description: College players do not get to skate in a big arena like the Fleet Center often, and tonight, as the 45th annual Beanpot Tournament got under way, a few of them acted as if they were playing in the National Hockey League.

title: For Greedy Fugitives, It's 'Go Directly to Jail'
description: After Carlos Camilo was arrested in the Bronx on a charge of selling marijuana, the authorities say, he skipped his court date and fled to Albuquerque, N.M., figuring he was safely out of the reach of the New York City Police Department. But he was low on money, so it came as a welcome surprise two weeks ago when he got an official-looking letter from something called the State of New York Division of Abandoned and Unclaimed Funds informing him that a windfall of $6,000 awaited him in its Bronx office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWIN, DR. BENJAMIN
description: SHERWIN-Dr. Benjamin. Beloved husband of Hilda, loving father of Lois and Jay Wertheimer and Mimi Sherwin. Adoring grandfather of Jeanne and John Bennett and Sandra and Elizabeth Wertheimer. Cherished great-grandfather of Addison. Devoted brother of Bess Feingold and the late Hon. Mitchell J. Sherwin. Dr. Sherwin was Director of Surgery at Lincoln, Lebanon & Jewish Memorial Hospitals. Funeral service private.

title: The New MSN as Prehistoric TV
description: FRUSTRATED with America Online? Perhaps you would prefer a competitor whose installation plays a tune with the incisive lyric ''Just too stupid to stop!''

title: Trade Pacts By Regions: Not the Elixir As Advertised
