description: When efforts to liberalize world trade stalled in the early 1980's, Washington turned its attention to opening trade on a regional basis as the second-best choice. That produced the North American Free Trade Agreement and a dozen similar pacts among other nations. And most economists, who hold that free trade is close to heaven on earth, widely applauded. The regional agreements, they argued, would not just prod reluctant nations like Japan and France to drop their opposition to open markets to global trade, but they would also help developing countries lock in free market initiatives and improve the climate for foreign investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIN, EDNA
description: BEIN-Edna. Beloved wife of the late David. Cherished mother of Sue and Calvin Bein, Linda and Dennis Klein. Loving sister of Al Brownstein. Adored grandmother of Michael, Jason and Eric. Services 10AM today Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFMACHER, RITA DEVOE
description: SCHIFFMACHER-Rita Devoe, on Feb. 2, 1997 of Great Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late C. Ellis Schiffmacher. Survived by her son Craig of Manhasset, and her sister Marion Smith of Rockville Centre. Also survived by several nephews, grand nieces, and grand nephews. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service on Wednesday 11 AM at the Community Church, Great Neck. Interment Greenfield Cemetery, Hempstead. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Women's Club of Great Neck or the Community Church of Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, FAITH BORTON
description: WESTON-Faith Borton, 97, on February 1, at Crosslands, Kennett Square, PA. The widow of the painter, Harold Weston, she was educated at Westtown School ('18) and Vassar ('22). She made her homes in St. Huberts, NY, Perpignan, France, New York City, and since 1977, at Crosslands. She was active in the Essex County, NY, Garden Club and the AAUW. She was a member of the Ausable Club and an Honorary Life Trustee of the Adirondack Trail Improvement Society. She is survived by two daughters, Barbara Weston Foster (Mrs. Esty) and Dina Weston Sudduth (Mrs. William), and a son, Bruce Weston, ten grandchildren and seven great - grandchildren. Memorial service at Crosslands, February 16, at 2:00 PM, interment at Keene, New York, in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORTELYOU, IRWIN FEARN
description: CORTELYOU-Irwin Fearn, on January 29, of Rumson, NJ. Born Mobile, AL Sept. 23, 1896, daughter of George Fearn, Jr. and Aline Kennerly Irwin. Married April 18, 1922 to George Bruce Cortelyou, Jr. who died in 1973. He was a former Treasurer of New York Life. They had no children. She was a real estate broker in Monmouth County and art historian specializing in early American art. Services at 2:00 P.M., Tuesday, February 4, at All Saints Episcopal Church, Navesink. Interment private.

title: Channel 31 Must Prove Its Broadcast Strength
description: The shift of up to 50 Yankee games from Channel 11, a powerful VHF station, to Channel 31, a less potent UHF station, is not a fait accompli.

title: Oakley Ready to Confront Barkley
description: The recipe exchanges and the stroll through Central Park are off. Charles Oakley did something highly uncivilized to Charles Barkley today.

title: Officials Protest Reduced Housing Tax Credits
description: The Pataki administration has sharply redirected the benefits of a Federal housing tax credit program to upstate New York, provoking protests from city officials and housing advocates in New York City, where the program has been a cornerstone of efforts to build homes for the poor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, LAWRENCE A
description: FLEISCHMAN-Lawrence A. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Public Library mourn the loss of Lawrence Fleischman, devoted husband of Trustee Barbara Fleischman, and esteemed friend of the Library. His deep personal affection for and commitment to The New York Public Library and to our Library for the Performimg Arts and its staff will be forever remembered. A passionate collector and scholar of art and antiquities, Mr. Fleischman's interest and generous philanthropy have had a profound and lasting impact on cultural institutions in New York, in the nation, and abroad. We will always be grateful for his wisdom and dedication to our Library. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Barbara, and to his children, Rebecca, Arthur, and Martha. Elizabeth Rohatyn, Chairman Paul LeClerc, President Brooke Russell Astor, Honorary Chairman Marshall Rose and Andrew Heiskell, Chairmen Emeriti

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, REBECCA B.
description: TEPPER-Rebecca B., 92, on February 2, 1997. Loving wife of the late Jacob. Beloved mother of Marvin and Elise, Donald and Elida, and Irwin and Joan. Cherished grandmother of Shelley and Steve, Edward and Beth, Jackie and David, Jan, Ellen and Rob, Michael, Jeffrey, Rosalie, and Matthew. Adoring great grandmother of Paul, Veronica, Dean, Jordan and Gregory. Dear sister of Fay, Stanley and Sol. Service Wednesday 10 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck.

title: No Headline
description: ''I don't think his trial -- if he is granted a trial -- will necessarily give us the unequivocal proof, but at least in regard to new evidence, we will know more than we do now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOHN CAMPBELL
description: HENRY-John Campbell. Kane Lodge #

title: E.P.A. Warns Rhode Island About Water Quality Efforts
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has warned Rhode Island that unless the state increases its spending on water pollution programs, the Federal agency might revoke its authority to carry out the Clean Water Act.

title: Let's Keep The Pol In Politics
description: The American people returned to office a President of one party and a Congress of another. Surely they did not do this to advance the politics of petty bickering and extreme partisanship they plainly deplore. No, they call all of us instead to be repairers of the breach.

title: Signs Growth Is Slowing Lift Bonds
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday for the fifth consecutive session, as investors saw further evidence of moderate economic growth.

title: Louis Merriam, 79, A Former Executive
description: Louis T. Merriam Jr., a civic leader in Connecticut who also served as chief executive of Revere Sugar, died in his home in Darien on Saturday at the age of 79. Mr. Merriam, known as Junie, died of bladder cancer, his wife, Marjorie, said.

title: Investor Recommends Spinoff of Telerate
description: A fund manager who acquired a 5.4-percent stake in Dow Jones & Company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing yesterday that the company should consider alliances, joint ventures or a spinoff of its Telerate unit.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES RAISES QUARTERLY DIVIDEND 13%
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had raised its dividend 13 percent. A quarterly dividend of 31 cents, up from 27.5 cents, will be paid on March 10 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 21. The company also said its chairman, Robert F. Daniell, would retire on April 29; the post will be assumed by the president and chief executive, George David. United Technologies, based in Hartford, is an aerospace, building systems and automotive-parts company.

title: Ballot Language Challenged
description: Voters will be asked on March 11 whether Newark should guarantee an $11 million bond issue to build a baseball and soccer stadium in a riverfront park. But the group that forced the referendum, the Save Riverbank Park Coalition, says that the ballot description of the project reads like a commercial for the sports complex and emphasizes that it ''would further economic development.'' It also says that even if the bond guarantee is voted down, construction will go ahead -- an assertion that the coalition says is not necessarily true.

title: Chess
description: The encounters between Anatoly Karpov and Garry Kasparov during the double-round Las Palmas International Tournament on Grand Canary Island in December generated more than the usual tension. They had avoided playing each other since the Linares Tournament in March 1994. Moreover, when Kasparov headed the Russian team in the Olympiad in Armenia in October, Karpov did not appear as his teammate. It's a good guess that Kasparov did not ask him or that, if he did, Karpov refused.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, RAYMOND B.
description: KING-Raymond B. on February 2, 1997 of Mt. Vernon, NY. Formerly of St. Anselm's and St. Nicholas of Tolentine in the Bronx. Survived by five sons and 11 grandchildren, Funeral Mass Thursday, 10 AM at Sts. Peter & Paul RC Church, Mt. Vernon NY. Reposing at the Burr Davis Sharpe Funeral Home, 584 Gramatan Avenue, Mt. Vernon, NY (Fleetwood) on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9.

title: Q&A
description: Touch Screens

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mix-Up on Airline Tax Has the Treasury's Face Red
description: It is not only taxpayers who have trouble figuring taxes. So does the United States Treasury, which, it turns out, never actually collected $1.2 billion in income last year that it thought it was receiving all along from the nation's airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, HELEN B
description: LAZAR-Helen B. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Helen B. Lazar, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. A. Ephraim Diamond, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Trees Lost for Rail Line
description: When New Jersey Transit proposed to build a light rail system along the Hudson River waterfront, Bayonne officials had to lobby to be included. But two weeks ago, residents along a 17-block stretch of Avenue E were appalled to discover that trees shielding their backyards from an existing freight rail line were being cut down to make room for the new tracks. ''Bayonne is a real tree town,'' said Councilwoman Dorothy Harrington, who fought to bring the rail line to the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN
description: PERLMAN-Julian, on February 1, 1997. Loving father to Tom and the late Jane Elizabeth. Husband of the late Jane. Brother to Murray Perlman and Charlotte Walsh. Son-in-law of Anne Norris. Friend to Sylvia Wolf. A kind and devoted uncle. Services Tuesday 12 P.M., at Temple Israel of the City of NY, 112 East 75th Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNDELL, JAMES WARD
description: MUNDELL-James Ward, 72. Of acute emphysema in Chile. Founder and President of Chol Chol Foundation for Human Development. Former Maryknoll Missionary. Born Washington, D.C., Georgetown graduate. Survived by brother, Monsignor Joseph Mundell and two sisters, Mary Catherine Coffey and Anne Creed and loving nieces and nephews. Memorial Mass on February 8, Immaculate Conception Church, Washington, D.C.

title: Big Swedish Banks End Merger Talks
description: Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken A.B. and Nordbanken A.B., Sweden's third- and fourth-largest banks, said yesterday that they abandoned talks about merging their operations, which would have created one of Scandinavia's top two banks.

title: U.N. Plaza Hotel Is Back on Market
description: Amid a surge in tourism and growing demand by investors for New York City hotels, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday brought one of the city's choicest business assets, the 427-room United Nations Plaza Hotel, back onto the market following a failed attempt to sell it in 1995.

title: Twists and Turns in Chimp AIDS Research
description: IT was not easy for scientists to decide to use chimpanzees for AIDS research back in the 1980's. But as much as they hesitated to give the animals a fatal disease, researchers believed that they could console themselves with two thoughts: the chimpanzee would turn out to be a useful model for human AIDS, and the animals would come down with the disease soon after being infected, and thus would not suffer long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, JILL
description: ORENSTEIN-Jill. Beloved mother of Geri and Pamela. Loving mother-in-law of Stephen and Scott. Adored sister of Scott. Devoted sister-in-law of Cookie. A kind, giving and loving woman who will be missed greatly.

title: Compaq Reduces Prices on Some Models
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation cut prices as much as 27 percent today on desktop computers for corporate customers, portable computers, file servers and work stations.

title: First Lady Talks of Mice and Men on 'Rosie' Show
description: ''This is getting too nice,'' Oscar the Grouch finally grumbled on ''The Rosie O'Donnell Show'' today, after Hillary Rodham Clinton had finished warbling about ''goin' steady,'' and chortling about getting kissed on the cheek by Tom Cruise, and showing off a picture of herself in ponytail and pink poodle skirt at a White House 50's party in the arms of ''my handsome husband.''

title: State Police Faulted In Tampering Inquiry
description: A special prosecutor's four-year investigation into the worst scandal in New York state police history found that troopers were able to plant evidence routinely in criminal cases in rural New York because they had no fear of detection by supervisors, who maintained a willful ignorance.

title: The Jets Are Cornered Once Again
description: For those of you keeping score, Robert K. Kraft was 2-0 in the coaching derby yesterday while the Jets remained the only team in the National Football League without a head coach. Once again, the Jets had painted themselves into the corner that only they seem to occupy.

title: Norwegian Defends Title
description: The Super-G is the newest of Alpine skiing's four disciplines, but there was nothing new about today's winner on the first day of the world championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOORSTEIN, HAZEL (NEE SHAPIRO)
description: BOORSTEIN-Hazel (nee Shapiro), age 98, of Vineland, NJ, formerly of Springfield, NJ, died February 2, 1997. She was the beloved wife of the late Isidore Boorstein; cherished mother of Louise B. Schwartz of Vineland, NJ; loving nana of Randy Jill Schwartz, Jay Finestone, Harriet Schwartz Crew, and Geoffrey Crew; adoring greatgrandmother of Adam, Laura, Alexander and Hilary.

title: Sound, but No Fury, Signifying a Rematch
description: The vanquished champion vowed a knockout. The new champion vowed to perform better. And the promoter was on a hyperbole high, citing Shakespeare, Faulkner, Einstein, the Kennedys, Snoop Doggy Dogg and God in meandering soliloquies designed to push the Mike Tyson-Evander Holyfield rematch on May 3 in Las Vegas, Nev., as the greatest athletic endeavor since, presumably, the first velociraptor races.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: 'Cruel' Sweepstakes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUENSTEIN, ERNEST
description: GRUENSTEIN-Ernest. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences on the loss of our member, Ernest Gruenstein. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Advent of Testing for Breast Cancer Genes Leads to Fears of Disclosure and Discrimination
description: DR. BARBARA WEBER is still reeling from the experience of a patient who told her insurance company that she had a mutated gene that could cause breast cancer.

title: Covered in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOERFLER, WILLIAM
description: DOERFLER - William. Beloved husband of Annette. Devoted father of Marvin. Adored grandfather of Steven, Brian and Eric. Services were held on Monday, February 3, 1997. Interment in Linden Hills Jewish Cemetery. Garson Funeral Directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FRANK
description: BERNSTEIN-Frank. The Board of Directors of Rivercross is deeply saddened by the passing of our General Manager and Corporate Secretary. He was an excellent Manager, but more importantly, Frank was a constant reassuring presence, a friend. He was head of our household, part of the fabric of our building, and as such will be greatly missed. We wish to extend our sympathies to his wife Marsha, daughters Brenda and Abigail, son-in-law Michael, and all of his familty members. John P. Weatherhead, Jr. President

title: In Subways, Shouldering The Burden
description: THE next time you plunk a subway token into the slot, think about this: all by yourself, you have paid for nearly the entire cost of the ride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MILDRED (NEE ROTH)
description: KAUFMAN-Mildred (nee Roth). Of Little Neck, NY. Beloved wife of the late Abraham, devoted mother of Paul and Robert, loving grandmother of Jill, Lindsay, Chris and Harley. Services Tuesday. For info ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: RPM BUYS TREMCO FOR $230 MILLION FROM B. F. GOODRICH
description: RPM Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Tremco Inc., another maker of sealants and coatings, from the B. F. Goodrich Company for $230 million in cash. RPM, of Medina, Ohio, said Tremco had 1995 sales of about $330 million. RPM said it expected to repay about half of the purchase price by selling certain Tremco and RPM product lines. B. F. Goodrich, the Akron, Ohio, supplier of specialty chemicals and aircraft components, said the sale would increase its first-quarter earnings by about $85 million.

title: Kiki Kogelnik, 62, Artist and Designer
description: Kiki Kogelnik, an artist known for rakish depictions of figures and heads, died on Saturday at the Vienna Private Clinic. She was 62 and had homes and studios in Vienna, New York and Bleiburg in southern Austria.

title: Bowie Goes Futuristic
description: David Bowie's newest audience has a different look: Wall Street investors in three-piece suits.

title: Late 40's Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufacturing and Design Links Are Encouraged
description: New York City's failure to link its designers and manufacturers is costing the city jobs and marketable products, a new study says. To solve the problem, the two sectors should create a design center and a trade council, and foster more communication, the report suggests.

title: Kmart Seeking Home Improvement Merger
description: The Kmart Corporation and Waban Inc. said yesterday that they were negotiating to combine Kmart's Builders Square stores and Waban's Homebase chain, forming an independent company that would be the third-largest retail home improvement chain in the nation with 250 stores and annual revenue of $4 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, MOLLY
description: FINKEL - Molly. Congregation Ohab Zedek, Belle Harbor, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Joel Berkowitz, President

title: Cancer Is Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Death of Cosby's Son Touches the Hearts of Donors
description: Shaken by the murder of Ennis Cosby, the comedian's son whose goal in life was to teach needy children in New York City, several readers sent gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in his memory, saying they wanted their donations to help children with learning disabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, CECIL
description: LEWIS-Cecil. Sagittarius risen, his quill at rest. Hail to thee, blithe spirit, you were the best. Eric Emory

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESBITT, HELEN
description: NESBITT-Helen. On Feb. 3, 1997. Devoted wife of Murray. Loving mother of Judy and the late Richard. Cherished grandmother of Pan. Dear sister of Anna Greenberg, Elsie Levine and Leo Rifkin. Dear mother-in-law of Izetta. Graveside service on Wednesday 11:30 A.M., at the Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Tough Times For Crime And Its Writer
description: NEW YORK has been a tough town for Matthew Scudder. He once shot a child by mistake in Washington Heights, ending his police career but propelling his drinking career. Danger trailed him everywhere, from the gin joints of Hell's Kitchen to the tombstones of Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Shortsighted on Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: At Game Suppers, Old New England Meets New
description: IT is a longstanding rite, one that Meg Ostrum, the associate director of the Vermont Folklife Center in Middlebury, says is about ''building community'' and ''preserving tradition.'' It dates back to 1621 and the Pilgrims' original harvest festival, now known as Thanksgiving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALBURG, MARIE R.
description: WALBURG-Marie R. Educator, 88. Died of pneumonia at New York Hospital on Friday, Jan. 31. Beloved sister of Marjorie McNeil and Jamie Graham. Mrs. Walburg was a longtime educator with the New York City Board of Education. Viewing Tuesday, February 4, 4-8 Church of the Master, 86 Morningside Avenue. Funeral service Wednesday, February 5 at 10 A.M., Church of the Master.

title: Rodman, Warned by N.B.A., To Return After All-Star Game
description: The National Basketball Association announced yesterday that Dennis Rodman would be reinstated next Tuesday after serving an 11-game suspension for kicking a courtside cameraman.

title: A Test of Student Metrocards Is Planned
description: After nearly a year of negotiations, transit and school officials in New York City said yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a plan to begin replacing student passes with two versions of the Metrocard.

title: In New York, Many People Anticipated The Verdict
description: This time, almost no one erupted in ecstatic cheers or gasped in stunned dismay. This time, almost no one seemed surprised.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHDERS, GERTRUDE MAY
description: AHDERS-Gertrude May. Age 92, of Valley Stream, New York. Died February 3, 1997. Born in Prague 1904. Loving mother of Rita Pollack of Rockville Centre and the late Frederick Edward May; devoted grandmother of 6: Ronald Peter May and Paul Edward May of Chicago, Lisa Jean Cortez of Austin, TX, David Eric May of St. Louis, Barbara Pollack Rincon of Corpus Christi, TX., and Cliff Pollack of Plainsboro, NJ. Caring aunt of Lori Miller, Dorothy Tristman, Liesi May Shannon and Lori May. Memorial service 2:30 PM, Wednesday, February 5, Gutterman's, in Rockville Centre.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Real-Life Drama
description: A state judge in Fort Worth, Tex., yesterday denied a motion to restrain NBC from showing its movie ''Love's Deadly Triangle'' in the Fort Worth area, meaning that the film, based on a real murder case, will be seen nationwide as scheduled on Monday night. It has drawn protests from lawyers defending the two teen-age defendants.

title: Subdued Pandemonium, Color-Coded Responses
description: Inside the courtroom tonight, there was airless silence. Then a quiet gasp as the verdict was read. O. J. Simpson, found liable in the deaths of his ex-wife and her friend, met the news with no expression.

title: Houston Has the Upper Hand For Knicks in Ewing's Absence
description: With a few minutes left, he surveyed the landscape: Patrick Ewing and Charles Barkley were watching in custom-tailored suits. Hakeem Olajuwon was being fronted and frustrated. And Clyde Drexler was receiving treatment in the locker room.

title: For Want of Clothing Money, Career Training Is Almost Lost
description: At 37, Curtis White has learned it is never too late to listen to your mother. Back when Mr. White was a teen-ager in Queens, back before he became a drunk, an addict and a thief, his mother suggested that he get a job in health care, as a nursing assistant.

title: Son Knows Best: There Sure Is a Story Here
description: UNDERSTAND one thing about David Brinkley, and the rest of his story falls easily into place: He has always said and done precisely what he wanted, when he wanted, no matter the consequences -- ''good and bad,'' he acknowledged.

title: With Success of Cameras, Concerns Over Privacy
description: Video surveillance cameras, which the New York Police Department wants to install in the city's housing projects, subways and possibly on certain streets, have been credited with driving down crime in Baltimore's central business district and in several Boston housing projects. But other police departments around the country have unplugged their cameras, saying that they did not reduce crime, and civil libertarians worry about the ramifications of allowing the government to videotape its law-abiding citizens.

title: Moving Into Rentals
description: Douglas Elliman, New York's largest residential sales brokerage firm, has purchased J.I. Sopher Realty Inc., a leading rental brokerage company, for an estimated $2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFLE, LOUIS A.
description: PFEIFLE-Louis A. The Board of Directors, Administration, and Medical and Dental Staff of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center expresses their profound sorrow on the death of Louis A. Pfeifle, former Chairman of the Board of Directors, and founding member of the Nassau Suffolk Hospital Council and the Hospital Trustees of New York State. He was a leader and a visionary, his wise counsel and understanding commanded the highest level of respect and admiration in our community and throughout the state. His concern, devotion and dedication to the Medical Center and our community set an example for us all to follow. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Fredric Rose, Chairman of the Board of Directors Thomas Ockers, President Gopal A. Bhandarkar, M.D., President of the Medical and Dental Staff

title: Youth Program Gets Larson Grant
description: During the years when he was supporting himself waiting on tables in SoHo, Jonathan Larson received several grants and awards, mostly modest, to further his creative work. One of them supported a workshop tryout of the show that would become the hit musical ''Rent.''

title: Budget Amendment Shuns Democratic Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility Deal Aims to Cut Cost of Power
description: The AES Corporation, a developer and operator of power plants, announced yesterday that GPU Inc., a company that owns utilities in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, had agreed to buy electricity from AES in an unusual arrangement.

title: Stocks Advance in Late-Afternoon Rally
description: A late-afternoon rally pushed stock prices higher yesterday, ending what had been the second consecutive day of sluggish trading.

title: Money Saved From Prison Jobs Sends an Ill Boy to Disney World
description: On Wednesday, Casey Kingman will join the legions of children who have made the pilgrimage to Disney World. What sets his journey apart from thousands of others is this: Casey's trip was paid for by several hundred murderers, drug dealers, bank robbers and other felons at the Federal Correctional Institution here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, ANTHONY THOMAS
description: BOYLE-Anthony Thomas, 53, of Roselle, NJ on February 3, 1997. Husband of Maureen and father of Jeanine. Brother of Carole Schwartz. Held a Ph.D. in Comparative Literature from New York University. Taught at Union County College and Brooklyn College. Member of Board of Trustees for Roselle Public Library. Member of National Board of American Association of Kidney Patients and Past Pres of AAKP Northern New Jersey chapter. A teacher, friend, and Renaissance man.

title: Sylvia's Adds Spice to Student Menu at Columbia
description: New Yorkers, celebrities and tourists by the bus load have flocked to Sylvia's, the restaurant that has been a fixture in Harlem for 35 years, for its smothered chicken, barbecued ribs, collard greens and the like. Last night, about 1,000 Columbia University students got their taste of Sylvia's cooking, smelling the aroma of barbecue as they waited in long lines for the opportunity.

title: Republicans Offer to Forgo Drafting Their Own Budget
description: Rather than develop its own budget proposal, the Republican leadership in Congress wants to try to reach agreement with the Clinton Administration in the next few months on the broad elements of a program to eliminate the Federal deficit, Congressional aides said today.

title: Corrections
description: The Media column in Business Day on Monday, about donations to news organizations from charitable foundations, misstated the terms of grants from the Pew Charitable Trusts. Pew may provide financing for part-time consultants who may work from a newsroom to organize community events and other programs related to topics covered by the news organization. It does not pay newsroom staff salaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, HAROLD
description: WAGNER-Harold. Devoted husband of Bea (nee Siegel). Beloved father of Jeffrey, Stuart and Marc. Fond father-in-law of Bette, Dolores and Ellen. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. Dear brother of Miriam Lennon, Hannah Eichler and the late Milton Wagner. Fond uncle. In repose at Parkside, 2576 Flatbush Avenue at Kings Plaza, Brooklyn. Services at 1 P.M. on Wednesday.

title: Accounts
description: * French Toast by Lollytogs, New York, a maker of children's sports wear and school wear, placed its account in review after six years at Follis Advertising, New York. Billings were estimated at $3 million. The review is expected to end in early March with the naming of a creative boutique to replace Follis, which was excluded from the review.

title: Online Refund Should Require Just a Click
description: To the Editor:

title: Haskins Broke Barrier By Playing His Best
description: HE remembers coaches from some other colleges in 1966 asking him, ''Don't you have a quota at your school?''

title: Harry H. Wachtel, 79, Confidant And Legal Counsel to Dr. King
description: Harry H. Wachtel, a Manhattan corporate lawyer who for many years acted as a confidant and legal counsel to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Monday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 79.

title: 73 Israeli Troops Die As 2 Copters Collide
description: Two Israeli helicopters ferrying soldiers to south Lebanon collided in midair yesterday over the northern Galilee, killing all 73 men on board. It was the the worst military air disaster in Israeli history and the accident stunned the nation.

title: Measure on Term Limits Heads for House Vote
description: The House Judiciary Committee proposed today that Senators and Representatives be limited to 12 years in office, setting the stage for a vote next week on a constitutional amendment that Speaker Newt Gingrich has promised will be the House's first legislative business of the year.

title: Long Missing and Long Misjudged, a Soldier Is Buried
description: For 30 years Pfc. Allen L. Adams was branded a deserter, thought by the Army to be yet another soldier who had fled to avoid being sent to Vietnam. But six weeks ago, when workers in Washington, D.C., found human bones in the rubble of a building they were demolishing, that easy assumption was undone: the remains were those of Private Adams, and the authorities now believe that he disappeared in the summer of 1967 not because he had deserted, but because he had been killed.

title: True North, resuming its drive to expand in Europe, agrees to acquire Wilkens International.
description: TRUE NORTH COMMUNICATIONS is making its first moves to expand in Europe since the dissolution of a worldwide cooperative agreement with Publicis S.A., its partner in a separate joint-venture European agency network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, LAWRENCE A.
description: FLEISCHMAN-Lawrence A. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Public Library mourn the loss of Lawrence Fleischman, devoted husband of Trustee Barbara Fleischman, and esteemed friend of the Library. His deep personal affection for and commitment to The New York Public Library and to our Library for the Performimg Arts and its staff will be forever remembered. A passionate collector and scholar of art and antiquities, Mr. Fleischman's interest and generous philanthropy have had a profound and lasting impact on cultural institutions in New York, in the nation, and abroad. We will always be grateful for his wisdom and dedication to our Library. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Barbara, and to his children, Rebecca, Arthur, and Martha. Elizabeth Rohatyn, Chairman Paul LeClerc, President Brooke Russell Astor, Honorary Chairman Marshall Rose and Andrew Heiskell, Chairmen Emeriti

title: Players and Umpires Begin Talking
description: In a six-hour meeting today that was attended by more lawyers than umpires or players, people on all sides of the incendiary issue of on-field relations between players and umpires and off-field actions by the league presidents pledged to work toward a more harmonious relationship.

title: Barkley Is Muzzled, Temporarily
description: The Knicks wish Charles Barkley would shut up. He won't. But beating Barkley's team last night made the Knicks feel better about answering Barkley, one of their harshest critics.

title: Some Shifts At Apple, But No Layoffs or Unit Sales Yet
description: Apple Computer Inc. shifted its top management today but failed to announce its much-anticipated reorganization, as company officials conceded that they were still not ready to say if they would lay off more workers or sell any units.

title: Firm Dollar And Rate Bet Lift Bonds
description: Treasury prices closed higher yesterday for the sixth consecutive session as investors remained optimistic that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged. Fed policy makers concluded the first day of a two-day meeting yesterday.

title: N.R.A. Power Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEITLIN, BESSIE (WOLSK)
description: ZEITLIN-Bessie (Wolsk), age 90, entered into rest February 3, 1997. Of Cambridge, MA., formerly of Purdys, NY and Bal Harbour, FL. Beloved wife of the late Edward J. Zeitlin, dearest mother of Robert Zeitlin of Stow, and Ruth Fischbach of Cambridge. Cherished mother-in-law of Judy Zeitlin and Gerald Fischbach. Devoted grandmother of Andrew and Jeremy Zeitlin and Elissa Fischbach Grayer, Peter, Mark, and Neal Fischbach. Adoring great grandmother of Annie and loving aunt, cousin, and friend to many. Her love and generosity enriched our lives beyond compare. Service Wednesday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Bessie Wolsk Zeitlin Scholarship Endowment Fund, Brandeis University or to the charity of your choice.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks finished lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 leading issues fell 128.36 points, or seven tenths of 1 percent, to 18,185.97. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 228.38 points, lifted by export company stocks.

title: For Simpson, A Modest Life Is Likely Now
description: For O. J. Simpson, a financial game of cat and mouse that may well haunt him for the rest of his life has just begun.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the painter Theodoros Stamos yesterday misidentified a survivor. Kostas Stamastelos is his brother, not a sister.

title: Pamela Harriman Is Unconscious In Paris Hospital After a Stroke
description: Pamela Harriman, the American Ambassador to France and national co-chairwoman of Bill Clinton's 1992 Presidential campaign, remained unconscious today after suffering a brain hemorrhage on Monday, officials said.

title: Lamb To the Slaughter
description: On the vast spectrum of American culture, Brian Lamb, the eminence grise of C-Span, is to imperturbability what Madonna is to narcissism. In a TV universe of honking pundits, he has staked his entire network on serving up information deadpan, without ever raising his nonpartisan voice. Nothing gets him ticked off.

title: Rodman's Civil Rights?
description: To the Editor:

title: New H.M.O. Rules Expand Patient Rights and Create an Arbitration Panel
description: The Whitman administration announced new regulations for health maintenance organizations today that are aimed at giving consumers more say over their health care, including the power to appeal -- to an independent panel -- any decision to limit care.

title: President Reprises the Goals Of U.S. Achievement Standards
description: As the governor who pushed through sweeping changes in Arkansas' schools in the 1980's, Bill Clinton rode the issue of education into national prominence, which propelled his original candidacy for President in 1992.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SEEK ENCRYPTION-EXPORT APPROVAL
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it would seek approval from the Commerce Department to export stronger encryption technology after three companies announced plans for such exports on Monday. In order to win approval, the companies, which include the Digital Equipment Corporation, agreed to set up systems that let the government use the courts to obtain keys used to decode encrypted information. Encryption is used to scramble information so that it cannot be tampered with when it is sent across networks.

title: Painful Nazi Era Legacy: Hidden Personal Histories of Survivors
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's discovery that, although she was raised a Roman Catholic, she was of Jewish background and had lost relatives in the Holocaust, opens a window onto one of the more poignant legacies of the Nazi era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMRIN, LEONARD
description: BAUMRIN-Leonard. On February 4, 1997. Beloved father of Steven, Michael and Gail. Cherished grandfather of Julien, Max, Chloe, Emily and Joshua. Dear brother of Bernard. We will miss you and we loved you. Services Thursday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Finland to Sell Stake In Electric Utility
description: The Finnish Government said yesterday that it would sell part of its class A shares in the Kemijoki electricity utility in northern Finland to UPM-Kymmene Oy, Enso Oy and Imatran Voima Oy for 2.1 billion markkaa ($488 million).

title: Township Gets $358,000
description: The Dover Township Police Department's pursuit of what it had considered a drug-smuggling case paid off yesterday when it received a check for $358,000 that had been seized from the defendant in the case. The money, which is more than the department's entire annual budget for equipment and supplies, must be used to buy new equipment, said the Police Chief, Michael Mastronardy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO.,Los Angeles, an integrated oil company, said it planned to spend $300 million to build a plant in Carson, Calif., that will make polypropylene, a widely used plastic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, REBECCA B.
description: TEPPER-Rebecca B., 92, on February 2, 1997. Loving wife of the late Jacob. Beloved mother of Marvin and Elise, Donald and Elida, and Irwin and Joan. Cherished grandmother of Shelley and Steve, Edward and Beth, Jackie and David, Jan, Ellen and Rob, Michael, Jeffrey, Rosalie, and Matthew. Adoring great grandmother of Paul, Veronica, Dean, Jordan and Gregory. Dear sister of Fay, Stanley and Sol. Service Wednesday 10 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR) Great Neck.

title: Did He Do That?
description: Steve Urkel on CBS?

title: G.O.P., After Fumbling in '96, Turns to Orator for Response
description: Republicans took no chances this year with their response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message.

title: Penn's 25 Help Eagles End Big East Slide
description: For Boston College, and especially for Scoonie Penn, tonight's Big East game was rewarding. For Syracuse, and especially Coach Jim Boeheim, it was dismal.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS INC. (CSCO, NNM)
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 61 percent in the second quarter, slightly exceeding analysts' estimates, as sales of computer-networking equipment grew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ANDREW J.
description: WEISS-Andrew J., of NY, Tuesday, February 4, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Regina Weiss. Devoted father of Ronnie Armuth and Walter Weiss. Dear brother of Irene Olshan. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. For more information contact the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ.

title: Good Results Reported In Tokyo Land Auction
description: The JNR Settlement Corporation, the company entrusted with disposing of the debts of Japan's former national railway company, raised a greater-than-expected 372.3 billion yen ($3.05 billion) this week in auctioning parcels of land in Tokyo. Eleven companies and corporate groups took part in the auction held yesterday. JNR Settlement did not disclose the amounts of the winning bids.

title: Pass the Salt Alternative, Please
description: AMBI of Tarrytown, N.Y., is producing a salt alternative, Cardia, with 54 percent less sodium than table salt, the company says. The taste and texture of Cardia, which replaces some of the sodium chloride with potassium chloride and magnesium sulfate, are virtually the same as regular table salt. In recipes it can be substituted, measure for measure, for regular salt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLAK, ULANSKY, CLARA (NEE FISHER)
description: POLLAK-ULANSKY-Clara (nee Fisher). On February 4. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Sydney S. Pollak and Ben Ulansky. Adored mother of Ann and Saul Adelman, Dr. Henry and Audrey, Karen and the late Dr. Lewis, Dr. Edward and Karen. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey and Janet, Seth and Michele, Adam, Joshua, Noah and Dara, Sara and Steven Levine. Dear step-mother, grandmother and great-grandmother of the Ulansky/Kohnstamm families. Services Thursday, 11:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, Yonkers, NY. Shiva at the Adelman residence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANDAH, JUDGE SABRI
description: KANDAH-Judge Sabri. Husband of the late Margot. Service Thursday, 6:30 P.M., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial will follow in Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, MICHAEL V.
description: JONES-Michael V. The faculty, residents, and staff of the Residency Program in Social Medicine and the Department of Family Medicine of Montefiore Medical Center mourn the sudden and painful loss of our revered and esteemed colleague, Dr. Michael V. Jones, who brought wisdom, humor, and social commitment to all those who knew him. Our deepest sympathies go out to his mother, Mrs. Classie Guye, and daughter Marjana, and all his family and friends. Memorial Service will be on Thursday, February 6th, at the Unitarian Universalist Church, 160 Central Park West at 3 P.M. Reception: 4-6 PM.

title: BANKAMERICA TO BUY BACK $650 MILLION MORE IN STOCK
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said late Monday that it planned to buy back $650 million more in common and preferred shares by the end of 1998. Last March, the bank holding company, based in San Francisco, said it would buy back as much as $2 billion of its common stock and $1 billion of its preferred stock by the end of 1997. BankAmerica shares closed up $1.375 cents, at $114.625. It also increased the quarterly dividend on its common shares 13 percent, to 61 cents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IRIS MURDOCH, the 77-year-old British novelist, is suffering from Alzheimer's disease, her husband, Prof. JOHN BAYLEY, told The Daily Telegraph of London in an interview published yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBORN, FRANCIS PAUL ''PAULO FRANCIS''
description: HEILBORN-Francis Paul ''Paulo Francis''. Viewing Friday, 11AM2PM, John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue at 70th St., NYC.

title: Little Fund, Big Gains: Growing Concerns
description: The country's best-performing stock mutual fund went on sale to the public for the first time this week, and anyone who wants to buy shares in the fund had better hurry. For investors, though, the question is not just whether shares will be readily available but whether the fund can stay ahead of the pack once it loses its special status.

title: Civil Jury Finds Simpson Liable in Pair of Killings
description: The case that has riveted America for two and a half years, divided the nation by race and sex, and raised troubling questions about the power of celebrity and the nature of justice ended tonight when O. J. Simpson was found liable in the civil lawsuits brought by the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Baiul Is Granted a Plea Bargain
description: A judge in West Hartford, Conn., yesterday allowed OKSANA BAIUL, the Olympic gold medalist who was charged with drunken and reckless driving last month after skidding off the road, to start an anti-drunken driving advertising campaign aimed at teen-agers as part of a plea bargain.

title: Why Be a Temp? For Belichick, Loyalty
description: Bill Belichick stood next to the Jets' president, Steve Gutman, this afternoon and assumed the role of good soldier. Belichick agreed to accept the Jets' head coaching job and relinquish it when Bill Parcells, who was named a consultant to the team for 1997, is ready to take the helm.

title: WMX to Shed Assets Worth $1.5 Billion
description: After several years of trying unsuccessfully to turn itself into a global environmental services conglomerate -- and after a year of plunging earnings -- WMX Technologies Inc. acknowledged yesterday that it had had it right the first time.

title: Views of a Legal Ordeal
description: Contrary verdicts by two different juries will forever frame the public view of the legal ordeal known as the O. J. Simpson case.

title: Let Him Heed Aurelius, That Noble Roman
description: To the Editor:

title: Y'all Hear? African English With a Dixie Drawl
description: Little can prepare the unaccustomed visitor to this burned-out and bullet-pocked city for reminders of the place that most Liberians still consider their mother country: the United States.

title: MILLER TO FORM TOWING NETWORK WITH 30 COMPANIES
description: Miller Industries said yesterday that it would buy 30 towing companies in 15 states to form Road One, the nation's largest towing service and the first interstate network of its kind. Miller said it had agreed to pay $66.5 million in stock, cash and assumed debt for 18 companies with combined annual revenue of about $56 million. It also signed letters of intent to pay an undisclosed price for 12 other towing companies, with combined annual revenue of $21 million. Miller, based in Atlanta, had 1996 revenue of $125.7 million. Shares of Miller rose 75 cents yesterday, to $20.75.

title: Venture Capital Discovers New York's New Technology
description: Long accustomed to being overlooked in the high technology field, New York City is fast becoming a magnet for venture capital investments in start-up companies offering new-media and Internet-related services, a new national survey says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISTER, SVEN J., M.D.
description: KISTER-Sven J., M.D., of Palisades, NY, on February 3, 1997, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Christine; devoted father of Karin Kister Howard of East Providence, RI and Karl Sven Kister of NYC; grandfather of Katherine and Elizabeth Howard; and brother of Sigurd Kister of Columbia, MD. He was born April 23, 1927 in Tallinn, Estonia. Graduate of Dartmouth College '55, Dartmouth Medical School '56, and Harvard Medical School '58, he completed his internship and residency at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, NYC, in 1964. He was Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery, Columbia University, College of Physicians & Surgeons and Associate Attending Surgeon, Presbyterian Hospital, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, NYC. He engaged in research and published extensively in etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of breast disease, particularly cancer. His extraordinary love and devotion to his family and his tireless dedication, empathy, and respect for his patients, as well as his appreciation for the quality of their lives will be missed by all. Services will be private.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DEFENSE OF SPEECH -- Governor Pataki has defended earning $15,000 for out-of-state speeches, saying that he would be in demand even if he weren't the state's chief executive. B5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, HERBERT
description: LANE-Herbert. Dearest Harriet, the wonderful times shared together we will always remember. The warm, kind, wonderful person Herb was, we will never forget. All our love always. Joan and Stephen Stark

title: Dallas Woman Is Sentenced To Death in Murder of Son
description: A Texas jury today sentenced a suburban Dallas housewife to die for slashing her five-year-old son, Damon Routier, to death as he slept on the family's living-room sofa in the middle of a June night last year.

title: Subway Plan: Let People Off Before Trying To Board Car
description: Trying to get millions of New Yorkers to be polite while using the subways -- stepping aside to let passengers off trains before filing into the car -- is a problem that most people would agree transcends etiquette.

title: Police to Press Property-Crime Fight and Install Cameras
description: After four years of steep drops in violent crime, Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday outlined plans to step up efforts against property crimes like burglary and auto theft and to install new video surveillance cameras in some housing projects and subway stations.

title: Nassau to Help Home Buyers
description: Nassau County officials announced a program today that is to provide first-time home buyers up to $10,000 to use toward a down payment.

title: Morass of Competing and Colliding Images
description: When Tom Brokaw called last night's two biggest news stories ''an unlikely confluence of events,'' he was displaying a talent for understatement. For an hour the experts and the correspondents and the images, past and present, had been colliding on all news channels.

title: Chico Science, 30, Brazilian Pop Music Star
description: Chico Science, a songwriter and band leader who was widely hailed as the future of Brazilian music, died on Sunday after a car accident near the northeastern city of Recife, where he lived. He was 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SYLVIA
description: MILLER-Sylvia, 97, on February 2, 1997 at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. Formerly a resident of Great Neck, beloved wife of the late Irving Miller, devoted mother of Jack and his wife Gladys, Alfred and his wife Joan, Arnold and his wife Linda, loving grandmother of David, Barbara, Wendy, Paul and his wife Donna, Asher and Tamara, and adoring great-grandmother of Marc. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 5, at 2 P.M., at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 15 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR Station.

title: Purity in Politics
description: Mad for money and fearing they will be outspent, political parties and their candidates enmesh themselves in complex schemes to raise campaign funds. These often seamy practices repel voters and decrease confidence in the integrity of the parties and elected officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARENGO, NORMAN P.
description: MARENGO-Norman P., of Long Island, died suddenly on January 11, 1997 at age 83. Among the founding members of the faculty of C.W. Post College of Long Island University. Chairman Emeritus of the Biology Department. Loving husband of the late Mildred MacAusland Marengo. Survived by Robert Marengo of Cookeville, Tennessee and Mary Fairchild of Brooklyn; also by 2 grandchildren, Ariel Marengo and Jesse Kalb. Memorial service on Saturday, February 15, at 2 PM in the Chapel of C.W. Post College, Northern Boulevard, Greenvale.

title: Jetting to Nowhere
description: Jets fans are used to waiting. It has been almost three decades since the glory days of Broadway Joe, and the Jets ever since have been a basket case waiting for resuscitation. But now, when we are told that the savior has finally been found, it is frustrating to learn that he is not quite ready to take the field. It will be another year before Bill Parcells, the coach who won two Super Bowl titles with the Giants and took the Patriots to the Super Bowl this year, can take charge of the hapless Jets and try to work his supposed magic.

title: Changing History -- on a Budget
description: After a lifetime of running for office, President Clinton is now said to be running for a place in history. Last night he may have set some kind of laundry-list record for State of the Union Messages by unveiling dozens of proposals to improve education, expand health care, fight crime, employ people on welfare, explore outer space, clean up rivers and carry out other projects. It was a far cry from his declaration last year that the era of big government was over, except for one fact. He pledged to do it all in a world of diminished resources resulting from his pledge to balance the budget in five years. Missing from the address was a clear outline of how he intends to pay for it.

title: Key Dates in the O. J. Simpson Case''
White House Says Files Clear Labor Nominee
description: The White House sent a sheaf of documents to key senators today in an attempt to show that Alexis M. Herman, its nominee as Secretary of Labor, had a minimal role in setting up political coffees with President Clinton that have become embarrassing.

title: Exodus From New England: Assistants Flee
description: The Jets' coaching staff is more uncertain of its future than the players. Even the offensive coordinator Ron Erhardt said today that he would not know until Friday what role the interim coach, Bill Belichick, has for him. Other Jets coaches likely to remain are Bill Muir (offensive line) and Pat Hodgson (tight ends).

title: Crown Hts. Civil Rights Trial Is Set to Go to Jury Today
description: Lawyers for two black men charged in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights yesterday attacked the motives of the police and prosecutors, questioned the testimony of important witnesses and asserted that the defendants were scapegoats in the politically charged case.

title: Nonallergenic Dog? Not Really
description: THEIR sons, 8 and 10 years old, were begging for a dog, but Laurie and Lou Gallo had always thought it out of the question because of Mr. Gallo's allergy to cats and dogs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRINSKY, MILTON, M.D.
description: KRINSKY-Milton, M.D. on Feb. 3, 1997. Beloved husband for over 62 years of Josephine (nee Bachrach), father of Robert, Edward and Dr. William, father-in-law of Carol, Roberta and Mary, grandfather of Alice, John, Rachel, Daniel, Ann, David and Ben Krinsky, grandfather-in-law of Scott Titus and step-grandfather of Amy Fishman, great-grandfather of Kenna Titus. Services private.

title: In Williams's Absence, Nets Pull Together
description: They have nerves that have endured Coach John Calipari's shouts and screams, and bodies that have absorbed injury and pain. But the Nets grew a little more frayed, and a little more fragile even before tonight's game.

title: MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY REST OF SOUTH AFRICAN FIRM
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the remaining 49 percent of Smith Borkum Hare (Pty) Ltd., a South African securities firm, that it does not own and named Jeffrey L. Humber as chief executive of the firm. Humphrey Borkum, 51, a former chairman of the Johannesburg stock exchange, will become chairman of the firm, which is based in Johannesburg, South Africa. He was previously a managing partner of the firm. Mr. Humber, 50, is a managing director in Merrill Lynch's public finance department and has been with the firm for 12 years. He was previously finance and revenue director for the District of Columbia.

title: For frequent-stay awards, the two Hiltons join forces in an agreement aimed at the bottom line.
description: THE Hilton Hotels Corporation's chief executive, Stephen Bollenbach, tells his troops that ''the biggest players win the game'' when he is talking about the impact of the Hilton Honors frequent-stay program on the chain's bottom line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORETSKY, MILTON
description: PORETSKY-Milton, Feb. 4, 1997, of Roslyn, Long Island. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Jeffrey, Howard and the late Gary. Loving father-in-law of Janet. Dear brother and loving grandfather. Services Thursday, 10 AM, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Man Is Shot in Robbery at Canarsie Store
description: One person was arrested last night in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn after the police said he robbed a grocery store, pistol-whipped a clerk and shot another employee, critically wounding him.

title: Against Cigarette Machines
description: Lawyers for five Bergen County communities argued in Superior Court in Hackensack yesterday that ordinances banning cigarette vending machines were justified in order to curb smoking among teen-agers. Five vending machine companies are trying to overturn the 1995 ordinances on the ground that the measures unfairly interfere with their business rights. But lawyers for Carlstadt, Hackensack, Mahwah, Palisades Park and Washington Township noted that in 1994 the State Supreme Court upheld an East Brunswick ban on the machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWDEN, DR. LEMUEL
description: BOWDEN-Dr. Lemuel, 82, of Virginia Beach, died February 2, 1997 in his residence. Dr. Bowden was a native of Norfolk. He is survived by his wife, the former Charlotte Lewis Griswold of Louisville, KY by five of his six children: Howard G. Bowden of Houston, Tx; Margaret Bowden Nickodemus, M.D. of Sandpoint, ID; Mary L. Bowden ScD of Columbia, MD; Rebekah B. Brown of Hamilton, VA; and Stella F. Bowden of East Windsor, CT. Survivors also include a brother, George E. Bowden of Bethesda, MD and a sister, Elizabeth B. Couper of Charlottesville, VA. A memorial service will be conducted at 2 PM, Thursday, February 6, 1997 at Eastern Shore Episcopal Church by Rev. Andrew MacBeth and the Rt. Rev. C. Fitzsimmons Allison. Prior to his death, Dr. Bowden requested that flowers be omitted at his funeral and that memorial contributions, if any, be made to the Latin/Greek Institute, The Graduate Center North, 25 West 43rd Street, New York, New York 10036, to the Salvation Army, or to any other charity of one's choice. For information, contact H.D. Oliver Funeral Apts, Laskin Road, Virginia Beach.

title: A Royal Rebel's Pitch to America
description: To Howard J. Rubenstein, it was a no-brainer. His longtime client Weight Watchers International needed a new spokeswoman; a new client, Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, believed in healthy eating, needed money to pay off debts, and, perhaps most important, was a publicity machine. ''She just has to smile, and the cameras go off,'' he said.

title: Body of Depressed New Mother Found, Apparently a Suicide
description: The disappearance of a 33-year-old woman from her home in Wading River on Monday was solved early this morning when her body was found on a nearby beach. She had apparently committed suicide, the police said.

title: Surplus Budgeting
description: To the Editor:

title: Spano Passes On Top Job In Westchester
description: State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, who was urged to run for Westchester County Executive after Andrew P. O'Rourke announced that he was leaving the position, said today that he would rather remain in Albany.

title: The Cracker That Wouldn't Die (Put That in Your Chowder)
description: Hardly anyone complained when Brown Edge Wafers or the kind of Chips Ahoy cookies that came coated with tiny multicolored sprinkles disappeared from grocery stores last year. In fact, except in the case of one rather bland brand, there was no consumer outcry over the 300 or so other products that Nabisco discontinued in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, BERT
description: FISHER-Bert. February 3, 1997. Beloved son of the late Jacob and Clara Fisher. Dear brother of Donald and the late Raymond. Also survived by sister-in-law Renee, niece Rebecca, and nephews Robert and Kenneth. Donations to Mount Sinai Hospital. Services private.

title: Telecommunications Venture In Europe Could Break Apart
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. confirmed today that it was in talks with its partner, Veba A.G. of Germany, concerning the future of their telecommunications joint venture in light of their significant differences about how to compete in the German and pan-European market.

title: Adelphi, a Little University With Big Ideas
description: This is the story of a university that tore itself apart.

title: Bits, Pieces and a Drive To Turn Them Into Art
description: Thornton Dial has never seen a painting by Jackson Pollock, at least not that he knows of. He has never seen a Julian Schnabel or an Anselm Kiefer. ''I'd never seen any artist's works,'' Mr. Dial said recently. ''I can't copy off anybody because it's something I do my own self.''

title: Martha Stewart to Buy Her Company
description: Martha Stewart, whose home and garden tips ignited a publishing and broadcasting empire, is buying most of her company from Time Warner Inc. to gain more control over direction and marketing.

title: A Cheerless Election in Pakistan
description: The voters of Pakistan were understandably sullen about their election this week. Forced to choose between two former Prime Ministers -- Benazir Bhutto, ousted last November on corruption charges, and Nawaz Sharif, removed on the same grounds in 1993 -- they have given Mr. Sharif another chance to govern. The lack of enthusiasm was reflected in a dismal turnout of about 30 percent. Clearly Mr. Sharif's first task is to clean up the bribery and influence-peddling that have nearly destroyed the political institutions of a country ruled by the military for half its history.

title: Giuliani Says 1996 Film Making in City Set Records
description: Television and film production in New York City rose in 1996 to record levels for the third consecutive year, according to figures released by the Giuliani administration yesterday, though the figures in at least one category -- number of shooting days -- are in dispute.

title: SERBIAN PRESIDENT ACCEPTS VICTORIES BY HIS OPPONENTS
description: President Slobodan Milosevic, abandoned in recent days by key supporters, unable to force his police or army to crush daily street protests after 77 days and facing intense diplomatic pressure, announced today that he would reverse the decision that touched off the protests and restore opposition victories in local elections.

title: Denver Student Accidents Cause Change
description: Last week, on the same cold Tuesday morning, one little girl on her way to school was killed and two others were injured in separate car accidents at different intersections.

title: Pepsico Profit Plunges 84.5% for Quarter
description: Hurt by unexpectedly large losses in its international beverage business and by sluggish profits at two of its three fast-food chains, Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings plummeted 84.5 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIEGEL, ESTELLE (NEE LENTIN)
description: BIEGEL-Estelle (nee Lentin). Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of David and Howard Biegel. Devoted grandmother of Geoffrey. Services will be held on Wednesday, February 5, at 10 AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, New York. Friends who wish may contribute to the Menorah Park or the Alzheimers Association.

title: Horror of a Hidden Chinese Famine
description: HUNGRY GHOSTS

title: He Knows the Game, Not How to Get Along
description: Great coach. Horrible person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, HARRY H.
description: WACHTEL-Harry H. The partners, associates, counsel and employees of Rubin Baum Levin Constant & Friedman record with profound sorrow the passing of Harry H. Wachtel, a founder and former partner of our firm. His warmth, creativity and adherence to the highest standards of our profession and his dedication to the utilization of the rule of law for the benefit of all members of society will long be remembered by those of us who were privileged to have worked with him. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Lucy, his children, Alan, Bill and Susanna and his grandchildren.

title: Cigar Is Horse of Year Again
description: Cigar was in Kentucky to open his career as a stallion, but officials gathered tonight to honor him as best older horse of the year for 1996 and to name him Horse of the Year for the second straight season.

title: Flea-Flicker Jets Hire Parcells, but Not to Coach
description: The Jets, unable to make a deal with the New England Patriots for the rights to Bill Parcells as head coach, executed an end-around today. They hired Parcells's top assistant, Bill Belichick, as head coach for a year and named Parcells as a consultant who will eventually take over.

title: S.E.C. Asks Judge to Soften Stand on Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is urging a Federal judge to reconsider her earlier decision making it tougher for investor lawsuits against companies to go forward under a year-old law.

title: A Woman's Shooting of Attacker Rivets Mexico
description: The hush of the deserted train station in the hazy dawn was broken by the argument between two women and a man coming from a night of drink and dancing.

title: American Air Pilots Offer Concessions as Labor Dispute Escalates
description: With a week and a half to go before a possible strike by pilots at American Airlines, the war of words -- or, more accurately, numbers -- heated up yesterday between the company and the pilots union.

title: Executives Shift Jobs At McCann-Erickson
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had revamped a unit responsible for buying $1 billion worth of national broadcast television commercial time.

title: Williams Wants $9 Million
description: Is Bernie Williams worth $9 million a year? General Manager Bob Watson said that is one of the issues the Yankees are grappling with in discussing a contract offer with Scott Boras, Williams's agent.

title: The Economy, Stupid
description: To the Editor:

title: 73 Are Killed As 2 Copters Collide in Air Over Israel
description: Two Israeli helicopters ferrying soldiers to southern Lebanon collided in midair this evening over the northern Galilee, killing all 73 soldiers on board in the worst military air disaster in Israeli history.

title: Albright Grateful for Her Parents' Painful Choices
description: As a young Roman Catholic girl in exile in London, Madeleine K. Albright, would ask her parents what it was like growing up in Czechoslovakia.

title: A Fateful Error
description: In late 1996, the impression was allowed, or caused, to become prevalent that it had been somehow and somewhere decided to expand NATO up to Russia's borders. This despite the fact that no formal decision can be made before the alliance's next summit meeting, in June.

title: Theater in Review
description: Money Gods Are No Match

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Let Him Heed Aurelius, That Noble Roman
description: To the Editor:

title: Ed Danowski, 85, Star Player For Fordham and the Giants
description: Ed Danowski, a football star at Fordham who went on to lead the Giants to two National Football League titles in the 1930's, died last Saturday in East Patchogue, L.I. He was 85.

title: Foster Parents Are Cleared
description: In 1993, two boys accused their foster parents of depriving them of food and keeping them locked up in their Englewood attic. After three years of investigations, the couple have been cleared of most of the allegations. Ike Gavzy, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor, said yesterday that the boys, now 13 and 14, had admitted that they were pressured by another foster child in the family to corroborate a story she had made up after she was caught shoplifting food.

title: Hamilton's 28 Points Not Enough
description: The scene in the St. John's locker room after tonight's game was not an unfamiliar one: the Red Storm players, for the third straight game, sat stunned before their lockers, too tired to undress, too frustrated to speak.

title: Better Off Without It
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain's Leader Hits Out At European Labor Rules
description: In a new assault on the European Union seen as a prelude to his presumed electoral campaign, Prime Minister John Major of Britain said today that European employment policies were too protective of workers and stifling to business, and pledged that his Conservative Party would not accept European Union labor laws.

title: Theater in Review
description: If It's Only a Paper Moon,

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Cosby's Troubles Won't Diminish Fans' Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: New Clues in an Old Murder Case
description: More than four decades after Dr. Sam Sheppard was convicted of murdering his wife in a trial that transfixed America, a team of lawyers, private investigators and a renowned forensics expert put together by the couple's son today presented new DNA evidence that strongly suggests what the son says he knew all along: that his father was innocent.

title: Fire Department Evicted
description: It is not every day that a fire department is evicted for nonpayment of rent. But in Cherry Hill, that is why two of the township's seven fire battalions had to find new quarters Monday. They were evicted by volunteer firefighters, who own the buildings. Most of the volunteers have been replaced by the township's three-year-old paid fire department.

title: PRESIDENT, CITING EDUCATION AS TOP PRIORITY OF 2D TERM, ASKS FOR A 'CALL TO ACTION'
description: President Clinton tonight assembled the patchwork proposals of his last Presidential campaign into an agenda for his final term, issuing a ''call to action'' to the nation and arguing that even within straitened budgets the Federal Government could help improve education, modernize technology and provide health care.

title: MCI Division Is to Move
description: MCI has leased 89,589 square feet in the Met Life Building -- most of the sixth floor and space on the concierge level of the lobby -- at 200 Park Avenue, just north of Grand Central Terminal. The Washington-based global communications company will be moving its New York corporate national accounts division, which serves its largest Manhattan commercial customers, from 757 Third Avenue, at 47th Street.

title: LCI TO SPEND $100 MILLION FOR STAKE IN FIBER OPTIC CABLE
description: LCI International said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire an interest in a fiber optic cable being built from Chicago to Los Angeles by IXC Communications Inc. for $100 million. LCI, a long-distance telecommunications carrier based in McLean, Va., also said it was negotiating to buy more stakes in IXC fiber optic cables along the New York-Atlanta and Cleveland-New York-Boston routes. The agreement calls for IXC, based in Austin, Tex., to provide LCI with 3,100 additional miles of fiber optic cable along its Los Angeles-Chicago route, which is scheduled to be finished by summer.

title: Dow Jones Family Feud Grows More Intricate
description: The complex drama involving the family that controls Dow Jones & Company grew more byzantine yesterday, as one of the family's younger dissidents sharply criticized other family members for misrepresenting her views about the management of the company.

title: Questions of Fairness
description: After losing a series of jury verdicts based on its news-gathering methods, including the much-publicized suit brought by the Food Lion supermarket chain, ABC wants to find out what the public thinks about techniques like hidden-camera investigations and reporters who misrepresent themselves to gain access.

title: Unanimous Verdict: Networks Chose Clinton
description: Faced with what one television executive described as an ''excruciating decision'' between covering President Clinton's State of the Union Message or the verdict in the O. J. Simpson civil trail, every broadcast network last night opted, with no apparent hesitation, to cover the President's speech live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDMAN, LARRY
description: DAVIDMAN-Larry. On February 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Edna, loving father of Ellen Yuder and Gail (Allen) Goldberger, cherished grandfather of Robin, Andrew, John, Michael and Lynn and great-grandfather of Jake and Dereck. Services Thursday 10:30 ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: As Usual, Jet Fans Are Put On Hold
description: Jet fans have endured a team beset by long periods without winning, the post-Joe Namath hex, a peppy coach who taught players a fight song, bad draft choices and second-class residency in a stadium named for its local rival. They have avenged the ignominy by not showing up for games they have paid to see.

title: On a Split-Screen Night, Clinton Gets the Full Attention of Congress
description: The Capitol scene was a study in acute distractedness tonight as the television monitors of the nation's lawmakers flashed away from California pictures of the climax of another O. J. Simpson trial even as President Clinton sought to pronounce on the State of the Union.

title: Personal Health
description: EIGHTEEN years ago, Doreen LeMoult of Darien, Conn., discovered that she had chronic myelogenous leukemia in a phase that could be rapidly fatal. The doctors at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York told her that with available treatment she had at most two years to live. That did not seem quite long enough to a mother of two young children. So she chose a 50-50 chance that she would survive potentially lethal doses of chemotherapy and radiation followed by a bone marrow transplant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LERNER, HARVEY
description: LERNER-Harvey. One year ago tonight, the evening sky opened up to receive a new star. Thanks for all of the joy that you brought into my life. Always on my mind-Forever in my heart. I miss you, Harvey. Love Always, Doug

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, FREDA
description: COE-Freda, 87, on February 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jules Coe and the late Jules Girden, cherished mother of Peggy Weinstein and Eugene Girden. Beloved grandmother of David, Dani, and Jonathan Weinstein and Steven and Lisa Girden and great grandmother of Lindsay and Alex Girden and Andrew and Benjamin Weinstein. A service will be conducted Sunday, February 9 at the Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hills, Queens at 1:30 P.M.

title: No Headline
description: ''My parents talked about how they met, and how they were high-school sweethearts. They talked about getting ready for various holidays, for Easter and Christmas.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES
description: INNISS-Charles. He defined the spirit of Brooklyn. He was a great supporter and friend of BAM. We mourn his passing. Our condolences to his wife and family. Bruce Ratner Chairman, Board of Trustees Harvey Lichtenstein President Brooklyn Academy of Music

title: Online Refund Should Require Just a Click
description: To the Editor:

title: From Pudding To Tea, Zagat Does London
description: VERY early on pleasant mornings in the spring of 1996, a solitary jogger bounced along the neatly ordered, almost empty streets of the charming Chelsea section of London, pausing only long enough to stuff fliers in mailboxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, SHELDON
description: STILLMAN-Sheldon. Age 66. Passed away Saturday at Doctors' Hospital on Staten Island. He was a much loved and prominent businessman and a respected partner of DMAS Insurance Agency in Staten Island. He served in the Army during the Korean War as a Corporal, a Specialist in Transportation. He graduated from Syracuse University in 1951 with a degree in Business, and was a member of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity. He was an active charter member of the North Shore Kiwanis Club of Staten Island, serving two terms as club President, and many years as Secretary and Fund Raising Chairman. He was very active in many charitable organizations on Staten Island. Mr. Stillman's father was Lou Stillman of the famous Stillman's Gym in Manhattan, at which some of the most prominent boxers in history trained and practiced for bouts at Madison Square Garden and other arenas. Boxers and trainers worldwide, as well as many celebrities and members of the public, frequented the gym. Mr. Stillman, beloved husband, father and grandfather, is survived by his mother Camille, his loving wife Donna, his two sons Randy, Scott and four grandchildren. He had a zest for life and enjoyed sharing with those around him. He brought sunshine, laughter and love into the lives of many. He will be sorely missed by a host of people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LESTER
description: KAPLAN-Lester. On Feb. 4, 1997, of cancer. Cherished husband of Gladys Kaplan, beloved father of Jeffrey and Scott Kaplan, and daughter-in-law Debra Kaplan. Adored grandfather of Seth and Alexandra Kaplan, beloved brother and brother-in-law of Helen and Ben Lenetsky. In his 72nd year. The world has been a better place for having had such a truly good soul inhabit it. His presence will be sorely missed, but his memory will always linger in the hearts of the many who loved him. In lieu of gifts, donations to the cancer organization of your choice, in his memory, will be appreciated. Services will be held ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey, on Thursday at noon.

title: Food Notes
description: Jezebel II

title: Report of Glut in Heating Oil Pushes Prices to 5-Month Low
description: Heating oil fell to a five-month low yesterday after a report by the New York Mercantile Exchange showed that more fuel than expected would be delivered this month in the Northeast, the biggest market for heating oil.

title: Muslim Party Gets Huge Margin in Pakistan's Parliament
description: Pakistan's general election turned into a landslide today as nearly complete returns showed the Pakistan Muslim League returning to power by overwhelming the Pakistan People's party led by the dismissed Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto.

title: Another Index of Winter's Misery Will Find Lots of People Scratching
description: IF hearing the wind chill factor makes you shiver, a new health-related weather index is sure to make you scratch. It is the dry, itchy skin index.

title: Winter's Vanishing Feast
description: THE water in Nantucket harbor is more than a little choppy; the tide is running out and the wind is coming in, a combination that produces spray, and plenty of it. Like the sky, the water is unvaryingly gray; like the air, it's bitingly cold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWIN, DR.
description: SHERWIN-Dr. Benjamin. Beloved husband of Hilda, loving father of Lois and Jay Wertheimer and Mimi Sherwin. Adoring grandfather of Jeanne and John Bennett and Sandra and Elizabeth Wertheimer. Cherished great-grandfather of Addison. Devoted brother of Bess Finegold and the late Hon. Mitchell J. Sherwin. Dr. Sherwin was Director of Surgery at Lincoln, Lebanon & Jewish Memorial Hospitals. Funeral service private.
