title: Morton Edell, 88, Cosmetics Executive
description: Morton Edell, an executive in the cosmetics and vitamin industries, died on Dec. 30 in Sarasota, Fla., at age 88. The cause of death was lung cancer, according to his son David.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMER, STEVENSON
description: FLEMER-Stevenson. 71, of Waitsfield, Vt. Died 2/2/97 at Naples, Fl after a brief illness. Born 1/8/26 in Princeton, N.J., son of the late William Flemer Jr. and the late Emma Wilkinson Flemer. Graduate of the Lawrenceville School, Dartmouth College and Harvard Graduate School of Design. Served in U.S. Army Air Corps in World War II. Member of the American institute of Architects. Practiced architecture with Yamasaki, Eero Saarinen, and then with Harry Weese in Chicago, and for many years with his own firm in Waitsfield, Vt. Beloved husband of Leslie Fulton Flemer, loving father of Wrenn Flemer Compere, Stevenson Flemer Jr., and Benjamin Flemer and grandfather of Anna and Pierre Compere and Oskar Flemer. Also survived by his brother, William Flemer III of Princeton, N.J. and pre-deceased by his brother, Dr. John Flemer. Memorial service to be held in late Spring in Waitsfield, Vt. in lieu of flowers, contributions to American Diabetes Assn would be appreciated or to charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN
description: PERLMAN-Julian. The Jerusalem Foundation mourns the passing of its good friend, Julian Perlman, a devoted friend of Jerusalem whose generous spirit will forever live on in the projects he helped to bring to life as the director of the Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation Inc. His friendship enriched everyone who worked with him. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Teddy Kollek, Honorary Chairman Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President Alvin H. Einbender, Nat'l Chrman Michael Neiditch, Nat'l President

title: A Spectacle a Year?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford's Sales Increase 2.8%, While Toyota's Soar 55%
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today that its sales rose 2.8 percent in January from a year ago, while Toyota said its sales jumped 55.5 percent. The final tally of sales figures showed that in January, American auto makers lost ground to their Japanese and European competitors.

title: 5 U.N. Workers Ambushed and Killed in Rwanda
description: Five United Nations employees investigating human rights abuses in Rwanda were ambushed on a country road today and shot to death, United Nations officials said.

title: Senators Doubtful Over Army's Policies on Women
description: One day after a 22-year Army veteran accused her former boss, the Army's top-ranking enlisted soldier, of sexually assaulting her last April, Army Secretary Togo D. West Jr. sought to assure Congress that the Army was a safe place for women to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTERS, MILDRED.
description: WINTERS-Mildred. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Mildred Winters, associated with The Times from 1957 until retiring in 1981.

title: With Music and Steps Baroque and French
description: Apollo's Banquet is neither a mythological revel nor a trendy restaurant. Nevertheless, it can provide a feast. Under the direction of Thomas Baird and Hugh Murphy, this organization specializes in Baroque music and dance, and on Monday night at the Kaye Playhouse it offered a program called ''Dances of the French Baroque Theater.''

title: INSIDE
description: Jets Pick Belichick (Or, Jets Pick Parcells)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAINE, CARDINAL H., M.D.
description: KAINE-Cardinal H., M.D., on February 5, 1996. We miss you and will remember forever. Dorothy, Mookie, Maryanne and Nadja

title: People
description: * David Ayriss was named a principal and creative director at Matthaeus Halverson, Seattle, now Matthaeus Halverson Ayriss. Mr. Ayriss had been senior vice president and creative director at Cole & Weber, Portland, Ore., a unit of WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSH, CLAIRE
description: HERSH-Claire, of Stamford, CT, on February 3, 1997 at Greenwich Hospital. Loving wife of Leonard. Mother of Lin and Ron. Sister of Helen and Shirley. Beloved aunt. Artist, designer and hostess. You will be missed. A memorial service will be held today at 11AM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT. There are no calling hours. Burial will be private.

title: Operating Profit for Sprint Up 4.6% on Volume Growth
description: The Sprint Corporation posted a rise today of 4.6 percent in fourth-quarter operating profits as it posted the strongest annual volume growth among the top three long-distance phone companies in seven years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, CHARLES
description: POWERS-Charles. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles Powers, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1979.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Clinton Aide Reconsiders
description: The White House spokesman said today that he should have disclosed last week that he advised Truman Arnold, the former finance chairman of the Democratic National Committee, on how to handle press inquiries about whether Mr. Arnold misused a White House computer database to track prospective donors to the party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILDNER, BENJAMIN
description: BILDNER-Benjamin. The Graduate School and University Center of The City University of New York mourns the passing of Benjamin Bildner, father of Albert Bildner of the Graduate Center Foundation's Board of Trustees and longtime member of the Graduate Center's Board of Visitors. Benjamin Bildner led a long, distinguished and productive life, in which he generously shared his self-made success through his support of educational institutions and other philanthropic causes. We extend our deepest sympathy to Albert and his wife, Lin, and the entire family. Frances Degen Horowitz, President Julien J. Studley, Chairman Graduate Center Foundation Bernd Brecher, Executive Director Graduate Center Foundation

title: A Band and Its Message Multiply
description: It's surprising that the Last Poets, the street poets and percussionists of the late 1960's and early 70's who paved the way for rap's socially conscious wrath, are still around. One member died of a brain tumor, another was convicted of armed robbery, one became a crack addict and others joined a religious commune and became evangelists. The evils the band preached against over 20 years ago -- racism, apathy, drug abuse -- have persisted if not worsened, while the time for the revolution the band called for has come and gone. But instead of disappearing, the band has multiplied. There are three groups calling themselves the Last Poets, and one of them, a trio with two of the original band members, performed at the Kitchen on Friday and Saturday nights.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pepsico's Profit Falls, Causing Drop in Stock

title: Off-Season Tomatoes Fit for a Salad
description: Intrigued by the yellow tomatoes turning up at some produce counters, I decided it was time to see whether this out-of-season fruit was worthy to be eaten raw. The answer is yes. They're not like summer tomatoes but there is something very appealing about them on an icy winter day.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANOUK AIMEE, the French film star, is being honored tonight by the Bide-A-Wee Home Association at a dinner-dance at the Plaza, but she says she does not want people making much of a fuss about it.

title: The Neutrality Myth
description: In virtually every article about the dispute between Swiss bankers and Jewish groups over the bank accounts of Holocaust victims, there is a historical reference that is blandly repeated over and over: ''Switzerland was neutral during World War II.'' Every time I read that reference I can't help thinking: What does it mean to be neutral between the perpetrators of the worst crimes against humanity in modern history and their victims? What does it mean to say that the same rules should apply to the money of both? What does it mean to put yourself outside history?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERLING, SHEP
description: STERLING-Shep. Feb. 5, 1988 ''And who shall say Whatever disenchantment follows That we ever forget magic, Or that we can ever betray, On this leaden earth, the appletree The singing, And the gold?'' Joey

title: Youth Must Be Served
description: Children's television, once upon a time merely a sleepy afterthought for network executives, has become a hotbed of competition. This week, networks are scrambling to impress advertisers, who will be deciding how to commit more than $700 million for the 1997-98 season. Much of that will go to cable, where the sturdy growth exhibited by both Nickelodeon and the Cartoon Network has inspired both Fox and Disney to start children's cable networks of their own as soon as possible.

title: Clinton Asks G.O.P. to Help in Fight for Chemical Weapons Ban
description: Facing stiffening Republican opposition to a treaty banning chemical weapons, Clinton Administration officials today promised a vigorous campaign to ratify the pact, with appeals for a bipartisan foreign policy made by the new Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen, a Republican.

title: Two Top AT&T Executives in Europe Quit
description: The AT&T Corporation said today that two senior executives had resigned in Europe. They are the latest of several top managers to depart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, E. JAMES
description: MURPHY-E. James, on February 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Alma (nee Bosque), dear brother of Joan and Ellen, and devoted uncle of Michael. Memorial service on Saturday, February 8, 2 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Immigration's Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 24 about a group that considers Texas independent referred incompletely to the existence of former nations among American states. While Texas was the only state to enter the Union directly as an internationally recognized nation, Vermont -- which entered the union in 1791 -- had been a self-governing republic since 1777. In addition, Hawaii was a monarchy and a republic before becoming a territory in 1900.

title: Of Dolls and Daredevils Spinning Sweet Visions
description: George Balanchine once said jokingly that he chose ''Coppelia'' for summertime performances by the New York City Ballet because it was ''the least harmful'' of crowd-pleasing, big traditional ballets. The production did look harmless when City Ballet performed it on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater, but not for the reasons Balanchine was thinking of.

title: One Fairway Owner Seeks Another Site
description: An owner of the sprawling Fairway market in Harlem is casting about for a place where he can create another outlet that sells high-brow foods at bargain prices.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Case of the Housewife

title: Preserve the Black College Exemption
description: Over the years, the number of students at black colleges and universities who have defaulted on student loans has been disproportionately high. In 1993 their default rate was triple that at other institutions. But because black universities also serve a disproportionate number of poor students, who are more likely to default, they have been exempt from a Federal law that terminates student loan programs at any institution with default rates of more than 25 percent in three consecutive years.

title: In Their Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, GERTRUDE S.
description: THOMPSON-Gertrude S. On February 3 in Ridgewood, NJ at age 89. The students, faculty and staff at the University at Albany, State University of New York, mourn the passing of Gertrude S. Thompson, a major benefactor dedicated to atmospheric science education and research at the University. She was an extraordinary woman with a love and commitment to the ecology of the Adirondack mountains. Generations of students will benefit from her philanthropy. Her legacy carries on. A memorial service will be held at 2PM on February 20 at West Side Presbyterian Church, 6 South Monroe Street, Ridgewood, NJ.

title: Lincoln Center Wants to Build a Theater East of Broadway
description: Almost 30 years after the opening of its last theater for the performing arts, Lincoln Center is negotiating to build a new hall for opera, dance and drama on the other side of Broadway in a high-rise building planned by Millennium Partners.

title: By the BBC, The Glory Of Gospel
description: The fact that an exceptionally fine documentary about American gospel music is produced by the BBC no doubt says something about American television. But instead of bickering, let's just rejoice because ''The Story of Gospel Music'' has been acquired by public television and can be seen on ''Great Performances'' tonight.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE Charles Krug winery, one of Napa Valley's oldest, has lately been going through something of a renaissance, which includes the addition of some new wines to its list. One of them is a white wine called pineau.

title: FIRST BRANDS TO ACQUIRE OPERATIONS OF NATIONALPAK
description: The First Brands Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Australian and New Zealand operations of Nationalpak from its parent company, National Foods Ltd., for $159 million. First Brands, based in Danbury, Conn., is a consumer-products company whose products include Glad trash bags. Nationalpak also makes consumer products. Its Australian and New Zealand operations posted full-year sales of $123 million. First Brands said its second-quarter earnings slipped 0.5 percent, to $15.4 million, and it warned that costs from advertising and promotion might limit growth in its third quarter. The company's stock fell $3.375, or 12.6 percent, to $23.50 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, MOLLY
description: FINKEL-Molly. EMUNAH mourns the passing of our beloved founder and benefactor. Molly devoted her life time to building a religious Israel with EMUNAH. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Dr. Rosalie Reich, Nat'l President

title: We Haven't Heard End Of This One
description: THE Jets better hope their contract lawyers are superior to their guards and their tackles. This reeling franchise took an audacious step yesterday in trying to hire Bill Parcells as a ''consultant'' without getting the approval of the National Football League.

title: David Berger, 81, Host of a Radio Show
description: David Berger, the longtime host and producer of the WQXR-FM radio program ''Music From Germany,'' died on Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Armstrong Carries Isles on Shoulder
description: The Islanders were due for a break after three consecutive defeats, all by one goal, all on the road.

title: Company's Rescue Expert Once Falsified Credentials
description: William A. Brandt Jr., the turnaround specialist chosen on Monday by the Mercury Finance Company to try to salvage the troubled company's credibility with lenders, lied about his credentials in a Federal bankruptcy court in 1988.

title: Inspiration From Past To Rally Support Now
description: President Clinton sought tonight to shake this capital and the nation beyond from the inevitable letdown they experienced following the victory of the West, led by the United States, in the 40-year struggle against militant communism, led by the old Soviet Union.

title: Pataki Defends Speech Fees As Unrelated to His Office
description: Defending his paid speechmaking, Gov. George E. Pataki asserted today that he would be a sought-after speaker even if he were not Governor, and said that as a gubernatorial candidate in 1994 he had not taken part in or endorsed Republican attacks on former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for similar earnings.

title: Assembly Speaker Proposes Publicly Financed Preschools
description: Saying that he wanted to improve children's readiness for school, the Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly today proposed a plan that would give parents the option of putting their children in publicly financed preschools.

title: W. E. Washburn, Authority on Indians And Historian, 72
description: Dr. Wilcomb E. Washburn, a historian and longtime executive of the Smithsonian Institution who was an authority on North American Indians, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 72 and also had a home in Princess Anne, Md.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, RACHEL
description: RIFKIN-Rachel. The Zionist Organization of America mourns the passing of a dedicated past president of its Women's Division; beloved sister of Bernard, chairman of the Finance Committee; Arthur and Irving. May her memory be a blessing for all of us. Morton A. Klein, Nat'l Pres Michael Orbach, Chrmn, Bd of Dir Dorothy Soloff, Pres Women's Div

title: Restoring Sparkle to Versailles, a Shrouded Jewel
description: In truth, the glory of the Chateau of Versailles lasted barely a century, from 1682 when Louis XIV brought his court here, to 1789 when Louis XVI was chased out by revolutionary mobs. Yet to this day, despite abandonment, unhappy restorations and repeated occupations, the immense palace still stands as a symbol of absolute power and outrageous opulence, at least to the millions of tourists who flock here each year.

title: Prison Guards Dislike Pact
description: Representatives of the state's 5,000 corrections officers said yesterday in Trenton that they were unhappy with the contract proposed by a state arbitrator. The state prison guards, who have been without a contract since June 1995, will vote on the offer on Monday.

title: Distinctive Ways of Moving
description: Dance Theater Workshop came up with an inspired pairing of standout performers -- women whose choreography grows out of distinctive presences and ways of moving -- in its Splitstream program on Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNISTRARO, ATTILIO
description: CANNISTRARO-Attilio. Beloved husband of Margaret. Devoted and wonderful father of Philip and Corinne Grandolfo, and son-in-law Jim. Loving grandfather of James Grandolfo, Anthony Grandolfo, Carolyn, Christine Grandolfo, and Suzanne. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., until Friday, 8:45AM. Mass of Christian burial, St. Lucy's Church, Friday at 9:45 A.M.

title: Mattel Profits Lowered by Hair-Chewing Doll
description: Mattel Inc. said today that net income rose 1.3 percent in the fourth quarter, reflecting two charges, including one for the recall of a doll that chewed children's hair. Earnings before the charges increased 22 percent.

title: Stocks Plunge; Nasdaq Index Is Down 25.31
description: The stock market plunged sharply in afternoon trading yesterday, led by steep declines in the prices of leading technology stocks.

title: Fed's Policy-Making Panel Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that a recent surge in economic growth will moderate and leave wage and price inflation under control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNTHER, EDWIN
description: GUNTHER-Edwin, 70, February 4, 1997. He worked for Popsicle Idustries as Credit Manager for thirty-eight years. His greatest love for thirty years was local politics and community issues, serving as Democratic State Committee Member and a member of Community Board 7. He was reliable, sturdy and a man who loved New York City. He is survived by his wife Phyllis, sons Bram and daughter-in-law Kate and Matthew. Funeral services Riverside Chapel, February 6, 4:30PM, 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, 386 Park Ave South, New York, NY, 10016.

title: Lloyds Buying Assets Of Brazil Joint Venture
description: Lloyds TSB Group P.L.C. confirmed yesterday that it intended to buy some assets from its Brazilian joint venture, Banco Multiplic S.A. Lloyds, Britain's second-largest bank, said the talks involved buying the assets from Multiplic Empreendimentos, which owns the other half of Banco Multiplic, and ending the companies' 19-year partnership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, MILTON J.
description: HAAS-Milton J. Beloved husband of Ethel. Dearest father of Edward and Regina. Grandfather of Brian and Benjamin. He will be terribly missed by all. We love you.

title: Goodyear And Top Rival Cut Japan Tie
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company officially closed the book on a big part of its past yesterday, finally acknowledging that an oil pipeline that has dragged down profit since 1983 was a mistake from the start.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about an expansion in Europe by True North Communications, omitted part of a sentence in some editions. It should have read, ''True North Communications, the world's seventh-largest agency company, with billings estimated at $7.5 billion, said yesterday that it would acquire Wilkens International in Hamburg, Germany, for undisclosed terms.''

title: Alan C. Nelson, 63, Who Led Immigration Overhauls for U.S. and California
description: Alan C. Nelson, who presided over sweeping changes in national immigration policy in the 1980's as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, then helped write California's tough new immigration law, died on Jan. 29 at his home in Sacramento. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINBACH, DR. HYMAN
description: MARINBACH-Dr. Hyman. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Dr. Hyman Marinbach, beloved brother of our devoted Member and Sisterhood Trustee, Edith Agus. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLECK, JOSEPH P.
description: ORLECK-Joseph P. The family of Joseph Orleck mourns the passing of a unique and generous spirit. Semi-pro baseball and basketball player, an early force at Billboard Magazine, in 1940 he founded Cashbox, and built it into an internationally respected music magazine. Beloved uncle, grandpa, brother-in-law, ingenious storyteller, wry wit. He took care of the whole family. Funeral services to be held Friday, Feb. 7, 11AM, at Mount Carmel Cemetery, 83-45 Cypress Hills St., Glendale, NY.

title: State of the Union: No More Federalism, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISTER, SVEN J.
description: KISTER-Sven J., M.D., of Palisades, NY, on February 3, 1997, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Christine; devoted father of Karin Kister Howard of East Providence, RI and Karl Sven Kister of NYC; grandfather of Katherine and Elizabeth Howard; and brother of Sigurd Kister of Columbia, MD. He was born April 23, 1927 in Tallinn, Estonia. Graduate of Dartmouth College '55, Dartmouth Medical School '56, and Harvard Medical School '58, he completed his internship and residency at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, NYC, in 1964. He was Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery, Columbia University, College of Physicians & Surgeons and Associate Attending Surgeon, Presbyterian Hospital, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, NYC. He engaged in research and published extensively in etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of breast disease, particularly cancer. His extraordinary love and devotion to his family and his tireless dedication, empathy, and respect for his patients, as well as his appreciation for the quality of their lives will be missed by all. Services will be private.

title: Matching a Gift Doubles the Impact of a Good Deed
description: Gale A. Drukier and her daughter, Jennifer, 18, were on the receiving end of what they called ''undeserved charity,'' and they counted their blessings by donating the gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Not only that, they decided to match the gift with a donation from their own pockets.

title: Air Disaster Leaves Israel Assessing Cost In Buffer Zone
description: United in grief as they began burying 73 soldiers killed on Tuesday night in a collision of two helicopters flying to Lebanon, Israelis were faced today with hard questions about their country's military involvement there.

title: Houston Art Museum Expands Exhibition Space
description: The Houston Museum of Fine Arts has begun work on a new limestone and glass building that will more than double the institution's overall exhibition space, making it the sixth-largest in the country in terms of public galleries, museum officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DESOSA, COUNT MAXIM
description: DeSOSA-Count Maxim. ''Our love, our hope, our sorrow, is not dead;... Lost Angel of a ruined Paradise!'' Eric

title: Setback in Deal to Preserve California Redwoods
description: The Houston financier who controls the largest grove of old-growth redwoods left in private hands has turned down scores of properties that the State of California offered in partial trade for the forest, dealing a new blow to the complex deal that the Federal and state governments hope to use to protect the ancient trees in Northern California.

title: Bridge
description: The colder the climate, the more popular is the game of bridge. This may be partly because the long winter nights of Scandinavian countries, among others, favor indoor activities. But where temperatures are high, bridge games are hard to find and the players are usually far from home.

title: Calendar: Lectures On Italian Design
description: Renaissance Design

title: Crown Hts. Jury Asks Judge About Forewoman Choice
description: Even before they began deliberating yesterday, the jurors in the Crown Heights trial made clear their sensitivity to the racial implications of the bitterly controversial case, raising questions about whether one of the black or Jewish members of the jury should lead it.

title: West Fails the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: Impact of Merger
description: The merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover is not expected to result in major job losses in New York City because there is little overlap between the two companies. But experts say the deal could set off a scramble among other investment houses to consolidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EULE, JULIAN N.
description: EULE-Julian N. Loving husband of Carole, father of Lisa and Brian, brother of Daniel, son of Hanna and Leo Minkin, passed away on January 30, 1997. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Julian N. Eule Memorial Fund, Office of the Dean, UCLA School of Law, P.O. Box 951476 Los Angeles, California 90095-1476.

title: Henry H. Barschall, 81; Experimented With Neutrons
description: Dr. Henry H. Barschall, a nuclear physicist who carried out early experiments with neutrons, helped develop the atomic bomb in World War II and then saw his laboratory destroyed by a bomb in Vietnam War protests, died on Tuesday at his home in Madison, Wis. He was 81.

title: With New Deal Fervor, Clinton Pushes Education Plan
description: President Clinton today evoked the spirit of the New Deal in arguing for the package of educational initiatives that were the centerpiece of his State of Union address before Congress on Tuesday night.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ESTHER WILLIAMS, who swam her way into stardom in the 1940's and 50's, is to be honored tonight by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at the Museum of Modern Art. Yesterday, she reminisced about some of the more acerbic reviews she received over the years.

title: Devils Find an Easy Mark in Their Division: The Islanders
description: The Devils imposed their will early tonight and the Islanders offered little resistance. The result was a 4-1 victory by New Jersey at Continental Arena that was not only the first in five games for the Devils, but also their first against an Atlantic Division opponent in more than two months.

title: THYSSEN TO ACQUIRE DETROIT METALS DISTRIBUTOR
description: Thyssen A.G., a diversified German steel maker, agreed yesterday to acquire Copper and Brass Sales Inc., a Detroit metals distributor, for an undisclosed sum. Copper and Brass, a closely held company that processes and distributes copper, brass, aluminum, stainless steel and nickel, has annual sales of about $500 million and 950 United States employees. Thyssen Inc., a unit based in Detroit, has 45 metal-processing plants in the United States that generate about $2.5 billion in annual revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, RUTH
description: GOLDBLATT-Ruth. On 2/5/97. Beloved wife of Ben. Devoted mother of Aviva, Marc, Lee. Cherished grandmother of five. ''Always a student, always a teacher.'' Services Fri. 9:30, Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills.

title: No Headline
description: ''When I see others eating, it's hard. I go to the back, so I don't see any food.''

title: State of the Union: No More Federalism, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Eliminating a Police Chief
description: Mayor James Whelan of Atlantic City scored a victory over the Police Department yesterday when the City Council approved his plan to eliminate the position of Police Chief. The Policeman's Benevolent Association had voiced strong objections when Mayor Whelan said he did not want to replace Nicholas V. Rifice when he retires as Chief on March 1. The move will give the Mayor and the City Council greater control over the department.

title: U.S. Wants Public Interest Rules For New Digital TV Channels
description: The Clinton Administration will try to impose new public interest programming requirements on broadcasters as a condition of awarding them extra channels for use in digital television, Vice President Al Gore said yesterday.

title: Woman Rejects an Abortion
description: Richard Collier, a lawyer, said yesterday that he was pleased to learn that his client no longer requires his services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMER, STEVENSON
description: FLEMER-Stevenson, 71, of Waitsfield, VT. Died Feb. 2, 1997 at Naples, FL., after a brief illness. Born 1/8/26 in Princeton, N.J., son of the late William Flemer Jr. and the late Emma Wilkinson Flemer. Graduate of the Lawrenceville School, Dartmouth College and Harvard Graduate School of Design. Served in U.S. Army Air Corps in W.W. II. Member of the American Institute of Architects. Practiced architecture with Yamasaki, Eero Saarinen, & then with Harry Weese in Chicago, and for many years with his own firm in Waitsfield, VT. Beloved husband of Leslie Fulton Flemer, loving father of Wrenn Flemer Compere, Stevenson Flemer Jr., & Benjamin Flemer and grandfather of Anna and Pierre Compere and Oskar Flemer. Also survived by his brother, William Flemer III of Princeton, N.J. and pre-deceased by his brother, Dr. John Flemer. Memorial service to be held in late Spring in Waitsfield, VT. in lieu of flowers, contributions to American Diabetes Assn. would be appreciated or to charity of your choice.

title: A Deal Reaffirms the Strength of the Individual Investor
description: In the new world of Wall Street, access to individual investors -- clients who were once sneered at by the professionals -- is now viewed as the key to success. And the blue-blood investment firms feel they must have it.

title: Pamela Harriman Is Dead at 76; An Ardent Political Personality
description: Pamela Harriman, the United States Ambassador to France, a leading figure in the Democratic Party and for decades one of the most vivacious women on the international scene, died yesterday at the American Hospital in Paris of complications of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 76.

title: Bearish on Russia
description: The Kremlin cover story about Boris Yeltsin's disability is that he is recuperating from double pneumonia. According to some independent medical minds, Yeltsin is at risk of suffering from the memory impairment that often follows extensive heart surgery.

title: BLOCK DRUG TO SHUT PLANTS, CUT WORK FORCE
description: The Block Drug Company said yesterday that it would close six plants and cut 400 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, in the next three years. Block, based in Jersey City, makes dental and household products, including Polident denture cleaners and 2000 Flushes toilet cleaner. The closings are intended to save $25 million a year that will be reinvested in existing brands and acquisitions, Block said. After the closings, manufacturing will be focused at plants in Brazil, England, Ireland, Puerto Rico, Tennessee and Wisconsin. The revamping will lower fourth-quarter earnings by $70 million, the company said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: C. Bowen Northrup, Journalist, 61
description: C. Bowen Northrup, a former correspondent and editor for The Wall Street Journal, died Monday at his home in Stone Ridge, N.Y. He was 61.

title: Young & Rubicam Dissolves Waring Unit
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York said yesterday that it would dissolve Waring & LaRosa, a New York agency purchased in May that had operated as a stand-alone unit. That agency's largest account will be absorbed by the New York office of Y.& R. Advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSEN, EDNA H.
description: CHRISTENSEN-Edna H., 83, orginally of Forest Hills. Died on February 3rd, 1997. Beloved by surviving nieces, Christine and Debby Bose.

title: Britain's Prudential Bids For Scottish Amicable
description: The Prudential Corporation joined the bidding yesterday for the life insurer Scottish Amicable, offering a package it valued at $:1.9 billion ($3.1 billion) as a challenge to a bid of $:1.4 billion by Abbey National P.L.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MARY C.
description: LEWIS-Mary C. The family records with deep sorrow the passing of our loving mother and grandmother on February 2, 1997. Carol Matthew, Raphael O. Lewis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORETSKY, MILTON
description: PORETSKY-Milton. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY, records with sorrow the death of its member and friend. May God comfort his wife Edith and family. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Arlene Kagan, President

title: And the Winner (Is ... Was) Will Be ...
description: WINNING a design competition doesn't always mean getting to build. On Nov. 23, James Corner, a professor of landscape architecture at the University of Pennsylvania, won out over 500 other proposals to refurbish the Greenport, L.I., waterfront. Key elements of the site are the harbor, a carousel and an old sailing ship.

title: Serbia Crisis: Not Over Yet
description: Although the opposition appears to have won a tremendous victory in its 78-day confrontation with President Slobodan Milosevic, the crisis that has rocked Serbia is far from over.

title: How One Man Confronted And Conquered Impotence
description: MY new doctor told me he was sending over a questionnaire before my appointment. The first page turned out to be a snap: marital status, date of birth, education. The next few pages were something else again: During sexual activity are you preoccupied about getting and maintaining an erection? How often do you have sexual intercourse or attempt to have sexual intercourse? Are your erections straight?

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on Tuesday about advances in transistors referred incorrectly to the flow that is amplified when a current is applied to a transistor's base. It is an electrical current, not a voltage.

title: After the Verdicts, Will It Still Sell?
description: As the verdict in the O. J. Simpson civil trial was flashed across America on Tuesday night, the sound coming from various television networks, magazines and publishing houses was something between a sigh of exhausted relief and a low moan of despair at the prospect of the greatest gravy train in media history finally starting to pull out of town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDMAN, LARRY
description: DAVIDMAN-Larry. On February 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Edna, loving father of Ellen Yuder and Gail (Allen) Goldberger, cherished grandfather of Robin, Andrew, John, Michael and Lynn and great-grandfather of Jake and Dereck. Services Thursday 10:30 ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Through Mourning to Hope
description: Beyond grief, there may be healing. That was one of the themes of ''After Sorrow,'' a production with text and stage direction by Ping Chong and choreography by Muna Tseng that was performed on Sunday night at La MaMa.

title: Promoter Postpones 'Ultimate Fight' in Manhattan
description: A promoter of ultimate fighting agreed yesterday to postpone a match he had scheduled for next month in Manhattan, while legislators in Albany moved a step closer to deciding the fate of the competition in New York State.

title: Surgery for Roberts
description: The Los Angeles Clippers' STANLEY ROBERTS will undergo surgery Saturday for a ruptured disk in his lower back, sidelining the center until at least late March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCH, DR. HERMAN LOUIS
description: MARCH-Dr. Herman Louis, Dec. 4, 1910-Dec 24, 1996. Memorial Service Feb. 9, 2 P.M., Lewis House, Eckerd College, St. Petersburg, Florida. Survived by his daughter Kendall and his many students and patients. Res ipse loquitor. Teacher, Healer, Rebel.

title: PUGET SOUND-WASHINGTON ENERGY MERGER APPROVED
description: The Puget Sound Power and Light Company's planned $868 million acquisition of the Washington Energy Company was approved yesterday by Washington utility regulators. The Washington Utilities and Transportation Commission said the companies would immediately lower residential electric rates by 3.24 percent. Rates would then rise in each of the following four years. Both companies' boards will meet tomorrow to consider the commission's decision. If approved, the acquisition would be completed on Tuesday.

title: 3 Swiss Banks Plan To Establish Fund For Nazis' Victims
description: Switzerland's three largest banks announced today that they are to set up what was called a ''humanitarian fund for the victims of the Holocaust,'' with an initial worth of around $70 million.

title: Unconventional spokesmen talk up U.S. Robotics' fast modems in a new TV campaign.
description: IN a bid to attract the casual Internet user, the U.S. Robotics Corporation, the largest maker of computer modems, has begun advertising on television and featuring unconventional spokesmen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEEVER, CATHERINE A.
description: McKEEVER-Catherine A., of Los Angeles, CA, formerly of Corona, NY, January 30. Born in England 1898. Devoted wife of the late Edward J. Beloved mother of Betty and James, grandmother, and great grandmother. Service is on Thursday, February 6th, at St. Raymond Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y.

title: Vacco Opposes Merger of Telephone Services
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York yesterday opposed the tentative $23 billion merger between Bell Atlantic and the Nynex Corporation, saying that it would deprive New Yorkers of the competition needed to drive down telephone rates.

title: Bronx Democrats Use Arcane Rules to Bump Insurgent Off Ballot
description: Just a day after the Jan. 15 deadline for candidates to file documents to qualify for a special election for a City Council seat, the Bronx Democratic County machine began gearing up. Its objective was straightforward: reduce the number of candidates trying to get on the Feb. 18 ballot from two to the one backed by the organization.

title: Legal Immigrants to Get Letters on Welfare Cut
description: The Clinton Administration began sending letters to one million legal immigrants today telling them that they might soon lose welfare benefits because they were not citizens.

title: For Simpson, Shrinking Economic Prospects and Persistent Pursuit
description: During his criminal trial on murder charges, O. J. Simpson faced the painful but straightforward prospect of years in prison. But now that Mr. Simpson has been found liable in a civil suit for the slaying of his former wife and a friend, he is confronting a significantly more complex financial liability that appears likely to wipe out his fortune and slash his economic prospects.

title: Cash-Strapped Millrose Loses Olympians
description: Six months after the Summer Olympics, track and field in the United States is in such decline that the sport's governing body cannot afford to pay its most accomplished female stars, Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Gail Devers, to compete in the Chase Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBAN, FAIRFIELD WALLACE
description: HOBAN-Fairfield Wallace. Beloved father of Robin Hoban, Susan Hoban Pikal and Kerrin Hoban, suddenly of heart failure on February 2. He will be sorely missed by his family, the chess community and his many friends. Services are private, but a memorial service will be planned at a later date. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to: Isabella Geriatric Center, Fairfield and Anita Hoban Memorial Fund, Attn: Karen Brinn, 525 Audubon Avenue, New York City 10040.

title: A Deco Original Bursts Forth
description: HIS name is barely pronounceable, his reputation insignificant, his design career short, his furniture too rare to be fashionably collectible now. In short, Hugo Gnam (pronounced geh-NAHM), a Swiss-born, Manhattan-based designer who flourished briefly in the Art Deco era and died last month, is the ideal subject for a solo exhibition.

title: AOL's Bottom Line
description: For all its high-tech trappings, America Online's recent crisis is just another chapter in the pitfalls of the curious news and information business.

title: State of the Union: No More Federalism, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. The Board and staff of Brookwood Child Care mourn the death of our longtime Board member and friend. His leadership and compassion were vital as Brookwood continued its mission to serve Brooklyn's most vulnerable children and families. His caring and devotion will be missed. We extend our sympathies to the entire Inniss family. Ellsworth G. Stanton III Brookwood Child Care

title: The Downhill Finally Comes East
description: Bill Johnson, the 1984 downhill Olympic gold medalist, has managed over the last decade to subdue his rebel streak the way Red Adair caps oil wells. But the inner fire in Johnson still rages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, MITCHELL
description: GOODMAN-Mitchell. Educator, activist, mensch. We will miss you. Friends of Mitchell Goodman

title: Welcoming 'Big Brother' Watchfully
description: FOR the longest time, the biggest thing little East Newark had to worry about was its name.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A JURY'S SENSITIVITIES -- The Crown Heights jury asked whether a black or Jewish juror should lead the panel in the racially charged case. B3.

title: Bullets Don't Stop a Captain's Altruism
description: When Capt. Timothy T. Galvin was rushed to Lincoln Hospital yesterday with bullets lodged in his neck and groin, he never lost consciousness, which gave him plenty of time to worry. He worried about the safety of the officers who had helped him search for weapons in the apartment building on the Grand Concourse before they were all showered with gunfire. And as he lay in the hospital bed, swaddled in bandages, he worried about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir, who had interrupted their duties to stand by his side.

title: Captain Leading Weapons Raid Is Shot After Finding Arsenal
description: A city police captain leading a weapons raid was shot in the face yesterday morning after discovering a small arsenal of guns and explosives in a transit worker's Bronx apartment.

title: Solution for the Ages, Or a Nuclear Hazard?
description: In Eddy County, where cows far outnumber people, there is a lonely 16-square-mile patch of Chihuahua Desert that locals call the world's most studied piece of real estate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZIG, MARGOT
description: HERZIG-Margot. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute mourns the passing of Margot Herzig, a remarkable lady, distinguished Trustee, committed friend and loyal benefactor of the hospital. Margot leaves a profound void at HJD. Her lifetime of dedicated work, encourgement and philanthropic support of our major intiatives will always be remembered. To her children Jane Godsick, John Roten, Alan Herzig, and the late Donald Herzig, her grandchildren and great-grandchildren, we extend our heartfelt condolences. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman of the Board Victor H. Frankel, M.D., Ph.D., President John N. Kastanis, FACHE, Chief Executive Officer Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief

title: Prosecution Asserts Payments Were Bribes to Newark Ex-Aide
description: Prosecutors in the Federal bribery-conspiracy trial of the former chief aide to Newark's Mayor today began the tedious job of using financial documents to show that the payments were bribes, not loans, as the defense contends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTS, NATALIE ROE
description: POTTS-Natalie Roe, 87, peacefully at home February 4, after a brave battle with cancer. Widow of William R. Potts; mother of Anne Olson & William R. Potts, Jr. A lifelong volunteer including service with the Bethlehem Day Nursery, the Day Care Council of the City of New York, & the Huntington Hospital Auxiliary. Funeral arrangements are pending.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISER, STEVEN R
description: WEISER-Steven R. 6/25/47-2/6/93 We'll love you forever. We'll miss you for always. Robin, Jessica, Lauren and Jill

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: What Kind of Cactus?

title: U.S. Says It Cannot Meet Goal for Nuclear-Waste Disposal
description: Fourteen years ago, the Energy Department and the nation's nuclear utilities struck an agreement for the Federal Government to dispose of high-level radioactive waste from civilian reactors.

title: Sony's Earnings Accelerate As Strong Dollar Lifts Sales
description: The Sony Corporation said today that earnings doubled in its fiscal third quarter, mostly because of gains in overseas sales aided by the strengthening dollar.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Apple Chief Presses Plans But Offers No New Details

title: In Boston or Hanoi
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Blocks Wake's Road To No. 1 Spot
description: Two years after enduring the worst season in school history, Duke made an emphatic return to college basketball's spotlight tonight, knocking off second-ranked Wake Forest on its home court, 73-68.

title: MORGAN STANLEY AND DEAN WITTER AGREE TO MERGE
description: The Morgan Stanley Group, one of Wall Street's elite investment firms, and Dean Witter, Discover & Company, which sells stocks and bonds to small investors, agreed to merge yesterday into the world's biggest securities company in a transaction valued at $10.2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORRENTI, DAVIDE (ARGUE)
description: SORRENTI-Davide (Argue), age 20, died from complications due to Thalasemia on February 4, 1997. He is survived by his mother Francesca, brother Mario, sister Vanina, step-father Steve, father Riccardo, grandmother Maria, and many loving friends and family. Davide was a creative and talented photographer and artist, published in magazines such as, Interview, Detour, Raygun, Dazed and Confused, Surface, 20 Ans, Biba and others. He also worked for advertisers such as Matsuda and Request Jeans. Davide will be dearly missed. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th St.), NYC. Thurs., 3-5PM, 7-9PM and Friday 2-5PM, 79PM. Funeral services private.

title: By Looking in the Mirror, He Is Living Up to Expectations
description: During the first week of training camp, his new coach said he expected him to eventually be the game's most productive shooting guard. Yet two months into the regular season, Allan Houston recalled Jeff Van Gundy's statement and thought, ''Me?''

title: The Dance Of Infidels In Hempstead
description: THE Jets have become a bit too treacherous for my taste. Call it a hunger for nostalgia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORP.,Norfolk, Va., completed its $115-a-share tender offer for 8.2 million common shares of Conrail Inc., the most it could buy without setting off Conrail's poison-pill defenses. Norfolk Southern is pursuing a $10.32 billion hostile bid for Conrail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSEL, ALVIN
description: KASSEL-Alvin. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our longtime member, good friend and former Governor of the Board. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Doris and the family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZIG, MARGOT ROTEN (NEE BLOCH)
description: HERZIG-Margot Roten (nee Bloch), died February 4, 1997. Adored and devoted wife of the late Julius F. Roten. Wife of the late Leonard Herzig. Loving and caring mother of Jane Godsick, John Roten, Alan and the late Donald Herzig. Beloved grandmother (Gogo) to Jeffrey and Christopher Godsick, Lisa Hoyt, Bonnie Roten, Peter, Michael, Amy and Jill Herzig. Cherished Gogo of Samantha, Trevor, Emily, Sean, Amy and Kelli. Dear mother-in-law of Steven, Barbara, Jeanne and the late Gwen. Honorary member of the Board of Trustees and former head of the Women's Auxiliary at The Hospital for Joint Diseases. She was on the Board of Directors of Ramapo Anchorage Camp. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81 St today, Thursday, at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Ramapo Anchorage Camp, PO Box 266, Rhinebeck, NY 12572 and/or The Hospital for Joint Diseases, c/o Ms. Randye Goldstein, 301 E. 17th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: REPUBLIC TO BUY CALIFORNIA WASTE HAULER
description: Republic Industries agreed yesterday to buy Taormina Industries, a waste hauler in California, for about $250 million in stock. It was the third purchase announced this week by Republic, which is led by the acquisitive billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga. Taormina Industries is one of the largest privately held waste companies in California, serving more than one million customers. Earlier this week, Republic, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., agreed to acquire Courtesy Auto Group, for $30 million in stock, and Wallace Automotive Group, for $55 million in stock. Republic's stock dipped 87.5 cents, to $38.625.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Buckingham Palace Goes on Mouse Alert
description: MICE have invaded the kitchens and servants' quarters at Buckingham Palace, Reuters reported yesterday from London.

title: In Evolution of Clinton, A Few Echoes Survive
description: Four years ago, in his first major address to Congress at the beginning of his first term, President Clinton announced a plan that, among even more audacious initiatives, would make the Head Start education and nutrition program available to ''every eligible child.''

title: Sunny Sound, Sloppy Look
description: In the song ''Pine Away,'' the band Apples in Stereo longs for a distant place and time, a ''simple life where simple pleasures still belong.'' That time seems to be the late 60's, when the Beatles and the Beach Boys were at the peak of their pop powers, and where Apples in Stereo draw the inspiration for their classic, billowing pop. The band is not alone in its nostalgia. On Sunday night at Fez, it was joined by two like-minded groups, the Push Kings and Poole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, LAWRENCE A.
description: FLEISCHMAN-Lawrence A. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Public Library mourn the loss of Lawrence Fleischman, devoted husband of Trustee Barbara Fleischman, and esteemed friend of the Library. His deep personal affection for and commitment to The New York Public Library and to our Library for the Performimg Arts and its staff will be forever remembered. A passionate collector and scholar of art and antiquities, Mr. Fleischman's interest and generous philanthropy have had a profound and lasting impact on cultural institutions in New York, in the nation, and abroad. We will always be grateful for his wisdom and dedication to our Library. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Barbara, and to his children, Rebecca, Arthur, and Martha. Elizabeth Rohatyn, Chairman Paul LeClerc, President Brooke Russell Astor, Honorary Chairman Marshall Rose and Andrew Heiskell, Chairmen Emeriti

title: A Democrat in China: Like an Egg Against a Rock
description: In this gray industrial city in central China, Tong Yi lives a life of internal exile, reduced to the status of a nonperson by the Chinese security apparatus.

title: N.R.A. Challenge Ended
description: Neal Knox, the first vice president of the National Rifle Association who was trying to oust the group's leaders, says he is backing off his challenge because the leaders had ''poisoned'' his reputation.

title: Disabled Adults Unshutter the World
description: John Bromley waits with childlike impatience for the arrival of his photography teacher, who has printed Mr. Bromley's latest roll of film -- exuberant images of friends at a local disco -- and is stopping by with contact sheets.

title: A Design Inspired By O'Keeffe's Life
description: THE Georgia O'Keeffe Museum, which is scheduled to open on July 17 in Santa Fe, N.M., not only has the artist's name on it, but also has the austere and sensual style of her most famous paintings, like ''Jimson Weed'' (right).

title: Opposition in San Francisco to Unmarried-Partners Policy
description: When city officials here gave unanimous approval last year to an ordinance requiring companies that work with the municipal government to offer health and other benefits to the unmarried partners of their employees, it seemed an easy civil rights victory for San Francisco's influential gay and lesbian constituency.

title: U.S. Urges Russia to End Production of Nerve Gas
description: As it fights to persuade the Senate to approve a treaty banning chemical weapons, officials said today, the Clinton Administration has asked Moscow to stop producing a lethal nerve gas that has caused concern among Republicans over whether the pact can be effective.

title: Parcells Off Limits to Jets For Now
description: One day after the Jets named Bill Parcells as their 1997 consultant and their 1998 coach, the National Football League's commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, placed an embargo on him, stating that Parcells was off limits to the Jets until Tagliabue can review all the terms of his unusual contract.

title: Defense Is the Best Offense
description: When a basketball team leads by 36 points and wins by 32, much of its success has to come from its offense. But defense made the difference tonight as Connecticut, the nation's top-ranked women's team, routed Seton Hall, 85-53.

title: Network Formed to Hold Manufacturing Jobs
description: Through the years, manufacturers have tried to stop the steady decline of jobs in New York City by forming trade associations and persuading the city to offer tax abatements and loans. Even so, manufacturing jobs have fallen from a peak of 950,000 in the 1950's to 260,000 today.

title: Nippon Credit Shares Skid on New Rumors
description: Shares of the Nippon Credit Bank Ltd. plunged 16 percent yesterday amid new rumors that the bank was facing a financial crisis. The bank, which has been dogged by such talk for the last couple of years, said that the bank's operations ''continue smoothly'' and that it had ''abundant'' funds.

title: Two Companies Name New Ad Agencies
description: Two account reviews ended yesterday with agency changes.

title: Roche to Buy Flavor Maker for $1.1 Billion
description: Roche Holding A.G. said today that it had agreed to buy Tastemaker, a flavors company, in a transaction that the two sellers, Hercules Inc. and Mallinckrodt Inc. of the United States, valued at a total of about $1.1 billion, including debt assumption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, A. SYDNEY IV
description: ROBERTS-A. Sydney IV, of Palm Beach, Fl. and Westport, MA. died Feb. 3, 1997. He was 82 years old. Mr. Roberts graduated from St. Georges School and Yale University, Class of 1936. During W.W. II he served as Lt. Commander in the U.S.N.A. He was a member of the Everglades and Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach and the Acoaxet Club in Westport, MA. Mr. Roberts was married to the late Mary Ellen Plante (Roberts) and is survived by a daughter Amy Roberts Lee of Palm Beach and Westport, two sons Henry P. Roberts of Mattapoisett, MA, and A. Sydney Roberts V of Palm Beach and Westport, and seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his second wife Mary Stair Roberts. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 8th at 11 A.M., in Bethesda-By The Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach. Interment will be private. For information Northwood Funeral Home West Palm Beach.

title: Sliding Past Color Barrier
description: A public service advertising campaign marking the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's breaking the color barrier in baseball was begun this week by the Simon Weisenthal Foundation, a human rights organization, and TDI, a Manhattan-based media company specializing in transit advertising.

title: Bohumil Hrabal, 82, Who Defied Censors in Wry Tales of Ordinary Czechs
description: Bohumil Hrabal, who was widely regarded as the grand old man of Czech literature and whose novella ''Closely Watched Trains'' became an Oscar-winning film, died on Monday in a fall from a Prague hospital building. He was 82.

title: Mitchell Goodman, Antiwar Protest Leader, Dies at 73
description: Mitchell Goodman, the impassioned author who organized an antidraft protest that led to the trial of the Boston Five in 1968 and helped galvanize opposition to the Vietnam War, died on Saturday at his home in Temple, Me. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISNER, SANFORD
description: MEISNER-Sanford, Sunday, Feb. 2, 1997 at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif., at the age of 91. The Board of Directors, the faculty, staff and students of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre, together with the faculty, graduates and former students of 62 years, join with his family and friends in mourning the passing of their great mentor and teacher. The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre will hold a tribute program to the memory of Sanford Meisner in the Sanctuary of Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54 Street at 4PM, on Thursday, February 13, 1997.

title: The Verdict on Simpson's Story
description: Unlike their counterparts in O. J. Simpson's criminal trial, jurors in the civil case brought by the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman got to hear Mr. Simpson testify. They got to hear his account of the cuts on his hands. They heard him deny that he beat his former wife. They heard him say he never owned the shoes that appear on his feet in numerous photographs. The jury decided unanimously that Mr. Simpson was lying. They also refused to believe his lawyers' familiar argument that blood and other evidence linking him to the crime scene were manufactured by a fast-moving and efficient conspiracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESAVOY, RACHEL
description: LESAVOY-Rachel. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the sister of its esteemed member, Mrs. Leon Feldman, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Journal Rejects Ad From Rival
description: The Wall Street Journal has rejected an advertisement from Fortune magazine promoting Fortune's recent piece on a shareholder revolt at The Journal's parent company, Dow Jones & Company.

title: New and Improved
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLENNIUM CHEMICALS SELLS OFFSHORE UNITS
description: Millennium Chemicals Inc., based in Iselin, N.J., said yesterday that it had sold several offshore companies for about $305 million in cash, which it planned to use to reduce its bank debt. Millennium, a chemical maker spun off from Hanson P.L.C. last year, said the assets fetched close to book value. Millennium did not identify the buyer or the companies, which it said primarily held deposits denominated in British pounds. Hanson spun off Millennium to its shareholders on Oct. 1, leaving the newly independent company with $3.65 billion of debt. The company's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $20.125.

title: City Opera Plans 8 New Productions Next Season
description: The New York City Opera is to present eight new productions during its 1997-98 season, the first one entirely planned by Paul Kellogg, who has been the company's general and artistic director since January 1996. The season will include the New York premiere of Tobias Picker's ''Emmeline'' and the American premiere of Tan Dun's ''Voyage of Marco Polo,'' as well as a staging of Benjamin Britten's rarely performed ''Paul Bunyan.''

title: Unfair Sentencing
description: A provocative report in the Journal of the American Medical Association has underscored the absurdity of a Federal sentencing policy that penalizes the sale or possession of crack cocaine, which is popular in poor black neighborhoods, far more severely than the sale or possession of powdered cocaine, popular among whites.

title: Room for Gardens
description: To The Home Section:

title: Williams Offered a 3-Year Deal
description: The Yankees apparently believe Bernie Williams is a $6 million man, not a $9 million man just yet.

title: Simpson Verdict Confronts A Public Seemingly Numbed
description: Jennifer Day, the 20-year-old white editor of the student newspaper at Wayne State University in Detroit, was at the ballet and ''so happy not to hear about it.'' When her mother telephoned her late Tuesday to tell her of the O. J. Simpson verdict, Ms. Day was annoyed.

title: New York Mayoral Race
description: To the Editor;

title: Times Square to Get More Big TV Screens
description: The battle of the moving image rages on in Times Square, with a Korean electronics company planning to erect two more oversized television screens at the square's south end by mid-March, one of them measuring 40 feet by 40 feet.

title: A Bad Super Bowl Play
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York is persistently tone-deaf when it comes to issues of conflict of interest within his administration. This week he is defending his chief counsel's decision to accept a free Super Bowl trip from State Senator Ronald Stafford, who is also on the board of directors of a state-regulated bank.

title: N.R.A.'s Mistakes Don't Detract From Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ultimate Status Symbol for Yearning Hearts
description: When she walked her collie through the clammy streets, when she went to the park, when she took the bus, Sharon Tauber would see him, the mysterious, dark-eyed man with the long ponytail, behind the glass of the art-cinema ticket booth, and her heart would jump.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an Op-Ed article on Tuesday about partisanship in American politics misidentified the Representative who assaulted Senator Charles Sumner in 1856. It was Preston Brooks.

title: Mexican Rebels Vow a Long, Hard Battle
description: This article was sent from a location outside Mexico City where the reporter and five other journalists were taken blindfolded on Tuesday to interview rebel leaders.

title: Tiffany Interior Under the Gun
description: IT sounds so simple. The Reformed Church of Herkimer, N.Y., needs to restore its steeple. The pastors and the majority of the congregation also want to restore the original pristine white interior of the 1835 building and undo some 1912 alterations.

title: Bond Prices Drop Ahead Of Jobs Data
description: The prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday for the first time this week as investor concern deepened that tomorrow's employment report might come in stronger than expected and revive fears of higher inflation.

title: Wall Street's Search for the Perfect Blend
description: Even as the directors of the Morgan Stanley Group met on Tuesday night to approve a $10.2 billion merger with Dean Witter, Discover & Company that would shake Wall Street, the investment bankers were bombarded with telephone calls asking about their rumored takeover of Paine Webber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRINSKY, DR. MILTON
description: KRINSKY-Dr. Milton. The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center records with sorrow the passing of Dr. Milton Krinsky, a distinguished long-time Emeritus physician in the Dept of Medicine. Our condolences to his wife Josephine and his bereaved family. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees David I. Schachne, Chairman, Executive Committee Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Alvin I. Kahn, Sr. Vice President, Medical Affairs Herbert L. Elliott, President, Medical Board Michael Weber, MD, Chairman, Dept of Medicine

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL BUYS STUD AND PIPE PRODUCER
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it had bought the American Tube and Pipe Company for an undisclosed price. American Tube's products are used in fence construction and in fire sprinkler systems. The company also makes steel studs and trusses for use in residential and commercial construction. American Tube, based in Phoenix, has annual revenue of $120 million. Officials expect the acquisition to add to its earnings immediately. Tyco, with headquarters in Exeter Park, N.H., makes medical bandages, telecommunications cables, burglar and fire alarm systems and fire sprinkler systems.

title: Clinton Is Set to Send Congress A $1.7 Trillion Budget Proposal
description: President Clinton will send Congress detailed proposals on Thursday for balancing the Federal budget by 2002, including tax and spending cuts that Administration officials said would yield a surplus in five years.

title: Rushing to Eat Elsewhere
description: To The Home Section:

title: Dumping Fine is $7.2 Million
description: In what is described as the largest penalty ever imposed on solid-waste haulers in New Jersey for illegal dumping, the State Department of Environmental Protection has ordered the owners of two jointly operated companies in Hillsdale to pay $7.2 million, Commissioner Robert C. Shinn Jr. said yesterday. Sal Car Transfer Systems and Northeastern Recycling Company handled 100 tons of garbage a day from 1988 to 1991 without proper permits and disposed of it in an illegal dump, Mr. Shinn said. D.E.P. inspectors investigated the landfill after receiving complaints from nearby residents, said Amy Collings, a D.E.P. spokeswoman.

title: Plaintiffs Return to Court to Argue Punitive Damages
description: Less than 24 hours after a jury unanimously found O. J. Simpson liable for the deaths of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman and ordered him to pay $8.5 million in compensation, the parents of the victims went back to court this afternoon, this time to argue over punitive damages and to seek a further measure of personal closure.

title: Big Brother wants to manage the broadcast spectrum again.
description: ASK the nearest economist about Federal auctions of the airwaves, and you're likely to get an ''I told you so.'' Only recently viewed by Washington ''realists'' as another impractical scheme from libertarian dreamers who never met a free market they didn't like, competitive sales of space on the communications spectrum have been embraced by mainstream politicians as a painless way to raise revenue. With $20 billion garnered thus far and Congress counting on an additional $2.9 billion from an auction in April, the long campaign to unleash market forces has apparently been won.

title: Veteran Executive Is 'Tough And Direct'
description: When a group of bond traders defected from Morgan Stanley & Company in 1992 to join a competitor, those who stayed behind recalled the words of John J. Mack.

title: An Incomprehensible Bore That Defies Intuition
description: HAMILTON'S BLESSING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFLE, LOUIS A.
description: PFEIFLE-Louis A., of Blue Point on Feb. 3, 1997. President of Rollie Inc. and active in community affairs. He was a former Brookhaven Town Councilman, former chairman of the Board of Directors of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center and a founding member of the NassauSuffolk Hospital Council and the Hospital Trustees of New York State. Member of North Patchogue Fire Dept. A former chairman of the Suffolk Community College Foundation and served as president of the Patchogue Chamber of Commerce. Beloved husband of Joanne Felice Pfeifle. Loving father of Jeffrey Pfeifle, Kimberly Pfeifle, Karen Macielak and her husband Paul. Grandfather of Alexander and Maxwell. Dear son of Carrie Pfeifle. Brother of Richard Pfeifle, Kenneth Pfeifle and Jane Hastings. Closing prayer 9 A.M., Thursday at Robertaccio Funeral Home Inc., Patchogue. A Mass of Christian Burial 9:45 AM Thursday, Our Lady of the Snow Church Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, 101 Hospital Road, East Patchogue, NY 11772.

title: New York Times Co. Posts A 60% Rise in Net Income
description: Citing rising earnings from its newspapers despite a decline in circulation, The New York Times Company yesterday reported that net income rose 60 percent in the fourth quarter, to $52.7 million, or 54 cents a share, from $33 million, or 34 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: CULLIGAN TO ACQUIRE AMETEK WATER TREATMENT UNITS
description: Culligan Water Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Ametek Inc.'s water-filtration business for $131 million plus assumed debt of $25 million to $75 million. The operations make water filtration and treatment products under brand names that include Ametek, Plymouth and American Plumber. The business had 1996 revenue of about $68 million. Culligan, a maker of water treatment products based in Northbrook, Ill., said the acquired assets include Ametek's manufacturing and office operation in Sheboygan, Wis., as well as operations in France and Britain. Culligan's stock was up $1 a share, to $37.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., gained 37.5 cents to $21.50.

title: Uniform Maker Grows From Hup-Hup to Hip-Hop
description: Michael Spiewak, the plain-clothed president of an industrial outerwear manufacturing company, seems an unlikely person to be discussing L. L. Cool J videos and using words like ''funky'' to describe fabric in pearlized pink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFRAN, BETTY ZUNK
description: SHAFRAN-Betty Zunk. On February 4, 1997 after a long illness. Wife of Jack, beloved mother of Eve, Seth and Josh. She will be surely missed by her husband, children and grandchildren and her children's friends. She was the mother of all mothers; loved by all. A feminist before her time and has held in many peoples hearts. Her feelings on God were ''what color is she?'' Survived by five grandchildren, god - mother Dutchie & all of the Goring family. Alumni of University of Michigan. Memorial service Friday, Feb. 7th at 4 P.M., at Community Church of Douglaston, 39-50 Douglaston Pkwy, Douglaston, Queens. Reception immediately afterwards at Douglaston Club, 600 West Drive. In lieu of flowers contributions may be to Community Church of Douglaston. P.S. Stingers for everyone!

title: Potential for Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: Madeleine Albright's Family
description: Madeleine Albright, still settling into her new job as Secretary of State, has been hit by a thunderbolt from the past. She recently learned from research done by The Washington Post that her ethnic and religious background was not what she thought. Ms. Albright, who was raised as a Catholic and became an Episcopalian when she married in 1959, discovered that her parents were born Jewish and that three of her four grandparents died in Nazi concentration camps. She now faces the difficult and bewildering task of reconciling the life she has lived with the world her parents hid from her. Ms. Albright and her friends say she never had an inkling of her Jewish roots.

title: Ecuadoreans Rally in Drive to Oust President
description: Banging pot covers and bearing placards calling for an end to economic austerity, nepotism and corruption, hundreds of thousands of Ecuadoreans filled streets throughout the country today at the start of a 48-hour general strike staged to force President Abdala Bucaram out of office.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 147.54 points -- or nearly 1 percent -- to stand at 18,038.43. On Wednesday, the Nikkei index declined 128.36 points.

title: Possible Partners For Airbus Jet Project
description: Airbus Industrie said yesterday that Alenia S.p.A. of Italy could take as much as a 10 percent stake in its superjumbo jet project and that Saab-Scania of Sweden could take as much as 5 percent. Alenia, a unit of Finmeccanica S.p.A., agreed in December to join Airbus on several projects, including the superjumbo plane, though no formal agreement has been reached. Saab, a unit of Investor A.B., has not yet formally agreed to become a risk-sharing partner, Airbus said.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC TO RENAME ITSELF CBS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would change its name to the CBS Corporation after it spins off its industrial businesses later this year. The media company ruled out such names as Westinghouse-CBS and CBS-Infinity in favor of CBS and its familiar ''eye'' logo after a $30,000 study by Lippincott & Margulies, a corporate identity consultant. Westinghouse acquired CBS Inc. in 1995 and bought the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, a radio company, last December. Westinghouse plans to spin off the industrial operations in the third quarter. Those operations will be named the Westinghouse Electric Company and will be based in Pittsburgh.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday about Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma misstated the action and carried an erroneous credit. Mr. Watts was practicing delivery of the Republican response to the President's State of the Union Message, not actually delivering it. The photographer was Andrea Mohin of The New York Times.

title: A Second Chance at Justice
description: If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Now that O. J. Simpson has been tried again -- this time in a civil court -- we are faced with two verdicts that appear to conflict, and some serious questions about our justice system. One lesson we can draw from the Simpson legal drama is that the civil process is better than the criminal at unlocking the truth.

title: Little Immediate Effect is Seen for City Economy
description: Because there is little overlap in the businesses of Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Dean Witter, Discover & Company, the immediate effects of their plan to merge will be minimal for New York City, company officials said yesterday.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Cornell

title: Objecting to Party Permits
description: Two groups in New Brunswick, home to Rutgers University, sued in Federal court yesterday to overturn a new ordinance requiring a permit for a party of 50 or more people where admission is charged or contributions are solicited. The measure is unconstitutionally intrusive and restrictive, said Jeffrey Vogel, the lawyer for the New Jersey Freedom Organization and the New Brunswick Coalition Against Police Brutality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, JULIA
description: BLUM-Julia. January 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Berthold (Bubie) Blum. Sister of Estella, Esther and Gertrude

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: State of the Union: No More Federalism, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAKUBIEL, SCOTT
description: JAKUBIEL-Scott, age 35 of East Lyme, CT., and Manhattan, died Jan. 27, 1997 in Tampa, FL., at the H. Lee Moffit Cancer Center. He was a graduate of Pratt Institute & was a popular Manhattan party designer and florist. Mr. Jakubiel was preceded in death by his mother, Arline Wye, and sister, Sandra Jakubiel, both of Connecticut. He is survived by his father, Robert Jakubiel of East Lyme, CT. A memorial service will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: Four Years of Change
description: In his first State of the Union Message, President Clinton was full of ideas and plans. This year he was full of ideas and plans, but they were much less sweeping. Page B8.

title: Clinton Tax Credit Plan Won't End Welfare Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: Ramadan Enters New York City School Life
description: As new immigrants and new converts swell the numbers of Muslims in New York City, the rites of Ramadan, Islam's holiest period, have quietly seeped into the culture of the city's schools.

title: Missing Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT'S MOVE TO CENTER LEAVES G.O.P. UNCONVINCED
description: Republicans today spurned a wide array of proposals in Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message despite President Clinton's embrace of such centrist causes as a balanced budget and citizen volunteerism.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia-India Nuclear Deal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLANDO, IGNATIUS
description: ORLANDO-Ignatius ''Nat'' or ''Iggy'' to his family and friends. Loving husband of Dorothy. Dear father of Jack, Denise, Robert and Tony. Loving grandfather of Sara, Cecelia, Nora, Chris, Alexander, Julia & Jack. Also survived by his loving brother Sal and sister Junie. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th Street), NYC today 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at Epiphany R.C. Church, on Friday, 10 A.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Cabrini Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation Chapel Fund, 542 East 5th St, New York, New York 10009.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN S.
description: PERLMAN-Julian S. All of us at New York City Opera express our sincere condolences to Mr. Perlman's family and colleagues at The Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation. His commitment to the cultural life of our city will serve as a lasting tribute.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Architecture Students Live Close to Nature
description: Frank Lloyd Wright believed powerfully in the importance of a well-rounded education, rooted in experience; he also believed in living close to nature. Thus it is that the desert foothills near Scottsdale, Arizona, are dotted with more than 60 odd shelters, built over the years by students at the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture, who sometimes live for more than a year in shelters they design or adapt, some with just enough room for a bed, a radio and a few candles.

title: San Francisco Eyesore Becomes an Oasis
description: WHAT does a retailer do when his store looks out on a bleak, trash-filled lot that is a haven for muggers and car thieves?
