description: DEATSCH-Nancy E. 80, of Tucson AZ, formerly of Shanghai, China and Japan, died January 28, 1997. Survived by nieces Kay E. Ruston of Tempe, AZ, Lynda G. Brummett of Chandler, AZ and Judith A. Haefner of Gilbert, AZ. Graveside services were held Wednesday in Greenwood Memorial Park, Phoenix, AZ. Reverend Carl Carolozzi officiated.

title: Let's Turn Politics Into Confrontation 101
description: To the Editor:

title: Emphasis Is on Operations Over Advanced Weapons
description: For the third year in a row, the Clinton Administration has cut military spending for modernization and weapons procurement to pay for current military operations and maintenance.

title: Geography and Class In 2 Simpson Verdicts
description: Stand on the infamous corner where the beatings and burnings of the 1992 Los Angeles riots began and ask Carl Wilson, a 27-year-old plumber who readily acknowledges that he joined the melee, why he is not moved by the verdict against O. J. Simpson.

title: German Unemployment Soars, Worsening Choices for Kohl
description: The number of jobless German workers soared by nearly half a million last month, to 4.66 million, an unexpectedly steep rise in what had already been Germany's highest unemployment since World War II, according to Government data released today.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Techno Seduction'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNTHER, EDWIN
description: GUNTHER-Edwin. The Reform Caucus of the NY Democratic State Committee mourns the loss of our longtime Treasurer, a dedicated advocate for reform and progressive principles.

title: No Headline
description: ''It kept nagging at me. I was pretty sure I was right that the answer couldn't be determined, and that E.T.S. hadn't thought about the problem that way.''

title: Victims Always Return
description: Arnost Korbel, Olga Korbel and Anna Spieglova were murdered almost a half-century ago. Now at last they are receiving what the living owe the dead of the Holocaust -- to remember their names, and never to forget they were put to death in the gas chambers because they were Jews, for that reason only.

title: Bonds Are Steady Ahead of Jobless Report
description: The prices of Treasury securities were almost unchanged yesterday as traders waited for the release this morning of the employment report for January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VENETCH, STEVEN
description: VENETCH-Steven. On February 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Drucilla, devoted father of Varcia and Frank, John and Karen, loving grandfather of Joanna and John. Reposing at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway at 214 Street, NYC, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral services at Saint Spyridon G.O. Church, Saturday, 10 A.M.

title: 75% Free-Throw Touch Betrays the Gaels
description: Manhattan did not do much celebrating after tonight's game, despite having every reason to.

title: Leaders of Both Parties Tentatively Agree on Plan to Raise New York City's Debt Limit
description: With New York City about to reach a state limit on its borrowing, which would put a halt to capital projects from school construction to bridge maintenance, state officials said today that there is a consensus on the basic elements of a plan to let the city circumvent the limit.

title: Between Budget Line Items, Horse Trades in Invisible Ink
description: Long before the Clinton Administration sent its budget tables, its pie charts and its five-year projections to the printers, it was already hinting at answers to the one question that dominates budget debates in Washington: where is the deal?

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, which marks the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City tomorrow, Sunday and Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Two Real N.B.A. Heroes
description: Dennis Rodman and some of the other bad boys of professional sports could learn a few things from Bryan Fretwell and Brahma Denson, two youngsters who will be honored this weekend by the National Basketball Association.

title: Japan Chip Maker Unveils Next-Generation Prototype
description: The NEC Corporation said today that it had developed the world's first four-gigabit dynamic random access memory, the largest-capacity memory chip yet developed.

title: Anecdotes of an Ex-Slave Turned Master 'Outsider'
description: In the expanding pantheon of outsider art, the down-homey work of Bill Traylor (1854-1949) by now approaches that of -- well, maybe Grandma Moses. What's more, as with that of any old master, his influence has begun to creep into the work of younger, more ambitious outsiders, as was apparent in recent art fairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADBELL, SONDRA
description: RADBELL-Sondra. Congregation Beth Sholom records with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sondra Radbell, beloved wife of our esteemed member Joel Radbell. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Kenneth Hain, Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emer. Howard Wolf, President Lester Henner, Chrmn of Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, RITA RODENBECK
description: ADLER-Rita Rodenbeck, of New York City and Southold, LI, on Feb. 5, 1997. Wife of the late Herbert Adler. Mother of Herbert J., Jr. and John R. Adler. Grandmother of John R., Jr., Brian, Ralph and Paul. Great-grandmother of John R. III, Brittany, Peter, Keith, Griffin and Scott. Memorial services Saturday, Feb. 8 at DeFriest Funeral Homes, Main Road, Southold, LI. at 11 A.M. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, HELENE, M.D.
description: ARONSON-Helene, M.D., of NYC, on February 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Naum Aronson, loving aunt of Claire Komisarow-Perez, sister-in-law of Bela Komisarow and cousin of Ruth Hardy. Longtime Attending and Professor of Psychiatry at NYU-Bellevue. Born in Poland 1911. Helene lost her parents and sister in the Holocaust. Graveside Friday, 11 AM, at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

title: Volcano! Lava! Help! Where's Grandma?
description: Mount St. Helens, call your agent. Maybe you have the snow-capped, lava-spewing look of this season's hottest movie stars. Volcanic action is poised to arrive in a big way, first with ''Dante's Peak'' and then with ''Volcano,'' a latecomer that at least has an ad slogan (''The Coast Is Toast'') better than its title or timing. On the other hand, on today's evidence, one neo-Pompeii picture could be quite enough.

title: In Fast-Changing Silicon Alley, Companies Adapt or Abort
description: In 1989, Bryan Thatcher started 12 Point Rule, a graphic design company, in his loft on St. Marks Place. Two years later, Mr. Thatcher, with his brother, Rob, helped to start Reproman to concentrate on computer imaging.

title: Making the Budget Bearable
description: The basic outlines of President Clinton's budget for 1998 were largely set the moment he made election-year concessions to the Republicans to balance the budget by the year 2002, cut taxes and ax welfare spending. But now that he must live within these tight confines, Mr. Clinton has mostly made sound, compassionate decisions to mitigate the worst harshness.

title: Clinton Presents '98 Budget, and a Goal
description: President Clinton today proposed a $1.69 trillion budget for 1998 that he said would cut taxes on the middle class, increase spending on education and health care and lead to an end to deficits by 2002 -- and for almost 20 years after that.

title: For Children
description: 'Goodbye Marianne'

title: Another Place for Fries
description: McDonald's is planting another set of arches on the Upper West Side.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NOVITSKY, HELEN
description: NOVITSKY-Helen. December 9, 1918-February 7, 1996. I love you forever, Mom. Mary

title: 40-Year Variable Mortgage Returns, in Strong Market
description: In another signal of the growing strength of the New York region's housing market, lenders are resurrecting the 40-year adjustable rate mortgages that were popular among first-time home buyers during the mid-80's.

title: War and Remembrance
description: The woman had not opened the book since she was 7, two-thirds of a century ago. She cradled it in her arms and marveled at the truth that sometimes things are not lost forever.

title: Port Authority Approves Newark Runway Extension
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved spending $93 million to extend one of the runways at Newark International Airport, breaking a logjam between the two states over a major expansion project at the region's fastest-growing airport.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Drawing From Life'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MOLLY.
description: BERGER-Molly. We deeply mourn the passing on Tuesday, February 4, 1997, of our beloved aunt Molly, devoted wife of Benjamin Berger. Molly dedicated her life to family and friends, and always shared with them her love of art and music. Denis and Alan Berger

title: Gore and Chernomyrdin Meet; Agenda Includes a Wider NATO
description: Vice President Al Gore sat down today for two days of talks here with the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, hoping to inject movement into an American-Russian relationship that has been stagnant for six months because of President Boris N. Yeltsin's infirmity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISTREICH, REGGIE
description: WISTREICH-Reggie. On February 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Margo. Loving father of Stacy, Nicole and Carl. Dear brother of Hugo and Adam. Cherished grandfather of Lauren and Emily. Service on Friday, 12 Noon, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Are Distant on Tax Cuts
description: Although both sides say they are optimistic about reaching a compromise, President Clinton's proposal today to cut taxes by nearly $100 billion over the next five years is distant, both in size and composition, from the tax-cutting demands of Congressional Republicans.

title: $650 Million Venture
description: Tishman Speyer Properties, which partly owns and manages Rockefeller Center, and the Travelers Insurance Company yesterday announced a joint venture to acquire commercial and mixed-use property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HO, NORMAN JOHN
description: HO-Norman John. Died on Jan. 23, 1997. An International Civil Servant in The United Nations Secretariat, he is survived by his wife Betty Church Ho, daughter Ann Ho and granddaughter Cheryl Andrews. Memorial service will be at Noon, February 20, at U.N. Church Center.

title: On Benefits, Just Do It
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: $2 Billion Deal Expected For Utility
description: In the first successful hostile takeover in the utility industry, Western Resources Inc. is expected to announce within the next few days the acquisition of Kansas City Power and Light Company for $2 billion in stock, bringing to an end a bitter nine-month battle for control, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Finding Signs of Hardy Life in Tough Surroundings
description: With a strong and colorful sense of its Nova Scotia setting, ''Margaret's Museum'' describes life in a remote coal mining community. It's an existence that the film's reckless, earthy heroine knows all too well. Rough-hewn Margaret MacNeil, played spiritedly by Helena Bonham Carter, has lost a father and brother to ''the pit,'' as the miners call it. And she works as a scrubwoman in the village hospital. Periodically throughout the film, which is set in the late 1940's and early 1950's, alarm bells sound as the hospital staff braces for new accident victims from underground.

title: Even Before Their Completion, Plans for Lilco Are Opposed
description: Even before state officials have completed their plan to cut Long Island's high electricity bills, opposition emerged today from an unusual coalition of business organizations, environmentalists and civic groups.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Art in Review
description: Rudolf Stingel

title: New Jersey Will Not Force High School's Desegregation
description: The Whitman administration refused today to order the desegregation of a predominantly black and Hispanic high school in Englewood, saying any state-imposed regionalization and busing would increase the school's racial imbalance, not ease it.

title: Milton Berger, Flamboyant Soul of Coney I., Dies at 81
description: Milton Berger, a Coney Island press agent who trumpeted the delights of Brooklyn's legendary amusement district so long and with such flamboyant verve that he became a local landmark, died on Monday at his apartment on Ocean Parkway. He was 81 and died knowing that come summer, Coney Island's vast pristine beaches and crystal-clear surf would once again be a magnet for millions and that peals of joyful laughter would be heard deep into the Coney Island night.

title: AVON AUTHORIZES BUYBACK OF UP TO $500 MILLION
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $500 million of Avon stock in the next three to five years. The direct seller of beauty and related products said occasional purchases would be made in the open market. Avon recently completed the repurchase of about 12.6 million Avon shares for $423 million. At the end of 1996, the company had about 132.8 million shares outstanding. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Avon shares closed at $60.375, down 50 cents. The company also raised its quarterly dividend 7.75 percent, to 31.25 cents a share, from 29 cents. The dividend will be paid on March 3, to stock of record on Feb. 18.

title: Yanks Invite 9 to Camp
description: The Yankees yesterday invited nine nonroster players to spring training, including DALE POLLEY, a left-handed relief pitcher for them last season; ERIC MILTON, a first-round draft choice in 1996 who pitched at the University of Maryland, and CARLOS REYES, who was the opening day starter for the Oakland Athletics last season. The additions boost the spring roster to 62.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''What could be more inappropriate,'' JULIA ORMOND asked the audience at a screening at the Council on Foreign Relations on Tuesday evening, ''than a British actress standing up and speaking to a group of important American intellectuals?''

title: SOVEREIGN BANCORP TO EXPAND IN NEW JERSEY
description: Sovereign Bancorp Inc. has agreed to buy the Bankers Corporation for $325 million in stock, expanding its foothold in central New Jersey. The acquisition will give Sovereign 15 bank branches and $2.5 billion in loans and other assets in Middlesex, Monmouth and Ocean counties in New Jersey. After the purchase, Sovereign will be the sixth-largest bank in New Jersey. Sovereign will pay a fixed rate of $25.50 in stock for each Bankers share, if Sovereign's stock remains between $11 and $16.50 a share. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Sovereign rose 25 cents, to $13.75, while Bankers rose 62.5 cents, to $24.375. If Sovereign's stock price were to drop below $11 a share or rise above $16.50, the exchange price would be changed.

title: Telephone Company's Cable, Ruled Unsafe, to Come Out
description: Connecticut's primary phone company has suffered a setback in its effort to become a major competitor in providing cable television service throughout the state.

title: Stocks Shake Midday Slide; Dow Up 26.16
description: A late-afternoon spurt lifted stock prices yesterday, even though blue-chip technology stocks extended their weeklong slide.

title: Student Proves That S.A.T. Can Be: (D) Wrong
description: Colin Rizzio considered himself a numbers whiz, but this time he thought he might have gone too far. He believed he had the right answer to a math question on his S.A.T., but he wondered whether the test's scorers would agree.

title: Encore for a '96 Proposal To Raise Business Taxes
description: The Clinton Administration is looking to Wall Street and corporate America to help underwrite its proposals to cut middle-class taxes and finance higher education, a strategy that met with little success last year.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Fly Away Home

title: Art in Review
description: Rudolf Stingel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, LORETTA VIDLAR ''PENNY''
description: RUSSELL-Loretta Vidlar ''Penny'' to her family and friends, age 52, on Feb 2, 1997, died in her sleep. Cherished wife of Bill, beloved mother of Valerie, devoted grandmother of Katherine Renee and Erika Lynn, and sister to Robert Purvis. A Memorial Gathering will be held on Sun, Feb 9th from 11am to 1pm at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., NY, NY 10014.

title: President Moves to Protect Half of Uninsured Children
description: President Clinton moved today to provide health care coverage to half of the 10 million American children who have no health insurance, and proposed a new program to finance medical care for several million people between jobs.

title: Panel Resumes Talks With Rebels Holding 72 Hostages in Peru
description: Members of a Government-designated guarantor commission resumed contact today with rebels holding 72 hostages in the Japanese Ambassador's residence, seeking a framework to resolve the standoff, which is now in its 52d day.

title: A Dictator Who Has Potential
description: Never underestimate the resourcefulness of a New York woman who can quote textbook chapter and verse about split ends, damaged cuticles and liquid liner. When Joy Miller (Fran Drescher), a plucky beautician from Queens, travels to Slovetzia to tutor the widowed president's children, she is undaunted by the fact that her education ended at beauty school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, HELEN B.
description: LAZAR-Helen B. Yeshiva University and its Albert Einstein College of Medicine note with deep regret the passing of Helen B. Lazar, the beloved wife of the late Jack Lazar and a trustee of the Lazar Foundation. Through the Foundation, Mr. & Mrs. Lazar established a fellowship in cell biology at Einstein, were respected members of the College's Society of Founders & Guardians of the University. To her children, grandchildren and entire family, we offer our sincere sympathy. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Board of Overseers, Albert Einstein College of Medicine Dr. Dominick P. Purpura, Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, JAMES
description: WESTON-James. To Jeanne, Jennifer and Jamie. Thanks for sharing your dad with so many friends. We will miss him very much.

title: New Head Named For D.M.B.& B.
description: MacManus Group in New York announced a shake-up of top management yesterday that included a change in leadership at its largest, most important unit, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROSLYN
description: LEVINE-Roslyn. On Feb 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Rubin. Loving mother of Leonard, Melvin, and the late Eileen Schneider. Cherished grandmother of nine and great grandmother of five. Dear sister of Sam Miller. Services Friday 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Suicide By a Detective
description: A 28-year-old Wood-Ridge police detective fatally shot himself in police headquarters late Wednesday after locking himself in his office and turning off most of the electrical power in the building, the authorities said. Detective Robert Plescia, a police officer since 1989, had returned to headquarters after his shift ended, said Frank Puccio, the first assistant Bergen County prosecutor. Officers in the darkened building heard a single shot ring out and found Detective Plescia in the still-illuminated detective bureau, Mr. Puccio said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIH, TERESA D. (NEE DONG)
description: SIH-Teresa D. (nee Dong). On Feb. 4, 1997. Loving mother of George, Charles, John and Pauline Yan, dear grandmother of 9 and great-grandmother of ten. Reposing the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Visiting hours Saturday 2-6 P.M. and Sunday 1-5 P.M. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:30AM St. Nicholas of Tolentine. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORRENTI, DAVIDE
description: SORRENTI-Davide. You've infused a spirit in us that words cannot describe and we will miss you for the rest of our lives. David Lipman and The LRG Staff

title: Patchwork Lineup for Knicks Keeps Putting Victories Together
description: The collage is not perfect. It needs a bit more glue and is still missing an important 7-foot piece in the middle. But everything else about the Knicks, all their other parts, seems to be in place.

title: F.B.I. Lab Favors Enforcement Over Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, FELICE
description: KAHN-Felice. Beloved wife of Leonard, loving mother of Nancy Dickson and Richard. Grandmother of Jonas, Vali and Emily. Formerly of Roslyn, New York, now of Bellevue, Washington.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Adelphi University referred incorrectly at one point to a professor in the social work department, Brooke Spiro. Professor Spiro is ''she,'' not ''he.''

title: The Merger: Reshaping Wall St. or a Step Back?
description: While some on Wall Street are hailing the merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover as the shape of things to come, it may turn out to be more of a step back into the securities industry's past.

title: Bringing a Little Human Warmth to the Fireworks
description: The American Repertory Ballet is one of many small companies around the nation that have sprouted from local academies, in this case Audree Estey's Princeton Ballet School, established in 1954. But the 22-member company stands out from the crowd. Its strong profile was much in evidence on Tuesday night at the start of the troupe's debut season at the Joyce Theater.

title: Reebok's Suit Over 'Jerry Maguire' Shows Risks of Product Placement
description: In the hit movie ''Jerry Maguire,'' Cuba Gooding Jr. portrays Rod Tidwell, a high-spirited and ambitious football player who nurses a film-long grudge against Reebok for ignoring the gridiron talents he so passionately believes he possesses.

title: MAPCO SELLS NATURAL GAS RESERVES IN TEXAS TO MESA
description: Mapco Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its natural gas liquids reserves in the West Panhandle fields in Texas to Mesa Inc. for $66 million. Mapco said it would buy back from Mesa all the natural gas produced at the fields. Mapco, an energy concern, said the reserves were expected to produce 850,000 barrels of liquids this year. Mesa, an independent energy concern, said the acquisition increased its West Panhandle liquids reserves by 25 percent and its total liquids by 10 percent.

title: Home Video
description: Coming and Going

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIENSTOCK, LAWRENCE
description: BIENSTOCK-Lawrence. We love you. Service Sunday, February 9, 10 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, SANDY
description: TURNER-Sandy. February 5, 1997. Friend, sister and community leader. Chair and a founder of the East Village Parks Conservancy. Formerly Senior Citizen Coordinator for Manhattan Borough President's Office. Coordinator for Oklahoma and Missouri for the 1980 Carter Presidential Campaign. Democratic District Leader. Survived by mother Lettie Turner and sister Joyce Bacon, of Illinois, and many friends and loved ones.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARBERRY, HELEN M. (NEE BOYLAN)
description: CARBERRY-Helen M. (nee Boylan), on February 5, 1997. Beloved wife of Charles. Devoted mother of Charles M., Carol Usiak, Cheryl Gay and Kelly Feeney. Dear sister of Joan Gronne. Loving grandmother of ten. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 9:30 AM, at St. Rose of Lima Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 7-10 PM, Friday 2-5, 7-10.

title: Clinton's Budget Holds Few Clues on Exactly How to Lower Spending
description: President Clinton plans to lower Government spending over the next five years by $252 billion, even as he increases spending -- sometimes dramatically -- on some of Government's most popular programs, from welfare to education to the environment to tax relief.

title: Rules Upheld, So a Bout Leaves New York
description: The promoters of an ultimate fighting event scheduled for today in Niagara Falls abruptly pulled up the stakes to their octagonal ring and headed for Alabama yesterday after a Federal judge refused to ease state regulations that among other things, bar kicks to the neck or anywhere else above the shoulders.

title: CHUBB SAYS IT MAY HAVE BUYERS FOR LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Chubb Corporation said yesterday that a number of potential purchasers had expressed interest in its life insurance unit, the Chubb Life Insurance Company of America. Chubb, based in Warren, N.J., said a sale of the life insurance business is likely to yield the greatest value for Chubb shareholders. The insurance company said that it was also reviewing alternatives for its real estate business and expected to receive proposals from parties interested in purchasing a portion of its portfolio of office buildings.

title: In Shift, Pataki To Spend More On Pollution
description: The Pataki administration said today that it would speed up its plans to spend money from a bond act for environmental projects, after complaints that Gov. George E. Pataki was reneging on his promise to use the money quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAIDO, JOSEPH THOMAS, AKA SMITH
description: KAIDO-Joseph Thomas, aka Smith. Chester and Carolyn Kaido of Lee Center, NY, mourn with deepest sorrow the passing of our brother on January 8, 1997.

title: Easing Food Stamp Rules
description: The State Department of Human Services will ask for a waiver of job requirements for some food stamp recipients in an effort to help people living in places with high unemployment rates, officials said yesterday. The new Federal welfare law requires people who apply for food stamps to have held a job or been enrolled in a training program for at least three months of the three previous years. In November, the state received a waiver of the work requirement for 15,000 food-stamp recipients living in 24 areas where unemployment exceeded 10 percent. If the new waiver is approved, an additional 5,000 people would benefit, John McKeegan, a department spokesman, said.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN SELLS FLOOR-COVERINGS UNIT
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its floor-coverings business for more than $195 million to Quad-C Inc., a merchant-banking concern in Virginia, and the United States private equity unit of Groupe Paribas of France. Collins & Aikman makes automotive interior systems. Proceeds from the sale, estimated at $170 million after taxes, will pay off debt, the company said. Collins & Aikman, which began as a textile company, has been building its business as an automotive-interior supplier. Selling the floor-covering business allows the company to pursue its automotive growth strategy.

title: Retail Sales Increased 5.8% in January
description: The sales increases that retailers were counting on for Christmas came too little and too late for many of the nation's stores.

title: On-Line Service Adds Modems And Posts Loss
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it would add 50,000 more computer modems to its on-line service, giving its frustrated customers more gateways to get through to the dial-up service.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Therrien

title: Holocaust's Children, One by One by One
description: FROM 1941 to 1945, at the urging of the Gestapo, 11,402 Jewish children were rounded up by the all-too-cooperative French police. The children were then transported in boxcars, a three-day journey that ended at the death camps, where virtually all were immediately slaughtered. The transit lists, meticulous German records of convoy numbers and names, included girls and boys, French citizens and refugees. The children were usually rounded up from their homes or the streets, separated from their parents, sent to the Drancy camp, which was guarded by the French police, and from there, like so much waste, disposed of in the East. Only 300 of these children survived: the oldest, the strongest, the luckiest.

title: A Gesture From Swiss Bankers
description: Self-interest rather than a humanitarian impulse has led three Swiss banks to establish a $70 million fund for the victims of the Holocaust, but the action is still a promising move. The motive in this case is less important than the signal that the Swiss banking industry belatedly recognizes it cannot brush off claims that it mishandled the accounts of Jews who died in the Holocaust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, EVELYN SIEGEL
description: ROSENTHAL-Evelyn Siegel. Beloved wife of the late William. Dear aunt. Burial services are on February 7, Mount Neboh.

title: Taxpayer, Not Politician
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley shareholders look like winners in big merger.
description: WHO got the better deal in the merger between Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Morgan Stanley Group Inc.? That's always a question in any so-called merger of equals, and is certainly an issue with a combination of firms as different as these.

title: Determination Keeps Kostadinova Atop High Jump Field
description: For a decade now, the high jump bar has not nudged higher than 6 feet 10 1/4 inches for women, just short of a landmark for the metrically challenged. Javier Sotomayor of Cuba has reached 8 feet in the men's competition, but the world, at least that part of it that measures in feet and inches, is still waiting for the first woman to jump 7.

title: 135,000 Children to Be Struck From Disability Benefit Rolls
description: The Clinton Administration today issued rules that it said would end disability benefits for 135,000 poor children, 14 percent of all children who now receive those benefits under the Supplemental Security Income program.

title: Art in Review
description: Boyd Webb

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the termination of a manufacturing agreement between Bridgestone and Goodyear Tire and Rubber misstated the reason for recent losses sustained by Goodyear. As the article noted, Goodyear attributed the losses to an oil pipeline it began in 1983, not to its relationship with Bridgestone.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about chimpanzees that are no longer needed for biomedical research misidentified the New York county in which the Laboratory for Experimental Medicine and Surgery in Primates is situated. It is Orange, not Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GIUA, MARIO
description: GIUA-Mario. Here's what you missed-Madonna as ''Evita''. We would have had a good howl! Love forever, Angela

title: $25 and Under
description: You can probably count the Portuguese restaurants in Manhattan on one hand. Luzia's has been one since 1994, serving homey Portuguese fare and American food in a tiny restaurant on Amsterdam Avenue dedicated largely to takeout.

title: F-16's Swoop In on Jetliner And Force Evasive Actions
description: One or two F-16 fighters repeatedly closed in on a Boeing 727 passenger jet bound for Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday afternoon, forcing the airliner to take emergency evasive actions so sudden that two flight attendants and a passenger were thrown to the cabin floor, according to the airline and air traffic controllers.

title: Seeking the Meaningful In a Store's Parking Lot
description: ''Suburbia'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Yankees Now Thinking Short-Term on Williams
description: In the wake of Bernie Williams's swift rejection of a three-year, $18 million contract offer from the Yankees on Wednesday night, General Manager Bob Watson said yesterday that his next move would be to attempt to avoid arbitration by agreeing on a contract for 1997. Then Watson would like to resume discussions on a long-term deal for the center fielder.

title: Foreign Aid Is a Bargain, in Dollars and Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAND JURY SEEKS FINANCIAL RECORDS FROM POLICE UNION
description: A Federal grand jury has subpoenaed 10 years of financial records from New York City's 29,000-member police union as part of a widening investigation into allegations of corruption.

title: Former Archer Daniels Executive Is Indicted
description: Reinhard Richter, a former executive at the Archer Daniels Midland Company, has been indicted on Federal charges that he used bogus invoices to steal more than $180,000 from the company.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: QUESTIONS ON ARREST -- The arrest of suspects in a Manhattan slaying has led some city detectives to question whether Federal agents withheld information that could have led to an earlier arrest. B3.

title: Clinton Urges Moratorium On Revenge
description: Confessing that the partisan slights and squabbles of Washington had sometimes made his heart ''a little harder,'' President Clinton urged politicians at a prayer breakfast today to ''rid ourselves of this toxic atmosphere of cynicism,'' forswear efforts to ''get even'' and instead work together for the common good.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Trainspotting

title: Assure Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZMAN, FRANK
description: SCHWARTZMAN-Frank, 87, on 2/6/97. Loving, devoted husband for 64 years of the late Pauline, beloved father of Deborah and Myron, cherished father-in-law of Judith, delighted grandfather of Max. Services 10 A.M., Friday, Parkside, Queens Boulevard.

title: Doorman, Using Radio, Helps Foil Crime
description: In the patch of urban jungle known as the Upper East Side of Manhattan, a modern doorman-to-police tom-tom system called Interwatch was credited yesterday with bringing about five fast arrests in the ambush of a pasta deliveryman on Wednesday night.

title: Donors Urge Neediest Campaign to Go for Record as It Nears End
description: With only three weeks to go in its 85th annual appeal, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has raised more than $4.5 million, raising a slim possibility that with a strong finish the fund could break the record it set in 1992, when readers gave $5.08 million.

title: Two Marketers Shift Accounts
description: Two advertisers ended reviews yesterday by changing agencies.

title: Drollery With a Purpose: Facing a Lover's Death
description: LOVE WARPS THE MIND A LITTLE

title: Peter Pan Is Reborn, And All Go Soaring
description: There's nothing unusual about a woman playing Peter Pan. But when she also supplies the voices of Tinker Bell, Captain Hook, Smee, Wendy, Mrs. Darling, all the Lost Boys and even the baby-sitting pooch Nana -- now, there's something that doesn't happen every day.

title: Chemical Weapons Treaty Serves U.S. Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Corporation For Medical Center
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today creating a public benefit corporation to run the Nassau County Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYBURGH, ALBERT H.
description: CLAYBURGH-Albert H., died peacefully on February 6, 1997 at St. Luke's Hospital. He is survived by his lover, companion, wife Sandra Church, three children Corlies Clayburgh, Jill Rabe, and James Clayburgh, eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Princeton University would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINBACH, DR. HYMAN
description: MARINBACH-Dr. Hyman. AMIT is deeply grieved at the passing of our generous supporter and beloved brother of our devoted Honorary National Treasurer, Edith H. Agus. A man of dignity and professionalism, Dr. Marinbach was a lover of Zion and Israel. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, National President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Columnist Wins a Suit On Articles About Rape
description: A state judge yesterday dismissed a libel suit against the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary over columns charging that a woman had fabricated an account of being raped in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Lawyer's Foundation Awash in Questions
description: John M. O'Quinn is the highest of high-flying lawyers -- and a highly visible one, too, playing a central role in turning plaintiffs' lawsuits involving silicone breast implants into a flourishing cottage industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, ROSE
description: GOLDENBERG-Rose. Wife of the late Sigmund A. Goldenberg. Dear mother of Paula Epstein, A. Carl Goldenberg, son-in-law Sidney, daughter-in-law Sondra. Grandmother to Ellen Bromley, Julie Epstein, Lawrence and David Goldenberg, and Nancy and Adam Kansler. Great-grandmother to Sara, Matthew and Melissa Rose Bromley. Funeral today, at 11 A.M., Gallagher's, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT.

title: Margaret Halsey, 86, a Writer Who Lampooned the English
description: Margaret Halsey, author of the 1938 best seller ''With Malice Toward Some,'' which poked fun at English customs and mores, died on Tuesday at the Nathan Miller Nursing Home in White Plains. She was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, HERBERT B., JR., M.D.
description: WILCOX-Herbert B., Jr., M.D. February 5, 1997. Husband of Elizabeth, father of Herbert B. Wilcox, III, Gordon W. Wilcox, Thomas E. Wilcox. Born in 1908, Dr. Wilcox graduated from St. Paul's School, Concord, NH, Yale College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He served in World War II with the US Army's Second General Hospital in Europe. On returning to the US he practiced medicine in Manhattan and Riverdale, NY and was an a Associate Professor of Medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. In addition to his wife and sons, he is survived by three daughters-in-law Catherine, Virginia and Whitney and five grandchildren: Alex, Tanya, Kate, Christopher and Virginia. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Redding Ridge, CT at 1:30 PM, Saturday, February 8th. In lieu of flowers contributions may be given to the College of Physicians & Surgeons, Columbia University or the Memory Disorders Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA. 02114.

title: Art in Review
description: Martha Rosler

title: 1,000 New High-Tech Jobs
description: High-technology companies are creating more than 1,000 jobs in the state, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. Mrs. Whitman said Chem Network Processing Services of Somerset, QuesTech of Eatontown, Teleport Communications Group of Dayton and Okidata of Mount Laurel will expand. She said Lucent Technologies will open a center for business customers in Parsippany.

title: Ross Finney, 90, Composer Of the Modern and Lyrical
description: Ross Lee Finney, a composer and teacher who was fascinated with the role of memory in both the composition and the understanding of music, died on Tuesday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFRAN, BETTY ZUNK
description: SHAFRAN-Betty Zunk. On February 4, 1997 after a long illness. Wife of Jack, beloved mother of Eve, Seth and Josh. She will be surely missed by her husband, children and grandchildren and her children's friends. She was the mother of all mothers; loved by all. A feminist before her time and has held in many peoples hearts. Her feelings on God were ''what color is she?'' Survived by five grandchildren, god - mother Dutchie & all of the Goring family. Alumni of University of Michigan. Memorial service Friday, Feb. 7th at 4 P.M., at Community Church of Douglaston, 39-50 Douglaston Pkwy, Douglaston, Queens. Reception immediately afterwards at Douglaston Club, 600 West Drive. In lieu of flowers contributions may be to Community Church of Douglaston. P.S. Stingers for everyone!

title: Let's Turn Politics Into Confrontation 101
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: The 10 people at the next table are all gorgeous. The women's bare shoulders emerge from slinky black dresses and they eat caviar with bright red lips. Languidly sipping Krug Champagne, the men lean over to nuzzle their necks, and when they signal for more caviar, a phalanx of waiters resplendent in gold and white uniforms hurries over to twirl the sparkling black eggs in buttered blini.

title: Save Smart Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting of Police Captain Prompts Review
description: As a police captain recovered in a hospital bed yesterday from two gunshot wounds he received Wednesday while searching a Bronx apartment for weapons, the police continued to question the apartment's occupant and canvassed the area for suspects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, LAWRENCE A.
description: FLEISCHMAN-Lawrence A. The Board of Directors of Thirteen/ WNET and Thirteen's president, William F. Baker, extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Lawrence A. Fleischman. We had the pleasure of knowing him through his wife, Mrs. Barbara Fleischman, who has long been part of the Thirteen/WNET family, as a member of our Board (1975 to 1984) and former chairperson of the Friends of Channel Thirteen. Barbara, you have shared your gifts of leadership and friendship with us for many years, and we are with you and your children, in our hearts, during this difficult time of mourning for your husband.

title: Police Chief Admits Having Child With an Ex-Prostitute
description: Police Chief Nicholas Pastore has admitted fathering a child with a former prostitute whom the state has declared to be an unfit mother. The child, a 23-month-old girl, is now living in a foster home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMER, STEVENSON
description: FLEMER-Stevenson, 71, of Waitsfield, VT. Died Feb. 2, 1997 at Naples, FL., after a brief illness. Born 1/8/26 in Princeton, N.J., son of the late William Flemer Jr. and the late Emma Wilkinson Flemer. Graduate of the Lawrenceville School, Dartmouth College and Harvard Graduate School of Design. Served in U.S. Army Air Corps in W.W. II. Member of the American Institute of Architects. Practiced architecture with Yamasaki, Eero Saarinen, & then with Harry Weese in Chicago, and for many years with his own firm in Waitsfield, VT. Beloved husband of Leslie Fulton Flemer, loving father of Wrenn Flemer Compere, Stevenson Flemer Jr., & Benjamin Flemer and grandfather of Anna and Pierre Compere and Oskar Flemer. Also survived by his brother, William Flemer III of Princeton, N.J. and pre-deceased by his brother, Dr. John Flemer. Memorial service to be held in late Spring in Waitsfield, VT. in lieu of flowers, contributions to American Diabetes Assn. would be appreciated or to charity of your choice.

title: Rangers Gain Size And Depth At Center
description: In what Coach Colin Campbell characterized as a trade of ''depth for depth,'' the Rangers yesterday sent the seldom-used defenseman Jay More to the Phoenix Coyotes in exchange for center Mike Eastwood and defenseman Dallas Eakins.

title: Albright: View From a Czech Town
description: On Feb. 25, 1994, the Mayor of Letohrad wrote to Madeleine K. Albright to tell her that her Jewish father hailed from this small Bohemian town and that her grandparents and other close relatives had died in Nazi camps.

title: Son Follows In Steps of His Father
description: FROM the passenger seat in the family car, a coach's son learns early in his life that the real road to the Final Four begins on some wintry route to a modest home or a cramped high school gym. It begins with panache and a pitch, with the father back at the wheel, wondering if the right message was delivered in that much-too-brief exchange with the 17-year-old object of his recruiting desires.

title: Julian S. Perlman, 70, a Foundation Chief
description: Julian S. Perlman, a New York lawyer and foundation executive who supported the performing arts in the city, died last Friday while visiting the Catskill village of Phoenicia, N.Y. He was 70 and lived on the Upper East Side and in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: New York City, Shortchanged
description: Not-for-profit groups have rejuvenated scores of blighted neighborhoods in New York City with the help of a Federal benefit known as the low-income tax credit, which fosters affordable housing in areas that banks and developers would otherwise shun. In a shift that will save the city billions in maintenance and refurbishment costs, the Giuliani administration wants to transfer rundown city-owned properties to those same not-for-profits, which would use the tax credit as leverage to rehabilitate the properties.

title: Civility Upbraided
description: The former Education Secretary, former drug czar and freelance scold William Bennett has made a living castigating liberals. Now he has turned his talent for censure on the Republican House Speaker, Newt Gingrich.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: He Never Says Goodbye

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Bull Market Worried Fed In December
description: Federal Reserve policy makers were unusually concerned about stock prices during their December meeting, about two weeks after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, questioned whether ''irrational exuberance'' had inflated valuations.

title: Car-Loan Crisis Forces Jayhawk Into Bankruptcy
description: The Jayhawk Acceptance Company said today that its bankers had cut off access to new money, forcing it to file for bankruptcy, the latest in a series of financial crises in the auto-loan industry.

title: Oh, My. He's Nude, Isn't He?
description: For almost a week, a four-foot-high statue of the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov stood outside the entrance to Princeton Day School, covered with black shipping plastic and duct tape. After the statue, a donation from the sculptor Greg Wyatt of New York, arrived on Jan. 31, administrators were nonplused to discover that the dancer was portrayed unclothed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER JENNINGS, the ABC ''World News Tonight'' anchor, is planning to marry for the fourth time, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Living Under Suspicion
description: If you're white and confused about why so many blacks think O. J. Simpson is innocent of murder, try a simple exercise. Take a few minutes to sit down with an African-American, preferably a male, and ask whether he has ever been hassled by the police. Chances are you'll get an education.

title: The Philharmonic Offers Britten's 'War Requiem'
description: This week, the first seven rows of floor seats at Avery Fisher Hall were temporarily removed to accommodate the expanded stage needed for the New York Philharmonic's performance of Benjamin Britten's great ''War Requiem.'' So tickets for this program, which will be repeated tonight and tomorrow evening, will be harder to come by.

title: Art Smuggling At Sotheby's: Executives Suspended
description: Sotheby's, the world's oldest and best known auction house, said today that it had suspended senior executives in connection with the smuggling of protected works of art from Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN
description: PERLMAN-Julian. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of Julian Perlman, a longtime member and enthusiastic supporter of the Museum. Together with his wife, the late Jane Perlman, and as President of The Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation, he was a true friend and a generous benefactor. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. He will be missed by all. Whitney Museum Of American Art Flora M. Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Gilbert C. Maurer, President David A. Ross, Alice Pratt Brown Director

title: German Fashion Art as Serious Art
description: GIVEN the current crazes for fashion-related art and photo-based art, the growing interest in one of their intersections, fashion photography, comes as no surprise. The latest indication is ''Zeitgeist Becomes Form: German Fashion Photography, 1945-1995,'' an ambitious if uneven survey organized by F. C. Gundlach, a former fashion photographer and writer, at Pat Hearn and Morris-Healy, neighboring galleries in Chelsea. Sponsored by the German Government as part of a series titled ''Photography in Germany From 1850 Until Today,'' it is one of several exhibitions of German photography in the downtown area right now.

title: Dutch to Open Inquiry Into Gold Looted by Nazis in World War II
description: The Netherlands, which lost 145 tons of gold to Nazi Germany in World War II, has decided to open an investigation into the whereabouts of some 75 tons of its gold reserves that were not returned.

title: Williams Rejects Thumb Surgery And Plays
description: Even the maintenance people did a double take when Jayson Williams walked into the Meadowlands for the Nets' shoot-around today. What happened?

title: Milosevic's Enemies Find Serbian City Hall Is Hardly a Stronghold
description: Mayor Veroljub Stevanovic pushed back the gauzy white curtain in his office and peered through the window at a group of chanting and whistling students in the street below.

title: $1.3 Billion Rise Would Halt Decline in Spending Abroad
description: The budget proposed today by President Clinton would stop the steady decline in spending on diplomacy and foreign aid in his first term. It included an increase in aid to the independent nations of the former Soviet Union and a plan to repay the United States' debts to the United Nations and other international bodies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIMAN, PAMELA
description: HARRIMAN-Pamela. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of its beloved friend Pamela Harriman. An esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council from 1977 to 1979, and of the Board of Trustees from 1979 to 1993, she will be remembered for her wise counsel and devoted participation in the life of the University. During her 16-year association with the University, Mrs. Harriman introduced the work of its scientists to new constituencies in both New York and Washington, DC. Her keen insight, good judgment and remarkable energy will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her son, Winston S. Churchill II, and her entire family. Torsten N. Wiesel, President Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Board of Trustees, and David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman, Board of Trustees and Chairman, The Rockefeller University Council

title: Skip Away 9-5 Choice In Debut as 4-Year-Old
description: Skip Away, last seen defeating Cigar four months ago at Belmont Park, completed his preparations today for his 4-year-old debut in Saturday's $300,000 Donn Handicap. It will be the year's first major race for older horses, and he will enter it as the 9-5 favorite carrying high weight of 123 pounds.

title: Private Places For Flowers And Dreams
description: THERE is a lovely ode to the artistry of a little-known landscape architect named Ellen Biddle Shipman at the Paine Webber Art Gallery in Manhattan. It draws some interesting parallels between the Country Place Era, the years between the 1880's and World War II when rubber and steel moguls tried to outdo one another with their grand estates, and today, when voracious interests range from the water gardens of ancient Persia to Colonial gardens billowing over with the vegetables and flowers Grandmother once grew.

title: Fashion Designer's Killing Is Tied to Lucchese Mob
description: The case sent understandable shivers through New Yorkers. A gunman disguised as a United Parcel Service deliveryman and an accomplice shot and killed a fashion designer on the Upper West Side a few days before Christmas in what seemed to be a botched robbery.

title: Company Briefs
description: KMART CORP., Troy, Mich., will close a store in Detroit by the end of April because the outlet has not been profitable for the last five years. The 120 employees at the Plymouth Road store will be laid off.

title: Set Damages That Hurt Simpson, Jury Is Urged
description: After having won an unusually large judgment of $8.5 million in compensatory damages against O. J. Simpson on Tuesday, the family of Ronald L. Goldman, joined by the family of Nicole Brown Simpson, demanded today that the jury hearing their wrongful-death civil lawsuit make an example of Mr. Simpson by ordering that he also pay heavy punitive damages.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES BUYS YORK WASTE DISPOSAL
description: Republic Industries Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire York Waste Disposal Inc. for $40 million in stock in the fourth acquisition in four days by the company. York Waste is a closely held waste-collection company that operates in south-central Pennsylvania and northern Maryland. The purchase is part of Republic's strategy to expand its waste business. On Wednesday it agreed to buy Taormina Industries in California for $250 million in stock. In the last two months, Republic has also built the nation's largest new-car dealer network. Earlier this week, it agreed to acquire Courtesy Auto Group in Orlando, Fla., for $30 million in stock, and Wallace Automotive Group in southeast Florida for $55 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLUSS, CHAIM SHLOMO
description: FLUSS-Chaim Shlomo. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Hersch Fluss on the loss of his beloved brother, Chaim Shlomo Fluss. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORLEY, CHARLES LUCIEN
description: MORLEY-Charles Lucien, 85, of Paris, formerly of U.S.A. Died on January 18, 1997. The interment took place on January 24, 1997.

title: Banca di Roma to Sell Assets to Padua Bank
description: Banca di Roma S.p.A. said yesterday that it would sell 55 branches and a controlling stake in Interbanca S.p.A. for about 724 billion lire ($453 million) to Banca Antoniana Popolare Veneta S.p.A. Banca di Roma said its Banca Nazionale dell'Agricoltura division would sell its 98 percent stake in Interbanca, a long-term corporate lender, for 627 billion lire in two phases. It will sell a 51 percent stake for 315 billion lire, or 55,250 lire a common share and 33,450 lire a preferred share by April 30.

title: Where China and Brooklyn Overlap
description: NEW YORK CITY has several Chinatowns. The oldest and most well known is Manhattan's, on the Lower East Side. The second oldest is in Flushing, Queens. The relative newcomer -- having sprung up mainly over the last decade -- is in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn. My family and I, Brooklyn residents since 1984, first heard about the Chinese neighborhood a few years ago, when several of its restaurants were recommended to us. The cooking and range of offerings rivaled those of restaurants we frequented in Manhattan, and I was quickly enchanted by the neighborhood, whose modest homes and stores conveyed solid warmth and a sense of aspiration, like the Brooklyn of the 1930's and 40's I have read about.

title: Tobacco Companies Fight Off Vote
description: New York State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's effort to compel two major tobacco companies to allow shareholders to vote on resolutions to curb teen-agers' access to tobacco has been rebuffed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Inside Art
description: Still Waltzing

title: All-Stars and ESPY's Going Heavy on Hoopla
description: Excess. Get ready for it, from the programming surrounding Sunday night's National Basketball Association All-Star Game to the hoo-ha attending ESPN's Monday night telecast of its self-important ESPY Awards.

title: Opel Sales Rise, But Profit May Sag
description: Adam Opel, the German unit of General Motors, said yesterday that sales rose 9.3 percent in 1996, to 28.3 billion marks ($17.2 billion), from 25.9 billion marks in 1995.

title: Real Estate Investor Convicted of Insider Trading
description: A real estate investor has been convicted of illegal insider trading and could face a fine of up to $2.85 million for his role in a 1987 incident that involved a former top broker with Oppenheimer & Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Sotheby's Embarrassed

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Jonathan Larson Performing Arts Foundation misidentified the beneficiary of a concert to be held March 3 at the Nederlander Theater. The proceeds will go to the New York Theater Workshop, not to the foundation.

title: Even With Agreement, A Goal Remains Elusive
description: The most important words about the budget today were probably ones unsaid.

title: William Reid, 86, Textile Executive and Adviser
description: William E. Reid, a longtime textile executive and occasional adviser to the United States Government on international trade agreements, died on Jan. 29 at his home in Tubac, Ariz. He was 86.

title: Barclays in Talks to Sell British Property Concern
description: Barclays P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in detailed negotiations to sell Imry Holdings, a property company, to the Dutch property investment fund Rodamco. Barclays, Britain's third-largest bank, said it had been in exclusive talks with Chelsfield P.L.C., a British property company, but those talks had ceased, a Barclays spokeswoman, Alison Lambert, said.

title: Billboard Sites Are Criticized
description: Several groups in Hudson County have accused a billboard company of violating industry standards designed to prevent cigarette and alcohol advertising near schools and religious institutions. In 1990, the Outdoor Advertisers Association of America advised members that liquor and cigarette advertising should be kept at least 500 feet away from schools and churches. But a coalition of 10 Hudson County groups cited 31 instances in which they said the company, Chesapeake Outdoor Enterprises of Union, failed to comply. Yesterday, Frank Nataro, the president of the company, said he would remove any ads that did not conform to the standard.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Trend of the moment: Cigar bars. Alternate trend of the moment: Female chefs. Put them together, throw in a room designed by the owner, Chris Williams (who also designed Nobu), and consultation by Drew Nieporent (whose own restaurants are just a few blocks south on Greenwich Street), and you have City Wine and Cigar Company, a restaurant and club that not only serves food and wine but also sells cigars, provides humidors and wine lockers and offers seminars on choosing tobacco.

title: Rail Funds Are Reduced
description: President Clinton's proposed budget contains less money than New Jersey Transit officials expected to receive for the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail project, transit agency officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHAR, THELMA H. (HORWITZ)
description: SACHAR-Thelma H. (Horwitz) of Chestnut Hill, MA, on Tuesday, February 4. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Dr. Abram Leon Sachar. Cherished mother of Dr. David B. Sachar, Dr. Howard M. Sachar and the late Dr. Edward J. Sachar. Loving grandmother of Mark, Sharon, Michele and Daniel and the late Kenneth. Great grandmother of Raphael Porag. Services were held at the Sachar International Center, Brandeis University, Waltham, on Thursday February 6. The family will be at her late residence, 250 Hammond Pond Parkway, Chestnut Hill, MA. 02167 through Sunday noon. Remembrances may be made to Brandeis University National Women's Committee, 415 South Street, Waltham, MA 02254-9110. For information contact The Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Female Cop Has Attitude, Will Go Far
description: Apparently because she clanged once too often on the male egos of the top brass in London, Detective Superintendent Jane Tennison has been ''exiled'' to Manchester. Not to worry. Our Jane will continue to shake up the blindered powers that be. Helen Mirren (''Some Mother's Son'') is back as Tennison, and ''Prime Suspect 5'' adds yet another impressive credit to one of the most impressive series, not to mention outstanding female performances, of the decade.

title: Chemical Neutralization Is Gaining in War on Poison Gas
description: When President Clinton challenged Congress on Tuesday to ''at last begin to outlaw poison gas from this earth,'' viewers of the State of the Union address may have envisioned conveyor belts feeding nerve gas rockets into furnaces.

title: Joining Dad At Work: Bad Idea
description: Characters in films aren't much inclined to Pirandellian rebellion. Still, it would have been a blessing if Farmer, played by Ben Gazzara in ''Farmer and Chase,'' had grabbed his creator by the lapels for a fatherly chat: ''Listen,'' he would say, ''if you make me take my wimp son into the family business, someone is going to wind up dead, and worse yet for you, the audience is going to come down with a bad case of the blahs.''

title: Seasoned Lobbyist Gave No Quarter In Quest to Legitimize Bloody Sport
description: A clue to the power of the lobbyist for ultimate fighting, James D. Featherstonhaugh, can be found on his sleeves. There, clasping the cuffs of a crisp shirt, are silver links embossed with the state seal.

title: North Korean Defector's Tale Reminds Japan of a Lost Girl
description: It was 19 years ago that a 13-year-old girl named Megumi Yokota set off from school to walk home, said goodbye to two friends just a few hundred yards from her home, and then vanished.

title: Erotic Fantasies as Topics To Discuss With Strangers
description: Gender-bending and acting out one's erotic fantasies in public have become so commonplace, thanks to television talk shows, that every self-respecting channel surfer has had ample opportunity to ponder the endless permutations and combinations of desire on parade. That's one reason why ''Visiting Desire,'' an exploration of fantasy by the experimental New York film maker Beth B, seems so pallid and behind the cultural curve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUIE, WILLIAM
description: LOUIE-William, 51, of Waldwick, NJ on February 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Michael, Trisha and Debra. Partner of Art Station in NY. Visitation on Sunday at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. Services at Old Paramus Reformed Church, Ridgewood on Monday. Contributions to American Cancer Society or Old Paramus Reformed Church.

title: Taiwan Exports Fall 3.4%
description: Taiwan's exports fell 3.4 percent in January from a year earlier amid a drop in shipments of electronics goods, the country's biggest export industry. Exports declined last month to $10.3 billion from $10.7 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said this week in a monthly report. Shipments of electronics products fell 10.4 percent, to $1.5 billion, in part because of lower prices for semiconductors and slow demand, said K. C. Hsu, the ministry's chief statistician.

title: Albright's Heritage Can Provide Inspiration
description: To the Editor;

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: High Stock Prices Caused Worry at Fed Meeting

title: A World Still Spun By Romance
description: One of the fixtures at the Hotel de Love, a transcendently tacky honeymoon hotel in Australia, is a silver-haired singing pianist named Ronnie (Alan Hopgood) who serenades the guests with croaking renditions of pop nuggets that seem to have found eternal life on ''lite'' FM radio. ''Love Will Keep Us Together,'' ''I Honestly Love You,'' ''Lost in Love,'' ''Hey, Paula!,'' ''Reminiscing'' and ''Baby I'm-a Want You,'' they're all at Ronnie's none-too-nimble fingertips.

title: Albright's Heritage Can Provide Inspiration
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spoken Word
description: ANNIE DILLARD, New York University, D'Agostino Hall, 108 West Third Street, Greenwich Village. A reading by the writer. Tonight at 7. Free. Information: (212) 998-8816.

title: Selling Votes Is Legal, So Russians Shop Around
description: The most star-studded and bizarre election in Russia's short experiment with democracy is to be held here on Sunday, and it has just about driven Aleksei Avdoshin around the bend.

title: North Korea Agrees to Take Taiwan Atom Waste for Cash
description: Facing famine and desperate for hard currency, North Korea has agreed to accept up to 200,000 barrels of nuclear waste from Taiwan, in exchange for tens of millions of dollars.

title: Pioneer in Sociology, Persevering Fighter for Civil Rights
description: For generations of black scholars, journalists and advocates of black causes, W. E. B. Du Bois stood as teacher, model, inspiration. If he is not so well remembered now, tonight's elegantly produced two-hour tribute may be a corrective. It celebrates his accomplishments -- and, some viewers may add, missteps -- between his birth in Massachusetts in 1868, when black Americans were barely emerging from slavery, to his death in Ghana in 1963, a day before the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s March on Washington.

title: Sea Change Down Under: Drifting to the Orient?
description: Their names are Fiona and Trevor and Caitlin, and their Australian accents are as broad as the Outback, but their parents hail from Hong Kong, Taiwan, Vietnam and Malaysia.

title: INTELLIGENT ELECTRONICS TO SPIN OFF XLCONNECT
description: Intelligent Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its XLConnect Solutions Inc. unit to shareholders. The spinoff would be subject to regulatory clearance, as well as approval by the Internal Revenue Service that the move could be completed on a tax-free basis, the companies said. Intelligent Electronics would give its shareholders 13.325 million shares of XLConnect common stock. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, XLConnect shares rose 25 cents each, to $7.50, valuing the spinoff at $100 million. Shares of Intelligent Electronics rose 25 cents, to $4.375. Intelligent Electronics, a computer-networking company, expected the spinoff to be completed by the end of the summer. The company owns 80 percent of XLConnect.

title: Trial Reruns May Heighten Polarization
description: SCOTT FITZGERALD got it wrong when he wrote that ''there are no second acts in American lives,'' but don't blame him. He didn't live long enough to witness American jurisprudence in the 1990's, with celebrated trials continually getting a second life.

title: BTR Agrees to Buy French Meter Group
description: The British industrial conglomerate BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Pollux Meter Group of France for $:163 million ($267.4 million).

title: Financial Problems Remain and Squabbles Must Be Settled
description: The latest firestorm began when the local Governor scoffed that speed skating is uninteresting, a bit like watching water beetles flit about the surface of a pond.

title: Bankers Questioned In South Korean Scandal
description: South Korean prosecutors questioned a former head of a South Korean bank and two current executives yesterday on suspicion of having taken bribes from the troubled Hanbo group in return for huge loans. The executives are the president of the Korea Exchange Bank, Chang Myung Sun; the president of the Korea Development Bank, Kim Shi Hyung, and the former president of the Cho Hung Bank, Lee Jong Yun.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NIEROW, JULIUS
description: NIEROW-Julius. February 7, 1996. We love you and miss you. You will be with us always. Your family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHMAD, ABU S. I.
description: AHMAD-Abu S. I. Beloved husband of Sophia. Died December 30, 1996, Paris, France.

title: Tagliabue May Press For a Deal on Parcells
description: Bill Belichick's reign as coach of the Jets might end as quickly as it started, with Bill Parcells, the Jets' coach-in-waiting, taking over the team as early as next week.

description: To the Editor:
