description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, LEONARD
description: BERKMAN-Leonard, on February 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Ray. Loving father of Paula and George Akst and Howard and Eileen Berkman. Adored and adoring grandfather of Jill and Rebecca Akst and Deborah and Emily Berkman. Cherished brother of Dorothy Nowak and Alvin Berkman. Service on Sunday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, ISADOR
description: BRESSLER-Isador, age 97, February 6. Survived by his wife Ethel, daughter Joan and Dr. Waldo Greenspan, brothers David and Ira, granddaughters Jane Sims and Nancy Greenspan, great grandchildren Zachary and Emma Sims. Services 1pm, today at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INNISS, CHARLES E.
description: INNISS-Charles E. The Board and staff of The New York City Police Foundation are saddened by the passing of former trustee, Charles Inniss. His profound commitment to community initiatives has improved the quality of life in Brooklyn, and will live on for future generations to enjoy. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Robin L. Farkas, Chairman Pamela D. Delaney, Exec. Dir.

title: Profit Rose for Quarter At British Telecom
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 9.6 percent in the last three months of 1996 on higher revenue from overseas operations. The company said it earned $:909 million, or $1.55 billion, in its fiscal third quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, up from $:829 million in the period a year earlier. Sales were up 3.6 percent, to $:3.76 billion.

title: MORRISON PETROLEUMS IN TALKS WITH POTENTIAL BIDDERS
description: Morrison Petroleums Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said yesterday that it was in talks that were likely to result in a more attractive bid than the unsolicited $652 million Canadian ($484.5 million American) takeover offer by the Canadian 88 Energy Corporation. In January, Morrison rejected Canadian 88's offer of $10 Canadian a share as ''financially inadequate'' and said it would solicit competing offers. Morrison said it was issuing the statement because shareholders who tendered their shares to Canadian 88 might not be able to withdraw their deposited shares after yesterday's deadline.

title: Painful Truth
description: South Africans thought they knew the worst about the crimes of apartheid. They did not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREINCES, MOLLIE
description: KREINCES-Mollie. Beloved wife of Arthur. Loving mother of Howard and Loraine, Leonard and Sheila. Dear sister of Ruth. Devoted mother-in-law of Doris. Cherished grandmother of Brad and Amy, Robin, Edward, Henry and Lisa, Jeffrey and Melissa, Beth and Jeffrey. Adored great grandmother of five. Service today 12 PM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, B. WELLINGTON
description: MURRAY-B. Wellington, age 55. Passed on Jan. 16, 1997. Musician who led the steel band, The Sound of Central Park, he was professionally known as Lord Wellington. Services held Jan. 25, 1997 in Miami, FL. Survived by a host of family and friends. Contributions may be made to Phoenix House. NYC memorial to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISNER, SANFORD
description: MEISNER - Sanford. Sandford Meisner was a longtime supporter and friend of The Working Theatre. We will miss him.

title: Barros Out 8 Weeks
description: DANA BARROS of the Boston Celtics will undergo surgery Monday on his left ankle, sidelining the guard for at least eight weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSEL, ALVIN L.
description: KASSEL-Alvin L. Dearest Doris, Kim, Bonnie and Kal, our hearts are filled with sadness. We mourn deeply of the passing of our beloved dearest and devoted friend Alvin. His friendship with our family will be an everlasting source of strength and loving memory. We will miss him and love him always and forever. Beverly and Larry Parsly and Family

title: Late Disappearing Act Does In the Nets Again
description: His locker was as bare as a college dormitory room after finals. Shawn Bradley was out of here, making his getaway for the All-Star Game break in brisk fashion. But at least everyone knew he had been here tonight. At least for a while.

title: Corrections
description: The television ratings on Wednesday for the week of Jan. 27 to Feb. 2 omitted a program. The ABC news magazine ''20/20'' should have been listed as No. 8, with a 13.9 rating and a 25 share. ''American Music Awards'' should have been one place lower, at No. 9, and ''60 Minutes'' and ''Spin City'' tied for No. 10.

title: Art in Review
description: Marina Abramovic

title: Seeing Bias in Their Utiity Rates, Mixed-Race South Africans Riot
description: Residents of mainly mixed-race neighborhoods around Johannesburg took to the streets today, blocking roads with debris and burning tires, throwing rocks and in some cases looting stores to protest what they say is discrimination by South Africa's new Government.

title: Poland, or Taiwan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, DAVID
description: GRANT-David. On February 7, 1997. Dearly beloved husband of Pauline. Loving father of Stephen and Robert. Devoted to his daughters-in-law Ruth and Bridget and to his grandchildren: Joseph, Laura, Thomas, Anna, Neil and Jane. He adored his family and was loved and cherished by them for his good humor and kindness. We shall miss him greatly. Services are on Sunday, February 9, 1 P.M., at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: LVMH MOET IS NEAR TAKEOVER OF DFS GROUP
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. is close to an agreement with Robert Miller, the billionaire, to buy his 38.75 percent stake in DFS Group Inc., a person familiar with the matter said yesterday. Executives with LVMH are said to be confident they can reach an agreement with Mr. Miller within a month. LVMH, the Paris-based luxury goods maker, last month completed its $2.47 billion purchase of a 58.75 percent stake in DFS from the co-founders Alan Parker and Charles Feeney. The company acquired Anthony Pilaro's 2.5 percent holding a week later.

title: A Shattered Career Rebuilt, And Now a Debut in Boston
description: Susan Davenny Wyner never intended to become a conductor. This is just one of the paradoxes about the concert she will conduct on Monday at Jordan Hall in Boston with an orchestra of top-notch freelancers. It will be the most significant and challenging performance of a lifetime that has been brushed with near-tragedy.

title: Stocks Close Higher as Dow Gains 82.74
description: A fickle stock market soared, sputtered, and then soared again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending sharply higher. The session showed once again how jittery the market can be in reaction to a news headline.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Support for Strong Dollar May Be Ending, Rubin Hints

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, LEONARD
description: BERKMAN-Leonard, on February 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Ray. Loving father of Paula and George Akst and Howard and Eileen Berkman. Adored and adoring grandfather of Jill and Rebecca Akst and Deborah and Emily Berkman. Cherished brother of Dorothy Nowak, Alvin Berkman and the late Irving Berkman. Service on Sunday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Harlem Dancers Picket Offices
description: The striking dancers of Dance Theater of Harlem picketed the company's headquarters on West 152d Street yesterday morning to protest auditions held there for replacement dancers. The dancers, members of the American Guild of Musical Artists, voted unanimously to strike on Jan. 21 after negotiations for a new one-year contract stalled, chiefly over the issues of apprentice dancers and increased working hours.

title: Beliefs
description: Nowhere in his latest book, ''Democracy's Discontent,'' does the Harvard political theorist Michael J. Sandel discuss assisted suicide or euthanasia, but one of his book's distinctions may be fundamental for framing what promises to be a long and difficult national debate over those issues.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Accepting Schubert in Toto

title: INSIDE
description: Jury Urged to Use Its Power

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Tail-Wagging End to a Long, Long Journey
description: Boris was back.

title: Vero Wynne-Edwards, 90, Evolution Theorist
description: Vero C. Wynne-Edwards, a British ethologist and naturalist whose writings on group selection in evolution became the focus of an often-acrimonious debate among theorists in the 1960's and 70's, died on Jan. 5 in a nursing home in Banchory, Scotland. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, WILLIAM H., MD
description: BERNSTEIN-William H., MD, 88, of Miami Beach, Fla. passed away Feb. 7, 1997. Husband of the late Freda (Fritzi). He is survived by children Janet (Stephen) Treadway, Susan Bernstein, and Bonnie (Peter) Dockter. Grandchildren: Charles Dockter, Sarah Dockter and Verne Thalheimer. A graduate of Tufts University and Tufts University Medical School, Dr. Bernstein was a Cardiologist at Mt. Sinai Medical Center from its inception through the present. A Board Member at Miami Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, he was also a member of the Dade and Florida Medical Association as well as the American Heart Association. Services will be 10AM, Sunday, Feb. 9th at Temple Emanuel on Miami Beach.

title: Military Pilots' Mission: To Intercept the Enemy
description: Their mission is to protect vast stretches of airspace off the New Jersey coastline, and almost daily, members of the Air National Guard's 177th Fighter Wing climb into sleek military jets and practice maneuvers up and down the shore. Most are commercial airline pilots who served in the Air Force before they joined the unit.

title: Personal Ads Draw Love-Parched To (Mainly Coffee) Bar
description: The bulletin board about halfway into the bar was shingled with hundreds of personal ads: Here was one from an investment banker with a thing for tall women. A 21-year-old blues singer, ''ready for a cerebral adventure,'' wrote that she wanted ''eyes that speak poetry.'' And there, on a stool across from the board, sat Lisa Jablonsky, 34, on a blind date with a man who had just informed her that truth be told, he had been dating someone for several months.

title: Fiscal Chicanery in New Jersey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey often describes herself as a fiscal conservative and social moderate. Her recent $16.4 billion budget proposal, geared to her re-election campaign, is indeed more generous to schools, the environment and other programs than past budgets were. But in fiscal terms, Mrs. Whitman's plans are anything but conservative. Once again she is using reckless gimmicks to balance the books. Her worst idea is to siphon huge sums from the state's pension systems to pay for ongoing government expenses and then replenish the pension funds with the proceeds from the biggest borrowing in state history.

title: AULT FOODS IS SELLING SOME ASSETS TO AGROPUR
description: Ault Foods Ltd.. based in Toronto, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell milk and cultured-products assets to the Agropur cooperative for about $145 million (Canadian), or about $107.4 million (United States). The sale includes the fixed assets of its Ontario fluid milk business and the rights to use Sealtest and certain other milk brands. The cooperative will also acquire the refrigerated and cultured-products business across Canada. Agropur, based in Granby, Quebec, is owned by 4,600 dairy farmer members and operates 14 processing plants across Canada. Ault will continue to sell milk throughout the province under the Sealtest and Lactantia brand names.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEY, ROSS LEE
description: FINNEY-Ross Lee. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of music.

title: Gershwin and New York Reflecting Their Tributes
description: The atmosphere was surprisingly placid on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, given the exuberance and electricity inherent in the program presented by the New York City Ballet. But a handful of memorable performances were scattered throughout.

title: Denials in Bribery Trial
description: The girlfriend of a former Newark mayoral aide who is on trial on Federal bribery charges, tried yesterday to dispel the prosecution's suggestion that $157,000 found in her home was illegally obtained.

title: Daniels Returns to the C.B.A.
description: Lloyd Daniels has rejoined the Fort Wayne Fury of the Continental Basketball Association.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: The Anglo-Saxon Way of Life? Mais Non!
description: When Europeans and Americans take stock of one another from their respective sides of the Atlantic, the results are predictable: caricatures, prejudice and mutual misunderstandings.

title: Don't Turn Blind Eye To the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Is Urged to Push Space Commercialization
description: While NASA has continually expressed support for commercializing space, it has a poor track record for encouraging businesses to invest in space activities, a private research group said today.

title: Harassment Vote at Rutgers
description: In a victory for faculty members, the Rutgers University Senate voted yesterday to let a five-member panel of students and faculty adjudicate harassment cases. The university's administrators, with the support of some professors and most of the student body, had argued that a single official trained in the intricacies of harassment law would be a better judge of these cases than a panel.

title: A Supplier Strike Idles Lines at Ford
description: Johnson Controls Inc. and the United Automobile Workers said today that they had made no plans to resume the contract negotiations that broke off at midnight, stopping production of some Ford Motor vans and trucks.

title: Shares of Schroders Rise on Bid Rumors
description: The shares of Schroders P.L.C. rose 3.7 percent yesterday to a record amid speculation that the company, Britain's largest independent investment bank, might be the target of a takeover bid, traders said. Shares of Schroders closed at 1,750 pence, up 62.5 pence.

title: Ewing Sounds A Warning For the Bulls
description: The last few years, he believed. He meant everything he said. But never before has Patrick Ewing felt the conviction he is feeling today. During his annual public discourse during All-Star Weekend, he made it clear that he believes his Knicks can unseat Michael Jordan's Bulls.

title: Judicial Dadaism
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ
description: Quintet on a Coltrane Model

title: No Headline
description: ''Not only can foreign policy be cool, but it can be awesome.''

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: Championship Aspirations

title: As Rebels Gain in Zaire, Army Morale Is Declining
description: For months after rebels invaded the border towns of eastern Zaire in October, their insurrection was confined to a long but narrow strip of land 1,000 miles from the capital. This country's vastness seemed to offer the Government here a kind of protection that its woeful army could not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYBURGH, ALBERT H
description: CLAYBURGH-Albert H. The officers and members of the Typophiles note with deep regret the death on February 6, 1997 of Albert H. Clayburgh, our longtime member and benefactor. His support of our organization and his many kindnesses will always be remembered. The Typophiles extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Theo Rehak, President

title: Sweepstakes Take Advantage of Hopeful Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan Balks at Warning Consumers on Contaminated Salmon
description: Just weeks before the 1997 fishing season begins in Michigan, the Environmental Protection Agency is threatening to do what the state has so far refused to do: warn the public against eating too much salmon caught in the state's Great Lakes waters.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about the proposed purchase of Nationalpak by the First Brands Corporation misstated the change in First Brands' earnings for the second quarter. They rose 5 percent; they did not fall five-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's background misstated the date she took office. It was Jan. 23, not Dec. 5, the date she was nominated.

title: Pataki Speech In Florida Had New York Ties
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and his aides have said repeatedly that his paid speechmaking causes no ethical problem, saying they carefully restrict his paid appearances to out-of-state venues, to avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest.

title: Illegal Immigrants Rose to 5 Million in '96
description: The estimated number of immigrants living in the United States illegally has increased by about 1.1 million people, to a total of 5 million people in the last four years, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today.

title: No Crown Heights Decision
description: A Federal jury in Brooklyn deliberated for a third day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the case of Lemrick Nelson Jr., 21, and Charles Price, 43, two black men charged with violating the civil rights of Yankel Rosenbaum, a Hasidic Jew who was fatally stabbed during the Crown Heights racial violence of 1991. Deliberations will resume on Monday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. The jurors, given a choice by Judge David G. Trager, voted to take the weekend off rather than continue the deliberations.

title: Toyota Output Hurt By Fire at Supplier
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation's production will fall behind by 50,000 vehicles after a fire at a parts supplier last week forced the closing of two plants, the vice chairman, Iwao Isomura, said yesterday. The company said it expected to resume normal production by Monday. It is not clear yet whether Toyota can make up the lost production by the end of the year, he said.

title: Executive Quits At Euro Disney
description: Euro Disney said this week that Xavier de Mezerac, the finance director credited with bringing the company's costs under control, had resigned after two years ''to explore career opportunities outside the company.''

title: Baiul Discusses Auto Wreck
description: OKSANA BAIUL, the Olympic skating champion, says she had four or five mixed drinks before crashing her Mercedes but that she was not drunk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONAN, ANDRE'
description: CONAN-Andre'. On February 6, 1997. Owner of Jeunesse Coiffure. Loving son of Louise. Beloved husband of Liliane (nee Milliou). Devoted father of Cyrille Conan and Francisca Papagno. Father-inlaw of Michael Papagno. Loving brother of Ausbert, Rene', Colette, Marie and Celestine. Family will receive friends on Saturday, February 8, at Leo F. Kearns, 6140 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, NY. Visiting 10:30AM-2:30pm. Religious services at 2:30 P.M. Donations to American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: NOODLE KIDOODLE TRIMS EXPANSION PLANS
description: The educational toy retailer Noodle Kidoodle Inc. said yesterday that it would scale back planned store openings in 1997 and cut 15 workers from its administrative staff. The company, based in Farmingdale, L.I., originally planned to open 10 stores in 1997, but its expansion plans now include just two stores for which it has already signed leases: one in Braintree, Mass., and another in Northville, Mich. Noodle Kidoodle also said that sales in the fourth quarter, which ended on Feb. 1, rose 72 percent, to $28.7 million, and more than doubled in the year, to $57.7 million. But sales in stores open more than a year, a closely watched indicator in the retailing industry, were unchanged.

title: A Pretty Good Life
description: The life story of Pamela Harriman, who died in Paris this week, reads like one of those bad novels in which women with gumption to spare come from nowhere and make the world their private property. As fiction it is old and tired, but when a real woman really pulls it off it is quite wonderful, probably because the real world's deck is so heavily stacked against real women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKIN, SYLVIA
description: LIPKIN-Sylvia. (nee Reiner). Died suddenly on Feb. 5, 1997. Survived by her son Stephen Kusiel and her daughter Susan Beesemyer. Memorial gathering will be held at the Manhattan home of her son on Monday, February 10 at 11A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEGGIERO, CHRIS
description: LEGGIERO-Chris. Happy Birthday. We will always love you. Mom, Dad, Marie, Dimitri Michael, Gregory

title: Injuries Take Sparkle Off All-Star Luster
description: Patrick Ewing, Alonzo Mourning and other National Basketball Association luminaries are too sore to play. Chris Gatling and Kevin Garnett, emerging players with unpolished games, will have to do. Meanwhile, the last-known whereabouts of Charles Barkley and Michael Jordan was a golf course in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Topics of The Times
description: The F-16 Mystery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALZMANN, ANTHONY
description: ALZMANN-Anthony. The Ocean Bay Park Association sadly notes the passing of this kind and gentle man, a fisherman at heart. A resident of OBP for over 40 years, Tony gave unstintingly to friends, neighbors, and especially to the volunteer fire department.

title: Evidence of a Murder-Suicide
description: Two Vineland teen-agers who had been reported missing by their parents were found shot to death yesterday in what appeared to have been a murder-suicide, Cumberland County prosecutors said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Air Force Halts Some Flights After 2d Close Call in 3 Days
description: After another encounter today between military jets and passenger planes, the Air Force tonight suspended all its flights, including the Air National Guard's, in the areas off the East Coast reserved for military use until its pilots can review the rules on how close military planes may approach civilian airliners.

title: Running Between The Olympics
description: SAUNDRA SMITH sat at her table in the Waldorf Astoria's ballroom earlier this week and celebrated with a thousand other guests Jesse Owens and the annual international award presented in his honor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, JAMES
description: WESTON-James. To Jeanne, Jennifer and Jamie. Thanks for sharing your dad with so many friends. We will miss him very much.

title: Objects of Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: No Fear of Reprisal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, SANDY
description: TURNER-Sandy. Our book club is saddened by the loss of a dear friend and a spirited leader. We will always remember her commitment and courage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, HERBERT B., JR., M.D.
description: WILCOX-Herbert B., Jr., M.D. February 5, 1997. Husband of Elizabeth, father of Herbert B. Wilcox, III, Gordon W. Wilcox, Thomas E. Wilcox. Born in 1908, Dr. Wilcox graduated from St. Paul's School, Concord, NH, Yale College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He served in World War II with the US Army's Second General Hospital in Europe. On returning to the US he practiced medicine in Manhattan and Riverdale, NY and was an a Associate Professor of Medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. In addition to his wife and sons, he is survived by three daughters-in-law Catherine, Virginia and Whitney and five grandchildren: Alex, Tanya, Kate, Christopher and Virginia. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Redding Ridge, CT at 1:30 PM, Saturday, February 8th. In lieu of flowers contributions may be given to the College of Physicians & Surgeons, Columbia University or the Memory Disorders Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA. 02114.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLB, PHILIP
description: KOLB-Philip. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the export of new data-scrambling software referred incorrectly in some editions to the power of such ''56 bit'' encryption systems, compared with less powerful 40-bit systems. A 56-bit system has thousands of times the computing power of a 40-bit system, not double.

title: CVS to Pay $2.8 Billion For Revco
description: The CVS Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Revco D.S. Inc. for about $2.8 billion in stock, a combination that will create the nation's second-largest drugstore chain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLB, PHILIP A.
description: KOLB-Philip A., 61. Of Oceanside, L.I. Passed away peacefully at Calvary Hospital on February 7, 1997. He is survived by his devoted wife of 36 years, Barbara, loving daughter Jane Gamble and son-inlaw Edward, of Carol Stream, Ill., son Thomas of Manhattan and granddaughter, Breana. Phil will be remembered for his loving ways and for the way he and his wife, Barbara, met life together. Services 12:30 PM, Sunday, Feb. 9 at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Texas Station Rejects Movie About Local Murder Case
description: A Fort Worth television station has decided against broadcasting an NBC television movie on Monday night about a real-life Texas murder case, citing concerns that the film could affect the case in court.

title: Rangers' Playoff Route Runs Into the Islanders
description: Thursday's trade for Mike Eastwood made it evident that the Rangers are looking ahead to the playoffs and matchups against bigger teams with more depth, like the Philadelphia Flyers and the Florida Panthers. But with a game on Long Island against the Islanders on Saturday afternoon and 11 of their next 13 games on the road, they need not look too far ahead for challenges.

title: Vallone Describes Vision Of Floating Casino Fleet
description: Peter F. Vallone, the generally cautious Speaker of the City Council, is hardly the riverboat gambler type, rarely even submitting a piece of legislation unless he knows he has the votes to pass it. Yesterday, however, he instantly became New York's most prominent supporter of floating casinos, urging the city to approve a virtual flotilla of the boats while keeping a substantial portion of the pot for the municipal treasury.

title: A Film That Out-Austens Jane Austen? No, but Almost
description: Plenty of bad movies have been made of good books, and a fair number of good movies have come from bad books. But a great movie of a great book? Speaking from a book reviewer's vantage point, I nominate Jane Austen's ''Pride and Prejudice,'' a co-production of the BBC and A&E, which is being rebroadcast by A&E in two parts, tonight at 9 and tomorrow evening at 8.

title: Sweatshop Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the Blue Bloods at Morgan Stanley Mix With the Just Plain Folks at Witter?
description: In 1989, Philip J. Purcell took his firm, Dean Witter Reynolds, out of all forms of program trading, the computerized strategies that big Wall Street firms use to instantly buy and sell hundreds of millions of dollars of stocks and bonds.

title: A Quick Fix on Campaign Reform
description: Rather than waiting for Congress to stop its partisan bickering over campaign finance reform, Americans should demand that the parties act on their own. Just as the Democratic National Committee recently prohibited contributions from foreigners, both parties and their state affiliates should set tough campaign finance rules for their Presidential, Congressional and state primaries.

title: Payrolls Swell by 271,000, But Inflation Stays in Check
description: A buoyant economy created more jobs last month than economists had expected, but growth in labor costs slowed, calming Wall Street's jitters about inflation.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, which marks the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today, tomorrow and Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Secretary of State Sells Foreign Policy at Home
description: Madeleine K. Albright took her first trip as Secretary of State today, traveling not to some foreign capital, not even to some state capital, but rather to Texas, determined, she said, to take America's foreign policy straight to the people.

title: Jimmy Weston Is Dead at 74; Genial Host of a Supper Club
description: Jimmy Weston, a glad-handing former athlete and one-time policeman who loved people, music and dancing so much that he opened a supper club that became Manhattan party central for more than two decades, died on Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 74 and had operated Jimmy Weston's on East 54th Street until 1989.

title: Steady Growth Seen In Strong Rise in Jobs
description: A buoyant economy led to a strong rise in new jobs last month, but with few signs of accelerating inflation, Government figures showed.

title: Swiss Begin to Question Image of Heroism in War
description: This land has nurtured a wartime vision of itself as an Alpine redoubt whose young men girded to fight Hitler's armies, even as geography and neutrality left them encircled and obliged to deal with the hated Nazi enemy.

title: Marx Leva, 81, Lawyer Who Framed Bill Unifying Armed Services
description: Marx Leva, a Washington lawyer who framed much of the legislation that unified the United States' armed services after World War II, died on Sunday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 81.

title: ABC's Just Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, HERBERT B., JR
description: WILCOX-Herbert B., Jr, MD. The Association of the Alumni of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia Univesity records with sadness the death of its dedicated alumnus and director emeritus on February 5, 1997. A graduate of the Class of 1934, Dr. Wilcox distinguished himself in his service with the Second General Presbyterian Hospital during World War II and as a long-time member of the clinical faculty of the college and the medical staff of Presbyterian Hospital. We join in expressing sincere condolences to the family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. Vice President for Health Sciences Dean of the Faculty of Medicine and his many friends in the P&S Alumni Association

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an encounter between a 727 jetliner and two military jets appeared in some editions yesterday with a passage omitted at the start of the continuation. Readers wishing corrected copies may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: QUEBECOR PRINTING ACQUIRES PETTY CO.
description: Quebecor Printing Inc. said yesterday that its Quebecor Printing (USA) Corporation unit had acquired the Petty Company of Effingham, Ill., a provider of direct marketing printing services. The company said it had paid $65 million and assumed $30 million of Petty's debt. Petty has 750 employees and annual revenues of about $125 million, Quebecor Printing said.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUHL, ARTHUR PAUL
description: RUHL-Arthur Paul. Son of Arthur Brown and Zinaida Ruhl. Died in New York City, January 13, 1997, at the age of 68. He was a resident of NYC most of his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELWIG, FLORENCE M.
description: HELWIG-Florence M., on February 5, 1997 at her Brooklyn home, age 95 years, graduated from Wellesley College (1925) after attending Packer Collegiate Institute where she later taught. Survived by a brother, Edward T. Helwig, his wife, Christine and their 16 descendants. Services are private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Wellesley College Scholarship Fund.

title: Sweepstakes Take Advantage of Hopeful Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Verdict in Officer's Death
description: After deliberating for two hours yesterday, a Gloucester County jury found a motorcycle gang member guilty of felony murder in the 1995 slaying of a Franklin Township police sergeant during a routine traffic stop. Charles Staples of Pine Hill had acknowledged planning a burglary just before the shooting of Sgt. Ippolito Gonzalez, but he testified that he did not know that a fellow gang member, Robert Simon, had stolen his gun from under his mattress, The Associated Press reported.

title: At Radio's Tea Party, Nothing but Static for China
description: Morning at Hong Kong's most irreverent, and popular, radio talk show begins with the rhythm of kettle drums and the gurgle of tea dribbling into a china cup.

title: Taking Beethoven for a Ride That Defies the Speed Limit
description: This may be a misperception, but Ursula Oppens's career as a pianist seems to have brought her to Beethoven by way of Elliott Carter, Conlon Nancarrow and Frederic Rzewski, which may be why her performance of the ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, in the Chase Recital Series, had so much the tone of new music.

title: 'Flynt' Celebrates Not the Man but Our Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Mother, Vindication And Sorrow
description: IRIS BAEZ was sitting in her basement, slowly sorting through scores of names on blue slips of paper, when her lawyer called. She stopped writing thank you notes to the people who attended a fund-raising event for victims of police brutality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEILSON, GOLDIE S. (COHEN)
description: KEILSON-Goldie S. (Cohen). Beloved wife of the late A. Roy Cohen. Loving mother of Linda (Nick) Di Giovanni, and the late Harvey Keilson. Dear daughter of the late Dora and Abraham Silon. Loving sister of the late Lillian, Norman, and Dr. Milton Silon. For further information please call Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 6701 West Commercial Blvd., Tamarac, FL, 1-800-758-1151.

title: N.A.S.D. Reviewing Erasure Of Broker Discipline Data
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is starting to review as many as 3,000 items of data involving brokers' disciplinary histories that it mistakenly purged from a data bank.

title: Elaborate Robbery Attempt Turns Into a Siege by Police
description: Fearing that armed robbers had taken hostages, the police locked 121 people inside a check-cashing agency here for more than three hours today. At least one gunman was inside, but the incident ended peacefully when the police concluded that he had fled.

title: Lott Calls for a Truce in the Budget Wrangle
description: It was Trent Lott the bad cop who went first today, as Congressional Republicans laid down some rhetorical markers before the start of negotiations with President Clinton on balancing the budget.

title: State Of Denial
description: Like parents telling us to eat our spinach, the father figures of network news kept instructing us as to which of the dueling stories on Tuesday night was the more nutritious. The State of the Union is ''important,'' the anchors agreed. It fulfills a constitutional commitment. It is Washington. And that circus on the other coast? It is merely ''fascinating,'' not important. It is -- need we say more? -- L.A.

title: A Light Snack of Jokes Served as Sound Bites
description: Whoever whispered in John Leguizamo's ear that he could be the next Jim Carrey ought to be locked in a screening room and forced to view ''The Pest,'' his disastrous entry into the dumbed-down teen-age comedy sweepstakes, for 24 hours without a break. Incoherent, shoddily made and offensive, ''The Pest,'' directed by Paul Miller from a screenplay by David Bar Katz, misuses Mr. Leguizamo's chameleonlike gift for caricature in the most cynical and depressing way imaginable.

title: Lilco's Sweet Deal
description: The proposed merger of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company has dug up a problem that was quietly buried eight years ago, when Lilco agreed to abandon its embattled Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Paul Singer, 92, Art Collector, Dies
description: Paul Singer, a psychiatrist who became a leading collector of Asian art, died on Jan. 19 at the Glenside Nursing Home in New Providence, N.J. He was 92.

title: Freedom's Dark Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Thief's Probation Closes Case of Purloined Royal Jewels
description: Describing the crime as ''near comical'' and its perpetrator as a misguided but ''decent fellow,'' a Federal judge sentenced a 21-year-old former baggage handler to four years' probation yesterday for rifling through an airplane cargo hold and stealing jewelry that he later learned belonged to the Duchess of York.

title: Tele-Communications Chief Gives Up President's Post
description: The board of Tele-Communications Inc. yesterday appointed Leo J. Hindery Jr. president. That title was previously held by John C. Malone, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEY, JUDITH L.
description: FEY-Judith L., on February 6, 1997. Survived by husband Albert, daughters Holly and Aimee Gabal, and Nancy Fey, son Daniel Fey, sister Kathy Rives. Reposing, Waterbury & Kelly, Briarcliff Manor. Services, Scarborough Presbyterian Church, Sunday 2:00PM

title: Almost 7 Months Later, Another Flight 800 Victim Is Identified
description: Almost seven months after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, sophisticated DNA tests have helped to identify the remains of another victim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLA, JOSE GARCIA
description: VILLA-Jose Garcia, 88. Poet, Jose Garcia Villa, national artist for literature of the Philippines, born in Manila 1908, has resided in the Unite States since 1929. His first book of poems, ''Have Come, Am Here'' (1942) brought him immediate recognition, praised by Mark Van Doren, Dame Edith Sitwell, E.E. Cummings to name only a few. On Villa's poetry, Cummings wrote, ''and i am alive to see a man against the sky.'' Villa's many awards include The Poetry Award of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. Villa is survived by sons, Randy and Lance and three grandchildren. Viewing Saturday and Sunday, 2:00-5:00, 7:00-9:00 PM at Perazzo-Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St. Funeral will be held Monday at Our Lady of Pompei Church 10:15 AM. Burial St. John's Cemetery.

title: Open Hearings on Judges
description: In a major change in the way that disciplinary proceedings against judges are handled, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that hearings on the most serious charges must be open to the public. Complaints against judges are investigated by the court's Advisory Committee on Judicial Conduct. Under the current system, if the committee decides that the allegations have merit and could lead to public sanctions, the finding becomes known only after a report is issued to the court. As of March 1, the court ruled, hearings will no longer be held in private unless they involve allegations that would lead to private admonishment.

title: Irish Neutrality During War Favored, Not Obstructed, Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Neutrality During War Favored, Not Obstructed, Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells Signs On With Jets for the Long Haul
description: The football world learned today at the Jets' parking lot -- how bizarre, how fitting -- that Bill Parcells will coach the team for a minimum of four years.

title: Ernie Sabayrac, 82, Innovator In Merchandising Golf Apparel
description: Ernie Sabayrac, an entrepreneur who popularized the concept of selling golf shoes and apparel in pro shops and whose modest parking-lot display of products became a forerunner of the modern merchandising shows, died on Thursday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 82.

title: DAKOTA MINING IN DEAL TO ADD USMX
description: The Dakota Mining Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival mining concern, USMX Inc., for about $22 million in stock. USMX, based in Denver, said the combined company would be a midsize gold producer with production of about 140,000 ounces annually, commencing in 1997, growing to 200,000 ounces in 1998. USMX's shareholders will receive one Dakota common share for every 1.1 common shares of USMX held. USMX owns mineral properties in North and Latin America. Dakota Mining, also of Denver, owns gold and silver mines in Idaho and South Dakota.

title: Clinton's Focus on Schools Hits Home
description: In outlining his ambitious agenda for education this week, President Clinton tapped into a deep national yearning to improve the nation's schools, even if it might mean accepting the revolutionary notion of national standards and perhaps even national tests to compare students, schools and states.

title: Other Carriers Preparing for A Strike Threat At American
description: A strike by the pilots of American Airlines threatened to begin next Saturday is by no means a sure thing. Still, airlines, passengers, cruise ships and other industries heavily dependent on air travel are not taking any chances.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO. Hoffman Estates, Il., said it would quit selling computer software and start selling 35-millimeter cameras in all its department stores by midyear.

title: Dey Wins Top Award
description: COURTENAY DEY, a 31-year-old sailor from Rye, N.Y., was named the 1996 Rolex Yachtswoman of the Year yesterday during a ceremony at the New York Yacht Club. DAVE ULLMAN, 50, of Newport Beach, Calif., was named Rolex Yachtsman of the Year. Dey, who was also yachtswoman of the year in 1990, won an Olympic bronze medal last summer for her performance in the Europe Class dinghy. She was a crew member on the women's Mighty Mary team in the 1995 America's Cup races. Ullman is a highly regarded dinghy sailor who emerged last year as a top competitor in five classes of larger keelboats.

title: A Painful Revision Of Swiss Self-Image
description: Switzerland has long nurtured a wartime vision of itself as an Alpine redoubt whose young men girded to fight Hitler's armies, even as geography and neutrality left them encircled and obliged to deal with the hated Nazi foe. That notion of wily heroism has come under assault in recent months. Older Swiss are facing an agonizing question: Did they buy survival with guile or, far worse, by collaborating with the Nazis?

title: Capital's Police Union Chief Asks U.S. Takeover of Force
description: Describing the streets of the nation's capital as a war zone where residents should fear for their safety, the head of the District of Columbia police union called on the Federal Government today to take over the Police Department and provide hundreds of millions of dollars to improve it.

title: APPLE SOUTH TO PURCHASE TWO RESTAURANT CHAINS
description: Apple South Inc. is buying two restaurant chains -- McCormick & Schmick's and Hops Grill and Bar -- for a total of about $124.5 million in cash, stock and assumed debt. The company said it would buy McCormick & Schmick's for about $48 million in cash, $5 million in Apple South stock and the assumption of $15 million in debt. It will buy Hops Grill and Bar for $31.5 million in cash and stock and the assumption of about $25 million in debt. Both chains will operate independently and retain their management. McCormick & Schmick's, based in Portland, Ore., has 16 casual seafood restaurants in Oregon, Washington, California, Colorado and Washington, D.C. Hops Grill and Bar, based in Clearwater, Fla., operates 18 casual restaurants in Florida, Colorado and Kentucky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, STANLEY
description: KURZ-Stanley, on February 6, 1997, beloved husband of Rona Hoffman Kurz. Loving father of Susan Eleftherakis, Jane Klemmer and Peter Kurz. Cherished grandfather of Clifford, Elizabeth, Katherine, Alexander, Kerry and Devon. Funeral services to be held Sunday, 11AM, the McMahon, Lyon & Harnett Funeral Home, White Plains: 914-949-7777.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERRIN, JOHN KERR
description: PERRIN-John Kerr. Sept. 14, 1918-Feb. 8, 1996. You are greatly missed by your daughters, sons-in-law and granddaughter.

title: Simpson Jurors Are in Recess, Without Decision on Damages
description: The decision on whether O. J. Simpson should pay punitive damages was handed to the jury this afternoon, with lawyers for the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman making a final emotional plea to the panel to ''speak for the victims.''

title: A Window for Chinese Refugees
description: While politics and time march on, 55 Chinese refugees from the freighter Golden Venture remain in legal limbo after more than three years in Federal detention. A new provision in the Federal immigration law, approved by Congress and President Clinton last fall, relaxes the legal standard used in considering asylum for Chinese refugees. For statutory and humanitarian reasons, the immigration authorities should review the asylum applications of the Golden Venture passengers under the new standard and parole those who are not a threat to public safety or likely to flee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINKOFF, ALICE
description: SINKOFF-Alice. Beloved wife of Marvin. Loving mother of Martin, Richard, Nancy and James. Dear sister of Peter Bernholz and Ellen Harrison. Dear sister-in-law to Kit Bernholz and Richard Harrison, and devoted aunt to Martha, Lucy, Jane, Dennis, Liz and Emily. Services to be held at Sunset Chapel, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, N.Y., on Sunday, February 9th at 12:00 noon. In lieu of flowers, send donations to AABA, 293 Central Park West, Suite 1R, NY, NY 10024.

title: POP
description: A Gesture of Reconciliation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEBINER, BENJAMIN
description: GEBINER-Benjamin. The Workman's Circle mourns the passing of our senior leader who devoted his energies to our organization and the Jewish community both as a lay leader and as a professional from his arrival in the U.S. in 1921 to the present. As a teacher in our Yiddish shuln, as Education Chairman and as Executive Director until his retirement in 1970, he helped establish and guide our organization through much of its early history. We extend our deepest condolences to Laura, Mimi and the entire family. Mark Mlotek, President Robert Kaplan, Exec. Director

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 5 about the two O. J. Simpson trials referred incorrectly to Trisha Lynn Smith, who surveyed civil lawsuits filed in connection with criminal trials. She is a student in the graduate legal studies program at the Columbia University School of Law, not a law professor there.

title: Clinton Bests Aurelius
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Rise on Release of Jobs Data
description: Investors who have kept to the sidelines of the bond market this week returned en masse yesterday after the Labor Department released employment figures that indicated that growth in wages was slow.

title: Russian Premier, Meeting Clinton and Gore, Remains Opposed to Wider NATO
description: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia, after meetings with President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, said today that Moscow remained opposed to an enlarged NATO and confused by its aims.

title: All-Stars Are Tepid On Return Of Nelson
description: The room was full of Don Nelson castoffs and critics, each either feeling shipped off or pushed away by him at one time or another, and each of them was an All-Star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, GENEVIEVE KELLOGG
description: LAWRENCE-Genevieve Kellogg. Age 86. On February 4, 1997. Wife of the late Robert C. Lawrence, Jr. Mother of Genevieve L. Wood and Robert C. Lawrence III. Grandmother of five. Great grandmother of four. Memorial services are on Saturday, February 15th, at 10 A.M., at Saint Georges by the River, Rumson, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLINGFORD, ELDON R., JR.
description: WALLINGFORD-Eldon R., Jr. 72, formerly of Bedford, NY, died of natural causes at his home in Somers. Born in Ashland, Kansas, Mr. Wallingford graduated from Dartmouth College, and served as an officer in the U.S. Marine Corps during World War II & the Korean War. He retired as a Vice President of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in 1983. He was a member of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, and the Friends of John Jay Homestead. Survivors include his five children Dick of Napa, CA, Peter of Seattle, WA., Jessie Dean of Alexandria, VA., Amanda Martin of Cedar Grove, TN., & Matthew of Somers. He is also survived by his father Eldon Wallingford of San Francisco and a brother and sister. A Memorial Service will be held at 11AM Friday, February 14, at St Matthew's Church in Bedford.

title: Symbols of Old South Feed a New Bitterness
description: In the 1860's, the fight was about states' rights and slavery. In the 1960's, the battle was joined over voting rights and segregation. Now the war is over symbols, mere vestiges of the previous two campaigns but powerful enough to demonstrate how deep the racial divide remains in a region that fancies itself the New South.

title: Conversion of Albright's Jewish Family Followed a Well-Trod Path
description: What do Fidel Castro, three founding members of the Jesuit order, Saint Teresa of Avila and Cardinal Jean Marie Lustiger of Paris have in common with Secretary of State Madeleine Albright?

title: RUBIN HINTS AT END TO LONG U.S. PUSH OF STRONG DOLLAR
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, taking a little air out of the rapidly rising dollar, suggested today that the Administration had ended its two-year-long effort to drive up the dollar against the world's other major currencies.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage, and Off column in Weekend yesterday about the props needed for ''The Tokyo Shock Boys'' misstated its Off Broadway starting date. Performances begin at the Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village on Tuesday, not on April 11.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRUCKER, ELLA
description: DRUCKER-Ella. February 8th, 1989. I ache from not hearing or seeing you. I miss you so very much. Rest in peace, sweet friend. With Eternal Love, V.

title: Police Union Hires New Negotiator For Pact Talks
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, whose top labor negotiator stepped aside because he faces Federal corruption charges, said yesterday that it was hiring the chief negotiator for the city's sanitation workers to help end its impasse with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSEL, ALVIN
description: KASSEL-Alvin. My uncle, good friend, confidante, surrogate father, I love you and will miss you so. Karen

title: Oil and Other Fuels Plunge; More Warm Weather Is Seen
description: Energy prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, dragged down by growing expectations that a mild winter in the Northeast would keep inventories of heating fuels high.

title: 3 Ecuadoreans Laying Claims To Presidency
description: The morning after their President was ousted on the ground of mental incompetence, Ecuadoreans awoke to a more dizzying spectacle: three people claiming to be President.

title: Ex-Assistant To Giuliani Will Head Housing Dept.
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has named Richard T. Roberts, a former mayoral assistant, to be commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: Slaney Is Still Golden After 23 Years at the Millrose Games
description: She won her first race at the Chase Millrose Games 23 years ago, and if her career has been left unfulfilled by injury and an infamous collision, Mary Decker Slaney has never lost her sense of front-running determination.

title: New Haven Police Chief Quits in Scandal Over Child
description: In the last seven years, this city's flamboyant Police Chief, Nicholas Pastore, became a national figure in law enforcement circles as he transformed an iron-fisted Police Department into a friendly force that tried to win the hearts of neighborhood residents.

title: Faulkner And Flood, A Setting For Love
description: Actually, Faulkner never wrote anything called ''Old Man.'' ''William Faulkner's 'Old Man' ,'' a Horton Foote adaptation on CBS tomorrow night at 9, is actually taken from Faulkner's 1939 novel ''The Wild Palms.''

title: Viciosa Gets A Big Kick In Capturing Wanamaker
description: In Spain, middle-distance runners spend the winter running cross-country or distance races. On New Year's Eve, Isaac Viciosa won a celebrated 9-kilometer (5.6-mile) race down a six-lane street in Madrid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, FRANK R
description: WILSON-Frank R. On February 7. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Loving father of Patricia Wilson Boyle, Grace Wilson and the late Catherine, Tommy and George Green. Dear brother of Ruth, Dorothy, Richard and the late George. Fond grandfather of 6. Reposing Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn until Monday. Services Monday at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIMAN, PAMELA
description: HARRIMAN - Pamela. The Trustees of the Winston Churchill Foundation of the U.S. record their deep sadness at the death of Pamela Harriman, the mother of our fellow Trustee, Winston Churchill, who was herself a member of the Board for many years. Her deep interest and generous support helped make the Churchill Foundation Scholarship Program one of the most successful and prestigious of its kind. Our condolences to her family. John L. Loeb, Jr., President

title: Streamline the Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Jan. 20 about the widespread use of the Internet in Finland misstated the percentage of the population there who had used it over a three-month period. It was 11 percent, not 1 percent.

title: San Francisco Moves to End Benefits Rift
description: City officials said today that they had reached tentative agreements with United Airlines and the Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Francisco that will remove two major obstacles to a new ordinance requiring all city contractors to offer health and other benefits to the unmarried partners of their employees.

title: After Life of Wandering and Woes, Finally a Home
description: Joseph Mitchell sat in the dim light of his one-room apartment in Jamaica, Queens, on Monday, talking about his travels, the devastating losses that led to them, and his longing to return to his life as a hobo.

title: Montefiore Could Be Fined If Care at Jacobi Falters
description: Addressing longstanding concerns that private medical centers do not send their best doctors to public hospitals, New York City has brokered a contract with Montefiore Medical Center that insures it will adequately staff Jacobi Medical Center or face fines that could top $25 million.

title: DANCE
description: Affluent Party Is Crashed

title: Bridge
description: If your partner opens one no-trump and you have a solid minor suit and little else, it is simple to raise to three no-trump. If your opponent intervenes, three no-trump is still reasonable, since it is unlikely that opener has two weak suits.

title: Sensational Murder Trial Grips Georgia
description: In most criminal cases, prosecutors might be satisfied when a defendant is put away for four consecutive life terms without the possibility of parole.

title: Another Tie, But No Joy For Devils
description: Though they did not lose the game, the Devils did lose their lead, their composure and a chance to pass their first serious divisional test in more than two months tonight. They settled for a 2-2 tie with the Florida Panthers after taking a two-goal lead in the third period at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JULIAN
description: PERLMAN-Julian. The Board and staff of The Public Theater/New York Shakespeare Festival are deeply saddened by the loss of Julian Perlman. As director of The Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation, Mr. Perlman has been a generous and loyal supporter for many years. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. George C. Wolfe, Producer

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CASINO FLEET -- The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, is urging the city to approve a flotilla of floating casinos, operating from all five boroughs. Page 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIENSTOCK, LAWRENCE
description: BIENSTOCK-Lawrence. We love you. Service Sunday, February 9, 10 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Distonia Foundation, 300 E. 72nd Street, NY, NY 10021 212-288-0043

title: Cable and Wireless Ends Venture With Veba
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. pulled out of its German telecommunications alliance with Veba A.G. and received 2.21 billion marks, or $1.3 billion, for its share in the venture, leaving Veba and RWE A.G., the group's other member, to seek ''a new international partner,'' the companies said today.

title: Battling The Sound And Fury Of the Show
description: What becomes a rock diva most? Definitely not a televised version of a gargantuan stadium concert. ''Tina Turner's Wildest Dreams Concert'' (tonight at 8 on Showtime) presents all the familiar qualities that make her likable: playful sexual energy, raucous music, an adamant refusal to age. She comes on, legs prancing (fresh from her Hanes commercial), head shaking and voice wailing on songs like ''Private Dancer'' and ''Proud Mary,'' as well as lesser-known songs from her recent album, ''Wildest Dreams.'' Despite all that, the concert fails to show her to very good advantage. It was filmed last November in Amsterdam at an arena crowded with 55,000 people, and even with plenty of close-ups, this special never escapes the distancing sense that Ms. Turner is projecting to the 5,000th row.

title: Principal Gets Her Job Back Under a Deal With Crew
description: The principal of a Bedford-Stuyvesant school for gifted children who was ousted by her district superintendent three months ago will return to her post on Monday under an agreement brokered by schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, his spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: POP
description: The Things That Love

title: C.I.A. Nominee to Pay $5,000 to Settle Inquiry
description: President Clinton's nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, Anthony Lake, agreed today to pay $5,000 to settle a Justice Department civil inquiry into his stock dealings while he was the President's national security adviser.

title: Frederick J. Almgren Jr., 63, Math Professor
description: Frederick J. Almgren Jr., a mathematics professor at Princeton University who studied the geometry of surfaces, died on Wednesday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 63 and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Gownbeat
description: GOWNBEAT Lawyers in the Fox News v. Time Warner antitrust case met recently in the Brooklyn courtroom of U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein to schedule their jury trial. Yosef J. Riemer (representing Fox, the plaintiff) wanted an early date. He didn't quite get it, but he and his opponent, Robert D. Joffe, got a lesson in judicial cool. THE COURT: May I have a calendar? ... Wait, I have it. I have my Golden Age Jazz Calendar. ... Let's see. December is John Birks (Dizzy) Gillespie month. That seems like a good month. JOFFE: It sounds right for this case, Your Honor. THE COURT: October is Billie Holiday month. RIEMER: We are liking the music better every month you go backwards, Your Honor: Who is, say, May? JOFFE: The difference, Your Honor, between April and May is not substantial. Not meaningful. THE COURT: May is Lester (Prez) Young. RIEMER: We've always been a big fan of his. THE COURT: Charlie (Yardbird) Parker month seems to me the right month. That's November. RIEMER: Yes, Your Honor. THE COURT: Jury selection on Monday, the 3d of November, which is Henry Grimes - bassist - day.

title: SoHo-by-the-Sea? Asbury Park Advances, but Cautiously
description: Here in the downcast remains of what was once a flourishing entertainment capital, people have pinned their hopes on attracting artists to live, work and exhibit amid the leftover downtown grandeur and the still-proud Victorian neighborhoods. At $100,000 or less for a roomy 19th-century house, even artists can afford to live in Asbury Park, residents will tell you, as they voice their hopes that their small city, with its ornate but silenced carousel and its corroded, derelict hotels, will become a SoHo-by-the-Sea.

title: The First Supermodel
description: Lisa Fonssagrives, a self-described ''good clothes hanger,'' was a leading figure during the 1940's and 50's in the business of being beautiful. A consummate professional, the willowy Swedish model projected a combination of lofty sophistication, impossible slimness and radiant physical well-being. She worked with the foremost fashion photographers of her time, and together they produced classics. In the early 1930's, Fonssagrives's first husband, a dancer turned photographer, sold photos of her gamboling on the French coast to European magazines. She entered fashion's big time in 1936 when Horst P. Horst was commissioned to do test shots of her for Paris Vogue. In LISA FONSSAGRIVES: Three Decades of Classic Fashion Photography (Vendome, $75), with an essay by the art historian Martin Harrison, the photographer David Seidner has assembled more than 100 images of her by 21 photographers. The pleasure of the collection, aside from its appeal to the fashion-afflicted, is the quality and variety of photographic vision. Some photographers, best represented by Horst, use Fonssagrives as a key element in formal compositions. Others, notably Louise Dahl-Wolfe and Frances McLaughlin-Gill, portray her as an active woman in less studied environments. Erwin Blumenfeld exploits her dancer's strength and agility by photographing her leaning out from the Eiffel Tower, her skirts billowing in the wind. The few disappointments -- images of vaporous fantasies of the model swathed in chiffon -- only enliven the whole by contrast. Her collaboration with Irving Penn, whom she married in 1950, transcends mere mastery of technique, graphic design and merchandising. In the soft northern light in which he photographed her wearing the Paris collections, both the woman and the clothes crackle with wit and sex appeal. Fonssagrives, who died in 1992 at the age of 80, was a direct descendant of the Gibson girl, but her own progeny are difficult to discern among the disordered and disturbed images in vogue today. Rosemary Ranck

title: Ireland Without Saints
description: In his first novel (but not his first to be published in America), Patrick McCabe presents a devastating portrait of a backwater community on the border between the Irish Republic and the North. Not surprisingly, CARN (Delta, paper, $11.95) shows us a place in which the uncertainties of the present meld into the tragedies and glories of the past. The town of Carn's fortunes ebb and flow with the economic vicissitudes of faraway countries that are only dimly recognized by the local people -- but they also vary with the endless, much more immediate cycles of the Irish ''troubles.'' In this book, which was originally published in 1989, Mr. McCabe uses a more traditional narrative technique than that of his acclaimed second novel, ''The Butcher Boy,'' but his prose here is equally graphic. Unflinchingly, he introduces his readers to a society in which the local priest doesn't hesitate to wield his unquestioned power over his parishioners, in which unwed mothers furtively kill and bury their newborn children, in which young men become hopelessly ensnarled in the sort of raids and counterraids that both create heroes and destroy them. Focusing on two women who dream of escape but are finally sucked back into the only world they truly know and understand, Mr. McCabe creates a story that is searing and brutal yet still tender in its subtlety and sympathy. He leaves the people of Carn waiting for a miracle, making it painfully clear that what they yearn for -- a return to the imagined certainties of the past -- is impossible. Lauren Belfer
