In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the J. Wood Platt Caddie Scholarship Trust.

title: Jackson's 'Purity'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AWAKENING TO SLEEP
description: Verlyn Klinkenborg's article ''Awakening to Sleep'' (Jan. 5) abounds with fascinating information about circadian clocks and rhythms and receptors within the body. There is repeated reference to the fact that scientists cannot agree on what sleep is for.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, IRVING T
description: BERGMAN-Irving T. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Julian, James and Peter Bergman, and Jessica Honig. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Stacey. Services Tuesday, 10:30, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: The Abiding Urge To Watch Things Go Ka-Boom!
description: SINCE THE DAYS OF beheadings and before, humans have always enjoyed a lusty gorefest -- from a safe vantage point, of course. One can only imagine the conversations of Parisian crones, knitting and cackling at the foot of the guillotine, the nearest equivalent of a disaster movie in 18th-century Paris:

title: On Fourth Avenue, Going Against the Flow
description: FROM the secondhand desk of his tiny secondhand bookshop on Fourth Avenue, Steve Crowley can boot up his computer any time to search for out-of-print volumes. But he is still a throwback.

title: Surprising Some, Winter Makes a Seasonable Return
description: It came as a surprise to some, and a delight to others. Slightly more than two inches of wet, fast-melting snow fell yesterday on New York City and much of the metropolitan area, coating trees and lawns with fat snowflakes and painting streets and sidewalks with sheets of ice.

title: For Whitlock's, Life After New Haven
description: I am writing to praise your article on bookstores (''Hours of Pleasure, Digging Among Old Books,'' Jan. 19), and only mildly to point out where there seems to be a somewhat misleading statement involving my family. The article said ''the demise of the New Haven landmark, Whitlock's, notwithstanding . . .''

title: Q and A
description: Spanish Glass Museum

title: Accidental Tour
description: To the Editor: Reading Alice Furlaud's essay, ''An Accidental Tour,'' (Jan. 19) reminded me of an out-of-country experience of my own. For 12 years, we have rented a house in a tiny Provencal village, Roussillon. Every time we've gone there it has been a perfect vacation.

title: The Albright Syndrome
description: Madeleine Albright must have known.

title: Lionel Was King and the Steam Engine Rolled Across the Nation
description: VISITORS can all get aboard the Fairfield Historical Society's exhibition ''Tickets Please: Vintage Toy Trains 1918-1950,'' on display through March 2.

title: Probing Perception Through Bold, Colorful Geometric Forms
description: James Juszczyk: Haiku Geometrics

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Kory Apton and Phil Griffin
description: IT is Phil Griffin's habit to surprise Kory Apton on her birthday, Jan. 31. When she turned 30, for instance, he left a plane ticket to the Virgin Islands and a book about scuba diving on her bed, with instructions to catch the plane, read the book and meet him at the airport in St. Thomas.

title: Someone Familiar . . .Stages a Homecoming
description: SHE STANDS ON THE BROADWAY stage with the lights burning, the director barking, her heart jumping and suddenly her mind is leaping back to 1984. And there she is, a struggling comedian rehearsing her first big show, worrying that her voice will crack and that her jokes will leave the expectant audience cold.

title: 900 Reasons for Making The Bowlers' Record Book
description: One week ago, Jeremy Sonnenfeld was just another skinny sophomore lost in a sea of 25,000 students. In the mornings, he studied business administration at the University of Nebraska. In the afternoons, he worked out with the rest of the school's top-ranked intercollegiate bowling squad at the lanes in the student union.

title: 'American Pie': 25 Years Ago, America Listened
description: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO this week, Don McLean's ''American Pie'' ended a four-week run as the No. 1 song in the country. It was McLean's first and biggest hit, it galloped on for eight and a half minutes, and it sold more than a million copies.

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: In ''The Clinton Principle'' (Jan. 19), Garry Wills implies that Clinton as President is making it up as he goes. But improvisation is the nature and strength of a democratic society. The initial architects of our nation -- Washington, Jefferson, Adams -- improvised from day to day, year to year, to keep our ship of state afloat.

title: Ernest Griffith, 100, Researcher And Expert About Government
description: Dr. Ernest Stacey Griffith, a political scientist and former Federal official who wrote on the workings of government, died on Jan. 17 at the Parkview Nursing Home in Portland, Ore. He was 100.

title: Who Gets the Edge?
description: On sunny mornings in our neighborhood park, you can find a conclave of anxious mothers casually dressed. My son Sam and I were there one day when one mother -- I'll call her Kate -- asked Sam's age and birthday. ''He'll be 3 in December,'' I said. She informed me that the town required entering kindergartners to be 5 years old by Oct. 1. We would miss the cutoff. She seemed vaguely triumphant.

title: At Sport's Shrine, Everything but a Game
description: Upon first beholding the Official All-Star Cafe last week, Walt (Clyde) Frazier, that signifier of cool, that wizard of words, swayed slightly and said, ''It is.''

title: LOVE HURTS
description: 1. Banned by the Food and Drug Administration in 1990, gamma hydroxybutyrate (GHB), an alleged aphrodisiac and muscle enhancer, continues to wreak havoc. 2. Last fall, four young men from Long Island were hospitalized with severe throat, lung and body burns. They had tried to make home-brew GHB, but their chemical mix gave off caustic fumes. 3. In the San Francisco area, GHB-related emergency-room admissions topped 100 last year, up from 37 in 1995. 4. Overdose may cause coma. ''Better Sex Through Chemistry,'' a 1995 book that praises GHB's ''disinhibiting'' effects, advises users to lie down, thus preventing injury from ''falling, stumbling or dropping to the ground.'' 5. What's the payoff? Less drastic doses can delay orgasm. ''I once wore out five phone-sex partners,'' reports a woman who has used the substance. ''Then I passed out.''

title: Fans of the Music of the Pinelands Get a Place to Stomp Their Feet
description: You have to look closely to find the new Albert Music Hall on Wells Mills Road in Waretown. The front of the building, which was dedicated last month by a group of musicians and supporters whose roots in New Jersey's Pine Barrens go back more than four decades, faces a parking lot. But the fact that the simple tan building with an inviting front porch is tucked away does not stop people from finding their way there every Saturday night to listen to the Sounds of the Jersey Pines, a special blend of bluegrass, country and folk music. Admission is $4 (free for children under 12). The first act usually starts about 8 P.M.

title: Lower Level of Proof
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Deal Crowned A New King Of Wall St.
description: THANKS to the Banc One Corporation and First USA Inc., the historic $10.2 billion merger of the Morgan Stanley Group and Dean Witter, Discover & Company was almost derailed -- at least for a moment.

title: My Office, Myself
description: HOMI BYRAMJI'S normal commute from Boonton Township to Lake Success on Long Island takes about an hour and 20 minutes. That's on good days. On bad days. that commute can stretch to three hours. Not that Mr. Byramji doesn't make the most of his car-bound solitude. ''I have listened to every self-improvement, sales and motivational tape in creation,'' he says.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRAGER, HAROLD
description: PRAGER-Harold . Eighteen years ago our love sprouted. It flowers forever. Your wife Dorothy

title: A New (Formerly Corrupt) Prime Minister for Pakistan
description: Benazir Bhutto was dismissed as Prime Minister three months ago on corruption charges. That didn't stop her from running again.

title: Tried and Tried Again, With a Vengeance
description: OK., maybe O. J. is half-guilty.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Uncle Sam May Offer A Reason To Sell
description: As Washington prepares for serious budget negotiations, it seems possible, maybe even likely, that a deal will give investors a brief opportunity to sell stocks while paying an amazingly low tax bill.

title: An Inquiry Clouds a Lobbyist's Success Story
description: A few years ago, Pauline Kanchanalak wanted to become a Washington lobbyist for the Government of Thailand. Officials turned her down, believing that she lacked the connections to be effective in the corridors of power in the United States capital.

title: Reunited, but Not as Mary and Lou
description: MARY TYLER MOORE'S unmistakable voice cracked slightly with tension. ''Excuse me, sir!'' she said to a young man carrying a video camera, as all around her, in the elegant main courtroom of the Multnomah County Building here, people froze. ''Who are you shooting for?''

title: Tragedy of the World of Performers
description: ALONE on stage, Bert Williams, a black man in blackface and white gloves, is fielding questions from an imaginary audience between performances of ''The Ziegfeld Follies.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'HONAU, CHARLES E.
description: D'HONAU-Charles E., 69, died on February 5, 1997 at University of California San Francisco Medical Center, of complications from C.O.P.D. A graduate of The Pingry School and Princeton University, he was Asia Publisher of TIME Magazine, based in Tokyo before retirement. He is survived by his wife, Maureen, and sons, Charles and William, all of San Francisco. Funeral services at Old Mission Dolores, San Francisco de Asis will be private. Friends who wish may contribute to Princeton University, Class of '49, P.O. Box 46, Princeton, New Jersey 08544-0046.

title: The New Approach in Arverne: Incrementalism
description: HOW do you give a two-family New York City house a ''beachy'' look?

title: Debating Beauty Pageants
description: A recent article in the section described a beauty pageant. Some say such events are degrading and anachronistic. Do you agree?

title: Betsey Patterson, Charles Gifford Jr.
description: Frances Elizabeth Patterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Patterson of Kenilworth, Ill., was married there yesterday to Charles Kilvert Gifford Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gifford of Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. The Rev. Gilbert Bowen performed the Congregational ceremony at the Kenilworth Union Church.

title: A Giants Back to Offer Play-by-Play at Concert
description: THE ''Philharmaniacs'' are back, and helping them into the end zone today is the New York Giants running back Keith Elias -- all part of the Westchester Philharmonic's children's series at Purchase College, where game times are 1 and 3 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: A table in the Automobiles section last Sunday, with the Behind the Wheel column, misstated two specifications for the BMW Z3 2.8 roadster. Its six-cylinder engine has 189 horsepower, not 138, and maximum torque of 203 foot-pounds, not 133.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 26 about desegregating Connecticut schools misattributed a comment from a superintendent who questioned the value of sending a suburban town's most talented students to magnet schools in the cities, and leaving behind a talent gap. The speaker was the New Canaan Superintendent, Gary Richards, not Carol Harrington of Fairfield. Mr. Richards was referring to his school district, not Fairfield's.

title: Thy People Shall Be My People
description: CLOUD CHAMBER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIX, SOL
description: ELLIX-Sol, 93. Beloved husband of Betty, loving father of Gloria Sacks, Eleanor Ellix, late Rita Ellix. Father-in-law of Bernard Sacks and Joseph Katz. Grandfather of Sandor, Lizzi, Jonathan, Elaine, Jeffrey, Michelle, and Peter. Great-grandfather of Sadie.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A Paris-moored suspense puzzle, an early 20th-century biodrama, an all-American comedy and a British musical lark provide variety and diversion as standouts on the movie menu this week.

title: Proposing Marriage? Make It Short, Sweet and Real
description: TO propose to Bronwen Hruska, Graham Rayman left a letter on a table in their Manhattan apartment, along with a bottle of wine, a glass and a tape he made of their favorite Van Morrison songs. In the letter, Mr. Rayman, a 30-year-old writer, explained why he wanted to spend his life with her, instructed her to put on the tape, drink some wine and think about her answer. If it was yes, he would be waiting at 9 P.M. at their regular hangout, the Paris Commune in Greenwich Village.

title: Sunlight Re-enters Holy Sepulcher Dome
description: After decades of being covered with scaffolding and enmeshed in bitter sectarian squabbles, the dome of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem has been restored, letting sunlight once again illuminate the site where Christians believe that Jesus is buried. The 900-year-old church and marble tomb, the holiest Christian site in Jerusalem, is controlled by three churches -- Roman Catholic, Greek Orthodox and Armenian Orthodox.

title: Women, Guns and a Lobbyist Who'd Bring Them Together
description: WHO -- Tammie Maddox, 30, vice chairwoman of the women's issues and information committee of the Association of New Jersey Rifle and Pistol Clubs. Long before she could drive a car, Ms. Maddox learned how to handle a .22-caliber handgun. At 12, she tagged along with her father, Bob, when he went target-shooting at the Monmouth County Pistol and Rifle Club. Now she's looking at firearms not just as a source of recreation, but also as a means of protection. With eight other women, she has been walking the halls of the State House in Trenton, lobbying for legislation that would allow any competent person who completes a firearms safety or training course to carry a handgun. (Similar legislation has been passed by 31 states.)

title: Of Mice And Architects
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shortage of Terminals Spells Computer Access Denied
description: Ed Powell groaned when he saw a police officer escorting a teen-ager he knew out of the Flatbush branch of the Brooklyn Public Library in December. Mr. Powell, whose Umma Group Inc. organizes civilian anticrime patrols in the neighborhood, knew that the young man had once worked as a look-out for a major drug dealer. He could only imagine what the teen-ager was up to. But when Mr. Powell got him into his car for a talk, he was stunned by the teen-ager's explanation.

title: The Jazz Martyr
description: Keith Jarrett has a serious post-whiplash condition right now, which he views as an occupational hazard. Most pianists do not have his back and neck problems, but most pianists, even if they draw on the full weight of their bodies, manage to constrict the ostentation of movement to their hands and arms and shoulders and feet. Keith Jarrett takes on the piano with all his self, the self of a raging spirit and of a small body, like Jacob wrestling with the angel of the Lord. During his solo improvisation concerts of the 1970's, he would go into a state of what appeared to be ecstatic pain. While playing the notes urgently and self-referentially, he would slide off the bench so that he was sometimes on top of the piano and sometimes beneath it and most often wrapped around it. His face could not possibly have gone through a more anguished and peculiar range of expressions; he grunted and groaned audibly, periodically shaking with spasms and shivers. He looked as though he were giving birth to a square baby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINES, WILLIAM WALKER
description: HINES-William Walker, 76, on Feb. 1, at home in Kinston, NC. Mr. Hines attended The Woodberry Forest School in Orange, VA and The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill where he was a member of the society of Phi Beta Kappa. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II, and retained a great affinity for the sea as an accomplished yachtsman all his life. He was a member of St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Kinston. He is survived by his nieces, Marguerite Cameron of Morehead City, NC, Nancy Hines and Ruth Hines, both of Raleigh, NC. Services were held graveside at The Maplewood Cemetery in Kinston, NC on February 2nd. To his memory, donations may be made to The Caring House, 2625 Pickett Road, Durham, NC 27705.

title: Drivers Angry at Dubious Distinction: State's Top Insurance Rates
description: Since she is a minister, it simply would not have been right for Darlene Williams to register her car at a relative's address in North Carolina to get cheaper car insurance rates than in her hometown of Brooklyn. But, God knows, she wanted to.

title: Stagnant Strip Is Trying to Party
description: In the late 1970's and early 80's, First Avenue between 60th and 65th Streets was the Manhattan hot spot for young singles, with restaurants and clubs like Maxwell's Plum, Adam's Apple and Magique.

title: Irish Inquiry Set on Store Chain's Political Gifts
description: A Government-appointed tribunal will start seeking information next week about $5.7 million distributed in recent years to past and present members of Parliament by Dunnes, the largest chain of department stores in Ireland.

title: 'Truth' and Fear In Black and White
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, which marks the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Money Politics, and Its Suckers
description: SO who are the bad guys?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHOROROF, LAURENCE
description: CHOROROF-Laurence. 2/9/56-3/14/94. To have known him, to have had him, for even so short a time is our blessing.

title: From Storefronts to Supermarkets
description: LIKE 14 million other Americans last year, Muriel Page turned to H & R Block for help in filling out her tax return. She was pleased enough with the results that Block caught her attention with the flier it mailed last summer announcing its recent entry into the mortgage business.

title: Flyers Flex Muscles, but Devils Force Them to Cry Uncle
description: After playing well against several weaker teams recently, the Devils have also had some success in two tests against contending teams the past two nights. They defeated the Philadelphia Flyers by 4-2 tonight with a three-goal rally in the last period, just 24 hours after a tie with the Florida Panthers.

title: 'Crime of Rage'
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring the Contradictions of a Black Panther
description: LIKE MANY IN AMERICA, Roger Guenveur Smith had been aware of the Black Panther Party co-founder Huey P. Newton from the familiar poster tacked up in the nation's collective unconscious: Newton, the regally recalcitrant revolutionary of the late 1960's, seated on a wicker throne in a black leather jacket, spear in one hand, rifle in the other.

title: Jordan Won't Return If Jackson Doesn't
description: Michael Jordan said today he will retire if Phil Jackson is not retained as the Chicago Bulls' coach in the off season.

title: Enrollments in Hospices Are Swelling
description: WHEN John Volpe of East Atlantic Beach learned he was terminally ill, he knew that although he couldn't choose not to die, he could decide how. Together with his wife, Claire, he enrolled in a hospice program, a system of care that focuses on alleviating pain and enhancing quality of life for patients who choose to die at home.

title: Beyond Black and White
description: Color-Blind

title: Top-Hitting Payton Has a Sound Shot at Mets
description: Jay Payton can hit. That's the easy part for the muscular outfielder.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Tom Hayden Asks Action On Finances Of the Mayor
description: The uphill some say desperate -- battle of Tom Hayden to become Mayor of the nation's second-largest city began in earnest this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRESOV, BORIS V.
description: GRESOV-Boris V. On February 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Letitia. Father of Winston Graham and Christopher Leo. Grandfather of Frederick, Alexandra, and Ian Christopher. Brother of Helena de Haubensak. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Maryknoll Fathers, Ossining, New York.

title: A Forgotten Voice From an Age of Exploration
description: SAD to say, Norman Lewis is one of those artists best known for not being as well known as he should be. Mostly he is known as the one black artist among the New York Abstract Expressionists of the 1940's and 50's. ''Norman Lewis: Social Realism to Abstraction, 1933-1948,'' the exhibition of his early work at the Ben Shahn Galleries of William Paterson College here, will probably not earn him many new devotees, but those already attuned to the refinements of Lewis's mature work will be happy to learn more about his development.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZYWOTOW, SAMUEL
description: ZYWOTOW-Samuel. 2/9/93. Missing you is unimaginable. The sun, the laughter-no more. Lorraine

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: As disheartened as I have become with Bill Clinton, I found Wills's article measured, learned and mildly reassuring -- except for his reference to the ''erupting bimbos.'' With this, he deflects that particular ''personal scandal'' rather neatly away from Clinton and puts the onus on the women. If Clinton's alleged behavior had involved, for example, a powerful C.E.O., a respected scientist or an intelligent woman of royal blood, would he have left us with the same derogatory view of who really did what to whom?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Holding My Own in No Man's Land Women and Men and Film and Feminists. By Molly Haskell. Oxford University, $25.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Prescriptions for Peace
description: PREVENTIVE DIPLOMACY Stopping Wars Before They Start. Edited by Kevin M. Cahill. 370 pp. New York: The Center for International Health and Cooperation/Basic Books. Paper, $25.

title: Albright Discovery May Show Jews' Assimilation, Not Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Albright Discovery May Show Jews' Assimilation, Not Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Zero-Risk Leadership
description: President Clinton opened his State of the Union Address by asking Americans to ''rise to the decisive moment.'' In an unscripted aside, he added that he was given a second term ''to take the tough decisions.'' So it seems fair to ask: What exactly are the tough decisions he recommends?

title: Rebecca Alberts And Roger Katz
description: Rebecca M. Alberts, a daughter of Elaine and Phillip Alberts of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married on Friday to Roger N. Katz, a son of Dr. Robert Katz of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Dr. Marie Sathmary. The ceremony was performed on the beach on Young Island, off St. Vincent, the West Indies, by Ianthea Leizertwood, the island's registrar.

title: A Latter-Day Hudson
description: EUGENE FLINN is describing the guests of his former employers, a wealthy Philadelphia couple known for their flawless parties. ''They didn't just walk out; they floated out,'' says Mr. Flinn, who owns Amanda's with his wife, Joyce.

title: TAKING THE KIDS
description: Suburbia

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Louis Remy Mignot's painting ''Cotopaxi'' misstates the work's approximate date. It is 1859, not 1959.

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, in the Center Ring . . .
description: ASK anyone who knows about the art of tossing Indian clubs, rings or balls into the air -- and keeping them there elegantly -- and chances are you will hear homage paid to Lottie Brunn.

title: A Little Squab Will Do You
description: THE AXIS OF FINE DINING HAS SHIFTED, FROM the pomp and preciousness that framed a memorable restaurant meal 10 years ago to something far simpler and more personal. In Paris today, a memorable meal might be the food you get in a bistro, something as simple and nostalgic as a roast or a chop, something that is in essence home cooking, but done to a fine turn.

title: Skepticism Over School Pledge
description: WHAT appears at first glance to be good news from Albany for the schools -- increased state aid, assurances of no cuts to districts and reduced property taxes -- has been met with cautious enthusiasm and some skepticism from Westchester superintendents.

title: Ferns That Wrap Around Your Green Thumb
description: It's always about this time of year that my houseplants look the way I feel. They lean against the window, craning their necks, looking vainly for the sun. We are pale, wimpy versions of our robust energetic selves when we're basking up on our tar beach in June. (My new place in Red Hook, Brooklyn, has a nice flat roof, and I'm already picturing a little container garden up there.)

title: To Get More Defensive, Try Cost-Cutting Companies
description: WITH the market looking so pricey these days, judicious stock picking may soon gain on broad market bets as an investment strategy. And while selective investors can use many different guideposts to pick companies, one yardstick sounds a very familiar theme: downsizing and similar cost-cutting maneuvers.

title: Elisabeth Frost and Paul Zintl
description: Dr. Elisabeth Pepperell Frost and Paul Andrew Zintl were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Samuel T. Lloyd 3d, Trinity's rector, performed the ceremony. Dom Philip Lawrence, the abbot of the Monastery of Christ in the Desert in Abiquiu, N.M., took part in the service.

title: Rare Infection Quickly Kills College Student
description: A 20-year-old student at Fordham University in the Bronx died yesterday at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital of a contagious bacterial disease.

title: A Beverly Hills Lunch On the Flight Home
description: Mom never packed a lunch box like this: maki sushi rolls, grilled lobster panini, crispy Southern fried chicken. No Miracle Whip, bologna or peanut butter in sight.

title: TAKING THE KIDS
description: Zeus and Roxanne

title: In Paris, Chefs Change Places In Style
description: SOME great French chefs have been playing musical chairs, with happy results: Rarely have Parisians had such a choice of fine dining establishments. During the past few months, the Michelin three-star chef Pierre Gagnaire has moved from St.-Etienne, 30 miles southwest of Lyons, to a modern Right Bank dining room; the Michelin three-star chef Alain Ducasse has taken over the sumptuous Art Nouveau mansion run by Joel Robuchon before his retirement in July, and Benoit Guichard has reopened Jamin, Mr. Robuchon's former restaurant, which had been closed for the past three years. Mr. Robuchon himself is now a consultant at the newly refurbished L'Astor on the Right Bank, where Eric Lecerf is chef.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHAR, THELMA
description: SACHAR-Thelma. The Brandeis University National Women's Committee deeply mourns the loss of its loyal member and beloved friend, Thema Horowitz Sachar. A permanent member of the National Board, she was involved throughout her life in the Committee's work in support of the University's libraries. We offer profound condolences to her sons, Howard and David, and their entire families. Ellen J. Atlas, National President

title: The Key to the Mall? That's Entertainment
description: THEME restaurants, large-format movie screens and simulated wilderness adventures will join off-price stores and factory outlets in a 2.1-million-square-foot shopping center if the Mills Corporation wins permission to build north of Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

title: Packing Light
description: To the Editor: We at Outdoor Research were pleased to see our name mentioned in Susan Spano's ''Packing Light: The Right Stuff, Stuffed Right'' (Nov. 10). But because Ms. Spano coupled a description of our kit with an enumeration of things that do not come with the kit, consumers calling us are confused.

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: Wills writes that I ''blame'' the press for not preventing the election of Clinton, ''for not building fires of ardent indignation'' about the President's character flaws. My piece said nothing of the kind. What was missing from the campaign coverage, I argued, was the sort of thorough reporting and analysis that would have helped the public understand the significance of the Clinton ethics scandals and any role they might play in the second term. I called for facts, not fires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNAK, FLORENCE SHERMAN
description: PASTERNAK-Florence Sherman. Beloved wife of Louis, M.D. Devoted mother of Brent and Saree, Debi, Cheril and Steven, and Doug and Suzanne. Dear sister of Jack and Helen Sherman and adored grandmother. Services on Sunday 11 AM, at The Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, opposite LIRR.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZABO, SZILARD
description: SZABO-Szilard, born on February 5, 1918 in Budapest Hungary. A man of warmth, love, humor, and many talents, he died Feb. 6, 1997 with his loved ones by his side. He will be greatly missed by his wife Maria, sons Szilard, Gyorgy, and Andrew, daughter Judith Kemp, son-in-law Richard, daughters-inlaw Judit, and Zsuzsa, brother Laszlo, and grandchildren Gyorgy, Peter, Judit, Szilard. His loss will also be mourned by his many friends as well as colleagues and admirers of his work with the Hungarian Community and Theater. We will always love you. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, February 9, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Stephen of Hungary, 414 East 82nd Street at 1st Avenue, Monday, February 10 at 10:00 AM. Please contribute to the American Liver Foundation, 998 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, New Jersey.

title: Tigers' Bell Battling The Demons of 1996
description: For the Yankees, spring training 1997 comes too soon. They are still celebrating World Series 1996. For the Detroit Tigers, on the other hand, spring training cannot start soon enough. The faster 1997 begins, the sooner they can forget about the nightmare that was 1996.

title: Royal Scam
description: A FEW WEEKS AGO THE FORMER Duchess of York, Sarah Ferguson, became the official spokeswoman for Weight Watchers, a subsidiary of the H. J. Heinz Company, the ketchup maker. She will be paid $1 million -- with a bonus if she keeps the fat off -- for appearing several times during the coming year on behalf of Weight Watchers. The world has become so numbed to celebrity endorsements that the arrangement attracted only passing notice: If Bob Dole can hawk Visa cards, why can't Sarah Ferguson peddle diets? But the Duchess's deal is new and a bit different, a footnote to the final chapter of the epochal struggle between aristocratic values and market values.

title: Black Spokesman?
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Sunny Side of the Street
description: I FIRST ran into David (Tee) Theresa back in November, on Monroe Street in Hoboken, where a couple of hundred people showed up for the dedication of a sidewalk plaque outside the vacant lot on the site of the home where Frank Sinatra grew up.

title: Best Convertible In a Leading Role
description: AS my car pulled up to the oppressively status-conscious stage known as the Ivy restaurant, something amazing happened. The dread I commonly felt when I stepped from my usual car, a Chevy Lumina, in full view of the patio filled with agents and producers, cellular phones and Armani sunglasses, lifted like a morning fog.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TAP DOGS

title: Mary Verbeck, John Spilman 5th  Mary Meigs Verbeck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pieter Lighthall Verbeck of Darien, Conn., was married there on Friday to John Armistead Spilman 5th, the son of Mr. Spilman 4th of Lutherville, Md., and Baroness Joan von Pantz of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. James Kowalski performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.    Mrs. Spilman, 28, is the marketing manager of Family Money magazine in New York. She graduated from Trinity College in Hartford, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.
description: The bride's father is the managing partner of Communications Partnership, a marketing and advertising consulting company in Darien. Her mother, Linda A. Verbeck, is a certified financial planner at Retirement Counseling Associates in Darien.

title: After Beetle's Toll, Tree-Replacement Math
description: Residents of Greenpoint, where hundreds of trees have been attacked by a parasitic beetle, warned last week of a potential showdown if the state follows through with its plan to remove the trees without guarantees of replacing them.

title: Lost in the Mail
description: To the Editor: I have traveled extensively for more than 50 years and at various times and places have mailed postcards to friends and family. That is, I went to the post office, affixed postage and dropped them into the correct slot. A very high percentage of my cards do not make it. (Albania had 100 percent nondelivery: a dozen cards, weighed and with air-mail stamps, posted in the main post office, never appeared.)

title: A Rush to Build Complexes to Care for the Aging
description: WITH the nation's ninth largest population of residents 65 and older, New Jersey is becoming a magnet for the development of specialized housing for the elderly.

title: Wilderness Deluxe
description: IN the modest airport of Kununurra in Western Australia, my husband, Bill Brewster, and I were greeted by an imposing sign welcoming us to ''The Shire of Wyndham, East Kimberley.'' Lest there be any misunderstanding, though, someone had seen fit to add the words ''The Last Frontier.''

title: Plan Is Near to Improve Goldens Bridge Parking
description: FORCED to park along State Road 138 near the train station here, a man who lost out in the yearly lottery for a parking permit at the station arrived from Manhattan one night and, having forgotten where he had left his car, walked up and down the road pressing the door button on the car's remote control until he heard a responding click.

title: How Much Candy? Well, How Much Do You Want?
description: In a place where ''closed'' signs outnumber the people in the winter, an open store is sure to draw attention from the naturalists and the townies who hold tight to this quiet, wind-swept time -- particularly if the store beckons with signs promising fudge that's ''fresh,'' ''rich'' and ''creamy smooth.''

title: Searching For a Sound to Bridge The Decades
description: IT WAS CRUNCH TIME FOR U2. THE IRISH band's next single had to be finished within three days, and the deadline for the complete album, which had not yet been entitled ''Pop,'' was less than a month away. U2, with its producers and engineers, was recording and mixing in two studios simultaneously. Workdays stretched to 14 and 16 hours. But even at that stage, everything was subject to change -- including, as it turned out, the final deadline. ''We have trouble finishing things,'' said the Edge, U2's guitarist. The album, originally due last September as a pre-Christmas release, was finished in late December, with all-night recording sessions up to the last minute. It is to be released March 4.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Canandaigua Wine Tries to Get Its Bottles in a Row
description: THANKS to a reputation for cheaply acquiring liquor companies that nobody else wanted, and then turning those businesses around, the Canandaigua Wine Company was riding high in the fall of 1995.

title: U.S.-Jamaica Spat Undermines Region's Anti-Drug Efforts
description: Hoping to step up its fight against drug trafficking, the United States instead finds itself stuck in a messy dispute with Jamaica that threatens to undermine anti-drug efforts throughout the Caribbean.

title: Maybe No Problem For Personal Computers
description: I have just read your article (''Q&A: Computer Crunch at the Millennium,'' Jan. 26). I don't think you make a clear distinction between the millennium problem for personal computers and for large systems with big number-crunching programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWENS, BEATRICE BERGEN
description: OWENS-Beatrice Bergen. Beloved wife of the late Joseph E. Owens. Beloved aunt of Richard B. and John G. Cronin and Austin Kilbourn. Funeral Friday, February 14, at 10:30 AM, St. Thomas More Catholic Church, 65 East 89th St. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to St. Thomas More Church, attention: Father Stan Moseley.

title: Miami Marches to Line Too Often for Rutgers
description: Bob Wenzel took a long look at the final scoring sheet tonight. One category in particular stood out to the Rutgers basketball coach: Miami attempted 22 free throws, while Rutgers attempted just 7 -- none in the second half.

title: State of the Union Enemies
description: In his annual message to Congress last Tuesday night, President Clinton pronounced the union's state strong. But he declared that the United States still has an enemy.

title: Edinburgh
description: To the Editor: It was criminal for Marilyn Stasio, in her essay on Edinburgh crime writers, ''A Wonderful Place for a Murder'' (Jan. 12) to omit the names of Arthur Conan Doyle and Sherlock Holmes. Doyle was born in Edinburgh and completed medical school there. The Edinburgh University historian Owen Dudley Edwards has pointed out that the origin and sites of many Holmesian adventures are in Edinburgh although they were described as London settings, doubtless to appease The Strand Magazine's editor.

title: A Quick Guide to Big Ideas, if You Didn't Get to Davos
description: DAVOS, the shorthand by which the World Economic Forum's annual jamboree in this ski resort is known, is over for this year. Nelson Mandela, Yasir Arafat, Bill Gates and Jack Welch, among others, spoke. And while they were not talking -- in fact, even while they were up there on the podium -- the business elite used their view from these Alpine peaks to ponder and discuss where the world is and where it may be going, in forums large and small.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, SARAH
description: WAXMAN-Sarah. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted and dear sister of the late Manya Gershunoff and Isadore Toporoff. Loving aunt of Clara Blackman and the late Mitzi Wane. Adoring grand aunt of Susan, Elinor, Joan and Amy. Great grand aunt of David, Jon, Michael and Adam.

title: Martha Stoberock And David Ives
description: Martha Stoberock, an illustrator, and David Ives, the playwright, are to be married this morning on the stage at the Primary Stages Theater in New York. The Rev. Leslye Noyes, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Where Skyscapers Are Salt Shakers And Table Lamps
description: ONE EVENING A FEW YEARS ago on a collecting mission, Margaret Majua got into the car of a man she did not know, to drive to a place she had never been. And then she noticed the baseball bat.

title: Are They Dead Yet? Well, Yes and No.
description: ABE VIGODA has been dead so long he's learned to live with it.

title: The 'Oscars of Fashion': Slouching Toward Prime Time
description: IN so many ways, the annual awards gala of the Council of Fashion Designers of America strives to live up to its self-given title, the Oscars of Fashion.

title: If It's a Baby Photo, He Probably Took It
description: ALTHOUGH you might not know his name, you may have one of his calendars on your wall.

title: Where Garden Grew, Store May Take Root
description: Sometimes there is not enough space in a crowded city, and that fact gave a band of neighborhood gardeners pause last week as they spent what may be one of their last afternoons enjoying the birch trees and winter blossoms that have sprung from a former dumping ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, ANNA (GEMUNDER)
description: BROOKS-Anna (Gemunder), age 91. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Dearest mother of Elaine Brichta and Merav. Devoted daughter of the late Beryl and Esther. Loving sister of the late Dreizel, Abe, Gertrude, Fanny, Yetta and Shaindel. Cherished grandmother of Donald (Dana), Alan (Galit) and Dale Brichta. Great-grandmother of Jacob, Sophie and Gabrielle. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 66th Ave., Forest Hills.

title: A Fiery Minister To the Unconverted
description: ELIOT FISK HAS BEEN reconsidering his approach to the guitar lately. And in the process, he has been pondering the potential of his instrument both as a lure for new classical-music listeners and as a tool for social change.

title: AWAKENING TO SLEEP
description: While in college I experimented with sleeping from 3 to 7 A.M. and from 2 to 5 P.M. This schedule enabled me to achieve a better academic performance than at any other period. And I had plenty of energy.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: IN THE DEEP MIDWINTER

title: Terrestrial and Celestial
description: IF Alexander Heilner is to be believed, Oakland has a Loch Ness Monster -- either that or the city is the habitat of a sci-fi plant consisting of a single stem crowned by a bud.

title: Legal Questions in Cemetery Eavesdropping
description: The case of Darlie Lynn Routier, who was sentenced this week for the murder of her son, drew national attention because it was a case of a woman being given the death penalty.

title: County's Top Job Lures Plenty Of Democrats
description: THE plot is strikingly similar and the cast of characters not unlike that of 27 years ago, but will there be a happy ending again for Democrats when the scenario goes into rerun next fall?

title: ALLIES WELCOMING U.S. HINT AT PAUSE IN DOLLAR'S SURGE
description: Partly shell-shocked and partly delighted by the dollar's extraordinary surge in value in recent months, finance ministers and central bankers from the world's seven largest capitalist countries voiced relief today after signals from the United States that a pause was in order.

title: Suture: Artworks That Are Joined by a Thread
description: AS Annie Herron, an art critic and a curator, made the rounds of artists' studios in Brooklyn, she noticed a curious trend: the use of stitching, or suturing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOHN CAMPBELL
description: HENRY-John Campbell. On January 30, 1997. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, at 11 o'clock on Thursday, February 13.

title: Oh, There's a Grand Motel, With a . . .
description: WE spent a night in a Connecticut motel the other day: let's call it the Holiday Western Hampton Ramada Six.

title: Voyaging Round the World Alone, and Safely
description: It has been 32 years since Sir Robin Knox-Johnston, a British yachtsman knighted for his global exploits, completed the world's first solo, nonstop, round-the-world voyage. Now Sir Robin has a land-bound quest: to look into the safety of new sailboats following in his oceanic footsteps.

title: A Freshman in Congress Faces Up to Democracy
description: A couple of union lobbyists recently paid a call on William J. Pascrell, a first-term Congressman so fresh to Capitol Hill that he had arrived in Washington -- Clampett-style, to hear him tell it -- with a carload of his belongings earlier that morning and spent the time just before dawn wrestling with a shower curtain in his new apartment. Mr. Pascrell, a Democrat who gave up steady work as a state Assemblyman and Mayor of Paterson to come to the House of Representatives, was one of labor's few success stories last November. With the help of unions, he narrowly defeated a Republican freshman, William J. Martini, in a campaign that Mr. Pascrell himself calls ''a food fight.'' And the labor lobbyists wanted to let Mr. Pascrell know that they do not much like his support for a balanced budget amendment. His decision will not be symbolic, either: a vote this month is likely to be so close that a change of one heart could make all the difference.

title: On Edge Of Luxury, Kazakstan Is Deprived
description: The homemade cherry cakes on Bulat Atabayev's long dinner table made his niece's sixth birthday a sumptuous affair. But Mr. Atabayev, a theater director, was unhappy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-22

title: Alisa Gettenberg, Scott Lessing
description: Alisa Ann Gettenberg, a lawyer and vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York, was married last evening to Scott Lawrence Lessing, a management consultant at McKinsey & Company in New York. Rabbi Meir Berger officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.

description: Gas Station

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MJAANES, OTTO
description: MJAANES-Otto. Melek's very much loved husband and Haakan's wonderful father died at home in NYC on February 5, 1997. We are suffering the loss of a very warm, extraordinary and compassionate human being, a prophetic visual poet, a very colorful, ferociously volcanic, brilliant artist. We love you and miss you very much Ottoshkom. Memorial service at 3:00 PM Sunday, February 16, 1997, Bethlehem Lutheran Church, 490 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Otto Mjaanes Fund, c/o Art Students League of NY. Melek, Haakan, family and friends

title: A Marriage Today, Conflicts Tomorrow?
description: LAST month, as the heads of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter met secretly to forge an alliance of their armies of investment bankers and retail salesmen, an odd confluence of events demonstrated just how awkward such Wall Street combinations can be.

title: Taking Advantage of the Versatile Kale
description: NOT all vegetables are at their best steamed and served al dente. Bitter greens like kale actually benefit from longer cooking, which makes them sweet and tender.

title: Taking Steps to Insure Affordable Housing
description: As your article points out $(''Affordable Housing Gradually Expands,'' Dec. 29$), Westchester County is less than halfway to its goal of providing 5,000 units of affordable housing by 2000. As your sources wisely noted, even this goal is a modest one, intended to address bare bones needs.

description: ONCE she rode the subway from Far Rockaway to Harlem, looking for a game of ball. Now she rides the airlines, planning the ultimate comeback.

description: SHAPIRO-Jeanette. On February 7, 1997. Dear sister of Louise Feinberg. Loving aunt of Carl and Richard Feinberg. Services Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York, on Sunday, at 2 P.M. For information please call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack New Jersey at 1-800-522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, ETHEL GILFILLAN
description: DONNELLY-Ethel Gilfillan, 86, of Iowa City, sister of Herbert Tekworth, Long Island and a friend to many. Died Feb. 4, 1997, Iowa City.

description: ACCEPTABLE LOSSES. By Edra Ziesk. Southern Methodist University, cloth, $22.50; paper, $12.95.

title: The Spy Agency's Many Mean Ways To Loosen Cold-War Tongues
description: THEY had ways of making you talk.

title: Lost in Space on Philadelphia's Independence Mall
description: THIS CITY'S HISTORIC SHRINES are targets for drive-by patriotism -- parking and getting a peek at the Liberty Bell, and a tour of Independence Hall too if you're ambitious. Then, before the meter runs out, you're on your way to Amish country or Atlantic City.

title: City Labor Director Backs Effort to Organize Workfare Participants
description: In an important boost to the metropolitan area's most ambitious unionization drive in years, Stanley Hill, head of New York City's largest union of municipal workers, said yesterday that he would back efforts to organize the city's 35,000 welfare recipients who are required to work for their benefits.

title: Unromantic Economic Facts Cast Pall Over Niagara Falls
description: Winters have never been kind to the Honeymoon Capital. The city grit seems to transform the curbside snow into oatmeal clumps. The spray rising from the falls stings the face. And the Twist o' the Mist ice cream stand, which is shaped like a huge, cherry-topped cone, is closed until springtime, when the tourists return.

title: Building a Room of My Own
description: I NEEDED A PLACE TO WORK. THAT AT least is the explanation I prepared for anybody who asked about the little building going up, very slowly, in the woods behind my house. I was building a ''home office,'' an enterprise so respectable that the Government gives you a tax deduction for it. The fact that it would also be a room of one's own, a temple of solitude off the beaten track of everyday life, was a part of the plan I kept to myself.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column last Sunday, about efforts to bring casino gambling to the St. Regis Mohawk Indian reservation, misstated the view of one of the tribe's three governing councils. The column quoted a restaurant owner, Loran Thompson, as saying that the traditional Mohawk council would support a casino as long as the council ran it. The traditional council officially opposes casino gambling, according to its administrator, Joyce Mitchell.

title: 2 Giuliani Advisers Prosper From City Lobbying
description: Two of the most influential members of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's kitchen cabinet, Raymond B. Harding and Herman Badillo, have built a prosperous lobbying business at their law firm even as they continue to serve as close advisers to Mr. Giuliani, who controls the very city agencies that they are lobbying.

title: Isles Covet a Top Star Like, Oh, Say, Messier
description: Before yesterday's game against the Rangers, Islander General Manager Mike Milbury said he had a list. It shows the names of hockey players who will become free agents this summer, particularly those who are unrestricted, veteran stars who can be signed without compensation to their former teams.

title: That's Entertainment?
description: To the Editor:

title: Firms to Speed Exchange of Listings
description: Residential real estate concerns whose listings represent 85 percent of the Manhattan market have agreed to set up an electronic data-communication network to provide one another with faster and more accurate information on listings shared with other offices.

title: The Metamorphosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Families Survey Flight 800 Wreckage
description: Nearly 160 relatives of the passengers killed in the crash of T.W.A Flight 800 were allowed to tour three cavernous hangars in Calverton, L.I., to see the wreckage of the Boeing 747 that exploded last July. It was the largest group of family members to see the wreckage to date, and the families said they were hoping to assess the pace of the investigation and to come to terms with their grief.

Beloved mother of Karen Kelly, Colleen Ahearn, Edward Carey and Tracy Carey. Loving sister of Edward Gibson. Also survived by six grandchildren. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, Inc., 82-19 Northern Blvd., Jackson Heights, on Sunday, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10:15 AM, St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, REV. MSGR. JOHN F.
description: O'BRIEN-Rev. Msgr. John F. of Immaculate Conception Seminary, South Orange, NJ, on February 6, 1997. Brother of Rita O'Brien Kenah and brother-in-law Alvah Martin Kenah. Uncle of Richard M., John F., Thomas J., James M., Margaret R. and Patricia M. Kenah. Also survived by two grandnephews and six grandnieces. Msgr. O'Brien will lie in state in Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 217 Prospect St., South Orange, NJ on Sunday, 3:30-7:30 PM. Vigil Service will be held at 8:00 PM. Funeral Mass offered on Monday at 10:30 AM. For information, Preston Funeral Home, South Orange, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report column on Jan. 12, about new cruise ships, referred incorrectly to tonnage. A ton, in the context of the report, is 100 cubic feet of internal capacity, more formally known as a gross register ton; it is not a measure of weight.

title: THE LAPTOP COLONIALISTS
description: Michael Paterniti's well-written article ''The Laptop Colonialists'' (Jan. 12) gives the impression that there are only young Americans working in Saigon who spend most of their evenings at the Q Bar. But the majority of American expatriates are serious businesspeople, with families and steady jobs, here for the long run. We work well with the Vietnamese, and we realize we are guests in their country. In addition, there are a large number of Vietnamese-Americans who have returned to help rebuild their country of birth.

title: New, Reviled College Subjet: Computer-Linked Injury
description: In dormitory rooms in this college town, and on campuses across the country, students spend countless hours hunched over computers, typing term papers, browsing through computerized library files, cruising the Net and sending E-mail to their friends. They also send E-mail to professors to whom they may rarely, if ever, speak in person.

title: It's No Longer The Church
description: BUNDLED up in oversized ski jackets, the 17 teen-agers strolled into the small room at St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church, plopping down on folding metal chairs lined against turquoise walls. Some carried boom boxes. The bounce of a basketball against the linoleum floor reverberated through the air. It was Friday night and these teen-agers had come to rap with the neighborhood priest.

description: To the Editor:

description: So what will the Jets look like in 1997 under (a) Bill Belichick, (b) Bill Parcells or (c) both?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOOLMAN, IRVING
description: SCHOOLMAN-Irving, on February 7, 1997, in West Palm Beach, FL. Devoted father of Richard and father-in-law of Pamela. Brother of Shirley and Betty and cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Funeral services will be at Levitt-Weinstein, West Palm Beach, 4 PM, Sunday.

title: Swiss Money For Survivors
description: After trying a hard-line approach, and then after trying foot-dragging, Switzerland and its banks appear to have gotten the message. Self-interest finally dictated a friendlier approach to the Holocaust victims who claim that the banks ''lost'' accounts created in the 1930's and 1940's by Jews. The three biggest banks set up a $70 million fund to begin to compensate some of the elderly victims and their heirs. And there were signs that the Swiss government would also kick in money.

title: New Canaan Acts to Condemn Rental Complex Site
description: IN almost five years of bickering between New Canaan and Avalon Properties over the developer's proposal to build a mixed-use project on Elm Street, the state's courts have consistently ruled against the town.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KARASIK, RICHARD
description: KARASIK-Richard. February 28, 1931-February 9, 1994 I know you are so proud of Vicki. Love, Jan

title: Armed Forces In Ecuador Abandon Ousted Leader
description: Ecuador's military, which had foresworn taking sides between three political leaders claiming to be President of this small Andean nation, said tonight that they no longer recognized Abdala Bucaram as President.

title: A Piece of Plastic That Says New Jersey
description: The state government wants to be among the growing number of special interests issuing plastic money. A bill passed by the Senate unanimously in November and pending in the Assembly Appropriations Committee would create a state credit card that could be issued to public employees to make purchases for the state and to private citizens as a personal credit card.

title: The Life You Save May Be Your Own
description: NOT EXACTLY WHAT

title: The 'Rach 3' Can Be Rock or Rack
description: IT SEEMS SAFE TO SAY THAT Rachmaninoff's Third Piano Concerto never enjoyed such a high profile -- not in Vladimir Horowitz's prime, not even when the composer was alive and playing the work himself -- as it has in recent months, in connection with the film ''Shine,'' about the Australian pianist David Helfgott. For anyone left who has not seen the remarkably popular movie, this concerto was, broadly speaking, the fulcrum on which Mr. Helfgott's complex and tormented young life turned. As the film tells it, Rachmaninoff's sweeping, brooding, difficult music became an obsession for the promising young pianist.

title: My Brother, Myself
description: IMAGINING ROBERT

title: Gayle Kirkpatrick, Sportswear Designer, 62
description: Gayle Kirkpatrick, a fashion designer known for his youthful, modern approach to American sportswear, died on Jan. 25 at his home in New York City. He was 62.

title: In a Golden Age of Discovery, Faraway Worlds Beckon
description: Standing outside the dome of Lick Observatory on this lofty summit, two astronomers gazed beyond the foothills to the far horizon where California meets the Pacific Ocean. As the solid world at their feet rotated east, the great red sphere of glowing hydrogen seemed to sink perilously close to a doomsday collision, only to slip harmlessly out of sight in the west.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERLEY, BETTY MAYER
description: KERLEY-Betty Mayer, died February 5, 1997, in Woodbridge, CT. Memorial services will be held at 10 AM, Monday, at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich.

title: Looking Abroad? It Still Pays to Diversify
description: Given the incredible recent gains in the domestic stock market, investors understandably are thinking about diversifying abroad, where stocks may be undervalued. But how should they do it? There are funds that invest in developed markets, emerging markets or both; in specific regions of the world or around the globe; in all sizes of companies or solely in small ones.
