title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Jan. 26, about living wills, misstated the cost of an emergency medical evacuation to the United States from Salzburg, Austria. It was $25,810, not $15,000. Travel insurance paid $15,000, the policy's limit; the family paid the rest.

title: In Cold City's Warm Spot, Darling Buds Are Coming
description: Christmas lights still twinkle in some windows of the city, but in an old municipal greenhouse tucked away in a corner of Queens, winter gets little thought.

title: Now TV Interrupts Milosevic's Programming
description: FOR the last few nights, Serbian television viewers have been treated to a new show: demonstrators being chased down Belgrade streets, kicked, bludgeoned and hauled away in police vans. Demonstrations like these have been taking place for two and a half months, but such scenes used to be reserved for news programs in other countries. Now, for the first time, television coverage has been bringing the full fury of Serbia's political crisis into Serbia's own living rooms and bars.

title: A Fight Without Victors
description: IT all started with some innocent-looking flowers on an undistinguished Chelsea side street. Now -- three years, dozens of court cases and a labyrinth of torment later -- a landlord is in jail and his nemesis, a flight attendant-turned-tenant organizer, says she's moving out of the apartment she fought so hard for.

title: A Life in Philanthropy Based on Volunteerism
description: WHEN Joan S. Gilbert retired from her position as manager of community relations at Texaco last month, she planned to take a six-month sabbatical from all things work related. That plan lasted about six days. Sufficiently sated with leisure and finding her services as much in demand as ever, Ms. Gilbert upgraded her computer, bought a fax machine and made the rounds of office-supply stores.

title: G.O.P. Aiming to Build a United Front
description: JUST a day after County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said he would not run for re-election, State Senator Nicholas A. Spano flirted with the idea of running for the nomination but decided to say no.

title: Struggling Seton Hall Lets One Slip Away
description: Walking off the court at Fitzgerald Field House today, Shaheen Holloway raised his elbow pads as if he were going to throw them to the floor. Maybe it was a good thing he did not. The way things have gone for Seton Hall lately, he might have missed.

title: That Garcia Girl
description: YO! By Julia Alvarez. 309 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $18.95.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Business Diary column last Sunday about the fourth-quarter results for Philip Morris misstated the period in which the company sold 891 billion cigarettes. It was all of 1996, not the final quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LA CRUZ, HIPOLITA (DONA POLITA)
description: DE LA CRUZ-Hipolita (Dona Polita). On February 7, 1997, our mother, a special loving presence died peacefully at the Kateri Residence on Riverside Drive in New York City. Deep sorrow is felt by family members, her daughter Elma M. Lopez (Paula), her son Peter De La Cruz, and grandchildren Melissa, Corey, Adriana, Casondra and Mario. Our sincere appreciation to the twelfth floor staff at Kateri Residence for the care given our mother. A heartfelt thank you to Bere Evers and our mother's ''guardian'' Argentia Rivera for their moral support. Thank you mother for the love you gave us and your truly generous nature. Especially from you daughter siempre Te Adoro Madre. Now that your winter surrounds you, may your spirit be at peace. Services were held privately.

title: Chemical-Arms Pact Has No Reagan Imprimatur
description: To the Editor:

title: Reminders of the Cold War
description: The Russian Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, was in Washington last week, and he warned that an expansion of NATO would play into the hands of nationalist enemies of the Yeltsin Government.

title: For the Curious, Access To F.A.A. Information
description: THE Federal Aviation Administration has always sought fines from airlines and aviation contractors that violate its rules, but a few days ago the agency began doing something else as well: routinely announcing the penalties, so that travelers will know about the violations. And in three weeks the agency will begin to offer more information over the World Wide Web: data on accidents and other incidents.

title: In Final Adieu, France Gives Pamela Harriman Top Honor
description: Conferring France's highest distinction on Pamela Harriman posthumously for her service as United States Ambassador here, President Jacques Chirac of France placed the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor on Mrs. Harriman's flag-draped coffin this morning.

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: It is sad that today, after a four-year term, one of his apologists is still trying to come up with something, anything, that it can be said President Clinton believes in. It is ironic too that, given the litany of Clinton's ineptitude in office chronicled so well by Garry Wills, many of those who voted to re-elect the President did so because they figured that he who governs least (or should we say, without significant effect) governs best.

title: For Indians, Environment Becomes New Battleground
description: A narrow dirt road leads away past a tiny cluster of houses and a stone mission church that make up this settlement on the Fort Belknap Reservation. It runs past the sun dance lodge and the powwow grounds and into the forest that cloaks the Little Rocky Mountains.

title: Here Comes the Sun, and a Sculptor Says It's All Right
description: USING sunshine and shadow to predict the change of seasons is not an exact science, whatever the followers of Punxsutawney Phil, the groundhog of record, may think. Using the sun to tell time is a different story. People have been doing it since time immemorial, with great accuracy but rarely so artfully as Robert Lee Adzema.

title: Crime Stoppers
description: FOR YEARS, AMERICA'S ELEVATED CRIME RATE SERVED AS A political Rorschach test. Blame it on lenience of laws and courts or blame it on poverty, racism and social neglect. New York's sharp drop in homicides refocuses the debate on a point so simple that it looks radical: crime control begins with police. In hindsight, it certainly seems obvious. The key to the change, observes Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, is recognizing that the Police Department's ultimate role ''is to prevent crime as opposed to arresting people who have already committed crime.'' Why has the obvious proved so hard to grasp?

title: A Loopy Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: College Finally Finds a Home in Downtown Bridgeport
description: STUDENTS sitting on upholstered benches in the atrium that is the main entrance of the new Housatonic Community-Technical College in Bridgeport might find it difficult to imagine that the building had once been a shopping mall.

title: Let's See, If Xi Hits Triple Word Score . . .
description: KA. JO. XI. UT. HM. AI. PE. These may not be instantly recognizable as such, but they are words, and to Scrabble players, they are essential. They are some of the 97 two-letter words acceptable by Scrabble standards and they can make for key plays.

title: Hearts on Their (Matching) Sleeves
description: WHEN YOU MAKE A ROMANTIC statement as emphatic as Donald and Nancy Featherstone's -- since December 1980 they've worn matching outfits, all the time -- you learn to expect questions. Nancy, 44, eagerly fields them from the couple's cozy Victorian home in Fitchburg, Mass. She's wearing a brown wool suit. He is, too. A very contented 61-year-old who has grown rich manufacturing plastic pink flamingos, Donald chimes in now and then as the questions arrive. Starting, of course, with one they've heard before: Why?

title: Bush Backs Albright on Chemical Arms Ban
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright received strong backing today from former President George Bush for a treaty to ban chemical weapons, as well as for an increase in spending on foreign affairs and a plan by the Clinton Administration to pay the United States' debt to the United Nations.

title: The Sweetest Words: 'We're Booked'
description: FORGET about getting a table at Chef Vola's on Valentine's Day. Both seatings were booked a month ago.

title: BEST SELLERS: February, 9, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Donna Rothman, Gary Garrelick
description: Donna Gail Rothman, a daughter of Ann K. Rothman of Danby, Vt., and Bernard A. Rothman of New York, is to be married today to Gary Shawn Garrelick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart J. Garrelick of Norwalk, Conn. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to perform the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Of 'Of a'
description: ''ACE! IT'S AN EPIDEMIC!''

title: Woman Is Killed When 2 Cars Hit Her
description: A Manhattan woman was killed late Friday when she was thrown across Canal Street by a hit-and-run driver and then struck by a second vehicle, the police said.

title: Social Security and the First Wives' Club
description: Q. I'm over 50, divorced after 21 years of marriage and my ex-husband has remarried. Can I still collect his Social Security benefits or will his new wife get them all?

title: F.Y.I.
description: Expecting a Ride

title: A Bumpy Road, Traveled With Grace
description: THE Royal Winnipeg Ballet is coping with a certain amount of turnaround, and it is not of the sort executed onstage. The company has a new artistic director, again, and some of its non-Canadian dancers have left without warming up to the wintry capital of Manitoba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, HARRISON EDWARD (HARRY)
description: DONNELLY - Harrison Edward (Harry), February 7, 1997, of Somers, NY. Beloved son of Edward and Lauralee. Brother of James L. Grandson of Patricia C. Donnelly and Jesse and Dorothy Watkins. Great-grandson of Anna K. W. Bizzoso and Charlotte Conevery. Also survived by several aunts, uncles and cousins. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Monday, 2-4, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at New St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Yorktown Heights, NY, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Amawalk Hill Cemetery.

title: N.F.L. Moves Up Parcells Hearing
description: Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, has called both the Patriots and the Jets to nudge them into talking about a deal to solve the vexing problem regarding Bill Parcells. If both teams cannot agree today to an arrangement that brings Parcells to the Jets as coach this season, then Tagliabue will conduct a formal hearing with the clubs tomorrow to resolve at least the issue over whether the coach can act as their consultant this year.

title: THE LAPTOP COLONIALISTS
description: American expatriates in Vietnam are fooling themselves. Vietnam is a country that does not believe in democracy, freedom or the rights of the individual.

title: Network
description: JEWISH POWER

title: ODE TO JOE
description: Joe Franklin, the 70-year-old New York institution who ended his television talk show in 1993 after a record 43-year run, returns tonight in ''50,000,000 Joe Franklin Fans Can't Be Wrong,'' a documentary on WNET. Franklin, as fans know, staged one the most compellingly bad TV programs in history. The documentary chronicles visits from stars like Bing Crosby but, more typically, Mrs. Babe Ruth and the Sparks, an a cappella group that sang''I Like You Very Much.'' Franklin had been on the air almost 20 years before Joshua Brown, the director, was born. Brown doesn't deny Franklin's camp appeal, but he hopes to convey his ''benevolent'' side as well. ''There's something touching,'' he says, ''in the way he's always trying to champion new talents, regardless of their actual abilities.''

title: End of an Empire
description: DOWN WITH

title: Financial Companies Merge
description: Two of the biggest American securities firms stunned the business world last week. They said they would combine in a merger valued at $10.2 billion to form one of the world's biggest financial companies -- Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co.

title: No Televised Circus
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: African-American Relations

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SUNNYSIDE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERY, VIRGINIA KELLOGG
description: AVERY-Virginia Kellogg. The Trustees, Auxiliary & Staff of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden mourn the passing of Virginia Avery, widow of Dr. George S. Avery, former Director of Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Virginia was a warm friend to countless people associated with the Garden. Contributions in her memory may be made to Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Brooklyn, New York 11225. Lois M. Carswell Judith D. Zuk Allan F. Kramer II

title: Dear Dr. Greenspan
description: ''Dear Dr. Greenspan, I have a terrible problem. I'm feeling irrationally exuberant about the U.S. stock market and I just can't shake it. I know you've said 'irrational exuberance' is bad for my health, and I've tried everything: Hypnosis. Valium. Short-selling. Even rereading your speeches from 1987. But nothing works. Every time I come over here to Europe, or visit Japan, I return home itching to invest more in the U.S. market. Please, please help me. Sincerely, Mr. Full E. Invested.''

title: 'Round and 'Round On Bus-Fuel Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Stern's Big Item Is Still Rodman
description: Of all the issues facing the National Basketball Association, Commissioner David Stern today again found himself addressing the one most likely to end up on tabloid television.

title: Park Avenue's 'Gardeners' Work for Private Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: This Cold House
description: My father grew up in northern New York State. My mother grew up in northern Minnesota. In my father's town, they used to say that there were only three seasons: July, August and winter. In my mother's town, winter blizzards were so savage that cows froze to death. Which is to say, my parents are tough people. When they married, they settled in northern Connecticut, a location that must have seemed positively tropical to them after their upbringings.

title: Romantic Songs Of Ireland
description: ON Valentine's Day, romantic music of Ireland can be heard at the Quick Center for the Arts, Fairfield University. The 8 P.M. Friday show will include ballads sung by the Gaelic-American Glee Club and a performance by John McDermott, whose recording of ''Danny Boy'' has been a top seller in Ireland and Canada. Other songs on his list: ''When You and I Were Young, Maggie,'' ''Natives'' and ''The Green Isle of Erin.'' The number to call for more information is 203-254-4010.

title: With Daring, Meno and Sand Are Taking On the World
description: There is nothing dismissive about a pair of third-place finishes at the world figure skating championships. But, in their own minds, Jenni Meno and Todd Sand did not win a second bronze medal in 1996 as much as they lost a shot at silver and gold.

title: The Games (And Ghosts) Of Yesterday
description: IN A JOB THAT REQUIRES WATCHING MORE television sports than a nervous bookie, I've discovered the ideal reason to watch even more: the Classic Sports Network, a 21-month-old cable wonderland of sports oldies, where everybody exists in the past tense, the sideburns are long, the outcomes are foregone conclusions and my youth -- and the youth of others -- regularly passes before me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTHEIMER, ROBERT W.
description: ASTHEIMER-Robert W., age 74, of Fairfield and Westport, CT. Husband of Marguerite F. Astheimer, died Thursday, February 6, 1997. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 15, 1997, at 11:00 AM in the Saugatuck Congregational Church, 245 Post Road East, Westport, CT.

title: DIARY
description: WALL STREET

title: How to Get the Most Out of a Radiator
description: A RADIATOR is a device used to disperse the heat generated in the furnace to other parts of the house. The heat may be transmitted from the furnace to the radiator with either steam or hot water. Most radiators use a combination of convection and radiation to heat their surroundings.

title: The Road Warrior's Books on Tape
description: Theseus is dispatching bandits on the road to Athens, skillfully dealing with scurvy and brutal thugs who would hijack your cart and strip it in minutes. I am navigating the West Side Highway, looking past the hulk of an abandoned Chevy Nova to the wine-dark Hudson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, ROSALIND R.
description: ROSNER-Rosalind R. On February 8, 1997, in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late Oscar S. Survived by Seth and Ann Rosner, Jonathan L. and Lydia S. Rosner, Beth and Bibi Giokas, Marianne and Garth Klimchuk, Joshua and Robin Rosner, Rachel Rosner and great-grandchildren Aaron and Sasha. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dance Fever
description: THE JOFFREY BALLET

title: Coastal Disturbances
description: The idea for THE LADY FROM SHANGHAI (1948) is a corker and Orson Welles's ability to direct a good cast against fascinating backgrounds has never been better displayed. Welles as a roving Irish seaman is hired onto a luxury yacht off California. Soon he becomes aware of personal danger aboard this floating nest of vipers that includes a famous criminal lawyer (Everett Sloane), his seductive wife (Rita Hayworth, above with Welles) and a wild-eyed maniac (Glenn Anders). Although the triple-cross murder plot gets confusing, the shattering finale is one of the great thriller showdowns on film -- WEDNESDAY at 2:35 P.M. on SHO. -- Howard Thompson

title: Enclave Reflects Aborigines' Plight
description: In the shadow of gleaming skyscrapers three subway stops from the central business district, young men in T-shirts, cut-offs and running shoes sell heroin openly. Alleys behind derelict two-story row houses smell of urine and garbage. Used syringes glint in the blazing sunlight. Broken glass crunches underfoot.

title: A Dropout Says Goodbye To Anonymity
description: DON DENARIE slid out of the old Dodge gas sucker looking rather puckish. He tilted his beret just so over his pile of blondish white hair and bounded around the corner to his regular hangout, By Bread Alone, like a young man in love. ''My legs went bad a few years ago,'' he said, seeming surprised that they were acting so sprightly.

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: Does the President believe in anything? Actually, yes. He believes in us -- which is why we twice elected him.

title: A Model of High-Density Residential Development
description: IN deciding how to develop the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle, those involved might do well to glance across the street. An exquisite model of high-density development, albeit on a smaller scale, stands on the east side of the intersection: The apartment house at 240 Central Park South has set a standard for architecture and planning since 1940, although it is now in less than superb shape.

title: THE BOOR WAR
description: The tone of Tierney's article was light, but these encounters can be anything but funny. People who litter and spit and vandalize don't care about other people. Tierney is just lucky that the altercation he described didn't end with a gunshot to the head.

title: Alone, in a Crowd
description: Tiger Woods, the new golf superstar, is one of the few minority professionals in his sport. William S. Cohen, the new Secretary of Defense, is the only Republican in a Democratic Cabinet. Are you the only member of a minority group in your office, or the only conservative in a company full of liberals? Or are you the only 60-year-old in an office staffed with youngsters, or the only woman in senior management? Has the situation affected how you do your work or created any unusual situations? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Soccer's Passions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Liberty Against the Law

title: How to Unclog the Internet
description: I HAVE seen the future and it isn't working. Like most Internet users, I used to envision cyberspace as a vast open terrain that one explored as if sailing through the galaxies on the Starship Enterprise. Now I'm starting to view it as a rush-hour traffic jam on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue.

title: Where the Art Will Be in 1997
description: Thanks to blockbuster exhibitions, the popularity of art museums is growing. That is one reason why travelers should know about the 1997 Traveler's Guide to Art Museum Exhibitions. This guide, now in its ninth year, goes beyond the blockbusters, listing more than 1,500 exhibitions at 250 museums in the United States and in major cities overseas.

title: Robert Becker, Margaret Lowery
description: Margaret M. Lowery and Robert A. Becker, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday evening in Philadelphia. Judge David N. Savitt of the Pennsylvania Court of Common Pleas in Philadelphia officiated at the Rittenhouse Hotel.

title: Black-Owned Supermarket Clears Hurdle With Loan
description: High prices and low quality have long plagued grocery shoppers in Harlem. And industry experts say the underlying problem is that most of the area's supermarkets are too small to buy in quantities that allow them to offer truly competitive prices. But community activists also point to another factor: that none of the supermarket owners are black.

title: At Cabbies' Way Station, Oil Boxes Become Prayer Mats
description: The Mobil gas station at First Avenue and 90th Street seems ordinary enough with its fluorescent lights and rows of gas pumps. But customers and occasionally, employees, may be found praying in corners on musallahs, or prayer mats, improvised from flattened cardboard Mobil Oil boxes.

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: Barring the outbreak of a war, Clinton's best chance of achieving greatness lies in tackling the issue of entitlements. The benefits of a solution to this problem would not be felt in the short term, but the strains would be. Is the President willing to shoulder such public animosity to do what is right, even though it would all but guarantee Al Gore's defeat in the election of 2000? I doubt it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERFELD, RUTH (FIELDS)
description: LIEBERFELD-Ruth (Fields). On Friday, February 7, 1997, of Montclair, NJ. Dear sister of Sylvia Kaplan, the late Helen Melniker and the late Lillian Rosenthal. Dear aunt and great-aunt. Funeral services private.

title: Messier's 3 Goals Make The Rangers Feel at Home
description: Road, sweet, road.

title: An Insurance Policy For Vandals' Parents
description: Parents can be held responsible for their children's actions even when they cannot always control them, but in New Jersey, homeowners' insurance must cover the cost of damage the children do, the State Supreme Court has ruled.

title: INTO THE WOOD
description: CONTEMPORARY ARchitecture, with its open spaces and sharp edges, is not always famous for its warmth. But in this New York town house, the rigors of modernism are tempered by human proportions and rich textures, producing interiors that are spare but not Spartan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWITT, FLORENCE
description: HEWITT-Florence. The heart of our family passed away on Friday. She is dearly beloved by her husband Bernard; her children Michael and wife Gloria, Peter and wife Barbara, and Wendy and her husband Barry; her ten grandchildren, Jamie, Jon, Adam and wife Barbara, Jonathan, Peter and his wife Lila, Kelly, Christopher, Cory, Gloria, Mike; her brother Stanley and his wife Doris; and two adored great-grandchildren, Luke and Ishaan. She will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Sanctuary
description: William Faulkner and the Tangible Past

title: Grandma's Chocolate-Truffle Job
description: It's not unusual for people to boast about their grandmother's baking. But how many can say that Grandma's sweets are savory enough to be served in a French restaurant in SoHo?

title: American Justice, Not Simpson, Was Real Loser
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Plans More Fires to Prevent Fires
description: To invigorate Federal forests and prevent uncontrollable fires, the Government will move aggressively to clear and burn dead wood and underbrush, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said on Friday.

title: Be Sensitive to Your Valentine (or Else)
description: ROMY LERNER remembers it too well. On the eve of Valentine's Day two years ago, her boyfriend ended their relationship. She went directly home and ate the present she got for him: a box of chocolate roses.

title: McCall Tries to Explain Bizarre Actions
description: Even for heavyweight boxing -- which in the 1990's has seen a title fight interrupted by a parasailor and Andrew Golota losing two bouts for hitting below Riddick Bowe's ample belt line -- Oliver McCall's actions yesterday and Friday night may have been the strangest yet.

title: Packing Light
description: To the Editor: ''Packing Light'' should be required reading before one is allowed to check in for departure -- anywhere. You can spend a month traveling from near the Equator to Tierra del Fuego using only a duffel (19 by 14 inches when mashed flat) and a small backpack.

title: Paper Route
description: PERSONAL HISTORY By Katharine Graham. Illustrated. 642 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Skip Away A Few Steps Too Short In the Donn
description: Skip Away opened his pursuit of Cigar's history-making level of racing today, but finished a length and a quarter short as Formal Gold led every step of the way to win the Donn Handicap.

title: The Shroud of Milford
description: For decades, the tiny museum in Milford, Pa., was a wannabe. Its prize item -- a bloodstained, 36-star American flag on which Abraham Lincoln's head supposedly rested after John Wilkes Booth shot him -- was given little credibility, sometimes even at the museum, where it once hung from a shower-curtain rod. But as the nation celebrates the 188th anniversary of Lincoln's birthday this week, Milford is feeling justifiably cocky. Thanks to Barbara Buchanan, president of the Pike County Historical Society (pictured right), and Joseph Garrera, an Lincoln expert from Fredon, N.J. (left), the flag (now enclosed in an air-tight, 25-foot-tall case) has recently become an acknowledged star.

title: Putting Life's Trials In a Sacred Context
description: IN the world of politics, Ralph Reed and the Christian Coalition have come to signify sweeping change among the nation's 40 million-plus evangelical Protestants. But signs of a quieter cultural shift can be seen on a visit to a Christian bookstore.

title: LEAVE OZZIE AND HARRIET ALONE
description: Although the universality of family minutia is undeniable, Curtis is wrong in asserting that ''there is nothing about these daily decisions that depends on wealth or class.'' On some level, every aspect of a family's life is shaped by its economic status.

title: Lifelong Romance With Horses, Caring for the Abused Ones
description: LIKE a mother calming her child, Ginny Devlin cupped the cheek of the dark brown Appaloosa, Justin, and stroked down toward his muzzle. ''Children and animals always get the short end of the stick because they can't speak,'' said Ms. Devlin, 50, leaning against the rough rail fence that surrounds the seven-horse stable at Ryton Farm in Bethlehem. ''And with horses, there aren't a lot of people willing to speak out for them. But that's where I come in.''

title: The Mellowing of the Quintessentially Crabby City
description: If a city of seven million people can be said to have moods, which for the sake of argument it shall be presumed that it can, the mood of New York City oscillates perpetually between the extremes of smugness and disgust.

title: Assigning Labels Where None Exist
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Brinkmann, 62, Actress, Director and Theater Founder
description: Ruth Brinkmann, an actress and director who was a founder of the English Theater in Vienna, died there on Jan. 18. She was 62.

title: TAKING THE KIDS
description: Waiting for Guffman

title: P.B.A. Funds Are the Focus Of an Inquiry
description: The Federal investigation into the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is focusing on a variety of union accounts, which hold more than $100 million in assets, including tens of millions of dollars paid annually by the city to the police union.

title: Men's Hems Are Rising
description: Fluctuating hemlines, once the barometer of women's fashion, are now an issue for men's coats. Dress coats have been at low-calf length for a decade, but 40-inch, shaped coats, worn with narrow trousers, showed wide acceptance on young men attending the New York men's-wear collections last week. The silhouette recalls the Edwardian without the bowler and the Savile Row man without the homburg. Today, the coats are worn with a knit or baseball cap, or no cap.

title: A New Budget Battle Begins
description: With a thump, President Clinton dropped his four-volume, $1.69 trillion budget proposal for fiscal year 1998 on Congress' doorstep last week. Muttering about lessons learned in previous budget brawls, Republicans carried it inside for inspection, rather than dumping it straight in the trash as they had for two years running.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Jan. 26 about Nagasaki reversed the identities of two restaurants. On page 6, the exterior was that of Miyakawa; on page 26, the restaurant was Ichi Riki.

title: For Kernen, a Twist for the Better
description: Bruno Kernen is a trained engineer capable of designing bridges and roads, but today at the world Alpine skiing championships, he spent his afternoon designing something else: an upset.

title: When All Roads Lead South By Southwest
description: ON a starry March evening in Austin, Tex., a six-pack of kids pulls up to Sixth and Congress in a 1966 Ford Fairlane, older than its occupants by at least 10 years. The convertible top is thrown back. ''Hey mister,'' one of them calls out to one of us, ''Is this the way to Yasgur's farm?'' We get the generation-gap joke (do our Woodstock age rings really show so?), but what exactly does this 20-year-old want from us 40-year-olds?

title: How We Can Save Main St.
description: A CENTURY ago, the Village of Garden City represented the nation's first community to be planned in a rational and thoughtful manner.

title: AWAKENING TO SLEEP
description: It strikes me as self-serving for sleep researchers to hypothesize that insomnia is more a matter of perception than an actual disturbance. If researchers cannot discover the difference between good sleepers and insomniacs from their EEG's or breathing patterns, then common sense suggests that they look for other factors rather than ascribing insomnia to the black box of ''perception.''

title: An English-Speaking Police Unit for Indonesia
description: ''The police have the duty to protect tourists.'' So said Lieut. Gen. Dibyo Widodo of the Indonesian National Police, speaking of Indonesia's new 70-member English-speaking police unit, with special brown and red uniforms.

title: Church Group Battles Pathmark Proposal
description: The block bounded by 144th and 145th Streets, Frederick Douglass Boulevard and Bradhurst Avenue has been an eyesore to local residents for more than 20 years, its three dilapidated buildings on a city-owned, garbage-strewn lot dwelling places for rats and the homeless.

title: Future Trucks: Muscular but Soft Inside
description: IF you think today's sport utility vehicles are plush, just wait. Future versions, suggested in hybrid car-truck concept vehicles on display at the Chicago Auto Show, have the high, aggressive look of off-road gladiators but will offer luxury-car appointments and standards of ride, handling and fuel economy that approach those of family sedans.

title: 30 Years Later, Florence Warily Watches the Arno
description: IT LOOKS ALMOST LIKE A POST-MODERN installation, Cimabue's ''Crucifixion'' suspended in midair by four stainless-steel cables in the damp, dark Santa Croce refectory. A masterpiece of 13th-century Italian painting, Cimabue's lyrical, sensual Christ still bears the wounds it suffered when the waters of the Arno River raged through the center of Florence in 1966.

title: Falling Out and In
description: BITTER LAKE By Ann Harleman. 253 pp. Dallas: Southern Methodist University Press. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $12.95.

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column on Jan. 26, about restaurants in the East 50's in Manhattan, included an outdated reference to Oceana. It received a three-star rating from The New York Times on Oct. 4, 1996. The two-star rating was from an earlier review, on Dec. 2, 1994.

title: The Bloch Who Left Block
description: EVEN as a teen-ager, Thomas Bloch aimed to become chief executive of H & R Block, the company founded by his father, Henry, and his uncle Richard.

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: Sometimes a writer goes too far in painting word pictures. Here are some of Garry Wills's phrases for Republicans: ''secretly alerted,'' ''hit team,'' ''full of errors,'' ''a joke,'' ''parroted endlessly.'' Here are some words and phrases about Clinton: ''bone deep,'' ''intense,'' ''bedrock experience,'' ''nerve and concentration,'' ''obvious affection.'' Is there a hint of partiality here?

title: Perth, All Grown Up
description: Here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and seemingly bound for a dive . . . Nothing will content them but the extremest limit of the land . . . They must get just as nigh the water as they possibly can without falling in ... HERMAN MELVILLE

title: For a Prewar Site, A Design in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: The Starry 'Three Sisters' Cast Reveals a Trend
description: ANTON CHEKHOV'S ''THREE SISTERS'' is a kind of New York perennial, popping up regularly in limited runs (a Russian production, in Russian, appeared at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Broadway in November) and in Off Broadway experiments (Richard Schechner's version last month, with each of the four acts set in a different time, will play an encore at La Mama from Feb. 26 through March 9). But rarely is it given a Tony-eligible staging, the kind of full-scale, conventionally interpreted treatment meant to withstand the scrutiny of Broadway audiences and critics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTON, JIMMY
description: WESTON-Jimmy. Beloved father of Jeanne, Jennifer and Jaime. Brother of Eugene and the late Warren and Mary. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday, 7-9 PM, Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass St. John the Evangelist R.C. Church, 1st Ave at 55th St, Monday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Francis Pope Memorial Foundation, 401 E. 81 St, Suite 20A, NY, NY 10028.

title: A Landscape Master Lost in the Shadows
description: IN THE 127 YEARS SINCE HIS death, the landscape painter Louis Remy Mignot has haunted the margins of 19th-century American art. A curious specimen, a Southerner of French parentage, he was described in 1880, a decade after his death from smallpox at the age of 39, as ''one of the most remarkable artists of our country'' by Samuel G. W. Benjamin in his book ''Art in America.''

title: Will the Real Puccini Please Stand Up?
description: WHEN Charles Rosekrans was 9, he stood in front of a mirror and conducted the overture to Bizet's opera ''Carmen,'' but he was not sure whether it was a baton or a baseball bat he wanted in his future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKIN, SYLVIA. (NEE REINER)
description: LIPKIN-Sylvia. (nee Reiner). Died suddenly on Feb. 5, 1997. Survived by her son Stephen Kusiel and her daughter Susan Beesemyer. Memorial gathering will be held at the Manhattan home of her son on Monday, February 10 at 11A.M.

title: No Time For Winter's Gloom
description: Fashion salutes the stars among it, and glasses are raised to honor a bookshelf of new authors.

title: The Price of Love
description: Love has its costs, and although most cannot be measured in dollars and cents, there is always a bottom line to any budding relationship. And, sadly, those expenses, especially the ones tied to Valentine's Day, have gone up. Beverly Wettenstein of New York, the author of ''A Woman's Book of Days,'' has put together what she calls her ''Cost of Loving Survey.'' It shows how the costs of courting and a wedding have risen over 10 years, providing more proof that love indeed ignores most norms -- including the Consumer Price Index. Since 1987, the prices of all these items have risen faster than the inflation rate.

title: Consumers and Managed Care
description: More than 50 million Americans are now enrolled in health maintenance organizations. Nearly three-quarters of those who receive health insurance through their employers are covered by some type of managed-care plan, up from 51 percent just two years ago. The growing dominance of managed care has helped control health care cost increases. Over time, managed care may also improve medical outcomes by emphasizing preventive care, coordinating the delivery of services and reducing the number of unnecessary procedures and tests.

title: Henry James on Film
description: To the Editor:

title: Overcoming the Home-Court Disadvantage
description: Their green and white uniforms are old and ragged. They have no formal name, no mascot, no cheering section, not even a home court.

title: Choices in Home Care Service
description: IF Lilly Cohen had her way, all patients who needed home care would know they have a choice. As she noted, ''People take a hospital's referral as gospel, when the fact is you can choose any home care agency you want and still get Medicare coverage.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAY, FRANCES
description: RAY-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Ray (Sam). Devoted mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother, aunt. Rest in peace. Your Children

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45 - 2/9/94 No one could have fought harder. It still seems so strange and unfair. Miss you always. Vicki

title: Utility Deregulation: Lots of Questions About a Big Change
description: Vic DeLuca was ready as he approached the microphone, producing a three-page speech and several envelopes full of props.

title: Bridge Turns Man's Quiet Retirement Into 'Seven Plagues'
description: ''I didn't ever think my retirement would end up like this,'' said Augustine Barry, a simple man who left his job as a homeless outreach worker the minute he turned 62 three years ago. He thought he would live out the rest of his life in the peace of his garden, tending to his chickens and ducks.

title: Alison Kirk, Christopher Long
description: Alison Goodrich Kirk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Kirk 2d of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Christopher William Long, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Long of London. The Rev. Anthony Roberts performed the ceremony at St. John's Anglican Church in Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 26 about residential development in Manhattan misstated the financing arrangements for two buildings being developed by the Related Companies L.P. Financing for the rental tower at 84th Street and First Avenue and the residential portion of the development on Union Square between Fourth Avenue and Broadway is being supplied by tax-exempt bonds issued through the New York State Housing Finance Agency. Guarantees for repayment to the bondholders are being supplied by Fleet Bank and Hypo Bank of Munich.

title: Helping to Build Children's Self-Esteem
description: MY daughter's grades are dropping and she is hanging around with the wrong crowd. I don't know what to do. My son was sent to the principal's office twice last week, I've tried everything and he just won't listen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, LEONARD
description: DAVIS-Leonard, 40, on November 28. Artist, writer, dear friend and brother. Son of Theresa and Sidney, of Englewood, NJ. Devout member of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Brown University, Parsons School of Design, Starr Foundation Fellow Royal Academy of Art, London. We miss you, Lenny. Your creative spirit will always be with us. Memorial service Saturday, Feb. 15, 11 A.M., Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Seasonlong Quest For a New Year's Duck
description: On the New Year's Eve just past, Ruth and I continued our tradition of dining on roast wild duck and oysters Florentine, but the ritual had been in doubt since the opening of the hunting season in late October. With a week to go before the ceremony, I had failed to outwit a single bird.

title: As if From a Time Capsule, an Antihero
description: ALTHOUGH IT IS HARD TO KNOW just what we may need on this trip to a new century, it is time to think seriously about packing. The Metropolitan Opera seems to have the right idea, starting with the essentials and installing a new production of Alban Berg's ''Wozzeck'' on Monday evening. The opera, which was first produced in 1925 and centers on the impotence of an antihero in the face of an implacable fate, is virtually a time capsule from a century that has insistently identified itself with modernity and as insistently pondered the modern predicament.

title: As Web Pages Blossom, So Does a Firm
description: IN a white frame house, converted to a hive of business activity on Halstead Avenue here, the average age of the 24 employees of On-Line Design is 28. Which is not surprising, considering that the activity they are engaged in -- creating Web sites -- is barely 10 years old.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 9, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Unfamiliar Turf
description: Detective Superintendent Jane Tennison (Helen Mirren) is back facing another tough challenge in PRIME SUSPECT: ERRORS OF JUDGMENT, a two-part Masterpiece Theater presentation -- SUNDAY at 9 P.M. on CHANNELS 13 and 49. Transferred to the Manchester police as community relations officer, Tennison is given the shooting of a young drug dealer to investigate with the aid of a reluctant new team. An unexpected confession leads to a kidnapping and another murder, and she finds herself in a nightmarish underworld ruled by The Street (Steven Mackintosh), in pursuit of a killer, surrounded by people she doesn't know or trust and involved with a man she can't have. Can it possibly get any worse? -- Yolanda A. Andrews

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: For Anxious Children, This Salon Makes the Cut

title: Who's No. 1? She'd Better Be
description: To the Editor:

title: In Celebration of Jackie Robinson
description: AS director of development and public relations for the Jackie Robinson Foundation, W.(Will)H. Mebane Jr. is making sure that the 50th anniversary of Robinson's breaking the color barrier in major league baseball is properly celebrated.

title: Elizabeth Gatov, 85, Ex-Treasurer of U.S.
description: Elizabeth Rudel Gatov, a wealthy California businesswoman who was long active in Democratic politics and served briefly as Treasurer of the United States, died on Jan. 25 at her home in Kentfield, Calif., near San Francisco. She was 85.

title: What's That You Say Now, Mrs. Robinson?
description: IT WAS 30 YEARS AGO NEXT DECEMBER that the world first chortled at the scene in ''The Graduate'' in which a smug Los Angeles businessman takes aside the baby-faced Dustin Hoffman and declares, ''I just want to say one word to you -- just one word -- 'plastics.' ''

title: Clinton Has a Chance to Shape the Courts
description: With nearly 100 judicial vacancies to fill as he begins his second term and the likelihood of many more to come, President Clinton has a remarkable opportunity to influence the Federal courts well into the next century.

title: Bus Terminal Will Show How Big A Sign Can Get
description: For years, the Port Authority Bus Terminal, with its 27 giant X-shaped trusses, has looked to some observers incomplete, like a distracted child's not-quite-finished erector set. Now the authority plans a striking addition: a huge, bold billboard that will stretch across the the terminal from 40th to 42d Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZTOL, KAREL (WIL LIAMS)
description: SCHWARTZTOL - Karel (Wil liams), age 52, of Thousand Oaks, CA, on Tuesday, Jan. 28, 1997 at her residence following a brief illness. Loving wife of Bob Williams. Cherished daughter of Sunny and the late Ben Schwartztol. Adored mother of Dr. Steven Ainbinder. Caring sister of Robert and Holly. Beloved aunt of Jill, Larry and Andrew. Funeral services were held Jan. 30 in CA. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. For information, Conejo Mountain Memorial Park, 2052 Howard Rd., Camarillo, CA 93012.

title: Show Features Artwork Formed From Cuttings and Branches
description: ENTERING the exhibition area at the Esther Raushenbush Library at Sarah Lawrence College here is like walking onto a stage set for ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title: 2,500 Champions Will Be Chasing Ribbons at the Garden
description: The Hound of the Baskervilles need not apply, but 379 other highbrow hounds did and are among 2,500 canines, all of them champions, who qualified to perform at the 121st annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Tuesday. This year the renowned competition, which bestows honors equivalent to the movie industry's Oscars, filled its capacity quota in record time -- less than an hour.

title: Fugue State
description: MEMORY SLIPS A Memoir of Music and Healing. By Linda Katherine Cutting. 240 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $24.

title: The Mission
description: Horton Foote wrote the teleplay for OLD MAN, an adaptation of William Faulkner's short story set on the Mississippi -- SUNDAY at 9 P.M. on CBS. The cantankerous river provides a massive stage for the drama. Arliss Howard (above) plays a convict, recruited to save stranded victims of the great flood of 1927, who finds a heavily pregnant woman snagged in a tree (Jeanne Tripplehorn). Getting her down is the simplest of his tasks. The swollen river is rife with dangers and the baby comes early. But the relationship that develops between the man and woman as they journey to solid ground is the heart of the story. -- Caitlin Lovinger

title: Under the Sway Of Public Taste
description: To the Editor:

title: Sipping Starbucks, Measuring 'Progress'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambitious Menu in Croton-on-Hudson
description: APPROPRIATELY named, La Finestra has the advantage of two outside walls paved with large expanses of glass. Pretty lace panels cover the windows giving dining areas a sense of intimacy and neatly masking the view of the Shop Rite shopping center as well.

title: Sounding Off In Favor of H.O.V. Lanes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BOOR WAR
description: Instead of the word ''crank,'' I would have preferred ''mindful urbanite'' or ''caretaker.'' A caretaker is thoughtful and considerate. By definition a crank is ill tempered, grouchy and eccentric. We need more caretakers in this world.

title: A Substance Hazardous to Women
description: STRAIGHT MAN

title: Government as Curator
description: The Montclair Art Museum is showing the life's work of a local artist: 30 years of Janet Taylor Pickett's paintings and sculptures. Naturally, the artist was delighted when she learned her show would move to New Jersey State Museum in Trenton this summer. ''It's the biggest exhibition of my career,'' said Ms. Pickett, who has taught art at Essex County College for 25 years.

title: Medicare Cuts Would Reduce At-Home Care for Patients
description: Medicare spending on home health agencies and nursing homes has skyrocketed in the last five years, and Congress and the Clinton Administration have decided that they must control those costs as part of any plan to balance the Federal budget.

title: An Invitation to Step Into a Formidable Future
description: WELCOME TO DANCE IN the new millennium. The past and present of the art will be preserved, together with expert commentary and thought-provoking educational material, on slender disks whose treasures can be revealed with just a flick or two of a mouse. Nothing new will be lost. The remaining traces of an ephemeral history will be recovered. Dance, on state-of-the-art tapes, will be shown nightly on national television or rented from the video shop down the block. As a result, large audiences will flock to theaters to see the real thing, live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHBURN, MARY BRENNAN
description: WASHBURN-Mary Brennan, 82 on Feb. 3. Clever. Humorous. People, politics and book lover. Glamorous always. Fashion copywriter, League of Women Voters leader, national Head Start Public Affairs Director, award-winning writer, documentary producer. Loved and missed by sons Michael and Daniel, granddaughters Mara and Kate, daughters-in-law Nancy, Mary K. and Linda. Donations to Women's Interart Center, 549 W. 52nd Street, NYC 10019.

title: No Headline
description: ''If we don't teach children about the market economy from an early age they will end up like us. The older generation knew nothing about economics. We never gave it a thought. As a result, we are like blind kittens bumping into walls, looking for a way out.''

title: To Make a Buck, Some Monkeying at the Zoo
description: Fierce Creatures

title: Snap, Snap, Snap
description: IT was growing dark in Monemvasia, the ethereal Byzantine city built on a Gibraltar-like rock off the Peloponnesian peninsula in Greece. For hours, my husband, Duke, and I had clambered along the castellated stone walls; him taking pictures of crumbling medieval structures; me trying not to focus on the sheer drop to the sea. Suddenly Duke, who was 10 feet behind me, cried out in alarm.

title: Joseph Noshpitz, 74, Expert In Children's Behavior, Dies
description: Joseph D. Noshpitz, a child psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who explored broad influences on behavior in his clinical work, teaching and writings, died on Jan. 28 at his home in Washington. He was 74.

title: Swiss Role in War Isn't Black and White
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting a Radiator to Maximum Use
description: A RADIATOR is a device used to disperse the heat generated in the furnace to other parts of the house. The heat may be transmitted from the furnace to the radiator with either steam or hot water. Most radiators use a combination of convection and radiation to heat their surroundings.

title: Green Takes Head Start On '98 Senate Campaign
description: New York City's Public Advocate, Mark Green, has embarked on an early and aggressive effort to clear the field of other Democratic challengers to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in 1998. He has announced a list of 130 people who support his candidacy and has begun a national search for campaign funds.

title: A Little-Known Break For Mom-and-Pop Shops
description: A FEDERAL law passed last summer allows the self-employed to deduct almost half of the cost of their health care coverage. But a little-known part of the tax code might offer a better deal: it allows a 100 percent deduction and even lets companies write off other medical expenses.

title: The Real 'Star Wars'
description: At a packed movie theater the other day, a parental ritual was under way next to a big poster in the lobby. Pointing with enthusiasm to scenes from the picture, a dad said to his son: ''Here are the Imperial walkers . . . and over here is the Millennium Falcon.'' The boy nodded, finding a common bond with his father in the way kids have done for years when they went with parents to their first ball game or maybe first ''Nutcracker'' ballet. ''Star Wars'' has been endlessly described as a triumphal marriage of movie-making and merchandising, but this particular re-issue is most of all a tour de force of cross-generational sharing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, SAMUEL TAYLOR, JR.
description: MOORE-Samuel Taylor, Jr., age 75, of Southport, CT. Husband of Mary Kennedy Moore, died on Friday, February 7, 1997. Memorial services will be held on Saturday, February 15, 1997, at 12:00 Noon in Trinity Episcopal Church, Pequot Ave., Southport, CT.

title: Black, Yet White: A Hated Color in Zimbabwe
description: John M. Makumbe is a professor of political science. Richard Nyathi is chief librarian for a Government ministry. Stanley S. Gunda is a senior financial officer in another ministry. Not so long ago, they might have been killed at birth.

title: Interview with a Vampirette
description: On Valentine's Day, most lovers share nothing stronger than heart-shaped mints and Champagne. Within the so-called Gothic Death Rock scene, a fringe group known as ''practicing vampires'' express their love by drinking each other's blood. Dwelling in the urban U.S., numbering in the hundreds, these vampires often communicate in underground magazines like Blue Blood, published in Atlanta. Some believe that blood-drinking insures immortality, but most admit - wistfully - that vampirism is more of a life style. What's involved? From her velvet-draped apartment in San Francisco, Danielle Willis, a pale, attractive 30-year-old, shared the details.

title: Love Without Reservations
description: I HAD no one to blame but myself. And St. Valentine, at least if he had anything to do with creating the day that bears his name. Who ever heard of such a forced concept as being mandated to show love for someone? But my wife, Lori, wanted to do something special last Valentine's Day.

title: New Split on Columbus, Over BID Plan
description: In the last 10 years, as Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue have enjoyed an economic revival of sorts, Columbus Avenue has lagged behind.

title: Tax Checkoffs: More Choice, Less Share
description: In 1982, the state began allowing income tax payers to check off a box on their returns dedicating $5, $10 or more of their 1981 refund check to the New Jersey Endangered and Non-Game Species Program.

title: Prize Time Among Plants Large and Small
description: ''AND the winners are . . .'' This is the cry every year as garden-worthy plants are picked out and presented with honors by top-of-the-line organizations and their resident experts for special consideration in settings large and small.

title: Hiding Behind the Flag
description: JASPER JOHNS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOND, LEO
description: BLOND-Leo. 81, died of cancer on February 5, 1997. Devoted husband of Bessie, loving father of Joseph and Rima, son-inlaw Steven and grandson David. Thirty years with the NYC school system, teacher Jr. H.S. 35, PS 144, and H.S. of Performing Arts, Assistant Principal at Jr. H.S. 232, Examiner with Board of Examiners, Organizer with Teachers Guild. Twenty years Waterfront Director, Camp Monroe, writer for many educational periodicals and varied magazines, and had many letters published in the NY Times. Graduate NYU Evening College and graduate schools Columbia & Teachers College. NYC fireman for 6 years with Hook & Ladder Company #

title: Lover Come Back
description: Good news from Verona! We all thought the love between Romeo and Juliet ended tragically, but in fact, the poison wasn't real. Their dagger scars have vanished -- Juliet covered hers with a tattoo of the sun, while Romeo had extensive plastic surgery. Their marriage has survived not only eternity but Hollywood as well. And now, after turning down Oprah, they've consented to an exclusive Valentine's Day Interview.

title: Albright Discovery May Show Jews' Assimilation, Not Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Diane Ackerman
description: Diane Ackerman's new book, ''A Slender Thread,'' is a nonfiction account of her experiences taking calls at a suicide- and crisis-prevention center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LUCE, HOLLINSHEAD
description: de LUCE-Hollinshead, 84, formerly of Oyster Bay Cove, New York, on Feb 2. He loved the sea and the vessels which plied it, blending a 35 year career as a naval architect and shipbuilding executive for Bethlehem Steel Corporation with a lifetime avocation as a small boat designer, builder, and sailor. Graduated Webb Institute of Naval Architecture in 1943, active in the affairs of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, served on committees of the American Bureau of Shipping, the US Coast Guard, and the National Research Council. Survived by his loving wife of sixty years, the former Martha Thacher Hudson of Brooklyn, New York; son John of Milltown, NJ; daughter Judith of Cincinnati, OH; and granddaughter Lena, of Milltown. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to Mystic Seaport, Development Dept, 75 Greenmanville Avenue, Mystic, CT. 06355.

title: The 'Wise Apes' and Their Friends
description: IF someone wants to be treated well, he may try to appeal to ''fellow feeling,'' as Shakespeare's Shylock did. ''Hath not a Jew eyes? If you prick us, do we not bleed?'' Can't you see, in other words, that we're all alike? It's a strategy that animal rights advocates understand well. Their statements and brochures are full of references to devoted mothers and playful youngsters, not only because mothers have evolved to be devoted and young animals have evolved to be playful, but because such traits ring a bell with human observers.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Some Surprises After Some Letdowns
description: I DREADED returning to 68 West Main in Oyster Bay after a disastrous first visit. A tablemate that night called the experience the worst of all worlds. ''I had a terrible meal'' he said, ''but still put on two pounds.''

title: Sarah Bradbury, Keith Robbins
description: Sarah Riddle Bradbury, the daughter of Mrs. Morgan Scott Brown of Louisville, Ky., and John Randolph Bradbury of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Keith Wyatt Robbins, the son of Mrs. John Ernst of Lancaster, Pa., and Dr. Timothy Wyatt Robbins of Downingtown, Pa. The Rev. Robert Tallmadge Jennings performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Francis in the Fields in Harrods Creek, Ky.

title: This Impudent Ex-Cheerleader Has Something Different to Sing
description: PERHAPS THE WORST THAT can be said about contemporary country music is that so much of it seems ill-fitted to so many times of day. Country is great for running errands at lunch time, for doing lawn work on weekend afternoons, for a kick-up-the-heels Saturday night. But what music coming out of Nashville these days seems suitable for early mornings with a cup of expectations, for twilight on a doubtful summer evening, for that midnight hour between disappointment and dreams?

title: New Sketch Out Of Rape Suspect
description: The police issued a new sketch last week of a man they suspect of raping three women and robbing four others on the Upper East Side since August. Officers will report on the investigation in a public meeting at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday at the Robert F. Wagner Middle School, 220 East 76th Street.

title: Bloomin' Love
description: The Society for American Florists estimates that nearly 95 million roses will be sold nationwide on Friday, Valentine's Day, with red roses, symbolizing love, the most popular. These are places and prices for a dozen long-stemmed red roses around the city this week:

title: Q. & A.
description: Religious Symbols In a Lobby

title: Dining Russian Style, The Good and the Bad
description: SPASIBO, thank you in Russian, is the name of a new restaurant in Woodmere that indeed deserves a spasibo for food, but a no spasibo for service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLINS, LESTER
description: WOLINS-Lester. We will always remember the fun and the good old times we shared. You will be missed. Lorraine and Shirley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, NAOMI
description: REISS-Naomi. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire bereaved family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus David Werber, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLINS, LESTER B.
description: WOLINS-Lester B. Passed away February 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Lorraine. Loving father of Susan and Ellen. Adored grandfather of Michelle and Robyn. Graveside services on Tuesday 11 A.M., at The New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: In Russia, Teaching Tiny Capitalists to Compete
description: In Nadezhda Shilyayeva's first-grade class, the words of the day are ''profit'' and ''inventory.'' As the kindly teacher bounces her pointer along the curly blackboard script, her 26 students at School 139 sing the syllables in unison.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REITMAN, EDWARD
description: REITMAN-Edward. February 9, 1988. In loving memory. Rest in peace always. Your Family

title: For 'Today,' New Chemistry as Lauer, With His Easy Style, Steps Into a Coveted Spot
description: MATT LAUER likes to say that he is ''cocktail party smart -- you take me to a cocktail party, and you've got doctors, lawyers, plumbers, insurance salesmen there, I can go around the room and have an intelligent conversation with those people for a certain amount of time.''

title: In Ballet Troupe's Absence at a Benefit, Arthur Mitchell and Students Step In
description: THE hall was sold out 10 days before the concert, a good sign for the 15 nonprofit groups set to benefit from Music America, the yearly cultural event dedicated to the life and work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, MILTON
description: BRODSKY-Milton. Precious memoriesnow and forever. Love, Grace and Ruth

title: THE CLINTON PRINCIPLE
description: Garry Wills paints a sympathetic portrait of Bill Clinton and reveals that, after all, he does believe in government. Fine. But we ought to learn these lessons from his first term.

title: Taking Pride In Farmland Law
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAVE OZZIE AND HARRIET ALONE
description: Gregory Curtis's article ''Leave Ozzie and Harriet Alone'' (Jan. 19) had a special effect on me, a newly engaged 31-year-old, trying to spin-doctor the negative jumble of stories and statistics about marriage and family -- and find reason to be optimistic about the life my fiance and I will have together. Thanks to his article, I see that the likelihood is that we will be more like Ozzie and Harriet than I would have guessed. Our life will be, for the most part, ''a quiet, gentle comedy'' of small decisions, errands, chores and not terribly meaningful conversations. I'll take it.

title: Newcomers Crash the All-Star Party
description: Not long ago, Christian Laettner had a petulant reputation. He was called spoiled. He was called a crybaby. And those were the nicer things some people said.

title: Bubba Don't Preach
description: Forgive me, Mr. President, for I have sinned.

title: For One-Line Ideas, Disney Is All Ears
description: In 1988, the Walt Disney Company asked John Gregory Dunne and his wife, Joan Didion, to write a screenplay about Jessica Savitch, the network anchorwoman who died in 1983.

title: Overseas Index Funds Miss the Boat With U.S. Investors
description: INDEX investing has gone from a borderline strategy to big stuff. The style, which involves mimicking a benchmark index like the Standard & Poor's 500, now governs about 120 mutual funds, up from a mere 20 in 1990. The assets of the most widely held of those funds have grown more than a hundredfold in the last decade, to $65 billion. And even Fidelity, the fund family known for entrepreneurial stock picking, will soon expand its index fund offerings.

title: THE BOOR WAR
description: I have read many strange articles over the years, but few as strange or even irresponsible as John Tierney's ''The Boor War,'' urging people to become urban cranks (The Big City, Jan. 5). Did it occur to him that someone could be hurt or even killed as a result of what he advocates?

title: What About Bob?
description: Poor Bob Guccione. On Jan. 22, the publisher of Penthouse magazine scored a major First Amendment victory in Federal court, but all anybody wanted to talk about (still) was the free-speech crusade immortalized in ''The People vs. Larry Flynt.'' Pretty galling, considering that Guccione believes Flynt has tried to have him killed. ''There were three contracts out on my life that I know of,'' he claims, based largely on unverified tales from Flynt's former brother-in-law. ''He is a sick, demented character. He is no hero.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBAUM, JONAY, ADRIENNE
description: ROSENBAUM - JONAY - Adrienne. Happy Birthday, darling. Every moment in our hearts. We miss and love you more each day. All our love, Mom, Dad and Janie

title: Surfing for Spring Break
description: AS spring break approaches, Cancun, Mazatlan and Acapulco, Mexico, lure college students with their siren songs, along with the Florida beach-and-beer capitals: Daytona and Panama City, and South Padre Island, Tex. The Bahamas and Jamaica glimmer in the sun. The season runs from the end of this month into April, peaking at Easter week, March 21 to 29. Cheap package trips abound, but come with some caveats for students -- and their parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, JACK
description: STEIN-Jack. Beloved husband of Rosalie. Devoted father of Barbara Stein and Arthur Ted Stein. Loving grandfather of Scott and Cara. Services Sunday 12:15PM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Quitting A New Job? You May Pay The Movers
description: KARA KAUFMAN, 23, has worked for two companies during the last year, and although her first employer paid thousands of dollars to move her from Atlanta to New York, she was off to Seattle within two months to take another job. Ms. Kaufman said that when she told her boss at employer No. 1, the Cable News Network, that she was leaving, he asked her to pay back her moving costs.

title: Gay Isn't a Synonym For Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bistro Style for Downtown New Haven
description: THE locale of Barkies Grill and Rotisserie in downtown New Haven is a familiar one, having been home for years to Bruxelles, a congenial brasserie diagonally across from the Shubert Performing Arts Center.

title: Wringing Laughs From the Real World
description: WHEN ''Space Jam'' hit the screens, offering a cartoon parade of Warner Brothers characters, the sharp-eyed reporters at ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central saw something horribly wrong. Speedy Gonzalez, the litte Mexican mouse with the big sombrero, barely made it on screen. Was this mere happenstance, they wondered, or were sinister forces at work?

title: To Propose Or Dispose?
description: Momentous and romantic, Feb. 14 is a big day for marriage proposals. But it's also big for breaking up. And some just find it all depressing. The two faces of Valentine's Day, in Styles, page 49.

title: OFFICIALS SAY MOB IS SHIFTING CRIMES TO NEW INDUSTRIES
description: With their longtime control of extortion and bid-rigging rackets in New York City and New Jersey weakened by years of relentless prosecutions and by regulatory crackdowns, the region's Mafia crime families are switching increasingly to white-collar crimes as ripe sources of plunder, law enforcement officials say.

title: Making a Reasoned Case Against Big Government
description: WHAT IT MEANS TO BE A LIBERTARIAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEWITT, FLORENCE
description: HEWITT-Florence. The heart of our family passed away on Friday. She is dearly beloved by her husband Bernard; her children Michael and wife Gloria, Peter and wife Barbara, and Wendy and her husband Barry; her ten grandchildren, Jamie, Jon, Adam and wife Barbara, Jonathan, Peter and his wife Lila, Kelly, Christopher, Cory, Gloria, Mike; her brother Stanley and his wife Doris; and two adored great-grandchildren, Luke and Ishaan. She will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Wounded Man Dies After Almost 2 Days in a Police Holding Cell
description: A 27-year-old man who had spent nearly two days in police custody after being treated for a stab wound to the chest died early yesterday after attacking several police officers in a Brooklyn holding cell, the police said.

title: Italian Isle a Stepping Stone for Illegal Immigrants
description: In recent years, this lonely patch of Italy, a windswept island that lies closer to Africa than to Europe, has seen thousands of illegal immigrants arrive on its shores.

title: This Year, No Argument About the M.V.P. Choice
description: It was the most polite of controversies, without an ounce of the bitterness that has been exhibited over past voting for the All-Star Game's most valuable player award.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, which marks the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: John Perry Miller, 85, Professor And Yale Graduate School Dean
description: Dr. John Perry Miller, an economics professor for more than 40 years at Yale University who was the dean of the university's graduate school in the 1960's, died yesterday morning at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 85.

title: New in Cambodia: Justice Without Torture
description: When he was a police officer here in Kandal Province, criminal investigations were straightforward. ''We beat the suspects,'' Ouk Vandath said.

title: No to Expansion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, HELEN GEWERTZ
description: JOFFE-Helen Gewertz, age 66, on Friday, February 7 of Paramus, NJ. title: Setting Ethics for Prosecutors
description: The case of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the late Somerset County Prosecutor who was convicted last year of tax fraud, embezzling and abuse of power, has prompted calls for a statewide code of ethics for prosecutors. Today, the State Senate's Judiciary Committee will consider a bill that would bar prosecutors from accepting gifts or having business interests that could conflict with their duties.

title: Long Journey to Oblivion For the O'Neills' Cottage
description: Eugene O'Neill's autobiographical masterpiece, ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' has endured as one of the American theater's most powerful dramas, but the house that served as its setting stands on less solid ground.

description: Stephen Malkmus undercounts when he sings ''I'm of several minds'' in a song on Pavement's new album, ''Brighten the Corners'' (Matador).

title: Wall Street Journal on Line: Readers Pay but Profits Remain Elusive
description: From the moment that newspapers moved onto the Internet, some media futurists have been predicting that Americans will some day read their daily papers the way John P. Trebnik reads The Wall Street Journal: He points his Web browser at http://wsj.com, scans the articles he is interested in, downloads a few to be read or printed later, and logs off.

description: It was the same kind of tiered stage used for award ceremonies at the Olympics. Gold, silver and bronze medals were standard here too. Even the triumphal music was similar.

title: Success Story Under Wraps: Welfare Study
description: POLITICIANS often complain that the public hears about government only when it messes up. So it is striking -- and intriguing -- to come across a story of government success that a politician, in this case, Gov. George E. Pataki, has been keeping under wraps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, JOSEPH I.
description: CAREY-Joseph I. Of Sleightsburg, NY. A retired civil engineer for the NYC Water System at Ashokan Reservoir. Died Thursday, February 6, at Kingston, NY. Born in Brooklyn, February 1, 1920. Son of the late Joseph and Kathleen Tully Carey. He was a WW II Marine Corps veteran having served as a second lieutenant in the South Pacific. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Prep, St. John's and Cornell Universities. Survivors are his wife Juletta Egan Carey; four daughters, Kathleen Mihm, Julie Carey, Mary Lieb and Elizabeth Brown; five sons, Joseph, Dr. John, James, Frank and Robert Carey; one brother, Gerard Carey. Funeral was held today from the Gilpatric-Murphy Funeral Home, 176 Braodway, Kingston, NY 12401.

title: Giuliani Defends Adviser Role of 2 Lawyers Who Represent Lobbying Clients
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his relationship with Raymond B. Harding and Herman Badillo -- two lawyers who serve as unpaid, informal advisers to him while representing clients lobbying his administration -- was beyond legal or ethical reproach.

title: Tomba Has a Hard Act To Follow: Compagnoni
description: The ski resort of Sestriere was built by the Agnelli family and is still controlled by them. And when the Agnellis paid Alberto Tomba handsomely to postpone his retirement, he was supposed to be the centerpiece of these world championships.

title: INSIDE
description: Testing Students for Alcohol

title: A Show Dog's Day
description: The Afghan Ch. Tryst of Grandeur has won 133 bests-in-show, the only hound to win more than 100 times. Tomorrow, after nearly 500 shows, Tryst will compete in her last event, the Westminister Dog Show in Madison Square Garden, before being bred to the Afghan Ch. Tried and True of Grandeur. Michael Canalizo, her handler, is praying for a good hair day. ''Afghan hair is the cloesest to human hair,'' he said. ''In high humidity, it frizzes. Dry heat causes static electricity.'' Insuring a good hair day takes about four hours of shampooing and styling each week, with two ''comb outs'' on show days.

title: Clinton Plan Could Push Tuition Up
description: President Clinton's goal in the budget he proposed last week for higher education is to make college more affordable.

title: A Wider Public for Noncommercial Radio
description: For the first time, public radio stations are being asked to demonstrate their relevance to their own communities or risk having their Federal funds cut off. The demand for accountability is forcing a new discipline on smaller broadcasters, who are struggling to broaden their appeal without crossing the line into commercial radio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, MARY E.

title: Data Service's Users Not Told Of Other Lines
description: While thousands of frustrated America Online subscribers tried in vain to dial into the service through its clogged electronic doorways during the last few weeks, the company made little or no effort to let people know that they could use older entryways where the crowds were smaller.

title: PRIVATE VENTURES HOPE FOR PROFITS ON SPY SATELLITES
description: Commercial spy satellites are about to let anyone with a credit card peer down from the heavens into the compounds of dictators or the backyards of neighbors with high fences.

title: Military Air Controller Is Criticized in Close Encounter
description: Civilian investigators said today that they believed that a military air traffic controller had failed to provide enough information about the identity, route and location of two civilian aircraft to the pilots of two F-16's, setting the stage for an encounter on Wednesday in which one or both fighter planes flew too close to a passenger airliner.

title: The puzzle of making the Internet into a competitive broadcast medium.
description: WITH on-line and interactive media businesses across the country scrabbling to stay in business, the bells and whistles of multimedia on the Internet may well be covering the groans of those who have discovered the realities of digital commerce.

title: Peaches Prospered in 1996
description: Last year's record-setting rains proved a boon for peaches but a bane for corn, according to the State Agriculture Department's year-end statistics, released last week. New Jersey farmers grew 78 million pounds of peaches in 1996, up from 70 million in hot, dry 1995. But the sodden spring delayed the planting of sweet corn and reduced yields to 6,000 pounds per acre, from 8,000 the year before.

title: Rice Stages His Own Shootout in East's Victory
description: His motto is: ''When in doubt, shoot. And if you're off, shoot again.'' So Glen Rice shot. And shot. And shot. And when the third quarter was complete, the world of hoist-and-hope basketball had a bold new champion.

title: Storm Song Opens '97 With Loss In Florida
description: A champion bit the dust for the second day in a row at Gulfstream Park today. On Saturday, it was Skip Away, the top 3-year-old colt in America last year, finishing second in the Donn Handicap in his first start of 1997. And today, it was Storm Song, the champion 2-year-old filly of last season, running fifth in a field of six in her debut while Glitter Woman took the Davona Dale Stakes.

title: Intrinsic Avant-Gardist Has Crush on Tinker Bell
description: For more than 25 years, Lee Breuer has been a renegade in the experimental theater, a playwright and director who has repeatedly collided with convention. Among his many radical ventures are the Dadaesque ''Shaggy Dog Animation,'' ''The Saint and the Football Players'' (a sports-art spectacle for forklift trucks and marching band) and his feminized, Americanized ''King Lear.'' In a switch -- more an about-face than a change of pace -- his newest work is a musical puppet version of ''Peter Pan'' called ''Peter and Wendy.''

title: The Right Choice for the C.I.A.
description: The Justice Department concluded on Friday that Anthony Lake, President Clinton's choice for Director of Central Intelligence, committed no criminal wrongdoing relating to his role in the tacit United States approval of Iranian arms shipments to Bosnian Muslims in 1994.

title: Shippers Expanding Into Cyberspace
description: ''Point, click, ship.'' That mantra from a Federal Express Corporation advertising campaign sums up the ambitions the overnight shipping industry has for computer technology. Express companies compete with each other and the United States Postal Service not only on speed, price and reliability, but also on convenience and ease of use, and that is where computers come in.

title: Bridge

One is awarded to the Grand National Team Champions, and the second, which he presented himself, goes to the winners of the New England Knockout Teams, which will be played this week in Cromwell, Conn., as part of a regional championship. It will be the 50th contest for the trophy, which he won himself in 1951.

title: Treasury Sets Debt Refunding For This Week
description: The Treasury undertakes its quarterly refunding this week with auctions of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. The schedule of financing also includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.
