title: Marshall Plan Model
description: To the Editor

title: How California Betrayed Its Schools
description: Through most of this century, California served as a symbol of boundless promise and possibility. At the close of the 1960's, a breathless Time magazine described it as ''El Dorado'' and a ''mirror of America as it will become.'' The promise turned dismal with the tax revolt of the 70's. It fractured the civic structure and savaged support for California's universities, libraries, children's programs and, most tragically, its public schools.

title: Intelligent Software Finding Niche
description: Once the territory of large corporations, research laboratories and the military, advanced artificial intelligence research is now increasingly driven by the consumer electronics and entertainment industries.

title: George W. DeFranceaux, 83; Encouraged Investment in Housing

title: 3 Shepard One-Acters, An Illuminating Mixture

title: Dorothy Fosdick, 83, Adviser On International Policy, Dies
description: Dorothy Fosdick, the foreign policy expert who helped fashion the United Nations, the Marshall Plan and NATO in the 1940's, advised Adlai E. Stevenson in the 1952 Presidential campaign and then spent nearly three decades as Senator Henry M. Jackson's chief cold war strategist, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Washington. She was 83 and had continued to live in Washington after Senator Jackson's death in 1983.

title: For Fat Tuesday, a High-Calorie Treat
description: Ask most Americans what they associate with the Fat Tuesday celebrations before Lent and they are likely to mention the Mardi Gras parades of New Orleans, and maybe the Deep South tradition of exchanging king cakes, foot-wide loops of pastry covered with brightly colored icing.

title: One Deadly Triangle Too Many
description: A Texas court has upheld NBC's right to broadcast a movie tonight about the murder of a 16-year-old girl, even though the two teen-agers the film portrays as committing the crime have yet to be tried. But the television station in the area where the trial will be held has decided on its own not to air the film. Both decisions were correct. The network has a constitutional right to show ''Love's Deadly Triangle: The Texas Cadet Murder,'' but that does not necessarily mean it is a good idea.

title: Companies and Worker Groups Help the Neediest
description: When Thomas Mulkeen won a raffle at work, his prize was a $250 donation to the charity of his choice. He chose The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, adding his company to scores of others whose employees and managers pitch in each year to help the city's poor.

title: ECUADOR'S CRISIS OVER PRESIDENCY ENDS PEACEFULLY
description: The extraordinary flurry of claims to the presidency of this small Andean nation came to a peaceful, equally extraordinary solution today, as an agreement was reached for the Vice President to serve as Interim President.

description: John F. Kennedy Jr. has heard it all by now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, JOHN R.
description: BURKE-John R., 87, of Bronxville, NY, formerly of East Syracuse, died Saturday in St. Joseph's Hospital after a long illness. He graduated from Christian Brothers Academy. He lived in Bronxville, NY, for the past 50 years. He retired from Saks Fifth Avenue and Bonwit Teller. He was an Army veteran of World War II. Surviving are two brothers, Paul C. of Illinois and Robert E. of Rochester, NY; one sister, Anne Burke Tucker of East Syracuse; and several nieces and nephews. Services are private. There are no calling hours. Burial will be in St. Mary's Cemetery, DeWitt, NY. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: An undergarment maker hopes the Marilyn Monroe image has not lost its sizzle.
description: MARILYN MONROE once said she did not have anything on but the radio, but to judge from the latest Warnaco ads, the Hollywood sex symbol never looked more glamorous than when she donned her undergarments.

title: What Do Women Want? Movies
description: After years of making action and adventure films for boys of all ages, studio executives are concluding that a new audience has emerged that is changing all the rules.

title: Water Main Bursts Open, Soaking Block In Brooklyn
description: In the latest reminder of New York City's hoary infrastructure and the havoc it can wreak, a water main dating from 1858 betrayed its age early yesterday morning, bursting open under Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, dumping eight feet of water into basements along one block and threatening major delays this morning for many commuters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is something to be said for sticking with a show over the long haul: an actor can move from the role of son to father, as did MARK NASSAR, one of the creators of ''Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding.''

title: Ex-Senator in Halfway House
description: David J. Friedland, the former State Senator and convicted racketeer who faked his death in a scuba diving accident to avoid prison in 1985 and was a fugitive for two years, is out of jail, but not yet home free. Mr. Friedland, 57, was released from Federal prison in Coleman, Fla., last month after an eight-year sentence and now lives in a halfway house in a Salvation Army shelter in West Palm Beach. He is to be released in July.

title: Young Inventor Is Honored
description: Ten years ago, while working part time at an industrial design firm, an engineering student named Martin Pettesch heard about a troubling problem. Workers delivering gasoline to service stations sometimes mistakenly pumped the gas into ground-water monitoring wells, contaminating ground water, because both the wells and underground gasoline tanks were capped with round covers. Mr. Pettesch's solution, now in use at thousands of service stations: triangular well covers.

title: Standard Schnauzer Is Looking Good
description: There are grave responsibilities that come with being sent to the head of the pack. Being the top-ranked dog in the nation isn't all gravy, not with the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, dogdom's ultimate proving ground, looming on the calendar today and tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORON, SIDNEY G.
description: CORON-Sidney G. On February 8, 1997. Beloved husband of Anita. Devoted father of Merrie, David and Mark, and daughters-in-law Nancy and Chris. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Erica, Shaun, Amanda, Andrea, Jason and Amy. Much loved uncle of Carole, Elliot, Roberta, Melissa, Harris and Jonathan. Brother of Ira. Proudly served in World War II, retired Colonel in U.S. Army Reserve. Services at noon, Tuesday, February 11, Gutterman Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Brooklyn-Queens Linkup Is Achieved in New Water Tunnel
description: In a subterranean chamber more like a movie set than like the site of the most expensive capital project ever undertaken by New York City, engineers announced yesterday that they had connected the Brooklyn section of the city's long-awaited Third Water Tunnel to a section in Queens.

title: Wicked, Yes, but Not Mean-Spirited
description: Chris Rock is probably the funniest and smartest comedian working today. But his act, like that of most great comics, can be analyzed to death without ever capturing the spark of insight and imagination that makes it howlingly funny. The best proof of his wit is watching his recent HBO special, ''Bring the Pain,'' a stand-up act that displays his humor at its height. He brings a raw but sophisticated satirical spin to every major division in America -- race, sex and class -- and manages to be irreverent without being mean-spirited.

title: 2 G.O.P. Senators Call for Suspension of the Army's Top Enlisted Soldier
description: Two Republican Senators said today that the Army should suspend its top-ranking enlisted soldier until accusations of sexual assault and harassment against him were resolved.

title: Queen of Soothsayers: His Highness, Kleo Patra
description: Kleo Patra, the Balkan Prophet, addressed by followers as Her Highness, Her Excellency, Her Holiness, swept into the television studio wearing a fake leopard-skin cape, tossed it aside and called on a makeup artist to begin work as he sat in a self-styled throne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORSTMANN, WILLIAM J.
description: HORSTMANN-William J. on February 8, 1997 of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Marjorie (nee Renken), devoted father of Barbara Lauro, William, Jr., Jane Mangione, and the late Ann Marie Emslie. Dear brother of Joan Lander. Also survived by 11 loving grandchildren. Reposing at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Ave. at 215 St., Bayside today, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service Tuesday, 10:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, ROSE.
description: HIRSCHHORN-Rose. Darling, one year ago you left and the feeling of deprivation grows more intense. I am bereft and desolate. I am filled with sadness. There is no surcease from the pangs of loneliness. You were not only the love of my life, you were my steady consort in my social, cultural and professional pursuits, all the more reason for my overpowering grief! Herbert

title: A Texas Murder Case as a Teen-Age Soap Opera
description: ''Love's Deadly Triangle: The Texas Cadet Murder'' has been relentlessly promoted by NBC as ''The movie some people don't want you to see!'' This, of course, is the film about David Graham and Diane Zamora, Texas teen-agers obsessively in love who are accused of killing another teen-ager, Adrianne Jones, after she had a one-night fling with Mr. Graham.

title: Game's Final Seconds Again Betray St. John's
description: With 9.5 seconds left in overtime yesterday, Zendon Hamilton touched down after dunking to give St. John's a 1-point lead over Boston College. The end of the Red Storm's five-game losing streak was in sight.

title: Jesse Helms Mocks the Senate
description: Trent Lott and his fellow Republicans may feel a need to humor Jesse Helms in his erratic management of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, but they only embarrass themselves and the Senate by letting Mr. Helms hijack a treaty that would ban chemical weapons. Mr. Helms plans to set aside consideration of the treaty until he can force the State Department and the United Nations to reorganize themselves. That could take years.

title: Man Fatally Shoots His Father and Himself
description: A man fatally shot his 75-year-old father and then himself in an apartment on the Upper West Side yesterday, following a four-hour standoff with the police, including dozens of hostage negotiators, officials said.

title: A Few Still Wait for Felipe Lopez
description: LATE afternoon outside Madison Square Garden, on 33d Street near the corner of Eighth Avenue. Family members, as always, wait for Felipe Lopez to finish his business for the day. A shower. Interviews. The cleanup following another St. John's defeat, the sixth in succession, one more time to explain why he and his team are not what people once upon a time decided they would be.

title: Laundry: A Hanging Offense
description: Never mind the dirty laundry. Come Feb. 25, residents of Brigantine will face fines of up to $1,000 if they air their clean laundry in front of neighbors. The City Council passed an amendment last Wednesday to the property maintenance code making it illegal to hang clothes in a front yard. Councilman James Frugoli said he introduced the measure after complaints from residents of the shore town of 12,000 who ''didn't want to see people's underwear and unmentionables hanging out in the front yard.''

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: Joel Berger, a conservation biologist at the University of Nevada at Reno, had no idea his research into moose habits would get quite this, well, hairy.

title: A March Against Guns
description: Marching quietly from the post office where four people were murdered in 1995 and past the house where a woman and her three daughters were found shot dead last month, about 80 people took to the streets of Montclair yesterday to urge bans on guns, The Associated Press reported. The town of 38,000 has been shaken by the killings, said Montclair's Mayor, William N. Farlie Jr., who marched with the protesters. ''The time has come for more than words and prayers,'' he told the crowd. ''We have to act.''

title: Spike/DDB Comes Out Swinging
description: Several marketers have made changes in their accounts.

title: San Francisco Raises a Day's Worth of Toasts to Honor Herb Caen
description: Thousands of San Franciscans turned out on Friday night to bid farewell to Herb Caen, the newspaper columnist who for nearly 60 years served as their city's most tireless civic booster and its ultimate man-in-the-know.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STRAUSS, LAURI
description: STRAUSS-Lauri. Your love and laughter are always with us. Lentsch-bentsch. Mom, Dad, Julie, David Gregory, Emily

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A MAYORAL DEFENSE -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended the roles of two advisers who represent clients lobbying City Hall. B3.

title: Chewing gum makers have come up with a base material that is biodegradable and digestible.
description: IN the 1880's, chewing gum as it is essentially known today was invented, and people have been spitting it out on sidewalks and sticking it to park benches or under restaurant tables ever since. Generations of children have been warned not to swallow their gum, lest it sit undigested in their stomachs for untold years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASCELLA, RALPH A.
description: CASCELLA-Ralph A. 8/25/29-2/11/ 87. Beloved husband, father, brother-you saw and heard the thrush. Forever missed and so dearly loved. Your family

title: National Front Wins Control of a 4th City in Southern France
description: The anti-immigrant National Front party inflicted a stinging defeat on French Government and opposition parties today by winning control of the municipal council of the Marseilles suburb of Vitrolles.

title: Those Thin Displays
description: The hang-on-the-wall television, talked about for a generation, is here -- but it's not cheap. Hammacher Schlemmer, the Chicago-based catalog company, started selling QFTV's panel TV, for $25,000. Both this and its $13,999 cousin, to be shipped this month by Pixelworks of Lake Oswego, Oregon, use technology developed by Japan's Fujitsu Corporation.

title: Load in the Back
description: President Clinton's ''balanced'' budget pretense is now plain to see: delay two-thirds of any spending slowdown until after leaving office. When the time to cut comes, he'll be gone.

title: How an Agency Was Left Behind on the Road Ahead
description: It is always comforting to find a villain in a story of organizational failure and the Internal Revenue Service's computer modernization debacle presents a ready candidate: Richard M. Nixon.

title: A Lion of B Movies To Sell Company To an Independent
description: Roger Corman, the Hollywood producer known for his prolific output, has agreed to sell the Concord New Horizons Corporation, his motion picture production and distribution company, to Elliott Kastner, a veteran independent producer.

title: Omnicom Unit Cuts Ties With AT&T
description: BBDO Worldwide in New York and the AT&T Corporation have agreed to end their relationship, freeing BBDO to seek the account of an AT&T rival, the GTE Corporation.

title: In Spring, Baseball Teams Think Of Autumn
description: Albert Belle was talking about himself, but he could just as well have had most major league teams in mind. ''It's a great opportunity,'' he said, ''to start over and try to work things out.''

title: Campaign Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Villanova Grounded By Hustling Kentucky
description: Rick Pitino, the Kentucky coach, looked at the Villanova front line and thought, uh-oh!

title: Astaire-Hayworth Duet Reflected in a Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet went to the movies on Saturday night, when the featured attraction at the New York State Theater was Jerome Robbins's ''I'm Old Fashioned.'' Mr. Robbins's choreography reflects the sways, swings, glides and swoops in a duet that Rita Hayworth and Fred Astaire performed in the film ''You Were Never Lovelier.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JAMES B.
description: ANDERSON-James B. in Westport, CT, retired attorney with Whitman and Ransom, NYC. Husband of the late Jane Anderson, father of David and Michael Anderson, Lisa Moser and Susan Gaumond. Services Tuesday, Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Westport, CT.

title: Rangers Take Florida Vacation, but on the Ice
description: After his team had stretches of sloppy play against the Islanders on Saturday night, Rangers Coach Colin Campbell promised a more consistent effort against the Florida Panthers tonight.

title: To fulfill a children's educational TV quota, everything old becomes new again.
description: WHEN the Federal Communications Commission voted in August to require television stations to broadcast three hours of educational programs for children, the F.C.C. chairman, Reed E. Hundt, envisioned a new world of production, one in which ''the creative community can invent a whole new art form: the art of teaching children with television.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar Rebounds From Drop After Group of Seven Talks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IRVING R.
description: LEVINE-Irving R., age 73, on February 9, 1997. Mr. Levine was an advertising and production director for Revlon and Torlow advertising agency for the past 25 years. He was a member of the Dellwood Country Club, New City, NY for over 40 years. He is survived by two brothers, Murray and Saul, five nieces and 12 great-nieces and nephews. He was also pre-deceased by a brother, Martin and a nephew, Dr. Richard L. Levine. Services will be held today, 1:30 PM at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, NY.

title: Netanyahu and Arafat Say Peace Talks Are on Track
description: The Israeli and Palestinian leaders met today in what both described as a ''constructive'' meeting and agreed to start detailed talks next Sunday on further steps in carrying out their peace agreements.

title: H.I.V. Testing For Newborns Debated Anew
description: New York hospitals quietly began the open mandatory testing of newborns for H.I.V. this month in the first such program in the nation. And, in maternity wards and nurseries across the state, doctors, nurses and social workers continue to wrangle over the value of such testing with the undiluted passion that has inflamed the political debate for years.

title: Indoor Circuit Needs Recharge
description: Even with a full house for Friday night's Chase Millrose Games, one could not help feeling a sense of emptiness about track and field in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASTRO, ANGELINA (NEE ACCURSO)
description: NASTRO-Angelina (nee Accurso), age 82, on Feb. 8, 1997 of Plantation, FL formerly of Alpine, NJ. Beloved wife of pre-deceased Joseph (1978). Devoted mother of Pat Nastro and pre-deceased Nicoletta Iannone (1995). Loving mother-in-law of Linda Nastro and Albert Iannone. Dear sister of Nini Accurso. Loving grandmother of Emil, Joseph and Virginia. Loving great-grandmother of Nicholas and Andrew. Funeral from the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave, Cliffside Park, NJ on Wednesday, Feb. 12, 1997, thence to Madonna R.C. Church, Ft. Lee, NJ where the Funeral Mass will be offered. Entombment at Madonna Mausoleum, Ft. Lee, NJ. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, THOMAS J.
description: FLANAGAN-Thomas J. On February 10, 1997. Employed as printer for New York Times for 38 years. Devoted father of Thomas J. Flanagan Jr. and dear brother of Joseph P., Margaret Hanson and Catherine Cooney. Also survived by two grandchildren, Alyssa Marie and Daniel Thomas. Funeral Friday, 9 A.M. Mass of Christian burial at Resurrection R.C. Church, 9:30 A.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Reposing at Byrnes Funeral Home, 2384 Gerritsen Ave, Brooklyn.

title: TOY BIZ IS PLANNING TO ACQUIRE COLORFORMS
description: Toy Biz Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Colorforms Inc., a privately held toy making concern, for an undisclosed sum. Toy Biz, based in New York, makes toys based on Marvel comic book characters and other trademarks. Colorforms, based in Ramsay, N.J., makes preschool toys and games. The Andrews Group, a New York company headed by Ronald O. Perelman that owns a controlling stake in the Marvel Entertainment Group, has proposed acquiring the shares of Toy Biz that Marvel does not already own to transform Toy Biz into a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Flat Handbags (Travel Lightly)
description: The newest handbags are flat as pancakes, requiring heavy editing by the women who carry them. All those extras not essential have to be eliminated, because there is just no room in the bags. But they do look good, especially with the skinny little dresses and narrow pants suits fashionable for spring. (Reading matter and extra shoes can always go into a tote bag, can't they?)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASCELLA, RALPH A.
description: CASCELLA-Ralph A. 8/25/29-2/11/ 87. Beloved husband, father, brother-you saw and heard the thrush. Forever missed and so dearly loved. Your family

title: For France, Sagging Self-Image and Esprit
description: When Bernard Liautaud started Business Objects, a software company, he applied a simple formula that he naively thought might stir the imagination and shake the torpor of his country: dump French habits and do things the California way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, ARTHUR
description: KENT - Arthur. Our Council mourns the passing on February 9 of longtime former president of Local 11 of the National Assoc. of Broadcast Technicians and member of our executive board for many years. His involvement with the trade union movement and the broadcasting industry began with the Voice of America during WWII. He later worked on such top shows as Milton Berle's ''Texaco Star Theater,'' Sid Caesar's ''Your Show of Shows,'' and Jack Paar's ''Tonight'' show. Always organizing, promoting the teaching of labor history and the use of union professionals, he helped found the NYC Chapter of the National Academy of TV Arts & Sciences (NATAS), and was its presdient at the time of his death. He helped re-open the Astoria Sudios and establish the Museum of the Moving Image. A warm, self-effacing man, he was the consummate professional and trade unionist. We will miss his energy, dedication and commitment. Condolences are extended to his wife Jeannette and their children, Martin, Stephen and Susan. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer a donation to the Arthur Kent Scholarship Fund of the NYC Chapter NATAS (1560 Broadway, NYC 10036). NYC Central Labor Council Brian M. McLaughlin, President Ted H. Jacobsen, Secretary Margaret Samuels, Treasurer

title: Aches Remain, but Few Have Anger Left
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton found yesterday, as he spoke on talk radio, that there was more interest in his run for Mayor than in the Crown Heights verdicts. Black people in Jamaica, Queens, gave blank stares when asked about the case. Hovering helicopters and beat-up cars with undercover police officers riding around Brooklyn never went into action.

title: INSIDE
description: Subway Ridership Jumps

title: A 2d Verdict, And Thoughts Of Last Time
description: MOMENTS after the guilty verdicts were announced yesterday in Crown Heights II, an architect of the troubled first Crown Heights trial picked up the phone and asked to be put through to Janet Reno, the United States Attorney General.

title: Kirov Ballet Cancels Tour Of East Coast
description: The Kirov Ballet has canceled its three-city American tour, scheduled for the spring. The company was to have performed at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in May and at theaters in Boston and Philadelphia.

title: People
description: * Thomas L. Harrison and Michael Birkin were promoted, respectively, to president for United States operations and president for international operations at the Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom Group, New York. They assume the duties of Peter Jones, who is retiring. Mr. Harrison had been president of the Diversified Healthcare Communications Group, New York, a part of the division, and Mr. Birkin, based in London, had been managing director for the division's European operations. John Wren continues as chairman and chief executive of the division.

title: Radar Jammer Is Criticized In U.S. Study
description: A Navy electronic radar-jamming device used in Bosnia to protect Marine Corps fighter pilots from possible Serbian missile attack has been criticized for flawed performance in a new report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Clinton Aides Say That Income Gap Narrows
description: A new White House report contends that the gap between rich and poor in America appears to have stopped widening and may have reversed.

title: Cassandra Ides Jones, Bank Official and Interior Designer, 48
description: Cassandra Ides Jones, a former executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank and the owner of an interior design company, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. Mrs. Jones, who was 48, died of breast cancer, her husband, Robert Childress Jones Jr., said.

title: Political Madness in Ecuador
description: Ecuador's political crisis, which at one point last week saw three different people claiming to be president, was simplified and steered away from imminent violence by a military-engineered compromise on Sunday. One President was removed, another installed temporarily and the third left waiting to take over after a congressional vote, possibly as early as today. But along the way, democratic legitimacy was undermined, the military drawn deeper into civilian politics and the prospect of resolving Ecuador's serious economic problems indefinitely deferred.

title: Alice Yang, Curator And Historian, 35
description: Alice Huei-Zu Yang, an art historian and curator, died early Saturday morning after a hit-and-run accident at Canal and Varick Streets in Manhattan. She was 35 and lived in TriBeCa.

title: Spanish Judge Shot to Death; Police Blame Basque Rebels
description: A Spanish Supreme Court judge was shot and killed by a gunman in front of his Madrid apartment building today, and the Government blamed the Basque separatist group E.T.A.

title: Islander Coach Confronts the Past Head On
description: In many ways, Rick Bowness is a lot like his mentor, Mike Milbury -- minus most of the histrionics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, EMANUEL J.
description: EVANS-Emanuel J. The Covenant Foundation mourns the passing of Emanuel Evans, beloved father of our esteemed Board Chairman, Eli N. Evans. Emanuel Evans served as Mayor of Durham, NC from 1951-63. A near lengendary figure, he was known throughout the South for his success in bringing desegregation to Durham's schools, public accommodations, the police and fire departments and city agencies. He and his late wife, Sara, were active in the leadership of the United Jewish Appeal and Israel Bonds, they also worked to create and support the Center for Judaic Studies at Duke University. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Susan Crown, President Dr. Judith Ginsberg, Exec Director The Covenant Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERLICH, IZA M.
description: ERLICH-Iza M. The Western New England Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the death of our beloved colleague and friend, Iza M. Erlich, who died February 9, 1997. Memorial contributions may be made to The Western New England Institute for Psychoanalysis, 255 Bradley Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06510. Sidney H. Phillips, M.D. President WNEPS Stephen R. Atkins, M.D. President WNEIP

title: Westinghouse To Buy Units From Gaylord For $1.5 Billion
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Nashville Network and Country Music Television's United States and Canadian operations, both of which are owned by the Gaylord Entertainment Company, for $1.55 billion in Westinghouse stock.

title: Tagliabue Does the Right Thing
description: IN the duel for Bill Parcells, as in anything else, two wrongs didn't make a right.

title: That Shiba Inu in the Window
description: There were 28 shiba inus competing for best of breed at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show yesterday, which is probably more shiba inus than New York City has ever seen in one spot before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, REV. JOHN JOSEPH
description: McCARTHY-Rev. John Joseph, S.J. Dear brother of Dr. Patrick J. McCarthy and Mrs. James Durkin. Reposing at the Loyola Hall Chapel, Fordham University, Wednesday, 3-5PM and 7-9PM and Thursday 3-5PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 8PM at Fordham University Church. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors.

title: 'Whistle' Runs Out Of Steam On the Road
description: ''Whistle Down the Wind,'' the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical in tryouts at the National Theater in Washington, will not open on Broadway this year. The musical, which was scheduled to begin performances at the Martin Beck Theater on June 3 and open on June 15, needs more work, the composer said yesterday.

title: Death Wish Bill Advances
description: By a vote of 7 to 2 yesterday, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a proposed constitutional amendment intended to speed up the appeals process for inmates who wish to be executed. The measure, which would have to be approved by a three-fifths majority of both houses before being placed on the ballot, would allow mentally competent inmates to waive their right to additional appeals after the initial appeals process is over.

title: Opponents Gain From Rangers' Weak Spot
description: The Rangers rank first in the National Hockey League in power-play scoring. Yet that celebrated strength has been virtually offset -- especially lately -- by their dismal penalty killing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Bad Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: HBO Should Have Pulled Out of Bout
description: For seven weeks before Friday night's Oliver McCall-Lennox Lewis spectacle, HBO Sports had serious doubts about McCall's state of mental health.

title: In the Long Shadow of Beethoven's String Quartets
description: The members of the Emerson String Quartet have been together for more than 20 years. This is often trouble time, when string quartets are struggling with personality clashes, dissension and jadedness.

title: 2 More Aerial Close Calls Are Reported
description: Three more F-16 fighters flew too close to civilian jets in two separate incidents on Friday, the Federal Aviation Administration said today, making a total of four such incidents on Wednesday and Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZABO, SZILARD
description: SZABO-Szilard. The Feszek Klub sadly mourns the loss of its distinguished member. Gabor Carelli, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, ELAINE H. (NEE SILVERMAN)
description: MARX-Elaine H. (nee Silverman). Devoted mother of Barry and his wife Allyn, Philip and his wife Sheryl, David and his wife Robin. Adoring grandmother of Mellisa, Deborah and Danny. Loving sister of Harriet and Edna. Services today 1 PM, ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'', (Parkside Building), 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, corner Avenue V.

title: Talk of Takeover Lifts Fund Manager's Shares
description: The shares of Mercury Asset Management Group P.L.C. jumped yesterday amid speculation that the company, Britain's largest fund manager, might be the target of a takeover bid. In addition, the SBC Warburg securities firm raised its investment opinion on Mercury, increasing the target share price to 1,500 pence from 1,390. Mercury shares rose 26.5 pence, to 1,382.5 ($2.26), yesterday.

title: Harriman's Caring Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Death by Black Hole

title: Is U.S. Less Hospitable?Boom in Foreign Students Seems to Be Over
description: WASHINGTON  For more than four decades, American colleges and universities have had a seemingly irresistible appeal to students from other countries, and the education of foreign students in the United States has been a growth industry.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD B. STOLLEY, the founding managing editor of People magazine, and LISE HILBOLDT, an actress and former Hollywood Diary columnist for Buzz magazine, know a thing or two about reporting romantic news. But on Saturday they were in their own wedding story: they were married in St. James' Church on Madison Avenue and celebrated at a reception at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Chess
description: The rating lists of the rival Professional Chess Association and International Chess Federation should be identical, but they are not. Indeed, each organization puts Garry Kasparov at the top and also the first seven players on each list are the same, though not in the same order.

title: Foster's Brewing Posts 2% Gain in Net Income
description: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. said yesterday that its net income rose 2 percent in the six months that ended on Dec. 31. The rise to $169.4 million (Australian), or $129 million (United States), was attributed to higher earnings from the Australian beer division. Foster's, Australia's largest brewer, said its performance was held back by a one-time loss before tax of $5.6 million (Australian), mainly from restructuring costs at Molson Breweries in Canada. Foster's holds a 40 percent stake in Molson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, BARBARA (NEE WAYNE)
description: RUBENSTEIN - Barbara (nee Wayne). On February 10, 1997. Beloved wife of Martin. Loving mother of Steven, Donald and Alan. Dear sister of Dr. Richard Wayne. Adoring grandmother of Katelyn, Anne, Emma, Christine, Andrew, Melissa and Emily. Family will receive friends Tuesday (today) from 7-9PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, N.Y. Funeral services Wednesday, 10AM at the Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Memorial donations to Scleroderma Foundation of the Tristate Area, 1182 Teaneck Road, Suite 104, Teaneck, NJ 07666.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, SR. MARY MERCIA
description: O'CONNELL-Sr. Mary Mercia, R.S.M. on February 9, 1997. Mass of the Resurrection, Thursday 9:45 AM, Church of the Sacred Heart, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry. Prayer service Wednesday 7:15 PM. Memorials to Sisters of Mercy retirement fund appreciated.

title: Officials Fear Universities Are Losing World Prestige : A Quiet Crisis For Germany
description: HEIDELBERG  Encrusted on a hillside between the Neckar River and a Rhineland castle, this small university town is a jewel among the country's seats of learning. The steep streets seem to hold faint echoes of student princes carousing; wooded paths evoke long walks pondering the teaching that made Germany a cultural power. In the tea shop, crowded with hikers on a Sunday, the walls are covered with black-paper silhouettes and photographs of students with dueling scars in the Prussian tradition.

title: Executive Changes
description: ANN TAYLOR STORES CORP., New York, named Catherine Sadler executive vice president for marketing of its Ann Taylor Inc. unit.

title: Netscape and Agency Agree to Part Ways
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation yesterday announced a mutual agreement with Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White in Salt Lake City to part ways because of a potential conflict. As a result, the Netscape account, with billings estimated at $10 million, will be placed in review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, DR. JOEL J.
description: MORRIS-Dr. Joel J., on February 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary Lee (nee Keats). Devoted father of Danielle Keats Citron and Jeanine Keats Morris. Adored son of Blanche Morris. Cherished sonin-law of Louis S. Citron. Dear brother of Ronald A. Morris.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about commercial surveillance satellites gave incorrect approximations, in some copies, for the satellites' powers of resolution. In each case, the resolution in feet is about three times the resolution in meters, not one-third that number.

title: Nynex Official, Facing Reduced Duties in a Merger, Quits
description: As Bell Atlantic and Nynex closed in on their merger, a top Nynex executive abruptly resigned yesterday. Richard A. Jalkut, the president and chief executive of Nynex's core telecommunications unit, said he would leave once the deal was completed, probably in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERWITZ, ANNE SCHER
description: LIEBERWITZ-Anne Scher, 92, a 20 year resident of Miami Beach, and formerly of Great Neck passed away Sunday, February 9, 1997. She is survived by many devoted and loving nieces and nephews. Mrs. Lieberwitz was Treasurer of Colonial Sand and Stone Co. the largest supplier of concrete to the tristate construction industry and a long time benefactor of U.J.A. Federation.

title: Coffee Surges on Supply Fears As Strikes Loom in Colombia
description: Coffee prices surged yesterday on concerns that a strike in Colombia would disrupt exports at a time of lean inventories in the United States.

title: Seeking Matching Funds
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey, Democrat of Woodbridge, who has raised $535,850 for his gubernatorial campaign, applied yesterday for state matching funds, the the first candidate to do so. To be eligible for the funds, granted on a 2-to-1 ratio, candidates must pledge to spend no more than $3.1 million, to accept no individual contributions larger than $2,100 and to appear in at least two televised debates, said Frederick M. Herrmann, executive director of the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission.

title: U.S. Judge Approves 1980's Insider Settlements
description: A Federal judge gave final approval yesterday to seven class-action settlements that will pay $68.9 million to investors who say they were defrauded by Ivan F. Boesky and others involved in insider-trading scandals of the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, ALEXANDER D.
description: GOODMAN-Alexander D., of Hillsdale, NJ, retired from Bulova Watch Co. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Stephen, Thomas Goodman and Suzanne Rittweger. Loving grandfather of Jay, Douglas, Laura and Holly. Services private. Donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated. For more information ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 800-522-0588.

title: All Society Isn't Divided Into Black and White
description: To the Editor:

title: Delighted Campus, 'After 10 Years of Decline,' Hails the Decision
description: At first, students, faculty members and administrators at the Adelphi University campus here were stunned by the news that the State Board of Regents had ousted all but one of the university's trustees.

title: Brash Parents to 80's Deals Emerge as 90's Rivals
description: Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph R. Perella, who rose to prominence as partners in Wall Street takeover wars of the 1980's, are doing business together again. Only this time they are on opposite sides of one of the biggest deals of the 1990's.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THE PRINCESS OF WALES has long been an admirer of the designer GIANNI VERSACE and has worn his clothes, so when she was asked to write the forward for his new book, ''Rock and Royalty,'' to raise money for AIDS research, she agreed.

title: Strike Is Authorized By PATH Signalmen
description: The union that represents signalmen on the PATH commuter line has voted to authorize a strike, which could cripple the rail service that shuttles more than 80,000 commuters between Manhattan and New Jersey each day. Forty-eight members of the 56-member union approved the walkout, union officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, SHARON
description: PETERSON-Sharon, died Sat., Feb. 8th. She was a beloved member of the Brooklyn Ethical Society, WBAI Radio and Park Slope Food Co-op. We acknowledge with sadness the passing of Sharon, who so loved life, people and social justice. A medical librarian at Brooklyn Interfaith Hospital, she leaves two sons, David and Kevin, and a multitude of friends. A memorial service will be held today, Feb. 11th, at 1:30PM at the Brooklyn Ethical Society, 53 Prospect Park West. Donations should be sent to Sharon's Fund. For information call 718-499-5802.

title: Why Web Search Engines May Speed Past Missing Links
description: THIS column appears weekly not only in newsprint but also on the World Wide Web. Yet if you hunt for it with one of the popular Web-wide search engines like Altavista, Infoseek or Hotbot, you will probably never find it.

title: Parcells Case Resolved
description: Two weeks of wrangling over Bill Parcells ended yesterday in a deal that freed him from his obligations to the New England Patriots and allowed him to begin coaching the Jets this year. The Patriots did not receive the compensation they coveted -- the No. 1 pick in this year's college draft -- but got four picks over all, including the Jets' first choice in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARRICK, ALEXANDER B.
description: WARRICK-Alexander B., 76, died February 9 in Vero Beach, FL. He is survived by a wife, the former Frances Stone, a son, Alexander Jr., a daughter-in-law, and 3 grand children. He was a member of the Yale class of 1942 and retired from the Chemical Bank in 1972 to build the Stage Neck Inn of York Harbor, ME. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be sent to the Hackley School, 293 Benedict Ave., Tarrytown, NY 10591.

title: A Vote on School Vouchers
description: The Lincoln Park Board of Education is scheduled to vote tonight on a school voucher plan that critics contend is unconstitutional. The measure would provide public funds from $1,000 up to half the cost of tuition for parents who want to send their children to private and parochial high schools.

title: Persecuting The Christians
description: Some columns can be postponed for more important topics, some put off until they seem newsier and many dropped because they do not flesh out. But some have to be written as soon as information is collected, no matter how late.

title: Jury Believed Evidence, Not Simpson
description: It was the trail of blood, it was the photos of the Bruno Magli shoes, it was the glove, the mobile phone calls, the cuts on his hand. In short, members of the jury said today in explaining why they had found O. J. Simpson liable in his civil trial, it was simply the evidence.

title: Use the Card Catalogue!
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Wants a 2-Year Deal
description: The Yankees and Bernie Williams are still not in the same ball park. General Manager Bob Watson said yesterday that the Yankees would like to reach an agreement on a one-year contract with Williams so that they could skip the salary arbitration hearing scheduled for Feb. 19. Scott Boras, Williams's agent, said he is waiting for word from the club on a two-year proposal he made last Thursday.

title: CABARET
description: In Good Voice at 68,

title: A Top-10 List Not Too Many Care to Be On
description: As if Gilbert Amelio, the chief executive of Apple Computer, and Paul Fireman, the chief executive of Reebok International, did not have their hands full already, the public pressure for improved stock performance is about to grow. Both companies are on a list that the huge California Public Employees Retirement System plans to release today of its 10 target companies for 1997.

title: Rutgers Is Dropping Charges
description: Rutgers University plans to drop charges against a member of the Socialist Workers Party whom its campus police arrested for selling books without a permit, officials said yesterday. A lawyer for the party member, Robert B. Miller, maintained that written material should be exempt from requirements for vending permits under First Amendment guarantees of free speech.

title: Clinton Begins Campaign for His Education Proposals
description: Clearly comfortable in his own tribe, President Clinton began politicking among the politicians today, starting his itinerant national campaign to create education standards and to soften changes in the welfare system by addressing a special session of the Maryland Legislature.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 3 about a change in the format of a Los Angeles radio station misstated the title of Steven Baker, a record company executive who lamented the change. He is president of Warner Brothers Records, not president of Reprise Records, a Warner Brothers label.

title: Law Lets Regents Punish Leaders, Sparing Colleges
description: The state law that resulted in the removal of 18 Adelphi University trustees is perhaps a unique method in the United States for dealing with college mismanagement and has been used only three times in the last 80 years.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Reading of Mahler's Sixth

title: Krupskaya's Husband?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES, St. Louis, announced that it had put a job freeze in effect, but said the plan would affect only administrative and back-office employees and not pilots or other front-line workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, ROBERT E.
description: EINHORN-Robert E. On Feb. 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Stacey. Father of Gregory and Victoria. Brother of Stephen. Son of Bill and Lydia and friend to so many. We all love you very much. Services Tues, 11:30AM, at Free Synagogue of Westchester, 500 N. Columbus Av, Mt. Vernon, NY. 914-664-1727.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARDO, WILLA EATON
description: PARDO-Willa Eaton. Died on February 6, 1997. A devoted wife, sister, aunt and friend as well as a very active community person. Will be memorialized Thursday, February 13th, at 3 P.M., at Saint Pascals R.C. Church, 112-43 198 Street, Saint Albans, New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Continues to Shrink
description: Japan's current account surplus shrank in December for the 28th time in the last 30 months as Japanese travelers continued to spend heavily overseas and the prices of imported goods rose with the strong dollar. The surplus declined 23 percent from December 1995 to 820.7 billion yen ($6.66 billion), the Ministry of Finance said yesterday.

title: Founder of Crazy Eddie Gets 8 Years in Prison and Big Fine
description: Eddie Antar, the founder of the Crazy Eddie chain of electronics stores, was sentenced to a total of eight years in prison and fined $250,000 today for falsifying the chain's books and fleeing the country to avoid prosecution.

title: Times Mirror Gives Options to Workers
description: Times Mirror Inc. said today that its board had decided to award options for 100 shares to eligible employees as a reward for the company's performance in the 1996 fiscal year.

title: MESA IN $270.5 MILLION DEAL FOR GREENHILL PETROLEUM
description: Mesa Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Greenhill Petroleum Corporation, a United States subsidiary of the Australian mining company WMC Ltd., for $270.5 million. Greenhill owns properties in Louisiana and Texas and in the Gulf of Mexico. Mesa, an oil and natural gas company in Irving, Tex., said it expected to increase production on those properties to more than 12,000 barrels of oil a day in 1998 from the current 9,300 barrels. Mesa said the properties had total proven reserves of 30 million barrels of oil as of Jan 1.

title: The Busiest Remember the Neediest
description: Irwin and Beatrice Boehm of Washington Heights are an older couple often busy with doctor's visits. ''The 'Golden Years' require such activities,'' they wrote in a letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''Our recent involvements almost caused us to overlook our annual tradition of sending a contribution to your most worthy Fund.''

title: G. Stockton Strawbridge, 83, Dies; Retail Industry Executive
description: G. Stockton Strawbridge, who helped transform Strawbridge & Clothier from a small family dry goods store into a department store empire that girdled the Philadelphia area, died at his home in Newtown Square, Pa. on Saturday. He was 83.

title: Information's Value Eludes Internet Provider
description: To the Editor:

title: Snow Geese Survive All Too Well, Alarming Conservationists
description: THE striking sight of thousands of snow geese flying north in waving skeins across the spring sky is an annual thrill for midcontinent birders, and it should be, too, for environmentalists, who fret constantly about threats to waterfowl survival.

title: Albania Struggles to Contain Dissent Over Lost Investments
description: Angry demonstrators swarmed today through the port city of Vlore, throwing stones, burning cars and battling riot policemen. Two people were reported killed and several dozen were hurt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, EDITH (BERNSTEIN)
description: BARON-Edith (Bernstein). On February 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Irving. Cherished mother of Susan ''Robert'' Eber, Andrea ''Robert'' Schwarz and Deborah ''Norman'' Ellis. Adoring sister of Selma Linderman, Martin and Edwin Bernstein. Devoted grandmother of Gabriel, Jordan, Alexander and Ilana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, ELIZABETH ANTOINETTE
description: FARRELL-Elizabeth Antoinette, 87, of cancer on February 8, 1997 in Los Angeles. Former resident in New York and Largo, Florida. Born Rotterdam, Holland arrived U.S. age 11 and offered an exemplary lifetime of work, motherhood, service, friendshp and love. Widow of William Farrell. Remembered always with tenderness and love by daughter, Adelaide, granddaughter Karen, and son-in-law Alvin.

title: Patterns
description: Hilfiger Active Wear for Men

title: Progress on Integration
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYNE, NORMAN
description: PAYNE-Norman. The Officers and Staff of Dazian Fabrics note with sorrow the passing of our esteemed colleague, Norman Payne. During his 44 year tenure at Dazian, Mr. Payne conducted his sales functions with highest integrity and diligence. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Sarah, and family. Dazian Inc. Louis Feinberg, President

title: Vote Delayed On Measure To Balance The Budget
description: Afraid that they do not have the votes for approval, House Republican leaders decided today to postpone at least until next month further action on a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget.

title: President and Congressional Leaders to Hold Capitol Hill Meeting
description: President Clinton and Congressional leaders will sit down to talk about issues on Tuesday at the Capitol, in a vaguely organized meeting where no one knows quite what to expect.

title: Parcells Deal Is Pricey for the Jets And Just About Right for Patriots
description: In a deal brokered by Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, the Jets finally got their man. And on the surface, retaining this year's No. 1 overall draft pick and getting Bill Parcells, a proven N.F.L. coach, seems to be a good deal for the Jets.

title: The Mets Sign Another Part Of Their Past
description: The Mets must think if it worked for the Yankees, it can work for them too.

title: New Vistas Open for Earthbound Astronomers
description: EVER since the reign of Louis XIV, wine bottles manufactured in Paris by the Compagnie de Saint-Gobain have been green -- and so is the glass from which this old French company cast the 100-inch-diameter mirror for America's Hooker telescope on Mount Wilson, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ABRAHAM
description: FRIEDMAN-Abraham, of West Hartford, CT. formerly of Brooklyn, NY, a retired attorney died February 9, 1997. Survived by wife Gladys, son Stephen, two daughters Judith Jacobson and Leah Freedman, two sisters and nine grandchildren. Services were held Monday. For information Weinstein Mortuary of Hartford.

title: ABC Sets Review Of Majority of Account
description: The ABC television network said yesterday that it had begun a review on the majority of its account, which has been handled by the Grey Entertainment unit of Grey Advertising in New York since 1975. Billings were put at $30 million to $40 million.

title: BBDO New York Keeps Doritos Account
description: The Frito-Lay Company unit of Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that a creative competition on the Doritos snack-chip account, with billings estimated at $40 million, had ended with the incumbent, BBDO New York, retaining the assignment.

title: Doing the Shuffle
description: After all that hoo-hah about money corrupting the recent elections, you expected the Washington crowd to plunge right in and do something about it? Of course you didn't.

title: Accounts
description: * Dana Perfumes, Stamford, Conn., a division of Renaissance Cosmetics Inc., to Lotas Minard Patton McIver, New York, to handle advertising for the Navy and Navy for Men line of fragrances. Lotas Minard also handled the account under the line's previous owner, the Procter & Gamble Co. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

title: Out of the Mouths of Black Poets
description: In ''Underground Voices,'' a short film by Reg E. Gaines, a poet named Sharif proclaims, ''It's a movement!'' That movement is a resurgence of poetry performed by African-Americans, and it showed its strength with ''Word: Life,'' which took over Irving Plaza on Saturday for a seminar and concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, GEORGE O.
description: THOMPSON-George O., Feb. 8, 1997 of Hampton Bays, LI. Beloved husband of the late Marie. Loving father of George F., Kay & Mary; also survived by 2 grandchildren. Reposing at the R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 East Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, Long Island. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 9:45 AM at St. Rosalie's R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. Family will receive friends on Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at the Funeral Home.

title: Tax Charges for Financier
description: Barry H. Trupin, a New York City financier who made millions off tax shelters in the 1980's and was convicted in 1995 of trying to sell a stolen Marc Chagall painting, was charged yesterday with evading more than $6 million in income taxes, according to a Federal indictment.

title: Bonds Mixed As New Issues Are Awaited
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday as the dollar weakened and traders prepared for new supply coming to market as well as fresh economic data later this week.

title: 14 Insurers Scrutinized By Regulators
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said late yesterday that it was inspecting 14 insurance companies after finding evidence of abusive sales practices in the marketing of variable annuities by other insurers.

title: In Test, Courtesy Gains Beachhead in Subways
description: If the Transit Authority really wants to prevent people from pushing through subway doors before riders get off the train, then commuters like Elizabeth G. Carnesecchi think the pilot program kicked off yesterday was just too nice.

title: T.A. Needs Own Lesson in Subway Etiquette
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants a Strain on Schools : Can Hong Kong Cope With Influx?
description: HONG KONG  Two years ago, 15-year-old Lam Cheong Hung immigrated to Hong Kong from Kwongling, a small town in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong. Upon arrival, he immediately began applying to schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPER, LEON
description: JASPER-Leon. With deep sorrow and regret, Temple Zion mourns the passing of our President Emeritus, Leon Jasper. We will miss his wisdom, knowledge and guidance. His total devotion to our synagogue was unmatched. We send our condolences to his wife Florence. Irving Dropkin, Rabbi David Koegel, President David Goldberg, Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLIARD, BARBARA JEAN
description: HILLIARD-Barbara Jean. Formerly of New York, on Friday, in Anderson, IN. Mother of Vincent D. Hilliard of New York, Rodney Hilliard, Brenda Cox and Teri Perine. Services Thursday in Indiana.

title: Douglas Opens Next Chapter
description: The biggest fight of Buster Douglas's life was not in a ring seven years ago. It was in a hospital bed four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERR, ALAN S.
description: PERR-Alan S., on February 8. Beloved father of Alexis and Bryan and beloved stepfather of Chandra Whitehead. Devoted son of Dr. Mortimer and Sally Perr. Dear brother of Susan. Services will be held today, 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, Rumsey Road, Yonkers, New York. For more information call Weinstein Memorial Chapel Inc, 914-793-3800.

title: At the Wire, Auction Fans, It's, It's . . . Christie's!
description: Swords will forever be drawn between Hertz and Avis, between Coke and Pepsi and, in the rarefied world of art, between Sotheby's and Christie's. The rival auction houses have been battling for two centuries to corner as much of the art business as they can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RUTH
description: FRIEDMAN-Ruth. Beloved mother of P'tach's esteemed Board members, Dr. Ira and Erika Friedman. Condolences to her children, Dr. and Mrs. Friedman, and Mr. and Mrs. VanAmerongen, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Children of P'tach

title: Schnauzer Is Champion Once Again
description: A grizzled veteran of the show dog wars, the standard schnauzer who defeated 93,725 other canines last year, and two rank amateurs on the scene, a surprisingly poised wire fox terrier and a flashy Japanese chin, became the first group winners last night at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

title: 6 Admit Guilt In U.S. Case Against Mob
description: After working out a deal in which Federal prosecutors dropped murder and racketeering charges, two high-ranking Genovese crime family members pleaded guilty yesterday in Manhattan to extorting payoffs from a construction union and a garbage hauling company.

title: Contrasting Reactions As They Hear the Verdicts
description: The two men reacted differently to the reading of their fates.

title: No Longer the Unthinkable
description: In the weeks since the signing of the Hebron agreement, the final destination of a Palestinian-Israeli peace settlement has begun to emerge from the political haze. Such a settlement must not only end the Israeli occupation and colonization of Palestinian soil, it must give the Palestinian people a sovereign, uncontested, independent state of their own. This is a matter of justice and practicality. If a truly lasting and stable peace is the goal, there is no other option.

title: Earnings Shortfall Ignites Drop in 3Com Shares
description: Shares of the 3Com Corporation tumbled today after the company said that earnings for its third quarter, ending Feb. 28, would fall below Wall Street analysts' estimates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TETAMORE, RUTH L.
description: TETAMORE-Ruth L. We mourn the death of our amazing mother and friend. In long illness, her passion for people, learning and beauty, sustained her and us. Her triumphant life and courageous death leave an inpired legacy to the many who loved her. Memorial service will be announced. Please give to charity in her memory. Denise Kahn, Albert Wray, Larry and Sherri Kahn

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: ROCK
description: Without the Theatrics,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLB, PHILIP
description: KOLB-Philip. To my lifelong, camera shy good friend-we will miss you forever. Ruth and Fred Greenwald

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a girl for the singer MELISSA ETHERIDGE and her companion, JULIE CYPHER. BAILEY JEAN CYPHER, weighing 8 pounds, 10 ounces, was born to Ms. Cypher yesterday, Gayle Fine, a spokeswoman for Ms. Etheridge, told The Associated Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTUCH, JOSEPH
description: PASTUCH-Joseph, February 10, 1997, of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Keith, Lon and Brett. Dear brother of Norma Dinkin and Sarah Siegel. Loving grandfather of Sean, Robyn, Justin, Ryan, and Jenna. Services today, 1:30 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Human Presence in Americas Is Pushed Back a Millennium
description: After long, often bitter debate, archeologists have finally come to a consensus that humans reached southern Chile 12,500 years ago. The date is more than 1,000 years before the previous benchmark for human habitation in the Americas, 11,200-year-old stone spear points first discovered in the 1930's near Clovis, N.M.

title: Swiss Unemployment Hits Record of 5.7%
description: Switzerland's unemployment rate rose to a record 5.7 percent in January, at the upper end of estimates, as more companies shed workers in the country's longest no-growth period since World War II. The Swiss economy is expected to grow as little as five-tenths of 1 percent this year, having barely grown since 1990. The economy stalled as consumer spending shrank amid rising unemployment, falling real wages and slowing export growth.

title: Suit on Fare Increase Is Settled
description: Two groups that sued to roll back a 25-cent increase in New York City subway and bus fares, arguing that they were racially discriminatory, settled the suit yesterday when transit officials agreed to pay for a study to look into their concerns.

title: Ecuador's Military Code: Democracy Is Better
description: When Rosalia Arteaga addressed Ecuadoreans for the first time as their undisputed Interim President on Sunday, her backdrop was a sea of stars and bars, representing the country's most powerful admirals and generals lined up behind her.

title: Paul Cummings, 64, Expert on Drawings And Prints of U.S.
description: Paul Cummings, a curator, publisher and authority on American drawings and prints, died on Friday at Beth Israel North Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: In America, Boasting Has Proud History
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader's Digest breaks with a four-decade tradition by selling space on its back cover.
description: READER'S DIGEST, for the first time since it began accepting advertising 42 years ago, is selling space on its back cover.

title: Dow Jones Nominates 7 Directors to Board
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had nominated seven directors, four of them new candidates, and cut the size of its board.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar Falls, Then Rebounds After Group of Seven Talks

title: A corner turns for Yahoo and other Internet search concerns.
description: THANKS to those clown-size fish in the company's TV ads, or the hillbilly yodel in the radio spots, even investors who have never surfed cyberspace have likely heard of Yahoo -- a leader in the market for services that help users search for information on the World Wide Web. Following the example of McDonald's and other consumer-product marketers, Yahoo, like its closest competitors, Lycos, Excite and Infoseek, has been building brand awareness through sizable television and radio advertising campaigns.

title: F.A.O. Schwarz Sets A New Growth Spurt
description: F.A.O. Schwarz's flagship Fifth Avenue store, long a mecca for children and parents, is to grow by more than 60 percent. The toy retailer has signed a new 20-year lease in the General Motors Building at 767 Fifth Avenue, increasing its retail space from 40,800 to 65,600 square feet.

title: Analysts Debating Valuation of Stocks
description: As the Dow Jones industrial average flirts with the stunning level of 7,000, several leading analysts on Wall Street are counseling that the old rules no longer apply when judging whether the stock market has soared beyond reason.

title: A Right to Join NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Main Breaks, Again, and 3 Are Homeless
description: Water mains break in New York City more often than ''Cats'' is performed on Broadway, more often than the Jets change coaches. Five or six hundred times a year, a rupture occurs along the city's 6,000 miles of mains.

title: Swenson Defers Recital
description: The soprano Ruth Ann Swenson has postponed her New York recital debut on the advice of her doctor. The concert, originally scheduled for 2 P.M. on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall has been rescheduled for May 11. All tickets for this Sunday's concert will be honored on the new date. Information: (212) 875-5030.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATZ, SYLVIA
description: SHATZ-Sylvia. On Feb. 9, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John R. Shatz and the late Barnett Mackler. Devoted mother of Judith Jacobson, Ruth Chacon and Joan Kurland. Loving grandmother of Kate Beckerle. Dear sister of Roslyn Josephson. Friends will be received Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Tuesday eve 6-8 PM, with a service on Wednesday at 12 noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASTRO, ANGELINA (NEE ACCURSO)
description: NASTRO-Angelina (nee Accurso), age 82, on Feb. 8, 1997 of Plantation, FL., formerly of Alpine, NJ. Beloved wife of pre-deceased Joseph (1978). Devoted mother of Pat Nastro and pre-deceased Nicoletta Iannone (1995). Loving mother-in-law of Linda Nastro and Albert Iannone. Dear sister of Nini Accurso. Loving grandmother of Emil, Joseph and Virginia. Loving great-grandmother of Nicholas and Andrew. Funeral from the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, NJ, Wednesday, February 12, 1997 at 9:15AM thence to Madonna R.C. Church, Fort Lee, NJ where the Funeral Mass will be offered at 10AM. Entombment at Madonna Mausoleum, Fort Lee, New Jersey. Visiting hours on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: The Anatomy of Medical Ignorance
description: TUCSON, Arizona  At first Dr. Marlys Witte, a surgery professor at the University of Arizona, found that even her own colleagues resisted the proposed new course.

title: Charged When He Returned
description: When Warren Mattei, an investment banker, formerly of Summit, was divorced in 1992, he was ordered to turn over $2.7 million in cash and stocks so a judge could apportion the assets between Mr. Mattei and his former wife. Instead, he returned to his native England, where he bought a town house in London and a Bentley, Edward M. Neafsey, the Union County Prosecutor, said.

title: Relax, Wagnerians: 'Tristan' Voices Are on the Way
description: Forecasters tell us that the ''Tristan und Isolde'' drought is almost over. Wagner's disturbing hymn to sensuality has survived in recent years mostly in smaller European houses, where less than heroic voices have coped (barely) with its rigors. ''Tristan'' is stirring again. The Los Angeles Opera has revived its David Hockney production, and major companies domestic and foreign, cheered by a new generation of singers, have put it on their schedules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESEL, MILDRED
description: WIESEL-Mildred. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth-El, Cedarhurst, NY and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Allan Kroningold, President

title: CANADIAN 88 WITHDRAWS BID FOR MORRISON PETROLEUMS
description: The Canadian 88 Energy Corporation has withdrawn its unsolicited takeover bid of the equivalent of $487 million for Morrison Petroleums Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, saying it was concerned that some of the target company's assets might be less valuable than expected. Canadian 88 said a temporary suspension order against the sale of new shares also contributed to its decision. The bid was one of the most contested in the Canadian energy industry. On Friday, Canadian 88, also based in Calgary, said it would extend its offer until Feb. 19 after it was temporarily suspended by regulators from issuing new shares to help pay for its tender offer. On Saturday, it withdrew the offer.

title: A Car Crash, a Disturbance, the Aftermath
description: The verdicts yesterday added another link to a chain of events that began on a summer night when a 7-year-old black boy stopped to adjust his bicycle near an intersection in Crown Heights.

title: A Pledge to Live in the State
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee confirmed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's choice for transportation commissioner yesterday, but not before the nominee, John J. Haley, pledged that he would become a full-time New Jersey resident within 60 days. Mr. Haley, who has been Acting Commissioner since Jan. 6, replaced Frank J. Wilson, who resigned in November after being criticized for discussing job opportunities with companies seeking state business.

title: It's Heavy Going for Sex, Satan and Heavy Metal
description: The official accusations have shocked Egypt's conservative society, with tales of clandestine parties in which young people took drugs, engaged in group sex and then unearthed corpses from Cairo cemeteries.

title: NEW YORK REGENTS OUST 18 TRUSTEES FROM ADELPHI U.
description: The New York State Board of Regents removed 18 of Adelphi University's 19 trustees yesterday, saying they had paid the university's president too much, did not keep track of his compensation and failed to review his job performance.

title: In Reversal, Army Suspends Sergeant In Sex-Assault Case
description: Under growing pressure from Congress, the Army today suspended its highest-ranking enlisted soldier while he is investigated because of accusations of sexual assault and harassment.

title: De Beers and Russia Fail to Reach Pact
description: De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, said today that no agreement had been reached with Russia over a new marketing pact for uncut diamonds. Reports over the weekend in Moscow said a deal had been struck.

title: Omnicom Takes Stake In Interactive Agency
description: Omnicom Group in New York has acquired what was described as a significant minority interest in Organic Online, an agency in San Francisco that creates interactive advertising for marketers like the Colgate-Palmolive Company, Levi Strauss & Company and the McDonald's Corporation. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Replace Old Mains? The Answer Isn't So Easy
description: If New York's water mains break hundreds of times a year, why don't city officials simply replace all of the oldest ones?

title: 2 Guilty in Fatal Crown Hts. Violence
description: Two black men were convicted yesterday in the death of a Hasidic Jew in the 1991 violence that shook Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and laid bare once again New York's deep racial divide.

title: N.F.L. Brokers Deal, and Parcells Can Coach Jets
description: Ending one of pro football's more confounding legal scrimmages, National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue brokered a deal yesterday that freed Bill Parcells from his obligations to the New England Patriots and allowed him to sign on immediately as head coach of the Jets.

title: WBT HOLDINGS INCREASES ITS BID FOR AMERICAN FILTRONA
description: WBT Holdings L.L.C. agreed yesterday to raise its takeover offer for the American Filtrona Corporation by 8 percent, to about $172 million. WBT said it would pay $46.52 for each of American Filtrona's 3.7 million shares outstanding, up from the $43 offered in December. Shares of American Filtrona soared $3 yesterday, to $43. WBT Holdings is owned by several trusts of the Walter Bunzl family. American Filtrona, based in Richmond, makes fiber cigarette filters and plastic products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABER, BARBARA (STEIN)
description: TABER-Barbara (Stein) of Dover, MA on February 10. Wife of Herbert Taber. Daughter of Sylvia (Wetstone) Stein of Quincy, MA. Devoted mother of Kenneth W. Taber and his wife Andrea P. Taber of New Rochelle, NY and Mark L. Taber of Cohasset, MA. Dear grandmother of Sarah, Rebecca and Matthew. In lieu of flowers remembrances in her memory may be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Barbara Taber Tribute Fund, 1309 Beacon Street, Brookline, MA 02146.

title: No Headline
description: ''Today, I look at France -- our great conceptual thinkers and lousy doers, our brilliant engineers and lousy marketers, our risk-averse culture that if you fail once it's all over -- and I wonder if we're not simply going to miss out on tomorrow.''

title: Senate Chief in Albany, Reversing Himself, Says He Backs a Ban on Ultimate Fighting
description: Just months after he pushed for legislation that made New York the first state to sanction the bruising competition known as ultimate fighting, the State Senate majority leader reversed himself today and said he would ask the Senate to pass a bill banning the sport throughout the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONNER, ROBERT FARRINGTON
description: BONNER-Robert Farrington, of Short Hills, NJ, on Sunday, February 9, 1997. Husband of Jane Gassaway Bonner. Father of David F., Margaret M. and Nicole. Son of Maud K. and the late Walter F. Memorial service in Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ, Thursday, February 13, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Millburn-Short Hills Volunteer First Aid Squad, PO Box 226, Millburn, NJ 07041.

title: Jury Decides Simpson Must Pay $25 Million in Punitive Award
description: Writing one of the final chapters in O. J. Simpson's long legal case, a civil court jury here ordered him today to pay a financially debilitating $25 million in punitive damages to the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman.

title: In Duel of Goalies, B.U. Breaks Through to Win the Beanpot
description: Boston University won its 20th Beanpot Tournament championship, and its third in a row, with a 4-2 victory over Boston College tonight before a capacity crowd of 17,565 in the Fleet Center.

title: Supremacist Found Guilty In 5 Robberies
description: Peter K. Langan, an acknowledged member of a right-wing revolutionary cell that robbed more banks than Jesse James, was found guilty in Federal court here today on five counts of bank robbery and using an explosive device during a robbery.

title: Wayne Gretzky's 900th Goal Will Be His First in a Long Time
description: Wayne Gretzky's next goal will be significant in more than one way. It will mark another major milestone -- No. 900 -- in a remarkable professional career that began 19 years ago in the World Hockey Association.

title: Immigration Fosters Surge In Subway Use
description: Despite a 25-cent fare increase, subway ridership in New York City soared last year to its highest level since the early 1970's, as the immigrant surge that has reinvigorated neighborhoods throughout the city has rippled over to the transit system.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: For Jefferson, Less Reverence, More Explanation
description: AMERICAN SPHINX

title: The Men's Shows Seek a New Hero
description: What do men want? The question Freud once asked about women, illustrating their quaint complexity to the opposite sex, is now being asked about men by magazines and designers catering to them.

title: Seton Hall Fades Away, Leaving Miami Atop East
description: A number of statistics could be used to explain Seton Hall's loss to Miami tonight. But confidence was the story: Miami had it, and Seton Hall did not.

title: Tribute to Takemitsu Evokes a Private World
description: Conventional wisdom holds that Toru Takemitsu was Japan's most prominent composer because his music bridged the distinct musical cultures of East and West. There is something to that: from his works of the 1950's through those he composed just before his death nearly a year ago, Takemitsu used the soft edges of French Impressionism and the sonorities of traditional Japanese music, in both its courtly and exuberant forms, to temper the dissonances and angularity of a fundamentally avant-garde style.

title: Insights Into Why U.S. Students Lag Behind in Global Academic 'Horse Race'
description: WASHINGTON  American students have rarely fared well in international comparative studies of educational achievement, and a body of common wisdom has developed to explain why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERKLOOT, NICHOLAS J.
description: VanderKloot-Nicholas J., 89 years old, of Palm Beach, FL, died at his home on February 9, 1997, after a three month battle with cancer. Born in Chicago, IL, on April 25, 1907, Nick joined R.R. Donnelley & Sons, the world's largest commercial printer, as a pre-apprentice, in 1924 at the age of 17. During his 48 years at Donnelley, Nick had a distinguished career as a leader in the printing industry and as a legend at Donnelley as Senior Vice President and a member of the Board of Directors. He also was a Director of the Lake Shore Club of Chicago and a member of the Chicago Athletic Club, the Union League Club, and the Calumet Country Club. In 1972, he retired from Donnelley to Palm Beach, where he was a member of the Board of Directors and Treasurer of the Beach Club until 1996. A veteran of WWII, Mr. VanderKloot served as a Lieutenant Colonel on the Army Air Force Air Command Staff at the Pentagon. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Mary Louise; his step-son, Ron Klensch of Chicago, IL; and his nephew, Frederic VanderKloot of New York. Mr. VanderKloot was preceded in death by his daughter, Pamela, in 1981. A Memorial Service will be held at 2:00 P.M. on Saturday, February 22, 1997 at Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, with the Rev. Ralph R. Warren, Jr., D.D. Rector of Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach, FL, officiating. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

title: Marx, Not Hegel
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning From a Loss
description: Five years ago, when Lemrick Nelson Jr. went to dinner with Brooklyn jurors to celebrate his acquittal for the murder of a Hasidic Jew during the Crown Heights violence, he had no way of knowing the verdict was, in essence, temporary. Yesterday, a Federal jury convicted Mr. Nelson on a related charge for the same incident, largely because Federal prosecutors were able to use the first trial as both a cautionary tale and a blueprint.

title: Teammates Feel Ewing Has More Faith in Them
description: Before they played for New York, Larry Johnson, Chris Childs and Allan Houston had heard disturbing stories about how the ball would go inside to Patrick Ewing and never be seen or heard from again, and about how the offense would never change. Like the kids who summon enough courage to one day knock on the door of the dilapidated home to find out for themselves if it is haunted, they tried not to be frightened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENQUIST, IRVING F., M.D.
description: ENQUIST-Irving F., M.D. On February 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Kristine Fach, Erik, M.D. and Rolf. Cherished grandfather of Bradley and Alexis Fach and Erika and Hannah Enquist. Dear brother of Mae Marinkovich and Lois Galinski. Reposing Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. Visitation Tuesday 3-5, 7-9. Funeral service Wednesday, 11AM, at The Congregational Church, Manhasset, N.Y. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please direct donations to ''Adventure in Learning'', c/o The Congregational Church, Manhasset, N.Y.
