title: Ousted Yeltsin Bodyguard Wins Parliament Seat, Threateningly
description: Ousted from power and roundly condemned by Russian reformers, the shadowy former bodyguard of President Boris N. Yeltsin clawed his way back into the political ring today by winning a seat in Parliament.

title: Family Feud Takes Some Zing Out of Annual Toy Fair
description: There was toylock when the Toy Fair opened in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Garment District Wants In
description: Sandwiched between two of Manhattan's busiest hubs for new retail development, Times Square and Herald Square, property owners in the Garment District want some of the action.

title: Republicans Delay Budget Amendment
description: House Republican leaders postponed at least until next month further action on a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: 'Goldberg' Variations

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIMAN, AMBASSADOR PAMELA
description: HARRIMAN-Ambassador Pamela. On Wednesday February 5, 1997, Ambassador Pamela Harriman died in Paris, France; widow of Governor W. Averell Harriman, and mother of the Honorable Winston S. Churchill, M.P. She is also survived by grandchildren and great grandchildren. Funeral services will be conducted Thursday, February 13, at 10 AM at the Washington Cathedral, Wisconsin and Massachusetts Avenues, N.W., Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pamela Harriman Memorial Fund, c/o The Office of the President, The College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia 23185.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAVRICK, ISADORE
description: SHAVRICK-Isadore. We want to convey our heartfelt sympathy to our Rebbetzin, Claire Hertzberg, on the loss of her father, and to Mrs. Shulamith Shavrick on the loss of her husband, Isadore ShavShavrick. Victor Schildkraut, President Lee Potasinski, Exec Vice Pres

title: DANCE
description: Encountering Perils

title: A Subtle Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Jean Hewitt, 71, Home Economist and Food Writer for The Times
description: Jean D. Hewitt, a former food writer and home economist for The New York Times and an early advocate of natural foods, died on Sunday in the Bon Secours-Venice Hospital in Venice, Fla. She was 71 and made her home in Venice.

title: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE TO ADD TRAMMELL CROW CENTER
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company agreed yesterday to buy the 50-story Trammell Crow Center office building in Dallas for $162 million in cash. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, said it would buy the building and its mortgage from two pension funds, the California Public Employees Retirement System and the Teacher Retirement System of Texas. The 1.13 million square-foot building is 80 percent leased. Its rents average $21 a square foot, compared with the more than $30 a square foot average rent at Crescent Office Towers, a building Crescent owns in Dallas, the company said. This gives Crescent the potential of raising rents at the Crow property. Crescent is controlled by the billionaire investor Richard E. Rainwater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, RENE
description: METZ-Rene. The Officers and Directors of the Leo Baeck Institute send heartfelt condolences to Alice and Claudia, beloved wife and daughter of our dear friend and benefactor, Rene Metz. We shall always be grateful for his support of our work and our mission. Carol Kahn Strauss Ismar Schorsch

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, PAUL
description: CUMMINGS-Paul. 64. On February 7, of complications following a stroke. Former curator of Drawings at the Whitney Museum of American Art; past president of the Drawing Society. Beloved brother of Rita L. Yankasammy; brother-in-law of Sam; uncle of Devicka and Krishna of Garden Grove, CA. Donations may be made in his memory to The Library Fellows of the Whitney Museum, 945 Madison Ave, New York, NY 10021, or to the Poetry Project at St. Marks Church, 131 E. 10th St, New York, NY 10003. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTIMER, ELISABETH ''BETTE'' SMITH
description: MORTIMER - Elisabeth ''Bette'' Smith, 71, Montague, NJ, February 9, 1997. V.P. Westfall Productions and Secy-Treas. of Mortimer Foundation, Montague, NJ. Survived by husband, Charles G. ''Duke'' Mortimer, Jr., daughters, Nancy M. Wilson, Mendham, N.J., and Bonnie M. Baird, Ocean Twp., NJ; sons, Charles G. Mortimer, III, Verona, NJ, & Loren B. Mortimer, Clifton, NJ; a sister and seven grandchildren. Friends call Wed. 24 & 7-9 PM. Gray-Parker Funeral Home, 100 East Main Street, Port Jervis, NY. A memorial service at a later date will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, MARION GENGLER
description: PEARCE-Marion Gengler, 81, of Fairfield, CT., died peacefully at her home Sat., February 8, 1997. Born in NYC, she was a graduate of the Shipley School in Sewickley, PA, and attended Barnard College. She was predeceased by her husband, Arthur W. Pearce. She is survived by her three sons: Arthur Pearce, Jr. of Ithaca, NY, Gerald Pearce of Fairfield and William Pearce of Tarpon Springs, FL.; four daughters, Patricia Brodersen of Pompano, FL., Marion Pearce of NYC, Lucy Standing and Elizabeth Bonney, both of Fairfield; 1 sister Jean McCann of Newtown, CT.; 12 grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren. Friends are invited to attend a Memorial Mass today at 1:00 P.M., at St. Pius X Church, Fairfield., CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to: St. Vincent's Medical Center Foundtion, 2800 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT. 06606.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AZRAK, THEODORE, J.
description: AZRAK-Theodore, J. On Feb. 9, 1997. Beloved father of Joseph, Marianne Ayoub, Pamela, Elizabeth Warner and Christopher. Devoted brother of Rose Awad. Cherished grandfather of six. Survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97th St., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 am, Church of the Virgin Mary.

title: Stocks Tumble on Technology Selloff; Dow Drops 49.26 Points
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday following a wave of selling in the technology sector.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Friday about the abduction of Red Cross workers in Tajikistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the information that the workers had been kidnapped. It came from the United Nations, not the Red Cross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSHOR, SUSANNA RIVKA
description: YOSHOR-Susanna Rivka. Congregation Ohab Zedek, Belle Harbor, mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed member, Joseph Yoshor. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Joel Berkowitz, President

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: AVIS EUROPE TO BUY BACK INTEREST HELD BY HFS
description: Avis Europe said yesterday that it had agreed to buy back the 8.7 percent of its stock held by HFS Inc., which owns the Avis name in the United States. Financial terms were not disclosed. As part of the agreement, Avis Europe will license the Avis name for use in the car rental business in Asia and Africa and will pay annual royalties to HFS, which is based in Parsippany, N.J. HFS also franchises hotels and real estate offices. The transaction is contingent on Avis Europe's completing its public offering and listing on the London Stock Exchange, which is expected by the end of March. Avis Europe is 77 percent owned by the Belgian car importer and distributor D'Ieteren S.A.

title: Tokyo Stocks Rise by 1.8% After New Accord on Dollar
description: The Tokyo stock market rose 1.8 percent yesterday in the first day of trading since a group of the world's richest countries agreed to end efforts to raise the value of the dollar, a move that could hurt the earnings of Japan's big exporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, SIDNEY
description: BELL-Sidney, Feb. 8, 1997. Retired dentist and owner of Sidney Bell Fine Arts and Antiques. Survived by his wife Gloria, his son Dr. Stuart Bell and daughter-in-law Corinne of Baltimore, daughter Leslie, sister Rose Burger, grandchildren Douglas, Alexis and David, his niece Jane and nephew David Engel. Services today 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Diabetes Foundation or The American Heart Association.

title: Young Astronomers Scan Night Sky and Help Wanted Ads
description: AT the age of 26, Brenda Frye, a Berkeley graduate student, already seems assured of a career in the exclusive science of cutting-edge astronomy. She has had the privilege of controlling one of the largest telescopes in the world and has done significant research, including investigations of the chemistry of star-forming nurseries lying near the edge of the known universe.

title: Nets to Play It Straight, Not for Top Draft Pick
description: It is a lesson taught in driver's education, a tip offered for perilous conditions: Always steer toward the skid.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of a former Chinese Defense Minister yesterday rendered his surname incorrectly in some editions. He was Qin Jiwei, not Chen Jiwei.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: YO, STEP ASIDE, LADY -- Subway workers begin trying to coax commuters to employ some standard etiquette by stepping aside when other riders step off trains. B3.

title: On Ultimate Fighting, Let Marketplace Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, IDA WEISS
description: ALPER-Ida Weiss. On February 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of the late Howard. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Daniel and Michael. Loving mother-in-law of Marilyn. Graveside services Wednesday, 1 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: A Long Familiar Voice Still Finds New Effects
description: Marilyn Horne has been performing with the pianist Martin Katz for 30 years. ''It's the longest relationship of my life,'' she told an adoring audience at Carnegie Hall on Friday night during a recital celebrating their anniversary. ''It hasn't all been laughs,'' she confessed, ''but we're still here.''

title: A Second Crown Heights Verdict
description: Yesterday's Federal jury verdict finding Lemrick Nelson Jr. and another defendant, Charles Price, guilty for their roles in the 1991 slaying of Yankel Rosenbaum, during a night of mob violence in Brooklyn's Crown Heights neighborhood, provides a reasoned legal ending to a long ordeal for the city and those involved in the case. It also vindicates Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to use the nation's civil rights laws to bring a sense of justice that was missing when the outcome of the state court trial seemed not to match the evidence.

title: Thai School:A Family Affair
description: BANGKOK  As urban growth chisels away at the traditional Thai family, one school is calling students, along with their parents and grandparents, to the hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARKA, ROGER JOSEPH
description: ZARKA-Roger Joseph. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of Roger Joseph Zarka, beloved father of Jean-Marc and Katharine Zarka, Donors of our synagogue. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: British Hotel Company Sells 25 Properties
description: Queens Moat Houses P.L.C., a British hotel company, said yesterday that it had sold 25 hotels to a group of managers backed by Hambro European Ventures Ltd. for $:91.5 million ($149.3 million). Queens Moat, struggling to recover from a 1992 loss of almost $:1 billion, has sold all but 51 of its British hotels as part of its plan to pare debt and reorganize. It also operates hotels elsewhere in Europe.

title: Drop in Paper Demand Hurts Finnish Producer
description: Metsa-Serla Oy, a Finnish forest products company, said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 83 percent in 1996 as prices and demand for paper products fell. Pretax profit dropped to 315 million markkaa ($67 million) from 1.914 billion markkaa in 1995.

title: Apple to Take Big Write-Off On Acquisition
description: In two moves underscoring the extent of Apple Computer's planned corporate overhaul, the company said today that it would incur a huge loss this quarter to reflect the cost of acquiring Next Software Inc. and that its executive in charge of courting outside software allies would leave the company after only a year in the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EMANUEL
description: SCHWARTZ-Emanuel. Retired Vice President, Bankers Trust Company. Beloved husband of Gloria and the late Mary Schwartz. Father of Carl and Bernie. Grandfather of Robin, Martin, Julie and Marlo. Also, great-grandfather. Last of the Brighton Beach Bath Handball Gang of the '40s and '50s. Private interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday about proper names in literature misstated the given name of Sherlock Holmes's colleague. He is John H. Watson, not Thomas.

title: Bank Loan Gives Mercury A Chance to Renegotiate Debt
description: The Mercury Finance Company said today that it had secured a short-term, $50 million prime rate loan from the Bank of America, a lifeline that will allow it more time to renegotiate hundreds of millions of dollars in debts on which it has defaulted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTHAUS, JULIUS
description: LUSTHAUS-Julius, on February 10, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Sally. Devoted father of Marilyn and Rachel. Cherished grandfather of Nissa, Eric, Adam and Brian. Loving brother of Ruth and Libby.

title: Georgia's Rebel Battle Flag Is Hauled Down in Albany
description: Benjamin Franklin argued against using the eagle as a national icon because it had stood for the Roman Empire. Franklin knew that symbols are powerful, and memories long.

title: 2 Groups Sell Building
description: Two prominent civil rights organizations that had long owned and occupied a 21-story office building at 500 East 62d Street, between York Avenue and the East River, have sold it to a company that may develop a hotel there.

title: Fatal Shooting of Children, Particularly One, Shakes Miami
description: Rickia Issac, the youngest of five siblings, was a 5-year-old kindergartner who loved junk food, recited the alphabet in an earnest voice and was just learning to add. Three weeks ago, while walking home with a baby sitter from a Martin Luther King Day parade, she was fatally shot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAININ, ELISE VOGEL
description: BRAININ-Elise Vogel, on February 6th. Mourned by husband Max Brainin, daughter Ricarda Heller, grandsons Robert and Steven Heller, sister Mimi Schoen and brother Erich Vogel. She will be sorely missed by her many friends and relatives, and remembered fondly by those whom she helped and inspired.

title: Ameritech Suspends Effort To Enter Long-Distance
description: The Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn a filing with the Federal Communications Commission that had sought approval to offer long-distance telephone service in Michigan.

title: Classroom Volunteers
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: 2 CALDORS TO CLOSE -- A Caldor store in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn will close, in a blow to local redevelopment efforts. Metro Business, B6.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: A Bet on a Cosmic Scale, And a Concession, Sort Of
description: Dr. Stephen W. Hawking of Cambridge University in England -- the brilliant theorist regarded as one of Albert Einstein's intellectual successors -- has conceded defeat in a famous bet he made six years ago on a matter of cosmic significance.

title: Death Squad Killings of Basques: Was Spain's Government the Mastermind?
description: Lourdes Onederra remembers that it was an uncle who came to the family store in a Basque village east of here on the evening of Dec. 19, 1983, with the news that her brother had been shot to death that afternoon in a Basque cafe in Bayonne across the border in France.

title: 2 Georgia Senators Lower Flag of That Yankee State
description: First there was the feud between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ted Turner. Then came the Yankees versus the Braves. Now, New York and Georgia are at it again, this time over George E. Pataki's decision to remove the Georgia state flag from a display in Albany because it incorporates the Confederate battle flag.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Saturday about ''William Faulkner's 'Old Man,' '' a drama broadcast on CBS on Sunday, referred incorrectly to the origin of the title. Faulkner did in fact write a story called ''Old Man.'' It first appeared as half of a novel, ''Wild Palms,'' published in 1939.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Time Warner Reports Profit And Seeks to Cut Debt Load

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANG, ALICE HUEI, ZU
description: YANG-Alice Huei-zu. Students, faculty and staff of the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University, mourn the tragic loss of our gifted young colleague and friend. Alice was a rare individual of great talent and achievement, much loved and admired. We will miss her subtle mind, her generosity of spirit, her sudden infectious laughter. The quiet intensity of feeling that she brought to the living of each day was a gift of poetry to those who knew her. We extend our deepest condolences to the Yang and Szeto families.

title: Personal Health
description: ''THE greatest gift one can give to children is not protection from stress, change or loss, but the confidence and tools to cope with and grow with all that life offers, both the good and the bad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELSON, RAY
description: MICHELSON-Ray. Of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Michael; devoted mother of Golda Zenker; loving grandmother of Marc and Michelle. Services at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, New York, Wednesday, 11:30 A.M. For information ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 800-522-0588.

title: Judge Orders Toy Fair Landlord To Stop Dispute Over Credentials
description: In a ruling hailed by a toy manufacturers' trade group, a Federal judge yesterday ordered the landlord of the International Toy Center in Manhattan to halt its registration process for visitors to the American International Toy Fair, the $20.7 billion industry's premier trade show.

title: Of Czechs and Jews and the Blinding of Memory
description: In the cemetery of the small Bohemian town of Letohrad, which was home to Madeleine K. Albright's forebears, there is a simple marble slab tucked away in a corner where the snow is untrodden. Dated 1930, it reads simply: ''1914-1918: We gave our lives. You give love to your homeland.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABER, BARBARA (STEIN) OF DOVER, MA.
description: TABER-Barbara (Stein) of Dover, MA., February 10. Wife of Herbert Taber. Daughter of Sylvia (Wetstone) Stein of Quincy, MA. Devoted mother of Kenneth W. Taber and his wife Andrea P. Taber of New Rochelle, NY, and Mark L. Taber of Cohasset, MA, sister of Ellen Spokane of Tucson, AZ. Dear grandmother of Sarah, Rebecca and Matthew. In lieu of flowers remembrances in her memory may be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Barbara Taber Tribute Fund, 1309 Beacon Street, Brookline, MA. 02146.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about State Senator James E. McGreevey misstated the amount of money he has raised so far in his campaign for governor. It is $336,925. (He is seeking $535,850 in state matching funds).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TYSON FOODS INC., Springdale, Ark., the poultry company, sold four beef processing plants to the plants' managers for $41 million. The plants are in Harlingen and Garland, Tex., and Sioux Center and Orange City, Iowa.

title: Court Halts Ouster Of Adelphi Trustees
description: A day after the State Board of Regents dismissed 18 of Adelphi University's 19 trustees, the trustees won a temporary court order blocking their removal. But the Regents said they would appeal, and insisted that the trustees they had appointed on Monday were still in charge of the Long Island university. For their part, the lawyer for the 18 ousted trustees said they were in charge.

title: Marx and Lenin, Caviar and Vodka
description: Cafe Republic, spelled with a backward ''R,'' is tongue-in-cheek, old-time Soviet in tone. An elaborately framed picture of Lenin is prominently displayed over worn leather easy chairs in the bar; a portrait of Karl Marx ringed by flickering candles as if it were an icon hangs in the dining room, whose battered walls have bits of newspapers with Cyrillic type peeking through layers of reddish paint. These two small rooms also manage to suggest obeisance to the trendy well-heeled patrons who have been flocking to the restaurant since its Nov. 20 opening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANG, ALICE H.Z.
description: YANG-Alice H.Z. On February 7, 1997. She is survived by her husband, Gerald Szeto, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H.Y. Yang, and her brothers, Andrew and James. Services are on Thursday, February 13 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, at 11:30 A.M.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Advisers Say Dinkins Won't Run for Mayor
description: Two weeks ago, David N. Dinkins roiled the mayoral campaign in New York City by suggesting that he might enter the race to unseat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. But associates of Mr. Dinkins now say that while the former Mayor has enjoyed shaking up what some feel had become a desultory race, he has decided not to run, and would instead lend his support to one of the Democrats who have already declared their interest in running for mayor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNE RICE, the author of best-selling novels about vampires and witches, is another woman who believes in speaking her mind. As a result, she is being sued by a restaurateur in her hometown, New Orleans, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Chief Is Dismissed at Centennial Technologies
description: Centennial Technologies Inc., a maker of personal computer equipment whose stock soared last year, said yesterday that it had dismissed its chairman and chief executive, Emanuel Pinez, and had begun an investigation into the accuracy of its financial statements.

title: Campaign Finance Changes Lose Urgency in Both Parties
description: Reform of the campaign finance laws, described as a major priority by both Republicans and Democrats after charges of widespread abuses last year, is losing its urgency on Capitol Hill.

title: Chevron's Bet On Kazak Oil, A Long Shot, Is Paying Off
description: When Chevron began spending what would become $700 million on the Tengiz oilfields of Kazakstan, its competitors were at best skeptical.

title: The Surging Dollar? In U.S., Most Companies Shrug It Off
description: When the American dollar was soaring a dozen years ago, many American manufacturers warned that their businesses would be severely injured by an influx of cheap Japanese tractors, cars and other imports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSTAS, ILONA
description: ROSTAS-Ilona, on January 17, 1997 at age 92. Memorial Service on Saturday, February 15 at 2:00PM, The Admiral, 909 West Foster, Chicago. For information call: 847-256-2880.

title: In Zaire's Unconventional War, Serbs Train Refugees for Combat
description: Every morning, from an airport at the edge of this crumbling city, Yugoslav jets with Ukrainian pilots take off with a scream, headed east toward a huge, shifting war zone, bombing anything that moves in the impenetrable forest below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALKSTEIN, BEATRICE M
description: KALKSTEIN-Beatrice M. Age 91. February 8, 1997 in Stamford, CT. An actress for fifty years on Broadway, radio soap operas and TV, monologist and story-teller in New York and Stamford, for which she was Honored by the State of Connecticut in October 1991. Survived by sons Shawn of Stamford, Michael of Los Gatos, CA and Peter of New York, six grandchildren and various nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIMAN, AMBASSADOR PAMELA
description: HARRIMAN-Ambassador Pamela. On Wednesday, February 5, 1997, Ambassador Pamela Harriman died in Paris, France; widow of Governor W. Averell Harriman, and mother of the Honorable Winston S. Churchill, M.P. She is also survived by grandchildren and great grandchildren. Funeral services will be conducted Thursday, February 13, at 10 AM at the Washington Cathedral, Wisconsin and Massachusetts Avenues, N.W., Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pamela Harriman Memorial Fund, C/O The Office of the President, The College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia 23185.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLLEY, NICK
description: JOLLEY-Nick, February 8, our beloved brother, uncle and friend passed on unexpectedly. Service Saturday, February 15, 11 A.M., Redden's, 325 West 14th Street. Donations to the Actor's Fund.

title: From the Wings, a Prayer: A Black Troupe Improvises
description: It was the first day of rehearsals for a new production, and that meant there was a ritual to adhere to, a tradition to uphold. So administrators and employees of the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, N.J., and the cast of ''Wedding Dance'' fanned out, held hands and bowed heads.

title: Panel Upholds Fining City on Shelters
description: A state appellate panel yesterday upheld a Manhattan judge's order holding Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and two city agencies in contempt of court for forcing homeless families with children to sleep on floors, desks and chairs in a Bronx office while they await placement in the shelter system.

title: Benjamin Gebiner, 98, Servant of Jewish Culture
description: Benjamin Gebiner, who devoted a multifaceted career to Jewish communal life and the labor movement, died on Friday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 98 and had been general secretary of the Workmen's Circle.

title: Family Planning and Foreign Policy Are Linked, Albright Tells House Panel
description: In her first public appearance on Capitol Hill as Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright today asserted that family planning was an important component of the United States' foreign policy and urged Congress to support an Administration-backed measure that would speed the release of money for family-planning programs overseas.

title: Russia's Communists
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Mayor and 2 Others Are Indicted in a Rape
description: Three men accused of raping a waitress on Block Island, R.I., last fall -- among them a former First Warden, the equivalent of mayor -- have been indicted on nine counts of sexual assault.

title: Shuttle Starts Space Telescope Mission
description: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery soared into space today on their way to the Hubble Space Telescope, where they plan to replace two aging scientific instruments with more advanced ones, tune up guidance systems and generally make everything shipshape for many more years of cosmic exploration.

title: Money as Punishment
description: The $25 million punitive damages award against O. J. Simpson is high, but it is commensurate with the crime. It also reflects the jury's sensible desire to make it hard for Mr. Simpson to get rich again from scandal-peddling publications and trash television. Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki has the right to reduce the amount of the awards, but that would be a disservice to a jury that made a reasonable judgment about the defendant and the culture of celebrity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESCOTT, ELEANOR
description: PRESCOTT - Eleanor. Beloved wife of Nicholas George Garaufis, devoted and adoring mother of James Anthony and Matthew George Garaufis, cherished and loving daughter of Joseph Prescott. Services Wed., 10:15 AM, Temple Beth Sholom, 171-39 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, 2950 B'way, NY NY 10027 would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the new United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, reversed and misspelled the names of the President of the General Assembly. He is Razali Ismail, not Ismael Rezali.

title: Shorter Police Response Time
description: Since he became Newark's Police Director in July, Joseph J. Santiago said yesterday, the police have been responding faster to high-priority crimes. In June 1996, it took the police an average of 13 minutes to send a squad car to such crimes as robberies, burglaries and carjackings; by December, police had cut their response time to an average of two minutes, Mr. Santiago said.

title: Dime-Size Tables, Dollar-Size Welcomes
description: ARRIGO CIPRIANI peers at a customer's plate. ''What are you having?'' he asks.

title: To Help Its Bid, Hilton Proposes 25 Candidates for ITT's Board
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it planned to nominate as many as 25 candidates, including former New Jersey Governor Jim Florio, to replace the ITT Corporation's board and bolster the chances for its $6.5 billion bid for the casino and lodging company.

title: Knicks Respond to Van Gundy's Hook
description: When Patrick Ewing was playing for Georgetown more than 10 years ago on this same court, he remembered how John Thompson would substitute five players at the same time to send a message to the starters: wake up or sit down.

title: A Film Explores Using Food to Treat Epileptic Children
description: JIM ABRAHAMS is so convinced of the success of a controversial high-fat diet for treating children with epilepsy that he has created a television movie about one mother's struggle to care for her ailing son.

title: Whitman Goes on Road
description: The gubernatorial election is nine months away, but Gov. Christine Todd Whitman seemed to be stumping hard yesterday as she made seven stops in Morris, Sussex and Warren Counties, starting with breakfast at Harpers Bagels in Hackettstown at 8 A.M.

title: CASTLE HARLAN FUND ACQUIRES 60% OF U.S. SYNTHETIC
description: Castle Harlan Inc., a New York merchant bank, said yesterday that an investment fund it manages had bought a 60 percent stake in the U.S. Synthetic Corporation, a maker of synthetic diamond drill bits based in Provo, Utah, for about $60 million. The acquisition was made by Castle Harlan Partners II L.P., an investment fund representing corporate and public pension funds, college endowments, foundations and individual investors. Castle Harlan Partners II specializes in the purchase and subsequent sale of companies. Synthetic drill bits allow for faster drilling because they are sharper and more durable.

title: Having Their Say
description: Two representatives of the Food Lion supermarket chain will appear on ''Nightline'' tonight with Roone Arledge, the president of ABC News, and Diane Sawyer, the anchor of ''Prime Time Live,'' the show whose report on Food Lion led to a $5.5 million judgment for punitive damages against ABC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, ELFREEDA, (NEE EISNER)
description: GOLDSMITH-Elfreeda, (nee Eisner), of Hackensack. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Rhoda Gruen & Stuart Goldsmith. Dear sister of Irma Moskowitz, Rita Wolfberg, Alma Dobkin & Edward Eisner. Loving grandmother of 8 grandchildren & 9 great-grandchildren. Services Wed., 1:30 PM, Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack.

title: Deans' Pictures Open Debate in Virginia
description: Some students at the University of Virginia law school are protesting the recent hanging of portraits of the school's former deans -- all white men -- in a prominent hallway.

title: Auditors' Alarm Over Mercury Finance
description: How did auditors finally figure out that Mercury Finance was cooking its books?

title: Ericsson Earnings Rise Of 39% Tops Estimates
description: Ericsson A.B., the world's biggest supplier of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that its pretax profit jumped 39 percent, more than analysts expected, in the fourth quarter amid growing demand for mobile phones and networks. Pretax profit rose to 3.894 billion kronor ($533 million), up from 2.805 billion kronor in 1995's fourth quarter. That put full-year profit at 10.152 billion, up 33 percent.

title: Eating Well
description: THE company that manufactures Promise margarine has signed an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission to stop making false health claims for its butter substitute. The settlement fulfills a policy the commission set in 1994 to bring its food advertising policy into line with the Food and Drug Administration's rules for food labeling, which are much stricter.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about a review for the advertising account of the Netscape Communications Corporation misattributed a trade publication report about the review. It appeared in Advertising Age, not Adweek.

title: A Homecoming With Goats and Guns
description: Darrell James Roodt, the talented South African film maker responsible for the movie version of the musical ''Sarafina!'' and for a solemnly effective screen adaptation of ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' stumbles badly with his newest film, ''Dangerous Ground.'' An action-adventure yarn set in contemporary Johannesburg, the movie is continually stopping in its tracks to deliver simplistic, preachy political broadsides.

title: Public Advocate's Race
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Love of Chocolate
description: AN 11-year-old girl with a ponytail peers deeply into the polished glass showcase at Li-Lac Chocolates. Her eyes widen, and for a moment she seems to sigh. There are too many choices: foil-wrapped hearts, delicate little truffles, chocolate-drenched pretzels, thick bars of fudge.

title: Kofi Annan's Cautious Style
description: Kofi Annan has been Secretary General of the United Nations for six weeks, and some in Washington are already grousing that he is not doing enough to reform the U.N. It is true that Mr. Annan has not yet turned the organization upside down. But he faces a Herculean task. He must refocus and restructure the U.N. for a world no longer defined by the ideological conflict of the cold war. It will take time to make changes. But in this case patience may be rewarded by the development of an international body that can finally live up to the great promise that attended its birth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOHN CAMPBELL
description: HENRY-John Campbell. On January 30, 1997. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City, at 11 o'clock, on Thursday, February 13.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO BUY LENS EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would buy Innotech Inc., which manufactures equipment used to make eyeglass lenses, for $13.75 a share, or $123.8 million. Johnson & Johnson, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J., is the world's biggest maker of contact lenses. Optometrists use Innotech's products to manufacture difficult-to-make prescription eyeglasses, like bifocals, on site. The lens equipment costs a typical optometrist about $14,000. Shares of Innotech, which is based in Roanoke, Va., rose $4.64, or 52 percent, to $13.5156. Johnson & Johnson's shares climbed 37.5 cents, to $60.

title: All Together Now
description: In the latest example of ''synergy'' -- otherwise defined as multiple money-making potential -- in television, CBS Entertainment, Hallmark Entertainment and Crayola crayons announced yesterday that together they would create three one-hour family dramas to be shown in prime time on CBS in August.

title: Bozell Worldwide Acquires Kamstra
description: Bozell Worldwide in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, said yesterday that it had acquired Kamstra Communications, which will become Bozell Kamstra, a Bozell unit specializing in business-to-business campaigns. Terms were not disclosed.

title: In Patriotism's Name
description: The strange, and yet sadly banal, case of Madeleine K. Albright has fascinated and puzzled the media and the public since the revelation last week that she was born of Jewish parents who had converted to Roman Catholicism before World War II.

title: Another Camden Candidate
description: A scathing state audit issued last year accused Camden's City Hall of mismanagement and cited widespread political patronage as well as unethical business relationships involving city and county officials. Despite the state's grim assessment, the field of candidates who would like to run the city continues to lengthen. The city's Mayor, Arnold W. Webster, is seeking re-election in May.

title: Xando Coffee Bar in Broadway Debut
description: Manhattan has plenty of coffee bars, but it is soon to get a Coffee and Bar.

title: Court Order Halts Ouster At Adelphi U.
description: A day after the State Board of Regents dismissed 18 of Adelphi University's 19 trustees for, among other things, paying the university's president too much, the trustees won a temporary court order blocking their removal.

title: Bullets Get Old Friend To Solve New Woes
description: Even with a new coach, losing is a hard habit to break.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGAPITO, KARIN HEIDER
description: AGAPITO-Karin Heider. 2/12/87. Dear, dear Karin: I love you so very much. I always have. I always will. You are the only one for me. Love, Tony

title: Food Notes
description: Nonsweets for the Sweet

title: Clinton and Republican Leaders Agree on Five Goals
description: President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed today on a five-item list of issues, from the quite specific to the very general, where they hope to work out agreements.

title: Workfare Expert to Enter Private Sector
description: Three years after designing a workfare program for New York City that quickly became the nation's largest, Richard J. Schwartz, the senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, announced yesterday that he is leaving City Hall to design similar programs across the country -- this time, for a profit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ETHEL (NEE BLOCK)
description: HECHT-Ethel (nee Block), Feb. 10, 1997. Devoted wife for 56 years of Abner. Devoted mother of Johnathan. Sister of Arlene Fogel of Buffalo, New York. Services are at Temple Israel Center of White Plains at 10 A.M., on Wednesday, February 12. For information McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, White Plains.

title: Oral Roberts Students Anger Muslims
description: A group of Oral Roberts University students angered Muslims in the community when they disrupted Ramadan services at a local mosque and left only after the police had been summoned.

title: Pataki to Seek Some Taxes On Cigarettes Indians Sell
description: Setting the stage for a potentially bitter showdown, the Pataki administration announced today that it planned to start collecting taxes on some gasoline and cigarettes sales on Indian reservations despite persistent opposition from Indians who consider it an infringement of their sovereignty.

title: Minority Applications Drop in California
description: Statistics compiled by the University of California indicate a sharp drop in the number of applications received from black and Hispanic students for fall 1997 enrollment, prompting new concerns that the system's plans to stop using race as an affirmative-action factor in admissions is scaring away minority applicants. At the same time, the university reported receiving a record number of applications for next fall, as well as increases in applications from whites and Asian-Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALEMAN, IDA
description: HALEMAN-Ida. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Devoted mother of David and Helene Haleman, Edward and Laura Haleman. Adored grandmother of Deborah and Robert. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, at The Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Condemned Dog Is Saved by Agreement, Cooling Controversy
description: After overwhelming publicity suggesting that the punishment did not fit the crime, prosecutors here today dropped charges against the dog on death row for killing a rooster.

title: No Way Out for Innocents In a Harsh Ho Chi Minh City
description: ''Cyclo'' was shown as part of the 1995 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12, 1995. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Simone DeCalvacante, 84, Former Crime Figure in New Jersey
description: Simone Rizzo DeCalvacante, who the authorities say was the former head of a New Jersey Mafia family and whose underworld forte was devising rackets to milk union funds and extort money from legitimate companies, died on Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 84 and had lived in retirement for more than 20 years in Florida.

title: The new campaign for 3 Musketeers adds diversity to portray contemporary America.
description: MR. WHIPPLE has always been white. Uncle Ben has always been black. The Jolly Green Giant has always been, well, green. But there has been an unusual color change for another advertising character, which may be symbolic of the changing face of American consumers.

title: After Night in Jail, Jesse Jackson Appears Weary but Retains Old Zeal
description: Looking weary in wrinkled corduroys, the Rev. Jesse Jackson flashed a thumbs-up sign this morning as he walked into a courtroom filled with sheriff's deputies, Mr. Jackson's supporters and the fading ghosts of 1960's street demonstrations.

title: Greenmarkets Bountiful in Winter, Too
description: THEY have no ripe tomatoes or corn, but more than half the city's greenmarkets remain open in winter, selling items like apples, baked goods, cheeses and potatoes.

title: Don't Cry for Her
description: Nothing personal, but the omission of Madonna from the list of Oscar nominees for best actress highlights a welcome development. For years, the movie industry had so little interest in women that Academy Awards nominators had trouble scraping up five actresses in creditable leading roles to fill the category. This year there was enough surplus to leave the ''Evita'' star out. Perhaps Madonna can take comfort in the fact that she was sacrificed in the name of a positive trend.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Shift by China Is Seen

title: Lawyers for 2 Start Planning Appeals of Convictions in Crown Heights Killing
description: A day after two black men were convicted in the killing of a Hasidic Jew during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, their lawyers began planning appeals yesterday that will include the argument that putting both men on trial together harmed each man's case.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COMEAU, ANDREW GNUTON
description: COMEAU-Andrew Gnuton. You always will be missed. Life is not the same without you. Mami

title: MetroStars' Caricola Retires
description: NICOLA CARICOLA, who anchored the defense for the MetroStars last season after 11 years in the Italian League, announced his retirement yesterday at the team's training camp in Italy. The move by the 34-year-old Caricola opened a spot for another foreign player on the MetroStars, which will most likely be filled by a Brazilian.

title: Crash Stirs Israel Debate On Lebanon Buffer Zone
description: The disastrous collision last week of two Israeli helicopters ferrying soldiers to southern Lebanon has revived a sharp and sometimes bitter debate over whether Israel should unilaterally withdraw from its self-proclaimed buffer zone there.

title: It's Bonus Season On Wall Street
description: There they are again, the brash young men with slicked-back hair, prowling among the exotic sports cars in Steven Kessler's East 34th Street showroom. They finger the buttery leather seats of an $84,900 1993 Ferrari Mondial, or dicker over the $179,000 price of a 1994 Lamborghini Diablo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, SR. FRANCES (SR. JOSEPH REGINA)
description: DWYER-Sr. Frances (Sr. Joseph Regina). Beloved Sister of Charity, devoted staff nurse to numerous children at the New York Foundling died Feb 10, 1997. Dear sister of Catherine and Mary Dwyer and Anna Dangoia, and beloved aunt of Richard Dangoia. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St, Yonkers, NY, Wed 1-8 pm. Mass of Christian Burial Thurs 10am at the convent. Interment St. Agatha's Cemetery, Nanuet, NY

title: Honoring Thomas Edison
description: Marking the 150th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Alva Edison, Federal legislation was introduced yesterday to raise money to repair two sites in New Jersey honoring the inventor and five others elsewhere. Under the bill, the U.S. Treasury would issue two commemorative coins (for $1 and 50 cents) and another 50-cent coin to be circulated for a year.

title: Problems of Identity for All
description: The Ugly Duckling, by comparison, had it easy. The most celebrated example of an identity crisis in children's literature, he was able to work things out once he realized he was really a swan. For Margaret the Duck, the heroine of a story dreamed up by a character in Seth Zvi Rosenfeld's ''Flatted Fifth,'' now at the Intar Theater, things aren't nearly so simple.

title: Military Sex Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARSEN, MARY L. (VICKERS)
description: LARSEN-Mary L. (Vickers), 63, formerly of Bklyn, died Monday. Widow of Lars Carsten Larsen. Retired from Sea Farerers International Union. Funeral services Friday at 9:30AM, at St. Gregory the Great Church, Hamilton Sq., NJ. Calling hours, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 at Kingston and Kemp Funeral Home, 260 White Horse Avenue, Trenton, New Jersey.

title: Lamar Buys a Rival For $167 Million
description: The Lamar Advertising Company, an outdoor advertising company in Baton Rouge, La., has agreed to acquire another outdoor company, Penn Advertising Inc. in York, Pa., for about $167 million in cash.

title: Postpartum Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia's Song Debate Reveals Historical Irony
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Be flexible' is the advice as a holiday weekend and a strike deadline at American Airlines near.
description: A STRIKE by the pilots' union of American Airlines would not only shut down the carrier but would also severely inconvenience tens of thousands of passengers throughout the nation's crowded air transportation system.

title: At U.N., U.S. Must Lead and Follow, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord in Albany on the City's Debt Limit
description: With New York City about to reach a borrowing limit that would have prevented billions of dollars worth of school construction and other capital projects, the leaders of the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki today agreed to let the city circumvent the law that set the debt ceiling.

title: Convicted in Child's Death, Man Is Held in a New Assault
description: A Brooklyn man who spent 16 months in prison for killing a baby in 1985 was in custody yesterday on charges that he fractured the skull of a roommate's 5-month-old son, the police said.

title: Devils Get Zezel From Blues
description: Fans of the Devils have been looking for General Manager Lou Lamoriello to make a trade for an established center, someone of the caliber of the Boston Bruins' Adam Oates or the Toronto Maple Leafs' Doug Gilmour. For the time being, Devils followers will have to settle for Peter Zezel.

title: Blame the Fads
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor Prescott, 50, a TV News Producer
description: Eleanor Prescott, a producer for ABC News, died on Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 50 and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Halogen Lamps Burn Bright Despite Yale Ban Over Safety
description: When students spot fire inspectors in the cloistered courtyards of Yale University's dormitories, the warning spreads frantically via telephone, E-mail and hasty banging on walls: Hide your halogen lamps or suffer the consequences.

title: Rich and Famous and Remembering to Help Those Who Aren't
description: In the days after the death of her husband last month, Leona Helmsley talked with some of her associates about becoming more active in charitable giving as she inherited a $1.7 billion estate. Last week, she made one of her first contributions: a $25,000 gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from the Harry B. Helmsley Foundation.

title: School District In New Jersey Gives Consent On Vouchers
description: This comfortable northern New Jersey suburb waded into one of the hottest controversies in education when it approved a tuition voucher program tonight that would use local tax dollars to allow students to attend private and parochial schools.

title: New York Event: What Is, What's Not
description: New York may be one of the most exciting places to see music. Everything comes here, from Sudanese whirling dervishes to Chinese hard-rock bands. But there is a big difference between what comes to New York and what New York produces on its own: context. It may be one of the most important but least appreciated factors in live music events.

title: Study Disputes Abortion Trauma
description: ABORTION does not trigger lasting emotional trauma in young women who are psychologically healthy before they become pregnant, an eight-year study of nearly 5,300 women has shown, researchers report. Women who are in poor shape emotionally after an abortion are likely to have been feeling bad about their lives before terminating their pregnancies, the study found.

title: Offering Low Rent To Lure High Tech
description: In the latest attempt to lure small high-technology ventures to the old, underused office towers in lower Manhattan, six buildings will set aside low-rent space in a marketing campaign announced yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Diet-Diabetes Link Reported
description: PEOPLE who eat lots of potatoes, white bread and white rice in the mistaken belief that it is the best way to follow a low-fat diet may be doing themselves more harm than good. A steady diet of such foods may actually be a recipe for diabetes, according to a study by Harvard researchers being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Israel Frees 30 Arab Women In Long-Delayed Peace Move
description: After more than a year of delays and a day of last-minute legal challenges, Israel freed 30 Palestinian women from prison tonight as part of its accords with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Time Warner Sees Profits Rise by 79%
description: Time Warner Inc. reported a 79 percent rise in profit yesterday, and said it was determined to improve cash flow in an effort to pay off its $18 billion in debt to provide more financial flexibility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNICLE, WILLIAM J.
description: BARNICLE-William J., 56, of Monmouth Beach, N.J., on Feb. 10. Husband of Christine Grossman Barnicle. Son of Agnes Barnicle. Sister of S. Elizabeth Barnicle. Funeral 10AM, Friday, the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35, Wall, NJ. Mass 11 AM, St. Denis RCC, Manasquan. Entombment St. Catharine's Cemetery, Sea Girt. Visiting Wed. 7-9 and Thur. 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOFF, HAROLD
description: ROOFF-Harold. Beloved husband of the late Frances, devoted father of Karen Allison, dear brother of Gladys Koch, loving uncle of Mitchell Koch, B'rak Ilana, Eileen Previll, Stuart Gerstein and Alan Gerstein. Services Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, N.J., Wednesday, 11 A.M. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: Coleman Names New Chairman
description: The Coleman Company named Jerry Levin, who engineered Revlon Inc.'s turnaround, as its new chairman today, as the maker of camping equipment predicted a wider-than-expected fourth-quarter loss.

title: MEDIQ TO ABSORB RIVAL IN $138 MILLION DEAL
description: Mediq Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival medical equipment maker, Universal Hospital Services Inc., for $17.50 a share. Mediq, based in Pennsauken, N.J., put the total value of the transaction, including the assumption of debt, at about $138 million. Universal Hospital Services' stock jumped $4.375, to $16.75. Mediq's stock rose 18.75 cents, to $7.125. Universal Hospital Services, based in Bloomington, Minn., had revenue of $60 million in the year ended Sept. 30, while Mediq had revenue of $136 million.

title: Rodman Upstaged By Jordan
description: Bulls 103, Hornets 100

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, NANCY
description: LEVEY-Nancy. Wife of Marc. Mother of Jamie, Randi and Greg. Sister of Sue Hochberg. Daughter of Manny Thebner. After a long illness. A woman of great courage and beauty. She will be missed by all. Donations may be made to Terrance Cardinal Cooke, HCCHD Unit, 1249 Fifth Avenue, NYC 10029. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30 AM, Thursday.

title: Wine Talk
description: LAST week, this column talked about how, more and more, wines are being identified by the grapes from which they are made, like chardonnay and merlot, rather than by the place from which they come, like Chateau Latour or Beaujolais.

title: Bronx Haven Fears the Price Of Progress
description: ED YAKER never left the old neighborhood. He still lives in the Amalgamated Houses, a pioneering worker's cooperative in the northwest Bronx. He grew up on stories about the buildings' heyday, when hallways and living rooms buzzed with political debate.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Portland Readers Carry the Library's Books Back Home
description: About 1,000 volunteers converged on the granite steps of the main library here this morning, spending a cold drizzly day transporting books across downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, SOPHIE
description: RUBIN-Sophie. On February 10, 1997. Wonderful wife of David. Devoted mother of Linda and Martin. Proud grandmother of Heather, Benjamyne, Heidi, Ken, Rebecca and the late Christopher. Dear sister of Faye, Sidney and the late Izzy and Herman. Also survived by many wonderful friends and relatives. Services Thursday, 10:15AM, Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Epwy, Queens.

title: A Wildcat Who Loves to Be Pushed
description: Turn on the lights. Turn up the pressure. That is what seems to make Ron Mercer's blood boil.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: 'English Patient' Leads Oscar Nominees
description: Tom Cruise, the star of ''Jerry Maguire,'' got the call on a movie set near London. from his wife, Nicole Kidman. ''You're nominated!'' she screamed. Scott Hicks, the Australian creator of ''Shine,'' heard about his nomination while sitting in his office surrounded by friends in Adelaide. ''I'm speechless, but I can't stop talking,'' he said.

title: Bear Stearns Is Negotiating For Space in Proposed Tower
description: Bear Stearns & Company, the investment bank that has crisscrossed Manhattan for the last three years looking for a new home, is considering moving to a proposed 55-story tower on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: The Right Move at Adelphi
description: Adelphi University got the fresh start it needed on Monday when the New York State Board of Regents removed 18 of the school's 19 trustees for dereliction of duty. The Regents ruled that the trustees had tolerated deals that improperly benefited two of the ousted board members, had overpaid Adelphi's president, Peter Diamandopoulos, and had failed to evaluate his performance even though Adelphi suffered a crippling decline in enrollment and a damaged reputation.

title: Jeans Maker To Streamline Operations
description: The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee and Wrangler jeans, said yesterday that it would combine its 17 businesses into 5 as part of a streamlining expected to cut costs by $150 million a year.

title: Ecuadorean Is Again Elected Interim President, Five Days Later
description: The President of Congress was elected Interim President of the nation tonight for the second time in a week -- this time after some intensive maneuvering intended to keep him in the job.

title: Stocks Rebound After Early Selloff in Technology Sector
description: Stock prices rebounded late yesterday, despite an early selloff in the technology sector in what was yet another demonstration of the market's continued resilience.

title: Reuters Posts 17% Gain In Profit but Stock Falls
description: Reuters Holdings, the international news agency and financial information provider, reported a 17 percent gain in 1996 pretax profit yesterday, but its stock fell on concern about future earnings growth. Pretax profit for the year was $:701 million ($1.15 billion), up from $:599 million a year ago.

title: Matchmaker for Lonely Heart Opponents of 'New World Order'
description: In big-city lonely hearts columns, an NSSWM can often be found seeking a similarly nonsmoking single white female. But here on the plains of eastern Colorado, the Patriot Matchmaker features a novel preference in its personal advertisements: awareness of the ''NWO.''

title: Gretzky Aims to Regain His Goal-Scoring Touch
description: Midway through acknowledging today that his career-high 17-game goal-scoring drought is ''wearing on me,'' Wayne Gretzky thought of a possible bright side to his problem.

title: Bad News and Good News As Islanders Salvage a Tie
description: There are two ways the Islanders can look at tonight's 5-5 tie with the Ottawa Senators at Nassau Coliseum.

title: School Leadership Turnover Provides Opening for Crew
description: At least 12 of New York City's 32 community school districts are seeking new superintendents for the coming school year, raising the prospect of the highest turnover in district leadership in more than 25 years.

title: Sticks to the Ribs, Not to the Spoon
description: The thought of pork and beans may conjure up memories of cans of reddish brown beans in a sweet thick sauce, but this recipe bears no relation to the slow-cooked baked beans from those cans or the ovens of old New England.

title: Few Obstacles Stand in Eldredge's Way
description: A year ago, when opportunities were as plentiful as sequins, Todd Eldredge took the money instead of taking sufficient time to train before the national figure skating championships.

title: Panel Delays Vote on Pena Nomination
description: The Senate Energy Committee postponed a vote today on the nomination of Federico F. Pena to be Energy Secretary, saying that it wanted to study new questions that had been raised about his treatment of a minority business while he was Transportation Secretary.

title: More Delays In Hearings To Confirm C.I.A. Chief
description: Determined to delay or derail Anthony Lake's confirmation as Director of Central Intelligence, the chairman of the Senate intelligence committee once again postponed public hearings today on Mr. Lake's nomination.

title: Edwards Emerges From Nets' Rubble
description: It was like a successful archeological dig, with the Nets uncovering something thought to be lost, something a little crusted, something to stare at and figure out what it was. It was Kevin Edwards.

title: District's University Struggles to Survive
description: The University of the District of Columbia opened its doors 20 years ago as the only land-grant institution of higher education serving the nation's capital, and one of just a few in the country supported by a city.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUSFELD, DAVID
description: FUSFELD-David. You left me four years ago. I miss you. Wait for me. Sylvia

title: Coffee Prices Jump as Strike In Colombia May Cut Exports
description: Coffee prices jumped yesterday as a strike in Colombia began, threatening to delay exports from the world's second-largest grower.

title: Murder Trial Begins for Former Soldier
description: Spinning a tale of what they characterized as ''pure, unmitigated evil,'' prosecutors began their effort today to win death penalty convictions of a pair of former Army privates who are charged with randomly killing a black couple on a dark Fayetteville street in December 1995.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: St. John's

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLON, JOSEPH
description: POLON-Joseph. Beloved husband of the late Judith. Devoted father of Marion Polon-Fogliano. Cherished grandfather of Rachel Fornal and Seth Rogin. Dear uncle of Gail Siegel. Services Thursday, 10 A.M., at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: China Reported Ready to End Some Barriers
description: China has quietly told American officials that it is willing to abandon many of its largest trade barriers, including some of the laws that protect state-run and military-run industries from foreign competition, in return for membership in the World Trade Organization, according to senior Administration officials.

title: 100 at Diner Get Poisoning
description: More than 100 people reported symptoms of salmonella poisoning after eating corned beef at Harold's New York Deli in Parsippany on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, and 11 of them have been hospitalized, state officials said yesterday. Health officials learned of the outbreak last week, and recommended the temporary closing of the deli after more than half of the food handlers at the restaurant tested positive for salmonella, said Dana E. Sullivan, a spokesman for the State Department of Health and Senior Services. Salmonella bacteria can be spread by food that is undercooked.

title: Dreams, Symbols and a Magic Bird, in Paris
description: An appointment with ''Pelleas et Melisande'' has been waiting a while for Robert Wilson, and his arrival at the task comes with a sense not only of inevitability but also of fatigue.

title: Clinton Seems to Keep Running Though the Race Is Run and Won
description: Last year, President Clinton waged a campaign that looked like government, announcing initiatives at his political rallies and virtually never mentioning his opponent. Now, with his last election behind him, Mr. Clinton is running the White House in a manner that looks like a campaign.

title: Parcells Arrives With a Plan, And Very Early
description: Bill Parcells arrived at the Jets' complex before 7 A.M. today and began the daunting process of turning a laughingstock into a contender. He came equipped with his attitude, his swagger and his shrewd ability to get players to perform. The only thing he didn't bring was a prediction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, SYLVIA
description: GREEN-Sylvia. We will miss your warmth, caring and humor for the rest of our lives. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Jean and Jerry

title: And as Himself ...
description: You might think Edward M. Kennedy has had his fill of klieg lights, cameras and the other slings and arrows of celebrity. But the Senator from Massachusetts readily agreed to play himself next week in Monday's episode of the CBS drama ''Chicago Hope.'' He even insisted on writing his own lines.

title: The G.O.P.'s Bitter Pill
description: In the months since American women deserted the Republican Party at the polls, G.O.P. leaders have dismissed the gender gap as merely a matter of packaging, not substance. Republicans failed ''to communicate effectively to women'' was the departing party chairman Haley Barbour's rationale for the debacle. If only G.O.P. candidates hadn't sounded like accountants, if only they hadn't talked of killing the Department of Education, then moderate women would have found them as kind and gentle as Mister Rogers.

title: Associates Say Dinkins Won't Enter Mayoral Race
description: Ending two weeks of early turmoil in New York's mayoral campaign, David N. Dinkins has told associates that he will not challenge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani this year and will instead lend his support to one of the Democrats who have already declared their interest in running for Mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENHORN, LAURA M.
description: ELLENHORN-Laura M. Age 83. Beloved wife of Henry. Mother of Jane and son-in-law Ken, David and daughter-in-law Glenda, sister of Ruth. Grandmother of Marc, Jim, Ruth, Katie and Adam and great-grandmother of three greatgrandchildren. Service will be held today, February 12, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street at 11 A.M. Contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society or the Janssen Hospice Program, Tuckahoe, New York.

title: Peru and Rebels Open Talks to End the Siege
description: The Peruvian Government and Marxist guerrillas began today what they called preliminary negotiations to end the 55-day hostage siege at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, REVEREND JAMES E. CSP
description: JOYCE-Reverend James E. CSP. Age 90, on February 11, 1997 in Vero Beach, FL. A native of Portland, ME, Fr Joyce was ordained a Paulist priest on 2/24/38 at St. Paul the Apostle Church in New York City. Through the years he ministered in Paulist parishes in Toronto, Canada; Chicago, Boston, Baltimore and San Francisco. A veteran of WWII, he served as a Chaplain in the U.S. Navy. Visitation on Thursday, 2/13 at the Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach; 2-4 and 6-8. Funeral Mass will be on Fri at St. Helen's Church, Vero Beach at 11 am. On Mon, Feb 17 at 11 am, there will be a Mass at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Portland. Interment will follow at Calvary Cemetery in So Portland, Maine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROWBRIDGE, ANN L.
description: TROWBRIDGE-Ann L., age 91, of Farmington, CT., and previously South Woodstock, VT.; married for 57 years to the late Lewis S. Trowbridge; survived by sons Charles L., of Stamford, CT., Robert L. of Glastonbury, CT., and daughter Phyllis J. Trowbridge of Farmington CT, as well as 10 grandchildren and two great grandchildren; a devoted wife, mother, and grandmother; a talented artist and musician and an enthusiastic partaker of life. Services will be private.

title: Westinghouse Results Hurt By CBS Loss
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit from continuing operations declined 17 percent as an operating loss at its CBS television network offset stronger results at the company's television and radio stations.

title: Nominated to Federal Bench
description: Katherine Sweeney Hayden, a Superior Court Judge in Essex County since 1991, was nominated for a Federal judgeship yesterday by United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Keep on talking, Joan. JOAN RIVERS, the comedian known for her salutation ''Can we talk,'' will in fact hold forth for two hours every weekday at 7 P.M. on WOR radio, 710 AM, and the national WOR Radio Network, starting on March 3.

title: Yanks and Williams Are Getting Closer
description: The Yankees have just about conceded to Bernie Williams in the arbitration negotiations with their star center fielder, but there is still no deal.

title: Douglas at 255 For Ryan Bout
description: James (Buster) Douglas and Dickie Ryan, who meet in a 10-round heavyweight fight tonight in the Theater at Madison Square Garden, have one credit in common. Both have knocked out Mike Tyson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RUTH
description: FRIEDMAN-Ruth. Friends of Yeshivat Sha'alvim extends sincerest expressions of sympathy and condolences to our devoted Vice President of our Board of Governors, Dr. Ira Friedman and Erika upon the loss of his dear mother, Ruth. Also to the grandchildren, our alumnus, Dr. Richard and Joann. May the Almighty comfort you among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Updated Diner Food In Eclectic Decor
description: Tom Douglas's newest venture, Palace Kitchen, is the restaurant this chef has always dreamed of owning.

title: Arranging Sneak Previews
description: In an unusual agreement, Henry Holt, the publishing house, and Redeemable Features, a New York-based independent film company, have agreed to grant each other sneak peeks at what the other is working on at the early stages of the creative process.

title: Lilco Didn't Get 'Sweet Deal' on Shoreham
description: To the Editor:

title: APPLIED MATERIALS' EARNINGS BETTER THAN EXPECTED
description: Shares of Applied Materials Inc. surged in after-hours trading yesterday after the company posted first-quarter earnings that were not as weak as expected. Applied shares rose to $47.50, after closing on the Nasdaq market at $45.125. The company, the world's largest maker of chip-manufacturing equipment, said after the stock market closed that it had earned $29.6 million, or 16 cents a share, in the period ended Jan. 26, down from $171.6 million, or 93 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Excluding a $59.5 million extraordinary charge, the company earned $89.1 million, or 48 cents a share, surpassing analyst estimates of 44 cents a share. Applied Materials, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has had weaker earnings as chip makers scaled back plans to build plants last year in light of falling prices and weak demand.

title: Corrections
description: A list of newly appointed trustees of Adelphi University yesterday misspelled the given name of the president of Richard Stockton College in some copies. She is Vera King Farris, not Nera.

title: Singapore Grows More Than Forecast
description: Singapore's economy grew at a faster-than-expected rate of 5.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996. The acceleration brought growth for the year to 7 percent, an upward revision from a rise of 6.5 percent announced at the end of December.

title: Deadly Ratings
description: NBC's movie about a Texas murder case provoked a huge national reaction, most of it negative. But it did not attract an especially big audience on Monday night.

title: Poetry for the People
description: Passengers on Amtrak today will find a freebie: paperback copies of ''Great Love Poems'' (Dover Publications, 1992), a compendium of amorous verse by such masters as Andrew Marvell and Edna St. Vincent Millay. On Friday, Valentine's Day, copies will be waiting for jurors at the state's criminal courts in lower Manhattan, and for shoppers at the Lancome counter at Macy's in Herald Square.

title: Bulgaria's Socialists Block Change for Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Simpson, Assets Protected Briefly, Says Case 'Is Far From Over'
description: Told by a jury to pay a daunting total of $33.5 million in damages to the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman, O. J. Simpson found temporary refuge today behind an order by Judge Hiroshi Fujisaki that the families delay all collection efforts for 10 days while the judge reviews the huge award and the many defense motions certain to follow.

For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors.

title: Jerome Namias, Weather Forecast Expert, Dies at 86
description: Jerome Namias, an influential meteorological researcher who pioneered extended weather forecasts in the United States, died on Monday at the Scripps Torrey Pines Convalescent Hospital in San Diego. He was 86.

title: Elite Schools See Numbers Of Applicants Leveling Off
description: After zooming to record highs last year, applications to many of the nation's most competitive colleges and universities are tapering off. But it is a development that college admissions officers say is not surprising.

title: Big Losses and Bad Accounting Leave 'Subprime' Lenders Reeling
description: The business of lending money to the millions of Americans with tarnished credit ratings -- or none at all -- has always been a walk on capitalism's wild side.

title: Keeping the Atom Bomb From Hitler
description: BLOOD AND WATER

title: A Lack of Volunteers Thwarts Research on Prostate Cancer
description: It is one of the most important medical problems facing men over 55: what is the best way to treat early prostate cancer, the second leading cause of cancer death in men?

title: George Brampton Koelle, 78, Pharmacological Researcher
description: Dr. George Brampton Koelle, a pharmacological sleuth who spent more than 50 years unraveling secrets of the synapses, died on Feb. 1 at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center in Philadelphia. He was 78 and lived in Swarthmore, Pa.

title: Panel to Recommend Steps For Cutting Air Crash Rate
description: Two years after the Transportation Secretary proclaimed a goal of eliminating airline accidents, a White House commission, in a report to be released on Wednesday, will set a goal that experts believe is more realistic: cutting the rate by 80 percent.

title: State's Highest Court Issues Strict New Standards in Product-Liability Cases
description: New York State's highest court today established a strict new standard for filing product-liability lawsuits against manufacturers of toxic substances, a ruling that could significantly reduce the number of such cases.

title: Chocolate Maker's New Temptations
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Chantal Coady became so disenchanted with the chocolate department at Harrods, where she was working as a part-time salesclerk, that she dropped out of art school, spent a semester taking business courses, then opened a chocolate shop of her own, Rococo.

title: The Hot Zones
description: There is a concern that as globalization knits countries and markets together it will flatten cultural differences, as we're all forced to drink Coke, eat Big Macs and compute on Windows 95. In some ways, this is happening. But in other ways a country's distinct political and economic culture actually becomes more important in this brave new world.

title: Jets' Bus No Longer Wayward
description: IN a reversal of transportation technology, Bill Parcells wants the Jets to resemble a bus.

title: New York City Removes Staff at Women's Shelter
description: The entire staff of the only shelter for battered women run directly by New York City was replaced yesterday after investigators found that workers there had sex with the women, used drugs and alcohol on the job and allowed abusive husbands and boyfriends into the shelter at night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths
description: CAREY-Edith S., age 91, of Westhampton Beach, Long Island, passed away Feb. 4, 1997 following an accident in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Thomas I. Carey, D.D.S. She is survived by daughter, Patricia A. Ryan, of Rye, NY, son, Anthony W. Graziano, Jr. of Richmond, IN., and Thomas Carey, Jr, of Milford, CT. Beloved grandchildren: Elizabeth C. Moran, William F. Moran, Robin Virginia Graziano, Anthony W. Graziano III, Michelle, Megan & Michael Carey, and great grandchildren: Megan, Brian, and Colin Moran. A truly extraordinary woman of elegance and grace will be missed forever. The wake will be held on Friday, February 14 from 4-6 P.M., at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Rd., Westhampton Beach. The Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at the Immaculate Conception RC Church, Westhampton Beach at 10 A.M., on Saturday, February 15, 1997. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, New York 11792 or the Charity of your choice.

title: U.N. Aide Left Legacy Of Asia Role On Rights
description: When Chim-Chan Sastra's coffin returns on Wednesday from Rwanda, he will have repaid what he saw as a debt of honor to the world.

title: Darken the TV, Douse the Phone And Dally Over a Feast of Love
description: LOVE is such a delicate concoction, an ephemeral blend of illusion and reality. It must be conjured up and cajoled -- it cannot be forced. And it can be messy.

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief sports article on Feb. 1 reported an arbitration ruling in a dispute between the National Basketball Association players' union and its former leader, Simon Gourdine. Mr. Gourdine contended that he was unfairly dismissed last year, and a three-member panel ordered the union to pay $883,738 for his remaining salary plus interest.

title: Barbarity Under a Blood-Red Moon
description: ''Wozzeck'' sends the same subliminal message to virtually everyone who puts it on the stage. It is the idea of darkness from which points of light are trying to escape. The Mark Lamos production that opened at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night reconstitutes this picture with towering mouse-gray monoliths and support beams. Marie's bedroom, meagerly lighted, literally cowers beneath them.

title: Caldor, in 700-Job Trim, Says It Will Close 2 Stores
description: In a setback to neighborhood redevelopment efforts, Caldor Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest discount department store, announced yesterday that it was closing one store in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx as part of its continuing effort to climb out of bankruptcy proceedings.

description: The king of dog shows, the Westminster Kennel Club show, crowned its king of canines at Madison Square Garden: Ch. title: Little Change In Treasuries At Auction
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, as a sale of new three-year notes largely matched expectations. With two more Treasury auctions this week, however, market participants were reluctant to buy.

description: IAN TYSON walked through the door of the Star, a Basque boardinghouse and restaurant. In a cowboy hat and winter ranch coat, he cut a classic Western figure silhouetted by the noon light.

title: Russian Politician Sues U.S. Magazine for Libel
description: The man who is one of the Russia's richest businessmen and stormiest politicians filed a libel suit against Forbes magazine today, saying the magazine defamed him by linking him to shady business deals and the murder of a leading journalist.

description: LEVINE-Irving. Friends of over thirty years will never be forgotten. You will always be remembered for your integrity, knowledge and fortitude. The respect all of us have for you is a deep and lasting one. David Savitt Pace Press, Inc.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Tuesday about a concert in tribute to the late composer Toru Takemitsu misstated the presenter. It was Music From Japan, not the Japan Society.

title: Thrill of Cupid's Victory and the Agony of Conceit
description: Like Halloween, Valentine's Day has been whipped up from what was once a fairly modest occasion into a huge money-making souffle. Business is humming with sales of everything from greeting cards and chocolates to silk boxer shorts and, for the unapologetically conspicuous, multi-thousand-dollar baubles at swank jewelry stores. Television, of course, always alert to the prospect of a ratings blip, is sprinkling Valentine tie-ins all over this week's schedule.

title: Police Chief Retiring
description: Police Chief Charles Pascale, who was found liable in 1993 for sexually harassing the department's first female officer, will retire May 1, officials said yesterday.

title: Orange Juice Hits 4-Year Low; Crude Oil Slips as Stocks Rise
description: Orange juice futures prices sank yesterday to their lowest level in four years after the Government said a freeze last month would not reduce a record Florida orange crop.
