title: Bar Group Calls Screening For Judges Too Political
description: The City Bar Association has issued a double-barreled report saying that a judicial screening panel established by Gov. George E. Pataki gives the appearance that political influence affects the selection of many judges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILO, MARIUS
description: PILO-Marius. Age 91. On February 11, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Esther Pilo (nee Amir). Devoted father and father-in-law of Marvin and Jackie Pilo, of West Hartford, CT.; loving grandfather of their children, Elissa and Michael Pilo. Born in Salonika, Greece in 1905, he came to New York in 1920 where he lived for 77 years. He became an attorney in 1928 and practiced law continuously for 59 years until his retirement in 1987. He was an active leader in numerous Jewish and Sephardic causes, especially State of Israel Bonds, the Sephardic Jewish Center (originally of the Bronx, now of Forest Hills) and the Sephardic Jewish Brotherhood of America, Inc. where, among other capacities, he served 4 terms as its president. He will be sorely missed and remembered with love and admiration by all who knew, loved and respected him. Services Thursday, February 13 at 12:30pm at the Sephardic Jewish Center of Forest Hills, 67-67 108 St., Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: The Ebbing Hudson River Park
description: The edge of Manhattan along the Hudson River may be one of the most precious strips of land in the nation. Ever since the Manhattan waterfront became moribund, New Yorkers have dreamed about its potential for open parkland and recreational use. But that promise is slipping away.

title: Yawn. A global-warming alert. But this one has solutions.
description: STERNLY worded petitions and ringing screeds of principle are as much a part of campus life as grade inflation -- which is why Washington rarely takes them seriously. But the nation's movers and shakers would do well to pay attention to a statement on global warming by some 2,000 mostly academic economists.

title: Clinton Clears U.S. Media To Set Up Cuba Bureaus
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would allow American news organizations to open bureaus in Cuba for the first time in nearly 30 years, hoping that the presence of a foreign corps of journalists will increase diplomatic and political pressure on the Communist Government of Fidel Castro.

title: Megabite, Anyone? This Cybercafe Is Kosher
description: First, there was the cybercafe. Now, the kosher cybercafe.

title: No Headline
description: ''I wish the Cat to go on indefinitely, as a literary cat, not a cartoon cat. The alternative was to kill it.''

title: Train Kills Homeless Man
description: A homeless man was killed Tuesday night after he lay down in front of a New Jersey Transit train and ignored repeated warning whistles, officials said.

title: A Rescue Plan For a Mansion Dying of Neglect
description: IN 1931, Villa Cavrois, a low-slung, yellow-brick mansion in Croix, a suburb of the French city of Lille, was heralded as the masterpiece of Robert Mallet-Stevens, an architect who built extravagant Cubist follies for avant-garde aristocrats. Today, humbled by graffiti and rust, it looks like an abandoned factory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGIDSON, RUTH (NEE DAHUT)
description: MAGIDSON-Ruth (nee Dahut). Died peacefully February 11, 1997, of Stanford, CT, formerly of Lake Worth, FL., and Washington, D.C. Beloved wife of the late Adolph. Cherished mother of Jane Magidson of New York City & Marjorie & Stephen Rosenthal of Harrison, NY. Loving grandmother of Eric, Daniel and Jeffrey Rosenthal. Dear sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt. A service will be held Friday, February 14, 10:30 A.M., at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave., Rye, New York. Interment in Sharon Gardens Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Hadassah Children's Pavilion, C/O Mrs. Fran Buchin, 557 Covered Bridge Boulevard, Lake Worth, Florida 33467 or the charity of your choice.

title: Microsoft Notified Of Texas Inquiry
description: The Microsoft Corporation, which has fought a series of Federal antitrust investigations, now faces an inquiry by Texas state officials into its Internet products.

title: A Risky Test of Wills
description: With high profits in their industry and stability in the labor force, this should be a comforting time for airline workers who have endured the wrenching effects of airline deregulation for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, IRVING
description: SCHNEIDER-Irving. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Alan and Angel Schneider and Pam Fryer. Adoring grandfather of Nasha, Chandra, Roxanne, Evan and Cheyenne. Graveside services 10AM Friday, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Shares of Polygram Rise As It Meets Expectations
description: The shares of Polygram N.V. rose yesterday after the company, a Dutch entertainment concern that is owned by Philips Electronics N.V., said its 1996 profit had matched expectations, sales had risen and the film unit made its first profit. Polygram's shares rose 5.2 guilders, to 88.5, on the Amsterdam stock exchange.

title: Iona Regroups Just in Time To Inch Past Manhattan
description: Just seconds after the game began, Mindaugas Timinskas fired a long shot that clanged off the rim. The Iona College senior, dubbed by some as the Lithuanian Larry Bird, struggled for most of the next 39 minutes against Manhattan last night in a thriller at Draddy Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENKEL, IRENE GEORGINA GOLDBERGER
description: FRENKEL-Irene Georgina Goldberger, 72, of New York and Easthampton, on February 12, 1997. Wife of the late Dr. David A. Frenkel. Beloved and cherished mother of Michelle Sidrane, Ivy Frenkel Torres, and Karen A. Frenkel. Grandmother of Davida, Andrew and Juliana. Mother-inlaw of Alan Sidrane and Gary Torres. Funeral service Friday, 10 AM at ''Plaza Memorial Chapel'', 91 Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: At Carnival, a Homecoming for Haitians
description: The Carnival in Haiti, which ended Tuesday, was powered by the sort of thrill that comes when large masses of people gather to dance and enjoy themselves; the streets of Port-au-Prince were heavy with the sweet humidity of music and sensuality.

title: Bruce Weber's Pictures of Home (Who Says He's No Homebody?)
description: THE photographer Bruce Weber said that when Chris Isaak, the singer, was a child growing up in Southern California, his mother once turned on the air-conditioning and huddled her children before a roaring fire. ''For one day, we're going to pretend it's winter,'' Mrs. Isaak explained to her bewildered husband.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEW, ERNA (NEE OPPENHEIMER)
description: LOEW-Erna (nee Oppenheimer). Beloved wife of the late Semmy Loew and Willy Eichenwald. Devoted mother of the late Dieter and Klaus, much loved and admired Auntie Erna to cousins, family and friends. Interment private. Donations in her memory to the Anne Frank Center U.S.A., 584 Broadway, NY or your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISNER, IRIS STAR
description: EISNER-Iris Star. I'll see you again whenever Spring breaks through again. Happy birthday sweetheart. Love, Bill

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about commercial airliners' encounters with military F-16 jets misstated the distance covered by a Nations Air 727 during a rapid evasive maneuver off New Jersey on Feb. 5. It was 60 miles, not 6.

title: Football's Wheel Of Fortune
description: TRAINING camp doesn't begin for another five months, but the Jets and Giants are already engaged in full contact, of sorts.

title: What U.S. Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Physicians in Labor Union? H.M.O. Doctors Make Move
description: At first glance, it may seem nonsensical for doctors who own their health maintenance organization to join a labor union.

title: Mixing It Up With Disco
description: Stanley Love has chosen to blend disco dancing and music with traditional modern-dance techniques. He is also one of most exuberantly irrepressible of publicly gay artists. For those reasons and because of several solid past works, the program presented by the Stanley Love Performance Group on Saturday night at Performance Space 122 was a disappointment.

title: A New Message at the Citadel
description: The recent resignation of two of the four female cadets at the Citadel, and their allegations of potentially criminal hazing and sexual harassment, dramatized the resistance to gender integration within the previously all-male, state-supported military college. But with the appointment of retired Army Brig. Gen. Emory Mace as its acting commandant of cadets, the South Carolina institution's leadership signaled its commitment to change.

title: With Help, Strength to Face the World
description: On a cold winter night six years ago, Mary Martinez was overcome with fear as she raced to the hospital with her son Justin. He was only 2 and experiencing his second seizure, this one even more severe than the first frightening incident a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUKERMAN, CHARLES
description: ZUKERMAN-Charles, 88, of Pompano Beach, February 12, 1997, a real estate developer and inventor. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude. Loving mother of Michael and Howard (Andrea) Zukerman. Adored grandmother of Steven, Amy, Marc, Jodi, Jaclyn and Laura. Dear brother of Sidney (Ada), Herman (Martha) Zukerman and Sylvia Bernadette. Funeral services Friday, February 14, 1997, noon, at ''The Riverside'', Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York.

title: EUROPE POSTPONES CHALLENGE TO U.S. ON HAVANA TRADE
description: In a last-minute effort to avoid a major breach with the United States that could threaten the future of the World Trade Organization, Europe postponed today its legal challenge to American sanctions against companies doing business in Cuba.

title: Mexican Court Releases Woman in Assault Case
description: Ruling in a case that became a highly publicized feminist cause, a judge has freed a woman imprisoned for having killed a man who was trying to rape her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, JAY B.
description: BARON-Jay B. On February 12, 1997. Passed away peacefully at age 70. Survived by beloved sister, Ellen Ritt, dear companion Patricia Wild and her family, and by many friends and former business colleagues. Also survived by his friend, Owasco. Beloved son of the late Julia and Lawrence Baron. Service on Friday, at 12 noon, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment in Salem Fields Cemetery.

title: F.B.I. Finds Cache of Weapons In Superintendent's Apartment
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents uncovered a small cache of plastic explosives, rifles and bomb-making ingredients early yesterday morning when they raided a building superintendent's apartment in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: GTE Dismisses Its Ad Agency; Hires Shop Linked to Nynex
description: The GTE Corporation yesterday ended a five-month review on its advertising account, with billings estimated at $80 million, by dismissing the longtime incumbent agency and hiring a shop that works for a competitor, the Nynex Corporation.

title: Secular Turks Alarmed by Resurgence of Religion
description: Scenes that unfolded in this working-class suburb of Ankara over the last few days have stunned millions of Turks who want to believe that their country, even though it is now governed by an Islamist Prime Minister, will remain a secular democracy.

title: Pay for Needed Skills
description: To The Home Section:

title: Park Officer Wounded
description: The police cordoned off a neighborhood and surrounded a house where they believed gunmen who had wounded a park police officer were holed up yesterday, but when officers entered the house the suspects were gone.

title: Prominent Welfare-to-Work Effort Is Off to Slow Start
description: In his State of the Union address last week, President Clinton hailed five giant corporations for their pioneering efforts to put welfare recipients to work. But the limited progress of those companies is evidence of the daunting scope of the project.

title: Secretary Albright Must Embrace Her Past to Shape the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Chief Faces Critics In Arguing Military's Budget
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen today defended President Clinton's military budget against a barrage of criticism from former Senate and House Republican colleagues.

title: Yanks Sign Williams To Pact For 1997
description: The Yankees agreed today to pay Bernie Williams, one of their marquee players, $5.25 million for the 1997 season. So, Williams is happy. The Yankees are happy. Everyone is happy. For now.

description: Yertle the Turtle,

description: To the Editor:

title: West Bank Town Hails Freed Prisoner
description: The stream of visitors to the tidy stone house on a hillside here never let up today.

title: When Money Counts
description: YOU'VE found the right sofa. Now read the store's fine print: the fabric is probably extra.

title: Inspections Needed
description: To The Home Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, JUDITH (RICKI) MARZANI.
description: CUTLER-Judith (Ricki) Marzani. On Feb. 12, 1997. Beloved wife of Jason Cutler, mother of Jennifer Spector and Max Cutler, sister of Tony, Posy and Dan Marzani, stepdaughter of Charlotte Marzani. Private interment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Westchester. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the City College of NY.

title: Royal Navy Shipyard Sold
description: The Halliburton Company said today that its venture Devonport Management Ltd. had agreed to buy the assets and assume future liabilities of the Devonport Royal Dockyard Ltd. in Plymouth England, from the British Ministry of Defense for $66.1 million in cash. The Dallas-based Halliburton is an engineering, construction and energy services company. The dockyard services Royal Navy ships.

title: Harnisch Gearing Up For His Big Assignment
description: The last thing the 1997 Mets need or want is business as usual, especially since business as usual has translated into six consecutive sub-.500 seasons.

title: Federalism, Defined
description: To the Editor:

title: Secretary Albright Must Embrace Her Past to Shape the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Takes Parting Shot, but Won't Run
description: With a 15-minute parting assault on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, David N. Dinkins ended his two-week flirtation with a return to City Hall yesterday, saying he would not run for mayor but would do all he could to help unseat Mr. Giuliani this fall.

title: Even if German TV Doesn't Blush, You Might
description: Thursday evening. 11 P.M. On the national Vox cable television channel, a man dressed as a middle-aged blond woman conducts an earnest debate with a couple whose marriage has lost its zing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, I. LEE
description: BRODY-I. Lee, on Tuesday, February 11, 1997 of Boonton, NJ formerly of Fairlawn, NJ. Loving companion of Anna Terrazzino, devoted father of Robert Brody & Linda Greenberg, dear brother of Zelda Baum and Gayle Jacobs, loving grandfather of Scott, Brian, Lauren, Michael and Caroline. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ on Thursday, February 13, 1997 at 11:30 AM. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union. Memorial contributions may be made to: NY/NJ Phone-TTY Archives Fund, 61 Jefferson St., Metuchen, NJ; Telecommunications for the Deaf, Silver Spring, MD; Central Institute for the Deaf, St. Louis, MO; or the Hebrew Seminary of the Deaf, Skokie, IL.

title: Gain for Abortion Pill
description: The Population Council, the nonprofit group that holds the rights to sell the French abortion pill in the United States, said it had settled the litigation surrounding control of the drug and had arranged for it to be handled by a new company.

title: WAUSAU TO BUY OTIS SPECIALTY PAPERS FOR $58 MILLION
description: The Wausau Paper Mills Company said late on Tuesday that it had tentatively agreed to acquire Otis Specialty Papers, a unit of Rexam P.L.C., for $58 million. Wausau, based in Wausau, Wis., said Otis had 300 employees and an annual capacity of 70,000 tons of technical specialty paper. The proposed acquisition will increase Wausau's technical paper capacity more than 40 percent. Otis, which is based in Jay, Me., is a subsidiary of Rexam Inc., a United States unit of Rexam P.L.C., which is based in London.

title: Challenging the Telephone Merger
description: Attorney General Dennis Vacco of New York surely upset Bell Atlantic and Nynex by opposing their $23 billion merger. He may also have surprised Gov. George Pataki, who would probably rather not offend Nynex, a powerful constituent, or thwart a merger that promises to base itself in New York City. But Mr. Vacco's brief, filed with the Public Service Commission, is a cogent reminder why the merger could harm New Yorkers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, MARY ALICE
description: NORTON-Mary Alice. Formerly of Yonkers and NYC. Beloved wife of the late J. Francis. Dear mother of Mary Ann Gehan. Sister of Eleanor W. O'Malley. Grandmother of four. Reposing Flower Funeral Home, 714 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers on Friday 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral and religious services 10:15 Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, IVAN G., SR.
description: OWEN-Ivan G., Sr., husband of Susan (Battey) Owen, of 48 Meadow Avenue, Weekapaug, RI. Memorial Services will be held in the Dunn's Corners Community Church Presbyterian, 221 Post Road, Westerly, RI 02891 at 11:00 AM. Donations: Dunns Corners Community Church or to Weekapaug Chapel Society, c/o Rev. Alexander Ogilby, 42 Meadow Avenue, Weekapaug, RI 02891.

title: Putting an Era to Rest, Very, Very Slowly
description: There are evidently several ways to take ''Palestrina,'' the 1917 Hans Pfitzner opera that Covent Garden has revived and will take to the Met in this summer's Lincoln Center Festival. For some people, it is the final magnificent sunset of German Romanticism, and given that its admirers have included Thomas Mann, this is a viewpoint one has to respect if not remotely understand. Unbelievers are more likely to find it four and a half hours of gentle tedium.

title: Beware the Princelings
description: The 4,000 tai zi dang ''princelings,'' the corrupt capitalist offspring of China's aging Communist rulers -- were gratified last February when one of their notorious members bought his way into a ''coffee'' chat with the President of the U.S.

title: Tyson Set to Join Ameritech Board
description: The Ameritech Corporation plans to announce today that it expects its newest board member to be Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former top White House economic adviser.

title: Jets Waive Lowery and Young
description: On his second full day as the Jets' coach, Bill Parcells started reshaping his roster yesterday. Parcells cut two longtime veterans, kicker Nick Lowery and safety Lonnie Young.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLER, FRANKLIN
description: STOLER-Franklin. On February 12, 1997. Beloved son of Sam. Cherished brother of Ivan and Adam. Services Friday, 10:30AM, ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, EDITH S.
description: CAREY-Edith S., age 91, of Westhampton Beach, Long Island, passed away Feb. 4, 1997 following an accident in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Thomas I. Carey, D.D.S. She is survived by daughter, Patricia A. Ryan, of Rye, NY, son, Anthony W. Graziano, Jr. of Richmond, IN., and Thomas Carey, Jr, of Milford, CT. Beloved grandchildren: Elizabeth C. Moran, William F. Moran, Robin Virginia Graziano, Anthony W. Graziano III, Michelle, Megan & Michael Carey, and great grandchildren: Megan, Brian, and Colin Moran. A truly extraordinary woman of elegance and grace will be missed forever. The wake will be held on Friday, February 14 from 4-6 P.M., at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Rd., Westhampton Beach. The Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at the Immaculate Conception RC Church, Westhampton Beach at 10 A.M., on Saturday, February 15, 1997. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, New York 11792 or the Charity of your choice.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Thomas B. Stoddard, 48, Legal Advocate of Gay Rights
description: Thomas B. Stoddard, a lawyer whose persuasiveness and erudition advanced the cause of equal rights for gay men, lesbians and people with AIDS, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVICI, PASCAL, JR.
description: COVICI-Pascal, Jr. Of Dallas, TX, formerly of New York, died Feb. 9, survived by wife of forty-five years Joan Fortescue Covici; daughter Anna Covici Propp; son John and two grandsons. Born Sept. 2, 1930, son of late Pascal and Dorothy Soll Covici. Graduate of Harvard University, author of numerous books, scholarly articles, and a specialist in American literature. He spent his entire career at SMU where he was head of the English Dept. (1975-1979) & held the E.A. Lilly Professorship in American Literature. Memorial services to be held at SMU next month. Memorials to the Pascal Covici Prize in American Literature at SMU will be appreciated.

title: SEARS PLANS TO DOUBLE NUMBER OF STORES BY 2000
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it planned to open many more department and specialty stores in the next few years. Sears expects to have 860 department stores by 2000, up from 800 now. It also plans to expand its credit-card operations, services businesses and specialty chains like auto centers, Homelife furniture stores and hardware shops. In all, Sears expects its number of stores to double by 2000. ''A more aggressive growth strategy is now appropriate,'' Arthur Martinez, Sears' chairman and chief executive, told about 250 analysts and investors at a meeting yesterday in Chicago.

title: Bridge
description: Celebrities are quite often bridge enthusiasts, but virtually none are experts. The only obvious exception is Omar Sharif, who, 35 years after winning an Academy Award nomination for his role in ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' can still take on the world's best players on even terms.

title: Domino's Pizza Narrows Review
description: Domino's Pizza Inc. said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its account, with billings estimated at $75 million, after deciding to divide the account into creative and media assignments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENGROFF, SAMUEL Z.
description: WENGROFF-Samuel Z. February 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Miriam (nee Lake). Loving father of Richard, step-father of Jeffry Wengroff and Linda Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of Robyn and Bryan Wengroff, Howard and Elliot Kaplan. Fond great-grandfather of Steven, Elyssa & Nicole Kaplan. Devoted brother of Frieda and Irving Chait. Family will receive visitors Friday, 9 AM at the Harden Funeral Home of Bayside, Northern Boulevard at 209 Street. Service at 10 A.M. Entombment in Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLANOS, DONALD F.
description: CASTELLANOS-Donald F., on Monday, February 10, 1997 of the Chelsea section of NYC. Devoted brother of Mary Comba, Francis W. and James J. Castellanos; Daniel L. Wollenziehn. Mr. Castellanos was appointed to the New York State Banking Department by then Governor Mario Cuomo. He served the banking department for seven years acting as: Executive Assistant to the Superintendent of Banking, Director of Community Re-Investment and Director of Community Services. Prior to his appointment to the banking department he worked with Chase Manhattan Bank, NYC for twenty-three years. He was active in, and a contributor to, numerous community causes. Mr. Castellanos was an Army veteran of the Vietnam War having received the Good Conduct Medal, the Vietnam Service Medal, the National Defense Service Medal & the Vietnam Campaign Medal. Funeral services will be held Saturday, 8:30 AM from the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Road, Wayne, NJ, then to Holy Cross RC Church, Wayne, NJ, where at 9:30 AM a scripture service will be held. Friends may call Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Interment will be in Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In Texas, former President GEORGE BUSH has had a ballroom, a highway, a gallery of the Pacific war and an elementary school named for him. Yesterday, a medical facility was added to the list: the newly formed President Bush Center for Cardiovascular Health at Hermann in Houston. The center will serve as the hub for cardiovascular services at Hermann Hospital, Hermann Children's Hospital and 43 outpatient clinics in Houston and southeast Texas. The announcement was made at a luncheon at the hospital attended by Mr. Bush and his wife, Barbara, who have been living in Houston since 1993.

title: Escaping From It All At Hotels Amid It All
description: New Yorkers happen to live in a city that has one of the greatest collections of hotels in the world, ranging from ultraluxe to downtown hip. So when the clutter of unpaid bills and dirty dishes becomes too much, it's tempting to escape -- to New York.

title: Earnings Climb 17% At Columbia/HCA
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 17 percent in the fourth quarter as its hospital admissions and surgery cases increased.

title: French Are Right to Question Changing World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, LEWIS
description: JACOBS-Lewis, age 93, on February 11, in Manhasset, L.I. Beloved husband of Lillian Wilentz Jacobs, father of Ellen Freyer Poss and son-in-law Sam, Carol Jacobs Mendez and son-in-law Paul, and devoted grandfather of Caryn Mendez and Jonathan and wife Karen Mendez, Daniel and wife Joanne Freyer and Adam Freyer. Service will be held February 14 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street at 10:45am. Shiva at 211 E. 70th Street, apt 20A, between 1 and 4 P.M., Sunday, February 16.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Whitman's Fiscal Mentor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Jan. 30 about the 1997 International Housewares Show in Chicago referred incompletely to poor sales results last year for Krups appliances in a shade of bright yellow called Sunflower. The products were offered only to retailers, not to consumers.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Jan. 31 about a grant to the Brooklyn Museum from the David Schwartz Foundation misidentified Mr. Schwartz. Mr. Schwartz, who died in 1985, was chairman of Jonathan Logan, a maker of women's apparel. The foundation is run by his son, Richard Schwartz, vice chairman of the New York State Council of the Arts and president of a private investment corporation.

title: U.N. Report Comes Down Hard on Rwandan Genocide Tribunal
description: The United Nations issued a scathing report today on the international criminal tribunal it set up to investigate the 1994 genocide of over half a million Tutsi and Hutu in Rwanda and judge those held responsible. The report concluded that ''not a single administrative area functioned effectively.''

title: 'Underground' Art Video Show
description: THE bowels of Rockefeller Center can seem like a Dantean maze. From Feb. 21 through May, visitors will be stopped in their tracks again, but for a delightful reason: videos from the Museum of Modern Art will be shown on digital screens in the underground concourse of 1251 Avenue of the Americas. The building is owned by Mitsui Fudosan, a Japanese real estate company, and it is sponsoring the installation. The show will feature 14 short films made over the last 29 years. Among the diversions are William Wegman's deadpan dogs, Cecelia Condit's fairy tale about cannibalism in Michigan and Chris Marker's comedy about an elephant swaying to tango music. Information: (212) 302-6386.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISTER, DR. SVEN J.
description: KISTER-Dr. Sven J. The members of the Department of Surgery of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and the Surgical Service of the Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our long term esteemed colleague and friend. He spent all his professional life at our institution and leaves a host of peers, students, patients and friends who benefited from his personal and compassionate care of patients, his respected surgical skills and his loyalty and support of his colleagues. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife Christina, his children Karl, and Karin, his brother Sigurd and his grandchildren Katherine and Elizabeth. Eric A. Rose, MD, Chairman and members of the Dept. of Surgery Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center

title: Secretary Albright Must Embrace Her Past to Shape the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: MAY TO BUY BACK UP TO $300 MILLION IN COMMON STOCK
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $300 million of its common shares. The retailer, based in St. Louis, said the buyback program was coming after a $600 million repurchase program that was announced in August 1996 and was completed last month. May Department Stores has 236.9 million common shares outstanding. The shares closed yesterday at $47, down 50 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange. In addition, May reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 6.8 percent, meeting analysts' expectations.

title: 4 Refuse to Aid Inquiry on Fund Raising
description: Three former members of the Clinton Administration and a Democratic Party fund-raiser have refused to cooperate with a House investigation into improper money-raising for the party, a Congressional committee chairman disclosed today.

title: Judge Allows God's Law To Mix With Alabama's
description: Behind Judge Roy Moore's bench in the Etowah County Circuit Court is an American flag, a Great Seal of Alabama the size of a car tire, and a bookcase filled with law books in neat leather volumes. In any courtroom in the state, it is much the same.

title: Question in New York Trial: How Long Is Arm of the Law?
description: For three months, a 13th-floor courtroom on Centre Street in Manhattan has been the scene of an emotional trial of three members of one family that has received far more attention in Venezuela than it has in New York.

title: World Champions (Except in Japan)
description: In Japanese baseball circles, the Yankees have become ugly Americans.

title: Chief Molds Phone Giant In Bell Atlantic's Image
description: It was the most anxiously awaited memo of the year at Bell Atlantic and Nynex: the announcement of who the top 100 executives would be after the two big regional Bell telephone companies complete their merger in the spring.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : 10-4, Good Buddy:CB Radios Enjoy a Roadway Renaissance
description: A generation after citizens-band radios had millions of people, especially truckers and other drivers, chattering over the airwaves in colorful jargon ("I tried to warn him about that Smokey, but he had peanut butter in his ears"), a revival is under way.

description: There has been talk of the clean-cut, Utah-polite Shawn Bradley doing a milk ad. If so, perhaps it should be for evaporated milk.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BASS, SILVIA
description: BASS-Silvia. You are always in my heart. I will always miss you. I love you. Your loving husband, Kermit

title: Petro Vietnam Rejects Bid by Foreign Partners
description: Vietnam's state-run oil company, Petro Vietnam, has rejected a proposal by a group of companies, including LG Group of South Korea, Petroliam Nasional Berhad (Petronas) of Malaysia and Conoco Inc. to build a $1.43 billion oil refinery in the center of the country. Petro Vietnam's director, Ngo Thuong San, said yesterday that the company would build the refinery without foreign partners.

title: Investors Put $24 Billion In Equity Funds
description: Mutual fund investors demonstrated their lingering enthusiasm for stocks by pouring an estimated $24 billion into equity funds last month, the fourth-largest total on record, a mutual fund trade group reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, CHARLES A.
description: GONZALEZ-Charles A., age 62, on February 11, 1997. Survived by his wife, Phyllis; daughter, Maggie Gile; son and daughter-in-law, Jeffrey and Toni Gile, two granddaughters, Megan and Jordan; three sisters, Mary Savarese, Sylvia Stano, and Helen Gauci; and several nieces and nephews. Visitation at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave., NYC, Sunday, February 16, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Make A Wish Foundation, 382 Main St., Pt. Washington, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABDOO, FREDERICK F.
description: ABDOO-Frederick F., 78, February 9, 1997. Beloved by his family, he is survived by his wife, Helen; three children, Lynda, Jayma, and Brian; daughter-in-law, Geri; and two grandchildren, Keegan and Cora; as well as by four sisters, Mary, Gemile, Freda, and Hannah; and a brother, John. An Air Force veteran of World War II, Mr. Abdoo graduated from Columbia College in 1941 and the Columbia University School of Law in 1947. He had a long career as a risk management consultant, most recently for the Yarmouth Group. Actively involved in Columbia College affairs, he was awarded the Columbia University Alumni Federation Medal in 1987. A memorial service will be held on Friday, Feb. 21, at 4:00 PM at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University, 117th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Frederick F. Abdoo Memorial Fund, C/O Columbia College, Office of Alumni Affairs and Development, 475 Riverside Drive, Mail Code #

title: St. Mary's Siberian Sale
description: The St. Mary Land and Exploration Company, a Denver-based oil and gas company, said today that it had completed the sale of its stake in a Siberian oilfield to the Ural Petroleum Corporation for as much as $17.2 million.

title: San Francisco Symphony Ends a Nine-Week Strike
description: The San Francisco Symphony is back in business. With a concert tonight, the orchestra members brought to an end a bitter nine-week strike that resulted in the cancellation of dozens of performances and left both sides still trading accusations of misplaced priorities.

title: Iverson Is Battling His Bad-Boy Image
description: Allen Iverson dropped in 35 points in his first game against the Knicks, back on Nov. 12. His Philadelphia 76ers won the game, and people exiting Madison Square Garden that night were left with a lasting image and an obvious conclusion.

title: Clinton Picks Little Rock For His Library
description: The records of the Clinton White House, together with the President's letters, musings and memorabilia, are to be preserved in a library at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock, the White House said today.

title: French Are Right to Question Changing World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, FLORENCE (SEIDE)
description: GRAY-Florence (Seide). In her 98th year after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin F. Gray. Mother of Jane and Allen Schultz, Barbara and Seymour Jasper. Grandmother of 4 and great grandmother of 6. Graveside service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your charity of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUIRE, JUDGE SIDNEY
description: SQUIRE-Judge Sidney. On Feb. 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Helen; devoted father of Walter and Jason; cherished father-in-law of Sara Abramson, M.D.; loving grandfather of Harrison, Russell, Zachary and Andrew. Funeral service 12 noon, Thurs, Feb 13, 1997 Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Congregation Or Zarua, NYC or to a charity of your choice.

title: ITT Board Votes Unanimously To Reject Hilton Takeover Bid
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected the Hilton Hotels Corporation's $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid, setting up what is looking like a protracted struggle for control of the hotel and casino company.

title: Some Enthusiasm, Some Fear After School Voucher Vote
description: With her oldest son ready to start high school this fall, Marie Forbes could be one of the first parents to take advantage of the tuition voucher program that this town's Board of Education has just adopted. The new program will allow high school students to attend private schools using local tax dollars, but Mrs. Forbes says she wants nothing to do with it.

title: We Are Not the World
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that the growing international mobility of goods, capital and technology has completely changed the economic game. Nations, conventional wisdom tells us, no longer have the power to control their own destinies; governments are at the mercy of international markets.

title: Continued Rise In the Dollar May Compel Officials to Act
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his allies in the Group of Seven industrial nations are trying to rein in the dollar, which has jumped 14 percent against the German mark and 16 percent against the Japanese yen in the last year.

title: Getting Caught in the Web
description: DEEPER

title: Lott Says He Sees Chance for Broad Cut in Capital Gains Taxes
description: One day after agreeing to accelerate negotiations with the Clinton Administration over taxes, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said today that he saw cracks in the Democrats' long-standing opposition to a broad cut in capital gains taxes.

title: New Editor Changes the Cadence of The Village Voice
description: The writers of The Village Voice knew their alternative world was changing yet again when their new leader gave them an introductory pep talk by quoting a favorite, now-dead editor of The New York Post.

title: With its canned soup turning 100, Campbell has begun a campaign for soups sold in glass jars.
description: HOW is the Campbell Soup Company marking the 100th anniversary of its condensed soup in cans? By blitzing America with a campaign pushing ready-to-serve soup sold in glass jars.

title: For the Roads Oft-Traveled
description: Testifying before a House transportation subcommittee yesterday, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said that New Jersey was justified in demanding more in Federal highway money than its drivers pay in Federal gasoline taxes.

title: Top Piano Competition Is Embracing the Basics With Live Performance
description: One of the biggest challenges for an international piano competition is the logistics of screening applicants. How can one panel of judges hear dozens, sometimes hundreds of pianists from around the world?

title: For Snug Sleep on Cold Nights, a Duvet
description: ONE final cold morning, you will wake up from a troubled, thrashing slumber and scrape rock bottom. After years of lying under poly-filled comforters, snarly squares of cotton knit and hairy Army blankets, you will get up, or try to, and heed the advice of your worldly friends: Get a duvet -- a goose-down-filled blanket.

title: Greener $$$ and Pastures
description: The televangelist in the White House has found a soul mate in a televangelist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEBINER, BENJAMIN
description: GEBINER-Benjamin. We mourn the loss of a learned and compassionate friend whose sense of social justice extended to people everywhere. He championed worker's rights, and, as a believer in Isrel, he supported labor Israel's message. He demonstrated a strong love for his family, to whom we extend our condolences, and for the Jewish people, his extended family. National Committee for Labor Israel/Israel Histadrut Campaign Jay Mazur, President Jerry Goodman, Executive Dir.

title: TRADING IN CENTENNIAL TECHNOLOGIES HINGES ON INQUIRY
description: Shares of Centennial Technologies Inc., which have not traded since Monday, will not trade again until the company releases more information about an internal investigation of accounting irregularities, an official at the New York Stock Exchange said. The company, which makes personal computer equipment, dismissed its chief executive on Tuesday, suspended its chief financial officer and began investigating the accuracy of its earnings reports for the quarter ending Dec. 31 and previous periods. The stock finished Monday at $16.50 a share. It reached a 52-week high just six weeks ago on Dec. 30, when it traded at $58.25. The accounting problems were discovered as outside auditors from Coopers & Lybrand were conducting a quarterly review.

title: A Restaurant Fights Trump For Survival
description: SABATINI'S is a casual spaghetti joint, with small tables in rows and a TV above the long bar that fills up with casino employees between shifts. For years, Clare Sabatini has wanted to give the place some new touches, a little of the oomph of the gambling palaces surrounding it. But why bother?

title: Gun-Shy Devils Still Survive
description: Demonstrating that a good offense is indeed sometimes the best defense, Dave Andreychuk came to the Devils' rescue tonight in a 3-2 victory over the Hartford Whalers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, FERNE R.
description: SCHWARZ-Ferne R., of Reading, Pennsylvania. Beloved and adored of Mark, Roger, Saul, David, Lucy, Nancy, Jeffrey and Debbie. Her energy, wisdom, commitment and sense of humor will be forever missed. Donations to personal charities or the Park Avenue Synagogue. Memorial service in New York City at later date.

title: Groups Seek To Persuade The Public On Donations
description: With efforts to change the campaign finance laws stalling in Congress, the advocacy group Common Cause announced today that it would take the case to the public and try to force Congress to act.

title: Stock Prices Rise Sharply as Technology Issues Rebound
description: Stock prices soared to record levels yesterday, bolstered by renewed strength in technology issues.

title: Inquiry Into Belle's Betting
description: Major League Baseball's security chief will gather information on the latest off-field development involving Albert Belle, an official said yesterday. But baseball officials were not jumping to a conclusion that Belle's admissions about gambling on professional football and college basketball games will lead to serious trouble for the slugging outfielder, who is the highest-paid player in the sport's history.

title: Congressional Panel Hears Options for Delayed Space Station
description: If Russia further delays or fails to produce a major component of the planned international space station, the United States is considering several steps to minimize the impact, including possibly delaying the launching of the first elements of the project by several months, officials said today.

title: Embarrassed, Giuliani Promises Changes at a Shelter for Women
description: Saying he was embarrassed by what city investigators described as widespread wrongdoing and sexual misconduct at a city-run shelter for abused women, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he assumed full responsibility for the failings and would order major changes in how the shelter was run.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN BEGINS TENDER OFFER FOR CONRAIL
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a tender offer for the 90.1 percent of the common shares of Conrail Inc. it does not already own. Before Norfolk Southern, a hostile bidder based in Norfolk, Va., can buy additional shares, it must find a way to defeat Conrail's ''poison pill'' defenses, which are designed to make a hostile acquisition too expensive. Norfolk Southern and the CSX Corporation, based in Richmond, are battling for control of Conrail, based in Philadelphia. CSX has agreed to buy Conrail for $9.43 billion. Norfolk Southern has offered $115 a share, or $10.32 billion. Norfolk Southern said it intended to ''consummate a merger'' if enough Conrail shares were tendered by the offer's deadline of March 12.

title: Sony Starts Crave, A New Record Label
description: The Sony Corporation brought out a new record label yesterday, founded by the singer Mariah Carey, to be known as Crave.

title: Secretary Albright Must Embrace Her Past to Shape the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: BELLSOUTH TO ACQUIRE WIRELESS CABLE OF ATLANTA
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wireless Cable of Atlanta Inc. for $46.9 million in stock. BellSouth said that with Wireless Cable's licenses it would be able to provide wireless cable TV service to more than 70 percent of households within a 35-mile radius of downtown Atlanta. The telecommunications provider, based in Atlanta, will pay 0.49 of a share for every Wireless Cable share. That figure could be adjusted if BellSouth's stock price changes significantly before the deal is completed. Wireless Cable's shares rose 13.6 percent on the news, gaining $2.375, to $19.875, in Nasdaq trading. BellSouth's shares gained $1.50, to $46.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONVERSE INC., North Reading, Mass., a maker of athletic and leisure footwear and sports apparel, announced that a United States Bankruptcy Court had approved liquidation of its subsidiary, Apex One Inc.

title: Historic Knitting With Designer Flair
description: CLOTHING designers in need of inspiration should hop on the next Amtrak Metroliner to see ''Looping and Knitting,'' an exhibition at the Textile Museum in Washington. In this show of handmade objects, which runs through July 27, there are pre-Colombian relics, an 1820's English drawstring purse that the heroine of a Bronte novel might have owned and a serrated Peruvian trimming (above) from 200 to 300 B.C. There is also a sporty Egyptian sock from between the 12th and 14th centuries that looks pure L. L. Bean: crisp, white and smartly striped in bands of blue and black. The Textile Museum is at 2320 S Street, NW; (202) 667-0441.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIGHTINGALE, GEOFF
description: NIGHTINGALE-Geoff. On February 9, 1997 at age 58, of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y. Senior BursonMarsteller executive. Beloved husband of Gisela. Devoted father of Alyssa and Christopher. A memorial service will be held today, 3 PM, at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of Huntington, 109 Brown's Road, in Huntington, L.I.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: FATAL FIRE -- Three people, apparently homeless, died when a shack caught fire under the boardwalk in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. B3.

title: Theater in Review
description: Of Immigrants and the Prairie:

title: Peter Serkin Cancels
description: The pianist Peter Serkin has canceled his appearance with the Minnesota Orchestra today at Carnegie Hall because of illness. Replacing him will be Jean-Yves Thibaudet, performing Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini. The remainder of the program remains unchanged. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Report on Sloppy F.B.I. Lab Work Begins Taking Toll at a Trial
description: In the first of many courtroom challenges expected nationwide, lawyers defending members of a paramilitary group here are seeking to cast doubt on a Federal expert's testimony by citing a Government report on sloppy work in the F.B.I.'s crime laboratories.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, Lectures and a Tour
description: Explorations of Color

title: Bank of Korea Moves to Strengthen Won
description: South Korea's central bank conducted forward currency transactions for the second consecutive day today. It is the first time the bank has used this method to defend the won from losing value against the dollar.

title: Hopeful Cities Explore Bidding for Games
description: In the roomful of Billy Payne wannabes, men and women from eight American cities gathered today to learn how to become the host of the 2008 or 2012 Summer Olympics. It is a numbing process, one that is more precise, difficult, restrictive and professional than when Payne led an audacious campaign in the late 1980's to bring the 1996 Summer Games to Atlanta, beating Athens, the sentimental favorite.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Four-Way Tie in ECAC

title: Douglas Is Old, Fat and Winner of Decision
description: James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight who knocked out Mike Tyson in 1990, lost the title to Evander Holyfield eight months later, ballooned to 400 pounds and almost died, is back in business. He may be 36 years old and he may be amply fed at 255 pounds, but he still has that quick left jab and the ability to land combinations of four or six left and right hooks.

title: William Homans Jr. Dies; Civil Rights Lawyer Was 75
description: William P. Homans Jr., a Boston civil rights lawyer who championed the downtrodden, the oppressed and the out-and-out villainous with such verve that he became a legend in Massachusetts legal circles, died on Feb. 7 at a nursing home in Phoenix. He was 75 and had lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANG, ALICE
description: YANG-Alice. In memory of Alice Yang, our beloved colleague and friend, who was one of the most engaging intellectuals involved with the arts today and, worked at The New Museum of Contemporary Art as Assistant Curator from 1988-1993. Her colleagues and friends admired and loved her brilliance, her thoughfulness and grace, her smile. We were privileged to know her and mourn the loss of this talented young woman who was so committed to life. As we gather today for her funeral, we extend our deepest sympathy to the Yang and Szeto families, for we will miss her always.

title: Deal Making at Home
description: A group of movie makers have turned to the Internet as a way of raising money to make independent films. This process allows them to bypass agents and shop their films to international distributors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTENBAUM, MICHAEL
description: HARTENBAUM-Michael, age 14. Beloved son of Ron and Laura; beloved brother of Steven and Jonathan; beloved grandson of Sylvia and the late Walter Schwartz and Gloria and Bela Hartenbaum. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Donations to CACLD (Connecticut Association of Children with Learning Disabilities) CACLD/ Michael Hartenbaum Memorial Fund, 25 Van Zandt Street, Suite 15-5, East Norwalk, CT. 06855, tel: 203-838-5010, would be greatly appreciated.

title: 'Murphy Brown' to Continue On CBS for Its 10th Season
description: The CBS comedy ''Murphy Brown,'' thought to be in its last season on the network, will return for a 10th season next fall, the network announced yesterday.

title: Beach Clubs and Ski Slopes Would Lose Money, Too
description: As the strike deadline fixed by American Airlines' pilots draws nearer, travel agents have been besieged by worried clients at destinations where American dominates the air-travel market.

title: Researchers Warn Driving and Phone Chats Don't Mix
description: Talking on a cellular telephone while driving may not cause brain cancer, as was once suggested, but two Canadian researchers have evidence that it is hazardous to health.

title: Dallas Cowboy Sues City Over Rape Accusation
description: A player for the Dallas Cowboys filed suit today in Federal court against the City of Dallas and the police, asserting that his civil rights were violated when officers investigated accusations made last December and later recanted by a 23-year-old woman that he had raped her.

title: Start the Hearings on Mr. Lake
description: The Senate's consideration of the nomination of Anthony Lake to be Director of Central Intelligence is beginning to look more like a demolition job than a reasoned review of his qualifications. Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, has an obligation to examine Mr. Lake's fitness to run one of the Government's most sensitive and troubled agencies. But Mr. Shelby keeps postponing hearings and raising new issues, leaving the impression that he would rather undermine the nomination than vote on it.

title: High North Korean Official Reported to Seek Asylum
description: A top North Korean leader slipped away during a shopping trip in Beijing and asked for asylum in South Korea, the South Korean Government announced on Wednesday. If confirmed, the defection would amount to a spectacular coup for Western intelligence services trying to learn more about North Korea, one of the most isolated countries in the world.

title: U.S. Can Wait on Full Japan Air Pact
description: The United States will not demand that Japan fully open its cargo and passenger aviation market immediately to reach an accord next month at air trade talks.

title: House Rejects Term Limits, Bringing Drive to a Dead Halt
description: The movement to impose term limits on members of Congress suffered a devastating defeat tonight, with a proposed constitutional amendment not only failing in the House but receiving fewer votes than it did two years ago.

title: A Fervent Choral Portrait of Walt Whitman
description: The New Amsterdam Singers are best known for their rewarding programs of a cappella music from all periods, usually performed in church settings. They also sing large choral works with orchestra, like Haydn's ''Mass in Time of War,'' which was the first half of an impressive program the singers gave on Sunday afternoon at the John Jay Theater.

title: Events: Talks on Digital Art and Italy
description: Art and Computers

title: A Prosecutor-Manager, Tested by Crown Hts.
description: As the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Zachary W. Carter commands more than 150 prosecutors handling hundreds of cases from three New York City boroughs and Long Island. But in recent weeks, Mr. Carter, 46, has appeared consumed by a single case.

title: Cuba Gives Long Prison Terms to Six Who Tried to Flee to U.S.
description: A Cuban court has sentenced six Cubans to prison terms ranging from 8 to 20 years for trying to flee to Florida in a commandeered tugboat last year. They were intercepted by the United States Coast Guard and handed over to the Cuban authorities.

title: Newark Extortion Trial Challenges Legal Skills of Judge and Lawyers
description: The Federal extortion and conspiracy trial of a former top aide to Mayor Sharpe James of Newark is posing a challenge not only to the jurors who must sort out a web of circumstantial evidence that the prosecution is laying out. The case is also presenting a challenge to the presiding judge, who must consider often-contradictory court precedents from an increasing number of public corruption cases.

title: U.S. to Increase Funds for Anti-Milosevic Media and Unions
description: The United States is significantly expanding its support of newspapers, radio stations and trade unions opposed to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, senior American officials said today.

title: Slaves' Contribution To Monticello Style
description: IF any piece of furniture at Monticello symbolizes the dexterity of Thomas Jefferson -- who inspired his country as gracefully as he grafted peach trees and played the violin -- it is the revolving walnut bookstand on the desk in his study.

title: French Are Right to Question Changing World
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Lower As Auction Disappoints
description: Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, following poor results at a Treasury auction of new 10-year notes.

title: Dispute at American Airlines Draws Clinton Plea
description: American Airlines canceled most of its Friday night overseas flights today in the face of a looming strike deadline, as President Clinton urged the nation's second-largest carrier and its pilots' union to use mediation to resolve a dispute that he said ''has huge implications for our country.''

title: America Online's Strategy Raises Eyebrows
description: America Online Inc. has long divided Wall Street into two sharply defined camps.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the rivalry between Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses understated the 1996 profits reported by Sotheby's. They were $68.2 million, not $62.8 million.

title: Economist's Survey Supports Theory That Inflation Is Overstated
description: In an effort to bolster his case that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation, Michael J. Boskin, the head of a panel that examined the issue last year, is circulating the results of a survey of fellow economists that backed his conclusions.

title: The Pop Life
description: U2 Amid the Lingerie

title: Yankee Ingenuity Helps Build Resort
description: If you happen to bump into Al Endriunas at this small but bustling ski resort, you might take him for one of the trail crew. Endriunas is a hillside worker, as apt to be driving a backhoe as positioning a snow gun. But make no mistake, he is also the boss.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BEN BRADLEE, the former executive editor of The Washington Post, called his memoir ''A Good Life.'' So what was his boss, KATHARINE GRAHAM, to call hers? Her granddaughter Katharine Weymouth suggested ''A Better Life,'' Mrs. Graham recalled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMSLIE, JEAN
description: ELMSLIE-Jean, 88, died in Palm Beach, FL, February 11. An inventive sculptor, her work is permanently displayed at the Norton Museum in West Palm Beach. Survived by daughters, Alexandra Whitelock of Calais, VT and Victoria Duval-Belding of Colorado Springs. There will be no services.

title: INSIDE
description: Korean Defection Reported

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKHEIM, SAMUEL
description: SACKHEIM - Samuel. Devoted husband of Mildred. Adored father of Judith Freeman and Randi Sackheim. Loving brother of Ida Pestka. Cherished grandfather of Joel, Jacob and Joseph. Dearest uncle. Services Thursday, 12:30pm, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BEATRICE
description: BROWN-Beatrice. The New York Pops mourns the death of Beatrice Brown, a founding member of the orchestra. Bea will be missed by all, and remembered for her dedication to music, her sparkling personality, and her benevolence towards musicians and friends. The New York Pops Orchestra Skitch Henderson, Founder & Music Director Peter B. Lane, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTIGAN, ANNA M. (NEE BOARDMAN)
description: HARTIGAN-Anna M. (nee Boardman). On February 11, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving sister of the late Aux. Bishop John J. Boardman, Director of the Propagation of the Faith, 1937-1966 and the National Treasurer. Dear cousin of Elizabeth A. Jennings and Mary V. Farrell. Wake Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10:15 AM, Our Lady of Angels Church. Request donations in her memory to the Propagation of the Faith.

title: 3 Sides of 'Dirty War' Laid Bare In One Day in Spain's Top Court
description: The scene at the 18th-century Spanish Supreme Court building this afternoon spoke volumes about the war that Spanish governments and Basque militants have been waging against each other for the last 29 years.

title: What the Next Sled of Toys Is Up To
description: KEN is changing diapers, and Barbie is working at the computer. What is the toy world coming to?

title: Isles Shock Penguins In Rare Road Victory
description: A thing of beauty? Hardly. A joy forever? Not in the endless National Hockey League regular season. But for the Islanders, tonight's 5-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins will be taken for what it was: a rare road triumph over one of the N.H.L.'s better teams.

title: Theater in Review
description: Doomed Love and Betrayal

title: Security Company at Women's Shelter Was a Target of Complaints
description: The private security company whose guards have been implicated in the mistreatment of residents of a battered women's shelter in the Bronx has been the target of many complaints over several years of beating and choking people and making sexual advances at city homeless shelters.

title: Panel Orders Nynex to Give Big Refunds
description: Ending more than a decade of litigation, the New York Public Service Commission yesterday ordered the Nynex Corporation to pay $109.6 million to its customers in the state -- at least $8.70 a customer -- for what it called shoddy service and improper business practices between 1984 and last year.

title: 3 Are Killed in Fire at Boardwalk Shanty in Brooklyn
description: A smoky blaze tore through a makeshift shanty under the Brighton Beach Boardwalk last night, killing three homeless people who had apparently been living there.

title: Goldman Sachs In Talks With Charles Schwab
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company is negotiating to sell its mutual funds through the Charles Schwab Corporation, the big discount broker, as Wall Street pursues its latest enthusiasm, the Main Street investor.

title: Meno and Sand Slip In the Short Program
description: The three-time national champions Jenni Meno and Todd Sand stumbled out of a lift and fell on a death spiral tonight during the short program of the pairs competition at the United States figure skating championships and slipped to second place.

title: Educating Contractors
description: To The Home Section:

title: Political Hat Trick
description: Larry Chatzidakis, a Republican car dealer from Mount Laurel, has served as a Burlington County freeholder since 1995 and as a member of the Mount Laurel Township Council since 1985. But last month, when he took yet another job -- as a state assemblyman -- some said he was overdoing it.

title: Earnings Rise at U S West Communications
description: U S West Communications Group, the main telecommunications arm of U S West Inc., said yesterday that its net income rose 10.7 percent in the fourth quarter as it added phone lines and set tighter cost controls.

title: New Leader In Ecuador Is Known For Agility
description: With the Congressional election of Fabian Alarcon as Interim President, a flamboyant and unpredictable leader nicknamed El Loco, or madman, has been replaced by his virtual opposite: a consummate deal-maker known as El Bailarin, the dancer.

title: NINE WEST TO CLOSE 3 PLANTS AND DISMISS 1,000 WORKERS
description: Nine West Group Inc., the largest maker of women's shoes in the United States, said yesterday that it would close three plants and dismiss 1,000 people, half of its United States manufacturing work force, as it shifts shoe production abroad. The moves will result in charges, though the amount has not been determined, Robert Galvin, its chief financial officer, said. Nine West, already a low-cost producer, acquired most of the plants from the U.S. Shoe Corporation, now a unit of Luxottica Group S.p.A., in May 1995. Shares of Nine West, based in Stamford, Conn., fell $1.375, to $49.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Nine West, which is based in Stamford, Conn., sells its products through more than 7,000 retailers worldwide.

title: In Era of Belt-Tightening, Modest Gains for Workers
description: American workers downsized, re-engineered and shoved into salary ruts -- are slowly beginning to climb back up.

title: Legal Hurdle Cleared in Sale of French Abortion Pill in U.S.
description: The Population Council, the nonprofit group that holds the rights to sell the French abortion pill to American women, announced yesterday that it had settled the litigation surrounding control of the drug, and arranged for it to be handled by a new privately held company, Advances for Choice.

title: Lipinski Works to Improve Her Standing
description: She was 6 at the time, so it must have been the Olympic season of 1988. Tara Lipinski became mesmerized by the figure skaters and swimmers who won their gold medals in Calgary, Alberta, and Seoul, South Korea. She had her father construct a series of boxes so that she could stand on a pretend victory podium with them. It didn't matter which athlete or which country or which national anthem. Always she stood on top, she said, where the gold medalists stood.

title: It's the Red Storm's Turn To Win a Cliffhanger
description: St. John's is a team on the brink. For the past four games a total of 11 points separated the Red Storm from a victory. Being close only counts as a big L.

title: Mario Simonsen, 61, Ex-Brazilian Finance Chief
description: Mario Henrique Simonsen, an economist who served as Brazil's Finance Minister in the tumultuous 1970's, died on Sunday at a hospital in Rio de Janeiro. He was 61.

title: In Africa, Making Offices Out of an Anthill
description: AFRICA owes its termite mounds a lot. Prospectors mine them, looking for specks of gold carried up from hundreds of feet below. Africans building mud huts love them, because the grainy soil inside is just the right consistency for hard-packed floors. And of course, to aardvarks and other insectivores they are giant helpings of baked alaska.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Secretary Albright Must Embrace Her Past to Shape the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: A Runaway Lands in an Attic

title: Air Bags Prompt Safety Bill
description: New Jersey could become the first state in the nation to prohibit children under 12 from sitting in the front seat of a car equipped with a passenger-side air bag, if a bill introduced Monday becomes law.

title: Many Felt Protected At Shelter
description: A nondescript six-story brick building in an industrial neighborhood in the Bronx, the New Day shelter for battered women is meant to be a safe house, unnoticeable amid the bodegas and muffler shops.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Airlines Cancels Some Overseas Flights

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUERY, ROBERT LESLIE
description: LUERY-Robert Leslie, 79, of Laguna Beach, CA., on February 10, 1997 at South Beach Hospital. Father of Andrea Fenton, Michael and Russell Luery. Former husband of Anita Meyers Luery. Predeceased by his daughter Roberta Jeanne Luery. Retired Property Manager of W.M. Capital Management whose holdings include the Empire State Building. Funeral Services will be held on Friday Feb. 14th in Temple Sinai, 458 Lakeside Drive, Stamford, Ct. Burial will follow in Fairfield Memorial Park, Stamford. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Temple Sinai or to the Roberta Jeanne Luery Memorial Fund for Study Abroad, Attention: Jack Pirozzi, Box 1228, 1 Brookings Drive, Washington University, St. Louis, MO. 63130. For information Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Stamford, Connecticut.

title: Tomba Tumbles Way Out Of Picture
description: The bleacher section closest to the television cameras has been Italian country since these world Alpine ski championships began.

title: Arts Endowment Official Resigns
description: Omus Hirshbein, the director of the music, opera and presenting programs of the National Endowment for the Arts since 1994, is to leave his position to be come president of Meet the Composer, an organization devoted to expanding the audience for new music. Mr. Hirshbein is to take up his new post on March 10.

title: To Little, Add Much. To Much, Add Little.
description: NO one ever accused Orlando Diaz-Azcuy of having swatches on the brain. He is that rarity, a designer with a sense of mission: to endow minimalism with a sense of history's riches.

title: A Rental Tower Is Planned for West Side
description: A block of Broadway in the 50's that has frustrated developers for more than 30 years with failed plans for an office building, a Planet Hollywood restaurant and a luxury hotel would become a 45-story rental apartment tower under a plan by Related Companies.

title: Secretary Albright Must Embrace Her Past to Shape the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not Real Big, but Texas Takes to It
description: New York has its official state muffin (apple), Arizona its official neckwear (bolo tie), and Massachusetts its official dog (Boston terrier).

title: Ferraro Asks Backers to Await Her Decision on Senate Race
description: Hoping to prevent potential Democratic rivals from getting a head start, Geraldine A. Ferraro has sent letters to possible supporters asking them to delay their decision on whom to endorse to run against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in 1998.

title: Third Place for Davis a Confidence Booster
description: As he skated to third place in tonight's short program of the national figure-skating championships, Scott Davis hoped that he had begun to overcome a familiar obstacle -- his confidence level.

title: 'Liberty' for New York Club
description: The New York team in the new Women's National Basketball Association will be known as the New York Liberty, and its logo shows the Statue of Liberty, with the flame from its torch hinting of a basketball.

title: New York: Capital of Love
description: LOVE is just around the corner almost anywhere in New York, and not just on Valentine's Day. It beckons on Riverside Drive at 122d Street, where lovers on a high (it's one of the highest points in the city) can go far higher, ascending the tower staircase of Riverside Church to the carillon for a kiss in the clouds. Talk about wedding bells! There are 74 of them, the largest 20 tons.

title: Police Union And City Hall To Resume Negotiations
description: Deadlocked and not having negotiated in almost two months, the Giuliani administration and the police union said yesterday that they would resume negotiations next week in the hope of ending a bitter impasse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, FLORENCE
description: GRAY-Florence. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed life member, wife of our late past President Benjamin F. Gray and extend our heartfelt condolences to her children Jane and Allen Schultz, her grandchildren John and Marcia Schultz and her family. Murray B. Hirsch, President Howard Ecker, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANSSEN, ELEANOR HILL
description: JANSSEN-Eleanor Hill. February 9, 1997. Formerly of Mt. Pleasant, TN, & NYC. Relatives and friends are invited to a memorial service Friday 11:15AM, St. Mary's At The Cathedral Church, Philadelphia. Donations in her memory may be made to Saint Mary's At The Cathedral Church, 600 E. Cathedral Road, Philadelphia, PA. 19128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADE, CORNELIUS J
description: WADE-Cornelius J. Of Glen Cove, formerly of Locust Valley. On February 13, 1997. Age 78. Beloved husband of the late Ann Wheeler. Loving father of Alice E. (Joseph P. Altier). Proud grandfather of Robert, Connor and William. Visiting Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, on Saturday, from 11 A.M.-1 P.M. Service and interment are private.

title: A Cat and Its Humans Get a Makeover. Meow!
description: It's not an encouraging sign that over the opening credits of the Disney remake of its 1965 hit ''That Darn Cat,'' the original theme song, a slinky ''Pink Panther''-influenced finger snapper sung by Bobby Darin, has been replaced with a jangling kiddie hip-hop number. Escalating the beats per minute in a family film is an almost sure sign that it is terrified of letting the pace slacken, lest a wee head begin to nod.

title: William M. Klein Jr., 63, Dies; Directed Gardens in 3 States
description: William McKinley Klein Jr., a botanist who revitalized the study of plants and botanical gardens in Florida, Hawaii and Pennsylvania, died of heart failure on Wednesday at Coral Gables Hospital in Florida. He was 63 and lived in Hawaii.

title: A Fashion Industry Center
description: The Garment Industry Development Corporation has received a $400,000 grant from the Empire State Development Corporation to establish a fashion technology center in lower Manhattan, representatives announced yesterday.

title: Air Force to Change Rules On Identifying Other Planes
description: The Air Force plans a major change in procedures used by fighter pilots who encounter unidentified aircraft in their drill areas, a senior Air Force official said today.

title: British Fund Manager Sets Up Line of Credit
description: Shares of Mercury Asset Management fell 3.2 percent yesterday after the company, Britain's largest fund manager, said it would set up a credit line of $:250 million ($408.5 million) for a potential financial crisis. The credit line, which could be used to defend against a hostile takeover or to make emergency payments to customers, is being set up by J. P. Morgan & Company and Royal Bank of Scotland. Shares of Mercury Asset Management gained as much as 12 percent in the last five weeks amid takeover speculation.

title: 2 Cleared in Gifts Tied to Ex-Cabinet Member
description: The special prosecutor investigating Mike Espy, President Clinton's onetime Agriculture Secretary, suffered his first setback today as a Federal Court jury acquitted two former executives of a crop-insurance company of making illegal campaign contributions to Mr. Espy's brother.

title: Shippers Preparing Strike Alternatives
description: Mail around the United States is being rerouted in expectation of a strike at American Airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAICHER, ELIZABETH MAULSBY BOULDIN
description: BLAICHER - Elizabeth Maulsby Bouldin. Of Vero Beach, FL and St. Huberts, NY, died on February 12, 1997. Survived by her husband Frederick M. and their children Elizabeth M., Frederick M., Jr., Peter B., Arthur A. and Christopher Y., and 7 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Princeton, New Jersey, at a later date.

title: Dayton at Risk
description: Are the United States and its European allies serious about making the Dayton accords work? A violent provocation by Croats in the Bosnian city of Mostar raises that question in painful form.

title: Thomas Stoddard, 48, Dies; An Advocate of Gay Rights
description: Thomas B. Stoddard, a lawyer whose persuasiveness and erudition advanced the cause of equal rights for gay men, lesbians and people with AIDS, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: Places Where Hearts Take Flight (or the Ferry)
description: Here is a sampling of some of the ways to celebrate Valentine's Day this weekend:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, DAVID
description: GRANT-David. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David Grant, associated with The Times from 1959 until retiring in 1978.

title: The Debacle at Adelphi
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside Photography
description: Fame sat so lightly on Saul Leiter that when it went away in the 1970's, he didn't miss it. Now that it rests ever so lightly on him again, he is still unimpressed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: As Dow Crosses 7,000, Investors Don't Look Back

title: CHRONICLE
description: It may be a holiday on Monday, but that will not deter JACK QUINN, who is stepping down as White House counsel, from starting a new job -- or two.

title: Royals Win Goodwin Case
description: Kansas City yesterday won its arbitration case against outfielder TOM GOODWIN, who, nevertheless, more than tripled his 1996 salary of $312,500. THEODORE HIGH awarded Goodwin the $1.05 million salary the Royals wanted to give him instead of the $1,795,000 he sought.

title: Harlem Dance Contract
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem and the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents the company's dancers, announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement on a new two-year contract, ending a 19-day strike. Under the contract, the 32 dancers will receive a 5 percent raise in each year. Under the old contract, which expired Sept. 30, the wage scale ran from $269 a week for apprentices to $767 a week for principal dancers. The raise is to be paid retroactively. The contract guarantees 40 weeks of work in the first year and 30 in the second.

title: Emmerling Post Gets I.R.S. Contract
description: The Internal Revenue Service in Washington awarded a five-year contract yesterday to Emmerling Post Advertising in New York to handle marketing communications and public service advertising, which had been handled for 11 years by Action Productions in New York. Spending was estimated at more than $1 million annually. The decision came after an eight-month review that had been narrowed to Emmerling Post and two other finalists: Frankel & Company in Chicago and Meridian Communications in Pittsburgh.

title: Heinz and Campbell Settle
description: The H. J. Heinz Company and the Campbell Soup Company settled a legal dispute yesterday over Heinz's attempt to hire a Campbell executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, IVAN G., SR.
description: OWEN-Ivan G., Sr., husband of Susan (Battey) Owen, of 48 Meadow Avenue, Weekapaug, RI. Memorial Services will be held in the Dunn's Corners Community Church Presbyterian, 221 Post Rd., Westerly, RI 02891, Saturday, Feb. 15, at 11:00 AM. Donations: Dunns Corners Community Church Presbyterian or to Weekapaug Chapel Society, C/O Reverend Alexander Ogilby, 42 Meadow Avenue, Weekapaug, R.I. 02891.

title: Many in Battered Women's Shelter Say Life Was Mostly Humdrum
description: For many of the battered women living in the Bronx shelter that investigators say was rife with misconduct, life inside is made up of mundane moments that do not seem to jibe with the bold-faced headlines about abuse and harassment: Every day, with few exceptions, they wake up, pour cereal into breakfast bowls, walk their children four blocks to school, watch soap operas on TV. On occasion, they hop the train to go to court.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column on Wednesday, about helping children deal with a parent's cancer, misspelled the middle name of the author of ''When a Parent Has Cancer: A Guide to Caring for Your Children'' (HarperCollins). She is Dr. Wendy Schlessel Harpham, not Schessel.

title: Legality, Not Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: A General Motors Axle Supplier Is Also Facing a Strike Deadline
description: The Allied Pilots Association at American Airlines is not the only union that has set a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. on Saturday. The United Automobile Workers union's contract with a critical supplier of the General Motors Corporation will expire at the same time, and the union has prepared itself for a strike.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Prop Fiction'

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the ITT Corporation's rejection of a takeover offer from the Hilton Hotels Corporation misstated the ownership of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, which is a partner with ITT in Madison Square Garden. It is independent; it is not a unit of Time Warner Inc.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Another Dollar, Please

title: Giuliani Urges Lobbying Ban For Agencies
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he wanted to prohibit all lobbying of city agencies, asserting that his administration was so accessible and fair that there was no need for anyone to hire lobbyists. But the Mayor conceded that he did not know how such a ban would work and that the concept raised knotty questions about free speech.
