title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SQUIRE, JUDGE SIDNEY
description: SQUIRE-Judge Sidney. On Feb. 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Helen; devoted father of Walter and Jason; cherished father-in-law of Sara Abramson, M.D.; loving grandfather of Harrison, Russell, Zachary and Andrew. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Congregation Or Zarua, NYC or to a charity of your choice.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The eagerly anticipated 64-seat Jean-Georges restaurant will not open until mid-March, but you can get a preview. The lounge is already serving breakfast, lunch and dinner every day.

title: Cosmic Amino Acids Also Show Left-Handed Bias, Study Says
description: Scientists have long sought to explain a great mystery: the fact that nearly all living organisms on earth are made of proteins assembled exclusively from the left-handed versions of certain amino acids.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TE ROLLER, WILHELMINA EVA MARIA
description: te ROLLER-Wilhelmina Eva Maria. Age 100. Died on February 12, 1997, New York City. Born in The Netherlands (Holland). Survived by 3 cousins: Aldegonda Gertrudis Rask nee Brak, (Finland), Margaretha Francine Van Rooij nee Brak (The Netherlands), Johan Frederik Brak (The Netherlands). Friends may call Friday 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service Saturday 9:30 A.M. Burial at St. Gertrude's Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: M.T.A., Too, Could Learn Some Manners
description: THE Transit Authority's experiment in subway courtesy went smoothly enough at Grand Central yesterday during another morning rush. It almost makes you wonder if the sun will rise in the west and donkeys will speak.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: F.B.I. Killed Unarmed Man, Inquiry Shows
description: A 21-year-old murder suspect who the F.B.I. had said was fatally shot Jan. 30 after opening fire on agents was unarmed when he was killed, the authorities said today.

title: Accounting at Pearson U.S. Unit May Force $163 Million Charge
description: Pearson P.L.C., the British media company, said today that it may take a $163 million charge against last year's earnings after discovering ''improper accounting'' practices at its Penguin USA book publishing unit.

title: 3 Top South Koreans Seized in Bribery Case
description: The authorities arrested a Cabinet minister and two prominent lawmakers today in a bribery scandal that has become a crisis for President Kim Young Sam.

title: Peter the Great's Boat Mesmerizes Russian Emigres
description: Vadim Shvartsman stood and stared, rubbing his chin from time to time. He was looking at a piece of the history of the country he fled 17 years ago, a rugged and hallowed object he had not seen since he was a teen-ager.

title: Surviving on Grace in a World Beyond Hope
description: IT'S no secret that when people in a Chekhov play talk about how wonderful tomorrow is going to be, what they're really saying is that today is lousy. Still, it's a special treat to see what an actor like David Strathairn can make of this sad spiritual grammar, speaking in the future tense because life in the present is all too glum, all too boring, all too distant from anything noble.

title: Slow Growth and Revamping Cost Lead to Loss at Philips
description: Reflecting charges taken as part of a sweeping overhaul, as well as slower sales growth, Philips Electronics N.V. reported an unexpected net loss for the fourth quarter today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAVRICK, ISADORE
description: SHAVRICK-Isadore. We want to convey our heartfelt sympathy to our Rebbetzin, Claire Hertzberg, on the loss of her father, and to Mrs. Shulamith Shavrick on the loss of her husband, Isadore Shavrick. Jewish Center of Bayside Oaks Victor Schildkraut, President Lee Potasinski, Exec Vice Pres.

title: Hyatt Affiliate Studies Site
description: Last March, when Kraft Foods announced plans to vacate its sprawling five-story building in White Plains, with 623,700 square feet, brokers fretted about finding a buyer for such a distinctive property.

title: Finding Time To Go Around Will Test Torre
description: The Yankees have quickly progressed from celebrating a World Series title to deliberating over how they can win another one, from being assertive on the field to being analytical off it, and from being in banquet mode to being back in the daily grind. Even before pitchers and catchers officially report on Friday, it is obvious that the honeymoon phase has ended.

title: MUSICLAND TO CLOSE 75 STORES AND SEEK INVESTORS
description: The Musicland Stores Corporation said yesterday that it would close 75 stores and was looking for new investors to shore up its finances. The company, which operates about 1,466 Sam Goody, Musicland and Media Play stores, said the closings would result in a fourth-quarter charge. Musicland, based in Minneapolis, has lost money in 8 of the last 10 quarters as big retailers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Best Buy Inc. sold music priced near cost to attract shoppers. In addition, music sales have slowed in recent years. Shares in Musicland were unchanged at $1.375.

title: For Baseball, Redemption Is the Basics
description: ONE day before the official reporting date for pitchers and catchers, more than a week before the mandated arrival of everyone else, David Cone wandered out of the clubhouse at the Yankees' complex here yesterday and bumped into Derek Jeter, who was strolling in from one of the practice fields.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNNERS, REBECCA
description: SUNNERS-Rebecca. Age 90. On February 12, 1997 in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late William Sunners, mother of Harold and Marilyn, mother-in-law of Norman Cranin, sister of Samuel, grandmother and great-grandmother. Willy's waiting.

title: British Soldier's Death in Ulster Raises Fears of New Violence
description: A heightened sense of fear and gloom pervades Northern Ireland as the feeling spreads that there will be more sectarian violence in the British province before there is any likelihood of a lasting peace.

title: Police Offer Reward
description: Eight days after a police captain was shot in the face while searching a Bronx apartment for guns, the police said yesterday that they are searching for a man they believe fired the weapon, and they offered a $21,000 reward for information leading to his capture.

title: Warehouse Insurance Fraud
description: At its height, Scrimshaw Handcrafts had a dozen outlets along the Northeast coast and earned more than $4 million a year selling items like jade and ivory figurines. But in 1990, prosecutors said, the owners filed a false insurance report, claiming that a faulty fire sprinkler in their Ocean Township warehouse had leaked and destroyed hundreds of thousands of dollars of merchandise.

title: TOP EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE ANDERSEN
description: Andersen Worldwide said yesterday that its managing partner and chief executive, Lawrence A. Weinbach, would leave the firm when his term expires at the end of August. The accounting and consulting concern said Mr. Weinbach, 57, had not decided what he would do after leaving Andersen Worldwide. Mr. Weinbach has been chief executive since 1989, when he filled six months of an expiring term and was then twice elected to the post. Andersen Worldwide's more than 2,700 partners will elect a nominating commission that will propose names of possible successors to Mr. Weinbach, but that decision will not be known for several months, the company said.

title: Corrections
description: The Taking In the Sites column in Business Day on Monday, about World Wide Web sites of shipping companies, provided an outdated electronic address for TNT Express Worldwide. Its new site, which offers tracking of packages, may be found at http://www.tntew.com. The site described in the column is for TNT Ltd., an Australian company that was once part-owner of TNT Express Worldwide and has since been bought by the TNT Express's new owner, Koninklijke PTT Nederland N.V.

title: ROWLAND SEEKING TAX AND JOB CUTS
description: Continuing his drive to shrink state government, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a two-year $20.5 billion budget that would substantially cut the state income tax and reduce the work force by about 10 percent.

title: NEWPORT PETROLEUM TO ACQUIRE CIMARRON
description: The Newport Petroleum Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Cimarron Petroleum Ltd. for stock valued at $369 million (Canadian) , or $273 million (United States). The acquisition would enable Newport Petroleum to expand its oil and gas operations in western Canada. The combined company, which is to continue under the Newport name, would have natural gas reserves of 380 billion cubic feet and crude oil and natural gas liquid reserves of 20.3 million barrels. Estimated output for 1997 is 25,000 barrels of oil a day. Under the deal, Cimarron shareholders would receive 2.61 Newport shares for each Cimarron share they hold. Newport said the offer represented a 26 percent premium to the recent market price of Cimarron shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, FRANK
description: WILSON-Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Wilson, associated with The Times from 1974 until retiring in 1992.

title: Knicks' Childs Finally Gets the Best of 76ers' Iverson
description: Chris Childs decided he would not chase Allen Iverson like a skittering leaf along a sidewalk. He would not lunge. He would cut off his angles and simply wait for him to make a move.

title: Pilots' Rifts Create Hurdle To a Contract
description: The Allied Pilots Association, the union that has pushed American Airlines to the brink of a strike, is in many ways a misnomer. From its founding in 1963 through recent weeks, its members and leaders have made disunity their hallmark.

title: Verdict in Student's Slaying
description: Two Paterson youths were convicted yesterday of felony murder in the July 1995 slaying of a Rutgers honors student who had just returned from a humanitarian trip to Costa Rica, officials said.

title: Rifts Among Pilots
description: Fissures within the pilots' union at American Airlines, which is on the brink of a strike that could strand thousands of passengers, are proving an obstacle to progress in the labor talks. There was little movement toward common ground yesterday.

title: Nelson: 'No Hard Feelings'
description: Ernie Grunfeld picked up the telephone Tuesday and heard a voice from the past. Don Nelson was calling to say hello, talk business and reconcile. It was the first time Grunfeld and Nelson had spoken since last March 8, when Grunfeld knocked on Nelson's hotel room door in Philadelphia and relieved him of his duties after 59 games, the shortest coaching tenure in franchise history.

title: 'Star Wars' Names Resonate in Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy Can Curb North African Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton and Friends: Strong Ties, Few Questions
description: From the Whitewater investigation to the White House guest list, from financing his campaigns for governor to raising money for the 1996 elections, a thread runs through Bill Clinton's career: the Arkansas friends he relies on for political and financial support.

title: Chubb Security in Talks For Sale of Company
description: Chubb Security P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks to sell the company for up to $:1.27 billion ($2.07 billion), prompting a surge of almost 25 percent in the company's stock price. Chubb, a British company that produces security products ranging from closed-circuit television equipment to fire extinguishers, made the statement after shares surged on speculation that a bid, probably from overseas, was imminent.

title: From Green Eggs To Ham, Hands On
description: YOU know you've earned your stripes as a parent when you start quoting from Dr. Seuss. Recently, I tried to persuade my little girl that she should taste a vegetable (eggplant) that she insisted she wouldn't like. ''Try it! Try it! And you may,'' I found myself reciting. ''Try it and you may, I say!''

title: Not Just for Viewing, But Also for Healing
description: IN contemporary Western culture, art is confined to special places: museums, chiefly. One looks at it or not, as the fancy strikes, and for many viewers a postcard reproduction of a painting or a sculpture is almost as good as the real thing. After all, the original is basically there, isn't it, just reduced to take-home size?

title: Insurer Grows, Equating Size and Survival
description: American General's $4.4 billion shopping spree to gain size and strengthen its position in the fiercely competitive insurance industry reached its culmination yesterday with an announcement by the company that it would acquire the USLife Corporation for $1.8 billion in stock.

title: Ethics Panel Clears Lynch
description: A bipartisan legislative committee cleared State Senator John A. Lynch yesterday of charges that he helped secure the passage of a 1991 bill benefiting optometrists in exchange for $28,500 in campaign contributions.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Purple Noon

title: Administration Welfare Plea Is Scorned
description: Administration officials pleaded with Congress today to restore welfare benefits for legal immigrants who have not become citizens. But President Clinton came under blistering criticism from liberal Democrats, who said he should never have signed the bill that ended such benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JEROME
description: GOLDSTEIN-Jerome. February 13, 1997. Survived by wife Miriam, daughter Elisse, brother Milton and sister Adelaide Berman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEER, RAY
description: SCHEER-Ray, 90, of Lake Worth, FL., formerly of NYC died February 12, 1997. She is survived by her sons Malcolm E. and Dr. Stuart C., and two grandchildren Jennifer and Nicholas Scheer. Services will be graveside Sunday, February 16 at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ. For information call Riverside Park West 362-3600.

title: For Some, New Toy Is Not All Fun and Games
description: In its April issue, Games magazine declares a new toy called Orion's Crystal -- a softball-sized transparent ball -- ''the next big thing.'' After all, there is a picture of Bill Gates shaking hands with the inventor, Davis Merran. And there is another of President Clinton with one on his desk in the Oval Office.

title: Will the Asteroids Destroy Kansas City? Guess.
description: The little boy, clutching his goldfish bowl, says, ''Daddy, I'm scared.'' About a half-hour later, his mother says to her husband, ''Honey, I'm really scared.'' Meanwhile, back at the lab, the experts are warning, ''No one within a 20-mile radius will survive.'' Obviously, folks, this is yet another disaster movie. ''Asteroid,'' a four-hour special-effects exercise, can be seen on NBC Sunday and Monday. Improbability reigns.

title: Call It Double Jeopardy
description: Suppose that while visiting a small town a prominent black civil rights leader -- call him Mr. A -- is charged with killing a white police officer. Prosecutors say the officer was trying to arrest him for disorderly conduct, but a mostly black jury finds that the charge was fabricated and that damaging physical evidence against Mr. A was planted. He is acquitted, but is emotionally and financially drained.

title: Defense Spending Boon
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHE, THOMAS KIRBY
description: ROCHE-Thomas Kirby, of Muttontown, NY, on February 12, 1997, at the age of 79. Survived by his wife Beverly, as well as by Gary Knapp, son John, daughters Caroline dela Bretesche, Claire Ferreyrulles & Barbara Makowski. Sisters Mrs. Earl Smith and Mrs. Billy Bryant, and 10 grandchildren. Combat infantry officer in WW II, wounded, awarded Silver Star, Cruix de Guerre and Bronze Star & the Purple Heart for actions in combat. Thereafter engaged in Washington and New York in International Matters and litigation. Burial will be in Arlington National Cemetery. Memorial Service at 11 A.M., Monday, Feb. 17, Christ Church, Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to a charity of your choice. For further information contact the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home Inc., 293 South St, Oyster Bay (516) 922-6700

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Very Brady Sequel

title: Dinkins Picks Messinger As His Choice For Mayor
description: After concluding he did not want the job for himself, David N. Dinkins endorsed Ruth W. Messinger's bid for City Hall yesterday. Mr. Dinkins said Ms. Messinger would be the strongest Democratic candidate, and Ms. Messinger responded by warmly praising Mr. Dinkins's performance as Mayor.

title: Sex With a Psycho, Just for Starters
description: ASYLUM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLANOS, DONALD F
description: CASTELLANOS-Donald F. All of us at Congregation B'Nai Olam mourn the loss of our good friend and long time supporter. His devotion to community improvement and social awareness was admirable. Our condolences to Daniel, his long time companion, and to the extensive family.

title: Home Video
description: Seismic waves from the ''Star Wars'' phenomenon (in which a 20-year-old monster hit is put back in theaters, whereupon it threatens to earn $100 million more) naturally reverberate to the very bedrock of home video. Other than a ''Lion King,'' ''Independence Day'' or other fresh new juggernaut, there are few more prolific properties than a big old title like ''My Fair Lady'' that can ride a theater rerun to a splashy rebirth on videocassette.

title: Stocks Up Again in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks rose here today for the fourth day, helped by the weak yen and by gains the previous day on Wall Street. At the close, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 33.94 points, or almost one-fifth of 1 percent, at 18,722. On Thursday, the Nikkei index gained 278.10 points, or 1.51 percent.

title: Cultures That Clash In Marriage
description: Trailing a cloud of television stardom, Matthew Perry of ''Friends'' plays a wisecracking New York-based real estate developer in ''Fools Rush In,'' a lackluster comedy about a shotgun wedding. His leading lady is Salma Hayek, beaming ingenue and proud owner of the best midriff in movies.

title: Rangers, Gretzky Are Unable To Produce
description: The Rangers had plenty to play for at the Kiel Center tonight.

title: Questions Unasked
description: Why are Communist and militant Islamic dictatorships persecuting Christians? Why are Western democracies reacting so passively -- or not at all? What can be done to ease the repression?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOLOMON, NAT L
description: SOLOMON-Nat L. Happy birthday on this your 100th anniversary. I miss your wisdom and humor. The weather has been bad all week, but it will be Good Friday. Horace

title: Calipari Shows Concern Over Bradley's Lethargy
description: Nets Coach John Calipari is trying to do what the rest of the league has been attempting to do for three years: Figure out Shawn Bradley.

title: 'Star Wars' Names Resonate in Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennsylvania Bank Deal
description: Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire a smaller in-state rival, Founders Bank, in a stock swap valued at about $15 million. Founders shareholders will receive about $15.12 of Susquehanna stock for each Founders share held based on Wednesday's closing prices. Founders, of Bryn Mawr, has total assets of $103 million. Susquehanna, based in Lititz, has total assets of about $3 billion.

title: Injury to O'Neal Is a Blow to Lakers
description: In a development that could take the Los Angeles Lakers out of the championship picture, Shaquille O'Neal will miss the next 8 to 10 weeks because of ligament damage in his left knee.

title: GTE Change Brings 2d Ogilvy Conflict
description: There is additional fallout from a decision by the GTE Corporation to move its account, with billings estimated at $80 million, to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York from Focus GTE, a dedicated unit of DDB Needham Worldwide in Dallas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESSEL, ALEXANDER
description: HESSEL-Alexander. The Board of Trustees, President David Chang, Chancellor George Bugliarello, the faculty, alumni, staff and students of Polytechnic University note with profound sorrow the passing of Alexander Hessel, retired professor of the Electrical Engineering Department. After receiving his doctorate at Polytechnic, Professor Hessel served on the University's faculty for more than thirty years, and was deeply admired and loved both by his colleagues and by the graduate students who worked with him. In the field of electromagnetic theory, he was one of the world's foremost experts in microwave phased array antennas for military radar applications. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Miriam Hessel, and family.

title: People
description: * Kent Ord, senior vice president and managing director at Evans Group, Seattle, was named to head Futureworks, a new interactive division.

title: Mercedes-Benz's new campaign is injecting fun-loving spirit into precise German engineering.
description: ATTEMPTS to create warm, fuzzy feelings about the vehicles sold by Mercedes-Benz of North America continue with an extensive and expensive brand image campaign -- its largest ever -- that seeks to play up the tonic in Teutonic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SACKS, ALVIA
description: SACKS-Alvia. Mar 3, 1916-Feb 14, 1996. I miss you today as I do every day. Love, Nancy

title: Mets Aren't Pushing the Big 3, So Acevedo Could Find a Spot
description: The Mets have come one year and a million miles away from putting all their hopes on the shoulders of three young pitchers.

title: Developing Rhythms And Ideas
description: The trumpeter Terence Blanchard and the alto saxophonist Donald Harrison, who emerged from New York's pack of strivers while in Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers and worked together off and on through the 80's, are on again. Both have moved back to New Orleans, and for the first time since 1989 they are sharing the reins of a quintet, alongside the three members of Mr. Blanchard's working group.

title: Panel Issues 52 Subpoenas In Inquiry on Fund Raising
description: The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today began its examination of questionable campaign finance practices, issuing 52 subpoenas for documents held by a group of American and Asian contributors and fund-raisers as well as Federal agencies with whom they had contact.

title: Art in Review
description: Ilan Averbuch

title: Art in Review
description: Diana Cooper

title: CHRONICLE
description: When RUBY DALLAS YOUNG was a showgirl in the early 1930's at the legendary Cotton Club in Harlem, she used to encourage an insecure teen-age singer: LENA HORNE.

title: A Countess Who Knows The Score
description: The critical consensus about Kiri Te Kanawa in recent years has been that whatever one thinks of her artistry, the rosy bloom has gone from the voice.

title: U.S. About to Give Rules On New Children's Car Seats
description: The Government will soon issue long-awaited regulations to simplify and standardize the installation of child safety seats in cars.

title: In American Eagle, Union Sees a Threat
description: They may earn only a third to a half as much as the $120,000 a year that pilots average at American Airlines. But pilots at American Eagle, the company's commuter line, will put up with no second-guessing of their abilities.

title: For Children
description: 'The African Drum'

title: Cleaning Up Campaigns
description: Four months after last fall's bitter Senate race, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and other prominent New Jersey politicians will discuss today how to bring a more positive tone to state political campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CISEK, MIECISLAUS J., (MICKEY)
description: CISEK-Miecislaus J., (Mickey), CPA. On Feb. 12, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Mary A. Cisek. Dear uncle of Katherine T. Cisek. NYU School of Commerce, Class of '29, magna cum laude. Supervising special agent NYS Tax Dept for 38 years. Funeral mass at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Brooklyn, Saturday 9:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Viewing Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Ridge Chapels, 405 91st Street, Brooklyn.

title: Clinton Meets With Netanyahu and Urges Syrian Talks
description: Describing Israel's agreement to withdraw from most of the West Bank city of Hebron as having brought ''a renewed sense of promise in the Middle East,'' President Clinton met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today and urged the resumption of negotiations between Israel and Syria.

title: HILTON URGES ITT NOT TO UNLOAD ASSETS
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation urged the ITT Corporation yesterday not to sell assets unrelated to its hotel and casino businesses quickly as a way to fend off Hilton's $10.5 billion bid. In a letter, Hilton's chief executive, Stephen F. Bollenbach, said he was upset by statements that ITT would unload assets like its 50 percent stake in Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks and Rangers sports teams. ITT said on Wednesday that it planned to focus on its casino and hotel businesses. It recently cut its stake in the French telecommunications company Alcatel Alsthom S.A. ITT shares rose 62.5 cents each yesterday, to $58.25. Investors apparently were speculating that the strategy would increase ITT's value, since the proceeds from asset sales could be invested in its faster-growing casino and hotel businesses. On Wednesday, ITT rejected Hilton's unsolicited takeover offer, calling the proposal inadequate and vowing to stay independent by focusing on its Sheraton hotel chain and Caesars World casinos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, HENRIETTA SIMONS
description: WEIL-Henrietta Simons. The officers, leadership and staff of UJAFederation mourn the passing of Henrietta Simons Weil, a member of a legendary family with a proud history in the community. Mrs. Weil was a dedicated philanthropist who supported numerous charities throughout her life. She was the wife of Frank L. Weil, founder of the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, who passed away in 1957. The firm continues to be one of UJA-Federation's most generous supporters. Mrs. Weil was also the granddaughter of the first Jewish governor in the United States, Moses Alexander of Idaho, a champion of human rights. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family and loved ones. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a boy for MICHAEL JACKSON and his wife, DEBBIE ROWE. The baby was born at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles at 1 A.M. yesterday, with Mr. Jackson in the delivery room. Beyond those few facts, the baby's arrival is cloaked in secrecy. No one is saying how much he weighed, or what he will be named.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, DAVID N.
description: SHAPIRO-David N., 77, of Great Neck. February 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Rhoda; devoted father of Joseph, Lawrence and Daniel; cherished grandfather of Anne, Clara, Sally, Claudia, Nathan and Robert. Services today 12 noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York.

title: Stocks Race Past New Milestone As Dow Breaks 7,000 Barrier
description: The stock market, seemingly oblivious to worries among some Washington policy makers and Wall Street analysts that share prices are too costly, continued its blistering upward march yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average surged past 7,000 points for the first time.

title: Memories of Penny Philanthropist Stir Gifts to Neediest
description: George C. Ginsberg, known as the Penny Philanthropist because of his charitable donations in small denominations, wanted to see The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund break the $5 million mark. He had predicted that it would happen last year and when it did not, he simply started giving all over again.

title: Going to Great Lengths To Get From Point A to B
description: Think you are having trouble trying to get where you want to go because there could be an American Airlines strike at midnight tonight? If so, welcome to the club, of which Debbie Crabb of Dallas is a charter member.

title: At Service, Clinton Recalls Pamela Harriman the Patriot
description: Before a high-powered assembly of almost 1,200 people, drawn from the worlds of politics, diplomacy, show business and high finance, President Clinton led a memorial service for Pamela Harriman this morning, praising her as a woman of elegance and indomitable will.

title: Banning New Investment in Myanmar
description: The Clinton Administration may be nearing a decision point on Myanmar, the Southeast Asian nation that has been deformed by a brutal military dictatorship. When President Clinton's top foreign-policy advisers take up the issue today, they should recommend activating a ban on new American investment in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma. It would be an excellent start for Mr. Clinton's new team, and give Secretary of State Madeleine Albright evidence of American resolve that will be useful in her visit to China in 10 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEERING, JAMES A. JR.
description: DEERING-James A. Jr. Of New City, NY on February 12, 1997. Husband of Rosemary. Father of Susan Renzulli and Roseann Hetrick, brother of Robert, Joan Barker and Edna Persina. Also survived by three grandchildren. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10am, St. Ann's Church, Nyack, NY. Burial St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main Street, New City, NY, Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm.

title: Saving Romania's Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Have Japanese Pitchers
description: The Mets have yet to lure the likes of a Hideo Nomo from Japan or a Chan Ho Park from South Korea for their pitching staff, but they are starting to take some steps toward the Orient.

title: Tajik Rebels Said to Kill U.N. Aide in Hostage Deal Gone Awry
description: Tajik rebels have killed a United Nations observer they had been holding hostage in a campaign to secure the release of fellow insurgents, Russian news organizations reported today.

title: Doing Miracles Isn't a Bed of Roses
description: ''Touch'' is an Elmore Leonard novel tailor-made for the talents of Paul Schrader, who has written and directed it for the screen. This story has questions of faith, religious stigmata, a possible saint, a set of colorful sleaze bags eager to exploit him and an avenging fundamentalist who identifies with Christian martyrs. The last character, dressed in a paramilitary uniform, deeply suspicious of women and leading a fervent campaign for ''the return to time-honored ecclesiastical and sacramental rites,'' might as well be Travis Bickle Lite.

title: U.N. Chief Says Abandoning Aid Force for Zaire Was a Mistake
description: Abandoning plans for military intervention in Zaire was a mistake, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today, suggesting that the plan to establish a force to help refugees should have been merely suspended so that it could be revived if needed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, GEORGE E.
description: KRAUS-George E., 88, of Scottsdale, AZ, formerly of New York, died February 13. Beloved husband of Bobbi, cherished father and father-in-law to Marlene and Steve Morris of New York and Leslie Kraus and Susan Rosenthal Kraus of Minnesota. Loving grandfather of David and Gary Morris and Erica Rosenthal Kraus. His goodness, wisdom and sense of humor will be forever appreciated. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Pataki Amends Budget Proposals For Medicaid Cuts and Tax Relief
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today modified his proposed budget to soften his Medicaid cuts somewhat and include co-op owners in a program he is pushing to hold down local property taxes across the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAGDEN, CRAWFORD
description: BLAGDEN-Crawford, on February 10, 1997 age 84. A decorated Veteran of WWII. He was awarded the Silver Star, the Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. Husband of the late Mary K. Blagden. Father of Crawford Blagden, Jr, Elizabeth B. Strawbridge, Frederic K. Blagden, Samuel P. Blagden, nine grandchildren, five great grandchildren. Interment private. Memorial service will be at St. Marys in Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, NY, April 4, 1997 twelve o'clock (noon). In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ruffed Grouse Society would be appreciated.

title: An Outpost Whose Futures Have Come and Gone
description: The old yacht club lies in ruins by the banks of the mighty Congo, just like the Hotel Leopold, the grand old palace where Humphrey Bogart stayed during the filming of ''The African Queen'' here in 1950.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: House Arrest

title: January Retail Sales Rose 0.6%, Slightly Less Than Expected
description: Retail sales rose modestly in January, following a holiday shopping season that was much weaker than retailers had hoped, Government figures showed today.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Trees Lounge

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIER, EVA
description: MAIER-Eva, on Tuesday, Feb. 11, 1997. In memory of a loving and dear friend. Stephanie Noland and Kenneth Eluto

title: Giuliani's Report Card: Charts Full of Optimism
description: By the time Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani got to the 48th chart yesterday showing that New York City was somehow safer, cleaner, healthier, smarter and even drier than it had ever been, only one statistic from the torrent could still be remembered: the number of mayoral charts is now at least 30 percent larger than under any previous mayor.

title: Where 3 Died, a Home on the Margins of Society
description: The places where the homeless sleep are tucked away in Brighton Beach, hidden under the boardwalk in crevices that are dark even in daylight. Except for the panhandlers, and the small crowd in front of the liquor store, a passer-by might think that those who filled the encampments of the past have all found shelter.

title: Nanny, Accused of Murdering Baby, Enters Not Guilty Plea
description: A British teen-ager who came to the United States to work as a nanny for a Massachusetts family has been charged with with murdering the 9-month-old child she was hired to watch and has pleaded not guilty.

title: NORTHSTAR TO ACQUIRE MORRISON FOR $476 MILLION
description: The Northstar Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Morrison Petroleums Ltd. for about $643 million (Canadian), the equivalent of $476.4 million (United States). Under terms of the agreement, Morrison shareholders would receive seven-tenths of a share of Northstar stock for each share they hold. The two oil and gas exploration companies are both based in Calgary, Alberta. They also said that after the acquisition was completed, the new company would buy back about $325 million (Canadian) of stock. The agreement followed a protracted struggle by Morrison to resist a hostile offer from the Canadian 88 Energy Corporation and an affiliated concern, the West Central Capital Corporation.

title: New Swiss Generation Rejects Wartime Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Pledge Against Child Labor

title: Village Voice Owner Buys 2 Publications
description: Stern Publishing Inc., the bicoastal owner of New York's Village Voice and Southern California's L.A. Weekly and O.C. Weekly, has reached into the heartland to buy City Pages, an established arts, politics and entertainment weekly covering Minneapolis and St. Paul, the company has announced.

title: Clinton Demands Action on C.I.A. Nominee
description: Unprompted by any question, President Clinton used the occasion of a White House news conference today to urge the Senate to hold a hearing and a vote on Anthony Lake, his nominee for Director of Central Intelligence.

title: No Headline
description: ''Our men treat women like objects. They drink; they smoke; they have bad hygiene and care only about themselves. These Americans don't smoke or drink. They really seem to want to settle down and take care of their families.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, FERNE R.
description: SCHWARZ-Ferne R., of Reading, Pennsylvania. Beloved and adored of Mark, Roger, Saul, David, Lucy, Nancy, Jeffrey and Debbie. Her energy, wisdom, commitment and sense of humor will be forever missed. Donations to personal charities or the Park Avenue Synagogue. Memorial service in New York City at later date.

title: Clinton's Forecast of Surplus Is Disputed by Capitol Agency
description: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said today that President Clinton's budget plan would leave the Federal Government with a deficit of at least $49 billion in 2002 instead of the $17 billion surplus the White House projects.

title: Jets Open the Vault for Parcells
description: What price success? When it comes to Bill Parcells, the Jets seem to have no limit.

title: Sears to Open 110 Stores in New York by End of 1999
description: Sears Roebuck & Company will open 110 stores across New York State by the end of 1999, with the largest share of the expansion -- 2 large department stores and 33 smaller specialty stores -- in New York City, the senior economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Rising Spiral of Modernism
description: DESPITE its dynamic history, sculpture plays a wallflower role in contemporary art. Painting, photography, video and installation all take their turns in the limelight, but sculpture tends to stay to the side, marooned on museum terraces or dutifully plugging a decorative hole in this or that civic project.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: French Basques Dream of Autonomy
description: Across the Pyrenees, in the part of Basque country that lies in Spain, the 2.2 million Spanish Basques have managed to achieve a large measure of autonomy from Madrid.

title: Farm Workers Hit by a Freeze and Hard Times
description: Dressed in jeans and muddied sneakers, and packing a lunch bag in case they found jobs today, Tereso Reyes and Evangelina Alvarez got into the car of another couple in the fog of the early morning to drop in on the farms of South Florida's agricultural fields. Car pooling saved on gas and rejection -- at each stop the two men jointly asked for work for themselves and their wives. Each time the answer was no.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, THOMAS
description: TAYLOR-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Taylor, associated with The Times from 1949 until retiring in 1983.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEYERS, BONNIE LYNN
description: MEYERS-Bonnie Lynn. February 14, 1966-June 7, 1974. Dearest one, living in our hearts and minds and in your nieces and nephews. Mother, Mark, Jud, grandparents

title: Sporting Goods Concerns Agree to Combat Sale of Soccer Balls Made by Children
description: In a plan intended to fight child labor, a coalition of major sporting goods manufacturers and child-advocacy groups has pledged to combat the sale of soccer balls stitched by thousands of children in Pakistan, which produces 75 percent of the world's hand-stitched soccer balls.

title: As for Bipartisanship, the Future Looks Dim
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, IRVING
description: KORN-Irving, of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. On Feb. 13, 1997. Survived by his loving wife, Lee Korn, beloved sons Sheldon and Robert Korn. Five grandchildren: Ilene, Stacie, Melanie, Gary, and Wendy. Nine great grandchildren: Danny, Mathew, Jordan, Jamie, Emily, Ross, Lucas, Casey, and Dylan. Services will be held Sunday, Feb. 16, in Palm Beach. He will be missed.

title: Answers in Archives
description: To the Editor:

title: Nods in Governor's Race
description: State Senator James McGreevey of Woodbridge, who is seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, won endorsements yesterday from five of his party's county chairmen, his campaign office said. Mr. McGreevey now has the party leadership's support in 10 counties, mainly in northern and central New Jersey.

title: Staples Deal May Face F.T.C. Challenge
description: The Federal Trade Commission is considering a challenge to Staples Inc.'s planned $3.4 billion acquisition of Office Depot Inc. unless the companies can convince antitrust officials that the merger will not cause consumer prices to rise, a person familiar with the discussions between regulators and the companies said.

title: Nokia Reports 76% Profit Surge in Quarter
description: Nokia, one of the world's largest manufacturers of mobile telephones, said today that pretax profit jumped 76 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996 and that it expected strong growth this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLON, ANGELO ANTENORE
description: CARLON-Angelo Antenore. On February 12, 1997. The family of Antenore mourn his passing with deep sorrow. Viewing at Campbell's Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81st, February 19, 1997, 5-8PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, PAUL
description: CUMMINGS-Paul. Paul Cummings' Connoisseurship and diligent efforts, together with the guidance and support of the Drawing Committee of the Whitney Museum of American Art, built the Museum's modest group of 20th century American drawings into one of the preeminent collections. I was privileged to work with Paul and observe that his demanding impatience brought out the excellence in others. His knowledge and scholarship were recognized in the pioneering exhibitions of Whitney Museum drawings held at the National Gallery of Art and the Ochenbach Foundation. I will miss a singularily provocative contributor to the art community and express my deepest sympathy to his family. Tom Armstrong Director Emeritus Whitney Museum of American Art

title: Nudging Israel and Syria
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called on President Clinton yesterday with the Mideast peace effort back on track. Mr. Clinton tried to nudge matters ahead by encouraging Israel and Syria to return to the bargaining table to discuss the Golan Heights, diplomatic relations, security and Lebanon.

title: Even Bullish Analysts Are Looking Sheepish
description: The surge of the Dow Jones industrial average past 7,000 has been so swift this year that it has even left optimists like Hugh Johnson in its dust.

title: Gunfire Injures 2 Students At High Schools in Bronx
description: Two students were shot and wounded in separate incidents at Bronx high schools yesterday, even as Chancellor Rudy Crew was urging stiffer penalties against violent students, including expulsion.

title: Video Valentines to Russia, Seeking Patient Brides
description: Michael, a 51-year-old chiropractor, looks earnestly into the camera as he explains how he built up a thriving business in Pennsylvania, then retired early to devote himself to tennis, ballroom dancing and the pursuit of a Russian bride.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be legally observed.

title: HOUSE BACKS BILL ON MONEY TO AID FAMILY PLANNING
description: In a narrow victory for the Clinton Administration, the House today approved a measure to speed up the release of money for family-planning programs overseas.

title: Art in Review
description: Annette Messager

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, IRVING
description: SCHNEIDER-Irving. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Alan and Angel Schneider and Pam Fryer. Adoring grandfather of Nasha, Chandra, Roxanne, Evan and Cheyenne. Graveside services 10AM Friday, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: 18 Adelphi Trustees Resign, Abandoning a Court Battle
description: After months of scrutiny, bitter public hearings and ultimately a ruling against them, 18 trustees of Adelphi University resigned this afternoon, saying that they feared ''possibly fatal damage to this institution'' if they continued their fight for control of the university.

title: Swedish Manufacturer Reports Increase in Profit
description: Atlas Copco A.B., a Swedish maker of industrial machinery, reported yesterday that it had a 6.6 percent increase in pretax profit in the fourth quarter of 1996 compared with the quarter a year earlier. Its fourth-quarter pretax profit rose to 838 million kronor ($114 million) from 786 million kronor ($106 million).

title: Dr. Henry Margenau, 96, Yale Physicist and Spectroscopy Expert
description: Henry Margenau, a professor emeritus of physics and natural history at Yale University and an expert in spectroscopy, microwave theory, nuclear energy and the philosophy of science, died on Saturday in Hamden, Conn. He was 96 and lived in Hamden.

title: A Word To the Wise
description: Hugh Price of the National Urban League tells the story of Cambria Smith, a teen-ager who began to flourish academically when she left a lousy junior high school environment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and enrolled in the Science Skills Center, an experimental high school in downtown Brooklyn that emphasizes discipline, hard work and intellectual achievement.

title: F.D.A. Chief to Become Yale Medical Dean
description: Dr. David A. Kessler, who has been commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration longer than any one else, will become dean of the Yale University Medical School on July 1.

title: Detours Clog East Side After a Steam Pipe Releases Asbestos
description: A 24-inch steam pipe ruptured at a Manhattan construction site yesterday morning, spraying some of the pipe's asbestos insulation into the air and disrupting traffic near the Queens-Midtown Tunnel through the evening rush hour.

title: Leonard Is Ready to Fight
description: SUGAR RAY LEONARD is ready. He is certainly rested. He has not fought since losing to TERRY NORRIS in 1991. But he will face HECTOR CAMACHO on March 1 in Atlantic City in a pay-per-view bout rescheduled when New Jersey regulators sought to bar the original promoter for alleged mob ties. The bout was originally scheduled for Feb. 28.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSTROW, IRENE
description: OSTROW-Irene. Thank you for everything. I miss you. S.

title: Too Many Federal Court Vacancies
description: The backlog of pending cases in the Federal court system continues to grow as aggressive partisan tactics by Senate Republicans and neglect by the Clinton Administration have nearly paralyzed the confirmation process for new Federal judges. The result is delayed justice for litigants and an unreasonable burden on the courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARCY, JOHN J
description: DARCY-John J. Attorney, of Fairfield, CT, died of cancer February 12, 1997. Born January 10, 1924 in Lahinch, Ireland. Beloved husband of fifty years to Lucile (nee Lebowich). Cherished father of Jonathan, Martha, Sam and Eve.

title: F.B.I. Looks at Whether China Funneled Money to Democrats
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining whether Chinese officials or their agents may have used people close to President Clinton to give money secretly to the Democratic Party over the last five years, Government officials said today.

title: U.S. Remains Odd Man Out In Global Push For Phone Deal
description: With only two days left in talks aimed at opening up the $600 billion worldwide market for telecommunication services, the power to forge or to kill an agreement lies almost exclusively with the United States.

title: A Gay Couple's Breakup In a Setting of Solidarity
description: Just because it has a cuddly sounding title and is opening on Valentine's Day, don't expect ''Boyfriends'' to be a carnival of cozy hearts-and-flowers cheer. This no-budget English movie, which follows the interactions of three gay male couples during a country weekend in which they sort out their relationships, offers a dourly realistic view of contemporary romance.

title: A Whole New Meaning For Executive Privilege
description: Luther Whitney, the courtly old burglar played by Clint Eastwood in his new thriller, ''Absolute Power,'' has a mansion to rob. His plans have been meticulously laid. But just as Luther is in the midst of raiding a walk-in vault filled with loot, the heist is interrupted and Luther is trapped behind a one-way mirror. What he glimpses in an adjoining bedroom is really something to squint about.

title: Sales Up for Small and Medium Condos
description: Spurred in part by the increasing cost of rental apartments, sales of small and mid-sized Manhattan condominiums rose significantly last year, while sales numbers for bigger condos -- with a more limited supply -- remained relatively flat.

title: Shut Up and Drive
description: Sometimes it takes real effort and ingenuity to prove the obvious. Such is the case with the work of two University of Toronto researchers who have published a report in The New England Journal of Medicine demonstrating that driving while talking on a cellular phone is a bad idea.

title: Justice May Require Second Trial on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch Government Assists in Fokker Talks
description: The Dutch Government confirmed yesterday that it was involved in talks on a rescue plan for Fokker N.V., the collapsed aircraft builder, and said the discussions were being taken seriously. A Government spokesman confirmed reports that the Minister for Economic Affairs, Hans Wijers, had been closely involved in talks among a number of parties and that the initiative for the plan came from the Dutch industrial company Begemann N.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILO, MARIUS, ESQ.
description: PILO-Marius, Esq. On February 11, 1997. The Sephardic Jewish Brotherhood of America notes with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed founding member & past President, Marius Pilo. His many years of loyal and devoted service added immeasurably to the progress of our organization. We extend our condolences to his family. Bernard Ouziel, President

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Robert D. Currie, Stage Manager, 62
description: Robert D. Currie, the production manager for City Center, died on Wednesday at Tisch Hospital, New York University Medical Center, in Manhattan. He was 62 and had homes in Manhattan and North Bushkill, Pa.

title: $25 and Under
description: The term comfort food has earned a pedestal in cliche heaven over the last 10 years, but that has not made the nurturing, unthreatening dishes embraced by the term any less popular. Nor has it discouraged restaurants from endless offerings of meatloaf, roast chicken, salmon and steak. Can you chew mashed potatoes and yawn at the same time?

title: The Spoken Word
description: PINEWOODS DIALOGUE: AN AFTERNOON WITH DAVID LYNCH, American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue and 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. A screening of Mr. Lynch's new film, ''Lost Highway,'' followed by a discussion with the film maker. Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets, $24; $12 for members of the museum. Information: (718) 784-0077.

title: A New Surge of Growth, Just as Death Cut It Off
description: When Peter Cain died of a cerebral hemorrhage last month, he was 37 and in the middle of a great leap forward in his chosen field, which was painting. He gained visibility in the late 1980's as a ''car painter,'' a maker of cool yet oddly visceral, if not sexual, images of disturbingly truncated Mercedeses and other cars.

title: Subway Inefficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP., Dallas, agreed to acquire Robbins Inc.'s Residential Flooring division and its Search Flooring Inc. affiliate for about $10 million in cash, $40 million to $45 million in short-term capitalized leases and obligations and about $10 million in debt.

title: For Jarrett and Earnhardt, May the Best Dale Triumph
description: The Super Bowl of Nascar racing, the 34th annual Daytona 500, completed its 42-car field today with two veterans named Dale stamping themselves as notable contenders.

title: Brodeur Scores a Top 10 in Shutout
description: The statistics are getting better for Martin Brodeur, the leading goaltender in the National Hockey League. After going through a stretch in which he allowed several soft goals, Brodeur is now undefeated in his last 10 starts after tonight's 4-0 victory over the Hartford Whalers.

title: King Family Makes Appeal For Trial for James Earl Ray
description: The family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. publicly appealed today for a trial for James Earl Ray, who confessed to killing Dr. King but then recanted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLEY, ARCHIBALD RICHARD, M.D.
description: FOLEY-Archibald Richard, M.D. On February 12, 1997. Survived by his sister, Edna Foley Gannon, and many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Visitation at the Abbey (Campbell Bldg) 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Friday 5-7PM. Mass of Resurrection at the Church of Our Saviour, Park Avenue at 38th Street, Saturday 10:30 AM. Burial will be in Kingston, Ontario, Canada. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Fountain House or a charity of your choice.

title: For Many From Hong Kong, Vancouver Is a Way Station
description: On Thursday nights in downtown Vancouver, the back room at the Victoria restaurant fills with Chinese women who have come to play mah-jongg, feast on delicacies like marinated jellyfish and show off jewels, cell phones and other gifts from their husbands, who are all back in Hong Kong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOFF, GUSSIE
description: SOLOFF-Gussie, on February 13, 1997, in Hollywood, FL. Beloved wife of the late William. Dear mother of Iris Gotterer and Buddy Soloff. Son-in-law of Stan. Daughter-in-law of Marsha. Loving grandmother of Jon Gotterer, Nina Molin, Amy and Bruce Gutenplan and Hilarie and Wendy Soloff. Great-grandmother of Hannah, Willie Moe and Jackson. Graveside services on Sunday, Feb. 16, 1997 at 10:30AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For information Gutterman's Inc, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Prettiness And a Battle
description: Michael Smuin has had a long and distinguished career in ballet, musical theater and film, as both a dancer and a Tony and Emmy Award-winning choreographer. To judge from the program presented by Smuin Ballets/SF on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Smuin is a choreographer in love with the sheer prettiness of classical ballet and ballet bodies. Given the duality of his work, however, one might have expected the evening to be a good deal more boldly theatrical.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Jean D. Hewitt, a former food writer and home economist for The New York Times, referred incorrectly to the opening of The Times's test kitchen. It was opened in 1944; Mrs. Hewitt planned and supervised a major renovation in 1969.

title: Restaurants
description: Everybody in New York seems to be looking for the perfect neighborhood restaurant.

title: Liton Negotiating With General Instrument
description: Liton Group of Taiwan said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the Taiwanese semiconductor operations of General Instrument Corporation. In what would be the latest in a series of purchases of foreign assets by Taiwanese technology companies, Liton would pay about $250 million for the operations, according to a report in Economic Daily News, Taiwan's top business daily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, THOMAS J
description: FLANAGAN-Thomas J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Flanagan, associated with The Times from 1960 until retiring in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, FLORENCE (SEIDE)
description: GRAY-Florence (Seide). In her 98th year after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin F. Gray. Mother of Jane and Allen Schultz, Barbara and Seymour Jasper. Grandmother of four and great grandmother of six. Graveside service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your charity of choice.

title: For Some Battered Women, Aid Is Only a Promise
description: Since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office with a pledge to tackle domestic violence, battered women have been urged to come forward by subway and bus posters and by specially trained police officers and hospital emergency room workers. But when they do, by calling a special line, there is often no help available for them: no shelter and no social services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAIS, BERTHA
description: WAIS-Bertha. On February 12, 1997. Beloved sister of Pauline. Funeral services private.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: TWO SHOT AT SCHOOLS -- As officials described a get-tough policy on weapons, two students were shot in separate incidents at New York City schools. B3.

title: Price Soars and Yield Falls To 6.62% on 30-Year Bond
description: Bond investors shrugged off a mediocre Treasury auction yesterday and went on a buying spree.

title: By Whatever Name, Easier to Like
description: THE paradoxical vogue for outsider art makes you wonder what outsider means, anyway. Outside what? Especially in an art scene as fragmented as it is? The term has become a catchall for the art of the academically untrained, the insane and children, as if the work of a preternaturally gifted black artist like Thornton Dial were related to the crayon scribbles of a 3-year-old.

title: Irabu Tells Panel He Wants to Be a Yankee, Not a Padre
description: Hideki Irabu made his pitch yesterday to be permitted to follow his heroes as a member of the Yankees. Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Mickey Mantle were the players the Japanese pitcher cited as the attraction the Yankees hold for him.

title: Skating Coverage May Be Sliding Out of Control
description: The United States figure skating championships used to be such a singular event on ABC-TV, before there were rock-and-roll skaters, skaters named Elvis, skaters pretending to be Elvis, skaters marrying their agents or former skaters foiling their own kidnappings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, THOMAS B
description: STODDARD-Thomas B. The board and staff of Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund mourn the death of Thomas B. Stoddard, civil rights champion and Lambda's former executive director. To lesbians, gay men, people with HIV and AIDS, and Lambda in particular, Tom was not just a part of our civil rights struggle, he was an irreplaceable leader and friend. As Lambda's executive director from 1986 to 1992, when the country rarely saw such a persuasive and confident gay activist demanding public attention and respect, Tom taught us the power of pride, dedication, and even humor. He was another of the great leaders of our civil rights struggle who kept fighting until his death. The force of his eloquence and intellect, and his determination to continue the fight for justice even in the face of his own illness with AIDS, inspires Lambda and many others for the future. Lambda expresses sympathies to Tom's spouse, Walter Rieman, and other members of his family. Kevin M. Cathcart, Executive Director Shedrick O. Davis, III Gale Richards, Co-Chairs of the Board of Directors Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the prospects for young astronomers misidentified the institution that operates the Hale 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar. It is the California Institute of Technology, not the University of California.

title: Drug Therapy At Diet Centers Raises Fears
description: Last summer, Jenny Craig Inc.'s revenues and stock plummeted after a new weight loss drug hit the market, luring away customers eager to try a quick fix.

title: A Defector From Korea Is a Hot Potato For Beijing
description: Facing a diplomatic nightmare, the Chinese authorities pleaded today for calm on the Korean peninsula and played for time as they threw a cordon of troops around a South Korean Embassy building where a stalwart of North Korea's Government has taken refuge, apparently in an attempt to defect to Seoul.

title: A Plea for Treating People Humanely
description: It was 25 years ago that Geraldo Rivera, using a stolen key, entered the Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded and exposed its nightmarish conditions on WABC-TV. As he recounts the shock of what he saw at this now defunct Staten Island institution in the documentary ''Unforgotten: 25 Years After Willowbrook,'' he calls it ''the defining moment of my life'' and begins to weep.

title: Clinton Wants Anti-Drug Ads for Youths
description: In a new effort to stem the spiraling rise of illegal drug use by adolescents, the Clinton Administration wants to spend $175 million on a national advertising campaign that would seek to dissuade teen-agers from experimenting with marijuana and other drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, FLORENCE S
description: GRAY-Florence S. Nana I have been touched by an angel. Thank you for demonstrating the value of family. Memories of you will be with me forever. Johnny

title: Pohang Steel to Buy Businesses From Sammi
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company agreed yesterday to buy businesses from the debt-ridden Sammi Steel Company for 719.4 billion won ($827 million). Sammi is a South Korean specialty steelmaker that profited at home only to expand overseas beyond its means, racking up more than $1.2 billion of debt -- an amount equivalent to its annual sales. Pohang, also of South Korea, is the world's second-largest steel producer, behind the Nippon Steel Corporation of Japan.

title: Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal restaurant review last Friday, about the City Wine and Cigar Company, misidentified the club's designer and referred incorrectly to his previous work. He is Chris Smith, not Chris Williams. Mr. Smith was a member of the team that designed Nobu; he was not the sole designer.

title: New Rwanda Killings Dim Hopes for Amity
description: The young trader knew something was odd about the military checkpoint when the soldiers asked the passengers of four minivans to get out and sit on the grass. The seven guards were shabbily dressed, but they carried automatic weapons.

title: Military Sex Abuse Scandal May Start at Top
description: To the Editor:

title: A Movie on His Life Enrages George Wallace
description: In one scene, a black servant, ice pick in hand, stands behind a seated George Wallace and briefly considers stabbing him in the back for the pain he has caused black people in the struggle over civil rights.

title: No Headline
description: ''We want them to tell the truth -- the good, the bad and the ugly. But do not make things up that did not occur.''

title: Giving Movement to Balanchine's Faith
description: ''Agon,'' the landmark ballet by George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky that astonished the dance world in 1957, has rarely been danced better than it was on Thursday night by the New York City Ballet.

title: Peru Crisis Takes Toll on Hostages' Health
description: As negotiations to end the rebel siege at the Japanese Embassy residence here proceed ever so slowly, the physical and psychological well-being of the 72 hostages inside is deteriorating, raising concern that the captives will suffer severe medical consequences if the crisis is not resolved soon.

title: The Three Sisters, Avenged: A Dominican Drama
description: When the dictator Rafael Trujillo had the sisters Patria, Minerva and Maria Teresa Mirabal killed in 1960, he and his minions thought they were finally rid of a threat to both their power and their egos.

title: INSIDE
description: Child Agency Details Errors

title: Miami Acquires Mashburn From Dallas to Bolster Its Firepower
description: Pat Riley wanted another scorer. Jamal Mashburn wanted a change of scenery. Both men got their wish yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: What? No Sneakers?
description: Notes for a book on walking:

title: The New Hollywood
description: ''This is Hollywood,'' says Franklin Foer, a writer for Slate, the on-line magazine that Michael Kinsley created for Microsoft. Mr. Foer was joking, but just barely. The ''campus'' outside Seattle housing Slate and Microsoft's other ''interactive media'' is as unglitzy as any suburban office park. Yet the Hollywood analogy is still correct. The atmosphere here -- part creative ferment, part gold rush -- recalls the rapidly expanding movie studios of the late 1920's just as sound came in.

title: After Adelphi, Educators Differ on Ethical Issues
description: Many colleges, universities and other nonprofit organizations depend heavily on board members for money and other contributions, and that world has closely followed the New York Board of Regents ruling this week expelling trustees of Adelphi University who were accused of failing to separate their business interests from the university's and of paying the Adelphi president too much.

title: On Envying Harriman
description: To the Editor:

title: For Torre, Yearning To Regain Spirit of '96
description: One year ago, Joe Torre sat in his new manager's office and boldly declared that the Yankees could advance to the World Series. Some mouths opened, but Torre's prediction proved correct.

title: Clifton, a Career Jet, Retires
description: Kyle Clifton, a gifted middle linebacker who never realized his dream of helping the Jets win a championship -- a Don Mattingly of sorts, in a helmet and shoulder pads -- announced his retirement yesterday after spending 13 seasons in the National Football League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, GRETA M.
description: LANDIS-Greta M. On November 11, 1996. Wife of the late George Landis. Survived by the Valka family. Supporting member Museum of Jewish Heritage, AMIT Women's Inc. which supports children's homes in Israel, Keren-OR, Inc. which treats blind children in Israel. Memorial service to be held on Thursday, February 20, 1997, at 10AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: Museum Given A van Gogh
description: Pamela Harriman has left van Gogh's 1890 still life ''White Roses'' to the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The painting, which depicts a profusion of white roses against a green background, will be the first van Gogh still life to enter the permanent collection. Mrs. Harriman, the United States Ambassador to France, died on Feb. 5 in Paris.

title: Meno and Sand Upset in Pairs
description: In the first upset of the national championships, Kyoko Ina and Jason Dungjen of the Figure Skating Club of New York beat the two-time world bronze medalists Jenni Meno and Todd Sand in tonight's long program to win the gold.

title: Canada to Let Foreign Banks Compete More
description: Canada plans to bolster competition in its tightly controlled banking industry by loosening restrictions on foreign banks from the United States and other countries, officials in Ottawa announced today.

title: Campbell Tries to Light A Fire Under Rangers
description: Rangers Coach Colin Campbell is a reflective man. But he cannot seem to figure out why his team lacks a sense of urgency. Today he said he was not sure his team was desperate enough or committed enough to warrant trading its first-round draft pick for a player who could help them make a run at the Stanley Cup.

title: With Business Sluggish, Resorts Try to Woo Women
description: From the time she was 4, Susan Kettle spent almost every weekend on the slopes during ski season. ''I even chose Fort Lewis College in Durango because it's near Purgatory,'' the 35-year-old resident of Highlands Ranch, Colo., said, referring to the noted ski resort. ''And I taught my husband, Danny, to ski.''

title: Kwan Overcomes Jitters With Grace As Bobek Stumbles
description: In figure skating, where gossip and rumor travel at the speed of light, Nicole Bobek had the buzz of a hot stock tip. The insider trading before tonight's short program was brisk: her back pains were gone. She was landing the triple lutz. Don't count her out. If she could only hold it together, and that was a big if, maybe she would actually give Michelle Kwan a run for her money at the national championships.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: John R. Bartels, 99, Dies; Was Oldest Federal Judge
description: John R. Bartels, for 38 years a Federal judge of the Eastern District of New York, died on Thursday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Europe's Shameful Trade In Silence
description: Europe begins, as the Italian writer Roberto Calasso reminds us in ''The Marriage of Cadmus and Harmony,'' with a bull, and a rape. Europa was an Asian maiden abducted by a God (who changed himself, for the occasion, into a white bull), and was held captive in a new land that came, in time, to bear her name. The prisoner of Zeus's unending desire for mortal flesh, Europa has been avenged by history. Zeus is just a story now. He is powerless; but Europe is alive.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINE PILOTS STRIKE BUT CLINTON ORDERS THEM BACK
description: Invoking seldom-used emergency powers, President Clinton intervened today minutes after midnight to halt a strike by American Airlines pilots that had threatened to disrupt air travel nationwide.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Pilots Walk Out; Clinton Orders Them Back

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIE, ROBERT
description: CURRIE-Robert. The staff of Alan Wasser Assocs. mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Robert Currie. We express our profound sympathies to his family and to his companion, Susan Bell.

title: What Comes Down After Georgia's Flag?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Appears To Ease Stance In Global Talks On Phone Deal
description: After months of playing hardball in global trade talks, the United States is on the verge of endorsing on Saturday a sweeping agreement that would commit most of the world to opening telecommunication markets to competition, American officials indicated tonight.

title: Chevy Chase, Gambling on a Good Time
description: To the legions who have returned as losers from the glitzy playgrounds of the Nevada desert can now be added the people responsible for ''Vegas Vacation.''

title: Mount Sinai And N.Y.U. Halt Merger
description: A proposed merger by New York University and Mount Sinai Medical Centers, which for the first time would have combined not only two hospitals but also their medical schools, has fallen apart because the two sides failed to agree on who would control the medical school.

title: Defining Charity With Faith, Hope and a Check
description: On New Year's Eve, Howard M. Kaplan sat down to send his annual contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and to consider, for a moment, the general state of affairs. Mr. Kaplan was among the many contributors who took the occasion of their charitable gift as an opportunity to communicate their thoughts and opinions. All readers of The New York Times, they are used to hearing about the world according to the newspaper; in notes and letters accompanying their donations, they presented the world according to them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, ANITA
description: ROSENFELD-Anita. February 13, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Stephen and his wife Elise, Linda and her husband Tom. Cherished grandmother of Scott and David. Adoring great grandmother of Rhys, Evan and Sidney-Rose. Loving sister of Essie. Services on Sunday, at 11 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMENDOLA, MARIO J.
description: AMENDOLA-Mario J., of Mt. Vernon, N.Y. on February 14, 1997. Brother of Frank, Gilda, Lena and Ann. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 24 and 7-9 P.M. Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Sts. Peter and Paul Church, Fleetwood Tuesday, February 18 at 10 A.M.

title: Dispute Arises Over Proposal For Wiretaps
description: An old quarrel about the F.B.I.'s plan to modernize its system for eavesdropping on telephone conversations has flared anew.

title: Balancing Bleakness And Feelings
description: At the beginning of Julia Heyward's ''Miracles in Reverse,'' a multimedia performance at the Kitchen (512 West 19th Street, Chelsea) through tomorrow, a woman sits in a room while eerie keyboard tones and channel-surfing snippets fill the air.

title: Ward Could Skip Pacer Game
description: Charlie Ward received treatment on his sprained left ankle yesterday, but there is no guarantee that the Knicks' reserve point guard will be able to play in tomorrow's game against the Indiana Pacers. ''We're not sure,'' Coach Jeff Van Gundy said yesterday.

title: Air Traveler's Lament: Just Get Me Out of Here
description: Somewhere along the coast of Grenada, a chartered boat rocks gently in blue-green waters, beckoning Frank Iaccio, the way a cradle beckons a tired child. The sands of Puerto Rico, meanwhile, await William Hult, who works so hard. He needs this weekend getaway. He really needs it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARENSBERG, CONRAD M
description: ARENSBERG-Conrad M. The members of the Department of Anthropology at Columbia University, together with their colleagues at Barnard College and Teachers College mourn the death of their teacher, colleague, and friend of many years, on February 10. His warmth of heart, world-encompassing scholarship, intergrity and defiant courage have left an indelible mark upon his friends and students, and the discipline as a whole. His life and work have been a great gift to all of us.

title: N.J. Budget Proposal Isn't 'Fiscal Chicanery'
description: To the Editor:

title: EMS CHEMIE TO JOIN H.B. FULLER IN CHEMICALS VENTURE
description: Ems Chemie Holding A.G., a chemical and engineering company based in Zurich, will combine its auto parts specialty chemicals business with that of the H. B. Fuller Company, based in St. Paul. Terms were not disclosed. Ems will contribute its Ems-Togo unit, and Fuller will bring its H. B. Fuller Automotive Company into the venture, to be called Eftec. It will supply adhesives, coatings and sealants to the automotive industry and will post 1997 sales of about $250 million, Fuller said. Fuller will own 70 percent of Eftec's American operations, and Ems will hold 70 percent of Eftec's European operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, BRUCE CHARLES, M.D.
description: BEHR-Bruce Charles, M.D., 48, on February 12, 1997. Dear husband of Tami. Loving father of Brittany and Joshua. Dearest beloved son of Dr. Irving and Florence Behr. Devoted brother of Joan and Donald Schaeffer and adoring uncle of Andrew Schaeffer. Funeral services on Sunday, 9:30 AM at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWENS, NAOMI RUTH LOEFER
description: OWENS-Naomi Ruth Loefer, who died peacefully in her sleep in the early morning of February 4, 1997. It was the culmination of her 12 year battle with breast cancer. She leaves behind her husband of 35 years Ray Owens, her brother Jeffrey Loefer and a host of friends. She was born July 6, 1937 in Berea, Kentucky and then lived in San Antonio, Texas, and then in Altadena, California. She had a BA degree from Reed College, and a MA in Anthropology from the University of Chicago and taught at the University of Texas at Austin and at Rajshahi University in Bangladesh. A memorial service will be held for Naomi at 15th Street Meeting of Friends, 15 Rutherford place, New York, New York, at 1:30PM, Saturday, March 1, 1997.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORNICK, BESS
description: GORNICK-Bess, 94, on February 13, 1997, in NYC. She is survived by her daughter, Vivian, and a son, Fred, her granddaughters, Janet and Lisa, and a great-grandson, Zachary. Memorial services will be held on Sunday, February 16, at 2:30 P.M., at Wien & Wien, 152 Second Avenue, New York City.

title: U.S. Aide Assails Colombia as New Drug Sanctions Are Studied
description: A senior State Department official lashed out at the Colombian Government today for ''cooperating'' with drug traffickers and stopped just short of predicting that the Clinton Administration would impose economic sanctions on Colombia for the second year in a row.

title: TCF FINANCIAL TO BUY COMPUTER LEASING COMPANY
description: The TCF Financial Corporation agreed to acquire the Winthrop Resources Corporation for $326 million in stock. Winthrop leases computers, telecommunications systems and other equipment. TCF is a savings bank with $7.1 billion in assets. It offered stock worth $36.50 a share based on its closing price on Thursday. TCF will pay 6.9 million shares, exchanging one share for 1.2877 Winthrop shares. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, TCF shares fell 62.5 cents, to $46.50. In Nasdaq trading, Winthrop stock gained 37.5 cents, to $34.375.

title: Nathan Lerner, 83, Innovator In Techniques of Photography
description: Nathan Lerner, a photographer, designer and teacher, died on Feb. 8 at Northwestern Hospital in Chicago. He was 83, and lived in Chicago.

title: Drive to Restore Police Post
description: A group of Atlantic City residents began collecting signatures yesterday on petitions calling for a special election to restore the post of police chief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPERMAN, PAULA
description: KOPPERMAN-Paula. On February 11, 1997. Loving mother of Diane, dear sister of Sara, Fannie, Alice and Rose. Graveside service 1pm at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Science Times on Tuesday about the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed air quality standards misstated the proposed and current limits on ozone. The proposed limit is 0.08 parts per million, not per billion. The current limit is 0.12 parts per million, not per billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, IRVING
description: KORN-Irving. Deeply saddened by the death of this caring man devoted to family, friends and charitable causes, I cherish the decades of professional challenge and experiences we shared. Sylvia joins in heartfelt condolences to his family. Bernard Rackear

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, RICHARD MARSHALL
description: CASHIN-Richard Marshall, 72, international aid official, resident of New York City and Cotuit, MA, died peacefully on February 13 of complications from pulmonary fibrosis. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Mary Walsh Cashin, four children, Anne Goldenheim of Wilton, CT, Richard M. Cashin, Jr. of New York City, Jane Demers of North Andover, MA, and Stephen Cashin of Washington, D.C., as well as twelve grandchildren and a sister, Mary J. Cashin of Westwood, MA, formerly of West Roxbury, MA. Born April 3, 1924 in Boston, he was a graduate of Roxbury Latin School (Class of 1942), Harvard College (Class of 1946), Boston University (1949), and Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies (1959). An Army veteran of World War II, he was an officer in the Department of State for 29 years, first on the staff of the U.S. Office of Refugee and Migration Affairs, and subsequently in the Agency for International Development, serving tours in Libya and Ethiopia, and serving as Director of the programs in Ghana, Indonesia, and Pakistan.
