He then joined the United Nations World Food Programme in Rome, serving for eight years as the Director of Program and Policy before returning to the United States where he joined the Catholic Relief Services in a similar capacity. In recent years, he volunteered his services at the Interfaith Hunger Appeal and the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, both in New York City. He was a member of Dacor, Inc. and the Knights of Malta. He spent his life in the service of the poor, always with dignity and respect. Visiting hours will be held Monday, February 17 from 79 PM at St. John the Evangelist Church, 55th St and 1st Ave, Manhattan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said Tuesday, February 18 at 10 AM, also at St. John the Evangelist Church. Burial will be in St. Joseph's Cemetery in West Roxbury, MA on Wednesday, February 19 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Roxbury Latin School.

title: Selling Dr. Seuss
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Almost all team events place a premium on partnership experience and sophistication.

title: Eurotunnel Says Sales Rose Despite Fire
description: Eurotunnel, the operator of the English Channel tunnel, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter sales rose slightly despite a fire in November that disrupted service. The company said fourth-quarter sales jumped in French francs and plunged in British pounds largely because the pound rose 18 percent against the franc last year. Neutralizing the effects of currency fluctuations, sales rose about 3 percent.

title: Grand Old Braggarts
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Hearts Are Worn On the Sleeve
description: MARIO RIBAUDO was thinking about hearts yesterday. Not the fuzzy red Will-You-Be-My-Valentine ones, but the real thing. What else would you expect from Mr. Ribaudo, the Sicilian Liver Guy at the Arthur Avenue Market, where he sells lamb hearts, brains and sweetbreads?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKS, CLARA
description: LAKS-Clara. On Feb. 13, 1997. Loving mother of Eugene and Cynthia Laks, Martha and Arthur Hausman, and Norma and David Kesselschmidt. Beloved grandmother of Allison, Jason, Jeremy and Diana. Services were held privately.

title: Chinatown Groups Ask Mayor to Rethink Fireworks Ban
description: Calling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's ban on fireworks a violation of the freedom of speech and religion, business owners and community advocates in Chinatown appealed to the Mayor yesterday to allow firecrackers to be set off in designated areas for the conclusion of the Chinese New Year celebrations on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELINK, HELEN
description: BELINK-Helen. Beloved mother of Susan and Alan, cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Alexandra, sister of Muriel, passed peacefully, February 11, 1997, on the evening of wedding anniversary with her dearly beloved husband, Cantor Norman Belink, Cantor Emeritus, Temple Sinai of Roslyn. Vivacious, life loving, life giving, we hold our mother in our hearts forever. Funeral Service graveside, on Sunday, February 16, 11:00 A.M. at New Montefiore Cemetery. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Dr. Steven Goodman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOSEPH
description: MURPHY-Joseph. Devoted uncle of John and Stephen. Interment in Marlboro, Massachusetts. For information call John P. Rowe Funeral Home, 508-485-0855.

title: Giants and Hamilton Agree on a Contract
description: The Giants agreed to terms yesterday with defensive end Keith Hamilton, an unrestricted free agent, on the eve of the free agent signing period. Terms of the deal were unavailable.

title: AOL's Flat Rate Makes Sound Business Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore's Staff Did Not Object To Temple Event, Aide Says
description: Despite a warning from the National Security Council that a fund-raising luncheon at a Buddhist temple should be approached with ''great, great caution,'' Vice President Al Gore made the appearance anyway after his own national security adviser raised no objections to the trip, Mr. Gore's spokeswoman said today.

title: Plan to Raise Home Values
description: In the two decades since gambling arrived in Atlantic City, neighboring Ventnor has seen its housing stock decline, and the strain on municipal services increase, its Mayor said yesterday.

title: Criticism of Lobbying Is False Issue, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani angrily sought to quell criticism of his administration's dealings with lobbyists yesterday, even as two of his most prominent advisers promised that they would temporarily cease lobbying city agencies.

title: Excerpts of Remarks By Giuliani on Lobbying
description: In his weekly radio show on WABC-AM yesterday morning and at a news conference later in the day, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani expressed his views on lobbying. Here are excerpts of those remarks.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Questions Its Leader
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People returned to New York yesterday for its annual meeting, with members expressing optimism about the group's financial health but raising questions about the temperament and managerial style of its new leader, Kweisi Mfume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARR, CHARLOTTE A
description: BARR-Charlotte A. Loved wife of the late Jerome. Loving mother of Marjorie and Charles Spector. Cherished grandmother of Brian and Madeline Spector, Emily Spector, Monica and Joel Greenberg. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 10:15 AM, Sunday.

title: Detroit Newspaper Unions Offer to Go Back to Work
description: The striking Detroit newspaper unions announced yesterday that they would make an unconditional offer to send 2,000 employees of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press back to work after 20 months off the job.

title: Part of Autopsy Is Released In Slaying of Colorado Girl
description: A Boulder County District Judge released portions of the autopsy of JonBenet Ramsey today, indicating that the 6-year-old beauty princess was not only strangled, but also suffered severe head injuries and some kind of sexual assault.

title: Valentine's Day Conviction
description: A Passaic man was convicted yesterday of murdering an acquaintance who had inadvertently tipped off his girlfriend that he was seeing another woman, prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, RICHARD J.
description: JACOBY-Richard J. Of Bronxville, N.Y., On Feb. 14, 1997. Husband of the late Gail, father of Tracy, R.J. and Katie. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-5 PM Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, February 17, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Gail Williams Jacoby Memorial Scholarship, C/O St. Lawrence University, Canton, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLEY, MIRON M.
description: WALLEY-Miron M. Age 88, an attorney. Died of congested heart failure on February 12, 1997 in Philadelphia, PA. Formerly of Plainfield, NJ and Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Silvia S. Walley and devoted father of William A. Walley, Barbara W. Schaff, and David G. Walley. Loving grandfather of eight grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. The family kindly asks that contiributions in his memory be made to The Rutgers Law School Alumni Fund, College Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ. Memorial service will be announced at a later date in Palm Beach, FL.

title: Bradley's Game Remains A.W.O.L.
description: Shawn Bradley and John Calipari had their heart-to-heart talk. The result remains to be seen.

title: Forbes Sells Newspapers
description: Forbes Inc. has sold its New Jersey newspapers for an undisclosed amount to the North Jersey Newspapers Company, a unit of Medianews Group.

title: Chinese Immigrants From Stranded Ship Are to Be Released
description: The Clinton Administration decided yesterday to release all 53 remaining illegal Chinese immigrants who have been detained by Federal immigration authorities since the freighter Golden Venture ran aground off Queens three years and eight months ago.

title: Train Station Turnabout
description: An underused train and bus station is to be transformed into a commercial complex in an effort to revitalize impoverished Asbury Park.

title: School Budget Is Attacked As Inadequate
description: Many governors and President Clinton have pushed ambitious new education programs recently, but Gov. John G. Rowland took a different tack in the budget he presented on Thursday. He did not raise spending on state schools, he trimmed the budget for higher education and he offered a small spending increase for one of the most pressing educational issues facing the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCREA, JAMES K.
description: McCREA-James K. Beloved father of James Terence McCrea. Passed away on February 13, 1997, in New York City. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street today, on Saturday, February 15th, 3 P.M. Friends will be received starting at 2 P.M.

title: Company Briefs
description: FOSTER WHEELER CORP., Clinton, N.J., an engineering and construction company, is taking a pretax charge of $24 million in its fourth quarter to reflect costs associated with asbestos litigation that it may not be able to recover from insurers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABDOO, FREDERICK
description: ABDOO-Frederick The members of the Columbia College Alumni Association mourn the passing of its loyal alumnus, Frederick Abdoo, an active and generous supporter of the college and a devoted member of the class of 1941. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Helen, his children and family. Fred will be missed by all of us.

title: Treasury Prices Move Higher Again on Good Economic News
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to forge ahead yesterday on good economic news, but further gains were stymied by profit taking in a shortened trading session ahead of the long Washington's Birthday weekend.

title: My Cheap Thrill
description: Drinking coffee with the President of the United States and a dozen other people was well worth the cost of the round-trip air fare from Boston to Washington.

title: Mayor Giuliani Ignores the Point
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposal for a new law banning lobbying of all New York City agencies is a good idea only if his goal is diversion. Challenged to clean up an embarrassing problem in his own administration, he responded with a spur-of-the-moment legislative proposal that is both sweeping and impractical. It is as if Mr. Giuliani were criticized for parking at a crosswalk and responded by banning cars from the city.

title: Display of Two 1526 Bibles Celebrates Translator
description: Reunions that unite the long-separated are momentous occasions. So it seemed appropriate that a few people should have gathered yesterday morning to watch as an employee of the New York Public Library gently wheeled out a cart containing the only two complete copies of a nearly 500-year-old New Testament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLEY, ARCHIBALD RICHARD, M.D.
description: FOLEY-Archibald Richard, M.D. On February 12, 1997. Survived by his sister, Edna Foley Gannon, and many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Visitation at the Abbey (Campbell Bldg) 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Friday 5-7PM. Mass of Resurrection at the Church of Our Saviour, Park Avenue at 38th Street, Saturday 10:30 AM. Burial will be in Kingston, Ontario, Canada. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Fountain House or a charity of your choice.

title: Sidney Poitier as a Shrewd, Subtle Mandela
description: Nelson Mandela is so familiar a presence it is hard to believe any actor could displace him. And the banner-image of him is so simple -- suggesting only a saintly endurance that carried him through decades as a political prisoner under apartheid -- it is hard to imagine a television movie that sees him in more complex terms. But in ''Mandela and de Klerk,'' Sidney Poitier and Nelson Mandela merge with astonishing ease, like a double-exposure photograph in which one image is laid over the other with perfect symmetry.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOKOLOW, MEL
description: SOKOLOW-Mel. We adore you, miss you, and we are inspired by you. Love and hugs forever, Diane, Betsy, Alec and Sam

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION OFFERS TO BUY TORCH HOLDINGS
description: The Bellwether Exploration Company offered yesterday to acquire oil and natural gas interests held by Torch Energy Advisors Inc., a subsidiary of the Torchmark Corporation, for $209 million. As part of its offer, the oil and gas company based in Houston is ready to invest $23.2 million of working capital into the Torch ventures and to pay Torch up to $10 million extra if certain unspecified conditions are met. Torch said it would recommend the sale to its shareholders. The properties Bellwether is considering had estimated reserves of 17.8 million barrels of oil and 147.4 billion cubic feet of natural gas as of June 30. As of the same date, Bellwether had reserves of 1.8 million barrels of oil and 33.1 billion cubic feet of natural gas.

title: Nature's Agenda in Yosemite
description: Nature has rude ways of complaining when people step too heavily on it. A devastating mudslide on a California hill announces that somebody built too many houses there. A ruinous flood in the Pacific Northwest proclaims that somebody cut down too many trees. When human beings overload the system, the system usually strikes back.

title: Ex-Centennial Head Is Arrested by F.B.I.
description: The former chairman of Centennial Technologies Inc., Emanuel Pinez, was arrested today on charges of securities fraud by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Paper Makers Plan a $1.7 Billion Merger
description: Abitibi-Price Inc. and the Stone-Consolidated Corporation said today that they would merge in a transaction valued at about $1.7 billion (United States), creating the world's largest maker of newsprint.

title: Robert Mallary, 69, Junk Artist Behind the Growth of Sculpture
description: Robert Mallary, a junk artist who contributed to the blossoming of American sculpture in the late 1950's and early 60's, and was also a pioneer in the use of plastics and computers in art, died on Monday at Cooley-Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. He was 69 and lived in Conway, Mass.

title: An 'Emma' Both Darker And Funnier
description: ''I am going to take a heroine whom no one but myself will much like,'' Jane Austen wrote of ''Emma,'' vastly underestimating her readers' good taste. The trick of adapting ''Emma'' is to recapture Austen's delicate balance, which allows us to see why the heroine still has friends and social influence, despite being the worst matchmaker and busybody in the village of Highbury. In this smart and spirited new version. Kate Beckinsale's Emma walks that fine line beautifully. Her Emma meddles in her friends' lives with near-disastrous results, and of course remains blind to her own romantic feelings for her old friend Mr. Knightley. But her sure-fire social assumptions are innocently wrongheaded, not willfully arrogant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the sentencing of Eddie Antar, founder of the Crazy Eddie chain of electronics stores, for falsifying records misidentified the judge. He was Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Federal District Court in Newark; Faith S. Hochberg is the United States Attorney in New Jersey.

title: Making Air Travel Safer
description: Statistically, commercial air travel is one of the safest forms of transportation available. But spectacular disasters like the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 last summer, the earlier crash of a Valujet plane into the Florida Everglades and the 1988 terrorist bombing of a Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland, have led the flying public to ask whether more precautions might reasonably be taken to reduce the risk of passenger fatalities.

title: Valentine.Mets.Com: An Organized Camp
description: One day before the real sweating was to begin, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine, the front-office staff and a handful of players started mapping strategy today for 1997.

title: For Gender Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Wells Talking Only Baseball
description: David Wells predicted today that he would be ready to pitch for the Yankees by opening day and asked a reporter to focus on baseball and not the street brawl last month in which he fractured his left hand.

title: Fish Plan Is Out of the Water
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman rejected a proposal yesterday that would have enabled a Russian fish-processing vessel to drop anchor in the Delaware Bay and process fish caught by Cape May commercial fishermen.

title: Japan Cooperative Gets An $8.33 Billion Bailout
description: A company backed by the Japanese Government said yesterday that it would cover the entire losses suffered by the Kizu Credit Cooperative, once Japan's largest credit cooperative, whose collapse in 1995 focused attention on the nation's banking crisis. The Deposit Insurance Corporation, which pools funds from banks for such emergencies, said it would give 1.034 trillion yen ($8.33 billion) to a special bank set up to dispose of Kizu's bad loans.

title: Producer Prices Fall and Industrial Output Is Flat
description: Largely reflecting a big drop in the cost of food, the prices charged by American producers fell in January, the first monthly decline in more than two years, the Labor Department said today.

title: In the Wake of 'Showboat,' a Showcase for Voice
description: ''Chicago'' it definitely is not.

title: BIOGEN NAMES ITS PRESIDENT TO BE CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Biogen Inc. said yesterday that James R. Tobin, its president and chief operating officer, had been named chief executive. Mr. Tobin, who is 52, succeeds James L. Vincent, 57, who will continue as chairman. Mr. Tobin joined Biogen three years ago, after 22 years with Baxter International Inc. Mr. Tobin joined with the understanding that he would succeed Mr. Vincent if Biogen met its goal of becoming a fully integrated pharmaceutical company. Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., was one of the first biotechnology companies but had until recently derived all of its income from royalties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERICK, SHIRLEY A. DEL RAY
description: SCHERICK-Shirley A. Del Ray, FL, age 81, February 14. Beloved sister of Edgar Jay. After a trying illness, a totally decent person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, JOSEPH SOLOMON ''SOL''
description: KENT-Joseph Solomon ''Sol'', on Monday, February 10, of Waltham, formerly of Lexington, MA. For 47 years the beloved husband of Selma. Devoted and loving father of Aileen and Scott Yates of Waltham, MA, David and Claire Kent of Dunstable, MA and Stacey and Elliott Berger of Sandown, NH. Cherished papa of Kayla, Noah, Olivia, Hannah, Rachel and Shira. Loving brother of Esther Naiburg and Michael Kent. Electrical Engineer graduate of City College, he went on to help found Environmental Resources and Technologies, Inc. Services were held at Temple Isaiah, Lexington, MA. Memorial observance at his late residence through Wednesday morning. Remembrances may be made to Temple Isaiah, 55 Lincoln Street, Lexington, MA. 02173. For information contact Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: 6 Children Who Need Not Have Died
description: Of the eight children whose cases were recounted in the report released by Nicholas Scoppetta, the Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, these six died. Here are brief accountings of how the young lives were lost.

title: 3 Army Instructors in Germany Are Accused of Sexual Assault
description: Already smarting from accusations of sexual misconduct by soldiers back home, the United States Army acknowledged today that three male training instructors had been suspended from duties and two of them detained after 11 women who are soldiers complained of sexual mistreatment at a base in Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAGER, YVETTE. (YECHAVED CHANA BAS YOSEF)
description: JAGER-Yvette. (Yechaved Chana bas Yosef) The Briyuth Society of the New York City Health Department mourns the loss of our cherished retiree member. Devoted mother to Elliot Jager. Memorial services are at United Hebrew Community, 201 East Broadway, Manhattan, Sunday, February 16, 9 A.M. May the Almighty Comfort you among the mourners for Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Jail Time Is Postponed
description: A one-year jail sentence for an accountant who admitted defrauding 24 investors in Morris and Bergen Counties of $1.2 million was ordered postponed for five years yesterday.

title: Unser Learns Some Things in IROC While Showing How to Win
description: He will not be in Sunday's big race, the Daytona 500, but Al Unser Jr. outraced most of the 500's serious contenders today in the 100-mile Firebird International Race of Champions title event.

title: Gone to Junkyards, Almost Every One
description: Ten years ago, Hunts Point was a place where cars went to die gruesome and pitiless deaths.

title: Amrom H. Katz, 81, Early Expert on Space Reconnaissance
description: Amrom H. Katz, whose studies prepared the way for space reconnaissance -- the use of space satellites to collect intelligence by photography and other means -- died on Monday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be legally observed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPKOFF, CLARENCE JOSEPH (LARRY) M.D.
description: LIPKOFF-Clarence Joseph (Larry) M.D. Age 85 of Point Lookout, Milford, CT., died Tuesday in Milford Hospital. He was the husband of the late Helen Murray Lipkoff. Dr. Lipkoff, son of the late John A. and Dorothy Sarason Lipkoff, was born in New York City, Dec. 31, 1911. He was a U.S. Army veteran having served with the Medical Corp. in the Pacific theater. Dr. Lipkoff was board certified in General Surgery for the states of CT. and NY. He was an Assistant Medical Examiner for the State of CT and was the Director of Utilization Review and Medical Quality Assurance for Milford Hospital for many years. Dr. Lipkoff received his Bachelor of Science degree from University College at New York University in 1932 and his Medical Degree from Bellevue University School of Medicine at New York University in 1936. He served his internship & residency in Pathology and General Surgery at Knickerbocker Hospital, New York City. Dr. Lipkoff is survived by a sister, Dell Schwamm Oliphant of Fairfield, IA; two nephews, Jonathan Schwamm of Fairfield, IA, and Richard Wirin of Marlboro, NJ; and four nieces, Daphne Schwamm of Livingston Manor, NY, Diane Wirin and Peggy Wilson both of Morro Bay, CA and Anne Marie Schwamm of Fairfield, IA. A memorial service will take place on Saturday at 2 P.M., in the Cody-White Funeral Home, 107 Broad Street on the Green, Milford, CT. Commital will be private. Memorials may be made to the Milford Hospital Building Fund, 2047 Bridgeport Avenue, Milford, CT. 06460.

title: Skater Has Her Diploma, If Not Gold
description: SEVENTEEN and a half years. Think about that. Before Michelle Kwan was even born, Carol Heiss Jenkins began coaching Tonia Kwiatkowski.

title: Seen as Threat, Gang Chief Gets a Life Term in Solitary
description: Saying that only extraordinary restrictions can prevent a Bronx gang leader from continuing murderous enterprises from behind bars, a Federal judge sentenced the head of the state's Latin Kings street gang yesterday to a life sentence that must be served in solitary confinement and with severely limited visits from family members and his lawyer.

title: A Showdown Forced by the Power of a Union
description: The pilots' dispute at American Airlines represents a rare instance in which a union in the United States holds not only extraordinary power over its employer, but also over much of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, TOM
description: STODDARD-Tom. We, the Board of Directors and Staff of The American Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the loss of our most valued colleague, treasured friend, and Co-Chairman of our Board. We have come to rely daily on his judicious counsel and penetrating insight, while admiring his deep sense of equality and his high moral standards. We have benefited from his cheerful determination and steely focus. And, most of all, we have cherished his never-failing inspiration to complete our work and find a cure for AIDS. Our love goes to Walter, his beloved partner. We will miss Tom. We already do. Mathilde Krim, Chairman of the Board Elizabeth Taylor, Founding National Chairman Art Ammann, President Jerry Radwin, Chief Exec. Officer American Foundation for AIDS Research

title: HIGHLANDS INSURANCE CUTS OFFER FOR VIK BROTHERS
description: Highlands Insurance Group Inc. cut its offer for Vik Brothers Insurance Inc. again yesterday, this time to $97 million. Highlands first slashed its offer for Vik Brothers in January from $164 million to $110 million, when Vik reported a loss for the 1996 fiscal year. This time, Highlands said it was modifying its offer for technical reasons and because of the unspecified involvement of a third party. Under the new deal, Highlands would issue 1.7 million shares and $21 million worth of preferred stock to the owners of Vik Brothers, as well as assume $40 million of Vik Brothers' debt. Highlands specializes in commercial property and casualty insurance.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: LIFE FOR GANG LEADER A Federal judge sentenced a Bronx gang leader to a life sentence of solitary confinement to keep him from ordering crimes from prison. Page 26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, ANN
description: COOPERMAN-Ann. Beloved wife of the late Mark Cooperman, loving mother of Bill. Adored grandmother of Rhonda, Allison, Melissa, Mitchel and Fletcher. Cherished sister of Sidney Bender. Funeral services Sunday 1 P.M., at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I.J. Morris Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: In Assisted Suicide Debate, Consider the Subtext
description: To the Editor:

title: PIMCO PLANS TO BUY STAKE IN OPPENHEIMER CAPITAL
description: Pimco Advisors L.P. agreed yesterday to acquire Oppenheimer Group Inc.'s one-third stake in the institutional money manager Oppenheimer Capital L.P. for $265 million in preferred stock and assumed debt. Pimco, a bond fund manager, has been trying to increase its equities money management business. About 73 percent of Pimco's $110 billion in assets is in bonds. Oppenheimer Capital oversees about $48 billion in assets, 78 percent of which are invested in stocks. The transaction would create one of the largest investment firms in the United States, with $158 billion under management.

title: New York Delays Sewage Release at E.P.A. and Whitman's Urging
description: New York City officials were planning to dump about 500 million gallons of raw sewage into the East River during repairs to the city's sewage treatment system, but the dumping was postponed at the last minute under pressure from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, state and city officials said last night.

title: New Questions On Investments For a Nominee
description: In a new set of questions about the nomination of Alexis Herman as Secretary of Labor, a Senate committee is examining why she received an ownership interest now worth as much as $500,000 in a real-estate development here without investing any money, Government officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a chart in Business Day yesterday about commercial diet centers that dispense weight-loss drugs referred incorrectly to the sponsorship of a study by Dr. Michael Weintraub on the drugs' safety. It was conducted while he was a professor at the University of Rochester; it was not conducted for the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about Haiti's celebration of Carnival misstated the location of Jacmel. The town is on the southern coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, RABBI RALPH
description: SILVERSTEIN-Rabbi Ralph. Friends and family announce with great sorrow the passing of this distinguished clergyman and community leader on February 11 at the age of 86. Ordained in 1940, he served as Rabbi at The Ninth Street Temple, The Madison Jewish Center and Temple Sinai, all in Brooklyn. Beloved brother of Milton and Jerome Silverstein, Deborah Freedman, Yvette Greisman and the late Ruth Brooks. A graveside service will take place Sunday, February 16, at 2:30 PM, the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Market Luster Fades a Bit as the Dow Retreats by 33.48
description: The euphoria that swept Wall Street into a new millennium this week ended not in a bang, but with a whimper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, HERBERT B.
description: EHRLICH-Herbert B. Beloved husband of Ina, devoted father of Michael and Lisa, Robert and Wendy, Michael, Stephanie, Gail, Ellen, adored son of Rose, dear brother of Fran, adored grandfather of Austin, Clayton, and Bela. Services Sunday, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside Nassau North Chapel'', 55 North Station Plaza, opposite LIRR.

title: White House Said to Be Trying To Sway Republicans on Treaty
description: Seeking to keep the United States from being left on the sidelines when a chemical weapons treaty takes effect, the Clinton Administration is reportedly willing to vow ''overwhelming and devastating'' retaliation against any enemy using such weapons on American troops.

title: VINTAGE PETROLEUM BUYS PROPERTIES FROM BURLINGTON
description: Vintage Petroleum Inc. agreed yesterday to buy certain properties and operations from Burlington Resources Inc. on the coasts of Texas and Louisiana for $114.1 million. Vintage Petroleum is an independent energy company. Burlington Resources is an oil and gas company. The acquired properties include several onshore fields, five offshore fields and numerous smaller fields covering more than 74,000 acres. Vintage Petroleum said it would operate the properties, which have current net daily production averaging about 5,200 barrels of crude oil and 17 million cubic feet of natural gas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAHL, MERTON P.
description: STRAHL-Merton P., M.D. USN Retired. Age 92. In Altamonte Springs, Florida. Formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Survived by his beloved wife Sally and many loving nieces and nephews. Services on Sunday, February 16, 1997 at 1:30 P.M., at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: CLINTON AND GORE RECEIVED WARNINGS ON ASIAN DONORS
description: Foreign policy advisers to President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore repeatedly issued warnings against maintaining ties and granting access to several Asian-American fund-raisers and donors who sought to influence American policy and capitalize on their White House connections, according to documents released today by the National Security Council.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a strike vote by the union that represents signalmen on the PATH commuter line misstated the union's contract status. Its contract remains in force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTELS, JOHN R. SR.
description: BARTELS-John R. Sr. Federal Judge Eastern District of New York. Husband of the late Anne. Father of John and William. Grandfather of Gilpin, Kristin, Anne, Elizabeth and Jackson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Tues Feb 18, 5-8 p.m. Service Wed. Feb 19, 11 a.m. at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange St., between Hicks and Henry St, Bklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to LI College Hospital, Bklyn

title: Classroom Computers Risk Injury to Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIES, HANNA, M.D.
description: MARGULIES-Hanna, M.D. Born in Vienna, Austria. Beloved wife of the late Simon, devoted mother of Joyce, loving mother-in-law of Uttam Shah, cherished grandmother of Shruti and Lily, loving sister of Gerda Haas, sister-in-law of the late Richard Haas. Services 12:15 Sunday at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Colonial of Australia To Buy Jardine Stake
description: Colonial Ltd., an Australian insurer preparing to sell shares to the public, will pay Jardine Pacific Ltd. $163 million for its 50 percent stake in their Asian insurance venture.

title: Mussina and Orioles Agree to One-Year Deal
description: MIKE MUSSINA and the Baltimore Orioles have been unable to negotiate a multiyear contract, but yesterday they settled on the highest one-year salary achieved in a case scheduled for arbitration. The Orioles will pay their No. 1 pitcher $6.8 million, and they agreed to continue negotiating on a longer contract.

title: Substation Explosion Strands Subway Trains on Manhattan Bridge
description: An explosion in a power station under the Manhattan Bridge yesterday knocked out electricity to subway trains in both directions during the morning rush, stranding six trains on the bridge and jumbling service for thousands of commuters.

title: Germans Wonder: Twilight for Kohl?
description: A tantalizing question has burst forth from Bonn's placid politics: is Helmut Kohl politically mortal?

title: Rebels in Tajikistan Begin to Free Hostages
description: Easing a tense standoff, Tajik rebels began releasing their hostages today, just one day after they proclaimed they had begun to kill their prisoners.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: A One-Man Show

title: Children's Agency Details Errors and Sets Sanctions
description: New York City's child welfare agency, long criticized for concealing its mistakes and failing to hold workers accountable, described in graphic detail yesterday an array of errors and oversight in the agency's handling of the cases of eight abused children and said 21 employees and managers would face disciplinary action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERPOINT, MARGARET S.
description: PIERPOINT-Margaret S., of New York City and Madison, CT, on February 14, 1997. Survived by her husband, Powell, her daughter, Harriet P. Bos, her sister, Lillian S. Forsch, her brother, William S. Sagar, Jr., and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., Wednesday, February 19, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: An Old Dream For the Arts, A New Chance For the City
description: Is any site in Manhattan more vexed than 2 Columbus Circle, Huntington Hartford's pseudo-Venetian palazzo, which in 33 years has never become the cultural center it was once called? In May the Department of Cultural Affairs, which has occupied it since 1979, will make way for whoever the city decides may buy the building.

title: Japan Hesitant About U.S. Antimissile Project
description: After three years of exploratory talks, Administration officials say Japan has all but decided against taking part in an antimissile defense project with the United States for fear of offending China and overspending scarce military resources.

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL TO BUY NEW IBERIA BANCORP
description: The Regions Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy New Iberia Bancorp Inc. for $65 million in stock. Regions Financial, of Birmingham, Ala., has assets of $20 billion, including pending acquisitions. New Iberia, based in New Iberia, La., is a banking company with assets of $299 million. Under the agreement, Regions will swap 1.1 million of its shares for all of the shares outstanding of New Iberia, at a ratio of 0.36 Regions share for each New Iberia share. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Regions Financial stock climbed 25 cents, to $57.75. On the American Stock Exchange, New Iberia Bancorp stock was unchanged at $21.

title: Trouble Spots on the Road
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Belle Keeps Dragging Game Down
description: THE story leaked out in part, at least -- in not the most honorable of ways. But once Albert Belle in sworn testimony admitted to a grandstanding attorney named Richard Lillie that he gambled on college basketball and pro football, he just couldn't resist the temptation to drag the entire community of major league ballplayers into the muck alongside him. Baseball's one-man public relations wrecking crew strikes again.

title: L.I. Schools Wary of Plan To Increase State Aid
description: SHAKEN by years of reductions in state aid, education officials on Long Island are reacting skeptically to Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to increase state aid and cut school taxes.

title: Childs Is on His Teammates' A-List
description: With Chris Childs, it's a respect thing.

title: The Way We Worked: A Journey Into the Past
description: THE office worker who comes home bleary after hours in front of a computer screen, or the gate attendant at Newark Airport exhausted after a day of shepherding passengers onto planes, might win scant sympathy from a family member of another generation. ''Work? You call that work?'' the old-timer might say. ''Let me tell you . . .'' And then would follow a much-told tale about, say, shining patent leather shoes in the factory 14 hours a day for two cents an hour.

title: Using Renaissance Methods To Create a Mission's Fresco
description: CENTRAL Islip is a long way from Italy, and the Montfort Catholic Mission building in this run-of-the-mill Long Island town is a far cry from a grand Roman cathedral built in the Renaissance style.

title: The Schmooze Express: A Rite of Passage
description: As the debate rages in Washington over money and politics, and cozy relationships between lobbyists and politicians, there was little talk, if any, about such good government concerns aboard the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce's 60th annual schmooze express this year.

title: Mets' McIlvaine Feels No Pressure as He Looks for Improvements
description: Mets General Manager Joe McIlvaine will not entertain for a minute the thought that he might be the general manager on the griddle in New York.

title: You Can't See This
description: ''I grew up with the cold war,'' Francis Gary Powers Jr. says with pride. ''Whenever we had show and tell at school, I always brought my dad.''

title: THE LOOTING and SMUGGLING and FENCING and HOARDING of IMPOSSIBLY PRECIOUS, FEATHERED and SCALY WILD THINGS
description: As the world's largest exotic reptile show -- the National Reptile

title: Suddenly, Country Tries Again
description: IN 1938 Orson Welles shocked the radio audience with his realistic adaptation of ''The War of the Worlds.''

title: Books In Brief: Fiction
description: ZERO TOLERANCE By Thomas Richards. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.

title: Blame Judges, Not Voters, for California's Declining Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, JOSEPH (ABITABILE)
description: PETERS-Joseph (Abitabile). On Feb. 6, 1997, in Florida. Our deepest condolences to your sisters Sally Paolillo and Francine Abitabile, your nephew Guy Paolillo and your niece Tina Androulakis. You will be missed. May you rest in peace. Betty and Pattie

title: How to Scale Down a Stadium for Giants
description: Ritu Pradhan knows which seats at Giants Stadium are red and which are blue. Thomas Fallon could recount the stadium's dimensions in his sleep. And Matthew Gosser has lots of different perspectives on the stadium: from the field, from the press box, from the air.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Scent of Memory

title: Books In Brief: Fiction
description: MARGINALIA By Doran Larson. Permanent Press, $22.

title: New Captains, Steady Ships
description: Every time a mutual fund manager leaves Fidelity Investments, a game of musical chairs ensues. The departing manager's seat must be filled, generally by the manager of another fund, who then must be replaced, and so on.

title: Golf's Price Tag
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Keeping Children Busy During a Break
description: THE words, winter break, summon to mind an idyllic vision of children happily skating the week away on a frozen pond. But a week's vacation for all is no longer the rule. Many county schools will enjoy only a day or two of vacation, while some will close their doors for a week. Whichever is the case, places to skate or learn to do so are plentiful in Westchester, as are many other activities.

title: Rainbow Company, Restructuring in Stamford
description: WHAT was the board of directors thinking when it voted to move the Rainbow Theater Company from a college in Norwalk to an arts center in Stamford? Excitement, expansion, elegance. That's what. But the switch to a tony address in a high profile neighborhood resulted in a diminished audience -- and the Rainbow is restructuring.

title: Lindh Wins the Title She Knew Was Hers
description: It was 48 hours before the downhill at the world Alpine skiing championships, and Hilary Lindh was trying to describe what it feels like to stand in the starting gate and be certain you are going to succeed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARR, CHARLOTTE A.
description: BARR-Charlotte A. Loved wife of the late Jerome. Loving mother of Marjorie and Charles Spector. Cherished grandmother of Brian and Madeline Spector, Emily Spector, Monica and Joel Greenberg. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 10:15 AM, Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, GRETA M.
description: LANDIS-Greta M. On November 11, 1996. Wife of the late George Landis. Survived by the Valka family. Supporting member Museum of Jewish Heritage, AMIT Women's Inc. which supports children's homes in Israel, Keren-OR, Inc. which treats blind children in Israel. Memorial service to be held on Thursday, February 20, 1997, at 10AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: Mother's Outrage Prompts Bill on the Right to Nurse in Public
description: One mother's outrage may lead to a new law in Connecticut, a measure to protect the rights of mothers to breast-feed their children in public.

title: From Silver Screen to Setting a Screen
description: Curley of ''Of Mice and Men'' dribbled the ball up court. Russell of ''Waiting to Exhale'' drilled a 3-point shot. The lead of ''Santaland Diaries'' hit a shot over the yuppie dad from a Ford Commercial. The Yiddish theater specialist pulled down a rebound and was fouled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BISO, GUSTAVE L.
description: O'BISO-Gustave L. On February 12, 1997, of Lincoln Park, NJ. Formerly of Forest Hills, NY. A former independent jewelry designer and manufacturer in the NYC area, retired in 1986. Survived by his wife Ilda (Ripandelli); two daughters, Christine (George) Nadzam and Carol (Karel) Peters. Friends may call at the Keri Memorial Home, 125 Main St., Lincoln Park, NJ, on Saturday, February 22, between the hours of 3-5 PM. Funeral services will commence at 4:30 PM. For more information: 201-694-1582

title: How Hess 'Wouldn't Give Up'
description: YOU seldom hear his voice or see him quoted. Leon Hess prefers it that way. In building his $650 million fortune as the commander of Amerada Hess Corporation, he once retained a personal public-relations man, the late Ben Sonenborn, to help keep his name out of the newspapers.

title: Books In Brief: Fiction
description: POUNDEMONIUM

title: Massachusetts Decontrol Aftermath
description: A DRIVE is under way in Boston and two of its smaller neighbors, Cambridge and Brookline, to accelerate the production of low-rent housing and assist tenants who have been, or will be, displaced by rent increases resulting from the end of rent control.

title: A Pillar of City Housing: Tax Relief
description: IN the prosaic parlance of officialdom, they are deadeningly designated: the J-51 Tax Exemption and Abatement Program and Section 421a of the New York State Real Property Tax Law. But for Henrietta Cohen, an 84-year-old widow, and Azizur Rahman, an emigre from Bangladesh, they are lifelines to a decent, affordable home.

title: Harry Spence Clears Paths For the Schools Chancellor
description: Late last fall, a pivotal piece of school legislation hung in the balance, a bill to greatly increase the power of the New York City Schools Chancellor. A major hurdle had been surmounted when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed to set aside his longstanding opposition. But in the weeks before the vote, the Mayor nearly changed his mind.

title: Middle Manager
description: BEFORE THE DAWN

title: Whose Thomas Jefferson Is He Anyway?
description: MY INITIAL ADVICE TO Ken Burns was clear, sharp-edged and, as subsequent events would show, dead wrong. You cannot make a documentary film about Thomas Jefferson, I warned, because Jefferson predates the photograph. All the earlier Burns documentaries depended upon gritty photos -- of Civil War battles, old-time baseball players or Western landscapes -- artfully arranged and mixed with talking heads who explained what the pictures meant. This was the signature style of Mr. Burns's production company, Florentine Films, but it could not work for an 18th-century subject.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNGLASS, MARK
description: BRENNGLASS - Mark. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the brother of its esteemed Trustee, Mr. Samuel L. Brennglass and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Obsession, Compulsion, the Need for a Cure
description: THE Obsessive-Compulsive Foundation, headquartered in Milford, celebrates its 10th anniversary this month. The staff of four full-time employees, along with volunteers at eight affiliate offices nationwide, offers guidance to people with the disorder, makes research grants and supports more than 250 self-help and professional groups. The group is primarily funded through membership dues, but also receives corporate donations and sells literature.

title: Children's Books
description: THE BALLAD OF LUCY WHIPPLE By Karen Cushman. 195 pp. New York: Clarion Books. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Caring for a Student Body
description: AT 8 A.M., the school day had not yet officially begun but the parade of injury and woe through the health office at Bergenfield High School was already underway, led by Nicole Iasiello, an 11th grader hobbling clumsily on crutches, and a young man carrying her books.

title: Peru Continues Talks With Marxist Guerrillas
description: The Peruvian Government and Marxist guerrillas continued talks today to end the siege at the Japanese Ambassador's residence, where the rebels are holding 72 hostages.

title: Finding the 'Lost' History of the Algonquians
description: IN 1965, armed with a newly earned Ph.d., John A. Strong arrived at Southampton College to teach history. His expertise in his first college post were American protest movements and minorities.

title: Ellen Shemitz, Peter Wagner
description: Ellen Jean Shemitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Shemitz of Woodbridge, Conn., was married last evening to Peter Thomas Wagner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wagner of Lakewood, Ohio. They were married at the Hermit Club, a club for amateur actors in Cleveland. Rabbi Linda Mahalic performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Thomas Weber, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: Point of Disorder
description: COUNCILMAN Thomas A. DeGise sat in his shirt sleeves for three hours in City Council chambers, under the blank gaze of mayors dating to 1838, in portraits, and in front of the often hostile glare of 100 taxpayers, on wooden benches.

title: Sunday, February 16, 1997
description: J.D.! 1. J. D. Salinger recently announced (through an intermediary) that he would release a bound version of ''Hapworth 16, 1924,'' a novella first printed in The New Yorker in 1965. 2. Fans are tantalized, which could be a problem. Roger Lathbury of Orchises Press in Alexandria, Va. the assigned publisher, and a somewhat reclusive outfit itself has been hinting that public interest could ruin the project. 3. At times, Salinger can be a very active recluse. Web sites like the Holden Server have been bullied into silence by Harold Ober Associates, his literary agency. 4. Another web site, Letters to J. D. Salinger, solicits fan mail written ''to'' Salinger by critics, fans and scholars who have despaired of reaching him. 5. As for ''Hapworth''? ''It's on!'' Lathbury said earlier this month. ''It's just been pushed back to mid-March.''

title: For a Glen Cove Complex, a Resident 'Super'
description: THE 19 houses being built on Old Tappan Road here under the name of Lattingtown Preserve will have an unusual amenity -- a resident caretaker. Sales at the development start today.

title: South Korea Is Upset and Its Leader Imperiled by Tycoon's Way With Forbidden Fruit
description: Chung Tae Soo, a tycoon who built one of South Korea's largest conglomerates, used to send his chauffeur in a Mercedes-Benz to deliver cartons of apples as gifts to selected politicians and bankers. Hidden under the apples, South Korean prosecutors have said, were piles of cash.

title: Tap, Tony Bennett and Gershwin
description: IN a busy week at the Stamford Center for the Arts the spotlight shines on local talent as well as two icons of American music.

title: Little Men Stand Tall For South Carolina
description: South Carolina likes to play the game big but it especially likes to play the game small.

title: A Beginning For South Africa
description: MANDELA AND DE KLERK traces the career of Nelson Mandela (played by Sidney Poitier, above) from his imprisonment in 1964 for organizing the African National Congress through his election to the presidency of South Africa three decades later. The film details the inside political maneuvering between Mr. Mandela, F. W. de Klerk (Michael Caine) and the hard-liner Prime Minister P. W. Botha (portrayed with verisimilitude by Gerry Maritz).For their part in ending apartheid, Mr. Mandela and Mr. de Klerk shared the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: A Romantic Troubadour, Enchanter Of the Young
description: JIMMY DURANTE ONCE SAID TO me that rock-and-roll was three chords, two of them wrong,'' Tony Bennett recalled.

title: From Braque's Later Years, The Products of Slow Time
description: IN ART, AS IN ALMOST everything else, ours is the age of the quick fix, the glance that lasts hardly longer than a sound bite and the reputation shaped by marketing campaigns, talk shows and celebrity endorsements. It is a rare person who still believes that as the poet John Keats once famously wrote, a work of art should be the ''foster child of silence and slow time.''

title: Quiet Midday Is Misleading At a Sixth Street Restaurant
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Law Firms Dominate Contracts for Teachers
description: On Long Island and elsewhere in New York State, there was a time when teachers negotiated their contracts directly with school boards or superintendents. But that was 20 years ago. Today contracts are usually negotiated between teachers and labor lawyers representing school districts.

title: The Not-So-Invisible Hand In the Great Dow Climb
description: THE mutual fund industry has been going to great lengths to deny responsibility for the stock market's boisterous rally, which last week took the Dow Jones industrial average above 7,000 and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over 800, each for the first time.

title: They Call It Polyluv
description: Maybe your Valentine's Day take was a bit thin. Maybe you're bored with just one him or her. Maybe (granted, this is a leap) you're ready for ''polyamory.''

title: By the Inch, By the Cent, By a Child With Heart
description: Michael Feher, 8, left a cup, along with a message, on a table in the hallway of his Upper East Side apartment building, a reminder to his family, neighbors and anyone else who might walk by to donate to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Bankrupt? So What?
description: NO, Robert M. Renneisen, chief executive of the Claridge Casino Hotel, is not looking for his next job.

title: The Rangers' Downward Trend Deepens
description: Colin Campbell was looking for some urgency from his team this afternoon. He got lethargy instead.

title: Parcells Is the Bully That New York Needs
description: Personally, I don't much like Bill Parcells, smirky bully that he is. Not a nice guy. But I am delighted that he is coming back to town. It's been awhile since we've had the kind of coach we deserve -- a winner with a mean streak who wants to be here.

title: By These Compasses, the Market May Be Turning South
description: THE nervousness over stocks is palpable in the personal-finance magazines for March. Much of the boundless optimism at the end of last year has turned to caution and sweaty-palm advice on how to weather a market downturn.

title: Cold Event Turns Hot at the End
description: IN a week just dying for some ex citement, tiny Tara Lipinski all of 14 -- saved the best for last. With a 6-foot smile on her 4-foot-8-inch body, she captured the national figure skating championship as the last skater of the entire event.

title: The Venerable History of Incivility
description: INCIVILITY in bipartisan politics and government in America is as old as the Republic.

title: INVASION OF THE EURO-TAGGERS
description: It's hard to believe that New York, of all cities, is having such a hard time appreciating the beauty of graffiti (Sunday: ''Invasion of the Euro-Taggers,'' Jan. 19). I can remember as a small boy visiting my uncle in SoHo and going down to the subway platforms just to watch the trains speed by, all ablaze in color. Let's not forget where Jean-Michel Basquiat and Keith Haring started.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: Bruce can't be the next Woody because Dylan already has that spot. Bruce is the next Dylan.

title: Demand for Baby Eels Brings High Prices and Limits
description: Europeans and Asians are developing an almost insatiable appetite for New Jersey eels, a Rutgers University scientist says. Now, fishermen here can get thousands of dollars for a bucket of inchlong baby eels.

title: Like Felix Unger on Wheels
description: When William Jones sweeps the sidewalks of Times Square, among the most heavily traveled in the city, Felix I helps him tackle their grit and grime.

title: How About One in Every Color?
description: Median household income in the United States is about $35,000. That's less than two-thirds the average bonus that the securities industry's 150,000 workers in New York CIty are expected to draw. The record bonuses for 1996 have already touched off a spending spree that not only improves the region's economy but affects its cultural climate, too.

title: Unilever: Not Just Vanilla Anymore
description: IF the giant consumer products company Unilever P.L.C. were a football team, until recently it would have epitomized the conservative approach of three yards and a cloud of dust. Its moves had been predictable, and it relied on financial heft rather than on nimbleness to gain a point or two of market share.

title: Roll Out the Barrel
description: NIAGARA

title: Uncertainty Unites Agencies
description: From parents predicting a sharp rise in dangerous crime to children worried about the prospect of supporting their elderly parents, New York's 500,000-strong Haitian community is worried about the effects of changes in welfare laws.

title: This Time, No Struggle: St. John's Routs Rutgers
description: An easy victory over a Big East opponent became a reality today for St. John's. After five games decided in the closing seconds, four of them defeats, the Red Storm trounced Rutgers, 73-58, after leading by as many as 26 points with 3 minutes 33 seconds left.

title: 'YOU HAVE A COLD HEART, DEGAS!'
description: Since I first saw Sister Wendy on PBS, I have been vexed by one question: Is she a real nun or a British send-up of Catholicism?

title: Justus Schifferes, 82; Wrote About Health
description: Dr. Justus J. Schifferes, an editor and writer on health and science, died on Jan. 25 at the Inglemoor Nursing Home in Livingston, N.J. He was 82.

title: The Best and Worst of Times in the Northern Baja
description: IT has lately struck me that some trips can't be tamed by planning. They go astray, no matter how well conceived. Moreover, these aberrant trips, marked by the lowest lows, often also feature the highest highs.

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle Avoids Space Junk

title: Homer's Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column on Jan. 5 about long-term rentals in Zihuatanejo, Mexico, misstated the address of Elizabeth Williams, a broker. A phone call from Ms. Williams on Jan. 30, pointed out that it is APDO 169, Zihuatanejo, Guerrero, Mexico, not APDO 19.

title: Like Oil and Water: A Tale of Two Economists
description: THEY have met only once since Paul Krugman returned last summer to the prestigious economics department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It was a brief, accidental encounter among the file cabinets and secretaries' desks near Lester Thurow's office. ''We exchanged pleasantries,'' Mr. Thurow said. ''He was telling someone about a trip he had made to the far south of Argentina, and I listened politely.''

title: Clarifying Matters On Glen Cove Plan
description: Many of the accomplishments credited to Mayor Tom Suozzi occurred in previous administrations, some over a quarter of a century ago. For example, Acclaim Entertainment was ''lured'' to Glen Cove by the previous Republican administration, as was the Cineplex Odeon Theater complex. The writer reports that Tom Suozzi ''poured millions of dollars into an urban redevelopment projects aimed at the financially depressed downtown that included new sidewalks and fancy street lamps, and'' (most laughably) ''the construction of a multilevel parking garage.'' These projects were, of course, completed in the late 1970's and early 1980's under various administrations and had nothing to do whatsovever with the current Mayor or the waterfront project.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAGRON, RENE
description: DAGRON-Rene. Remembering the gentle giant, with his green thumb, his heart of gold and his 33 years of laughter. Sidney Morris

title: Record Housing Sales Reported
description: RECORD sales of residential properties for the fourth quarter and all of 1996 have been reported by real estate companies associated with the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service.

title: Dying Is as Dull as Living
description: LOVE WARPS THE MIND A LITTLE

title: In Nagasaki, Beauty And Tragedy Entwined
description: THERE may be prettier cities in Japan than Nagasaki, but there is none where beauty and tragedy are so intertwined, where a walk through the streets makes one alternately smile at the colorful carp in the canals and gasp at a plaque recording the city's wrenching past, where the hot springs in the surrounding hills -- the delight of countless tourists -- are also filled with memories of torture and death.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, PHILLIP
description: CONHEIM-Phillip. February 21, 1944. In ever loving memory. Daughter, Marilyn

title: Parole Is Denied Skinhead in 1990 Anti-Gay Murder
description: The New York State Board of Parole last Monday denied the request of Erik Brown, one of three skinheads involved in the anti-gay murder of Julio Rivera in a Jackson Heights schoolyard in 1990, for an early release from prison.

title: Overshadowed by 125th, 116th Street to Polish Image
description: While planning for economic development in northern Manhattan continues, East 116th Street, the main commercial thoroughfare in East Harlem, is being overlooked, local leaders say. In fact, they say, it has been overlooked for quite some time.

title: The Other Emma Confidently Makes Her Case
description: COSTUME DRAMAS, particularly costume dramas based on Jane Austen novels, are so in vogue these days that the release of two competing versions of ''Emma'' within six months was perhaps inevitable.

title: Other Hotels
description: To the Editor: We recently returned from three weeks in northern Italy, where we stayed at a motley assortment of hotels gleaned from guidebooks and the Internet. Our goal had been to pay no more than $125 a night for a double with bath.

title: Micro-Loans for the Very Poor
description: Anyone who scoffs at the value of 62 cents should talk to Muhammad Yunus. In 1976, the Bangladeshi economics professor tried an experiment. From his pocket, he lent the equivalent of $26 to a group of 42 workers. With that 62 cents per person, they bought the materials for a day's work weaving chairs or making pots. At the end of their first day as independent business owners, they sold their work and soon paid back the loan.

title: A Year-Round Greeting Card
description: John Zammit just may be the city's best example of a man with the holiday spirit.

title: As Foes Splinter, Afghan Islamic Victors Press On
description: After being stalled for months on the plateau north of Kabul, the forces of the militantly Islamic Taliban movement are once more on the march across Afghanistan. Their objective this time is a breakthrough into northern flatlands beyond the peaks of the Hindu Kush mountains.

title: Managed Care's Flaws Can't Be Legislated Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Savings Plans: The Experiment Begins
description: THIS year, Government officials, health care economists and insurance analysts will be watching the behavior of people like Matthew C. Dailey and Daniel A. Fields.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some regional editions on Jan. 26 about proposals for residences for older people in Connecticut omitted three words, altering the meaning of a quotation from Frank Goldsmith, referring to the upkeep of his house. He said, ''We realized that we couldn't take care of it all anymore.''

title: Visionaries Who Flex the Limits of Reality
description: Visionary Works

title: Dinkins's Endorsement Rivets Black and Hispanic Officials
description: The endorsement of Ruth W. Messinger by former Mayor David N. Dinkins was a prime topic at a forum sponsored by a group of black and Hispanic politicians for Democratic mayoral candidates here today. Some members of the group had hoped that Mr. Dinkins would endorse Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President and the only Hispanic in the race.

title: In White Plains, Home Brews and Food
description: WE are partial to what might be loosely called theme restaurants. Dining in one is like buying a twofer. Places like Koloniale, Grill FX, the Bayou, Habebe and even the City Limits Diner and Per Voi serve up, along with expected nourishment, a taste of another country, another place, the strange or the exotic. Their out-of-the-ordinary atmosphere is often exciting and refreshing.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: Oh, the irony! A multimillionaire singing of society's downtrodden.

title: Warm Welcome, Soul-Satisfying Food
description: THE secret is out. Rockville Centre residents have been flocking to Caffe Riviera since it opened 10 months ago. The rest of us will find it worth a trip.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: I found myself nodding in agreement with Dawidoff's paean to Bruce Springsteen -- until I read the offhand swipe at Joni Mitchell. Far from declining, Mitchell has moved beyond the confessional love songs of her commercial prime to a new depth of characterization, an articulate social conscience and an unflinching examination of issues like sexuality and aging.

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on page 16 of The Times Magazine today misstates the year the column began. It was 1979, not 1977.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be legally observed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, DR. STANLEY
description: STILLMAN-Dr. Stanley. On February 14 of Alzheimer's. Beloved husband of Pauline (Zahm), devoted father of Larry and Danny, and loving brother of Allan, Cynthia (Barclay) and Alice (Schonberg).

title: Weighing Clout of Pilots Against Economic Costs
description: Because the economic reach of the pilots' union vastly exceeded its political grasp, President Clinton was free to intervene almost instantly to keep the jets flying when the pilots struck American Airlines just after midnight on Friday.

title: The 'World of Made'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERPOINT, MARGARET S.
description: PIERPOINT-Margaret S., of New York City and Madison, CT, on February 14, 1997. Survived by her husband, Powell, her daughter, Harriet P. Bos, her sister, Lillian S. Forsch, her brother, William S. Sagar, Jr., and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., Wednesday, February 19, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: Men in Tight Sweaters: Shrink-Wrap for the 90's
description: A SHAPELY sweater stretches across a swelling chest, clinging to every curve. This is the Lana Turner of the 1990's? No, it is a male model showing off the latest hug-me-tight knits.

title: An Open Invitation To Visit Bayonne
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokers Hail Right to Prepare Contracts
description: A MAJOR victory'' is what Westchester real estate brokers call their newly won right to prepare simple contracts for sales of residential property.

title: 'Jefferson' Biographer In TV Documentary
description: NATALIE S. BOBER writes books for young readers that their parents might easily borrow. Her biographies, aimed at age 12 and up, illuminate history so vividly that honors fall her way like dominoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPERO, EDWARD, M.D.
description: SHAPERO-Edward, M.D. The Board of Trustees and the members of the Medical Staff of the New York Downtown Hospital extend their deepest sympathies to the family of the late Edward Shapero, MD. A member of the New York Infirmary Staff from 1955 to 1994, a former Chief of Strang Clinic and valued member of the Senior Surgical Staff. He was a superb surgeon, and a devoted and skilled educator of house staff and of many fine surgeons. Beloved by his colleagues and by the Hospital and the patients whom he served. He will be greatly missed. Ronald H. Menaker, Chairman Board of Trustees New York Downtown Hospital Sun-Hoo Foo, MD, President Medical Board/Medical Staff Howard Beaton, MD, Chief, Department of Surgery

title: Dow Breaks Another Ceiling
description: The bulls are charging, and it's not Pamplona.

title: Upper West Side: Homey and Trendy
description: ANSONIA ** $(rating: two stars$)

title: Man in the Americas
description: A party of hunters and gatherers camped by a creek long ago in what is present-day southern Chile. For a year or more, they lived in shelters of wood and hide and made tools of stone and bone. By a fire one day a child left a footprint in the clay, a clear mark that people were in the Americas much earlier than archeologists used to think.

title: In 2002, Mr. Speaker?
description: AH, youth. A. Gifford Miller has plenty. When he was elected Council member from the Upper East Side last year, Mr. Miller, then a 26-year-old Democrat, earned an asterisk next to his name by becoming the youngest person ever elected to the city's decidedly middle-aged legislature. Politically astute beyond his years, Mr. Gifford outmaneuvered three other Democrats during a special election last winter to fill the seat vacated by Charles Millard, who resigned to become president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.

title: Love and Heartbreak
description: One of the surprises in DICK TRACY (1990) comes when an orphan newsboy, befriended by the sleuth, needs a name for officialdom. ''Tracy,'' he says shyly, ''would you let me call myself Dick Tracy Jr.?'' The tough cop nods, one knuckle brushing away a tear. Warren Beatty (above with Charlie Korsmo) who directed and stars in this version brings humanity to the ironjawed detective. The makeup, costumes and decor are radiant -- the 1920's come to the screen in vivid colors. Al Pacino adds whimsy and Freudian dimension to his villain; and in the juiciest female role, Madonna excels. The old comic strip has been gloriously re-invented -- MONDAY at 8 P.M. on CHANNEL 55 and TUESDAY at 8 on 11. Howard Thompson

title: When Safety Devices Bite Back
description: THE Air National Guard F-16 flying near Atlantic City thought it was swooping in unobserved on a Nations Air Boeing 727 on Feb. 5. Instead, it set off computerized anti-collision alarms in the passenger jet's cockpit, and the civilian pilot's emergency maneuvers -- a steep dive, then a climb -- threw three people to the floor of the passenger cabin.

title: Considering Telecommuting
description: Last week's front-page article described telecommuting. Would you like to telecommute? Why or why not?

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Noel Ignatiev
description: Noel Ignatiev, a Harvard lecturer, is co-editor of ''Race Traitor,'' a journal whose motto is ''Treason to whiteness is loyalty to humanity.''

title: A Baritone at Ease With Risk and Angst
description: LET'S be serious: it is Bellini. It won't be a lot of fun for you.'' Thomas Hampson is on his home phone, answering a friend's question about ''I Puritani'' at the Metropolitan Opera, where an otherwise tepid review described Riccardo Forth, the role he sang, as ''the only real person onstage.'' Mr. Hampson, the reviewer added, was ''living dangerously, as someone else, and he never for a second seemed likely to falter.''

title: Link to Grand Central For L.I.R.R. Gains
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has thrown his support behind a longtime plan to link the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, and is working to secure Federal financing, people close to him say. The L.I.R.R. link, at $2.1 billion, would be one of the most expensive public works in the state's history.

title: A Legal Clause Could Relieve Tension
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufactured in Britain. Now Selling in America.
description: DURING A BREAK IN HIS morning radio show, the disk jockey Rick Dees looks worried. ''Are you girls making fun of me,'' he asks. Sitting in front of him are the Spice Girls, five young women from London who have had hit records around the world. Two are wearing impossibly short skirts, a third a neon green jump suit, another a pair of black pants and a T-shirt and the last a maroon athletic suit. They have already flattered Mr. Dees by telling him he looks like Michael Keaton. They have told him about their motto, ''girl power.'' They have nodded politely as he dropped the names of old-timers like Rod Stewart and Paul McCartney.

title: A Tired Boxing Hall Is Ready to Be a Contender Again
description: In the basement of the newly renovated Lost Battalion Hall, the electronic bell sounded, and Juan Rodriguez came out jabbing. Over the course of the two-minute round, he was rocked by a series of blows to his face from the fists of Ray Labore who at 6 feet, 3 inches was 20 pounds heavier with a reach advantage of nearly three inches.

title: At Home: The Governor's Close Ties to Prudential
description: While some other governors have become directors of the Prudential Insurance Company after leaving office, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is unusual in that she had close ties to the company before she was elected.

title: The Left He Left Behind
description: RADICAL SON

title: BENEFITS
description: Journalists at the Plaza

title: The Suit Threatening '98 Track Games
description: I felt the article ''Suit Threatens '98 Track Games'' $(Feb. 2$) captured valid points from both sides. However, I must take umbrage with the comments by Donald Rechler, the head of Reckson Associates, which owns the Omni Building. Mr. Rechler alludes to a ''professional soccer league'' utilizing the permanent stadium, which I assume refers to the Rough Riders, the only professional soccer team on Long Island and tenants at the former Mitchel Athletic Complex.

title: First Come Catalogues, Then Seeds, Then Flowers
description: It's seed-starting time again. The early birds who planted their shamrock seeds in January will have Kelly-green leaves with yellow flowers by St. Patrick's Day. (So maybe we late birds could have St. Patrick's Day a month later?)

title: Managed Care's Flaws Can't Be Legislated Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Artists Made Famous By a Director's Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Ole Fat Choy! A Restaurant Returns
description: When the metal shutters closed two months ago at La Caridad, the venerable Cuban-Chinese restaurant known for its earthy ropa vieja and long lines, longtime patrons were distraught.

title: Author! Author!
description: Hallucinating Foucault By Patricia Duncker. 175 pp. Hopewell, N.J.: The Ecco Press. $21.

title: Wall Street Is Looking More Like Tokyo
description: Just for a moment, think back to a year ago, the last time markets closed to honor Washington's Birthday. Since then oil prices have risen by several dollars a barrel. Long-term interest rates are also up. And the Dow Jones industrial average has leapt by about 1,500 points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARNALL, KATHARINE WHIPPLE
description: DARNALL-Katharine Whipple, 86. On February 12, 1997, in Asheville, NC. Wife of the late Frank McGrann Darnall. Survived by her son Edward Crosby of NYC and two grandchildren, Kimberley and Gregory. Memorial services will be held in Asheville, NC, and Chappaqua, NY, at a later date.

title: I Spy
description: The Boy Who Went Away By Eli Gottlieb. 208 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $21.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARINGER, EDWARD G.
description: GARINGER-Edward G. February 13, 1997. Beloved husband of Carole E. Garinger. Loving father of Lawrence and Helen. Dear fatherin-law of Carole and Jim. Adored grandfather of Geoffrey, Brandon and Alex.

title: Confrontation Won't Help China's Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFA, MINNA
description: YAFFA-Minna. On February 14, 1997. Adored wife of the late Saul. Beloved mother of Elaine, Richard, Phyllis, Claire and Irving. Cherished grandmother of Amy, Dale, Richard, Robert, Samuel, Peggy, Cathy, Jennifer, Jackie and Paul. Service private. In lieu of flowers contributions to Family Service League of Suffolk County.

title: Crime
description: Like those ubiquitous bottle caps clustered around bus stops, Lawrence Block's crime novels are embedded in the streets of New York City. It takes more than an eye for local color or an ear for the vulgate to capture that feeling of ground-in grit that surfaces in EVEN THE WICKED (Morrow, $23), Mr. Block's 13th Matt Scudder mystery. It takes a certain sensibility to appreciate the animal comforts of a gin mill like Jimmy Armstrong's and to hear the music in two guys talking the same language:

title: Land of the Big Boom
description: DEEP in the Pine Barrens, in pygmy forest where a basketball player would stand a foot above the endless dwarf trees, the locals tend to be good-natured. In the tiny hamlet of Warren Grove, people maintain this aplomb even when the attack jets scream out of the sky dropping 500-pound dud bombs, or drilling rusted tanks into Swiss cheese with blazing 40-millimeter guns.

title: Bobbi Brown Puts Best Faces Forward
description: THE lights in Adrienne Vittadini's Seventh Avenue showroom were steamy hot. But the model, a golden-haired Amazon with creamy skin and no trace of a stomach under her clingy taupe dress, was icy cool.

title: E-Mail Is Becoming a Conduit of Prejudice on Many Campuses
description: The first sign of trouble came in a nighttime phone call. Joon Park, a junior at Indiana University in Bloomington, listened as a frantic student told him on Jan. 31 that a hate message had been sent via electronic mail to 700 members of the Asian Students Association, the group of which Mr. Park is president.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT PARK

title: Suzanne Silber, David Goldstein
description: Suzanne Carrie Silber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Silber of Bellport, L.I., is to be married this evening to David Andrew Goldstein, a son of Mary Goldstein of New York and the late Martin Goldstein. Rabbi Joseph Potasnick is to officiate at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Running Afoul of Fowler
description: Grammar, Henry Fowler wrote in 1926 in his ''Dictionary of Modern English Usage,'' is ''a poor despised branch of learning.'' Seventy years later, it is hard to argue that grammar -- at least Fowler's kind of grammar -- fares any better. His work has long been written off by academic linguists, who are more concerned with how language is used than with how it should be used. In the latest assault, Fowler is all but expunged from his own book.

title: A Mother's Perspective On 'Family Values'
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarifying Matters On Glen Cove Plan
description: I was disappointed to read in your Jan. 12 article entitled ''Glen Cove Puts Faith in Waterfront Plan'' that the waterfront plan is being pursued, in part, to enhance Mayor Thomas Suozzi's political aspirations. The waterfront plan will only succeed if it remains a bipartisan effort.

title: Proposed L.I.R.R. Link To Grand Central Gains
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is maneuvering to set aside a large pot of Federal money to link the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, people close to him say. As a result of Mr. D'Amato's support for the project, championed by Gov. George E. Pataki, the plan is no longer a transportation planner's pipe dream but a near-term priority on Capitol Hill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, BRUCE CHARLES, M.D.
description: BEHR-Bruce Charles, M.D., 48, on February 12, 1997. Dear husband of Tami. Loving father of Brittany and Joshua. Dearest beloved son of Dr. Irving and Florence Behr. Devoted brother of Joan and Donald Schaeffer and adoring uncle of Andrew Schaeffer. Funeral services on Sunday, 9:30 AM at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Will Try for $50 Million Fund
description: Seeking to revitalize its troubled finances, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced a five-year campaign today to build a $50 million endowment, the first such fund-raising effort the civil rights organization has attempted.

title: The Work-at-Home Executive
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings on Home Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Bastions of Justice, Guardless, Become Targets of Crime
description: If they had been the first, they could be called brazen. But the thieves who dared break into the New York State Supreme Court building at 360 Adams Street last weekend followed a well-worn path.

title: Privatizing Still at Issue
