description: TWO months after proposals for privatizing some government jobs divided the Westchester County Board of Legislators, the issue remains unresolved -- and it could take months, or even longer, for a resolution.

title: CB Radios Are Still Drivers' Good Buddies
description: THESE days, Crocodile is scanning for Newt. Since a Florida couple showed last month that cell phones are nothing but glorified CB's, Crocodile, a transcontinental truck driver, has decided that Newt Gingrich and other politicians ought to 10-4 with their constituents on Citizens' Band radio. ''I think from time to time Washington needs to tune into channel 19 and get some idea of where they need to go, and I don't mean directions,'' said Crocodile by cell phone from outside Nashville, while he and his partner, Angel Eyes (Connie Carter), were hauling 43,000 pounds of aluminum from Seattle to Charleston, S.C.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: What a wonderful surprise to find a real American statesman on your cover (''The Pop Populist,'' by Nicholas Dawidoff, Jan. 26). Bruce Springsteen has managed to remain current, not through hair transplants but by continuing to articulate the hopes and fears of those whose stories would otherwise go untold. Instead of becoming an embarrassing reminder of our misspent youth, Springsteen has actually made growing up seem cool.

title: In What Bleak Midwinter?
description: Parties for an exhibition, two books and four charities were helping keep Manhattan aglow last week.

title: Police Are Told That Missing Girl Was Slain
description: For 15 months, no one in the city's Child Welfare Administration or school system noticed the disappearance of 8-year-old Justina Morales of Bedford-Stuyvesant, a girl known to child welfare officials.

title: Why Does State Care About Gay Marriage?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mayor Faces Serious Talk About Recall
description: LATELY, James Whelan can't seem to take two steps without trouble grabbing at his heels.

title: A Fine Hour For Squishy Sciences
description: IT used to be that when the Westinghouse Science Talent Search rolled around, folks could count on being bowled over by the high school students who had mastered subjects most adults barely comprehend. There was the girl who injected mangrove jellyfish with Chlorella algae, the boy who noodled around with near-field photolithography and nanotechnology and the girl who aced alpha-ketoglutarate dependent dioxygenases.

title: Shine
description: In the exquisite balancing act that is fashion, the arrival of soft, romantic clothes brings out the imp of the perverse in makeup. The spring face you see here shimmers with irony. The eyes are luminous, the mouth aquiver with gloss. And the hair has plenty of attitude.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAHL, MERTON P.
description: STRAHL-Merton P., M.D. USN Retired. Age 92. In Altamonte Springs, Florida. Formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Survived by his beloved wife Sally and many loving nieces and nephews. Services on Sunday, February 16, 1997 at 1:30 P.M., at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: How a State Regulated a Hand That Feeds It
description: Two years ago, soon after he took charge of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Arthur F. Ryan took what might seem to be an unusual step for a chairman. He encouraged New Jersey's insurance commissioner to investigate the company.

title: Carnival of Succession
description: Carnival 1997 will probably not be remembered in Ecuador for its costumes or music but for a tragicomedy tug of war over the presidency that tossed out a rock singer and replaced him with a dancer.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DA-Dum (Beep-Beep Div.)

title: A Long-Lost Tribe Looks for a Future
description: HE turned the page, and there was a photograph of a little boy wearing an Indian headdress. ''That's me,'' Robert Pharaoh said, gently touching the photo. ''My Aunt Pocy made that for me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNIS, JOSEPH A.
description: DENNIS-Joseph A. (10/1/39-2/7/ 97). A free spirit who brought joy to all. A gala celebration honoring his life will be held at the Alvin Ailey Center, 211 W. 61 Street, NYC, Sun. 2/23/97 at 5PM. Festive dress.

title: Building Gone; Dust Is Unsettled
description: On this, everybody agrees: Last Sunday afternoon, a fire broke out on the second floor of 537 East Fifth Street, a city-owned building that more than 20 squatters had occupied for years. Everything else is in dispute.

title: COLD DUNK
description: This weekend, a dozen New Yorkers are at Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H., with scuba gear and a chain saw. Their sport: ice diving, which sounds like just the thing for people who feel betrayed by the mild Northeast winter of 1996-97. ''The water will be 34 degrees, maybe 36 if we hit a hot spring,'' says Kourosh Mahboubian, whose Mad Dog Expeditions organizes this adventure in polar-bear one-upmanship. The divers, part of a larger populace of about 12,000 ice divers across the United States, wear dry suits over inch-thick long underwear. They descend about 40 feet and engage in favorite antics like walking upside down on the underside of the ice. And they're often asked: Are you nuts? ''That's why we go to New Hampshire,'' Mahboubian answers, citing the state's tolerance of oddballs. ''At the lake, the ice fishermen only ask us: 'Did you see any big fish down there? Can you put one on my hook?' ''

title: Hard Times For Zaire: It Can't Give Cash Away
description: In a crowded corner of downtown Kinshasa popularly known as Wall Street, money-changers running their fingers over colorful stacks of the local currency, the zaire, eagerly wait throughout the day for any customers carrying American dollars or francs from Belgium and France.

title: As Some Crimes Fall, Push-In Attacks Rise
description: Since September, when the Police Department expanded its anti-drug efforts to Washington Heights and Inwood, those neighborhoods have seen a large drop in serious crimes like murders and shootings.

title: For Leaders of Many Colleges, Hideaways Are a Must
description: Ruth Simmons, president of Smith College, was talking about the difficulties of being a college president these days.

title: Enhanced CD's: Often Intriguing Yet Still Erratic
description: IT MAKES PERFECT SENSE. The CD's that play in your stereo system and the CD-ROM's that replaced floppy-disk programs rely on the same laser technology. So why not manufacture enhanced CD's that work both ways, with music for the stereo and pictures for the computer?

title: Some Might Say It's a Honey of an Idea
description: Have you heard the one about the state insect?

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column on Jan. 26, about restaurants in the East 50's in Manhattan, included an outdated reference to the executive chef of the Typhoon Brewery. James Chew left the restaurant in December. Jerry Rozelle holds the position now.

title: New Zealand
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Bruce Weber (''New Zealand on Two Wheels,'' Jan. 5) and others, the secret is out. Four years ago, two friends and I took our gear, tents and bikes to New Zealand where we'd spend the next three months cycling the North and South Islands. We decided to take it as it came. That involved two of us leaving the other. Susan and I wanted to cycle leisurely, 60 miles or so for the day, taking in sights, many which the author spoke of, many which will remain secret. Our original third member wanted to ride from point A to point Z without smelling the sheep, so to speak. So we split up.

title: Teaching New Scarfs Old Tricks
description: As winter starts to drag, like a scarf falling off the shoulders, a new generation is rediscovering an old scarf trick. With its neat, tailored look, it could be called the loop tie.

title: Uncle Fidel
description: I WAS SPRINTING ACROSS THE TARMAC, DETERMINED TO prevent the Moscow-bound Yak-40 from leaving without me, when the chief of airport security caught up. ''Where's Uncle Fidel!'' bellowed Ilkhani, cocking his K.G.B. pistol and sticking it in my ear.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the campaign for mayor of Los Angeles referred incorrectly to the status of an ethics complaint brought against Mayor Richard Riordan by his opponent, Tom Hayden. The statement that ''Ethics commission officials said they would look into the complaint'' should have been attributed to Mr. Hayden's campaign spokesman. The commission itself did not comment on the complaint.

title: Senior Soldier Stands Accused
description: Already stung by incidents of drill sergeants assaulting young female trainees, the Army suffered another blow last week when it suspended its highest-ranking enlisted soldier, who is accused of sexual misconduct.

title: Hungry Crane
description: To the Editor: The beautiful color photo of an African crowned crane (Dec. 1) reminded me of a close-up encounter in Bamako, Mali, when I was a Fulbright professor in West Africa. During breakfast in the garden of a hotel where crowned cranes lived as pets, one came near the table and with a gesture of its tall head showed interest in my croissant. I didn't want to offend such an imposing visitor, so, while watching the bird's graceful legs approach and retreat, I took advantage of its pause at a distance and devoured the croissant in a gulp or two, after which I was able tranquily to enjoy a pot of tea.

title: Where Wildlife Meets Wild Surf
description: FACED with the multitudinous life choices that confront a child growing up in New York City, my son on turning 13 settled on his. He wanted to be a surfer.

title: Managed Care's Flaws Can't Be Legislated Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Realizing Dream of Becoming a Triathlete
description: AT 47, as she anticipated her 50th birthday, Maggie L. Finch decided her gift to herself would be competing in the Ironman World Triathlon Championship. The problem was, Ms. Finch, at that point, could only run a mile, bike about 10 miles and swim about 20 lengths of a pool.

title: The Great Leap Backward
description: HUNGRY GHOSTS Mao's Secret Famine. By Jasper Becker. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Managed Care's Flaws Can't Be Legislated Away
description: To the Editor:

title: There's Nothing Conservative About the Classics' Revival
description: The canon -- that body of Western thought and art that is supposed to be at the core of all our education -- is succumbing to attack or neglect, is opposed as repressive or dismissed as irrelevent. If so, then the ancient Greek and Roman cultures, ''the classics'' par excellence, the core of the old canon for so much of Western history, should be the least retrievable part of the ''authorized'' past.

title: Brodeur Wows Devils and the Home Folks
description: When the Devils last visited here two weeks ago, Martin Brodeur did not get to play before his family and friends. Tonight, Brodeur started in goal and set a team record in a 4-1 victory over the Canadiens at the Molson Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLON, ANGELO ANTENORE
description: CARLON-Angelo Antenore. On February 12, 1997. The family of Antenore mourn his passing with deep sorrow. Viewing at Campbell's Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81st, February 19, 1997, 5-8PM.

title: Inquiry Finds Possible Illegal Ballots Cast in Upset of Dornan
description: Four months after the November election, state and Orange County investigators are still looking into charges by former Representative Robert K. Dornan that voter fraud sealed his narrow defeat at the polls.

title: Envoy Accused In Fatal Crash Loses Immunity
description: The State Department said today that the Republic of Georgia had waived diplomatic immunity for a senior diplomat who was involved in a car crash that killed a teen-age girl in Washington last month.

title: A Patron of the Arts Needs a Patron
description: HAIR pulled back in a ponytail, padding around in socks and jeans, Melissa Harris looks like a schoolgirl planning a sock hop in a five-story, 19th century town house. But as senior editor of Aperture magazine, she is actually helping to edit the summer issue, which is due out in August.

title: A Music Student Needn't Just Recite
description: To the Editor:

title: The Incredible Sinking Hulks
description: Once a month in Atlanta, World Championship Wrestling, one of the two dominant pro-wrestling federations in the country, holds open tryouts for wannabes between the ages of 18 and 29. The odds of success are very slim, but the hopefuls keep coming. On a recent Wednesday, 10 jumbo men arrived at the Power Plant, W.C.W.'s drafty warehouse gym. The crew included Paul, a portly former high-school wrestler from Michigan; Sam, a 460-pound correctional officer from Florida (below); Rick, a large, bearded Mississippian, and Dale, seemingly the hottest prospect, a seven-foot, 300-pounder from Ohio who declared himself ''the future of pro wrestling period!'' Here's how they fared.

title: At a Cafe, Internet And Coffee
description: IT used to be that the most you could get from a cup of coffee was a caffeine jolt. Now, at the Internet Cafe in Stony Brook, two cappuccinos can get you cruising time on the information superhighway.

title: Follow the Crowd?
description: Offices are often populated mainly by workers of one sex, one race or one generation. But what of the employees who stand out from the group? Do they try desperately to fit in, or do they celebrate their differences? Have you ever stood alone? Did it create any distressing or humorous situations? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Sex Harassment Case Polarizes Soldiers
description: From the coed barracks to the mixed-sex training ranges of Army bases like this one across the country, the line is hardening on the sexual harassment front.

title: Giuliani Style: Fast Answers As Problems Go Public
description: Last Thursday, about 15 minutes before he was to be showered with new questions about the lucrative lobbying of two close advisers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came up with a perfect deflection: he proposed to shut down all lobbying of city agencies, an idea so drastic that it left the high-powered jaws of city commissioners and deputy mayors hanging open when he announced it at a news conference.

title: Bringing a Reclusive Composer to Light
description: THIS IS A STORY OF persistence rewarded. In 1975 the American cellist Frances-Marie Uitti, then living in Rome, was rehearsing music by Anton Webern in a cold, underground little hall, Beat 72.

title: Cooperation Is Not Surrender, Gingrich Says
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich assured Republicans in his home state of Georgia today that the mood of bipartisanship and conciliation in Washington will not dull his conservative edge.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Unsettling Images From an Unsettled Land
description: WITH South Africa in the headlines daily, Americans are familiar with the tumultuous story of that country, at least in broad outline. Awareness of its culture has lagged far behind. Although some South African writers have reputations here, the visual arts are really unknown territory.

title: Europe's Wild Ride
description: If you thought 1989 was an exciting year in Europe, with the Berlin wall crashing down and Communism being swept aside, then you won't want to miss 1997. Because the two major balancing institutions in Europe, NATO and the European Union, are both going to be ''adjusted'' in 1997, and it's going to make for a wild and crazy Eurocoaster. The Clinton Administration isn't worried. It's assuming that these two major balances in Europe can be simultaneously ''adjusted'' and create a new, even more stable equilibrium.

title: Windows on the World Is Good Place for Rainbows
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Wait in a Windy Blind Before the Goose Is Cooked
description: There are few ways to enjoy a cold, wet wind blowing across a soggy cornfield. Hunting geese is one of them, provided there are geese. Unless, and until, these last huntable waterfowl of the season lumber into shooting range, a wait inside a goose blind can seem as eternal as a sermon by a long-winded preacher.

title: Like a Soap Opera, Magazine Serial Draws Japanese Readers
description: TERUMI'S life is getting complicated. When she moved to Westchester from Japan two years ago, Terumi, 31, was completely isolated -- her English skills were limited, she had neither Japanese nor American friends here, and she was baffled by life in New York. Terumi's husband, Yoshio, worked long hours and seemed indifferent to her loneliness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MILTON
description: WASSERMAN-Milton. 71, after a courageous fight against cancer. Founder and President of MERJ Insurance Brokerage. Adored husband and life partner of Rhoda (Rosner) for forty-eight years. Loving father of Susan (Sanders), Jeffrey (Wasserman) and Debi (Snyder). Cherished grandfather of Adam, Ashley, Emmanuel, Jessica, Stephen and Jasmine. Devoted brother of Stanley and his late sister Sylvia (Singman). His caring and generous presence will be forever missed by his family and friends. His heroic ability to conquer the everyday battles of life serve as an example of ''menschlichkeit'' for all of us. Funeral services Sunday, 10:30 AM, Parkside Funeral Chapel, Queens Blvd. 718-896-9000. Interment to follow.

title: Shows Reflect Multitude of Different Styles
description: ON view in the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here are two imports from the Montclair Art Museum in New Jersey, one a retrospective by the Westchester painter Hananiah Harari, the other an investigation of American Indian influence on American Modernism.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: If Springsteen's decision to take a more direct public stand on social issues that matter to working-class and underprivileged people has the effect of putting off ''those got-damed Republicans'' to the extent that it becomes easier to get tickets to his concerts, the country is already better off for it.

title: Despite Anger Over the Strike Ban, a Pledge to Do Their Best
description: These were grim, tight-lipped men, in their crisp blue uniforms with the four stripes of a captain or the three of a co-pilot on their sleeves, pulling their bags on wheels back into Miami International Airport just hours after President Clinton stopped the strike that many were prepared to wage for a month or more.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about hospice care misspelled the surname of a nurse. She is Jean Brace, not Bruce.

title: Oscar Beckons
description: Forget blockbusters. Forget tornadoes, aliens from outer space and monsters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADBELL, SONDRA
description: RADBELL-Sondra. Loving wife, mother, grandmother, friend. We will love you forever. We will always look to you for guidance and understanding and you will always be in our hearts. Love, Joel, Robin, Heidi, Kim, Doug, Seth, Amanda and Jared

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, HELEN GEWERTZ
description: JOFFE-Helen Gewertz. February 7, 1997. Family and friends mourn this wonderful woman. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Jan. 5, about Sarasota, Fla., referred incorrectly to John Ringling Towers. A reader's letter received on Jan. 29 points out that the building did not close for good when Ringling felt the pinch of a sharp decline in real estate. Further research shows that the building, first opened in 1926, was known under a series of names: first El Vernona, then the John Ringling Hotel and finally John Ringling Towers; it closed permanently in 1980. It was never known as the John Ringling Towers Hotel.

title: City to Consider Allowing Merchants to Run Market as a Co-op
description: In its latest effort to quell mounting discontent among merchants at Mart 125, the city-owned indoor market, the city has agreed to consider the merchants' request that they be allowed to buy the building and run the market as a co-op.

title: Arnost Kleinzeller, a Physiologist, 82, Dies
description: Dr. Arnost Kleinzeller, an emeritus professor of physiology at the University of Pennsylvania who studied the way cells regulate their fluids, died on Feb. 1 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 82.

title: Is South Beach Big Enough For Two Hotel Kings?
description: AS the proprietors of Studio 54 in the late 1970's, Steve Rubell and Ian Schrager rode a disco beat to instant fame. Business partners became prison-camp cell mates in the early 1980's, when they were convicted of evading Federal income tax. But well before decade's end, the paroled pair made a triumphant return to the Manhattan social scene with two chic and profitable hotels, Morgans and the Royalton. (Mr. Rubell died in 1989, before their third investment, the Paramount, opened its doors.)

title: An Attack on Sexism in the Judicial System
description: LORRAINE DUSKY leans back in her office chair and lets out an energetic laugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RUTH
description: FRIEDMAN-Ruth. W.S.I.S. sorrowfully mourn the passing of Mrs. Ruth Friedman, the mother of our esteemed members and friends, Dr. Ira Friedman and Mrs. Dorothy Van Amerongen. May the Comforter of Zion and Jerusalem comfort you. Moshe Morduchowitz Rabbi Richard Wigler President

title: Loaded Guns: Whose Responsibility?
description: DAVID KENNEY was 12 years old when he died of a gunshot wound to the head nearly eight years ago. The Naugatuck youngster wasn't a robbery or drive-by shooting victim. He wasn't even shot intentionally. It was an 11-year-old friend who pulled the trigger as the two boys played with a loaded .22 caliber pistol owned by the friend's father, a part-time Seymour police officer, Charles Zwick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEY, F.H. LEWIS
description: ELEY-F.H. Lewis. On Tuesday, February 11, 1997. Husband of Jean. Father of Karen Eley and Jennifer Handler. Grandfather of Olivia and Emma Handler. Donations to Lutheran School for the Deaf, Mill Neck Manor, NY.

title: Philadelphia
description: If winter has deadened your spirits, maybe you'd rather be in Philadelphia. No one will guarantee fair weather, but they will promise you a rose garden (or 50) in the form of the Philadelphia Flower Show, the nation's oldest, biggest and most prestigious indoor floral exhibit, which runs this year from March 2 to 9.

title: Christie's Wins by a Hammer
description: Since the 18th century, Sotheby's and Christie's have been in fierce competition in the art auction market. But for the first time since 1954, Christie's has won out over its larger rival.

title: Common Threads
description: Central park west. a cold, sunny day. In front of the Museum of Natural History, there's a motley crowd of folks milling about: a busload of tourists here to show their kids the dinosaurs, a group of homeboys on their way somewhere and some bored-looking private-school kids lounging on the steps waiting for someone or something. The odd thing is that everyone is dressed almost exactly alike -- lots of puffy ski jackets, lots of polo shirts, lots of Gore-Tex and polar fleece. Designer logos (DKNY, Nautica, Ralph Lauren, North Face, Tommy Hilfiger) are de rigueur, as are bright Crayola colors. Industrial-strength sneakers and high-tech hiking boots are big; so are baseball caps and ski hats. The whole scene looks suspiciously like a tailgate party at an Ivy League football game.

title: A Habitat to Be Built By Women, for Women
description: In Paterson's First Ward, where Habitat for Humanity has built so many houses that the group now has its own subdivision, a campaign is under way to build two more, this time using exclusively women as the architects, contractors and laborers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 2 about overcrowding in schools misstated the gender and given name of the school planning administrator for the Suffolk County Board of Cooperative Educational Services. The official is a woman, Paula Klingelhoefer, not Paul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTELS, JOHN R. SR.
description: BARTELS-John R. Sr. Federal Judge Eastern District of New York. Husband of the late Anne. Father of John and William. Grandfather of Gilpin, Kristin, Anne, Elizabeth and Jackson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Tues Feb 18, 5-8 p.m. Service Wed. Feb 19, 11 a.m. at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange St., between Hicks and Henry St, Bklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to LI College Hospital, Bklyn

title: Correct Ways to Paint Early American Furniture
description: MOST people think of Colonial furniture as simple and plain, with little or no color. Indeed, many early pieces had little more than an oil finish. There were a number of reasons for this esthetic austerity. Paint was a scarce commodity in 17th century, and craftsmen were even rarer. Early settlers were busy carving out a living from the wilderness and had little time for decoration. Also, many Puritans believed that personal and home adornment was frivolous and even sinful.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. Cherished mother, take my right hand and lead me down the aisle to Kevin's waiting arms. Allison

title: A Federal Grant for Greenwich Avenue?
description: FASHIONABLE stores and restaurants as well as a boulevard-like air have caused Greenwich Avenue to be thought of as Fairfield County's version of Fifth Avenue. Indeed, with a Saks Fifth Avenue store and a goodly number of specialty shops catering to the tastes of the affluent, Greenwich Avenue and its side streets may be the toniest shopping district in Connecticut.

title: School Districts See Wicks Law as Costly Burden
description: WITH many of the county's school districts involved in major projects to remodel existing buildings or develop additional space to meet their expanding enrollments, the regulation known as the Wicks Law has come under increasing scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIE, ROBERT D.
description: CURRIE-Robert D. The entire City Center family is deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our extraordinary production manager, Bob Currie. Bob's commitment, professionalism, and expertise, as well as his renowned sense of humor, will be greatly missed. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Bob's longtime companion, Susan Bell, and to his brothers Alan and William. A memorial service will be held at City Center (W. 55 bet. 6 and 7 Aves.) on Friday, April 4, at 3:30 PM. Judith E. Daykin President and Executive Director

title: Roving Taxis With a Message Told Through Art
description: THE ARTIST PEPON OSORIO looks like just the sort of man cabdrivers think twice about picking up on the street. His skin is dark and pitted, his mustache militant, his forehead low; he stands a thickly packed 6 feet 2 inches tall.

title: Chasing After Nomads
description: DESERT PLACES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ANNE
description: KAUFMAN-Anne. On January 31, 1997. Beloved sister of Sara Landis. Devoted aunt to four of her nephews and their children. Interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: The Classic Moment
description: One night in December of 1995, a capacity crowd of students, academics and classics buffs streamed into the turn-of-the-century limestone mansion that houses New York University's Institute of Fine Arts on the Upper East Side. They came to hear a lecture titled ''Further Thoughts on the Parthenon and Its Frieze,'' delivered by Joan Connelly, an associate professor of fine arts and MacArthur Fellow whose radically new interpretation of the relief as a depiction of female sacrifice no less heroic than male martial exploits had provoked a debate that reached the pages of daily newspapers (including The New York Times).

title: That Certain Something: a Poll
description: HOW DOES ONE QUANTIFY movie stardom? By salary? By box-office receipts? By fan mail? Or is it something more mysterious: a combination of reputation, aura and box-office track record? At the end of last month, Quigley Publishing, which puts out the International Motion Picture Almanac, released its 64th annual poll listing the top movie stars. The results are, as always, fascinating and endlessly debatable.

title: Black SUNY Students Lose Suit On List of Names Given to Police
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Friday that an administrator at the State University College at Oneonta acted within his official capacity during an emergency situation in 1992 when he complied with a police request for a list of black male students.

title: A New Verdict in Crown Heights
description: Five and a half years after racial violence rocked Crown Heights in Brooklyn, with shock waves felt in Washington, two black men were convicted last Monday in the stabbing death of a Hasidic Jew attacked during the outbreak.

title: Blame Judges, Not Voters, for California's Declining Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Seniors in Partnership at the Public Schools
description: JEN STABELL, 15, tucked a few strands of blond hair behind her ear, smoothed down the front of her black vest and then stepped out to serve hot bowls of lentil soup. She and about a dozen of her peers from the culinary arts program at Platt Vocational Technical School were serving lunch to club leaders from the Milford Senior Citizen Center, to Milford school administrators and some school principals.

title: The Hollow Men
description: I Don't Want to Talk About It Overcoming the Secret Legacy of Male Depression. By Terrence Real. 383 pp. New York: Scribner. $24.

title: SHOCK AROUND THE CLOCK
description: Thank you, thank you for Lois Gould's article ''Shock Around the Clock'' (Style, Jan. 19). It is comforting to know that there is at least one fashion writer who has retained her sanity in the face of the designers losing theirs. Not that your magazine hasn't contributed its fair share to portraying fashion as costuming for burlesque. But all is forgiven after this witty and wise piece. Talk about style! Gould has it.

title: Beaux-Arts Facade and 'Old King Cole' in the Bar
description: IT'S startling to see a building vanish, like the 12-story office structure at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway, now just a pit in the ground until the 48-story Conde Nast building begins to rise this spring. But the open lot also offers a fresh perspective on the rich Beaux-Arts facade of the old Knickerbocker Hotel, just across 42d Street from the construction site.

title: A Brain's Best Friend
description: AFTER THOUGHT

title: Dual Celebration for Muslims
description: When the new crescent moon rose last Saturday night, the holy month of Ramadan had come to a close. It also marked the end of the first anniversary of the new Muslim Center of New York. Members celebrated both events last week with the traditional Id al-Fitr feast.

title: First It Was Comics, and Now It's Films
description: SOME young people fantasize about a life like Lindley Farley's. Others live it.

title: Rental Construction Revives to Meet Rising Demand
description: STRONG demand for market-rate rental apartments along with available financing is nudging developers to start or plan new projects.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: City Saved From Shortage Of Times Square Souvenirs

title: If a Republican Seizes the Center, Watch Out
description: FOR anyone trying to assess the state of the Democratic Party, the best place to look may not be Washington -- where President Clinton just had the rare pleasure, for a Democrat, of celebrating re-election to the White House -- but in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, THOMAS B.
description: STODDARD-Thomas B. The Board and the staff of the Human Rights Campaign mourn the loss of Thomas B. Stoddard. Tom's intelligence, leadership, eloquent passion and keen sense of humor guided our struggle through some of our most difficult times. Our sympathies to Tom's companion, Walter Rieman, and his family. Fred Hochberg Mary Breslauer Co-Chairs, Board of Directors Elizabeth Birch, Exec. Director Human Rights Campaign

title: How Towns Are Making Investments In Farmland
description: RIDGEFIELD officials, faced with the loss of one of the last remaining family farms in town, last year bought the development rights to the 101-acre property on Lounsbury Road for $2.1 million. By a vote of 1,800 to 1,300, townspeople decided to keep the fruit trees and vegetable fields from being turned into building lots.

title: Presidential Blessing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Books Whose Art Is the Book
description: ''THE ONLY BOOKS THAT INFLUENCE US,'' E. M. Forster once wrote, ''are those for which we are ready, and which have gone a little farther down our particular path than we have yet got ourselves.'' The same is true of art, and that sense of readiness suggests why artists' books, by nature always in limited and handmade editions and usually personal and eccentric, have become the focus of so much of their makers' energy and viewers' fascination.

title: Flowering In the Face Of a Giant Unknown
description: HONG KONG'S 6.3 MILLION PEOPLE produce more wealth in a year per capita than their British counterparts, yet there is no Globe Theater here. Hong Kong's streets are clogged with more Rolls-Royces than London's, yet there is nothing akin to the British Museum. Hong Kong, it is said, and it is widely believed, is a single-minded place, and its mind is on money. Hong Kong, it is widely believed, and it is routinely said, is a cultural wasteland.

title: For a Few Dollars More
description: Involuntary worker sacrifice has been a pillar of an economic expansion that is now the third longest since World War II. Soaring corporate profits and share prices have contrasted with stagnant wages. But workers who have survived downsizing are beginning to climb up from their salary ruts.

title: Mastering New Rental Cars
description: PATSY PALMER of Tallahassee, Fla., stepped out of her rental car in front of her hotel in Miami in December to get a suitcase from the trunk and found herself locked out by the car's automatic locks, with the keys in the ignition and the engine running. Avis referred her to an 800 phone number; she got fast help from a company called Lockmaster and was soon on her way. But the locksmith told her that a help-line dispatcher in Brooklyn had reported cases in colder climes where solo drivers on highways got out to scrape icy windshields and found themselves stuck in the cold without a phone.

title: The Spinmeister
description: Bad Boy

title: Speech Experts Praise Early Intervention
description: As the current president of the Westchester Speech-Hearing-Language Association, I speak for all the members in stating how pleased we were to read your article ''A Mother's Case for Early Speech Therapy'' $(Jan. 5$).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, IRVING
description: KORN-Irving. We are profoundly saddened at the passing of our dear and loyal friend Irving Korn. He expressed his compassion for children by generously embracing our cause. Our deepest sympathy both to his loving wife Lee and to his family. Mary G. Weiss, Founding Pres. Palm Beach Branch of The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation

title: Pass the Pate, Daddy
description: IT seemed a simple decision. We loved France, my wife, Mindy, and I, and we kept going back. So we decided to stake a claim to the place that had already claimed us, and bought a dilapidated house in a tiny village on Belle-Ile, an island in Brittany. We had a dream of counterbalancing our American lives with regular infusions of French langugage, culture and, of course, food. What we did not anticipate was how much trouble food would cause following the birth of our son -- first, what to feed the kid and second, how to get him to love it.

title: Fighting Cancer
description: The total Federal investment in disease-related research in 1996 was about $12 billion, or less than 5 percent of the $270 billion military budget and about 6 percent of the $190 billion of Medicare expenditures.

title: Sale of Office Developer to REIT Marks End of Era
description: ON the first working day after its merger with Cali Realty Corporation, the atmosphere around the offices of the Robert Martin Company was relaxed and cheerful -- almost giddy.

title: Conrad Arensberg, 86, Dies; Hands-On Anthropologist
description: Conrad M. Arensberg, a pioneering scholar who helped shift the focus of anthropology from the study of exotic primitive peoples to the examination of complex modern societies, died on Monday at a nursing home in Hazlet, N.J. He was 86 and had been professor of anthropology at Columbia University from 1953 until his retirement in 1980.

title: Shelby Woo, Relentless Girl Detective
description: ALAN Goodman has worked on enough successful children's television shows (''Clarissa Explains It All'' and ''Hey Dude,'' to name a couple) to know that it pays to listen to young folks. Several years ago, he was trying to come up with an idea for a new show when he happened to talk to his 10-year-old nephew on the phone. The nephew mentioned that he was reading the Hardy Boys, and something clicked in his uncle's head. He recalled that as a youngster he had read every single Hardy Boys book in the school library. He then made a quick trip to a bookstore, where he found that the books were still enormously popular. ''Kids love mysteries,'' he said.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: Bruce should be proud that Bob Dole's campaign people chose to play ''Born in the U.S.A.'' Regardless of the song's intent, it united people then and continues to do so today. That is why even Bob Dole loves the Boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAIS, BERTHA
description: WAIS-Bertha. On February 12, 1997. Beloved sister of Pauline. Funeral services private.

title: Splash
description: THE FATE OF A GESTURE

title: 2 Pine St. Neighbors Become Landmarks
description: Two turn-of-the-century Romanesque Revival neighbors on Pine Street -- the former Wallace Building (Nos. 56-58) and The Down Town Association (Nos. 60-64), a private luncheon club -- became designated landmarks last week. The action on the sites, between William and Pearl Streets, is part of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission's ongoing efforts to step up landmark designations in Lower Manhattan.

title: Clinton's Leash
description: Correction Appended

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: It is possible to get travel information on the World Wide Web by using a search engine like Alta Vista, Yahoo or Lycos. It is also bound to be time-consuming and probably fruitless. Luckily, several companies have already done the preliminary work.

title: Other Hotels
description: To the Editor: Because I just returned from South Africa, including a visit to the battlefields of Isandhlwana and Rorke's Drift, I was interested in Robert O. Paxton's article ''Birds and Battles in Boer Country'' (Dec. 1). I would strongly recommend to anyone who is considering visiting the Anglo-Zulu battlefields in northern Natal to consider staying at the Fugitive's Drift Lodge operated by the Dave Rattrays. Dave's love for the history of his country and especially the battlefields is reflected in the eloquent and moving way in which he describes these tragic events. The lodge itself is very comfortable with great food and interesting fellow guests. Contact Fugitive's Drift Lodge, Post Office Rorke's Drift, Natal 3016, South Africa.

title: Music Society to Play Work of Its Member
description: THE composer Joseph Goodman, secretary of the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society, always delights in the artists who take part in the society's free chamber music series at the Presbyterian Church in Pleasantville, but today he is doubly delighted: not only will the 3 P.M. recital feature the first Westchester appearance of Soli Espri, consisting of the mezzo-soprano D'Anna Fortunato, the clarinetist Chester Brezniak and the pianist David Witten, but it also offers the first East Coast performance of three songs from Mr. Goodman's ''Shakespeare Cycle.''

title: Homeless Man Dead After Fire in Queens
description: A homeless man died yesterday afternoon when he was caught in a fire that engulfed a shanty beneath the entrance ramp to a Queens expressway, the police said.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BOATING AND NATURE

title: Pataki Budget Plan Draws Mixed Reviews
description: FOR many groups in Westchester, Gov. George E. Pataki's latest budget proposal, his third since taking office, signals a sky-is-falling year ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCANN, DAVID A. OF LLOYD HARBOR
description: McCANN-David A. of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington. Husband of Carol (nee Gerard). Loving father of Peter, Anthony and Ellen. Brother of Elizabeth McCarthy. Visitation at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:45 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Main Street, Huntington.

title: A Dining Room Built for 3
description: MY friend Lori could not understand why I bought only three dining room chairs at the unfinished-furniture store. Like June Cleaver and Harriet Nelson, Lori is the matriarch of a four-person family. The notion of a dining area with three chairs is as foreign to Lori as an automobile with three wheels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPLEY, MARION J.
description: EPLEY-Marion J., Jr. retired Chairman of Texaco, Inc., died on February 15, 1997, at Harbour's Edge in Delray Beach, Florida. He was 89 years old and previously lived in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Epley practiced law in New Orleans, LA, from 1930 to 1947 when he joined Texaco there. In 1952 he moved to New York, serving as President of the company from 1964 to 1970 and as Chairman until his retirement in 1971. Following his retirement, Mr. Epley moved to Palm Beach where he served as President of the Good Samaritan Hospital for several years, and was a governor of the Everglades Club of Palm Beach. He was also a member of the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach and the Boston Club in New Orleans. Mr. Epley was born in Hattiesburg, Mississippi, and earned undergraduate and law degrees from Tulane University in New Orleans. He was a veteran of WW II, having served in the U.S. Navy from 1942 until 1945. Mr. Epley is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Dorris Ervin of Delray Beach, FL; a son, Marion J. Epley III of Millbrook, NY; a daughter, Sara Epley Davis of Houston, TX; seven grandchildren; and eleven greatgrandchildren. The funeral service and interment for Mr. Epley will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to: Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL, 33486. For information, Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Clinton, Stalling Strike, Averts Travel Chaos for Holiday Weekend
description: Travelers won a reprieve today from a potentially crippling strike by American Airlines pilots after President Clinton intervened, shifting attention to a board that will try to resolve the dispute between airline executives and union leaders within 60 days.

title: Bellinger Struts His Stuff, Scoring 31 for Peacocks
description: Ricky Bellinger pumped his fists and smiled after his running jumper put St. Peter's ahead of Iona, 63-56, with just over a minute remaining in today's game. His celebration may have seemed a bit premature, but the freshman point guard is normally ahead of the game. And led by Bellinger's career-high 31 points, the Peacocks went on to defeat the Gaels, 71-65, at the Yanitelli Center.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Word & Image column on page 20 of The Times Magazine today discusses the legal requirement that American news organizations obtain licenses from the United States Government before operating in Cuba. On Wednesday, after the magazine had gone to press, the White House gave such approval to 10 news organizations; one of them, CNN, has also received permission from Cuba.

title: Brokers Preparing Contracts
description: LAST month, a handful of real estate brokers in Westchester County began providing a service they had not provided before: the preparation of a formal contract of sale for buyers and sellers to sign and then take to their lawyers.

title: Disputed Conservation Plan Could Be Model for Nation
description: The nation's most ambitious attempt to reconcile the preservation of nature with urban development has reached a pivotal moment, and the future of an important aspect of Federal conservation policy may turn on the outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANCONA, CHARLES V., M.D.
description: ANCONA-Charles V., M.D. On February 13, 1997. Reposing at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, NY, Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Holy Family Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Sound Shore Medical Center, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Music in St. Paul
description: To the Editor: Neal Karlen's otherwise fine article ''What's Doing in St. Paul'' (Jan. 12) omitted one important aspect of that city's cultural life that should not be missed: the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra.

title: One Man Can Make a Difference
description: THE COLLAPSE

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: For Small Town, Plan for Private Prison Brings Hope and Fears
description: A plan to build a private prison near the school in this tiny town on the Plains has led to protests, tears and hostility between friends and neighbors.

title: Thumbs Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Bryn Mawr Trustees Choose New President
description: Members of a search committee for a new president for Bryn Mawr College were supposed to recommend several candidates to the trustees but were collectively swept off their feet by one: Nancy J. Vickers, a dean and professor of French, Italian and comparative literature at the University of Southern California who is as much at home with Madonna and George Michael as she is with Dante and Shakespeare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BENJAMIN E.
description: LEVY-Benjamin E. Officers and members of the Board of Directors of Medical Development for Israel, Inc. (MDI) and the Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel are saddened by the passing of Benjamin E. Levy, brother of the Chairman of the Board of MDI, H. Irwin Levy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Lillian, his children, 5 grandchildren and other members of his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Forster, President Shlomit Manson, National Executive Director

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUTTLEWORTH, JACK
description: SHUTTLEWORTH-Jack. On February 14, 1997, age 96. Husband of late Dorothea. Father of C.J. Grandfather of Charles, Edward, Susie and the late William. Memorial gathering at The Players Club later this week. Burial St. John's of Lattingtown Memorial Garden, March 1 at 11AM.

title: 'YOU HAVE A COLD HEART, DEGAS!'
description: All hail to Sister Wendy ('' 'You Have a Cold Heart, Degas!' '' by Marshall Sella, Jan. 26)!

title: More Women Are Filling Executive Positions
description: BARBARA KAVOVIT started her construction business by going to shopping malls in Westchester County to hand out business cards and solicit home remodeling work.

title: Postal Imperialism
description: Next month, uganda will issue a 200-shilling postage stamp featuring Disney's ''Toy Story'' to coincide with the opening of that film in China. Forget the fact that China, already upset with Disney over Martin Scorsese's film in progress about the Dalai Lama, is showing ''Toy Story'' in the first place. Why on earth is Uganda trumpeting the event? And when did postal services become a publicity arm of the American entertainment industry?

title: Louise Sunshine, Martin S. Begun
description: Louise Sunshine, a real estate executive, and Martin S. Begun, the associate dean of the New York University School of Medicine, were married in New York on Wednesday. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated at the home of Dr. Mona Ackerman, a friend of the couple.

title: East-West Fusion That Goes the Distance
description: DOME, lodged in Bertrand's old quarters, is another gastronomic triumph for Greenwich Avenue. Purists may disdain the torrid colors of the new wall painting in the atrium but the golden terra cotta arches and ceiling remain intact.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: But Is It Art?
description: AFTER THE END OF ART

title: Knowing a Tree by Skeleton, Twig and Bark
description: LEAFLESS trees provide wonderful opportunities for identification and observation. Their branch structure is distinctive and often exceedingly handsome. Sometimes the bark provides the strongest clue of all.

title: George and Brown Waste No Time as the Bidding Begins for N.F.L.'s Free Agents
description: It didn't take long for two of the National Football League's most sought-after free agents to be snapped up. Linebacker Chad Brown of the Steelers signed a contract with Seattle, and quarterback Jeff George reached agreement on a five-year, $27.5 million deal with the Oakland Raiders just minutes after the free agent signing period began at midnight Friday.

title: Confrontation Won't Help China's Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Whirlwind Indoor Tour Of New York City
description: ''Show Me New York,'' a new 22-minute video show on two giant side-by-side high-definition screens in an East Side theater, is enough fun to justify the admission of $11.50 for adults and $9 for children up to 12.

title: Albright Flies Toward Vexing Issues
description: In advertising terms, Madeleine K. Albright has had her national rollout as the new Secretary of State. She has laid down her themes of bipartisanship, global responsibility and public diplomacy, and through appointments and symbolism has tried to yank the center of foreign policy-making back into the State Department.

title: Boxers as Pawns
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Library of Congress Is an Internet Hit
description: Exactly a hundred years ago, in 1897, the Library of Congress's Jefferson building opened, inaugurating a new, populist era in the history of one of the world's great repositories of knowledge. For the first time, the library's books were available not just to members of Congress and their staffs, not just to scholars and specialists, but to Everyman.

title: 'I Got E-Mail From Bill!'
description: Deeper My Two-Year Odyssey in Cyberspace. By John Seabrook. 288 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Wells Ready For Sport, On the Field And Off It
description: Sporting a politically incorrect shirt and chugging on a bottle of water following his first official workout with the Yankees today, David Wells called himself lazy, admitted he is overweight and insisted he has no tolerance for people who cannot accept his rowdy style.

title: On the No. 7 Subway Line in Queens, It's an Underground United Nations
description: When Arelis DeLeon, a Dominican immigrant, steps onto a packed car of the No. 7 subway train at Junction Boulevard in Corona, Queens, each morning, she surveys the press of people crammed into seats, guessing who will get off first and leave her a place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNNERS, REBECCA
description: SUNNERS-Rebecca. Age 90. On February 12, 1997, in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late William Sunners, mother of Harold and Marilyn, mother-in-law of Elise Sunners and Norman Cranin, sister of Samuel, grandmother and great-grandmother. Willy's waiting.

title: An English Parish Polishes a Link to America
description: A parish church in Northamptonshire, England, has recently decided to celebrate its connection with George Washington. St. Andrew's in the village of Spratton, about 65 miles north of London, installed a plaque in October recording that Amphillis Twigden, the first President's great-great-grandmother, was baptized at its font on Feb. 2, 1602. The 13th-century stone font is still in use.

title: Job Security Dwindles as Rent-a-Job Companies Surge
description: Like more than 43 million others over the past two decades, Douglas E. Owens was downsized, unemployed, rented out, and basically left to survive by his wits. His resume went out to hundreds of companies and his feet walked miles of carpet in and out of interviews after he was cast out of the cradle-to-grave corporate world that he had e inhabited for 23 years.

title: DIARY
description: STOCK MARKET

title: Deficit: Public Enemy No. 1, It's Not
description: AS the Senate last week debated a proposed constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, the Senators in favor would not let the opponents forget where the public stands.

title: At Counters, Much Relief And Smiles
description: Perhaps a panel of labor scholars will someday debate President Clinton's invocation of the 1926 Railway Labor Act early yesterday morning to block a strike by American Airlines pilots.

title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction
description: AGAINST THE GODS

title: Books In Brief: Fiction
description: BAG MEN By John Flood. Norton, $24.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart last Sunday about bonuses for mutual fund management misstated the period used by the Fidelity Magellan fund to determine whether to pay its managers the bonuses or to assess penalties. The fees are determined monthly, not annually, based on fund performance for the prior 36 months, not the 36 months through the end of the fiscal year on March 31. According to the fund's semiannual report last September, Fidelity switched sometime during 1996 from paying a bonus to assessing a penalty.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Word of Caution On Sex Education
description: Your reporter, either through ingenue-like innocence or by design, apparently accepts at face value the Planned Parenthood party line view of ''health workers and educators'' in the story entitled ''Myths Cloud Teen-Agers' Knowledge of Sexuality'' $(Jan. 19$). Allow me to present an opposing view.

title: What a Physicist Finds Obscene
description: STEPHEN HAWKING has never been known as a particularly prudish man. Once, about 20 years ago, he agreed to give his fellow physicist Kip Thorne a one-year subscription to Penthouse magazine if a certain black hole, believed to be lurking in the constellation Cygnus, turned out to really exist.

title: What Dean Witter's Clients May Be Worth
description: DO you consider yourself an uninformed investor?

title: Facing New Challenges, Law Firms Diversify
description: WHEN Bernard Hyman founded the law firm of Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman in 1965, the practice concentrated primarily on real-estate law and thrived on the building boom that had enveloped Long Island -- housing complexes and shopping centers.

title: Retirees Returning To Fill the Talent Gap
description: The last time Kelly Gruber was seen in a baseball uniform, the players and owners had not even begun their long-running labor dispute. Scott Bailes last wore a major league uniform before that, when Cal Ripken Jr. was 395 games and three seasons away from Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game streak. And Tom O'Malley? O'Malley last played in the majors so long ago that two new teams and six new ball parks have been built since.

title: Law Schools Optimistic on Jobs
description: DESPITE intense competition, the two law schools on Long Island are optimistic over prospects for their graduates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, IRWIN
description: SCHWARTZ-Irwin. Beloved husband of Edith. Father of Paul (Barbara) Schwartz and Joan (Will) Weber. Brother of Selig Schwartz. Loving grandfather. Services today at 11:30 AM, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Airport Security
description: To the Editor: I have read with interest the letters on Jan. 12 in answer to the article, ''Wool on the Go: A Knitter's Yarn'' (Nov. 17) because I have found that security people do not find us as innocuous as we consider ourselves to be.

title: A Haven for Creative Talents, Then and Now
description: MONTCLAIR may never count as New Jersey's answer to SoHo, but how about its Provincetown, or maybe its Woodstock? In 1894, The New York Times wrote of Montclair as ''the home of more prominent artists and wealthy connoisseurs . . . than any other place in New-Jersey.'' Back then, artists came to Montclair for many reasons, but a cohesive group had crystallized around the most prominent among them, the landscape painter George Inness, who began frequenting Montclair in 1878 and made it his primary residence in 1885.

title: European Air-Fare Wars Are Slow to Take Off
description: NO fewer than three airports serve this sprawling and vibrant city, scheduled to become capital of a reunited Germany two years from now. But anyone who wants to fly to Frankfurt, Germany's banking and financial center, has exactly one choice in airlines: Lufthansa. A round-trip economy ticket costs about $400.

title: Hearing the Truth Through the Static With a Tape Analyst on the Case
description: WHO -- Paul Ginsberg, 51, professional tinkerer turned audio tape expert.

title: Reading the Torah, an Orthodox Women's Group Takes On Tradition
description: Once a month, Sharon Kalker, an Orthodox Jewish woman, clears the basement of her house in Hillcrest, Queens, and unfolds 30 chairs on the brown-carpeted floor. In the middle of the room, she rests an overturned bookcase on a table, placing a cover over it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, HERBERT B.
description: EHRLICH-Herbert B. Beloved husband of Ina, devoted father of Michael and Lisa, Robert and Wendy, Michael, Stephanie, Gail, Ellen, adored son of Rose, dear brother of Fran, adored grandfather of Austin, Clayton, and Bela. Services Sunday, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside Nassau North Chapel'', 55 North Station Plaza, opposite LIRR.

title: Greening of Reservoir, Part I
description: From the window of her 11th-floor apartment, Anne Marie Garti has a striking view of the calm waters of the Jerome Park Reservoir, the Manhattan skyline off in the distance. Her dream is that one day this view will take in a park surrounding the 94-acre reservoir, enveloping it with shrubbery, walking paths and flowers.

title: Confrontation Won't Help China's Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Reform in the Balance
description: Most officeholders in Washington still don't get it, but the American electoral system is in ethical and financial crisis. When it comes to President Clinton's fund-raising, the chips of news have now arranged themselves into a mosaic of scandal. Few reasonable Democrats any longer question the wrongness of their party's behavior in the last election. The remaining suspense is over how prosecutable it is.

title: Cottage Where Childbirth Is Standard Family Fare
description: AS her mother, Joan Schwarz-Lema, soaked in a warm bathtub and her father and a midwife assisted with labor, Victoria Francesca Lema was born in the early hours of a snowy morning here.

title: The Work-at-Home Executive
description: To the Editor:

title: Blame Judges, Not Voters, for California's Declining Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Summers, Mr. Leouzon
description: Stephanie Marie Summers and Eugene Leouzon were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony.

title: Trickle Tries to Keep His Concentration on Track
description: Starting in post position No. 27 in Sunday's Daytona 500 is Dick Trickle, a man trying hard not to let his thoughts drift several thousand miles away.

title: A Pacer Hero Facing His Hardest Challenge
description: The voice was weak at first. Raspy, breathy. Then as the conversation turned to basketball history, basketball lore, Roger Brown's voice became stronger, filled with authority and passion. After all these years, basketball is a sustaining life force. ''I'm glad I feel strong enough to talk,'' he said. ''I'll probably pay for it later on.''

title: Q. & A.
description: Sponsor's Selling a Co-op Unit

title: Another Proposal to Rename a Street Upsets San Franciscans
description: When the lone black member of the Board of Supervisors proposed last week to rename one of this city's streets in honor of a local civil rights hero, Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett, the sentiment appeared unassailable.

title: A Major Resource In Cancer Care
description: The article concerning treatment available for cancer patients on Long Island (''More Hospitals Providing Cancer Care,'' Jan. 12) failed to include a major resource in expertise and equipment available at the Nassau County Medical Center.

title: Mayor Angry Over Silence About Sewage
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani publicly chastised his senior environmental aides yesterday for not notifying him and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey about a plan to discharge 500 million gallons of raw sewage into the East River during repairs to the city's sewage treatment system.

title: Books In Brief: Fiction
description: The Pirate's Daughter

title: Brain Drain
description: WAR BY OTHER MEANS Economic Espionage in America. By John J. Fialka. 242 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: South Africa Slips in Role Of a 'Tiger'
description: THREE years ago, South Africa seemed on the verge of stealing the ''economic tiger'' title from its Asian counterparts. Its peaceful transition to majority rule and a booming, liquid stock market looked promising. Three closed-end funds began for eager American investors, and a couple of open-end funds followed suit.

title: 'Basically, I'm a Backroom Girl': Of Lovers, Husbands, Wealth and Power
description: SHORTLY before Pamela Harriman's death at 76 in Paris on Feb. 5, the world got a searing portrait of the American Ambassador to France with the publication of ''Reflected Glory,'' a biography by Sally Bedell Smith. Deep in the book, discussing Mrs. Harriman's manipulations of the press, Ms. Smith writes that late in 1992, just before Bill Clinton's inauguration, Mrs. Harriman agreed to talk to me for New York magazine ''on condition that her quotes be attributed to an 'intimate.' ''

title: Important Messages, More Than a Little Garbled
description: When the state sent 100,000 welfare recipients a letter in Spanish that greeted them, in a South American colloquialism for passive partners in gay sex, Heriberto Sanchez Soto was dismayed but not surprised.

title: The Latest Word
description: BACK TO FREUD'S TEXTS Making Silent Documents Speak. By Ilse Grubrich-Simitis. Translated by Philip Slotkin. 322 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: World War II's Unfinished Business
description: WORLD WAR II, with its global carnage and the Holocaust, is the epic of our age. Each generation has its own increasingly complicated interpretation of the war's meaning and mysteries, its heroes and villains, and more than 50 years later it retains the power to shock and surprise.

title: 'Everything for Sale'
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIG, ROBERT M.
description: ZWEIG-Robert M. of Boca Raton, FL, age 76, died February 12, 1997 at 11:40 PM. Born Brooklyn, September 16, 1920, to Pinkus and Rebecca, he graduated from Queens College and West Virginia University. Veteran WW II. President John Chatillon and National Scale Manufacturer's Association. Past Master, Masons. Retired to play tennis, fish, swim, write poetry and become a sculptor. He leaves: his wife of forty-nine years, Estelle; two sons, Paul (with Sandy in MD); and Michael (with Marie in CA); his older brother Sol (with Harriet in FL); and six grandchildren (Rachel, Aaron, Ben, Megan, Casey and Sarah). His spirit, as always, will inspire us forever.

title: Where Modern Stevedores Haul Cargo, 120 Feet Above the Docks
description: The porters, stevedores and longshoremen of old have mostly hung up their hooks and given way to a new breed of dock worker. Since the early 1970's, at the container terminal in Port Newark-Elizabeth they have been the operators who run the enormous cranes visible from the New Jersey Turnpike. From their waterfront perch atop the 120-foot cranes, the operators have a view of the Manhattan skyline and Newark Bay on one side, and a bustling stretch of the Turnpike and Newark International Airport on the other. But there is little time for sightseeing. Crane operators work quickly and in around-the-clock shifts to load and unload container ships that have come from all over the world and are in a hurry to be on their way again.

title: Australian Fishermen, Warned of Peril, Remain on the Rocks
description: They have their buckets, lunch packs and bait bags of worms, prawns or bits of mackerel, eel and squid. From Sydney's rocky coastline they ply their long, silvery lines for that magic moment when the bream, whiting, kingfish or anything else from hammerhead to dugong might strike from the pools below.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a dispute over fire insurance coverage of the Meridian Plaza office building in Philadelphia included an outdated reference to the insurance company involved. The company has been known as Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation since Aetna Inc.'s sale of its property and casualty portfolio last year to Travelers Group.

title: Putting Aside the Books But Keeping Insurance
description: WHEN Sally Rowe decided to take a semester off from the College of Charleston in South Carolina to ski and work in Colorado, she was losing more than a few months of school. She also lost her health insurance.

title: The Suit Threatening '98 Track Games
description: Mr. Rechler says that when soccer tournaments were held at Mitchel Field, traffic was ''chaotic,'' adding that ''busloads of kids were being dropped off. Cars were driving all over the lawns, and the people had no way to get in and out.''

title: An Eccentric Who Likes To Make Things Accessible
description: IF GROUP THERAPY SESSIONS were dances, they might look like David Dorfman's choreography. Vocal, playful and raw, his seriocomic dance-theater pieces explore both kinetic boundaries and personal issues. They address ethnic and sexual identity, the difficulty of intimacy and all the other emotional baggage a person carries while struggling to get through each day.

title: 4 Bdrm, 0 Vu; Rent, $4,300
description: ONE of the most striking things about the rental apartment in the West Village on Horatio Street near Washington Street, in the meat-packing district, is the price: $4,300 a month.

title: Once-Gritty Neighborhood Comes Alive
description: GANSEVOORT STREET marks the great divide.

title: Larry Flynt's Assailant Has Left a Trail of Bigotry and Murder
description: In the movie ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' an epilogue notes that the sniper who shot Mr. Flynt and his lawyer in 1978, during Mr. Flynt's pornography trial in Georgia, has not been brought to justice.

title: Living the Dream
description: PEOPLE dream about opening their own restaurants; Silvio Di Fiore, formerly the director of inventory control and loss prevention for an automotive company in South River, achieved his goal in August. He bought a small restaurant whose owner was eager to sell, hired an experienced chef and rechristened the tiny space Di Fiore's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, ERIC E.
description: OLSON-Eric E. Passed away on February 14, 1997, after a valiant battle against AIDS. His sense of humor, his beautiful smile and his sense of freedom will always live inside of us. He leaves behind a large family in Nebraska and many friends all over the world. We love you Eric. Rest in peace.

title: Not Your Mother's Meatloaf
description: WEIGHING THE MERITS OF THE KNOWN against a leap into the unfamiliar is a dance between the mundane and the risky. Meatloaf, for instance, is safe; curried meatloaf, on the other hand, requires courage. The more familiar a dish, the more freighted the improvisation. And yet the urge to improvise seems to increase in direct proportion to the risks that attend it.

title: One Last Flirtation With Love
description: IT'S only a four-character, one-set play, yet ''The Old Settler'' is so richly peopled, so panoramic in its reflection of Harlem in the early 1940's that the sounds of the Savoy Ballroom, Jimmy's Chicken Shack and the Down Home Restaurant permeate the living room and the kitchen on the McCarter Theater's stage.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Katharine DeWitt, John Kern Jr.
description: Katharine Margaret DeWitt and John Charles Kern Jr. were married yesterday in Cincinnati. Msgr. Joseph M. O'Brien performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Chapel at the Summit Country Day School.

title: Correction: Fretting Over the Market
description: A chart last Sunday about the performance of different types of mutual funds during bear markets omitted the percentage returns of the best- and worst-performing fund groups. Here is a corrected version.

title: Inspired Isles Play Like Champions
description: Twenty-five years from now, when the Islanders celebrate their second quarter century, how will they remember the players who currently wear their uniform?

title: Aha!
description: THE PROBLEM FACING THE ASSEMBLED editors of The New York Times in early 1977 was brow-furrowing: what kind of column could be created for the front of the Magazine that would seem to be right on top of the news, as if written for the daily paper, but could be written a couple of weeks ahead to conform to the longer lead time of the color-paged Magazine?

title: Cuba's Bridge to the United States
description: GUESTS at Havana's old Hotel Nacional who watch television can now choose between grainy black-and-white films extolling the glory of the 1959 Communist Revolution or feature films on HBO like the cold war thriller ''The Hunt for Red October.''

title: Et Tu, Ecru?
description: We recognize change as an immutable law of nature. However, Fran Lebowitz -- the author of ''Metropolitan Life'' as well as an endless parchment of gloomy social reflections -- has a slightly more pitiful view of evolution: ''I have never seen any change for the better.'' She includes in her bleak scroll of regret the decline of penny loafers, the extinction of Schrafft's, the thinning of denim, the decision to implant escalators in the Museum of Modern Art (thus ''turning it into a kind of Bloomingdale's'') and finally -- the greatest insult of all -- the abject loss of her pet duds to the sputter of fashion.

title: Anguilla Resort Takes A Holistic Turn
description: Coccoloba, a resort on the island of Anguilla that has had quite a few lives already, has reopened as a holistic version of a health spa. The resort, on a beach noted for its snorkeling and diving, was closed by Hurricane Luis in 1995. It has since been bought by a group of American doctors specializing in holistic medicine, who are reopening it as the first of what is planned to be a chain of resorts that cater to the mind, body and spirit. There are 44 villas open at present, with 80 more under construction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWOHIG, ALICE V.
description: TWOHIG-Alice V. Of Westwood, NJ, formerly of Jamacia, Queens, on Friday, February 14, 1997. Wife of the late Edward M. Twohig, Sr. Mother of Edward M., Jr., John J. and Robert P. Twohig. Sister of Blanche Spalckhaver. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral Mass at St. Andrew Church, Westwood, NJ, on Tuesday at 10 AM. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, NJ. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINFELD, MORRIS
description: KLEINFELD - Morris, M.D., passed away February 12, 1997. He is survived by his beloved wife, Miriam; loving children, Gail (Dr. Mark) Heifferman, Dr. Jay (Dr. Evangeline) Kleinfeld, Shelley (Dr. Matthew) Schwartz, and Karen (Dr. David) Lessing, and eight grandchildren. Services were held.

title: Cuisine in the Sky
description: To the Editor: Flying commercial airlines need not be a culinary bust as you imply in ''Nibbling Away at the Cost of Airline Food'' (Jan. 26). You should have included Milwaukee-based Midwest Express Airlines as a wonderful exception to the skimping. Midwest Express spends over $10 on, yes, delicious meals served on cloth tablecloths with complimentary wine. All topped off with warm chocolate cookies.

title: An Actor-Artist Draws a Portrait
description: AS AUDIENCES ARRIVE AT circle in the Square on Broadway to see ''Stanley,'' Antony Sher will already be high up on the set, busily painting away. Who is Mr. Sher, and who is this artist Stanley Spencer, whom the esteemed London-based actor -- in his American stage debut -- will proceed to impersonate for the better part of three hours?

title: Matchmaker
description: Jane Austen's clueless 19th-century heroine returns in another production -- SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on A&E. In this EMMA, produced by Sue Birtwistle and directed by Diarmuid Lawrence, Kate Beckinsale (''Cold Comfort Farm'') plays Emma Woodhouse, the pretty, rich young woman who has so little to do that she takes an interest in everyone's love life. As she makes and unmakes matches among her friends and neighbors in the English village of Highbury, she almost misses her own perfect romance. Mark Strong stars as the long-suffering Mr. Knightley and Raymond Coulthard plays the good-looking and rakish Frank Churchill.

title: Heartening Lessons of Winslow Whale
description: SEVERAL years ago, when Joyce Howell was sailing from New England to Canada, a pair of whales suddenly jumped out of the water off the stern, disappeared for about five minutes, broke the surface again with the same enthusiasm, and continued their playful antics for about a half an hour.

title: An Enhancement To Serious Activities
description: To the Editor:

title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction
description: Oddity Odyssey

title: Turks March In Campaign To Preserve Secularism
description: Thousands of Turks, most of them women, marched through the streets of Ankara today in the first major public protest against the policies of the Islamic-led Government.

title: Have a Cigar! But Will the Flavor Last?
description: THEY'RE at it again. Another cigar venture, the third since August, will soon go public. But while the renewed interest in cigar smoking may lift this stock smartly in the short run, long-term investors face a risk that no one can quantify: that, like Hula-Hoops, Pet Rocks and dozens of other forgotten items, cigars, as a fashion statement at least, may just be a fad.

title: Where Young and Old Just Click
description: THE teacher, Paul Warren, said, ''Maybe you could share something about yourself.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLANAHAN, SOPHIE LAY
description: McCLANAHAN-Sophie Lay. Of Modesto, CA. Formerly of Englewood, NJ, and Manhattan, passed away peacefully, February 9, just before her 90th year. Beloved wife of the late ophthalmologist, Dr. Robert McClanahan, mother of William, Sophie Barnes, Anne Bourne, and Sara Hancox, sister of Louisa Morton, grandmother of fourteen, great-grandmother of eleven. Memorial service April 19, Brookside Cemetery, Englewood.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about the performance of different types of mutual funds during bear markets omitted the percentage returns of the best- and worst-performing fund groups. A corrected version appears today on page 7.

title: Coast Guard Investigates How 3 Were Killed in Lifeboat Rescue
description: Coast Guard Petty Officer David Bosley was scheduled to leave the stormy coast of the Pacific Northwest in two months and head to the calmer waters off Oceanside, Calif. But when a sailboat's distress call came in early Wednesday morning, Mr. Bosley and three crewmen headed into the rough seas off La Push, Wash., about 115 miles west of Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSMAN, JACK
description: PRESSMAN-Jack. The Warsaw Ghetto Resistance Organization mourn the loss of its Secretary, Jack Pressman. A survivor of the Warsaw Ghetto, as well as the Oberlanzdorf and Gross Rosen concentration camps, Mr. Pressman devoted his life after the war to remembrance of the Holocaust. Born in Warsaw, he came to the United States in 1951, where he served as an engineer with the Otis Elevator Company. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Alina Kaplan; daughters Barbara Eckstrom, Jennifer Pressman and Eva Zeidman and their families; and his brother and sister-in-law, Adek and Hansie Pressman. Funeral services on Monday, February 17, 10 AM at the Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, Queens Blvd. & 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY. Benjamin Meed, President Warsaw Ghetto Resistance Organization

title: Treating the Young Warriors of the Playground
description: DAVID, a third grader, limped into the nurse's office at the Spring Garden School, the left leg of his gray sweat pants pulled up above his thin, bony knee, exposing a round red scrape.

title: The Fight Took 8 Rounds, the Film 22 Years
description: MANY DIRECTORS CAN SAY truthfully that they lived with a movie for a long time. Few can mean this as literally as Leon Gast, whose documentary ''When We Were Kings,'' a verite study of Muhammad Ali's unlikely recovery of boxing's top title in 1974, opened on Friday.

title: Natural Habitats
description: ''I look at these photographs with a prurient interest,'' John Updike writes in his introduction to THE WRITER'S DESK (Random House, $35), ''the way that I might look at the beds of notorious courtesans.'' Mr. Updike's implication is that most lovers of books will view these pages with the same voyeuristic fascination he does, and of course he is right. Jill Krementz has photographed more than 1,500 writers, and the majority of the 56 depicted here, each accompanied by his own commentary on the creative process, appear to feel comfortable with her. Jean Piaget sits at his desk, surrounded by piles upon piles of papers, yet he claims to have lost only one paper in his whole life -- and that, most likely, on purpose. An arresting Susan Sontag sits at a long wooden table filled with papers and stacks of books, staring seductively into the camera. The portrait of Toni Morrison is quiet yet regal: she sits on a sofa wrapped in a robe, writing in a notebook as the light of day approaches. Not all the writers are pictured at proper desks; several, including Walker Percy and Cathleen Schine, do their writing in bed; Ann Petry sits at her kitchen table; and Veronica Chambers sits on her kitchen counter with her laptop. Though Richard Ford is shown sitting at a desk, for him a desk is ''more of a concept than a thing.''
