The other writers portrayed include Edmund White, Eugene Ionesco, Katherine Anne Porter and Joan Didion . For anyone interested in writers and their work, Ms. Krementz has provided a small but revealing look beneath the covers. Robin Lippincott

title: A Long Look Backward
description: ON nights when she cannot sleep, Bessie Nickens retreats to the enclosed terrace of her apartment on East 23d Street. With the skyline glistening in the distance, this 91-year-old artist paints memories of another time and place: her childhood in the rural South early in this century.

title: Nets Repay Bullets for a Rout
description: After losing to the Washington Bullets on Friday, the Nets got revenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, LIN
description: CHEN-Lin. On February 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Susie Chen. President of Summit Import Corporation and Kam Man Food Corporation. He will be deeply missed by his loving family and friends. Funeral information, please call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., at 212-288-3500.

title: Artist Captures History in Memorabilia
description: KAREN SEVELL Greenbaum spent many years focusing her creative talents on the younger generation. She and a partner specialized in children's designs, like murals at Bloomingdale's and the Child Life program at Yale-New Haven Hospital as well as three nationally successful wallpaper collections with matching borders and fabrics and a line of bed linens by Wamsutta. They also developed a toy produced by Eden Toys and apparel and accessories sold under the name Whimsical Wares.

title: On the Books, More Fact and Less Fiction
description: EARNINGS season is upon us, and some accounting experts say the numbers you are seeing tell a more truthful story about corporate America than they once did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ARTHUR HOLROYD
description: MOORE-Arthur Holroyd. Retired President of Bridgeport Metal Goods. Died February 9, 1997, in Bridgeport, Connecticut.

title: Paulette Satur and Eberhard Muller
description: THE executive chef and part owner of Lutece, Eberhard Muller, likes to stroll through his pale peach dining rooms at least once a night, greeting guests. While he's not exactly looking for compliments, he's always available for them.

title: 68 NATIONS AGREE TO WIDEN MARKETS IN COMMUNICATIONS
description: More than 60 countries endorsed a landmark agreement today to open up their telecommunication markets to all rivals. The move legally commits governments to unlock the state telephone monopolies that still control well over half of the world's communications business.

title: Emergency Room
description: FIRST, BODY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIES, HANNA, M.D.
description: MARGULIES-Hanna, M.D. Born in Vienna, Austria. Beloved wife of the late Simon, devoted mother of Joyce, loving mother-in-law of Uttam Shah, cherished grandmother of Shruti and Lily, loving sister of Gerda Haas, sister-in-law of the late Richard Haas. Services 12:15 Sunday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: At Home in Two Worlds
description: IN CHINESE, A LANGUAGE RICH IN colorful and elaborate insults, one of the nastiest things you can call someone is ''neither East nor West.'' The object of the insult, it implies, is a real nothing: not only less than human but lacking even the stature of a thing, since a material object has to exist somewhere in space.

title: Women's Work
description: The two great women of Georgetown lived through history that others could only read about. They were raised to be the opposite of what they became. For years, they were happily in the shadow of famous men. Then, widowed, both struggled to remake themselves as serious players in arenas where women were rare.

title: Bishop's Quiet Action Allows Priest Both Flock and Family
description: Nothing seems unusual at the diocesan headquarters of an Eastern Rite Catholic Church here, but for one fact. The earnest, affable priest who welcomes a visitor inside, the Rev. Andre St. Germain, is a married man, the father of two grown sons and, he says happily, the grandfather of a couple of toddlers.

title: Robert Ridgely, 65, Film and TV Actor
description: Robert Ridgely, a film and television actor, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 65.

title: What's It Worth? Appraisers Tell All
description: STEPHEN SADTLER WAS THINKING last July that he might get $50 to $200 for his old sword at a garage sale. Then he heard that the ''Antiques Roadshow,'' a new television show that travels from city to city featuring on-the-spot appraisals, was coming to Seattle. So he decided that he would not sell the sword until one of the show's appraisers had taken a look at it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, RABBI RALPH
description: SILVERSTEIN-Rabbi Ralph. Friends and family announce with great sorrow the passing of this distinguished clergyman and community leader on February 11 at the age of 86. Ordained in 1940, he served as Rabbi at The Ninth Street Temple, The Madison Jewish Center and Temple Sinai, all in Brooklyn. Beloved brother of Milton and Jerome Silverstein, Deborah Freedman, Yvette Greisman and the late Ruth Brooks. A graveside service will take place Sunday, February 16, at 2:30 PM, the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KINSBRUNER, MAC
description: KINSBRUNER-Mac. On March 21, 1909 to February 16, 1972. In loving memory. The Family

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: A Car-Truck Hybrid in Full Bloom
description: IT was the coldest day of the year. The wind-chill factor had plummeted to 20 below zero. But I pictured myself heading to the beach in shorts and a T-shirt.

title: Quiet Midday Is Misleading At a Sixth Street Restaurant
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodbye, Divorce Court
description: EVERYBODY likes to talk about divorce. If not their own, then their sister's, brother's, cousin's, friend's. Or you-know-who's or what's his-name's. At social gatherings I attended over the last several years, strangers would invariably turn to me with eager eyes once they found out I was a divorce lawyer. Clucking sympathetically at ''how hard it must be,'' they were nevertheless hungry for dirt. And full of questions.

title: If Painting Is Apples, Must Music Be Oranges?
description: ONE OF THE CONNECTIONS the Eos Ensemble was trying to establish with its ''Minimalism and Baroque'' project recently was the old one between music and visual art, which never quite works, and which always never quite works for the same reasons. Time is a different substance from space. The ear operates otherwise than the eye. What is the reality that music depicts?

title: Tom, Dick and Xtmeng
description: THE LANGUAGE

title: Expense Means Many Can't Get Drugs for AIDS
description: Even though new drugs show great promise in combating AIDS, many patients are finding that they cannot easily get the costly medicines because of restrictions imposed by health maintenance organizations and by state programs set up to assist people with low incomes.

title: Guides for a Labor Labyrinth
description: Joanna Cheng sat at a folding table in a storefront office last Wednesday. She was speaking to some workers from a sweatshop that had shut down and disappeared without paying them. She was trying to track down the owner.

title: Troupe's Home a Warehouse
description: For the last two and a half years, the Pregones theater has been a troupe of wandering minstrels, giving performances wherever it could find a stage. But now, the 18-year-old Puerto Rican company has found a home of its own.

title: ROCK ME CHEAPER
description: Last fall, the promoters behind Rock 'n' Roll Fantasy Camp promised a Feb. 17 West Hollywood kickoff for a weeklong event that would allow civilians to jam with famous rock mossbacks (including Mountain's Leslie West!). The bad news: It's off. Sluggish sales have forced a delay. The good news: The promoters aren't giving up, a fact that could represent big savings for rock fantasists. If the revised camp opens April 2 in Miami Beach, the week will last five days instead of seven and won't cost as much ($2,795, down from $4,450). David Fishof, who helped dream it up, is sure these alterations mean solid gold. ''Use my quote,'' he says. ''Everyone has two businesses: their business and show business.''

title: Our Best Defense
description: The Chemical Weapons Convention an international treaty that commits member nations to destroy their chemical weapons and to forswear future production, acquisition or use of them -- is before the Senate for approval. Despite the fact that the treaty was negotiated under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, a number of Republicans have expressed reservations about it. I respect their motives, but their concerns are misplaced.

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: Finally, a celebrity who talks about the working class. ''I didn't see anybody,'' Springsteen is quoted as saying, ''not Clinton or Dole, addressing the concerns of working people.''

title: A Bridgeport Effort With a Global Link
description: AID TO ARTISANS, a Farmington-based company that has worked for 20 years in foreign countries has turned its attention to Bridgeport, where the company is helping to develop the Bridgeport Artisan Center. The center, designed as an economic incubator of sorts for artisans, is being created by Action for Bridgeport Community Development, a 30-year-old organization.

title: Paint Early American Furniture With Care
description: MOST people think of Colonial furniture as simple and plain, with little or no color. Indeed, many early pieces had little more than an oil finish. There were a number of reasons for this esthetic austerity. Paint was a scarce commodity in 17th century, and craftsmen were even rarer. Early settlers were busy carving out a living from the wilderness and had little time for decoration. Many Puritans believed that personal and home adornment was frivolous, and even sinful.

title: Embattled Superintendent Suddenly Says He'll Quit
description: On Wednesday, the day Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew told members of Community School Board 5 that he was considering suspending some or all of them, the veteran Superintendent of the failing Harlem school district Bertrand Brown, suddenly submitted his letter of resignation to the Chancellor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, JOHN FREDERICK
description: MALONEY-John Frederick. Died Friday, February 14. Beloved husband of Lucia (McKellar) Maloney. Dear father of John, Jr., and Robert McKellar, and Bonnie Hartman. Dear grandfather to Michael Hartman.

title: In Diaper Wars, Disposables Must Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRACCHIA, EUGENE JOSEPH
description: FRACCHIA-Eugene Joseph. 11/ 03/39-02/21/88. Lola Restaurant and the Taylor-Manning group of stores continue to mourn. We will hang tight. William Manning, Chairman Lola Restaurant Group, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTHRIE, HENRY B.
description: GUTHRIE-Henry B., a prominent lawyer in NYC for many years, died Wednesday, February 12, at his home in Bedford, NY, at the age of 94. He was predeceased just one month ago by his devoted wife of 64 years, Elizabeth Archer Guthrie. A native New Yorker, Mr. Guthrie graduated from Hill School in 1920 and Phi Beta Kappa from Princeton University in 1924. After graduation from Harvard University Law School in 1927 he joined the law firm of Shearman & Sterling in NYC. He became a partner of the firm in 1941 and practiced there until his retirement. Avid sailors, ornithologists and salmon fishermen, Mr. and Mrs. Guthrie also maintained a summer home in Southwest Harbor, ME. Active in civic affairs in NYC for many years, Mr. Guthrie was a former Chairman of the Board of Big Brothers, Inc., in NY and former Vice President of Big Brothers of America. He served on the Board of the Camille and Henry Dreyfus Foundation from its founding in 1946 until his death. He served as Secretary and Treasurer of the Board initially and served as its Chairman for a number of years. Mr. Guthrie was a former trustee of the Mount Desert Island Hospital, a Director of the United Hospital Fund of NY and a former Chairman of St. Luke's Hospital. He was on the Board of Green-wood Cemetery in Brooklyn and served as its President in 1973. He was a Director of Doubleday & Co. Inc., where he was Chief Officer of the Board for 10 years and also served as Chairman in 1973. Mr. Guthrie is survived by a brother-in-law, E. Chandlee Archer of Hanover, NH, and a niece, Elizabeth F. Nixon, of Greenwich, CT, as well as many other loving cousins, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held May 31, 1997, at the family home in Bedford. Contributions may be made to the American Museum of Natural History, Mianus Gorge Preserve Inc., College of the Atlantic, Bar Harbor, ME, or the charity of your choice.

title: Pet Therapy Promotes Love And Nurturing

title: A Big New Ferry Links Germany and Sweden
description: What is being touted as the largest passenger, car and railway ferry in the world went into service last month on the Baltic Sea between Trelleborg in southern Sweden and Rostock in northern Germany. Although this crossing has had ferry service since 1994, the new 8,600-ton ship, the Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, is designed to avoid disasters such as the sinking of the Estonia in the Baltic Sea in September 1994, when some 900 passengers died.

title: Drunken Driving Pondered
description: WHEN the Olympic skater Oksana Baiul skidded off the road in her Mercedes-Benz at almost 100 miles an hour in the early hours of Jan. 12 in Bloomfield, one of several apparent shortcomings in Connecticut's drunken-driving statutes was exposed. The statutes certainly have their defenders, who argue they protect individual rights, but increasingly vocal critics say they were written more to drum up business for lawyers than to protect the public.

Cherished father of Dr. Joshua Fried, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. and Naomi Brynien, Astoria, N.Y. Brother of Dr. Sally Fox, Birmingham, MI. A decorated WW II Naval Veteran and Chaplain of the Jewish War Veterans. An educator, humanist, labor organizer for the Furrier's Union and life-long fighter for peace, social justice and equality. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENTRY, JAMES BAXTER
description: GENTRY-James Baxter (''Baxter''). Born on September 9, 1906, in Lumber City, Georgia, the first child of Oscar Alachua Gentry and Mary Bird Baxter Gentry, died in Houston, Texas, on Friday, February 14, 1997. Mr. Gentry was predeceased by his wife of 69 years, Dora Ferrell Gentry on May 5, 1996. He is survived by his three sons, James Baxter Gentry, Jr., Chisholm Ferrell Gentry and Wilmer Edgar (''Bill'') Gentry; two daughters-in-law, Julia Smith Gentry (Mrs. Baxter Gentry, Jr.) and Judith Tift Gentry (Mrs. Chisholm Gentry); ten grandchildren, sixteen great-grandchildren, and many nieces, nephews and other relatives. He graduated from public school in Eastman, Georgia, and attended Emory University in Atlanta and received a law degree with honors from The Woodrow Wilson School of Law. He was engaged in the marine insurance industry for 46 years, retiring in 1971 as Vice President and Senior Partner of Johnson and Higgins Insurance Brokers of New York City. He also was the head of his firm's offices throughout South America and Europe. He was largely responsible for the introduction and implementation of multiple-peril insurance policies, and was considered the leading expert in this once revolutionary, now widespread form of risk coverage for business and industry. In his retirement he created a tropical garden on his Sugar Loaf Key estate in Florida which became internationally famous for the large variety and outstanding specimens of its palm trees and other cycads. He travelled the world with his wife, with frequent trips to Europe, Asia, South America and Africa, as well as Russia and China when both were first opened to foreign visitors from free-world countries. He was an active board member of Fairchild Gardens in Miami and a leading conservationist in the Lower Keys until he moved to Houston in March of 1995. He possessed an adventurous spirit, a keen intellect, and an unswerving dedication to the highest level of integrity in all his dealings both as a businessman and a friend to his many associates and acquaintances. A memorial service will be held in The Founders Chapel of Grace Presbyterian Church, 10221 Ella Lee, in Houston, at 2 PM, Wednesday, February 19, 1997. Graveside services will be held on Friday, February 21, 1997, at 10 AM, at Woodlawn Cemetery in Eastman, Georgia.

title: A Quintessential Island Italian Restaurant

title: Early Shepard Teaches a Lesson About Persistence
description: THE SIGNATURE THEATER'S Sam Shepard season, being presented at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is turning out to be importantly different from the company's earlier retrospectives devoted to the work of living American playwrights. In each of the previous Signature seasons that I have attended, most notably those honoring Edward Albee and Horton Foote, the playwright has been presented not quite as if he were dead but as if his most innovative days were over and his body of work effectively complete. The programs (selected by the playwright in each case) never reflected embarrassing questions about the significance of the work or the inevitability of the recognition that was eventually won. Those were the givens of being so honored.

In teams of five, 350 men and women met last summer to trek 300 miles -- on horseback, raft and bicycle, in canoes and ice-climbing rigs, armed with compasses, maps and a spirit for adventure.

The tradition goes back through the Hessians at Valley Forge and the condottieri who overthrew Italian city-states and even to the time of Achilles, who sulked in his tent because he thought Agamemnon was unfairly dividing the spoils of the Trojan war.

title: Bookshelf
description: DANGEROUS SKIES. By Suzanne Fisher Staples. Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 10 and up) A stunning murder mystery set on Chesapeake Bay, where a white family named Smith and a black family named Smith have lived since the 18th century. Buck Smith, the white farmer's son, and Tunes Smith, the black caretaker's daughter, were raised together, but when at the age of 12 they discover the body of Jorge Rodrigues in the water, everything changes. There is no happy ending to this novel about friendship, racism and power, and it offers much to think about.

Her poor effort was countered by a composed, athletic performance by Tara Lipinski, who became the nation's youngest champion at age 14.

title: Climate Also Seems To Affect Deep Sea
description: It is well known that the distribution and fate of living things on Earth's surface are drastically affected by changes in climate; forests, for instance, migrate hundreds of miles in response to advancing and retreating ice-age glaciers, and the plants and animals dependent on forests must follow or die. But creatures of the deep sea have been thought to be insulated from the heat, cold and climatic turbulence of the surface.

title: The Real Caribbean: Paradise Stops At the Beach's Edge
description: IT is a deliciously sunny Saturday morning at the peak of the tourist season, and at Heritage Quay here, hundreds of passengers are being disgorged from a pair of towering cruise ships into shops and restaurants with names like Smoke & Booze or Rasta Pasta. As a band serenades the visitors with a reggae version of ''Mr. Bojangles,'' a middle-aged American suddenly begins to dance with a T-shirt vendor. ''Did we mention that this is paradise?'' asks one of the brochures handed to arriving tourists.

description: HISTORY as docudrama revisits television on Saturday in the HBO presentation ''Miss Evers' Boys.'' The film, based on a Pulitzer Prize-nominated play of the same name, is an examination of one of modern America's darkest chapters of medical research and racial exploitation.

title: More Tortoise Than Hare

title: UNDER A BARE BULB
description: The evening's performance of Henrik Ibsen's ''John Gabriel Borkman'' has ended, and audience members have begun to disperse into the chill London air when a gray-haired woman in an awkward black dress materializes in the lobby of the Royal National Theater. She holds a blue bucket trimmed with silver tinsel, and the way she tilts it forward, combined with the beseeching look in her eyes, signals that she is collecting alms for something -- maybe the poor, maybe even herself. It seems a safe bet that she has wandered in from the windswept banks of the Thames on this night shortly before Christmas to seek out holiday-season good will.

title: Nicaragua on the Mend
description: FOR more than a decade, the only foreigners likely to visit Nicaragua in any numbers were ''internationalists,'' sympathizers of the Sandinista revolution inspired by the idea of sharing the hardships and dangers of a country under siege. Throughout the 1980's, the Sandinista army and contra rebels fought a brutal civil war centered in the country's mountainous north, while in the cities, food, water and electricity were constantly rationed and an American embargo encouraged ordinary visitors to stay away.

title: White Oak Growth Stock Fund
description: TIRED of trailing the Standard & Poor's 500?

title: THE POP POPULIST
description: Springsteen knows, I'm sure, that writing a good song about a social problem is still a lot easier than doing something to solve it. Contrary to the impression left by your article, I hope he knows that there are people with good hearts and constructive insights on both sides of the aisle and that Government does very little well.

title: The Innocents
description: Julie Schumacher's first collection of short fiction explores -- and usually celebrates -- the complicated passage from youth to adolescence. Most of the stories in AN EXPLANATION FOR CHAOS (Soho, $21) are told from the point of view of an outsider on the inside: a younger sister watching her elder siblings grow, a shy girl analyzing a more ''popular'' friend's interaction with adults or an only child serving as the pivot in an evolving divorce. These attentive children watch their parents and others carefully, translating observations into explanations: sometimes right, sometimes wrong, but always illuminating. In ''The Private Life of Robert Schumann,'' a girl uncovers a romance between her music teacher and the class outcast, her tangential initiation into the world of adult sexuality; in ''Rehoboth Beach'' a pair of young sisters jealously watch their older sister start, enjoy and then destroy an affair with a ''gentleman philosopher,'' a man the younger sisters are willing to ''kidnap'' to keep. And in the title story a woman is interrogated by an unknown questioner about her relationship with her father; despite her anger and frustration with his flaws, she cannot avoid acknowledging the depth of her love. A careful, subtle writer, Ms. Schumacher draws full characters with just a few lines, gently defining the fluid zone in which innocence gives way to understanding. Erik Burns

title: The Planes Keep Flying
description: President Clinton has now spared hundreds of thousands of travelers the disruption of interrupted vacations and business trips by postponing a strike by the pilots of American Airlines. The President's decision to invoke the Railway Labor Act of 1926 for the first time in 31 years to halt the dispute saved American Airlines substantial operating losses. It also cost the pilots, at least temporarily, considerable negotiating leverage. But it gave both sides up to 60 days in which to cool off and find a reasonable compromise.

But while the Roebling Company's machine shop in Trenton is being turned into a technology museum, the last of the mansions inhabited by the sons of John A. Roebling, the company's founder, was in danger of being demolished -- until preservationists convinced the city to save it.

The anniversary of their original arrest occurred last month, and it should have been marked as setting a record for stubborn wrongheadedness on the part of the United States Government.

title: Policy for Sale

How's about another five from the plaintiff and I decide the case on its merits?''

title: In a Culture of Hysterectomies, Many Question Their Necessity

If anything, the womb is the body's Atlas, bearing the weight not only of the human future but of bitter social and medical disputes. The abortion debate can be viewed as a question of who owns the womb -- woman or embryo. The most common surgical procedure in the United States is the much-criticized Caesarean section. And the second most common operation is another, more radical storming of the uterus, the hysterectomy.

Graham, an American priest who became one of the Roman Catholic Church's foremost authorities on the Vatican's role in the rescue of Jews in World War II, died on Feb. 10 at a Jesuit retirement home in Los Gatos, Calif. description: Yesterday's performance showed why the Knicks are better than they were in December. Their confidence has grown. Their chemistry has improved. But for the Knicks, the biggest tests are yet to come.

title: Wagnerian Time and Space, Without the Gods
description: On of the great Wagner productions, Klaus Michael Gruber's staging of ''Parsifal'' for the Netherlands Opera, is bowing out magnificently in a sequence of performances conducted by Simon Rattle. The production has been sold to a consortium of other European theaters, in Brussels, Florence and Paris, but these places cannot offer the Cinemascope expanse of the 80-foot Amsterdam stage, for which this ''Parsifal'' was designed, which it needs and which it embraces.

title: Rush Is On for Shore Rentals
description: The preseason forecast for the Jersey Shore calls for a mostly crowded summer, local real estate agents say. On what is traditionally the busiest weekend of the year for tenants to snap up summer rentals, the offices of the largest real estate broker on Long Beach Island were ''like a zoo all day long,'' Vivian Nolan, a rental agent at the Prudential Zachariae agency in Ship Bottom, said yesterday.

title: Where Is Compromise to Make a Mideast Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl software: a fantasy world stressing advice and the anxiety of romance.
description: I AM at a slumber party of some kind, as a group of high school girls giggles over a year book. Brandon, one girl gushes, is ''a total charmer,'' but his friend Derrick is ''big-time gorgeous in a completely natural way.'' The girls are ready to provide extensive advice on how to catch one of the class's hunks: ''Sit next to him Monday. He'll be eating out of your hand.''

title: In the Glare Of Success, Vulnerability
description: Late Saturday night, 14-year-old Tara Lipinski became the youngest figure-skating champion ever in the United States. An hour later, it was announced that she had her own Web site on the Internet. Television appearances and magazine profiles were in the works. The tropical storm of her celebrity had become a hurricane.

title: Where Is Compromise to Make a Mideast Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington's Birthday
description: The day, actually Feb. 22, is legally observed today.

title: Driven to Distraction Seems to Be Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: History Next; Watch the Closing Doors
description: In his introduction to ''New York Underground,'' tonight's express-train account of the building of the subway, David McCullough ranks the achievement with the Panama Canal and the Trans-Siberian Railroad, as three wonders of their era. The ensuing hour, which tells of the dreams and the drama that went into the digging of the tunnels that saved the city, demonstrates that he is not exaggerating.

title: Vermont Survey Finds Support For the Legalization of Hemp
description: Despite strong opposition from Gov. Howard Dean, most Vermonters favor legalizing hemp as an industrial crop, according to a University of Vermont study.

title: American Airlines Resuming Service After Clinton Stops Strike
description: WASHINGTON  American Airlines service was nearly back to normal Sunday, a day after President Bill Clinton ordered pilots back to work. But the prospect that his action might merely delay a strike appeared certain to jostle and confuse domestic and international travel until a solution is reached.

title: Still Seeing Humor in the Oldest Conflict of All
description: The defense never rests -- not if the accused is today's male and the public defender is Rob Becker, self-appointed champion of the modern-day Caveman, who hunts with a television remote control and clears the table one glass at a time.

title: Round Up the Usual Targets but Forget New York
description: Mayor Giuliani, take note: there's a satirical troupe working on 42d Street that you may want to hire for your re-election campaign.

title: An Ex-Felon Presses Hopes For the Bronx
description: At Public School 33, off Fordham Road, he pointed to the peeling paint and railed against incompetence and kickback schemes at the city's Board of Education.

title: Revisiting the Food Lion Case
description: Is deception by a journalist ever justifiable? That was the question raised by ABC's solemn attempt at self-justification last Wednesday night. ''Primetime Live'' and a special 90-minute panel debate moderated by Ted Koppel focused on Food Lion v. ABC, the case in which a North Carolina jury awarded the Food Lion supermarket chain $5.5 million in punitive damages because ''Primetime Live'' producers lied to get jobs at the supermarkets to show bad food handling practices.

title: One Man's Tough Faith In Jazz, In Words And Action
description: Inside many people in the jazz business lurk advocates yearning to raise a flag on behalf of the music. They do it in different ways. Over the years Steve Backer, who is quickly reassuming his role as a pivotal figure in the jazz record business after a few years away, has done it by heavily promoting pop jazz to support his more cutting-edge artists.

title: New Cast Has a Fling With Highland Romance
description: The New York City Ballet, in the home stretch of its winter season, continues with a spate of debuts and dancing that has obviously reached a new peak.

title: New Software Expected to Cut Web Delays
description: The World Wide Wait may be coming to an end.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY

title: Many Florida Blacks, Tossed by Population Shifts, Say They Feel 'Left Out'
description: M. Athalie Range became Miami's first black city commissioner in 1965, a time when the civil rights movement was ''roaring,'' she says, and blacks nationwide had the promise of new political and economic frontiers.

title: Times Site On the Web Wins Awards
description: The New York Times on the Web, the World Wide Web service of The New York Times, won 2 of the 10 prizes awarded by Editor and Publisher magazine last week, one for best overall on-line newspaper service and one for best editorial content by an on-line newspaper service.

title: Resistance to Serbia Turns Violent in Kosovo
description: Bajram Pajaziti walked solemnly down the hillside from his brother's grave, past a line of silent, motionless mourners, many wearing white and brown turbans, and stopped at the door of his father's small, whitewashed home to pull off his shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILIEN, LESLIE
description: LILIEN-Leslie, 71, of Blauvelt, NY, on Feb. 15, 1997. Salesman for Lion Match Corp of America. Survived by wife Anita and son Gary, grandchildren Stacie and Joshua.

title: Mandate H.I.V. Tests for Mothers, Not Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Rally, But the Team Is in No Mood To Celebrate
description: After separating the bodies and ministering to the wounded, the Knicks concocted a party line about their victory over the Pacers yesterday: the 19-point comeback was not impressive after all. If they were not so bad to begin with, many of the Knicks kept saying, none of their resolve would have been necessary.

title: Joy and Fear as Refugees Look to Freedom
description: Forty illegal Chinese immigrants imprisoned after their ship, the Golden Venture, ran aground off Queens, N.Y., say they are looking forward to freedom with a mixture of joy and trepidation after spending nearly four years in a county prison.

title: Jazz View Of Sinatra Ballads
description: The saxophonist Joe Lovano has been celebrating the release of his new album, ''Celebrating Sinatra'' (Blue Note), with a week at the Blue Note. Mr. Lovano has something to be happy about; the album takes material associated with Frank Sinatra and abstracts it, using a group that includes clarinets and strings and an oboe, along with a singer who mostly sticks to singing melodies, not words. It's a perfectly balanced piece of work, quiet chamber jazz at its best, with Mr. Lovano's odd phrasing, with its halts and velocity, taking the music somewhere new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, RITA H.
description: SULLIVAN-Rita H. Passed away suddenly in Palm Beach, FL, on February 14, 1997. A native of Forest Hills, Queens, who worked for Mobile Oil for 40 years. Loving sister of the late Rosemary, Robert, and Joseph Sullivan. Survived by nine nieces and nephews: Michael, Paul, and Sean Sullivan, Laura Leitman, Robert, Thomas, and Owen Sullivan, Mary Burke and Kathryn Perrone. Also survived by 26 great-nieces and nephews. Reposing Monday 2-4:30 and 7-9 PM, at New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Road, New Hyde Park, Long Island, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs R.C. Church, Forest Hills. Private interment Wednesday, at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MILTON
description: WASSERMAN-Milton. 71, after a courageous fight against cancer. Founder and President of MERJ Insurance Brokerage. Adored husband and life partner of Rhoda (Rosner) for forty-eight years. Loving father of Susan (Sanders), Jeffrey (Wasserman) and Debi (Snyder). Cherished grandfather of Adam, Ashley, Emmanuel, Jessica, Stephen and Jasmine. Devoted brother of Stanley and his late sister Sylvia (Singman). His caring and generous presence will be forever missed by his family and friends. His heroic ability to conquer the everyday battles of life serve as an example of ''menschlichkeit'' for all of us. Funeral services Sunday, 10:30 AM, Parkside Funeral Chapel, Queens Blvd. 718-896-9000. Interment to follow.

title: Government Data At Your Fingertips
description: Sifting through raw government data has always been intimidating, but that did not intimidate Tony Raymond. In fact, it inspired him.

title: Rivera Displays A Closer's Mind-Set
description: Mariano Rivera cruised into the clubhouse a day late for spring training workouts, and it was apparent that the Yankees' new closer is a little different from John Wetteland. He did not ride in on a Harley-Davidson motorcycle, as Wetteland would have. He did not bring in-line skates or a hockey stick, as Wetteland would have. He did not sprint to the coffee urn or fill his gums with tobacco, as Wetteland would have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JEFFREY LEONARD
description: COHEN-Jeffrey Leonard. On Feb. 12, 1997. Beloved son of Edna and the late Elihu, brother of Sandy (Sanford) and Barbara, adored uncle of Marisa, and friend to all. After a ten-year courageous battle with cancer. Shiva through 8 AM, Wednesday, at Sandy's home.

title: One More Stadium On Deck
description: Lakewood became the fifth town in a little more than a year to announce plans to build a new minor league stadium. The township is negotiating with the Watertown (N.Y.) Indians, a Class A affiliate of the Cleveland Indians, to bring the team to a new 7,500-seat stadium in 1999, Mayor Richard Work said Saturday.

title: Rangers Try Solving Their Own Troubles
description: Brett Hull. Brendan Shanahan. Bob Probert. Rick Tocchet. Tomas Sandstrom.

title: A Doctor Is Questioned Over Marijuana Law
description: In what may be a first small step toward action on the Clinton Administration's threat to punish doctors who recommend the medical use of marijuana under a new California law, drug-enforcement agents have questioned a doctor in Northern California who has endorsed the use of the drug by several patients.

title: Telephone Pact To Alter Rates And Services
description: For Carlos Galvis in Jackson Heights, Queens, the global telecommunications trade agreement signed over the weekend in far-off Geneva may hit quite close to home.

title: And the winner of the 'Worst Software Patent of the Year' is, hmm, a certain William H. Gates.
description: GREGORY AHARONIAN, the curmudgeonly editor of the Internet Patent News Service, will officially announce his annual ''Worst Software Patent of the Year'' award today.

title: NATO Expansion Is Critical to a Free Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A.'s Next Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: Dangerous Deception
description: How is it that an herbicide considered to be such a threat to human health that it is banned in Austria, Germany, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway and Sweden somehow manages to remain the most widely used pesticide of any kind in the United States?

title: Driven to Distraction Seems to Be Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Guards Approve a Contract
description: Despite misgivings, the state's prison guards approved a four-year labor contract that gives them no pay raises for the first two years. The union, which represents about 4,500 corrections officers, followed the advice of a state arbitrator and voted Friday to accept the new contract without appealing its terms, said Thomas Little, president of Policemen's Benevolent Association Local 105. About 2,700 guards voted for the contract, while 1,075 officers voted against it, The Associated Press reported. The guards, who had been working without a contract since June 1995, will receive 3.5-percent raises in the last two years of the contract, this year and next.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Clinton Is Half-Right on Schools
description: President Clinton has proposed a two-track strategy on education. He wants to create national curriculum standards for elementary and high schools, and he wants to use tax breaks and subsidies to allow more students to go to college. Although well-intentioned, this plan raises a dangerous possibility that Congress will approve only the more popular part: Mr. Clinton's pledge to make two years of college as common as a high school education. If politicians overlook efforts to improve elementary and high schools, our students will gain little.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, RICHARD M
description: CASHIN-Richard M. The Board of the Catholic Big Sisters extends deepest sympathy to our fellow board member, Mrs. Richard M. Cashin, on the death of her husband, who gave generously of his time and counsel.

title: Life and Death Under the Highways
description: Up a steep rocky hill under an off-ramp of the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens, Michael Howard Drucker has fashioned a home -- a berth, really -- for the last three years. On two slabs of concrete that support the off-ramp's steel beams, he has placed a wooden plank on which he sleeps and under which his two dogs, Max and Gertrude, lie watch.

title: After Prison, a Mayoral Race
description: Former Mayor Gerald McCann's return to politics is beginning to look like a sure bet. Mr. McCann, who was removed from office in 1992 after his conviction for bank fraud and then served two years in Federal prison, plans to announce his candidacy for the May mayoral election at a rally on Thursday.

title: Political Books Become Less Sober, More Pop-Oriented
description: It has been four years since Richard Ben Cramer produced what may be the best and is surely the longest political book of the decade, a 1,047-page opus on the psychology of Presidential candidates entitled ''What It Takes.'' Mr. Cramer's study of six contenders in the 1988 Presidential campaign enraptured critics and even sold modestly well.

title: Playing the Trade Card
description: For more than half a century, the United Nations has been the main forum for the United States to try to create a world in its image, maneuvering with its allies to forge global accords about human rights, nuclear tests or the environment that Washington insisted would mirror its own values.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, HAROLD
description: METZ-Harold. On February 13, 1997, in Goldens Bridge, NY. A lifelong resident of Brooklyn, ''Harry'' was the son of the late Mollie Strongin Metz and Sydney Metz, who co-founded the Avenue Z Jewish Center. Harry graduated from Brooklyn Tech H.S. and Brooklyn College. In World War II he served both in Europe and the Pacific in the 86th Army Division, 343rd Infantry Regiment, Company A. He later operated a TV repair business and then taught electronics at Chelsea Vocational High School in Manhattan for over 20 years. Harold touched the lives and hearts of many people throughout his life and was loved by everyone who knew him. He is survived by his wife Lola, his children Jeremy and Cara Koehler, and four grandchildren. He also leaves behind two devoted companions, Barbara Christesen and Morris Pataky, who will mourn his loss and cherish his memory forever.

title: Gordon, the Youngest Hotfoot, Dares to Win 500
description: The kid stole the show in the Daytona 500 today. Jeff Gordon, at age 25, became the race's youngest winner, and in the process helped provide a timely boost to his ailing team owner.

title: Torricelli's Internal Debate on Budget Issue
description: It is dizzying to listen to United States Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey make the case for a balanced budget amendment. And against a balanced budget amendment, and so on.

title: A Gay Voice of Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, SELIG
description: BURROWS-Selig. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Selig Burrows, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. A. Ephraim Diamond, Pres. Robert S. Puder, Secy.

title: Treasury Sets Bill Offering
description: The Treasury's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills will be postponed until Tuesday because of Washington's Birthday.

title: As Traps Grow, Wary Dealers Force Officers to Take Drugs
description: With the Police Department dispatching hundreds of undercover officers to buy drugs and then arrest the sellers in northern Manhattan and Brooklyn, many drug dealers have grown suspicious of all but their oldest customers. So, officials said, the dealers now force many customers to sample the drugs at gunpoint.

title: A Message for Hundley: It's About Schmoozing
description: The subject was communication and the culprit, it seemed, was Todd Hundley. Or so it appeared to the Mets' catcher today. For despite coming off a dream season at the plate, Hundley once again wearily found himself answering questions about his ability, or lack thereof, to relate to pitchers while catching.

title: INSIDE
description: Race to the Pole? Ha!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESTA, ETTORE
description: TESTA-Ettore. Passed away peacefully at home on February 15, at age 90, surrounded by his family: wife Constance, daughters Constance, Jeanette and Maria, son-in-law Robert Lutz, and grandson Eric. Also survived by his brother Guido and sisters, sistersin-law, nieces and nephews. Graduated from Brooklyn College of Pharmacy in 1927. Retired from the Upjohn Company after 30 years of service. Services are private. Donations may be made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund or to a charity of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLICKMAN, HENRIETTA
description: GLICKMAN-Henrietta. Our dearest Nani G.G. Always in our thoughts. Forever in our hearts. Love, Peggy, Steve and Erin

title: A Dangerous Skirmish Over Cuba
description: The American economic strangulation of Cuba is a cold war anachronism that is now threatening to upend a carefully constructed international system for resolving trade disputes. Fidel Castro will be the only winner if Europe and the United States undermine the new World Trade Organization in a needless fight over Cuba.

title: TV Woos Viewers With News Of Business
description: They can be found in Times Square, in Wall Street trading rooms and in Fortune 500 executive suites, in bars in business districts and in retirement homes from Florida to California. Those television screens with the ticker tape of stock market quotes sliding lazily across the bottom seem to be almost everywhere these days.

title: A Fast Notebook Is Among Apple's New Products
description: Apple Computer Inc. will ship several new products today, including a Powerbook model that will give the company the right to claim the world's fastest notebook computer. Apple is also shipping new and faster Power Macs, two new Newton devices and a digital camera.

title: Man Frees Wife Before Shooting Himself in Head
description: A 42-year-old Brooklyn man shot himself in the head after holding his wife hostage and keeping the police at bay for about eight hours in an intense standoff in Park Slope.

title: Hawkins Dance Revival
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company will present a revival of ''Early Floating'' and signature works by Hawkins at the Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues, tomorrow through Sunday. Tickets are $28; $14 for students. Reservations: (212) 772-4448.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: Panel Chairman Says Inquiry Into Fund Raising Is Expanding
description: The Republican who heads the House investigation into influence peddling by foreigners said today that his panel was sharply expanding its scope.

title: Graham Dance Troupe Cancels Season
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has canceled its two-week season at City Center, from April 8 to 20.

title: KOREAN SHOOTING IS CASTING CLOUD ON SIGNS OF THAW
description: South Korea went on a terrorism alert today as the police and soldiers fanned out in an intensive hunt for two men, suspected of being North Korean agents, who shot a prominent North Korean defector on Saturday night.

title: Studios Smarting From Oscars Snub Of Hollywood Fare
description: Days after the Academy Award nominations, movie executives are still riveted -- and in some cases angered -- by a question that cuts to the heart of the creative quagmire that appears to grip Hollywood: how could the studios have released 163 movies last year and have only one, ''Jerry Maguire,'' turn out to be a serious contender for the Oscars?

title: Charges in Beating at a Bar
description: Two college students and a third man were charged with beating a 23-year-old man, John Vollrath of North Wildwood, to death outside a bar, the Club Kaladu, here early Saturday, the A.P. reported. The police charged Christopher Short, 20, a student at Penn State University; his brother Adam, 18, a student at Widener University in Chester, Pa, and Joseph J. Mader 2d of North Cape May, whom the police described as an unemployed bouncer.

title: A Crime, They Say, to Shut Agatha Christie's Hotel
description: Standing like an aging but still proud matriarch, commanding one of the world's most spectacular vistas and guarding more than a century of secrets, the Pera Palace Hotel is a relic of Istanbul's most elegant era.

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASS, SYLVIA
description: KASS-Sylvia. Of Lakewood, NJ, died February 15. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. Services Monday, 12:15 PM, I.J. Morris, Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Family requests contributions be sent to American Kidney Fund.

title: Borland Secrets Suit Ends
description: Borland International Inc. said last week that it had settled its trade secrets lawsuit against the Symantec Corporation, a rival software maker. Borland and Symantec said that they had agreed to dismiss the lawsuit and all related counterclaims. The case began in the fall of 1992 when Gordon Eubanks, the chief executive and president of Symantec, hired Eugene Wang away from Borland. Mr. Wang was hired by Symantec as an executive vice president. He no longer holds that post.

title: Giving It the Old College Try Is Off to a Rough Start in the Pros
description: It is just a couple of dribbles after the tip-off, and he is standing up on the toes of his leather loafers shouting and waving like a shipwrecked man: Hey, over here! Look at me!

title: Ex-Trader in Sumitomo Scandal Admits Guilt on Fraud Charges
description: Yasuo Hamanaka, the central figure in a $2.6 billion copper scandal at the Sumitomo Corporation, admitted he was guilty of forgery and fraud in an arraignment held today, according to press reports here.

title: Research Firm Joins Rush to Sell Its Stock
description: Last year, when executives at Forrester Research, an information technology research firm, went looking for a senior analyst to bolster a critical new-media and technology service, they thought they had found the perfect candidate in Bill Doyle. Mr. Doyle was a longtime designer and builder of on-line services and had an impressive resume working for the likes of AT&T and Citibank.

title: N.A.S.D. Restores Purged Broker Data
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said last week that it had restored all 596 items of adverse broker data mistakenly purged from a data bank of brokers' disciplinary histories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNGLASS, MARK
description: BRENNGLASS-Mark. On February 14, 1997. Beloved brother of Samuel Lawrence Brennglass and the late Vivian B. Schechter. Dear uncle of Alan C. Brennglass and Evan S. Schechter. Services were held yesterday.

title: Wall Street Praises Halt To Pilot Strike
description: Last year, the company that owns American Airlines earned $1 billion, a record. But the stock price of the AMR Corporation remains far from a record. Since 1989, the stock market has roughly tripled, but AMR shares have languished below their high that year of $107.

title: The Devils Stop Offenses, but Not That Many Hearts
description: Men of a certain age, from a specific cultural background, might sense familiarity with, if not comfort around, authority figures like Lou Lamoriello and Jacques Lemaire.

title: Helfgott Adds 3d Recital
description: The Australian pianist David Helfgott, whose breakdown and recovery are portrayed in the film ''Shine,'' has added a third New York performance to his North American tour, a recital at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on April 23 at 8 P.M. Tickets go on sale Tuesday at the box office in Brooklyn and will be available from Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4100. The other concerts are at Avery Fisher Hall on March 4 and April 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ILUTOVICH, LEON
description: ILUTOVICH-Leon. Beloved husband of Renia and former Executive Vice Chairman of the Zionist Organization of America, passed away on Saturday, February 15. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday, February 18, 2 PM, at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91 St.), New York, NY. Interment will take place in Kiryat Schaul in Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCONNELL, CORNELIA SLOANE
description: McCONNELL-Cornelia Sloane, 77, on February 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late E. Riggs McConnell. Survived by her brother William M. Sloane II, and eight nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENHOFF, EDWARD S.
description: LENHOFF-Edward S. Of 721 Old Bedford Rd, Concord, MA, died February 15, 1997, at Emerson Hospital, Concord. Longtime professor of Nuclear Biophysics at Harvard University for 30 years. Loving brother of Mrs. Gabriel (Carol) Kosakoff of New York City. Longtime companion of Mary Snay of Concord, MA. Graveside service will take place Tuesday at 12 noon at Beth Israel Cemetery, Clarksburg, MA. No calling hours. For information, The Flynn & Dagnoli-Montagna Home for Funerals, 74 Marshall Street, North Adams, MA.

title: Crown Heights Verdict Was Victory for Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MORTON M.
description: BROWN-Morton M., 80, died Saturday. Beloved father of Linda Swartz, Steven Brown and Elizabeth Feldman. Cherished grandfather of eight, loved brother of Thelma Tepperberg and Leonard. Adored companion of Eunice Wilson. Funeral service will be Monday, 10:15 AM, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Shelter Rock Jewish Center Mens Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, GRETA M.
description: LANDIS-Greta M. On November 11, 1996. Wife of the late George Landis. Survived by the Valka family. Supporting member Museum of Jewish Heritage, AMIT Women's Inc. which supports children's homes in Israel, Keren-OR, Inc. which treats blind children in Israel. Memorial service to be held on Thursday, February 20, 1997, at 10AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: Rewriting History
description: To the Editor:

title: The Times is printed today in two sections. SportsMonday begins on page 33 and Business Day on page 41.
One Wish to Make: Helping the Needy
description: Mildred Hillson was born Dec. 15, 1911, just nine days before Adolph S. Ochs met an immigrant pauper on the streets of New York City on a wintry Christmas Eve. Moved by the chance encounter, Mr. Ochs began The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund the following year.

title: Whether or not it deserves it, the music industry is getting its own daily press.
description: THIS is what happened in the music industry at the end of last week: Steven Tyler of Aerosmith was told by his handlers that his skin was too saggy for him to appear shirtless in magazine photographs. Ice-T had a birthday. Polygram announced disappointing profits and more job cuts. The rapper Flesh-n-Bone turned himself in for violating parole.

title: Who Reached the North Pole First? A Researcher Lays Claim to Solving the Mystery
description: It has been a question debated in the annals of exploration for almost 90 years. Who was the first man to reach the North Pole, Adm. Robert E. Peary or Dr. Frederick A. Cook?

title: Bridge
description: Half a century ago, a player who picked up the North hand shown in the diagram would have no trouble after his partner bid one spade. He would bid three spades, promising four-card spade support and the values for game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGASI, ANTHONY
description: LAGASI-Anthony. 90 years old, Chef. President of Chef's de Cuisine, 1956-1971, awarded the coveted ''Medale of Merite Agricole'' by the French government. Founder of NYC Tech College's scholarship fund for study abroad. Longtime member of the Mazzini Lodge and its Master and Past Masters Association, Purple Circle, Scottish Rite and Kismet Temple of Long Island. Reposing at Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, 486 Rt. 23, Cedar Grove, NJ, (201) 239-1489.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Puts Recruiting at Top of Its Agenda
description: Having roused the torpid A.F.L.-C.I.O. in his first year as president, John J. Sweeney will announce on Monday the federation's ambitious all-out gamble to save the labor movement from further decline by shifting its focus to recruiting new members.

title: A Wondrous Trove of Khmer Art
description: The jungle temples and palaces of the ancient Khmer civilization were no secret to Chinese travelers in the 13th century or even to Portuguese missionaries 300 years later, but French explorers claimed to have discovered them in the 19th century. Now, after again being lost from view during two decades of war, genocide and occupation, Cambodia's cultural treasures are in a sense being rediscovered thanks to a major exhibition of Khmer art that has just begun a three-nation tour here.

title: Disney Hall: A Mirage Is Looking More Real
description: A decade after Walt Disney's widow, Lillian, donated $50 million for an architecturally imposing concert hall in downtown Los Angeles, local political, business and cultural leaders say they are finally confident that they will be able to raise enough money to prevent Los Angeles County from scrapping the long-stalled project.

title: U.S. Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodities markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most markets overseas were open. United States markets will reopen today.

title: Third World Might Not Welcome Global Market
description: To the Editor:

title: New Proof of Asteroid's Devastation
description: SCIENTISTS probing the deep sea have found the best evidence yet of distant turmoil wrought by a gargantuan asteroid that slammed into Earth 65 million years ago. The finding is expected to shed new light on the wave of global extinction and repopulation that swept the planet at the end of the age of dinosaurs.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column on Feb. 7 about ties between the German men's wear company Hugo Boss and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum misstated the benefits to the company. The Guggenheim has promoted Boss's name recognition by naming a gallery for the company and advertising Boss's support for exhibitions, but has not lent art for Boss to hang in its offices.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mac Software Developer Plans Motorola Alliance

title: Sumitomo Ex-Trader Wants Company to Share Scandal Blame
description: Yasuo Hamanaka, the copper trader at the center of the $2.6 billion trading scandal at the Sumitomo Corporation, admitted in court here today that he was guilty of forgery and fraud charges. But Mr. Hamanaka does not want the giant trading company itself to escape legal proceedings unscathed.

title: Errors Cast a Cloud Over A.C.C. Referees
description: The fierce competition in Atlantic Coast Conference basketball has been compromised by a pair of officiating gaffes that have given Duke an edge in the battle for first place and top seeding in next month's conference tournament.

title: Racial Killing Bursts a British Press Taboo
description: Stephen Lawrence, 18, a promising high school student of Jamaican parentage, was stabbed to death by a group of white youths cursing him with shouts of ''nigger'' as he waited for a ride home at a southeast London bus stop on an April night nearly four years ago.

title: Still Sovereign of His Own Art World
description: Andrew Wyeth is still alive. He proved it the other day by ordering a Bloody Mary, a shrimp cocktail (''Five shrimp, please'') and sweet-potato fries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HOWARD, M.D.
description: SCHNEIDER-Howard, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Virginia. Devoted father of Deborah S. and Victor A. Greenhut and David Schneider. Dear brother of Warren J. and Lawrence B. Schneider. Loving grandfather of Adam and Nathan Greenhut. Services today 1:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Nets Can't Rattle Steady Cavs
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers don't run down the clock, they walk it, which is nerve-racking to those who have to watch paint peel on the Cavaliers before they shoot. To counter this, the Nets pressed on occasion today and ran when possible, hoping for a turnover or a miss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNICK, HERBERT C.
description: VERNICK-Herbert C. Beloved husband of Cecelia. Adored uncle of Amy, John and Matthew Pitarra. Services today, 12 noon at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', 9860 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Marion Epley, 89, Former Texaco Chairman
description: Marion J. Epley Jr., a former president and chairman of Texaco Inc., died on Saturday at Harbour's Edge, a nursing home in Delray Beach, Fla., his family said. He was 89 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTH, EDITH (NEE BIALKIN)
description: BARTH-Edith (nee Bialkin). Beloved wife of Manny. Loving mother of Lawrence and Marianthe Barth, Roberta and Steven Ballin, Jane and Sandy Herrick. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, C.J., Myrto, Eden and Alex. Dear sister of Kenneth J. and Ann Bialkin and Robert and Harriet Bialkin. Adored aunt. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10:30 AM, Tuesday. Contributions may be made to N.Y. Hospital, Dept. of Oncology and Hematology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, WILLIAM T.
description: WHEELER-William T., born on July 24, 1946 in Shamokin, PA. Survived by his mother, Mrs. Monica Fitzpatrick of Shamokin and brothers Richard Wheeler of Rockville, MD, James Wheeler of Mechanicsburg, PA, and Michael Wheeler of Virginia Beach, VA.

title: Mets and Franco Hope McMichael Fits Puzzle
description: There is no question that the Yankees' Mariano Rivera put the setup spot on the map more than any bullpen artist of his era did. But stoppers like John Franco do not need a reminder of how valuable setup men like Rivera can be.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRED, PATTI and KIM GOLDMAN have started touring to publicize their new book, ''His Name Is Ron: Our Search for Justice'' (William Morrow), which they wrote with William and Marilyn Hoffer. Their first stop in New York will be tomorrow at Border's Books and Music, at 5 World Trade Center. They plan to visit 13 cities to promote the book, which was published last Friday.

title: SPECIAL COUNSEL INTENDS TO LEAVE WHITEWATER CASE
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, will step down by August to become the dean of the law and public policy schools of Pepperdine University in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, SR. MARY THERESA
description: COLEMAN-Sr. Mary Theresa, R.S.H.M., on February 16th, 1997, of Marymount, Tarrytown, NY. Reposing at Marymount Convent, 32 Warren Avenue, Tarrytown on Tuesday after 2:30 PM. Vigil on Tuesday, 7:30 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:30 AM. Interment Mount Calvary Cemetery.

title: Devers Pursues Missing Link
description: GAIL DEVERS has achieved almost everything possible in track, including two Olympic gold medals in the 100 meters. One thing is missing, however, and Devers will keep chasing it. That's an Olympic gold in the hurdles.

title: In the Driver's Seat, Without Driver's Education
description: CBS Sports exhibited a dual personality at Sunday's Daytona 500, smartly using technology to make the race more visually entertaining but amply demonstrating that its announcers' heads were stuck in Gasoline Alley.

title: Isles Control the Ice, The Canadiens the Net
description: If the Islanders fail to make the playoffs, they can look back to games like today's and shake their heads.

title: Despite Election, a Wal-Mart Goes Union in Canada
description: An unusual decision by an Ontario government panel has produced the first unionized store for the Wal-Mart chain, even though a majority of the department store's employees voted against joining the union.

title: Devils Make Do At Center
description: The Devils used three centers instead of four against the Rangers yesterday, and none of them was named Messier or Gretzky. Still, Bobby Holik, Denis Pederson and the newly acquired Peter Zezel held their own in a 2-2 tie that allowed the Devils to extend their unbeaten streak to a franchise-record 11 games.

title: Man Sought in Shooting of Officer Surrenders
description: A Bronx man sought in the shooting of a police captain two weeks ago surrendered to the police yesterday at his lawyer's office in lower Manhattan.

title: Pajamas That Look Presentable
description: At this time of year it's cozy to sit around after work or on weekends in comfortable pajamas. And when those pajamas consist of a knitted loose top and leggings or sweat pants, you look presentable if friends drop by or the handyman arrives to fix the sink.

title: Third World Might Not Welcome Global Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Bush Brothers & Co., Knoxville, Tenn., to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle the creative assignment for two brands, Bush's baked beans and Chili Magic, with billings estimated at $5 million. Those duties had been handled by Cole Henderson Drake, Atlanta, which resigned. The media duties remain at Media That Works, Cincinnati.

title: Plaintiffs in Business Cases Challenge Group Justice
description: There was David versus Goliath. The Lilliputians and Gulliver. And not long ago, Dexter J. Kamilewicz decided to take on the class-action legal system.

title: China Leaders' Return to Beijing May Mean Deng Has Worsened
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that they believed that the health of China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, had deteriorated significantly in recent days and was the reason for the sudden return to Beijing this weekend of several other top Chinese leaders.

title: From Skipping Haircuts or Coffee, Some Find Unusual Means for Giving
description: At 66, Juergen R. Goldhagen has let his hair grow, tying it into a ponytail. At first it was for fun, to inject a spark of style, even some Samsonesque vigor, into his post-retirement life. But he soon recognized an added benefit: a year's savings on haircuts could be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help the poor.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A PRESENCE LOST -- Steve Dudas may have been homeless, but he made a lasting impression among many on the streets of Forest Hills. Now, people are mourning his death in a fire. B3.

title: Third World Might Not Welcome Global Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Oscar Nominations Show Refreshing Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Allied Friction in Korea
description: Two critical developments in the last week have once again increased the tensions between North and South Korea. But the events also threaten to deepen the friction between two longtime allies -- South Korea and the United States.

title: R. K. Graham, 90, Creator Of a Lens and a Sperm Bank
description: Robert Klark Graham, who amassed a fortune in developing shatterproof plastic eyeglass lenses and later established a sperm bank whose first donors were Nobel Prize winners, died on Thursday in Seattle. Mr. Graham, who lived in Escondido, Calif., was 90.

title: Spy, Counterspy: As Both a Battler for a Cause
description: WHITTAKER CHAMBERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKEN, BERTRAM
description: HACKEN-Bertram. On February 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Ronnie and Philip. Graveside services are today at Mount Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York. For service time contact ''Sinai Chapels'', Fresh Meadows (718-445-0300).

title: Spain Accuses Basques In Fatal Bombing Attack
description: A car bombing in the northern city of Bilbao killed a Spanish policeman today, and the Government said it was the work of the Basque separatist group E.T.A.

title: Some Gadgets That Are Still Not Ready for Prime Time
description: SOME people go to auto races in the hope of seeing a spectacular crash. The rest of us sit at our computers. At the annual Demo 97 conference, much of the fun is in watching the people who make and sell computer products attempt to emerge unscathed from public demonstration of their unfinished wares.

title: Dance in Review
description: Whimsy, Conviction and a Coat

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCARLINO, VINCENT A.
description: SCARLINO-Vincent A., 87, of the Bronx, NY, on February 17, 1997. Owner of Scarlino Press in New York City. Beloved husband of the late Esther and devoted father of Louis of Chappaqua, New York and Victor of Stroudsburg, PA. Loving companion of Eleanor Walsh. Services private.

title: D'Amato Converted Donations To Help New York Candidates
description: William Jordan, a North Carolina doctor, thought he was helping to elect Republican United States senators when he made a $50,000 campaign donation last October.

title: Research Rationale
description: To the Editor:

title: Can I.R.S. Be Far From Classroom Door?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK, JACK
description: PASTERNACK-Jack. Uncle Jack was very special to us and he will continue to sing in our hearts forever. Anita, Arthur and all the children

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, BRADFORD D.
description: JONES-Bradford D. Died peacefully at age 83 after a long illness. A former editor of True Detective magazine and the author of hundreds of magazine articles published in the 1950's, Mr. Jones is survived by his loving wife Mary, and devoted son Stephen. Services will be at Frederick Funeral Home, 718-357-6100.

title: Zairian Military Jets Bomb Civilians in Rebel-Held Town
description: The embattled Zairian Government used air strikes today, for the first time, to punish civilians in a rebel town, sending three fighter jets to bomb the rebel-held city of Bukavu in eastern Zaire.

title: Russia Has Nothing to Fear
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov are scheduled to meet in Moscow on Thursday to discuss ways to strengthen ties between NATO and Russia -- despite Russian objections to the alliance's decision to bring in new members. The chances of progress will be greater if the Russians understand not just the inevitability of enlargement, but the reasons for it.

title: L.I.U. Turns On Offense And Clinches League Title
description: Long Island University 99

title: Small Software Company Nears Pact With Motorola
description: In the Macintosh computer community, Plan B just won't go away.

title: Communications Pact to Favor Growing Giants
description: The world's telephone companies have been in a lively mating dance for several years, pairing off and swapping partners at a brisk pace. But now the industry tango is about to become a tarantella.

title: Two Internet Start-Ups Catch Eye of Corporate Media Giants
description: New-media companies have had few friends lately. Much of the optimism of a year or so ago that information and entertainment sites on the World Wide Web could quickly lure big audiences and piles of money has evaporated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TITUS, ALAN WHITMORE
description: TITUS-Alan Whitmore, 65, formerly of Locust Valley, NY passed away Sunday, February 16th, after a lengthy illness at Beaufort Memorial Hospital, Beaufort, SC. He was a former member of the Creek Club in Locust Valley, Long Island, NY and a Vice President of Citibank in New York City. Mr. Titus was the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Warren I. Titus of Glen Cove, Long Island, NY. Surviving are his wife, Barbara, sons Stuart W. and Steven C. a daughter, Jaeann Sangerman, a brother Warren I. Titus, Jr., and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at The Brookville Reformed Church, Brookville, NY at a date to be announced.

title: Ties to Indonesian Rulers Secure Mother Lode of Gold Deals
description: A century after the Klondike gold rush, a modern-day stampede marked by political intrigue and fast deals has resulted in an American mining company staking claim in Indonesia to part of one of the richest gold strikes in history.

title: Waterfront Project Doesn't Qualify as Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Providence Is Reviving, Using Arts As the Fuel
description: On Weybosset Street, Teresa Level is selling works of art on consignment in a small gallery. In a loft upstairs that doubles as a home and production studio, Bob Zolli and his wife, Susan Arundale, are rehearsing songs for a musical they plan to produce in the spring. Around the corner on Empire Street, in a small room that serves as a home and art studio, Chris Horoshak is painting tedious patterns on canvas.

title: Don't Slight Disabled for Animal Rights' Sake
description: To the Editor:

title: In terms of managing mutual funds, must youth be served?
description: AS the stock market has soared during the last several years, it has often seemed as if the manager of the latest hot mutual fund is barely out of college. Is that a coincidence? Or is youth an advantage when it comes to running money?

title: Secaucus Corridor Emerges as Nerve Center In the Melding of Computers and Capitalism
description: You can't see it, feel it, smell it, stack it or hoard it in a vault. You can't use it to light a cigar or stuff a mattress. There are no coins to flip or to jingle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERATING, BETTIE W.
description: SERATING-Bettie W. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Arthur and Barbara. Loving grandmother of Kira, Peter, Michael and Jill. Service Wednesday 1:30PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: Dance in Review
description: Small Worlds That Go Together

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DULCHIN, ELI
description: DULCHIN-Eli. On February 10. Survived by wife of 58 years, Gertrude, daughters, Marilyn, Elaine and Bonnie, three son-in-laws, Armin, Jerry, and Barry and 8 grandchildren. One of the partners of B. Dulchin, Inc. for over 60 years. He will be in our hearts forever.

title: Plan for Freelancers: Collective Buying
description: The Earth Pledge Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded and led by the New York labor lawyer Theodore Kheel (inset), is organizing a collective purchasing program aimed at freelancers who work in new media areas in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPERO, EDWARD B., MD
description: SHAPERO-Edward B., MD, 86, on February 12, of a ruptured aneurysm. Dr. Shapero was a noted cancer surgeon and former Director of The Strang Clinic at New York Downtown Hospital. He was also an attending surgeon at The French-Polyclinic Hospital. Dr. Shapero was among the first 200 board certified surgeons. Until his death he served on a pension/ disability review board for the City of New York. He was a Major in the U.S. Army during World War II. He was a graduate of NYU & NY Homeopathic School of Medicine. Dr. Shapero is survived by his wife Sylvia, his daughter Anne Adler, her husband Richard, and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Strang Clinic, 320 East 15th Street, NYC 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMAN, MARTIN UDO
description: HEIMAN-Martin Udo. In his 84th year. Beloved husband of Ruth K. Devoted father of Michael and (Paula) and Diane Heiman. Loving Opa of Jonathan and Eric. Devoted brother of Karl and (Susanna) and Heiner (Israel). Caring uncle and great uncle of his loving nieces and nephews. Good friend to many who shared his life for so many years. Funeral service February 18, 1997, at 10:30 A.M. at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, New York.

title: Magic Coach On Hot Seat
description: Brian Hill is expected to be replaced as the Orlando Magic's coach this week, possibly as early as today.

title: Ancestor of Ebonics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Japanese Retailer Is Selling 16 Outlets
description: The Yaohan Japan Corporation, continuing to announce revamping plans, said today that it would sell 16 of its outlets in Japan to Daiei Inc., Japan's largest supermarket operator, for 33 billion yen ($264 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, SARA
description: FISHMAN-Sara. Cherished wife and best friend of husband Bernard. Loving mother of Carol Beth, mother-in-law of David, and dear grandmother of Molly and Ethan. On Feb. 16, 1997. Esteemed member for 22 years of the medical social work team of Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Her insightful, tender and courageous love for her family, friends and colleagues will be profoundly missed. Service at noon on Wednesday 2/19 at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. at Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: Publishers and Book Show Owner to Co-Sponsor Event
description: Hoping to make peace with book publishers and restore relevance to what many publishers have come to see as an outmoded, costly event, the new owner of the nation's biggest book show will announce today that the publishers' trade association has agreed to serve as a co-sponsor of the convention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ETHEL S.
description: MARKS-Ethel S., on February 16, 1997. Loving wife of Raymond. Dear aunt of Paul Neuhauser. For many years counselor of disabled youth at Federation Employment and Guidance Service. Funeral service private.

title: Oscar Adams, 72, a Pioneer As Alabama Top Court Justice
description: Former Justice Oscar W. Adams Jr. of the Alabama Supreme Court, the first black ever elected to statewide office in Alabama, died on Saturday at the Baptist Medical Center-Montclair in Birmingham, his hometown. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, PETER A.
description: COHN-Peter A., on February 17, 1997. Husband of the late Elizabeth Scharff Cohn; father of the late Jill Cohn Grossman. Survived by grandchildren Teri, Jeffrey, Douglas and Steven and by ten greatgrandchildren. Also survived by son-in-law Richard Grossman and step-sister Susan Adams. A retired Senior Partner of L.F. Rothschild & Co. and a devoted friend of many. Burial private. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Lenox Hill Hospital or to Princeton University would be appreciated.

title: For Bedouin, Peace Has a Bitter Taste
description: Gathering wood planks among the shipping containers, tents and household goods strewn on a rocky hillside near this town on the edge of the Judean desert, Mohammed Abu Ghaliya tried to put his house in order on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELANO, MARIA
description: MELANO-Maria. On February 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Mario. Devoted mother of Fabrizio and Laura. Adored grandmother of Michael and Brian. Dear sister of Giulia. Gracious mentor to generations of family and friends. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Monday and Tuesday, 24 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, on Wednesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Barnard College English Department, 3009 Broadway, NY, NY 10027, would be appreciated.

title: Off the Net, On the Stick, Into the Net
description: THIS strokes of genius are still there. As easily as if he were playing eight ball instead of hockey, Wayne Gretzky snatched the puck out of midair in his left glove, dropped it to the ice, then banked it off the side of the netting just out of Devil goaltender Martin Brodeur's reach to Niklas Sundstrom, who scored.

title: Image management, revivals and apple polishing: 20 questions about media and marketing.
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, DAVID M.
description: WEISS-David M., 89, of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of Lawrence L.I. and New York City, died on February 16, 1997. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Beatrice, daughters Cora Sue Simon and Jeannie Patricia Vine, sons-in-law David Simon and Dr. Ernest Vine, grandchildren Lainie J. Simon (Andrew Gross), Robin Vine Carpenter (Daniel), Charles Vine, and Skipper Vine, and great grandson Aaron Simon Gross. Dave Weiss was a long-time Resident Fur Buyer and was recognized in 1965 by the fur industry as Man of the Year. Beloved by his family and honored by his friends, he will be missed by all.
