Donations may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, Florida 33486 or the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEBOLD, MILES DAVID
description: SEBOLD-Miles David. On February 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Frances. Artist-Educator-Photographer, retired NYC Art Teacher, Bryant SHS, LIC, NY. Memorial service is pending. For information, Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Hts, NY.

title: Israel's Red-Line Map
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spread out Israel's ''red line'' map before President Clinton at the White House last week. It showed territory he said Israel would insist on holding as essential to the defense of the country.

title: Nets and Mavericks Clean House and Start Over
description: The unpredictable Nets Coach John Calipari sent Shawn Bradley and Robert Pack to Dallas tonight as part of a blockbuster nine-player deal, trading two starters he has not got along with for a fighting chance at future free agents.

title: Jefferson, Still a Force In the Idea of America
description: Perhaps in choosing Thomas Jefferson as the subject of his new work for television, Ken Burns was attracted by the challenge of bringing a man of words and ideas to a medium that is not famously receptive to such goods and of doing it without benefit of the vintage photographs that lent power to his masterwork, ''The Civil War.'' Although problems linger in this three-hour biography, ''Thomas Jefferson'' is a considerable accomplishment, a thoughtful and affecting portrait of the intellectual who captured the essence of a new nation's hopes in phrases that continue to resound around the world.

title: New Today: The Washington Edition
description: The Times today introduces a Washington Edition, with enhancements that include significantly later news and sports coverage. The edition will serve readers in the District of Columbia, Maryland, Virginia and Delaware. Its pages are transmitted by fiber optic cable for printing in Spingfield, Va., permitting later publicantion and wider home delivery.

title: Constitutional Session Runs Into Opposition
description: For those people (and there seem to be many) who think that state government is in need of serious repairs, 1997 should be an important year. This November, voters will decide whether to schedule a convention in 1999 where delegates can amend or even completely rewrite New York's single most important political document, the State Constitution.

title: Abe or Not, Few Give 2 Cents for 1
description: A PENNY lay on the floor by the cash register at Barney Greengrass, the temple to smoked fish on Amsterdam Avenue. ''See that penny?'' said Gary Greengrass, the latest member of his family to become a loxsmith. ''Nobody's bothered to pick it up.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Chien-Shiung Wu, 84, Dies; Top Experimental Physicist
description: Dr. Chien-Shiung Wu, a physicist who performed a historic experiment overturning what had been considered a fundamental law of nature, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEENAGHAN, MARGARET (PEG)
description: MEENAGHAN-Margaret (Peg). Of Staten Island, on February 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late James, loving mother of Thomas and James, dear sister of Rose Shevlin. Also survived by six grandchildren and one great grandchild. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, Staten Island, Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, 10 AM. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery (S.I.). Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Pax Christi Hospice would be appreciated.

title: 29 Years Later, Author Wins a 2d Newbery Medal
description: E. L. Konigsburg was awarded the 1997 Newbery Medal of the American Library Association yesterday for ''The View From Saturday'' (Jean Karl/Atheneum), a comic novel about a team of sixth-grade Academic Bowl competitors. The association's Caldecott Medal for illustration was won by David Wisniewski, the author and illustrator of ''Golem'' (Clarion Books/Houghton Mifflin), a story of the giant brought to life by a rabbi in 16th-century Prague, told in a fool-the-eye cut-paper technique.

title: Homeless Man Remembered as Kind but Troubled
description: Near his favorite stoop at the Sterling Bank branch on Queens Boulevard, Steve Dudas was known as the polite man with the dogs, a menagerie of them, gentle, forlorn and always well-behaved, not unlike their owner.

title: Many Deals In the Works For Mullin
description: Chris Mullin remains a hot topic of conversation as Thursday's trade deadline in the National Basketball Association approaches.

title: Elusive Wage Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: You're Broke at 2 A.M.? A.T.M.'s Don't Take I.O.U.'s
description: Some mysteries of the money net remain unsolved, and perhaps in the end, unsolvable.

title: Patterns
description: Designers Add at High End

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, FRANK
description: HELLER-Frank, 88, on Sunday. Beloved husband for 59 years of Grace Robinowitz Heller. Beloved father of Carol and Herb Corbin, Nancy Heller & Holly Gewandter. Beloved grandfather of Jeffrey, Suzanne and Leslie Corbin and Haley Heller Gewandter and great grandfather of Jessica Corbin. The family requests contributions to Frank Heller/Hebrew Institute Fund. Services 1:00 PM Tuesday at Hebrew Institute of White Plains, 20 Greenridge Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Steelers Keep the Free Agent Bettis
description: Enough is enough. The Pittsburgh Steelers finally held on to one of their own.

title: Investigate the G.O.P., Too
description: Congressional Republicans say they are committed to uncovering the whole truth about campaign finance practices in President Clinton's 1996 re-election effort. But Democrats are not the only ones whose fund-raising should be investigated. The coming inquiry should examine Republican activities as well.

title: Double Murder Trial to Begin
description: The capital murder trial of a Teaneck resident who has admitted drugging and suffocating his two children in a 1994 custody battle is scheduled to begin today. The lawyer for Avi Kostner, 52, plans to argue that Mr. Kostner's mental capacity was diminished by severe depression and various personality disorders he has suffered most of his life. ''His frame of reference is not the same one you and I have,'' the lawyer, Cathy L. Waldor, said yesterday.

title: Ad Spending Soars
description: As Wall Street turns to Madison Avenue to woo Main Street, financial services firms are setting advertising records.

title: 5 Admit Roles With Mafia In a Trash Hauling Cartel
description: On the eve of a major racketeering trial, five more defendants have pleaded guilty to state charges that they joined what prosecutors call a Mafia cartel that controlled New York City's billion-dollar-a-year private garbage collection industry.

title: Bayer Shifts 2 Big Brands
description: The Bayer Corporation in Morristown, N.J., has assigned the accounts of two brands, with billings estimated at more than $70 million, to two agencies on its roster.

title: The Times Begins Printing New Editions
description: The New York Times today begins printing editions near Washington and in New England for readers in those regions. The move will allow delivery of later news for those areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOFFETT, CHARLES M.
description: MOFFETT-Charles M., on February 14, 1997, of Brooklyn, teacher and jazz musician. Husband of Shirley Moffett. Father of Mondre, Charles Jr., Codaryl, Charisse, and Charnett, twelve grandchildren. Funeral service is on Thursday, February 20, 1997, 11:00 AM, at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Ave., Manhattan. Interment Glendale Cemetery, Bloomfield, NJ. For information contact George E. Cushnie Funeral Home, East Orange, NJ. 201-678-1790.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Sunday about Leon Hess, the Jets' owner, misidentified the renowned public relations man who once worked for him. The publicist was Benjamin Sonnenberg, not Ben Sonenborn.

title: Top Swedish Banks Open Merger Talks
description: Swedbank A.B. and Foreningsbanken A.B., two of Sweden's five biggest banks, said today that they were again discussing the possibility of merging and would issue a statement on Tuesday about their negotiations.

title: Crescent Buys Dallas Offices
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company agreed last week to buy almost all the assets of Carter-Crowley Properties Inc., including 14 office properties and a stake in the Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association.

title: No Headline
description: ''Theory is way ahead of experiment. It's like Hannibal trying to cross the Alps. We'd really like to run ahead and see what's on top, but we have all these elephants to deal with.''

title: Q&A
description: Stronger Nails

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLANEY, EMILY M.
description: MULLANEY-Emily M., on Feb. 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late James A. Devoted mother of James A. Jr. Mass of Christian Burial Wed., 11 AM, St Joan of Arc RC Church, Jackson Heights, NY.

title: Now Pacing Sideline, Pitino Proteges
description: When the phone rang for the first time in his new office, Jim O'Brien knew exactly who the caller had to be: his old friend, Ralph Willard. O'Brien and Willard had once been assistant coaches with the Knicks under Rick Pitino.

title: Cone, Older and Wiser, Is Set to Change Delivery
description: There are still private moments when David Cone cannot believe that the 1996 season has ended. There are also moments when he cannot believe it ever happened. Forget roller-coaster ride. Cone was stuck on a personal and professional bungee cord. Up and down.

title: Childs Feels Relieved, but May Miss Game
description: When the Knicks' Chris Childs was on the court grasping his injured left wrist during the fourth quarter of Sunday's game against the Indiana Pacers, he was hoping for the best. Today, he got it.

title: $20 for a Piece of Princeton
description: Princeton football fans can buy bits of soon-to-be-demolished Palmer Stadium and help pay for a new one in the process. The university has hired an Indianapolis company to set aside choice fragments of concrete, wooden seat planks and seat numbers from the 84-year-old stadium before the demolition begins March 3. The mementos will be sold for $20 to $200, Curt Krouse, Princeton's athletic marketing director, said yesterday. Sales will begin in May, when the university plans to auction some larger relics, such as scoreboards and benches, at alumni reunions. The new $45 million stadium is scheduled to open in 1998. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Clean Up the Shelter Mess
description: Shamed by accounts of widespread wrongdoing at a New York City-run shelter for battered women, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has ordered changes at the facility and vows to keep a closer watch. A quick cleanup of the mess at the New Day shelter is the least the city owes to women who fled abuse only to be subjected to the same coarse mistreatment in what was supposed to be a safe haven.

title: The Met Pioneered With Reproductions
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art was the first in the United States to make retailing a large part of its mission. In 1871, even before the founding trustees had a building, they bought 174 old master paintings in Europe and commissioned an engraver to make etchings of 10 of them. The etchings were presented to museums in Europe to tout the new collection but were also sold on consignment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ILUTOVICH, LEON
description: ILUTOVICH-Leon. The Federation of Polish Jews mourns the passing of its Vice President. A leading Zionist personality who devoted all his talents to the Jewish people and to the land of Israel. A survivor of the Holocaust, he was a shining example of the glorious Polish Jewry. Our condolences to his wife Renia and family. Kalman Sultanik, President Jechiel Dobekirer, Vice President Sam Bloch, Treasurer Dr. Solomon Goldman, Executive Secretary

title: G.M. Is Speaking Out on the Dollar and Other Issues
description: Just four years ago, a senior General Motors executive from Detroit appalled a roomful of diplomats and trade negotiators at an embassy dinner in Washington by loudly arguing that the nation's capital did not really matter because it did not manufacture anything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIE, ROBERT D.
description: CURRIE-Robert D. Beloved husband. I miss you every day of my life. Tanny McDonald-Currie

title: Woman Who Left the Citadel Tells of Brutal Hazing Ordeal
description: It was a frightening four-month transformation that the young woman said she would never forget: from unease, as one of the Citadel's first female cadets, to fear and dread, never knowing when rough jocularity would take a brutal turn.

title: U.S. to Pay New York Hospitals Not to Train Doctors, Easing Glut
description: In a plan that health experts greeted as brilliant and bizarre, Federal regulators announced yesterday that for the next six years they would pay New York State hospitals not to train physicians.

title: Tumbling for One Last Chance at Love
description: There can be a reckless aspect to loneliness, a desperation for intimacy so acute that it skews judgment and unleashes events that only intensify heartache.

title: A Sound That's Fresh (And Spiky)
description: The committed advocacy of great performers must be the fondest dream of any aspiring composer. The West would probably know of Alfred Schnittke and Arvo Part by now in any case, but the enterprising efforts of the violinist Gidon Kremer on their behalf a decade ago accelerated the process immeasurably.

title: Displaced Russian Has a New Faith but No Home
description: The troubles of Pvt. Aleksei Ivanovich Olenin began on a snowy day in November 1982. On the morning of that day, commanders summoned Soviet troops in Afghanistan to tell them that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, had died at the age of 75.

title: New Quiz Show Brings Some Levity to All-News Channel
description: Fred Bellemore is famous on the Vassar College campus in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for his extensive knowledge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HELEN PEARL
description: MILLER-Helen Pearl, 97, beloved wife of Paul, mother of Fanchon Scheier, mother-in-law of Saul, grandmother of Joshua and Joanna, great grandmother of Eliza, former soprano soloist of the YMHA, and Temple of the Covenant. She had a great appetite and zest for life.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday comparing the number and rate of hysterectomies with those for other kinds of major surgery misstated the rates. A corrected version appears today on page C8.

title: Chess
description: Alexander Alekhine, one of the greatest of the world champions, was noted for starting an attack on one flank, then unexpectedly shifting to the other with spectacular results. Despite his brilliant successes, there were players, over a half-century ago, who theorized that this strategem should not work, that if one flank resisted strongly, the other should be able to do the same. But Alekhine's supporters were quick to note that the escape of the first target of attack was often bought at the price of leaving the new target underdefended and vulnerable to quick hostile maneuvers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Over Here, a World Away
description: Roll call at Professor Rose Dios's calculus class at New Jersey Institute of Technology today will find students marked ''present'' in Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe. The students are enrolled in African Virtual University, which N.J.I.T. officials said is one of the first to use virtual, or electronic, classrooms to allow class participation across continents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOWLES, ALAN C.
description: KNOWLES-Alan C., of Essex Fells, New Jersey, on February 16, 1997, husband of the late Elinor Townsend, father of William T. Knowles and Mrs. Clara Elizabeth (Teedee) Carroll, brother of Howard T. Knowles, grandfather of Katherine K. Sadler, Stephen T. Carroll, Jr. and Reed C. Carroll, great grandfather of Alexandra G. & Francesca A. Sadler. Memorial services will be conducted at Union Congregational Church, 176 Cooper Avenue, Upper Montclair, New Jersey, Saturday, March 15th at 2 P.M. Memorial contributions may be made to the Union Congregational Church Memorial Fund or the West Essex First Aid Squad, P.O. Box 662, West Caldwell, New Jersey 07006.

title: Nets Get Better Than They Give
description: It's a trade that shows daring, foresight and imagination. And those are words not usually associated with the Nets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, GERTRUDE
description: SHERMAN - Gertrude, 95, of Southbury, CT., died suddenly on Feb. 16. Beloved wife of Monroe, adored mother of Susan and the late Nancy Rosenberg, sister of Edward Horn, cherished motherin-law of Dr Lawrence Rosenberg, treasured grandmother of Connie and Mark Hochman, Elizabeth Rosenberg, Eric Rosenberg, Mark Rosenberg & Andrea Needleman, beloved great grandmother of Sarah, Amelia, Jenna and Julian. Precious friend, ebullient and flaming spirit, compassionate, wise soul. Services at Pomperaug Woods, Southbury CT., at noon Thursday, February 20. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood.

title: HealthSouth May Acquire Horizon/CMS
description: The HealthSouth Corporation, which has gobbled up the competition to become the nation's biggest operator of rehabilitation and outpatient surgery centers, is negotiating to buy the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation, which operates hospitals and clinics, for about $1 billion in stock, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Dollar Rises vs. Mark and Yen; Foreign Stock Prices End Mixed
description: Continuing to climb against the German mark, the dollar broke above 1.70 marks yesterday for the first time since April 1994. Trading was kept thin by the Washington's Birthday holiday in the United States.

title: Putting a Honky-Tonk Spin On the Pain of Splitting Up
description: Jeff Tweedy, Wilco's songwriter and lead singer, knows that ''I sound like what's-his-name,'' as he sang on Saturday night at Irving Plaza. There are a lot of what's-their-names in Wilco's music: Gram Parsons, Neil Young, the Band, the Rolling Stones, the Byrds, the Beatles. Every so often, as in ''Somebody Else's Song,'' Mr. Tweedy admits to the burden of all those influences. But most of the time, he simply makes them rock.

title: Fed Cup Team Is Named
description: MARTINA NAVRATILOVA, the rookie captain of the United States Fed Cup team, yesterday nominated MARY JOE FERNANDEZ, CHANDA RUBIN, GIGI FERNANDEZ and KIMBERLY PO to the team that will travel to Haarlem, The Netherlands, for the first round March 1-2. The 15th-ranked Fernandez is the only returning member of the team that defeated Spain in the 1996 final.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDERMAN, MORRIS
description: SCHNEIDERMAN - Morris. Be loved husband of Miriam, father of Arthur, Judy, Steven, Helaine, Paul and Bette. Devoted grandfather of Susan, Adam, David, Sheri, Stuart, Sheila, Debra, Jonathan, Andy and Scott, and greatgrandfather of Amy, Lowell and Austin. Devoted brother of Belle, and the late Benjamin. ''Moishe'' was respected and loved by all in the family for his warmth, kindness, loving smile and sincere interest in all who came to know him. Services Tuesday, 2:15 PM, at I.J. Morris, Dix Hills.

title: Labor Dares Republicans To Cut Its Political Clout
description: John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, issued a defiant ''make my day'' declaration today to Republicans in Congress who want revenge on the labor movement for its pull-out-the-stops drive to defeat them in last fall's elections.

title: Bonds Reports to Camp Early
description: After a week in which he sparred publicly with the San Francisco Giants about the possibility of a contract extension, BARRY BONDS arrived at spring training in Scottsdale, Ariz., three days early yesterday and reiterated his desire to finish his career with the Giants.

title: Can I.R.S. Be Far From Classroom Door?
description: To the Editor:

title: Salinas Brothers Issue Denials In U.S. Drug Trafficking Case
description: Former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his brother, Raul, have strongly denied charges made by witnesses in a Federal case in Texas that they had links to drug traffickers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKS, GRAHAM GRANGER, M.D.
description: HAWKS-Graham Granger, M.D. February 15. Age 85. Survived by his wife Margery, brother Byron and children Ria and Graham, Jr. W.W. II combat infantry Regiment Surgeon of the 77th Division in Pacific Theater. Discharged as Lt. Col. Professor Emeritus Obstetrics & Gynecology & former Director of Obstetrics at New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. Service Thursday, 4 PM, February 20. Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue 91st Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Dept. of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center, 525 68th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, SELIG S.
description: BURROWS-Selig S. Age 83. Cherished husband of the late Gladys. Died 2/16 peacefully in his sleep after a long and valiant struggle with lung disease. Adored father of Kenneth, Jonathan, & Patricia Burrows, loving father-in-law of Milt Wolfson & Erica Jong. Grandfather extraordinaire to Jessica, Jordan, Jody, Tracy and Molly. Brother of the late Abe Burrows and the late Shirley Alter. Brotherin-law of Doris and Mel Sirow, Bobbie and Gene Wells, Taube & Manny Meltzer and Paul Alter. His spirit and courage, his wit, warmth and boundless generosity will be felt for generations. Services at 11:15 A.M., Wednesday, February 19, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Compuserve Chief Steps Down After Troubled Year at Helm
description: Compuserve Inc., the computer on-line service, said today that its chief executive, Robert J. Massey, had stepped down after a troubled tenure of a year and a half.

title: How 3 Worried Professors Turned Adelphi on Its Head
description: The campaign that ultimately toppled Adelphi University's board of trustees was born here two years ago in the campus cafeteria.

title: Firm Overpaid by $300,000
description: A recently released state audit found that consulting contracts awarded by the former Transportation Commissioner, Frank J. Wilson, skirted purchasing rules and may have cost taxpayers an extra $300,000. The contracts to reorganize the Transportation Department's engineering projects went to a California firm, O'Brien-Kreitzberg, which later approached Mr. Wilson with a job offer. Mr. Wilson resigned in December after accusations of conflict of interest.

title: No Disappointment With a Scrappy Tie
description: Yesterday's energetic 2-2 tie was a good point for both the Rangers and the Devils. For the first time in three meetings this season there was the smell and feel of a real regional rivalry. There were man-to-man battles all over the ice amid 72 shots on goal before a raucous capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, EMILY
description: WATERMAN-Emily, on Monday February 17, 1997, of South Orange, formerly of Newark, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel Waterman. Devoted Mother of Maxine Gleicher, Martin and Robert Waterman. Adored Mother-in-law of Chick Gleicher and Susan Waterman. Loving grandmother of Michael Gleicher, Lisa and Douglas Sanderson and Daniel Waterman. Funeral Services conducted from the Menorah Chapels At Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey, on Wednesday, February 19, 1997, at 11:30 AM. Interment King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Mr. Clinton's Challenge on Schools
description: President Clinton's education agenda, which dominated his State of the Union address, has tapped into a broad national concern about failing schools. Mr. Clinton's proposals for national standards and national tests are timely, sound and relatively inexpensive, given the results they are likely to yield. Some of his other proposals -- including teacher retraining, better reading instruction, school reconstruction -- are important as well.

title: A Sore Toe May Mean Wells's Gout Is Back
description: A frustrated David Wells hobbled out of Legends Field this afternoon, still unsure why his left big toe is ailing him and still unsure when he will pitch for the Yankees. Concern is escalating because the burly left-hander was in considerable pain today, and the Yankees believe he might have gout.

title: OFFICER'S CLEARING IN SAUDI BOMBING NOW UNDER REVIEW
description: Under pressure from Congress and top aides to Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, the Air Force is reluctantly considering reversing its decision to exonerate the general in charge of a housing complex in Saudi Arabia where 19 American airmen were killed by a truck bomb last June.

title: One Woman's Decision Against a Hysterectomy
description: LAST Thanksgiving, Antonia Alba had little heart for gratitude, turkey, or even a diverting family squabble. After months of dithering, she had scheduled a hysterectomy for the next week, and now she was in a panic. She did not want to lose part of her body. She did not know what to expect afterward. And though she was 40 years old, divorced, and with no new partner in sight, she still held hope of bearing a child, an option that obviously would vanish along with her uterus.

title: Ahmanson Sets A $5.8 Billion Hostile Bid for Great Western
description: H. F. Ahmanson, the holding company for the nation's largest savings and loan institution, said last night that it had made a hostile offer to buy the Great Western Financial Corporation, the nation's second largest savings institution, for $5.8 billion. Both companies are based in the Los Angeles suburbs and mainly serve California and Florida.

title: Amazon's Depths Yield Strange New World Of Unknown Fish
description: SINCE the middle of the last century, the Amazon River and its tributaries have provided passage to many an intrepid adventurer heading into South America's interior rain forests. But despite the fact that scientifically minded explorers have been floating down these waterways for more than 100 years, life in the river itself has remained largely unknown.

title: INSIDE
description: China's Leader May Be Ailing

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Cuban Government has invited about 100 American business leaders and celebrities to a $500-a-plate dinner in Havana next week to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the world-renowned Cohiba cigar, Reuters said, quoting a report in yesterday's Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel.

title: Chocolate Lover or Broccoli Hater? Answer's on the Tip of Your Tongue
description: Babies are born with a number of obvious genetic traits, like brown or blue eyes, black or red hair, dark or light skin. But parents take note: infants also enter this world equipped with a genetically determined number of taste buds embedded into the tips of their tiny tongues. Some have a few hundred or so buds while others are endowed with tens of thousands of receptors for sweet, sour, salty or bitter foods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, BEAVEN W.
description: MILLS-Beaven W., 79, High Point, N.C., died on February 14, 1997. Formerly with Continental Can Corporation, Jens Risom Design, and Alma Desk Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHRENS, REV. WILLIAM F.
description: BEHRENS-Rev. William F., 92, of Manchester Township, New Jersey, Sunday, February 16, 1997. Beloved father of William R., Barbara Cohan & Wilma Manning. Brother of Henry. Grandfather of eight, great-grandfather of ten. His wife Hazel passed away in 1985. Viewing Wedndsday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Anderson & Campbell Funeral Home, 115 Lacey Road, Whiting, NJ. Funeral service Thurs., 11AM, St. Paul Lutheran Church, Beachwood, New Jersey. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Paul Lutheran Church, Beachwood, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, VIRGINIA J. (NEE MCKAY)
description: SHEA-Virginia J. (nee McKay), on February 17th, 1996. Beloved wife of the late Joseph T. Loving mother of the late Joan V. O'Leary and Dennis J. Cherished grandmother of Joan O'Leary Sartorio, Jill O'Leary Kiernan, Brian Shea and Ammon Shea and great-grandmother of David O'Leary Kiernan and Joseph O'Leary Sartorio. Reposing 2-4 & 7-9 PM, Tuesday, at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, at 11 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: CORRECTION: Hysterectomy Rates
description: A chart yesterday comparing the number and rate of hysterectomies compared with those for other kinds of major surgery misstated the rates in some copies. A corrected version is below.

title: Caribbean Seeks to Attract More Airlines
description: For the Caribbean islands that supply the kind of vacations that Americans crave in the winter, the threat of an American Airlines strike at the peak of the tourist season was a scary reminder that their reliance on one airline could prove as economically devastating as some hurricanes.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Self-Portrait That's Naked

title: Repeal Urged for Law on Giving Away Assets to Get Medicaid
description: Clinton Administration officials urged Congress today to repeal a new law that makes it a Federal crime to dispose of assets to qualify for Medicaid coverage of nursing home expenses. They said that such abuses were not common.

title: For Remote Bird Species, the Sex of Hatchlings Is No Surprise
description: AMONG parents, one question never fails to arouse a lively debate: Which is the preferable sex to raise, boys or girls? While nearly everyone has an opinion on this impossible-to-resolve question, it remains the uncontrollable biological reality of sperm meeting egg rather than parental preference that casts the die for a little Jack or tiny Jill.

title: Sale of Gucci Lifts Investcorp Earnings
description: Investcorp, the Bahrain-based investment bank and holding company whose assets include a controlling interest in Saks Holdings Inc. of the United States, has reported that earnings rose 29 percent last year to a record, reflecting in part the overhaul and sale of Gucci, the Italian producer of luxury goods.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANDAU, EVA J.
description: LANDAU-Eva J., Feb. 18, 1982, who found well deserved rest and peace fifteen years ago today. Your Loving Son, Robert

title: Girl's Slaying Spurs Inquiry On City Lapses
description: More than a year after an 8-year-old Brooklyn girl vanished without attracting the notice of either her public school or child welfare workers who were monitoring her case, the police said yesterday that she had been beaten to death and her mother's ex-boyfriend was charged with killing her.

title: Life With Mother: Really Creepy
description: Fuzzy nostalgia for traditional family values, the supposedly good old ways, gets a swift kick in the pants tonight in the CBS ''inspired by actual events'' movie ''The Perfect Mother.'' Played with fiendish creepiness by Tyne Daly, Eleni Podarus is a family matriarch who, always for the good of the family, rules her two cowed sons and their wives with a firm hand. If that doesn't work, she has access to hired killers.

title: Eastern Europe's Wild Capitalism
description: When asked why the Albanian Government had not stepped in to end recent pyramid schemes before they swindled Albanians out of hundreds of millions of dollars, President Sali Berisha said his inaction was a sign of the Government's commitment to the free market. Even assuming that ideology, not corruption, explains his Government's failure, Mr. Berisha's view is disturbing. Such a misreading of capitalism has caused widespread misery in former Communist countries, which are still learning that the free market works best when not completely free.

title: Great Costumes That Can't Win
description: The costumes Arianne Phillips designed for ''The Crow'' helped spark a cult following, and the ones she made for ''Tank Girl'' were spun off into a clothing collection. Those she created for ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' made it the rare contemporary film that not only defines the characters through the costumes but also shows the arc of each character's development through them.

title: Quantum Theorists Trying to Surpass Digital Computing
description: IN the never-ending effort to make sense of the universe, the human brain long ago bumped up against its limits. Unchastened, brains learned to amplify themselves with pencils and paper, slide rules, mechanical calculators and electronic computers. And the computers get faster all the time.

title: A New Life Opens, After Prison and Battering
description: Since she walked out of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility three weeks ago without a backward glance, Charline Brundidge has chewed bubble gum and looked in a full-length mirror for the first time in a decade. She has learned to ride the subway, applied for a driver's license and bought a pair of Doc Martens boots.

title: Albright and Her French Counterpart Say Glass Is Half Full
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Foreign Minister Herve de Charette went out of their way this evening to pronounce a working truce in the sometimes strained relations between America and France, praising the two countries' long alliance.

title: Museums Step Up Their Retailing to Turn Art Into Revenue
description: At the American Museum of Natural History, painters are putting final dabs on dioramas for a show next month called ''Endangered! A World at Risk.'' Museum officials hope visitors leave with lofty ideas on biodiversity.

title: Talks on Sewage Discharge
description: New York and New Jersey officials are scheduled to meet tomorrow to work out an alternative to New York City's plan to dump 500 million gallons of raw sewage into the East River. Although the city had obtained a permit to discharge the sewage while a pumping station was shut down for repairs, the release was postponed at the last minute Friday after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman complained that she had not been told about it. Mrs. Whitman said the discharge could damage shellfish beds and tourism at the Jersey Shore.

title: Adelphi and Excellence
description: To the Editor:

title: Judicial Confirmation Isn't About Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Before Zagat
description: To The Living Section:

title: In Harlem, Clean Streets For the VIP
description: THE workfare cleaning crews swept through Harlem yesterday, hours before President Clinton visited Riverside Church to urge religious groups to help ease the transition from welfare to work. One crew had been diverted from its usual location to spruce up part of 12th Avenue near the route of the Presidential motorcade.

title: Grilling: Out of the Backyard and Into the Fireplace
description: A FIREPLACE is a bit like a prophet who is not honored in his own country. But fireplaces provide a singular opportunity not only to sample the remarkable flavor of grilled food in winter, but also to experience grilling at its most basic, which is the very height of the craft. This is because, unlike the fires in outdoor grills, fireplace fires are usually made with logs.

title: A Recall Effort Falls Short
description: Mayor James Whelan of Atlantic City will not have to face a recall, the City Clerk said yesterday. The Clerk, Benjamin F. Fitzgerald, said that organizers of a petition drive fell 1,714 signatures short of the 4,271 needed to place the recall question on the ballot.

title: Vintage Theater May Get New Role
description: With only 582 seats, it is not quite a palace. But the landmark Embassy 1 Theater at Broadway and 46th Street is certainly a little temple to the motion picture. It is also the last vintage Times Square cinema where you can still catch a first-run movie.

title: North Korea's Leader Says 'Cowards' Are Welcome to Leave
description: In another sign that North Korea might accept the defection of a top official, that country's Communist leader, Kim Jong Il, said in an official radio broadcast on Tuesday that ''cowards'' were welcome to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, ALZIE
description: JACKSON-Alzie. The members, Board and staff of Camp Sussex are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our friend and longtime chef, Alzie Jackson. Alzie was an inspiration and guide to the many young people that worked and trained in his kitchen. He was a dear friend to the children he cooked for and a breath of fresh air to those who had the good fortune to know him. We send our heartfelt condolences to his family. Funeral services Saturday, February 22 at Mt. Sinai Church, at Lanstown, PA, 11 AM. Call 718261-8700 for further information. Robert Silver, President Gary Cardamone, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEENAGHAN, MARGARET
description: MEENAGHAN-Margaret. With profound sorrow, the administration, faculty and staff of NYU Ehrenkranz School of Social Work mourn the loss of Margaret Meenaghan, mother of Dean Thomas M. Meenaghan. Our deepest sympathy to the Dean and his family. In lieu of flowers, donations to Pax Christi Hospice would be appreciated. Eleanore Z. Korman, Vice Dean Lucretia J. Phillips, Associate Dean

title: No Headline
description: ''In what country can companies go for five years without contributing to the pension fund or paying their taxes? But here, they survive.''

title: Whitman Leads All 7 Rivals
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman remains very popular in New Jersey and would easily beat any of seven potential rivals in the November election, according to a Quinnipiac College poll released yesterday. The poll of 875 people was taken between Feb. 11 and 16 with a margin of error of 3.3 percent.

title: Marriott Aims Overseas With Acquisition
description: Expanding its presence in the hotel business overseas, Marriott International said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Renaissance Hotel Group, a company based in Hong Kong that operates and franchises 150 hotels in 38 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, STEVEN J.
description: JENSEN-Steven J. on February 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Iris Degutz, devoted father of Christian and Michelle. Visiting at Schaefer Funeral Home, 4th Ave. and 42nd St., Brooklyn, Thursday, 2-5, 7-10PM. Memorial service, Thursday 2PM, in chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations to charity of one's choice would be appreciated. Private parking.

title: The Dealing May Not End At Trader Nets
description: It would be like dessert topping if the potential good coming from New Jersey's nine-player trade with the Dallas Mavericks could get even better, a possibility if a deal for the incoming Net Jim Jackson can be worked out before Thursday's 6 P.M. trade deadline.

title: Village Voice Turmoil Extends to Freelancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIELINSKI, FRANK
description: ZIELINSKI-Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Zielinski, associated with The Times from 1967 until retiring in 1978.

title: Labor Leaders Seek to Unionize Welfare Recipients Who Must Go to Work
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O's leaders have decided to seek to unionize the hundreds of thousands of welfare recipients who will be required to work for their benefits, with the dual goal of improving their working conditions and pressuring states and cities to give them permanent jobs.

title: Chase Manhattan Promotes an Executive
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had promoted James B. Lee Jr. to vice chairman of the bank, with responsibility for global investment banking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, SARA
description: FISHMAN-Sara. Cherished wife and best friend of husband Bernard. Loving mother of Carol Beth, mother-in-law of David, and dear grandmother of Molly and Ethan. On Feb. 16, 1997. Esteemed member for 22 years of the medical social work team of Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Her insightful, tender and courageous love for her family, friends and colleagues will be profoundly missed. Service at noon on Wednesday 2/19 at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. at Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: CCB TO PAY $325.1 MILLION FOR AMERICAN FEDERAL
description: The CCB Financial Corporation, a Southeast regional banking concern, has agreed to purchase a smaller rival, American Federal Bank F.S.B., for $325.1 million in stock, the companies said yesterday. American Federal stockholders will receive 0.445 CCB Financial common share for each American Federal share held. The companies valued the transaction at $28.86 a share based on CCB Financial's five-day average closing stock price through last Friday of $64.85. American Federal's shares jumped $6, to $27.50, in Nasdaq trading. CCB's shares fell $2, to $66, on the New York Stock Exchange. American Federal, based in Greenville, S.C., has about $1.3 billion of assets. It will be operated as a unit of CCB Financial, of Durham, N.C., which will then have about $6.9 billion in assets.

title: Messier Has Flu, Sore Back
description: Mark Messier, the Ranger captain, missed practice today because of the flu, Coach Colin Campbell said. In addition, Campbell said that Messier had been bothered by a sore back while going without a goal or an assist in the last four games.

title: OXFORD HEALTH PLANS INC. (OXHP, NNM)
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said yesterday that its net income more than doubled in the fourth quarter as enrollment in its managed health care plans increased.

title: Village Voice Turmoil Extends to Freelancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Pathmark and Brooklyn Group Both Profit as Partners
description: The revelation came to Roderick B. Mitchell nine Christmases ago, when his supermarket company in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was bleeding cash. And the first clue was Engelbert Humperdinck.

title: Bias Charged Against Branch-Campus Faculty
description: Invoking the language of the civil rights movement, Pearl Duncan, who has taught English at the College of New Rochelle since 1974, often uses the phrase ''separate but not equal'' to describe conditions at her satellite campus a few blocks from City Hall in Manhattan.

title: Theater in Review
description: Skewed Characters and Lines

title: A Trip to the Museum Is Far More Than What It Was
description: Nineteen pairs of sixth-grade eyes were riveted to the floor of the East Building at the National Gallery of Art. While some of the children simply stared down at their feet, a bit uncertain, others got on their knees and began copying the floor's triangular patterns for a math lesson on isosceles triangles and parallelograms. That done, the children, very much at home, moved from one part of the museum to another, chatting with the gallery's team of educators and docents like old friends.

title: Transcript of F-16 Pilots' Conversations
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the conversations of a Navy air traffic controller and two F-16 fighter pilots from the New Jersey Air National Guard on Feb. 5. In the transcript, which was released by the Air Force today, the air traffic controller is referred to as ''Giant Killer,'' the lead F-16 pilot as ''Smash 11'' and the trainee fighter pilot as ''Smash 12.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRUSCH, MICHAEL
description: PRUSCH-Michael. 86, On February 16. Beloved husband of Grace for 58 years. He was a Charter Member of Motion Picture Editors Local 771 for 44 years, serving as Vice President for 18 years and President for 6 years. His Film Libriarian career extended over a 60 year period with Fox Movietone News and Hearst Metrotone News. Viewing on Wednesday at Becker Funeral Home, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, Westwood, NJ. Funeral on Thursday, 11 am at St. John the Baptist R.C. Church, Hillsdale, NJ.

title: Moving to Insure Preservation, 2 States Sign Deal for Sterling Forest
description: New Jersey and New York signed a landmark agreement yesterday with the owner of Sterling Forest, a largely undeveloped 17,500-acre natural refuge, to acquire more than 90 percent of the land for $55 million, guaranteeing that the pristine acreage will not be developed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COASTAL CORP., Houston, an energy holding company, said it might sell part of its Corpus Christi, Tex., refinery to Maraven S.A. of Venezuela. Maraven's stake could be as high as 50 percent and cost $210 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, LIN
description: CHEN-Lin. On February 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Susie Chen. President of Summit Import Corporation and Kam Man Food Corporation. He will be deeply missed by his loving family and friends. Friends may call Friday February 21, 11am-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Funeral Monday, February 24, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell.

title: When 'Elegance' Meant Denying a Jewish Past
description: To the Editor:

title: When 'Elegance' Meant Denying a Jewish Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Stirring Up Old Terrors Unforgotten
description: John Singleton said he would never forget Minnie Lee Langley's fear and courage as she told him about the murderous rage she had witnessed as a child more than 70 years ago in Rosewood, Fla.

title: President Turns New York Visit Into Big Money
description: Just two weeks after he called on Congress to overhaul the campaign finance laws by summer, President Clinton flew yesterday to New York City, one of the political fund-raising capitals of the nation, to raise more than $1 million for Democratic candidates for the Senate.

title: Training Site for the Poor
description: About 60 percent of the 3,000 people who live in Union City's public housing are on welfare, according to the city's top public housing official. Today, construction will begin on a $2.9 million training center on Kennedy Boulevard, next to a public housing area, that will be used to help residents of public housing get off welfare and find jobs, said Virgilio Cabello, executive director of the Union City Housing Authority. The Campus for Learners, one of 25 centers being built by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, will include a technology lab, Mr. Cabello said. When it is completed, welfare recipients will be required to enroll in training or be forced to leave public housing, he said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Old Dominion Wins Easily
description: Nyree Roberts scored 19 points, including the 1,000th of her career, and Clarisse Machanguana had 26 last night to lead second-ranked Old Dominion to an 88-43 victory over East Carolina in Norfolk, Va.

title: Shares of Horizon/CMS Jump After Takeover Announcement
description: Shares of the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation jumped nearly 16 percent yesterday following the announcement that the company had reached a definitive agreement to be bought by the HealthSouth Corporation for nearly $1 billion.

title: Fifth Homeless Man in a Week Dies in a Shanty Fire
description: A homeless man living in a wood and cardboard shanty under a highway ledge in Brooklyn died yesterday when his makeshift home caught fire and a companion was unable to pull him from the flames in time, the police said.

title: Gordon Eats at a Place Without Slim Jims
description: What is stock car racing coming to? First there was the sight during the Daytona 500 on Sunday of Steve Grissom and Ken Schrader meekly apologizing to each other for running themselves off the track and out of the race, the kind of maneuver that pushed Cale Yarborough and Donnie Allison into a full-blown fistfight at Daytona 18 years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, EMILY
description: HAHN-Emily. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: Langdon Leads Duke In Dismantling Clemson
description: Clemson's plan was to make Duke, the Atlantic Coast Conference's most accurate and productive 3-point shooting team, drive to the basket. Then the Tigers, who pride themselves on their defense, expected to smother the Blue Devils' attack.

title: Savings From Allowance Helps Boy, 9, to Aid Needy
description: When 9-year-old Andy Mitchell leaves his home in Nyack, N.Y., for a visit to Manhattan with his mother, he does not always like what he sees: homelessness during the cold winters, ''people living inside boxes,'' he wrote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, ELAINE, R.N.
description: SIMON-Elaine, R.N. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with deep sadness the passing of our long-time friend and colleague, Elaine Simon, R.N., a distinguished and highly respected member of our nursing department from 1970 to 1996. An alumna of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing and a long-time board member of the school's alumni association, Elaine will forever be remembered for her outstanding commitment to patient care and education of the nurses of tomorrow. To her husband Al, her children Beth and Eric, the entire Simon family, and all who loved her, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Robert G. Newman, M.D., Pres. Gail F. Donovan, Sr Vice President for Operations Theresa Rejrat, R.N., Acting Vice President for Nursing Rose Muscatine Hauer, R.N., M.A. Dean Emerita, Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing

title: Hopes Rising for Selenium
description: SELENIUM, a mineral long feared for its toxicity, is on the road to becoming a Cinderella nutrient. As the last of 40 nutrients to be proved essential to human health, selenium is now the subject of both human and animal studies that suggest it can help prevent the two leading killers in the Western world: heart disease and cancer. It may also lift the human spirit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, BRADFORD D.
description: JONES-Bradford D. Died peacefully at age 83 after a long illness. A former editor of True Detective magazine and the author of hundreds of magazine articles published in the 1950's, Mr. Jones is survived by his loving wife Mary, and devoted son Stephen. Services will be at Frederick Funeral Home, 718-357-6100.

title: Service Station Chain Being Sold in Britain
description: The British leisure and media concern Granada Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell its Welcome Break auto service station division for $:476 million ($772.1 million) to Investcorp S.A., the Bahrain-based investment company. Granada also said it had sold its Westbury hotels for $:90 million to Chelsfield P.L.C..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, RITA P.
description: ROGERS-Rita P. February 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William Rogers. Loving sister of the late Florence Owen, Margery Carhardt, Martha Crocker, Evelyn Horner, Marie Powers, Helen Powers, August Powers, John Powers and William V. Powers. Loving aunt of William K. Powers, Leslie R. Carhardt and Dalton Carhardt. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral Saturday 10AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MORTON
description: BROWN-Morton. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY, records with deep sorrow the passing of its first Men's Club president and founding member. Heartfelt condolences to the family. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Arlene Kagan, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths      HUGHES, MARION
description: HUGHES-Marion, on February 17, 1997. Wife of Derek; mother of Robin O'Hara, Adam and Jennifer Hughes; sister of Penny Davis and Richard Brown. Services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Ave. at 53rd St., Friday, 11 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to WAR (Women at Risk), C/O Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, Comprehensive Breast Service, 161 Ft. Washington Ave., New York, New York 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAELI, DORIS
description: ISRAELI-Doris. On February 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Israeli. Mother of Miriam, Beulah and Phineas. Mother-inlaw of Stanley. Sister of Aaron and Samuel Solomon. Funeral services Thursday, February 20, 1997, 12:15 pm, Riverside Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Times Co. in On-Line Pact
description: The New York Times Company announced an agreement with America Online Inc. yesterday to expand the on-line provider's exclusive use of news and features from The New York Times, including original material developed by The Times. The new features, which will be available to the eight million subscribers of America Online, will include an expanded version of Science Times, a new People electronic page, crossword puzzle chat rooms and a monthly ''theme'' crossword puzzle that will appear only on the electronic service. Officials of both companies said that the measures were intended to satisfy the growing demand for exclusive content and services as the on-line market expands. Apart from the exclusive elements, The Times's news report is also available from its own site on the World Wide Web, at http://www.nytimes.com.

title: In Training for a Run on the Political Stage
description: Sometimes the opportunism that makes this city tick displays the symmetry of a cuckoo clock: Patrick J. Buchanan, the insurgent body puncher from last year's Republican Presidential primary circuit, will soon be returning to his television perch on ''Crossfire,'' the Punch-and-Judy debating show on CNN, just as Geraldine A. Ferraro is pondering leaving the show next year for another run at the Senate.

title: Blending Pop With Prayer for Tibet
description: A deep, unwavering ''Om'' filled Carnegie Hall during the fifth annual benefit for Tibet House when the audience sang to accompany Yungchen Lhamo's pristine, gliding vocal lines. ''This is not a pop song, this is a prayer,'' she said, at an event where songs outnumbered prayers but were offered in a similar spirit.

title: Madison Ave. Site Is Sold
description: A Madison Avenue building that houses a Gap store, Sumitomo Bank and other major companies has been sold for $67 million in the highest per-square-foot price for an office building in the 1990's, representatives who brokered the deal said yesterday.

title: Systems Analyst Lemaire Has His Machine Humming
description: The coach is the master of matchups. The goaltender has the best goals against average in the National Hockey League. And the team is unbeaten in 11 games. The Devils' system is working.

title: For some fliers, there may be a silver lining in the short-lived strike by American Airlines' pilots.
description: SOME business travelers could find a silver lining in the short-lived strike by American Airlines' pilots early Saturday, ended by President Clinton, who appointed a Presidential Emergency Board to recommend a settlement of the dispute by mid-April.

title: Auditor Is Dismissed by Mercury Finance
description: The Mercury Finance Company said today that it had dismissed KPMG Peat Marwick as its auditor, three weeks into a scandal about years of overstated earnings.

title: USAIR DECLINES TO BUY BACK SHARES FROM BRITISH AIR
description: USAir Group said yesterday that it would not exercise its option to purchase British Airways P.L.C.'s 24.6 percent stake in USAir. British Airways announced in December that it planned to sell the stake as a step toward dissolving a relationship that had soured after British Airways announced an alliance with American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation. USAir, which is based in Arlington, Va., has told British Air that ''it will not exercise its right of first refusal'' to buy the preferred shares, which are not publicly traded, a spokesman for USAir said. The stake, for which British Airways paid $400 million in 1993, can now be sold privately or through a stock offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORDBY, JAY J.
description: NORDBY-Jay J., age 42. On February 15, 1997. Devoted and beloved son of Dr. John and Ethel Nordby of CT., and brother of Wesley of CA. B.A. and M.A. in Russian from Middlebury College, M.A. in German from Princeton, Fulbright Fellowship, fluent in 11 languages and accomplished musician and television executive. Memorial services will be held in NYC at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, MILTON
description: WASSERMAN-Milton. WIZO New York mourns with Susan Sanders in the loss of her beloved father. Evelyn Sommer President WIZO USA

title: Darcy Ribeiro, 74, Expert On Brazilian Indian Culture
description: Darcy Ribeiro, an anthropologist who unlocked the cultural riches of Brazil's Indians for the rest of his country, died at a hospital in Brasilia on Monday. He was 74.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRIYANKA GANDHI, the 25-year-old daughter, granddaughter and great-granddaughter of Prime Ministers of India, was married yesterday to ROBERT VADRA, 27, an exporter.

title: Gout Gives Wells Pain, but Yanks Are Patient
description: David Wells has been more of a stand-up comic than a stand-up starter for the Yankees in training camp so far, tossing more one-liners than meaningful pitches and causing people in Yankeeland to smile sheepishly at his act. At least for now, team officials are still smiling.

title: New Call For Support Of Clinton On Schools
description: In remarks that reflected the delicate balance between Federal activism and local control in American education, Education Secretary Richard W. Riley, in his fourth annual State of American Education address, today urged support for President Clinton's ambitious program for the nation's schools and universities.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article on Monday about New York recitals by the pianist David Helfgott misstated a performance date. Mr. Helfgott will play at Avery Fisher Hall on March 18 (not March 4) and on April 8, and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on April 23.

title: On the Road to Capitalism, Tax Breakdown for Russia
description: The managers of Russia's largest carmaker like to think big.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Long Island University

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC. (LIZ,N)
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose nearly 22 percent in the fourth quarter on higher sales of its Lizsport, Lizwear and other casual sportswear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, FRANK
description: HELLER-Frank. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a longtime friend and major supporter of YU, and its Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law and Albert Einstein College of Medicine, beloved husband of Grace, member of the board of AECOM's National Women's Division, and father of Carol (and Herbert) Corbin, and Nancy Heller, CSL Fellow. A distinguished communal leader in behalf of Jewish education, he was former President of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater NY and of Camp Morasha and recipient of YU's Heritage Award. We extend heartfelt condolences as well to his brother Michael (and Sylvia) Heller, Fellows of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary; grandchildren I. Jeffrey and Suzanne L. Corbin, CSL Fellows, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTH, EDITH
description: BARTH-Edith. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Edith B. Barth, and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband Emanuel and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Harry Laufer, President

title: Jewish Right, Arab Left
description: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu signed the Hebron withdrawal accord it signaled a fundamental split on the Jewish right in Israel. Those who argued that for religious, nationalist or security reasons Israel must never cede one inch of the West Bank were left behind, as a large segment of the Jewish right joined the land-for-peace camp, creating a broad new center. Now the only debate left in Israel is not whether there will be a Palestinian state in the West Bank, but what size will it be: A size 15 wide, a size 10 narrow, or a size 7 small?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: After Demotion, Executive Resigns From Apple

title: D'Amato Says It Was 'Proper' To Shift Funds
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York said today that it was ''proper and legal'' to transfer campaign donations from the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which he was chairman of during the last election, to state and local candidates in New York State.

title: Just a Minute, Mr. Starr
description: Kenneth Starr's decision to leave his post as Independent Counsel in the Whitewater affair sometime this summer reflects a selfish indifference to his important civic obligations. Mr. Starr is not investigating some obscure town commissioner. The matters he has been asked to look into involve a sitting President of the United States, the First Lady and a score of senior officials.

title: Truck Was Rented by Oklahoma Bomb Suspect, Witnesses Say
description: Two important prosecution witnesses in the Oklahoma City bombing trial took the witness stand today and swore that the man who rented the Ryder truck the Government says carried the bomb was Timothy J. McVeigh.

title: Sauteed Turkey and a Rice Medley From the Old School
description: The appeal of old-fashioned dishes continues. A recipe for chicken Normandy that ran last month prompted considerable response. This recipe for sauteed turkey seasoned with mustard, lemon and capers should be just as popular. The recipe contains none of those ingredients found in fusion cooking: no lemon grass, no tamarind paste, no Sichuan pepper.

title: Pirates Can Laugh at Last
description: During the three weeks since Seton Hall's last victory, there had been no smiles, no fun. Frustration and anger had ruled the Pirates' world.

title: HEALTH AND RETIREMENT PROPERTIES IN $446 MILLION DEAL
description: Health and Retirement Properties Trust of Newton, Mass., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 30 office buildings for $446 million in cash, stock and assumed debt in a move that takes the company into a new real estate sector. The buildings are being bought from the closely held Government Properties Investors Inc., controlled by Rosecliff Inc. and Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, both of New York. They contain 3.4 million square feet of space and are leased to United States Government agencies. The buildings, which are in 17 states and the District of Columbia, will represent about 26 percent of the company's $1.7 billion real estate portfolio. Health care properties make up the other 74 percent.

title: Campaign Finance
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Rick Remick, vice president and account director at the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, was named president of a new unit, Leo Burnett Field Marketing Services, which will handle services for the Miller Brewing Co. media account. Mr. Remick reports to Pete Volz, executive vice president and client service director, who oversees the account of the Philip Morris Cos., which owns Miller.

title: Speed-Limit Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Racial Bias Suit Against Citibank
description: Two Citibank employees filed a racial discrimination lawsuit against their employer on Friday, contending that racist messages that were sent through the company's electronic interoffice mail system had caused them emotional distress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SLUTSKY, BERNICE
description: SLUTSKY-Bernice. 3/15/23-2/19/ 95. Two long lonely years have passed since you were taken from us. But your intelligence, vitality and love live on in me, your children and grandchildren. You are lovingly remembered everyday. Daddy, Larry, Richie, Jessica, Erica, Matthew, Daniel.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Under Pressure, Chief Resigns at WMX
description: Soros Fund Management has won Round 1 in its fight to revamp WMX Technologies Inc., the sprawling waste management company with shrinking profits.

title: Stars Come and Go, but NBC's 'Law and Order' Plugs Away, Just Getting Stronger
description: Nothing has ever been what it seems on ''Law and Order,'' NBC's critically acclaimed crime drama. Murderers turn out to be victims, victims to be accomplices. Motives are morally murky. The show's regular characters are often fallible, misguided or just plain wrong.

title: Competition Is Set For Dairy Queen
description: International Dairy Queen Inc. said yesterday that it had placed its account in review after 35 years at Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Zaire's Military Reported to Arm Rwandan Exiles to Fight Rebels
description: The Zairian Government has stepped up a campaign to arm Hutu guerrillas living among the largest population of Rwandan refugees still in Zaire, effectively making human shields of tens of thousands of refugees, according to diplomats and international relief workers.

title: From Pollsters in Britain, A Cry in the Wilderness
description: LONDON  Something once thought essential has all but vanished from British politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the growth in financial programming on television referred incorrectly to one new outlet. WBIS is a broadcast station, Channel 31 in New York; it is not strictly a cable channel.

title: Sun Microsystems Tightens Review
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., the computer company in Mountain View, Calif., has narrowed a review of its account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $70 million, to five finalists. The San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson, a unit of WPP Group that had handled the account for two years, was among several semifinalists eliminated last week.

title: Lehman's Chief Got a 34% Raise
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. paid its chairman and chief executive $6.7 million in cash and stock in 1996, 34 percent more than the $5 million it awarded him in 1995, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Hewlett-Packard Profit Up 15%, Exceeding Estimates
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose more than 15 percent, exceeding a consensus forecast of Wall Street analysts, who had expected the company's results to be flat.

title: Logging and Landslides
description: Intense winter storms in 1996 and 1997 have caused landslides all over Oregon, Washington, Idaho and California that have killed at least five people, destroyed spawning streams for endangered salmon, contaminated public water supplies and caused other havoc.

title: Mets' Lefty Is Full of Potential and Pranks
description: A few days before the Mets' spring training camp officially began last week, the pace around the pristine diamonds here was quiet, even still.

title: 2 Radio Deals For $1.6 Billion To Create Giant
description: In two deals worth a total of more than $1.6 billion, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the leveraged buyout firm, and the Evergreen Media Corporation agreed today to form the nation's largest independent radio broadcaster. The two companies plan to merge their radio interests and then buy the 10 stations owned by Viacom Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, SIDNEY
description: ROBBINS-Sidney. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Hts, NY mourns the untimely passing of our beloved member Sidney L. Robbins and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Beatrice and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Philip Adler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTHRIE, HENRY B.
description: GUTHRIE-Henry B. The Board of Directors of the Camille and Henry Dreyfus Foundation records with deep sorrow the death of our distinguished colleague on February 12, 1997. He served as a member of the Board since the Foundation was established, in 1946. As chairman of the Board for several years, he provided critical guidance in developing the Foundation's approach to its mission of supporting chemistry research and education. We will greatly miss his sound judgment and wise counsel.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TIFFANY JACKSON, a 25-year-old soprano from New Haven, didn't own quite the right dress to wear for her New York debut this Sunday at Town Hall until RITA ASEN, the managing director of the Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra, which will accompany Miss Jackson, was struck with inspiration.

title: Will Patients Be Paid?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accusations Roil Plan on Ownership of South Africa's Wine Industry
description: CHARGES that the South African wine industry profited from the use of forced labor under apartheid have spurred talk of boycotts in Britain and efforts in Johannesburg to block the privatization of South Africa's largest winegrowers' cooperative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITWIN, JOAN
description: LITWIN-Joan of Little Silver, on Feb 17, 1997. Beloved wife of Gordon N. Litwin. Devoted mother of Richard, Abby Mooney and Peter. Dear sister of Harriet Goldsmith. Loving mother-in-law of Michael Mooney and Christina Litwin, nee Berti, and adored grandmother of Matthew, Andrew, Sophie and Perry. Memorial service at Monmouth Reform Temple on Hance Road in Tinton Falls, NJ on Sunday, Feb 23, 1997 at 3:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Valerie Fund's Children's Cancer Center at Monmouth Medical Center. Her family will be at home for visitors in Little Silver on Wednesday and Thursday evening from 7-9 PM.

title: Head of Senate Judiciary Panel Reconsiders A.B.A. Advisory Role
description: Senator Orrin Hatch, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said today that he was considering ending the role of the American Bar Association in advising the Senate about candidates for Federal judgeships.

title: A Court for Addicts
description: Drug cases are flooding New York's criminal justice system, clogging the courts and crowding the prisons with nonviolent offenders who might do better with mandatory treatment instead of mandatory sentences. New York City is trying to ease the situation with a drug treatment court in Brooklyn that follows the promising example of similar courts in some 200 jurisdictions around the country.

title: Safer Lamp Than Halogen Is Coming to Dorms
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDANSKY, LILLIAN
description: RUDANSKY-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Mordecai Rudensky, loving mother of Dr. Sheldon and Mary, Raphael, and Judith and Dr. Maximilian Goldsmith. Survived by ten grandchildren and twentytwo great-grandchildren. Dear sister of Mollie Ginsburg, Sarah Arky and Dr. William Rubin. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30 AM Thurs.

title: In the TV Wars, Winners, Losers and Tantrums
description: DEFINING VISION

title: Site Sought As Memorial For Helmsley
description: During Harry Helmsley's life, his name was emblazoned across some of Manhattan's best-known hotels and office buildings. Now, after his death, the Helmsley name is seeking a new home, among New York City's major cultural institutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYCKMAN, WILLIAM T.
description: DYCKMAN-William T. The Board of Directors of Parsons Brinckerhoff Inc. mourns the loss of William T. Dyckman, our colleague and friend, who died February 14 at the age of 79. Bill Dyckman's career with Parsons Brinckerhoff spanned nearly 50 years. He served the company as partner, senior vice president, and chairman of the board, and directed the firm's efforts on numerous highway and transit projects. We extend our condolences to his wife, the former Ruth C. Duff, of Peekskill; his son, Warren Duff Dyckman of Peekskill; his daughter, Christine Dyckman Attardo of Ridgefield, Conn; and his six grandchildren. Board of Directors Parsons Brinckerhoff Inc.

title: Miller Freeman Expands
description: Miller Freeman Inc., the biggest organizers of trade shows at the Jacob K. Javits Center and in the nation, is expanding its operations in New York City, company officials said yesterday.

title: South Africa's Ugly Rugby
description: The image of rugby as a sport that could help reunite South Africans took a blow this week when television news played a tape of someone said to be the coach of the national rugby team in an obscenity-filled outburst, repeatedly referring to black Government officials with a racial slur.

title: 2 Agencies Clear a Doctor
description: Dr. Eric Braverman, the Somerset County physician who promoted alternative medicine on the radio until his license was suspended in New Jersey last year, has been cleared to practice in New York and Pennsylvania -- for now.

title: Delaney Kiphuth, 78, Athletic Director at Yale
description: Delaney Kiphuth, a former director of athletics at Yale and one of the first administrators of the Ivy League, died on Feb. 12 at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYWARD, JOYCE HELENA
description: HAYWARD-Joyce Helena, at her home in London on Feb 17. Beloved mother of Anthony and Verena, and her grandchildren Nicholas, Jessica, Nina, Simon, Emma and Jeremy. A memorial service will be arranged in London.

title: INSIDE
description: Starr Plays Down His Move

title: Justices Say Ban on Bias Forbids Retaliation, Even Against Ex-Employees
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Federal law protected workers from retaliation for filing complaints about discrimination on the job, even if the retaliation takes the form of a bad job recommendation after the worker is no longer employed.

title: Only Two Arbitrations Left
description: One salary arbitration case was heard yesterday and one was settled, leaving only two players on the hearing schedule. If the cases of Bill Risley of Toronto (today) and Rey Sanchez of the Chicago Cubs (Friday) are heard, arbitrators will have decided six cases this year, two fewer than the previous low of eight in 1995.

title: Flood of Dominicans Lets Some Enter U.S. by Fraud
description: The American mainland is 850 miles away, but the United States Government likes to call its consulates in places like this the front line in the struggle against illegal immigration.

title: Christopher Pettit Dies at 51; Ex-President of Lehman Bros.
description: T. Christopher Pettit, an investment banker who resigned last year as president of Lehman Brothers after disagreements over the direction of the company, died on Saturday near Windham, Me. He was 51.

title: Fogler and His Trio Are Leading the Gamecocks Toward Tournament
description: Eddie Fogler, a miracle man, the coach who has massaged and crafted the South Carolina basketball program back into one of the nation's elite, spent three varsity seasons at guard in the late 1960's at the University of North Carolina. Then he toiled there as an assistant under Coach Dean Smith for 15 more years.

title: Spinoff From Digital to Make Software Tools
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation plans to announce today that it is setting up an independent company, Tracepoint Technology Inc. to produce software development tools. The tools will be used to produce programs for computers using the Intel Corporation's Pentium microprocessors and the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 and Windows NT operating systems.

title: Fabri-Centers Agrees to Pay $3 Million to Settle Charges
description: Fabri-Centers of America Inc., which owns more than 900 stores across the country, agreed to pay $3.3 million yesterday to settle Federal charges that it had misled investors by overstating its earnings right before it sold securities in 1992 and for the next nine months.

title: Remembering an Italian Mother Just as She Would Like
description: MARTIN SCORSESE can direct, produce, act, provoke, inspire and charm. His mother, Catherine Scorsese, could do all that and more: she could cook.

title: It Could Make Any Groundhog Smug
description: The un-winter that has left New York largely bereft of the snow that buried the region last year continued yesterday, this time delighting New Yorkers with spring-like temperatures in the middle of February and making certain groundhogs look very good this year.

title: Senator Glenn Is Expected To Step Down
description: Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat and former astronaut who was the first American to orbit Earth, is expected to announce on Thursday that he will not seek re-election to a fifth term next year.

title: ENRON SELLING PIPELINE PARTNERSHIP TO KINDER MORGAN
description: Kinder Morgan Inc., a Houston-based investment company, said yesterday that it had purchased the Enron Liquids Pipeline Company for $40 million from the Enron Corporation. Enron Liquids Pipeline is 15 percent owner, operator and general partner of Enron Liquids Pipeline L.P., which owns three pipeline systems. The master limited partnership will be renamed Kinder Morgan Energy Partners L.P. and will continue trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The units of the partnership closed yesterday at $42.50, up $1.375.

title: Pessimism Is Increasing Over Labor Nominee's Prospects for Confirmation
description: Some White House officials are increasingly pessimistic that Alexis Herman can be confirmed as Secretary of Labor, fearing that her nomination will be a victim of the swelling Democratic fund-raising controversy, Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IKE
description: LEVINE-Ike. The Partners and staff of Stephen I. Soble and Company are in deep mourning over the loss of our long-time partner and friend, Ike Levine. He was a great leader of our firm and a close personal friend to most of our clientele over the last twenty years. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife Arlene, his children Lori and Glenn, and Mindy and Randy and to his grandchildren Bryan and Michael.

title: Supermarkets Are Few, Stores Many
description: New York's supermarket industry, which is dominated by mid-sized stores like C-Town, Bravo and Key Food and local chains like Sloan's and D'Agostino, includes more food stores per capita than most major cities. But 23 percent of New Yorkers shop for food outside the city and 11 percent of city residents' grocery dollars, about $1.5 billion a year, are spent in suburban stores, according to a report last June by the Manhattan Borough President's office.

title: Ingalls Wins Citizens Telecom
description: The Citizens Telecom unit of Citizens Utilities in Stamford, Conn., said yesterday that it had named Ingalls Advertising in Boston to handle its account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $17 million. Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, a unit of BDDP Group, parted ways with Citizens in January after handling the account for only three months. Ingalls, part of Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, was selected after a brief review that also included Houston Herstek Favat in Boston; both had participated in a previous review that ended with Wells Rich being selected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHESTACK, ALICE
