description: SHESTACK-Alice. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our longtime member. We extend condolences to the family. Services Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Thursday, February 20, 10:00 AM. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Why Is Ogilvy's Boss One of The Few Women at the Top?
description: Decades ago, the legendary adman David Ogilvy sought to raise consciousness at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide by asserting: ''The consumer is not a moron. She is your wife.'' Today he would add, ''She is also your boss.''

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SEWAGE STAYS PUT -- Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have put off a city plan to dump 560 million gallons of raw sewage into New York Harbor. B3.

title: Nynex Submits Long-Distance Plan
description: Nynex Corporation submitted a preliminary filing to New York regulators yesterday in an effort to provide long-distance phone service in New York State.

title: In Surprise Confrontation During Visit, President Is Criticized on Welfare Law
description: In a tense and unexpected twist to an event that had been arranged to promote his administration's welfare policies, President Clinton was assailed within the walls of one of Manhattan's most socially active churches yesterday for embracing a law that mandates massive reductions in social assistance rolls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MORRIS H.
description: LEVINE-Morris H., CPA, of Merrick, NY and Coral Gables, FL, on February 17, 1997 after a long and courageous fight against Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband for 60 years of Evelyn (nee Neilinger). Special brother and brotherin-law to Aaron Levine, Francine Levine, and Sam Blum and the late Helen Blum. Loving father of Dr. Arlene Goldsmith, NYC, Dr. Richard Levine, Miami, FL and the late Howard N. Levine of Lawrence, NY. Devoted father-in-law to Mark Goldsmith, Faith Levine and Jill Haber. Extraordinary grandfather to Kelly and Gwen Levine, Scott Goldsmith, Jennifer Goldsmith Adams. Ben Adams, and Jason, Julie and Alison Levine. A giant of a man in business and in family. Services will be held at The Riverside, West 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, February 19, 1:15 PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, tributes may be made to New Alternatives for Children at 37 West 26th Street, New York, NY 10010.

title: Catera Ad Pulled By Cadillac
description: The General Motors Corporation has pulled a TV commercial for its small Cadillac Catera because of concerns that the ad might offend women.

title: Earthbound All, in the Moonlight
description: The Colorado Ballet is a company of sleek, strong classical dancers with a large complement of Russian-trained staff members and performers. Christopher Wheeldon is a dancer with the New York City Ballet who trained and performed early on with the Royal Ballet of England. Out of that promising mix of ingredients has come an impressive new staging of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' presented on Sunday afternoon at the Auditorium Theater here.

title: When Bodies Collide, Look for Beukeboom
description: When someone suggested that Jeff Beukeboom and Brian Leetch were like two sides of the same coin, Beukeboom seemed amused to be so closely linked with a Norris Trophy candidate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the private off-campus residences of college and university heads misstated the location of an incident several years ago in which the chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley was threatened by an intruder. It was the on-campus residence of Chancellor Chang-Lin Tien, not his off-campus home.

title: Man Is Linked to 8 Crown Hts. Burglaries
description: A 29-year-old man with a lengthy criminal record and a history of parole violations was arrested and charged with breaking into several brownstones in Brooklyn and attacking at least four people who were at home when he struck, the police said yesterday.

title: A General in Mexico's Drug War Is Dismissed on Narcotics Charges
description: The army general who headed Mexico's national drug agency has been dismissed from the armed forces and faces imminent arrest on charges that he collaborated with one of Mexico's most notorious drug barons, Defense Minister Enrique Cervantes Aguirre announced today.

title: Cowboy at U.N.: A Smile and a Lasso
description: William Blaine Richardson spent his first day at work at the United Nations today and quickly distinguished himself as the politician he was until just five days ago: He went to the cafeteria and worked the room as if it were a Rotary Club luncheon.

title: Librarian Speaks Out on 'Primary Colors' Suit
description: When the book ''Primary Colors: A Novel of Politics'' was released last year, Daria Carter-Clark's friends and co-workers urged her to read it. Ms. Carter-Clark knew that the fictional book included a section based on the adult literacy program that she operates in central Harlem. But she could not understand why people who had read the book refused to tell her what it said.

title: Gore Informs Labor Of New Restrictions On U.S. Contractors
description: Vice President Al Gore told A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders today that the Clinton Administration would soon issue regulations imposing new restrictions on Federal contracts to companies that violate laws on occupational safety, overtime and union organizing.

title: Jet Pilot Knew Chase Target Was Airliner
description: The pilot of an F-16 fighter jet that came too close to a commercial airliner off the New Jersey coast two weeks ago had actually identified it as a passenger jet miles in advance, but continued to chase the Boeing 727 as an intruder into his airspace, Air Force officials said today.

title: Heinz U.S.A. Picks DDB Chicago Unit
description: Heinz U.S.A., a division of the H. J. Heinz Company in Pittsburgh, yesterday named the DDB Needham Chicago unit of Omnicom Group as its lead agency for advertising, handling brands like Heinz ketchup and Heinz Home Style gravies. Those brands had been handled for the last year by Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh, also owned by Omnicom, which continues on new products and special assignments. Billings were not disclosed. DDB Needham Chicago, which will also create a Heinz brand campaign, was selected without a review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, DOROTHY
description: WOLFF-Dorothy. Beloved mother of Joan (Joseph) Marks, Richard (Fran) Wolff and Barbara (Louis) Eisenpresser. Cherished grandmother of Susan Hirsch and Ruth Levenson, Robert & Michael, Lisa and Jennifer. Loving great grandmother of Rikki Wolff and Julia Levenson. Service 12 noon Wednesday, Feb. 19, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the National Alzheimers Assoc, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Ste. 1000, Chicago, IL. 60611-1676.

title: U.S. Company Says It Erred In Sales to Russian Arms Lab
description: The chairman of Silicon Graphics Inc. said today that his company ''made some serious judgmental errors'' when it shipped two small supercomputer systems last month to a Russian laboratory that designs nuclear weapons and performs computer simulations of nuclear explosions.

title: Nobel Scientist Pleads Guilty to Abusing Boy
description: A leading researcher at the National Institutes of Health who shared the Nobel Prize in 1976 for discoveries involving degenerative brain diseases pleaded guilty today to sexually abusing one of dozens of Micronesian boys he had brought to live with him in his Maryland home.

title: Circling the Wagons With a Bid for Great Western
description: For a chief executive, Charles R. Rinehart has long been unusually glum about the prospects of the company he runs. His new recipe for success: buy another company that is in just as bad a position and dismiss thousands of redundant employees.

title: Emily Hahn, Chronicler of Her Own Exploits, Dies at 92
description: Emily Hahn, an early feminist and a prolific author who wrote 54 books and more than 200 articles for The New Yorker, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 92, said her daughter, Carola Boxer Vecchio.

title: Coffee Prices Take Sharp Fall As Strikes End in Colombia
description: Coffee prices tumbled yesterday as an end to a week-old strike in Colombia erased the threat of export delays from that nation, the world's second-largest grower.

title: P.C. Is Nothing More Than Letters Here
description: The gloves come off early in ''Stonewall Jackson's House,'' Jonathan Reynolds's caustic comic tirade against political orthodoxy. A woebegone black guide leading a group through the haphazardly restored home of the Confederate general suddenly stops the tour to ask a well-to-do white couple from Ohio if she can come home with them, as their slave.

title: When 'Elegance' Meant Denying a Jewish Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABER, ANNA
description: GRABER-Anna Rose on February 18, 1997. Beloved wife of Sidney, cherished mother of Stuart, devoted sister of Sarita Sack and Joseph Appledorf. Adored aunt and great aunt.

title: Pilots in Control
description: Eight years ago, machinists at Eastern Airlines went out on strike, and its pilots honored the picket line. The nation's fifth largest carrier was shut down. The management of Eastern and its parent, Texas Air, encouraged President George Bush to resist convening an emergency mediation board and imposing a 60-day return-to-work cooling-off period.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Albright Question
description: At a dinner party last Saturday night, I found myself seated among some of the most loyal of Clinton enthusiasts in this most loyally Democratic of cities. But when I raised the question of Madeleine Albright's sudden discovery of her roots, there was only eye-rolling and sarcasm. One prominent Jewish friend of both the Clintons and the Secretary of State didn't hesitate to characterize Ms. Albright's professed ignorance about her past: ''She didn't want to know from Jewish.''

title: In Brooklyn, Passing the Torch of Success
description: THE lights in the cavernous freezer dimmed. The big fans fell silent.

title: Over the Rainbow: Starks Seals Victory at Buzzer
description: It was the kind of shot that kids dream about when they are growing up. Your team is down by 2 points. The ball is in your hands for a 3-pointer. The buzzer sounds. And the ball swishes through the net for victory.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AL PACINO, who used the Globe Theater in London, the new replica of Shakespeare's original theater, as a set for his documentary ''Looking for Richard,'' will continue that association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, SELIG S
description: BURROWS-Selig S. Age 83. Cherished husband of the late Gladys. Died 2/16 peacefully in his sleep after a long and valiant struggle with lung disease. Adored father of Kenneth, Jonathan, & Patricia Burrows, loving father-in-law of Milt Wolfson & Erica Jong. Grandfather extraordinaire to Jessica, Jordan, Jody, Tracy and Molly. Brother of the late Abe Burrows and the late Shirley Alter. Brotherin-law of Doris and Mel Sirow, Bobbie and Gene Wells, Taube & Manny Meltzer and Paul Alter. His spirit and courage, his wit, warmth and boundless generosity will be felt for generations. Services at 11:15 A.M., Wednesday, February 19, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: COOPER BUYING AVON RUBBER TIRE UNIT FOR $110.4 MILLION
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, based in Findlay, Ohio, agreed yesterday to buy the tire unit of Avon Rubber P.L.C. of Britain for $110.4 million, giving Cooper its first overseas tire factory. Cooper Tire said it bought Avon's complete tire business, which includes a manufacturing plant in Melksham, England, where Avon has headquarters; distribution companies in France, Germany and Switzerland, and the right to use the Avon name on tires, inner tubes and retreading materials. Avon Rubber described the move as a key part of its strategy to concentrate on other auto parts. It said profit at its auto parts businesses had risen 46 percent in the last two fiscal years.

title: Tastes Like Parmesan, Feels Like Gouda
description: A NEW cheese, Parrano, has arrived from the Netherlands, and it has all the makings of a winner. It incorporates the alluringly nutty taste of Parmesan with the pliant, versatile texture of young Gouda, making it easier than Parmesan to slice, shred and melt.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: When 'Elegance' Meant Denying a Jewish Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: Low-Fat Haagen-Dazs

title: Guilty Plea in Double Murder
description: A Teaneck man charged with capital murder in the 1994 death of his two children pleaded guilty yesterday just before opening statements in his trial were to begin. Avi Kostner, 52, told Judge Jonathan Harris in Superior Court in Hackensack that he killed his children, Geri Beth, 12, and Ryan, 10, rather than let their mother inflict on them the emotional trauma of conversion from Judaism to Christianity, his lawyer, Cathy L. Waldor, said. The mother, Lynn Mison, won custody of the children when the couple divorced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, HELEN M. (NEE CARNS)
description: GRAHAM-Helen M. (nee Carns), of Lynbrook, L.I. Formerly of Malverne, LI, February 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Zev. Loving mother of Eileen O'Donohue, Bernadette McTigue, Kathryn Hawkins, Robert B., Edwin and John. Cherished sister of Mary Curry. Dear grandmother of 30 & great-grandmother of 21. Family will receive friends Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook. Mass of Christian burial Friday, 9:45 A.M., at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne.

title: Stadium to Get Ashe's Name
description: The United States Tennis Association will hold a news conference today to announce that the new stadium at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center will be named for Arthur Ashe.

title: Cablevision Hangs On to SportsChannel
description: The harmonious partnership that acquired Madison Square Garden for $1 billion two years ago developed a major fissure yesterday when Cablevision Systems unexpectedly refused to hand the ITT Corporation one-half of SportsChannel as partial payment to help equalize their joint venture.

title: An Unlikely Legislator Overcomes
description: The seventh try was the lucky charm for Peter F. Leonard. After six failures to win election to the New Hampshire House of Representatives, he won a vacant seat last November by a handful of votes.

title: In a Pianist's Brahms, A Chopinesque Esprit
description: No one would call Brahms's piano works rarities, yet they make comparatively infrequent appearances on recital programs, and all-Brahms programs like the one Helene Grimaud offered on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall are few and far between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORA, GAUDENCIA
description: CORA-Gaudencia, on 2/17/97. An active member of the P.R.-Hispanic Community. Loving mother of Lorenzo Cabrera, Maria Rivera, Maria Velez and Suleika CabreraDrinane. Also survived by 14 grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Reposing at The Abbey (Campbell Bldg.) 1076 Madison Ave (81st St), Wed 2-9PM. Funeral mass Thursday 10AM, St. Cecelia's Church (E. 106 St.).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, GERTRUDE
description: SHERMAN - Gertrude, 95, of Southbury, CT., died suddenly on Feb. 16. Beloved wife of Monroe, adored mother of Susan and the late Nancy Rosenberg, sister of Edward Horn, cherished motherin-law of Dr Lawrence Rosenberg, treasured grandmother of Connie and Mark Hochman, Elizabeth Rosenberg, Eric Rosenberg, Mark Rosenberg & Andrea Needleman, beloved great grandmother of Sarah, Amelia, Jenna and Julian. Precious friend, ebullient and flaming spirit, compassionate, wise soul. Services at Pomperaug Woods, Southbury CT., at noon Thursday, February 20. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood.

title: Lebanon Seizes Japanese Radicals Sought in Terror Attacks
description: Lebanese authorities said today that they had detained as many as six suspected members of the Japanese Red Army guerrilla group whose presence in the Bekaa region of Lebanon has been the subject of complaints by the United States and Japan for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROSE
description: MILLER-Rose. On February 11. Beloved wife of Sam; devoted mother of Audrey and Ronnie Korth and Jerry and Isobel Miller; dear grandmother of Stacy and John Healy, Evan, Michele and Nicole; loving great grandmother of Shawn and the new arrival Sabrina Rose. Your light will always be with us-to guide our way and keep us warm.

title: Stocks Climb; Dow at High Of 7,067.46
description: Continuing to defy the predictions of even the most optimistic bulls, the stock market extended its early-year rally yesterday, rising sharply.

title: Theater in Review
description: Three Lovers in a Triangle

title: When 'Elegance' Meant Denying a Jewish Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIOGAS, ARTHUR
description: ZIOGAS-Arthur. The New York Chapter of The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International express their sorrow at the passing of Arthur Ziogas father of Alexandra Ziogas, our esteemed Executive Director. To his family and loved ones we extend our deepest sympathy. Robert B. Obernier President

title: Delving Into the Mind of a Closer
description: PERHAPS one lazy spring day here at Legends Field, Mariano Rivera will sit down with Rich (Goose) Gossage for a power chat about power pitching. The Yankees' new instructional aide has 22 years worth of bullpen tales for the defending champions' chosen closer. He would be happy to begin with October 1978.

title: Shares of Centennial Technologies Fall 81%
description: Shares in Centennial Technologies Inc. fell 81 percent today after the company said it had defaulted on lending agreements and warned it might not be able to pay its bills.

title: KEYCORP TO SELL WYOMING OPERATION FOR $135 MILLION
description: The financial-services giant Keycorp said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Keybank National Association in Wyoming to Community First Bankshares Inc. for $135 million. The Keybank operations in the deal include 28 branches, $1 billion of deposits and loans of about $850 million, of which Keycorp will retain $350 million. The branches currently employ 350 people. Community First, a bank based in Fargo, N.D., will offer employment to all workers at the acquired branches. Shares of Community First climbed $1.50, to $30.50, on the news. Cleveland-based Keycorp's shares rose 62.5 cents, to $55.625.

title: Mr. Stoddard's Gift
description: The death last week of Thomas Stoddard, at 48, has prematurely robbed America's gay rights movement of one of its most valuable champions.

title: Starr Says Job Change Is Not Linked to State of Investigation
description: Concerned that his resignation announcement could wound the Whitewater investigation, Kenneth W. Starr today began a public relations effort to dispel any perception that he had decided to wind down his inquiry without bringing charges against the President or First Lady.

title: Fatal Miscommunication
description: It seems inconceivable, even to jaded New Yorkers, that an 8-year-old child could have been missing for more than a year without someone from the public school system or the child-welfare bureaucracy taking notice. But that seems to have happened in the case of Justina Morales, a third grader who was apparently beaten to death 14 months ago by her mother's boyfriend.

title: Campaign Finance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, MARY HURLEY
description: KEEGAN-Mary Hurley. Wife of the late Peter V. Keegan. Mother of Patricia Keegan Peck and Kathleen Keegan Mattessich, and grandmother of Adam R. Mattessich. Sister of Edward Hurley and Margaret Weatherly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., 81 St., Wednesday. Funeral Mass at St. Elizabeth of Hungary Church, 211 East 83 St., Thursday, at 9:30 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Retired Clergy Fund, 1011 First Avenue, New York City 10022.

title: Wanted: Pro Players Who Think
description: ONCE upon a time, before Isiah Thomas developed into a whole basketball player, his first interest in his first few years with the Detroit Pistons in the National Basketball Association was to prove, as he would recall, ''that I belonged.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, ETHEL SCHNIEWIND
description: PRATT-Ethel Schniewind, on February 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sherman. Loving mother of Ethel M. Woolverton, Hiram Edward Manville, III (Nancy), Maria Helene de Laire, Deming P. Holleran (Romer), and the late Sandra E. Manville. Devoted sister of Margaret S. Stanley, Emily S. Walker, the late Helen S. Kerr and Henry E. Schniewind (Helen). Grandmother of thirteen, and great-grandmother of seven. Memorial services Saturday, 11 A.M. at St. John's of Lattingtown. Contributions may be made to the Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club, or a charity of your choice. For information, Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, NY.

title: Israel Leader on a Tightrope Over Jerusalem Housing Plan
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has had little respite from crises in his eight months in office, and no sooner had he returned from Washington than a new one loomed -- this time in the form of a demand from his right-wing allies that he begin construction of a new housing project in East Jerusalem.

title: Apple Official Resigns Amid Reshuffling
description: Marco Landi, the executive who was Apple Computer Inc.'s chief operating officer until the company reshuffled its top management earlier this month, has resigned, the company said late today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, MICHAEL
description: GOLDBLATT-Michael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael Goldblatt, associated with The Times from 1955 until retiring in 1990.

title: When 'Elegance' Meant Denying a Jewish Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Natural-Gas Seller To Expand Electric Business
description: The NGC Corporation, a fast-growing seller of natural gas, said yesterday that it was expanding its foothold in electricity marketing by agreeing to acquire Destec Energy, a major operator of independent power plants, for roughly $1.27 billion.

title: Theater in Review
description: Back to Arabia

title: The Congressional Sandbox
description: ''It's very high school,'' says Representative Michael Forbes of New York, describing the petty humiliations heaped on him by some powerful and supposedly grown-up G.O.P. colleagues in the six weeks since he became the first Republican to say he would not vote for Newt Gingrich as House Speaker. That is unfair to high school students. The snubs aimed at Mr. Forbes have more the flavor of a kindergartener's tantrum.

title: Japan's Global Trade Surplus Declines
description: Japan's trade surplus plunged 91.7 percent in January from the same month a year ago, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, IRVING
description: KORN-Irving. The Palm Beach Chapter of Women's American ORT mourns the passing of Irving Korn, husband of our esteemed member Lee Korn. He has been a longtime generous supporter of our organization.

title: Pilot Knew Target Was Commercial Jet
description: The pilot of an F-16 fighter jet that came too close to a commercial airliner off New Jersey two weeks ago had actually identified the plane as a passenger jet but continued to chase it as an intruder into his airspace, Air Force officials said yesterday.

title: Heart-Disease Progress Linked to Treatments
description: Medical and surgical treatments for heart patients have been much more important in the decline in heart-disease deaths in recent years than widespread changes in diet and other means of basic prevention, a new statistical study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARD, IDA
description: WEINGARD-Ida. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Dear mother of Barbara, Robert. Dear sister. Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Services Wed., 12 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIANNINI, SERGIO
description: GIANNINI-Sergio. On Feb. 16, 1997. Native of Rome, Italy. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee McCormack). Treasured father of Maria Adele Urciolo, Valeria Persons & Carla Francesca Giannini. Loving grandfather of Andrea, Elena and Claudia Urciolo. Dear brother of Massimo Severo, Vittoria and Luciano Giannini. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Saint Gabriel's Church, on Thursday, 10 A.M. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Casino Development Panel Tightens Its Property Rules
description: Since casino gambling started in Atlantic City two decades ago, it has been touted as the key to the city's revival. In fact, the State Legislature imposed a tax on casino revenue to pay for new housing for the city's predominantly poor residents.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR more than 50 years, Georges de Latour Private Reserve cabernet sauvignon from Beaulieu Vineyard has been the benchmark by which all California cabernets are judged.

title: Many Prefer Charter Schools
description: If the Princeton Charter School is any indication, New Jersey's fledgling charter schools will not suffer from an excess of empty seats when they open in September. The Princeton school, the first of the 17 to finish accepting applications, said yesterday that it had received 184 applications for its 72 places. The school will hold a lottery Friday to select its students. Charter schools are organized and run by parents or community groups but financed by taxpayers. Officials at other schools also reported high demand.

title: A Surgeon Goes on Trial In a Case Like a Movie
description: When the dragnet finally closed on Richie Ramos five years ago, the police had to take a hard second look before putting on the handcuffs.

title: After Whitman's Criticism, Sewage Dumping Is Put Off
description: After a four-day barrage of criticism from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that they would delay at least until next winter a city plan to dump 560 million gallons of raw sewage into New York Harbor while repairing valves in a Manhattan sewage pumping station.

title: Not Very English
description: To The Living Section:

title: Parcells Quickly Makes His Presence Felt
description: In one week at the controls, Bill Parcells has made sweeping changes in the way the Jets do things. He has even departed from his highly successful style by refusing to give his top assistants the titles of offensive and defensive coordinators.

title: U.S. WILL PROPOSE ARMS REDUCTIONS IN CENTRAL EUROPE
description: In a significant move aimed at placating Russian opposition to NATO's planned expansion eastward, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will take to Moscow new proposals to reduce conventional weapons sharply in Central and Eastern Europe, senior American and alliance officials said today.

title: Personal Health
description: DENTAL sealants, properly applied and periodically replenished, can eliminate decay in the chewing surfaces of teeth. Sealants, the plastic coatings applied to permanent molars, are second only to fluorides in preventing tooth decay over all and are more effective than fluorides in protecting the chewing surfaces of molars, where most cavities occur.

title: APPLIED INDUSTRIAL TO ACQUIRE INVETECH FOR $83 MILLION
description: Applied Industrial Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it intended to buy the privately held Invetech Company for $83 million in cash and stock. Invetech, based in Detroit, makes bearings and mechanical and electrical drive systems and has annual sales of $314 million, according to Applied Industrial. Applied Industrial, of Cleveland, distributes bearings, mechanical and electrical drive systems, industrial rubber products and fluid power components. Its shares rose $2.25, to $31.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: WHITETREE ACCEPTS $72 MILLION BID FROM ASCEND
description: Ascend Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Whitetree Inc. for about $72 million in stock. Ascend, which is based in Alameda, Calif., and makes products to link computer networks, will issue about 1.1 million of its shares for all the stock of closely held Whitetree. Ascend's shares closed down $1.875, at $62.375, in Nasdaq trading. Whitetree, based in Mountain View, Calif., developed so-called adaptable switching, which works with two different technologies for sending electronic data. The acquisition will provide ''key technology and product capabilities'' to Ascend, the company said.

title: Bond Prices Slip a Bit In Light Day
description: Treasury prices edged lower in thin trading yesterday, with many investors reluctant to buy ahead of today's report on consumer prices.

title: Japanese Stocks Advance
description: Stocks finished higher here today. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues advanced 128.37 points, or a little more than two-thirds of 1 percent, to close at 18,599.12. On Tuesday, the Nikkei index lost 279.90 points.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Talmudic Scholar's Son

title: Bronx Melee Erupts as Firefighters Try to Stop a Fight
description: A confrontation between two women over a robbery on a Bronx street last night turned into a violent clash with firefighters who tried to break up the dispute, only to be pelted with rocks, bottles and garbage cans.

title: AT&T, BELL ATLANTIC AND DSC SETTLE ANTITRUST SUIT
description: The AT&T Corporation, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the DSC Communications Corporation said yesterday that they had settled claims related to an antitrust lawsuit brought against AT&T by Bell Atlantic and DSC in February 1996. Terms were not disclosed. Bell Atlantic and DSC, a telecommunications equipment company, filed the suit on Feb. 14, 1996, contending that AT&T had designed its telecommunications switches to prevent the connection of other manufacturers' equipment. The suit, which asked for nearly $3.5 billion in damages, also contended that AT&T sought to monopolize the markets for telecommunications equipment and software and for caller identification services. AT&T had maintained that it did not engage in anticompetitive activities. Separate claims by Bell Atlantic and DSC against Lucent Technologies Inc., the telecommunications equipment maker spun off by AT&T last year, are proceeding.

title: Cheers for Boston's Pie
description: To The Living Section:

title: PAIRGAIN TO BUY AVIDIA TO BROADEN NETWORKING LINE
description: Pairgain Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it would buy closely held Avidia Systems Inc. of Wallingford, Conn., for $94 million in stock, to help broaden its line of networking equipment. Pairgain, based in Tustin, Calif., said it would incorporate Avidia's technology into its own line of products that allow for faster connections over existing telecommunications networks. Avidia's products use asynchronous transfer mode technology that lets computers share information on a network. Pairgain's products use a competing technology called Ethernet. Pairgain announced the purchase after its shares closed at $40.25, up 25 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CANDIDATES UNITED, TO AN EXTENT -- Looking to stand out in a blurred and crowded field, the four Democratic mayoral prospects used a campaign forum to pummel Mayor Giuliani -- but not each other. B3.

title: Successors in Search of a New Mandate
description: For thousands of years, the Chinese have looked up to one overarching authority -- whether emperor or commissar -- to rule them with the ''mandate of heaven.''

title: Ashe's Name On Stadium Is an Ace
description: WHEN her mother told 10-year-old Camera Ashe that the new stadium for the United States Open tennis championships in Flushing Meadows would be named for her father, she didn't say a word.

title: Nielsen Alternative Gets Financing Help
description: Two big advertisers have agreed to help finance efforts to introduce a national television audience measurement system that is meant to compete against Nielsen Media Research. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Events: Talks on Architecture And African-American Art
description: Pei Retrospective

title: Union Chiefs Vote to Oppose Expansion of Free-Trade Pact Unless It Is Modified
description: Putting the labor movement on a potential collision course with President Clinton, A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders voted today to oppose extending the North American Free Trade Agreement to other countries unless it includes protections on labor and the environment that the Administration has previously rejected.

title: No Headline
description: ''All the guys don't hold back. They play like guys. Jake is very strong, and he pushes me and hits me -- elbows, hips, everything. I get angry and push back, and that's the point. It makes me tougher for games.''

title: 'Larry Flynt' Posters Stir Anger in France
description: PARIS  A movie poster showing a man nearly nude in a position suggesting crucifixion superimposed on the body of a woman was banned Wednesday in Versailles and was under legal attack in the rest of the France by outraged Catholics.

title: Winning Is Now Miami's Virtue
description: If this keeps up, they will have to take pro basketball off NBC and put it on the Home Shopping Network. In Dallas, Don Nelson is dealing players as if he were dealing a hand of poker. And then there is Pat Riley in Miami. Over the past 15 months, he has changed his roster the way Dennis Rodman changes his hair.

title: Arrests in Theft of Torches
description: For decades, two 750-pound brass torches stood in front of the old Atlantic City High School. In the summer of 1995, just before the opening of a new high school, the torches disappeared from a storage room in the old school's basement. But recently, photographs of the torches turned up in a catalogue for an Atlanta antiques auction. And late Tuesday, the chief of maintenance for the city Board of Education and an antiques dealer were arrested and charged with stealing the torches.

title: Jazzy Tapping On Camera and Onstage
description: Looking for a night out? The Jazz Tap Ensemble, with its percussive dancers performing to a live jazz trio, often in homage to old masters, should top any list this week.

title: UNITED BANKSHARES TO BUY FIRST PATRIOT BANKSHARES
description: United Bankshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the First Patriot Bankshares Corporation of Vienna, Va., for $39 million. United Bankshares, a banking company based in Parkersburg, W. Va., said the deal valued First Patriot at $17 a share. First Patriot's shares rose $1.50, to $16.25, in Nasdaq trading. United Bankshares' stock was unchanged at $33.50 a share.

title: Executive Changes
description: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO., New York, said Joachim H. von Roy had resigned as head of its European pharmaceutical business after disagreements over strategy. Mr. von Roy will be replaced by Samuel Hamad, the current chief of all pharmaceutical operations outside the United States and Europe, effective immediately.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BYRON JANIS was not the kind of child who dreaded the approach of his piano teachers. In fact, he followed one of them, Adele Marcus, to Dallas when she moved there, and on Saturday he will play in her honor at Carnegie Hall.

title: Real Estate Dynasty Is Nearing the End
description: A real estate dynasty that was founded on a handshake by Benjamin Swig and Jack Weiler during the Depression and that grew into a $1 billion empire, including some of the finest hotels and office buildings in New York and elsewhere, is expected to end this week with the sale of its most prestigious properties.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: 'Bleeding' Trees

title: German Insurer Allianz Has 10% Earnings Rise
description: Allianz A.G., German's largest insurer, said yesterday that its 1996 profit rose 10 percent, which was at the lower end of expectations. Allianz's net income was 2.2 billion marks ($1.3 billion), up from 2 billion marks in 1995.

title: Japan Rewards Borrowing, And the Yen Keeps Falling
description: There's a reason the Japanese yen comes across as the weakling of the currency markets these days: Japan, with its struggling economy, frail stock market and cheap funds, has become a place to borrow, not invest.

title: Compaq Takes a Gamble With Its New PC
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation plans to announce today that it is entering the market for personal computers priced less than $1,000 with a machine based on a new chip produced by the Cyrix Corporation.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Transforming Abstraction

title: Surging Carolina Keeps Wake Down
description: For much of this season the North Carolina Tar Heels have been haunted by a single memory, a home game against Maryland in which they blew a 22-point lead in the second half and lost.

title: Records Melt Like Snowmen in Springlike Warmth
description: Temperature records popped like Champagne corks around the metropolitan area yesterday, making dreamers giddy with fantasies of an early spring.

title: Ousted Employee Challenges Military's Policy on Homosexuals
description: When John Hoffman told his supervisor at the Air Reserve station in suburban Willow Grove last year that he was gay, it did not occur to him that he could be discharged from the Reserves and also lose his full-time civilian job as a mechanic on the base.

title: In Move Aimed at Helping Defector, North Korea to Get Food Aid
description: South Korea and the United States say they will provide $6 million and $10 million of food aid to North Korea, respectively, in actions that could help lead to a resolution of the impasse over a high-ranking North Korean defector.

title: Bonds Ease, Ignoring Good Price Data
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday, despite a report of consumer prices that showed inflation under control.

title: Player and League Share Growing Pains
description: Her knee pads, intensity and vocal presence are still her trademarks. But one thing has changed this season for Jennifer Rizzotti: she has learned what it's like to play for a loser.

title: Giuliani Names Campaign Chief
description: Fran Reiter, who has become one of the most loyal and trusted members of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's inner circle, was named yesterday as the manager of Mr. Giuliani's re-election campaign.

title: New Breed Takes the Helm in Beijing: Well-Educated Technocrats
description: The man anointed to follow in the footsteps of Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping to rule China in the coming years, Jiang Zemin, is a mild-mannered intellectual who likes to quote Lincoln and who would be the first leader in Chinese history with a college degree.

title: United Hospital Closing
description: The struggling United Hospital in Newark will close, putting some 900 health-care employees out of work, officials said yesterday. Under the plan, Children's Hospital -- a unit of United Hospital -- will move across town within the next week to Beth Israel Medical Center. Saint Barnabas Health Care System, which owns Beth Israel, paid United Hospital's parent company $13 million for its state license to run the children's hospital and three clinics, said Ronald J. Del Mauro, president of Saint Barnabas.

title: Report Foreign Guests? French Tempers Flare
description: Even by the standards of an angry, sullen France, an unusual uprising is in the making: hundreds of French actors, film directors and cartoonists have said they are ready to go to jail if a new immigration bill is passed.

title: Convictions Of 3 in Mob Overturned In Slayings
description: Saying that prosecutors withheld evidence that could have swayed the jury, a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday threw out the murder convictions of three men involved in the infamous internal Colombo crime family war from 1991 to 1993 in which 10 people were killed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a union offer to end the Detroit newspaper strike misstated the papers' financial condition. The management says that they have been profitable since the fourth quarter of 1996, not that they are expected to be profitable beginning in the spring.

title: Mobil Consolidates Media Account
description: The Mobil Corporation in Fairfax, Va., said yesterday that it had consolidated the media part of its domestic account, with billings estimated at $60 million, at Optimum Media in New York, the media services unit of DDB Needham Worldwide. The assignment had been split among Optimum, Arnold Communications in Boston and Grace & Rothschild in New York. The decision came after a review among the three agencies and the Western International Media unit of Interpublic Group in Los Angeles. DDB Needham is owned by Omnicom Group.

title: X-Rated Fraud Uses Internet To Bilk Users
description: In what law enforcement officials describe as a fraudulent new high-technology scheme, telephone and Internet marketers are joining with telecommunications companies in emerging nations to bilk unsuspecting consumers around the world.

title: Fed Eases Rules on Expansion And Product Offerings by Banks
description: The Federal Reserve approved new rules today that would make it easier for banks to offer new products and to acquire other financial institutions.

title: PAINE WEBBER PLANS INCLUDE MONEY-MANAGEMENT FIRM
description: The Paine Webber Group, whose stock has soared amid takeover speculation, told employees in an internal memo last week that it planned to remain independent. Buying a money-management firm is part of that strategy, according to the internal memo. ''Paine Webber will continue to seek ways to grow -- independently -- both internally and through acquisition,'' according to a memo dated Feb. 13 from the chairman, Donald Marron, and the president, Joseph Grano. ''We will continue to seek appropriate asset management acquisitions that fit the firm's strategic mix.'' The Trust Company of the West, a unit of the TCW Group, is one of the money-management firms Paine Webber has considered buying, people familiar with the firm said. A spokesman for Paine Webber declined to comment. Shares of Paine Webber, the fourth-largest United States brokerage firm, have risen 76 percent since October.

title: Deng Xiaoping: A Political Wizard Who Put China on the Capitalist Road
description: Like Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai before him, Deng Xiaoping was among the small group of revolutionary elders who fought as guerrillas for the Communist cause and then dominated the leadership of the People's Republic they proclaimed on Oct. 1, 1949.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about President Clinton's trip to New York City reversed the identifications of two men in some copies. Earl G. Graves, a magazine executive, was in the foreground, and Dr. James Forbes Jr., senior minister of Riverside Church, at the far right.

title: Villanova Brings St. John's Back to Earth
description: Villanova gave St. John's a reality check tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Prices Rise, But Earnings Fall Sharply

title: Army Engineer Gave Military Data to Israel
description: A mechanical engineer working for the Army has said he ''inadvertently'' gave classified military information on Patriot missiles and armored military vehicles to Israeli officials, according to a court affidavit filed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: For Sharpton, Debates in Mayor Race Can Be Fun
description: THE REV. AL SHARPTON was the only one who seemed to be having a genuinely good time.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about the success of a Pathmark supermarket in Brooklyn mislabeled the amount of the store's net income. The figures were in the thousands, not millions.

title: Guards for Firehouse After Melee in Bronx
description: The day after a group of Bronx firefighters came under attack while trying to break up a street fight, their Webster Avenue firehouse in the Fordham section was put under heavy guard yesterday and their fire trucks were given a police escort.

title: Suit on Partnership Benefits
description: A suit challenging the state's ban on granting domestic partnership benefits will be heard today in the Appellate Division of Superior Court. The suit was filed in 1993 by the Rutgers chapter of the American Association of University Professors, an associate dean and several faculty members.

title: Poor Tracking of Students Is Partly Blamed in 2 Deaths
description: The failure of the school system to track absent students contributed to the death of two young girls, and hundreds of other children could be languishing at home and in trouble, the chief investigator for the city's public schools said yesterday.

title: Two Reports Show Inflation Is in Check
description: Two more economic reports showed that inflationary pressures remained at bay last month.

title: New York Jury Convicts Three Venezuelan Bankers of Defrauding Depositors
description: A Manhattan jury convicted three Venezuelan bankers yesterday of defrauding South American depositors, supporting the District Attorney's contention that international banking cases can be tried in New York even when the primary crime is committed outside the country.

title: Microsoft Taking a Stake in Video Games
description: Microsoft said today that it had taken a minority stake in Digital Anvil, an interactive software gaming company formed by Chris Roberts, formerly of Electronic Arts Inc.

title: A Hardware Store With a Big Ego
description: In this era of confessional talk talk shows, talk radio, computer chat rooms, skypagers that let you talk at any time to anyone from anywhere -- it was probably inevitable that someone would invent Restoration Hardware, the rapidly growing upscale tool-and-home-furnishings chain that is perfecting the art of store-as-autobiography.

title: U.S. Sees Few Changes in Chinese Relations
description: The death of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, had been expected for so long that officials in the Clinton Administration said today that it would prompt few drastic changes, if any, in how America handles one of its more important and difficult diplomatic relationships.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Finally, a Social Security plan that may achieve a consensus.
description: WHAT, another plan for reforming Social Security? After the Clinton Administration's advisory commission offered up not one but three radically different options in January, one might wonder what is left to say.

title: Bell Atlantic Takes Control of Iusacell
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and Grupo Iusa said today that they had completed the transfer of management control of the Mexican cellular phone company Grupo Iusacell to Bell Atlantic.

title: It's Automatic for Pulpit: Favored at 2-1 in Fountain
description: He has run only two races and none at all last year when he was 2. But he comes with the enduring name Pulpit, has won both starts by a combined 14 lengths, dazzles the clockers with his speed in workouts and is the talk of Gulfstream Park this season.

title: Shadows of Death and Secrets Lengthen in King Assassination Case
description: In the 29 years since Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated here, standing on the balcony in front of Room 306 of the Lorraine Motel, most official investigators have settled on a single explanation: that Dr. King was killed by James Earl Ray, a racist loner who stalked the civil rights leader and cut him down with a single shot from a .30-06-caliber hunting rifle.

title: Bounding With Vitality but Not Strain
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company celebrated the virtues of gentleness on Tuesday night when it opened a week's engagement at the Kaye Playhouse. The three works presented were created between 1961 and 1988. All attested to Hawkins's love of choreographic refinement.

title: Starr Offers Broad Defense Of His Decision to Resign
description: Kenneth W. Starr today characterized his resignation as the Whitewater independent counsel as a purely personal decision that had nothing to do with the progress of the three-year investigation of President Clinton and his wife.

title: Trade Deficit Grew Sharply Last Year
description: The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in December, bringing the imbalance for the full year to $114.2 billion, the largest gap since 1988, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: For Their Own Safety, Police Can Order People Out of Cars in Routine Stops, Court Rules
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that police officers may order passengers out of the cars they stop for routine traffic violations, even in the absence of any reason to suspect that the passenger has committed a crime or presents a threat to the officer's safety.

title: Pamela Harriman Estate Bequeathed to Churchills
description: Ambassador Pamela Harriman left an estate ''not much over $10 million,'' a close friend said today, though she had inherited more than $100 million on the death of her third husband, former Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York. The estate consisted mostly of property and jewelry.

title: Mexico's Jailed Anti-Drug Chief Had Complete Briefings in U.S.
description: Just days before he was detained on charges of collaborating with drug traffickers, the head of Mexico's antinarcotics program was given detailed briefings on what the United States knows about Mexico's cocaine cartels, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Leo Rosten, a Writer Who Helped Yiddish Make Its Way Into English, Is Dead at 88
description: Leo Rosten, the writer, scholar and language maven who introduced millions of Americans to the deep lexical pleasures of chutzpah and shlemiel and kibitz and nosh, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Coffee Prices in Sharp Rise On Forecasts of Tight Supply
description: Coffee prices surged yesterday after a United States inventory report and a Brazilian crop estimate heightened concern that supplies could grow scarce later this year.

title: Bill Would Penalize Drivers
description: During the drive home to Ridgewood on Feb. 7, 1996, Michael Eastman was struck in the head by ice that had crashed through his windshield. He died three days later. The ice apparently fell off the roof of a truck headed in the opposite direction along Route 17, said Assemblyman David C. Russo, Republican of Ridgewood.

title: True North Communications and Publicis find a way to end a European joint venture amicably.
description: WHAT has been perhaps the most fractious dispute in advertising ended surprisingly peacefully late yesterday when two big agency companies -- True North Communications in Chicago and Publicis S.A. in Paris -- agreed to settle all outstanding differences concerning the dissolution of a global business alliance.

title: G.M. May Sell Up to 20% Of Merged Parts Business
description: The General Motors Corporation is considering selling up to 20 percent of its huge automotive electronics and auto parts units, John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said today.

title: What Is Sex?
description: To The Home Section:

title: France to Auction Thomson-CSF
description: Thomson-CSF will be auctioned to companies rather than sold to individuals on the stock market, the French Government said yesterday, ending months of uncertainty over how Europe's largest military electronics maker would be sold. Most of the state's 58 percent stake, worth around 12.6 billion French francs ($2.2 billion), will be offered to French and European companies as the Government encourages consolidation of Europe's military industry.

title: Yanks Buzzing: That's Entertainment!
description: For ardent Yankee fans who are devotees of the always curious ways of George Steinbrenner's favorite team, today was a perfect day to be an insect perched on the clubhouse wall. Or inside Manager Joe Torre's office. Or in the parking lot. Or anywhere near Legends Field. It was buzzing.

title: ABC Admits Walters Had 'Sunset' Stake
description: ABC News confirmed yesterday that Barbara Walters had invested $100,000 in the Broadway production of ''Sunset Boulevard'' and then interviewed the musical's creator, Andrew Lloyd Webber, on ''20/20'' last December.

title: Martha Stewart's at Kmart, Changing the Sheets
description: SHE prodded average Americans to consider quince preserves. She ratcheted up their sense of inadequacy because they did not press their vintage linens and whip up exotic omelets with eggs from their own chicken farms.

title: G.O.P. Reward for Its Biggest Donors: 3 Days of Rubbing Elbows With Party Leaders
description: Just as Republicans in Washington are preparing to investigate fund-raising practices by Democrats, top Republicans gathered here today at a century-old, oceanfront luxury resort as a reward to their biggest contributors.

title: Cablevision Near Garden Control
description: Cablevision Systems said yesterday that it has arranged the financing needed to purchase the half of Madison Square Garden owned by the ITT Corporation. It is believed that Cablevision would borrow the money, not take on a partner.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Candidate Sets Run for Nassau Executive
description: Lewis J. Yevoli, a Democrat who has consistently won elections in so-called Republican strongholds, announced today that he would try to oust the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, in next fall's election.

title: When Money Counts
description: FORGET the second mortgage. Today, a bathroom face lift can be accomplished, if not with smoke, then with mirrors. Rather than the thousands of dollars a complete renovation would cost, it is possible to refresh and modernize a bathroom at a fraction of the cost with a few quick cosmetic flourishes.

title: Canada's Torn Sikhs: In a Holy Place, Unholy Rage
description: Chairs and tables are lined up on one side of the big community room at the Guru Nanak Sikh Temple and long red floor mats on the other. Members of the temple eat their post-prayer meals of lentils and flat bread in silence, some sitting on chairs, others cross-legged on mats.

title: Accounts
description: * Community Health Care Systems Inc., Maitland, Fla., to Cramer-Krasselt, Orlando, Fla., as the first agency to handle its Healthchoice managed care products. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: C. R. ANTHONY IN MERGER NEGOTIATIONS WITH STAGE STORES
description: The shares of the C. R. Anthony Company rose yesterday after the company, a retailer based in Oklahoma City, said it was in merger talks with Stage Stores Inc., a department store company. C. R. Anthony's shares rose $1.125, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading, giving the company a market capitalization of $62 million. Stage's shares were down 18.75 cents, to $18.125. The two retailers, which together operate 550 stores, said they had agreed on certain terms and were still discussing others. No formal agreement has been set. Stage, based in Houston, operates 316 department stores in 19 states under the names Stage, Bealls and Palais Royal. C. R. Anthony sells clothing in 224 specialty stores in 13 Southwestern and Rocky Mountain states.

title: Vans in Garment District
description: For the last 40 years, only six-wheel trucks have been allowed to load and unload in the garment district in Manhattan, prompting complaints about traffic and noise. Starting Monday, commercial vans will also be permitted.

title: The Global Backyard: Weird Is In
description: JOHN TREXLER, a plant connoisseur in Boylston, Mass., is obsessed with Gunnera tinctoria, a Chilean plant with enormous crinkled leaves and large furry buds that looks like something H. G. Wells could have dreamed up for ''The War of the Worlds.'' So what if it has to spend the rugged New England winter under pine needles and a whisky barrel to survive?

title: Public Relations Alliance Formed
description: Four networks of public relations agencies -- Iprex in Houston, Pinnacle Worldwide in Minneapolis, Public Relations Organization International in Chicago and Worldcom Group in New York -- have formed an international association, the Council of Public Relations Networks.

title: Calendar: Shows on Sewing And Audubon Watercolors
description: All About Home Sewing

title: CHRONICLE
description: George Washington was known as many things: a youth who could not tell a lie, commander in chief of the Continental Army, father of his country, President. But tycoon?

title: On-Line Guide Agreement
description: Microsoft and The Village Voice have agreed to exchange information to help their respective on-line guides to New York City, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Revamping With Technology, Competition and U.S. Aid
description: You wouldn't think Europe could learn anything about running railroads from the United States. Europe has the bullet-like TGV's and tilting trains; the United States has Amtrak.

title: Lemaire Isn't Sure Rangers Got Even
description: The Rangers and the Devils viewed their home-and-home series this week as a barometer of where they stand among the league's elite teams in their attempts to jockey for higher rankings in the playoffs.

title: Wilson's Mission Is to Turn Iron Gloves to Gold
description: When Bernard Gilkey and Lance Johnson arrived in Mets camp today, it was harder to find anyone happier than, well, most every teammate who crossed their path.

title: Bill Would Bolster Rent Control Laws
description: Trying to counterattack a Republican proposal to eliminate almost all rent protections, the Democratic-controlled State Assembly today proposed legislation that would keep rent regulations largely intact for 2.7 million tenants across the state.

title: Nigeria's Military Ruler May Run as Civilian
description: A national debate is taking place about whether Nigeria's military leader should run as a civilian in the presidential election next year.

title: Sisters, United in Success, Are Divided on the Details
description: In her inspirational 1995 memoir ''The Ditchdigger's Daughters,'' Dr. Yvonne S. Thornton paints a loving portrait of her father, Donald Thornton, a black New Jersey laborer, who held the improbable dream that his six daughters would all become doctors. Two of them did so; a third is a dentist, and the others are a lawyer, a nurse and a court stenographer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Prom Queen? Remark Stirs A Tempest
description: A tempest over some rather public name calling inside New York's Congressional delegation seems to be taking some time to defuse.

title: Possible Plan to Move Center
description: A study commissioned by the Federal Aviation Administration may recommend shutting down the agency's William J. Hughes Technical Center in Pomona and moving its operations and its 1,500 employees to Oklahoma City, two New Jersey lawmakers said yesterday.

title: Tough Side Of Albright Is Awaited In Moscow
description: In the first interview on Russian television with the new Secretary of State, Russia's most prominent television journalist, Yevgeny Kiselyov, leaned forward and asked the question most pressing to Russian viewers.

title: Uzbeks' Classical Master Reclaims Role in Queens
description: Ilyas Malayev's leap from stardom to obscurity makes his an extraordinary tale of the immigrant experience. In Uzbekistan, he was a beloved musician and vaudevillian with the tragicomic face of a clown. He once performed in stadiums packed with tens of thousands of fans, but in Queens, he seems to be just another aging refugee scraping by on welfare.

title: High Court Upholds 15-Foot Buffer Zone At Abortion Clinics
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a lower court's order keeping demonstrators at least 15 feet away from the doorways and driveways of clinics in upstate New York that were the targets of blockades and boisterous protests in the early 1990's. The decision reaffirmed the Court's broadly protective approach toward maintaining access for patients entering abortion clinics.

title: Unit of HSBC Buying British Train Company
description: Forward Trust, a leasing and finance unit of HSBC Holdings P.L.C., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the British train leasing company Eversholt Holdings Ltd. for $:410.9 million ($666.13 million) in cash and an additional $:42.5 million ($68.9 million) in loan notes. The purchase also includes the assumption of about $:273.1 million in debt.

title: Stevens Doesn't Score; He Just Defends Best
description: After serving well as captain of the victorious United States team in the World Cup last autumn, Brian Leetch of the Rangers played at a mediocre level in the first quarter of the National Hockey League season.

title: MEDEVA TO CLOSE CALIFORNIA PLANT AND LAY OFF 600
description: Medeva P.L.C., a British drug manufacturer, said yesterday that it was closing its International Medication Systems business outside Los Angeles and would dismiss most of the unit's 600 employees. Medeva said it would transfer some operations and employees to a plant in Rochester that it purchased last year from Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. for $370 million. International Medication Systems, with offices in City of Industry, Calif., makes and distributes vaccines and painkillers as well as other hospital products.

title: From Salinger, A New Dash Of Mystery
description: So, at long last, we have news that the famously reclusive J. D. Salinger is bringing out another book, not a new story, but one called ''Hapworth 16, 1924,'' which appeared in The New Yorker in the 1960's. Read in retrospect, that story continues -- perhaps even completes -- the saga of the Glass family, that band of precocious, high-strung whiz kids who have captivated Salinger fans for four decades. It also stands as a logical, if disappointing, culmination of Mr. Salinger's published work to date.

title: With Polite Nod to One Another, Democratic Field Uses Forum to Attack Mayor
description: Seeking to stand out in a blurred and crowded field, the four Democratic mayoral prospects used a campaign forum yesterday to pummel Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- but not each other. They disparaged his personal ethics, the decline of city schools and Mr. Giuliani's efforts to cut the welfare rolls.

title: U.S.-Europe Talks as Cuba Deadline Nears
description: With only hours to go before before a legal deadline, Clinton Administration officials said today that they were engaged in last-minute negotiations with the European Community to find a diplomatic solution to an increasingly bitter argument over America's trade embargo on Cuba.

title: Stocks Fall As Volatility Continues
description: Stock prices held steady for much of the day yesterday before slipping in late-afternoon trading in yet another demonstration of how a big bull market can swing wildly.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP TO BUY BACK 2% OF ITS SHARES EACH YEAR
description: The Campbell Soup Company has set a long-term goal of buying 2 percent of its shares outstanding each year, following up on a buyback program the company announced last year, analysts said. The company said in September that it would buy back $2.5 billion of its shares by 1999, with $1.5 billion being purchased by the close of this fiscal year, which ends July 30. The company disclosed the 2 percent target in a presentation late on Tuesday at the Consumer Analysts Group of New York annual conference in Naples, Fla. Campbell also said that it had reduced its worldwide staff by 6 percent, or 1,350 people, this fiscal year and that it was close to an agreement to sell its poultry business.

title: Heart Murmur Causes Delay In Nets' Trade
description: The disclosure of a childhood heart murmur by Khalid Reeves to doctors in Dallas today delayed the completion of the nine-player deal between the Nets and the Mavericks.

title: South African Rugby Coach Quits Over Slur
description: The South African Rugby Football Union accepted the resignation of the coach of the national rugby team today, two days after a tape of him using a racial slur to describe national sports officials was broadcast.

title: Warren Weaver of The Times, Long a Political Reporter, 74
description: Warren Weaver Jr., who covered politics and government in Albany, in Washington and across the country for The New York Times for virtually all his 42 years as a reporter, died this morning at Georgetown University Medical Center here. He was 74 and lived in Washington.

title: Pity the Poor Eurocrat, Who Can Do No Right
description: ''Stateless functionaries without faces,'' Charles de Gaulle once fumed at the European bureaucrats in Brussels.

title: Detroit Papers' Rehiring Policy Angers Unions
description: The Detroit newspapers held out an olive branch yesterday to the six newspaper unions that proposed over the weekend to end their 19-month strike. But the papers did not offer the only thing the unions wanted, an assurance that the strikers could go directly back to work.

title: Unions Woo Business District Workers
description: As business improvement districts multiply around New York City, they have become a target of union organizers, who complain that the workers hired by some districts to sweep sidewalks and empty trash cans are underpaid and unfairly treated.

title: Should the East End Secede? The Suffolk County Executive Pleads for Unity
description: For years now, the people living at the verdant, eastern end of Long Island's Suffolk County have been agitating for secession. They want to prevent their quaint farms and villages from becoming one big uber-mall fringed with grass. In recent months, their cry for independence has grown louder.

title: STRAWBERRIES AUDIO AND VIDEO CHAIN IN CHAPTER 11
description: Strawberries Inc., a chain of audio and video retail stores based in Milford, Mass., filed for Chapter 11 yesterday in a United States Bankruptcy Court. The closely held company listed assets of $79.6 million and liabilities of $76.9 million. Of the liabilities, $61.9 million was listed as secured debt. Strawberries Holdings Inc., owner of the company, also filed for Chapter 11 protection. The company operates stores in New England and the mid-Atlantic states.

title: Goldman, Sachs Names 2 Vice Chairmen
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the venerable Wall Street partnership, continued the gradual broadening and revamping of its top management yesterday by naming two new vice chairmen.

title: Speed, Jumping, Danger in Extreme
description: It's hard to imagine a slope so steep that a bent elbow touches the side of the hill if a skier stands sideways. But a pitch of 50 degrees is common for extreme skiers, who relish the thought of pounding their way down a narrow snow chute riddled with rock ledges and patches of ice.

title: The 'Redo Spirit,' Running Rampant
description: ''SCOPE CREEP'' can happen to anyone. But normally when a renovation project begins modestly and ends up engulfing the entire house, the owners start tearing their -- and sometimes their architect's -- hair out.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Maine

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Oscar W. Adams Jr., a former justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, referred incorrectly to Gov. Fob James Jr. Besides having held the post from 1978 to 1982, he was elected in 1994 to a four-year term and remains in office.

title: Male Students Help UConn's No. 1 Basketball Team Get Better
description: Kara Wolters grabbed a pass, and her next move was inevitable. At 6 feet 7 inches, with the ball in the low post, her back to the basket, Wolters spun toward the hoop.

title: Venezuelan State Airline Faces Collapse
description: Protracted efforts to salvage Viasa, the troubled Venezuelan state airline, appeared all but doomed yesterday, after Venezuelan Government officials announced they would spend no more money to save the company.

title: Time Warner Planning to Sell Stake in Legal Publisher
description: Time Warner said yesterday that it would sell its stake in the publishing company that owns the trade paper American Lawyer, but would keep its interest in Court TV. As a result, Steven Brill, who built a small empire on legal coverage, will leave the paper and cable channel he founded.

title: Excerpts From Opinions, Pro and Con, on Restriction of Abortion Protests
description: Following are excerpts from the majority opinion and the dissents today in Schenk et al v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York et al. The majority opinion was written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Joining the entire opinion were Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Concurring and dissenting in part were Justice Antonin Scalia, joined by Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas, and Justice Stephen G. Breyer.

title: A Sudden Rush to Marry at City Hall
description: By 1 P.M. yesterday, the line snaked from the elevators around the corner, up a staircase and back to the glass doors of the City Clerk's office in downtown Manhattan. Many of the 100 or so weary couples clamoring to get inside for marriage licenses or lightning-fast wedding ceremonies had been waiting for four hours, and rather than basking in marital bliss, they were furious.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a planned acquisition of the Invetech Company by Applied Industrial Technologies Inc. misidentified the stock exchange where shares of Applied Industrial trade. It is the New York Stock Exchange, not the American Stock Exchange.

title: Around West Hartford, Crows' Cry Is 'Evermore'
description: IN the pretty green suburbs, where peace and quiet are part of the package, like the family room and the walk-in closet, life depends on things being the way they've always been. Nothing is quite as jarring as the unexpected, be it a daughter's boyfriend's tattoos, a new neighbor prone to public displays of car repair or, heaven forbid, guests who stop by without calling.

title: Knicks' Road Trip Will Miss Easy Street
description: It will be the longest road trip of the Knicks' season, and the toughest.

title: Bre-X Loses Fee For Gold Stake
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd. will not receive any payment for the 30 percent stake in the Busang gold deposit that it gave to its Indonesian partners, said Mohamad (Bob) Hasan, an Indonesian businessman who helped broker the agreement.

title: Hamas Leader May Be Spared Extradition
description: Israeli and American officials are quietly looking for ways to avoid extraditing to Israel Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, a Palestinian Islamic leader who has been detained in a New York jail for more than 19 months, according to Israeli officials.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fairfield Suspends Principal In Wake of Test Tampering
description: Nine months after discovering tampering on standardized tests at its prize-winning Stratfield Elementary School, the Fairfield Board of Education took the first step tonight toward dismissing the school's popular principal.

title: Tony Bennett by Way of Armstrong, Not Sinatra
description: Few pop singers take more obvious delight in the pleasure of vocalizing than Tony Bennett, whose Carnegie Hall concert on Tuesday evening found him in high spirits and in perfect voice. At 71, his timbre is only marginally rougher than it was 33 years ago when he first recorded ''Who Can I Turn To?,'' a splashy Anthony Newley show tune he brought back late in the program with all the high notes intact.

title: Inspired by Unexpected, Readers Donate a Little More
description: Beatrice Lesser of the Bronx was surprised by another driver's act of kindness one Sunday last fall, so she decided to pass the gesture along to the needy.

title: UConn Routs Pittsburgh
description: The UConn women's basketball team rolled to its 25th victory without a loss this season as substitutes played most of the way tonight in a 103-71 rout of Pittsburgh. The 103 points and the 56 first-half points were season highs for the Huskies, who brought their Big East record to 16-0.

title: International Terminals To Drop Airport Cart Fee
description: After endless complaints from airline passengers, self-service luggage carts will soon be available without charge in the international arrival terminals at the three major area airports. Passengers on domestic flights, however, will still have to pay $1.50 for a cart.

title: Township Looks Warily at Energy Tax Cuts
description: For a generation, the gray Oyster Creek nuclear power plant, with its towering needle of an exhaust stack, has dominated the forest of scrub pines at the southern end of town.

title: High Court Hears Arguments About Congress's Power to Expand Constitutional Rights
description: A Supreme Court argument over a recent Federal law intended to protect religious observance from government interference turned today into a wide-ranging examination of the power of Congress not only to protect constitutional rights but also to define them more broadly than the Court itself has chosen to do.

title: When Household Habits Betrayed the Jews
description: DO you sweep dust toward the center of the room instead of straight out the door? Did you buy a new set of dishes last March? Do you suffer from such severe headaches that they prevent you from cooking on certain days of the week?

title: Bridge
description: One of the paradoxes of the game is that doubling a contract that is certain to fail may introduce an element of doubt into the certainty. An example is the diagramed deal in which North-South were using an artificial relay system. North's first four bids were artificial, asking for information, and at the finish he knew that his partner held a 4-6-2-1 distribution, with two major-suit aces and a major-suit king. He hoped for some quality, and there was. The ten-nine were crucial cards.

title: Ford Agrees to Sell Heavy-Truck Business
description: The Ford Motor Company agreed today to sell its heavy-duty truck business to the Freightliner Corporation, a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., in a move that would allow Ford to shed a money-losing business and Freightliner to increase its market share in the United States.

title: DENG XIAOPING IS DEAD AT 92; ARCHITECT OF MODERN CHINA
description: Deng Xiaoping, one of the founding revolutionaries of Communist China and the architect of economic modernizations that transformed the world's most populous nation, died Wednesday night in Beijing. He was 92.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S.Trade Deficit Grows

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALTEX PETROLEUM CORP., Dallas, a joint venture of Chevron Corp. and Texaco Inc., said it was selling its 40 percent equity in Bahrain Petroleum Co., to the Government of Bahrain, for an undisclosed amount.

title: JAZZ
description: Joking With the Blues,

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Young Pianist's Debut

title: New Type of Leader; Same Army Friends
description: The man anointed to succeed Deng Xiaoping, Jiang Zemin, is a new kind of authority for China: a quiet intellectual who would be the first leader in the nation's history with a college degree. While not as imposing a figure as Mr. Deng, he appears to be a secure strongman.

title: Richter Keeps Rangers In Game
description: Had it not been for goalie Mike Richter, the Rangers would have lost in overtime -- or earlier -- to the Devils tonight. Instead, they settled for a 1-1 tie, their second tie with their Hudson River rivals in the last two games.

title: The Players Win One
description: The players averted an unprecedented salary arbitration shutout yesterday. After arbitrators ruled for the clubs in the first three hearings, JAMES DUFF awarded Boston pitcher TIM WAKEFIELD the $2.5 million salary that he had sought. The Red Sox had argued for a $1.5 million salary for Wakefield, who earned $450,000 last year.

title: Help for the Impotent
description: To The Home Section:

title: In Looking to the Future, Hong Kong And Taiwan Face New Uncertainties
description: The death of Deng Xiaoping has cost Hong Kong one of its few protectors in Beijing and raised new uncertainties about the future both here and in Taiwan.

title: The Pop Life
description: David Bowie's Golden Years

title: Clinton Urges Campaign Against Youth Crime
description: Signaling the new emphasis of his anti-crime measures in a second term, President Clinton today visited a city that has seen an impressive reduction in juvenile crime statistics and declared that the battle against youth crime ''has got to become our top law-enforcement priority.''

title: David A. McCann, 67, Magazine Publisher
description: David A. McCann, a former publisher of Town & Country and Connoisseur magazines who was an expert at appealing to advertisers who wanted to appeal to the rich, died last Friday at the Jupiter Medical Center in Jupiter, Fla. He was 67.

title: Fable in Rap And Rapper In a Fable
description: ''Salut Cousin!'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28. The film, which is in French and Arabic with English subtitles, opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street west of Fifth Avenue, in Greenwich Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICHER, HERBERT
description: OESTREICHER-Herbert, died February 17, 1997. Beloved uncle of Philip Jonas and Anita Obstler. Residing Allendale Nursing Home, age 97. Recently Librarian at Cornell Medical Center Library. Funeral at Linden Hill Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONACO, CHRISTINE (NEE ROTUNNO)
description: MONACO-Christine (nee Rotunno), age 85, of Danbury, CT., formerly of Rutherford, NJ, February 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Pasquale, mother of Frank M. and Michael P. Monaco and Christine M. Merrer, dear sister of Michelina Seddo and Amelia Parnofiello. Also survived by 8 grandchildren. Funeral from the Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Avenue, Rutherford on Monday at 9:30 AM. Funeral Mass 10:00 AM at St. Mary R.C. Church, Rutherford, NJ. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. Friends will be received on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial donations may be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 1719 Rt. 10, Suite 225, Parsippany, New Jersey 07054 or the charity of your choice.

title: It's That Feeling of Being Watched
description: Men of all ages come to Amsterdam's lively red-light district to ogle women in minute outfits, who display their bodies in shop windows. Customers stroll back and forth, watch or stop to make a deal.

title: Record Raises For Players
