description: With Bill Risley of Toronto losing his salary arbitration case yesterday, players finished this year's schedule with the fewest winning cases in the 22-year history of arbitration. The players won only one of five argued cases. But did they really lose?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANG, BERTHA TILZER
description: STANG-Bertha Tilzer, a native of Staten Island, died of cancer on Feb. 19, 1997 at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 90. Mrs. Stang's late brother was Ira L. Tilzer. Mrs. Stang is survived by her nieces Louise Tilzer Greenfield of Manhattan, Leslie Tilzer Krasny of San Anselmo, CA., and three great-nieces, Lauren and Alexa Krasny and Jessica Greenfield. The funeral was held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, NYC on Feb. 20.

title: PRIDE PETROLEUM TO BUY 12 RIGS FROM NOBLE DRILLING
description: Pride Petroleum Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay the Noble Drilling Corporation $265 million for 12 drilling rigs and one rig hull. Noble said it wanted to sell the mat-supported jackup rigs, which are used to drill oil and gas wells, as part of a plan to focus on equipment that will drill in deeper waters. A jackup rig is floated into place above a drilling site, where its legs are lowered to the ocean floor until it establishes a foundation to support the drilling equipment. Both companies are based in Houston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIARCHOS, MELPO
description: NIARCHOS-Melpo, on February 19, 1997. Beloved aunt of Alexander, Michael and Philip Capparis. Beloved sister-in-law of Marlene Capparis. Service Saturday, 9 AM, at Greek Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, RUTH
description: CLARK-Ruth. Beloved mother of Judy and Andy, cherished wife of the late Joseph Clark, devoted and remarkable grandmother of Harriet, Aaron, Daniel, and Joseph, caring mother-in-law to Cheryl Ogburn, second mother to Miriam Camitta and her family, and noted expert on public opinion polls and newspapers. Died on February 20, 1997. She founded and was President of Clark, Martire & Bartolomeo, and was formerly Executive Vice President of Daniel Yankelovich, as well as Louis Harris. She is already missed by her wide circle of close friends, business associates, and the many people whose lives she touched.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Feeling Minnesota

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan. July 22, 1945-February 21, 1993. Four years ago today time stood still and our world shattered. Never to be whole again without you, we try to reshape our lives with the loving memories of you and your remarkable and heroic life. It is those memories that sustain us in a diminished world blanketed with our grief.

title: Envoy Named In Fatal Crash Surrenders To the Police
description: A diplomat from the Republic of Georgia, whose involvement in a fatal automobile accident last month focused attention on diplomatic immunity, walked into a police station here today and surrendered to face charges of involuntary manslaughter and aggravated assault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUNZI, JACQUES R.
description: STUNZI-Jacques R. Resident of Darien, CT. Died on February 13, 1997 in Darien. Born on May 16, 1920 in Lancaster, PA to the late Jean Jacques Stunzi and Lilly Handchin Stunzi. Graduate of Yale University, Class of 1942. International Banker and Senior Business Executive. Foreign Department, The Hanover Bank, NY, NY; Vice President, Celanese Corp., NY, NY; Vice President, American Express Co., NY, NY; Executive VP, Continental Bank International, NY, NY; President and CEO, Allied Bank International, NY, NY; Vice President and Head of Country, Japan, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., Tokyo, Japan; Vice President and Head of Country, Switzerland, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., NY, NY. Named ''Bank Of The Year's Banker'' by Finance Magazine, October 1969 as President and CEO, Allied Bank International. Member of Norwalk Yacht Club, Norwalk, CT; Tokeneke Club, Darien, CT, Noroton Yacht Club, Noroton, CT., Simon Bolivar Society; The Newcomen Society of the United States; Past President, The American Club, Tokyo, Japan. An avid and experienced sailor, Mr. Stunzi sailed and navigated his 50 foot sloop from Massachusetts to Grenada in the Caribbean and back to Connecticut at age 71. He served as Lieutenant, U.S. Navy in World War II. His destroyer, USS CORY was lost in the assault on Normandy in the invasion of Europe. First marriage terminated in divorce. Pre-deceased by Jacques R. Stunzi, Jr.; daughter Annelise Stunzi Ulrich, Orange, CT; son Paul Frederick Stunzi, Marblehead, Mass; Eric Christoper Stunzi, NY, NY, and second wife Virginia Wiese Stunzi of Darien, CT and Lima Peru. Stepchildren: Virginia Bayly; Luis Augusto Ducassi; Maria Ines Ducassi; Jorge Ducassi; Elvira McLauclan; and Javier Ducassi, all of Lima, Peru. Survived also by 8 grandchildren. Funeral service Saturday, February 22 at 1:00 PM; Chapel, St Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd., Darien, CT. Interment private. Contributions may be made to Darien Library, 135 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT. 06820.

title: People
description: * Gregory Spector, executive vice president at GCI Group, San Francisco, a unit of Grey Advertising , was promoted to president, succeeding Joseph W. Jennings, who is leaving to start a venture capital partnership.

title: Credit Lyonnais Shares Jump on Expectations
description: Shares of Credit Lyonnais S.A. jumped yesterday after a newspaper report encouraged expectations the state-owned bank will report a ''spectacular rebound'' in profit this year. According to an unattributed report in the daily financial newspaper Les Echos, Credit Lyonnais will post a profit this year of between 3.4 billion francs ($596.79 million) and 3.7 billion francs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the first-quarter earnings of the Hewlett-Packard Company misstated the company's growth rates in revenue and orders for the quarter a year ago. Orders grew 29 percent, not 22; revenue grew 27 percent, not 33.

title: No Silence on China
description: To the Editor:

title: Success Not Seen in Schools
description: Students at 12 of Paterson's 32 elementary schools cannot check out books from a school library. There is none. About 1,000 kindergarten children do not attend school for a full day because there are not enough classrooms. Eighth graders and eleventh graders continue to score poorly on standardized tests.

title: Two Who Define Today Amble In the Past
description: ''I DON'T know that I've spent more than an hour at a time in a museum,'' says Bruce Nauman.

title: Struggling Borland to Cut Work Force and Shift Product Focus
description: Borland International Inc., the struggling software company, said today that it would lay off 300 people, or about 30 percent of its work force, as part of a major revamping. Borland, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., will have 700 employees after the cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HAROLD
description: ROTH-Harold. Devoted husband of Hilda. Loving father of Mona and Joan and grandchildren, Kyle and Lia. Adored brother of Rosalind Krasnov.

title: Values First
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Can't Rescue Mavericks
description: After arriving from the Nets in a nine-player deal, Shawn Bradley did his best to key a comeback in his debut with the Mavericks tonight. The spindly center had six fourth-quarter rebounds and a follow dunk with 10 seconds left to cut Milwaukee's lead to 4 points, but the Bucks beat the Mavericks, 101-99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, MAURICE, JR.
description: MEYER-Maurice, Jr., 85, of Elberon, NJ, February 19, 1997. Husband of the late Carolyn. Father of Maurice III and Dorothy M. Purcell. Grandfather of six. Greatgrandfather of seven. Graduate of Newark Academy and Princeton University 1931. Member of Phi Beta Kappa, Bond Club, NY, Board of Governors, Jersey Shore Medical Center and Panel of American Arbitration Association. Senior partner, Hirsch and Company, members of the New York Stock Exchange. Chairman of Texas Pacific Land Trust, 1961-1990. Captain, US Tuna Team, 1956. Funeral services Sunday, February 23, at 1:30 PM, at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to Jersey Shore Medical Center Foundation, Neptune, NJ 07753 or VNA Hospice, 1100 Wayside Rd., Tinton Falls, NJ 07712.

title: Judge in Oklahoma Attack Backs U.S. on 6 Witnesses
description: The judge in the Oklahoma City bombing case today refused a defense request to suppress testimony from six important Government witnesses, saying there was no evidence that publicity about the case had tainted their testimony to a degree that it should be barred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEEVER, ROBERT EMMET
description: McKEEVER - Robert Emmet. Died peacefully February 5, 1997. Survived by his wife, Doris ''Suzie'' Baker; his former wife, Clara Tomkies, daughters, Sharon Surrarrer and Kimberly Kaye; son, Dow McKeever; a step-son Robert Nitzschke; grandchildren, Marc Surrarrer and Dara Kaye. He graduated from Princeton in 1949 A.B. cum Laude and had a distinguished career on Wall Street. He loved the ocean, gourmet food and a good game of Scrabble with his family. We will forever miss his optimism, great wit and splashing with him in the surf.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. We miss you. Love always Barbara, Frank, Miriam and Ann

title: Fielder And Torre's Easy Day
description: All it took was 10 minutes to defuse four months of discord between Cecil Fielder and the Yankees. All it took for Manager Joe Torre to placate the disgruntled Fielder was a promise that he would be the designated hitter.

title: Brooklyn Museum Knew How to Sell, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Nannies, Feminists and the Power of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Who Left Recall Deng With Gratitude
description: When Sue Ann Jung's family left China 18 years ago, they were among the first to benefit directly from the open-door policies of Deng Xiaoping after he consolidated his power in 1978. So yesterday, a day after Mr. Deng's long-anticipated death, Ms. Jung, 30, recalled what her parents used to tell her as she grew up in New York City.

title: Nannies, Feminists and the Power of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town's Strange Bedfellows Unite Behind Chinese Refugees
description: Jeff Lobach is a corporate lawyer with a good practice here. His wife, Cindy, sometimes tells him, ''I'd rather be called dumb, fat and ugly than a liberal.'' But one of their best friends for the last three and a half years has been the Rev. Joan Maruskin, who was flattered when Mrs. Lobach first called her a ''liberal left-wing wacko.''

title: New Start For Belle, New Start For Indians
description: Albert Belle was happy to be in Sarasota today. Many members of the Cleveland Indians were happy he was here too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDEL, RONNI
description: PENDEL-Ronni. Beloved daughter of Sylvia and Irving Weiss, loving mother of Elise. Devoted sister of Michael Weiss. Cherished aunt. May God grant her peace and serenity. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30 A.M., Sunday.

title: Utility Chief Retiring
description: Northeast Utilities said Bernard Fox would retire as chairman, chief executive and president in this year's second half.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, ANN P.
description: MARTIN-Ann P. Legg, 59, of Rochelle Park, on February 20, 1997. Mother of John T. and Gary M. Martin; daughter of Mary Mullins Legg; sister of Helen Centorino. Also survived by 7 grandchildren. Funeral services Saturday at 8:45 AM from Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave., Fords, NJ. Mass of Christian burial at 9 AM, at Our Lady of Peace R.C. Church, Fords. Entombment in Woodbridge Memorial Gardens Mausoleum, Woodbridge, New Jersey. Visitation Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Contributions may be made to Chem Care, 231 North Avenue, Westfield, NJ 07090.

title: Alphonse Nkubito Dies at 42; Ex-Rwandan Justice Minister
description: Alphonse Marie Nkubito, a former Justice Minister of Rwanda and an outspoken voice for human rights and the rule of law, died on Feb. 13 at his home in the capital city of Kigali. He was 42.

title: A Figure of Infamy Is Held in a 2d Outrage
description: Some of his neighbors here say they believed Lawrence Singleton when he claimed to have been framed for the rape and mutilation of a California teen-ager nearly two decades ago, a crime that had made him a figure of nationwide infamy. Others, who have known him from childhood, believed that whether he had been framed or not, a man could always change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASE, PEGGY K.
description: CASE-Peggy K., age 73, of N. Branford, CT. Beloved wife of George, died Thurs. Feb. 6 at CT Hospice. Mother of Carole Spadaro and Marcia Case, grandmother of Lisa Gallina, niece of Lorraine Brown, she was a graduate of Rhodes college & had MSW from NYU. Retired psychiatric social worker and accomplished violinist, she was a past president of Junior League of Westchester-on-Hudson, she produced Westchester Heritage map of Indian & colonial settlement and authored definitive monograph on Albert Bierstadt & his Tarrytown estate. Memorial Service 1:30 PM, Saturday, Feb 22, Irvington Presbyterian Church. Memorial contributions may be made to OPUS, 101 N. Central Avenue, Hartsdale, NY 10530.

title: Jackson Is Back With Pacers
description: The Indiana Pacers needed a replacement for Mark Jackson. So they traded for Mark Jackson.

title: U.S. Panel Urges Study of Medical Marijuana
description: Marijuana shows promise in aiding some medical conditions, and its use should be studied further, a panel of experts convened at the National Institutes of Health said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Attack on Hospital Plan

title: 62 Dealers and a Batch of Surprises
description: Whatever else they say about New York, no one can call it an art-challenged city. The latest refutation is ''The Art Show,'' the annual extravaganza that brings some of the country's top galleries together under one big roof. Now making its ninth appearance (through Monday) at the Seventh Regiment Armory, this 62-dealer show offers a chance to do the art walk from New York to, say, San Francisco, in a couple of hours without stepping outdoors.

title: Bullet in King Killing May Get Scrutiny
description: James Earl Ray's lawyers went back to court today with their eighth request that he be given a new trial in the murder of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. -- this time with a new ally, Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King.

title: South Africa Outlaws Antipersonnel Mines
description: South Africa unexpectedly announced today that it would ban the use of antipersonnel land mines and would destroy its stock of 160,000 mines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSTEN, LEO
description: ROSTEN-Leo. He endowed Jewish and non-Jewish people with the treasures of Yiddish, translating its Voice to the sentiments and experiences that all mankind can relate to in their everyday lives. Kenneth Lane, Wagnerian Heldentenor Valhalla Records, Lake Hiawatha, New Jersey

title: Eerie Visions With a Mood Of Menace
description: SOME artists have to strain for the shock effects that leave a spectator haunted and unnerved. Not David Lynch. The unnatural is second nature for Mr. Lynch, whose twisted, libidinous imagery yields nightmare films of such strange and menacing flair. At their evil best, which is also their worst, they leave you in no great hurry to be alone in the dark.

title: President Speaks Out On Nominee For Labor
description: The White House intensified efforts today to push its troubled nomination of Alexis M. Herman as Labor Secretary to a vote in the Senate, summoning Ms. Herman's supporters to talk strategy and bringing out President Clinton to underscore his support for the nomination personally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAWAY, TROWBRIDGE, JR.
description: CALLAWAY-Trowbridge, Jr., retired sugar company executive died February 17, 1996 after a long illness at his home in Delray Beach, Florida. Mr. Callaway formerly lived in Quogue, Long Island, New York, and in NYC. Born in 1912 in New York City, Mr. Callaway was educated at the Gunnery School and Harvard. He received general brokerage and investment training at George H. Farrington and Co., New York City and was with Clark Dodge & Company until 1942, when he went to Brown Brother Harriman and Company. He was a director of North American Sugar Company for many years and was VicePresident and Treasurer of that firm until 1970 when he retired. He was active in the Church of Atonement in Quogue, Long Island, a member of the Harvard Club of New York, and the Quogue Field Club. Mr. Callaway is survived by his wife Diana Stokes Callaway; by three sons: Trowbridge Callaway III of Ocean Ridge, FL, Norman T. Callaway of Princeton, NJ, and Tyler S. Callaway of La Jolla, CA, five grandchildren, two great grandchildren and by a brother, Samuel R. Callaway of Southbury, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Church of the Atonement, P.O. Box 928, Quogue, New York 11959. Funeral services will be private with a memorial service planned for the summer in Quogue, Long Island.

title: Leonard/Monahan For ABC Sports
description: The ABC television network said yesterday that it had named Leonard/Monahan Inc. in Providence, R.I., to handle the ABC Sports account, which had been handled for two years by the Grey Entertainment unit of Grey Advertising and occasionally fielded out on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $4 million.

title: Art in Review
description: Eugene Leroy

title: A Black Man Accused, A Town Destroyed
description: ''Rosewood'' describes a heinous, long-hidden racial incident that occurred in Florida in 1923, an escalating tragedy that led to the destruction of a prosperous black town. A false accusation of assault allowed Rosewood's envious white neighbors to embark on a witch hunt in which at least eight people (and probably many more) died. It took only a few days for the population of Rosewood to be scattered, and for the town to be wiped off the map. Black survivors of the massacre finally received reparations in 1993.

title: Guzzling Detergent, Eating Cactus. Yum.
description: Remember that weird kid in third-period study hall who would do anything for attention: turn his eyelids inside out, stick pencils in his nostrils, drop his pants in front of Babette Stemsky? Well, give him a Japanese accent, put him in ''Star Trek'' pajamas and multiply him by four.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNELL, MILFORD B.
description: SNELL-Milford B. Renowned pianist and vocal coach, died on February 17, 1997, age 91 years. He leaves no immediate survivors. Funeral services will be held on Monday, February 24, at 7:30PM in the St. Ignatius Church, 87th Street and West End Avenue.

title: Leave Standards to the States
description: Academic standards are a hot topic of discussion from the White House to the schoolhouse. But President Clinton's call for national standards for elementary, middle and high schools is cause for concern as well as comfort.

title: SOROS GROUP DROPS PLAN TO NOMINATE WMX CANDIDATES
description: An investment group that includes the investor George Soros said yesterday that it would not proceed with a plan to nominate a slate of four candidates to the board of WMX Technologies Inc. On Feb. 11, the investment group proposed the candidates after saying it had become frustrated with the trash-hauling company's lack of progress in increasing its stock price and had called for the removal of WMX's chief executive, Phillip Rooney. Mr. Rooney resigned on Tuesday. WMX is based in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Shattered by the Shooting That Made Her a Hero
description: Sunshine bleached Third Avenue in the South Bronx as Sharon Fields, a 26-year-old rookie police officer, walked her beat on June 15, 1984. Shoppers buzzed along the sidewalks of the commercial strip known as the Hub. She was glad to be out in the spring air. A block away, she spotted Officer Juan Andino, one of the nice guys in the precinct. She walked toward him, looking forward to a chat.

title: Clinton and Augustine
description: To the Editor:

title: Deng's Legacy: Finishing Long March to Capitalism
description: Deng Xiaoping, the architect of China's policy of economic openness, seemed to possess a magic touch with China's economy in its rocky transition from Communism to capitalism.

title: Sentence in Arson Long Ago
description: Twenty years ago, Kenneth Johnson Jr., then 14, set a fire that killed four emotionally disturbed men in a boarding house in Sea Bright.

title: Van Gundy Is in Good Shape for Contract Extension
description: He does not have an agent, a clothing deal or part ownership in the franchise. But it appears that Jeff Van Gundy might have job security with the Knicks beyond his current two-year contract.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart on Feb. 13 showing recent modest gains in average hourly wages, adjusted for inflation, carried two incorrect labels, and a chart on Sunday with the Diary column of the Money and Business reflected the errors. The figures were for nonsupervisory workers, not all workers, in private industry; they were given in fourth-quarter 1996 dollars, not December 1996 dollars.

title: Fore! Plan for Golf Atop Port Authority Bus Terminal
description: It is not easy to play golf in New York. In fact, the city ranks last nationally in the number of golf holes per resident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESTA, THOMAS J.
description: TESTA-Thomas J., formerly of Valley Stream, LI, Feb. 19, 1997. Husband of the late Dorothy (Downing), father of Gary, Kenneth and Raymond, brother of Raymond. Service in St. John the Evangelist Church, Riverhead, LI, Monday, at 11 A.M. Friends respectfully invited. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Jeopardy Clause Doesn't Prevent Repeat Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Warns Cuban Pilots
description: The State Department warned Cuban-American pilots today that they would be ''playing with fire'' if they attempted to cross into Cuban airspace in a protest on Monday to mark the first anniversary of the Cuban downing of planes flown by members of an exile group.

title: In Desire, A Glimpse Of Heaven
description: IT'S not a sight ordinarily known to inspire religious raptures. But when the extraordinary Antony Sher, in the title role of Pam Gems's ''Stanley,'' gazes upon a woman's unshaved armpit, the expression on his face suggests, quite unmistakably, that he has been vouchsafed a glimpse of paradise.

title: Friend and Foe in Korea
description: It is worrisome when American diplomats complain that dealing with South Korea, a traditional ally, has grown more frustrating than dealing with North Korea, a dangerous and unpredictable foe. Such complaints are not meant literally. But only North Korea can profit from the tensions Seoul has recently been introducing into its relations with the United States. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to South Korea this weekend provides a timely opportunity to set matters straight.

title: 'Flynt' Receives Thumbs Up By New Reviewer: A.C.L.U.
description: ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' the Milos Forman film that opened to some of the best reviews of the year but failed at the box office, received an unusual rave in Variety today, from the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of Southern California.

title: Art in Review
description: Judith Linhares and Sherri Kerlin

title: Antonio de Almeida, Conductor And Offenbach's Champion, 69
description: Antonio de Almeida, a conductor and musicologist who was an authority on the music of Offenbach and whose recordings helped restore the works of Massenet, Duparc and Chausson to the active repertory, died on Tuesday at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. He was 69 and had homes in St. Remy-de-Provence, France, and in Manhattan.

title: Nature Near Waterfront
description: For two decades, a 106-acre stretch of Liberty State Park near the waterfront has remained undeveloped. But now, thanks to the latest Green Acres bond referendum approved by voters last year, state officials plan to fill the site with nature trails, picnic areas, and a wildflower meadow, said James Hall, assistant commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Nets' Trade Satisfies at Least Two Patrons
description: LIKE any endangered species, Nets ticket-holders are to be cherished and nurtured. Therefore, when Ray and Rebecca Gatling recently asked to buy extra tickets, the Nets made sure they were accommodated.

title: Restaurants
description: I can't get the big guy with the coonskin cap out of my mind.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DILL, DAVID
description: DILL-David. January 8, 1997. A celebration of his life will be held Monday, February 24, 1997, 5PM at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette St, NY. Donations may be made to Roswell Park Alliance Foundation, POB 631, Buffalo, NY 14240-9856. Checks should be designated ''In memory of David Dill-Pancreatic Research.'' For further information, contact 212-628-2320.

title: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AGREES TO BUY 53% STAKE IN NHP
description: The stock of NHP Inc. soared more than 29 percent yesterday after the Apartment Investment and Management Company agreed to buy a 53 percent stake in the company for $138 million in cash and stock. NHP, based in Vienna, Va., manages 700 properties and 130,000 apartments. It is the nation's second-largest manager of apartment complexes, after Insignia Financial Group of Greenville, S.C. Apartment Investment, a real estate investment trust based in Denver, bought the stake from the Demeter Holdings Corporation, a unit of the Harvard Private Capital Group, and Capricorn Investors L.P. NHP said Apartment Investment also offered to acquire the remaining shares of NHP for $20 a share. In Nasdaq trading, shares of NHP rose $4.56, to $19.94.

title: Art in Review
description: Ursula von Rydingsvard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, ETHEL SCHNIEWIND
description: PRATT-Ethel Schniewind, on February 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sherman. Loving mother of Ethel M. Woolverton, Hiram Edward Manville, III (Nancy), Maria Helene de Laire, Deming P. Holleran (Romer), and the late Sandra E. Manville. Devoted sister of Margaret S. Stanley, Emily S. Walker, the late Helen S. Kerr and Henry E. Schniewind (Helen). Grandmother of thirteen, and great-grandmother of seven. Memorial services Saturday, 11 A.M. at St. John's of Lattingtown. Contributions may be made to the Grenville Baker Boys and Girls Club, or a charity of your choice. For information, Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, NY.

title: U.S. WON'T OFFER TRADE TESTIMONY ON CUBA EMBARGO
description: Just hours after the World Trade Organization appointed a panel of judges to hear a European challenge to Washington's embargo of Cuba, the United States said today that it would refuse to take part in the legal proceedings. It declared that the new body, which was intended to be the arbiter of world trade rules, ''has no competence to proceed'' in an issue of American national security.

title: Amendment To Ban Deficit Is Less Likely
description: The prospects dimmed further today for Congressional approval of a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget.

title: Pataki to Seek Waiver on Requiring Work for Food Stamps
description: Gov. George E. Pataki plans to seek a waiver from new Federal welfare rules requiring adults to work in exchange for food stamps, sparing tens of thousands of the neediest New Yorkers from the prospect of losing their benefits.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR underwent surgery yesterday for the removal of a brain tumor behind her left ear.

title: Harsher Hit-and-Run Penalty
description: The Assembly unanimously approved a measure yesterday that would make it a criminal offense punishable by 18 months in jail to flee an accident in which someone is seriously injured or killed.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Bulletproof

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHENCA, JACQUES
description: COHENCA-Jacques. Beloved husband of Emy. Loving father of Philip and Nevine. Adored Nono of Daniele, Adam, Stephanie, Jaime and Gregg. Cherished son-in-law of Vittoria. Father-in-law of Gail and Steven, and related family. Service at 10 A.M., on Friday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Crash Test Statistics A Mystery to Buyers
description: Shoppers looking at different types of vehicles in the dealer's showroom can compare price, power, warranty and headroom. Why not compare safety, too?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATSINER, SOLOMON
description: PATSINER-Solomon. Eternal inspiration of life, on Feb. 19th. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Devoted father of Martin (Marilyn) and Harriet (Marty) Ross. Dear brother of Minnie Pakula. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Leslie (Nat), Alyse and Alison. Dear companion of Essie Kleinman. Service Sunday, 1 P.M., Louis Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., corner of 167 St, the Bronx.

title: Home Video
description: Only One Nominee on Tape

title: Art in Review
description: 'A Tribute to Grace Borgenicht Gallery'

title: Messier, Graves and Who? How About Nemchinov?
description: Sergei Nemchinov may turn out to be the player the Rangers have been searching for as the replacement for Aleksei Kovalev, who has been lost for the season with a knee injury. Nemchinov, normally the team's third-line center, saw a lot of action as the right wing for Mark Messier's line in the 1-1 tie with the Devils Wednesday night, and the experienced Russian left some good impressions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLAN, JOAN
description: BERLAN-Joan, died February 19, 1997. Beloved daughter of Harriette and the late Irving Casin. Mother of Debra, Richard, Lisa and Jeffrey and daughter-in-law Deborah. Loving sister of Wendy Rosenbloom. Adored aunt of Daniel. Funeral Sunday 12:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Video Wall at Museum
description: Starting today, the Museum of Modern Art will present a program of video art on a new Digital Video Wall in an underground concourse in midtown Manhattan.

title: Art in Review
description: Florencio Gelabert

title: Albright Offers Russia Plan To Ease Concerns on NATO
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today presented the Kremlin with a new arms control proposal that would freeze military forces near Russia's European periphery, the West's first detailed response to Russian anxieties about NATO expansion.

title: Diner's Journal
description: At 7:30 P.M., there were still tables and a few seats at the sushi bar, but by 7:45 the line for tables at Blue Ribbon Sushi stretched out the door. In SoHo, people don't eat early. By 8:15, people could be seen peering through the window, shrugging and walking away.

title: On One Flight Across China, a Generation Gap Divides Deng's Mourners
description: Many passengers who boarded Flight XO-9115 this afternoon and traversed a country in mourning learned the news of Deng Xiaoping's death as they were leaving for the airport in Urumqi, the capital of the westernmost province of Xinjiang.

title: Chinese Exiles Wonder How Wind Will Blow
description: Inside the world of China's exiled dissidents where they talk about the future, the shape of China after the death of Deng Xiaoping has been the main topic for years, with nearly as many opinions as dissidents.

title: Tie, Tie, Tie: This One Keeps Devils Tied for 2d
description: Jacques Lemaire left the ice laughing tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, FLORENCE G. (NEE SANDLER)
description: STOCK-Florence G. (nee Sandler) Beloved wife of Daniel C. Stock. Sister of Lila Cooper of Pittsburg, PA. We will sadly miss her kind and gentle ways. Service Friday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: New York Times Company Announces a Promotion
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that James C. Lessersohn had been promoted to vice president for corporate planning.

title: Beijing After Deng: Paramount Indifference
description: Far to one side of Tiananmen Square, under the lazy plane trees that loom over a wide sidewalk, a young man approached the square with a floral wreath in memory of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, who died on Wednesday night.

title: Wall Street hopes Tandy can learn from past mistakes and stick with what it does best.
description: IS the Tandy Corporation finally turning itself around?

title: Corrections
description: The Market Timing column in the Money and Business section on Sunday misstated the release date for the quarterly earnings report of TRW Inc. The release was Jan. 21; it is not today.

title: $25 and Under
description: Xunta in the East Village and N 33 Crosby in SoHo are two surprisingly successful places. Why surprising? Because they are both tapas bars.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Accounts
description: * Vermont National Bank, Brattleboro, a unit of Vermont Financial Services, to KSV Communicators, Burlington, Vt., to handle its account, which had been at Paul Kaza Associates, South Burlington. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRICKER, ALICE (HONEY)
description: STRICKER-Alice (Honey), on February 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Adored mother of Jane Bronsky and Judith (Carl) Toth. Cherished sister of Edith Hagan. Devoted grandmother of Matthew, Caitlin, Benjamin and Meghan. Devoted friend of Paul Zimmerman. Services Sunday, 12 noon, ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Blvd. in Forest Hills.

title: World Bank Chief Asks Slimmer Staffs and Better Lending
description: The World Bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn, has proposed a sweeping reorganization costing up to $400 million that is intended to shake up the institution's vast bureaucracy and improve its performance in promoting the economic development of poor nations, bank officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, RUTH
description: SCHLESINGER-Ruth. Of Tamarac, FL., on February 18. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Peter, Richard and Fredric. Loving aunt of Honey and mother-in-law of Joan, Carol and Tina. Adored grandmother of Nicole, David, Lauren, Jamie, William, Rachel and Alexander. Cherished companion of Milton Wynn.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart on Feb. 13 showing recent modest gains in average hourly wages, adjusted for inflation, carried two incorrect labels, and a chart on Sunday with the Diary column of the Money and Business reflected the errors. The figures were for nonsupervisory workers, not all workers, in private industry; they were given in fourth-quarter 1996 dollars, not December 1996 dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, THEODORE
description: FISCHER-Theodore. Of Huntington Bay. Ret. owner Northport Marine Center. Beloved husband of the late Mary Ruth. Devoted father of Susan Baud, Deborah Nugent and Catherine. Loving grandfather of eight. Brother of David. Visitation Sun 2-5 P.M., at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington. In lieu of flowers memorial donations Halesite Fire Dept., 1 North New York Avenue, Halesite, New York 11743.

title: Saatchi Absorbs Sibling Agency
description: The London office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., has absorbed a sibling, K Advertising in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, DIANA (KLUTCH)
description: NELSON-Diana (Klutch), on February 20th, 1997. Beloved wife and companion of the late Dr. Jack Nelson, at whose side she worked and played for sixty years. Devoted mother of Peggy, Ruth, Steve, Mark. Cherished mother-inlaw of David, Lynda, Margaret. Loved grandmother of Jesse, Marya, Molly, Jacob. Dear sister to Ann Prosten. Beloved friend to many. In lieu of flowers, contributions gratefully accepted to the Diana and Jack Nelson Award for Excellence, NYU Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, NYC 10016.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Last Man Standing

title: Dissidents Lose in Vote To Curb Union's Chief
description: Dissident members of Local 32B-J of the Service Employees International Union have been rebuffed in a referendum that they hoped would reduce the power of their president, Gus Bevona, the nation's highest-paid union official.

title: Out in Space, Old Truths Are New Age
description: ''Star Wars'' Fun Fact No. 5,943: When Luke Skywalker and a band of fellow pilots stage the first film's big combat scene, it's a battle to see which tiny spaceship will be the one to shoot its missile into a target aperture and explode the big, spherical Death Star. So a film that is a perennial favorite with teen-age boys offers as perfect a model of sperm-and-egg fertilization as any Hollywood movie ever offered. While George Lucas et al. were popularizing the theories of mythic heroism espoused by Joseph Campbell, they also found room for Dr. Freud.

title: For Children
description: 'Music With Children, Families and Friends'

title: A Gallery Of No-Goods Up to None
description: When Bob Rafelson decides to get nasty, he really means it. The director's flawed but compellingly misanthropic film noir ''Blood and Wine'' imagines human beings as little more than circling birds of prey viciously pecking at each other in a frenzied struggle to possess a shiny object glimpsed from on high. If the movie occasionally gives its desperate characters a pang of conscience, it feels like the tiniest point of light, a perfunctory dot on a pitch-black canvas.

title: Best Western Narrows Review
description: Best Western International Inc. has narrowed a review on its account, with billings estimated at $18 million to $20 million, to four finalists. The account had been handled for four years by Rogge Effler & Partners in Los Angeles, a unit of Dentsu Inc., until that agency declined to participate in the review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINARY, JOHN S.
description: MINARY-John S. The executors of the Estate of William S. Paley and the Directors of the William S. Paley Foundation express their condolences to the family of John S. Minary on his passing. John Minary served William S. Paley and his family loyally for over 50 years bringing to a task his good judgement and devotion.

title: Pacific Bell Gives Ketchum New Role
description: The Pacific Bell unit of Pacific Telesis Group said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with Ketchum Advertising San Francisco by naming that agency to handle advertising for its Pacific Bell Mobile Services Business account, with billings estimated at $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMOLIAN, SHELDON
description: SMOLIAN-Sheldon, 83, of Redding, CT, passed away February 17, 1997 in Scottsdale, AZ. Harvard University '36. Chairman of the Board of Lorraine Industries, Bridgeport, CT, until his retirement. Survived by his wife Miriam; daughters Barbara Gerber of CA, Laura Megroz of VT, Margery Chapman and Lucy Cheatham of CO; son Peter of CA; brother Robert of FL; and nine grandchildren. Services, Friday in Scottsdale.

title: Prosecutor Plans Special Grand Jury in Fatal Beating of Girl
description: Saying the death of an 8-year-old girl whose murder went undiscovered for more than a year warrants a look at why city agencies failed to notice her disappearance, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he would impanel a special investigative grand jury to examine the case.

title: Zaire and Rebels Warily Begin Indirect Talks
description: Senior envoys from both sides of the widening civil war in Zaire sat down with mediators today in Cape Town, at the urging of South African and American officials, but they had little immediate success in agreeing to terms for peace talks, Clinton Administration officials said.

title: Yet Another Lukas Colt Will Challenge Pulpit
description: Pulpit drew the No. 2 post position today and was confirmed as the early favorite for Saturday's Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park, which will be only his third race and his first stakes. But eight other colts were entered to challenge his acclaim as the new star of this year's Kentucky Derby class.

title: Herbert Wilcox, 88, Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. Herbert B. Wilcox Jr., who practiced and taught medicine for four decades and whose patients included Winston Churchill and Sir Anthony Eden, died on Feb. 5 at the Evergreen Woods retirement home in North Branford, Conn. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINES, ARTHUR
description: PINES-Arthur, of Cross River, NY. Passed away February 18, 1997. He is survived by his beloved wife Esther, loving children Michael (Joli Springer) Pines, Deborah Pines (Lori Scaeles), Judith (Jeff Shevell) and the late Steven Jeffrey Pines, cherished grandchildren Emily Shevell, Micah and Deseree Springer, proud brother and sisters Miriam (William) Ruben, Seemon (Natalie) Pines, Cynthia Jacobson, and sister-inlaw Ada Agronin. Mr. Pines was an active member of the Katonah Lions Club and a career research chemist for Union Carbide. Service will be 11:30AM, Sunday at Temple Sharray Tefila, Bedford, NY. Interment at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY.

title: Welfare Overhaul Approved
description: The New Jersey General Assembly approved legislation yesterday to overhaul the state's welfare program, imposing time limits and work requirements on welfare recipients, but also offering incentives to help ease their transition into the workplace.

title: New Trustees of Adelphi U. Dismiss Embattled President
description: The new state-appointed board of Adelphi University today dismissed President Peter Diamandopoulos, the strong-willed academician whose high salary was criticized by faculty members and the State Board of Regents.

title: Bull Stumbles As Dow Falls Below 7,000
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday in what some analysts said was not a surprising retreat, considering how expensive the market had become.

title: Ken Starr's Problem
description: As he went into the job of Watergate Special Prosecutor in 1973, Archibald Cox said that one of his most important obligations would be ''deciding when not to prosecute someone.'' He meant that it would be unfair to let politically damaging charges hang over people indefinitely, without resolution.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: MORE RIDERS, MORE BUSES Expecting an influx of new bus riders with the elimination of two-fare zones, city transit officials are hiring 250 bus drivers and adding 205 extra buses. B3.

title: Federal Court Vacancies
description: To the Editor;

title: TRENTON APPROVES BILL OVERHAULING WELFARE SYSTEM
description: The New Jersey General Assembly approved legislation today to overhaul the state's welfare program, imposing time limits and work requirements on welfare recipients, but also offering incentives to help ease their transition into the workplace.

title: 'Bit Actor' to Star in a New Role: Mr. Chairman
description: As the senator for sale in the 1993 film remake of the Broadway classic, ''Born Yesterday,'' Fred Dalton Thompson warned an influence-peddling tycoon, ''You are making a terrible mistake treating me this way.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SHIRLEY
description: PRICE-Shirley, on February 19, 1997 in her 94th year. Loving aunt of Barbara and Richard Schpero, Ilene and Mel Morris, Nicki and Ira Harris, and Peter Price. Sister-inlaw of Trudy Price, great aunt of Suzanne and Steven Schpero, Marion and Eric Hertlein, Steven Morris, Jackie, Jonathan, and Bradley Harris. Great-great aunt of Harrison Hertlein. Sister to the departed Marion, Ira and Nat. Special cousin to many. Shirley was strongly devoted to her family. She had a great mind. Shirley loved and was loved in return. She was a good listener and a concerned friend. She will be greatly missed and never out of our hearts and minds. Service Sunday 1:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Johnson Wants to Go Out Swinging
description: Howard Johnson, a blast from the Mets' not-so-recent past, a cog in the halcyon days of the late 1980's, was one of the 59 players present for the first full-squad workouts today.

title: Get Real On Food Stamps
description: The litany of pointless cruelties in the new welfare law includes a provision that cuts off food stamps after just 90 days in any three-year period for desperately needy men and women between 18 and 50 who are temporarily jobless, are not raising minor children and are not eligible for Federal welfare benefits.

title: Art in Review
description: Louise Lawler

title: Dorm Days: UConn Players Leave Fame at the Gym
description: Their undefeated college basketball team may be the best in the nation and, since television loves a novelty, their sport's professional league may be all the visual vogue just now. But, for Nykesha Sales and Rita Williams, the star treatment stops right here at Watson Hall, where a blue Dumpster serves as a doorman and a spare sweatsock keeps the door from slamming so hard that the windowpanes rattle like teeth. Dinner isn't served, it's self-serve: the other night it was takeout on Styrofoam cartons cribbed from a post-practice spread of chicken, mashed potatoes and neon yellow corn rinsed down by Snapple straight from the bottle.

title: Caldor Granted Extension
description: The Caldor Corporation, the discount retailer, has received an extension to file its reorganization plan in bankruptcy court. Caldor said the court had moved the deadline to Sept. 1 from Feb. 28. Company officials said they would use the extra time to review Caldor's proposed five-year business plan with creditors. Caldor filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in September 1995.

title: PLACER DOME CANCELS BID TO TAKE OVER BRE-X MINERALS
description: Placer Dome Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled a takeover bid, valued at $6.74 billion (Canadian), or $5 billion (United States), for Bre-X Minerals Ltd. Bre-X, an exploration company based in Calgary, Alberta, won a role earlier this week in the development of the Busang gold deposit in Indonesia, the world's largest gold find. Placer Dome, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, announced the bid in mid-January in an attempt to secure a stake in the Busang mine. Earlier this week, the Indonesian Government approved a plan by Bre-X to develop the 70.95 million-ounce Busang mine with Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold Inc. of the United States and a group of Indonesian partners.

title: 'Star Wars' Names
description: To the Editor:

title: CABLEVISION CONSIDERS SELLING SOME SYSTEMS
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation is considering a plan to sell some of its peripheral cable systems and focus on its markets in New York, Boston and Cleveland, analysts said yesterday. The systems, which represent about 475,000 subscribers in areas like Maine and Michigan, could sell for $850 million to $1 billion. Cablevision, based in Woodbury, L.I., plans to use proceeds of the sale to help pay down its $2.9 billion of debt, analysts said they were told in a conference call with the company. Cablevision is looking to buy the 50 percent of Madison Square Garden L.P. it does not already own. ITT, which owns the other half, may sell its stake as a way to rebuff a hostile takeover by Hilton Hotels.

title: For Albright in Moscow, a Chorus of NATO Nyets
description: As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright arrived here for a first round of talks with Russian leaders, American officials sought today to lower expectations about any quick Russian acquiescence to NATO expansion.

title: Company Briefs
description: HI-LO AUTOMOTIVE INC., Houston, said the Hwang Family L.P., the holder of a 9.8 percent stake in Hi-Lo, had proposed forming a committee to search for a potential buyer of the company.

title: BRITISH PAPER COMPANY TO BUY UNIT OF AMERICAN FILTRONA
description: Bunzl P.L.C., a British paper and plastics manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the bonded fiber businesses of the American Filtrona Corporation for $72.5 million. The businesses, whose products include cigarette filters, had sales of $72.8 million and an operating profit of $8.9 million in 1996. Bunzl is buying the unit from WBT Holdings L.L.C., which agreed to buy American Filtrona for about $172 million on Feb. 10. The sale of the bonded filter business is conditional on WBT's completion of the American Filtrona acquisition.

title: Baerga Turns New Leaf in His Life Style
description: While the Yankees spent this week participating in their own form of Whisky Rebellion over pitcher David Wells's drinking habits, the Mets quietly welcomed Carlos Baerga, their newfound version of Billy Sunday.

title: Muzzled by Beijing
description: Nobody can say how many millions died in the famine. For almost four decades, China's leaders have feared to find out. The figure that foreign demographers think likely is 30 million.

title: Don't Unionize Workfare
description: Long before welfare was overhauled by Congress last year, New York City had introduced work requirements for welfare recipients. Now the city's largest public employee union wants to organize the 35,000 welfare recipients working in city jobs for their benefits, and the national A.F.L.-C.I.O. is seeking to unionize hundreds of thousands of such ''workfare'' participants around the country.

title: New Nets Look Fine In Defeat
description: For Coach John Calipari, today began with a gentle jog, a think session with the sun and the clean air as therapy to ease a mind racing with thoughts. And every thought led back to one thing: the nine-player deal that gave Calipari the talent he wanted.

title: SIERRA RECONSIDERS OFFER FOR PHYSICIAN CORPORATION
description: Sierra Health Services Inc., which has made a takeover offer for the Physician Corporation of America, said yesterday that it was ''seriously evaluating'' its options after a report that Physician would take a $60 million charge against earnings for the fourth quarter. Physician, a managed health care company based in Miami, said the charge was related to increased liabilities associated with its workers' compensation unit. Sierra, a managed care company based in Las Vegas, Nev., made the offer, valued at about $430 million, in November.

title: Judge to Rule in Ages-Old Indian Land Dispute
description: As an airconditioner purred quietly in a seventh-floor Federal courtroom, Navajo and Hopi voices rose over an ancient land dispute that stretches back before Kit Carson, before the Spanish conquistadors and beyond recorded time in the high desert mesas east of the Grand Canyon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, NATHAN L.
description: SAMUELS-Nathan L. February 19, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife, Beverly, sons, Stephen, William and Louis, sister, Lorraine and eight grandchildren. Funeral will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, 12 Noon, Friday, February 21.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: From the West End, With a Snag

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROLL, CLAIRE (NEE BACH)
description: GROLL-Claire (nee Bach). On February 19, 1997. Beloved wife of Shlomo, mother of Avrami and Elisheva, sister of Bernice Tepper. Shiva until Tuesday morning. Shiva information 914-354-6037.

title: Giuliani's Mother Is Injured in a Fall
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's mother, Helen, was slightly injured yesterday when she fell in her Upper East Side apartment. The Mayor said his mother, who is 87, was admitted to a hospital for observation and will undergo tests over the next two or three days.

title: Federal Board Sees Valve Flaw In Boeing 737's
description: The Boeing 737, the most popular airliner in history, is less safe than other airliners because the failure of a single valve, the one that controls the rudder, can cause it to crash, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: White House to Stop Putting Its Employees on Party's Payroll
description: Faced with a barrage of questions and embarrassing revelations about political fund-raising, the White House said tonight it was ending the practice under which some of its employees have been paid by the Democratic National Committee.

title: Ford Will Travel High Road With Adless 'Schindler's List'
description: The NBC presentation on Sunday of ''Schindler's List'' will be unusual far beyond the fact that a broadcast television network will devote three and a half hours during a crucial ratings period to a black-and-white film about the Holocaust. In an out-of-the-ordinary effort joining Hollywood, Detroit and Madison Avenue, it will run without commercial interruptions from advertisers, NBC or local stations.

title: Inside Art
description: Tracing Degas's Taste

title: Clinton Prohibits H.M.O. Limit on Advice to Medicaid Patients
description: President Clinton today prohibited health maintenance organizations from limiting what doctors may tell Medicaid patients about treatment options. And he urged Congress to guarantee similar protections for more than 100 million Americans with private insurance.

title: Assisted-Living Quarters for the Aged Are on the Rise
description: With the number of older people in the city expected to grow, developers are scrambling to build hotel-like rental projects that will offer tenants meals, as well as help with dressing and the monitoring of medication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, HERBERT
description: SCHWEITZER-Herbert. On February 16, 1997. Beloved husband, father, Zaidy, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. He will always live on in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: BERNSTEIN-Dorothy. The Board of Directors and staff of the National Association of Family Development Centers, Family Head Start, and Family Day Care, extend their heartfelt condolences to all the bereaved members of the Bernstein family. For 30 years Mrs. Bernstein was the Assistant Director of our agency as she administered to the total needs of families and children of preschool age while simultaneously acting as an inspirational role model to professional co-workers and staff with varied problems. A pioneer worker and builder of the Hebrew Day School movement in the United States, she labored tirelessly for religious Israeli causes and acted as a consultant to many worthy religious and secular Head Start and Day Care projects. Her life emulated her deeds. She will be sorely missed, and her memory will always be etched in our hearts. David Schwartz Chairman of the Board Dr. Alfred Schnell Executive Director

title: German Daily RefersTo Rifkind as a Jew
description: FRANKFURT  The respected Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung called attention Thursday to the fact that the British foreign secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, is a Jew in its coverage of Mr. Rifkind's speech Wednesday in Bonn.

title: Guerrilla Group's Commander Joins Talks in Peru Hostage Crisis
description: Negotiations to end the hostage crisis at the Japanese Embassy residence here moved forward today after the commander of the Tupac Amaru guerrillas took part for the first time in the talks, which observers described as constructive.

title: Turkey's Christians Need More Than Prayer
description: To the Editor:

title: Soul of Croatia Is Bared in Its Teeth
description: CAFE EUROPA

title: Pataki Is Summoned for Jury Duty
description: In 1995, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation to eliminate exemptions for serving on juries in New York. Now, the Governor has been ordered to report for jury duty in his hometown in Putnam County.

title: Zaire's Rebels Win New Converts
description: Every morning outside the storefront office of the newly opened Ministry of Information here, dozens of young men sign up for seminars in ''revolutionary ideology.''

title: Putting an Angel's Face on Betrayal
description: The cable movie ''Miss Evers' Boys,'' on HBO tomorrow, is as troubling for what it doesn't say as for what it says eloquently. Adapted from Dr. David Feldshuh's play of the same name by Walter Bernstein, whose recent memoir, ''Inside Out,'' recalls the insidious days of Hollywood blacklists, this fictionalized drama is culled from a very real situation in which black men in the South were used as guinea pigs in a Public Health Service experiment.

title: Harlem Unit Under Inquiry And Charges Are Possible
description: The findings of an internal audit of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation have been turned over to state investigators to determine whether criminal charges are warranted, state development officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, JORAM
description: ROSENFELD-Joram. Madison Partners deeply mourns the untimely death of our dear friend and colleague. We extend our deepest sympathies to Sonia and the entire Rosenfeld family. Bobbie Abrams Irv Kagan Bill Lyons Bill Spier Mike Yudin

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Loses 92.75 Points, Falling Below 7,000

title: Bowie's Latest Hit: Royalty-Tied Bonds
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has bought all the bonds marketed by David Bowie, the British rock star. The bonds will pay interest from royalties on some of his old songs.

title: Saab Cars USA Begins a Review
description: Saab Cars USA said yesterday that it had begun a closed review to consider ideas to introduce a 1998 coupe, the Saab 9-5, as well as for the Saab brand.

title: The Spoken Word
description: JON ROBIN BAITZ, Barnes & Noble, 1972 Broadway, at 66th Street. The playwright will read from his work ''The Substance of Fire.'' Tonight at 7. Free. Information: (212) 595-6859.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, GEORGE V.
description: O'BRIEN-George V., on Feb. 19, 1997. Husband of the late Dorothy H. (Abbott) O'Brien and Margaret (Kelly) O'Brien. Father of Eileen C. O'Brien. Formerly of Bradley St, Providence, RI. Retired R.I. District Manager, Social Security Admin. Military Funeral on Saturday at 8:00 AM from the Russell J. Boyle & Son Funeral Home, 331 Smith St., Providence. Mass of Christian Burial at 9:00 AM in St. Pius V Church, Eaton St., Providence. Visiting hours Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: U.S. Subsidiaries of Foreign Companies Gave Heavily to G.O.P.
description: When President Clinton announced last month that the Democratic National Committee would no longer accept contributions from American subsidiaries of foreign companies, he bristled at the Republicans' reluctance to join in that pledge.

title: Fewer City Inspections Mean Less Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Daredevils In Both Rock And Sports
description: Fans came to mosh for the Airwalk Sno-Core tour, a sextuple bill of high-volume, high-impact, high-testosterone bands at Roseland on Wednesday night. The package tour, featuring Face to Face, the Pharcyde, Voodoo Glow Skulls and Less Than Jake, didn't count on this week's warm weather; on most stops, it is to present snowboarding events by day at mountain resorts along with concerts. Sports videos were shown between sets.

title: What Women Could Do in Ancient Egypt
description: This is a good year for Egyptian art in New York. ''Queen Nefertiti and the Royal Women'' is gracing the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And a thematically far more provocative, if slightly less starry, show, ''Mistress of the House, Mistress of Heaven: Women in Ancient Egypt'' opens today at the newly renamed Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: Cash and Unlimited Gifts Are 'American Way,' Lott Says
description: After a private luncheon with 200 of the Republican Party's most generous patrons, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, cast a cold eye today on changing the way candidates raise campaign cash and defended unlimited donations as ''the American way.''

title: Researcher Says How C.E.O.'s Act Is Linked To Order in the Family
description: It is a classic management problem. A company is rolling along, unaware that the bumps it is hitting signal the need to change the way it does business. It isn't really broke, the chief executive thinks, so there's no need to fix it. A little tinkering will do the trick.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the anthropologist Conrad Arensberg on Sunday misstated the name of one of his collaborators. The collaborator was Eliot Chapple, not Eric Chappele.

title: Executive Changes
description: BASS P.L.C., London, appointed Thomas Oliver chief executive of its Holiday Inn Worldwide hotel chain.

title: Union at the Modern Agrees To a Three-Year Contract
description: A settlement was reached yesterday between the Museum of Modern Art and the union that includes some of its curators, librarians, sales people, graphic designers and conservators. They have been working without a contract since Nov. 1. On Dec. 17, they staged a one-day strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, AMELIA
description: SANGER-Amelia. Beloved wife of the late Malcolm Sanger. Aunt of Benedict A. Leerburger and grand-aunt of Ellen Leerburger and Marian Leerburger-Mahl.

title: Safeguards at Hospitals
description: The State Assembly approved a package of bills yesterday that would tighten security and protect patients at the state's seven psychiatric hospitals.

title: 205 More Buses Ordered To Handle Free Transfers
description: Expecting an influx of new bus riders in July, when people can start transferring between buses and subways at no cost, officials are hiring 250 bus drivers and adding 205 extra buses to New York City streets.

title: Clinton Says Mexico's Firmness Is Bright Side of Drug Scandal
description: President Clinton today called the arrest of Mexico's chief anti-narcotics official on charges of collaborating with drug traffickers ''deeply troubling'' but also encouraging because, he said, it demonstrated a commitment by the Mexican Government to combat corruption.

title: Nothing Dramatic, but Knicks Start Road Trip Well
description: They did not need a last-second 3-pointer from John Starks or a clutch rebound from Patrick Ewing in the final minutes. For one productive night of basketball, the Knicks just took care of business.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about the Bellwether Exploration Company's plan to acquire oil and natural gas interests held by Torch Energy Advisers Inc. included an outdated reference to the ownership of Torch Energy. It is an independent company; it is no longer a subsidiary of the Torchmark Corporation.

title: J. C. Penney Income Off Despite Sales Increase
description: The J. C. Penney Company, reporting results for a holiday season that disappointed many retailers, said yesterday that net income and operating earnings declined in the fourth quarter despite a 23 percent increase in sales. The results met analysts' expectations, which had been lowered early in January.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Two Days in the Valley

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Times Company Plans Stock Buyback
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its board had authorized spending of as much as $150 million for the repurchase of class A shares.

title: The Resurging Video, Reclaimed and Reoriented
description: It is not news that young artists are taking to video in growing numbers and with increasing ease these days, nor is it news that a great many of them are women. But it is a pleasant surprise to see the Museum of Modern Art acknowledging these developments with alacrity, focus and understatement in ''Young and Restless.''

title: Housing Starts Inched Up 2% For January
description: Construction starts on homes and apartments rose 2 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today, a smaller-than-expected increase that could signal that the real estate market is cooling after its strongest year in two decades.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 12 about prostate cancer research misstated a researcher's affiliation and the methodology of a recent Swedish study comparing deferred and immediate treatment. The researcher, Dr. Joseph Oesterling, is at the University of Michigan, not the University of Minnesota. In the Swedish study, the 77 patients in the group who were treated received a variety of treatments, alone or in combination, including surgery to remove their prostates or testicles, radiation and hormonal treatments, not surgery alone.

title: Judge Voids Election Plan For Council In Hempstead
description: A Federal judge yesterday or dered Hempstead, the largest mu nicipality on Long Island, to disman tle its at-large electoral system be cause it consistently excluded blacks from its Town Council.

title: Reports of Mild Economic Advances Raise Inflation Jitters
description: The release of moderately favorable economic reports by the Government yesterday raised investor concern about inflation, and the prices of Treasury securities dropped for the third day in a row. A decline in the dollar and a selloff in Treasury futures contributed to the steep drop in bonds in the afternoon.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Head of Panel Is Optimistic On Bailout For Capital
description: The Republican chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the District of Columbia said today that he believed that Congress would soon enact legislation recommended by the Clinton Administration that would address the District's chronic fiscal problems by putting many of its bills on the Federal tab.

title: In Citizenship, In Sickness and in Health
description: THERE actually were couples in the long line outside the marriage license bureau on Queens Boulevard yesterday who swore that they were in love. No kidding. Scout's honor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTHRIE, HENRY B.
description: GUTHRIE-Henry B. The trustees, administration, physicians, and staff of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center note with sadness the death of their distinguished, longtime, trustee and loyal friend. In 1953 he joined the board of Woman's Hospital, serving after its merger with St. Luke's Hospital as trustee and chairman of St. Luke's and, subsequently, as trustee and honorary trustee of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. We extend deepest sympathy to his family. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman Ronald C. Ablow, M.D, President

title: Three States Settle With Prudential On Sales Practices for Life Policies
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has agreed to pay $19.4 million to three of the states that had opposed a huge class action settlement the company reached with millions of customers who had been sold life insurance policies they did not need, the company and officials of the states said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKS, DR. GRAHAM G.
description: HAWKS-Dr. Graham G. The Faculty and Staff of The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Graham Hawks. A noted obstetrician and gynecologist, Dr. Hawks served as Director of Obstetrics from 1973 to 1979. Dr. Hawks was, at the time of his death, emeritus professor and honorary obstetrician/gynecologist at New York-Cornell. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Antonia M. Gotto, M.D. Dean Cornell University Medical College David B. Skinner, M.D. President and CEO The New York Hospital William J. Ledger, M.D. Chairman Dept. of Obstetrics & Gynecology

title: Subsidized Oppression?
description: To the Editor:

title: Scorecard for Garden's Main Event
description: Call it a tiff or a feud, but one thing is undeniable: ITT and Cablevision Systems, the once happy owners of Madison Square Garden, have developed a rift.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILTCHIK, JONATHAN
description: BILTCHIK-Jonathan, born in Chappaqua, NY, resident of Oakland and Los Altos, CA, died on February 16, after a lengthy, heroic battle against cancer. Beloved father of Marta and Gaylen, husband of Jan E. Hafner, devoted brother of David of Washington, DC, Jim of Los Angeles, and Peter of Carlsbad, CA. Cherished friend of Bluegrass musicians.

title: Quiet Man Deserves The Attention
description: THE star center fielder of the World Series champion New York Yankees made his first spring training appearance yesterday and what a bore he turned out to be. Didn't come swaggering through the clubhouse door with a cigar the size of a Louisville slugger between his lips. Didn't get involved in friendly but noisy horse play with Tim Raines and several others. Didn't require a morning news conference to state the nature of his demands for 500 at-bats or a contract extension or additional hot dishes for the clubhouse buffet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RALPH FIENNES may be a leading man of the moment, as well as a contender for an Academy Award as best actor. But he is not exactly demanding star treatment in London, where he opened on Wednesday night in Chekhov's ''Ivanov'' at the Almeida Theater.

title: AMERICAN SAYS PILOTS' DISPUTE WILL DELAY PLANE ORDER
description: American Airlines, the principal subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, will delay deliveries of the first of more than 100 planes ordered from the Boeing Company because of the dispute with its pilots' union, the airline's president, Donald J. Carty, said yesterday. The delay could affect as many as 25 aircraft scheduled for delivery beginning in early 1998, mostly 737's, Mr. Carty said. The total order, worth about $6 billion, was to be delivered between 1998 and 2002 but is contingent upon American's obtaining a contract with the pilots. The company announced the Boeing order on Nov. 21. American pilots went on strike early Saturday but were ordered back to work by President Clinton.

title: Math Gets Friendly, With Fewer Numbers And a Flair for Fun
description: On the theory that most people would rather look at flower petals, abstract sculpture and dazzling computer simulations than cold numbers, a new exhibition at the New York Hall of Science in Queens is luring visitors into thinking about some serious mathematics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINFELD, MORRIS, M.D.
description: KLEINFELD-Morris, M.D. Wellknown gerontologist and Founding Director of the Department of Long-Term Care Medicine at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center from 1975 until 1994, member of the Emeritus Staff until his death. Served on numerous hospital and medical staff committees at KJMC. Graduated from Baylor University in 1935, received M.D. Degree from Baylor University School of Medicine in 1938. Completed residency in medicine at Downstate Medical Center and Maimonides Medical Center. Served in the Armed Forces in 1941 to 1945, earned rank of Major. Diplomate of American Board of Internal Medicine, American Board of Preventive Medicine, Occupational Medicine. Teaching appointments included Professorships at New York University Medical Center and SUNY Health Sciences Center at Brooklyn. For almost 20 years, Director of the Division of Industrial Hygiene, also known as Occupational Medicine, for the New York State Department of Labor. Memberships in professional societies included the American College of Physicians, the American College of Preventive Medicine, the New York Academy of Science, and the American Academy of Occupational Medicine, in addition to many others concerned with safety, occupational medicine and internal medicine. Past Chairman of the Continuing Medical Education Committee of the Academy of Medicine of Brooklyn Inc. Conducted numerous seminars and symposiums relating to geriatric medicine. Author of over 100 scientific publications, lectured widely in medicine, pharmacology, and toxicology. Hospital appointments included Bellevue Hospital, Maimonides Medical Center, Kings County Hospital, University Hospital of Brooklyn, and St. Clare's Hospital. Survived by his wife, Miriam, and 4 children. On behalf of the Members of Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, we would like to express our condolences to the family. The medical world has lost a brilliant and devoted physician and educator. Rajat Mukherji, M.D. President, Medical Staff Michael B. Krasner, President, Board of Trustees David Minkin, President Emeritus Milton M. Gutman, Chief Executive Officer Mohammad Zahir Executive Medical Advisor Linda Brady, M.D. Medical Director

title: Facing 12.6% Financing Cut, UConn Takes Case to Hartford
description: For two years, administrators at the University of Connecticut have been thinking big. After persuading the state to provide a billion dollars in bonding to renovate and expand its campuses, university officials have been working on a more complicated task: attracting faculty and building programs that will bring the school national recognition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, DIANA
description: NELSON-Diana. We have lost a wonderful, staunchly loyal friend, a lady of remarkable courage and dignity whose death leaves a painful void in the life of our family. To Peggy, Mark, Steven, and Ruth our deepest sympathy. The Tuchman Family

title: Topics of The Times
description: Quit Faster, Ken Starr

title: Student, 18, Who Was Smoking in Bed, Dies in Blaze
description: An 18-year-old freshman at the School of Visual Arts died yesterday in a fire started when she smoked in bed in a Gramercy Park apartment building used for student housing, the Fire Department said. The room had an inoperative smoke detector, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, FRANK
description: HELLER-Frank. The Stein family mourns the death of our friend and counsel. Frank's quiet wisdom, fellowship, and generosity enriched the lives of all who were privileged to know him. May Grace and the entire Heller family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moe, Gerry, David, Sandy and Ronald Stein

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: China Plans Deliberately Simple Funeral for Deng
description: China today announced a spare and modest memorial ceremony for Deng Xiaoping, apparently reflecting the leadership's desire to impart a message of calm and continuity and perhaps to avoid risking any spontaneous displays of discontent.

title: Attack Is Waged on Plan to Pay for Fewer Doctors
description: Hospital executives around the nation and powerful members of Congress are reacting with rage to the Federal Government's highly unusual plan to award special payments to hospitals in New York State that agree to train fewer doctors.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nets Send McCloud To Lakers
description: It was the sly smile on George McCloud's face this morning that hinted he was not long for New Jersey and was on his way to being traded to a contender.

title: No Headline
description: ''When Mao died, we all felt strongly because we had worshiped him. Nobody worshiped Deng, and nobody is going to cry because he's dead. He was old. Death is natural.''

title: User-Friendly Campaign Records
description: New York State collects a lot of reports on campaign contributions, but not necessarily in a way anyone can understand. Individual or corporate donations can be scattered through hundreds of different forms in dozens of election boards. The obvious answer is to put the reports on a data base, where they will be easier to compile. New York City's Campaign Finance Board does this successfully, and the city is willing to share its software. The only thing missing is a law directing the campaigns and election boards to computerize.

title: New Works Teeming With Fauna
description: Sequitur, a new-music ensemble that made its debut on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, has a penchant for works with a theatrical element. Its directors, Harold Meltzer and David Amato, have an ambitious plan that includes commissioning works that integrate music with text, theater and dance, and although the inaugural program included no commissioned works, it gave an impression of what the musicians have in mind.

title: Revenge Of the Baby Bells
description: One year ago this month, President Clinton signed legislation that promised to lower consumers' telephone bills, create thousands of jobs and bring futuristic technologies to the homes of millions of Americans. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 was the most sweeping reform of the industry in 60 years, intended to break the monopoly on local phone and cable TV markets and to introduce competition similar to what we now have in the long-distance market.

title: 'Minor Dispute' Became A 'Senseless Homicide'
description: Following is an excerpt from the trial judge's findings in the departmental hearing of Officer Francis X. Livoti.

title: Medical Schools' Merger Failed Over Rankings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, W. RANGER
description: FARRELL-W. Ranger, 71, acoustical architect and graduate of M.I.T. School of Architecture, died February 16th. He joined the firm of Bolt, Beranek & Newman in its early days and was later transferred to NY. Subsequently, he established Ranger Farrell & Associates in Tarrytown, NY, taking on a number of projects with noted architects Philip Johnson & I.M. Pei. He authored several articles and papers, and was well known for inventing an acoustical fabric. His wife, Helena (Fenn) Farrell died in 1983. Survived by two daughters, Debra Dolinski and Suzi Peck; four grandchildren; a brother, Gabriel Farrell, two brothers-in-law, Dan H. Fenn, Jr. and John W. Fenn. His memory shall remain in the minds and hearts of his family who will remember summers by the ocean where his glorious sand castles would appear and be taken back out to sea. A Memorial service will be held at a date and time to be announced. Donations to Denison Nature Center, P.O. Box 122, Mystic, CT 06355. For information, the Dinoto Funeral Home, Mystic, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, JULIUS
description: WALLACE-Julius. Born in the Bronx, New York in his 89th year. One of ten children. Survived by his brother, Louis Wallace, his nephew and companion Melvin Wallace, his sister-in-law and companion Rita Wallace & numerous nieces and nephews. Julius was an officer of Hall Jewelers, Inc., a retail jeweler and importing business where he worked with his brothers, Nat and David. Julius was a veteran of the U.S. Marine Corp. Services will be held Sunday, 1 P.M., Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road and Queens Blvd. in Forest Hills.

title: The Fearless Average Investor
description: Wall Street insiders and Federal Reserve chairmen may worry that stock prices have risen too high and are headed for a fall, but not ordinary investors, according to a survey by Peter D. Hart Research Associates for the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 13 about the defeat of an effort to impose term limits on members of Congress referred incorrectly to the sponsor of a television advertisement that compared Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, to Fidel Castro. The sponsor was Term Limits America PAC, not US Term Limits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, DUDLEY W
description: NORTON-Dudley W.
