The Board of Directors, Administration and Medical and Dental Staff of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center expresses their deepest sorrow on the death of Dudley W. Norton, former Chairman of the Board of Directors and long-time supporter of the Medical Center. Words cannot express the deep sense of loss the entire Medical Center family feels at his passing. He took a personal and active part in the development of the Medical Center and had a keen sense of the future. His wisdom and dedicated guidance has served the Medical Center for more than forty years. Presented with the coveted ''TR'' Award by the Medical Center and the Nassau/Suffolk Hospital Council, he devoted endless hours to the benefit of our Medical Center and the community. He held the Medical Center first in his heart, among his many other interests. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Fredric Rose, Chairman of the Board of Directors Thomas Ockers, President Gopal A. Bhandarkar, M.D., President of the Medical and Dental Staff

title: ADT vs. Chase: Testing Limits Of Bank's Role In Takeovers
description: ADT Inc., continuing to resist a hostile $3.5 billion bid by Western Resources, will drag the takeover battle into the courtroom on Monday, saying that Chase Manhattan Bank violated fiduciary and contractual obligations by allying itself with Western.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINARY, JOHN S
description: MINARY-John S. The executors of the Estate of William S. Paley and the Directors of the William S. Paley Foundation express their condolences to the family of John S. Minary on his passing. John Minary served William S. Paley and his family loyally for over 50 years bringing to a task his good judgement and devotion.

title: Operators of Juice Bars Hope to Match Success Of the Coffee Chains
description: First, there was frozen yogurt, which was transformed overnight from ice cream's poor cousin into an American snacking staple. Then, there was caffe latte, a treat once reserved for gondolas and exotic outposts and now the morning sustenance of construction workers. Can blue-green algae and Ginkgo biloba be far behind?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HERBERT C
description: COHEN-Herbert C. On February 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Sophie. Adoring father of Jo and Gordon Gaynor. Proud grandfather of Stephanie, Lane, Adam, Scott and Lauren. Cherished great-grandfather of Cameron. Graveside service is on Sunday at 1 P.M., at the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SHIRLEY
description: PRICE-Shirley. Dear Cookie, thank you for loving me. I will love you forever! Peter

title: Moshing to Idiom-Hopping Tunes
description: The Offspring slipped into New York City to play at Tramps on Thursday night, with an unadvertised, sold-out show. The young, clean-cut crowd moshed happily and sang along with the hits that made the Offspring's 1994 album, ''Smash'' (Epitaph), a multimillion-seller -- particularly ''Self Esteem,'' about a guy whose girlfriend is only using him. ''The more you suffer,'' the crowd sang, ''the more it shows you really care.''

title: Safir Dismisses Officer in Case Of Illegal Use Of Choke Hold
description: Saying he wanted to send a clear message that police brutality would not be tolerated, Police Commissioner Howard Safir dismissed an officer yesterday who used an illegal choke hold on a man during a 1994 struggle on a Bronx street corner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, IRENE LECK SHEMBS
description: GOLD-Irene Leck Shembs, 89 of Asheville, North Carolina, died Thursday, February 20, 1997, in an Asheville hospital. Born in Newton, Iowa, she was a daughter of the late Thomas W. and Katherine Engel Goodhue and a niece of the late Wanda Stanard of Asheville. She retired to Asheville with her husband, William H. Leck, from New York City 30 years ago. A graduate of Iowa State University at Ames, she was a field director for the American Red Cross during World War II and a national home economist for Maytag Company, Newton, Iowa, and Leck Industries, NY. She was published in many magazines and made several guest appearances on the Today show. She was a member of Grace Covenant Presbyterian Church, The Children's Welfare League, Colonial Book Club, Chatmore Club, the Country Club of Asheville, and was a sustaining member of the Junior League. She is survived by a son, William J. Leck, and his wife, Maureen, of Rockville Centre, NY; daughter, Nancy Leck Galas, and her husband, Joseph, of Denver, CO; sister, Wanda Buchanan of Crystal Springs, MS; six grandchildren; 18 great-grandchildren; and nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, Monday, at Grace Covenant Presbyterian Church, Asheville, NC with the Reverend Genie Martin officiating. A reception will follow at the church. The family will receive friends from 3-5 PM, Sunday, at Morris Funeral Home, 304 Merrimon Ave, Asheville, NC. Memorials may be made to Grace Covenant Presbyterian Church, 789 Merrimon Ave, Asheville, NC 28804 or to the Owen Heart Center at Memorial Mission Hospital, 509 Biltmore Ave, Asheville, NC 28801.

title: Correction
description: A.M. Rosenthal's column yesterday referred incorrectly to the missile attack on the frigate U.S.S. Stark in 1987. It was Iraq that fired the missile, not Iran.

title: Pianist as an Explorer in the Land of Jazz
description: In the mid-80's, when the pianist Benny Green made his way to New York City from California, he was looking for something new. Mr. Green, who worked with the singer Betty Carter, rummaged around in the odd corners of a tune; he explored. Then he hardened. And for much of his career, he has wandered the halls of jazz as an anachronism, a soul jazz pianist who looked to popularizers like Oscar Peterson and Gene Harris for a way of thinking.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADISCH, RHODA
description: RADISCH-Rhoda. Beloved wife of the late Milton, loving mother of Lois, dear sister of Sally Kroll, devoted grandmother of Miriam and Anna, cherished aunt of Linda, Cynthia, Heather, and Joseph. Services 1:00 pm Sun, ''The Riverside''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Stocks Slide But Markets Close Mixed

title: Master of Many Arts
description: While rehearsing a play, actors often fill the margins of their scripts with notes to themselves about their roles. With Antony Sher, the script becomes a private illustrated version, in which the actor freely mixes his comments with his drawings of the characters. Some actors write books and others are artists, but Mr. Sher is a triple-threat: an actor, author and artist.

title: Decorum in the Court!
description: Avon has been ordered to move its court out of a gym in a municipal building and into more decorous premises by March 21 or risk losing it to another town, Monmouth County's chief judicial officer said Wednesday.

title: Miles to Go In This Old Armory
description: DR. NORBERT SANDER talks a mile a minute. Too bad he can't run as fast, although he did win the New York City Marathon in 1974. He remains fleet of phrase in his current long-distance pursuit: restoring the Fort Washington Armory to its place as the region's premier indoor running track.

title: From Hope to Despair and Suicide for a Teen-Age Immigrant
description: The letters from Queens arrived in the former Soviet Union, warning of new hardships in America, of growing hostility toward foreigners and of declining government aid for the persecuted. But Aron Akilov did not believe the stories his relatives told. He was fleeing Uzbekistan, where Jews were sometimes beaten and taunted. And as he and 15 relatives packed their bags, they envisioned a place where people worshiped freely, owned big houses and drove sporty cars.

title: PEPSICO SAYS IT HAS NO PLANS TO DROP U.S. BOTTLING UNIT
description: Pepsico Inc.'s beverage chief, Craig Weatherup, said yesterday that it was ''highly unlikely'' that the company would spin off its United States soft drink bottling business because it was profitable enough and too important to sell. Mr. Weatherup, chairman and chief executive of the Pepsi-Cola Company, said the bottling business gave the company numerous benefits in running its soft drink business. Investors have speculated that Pepsico may drop the bottling operation since it said last month that it would spin off its KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell restaurant chains to focus on drinks and Frito-Lay snacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, JOYCE FIELDS
description: SIMONS-Joyce Fields. On February 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Richard Fields and the late Judith Fields Alviani. Mother-in-law of Marjorie Vandow and Joseph Alviani. Loving grandmother of Matthew and Samantha. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Monday evening 7-9 PM, with a service on Tuesday, February 25, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Condolence Calls Put Rare Light on Deng's Family
description: Just north of the Forbidden City, where China's emperors once lived, a maze of dusty lanes and grubby back alleys are punctuated by simple red doorways befitting ramshackle homes. Behind some of these doorways, however, lie the elegant and spacious courtyard dwellings of the families of China's Communist Party leaders, a new kind of Forbidden City.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP., Waukegan, Ill., said that it would cut its United States production of boats and motors in the wake of lower-than-expected sales and it might close some plants.

title: Pataki Says Waiving of Food Stamp Rules Doesn't Signal Economic Problems
description: Defying claims to the contrary, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that his decision to give 38 counties and cities with high unemployment rates the option of waiving stricter new welfare rules did not signal that the state was having economic problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, FRIEDA BIALKIN
description: GOLDBLATT-Frieda Bialkin, died peacefully on February 18, 1997, just before her ninety-first birthday. Wife of the late Morris, mother of Jerome and Zita Rosenthal, sister of Miriam, Nettie, Bernard and Albert, grandmother of Ellen, James and Elizabeth. Her lively sense of humor and wonderful smile will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral service and interment was held on Friday, February 21 for family members only. Visitation Sunday, 3-6 P.M., at Will-O-Woods; Monday 5-8 P.M., Manhattan.

title: Regulation Redux?
description: To the Editor:

title: Iona Avenges a Defeat And Gains Top Seeding
description: Last year, Iona's season ended in disappointment. Canisius took away what the Gaels felt should have belonged to them: a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament title and a National Collegiate Athletic Association berth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, HELEN E.
description: BAKER-Helen E., 64, of Bethany, PA, on February 21, 1997 at her home. Survived by husband, Alexander J. Baker, son, Alexander J. Baker of Philadelphia, daughters, Cecilia Brennan of Westwood, NJ and Cathlin Baker of NYC. Employed with Lucent Technologies, she received a B.A. from Manhattanville College, an M.A. from NYU and a Ph.D. from Rutgers University. She was a harpsichordist and pianist and a music professor. Memorial service at 2 PM on February 23 in Bethany, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Riverside Church/Emancipation from Poverty Program, 490 Riverside Drive, NY, NY 10027.

title: Extend Tax Breaks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENDEL, RONNI
description: PENDEL-Ronni. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY mourns the loss of Ronni Pendel, sister of our Board member Michael Weiss, and extends sympathy to his family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi Jeffrey Scherr, President

title: UNITED GRAIN REJECTS HOSTILE TAKEOVER BID
description: United Grain Growers Ltd. said yesterday that it had rejected a $172 million hostile takeover bid by Alberta Wheat Pool and Manitoba Pool Elevators, calling the offer ''totally inadequate.'' United Grain, based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, is a grain merchandising and farm-service concern serving 100,000 commercial farmers in western Canada. Alberta Wheat Pool and Manitoba Pool Elevators are farmer-owned cooperatives that handle and market grain, special crops, seeds and oil seeds. On Thursday, Alberta Wheat Pool and Manitoba Pool Elevators offered $13.75 (Canadian) a share, or $10 (United States), for United Grain in a move they said was intended to prevent United Grain from being acquired by foreign competitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, JORAM D
description: ROSENFELD-Joram D. Kellstrom Industries, Inc., deeply mourns the loss of its Co-Chairman, Joram D. Rosenfeld. His advice and friendship will always be missed and we extend our most sincere condolences to Joram's family.

title: World Forestry Talks End in Division on Whether to Curb Logging
description: With the world's forests continuing to shrink, more than 70 governments ended two years of talks today deeply divided over whether to propose binding steps to curb overlogging.

title: The Met Presents the Season's First 'Aida'
description: There was a time not so long ago when the Metropolitan Opera was hard-pressed to cast a Mozart opera properly. Now there is an abundance of first-rate Mozart singers. And in recent years some exciting Wagner singers have emerged, to the relief of Wagnerites who feared this repertory was doomed with the departure of Birgit Nilsson and Jon Vickers.

title: Delayed, but Good Deeds Get Done
description: With only six days days left in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's 85th annual appeal, donations have slowed and the fund remains about $140,000 behind the total collected last year. The appeal, which began after Thanksgiving, runs until Friday.

title: Federal Funds for Clean Needles
description: Health and Human Services Secretary Donna Shalala says in a new report to the Senate that needle-exchange programs are an effective way to combat the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. But the Secretary does not go far enough. It is time the Clinton Administration lifted the ban on Federal funding for needle-exchange programs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the obituary of Deng Xiaoping on Thursday referred incorrectly at one point to the timing of his purge from senior posts in 1976. It occurred shortly before Mao Zedong's death, not afterward.

title: Darold Dobs, 54, Bowling Congress Leader
description: Darold Dobs, the executive director of the American Bowling Congress, died in Milwaukee on Feb. 10. He was 54.

title: Slaughter Touches a Farming Town
description: By the time Dr. Tim Eberhart was called to the scene, a half-hour after midnight, 15 victims were already dead. Two more were writhing on the ground and succumbed within minutes.

title: New Studies Show PCB's Persist In Hudson, and Are Entering Air
description: New studies by Federal and New York State scientists have found that the coating of PCB's on the shores and bottom of the Hudson River is not being cleaned up by natural processes, as some industrial polluters have asserted, and that substantial amounts of these toxic compounds are evaporating from mud flats and wafting in the air.

title: S.E.C. Investigating Firms In Sale of Municipal Bonds
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, Smith Barney Inc. and Paine Webber Group Inc. are being questioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission about whether they overcharged municipalities in bond sales, people involved with the inquiry said.

title: Curfew Siren Blares No More
description: The siren on top of City Hall meant to clear the streets when a daytime youth curfew was imposed -- is silent, and officials say it may not be fixed. But even without it, the curfew appears to be working, and more truants are going to school.

title: Lives in Their Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: Optimism at Seward Park

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, JAMES MONROE, M.D.
description: JONES-James Monroe, M.D. Of Bronxville, NY on February 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Agnes. Dear father of Deborah Lash and Gwyneth Jones. A memorial service will be held at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Tuesday, February 25 at 4:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, New York.

title: Anti-Intellectual Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: The South's Hidden Heritage
description: Amid all the controversy over Confederate war memorials and displays of the Confederate flag, it is often forgotten that there is more to Southern history than slaveholding and secession. There are many Southern traditions, and all deserve public recognition.

title: Robert Herman, 82, Physicist Who Predicted Big Bang Echo
description: Dr. Robert Herman, a physicist who began his career by predicting echoes of the origin of the cosmos and later developed a new field called traffic sciences in which statistics can be used to predict traffic jams, died on Feb. 13 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 82.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Parents Give TV Ratings Mixed Reviews
description: Six weeks after the television industry began displaying rating codes on screen to alert parents to programs that might be unsuitable for children, most parents say they do not use the ratings system for guidance, even though nearly all say they applaud the system in concept.

title: White in World League
description: STAN WHITE, the Giants' third-string quarterback, will play for the London Monarchs of the World League this spring. White has not thrown a pass during his three seasons with the Giants. He will join 95 other National Football League players who have already been allocated to the World League for this season. The league consists of six teams, each playing a 10-game schedule.

title: Columbus Circle Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: State College Offers Ph. D.
description: Rowan College will become the first state college to offer a doctoral program. Yesterday, the Commission on Higher Education authorized the school to offer a Ph. D. in educational leadership.

title: Profits at Honda Tripled in Third Quarter
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that its earnings more than tripled in the fiscal third quarter, putting it on track for the most profitable year in its 49-year history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELLER, SEYMOUR
description: TELLER-Seymour. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi I. Akiva Wulkan, MD, President

title: IN TURNAROUND, STARR SAYS HE'LL COMPLETE HIS INQUIRY AS WHITEWATER PROSECUTOR
description: In a startling reversal, Kenneth W. Starr announced this afternoon that he would not resign as the Whitewater independent counsel to become a dean at a California university until his investigation was completed.

title: Again, Britain Must Free Men Who Were Wrongly Convicted
description: In another humiliating reversal for the British justice system, the High Court today freed three men who had served 18 years in jail for murder, after prosecutors conceded that their 1979 trial was ''fundamentally flawed.''

title: Greenspan for Eased Rein on Derivatives
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, today applauded efforts in Congress to reduce United States Government regulation of derivatives and financial futures markets.

title: Belgrade Opposition Takes Control of the City Council
description: Serbia's opposition coalition took control of the Belgrade City Council today, the biggest prize so far in its fight to topple President Slobodan Milosevic and a main goal of its nearly three months of street protests.

title: Excerpts From News Conference: 'It Was a Mistake'
description: Following are excerpts from Kenneth W. Starr's news conference today in which he announced he would remain the Whitewater independent prosecutor until he completed his investigation, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Files Hint of Illegal Venezuelan Link to Democrats
description: The Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday that he had given Federal prosecutors evidence that a Venezuelan banking family might have illegally funneled campaign contributions to the Democratic Party during the 1992 election.

title: Politics as Pleasure: A Wall Falls
description: Created by the Western allies in 1951, the Berlin Film Festival has traditionally been the most political of movie jamborees. For many years it was a weapon in the cold war, serving as a showcase of Western cultural freedom. Later, in the mid-1970's, it became a symbol of East-West detente, offering an annual glimpse of how cinema was faring beyond the Berlin wall. But its role was always political.

title: Bowe Goes Marching Back Home
description: RIDDICK BOWE has suddenly become the envy of thousands of men and women who have ever dreamed of leaving the military after getting fed up with latrine duty, unappreciative drill sergeants and that thing served in the mess hall called, in polite society, slop on a shingle.

title: Child-Welfare Supervisors in Queens Charge Improper Pressures to Close Cases
description: Supervisors at a Queens office of the city's child welfare agency have charged that they are being pressured by superiors to end active investigations of abuse or neglect prematurely and improperly, to close out a vast backlog of cases.

title: Manfred Klafter, 77; Aided Holocaust Survivors
description: Manfred Klafter, a Dutch Holocaust survivor who founded an Israeli organization offering psychological and social support to Israel's 300,000 Holocaust survivors and their families, died on Feb. 6 in Bern. He was 77 and lived in Jerusalem.

title: Pennies to Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: Middle Class Hangs On
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders' Big Stretch Begins Poorly
description: Five games in nine days.

title: Club Med Has Loss and Hires a New Chief
description: Club Mediterranee S.A. posted a surprise loss today and said it had hired Euro Disney S.A.'s chief executive, who faces the task of improving the flagging fortunes of the vacation resort operator.

title: Katharine McKean, Tennis Player, 82
description: Katharine Winthrop McKean, an outstanding amateur tennis player of the 1930's and 1940's, died on Feb. 12 at her home in Hamilton, Mass. She was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODCOCK, ROBERT BELL
description: WOODCOCK-Robert Bell, 83, of Hope Valley and Little Compton, RI, formerly of Norwalk and Darien, CT, and Vero Beach, FL, died February 19, 1997. Husband of Frances Bennett Woodcock and father of Mary W. Johnson and Frances W. MeVay. Past president and owner of the John M. Glover Agency of Norwalk, CT. A memorial service will be held in Little Compton, RI, this summer. Burial service will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Sakonnet Preservation Association, Box 945, Little Compton, RI 02837.

title: OPEN MARKET TO BUY FOLIO FOR $45 MILLION
description: Open Market Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Folio Corporation, a software supplier for managing business information, for $45 million. Folio, a subsidiary of Reed Elsevier P.L.C., will operate as the Folio division of Open Market and will remain in Provo, Utah. Open Market, a software developer based in Cambridge, Mass., said it expected the acquisition to close by March 31. Reed Elsevier is a British-Dutch publishing company based in London.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, EZRA J.
description: DENERSTEIN-Ezra J. Beloved father and grandfather. Forever loved, forever missed, today and every day. Susan and Harris

title: Beliefs
description: Maybe it is enough to note that the organizers planned a conference for 450 people and that well over 1,000 came. Maybe it is enough to report the high proportion of attendees under 30.

title: Clinton Trampled Labor in Airline Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia's State Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Ratings System Receiving Little Use
description: Nearly all American parents say that they endorse rating television shows in principle, but most say they are not using the system to guide their children's viewing.

title: Leonard Altman Memorial at Carnegie Hall
description: A memorial concert for Leonard Altman, a musician, educator and arts preservationist, is to take place tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Voice and Freelancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: If both defenders err, and the declarer makes a contract that should have been defeated by correct play, there is a school of thought that pins the blame on the player who makes the final error. This can be cruel when the final error is subtle, and an earlier one, on the other side of the table, is not.

title: Patterson Set to Pursue Gatti and His Title
description: The last time Tracy Patterson and Arturo Gatti stepped into the same ring, it was an epic battle. They slugged it out for 12 rounds at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 15, 1995, with Gatti winning a decision and taking Patterson's International Boxing Federation junior lightweight title.

title: Declining Russian Army
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Use of Army to Fight Drugs Worries U.S.
description: Even before the head of Mexico's anti-narcotics program was arrested this week for collaborating with drug traffickers, United States officials had growing doubts about the wisdom of President Ernesto Zedillo's policy of entrusting more and more of the drug war to the armed forces.

title: Lewis Jacobs, 92, Writer and Teacher
description: Lewis Jacobs, a writer, film maker and teacher, died on Feb. 11 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 92 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Recent Changes at WMX Satisfy Dissident, for Now
description: WMX Technologies, the beleaguered waste hauler, and Soros Fund Management, the dissident holder of 5.2 percent of WMX's stock, have reached a detente.

title: Graf to Miss Fed Cup
description: Further endangering her No. 1 ranking, STEFFI GRAF announced yesterday that chronic tendinitis in her left knee has forced her to withdraw from next week's Fed Cup as well as two coming Corel Tour events, the Evert Cup at Indian Wells, Calif., and the Lipton at Key Biscayne, Fla. ''I really wanted to play on my own doorstep,'' she said of the Fed Cup event, to which she also owns the promotional rights in Germany. ''But my main goals are to play the French Open and Wimbledon.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GETTINGER, PAUL P.
description: GETTINGER-Paul P. Dearest father. 41 years. We love and miss you today and every day. Martin and Gloria

title: Real Goose Bumps for Scholastic As Its Share Price Plunges 40%
description: ''Goosebumps,'' the series of creepy children's thrillers that has enjoyed phenomenal popularity in recent years, produced a sudden fright for its publisher yesterday after investors learned of the books' declining sales and sent the company's stock plunging by 40 percent.

title: Couple Charged With Abuse of 7 Children
description: A pregnant mother of seven and her boyfriend were charged with child abuse today after authorities discovered bruises and welts on the children.

title: A Lawyerly Cry of Conscience
description: Citing systematic unfairness in what Justice Harry Blackmun of the Supreme Court once famously dubbed the ''machinery of death,'' the American Bar Association has called for suspension of the death penalty until the system is changed to afford adequate due process. This is a principled stand, even though it is unlikely to have much impact given the strength of the pro-death-penalty position among lawmakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINES, ARTHUR
description: PINES-Arthur, of Cross River, NY. Passed away February 18, 1997. He is survived by his beloved wife Esther, loving children Michael (Joli Springer) Pines, Deborah Pines (Lori Scaeles), Judith (Jeff Shevell) and the late Steven Jeffrey Pines, cherished grandchildren Emily Shevell, Micah and Deseree Springer, proud brother and sisters Miriam (William) Ruben, Seemon (Natalie) Pines, Cynthia Jacobson, and sister-inlaw Ada Agronin. Mr. Pines was an active member of the Katonah Lions Club and a career research chemist for Union Carbide. Service will be 11:30AM, Sunday at Temple Sharray Tefila, Bedford, NY. Interment at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY.

title: How Donor With Asian Ties Knitted Access and Success
description: On one of Beijing's busiest shopping streets, an eye-catching display for a small Chinese beer and soda company hangs in a glass case. The highlight of the display is a photograph of President Clinton and the First Lady, smiling at a White House Christmas party as they pose with the Chinese company's chairman and two other men. Beneath the photo sit an oversized beer bottle and two mugs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Compaq Presario 2000, a new personal computer priced below $1,000, cited one feature erroneously. The 14-inch monitor is sold separately for $300.

title: Financial Aid
description: Just two years ago Jerry Yang, now 28, and David Filo, 30, were toiling long and hard as modestly paid graduate students at Stanford University. But instead of turning glum, they started surfing the Internet for fun and profit. Well, not exactly for profit at the beginning. To pass the time, they put together a guide to their favorite sites on the World Wide Web. Soon the list became so unwieldy they had to develop a way to index and retrieve material from the Web, a service they made free to all Web users.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHRER, CARLTON J
description: ROHRER-Carlton J. On Feb 20, 1997. Brother of Elizabeth R. Reddy of Westlake, OH and J. Albert Rohrer of Youngstown, NY. Survived by two nieces and a nephew. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. on Mon 3-5 and 7-9 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Francis Xavier RC Church, 46 W. 16 St, (betw 5th and 6th) on Tues 10:30 a.m. Interment Lewiston, NY. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to St. Francis Xavier Church or a charity of your choice.

title: Gretzky Gets a Goal, but Ranger Drought Goes On
description: Mistakes were what the Rangers were all about tonight at the Hartford Civic Center. There were physical ones and mental ones. There were rookie ones and veteran ones. There were offensive ones, defensive ones and goaltending ones.

title: H.M.O.'s Reportedly Delayed Paying Hospitals and Doctors
description: Hospital officials and doctors said yesterday that some insurers and managed health care companies in New York state are delaying payments on tens of millions of dollars for medical bills, forcing some hospitals to borrow money to pay their own bills.

title: Getting to the Turnpike
description: Officials have come up with a revised plan for a highway connecting Route 1 and the New Jersey Turnpike in the traffic-congested central region of the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINSCHMIDT, HANS
description: KLEINSCHMIDT-Hans, 83, psychiatrist and art collector. Dr. Hans Joachim Kleinschmidt, who practiced and taught psychiatry in New York for five decades, died on February 21 in his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 83. Born in Prostkin, East Prussia in 1913, Dr. Kleinschmidt grew up in Berlin and began medical school at the University of Freiburg. In 1933, he fled the Nazi regime and escaped to Italy, where he completed medical school at the University of Padua. In 1939, he fled to Jerusalem, where he began a training in neurosurgery. He emigrated to the United States in 1946 and completed a residency in psychiatry at Hillside Hospital in Queens. He joined the staff of Mount Sinai Hospital in 1952, where he became Associate Clinical Professor of Psychiatry. He married Ruth Benjamin, a designer, in 1948 and was widowed in 1990. Dr. Kleinschmidt retired last year from an active clinical practice and throughout his career, wrote on the interrelations between creativity and psychoanalysis. Dr. Kleinschmidt also donated his services to survivors of the Holocaust in their efforts to receive remuneration from the German government in the years after World War II. His life was enriched by his abiding interest in art and literature. An expert in abstract expressionism, he edited Richard Heulsenbeck's memoirs on the origins of the Dada movement, published in 1959. A part of Dr. Kleinschmidt's private collection was exhibited by the University of Iowa's Fine Arts Dada Archives and Research Center in 1988. Dr. Kleinschmidt is survived by his four children, Peter, Trude, Catherine and Nina, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, February 23rd at 11 AM. Donations may be sent to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Some Ground Beef Is Contaminated in Deboning, U.S. Says
description: The Department of Agriculture acknowledged today that a relatively new method for deboning beef by machine contaminated some ground beef with bits of spinal cord, bone and bone marrow, in violation of Federal regulations.

title: Real Culprits in Education So Far Avoid Notice
description: To the Editor:

title: Chapter 11 Exit At Smith Corona
description: The Smith Corona Corporation is planning to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection next Friday.

title: North Korea Inches Toward Talks to Finally End '50-'53 War
description: North Korea confirmed today that it would attend a briefing by the United States and South Korea to explain proposed peace talks.

title: Fountain of Youth Has Speed
description: Partly cloudy but dry weather, a lightning-fast track and a ripping speed duel were forecast today for the Fountain of Youth Stakes, which will be run Saturday at Gulfstream Park as the second of three major Florida tests for the Kentucky Derby. The first race in the series, the Hutcheson Stakes, was won three weeks ago by a 105-1 shot, Frisk Me Now, who was back for more as the 20-1 long shot in the field of nine entered for the $200,000 Fountain of Youth.

title: Misfits and Lowlifes With Attitude
description: ''In-Betweens,'' Bryan Goluboff's garish kitchen-sink drama set in a Bronx slum, has had a painful and circuitous route to the stage. A production at the Westside Theater was canceled weeks before opening in 1994, when its director, Kevin Conway, was fired, and two of the actors, Bruno Kirby and D. B. Sweeney, quit.

title: Yanks Sigh as Wells Finally Toes Rubber
description: David Wells again provided an act that the Yankees have not seen all spring training, but this time the team was pleased with his routine because he actually stepped atop a mound in the bullpen and threw 50 fastballs in 10 minutes. Wells did not report any pain in a right big toe that is plagued by gout, and the Yankees hoped that his pitching performances will now become more renowned than his comedic performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATSINER, SOLOMON
description: PATSINER-Solomon. Eternal inspiration of life, on Feb. 19th. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Devoted father of Martin (Marilyn) and Harriet (Marty) Ross. Dear brother of Minnie Pakula. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Leslie (Nat), Alyse and Alison. Dear companion of Essie Kleinman. Service Sunday, 1 P.M., Louis Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Ave., corner of 167 St, the Bronx.

title: Jets Increase Ticket Prices
description: The Jets are no longer the lowest National Football League team in one category, the price of their tickets. The club yesterday announced an increase in prices that will put it second lowest in average seat cost, or about a nickel ahead of the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, ELLIOTT
description: BERNSTEIN-Elliott. Happy Birthday, dearest Elliott. ''It was a beautiful spring day the day you were born.'' Loved and missed so much, Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, IRENE
description: KOENIG-Irene. Feb. 20, 1997. Beloved mother & mother-in-law of Andrew and Yvonne. Cherished grandmother of Robert, Mark and Nina. Dear sister of Ibi and Manyi. Aunt of Tom (Krystina) Kramer, Vera and Marika, John (Cynthia) Koenig, Louis (Frici) Koenig. Funeral service from Paperman and Sons, 3888 Jean Talon West, Sunday, February 23, 1997 at 11:30 am. Shiva at 3982 Cote des Neiges #

title: Fiery Dazzle, Then Sadness
description: George Balanchine's ''Cortege Hongrois'' is a big, gaudily wrapped package that seems, deceptively, to have nothing much inside. Its lush Glazunov score adds to the effect. But the work, performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, has a great deal of enjoyable go-for-broke dancing, and the entire cast rose exhilaratingly to its challenges.

title: Dominican Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BYRNE, LAWRENCE WILLIAM
description: BYRNE-Lawrence William. 7/24/37-2/22/91. Six years now, Larry, we always miss you, we always love you. Rest in peace with Mom and Dad and now Kathleen. Doreen, Terry and Mary

title: No Headline
description: ''We all have to remember that he's recovering from a major heart operation. But I spent almost an hour with him, and we had a very sharp and good discussion. He did not use one note and he's really right on point, and I think he's very much in charge.''

title: Limon Troupe to Represent U.S. at Festival in Sarajevo
description: The Jose Limon Dance Company, Pink Inc. and Margo Lee Sherman have been chosen to represent the United States in the XIII International Festival Sarajevo, which opened in Sarajevo on Feb. 7 and runs through March 21. They will be the first American artists to participate in the festival and among the few to perform in Bosnia since war broke out there five years ago.

title: Japan Hasn't Really Failed
description: Americans have a puzzling penchant for viewing Japan in extremes. In the late 1980's, the fad or fear was that Japan represented a superior form of capitalism -- with industrial policy and lifetime employment -- that might end up dominating global business or owning America.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise On Big Board and the Amex
description: The number of open positions of short sales rose to record levels on both the New York and the American Stock Exchanges in the latest reporting month, the exchanges said yesterday.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Stage a Cautious Rally
description: Bonds staged a mild rally yesterday, as buyers emerged to take advantage of the lower prices and higher yields after three days of selling in the bond market. But even though there appeared to be interest at these higher yield levels, traders said investors remained cautious.

title: 12 Characters in Search of a Soap Opera, Again
description: They used to say that Tracy Quartermaine, the sinister sister of the Quartermaine clan in Port Charles, N.Y., was a cold-blooded cobra. She outscandalized and outsmarted the best of them -- deadly doctor impersonators, murderous mistresses, even a sly undercover agent named Scorpio.

title: Investing Manager Is Part of S.E.C.'s 'Soft Dollar' Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Dawson-Samberg Capital Management, an investment management firm in Southport, Conn., as part of a wider inquiry into financing arrangements between investment managers and their brokers.

title: Too Many Lawyers? Wait Until 2005
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently predicted that we will have 28 percent more lawyers by the year 2005. That means 839,000 working lawyers, compared with the 656,000 practicing law in 1994. From another perspective: Job growth in the legal profession will be twice the average projected for all occupations. Pretty promising stats for the most hated profession in the America.

title: Trial of Houston Doctor Linked to Unapproved Drugs Goes to Jury
description: Jury deliberations began today in the trial of Dr. Stanislaw Burzynski, indicted here on 75 counts involving unapproved drugs he developed and used to treat a variety of cancers.

title: UConn Sets the Tone With Weights and Hard Work
description: When Kara Wolters finished high school, she was, in her words, a 6-foot-7-inch blob. Now, 65 pounds lighter, the Connecticut center has become perhaps the most dominant player in women's college basketball, a tribute to what hard work in the weight room can do.

title: Despite Scandal, U.S. Plans To Certify Mexico Drug Fight
description: Despite the shock over the recent arrest of the Mexican Government's top anti-drug official on charges that he had links to drug traffickers, the Clinton Administration plans to certify Mexico next week as an ally in the war against illegal drugs, Government officials said today.

title: 737 Warning Draws a Shrug From Public
description: The warning by a Federal aviation agency that the Boeing 737, the workhorse of the American air transport system, is less safe than other aircraft is being greeted with a collective shrug of indifference by passengers.

title: The Knicks Get Overpowered at Their Own Game
description: The Knicks wanted to play a physical game. Force Gary Payton to cool his jets and emotions, and reduce the tempo to a crawl. Keep the score down and keep the crowd quiet. Brute force would prevail over ballet.

title: 'You vs. Us' Is Over, Albright Tells Wary Russians
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright tried to assure President Boris N. Yeltsin and the Russian people today that NATO is ''no longer a situation of you versus us,'' but she seemed to make little headway in easing Moscow's anxiety about expansion of the Western alliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUART, ELLEN E
description: STUART-Ellen E. Died in Venice, Florida. Mrs. Stuart was born in Newport, Wales. Moved to Hoboken, NJ in 1958. Lived in NY Tudor City from 1962-1990. Ellen was the Executive Medical Secretary to the Surgeon Director at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital in NYC. She was a member and former Grand Regent for the Daughters of the British Empire. She was a lector at Saint Patrick's Cathedral for Cardinal O'Connor and Archbishop Maguire, also lectored in French at Holy Family Church (Church of the United Nations). She is survived by her son Anthony C. Stuart, Sr. and four grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at the Epiphany Cathedral in Venice, Florida with notice of time later. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington, NJ. For information Earl F. Bosworth Funeral Home.

title: From a Juilliard Troupe, Works of Taylor and York
description: Spring is not here, by most accounts, but on Thursday night, the Juilliard Dance Ensemble ushered in the first concert in its Spring Performances series. This year's crop of performers from the Juilliard School's Dance Division is especially strong and versatile; moreover, no one can go wrong with choreography by Paul Taylor and Lila York, one of the most gifted of Mr. Taylor's creative progeny.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Man Arrested for Leaflets
description: Under a 1994 State Supreme Court ruling, protesters are permitted to hand out leaflets in the common areas of shopping malls if they abide by ''reasonable'' mall regulations.

title: Gotta Party
description: Many politicians say they detest Washington's big money game, and some actually mean it. But unfortunately, some of the nation's top lawmakers seem addicted to the power of fat war chests and the chance to socialize with rich and famous people in glamorous settings. The cause of reform suffered a hit this week when Trent Lott, the new Senate majority leader, came out forcefully as a defender of the Beltway influence-for-money game.

title: SHARP ABANDONS HOSPITAL JOINT-VENTURE PLAN
description: Sharp Healthcare, a nonprofit hospital chain, has backed out of a joint-venture agreement with the Columbia/HCA Corporation, Columbia/HCA said yesterday. In 1995, Columbia and Sharp agreed to form a partnership that would add four hospitals to the Columbia chain. But last November, the California Attorney General challenged the deal, saying that Columbia would be underpaying for its share of Sharp's assets. The Attorney General, Daniel E. Lungren, said yesterday that his office was ending its investigation of the proposed venture. Columbia/ HCA also faces resistance as it tries to acquire hospitals in other states.

title: About 1,496 Coyotes To Go
description: State officials fell short of describing New Jersey's first coyote hunt as a failure, but they have not decided whether to try again next year.

title: MAFCO HOLDINGS TO BUY MAFCO CONSOLIDATED SHARES
description: Mafco Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the 15 percent of Mafco Consolidated Group that is held by the public to take full control of the cigar maker. Mafco Holdings Inc. would pay $33.50 a share, or $114 million, for Mafco Consolidated. The company also said it would pay shareholders a special dividend of $10 a share. In New York Stock Exchange trading, shares of Mafco Consolidated jumped $4.75, to $42. The offer would be higher if the average closing price of shares of Consolidated Cigar Holdings Inc. exceeded $33 for 10 trading days before the acquisition. Mafco Consolidated owns 80.2 percent of the common stock of Consolidated Cigar. In New York Stock Exchange trading, shares of Consolidated Cigar were up 12.5 cents, to $25.

title: Site Change Is a Labor Coup
description: At the plush resort of Bal Harbour, Fla., where the barons of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. held their winter convention for many years, the closest that many of them ever got to a real worker was when a waiter handed them pina coladas at poolside.

title: New Nets Out of Sync in 2d Game Together
description: The scaffolding around the renovated Nets may stand for a lot longer than what was originally believed.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7

title: PHYSICIAN CORPORATION STOCK DROPS 44 PERCENT
description: Shares of the Physician Corporation of America fell 44 percent yesterday after the company said it would take an $80 million fourth-quarter charge that would jeopardize its pending purchase by Sierra Health Services Inc. Physician said it would take the charge to cover claims from workers' compensation policies it issued. The news led Sierra to say it was re-evaluating its $432.4 million stock offer for the operator of managed health care plans. In Nasdaq trading, Physician's shares fell $4.0625, to $5.0625. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Sierra rose $2.125, to $26.875.

title: SKYLINE CHILI GETS UNSOLICITED TAKEOVER BID
description: Skyline Chili Inc. said yesterday that it had recently received an unsolicited takeover offer of $7.50 a share for the company, detailing several options. Some of the alternatives were presented to the company's majority shareholders, who rejected them as inadequate. Skyline Chili, a restaurant chain, said its board had formed a special committee of directors to evaluate the offers made directly to the company along with its financial and legal advisers. On the American Stock Exchange, the company's shares last traded up $1.0625, to $9, before trading was halted at 2:55 P.M. At $9 a share, the company has a market capitalization of more than $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HAROLD
description: ROTH-Harold. Devoted husband of Hilda. Loving father of Mona and Joan and grandchildren, Kyle and Lia. Adored brother of Rosalind Krasnov.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHENCA, JACQUES
description: COHENCA-Jacques. The Board of Governors and members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member Jacques Cohenca. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his dear wife, Emilia, and to all his family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Norman Zarkin, President

title: INSIDE METRO
description: PRESSURE ON CASELOADS -- Supervisors at the city's child welfare agency say they are being pressured to end investigations. Page 25.

title: Charles Schinitsky Dies at 80; Helped Children Gain Rights
description: Charles Schinitsky, a champion of the legal rights of children whose work helped to revolutionize the juvenile court system in New York in a way that became a model for court systems nationwide, has died and will be honored in a program at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York on March 17.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHIELDS, FRANCES L.
description: SHIELDS-Frances L. We love you and miss you and you will always be in our hearts. Love and kisses forever, Henry and Eileen

title: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Up 4.24
description: Stocks closed mixed yesterday, despite a broad selloff in the technology sector.

title: With Big Broom, New President Prods Nicaragua
description: As a candidate for President last year, Arnoldo Aleman promised a break with the way things have always been done here, starting with a bureaucracy he mocked as corrupt, sluggish and unresponsive.

title: ARCHER DANIELS COMPLETES DEAL FOR GRACE'S COCOA UNIT
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company completed its purchase yesterday of W. R. Grace & Company's cocoa business for about $470 million in cash and assumed debt. The purchase gives Archer Daniels the world's largest processor of cocoa beans. Grace Cocoa sells more than $700 million in industrial cocoa and chocolate products. The final price was $40 million higher than the companies announced when the deal was disclosed in December. A spokesman for Grace said the higher price took account of increases in earnings and working capital. Grace said it had sold the cocoa business to focus on specialty chemicals and packaging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, WARREN, JR
description: WEAVER-Warren, Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Warren Weaver Jr., associated with The Times from 1948, until retiring in 1989.

title: Hempstead Election Ruling Is Called Political
description: A day after a Federal judge ruled that this town's system of electing Town Board members discriminated against blacks, the Town Supervisor insisted that Hempstead is not racist.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about a transaction involving CPC International Inc. and Koor Industries Ltd. reversed the companies' roles. CPC is buying, not selling, a 24.5 percent stake in Israel Edible Products.

title: Dollar Recovers to End Day Up Against Mark and Yen
description: The dollar recovered somewhat yesterday, ending higher against the Japanese yen and the German mark after a broad decline on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSHAN, DINAH
description: PERSHAN-Dinah. The Covenant Foundation mourns the passing of Dinah Pershan on February 17, 1997. Beloved grandmother of our esteemed Board member Dr. Betsy Dolgin Katz, Dinah Pershan was born in Krutya, Russia on November 11, 1892 to Asna Dubov and Israel Aaron Shulman. She came to the United States in 1909, and dedicated her 104 years to raising and caring for five generations of children-four children, ten grandchildren, twenty-one great-grandchildren, and two great-great-grandchildren. May those who mourn find comfort among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Judith Ginsberg Executive Director Eli N. Evans Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHMIELEWSKI, RICHARD (RICK)
description: CHMIELEWSKI-Richard (Rick). Age 60, of Greenwich Village, NY died on Thursday, February 20, 1997 of heart disease complicated by AIDS. After a long career with the NYPD, Rick founded and was proprietor of Rick & Company, and was president of the Greenwich Avenue Merchants Association. He will be deeply missed by his many nieces, nephews, and friends, his brother Joseph of Goshen, NY, his sisters Blanche Kowalczyk and Mary Dabrowski of Brooklyn, NY, his sisters-in-law Dolores and Sophie Chmielewski, his brother-in-law Peter Iorlano, his dear friend Tony Kastanas of Parsippany, NJ and his life partner, Sy Cohen of Greenwich Village. Funeral Service will be held at 9 AM, February 22, at the Evergreen Funeral Home at 131 Nassau Ave in Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers donations to the Community Research Initiative on AIDS (CRIA), 275 7th Ave, NY, NY 10001-6708 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ALLAN
description: ABRAMS-Allan. We at Menorah Home and Hospital note with sincere regret the loss of the beloved father of Robert Abrams, our most esteemed board member. We extend personal condolences to Bob and his family. Fred Abrams, President Paul Melinger, Chairman of the Board Shirley Windheim, Executive Director

title: Democrats to Return More Money Received From 'Improper' Sources
description: An internal audit commissioned by the Democratic National Committee in the wake of questions about the party's Presidential-year fund raising has identified additional contributions that will be returned, the party announced today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 31 about rising prices for Brooklyn town houses included a broker's erroneous reference to the buyer who paid $1.075 million for a house at 213 Congress Street. Christopher Thomas, manager of the Brooklyn office of the firm that handled the sale, said at the time that the buyer was a securities executive who had also looked at $2 million houses in Greenwich Village but preferred Cobble Hill. The purchaser's actual background is undisclosed, and Mr. Thomas says he was referring to the buyer of a different house.

title: The Next 42d Street
description: Above the entrance of a grim old office building in the Loop is a plastic sign ubiquitous in American downtowns: CHECKS CASHED MONEY ORDERS. Then you walk through the door and, as if propelled by a cinematic jump-cut, stumble instead into a dusty Xanadu -- an abandoned 1926 movie palace with a balcony that stretches to Heaven and a gilt-and-camp decor that a historian described as ''a cross-cultural concoction of Cambodian chimeras, Indian elephants and Thai-inspired temples.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MARSHALL
description: LEVINE-Marshall. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Marshall Levine, associated with The Times from 1961 until retiring in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARO, CLIFFORD J
description: KARO-Clifford J. Beloved husband of Ann. Devoted father of Jean and Daniel. Beloved brother of Alan and adored uncle. Services Monday, 10:00 A.M., at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your favorite charity.

title: U.S. Seeking Deportation Of Rebel Turned Informer
description: Nearly seven years after American officials secretly resettled a former Salvadoran guerrilla commander in the United States and paid him thousands of dollars for his services as an informant, the Clinton Administration is seeking to have the man deported as a terrorist.

title: Day to Test A Pair Of Delicate Met Arms
description: Bill Pulsipher and Jason Isringhausen, two of the Mets' surgically repaired blue-chippers, threw batting practice today and survived.

title: INSIDE
description: Police Officer Is Dismissed

title: Grandchildren
description: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler column ''Generations on the Move'' (Jan. 12) discussed grandparents' traveling with their grandchildren. I might qualify as an expert in this class.

title: State's Ratings of Schools Raise Hackles in the Suburbs
description: This has been an especially harsh winter for administrators in the suburban school systems around New York City, which include some of the best schools in the nation.

title: Intimate Strangers
description: WHAT FALLS AWAY

title: Safety Is the Real Issue When Considering Canopies
description: To the Editor:

title: Always at the Crossroads
description: RICARDO KHAN remembers it well, after a fashion and after perhaps 18 years.

title: Balancing Budgets on the Scales of Justice
description: DID you see what he wrote?'' said Judith Kulick, the administrator of the Municipal Court in Bernardsville. She sounded offended.

title: For a Passionate Few, Nothing's as Good as Gold
description: THE Dow may be flirting with 7,000, but don't expect all investors to be impressed. Some of them are much more enchanted by that traditional bedrock of investments: gold. And not just gold stocks or shares in gold mutual funds, but the real, solid, heavy, yellow stuff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, MEYER
description: ROSE-Meyer, of Houston, TX, on February 18, 1997, in Harrisburg, PA. Survived by his wife Frances (nee Levy); a daughter, Miriam Kalman Harris of Dallas; 5 sons: Elliott of Scarsdale, NY, Phillip of Woodland Hills, CA., Stephen of New Orleans, Joel of Harrisburg, Herbert Kalman of Houston; eight grandchildren. Services and burial were in Harrisburg. Memorial contributions to Congregation Beth Yeshurun, 4525 Beechnut Street, Houston, TX. 77096.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, JACK S.
description: MORRISON-Jack S. Born in Santa Barbara, CA, December 17, 1912. Died February 20, 1997, in Santa Barbara, CA. Jack was the son of Charles ''Chick'' Morrison, Studio Manager of Flying A Studios of Santa Barbara and Anna Marie Sandberg Morrison. Jack Morrison was a graduate of UCLA and received his Ed.D. from USC. He taught and was later Director of the Theatre Department at UCLA from 1947-1966. He served as Dean of the College of Fine Arts at Ohio University from 1966-1970. He was named Associate Director of the J.D. Rockefeller Fund in New York from 1970-1976 then Executive Director of the American Theatre Association from 1976-1982. Jack received the Life Achievement Award from UCLA in 1980 and was then awarded Professor Emeritus status. He was the author of many books, including, ''The Rise of the Arts on the American Campus'', 1973. Jack Morrison is survived by his son, Charles Eric Morrison, Sacramento; daughters Mary Anne Morrison-Roberts M.Ed. of Santa Barbara and Theresa C. Morrison, Newport Beach. He has 2 grandchildren, Katie Morrison and William E. Roberts. He was preceded in death by his eldest daughter, Patience Morrison. In lieu of flowers, family asks that contributions be made to the Santa Barbara Red Cross, 2707 State Street, Santa Barbara, CA 93105 in memory of Dr. Jack S. Morrison. Because Dr. Morrison has donated his body to the UCLA Willed Body Program for Medical Research, there will be no formal service.

title: Portrait of a Hustler Refutes Illusion of Glamour
description: To the Editor:

title: A Father of Collectives Now Inspires Collectors
description: At 4 A.M. on Thursday, Wang Min was roused by a friend who called to tell him the news: Deng Xiaoping was dead.

title: A Tough Deputy Switches Modes From Negotiation to Re-Election
description: By Thursday, less than 24 hours after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had transformed Fran Reiter from his blunt, driven Deputy Mayor into his blunt, driven campaign manager, the physical changes were already evident.

title: Acting Up
description: LOITERING WITH INTENT

title: Elimination of Overtime Threatens Training Plan for L.I. Air Controllers
description: Although the Federal Aviation Administration has recently begun hiring air traffic control trainees for the chronically understaffed New York Center, veteran controllers say they are worried that a persistent lack of resources for training may worsen high workloads, at least temporarily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELTZ, HARRIET
description: WELTZ-Harriet, 59, died peacefully February 21, 1997. Loved, cherished and adored by her surviving husband, Stuart S. Weltz, her children, Robin Parks and Irwin Weltz, her son-in-law, Alan, and daughter-in-law, Kerri, her grandchildren, Stephanie and Jason Parks, her sisters and brothers-in-law, Anita and Rabbi Louis Lederman, Elaine and Arthur Viders, and Nathan Gurvitch, her nephews and nieces, Ira, Barry, Neil, Shani, Shevi, Dassi and Stephen. She was the light of our life who enriched us all and will forever be in our thoughts and hearts. Funeral services today in Columbus, OH.

title: Waiting for a Transplant
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hybrid Style of San German
description: AN oddly matched pair of buildings anchors the east end of Plazuela de Santo Domingo, in the Puerto Rican town of San German.

title: Solid Geometry
description: The fabric of choice this season -- clingy, curvy stretch jersey -- comes in the hottest hues, the coolest cuts.

title: Life in the Exclusion Lane
description: ACCORDING to Chapter 48 of the 200-page New Jersey Casino Control Act, the Casino Control Commission can exclude anyone from gambling, dining, lodging or even using restrooms at Atlantic City casino hotels if that person is a ''career or professional offender,'' an associate of that offender, a convicted criminal or ''any person whose presence . . . would be inimical to the interest of the State of New Jersey or of licensed gaming therein.''

title: Advertising for Cruises To Reflect Real Costs
description: After an 18-month investigation by the Florida attorney general, six major cruise lines have agreed to advertise their prices to reflect the total cost of a cruise, including port charges. Until now, port charges, which can represent an added cost of as much as 30 percent, have usually been indicated in ads and brochures only by a notation like ''port charges and gratuities not included.''

title: Spanish Classes
description: To the Editor: Another answer to the query of Marie Berarducci of Needham, Mass., (Q & A, Jan. 19) about getting short-term Spanish instruction and housing in southern Spain would be to contact our International Council for Cultural Exchange, a nonprofit educational and cultural organization.

title: U.S. Soccer Teams Should Not Be the Visitors at Home
description: The unmistakable din grew as I approached R.F.K. Stadium in Washington. The voices of children mingled with the sound of sideline soccer academics debating the subtleties that define the beauty of the world's simplest game. Horns, cowbells and clinking beer bottles completed the soundtrack.

title: Don't Remember Deng as Capitalist Apologist
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sound Of Superstardom
description: To the Editor:

title: How Yiddish Shlepped to Conquer
description: ONLY weeks ago, there was a major linguistic tsimmes about the roots of Yiddish, the language spoken by so few yet heard by so many. Where did Yiddish originate? Was it Teutonic or something else, what with influences that bespoke a people on the move? The Jews of Eastern Europe left one country and went to another with little luggage beyond their expressive language and a talent for spreading it.

title: Hollywood Legend
description: For more than 40 years and in more than 70 films, BURT LANCASTER forged a successful career in Hollywood. An hourlong documentary, with Martin Sheen -- TUESDAY at 8 P.M. on AMC -- chronicles the life of the actor and reveals the man behind the image. Born in 1913 in New York City, he was a circus performer before making his debut in 1946 in ''The Killers'' (above, with Ava Gardner). He starred in westerns, war films and melodramas, and won an Oscar for ''Elmer Gantry'' (1960). In later years he aged gracefully in ''Atlantic City'' (1980), ''Local Hero'' (1983) and his final role in ''Rocket Gibraltar'' (1988). Yolanda A. Andrews

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Book of Lamentations By Rosario Castellanos. Marsilio, $24.

title: 'Hello, Thornton' and Other Wilder 100th Celebrations
description: THORNTON WILDER may have set ''Our Town'' in mythical Grover's Corners, N.H., but real-life Hamden was ''his town'' for almost half a century.

title: Two Hands to One, and the Long Way Back
description: LEADING a memorial symposium on the pioneering violinist Louis Krasner, Leon Fleisher spoke of him as a ''celebration of the human spirit.'' Mr. Fleisher is another celebration of the human spirit, as those who have recently heard him play piano concertos know.

title: Mama Le Cirque
description: IN THE MOVIE ''BIG NIGHT,'' two brothers, recently arrived from Italy, seek fame and fortune by opening a restaurant in New Jersey. One brother has a natural affinity for glad-handing and compromise; the other is convinced that pure and perfect renditions of his native foods are the only salvation in life. Unfortunately, taking a superior position to veal parmigiana in a place like New Jersey -- in the 1950's! -- is not what you'd call a good business decision.

title: MOMMY, WHAT'S A CLASSROOM?
description: The home-school phenomenon is racism and classism thinly disguised as concern for a child's welfare. By withdrawing, instead of working to improve the school system, these parents are guaranteeing that their children will be forced to face even greater social, racial and economic problems in the years to come. They are also insuring that their children will have no skills to deal with these problems.

title: The Future Works, Sometimes
description: SOMETHING about technology inspires prophecy. Start talking about circuit boards or electric cars or no-calorie fat, and before long the grand proclamations about the future begin accumulating. And now that technology intrudes on practically every aspect of cultural life (a cynic might even say that technology has replaced cultural life) futuristic speculation has become an obsession. Unfortunately, the predictions are almost always wrong.

title: Since Coming Out Is In, A Guide for the TV Audience
description: WHY are people all atwitter at the possibility that the lead character of the sitcom ''Ellen,'' played by Ellen DeGeneres, will come out of the closet on television? What's the big deal? There have been hordes of openly gay characters before her, especially in made-for-television movies, since ''That Certain Summer'' in 1971. And only last month, PBS aired the BBC's production of ''Breaking the Code,'' chronicling the life of the code breaker Alan Turing, who was gay.

title: Songs of Slavery Lifted by a Chorus of Horns
description: LIKE ITS TAPROOT THE BLUES, JAZZ has traditionally taken its themes from the here and now. When it was chiefly music to march, drink and dance to, jazz had no reason to look back. That began to change when jazz made its appearance in concert halls, a shift that coincided with the acknowledgement that black people have a past worthy of serious study. Still, jazz composers shied away from the painful theme of slavery.

title: Rescuing Track
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Bad Boys Start Watching Their Pockets
description: AT the age of 10, Gene Simmons dreamed of someday joining the bearded cantors who led the singing in his family's Hasidic synagogue in the Bronx. He and his family were newcomers to this country, having emigrated from Israel only the year before.

title: Twin Gothic Towers That Changed City's Geography
description: THEY had to move a street to build the twin Gothic skyscrapers at 111 and 115 Broadway, fronting on the Trinity Church cemetery. Among the most dramatic office buildings in New York, they are now in their 10th year of a long restoration. But why has the south face remained uncleaned? It has to do with that street.

title: Telecommuting, Part 2
description: A recent front-page article described telecommuting. Would you like to telecommute? Why or why not?

title: Filling Gap Left by Caldor
description: Hailed in July 1995 as a sign of the resurgence of Flatbush Avenue, the Caldor department store at the corner of Tilden Avenue may again be a bellwether.

title: Albert Shanker, 68, Combative Leader Of Teachers, Dies
description: Albert Shanker, who rose from being a substitute mathematics teacher to become a tough, canny labor leader who in the 1960's transformed New York City's United Federation of Teachers into one of the nation's most powerful unions, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Mr. Shanker, the longtime president of the American Federation of Teachers, the parent organization of the United Federation of Teachers, was 68 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Two Marian Andersons, Both Real
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN mentioning Marian Anderson evoked a host of images: the Lincoln Memorial, color barriers, civil rights, a slender, graceful presence on stage. Most of all, though, the name conjured up a dark, soulful, immensely musical voice.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Virtuous Reality

title: A Hub for Children Hanging Out in Chicago
description: O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, as befits the world's busiest site for passenger and air operations, has developed a large space with play equipment for children under 12 designed by the Chicago Children's Museum.

title: Devils' Unbeaten Streak Is Struck Down
description: The National Hockey League's third-longest unbeaten streak of the season, owned by the Devils, ended today.

title: SMOGA
description: ''I always wanted to take a yoga class, but I knew I'd be judged harshly -- maybe ostracized -- because I was a smoker,'' says Jo Walston, a former health-food-store employee who lives in Austin, Tex. Hence Walston's unique new concept: a yoga class for smokers. Held in the smoking lounge of an Austin coffeehouse, the class provides smokers with a peaceful yoga space in a judgmental world full of what Walston delicately calls ''New Age Nazis.'' In pratice, disappointingly, this doesn't mean students are using new powers of body control to, say, raise cigarettes to their lips using their feet. It does mean that students are allowed to light up in class (no one has yet), but within limits. ''Only between Yoga positions,'' says Walston.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUTTERWIL, ETHEL
description: GUTTERWIL-Ethel. Beloved sister, wife, mother, grandmother and GG. We miss you always. Love, Your daughters, Marcia Flanzig and Arline Joachim

title: Critics of 'Stealth' Mall Find Officials Too Quiet on Plans
description: Officials say it was an oversight. Residents see it as the hallmark of a back-room deal.

title: BENEFITS
description: March of Dimes Dance

title: Tale of Dome Stirred Memories of Another Father
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Fashion For?
description: In an earlier era, women wanted fashion to be a repository for, and an expression of, their dreams. They may still want it to fulfill their dreams, but if so, they are dreams rooted in pragmatism. A randomly selected group of 14 women around the country answered the question, ''What do you want from fashion?'' Their answers were remarkably unified on one point -- that fashion be created for their bodies and their lives. Indeed, they want fashion that makes them feel comfortable in the midst of their busy schedules.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Clinic

title: An Average Guy, With a Hit TV Show
description: IT is taping night on Stage 17 at the Warner Brothers studios, and the star of ''The Drew Carey Show'' is working the room like a politician. He roams the set between takes, conferring with the show's producers, joking with cast members and crew and wandering over by the studio audience to keep its spirits up. Late into this four-hour weekly marathon, Mr. Carey remains in remarkably good cheer, rather like Drew Carey, the amiable sitcom character he plays on television.

title: Immigrant's Death Becomes An Issue in Mayoral Race
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani issued an ardent defense of his welfare record yesterday after one of his Democratic rivals questioned whether his policies might have contributed to the suicide of a 19-year-old immigrant. The young man had apparently grown distraught, his relatives said, in part because he believed that his workfare requirements prevented him from attending English classes.

title: Some Keep Shining, but Most Just Fade to Gray
description: ACTORS OVER 60 SEEM TO BE enjoying something of a rejuvenation on screen. At 66, Armin Mueller-Stahl has an Oscar nomination for his performance in ''Shine.'' So does Lauren Bacall, 72, for hers in ''The Mirror Has Two Faces.'' In ''Absolute Power,'' Clint Eastwood, 66, is running them ragged as an older master thief. Last summer, Sean Connery, also 66, led a commando team into Alcatraz in ''The Rock.'' Earlier this winter, Jack Lemmon, 72, and James Garner, 68, galloped cross-country in ''My Fellow Americans.''

title: Remembering Prejudice, of a Different Sort
description: GROWING UP IN ATLANTA, Alfred Uhry was voted funniest in his class. ''I was pretty hard to take,'' he says now, ''putting on skirts and dressing up in gorilla suits. I embarrassed my sister Ann, who was a more successful teen-ager than I was, more normal. I was this weird little boy writing letters to the producers of 'Barefoot in Athens' to get the program. And I would come home and say I got prizes that didn't exist. When I won the Pulitzer, my mother called my sister and said, 'Alfred says he won the Pulitzer Prize.' And Ann said, 'Mother, he's not going to say he did. He really must have.''

title: Bail and Other Terrestrial Matters
description: OUTSIDE the Spartan Diner the other night, the fog was so thick that even the headlights of passing cars seemed menacing and mysterious. Inside, the vice president of the Long Island U.F.O. Network sipped coffee and talked about how hard things have been since the incident.

title: For Today's M.B.A.'s, A Serious Bit of Levity
description: DID you hear the one about the M.B.A. student? No, really.

title: Mexico's Drug Czar: Busted
description: On Monday General Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo was the commissioner of the National Institute to Combat Drugs, the top commander in Mexico's war against the drug trade. By Tuesday he was an indicted and imprisoned drug trafficker, accused of working with Amado Carrillo Fuentes, one of Mexico's most ruthless drug lords.

title: The Road Ahead
description: Straight from the heartland: A new generation of designers extends fashion's reach to the next generation of women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILESKI, ADAM H.
description: PILESKI-Adam H., on February 21st, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of John and Adrienne. Devoted grandfather of James, Tanya and Adam. Loving brother of Anthony Pileski and Mary Bishop. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, St. Kevin's, 9:45. Interment Mt. St. Mary's. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-10.

title: Florio Decides He Won't Run For Governor
description: Ending months of speculation that he wanted his old job back, former Gov. Jim Florio said today that he would not seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination but that he would do all that he could to defeat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in November.

title: Average Russian Still Fears a Wider NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Tales of 300 Years of Life in Connecticut
description: THE experiences of a young soldier during the Revolutionary War, the impressions of an English immigrant writing home in 1870, the reminiscences of a group of working women in the year 1914 -- these are some of the stories told first-hand in a new book, ''Connecticut Speaks for Itself.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 34 of The Times Magazine today, about people who dislike President Clinton and suspect that he is guilty of or has knowledge of various crimes, misstates the age of Hugh H. Sprunt, who published a report about the death of Vincent Foster. He is 47, not 57.

title: Clinton Crazy
description: The day before the election last November, Larry Nichols met me at Gibson's 286 Family Restaurant in Conway, Ark., a half hour from Little Rock, and after a lunch topped off with chocolate pie, drove with me in his mother's gold Mercury Marquis to a ranch house on the south side of town. Nichols is a pale, slightly doughy man of 46, and he wore a blue Adidas track suit and chain-smoked Trues. Tuning the oversize television in the living room to CNN, he sat down in a recliner with a view of the front door and a handgun at his side. ''They may just kill me,'' he said. ''You'll read one day that I got drunk and ran into a moving bridge. Or Larry Nichols got depressed over everything and blew his head off.''

title: INSIDE
description: Bomb at Atlanta Gay Club Leaves 5 People Injured

title: Mother Wins Health Care for Paralyzed Son in the Marines
description: Joanne Bertalan won the battle her paralyzed son could not fight -- a five-month struggle with Navy and Marine officials who had sought to strip her 22-year-old son of his veterans benefits.

title: Accusations Of Misdeeds On Donations Are Denied
description: A former Clinton appointee who is under investigation by the Justice Department and Congress over questionable donations to the President's re-election campaign today denied accusations that he had used his office to solicit donations overseas, or to further his own business interests.

title: In full bloom
description: On location in Senegal, fresh flower-strewn clothes, in fabrics light as tropical breezes.

title: A Stamford Landmark's Facade at the Center of a Battle
description: IN downtown Stamford, virtually denuded of landmarks after seemingly unending urban renewal, a nondescript 70-year-old building on upper Atlantic Street has become a line in the sand in the battle between preservationists and developers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTHINGTON, JOHNSON
description: WORTHINGTON-Johnson, age 84, beloved husband of Frances Claudet Johnson, died Feb. 20, 1997. He was educated at the Choate School and Brown University and remained active in his philanthropic dedication to the Choate-Rosemary Hall School, the Fairfield Country Day School and the Wakeman Boys and Girls Club. He was a member of the Country Club of Fairfield, CT, the NY Racquet Club and the Lyford Cay Club of Nassau, the Bahamas. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his four children, Marina Sutro, Joan Stott, Margo Johnson and Worthington Johnson, Jr. and 8 grandchildren. Memorial services will take place on Fri. at 11 AM at the Southport, CT Congregational Church. Donations in his memory to: Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, 385 Center St, Southport, CT 06490

title: Taking Two Bosnian Women's Case to the World
description: EVEN MORE THAN OTHER WAR crimes, rape does not easily lend itself to film. This aspect of the depressing litany of man's inhumanity to man -- and woman -- is hard enough to confirm without also having to depict it with camera and microphone. Rape is usually a witnessless crime, one that leaves no visible mark on its victim. There are no mass graves to photograph, no cigarette burns or jagged scars to display, no discarded canisters of chemicals or vials of nerve agents to be collected.

title: Once Visionary, Disney Calls Future a Thing of the Past
description: There is a place here where the future looks old. It is called Tomorrowland, and it is part of Walt Disney World, the most popular tourist destination on Earth.

title: In Latest Atlanta Bombing, 5 Are Injured at a Gay Bar
