description: In the fourth such incident in seven months, a bomb exploded in Atlanta on Friday night, this one injuring at least five people at a gay nightclub and compelling law-enforcement officials to explore whether a serial bomber is at large.

title: C. Donald Woodard, Karen Lauritzen
description: Karen Lauritzen, a managing director in the private banking division of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, and C. Donald Woodard, a television writer and producer in Los Angeles, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony with the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Dr. Robert Paul Sessions, a United Methodist minister.

title: Town-House Project On Hudson Advances
description: The Westchester County village of Dobbs Ferry has moved a step closer to getting its first major residential project in more than 10 years.

title: Who's a Guru?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ties That Bind
description: The New Golden Rule Community and Morality in a Democratic Society. By Amitai Etzioni. 314 pp. New York: Basic Books. $26.

title: Increasingly, Grandparents Raise Their Children's Children
description: On a typical day, Rita Tyler is up at 6 A.M. to make breakfast for her 5-year-old, Kamillah, and her 10-year-old, Leslie. She walks them to the school bus, does errands and house cleaning until 3 P.M., then watches over homework and playtime until it's time for dinner and, afterward, baths.

title: JUMP SUITS
description: Now at the height of fashion, pants in soft, fluid fabrics -- shown off by members of The Parsons Dance Company.

title: Study Hopes to Explain Decrease in Shore Birds
description: Nesting pairs of herons and egrets in the Barnegat Bay-Little Egg Harbor estuary in Ocean County have drastically decreased in the last 20 years, and scientists hope studying the area will help them learn why and help them find ways to reverse the trend.

title: The Bride Wore White -- and Black
description: I was married twice last summer. i wore two different dresses in two different colors in two different cities, where I said ''I do'' to the same man. The first wedding was for me. The second was for my mother.

title: A Kinder, Gentler NATO
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright tried last week to allay Russia's fears about an expansion of NATO. In a meeting on Thursday with the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, Ms. Albright presented a proposal to freeze military forces near Russia's European border. On Friday she met with a gaunt-looking President Boris N. Yeltsin to say that NATO is ''no longer a situation of you versus us.''

title: Coming Soon (and Better Late Than Never)
description: AT last, a largely unknown work by America's foremost black playwright is to be produced by America's foremost black theater.

title: Maybe a Strike Wouldn't Have Cost That Much
description: PERHAPS it was a political no-brainer for President Clinton to intervene last week and halt the pilots' strike at American Airlines.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: To Pick and Choose Among the Newcomers
description: THOSE who have been studying the nursery catalogues these past few weeks may have noticed something special about this year's offerings. Many of the perennials are familiar sorts fashioned in new colors or forms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURSI, PHILIP G.
description: TURSI-Philip G. Devoted husband of Frances (nee Valentino). Beloved father of Betiayn Tursi. Loving brother of Noel Tursi. Funeral Monday, 9:15AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Mass St. Edmund's R.C. Church, 10:15AM. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Winning Battle With Eating Disorders Leads to First Novel
description: JILLIAN MEDOFF doesn't look like a person who spent nearly a decade of her young life as a loose cannon, a woman who repeatedly damaged body and soul with drugs, pathological eating disorders and liaisons with the wrong men, including other womens' husbands. But then, Ms. Medoff has been through a lot of changes in the last 10 years -- from a self-hating loner who concocted elaborate suicide scenarios while starving herself into oblivion to someone who now considers herself ''fun, even in my neuroses.''

title: Pataki Appoints a Professor As CUNY Board Chairman
description: Gov. George E. Pataki moved to put more of his stamp on the City University of New York yesterday, naming Anne A. Paolucci, an English professor at St. John's University, as board chairman and Herman Badillo, an adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, as vice chairman.

title: Latin Markets Again Run With the Bulls
description: ANYONE who bought Latin American stock and bond funds a year ago can claim bragging rights at cocktail parties. The gains in both categories have been handsome, exceeding 40 percent in some cases.

title: German Specialties, Hearty and Rustic
description: JAEGERHAUS and cold weather go together like sauerbraten and potato dumplings. The new German restaurant in Farmingdale has the formula for warding off winter's icy blasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, JOYCE FIELDS
description: SIMONS-Joyce Fields. On February 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Richard Fields and the late Judith Fields Alviani. Mother-in-law of Marjorie Vandow and Joseph Alviani. Loving grandmother of Matthew and Samantha. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Monday evening 7-9 PM, with a service on Tuesday, February 25, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Family Sleuths
description: From Alex Haley to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, discovering your roots has the power to change your life. A new 10-part PBS series, ANCESTORS: A BEGINNER'S GUIDE TO FAMILY HISTORY AND GENEALOGY, tells how to uncover the mystery of how you became who you are, filling in the gaps historically, spiritually and even medically -- SATURDAY at 2 P.M. on CHANNEL 13. ''Lives are being saved,'' says Carol Krause (above), whose life was saved after family death records revealed a preponderance of cancer. Colette Moncrief DeVerge's search took her to Africa and into her own soul. ''If everything did not happen exactly the way that it happened,'' she says, ''I would not be sitting here talking today.'' Andrea Higbie

title: New Quartet at Sarah Lawrence
description: OLD friends come together in a new group today at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers with the first concert appearance of the New Prometheus Quartet. The ensemble consists of Eric Lewis, violinist and longtime member of the Manhattan String Quartet; Ronald Gorevic, violinist, and Matthias Naegele, cellist, both with the Laurentian String Quartet, and David Korevaar, founding pianist of Hexagon. The players said they formed the New Prometheus Quartet ''to enliven a repertory that extends beyond traditional string trios into piano quartets and other works.'' On the program tonight at 8 are piano quartets by Mozart and Faure and the Viola Sonata by the faculty composer George Tsontakis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, JEROME R.
description: MOORE-Jerome R. At 65, on February 9th, in NYC after a demoralizing two-year battle with cancer. Served USAF 1951-54 as Russian-German language specialist in Berlin. Final two years, headed up top secret project there. Upon release, attended Columbia University; graduated magna cum laude, and elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Joined American Oil as press representative for three years; thence for fourteen years at Hill & Knowlton, then world's largest P.R. firm. Elected youngest V.P. and, later Sr. V.P. in H & K's history. Handled several major accounts (Texaco, OwensIllinois, Warner-Lambert, Marathon Oil, etc.). In 1974, to Arthur Young, a top public accounting company as a principal and P.R. director. Retired in 1987, but continued to serve as P.R. counsel to companies. We honor him for his longtime friendship and wise counsel; for his great love of the sea, sky and all of nature, for his lifetime commitment to opera and the theater, and for his great affection for Scotties, ''the best dogs there ever wuz''. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his three surviving brothers: Jack, Tom and Larry, and their families. May he rest in peace. With all our love. Ita Sonnabend Ana Churrua Peter Diggins Don Maher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELTSCH, DR. VICTOR IRVING
description: TELTSCH-Dr. Victor Irving, of Shelter Island, NY, on February 22, 1997. Survived by his devoted wife, Marjorie, brother, Dr. Edward Teltsch, sister, Kathleen Teltsch, and in-laws, the Dorothy Ryder family. Memorial service to be held in March.

title: UConn, Capitalizing on Salt Water Connections
description: THE studies and projects underway at the University of Connecticut's campus at Avery Point in Groton are as varied as the marine life in Long Island Sound: aquaculture, marine sciences and research partnerships with marine businesses. And Avery Point's maritime heritage is getting richer as construction of a new marine sciences center begins.

title: Renting a Home: Luck and Skill
description: FEW things in travel are as unpredictable as renting an overseas house sight unseen. Or as irreversible.

title: New Dimensions in Working With Fiber
description: WHILE exhibitions of fiber art are numerous, they tend to have a narrow focus: only quilts, or only weaving. But for ''Threads: Fiber Art in the 90's,'' at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts, anything incorporating a threadlike element was a candidate. That criterion has resulted in an imaginative and vivid show.

title: Get Shorty
description: This spring's lean little jacket has roguish charm.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CONFLICTING ACCOUNTS The Creation and Crash of the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Empire. By Kevin Goldman. Simon & Schuster, $26.

title: 10 Months After Fatal Crash, Man Is Held in a Hit-and-Run
description: A 31-year-old truck driver was arrested Friday in connection with a hit-and-run accident in Greenwich, Conn., that killed a 5-month-old girl last April.

title: The Telephone Lottery
description: At 7 A.M. tomorrow, hundreds or thousands of people across the country will roll out of bed and simultaneously dial the Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority in hopes of reserving ferry tickets for the summer. Most of them will get a busy signal. That's what the redial button is for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABIGAS, FABIAN M.
description: CABIGAS-Fabian M. On February 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Esperandza. Loving father of Maria Soledad Cabigas and Samari Weinberg. Devoted uncle of Corazon. Also survived by 2 grandchildren, Fabiana and Sebastian. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72 St. Mass of Christian Burial Mon 10 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Handsome Decor for a Price in New Canaan
description: THE Roger Sherman Inn was for many years the only place in New Canaan for even quasi-fancy dining. A change in ownership in 1988 ushered in a French/ Continental menu and food served with a nouvelle flourish. The inn has now changed hands again, but much is still the same, and the decor is as handsome as ever.

title: New Bells and Whistles, But the Same Old Wires
description: ALMOST the entire world agreed recently to deregulate telephone markets, based on the American model. The move has been portrayed as leading to lower prices for phone calls -- a realistic possibility. But if you remember when the United States deregulated telecommunications a year ago, we were promised a lot more than just lower prices. Supposedly, the invisible hand of the marketplace would also build an information superhighway into our homes. Despite the talk from the deregulated utilities, this hasn't happened yet, and it doesn't look as if it will happen anytime soon.

title: Q and A
description: New Year's in Vienna

title: 100 Years of Broken Rules
description: You always dress for church, for travel and for dinner. You always carry a hanky and always wear underwear. You never, ever apply makeup in public. You never touch yourself in public; you never touch anything on yourself after you leave your own bathroom. Never smoke in the street. Never be late for anything. No linen or white before Easter or after Labor Day. Only white for baptisms and brides. No white socks except for tennis. Wear only black for funerals, and never wear black in the summer.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Snails and Puppy Dog Tails? Or Sugar and Spice?
description: SUZANNE REMY COLTON always imagined her perfect family a boy and a girl.

title: No Headline
description: ''Our goals as a people are not these pie-in-the-sky objectives that people grew up with in the 50's. They settle now for a house in the suburbs and to hell with the Moon.''

title: Me? A Star? Nahhh. Really? Well, if You Say So.
description: THAT ROLE YOU MENTIONED is one people tell me I was born to play. You could almost say that in some sense, it played me. It's not autobiographical, as some critics have suggested, although in a way I guess you could say it is -- you know, in the sense that in every role you use a part of yourself. In this case, it was a part of me I didn't know existed, until I acted it.

title: Rangers Frustrated by Own Poor Play
description: From Mike Richter in goal to Wayne Gretzky to the last forward on the fourth line, the Rangers had one of their worst games during one of their worst stretches of the season Friday night in Hartford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNN, HERBERT T.
description: BRUNN-Herbert T., 84, of Bronxville, NY, died Friday at Lawrence Hospital. Funeral services will be 9:30 AM, Tuesday, at the Village Lutheran Church, 172 White Plains Rd., Bronxville. Burial will be at Maple Grove Cemetery, Queens. Calling hours will be Monday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville. Memorial contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made to Calvary Fund, Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Last Angry Man
description: In 1970 two New York City police officers called on a New York Times reporter to tell him a story of corruption within the police department. The information led to the Knapp Commission, which investigated the charges, and eventually to the biggest shake-up in department history. Peter Maas turned their story into a book; and Sidney Lumet turned it into a movie. SERPICO (1973) is a provocative film about a man's rebellion against the sleaziness and second-rateness in American life. Al Pacino gives a splendid performance as Detective Frank Serpico, the bearded, bead-wearing cop, whose outrage bordered on obsession -- THURSDAY at 8 P.M. on TNT.

title: Public Schools? But of Course.
description: THERE is a public school in Brooklyn where first-graders enter a science classroom that resembles a rain forest, and there is a public school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan where fifth-graders isolate DNA. A third public school, supposedly the best in the city, is in East Harlem and most of its students are poor.

title: Bringing Home the Horror of the Holocaust
description: IN THE THREE YEARS SINCE IT was released, ''Schindler's List'' -- Steven Spielberg's harrowing, eloquent and ultimately hopeful drama about the Holocaust, and about one profiteering German who saved more than a thousand Jewish lives -- has deservedly come to be considered a classic film. But can ''Schindler's List'' work on television, as the dark isolation of the movie theater is replaced by the well-lighted comfort of your living room? Does television know how to handle such a sensitive and significant work of art? The test comes tonight at 7:30, when NBC devotes three and a half hours to the film, showing it without commercial interruptions.

title: Emblems for Reminding The Living of the Dead
description: EACH MARCH, WHEN SIGHTSEERS toured the historic houses of Natchez, Miss., Emily Kelley used to meet them at the door of her home, the Briars, her throat and ear lobes adorned with hair. No, it wasn't hormonal misfortune. It was her great-grandfather's. The hair, that is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARNICK, RICHARD F.
description: LAZARNICK-Richard F. Age 39. On January 26, in Huntington Beach, CA. Survived by his life partner, Paul M. Bradley, III in Lewes, DE. by his brother, Dr. Peter Lazarnick of Carrollton, Ga., his sister, Dana Osterman of Norwood, NJ and his fathers, Philip Sherbert also of Norwood, NJ and Joseph Lazarnick of Atlanta, Ga. as well as four nephews and two nieces. His mother, Phyllis Sherbert died in 1989. Memorial service will be held in Silver Spring, Md., on Sunday, February 23, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers the family and friends of Richard Lazarnick have established a Foundation to provide Healthcare Services to medically underserved populations. For information 202-265-4264.

title: In Praise of Jets
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fastening Your Seat Belt For a Bumpy Marriage
description: Q. When I asked my fiancee to sign a prenuptial agreement, she suggested waiting until after we were married. Does that make sense?

title: Building Will Plug Into the Future
description: Harlem's first building with wiring suitable for home-office computer hook-ups and other business support services is planned for the long-abandoned lot at the southwest corner of 116th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Needed: Another 'Wealth'
description: After a decade of getting, giving is now making news. Unusual donations crop up regularly on page one -- a retired laundress in Mississippi ($150,000 to a university), a secretive New Jersey businessman ($600 million, given anonymously), an eccentric oilman in Oklahoma ($22 million, half to the college that expelled him).

title: Turkey Finds European Union Door Slow to Open
description: Nowhere in the world is the divide between Europe and Asia as palpable as in this majestic city. Only here can one sit in a European cafe and gaze across a narrow waterway to Asia. Behind are Vienna, Berlin and Paris; on the other side lies a vast, unbroken expanse that stretches to Baghdad, Tashkent and Beijing.

title: A Slump in the Recording Industry? Not Here in Hoboken
description: When the weather is good, Tom Prendergast can gaze out the windows of the waterfront offices of Bar/None in Hoboken and look forward to the day when the record industry ''won't look so bleak.''

title: New Round In Fight Over Mortgage Fee
description: A VIRGINIA case that had mortgage borrowers and consumer advocates celebrating only a few weeks ago was appealed last week, with the two banks accused of illegal practices asking that the suit be dismissed.

title: Seeking a Theater Varied as a Rainbow
description: WHOSE THEATER WILL the American theater be? The subject is on the table because of the recent newsmaking debate between the playwright August Wilson and the critic Robert Brustein, which framed the question in terms of race. Mr. Wilson, accusing the nation's nonprofit regional theaters of ignoring black artists, called for the creation of separate black theaters across America. Mr. Brustein countered that art is color blind, and that classic plays should satisfy audiences and artists of all races.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Restaurant Elevates Pasta To Its Menu's Astral Plane

title: Anger Is Vented; Vent Is Shifted
description: Venting about the vent has paid off. After residents and local civic groups voiced considerable anger about a plan to build a 14-foot-tall air vent in the middle of a residential block in the Sugar Hill area, the Transit Authority dropped the proposal.

title: TRENT LOTT AND HIS FIERCE FRESHMEN
description: Men are from Mars; women are from Venus. Conservative Republican senators are fierce firebrands; liberal Democratic senators are compassionate activists. More biased journalism.

title: Robert W. Sarnoff, 78, Leader of RCA in a Decade of Diversification
description: Robert W. Sarnoff, who succeeded his father as chairman of the RCA Corporation and steered it into a hodgepodge of new businesses before being removed more than 20 years ago in a ''palace revolt,'' died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RUTH
description: SCHWARTZ-Ruth. Of West 110th Street, New York City, died Friday at her home after a brief illness. Born in Brooklyn to Dora and George Schwartz, she was a graduate of Eastern District High School. For many years Miss Schwartz worked as an administrative assistant for the Amalgamated Men's Clothing Manufacturers of New York. She was a frequent contributor of anecdotes, humorous observations and recipes to The New York Times, The Daily News and Prevention Magazine. She leaves her niece and nephew, Charlotte and Benton Berman of Connecticut, as well as great-nieces and nephews Paula and Scott Vogel, Elissa and Maier Benudis, Lee and Sherri Ganbarg of New York, and Peter and Tracy Ganbarg of New Jersey, as well as Todd and Tracy Berman and Leela and Joe Greenblott of Maryland. Miss Schwartz also leaves six grandnieces and nephews. Services 1 PM, Sunday, February 23, at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Donations to DOROT, NYC.

title: A Soft Money Party
description: Ever since he was first buffeted with questions about Democratic money-raising practices, President Clinton has been vowing to clean up the political fund-raising system.

title: Look What the Cat Just Dragged In
description: That Darn Cat

title: Croatia Anyone? Tourists Drift Back
description: Before war broke out in 1991 and destroyed a flourishing tourism business, Croatia was a popular place to go. Dubrovnik, Split and Korcula were familiar ports of call for cruise ships, and Croatian areas of Yugoslavia received between six million and eight million visitors annually. In January 1996 the United States State Department lifted its warning against travel there, and last year the number of tourists was back up to about 60 percent of the prewar figures. Some tour companies with offices in the United States are again offering trips there. Among them are these:

title: UConn Slowed, Not Stopped
description: Before his Villanova women's basketball team played Connecticut tonight, Coach Harry Perretta said it was a matter or choosing your poison.

title: Quebec's Little Girl, Conquering the Globe
description: LANGUAGE IS AT THE HEART OF just about everything in the independence-minded province of Quebec, as the French singer Charles Aznavour found out last October when he tried to sing a few songs in English during a concert here and nearly got booed off the stage.

title: Australia: Not That Boring
Even in Winter, The Market for Summer Rentals Is Hot
description: THE cellular phone rang in Sonnie Hall's silver blue Ford sedan -- again. ''What now?'' she said, as she picked it up. ''So how many of them are there?'' she asked. ''They didn't have an appointment and I can't see them today. I'm totally booked.'' She paused. ''So what weeks do they want?'' She listened. ''Aug. 2 to Aug. 16 is gone. If they'll do July 12 to 26 there's a few openings; if they leave a name and number I'll get a fax out Monday.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLLISTER, CHARLOTTE CHASE FENTON
description: HOLLISTER - Charlotte Chase Fenton. 6/11/06-2/23/47. Always loved and remembered. Diney

title: The Worst Was Yet to Come
description: NAZI GERMANY

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ONLY TWICE I'VE WISHED FOR HEAVEN By Dawn Turner Trice. Crown, $23.

title: Advocate of Big Changes at Public Schools
description: GORDON A. BRUNO, executive director of the Hartford-based Connecticut Center for School Change, had a long career as a school administrator before founding the center in September 1994. He is perhaps best remembered as the outspoken superintendent of Meriden's public schools, where he fought the Board of Education to deliver free breakfast to poor children. His contract was not renewed.

title: Isolated Elderly Need Young to Care
description: To the Editor:

title: TRENT LOTT AND HIS FIERCE FRESHMEN
description: When Richard Berke discusses Senator Lott's time at Ole Miss, we learn that he was a fraternity man, a cheerleader and a person of moderation, but we learn nothing about his attitude toward James Meredith's attempt to integrate the university, toward the assassination of Medgar Evers or toward the Freedom Riders.

title: Southern Stores Making Parking Easier for Pregnant Drivers
description: The supermarket parking lot in suburban Atlanta was nearly full as the evening shoppers circled, jockeying for spaces. But the few available spots were far from the store, making it tough for some shoppers, particularly expectant mothers, some struggling with wailing toddlers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRABKIN, STEVEN WAYNE
description: DRABKIN-Steven Wayne. 10/19/ 61-2/23/81. Memory has painted his image with colors that never fade. He is so dear to our hearts.

title: A Bus on the Way To Haight-Ashbury
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLME, MILDRED ''MIMI''
description: HOLME-Mildred ''Mimi'', age 68, of Sarasota, Florida died February 18, 1997 at the age of 68. She was born in Bristol, England and was a homemaker. She graduated from Riverdale Country School and Oxford University. She is survived by her daughters Roberta (Robin) Wolyner of New York, NY; Jennifer Holme also of New York, NY; sons Joseph Holme III of Sarasota and Simon Holme of Sarasota. Also a brother Robert Nicol of LaPorte, Colorado, and one grandchild. No service will be held. Memorial donations may be sent to Florida State University Foundation/Mildred Holme Scholarship Program, Office of Professional Development, 555 West Pensacola Street, Tallahassee, FL 32306-2027.

title: Delay Seen In Restoring NATO Role For France
description: France said more than a year ago that it would rejoin the NATO commands it left in 1966 if the United States would concede more of them to European officers. But now the French Government is under increasing domestic pressure to stay out and will probably decide to do so this spring, many French and American officials say.

title: Feeding Frenzy
description: You have promised yourself that this would be a year of glam hips and sparkling arteries. Resolving to go low fat and low cal, you surrender your Haagen-Dazs to scalding water, give your family-size Hellmann's to the local soup kitchen and begin hunting down anything made with Olestra (Has anyone actually eaten this stuff?) Hello, world, you're wending your way to waifdom.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A tingling British mystery, an intense war drama, a gripping monster spectacle and an effective page-to-screen translation of a best seller top the week's list.

title: Menus of the Rich and Famous
description: NONE of the many glittery enchantments of Southern California radiates more cachet than Beverly Hills. Even its ZIP code, 90210, is famous. Over 12 million visitors come to this city annually, attracted by its palm-shaded Mediterranean climate, luxury hotels and spas, and reputation as a kind of national park where the rich and famous still roam free in their natural habitat, nourished by fine California cuisine and wine, shopping in the boutiques along Rodeo and Beverly Drives.

title: What Do Two Rights Make?
description: The Supreme Court last week found itself once again at the messy intersection where two rights collide: the right of women to obtain abortions without having to make their way through gantlets, and the right of anti-abortion protesters to make their voices heard.

title: State Trying to Beat Beetles' Clock
description: Hoping to avert a standoff over the felling of trees infested with Asian long-horned beetles, city and state officials are to meet Wednesday with residents to resolve a dispute over funds for replacement trees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNE, CRYSTAL STAR
description: TOWNE-Crystal Star. Age 55, on February 18 at 4:28 AM. Bringer of light. Artist, mystic, poet, teacher & beautiful human being. Mother to Scott Himmelsbach and Ariel Joseph. Sister to John. Service at 3 P.M., on Sunday, March 2 at St. Francis Center, Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, N.Y. In acknowledgement to the staff of the 3rd fl Cohen Unit for their incredible kindness and generosity of spirit, we ask that instead of flowers donations may be sent in memory of Crystal to: North Shore University Hospital, Development Office, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, N.Y. 11030 with the notation: For 3rd Floor Cohen Unit. Namaste Om. Mani. Padme. Hum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADISCH, RHODA
description: RADISCH-Rhoda. Beloved wife of the late Milton, loving mother of Lois, dear sister of Sally Kroll, devoted grandmother of Miriam and Anna, cherished aunt of Linda, Cynthia, Heather, and Joseph. Services 1:00 pm Sun, ''The Riverside''

title: Boone Would Rather See Any Team but His Royals Finish in Last Place
description: Bob Boone will obviously win no humanitarian award this year. Gene Lamont will certainly not vote for him.

title: Keepers of the Dismal Faith
description: Not long ago, in a widely read introductory work on economics, I came upon an extended discussion of why popcorn is expensive at the movies. It turns out that economists have been debating this subject in scholarly journals for more than a quarter century.

title: And a Piano Doesn't Need Company
description: To the Editor:

title: An Inspiring Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Mailing It In: Art by Air
description: IT'S NOT EVERY MUSEUM THAT IS privileged to get an airmail missive from the Chilean conceptual artist Eugenio Dittborn. But no less than seven of them have landed at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo. They make up ''Remota: Airmail Paintings by Eugenio Dittborn,'' the 54-year-old artist's first major New York exhibition. But alas, for all its supposed freshness, the show turns out to be more about the strategy of packaging than the wizardry of art.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 23, 1997
description: Weeks

title: 'Take Back Your Mink,' Mattel Decrees
description: COLLECTORS have been warmly wrapping their Barbies for the last few years in tiny mink coats dyed red, tourmaline, even pink, and sold for $200 or so at furriers across the country.

title: Choosing a Bitter Pill
description: Dr. Suzanne Poppema is all for mifepristone, better known as RU-486. The Seattle physician compares its pending distribution in the United States by the Population Council to the liberating fall of Communism in Eastern Europe. She's worried, however, that patients are somehow failing to absorb the unpleasant (and widely publicized) realities about the so-called French abortion pill, which may be released here as early as the summer. She's in a position to know: for more than a year, Poppema's clinic -- one of six nationwide selected for a Food and Drug Administration trial of the drug -- has been dispensing mifepristone to dozens of pregnant women. Most patients, she says, still come in thinking it's a relatively no-muss form of birth control.

title: The Booming Voice of Liberalism
description: GLADSTONE A Biography. By Roy Jenkins. Illustrated. 698 pp. New York: Random House. $35.

title: The Limits Of Bait And Switch
description: IF YOU AGREE THAT CLASSICAL MUSIC needs to catch new listeners, what does one use for bait? Some readers suggest the backward-menu strategy: first tempt them with dessert, then gradually reel them toward the main course. It works in many cases and may have worked in mine. I wonder how much of a bite Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' would have taken out of my 16-year-old brain without the 15 years spent listening to my father's 78-rpm records of the standard repertory.

title: Kathleen O'Brien and Jay Dillon
description: WHEN asked to describe her wedding, Kathleen O'Brien said, ''Everything is connected with books and snowflakes.''

title: Progress For 2 Mets Pitchers
description: Bill Pulsipher and Jason Isringhausen continued to keep pace with the rest of the Mets' pitchers today -- a sign that they suffered no setbacks in their initial training-camp tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, ANNA
description: TRACHTENBERG-Anna, 91, of Edison, on February 2, 1997. Mother of Dr. Eugene and Bernice Trachtenberg. Sister of Bertha Goodman. Grandmother of two. Great-grandmother of two. Funeral services were held Friday at the Gosselin Funeral Home in Edison, NJ. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge. Shiva will be observed at son's residence.

title: Buyers of Harlem Ballroom Showed Little Sensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSTON, DOUGLAS P., JR.
description: KINGSTON-Douglas P., Jr. Age 71. Died on Feb. 22, 1997, at his home in Bristol, VT. Born in Buffalo, NY, the only son of Frances H. and Douglas P. Kingston. He is survived by his wife Sarah ''Sally'' Evans Kingston in Bristol, VT, his sons Douglas P. III, David E., and Thomas ''TK'' H. Kingston, and two grandchildren. Raised in New Canaan, CT, he graduated from Harvard University ('47) and received a Masters of Architecture from the Harvard Graduate School of Design. He received a Purple Heart for his service in southern France during WW II. He practiced with John M. Johansen in New Canaan, before moving to Baltimore, MD, in 1968 where he was a principal with the architectural firm CS&D until his retirement. He then fulfilled his lifelong desire and moved to Brtistol, VT, where he was chairman of the Board of Adjusters, delegate to the Addison County Regional Planning Commission, and a lister for the town of Bristol. He was a member of Addison County Amateur Radio Association and licensed as N1LXA, and the Bristol Rescue Squad Auxiliary. In keeping with his wishes, there will be no service, but the family will receive friends at home, 10 Elm Street, Bristol, VT, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 3-6 PM. Donations may be made to the Bistol Rescue Squad, Bristol, VT 05443 or Addison County Home Health Care Hospice, Marbleworks, Middlebury, VT 05753.

title: Deja Vu
description: MORE than 200 years old, and it, too, sits on the edge of a shopping center. When you review restaurants in New Jersey, you have to adjust to the fact that many are near shopping centers and have inelegant addresses.

title: I.R.S. Bans Deducting Medical Cost Of Marijuana
description: Stepping into a political and medical controversy, the Internal Revenue Service has ruled that taxpayers cannot deduct the cost of marijuana as a medical expense.

title: Just Drive a Used PC Off the Lot and Save
description: AS anyone who has ever bought a personal computer knows, obsolescence occurs sometime between when you sign the sales slip and when you load your new machine into the car.

title: Portrait of a Hustler Refutes Illusion of Glamour
description: To the Editor:

title: Look Out for Wires on the Roads
description: A PRECURSOR to change, and not a good one: a set of two thick, black cables stretched across your favorite roadway, attached to a massive steel box. The traffic engineers are at it again, doing a study that can only result in a change for the worse: a wider roadway, the construction of yet another suburban development, a mall expansion or, worst of all, a completely new mall.

title: Bar and Basketball Team Share Anger Over Shelter
description: When Project Renewal, a nonprofit social services agency, took over the management of the homeless shelter at Fort Washington Armory last October, many in the community were relieved. With the agency's proven record in managing shelters and its plan for daylong rehabilitation programs that would keep the 200 mentally ill men indoors, it was expected to be a vast improvement over the city, which at one time crammed more than 1,000 men into the Armory with little supervision, resulting in widespread panhandling.

title: A Historic Village With Seagoing Past
description: IT used to be that only during the summer would the Village of Port Jefferson be clogged with visitors who came by ferry across Long Island Sound, or by car or train to spend a day or a weekend.

title: Youth to Play in Grammy Jazz Band
description: LIKE many high school seniors with graduation around the corner, Michael Dopazo is living in a twilight zone these days, attending classes by necessity but focused heart and soul on the future. In 17-year-old Michael's case, however, the future has already begun.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON-Joanna. 8/16/69-2/23/83. More precious was the light in your eyes than all the roses in the world. Mom and Abby

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, SYLVIA
description: GORDON-Sylvia. In loving memory. Born in New York City, August 14, 1914, wife of the late Morris Gordon, photojournalist & pioneer in photography. She leaves her daughter Diane Gordon-Sacchetti of Manhattan, her sister Barbara Okin of Florida, her nieces and nephews of California, Ohio, Florida, New York, and her friends around the world. She was retired from her importing business from Italy. Services were private.

title: Selig Swears His Job Isn't What Most Think It Is
description: If it talks like a commissioner, walks like a commissioner, acts like a commissioner, smells like a commissioner and is paid like a commissioner, it figures to be a commissioner. But not according to Bud Selig, the man who has popularly been identified for nearly four and a half years as baseball's acting commissioner.

title: Margaret Servais, William Mangan
description: Margaret Mary Servais, the daughter of Nancy M. Servais of Walpole, Mass., and Robert A. Servais of West Mansfield, Mass., was married yesterday to William Joseph Mangan, a son of Mrs. T. Clifford Melim Jr. of Healdsburg, Calif., and John F. Mangan of San Francisco. The Rev. Anthony P. Sauer officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUIRHEAD, ISOBEL E.
description: MUIRHEAD-Isobel E. Of Jamesburg, NJ, on Feb. 19, 1997. Graduate of Douglas College and Fordham Law School. Member of Phi Beta Kappa. Retired from the Port Authority of NY and NJ in 1983, where she was Chief of Opinions and Appeals, Law. Awarded the Port Authority's Distinguished Service Medal in 1983. She is survived by her sister Margaret Swift of Jamesburg and her nephew Thomas Swift of Holmdel, NJ.

title: The Beat of Different Drummers
description: Offices usually have an ethos to which most workers conform. But what of the employees who stand out from the group? Do they try desperately to fit in, or do they celebrate their differnces? Have you ever stood alone? Did it create any distressing or humorous situations? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Magazine Looks at the Plus Side Of the Fashion World
description: HERE'S a surprising state of affairs: the editor of a fashion magazine who can't find anything to wear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSOHN, JACOB
description: ROBINSOHN-Jacob, on February 21st, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Ruth Maier Robinsohn and brother of Mendel. Trained in engineering at Columbia University and in law at New York University. For over sixty years, he was an attorney for the New York City Corporation Counsel's Office and a tenacious advocate of the city's interests. He was a founder and faithful supporter of numerous organizations devoted to the environment, animal welfare and family issues. Services today, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Drug Council Proposes Switch to Managed Care
description: The Governor's Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse would like Medicaid substance-abuse treatment programs to be handled through managed-care organizations, just like other medical treatment for Medicaid patients. The switch could save substantial amounts of money, said the council's executive director, Carolyn Bronson. But instead of putting the money back into the state and Federal coffers, the council would like the money used to increase the number of people eligible for treatment and the types of treatment.

title: Arts Group Wins Eviction Battle
description: ABC No Rio, the brash arts center that for three years has been battling eviction from its city-owned building, received an unexpected reprieve recently from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: Advisory Plan at Scudder

title: Legislators and Knee-Jerk Actions
description: MANAGING hospital stays by legislating minimum requirements cannot return health care on Long Island to a rational level of quality. Requiring by law that women and their newborns be allowed a minimum post-partum stay of two days does not guarantee quality care.

title: In Support Group, Early Alzheimer's Sufferers
description: EVERY Tuesday, a small group gathers in the New Hyde Park office of the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation. On a recent morning, several men and one woman, who used their first names only, sat on couches facing the group's facilitator, Susan Wallach.

title: 'Betrayal Trauma'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEDRIS, MARIE M.
description: GEDRIS-Marie M. 7/17/17-1/6/97. It's in Our Lady's Chapel, Saturday, March 1, 1:00PM, at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: In Nutley, Mementos of a Very Straight Shooter
description: Taking up 3.4 square miles of densely populated Essex County, Nutley probably reminds no one of the Wild West these days. But when the sharpshooter Annie Oakley and her husband were looking for a home near New York City in 1892, the farmlands, rolling hills and horse country of Nutley caught their eye.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE HOUSE ON BROOKE STREET

title: Jeeves and the Great White Way
description: ''Ah, Jeeves!'' I burbled as the honest fellow flung wide my bedroom curtains. ''God's in His heaven and all's well with Manhattan.''

title: No Dogs, or Lawyers, Need Apply
description: I OUTGREW my apartment, a cramped home-office studio. So I decided to trade it in for a two-bedroom share.

title: From the Boardwalk, Love at First Bite
description: It was a dark and summery night when I fell in love along the boardwalk in Wildwood. The Ferris wheel was spinning; the Tilt-a-Whirl was tilting and whirling. And my friends were shopping for salt-water taffy.

title: Lauren Meredith, Bradley Smith
description: Lauren Rollyn Meredith, a daughter of Kathryn S. and Robert R. Meredith of Rumson, N.J., and Bradley Charles Smith, a son of Beverly B. and Michael R. Smith of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday in New York. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club.

title: Robinson's Image Goes to Market
description: Jackie Robinson's breaking of baseball's color barrier 50 years ago will be remembered in a broad range of ventures, both high-minded and commercial: from academic symposia, statues and subways ads promoting racial tolerance to cereal boxes, T-shirts, gold commemorative coins and trading cards.

title: Winter Salads Flavored With Beets and Celery Root
description: CERTAIN kinds of salads seem tailored to winter. Salads served at room temperature with pungent greens like arugula or watercress make a good first course before a light meat or fish dish. Beets add a colorful note, too. If they are roasted in the oven, they develop an intense, concentrated flavor, which does not emerge when beets are boiled. Raw celery root is also good in salads. It usually shows up in French bistros as celeri remoulade, grated and tossed in a mustardy dressing. Waldy Malouf, the new chef at the Rainbow Room, combines it with hazelnuts, arugula and endive. He sprinkles the salad with a pungent aged goat cheese, which comes in stick form to make it easy to grate. Goat cheese sticks are available in specialty shops or from Coach Dairy Goat Farm, Rural Route 1, Box 445, Pine Plains, N.Y. 12567; (518) 398-5325.

title: Keeping Your Powder Dry
description: THE RETURN OF the regular, monthly Presidential news conference is a fine thing, not the least because it gives us a chance to instruct the Chief Executive -- and one another -- on the use of famous phrases.

title: Safety-Minded Playground Keeps Thrills
description: When Chris Crowley, a Parks Department landscape designer, presented his preliminary scheme for the playground at 83d Street and Riverside Park to a parent group a few weeks ago, it had all the standard play equipment and a nice design element or two, but the parents said they were a little disappointed.

title: Zaire Arms Its Refugees
description: At a jungle outpost named Tingi-Tingi, so obscure as to go unnamed on the map of Zaire, scores of Hutu refugees from Rwanda are dying every day of disease and hunger.

title: Loitering, or Job Hunting?
description: They come from all over: New Jersey, Manhattan, Queens and Long Island, by train, bus and foot. Latin American laborers, looking for a day's work. And they congregate in the parking lot of a Dunkin' Donuts in East Flushing, much to the distress of the proprietor.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: AIRLINE

title: Star Quality
description: On INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO, CHRISTOPHER REEVE talks about his love of acting, which began in fourth grade in Princeton, N.J. With typical humor, he tells of advice he got from John Houseman (''It's terribly important that you become a serious classical actor . . . unless they offer you a load of money to be something else''). He learned from Katharine Hepburn (in ''A Matter of Gravity'') and he says he didn't play Superman as a comic-book character, but as a friend. Now Mr. Reeve is beginning a new career. He has directed ''In the Gloaming,'' an HBO film with Glenn Close -- WEDNESDAY at 10 P.M. on BRAVO.

title: Mexican Can Sue U.S.
description: A Mexican doctor who was seized by bounty hunters and brought to trial in the United States after the torture and killing of an American drug enforcement agent, and then acquitted, can sue the Federal Government, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: How to Create a Garden in Four Days: Work Hard and Don't Sleep
description: In four days last week, Anthony V. Sblendorio and his team of nine landscapers and masons created a 1,500-square-foot garden with a moss-covered, flower-lined fieldstone walkway and a waterfall spilling into a pond with lily pads. A job of this size normally takes 10 days, so Mr. Sblendorio and his crew worked from morning until late into the night to finish before the judges began strolling through the 31st annual New Jersey Flower and Garden Show on Friday.

title: Ragtime, Madrigals And Songs by Brahms
description: CAMPUSES yield some of the more adventuresome music on the concert schedule this week. Today at 3 o'clock, for instance, Wesleyan University is host to Elite Syncopation, which describes the program of classic ragtime and early jazz as well as identifying the instrumental quintet playing favorites by Scott Joplin, Jelly Roll Morton, Eubie Blake and Duke Ellington.

title: Immigration Rules Enrage Russian Envoy in Seattle
description: The first Russian consul ever based in Seattle has so brimmed with post-cold-war good will during his four years here that he has handed out, by his count, more than 4,400 business cards.

title: Micro-Loans for Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Concealed Guns Won't Make Us Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Show Stoppers
description: Stripes play a starring role this season with long, stretchy dresses for evening, worn here by eight Las Vegas dancers.

title: The Law, Order And Life On the Streets
description: AS dusk settled over East Hartford one day recently, Iran Nazario was at a stop sign near the Charter Oak Terrace housing complex. A pack of teen-age boys swaggered by looking poised for action. ''I know that look,'' Mr. Nazario said, nodding at the youngsters as they dipped their way into the projects. ''All I'd have to do is give them that look back and say 'Yea,' and they'd be like, 'Man what you mean 'yea', and before you know it, they'd be tearing into me. It doesn't take much.''

title: U.S. and Private Cutbacks Mean Hard Times at Pantries
description: GLORIA DECAL, 44, of Hempstead, a single mother of two, had been told by her social worker to expect a cut in her family's $221-a-month allowance for food stamps.

title: James Tierney, 74, Rights Leader
description: James T. Tierney, formerly chief executive of the Fund for Peace, a nonprofit organization that focuses on such issues as human rights, the security of nations and conflict resolution, died on Jan. 26 at his home in Phoenix. He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK (PASTOR), JACK
description: PASTERNACK (PASTOR)-Jack. Born on the Lower East Side on 22 December 1902; died at Lenox Hill Hospital on 15 February 1997. Box office manager of the Palace Theater back-when; song plugger known as The Boy with the Golden Voice; drummer; comedian; singer; master of ceremonies; merchandiser; husband; father; grandfather; and all-around nice person who will be missed by all he met. Survived by his wife of fifty-eight years, Lillian; son, Fred; and grandsons, Alexander and Gregory. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Lenox Hill Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EZEKIEL, MARGARET
description: EZEKIEL - Margaret. Beloved mother, it's been one year. I miss you everyday. Lynn

title: Labor to Recruit Elderly Protesters
description: From the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s point of view, the internship program it set up last year to immerse college students in the labor movement was such a success that it has decided to set up a similar program for retirees.

title: Archer Winsten, 92, Movie Reviewer at The Post, Dies
description: Archer Winsten, who spent 50 years turning out crisp, thoughtful movie reviews for The New York Post, but only, he insisted, because he found the job a pleasant enough alternative to actual work, died on Friday at a daughter's home in Moreau, N.Y. He was 92 and had retired in 1986.

title: Beck's Fugue
description: For a certain kind of college kid right now, Beck is what Bob Dylan was ages ago, whenever, 1969: he's the singer-songwriter you could do a term paper on. You could write that Beck's approach to music evinces a comprehension of bricolage and the impossibility of esthetic originality in a post-modern moment of information overload; you could write how his grandfather was active in the neo-Dadaist art group Fluxus and how his mother hung around Warhol's Factory for a while; you could even write that the most intriguing ''sample'' on Beck's big slow-funk hit of last summer, ''Where It's At'' -- the part where this low, disembodied voice asks, ''What about those who swing both ways, A.C./D.C.'s?'' -- is nothing less than an embrace of gender confusion, though that may bother Beck's girlfriend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, HERBERT
description: SPECTOR-Herbert, 81. Beloved husband of Sylvia (Schachner), died on February 19, 1997 in Sarasota, Florida. Born in New York City in 1915. He was a graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School and an attorney in NYC since 1938. Following his service in World War II, Mr. Spector became a court attache in The Bronx County Court House. 33 years later he retired as Executive Officer of The First Judicial Department of The State Supreme Court. He taught for 18 years at The Bernard Baruch School of The City College of New York in the area of real property law, a field in which he was an acknowledged expert. He was a Democratic District Leader in The Bronx, a member of the Executive Board of The NYC Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith and The National Commission of The ADL. He served as Special Master in NY Supreme Court, was a Family Court Hearing Officer, and a Mediator in The Supreme Court in Florida. He was a member of The Bronx County and NY County Bar Associations and The American Judges Association. He was a member of Temple Hillel in Valley Stream for more than 35 years. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Sylvia. He is the father of Amy Applebaum, Stephen Spector and Cheryl Spector. All 3 children followed his lead and became attorneys. He also leaves 7 grandchildren, Seth and Jessica (Amy), Morgan and Michael with (Stephen and Jane), and Rachel, Daniel and Leah (Cheryl and Tom). An avid reader, golfer and bridge player he was deeply loved by his family and will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held at 1pm on Sunday, February 23 at Tishman Memorial Chapel, Swift Road and Stickney Point, Sarasota. Cremation will follow. Donations may be made in his name to The New York Anti-Defamation League, 823 United Nations Plaza, NY, NY 10017 or to: Hospice of Southwest Florida, East Team, 6055 Rand Blvd, Sarasota 34238.

Calling the Attorney General! A Federal law enforcement official is needed at the Executive Mansion. That location is about 1,200 yards from your office and can be identified by the presence of tourists, Democratic National Committee employees and strangers bearing gifts.

description: The genesis of Pat LaFontaine's most recent season of discomfort can most likely be traced back to one whopping hit he took on an unforgiving evening at Madison Square Garden nearly seven years ago.

title: Rush Is On -- in Riverhead and Bay Shore -- to Build Aquarium
description: AQUARIUMS have long been used as tools to resurrect dying seaside towns. On the Northeast Coast, Baltimore, Boston, Coney Island; Camden, N.J.; Mystic, Conn., and Portland, Me., have all benefited, in differing degrees, from the influx of tourists drawn by the riches of the sea on display.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HERBERT C.
description: COHEN-Herbert C. On February 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Sophie. Adoring father of Jo and Gordon Gaynor. Proud grandfather of Stephanie, Lane, Adam, Scott and Lauren. Cherished great-grandfather of Cameron. Graveside service is on Sunday at 1 P.M., at the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Princeton Clinches the Ivy League Title
description: Princeton used a 16-6 run to open the second half and held on for a 60-53 victory over Dartmouth tonight to clinch the Ivy League title and the nation's first bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: The Baths Are Getting Closer to a Trip to the Showers
description: There was hope and earnestness behind the splash of rumors circulating in southern Brooklyn in the last few months that the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club had been sold.
