title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROUT, THOMAS PECK JR.
description: PROUT-Thomas Peck Jr., 79, of East Dorset, VT. Formerly of Summit, NJ. On February 12, 1997. He is survived by his wife Joann Hill Prout, a sister Virginia Prout Combs of Wickenburg, AZ., a daughter Claudia Prout Casey of Peapack, N.J., a son Nicholas LeHuray Prout of Hoboken, NJ, a stepdaughter Julia O. MacDonald, a stepson Brian Scott T. Oakley, and a step-granddaughter, Sydney E. MacDonald, and many devoted nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his first wife Elise Cook Prout who died in 1986. During World War II, Mr. Prout was a P-38 pilot and served in North Africa and Italy. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross. In 1945 he took over the operation of Fair Oaks Hospital in Summit, New Jersey, which was started by his father in 1902. He served on the Board of Governors of Baltusrol Golf Club and on the board of the Ekwanok County Club in Manchester, VT. Contributions may be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHRER, CARLTON J.
description: ROHRER-Carlton J. On Feb 20, 1997. Brother of Elizabeth R. Reddy of Westlake, OH and J. Albert Rohrer of Youngstown, NY. Survived by two nieces and a nephew. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. on Mon 3-5 and 7-9 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Francis Xavier RC Church, 46 W. 16 St, (betw 5th and 6th) on Tues 10:30 a.m. Interment Lewiston, NY. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to St. Francis Xavier Church or a charity of your choice.

title: Stores Said to Violate '96 Box Cutter Law
description: An undercover investigation has found that many stores in New York City are ignoring a new law that prohibits them from allowing minors to buy box cutters, which are often used as weapons in the city's schools, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: When Ali Performed A Knockout on Film
description: WHEN you see him now, he's Muhammad Ali in name only. As he held the Olympic torch in Atlanta, the right hand that battered so many opponents shook with Parkinson's syndrome. In his rare television appearances, the voice that shouted amusing rhymes now mumbles. His eyes still twinkle, but his toes don't.

title: Goddesses, Harlots and Other Male Fantasies
description: A HISTORY OF

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Atlantic City column last Sunday misstated the financial situation of the Claridge Hotel and Casino, and the error was also reflected in the front-page index. The Claridge announced in December that it was seeking to negotiate a restructuring of its debt with corporate bondholders; it has not filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: A French Home, Humble but Sweet
description: THE Charente, in western France, may not have the storybook charm of the neighboring Dordogne -- its landscape is flatter, its architecture far less picturesque -- but for our family of four, it had charms enough to make the month we spent last summer in a house at the edge of the river pass all too quickly.

title: Traveling Light
description: To the Editor: I laughed till I cried at Joanne Kaufman's ''Travel Light? Yeah, Right!'' (Jan. 26). Having founded Overpackers Anonymous, I know her words will evoke a deep sense of community in many of us.

title: Riding the Strong Dollar For All It's Worth
description: SUDDENLY, Japan is a bargain. And Germany doesn't look so pricey either. Make no mistake, it's not like the glory days, when the yen was fixed at 360 to the dollar -- where it stayed for decades after World War II -- or even like the early 80's. Anyone who dined cheaply in Tokyo or stayed at a decent hotel for $30 in Berlin during the mid-70's will be disappointed.

title: In Canada, Troubling Times for the National Sport and the Nation
description: Americans raised in northern border towns gradually absorb some of the subtle but significant differences between their culture and that of neighboring Canada. One country grew from a revolution against England; the other evolved peacefully from British colonial control.

title: Guilt Lite
description: With five marriages, a few affairs and a history of late child-support payments haunting his past, Neal Donald Walsch (above) is no angel, but the Ashland, Ore.-based writer is doing pretty well as a divine messenger. His book, ''Conversations With God,'' recently reached No. 3 on The New York Times best-seller list, bringing readers a chatty Almighty who seems completely nonjudgmental about mankind's sinful ways. ''I do not love good more than I love bad,'' he tells Walsch. ''Hitler went to Heaven.'' Published by a small regional house before Putnam bought it last year, the book has developed a fervent following mainly through word of mouth. ''I'll read it until I memorize it,'' proclaims Renee Davis of Lake Oswego, Ore. ''I've never heard the truth -- the call for people to live up to their highest ideals -- stated so clearly.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Southern Journey

title: Establishing a Soap Is No Day at the Beach
description: WHEN a fresh-faced Kansas City girl ditches her husband-to-be in favor of a mysterious Southern California man she met on the Internet, she finds herself in a picturesque coastal town touched by romance, murder, misunderstandings and nefarious schemes in equal measure. Welcome to Sunset Beach, Miss K.C. Now, get busy. After a formidable publicity campaign to hype its Jan. 6 debut, it's time for ''Sunset Beach,'' Aaron Spelling's new daytime soap opera (weekdays at noon on NBC) to find a devoted audience.

title: Parcells's Pluses
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shedding Light on a Neglected Genius
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, Gugliemo Marconi is not responsible for radio as we know it. And Thomas Alva Edison was not the one to bring reliable electrical currents into homes and industries. Instead it was the work of Nikola Tesla, now a virtual unknown, that catapulted the world into the future.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a picture on Jan. 19 showing Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton in 1982 was printed in mirror image. Hillary Clinton should appear at the left.

title: Bread, Israel, Islam
description: Pay attention to Morocco. Pay close attention. What's going on here today is typical of a troubling chain of events that is unfolding throughout the Arab world and Turkey. It works like this: Pressure to join the global economy forces Arab governments to privatize state industries, to stop guaranteeing college grads a job and to raise bread prices. This restructuring produces huge income gaps. The losers take to the streets or drift toward Islamic fundamentalist organizations. To express their frustration, the losers denounce their government's relations with Israel, because that's the most effective and evocative way to delegitimize the regime for raising bread prices. The rulers respond by distancing themselves from Israel, but don't lower the price of bread.

title: Gatti Leaves Little Doubt In Rematch With Patterson
description: Arturo Gatti and Tracy Harris Patterson picked up here at the Atlantic City Convention Center early this morning where they left off two years ago at Madison Square Garden.

title: Nora Beloff, British Reporter, 78
description: Nora Beloff, a gifted political writer and foreign correspondent who was a trailblazer among women in British journalism, died on Feb. 12. She was 78 and a longtime resident of London.

title: Taking Their Seats on The Street
description: IT was the summer of 1960 and Wall Street didn't wear the ''For Whites Only'' signs that were common in 12-year-old Harold Doley's hometown, New Orleans. Yet Wall Street was as white as those segregated parts of New Orleans that were locked behind the signs of the Old South.

title: No Longer an Island (Musically), Cuba Adds to Caribbean Mix
description: THE FIRST THING THAT ONE hears in Issac Delgado's voice is how distinct he is from other Afro-Cuban singers. Most of his notes don't seem to start anywhere; they fuzz into being. And though he can coo, he can also chant, hard and strong.

title: Seeking Signs of Life In Kosher 'Tuna'
description: To the Editor:

title: Brioche and Buzz at Power Lit. 101
description: IN more civilized days, Norma Feder could stroll into the chichi restaurant at Barneys just minutes before Harold Evans's monthly literary breakfast and snag a choice seat. Now, she complains, she must show up a good half-hour before its 8:30 A.M. start to beat the clamoring hordes and claim her favorite perch, a tall bar stool along one wall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGUIRRE, ROMY.
description: AGUIRRE-Romy. On the 23rd of February, 1995. Still remembering you with love and pride. Your twin, Bela

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Master-full Imitations

title: Veronica Kelly, Michael Iuliano
description: Veronica Marie Kelly and Michael Peter Iuliano, associates at New York law firms, were married yesterday in the Sacred Heart Chapel of the Dominican Convent at Sparkill, N.Y. The Rev. Eric Andrews performed the ceremony.

title: Not Everyone Is Smiling at St. Luke's Clinic Plan
description: Ever since Mayor Edward I. Koch closed Sydenham Hospital in 1980, residents of West Harlem have been fighting for a medical institution to take its place. So when St. Luke's Hospital announced last year that it planned to build a primary care clinic on 125th Street near Morningside Avenue, Community Board 9 gave its approval.

title: How a State Initiative Helps Create New Jobs
description: A PROGRAM initiated by the state last May has proven helpful to companies expanding within New Jersey and has induced others to relocate to the state.

title: Explosives Missing at Airport
description: Sheriff's deputies training a bomb-sniffing dog either misplaced five pounds of explosives at Mitchell International Airport in Milwaukee or the material was stolen, the Milwaukee County Sheriff said on Friday. He made a public appeal for its return.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, W. HOFFMAN
description: BENJAMIN-W. Hoffman 87, of Garrison, NY and NYC, in peace at home on February 20th. Devoted husband to Joan Ellett. Loving father to Beverley Goodwin, John Bigelow and Nathaniel Prime. Six grandchildren and five siblings and many others will miss his love and charity. Funeral services Saturday, March 1st, 2 PM, St. Philips Church, Garrison. In lieu of flowers: Hospice of Putnam, 43 Kensico Dr., Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

title: Under Beirut's Rubble, Remnants of 5,000 Years of Civilization
description: Archeologists digging beneath the war rubble of central Beirut have found the remains of nearly 5,000 years of successive civilizations.

title: Bright Moments For Good Causes
description: Aiding the arts, students, neighborhoods, the homeless with AIDS, and social services.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Beautician

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTEMAN, EVELYN G.
description: ENTEMAN-Evelyn G. Age 82, of Hackettstown, NJ, on Sunday, Feb. 16, 1997. Mother of John H. F. of NYC. Step-mother of Elizabeth Hearns, of Lancaster, VA, and Willard of Providence, RI. Sister of Frederic Gabel of Morrisville, NC. Also survived by five step-grandchildren and five step-great-grandchildren. Funeral service will be on Saturday, March 1, at 2 PM, at the First Presbyterian Church, 14 Hilltop Rd., Mendham, NJ. Memorial gifts may be made to the Emma Willard School, 285 Pawling Ave., Troy, NY 12180.

title: DIARY
description: CAMPAIGN FINANCE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, SR.
description: LYONS-Sr. Margaret. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, on February 22, 1997. Dedicated emergency room nurse. Survived by several cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St, Yonkers, NY, on Sunday, 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, at the convent. Interment following, St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers.

title: On Guard! Don't Mess With Me!
description: LONG Island must be a very dangerous place. Why else would there be so many kung fu, karate and martial arts schools? There seems to be one in every other strip mall, scaring out more peaceful businesses like bagel barns and Hallmark card stores. I'm not talking about gentle arts like yoga or tai chi. I mean the smash-their-throats-poke-their-eyes-out-destroy-their-knee-joints world of the true martial arts.

title: Back From Down Under
description: FOR reasons that have little to do with the quality of its products, Mitsubishi sells hardly as many cars in this country in a year as General Motors' assembly lines turn out in a fortnight.

title: Goodbye Peep Show: Subway Barber Gets a New View
description: In 1995, John Drakakis's barbershop was subterranean and attracted few customers. He was miserable. This year, his new barbershop is still subterranean and still has few customers, but Mr. Drakakis is no longer miserable and he figures his business now has at least a fighting chance.

title: A Chalet of One's Own
description: WHILE hiking in the Swiss Alps one autumn, I passed a log chalet, smoke puffing neatly from the chimney, and children playing contentedly on the balcony in view of waterfalls, pastures, densely wooded forest and shockingly high mountains crowned with snow. Surrounded by the strong aroma of pine and the sounds of tinkling cowbells and rushing river water, I realized that my elegant room at the hotel in town was not quite what an Alpine vacation was meant to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, NORMAN PERKINS, SR.
description: BLAKE-Norman Perkins, Sr. Of Greenwich, CT. On February 20, 1997 at Greenwich Hospital. Husband of Eleanor Blake. Father of Norman P. Blake, Jr. and Leslie Blake Kotiza. A Memorial Mass will be held Monday, Feb. 24th, at 10:30 AM in St Mary's Church, 178 Greenwich Ave, Greenwich, CT. Burial will be private. Calling hours Sunday, February 23rd, 6-8PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Greenwich Hospital, Norman Blake Fund, 5 Perry ridge Rd, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAFF, JULIUS G. (''BUDDY'')
description: STAFF-Julius G. (''Buddy''), died on Feb. 15, 1997. He was the son of the late Commissioner Samuel G. Staff and the late Alice Grossman Staff. He was a graduate of the Barnard School for Boys and attended Hobart College, Geneva, NY. Mr. Staff was graduated from the University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL. His father was a Commissioner of the New York State Insurance Fund under three different administrations. His maternal grandfather founded one of the most successful and prestigious shoe manufacturing and retail stores of its time-Julius Grossman Shoes and Pedemode. Mr. Staff was survived by his former wife, Toni Kahal McGowan, of Prescott, AZ. He had also been married to Jane Freeman Kahn, of Beverly Hills, CA, who predeceased him. Burial was private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, PEARL YADOFF
description: FINK-Pearl Yadoff. Of NYC on Feb. 17. Lover of opera and the Sunday Times Crossword; obtained a Master's from Goddard at the age of 56. She is survived by brother Bernard Yadoff, daughter Janis Ian, son Eric Fink, daughterin-law Natalie and her beloved grandsons, Matthew, Brian and Shawn. Donations can be made to Goddard Coll., Plainfield, VT

title: Harassment Complaints and Cutbacks Trouble Washington's Libraries
description: Grace M. Kelly reveres the Martin Luther King Memorial Library, the biggest of the 27 in the District of Columbia's system. ''You can learn anything you want just reading a book in the library,'' she said as she struck the ''F1'' key on one of the electronic card catalogue's computer terminals so she could start her search.

title: 'The Key To the Mall'
description: To the Editors:

title: Morgan Stanley's Clunker of An Offering
description: Attention, Dean Witter customers (and amateur investors everywhere who are clamoring to get into new stock offerings): Morgan Stanley does indeed have a track record of doing some of the hottest deals on Wall Street, deals that you may be able to buy into once it merges with Dean Witter. But keep in mind that even Morgan Stanley, the investment banker to the corporate stars, underwrites the occasional stinker. Like the Cronos Group, which it brought public just over a year ago.

title: TRENT LOTT AND HIS FIERCE FRESHMEN
description: The four smiling Republican senators on the cover of the Magazine represent states that, in total, account for less than 5 percent of the United States' population (''Trent Lott and His Fierce Freshmen,'' by Richard L. Berke, Feb. 2). We have only ourselves to blame if we as citizens sit back and watch senators from Mississippi, Alabama, Kansas and Oregon (as well as others listed in your article) attack a woman's right to a safe legal abortion and other progressive measures.

title: Dina Venezky and Stephen Hahn
description: Dina Yael Venezky, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Richard Venezky of Newark, Del., was married last evening to Stephen Charles Hahn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Hahn of Kitchener, Ontario, Canada. Rabbi David Kaplan performed the ceremony at the DuPont Country Club in Wilmington, Del.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Dante's Peak

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JANET HAYES
description: WALKER-Janet Hayes. Founder and producing director of the York Theatre Company, died February 20, 1997 after a long and valiant battle with cancer. Wife of Charles Dodsley Walker, mother of Peter Hayes Walker and Susan Walker Wyss, grandmother of Natalie Starr Wyss, Branford Hayes Walker and Camille Walker Wyss. Sister of Dr. E. Morris Hayes and Marian Hayes Miller. She was born in Shanghai, China in 1925 of missionary parents, and recieved a Master's degree in music from the New England Conservatory and a Master's degree in theatre from Hunter College. As a singer, she was an active recitalist, giving concerts in Europe and the U.S. Later she appeared as a singing actress, in a career which included roles in many Broadway shows and in regional theatres. In 1969 she founded the York Theatre Company, which became known particularly for its outstanding revivals of musicals, generating numerous awards both for the theatre and for Janet. Memorial services will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, Connecticut at 1 P.M., on Tuesday, February 25, and at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, at 1 PM on Thursday, February 27. A celebration of Janet's life in the arts will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the York Theatre Co., Inc., 619 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10019, where a memorial fund is being created in her honor.

title: Patching the Cracks in the Rock
description: ADA AND BILL WELLS had been loyal customers of the Prudential Insurance Company of America for most of their lives. But at a time when they were settling into retirement and thinking of cutting back on their life insurance, a Prudential agent saddled them with a new policy that he promised would virtually pay for itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SHIRLEY
description: PRICE-Shirley, on February 19, 1997 in her 94th year. Loving aunt of Barbara and Richard Schpero, Ilene and Mel Morris, Nicki and Ira Harris, and Peter Price. Sister-inlaw of Trudy Price, great aunt of Suzanne and Steven Schpero, Marion and Eric Hertlein, Steven Morris, Jackie, Jonathan, and Bradley Harris. Great-great aunt of Harrison Hertlein. Sister to the departed Marion, Ira and Nat. Special cousin to many. Shirley was strongly devoted to her family. She had a great mind. Shirley loved and was loved in return. She was a good listener and a concerned friend. She will be greatly missed and never out of our hearts and minds. Service Sunday 1:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For Once, A Focus on The Fringe
description: MONDAY night's benefit show at the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center on the Lower East Side was billed as ''A Night of 100 Stars.'' There may have been 100 performers, but Jerry Stiller was the only famous person in the building.

title: Science Fiction
description: CITY ON FIRE (Harper Prism, $22), by Walter Jon Williams, is that rarest of entertainments, a sequel that improves on a successful predecessor. ''Metropolitan'' (1995) introduced the yoked conspirators Constantine and Aiah -- he of the keen mind, hard body and overpowering will; she of the humble background, bleeding heart and unquenchable ambition. Together, they pulled off a revolution that promised to renew a tired old world and usher in a vaguely defined utopia known as the New City.

title: Cheers, and Tears, For a Job Well Done
description: Big girls don't cry, except, of course, on Senior Night.

title: Peace Is Up to North Korea, Albright Tells Front-Line Troops
description: Visiting one of the last armed borderlines of the cold war at a time of turbulence and hunger in North Korea, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that a peace settlement between the Koreas ''basically depends on how much the North Koreans are hurting.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOTTY, CAROL
description: MOTTY-Carol, on February 21st, 1997 in Miami Beach. Renowned artist. Beloved wife of Norman Levenson. Devoted mother of Erik Bryan Slavin. Adored sister of Richard and Steven Finkelstein and the late Marilyn Finkelstein Robins. Cherished by her family and friends-Dayala and Vernell; Charlie, Jane, Emily and Amanda; Janice, Laura and Daniel; Gina and Craig; Jesse, Merry and Ali; Ruth, Herb and Harold; and Grace and Josh. Adam, Allan, Cara, Charles, Edyne, Elaine, Fred, Heather, Hillary, Jane, Jimmy, Kenny, Kia, Linda, Robin, Stacey, Tania, and many more too numerous to mention. She added vibrant color to our lives and will always live on in our hearts. Contributions may be made to Amnesty International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUGENT, HELEN MARA
description: NUGENT-Helen Mara, 89, died February 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph C. Nugent and the late John V. Mara. Loving mother of Maura Mara Concannon and the late Timothy J. Mara. Dear sister of Lillian Phelan and Jeanne Rohrs. Cherished grandmother of Christine Glithner, Kathleen Anderson and Sheila Concannon and the great-grandmother of Peter and Clare Glithner. For information, please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: Reader's Digest Grant Aids Second School
description: WHEN the Reader's Digest Foundation needed a new name for one of its programs, Laurance Rockefeller, a former member of the Reader's Digest board of directors, came up with Tall Tree. ''A tall tree has the ability to change the landscape, like tall trees in a forest,'' said Claudia Edwards, executive director of the foundation. ''The name signifies that this is a major way of giving back to the community.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a photograph appeared erroneously last Sunday under the Photographer's Journal heading. The picture, which showed a person dancing with a shadow, was taken in Brooklyn, and was intended for another section of the newspaper.

title: Watching for Banks in the Parade of Financial Mergers
description: AFTER Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover announced a $10.2 billion merger earlier this month, the new game on Wall Street became ''Who's next?'' Is Chase Manhattan about to buy Paine Webber, or will it snap up Prudential Securities?

title: Making the Pitch for Musicals
description: OVER the telephone, the Oakdale Theater's marketing manager, Jeff Provost, was reassuring a customer who thought she didn't want to see yet another ''Annie.''

title: Stamford's Clout, Another View
description: I just cannot let the article (''Stamford's Clout in Hartford,'' Feb. 9) go unchallenged. The record does not support its thesis that legislators from Fairfield County have been ''outsiders' or ''estranged'' at the State Capitol or, for that matter, standing short in leadership posts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITMAN, NELSON R.
description: REITMAN-Nelson R. February 17, 1997. You fought the good fight. Rest now. We love you. Your Family

title: Aging Victim of Spousal Abuse Finds Some Support
description: Eight years ago, Margaret K. packed her belongings in 40 boxes and placed them in storage, hoping that she could escape her abusive husband, leave their apartment in New York City, maybe return to Yugoslavia. But when she went back weeks later, her belongings were gone, she said. The boxes were filled with rags.

title: Taking Steps to Improve the Serving Staff
description: RESTAURATEURS know that the most brilliant kitchens and creative chefs can be sabotaged by disarray in the dining room. Yet the gap between continually improving food and often mediocre service remains a major concern on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGROOT, JOHN F., JR.
description: DeGROOT-John F., Jr., 38, of Wantagh, NY, on Feb. 21, 1997. A senior account manager for Rockwell Automation. Beloved husband of Lorraine, father of Thomas and Catherine, son of Mrs. John F. DeGroot, and brother of Deborah, Barbara, Mary Beth, Alison and David. Visiting at the Fairfield Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Sunday. Funeral Mass at St. Frances de Chantal Church, 1309 Wantagh Ave., Wantagh, 9:45 AM, Monday. Donations to St. Jutta Foundation, c/o Rev. M. Hegyi, Fordham University, Bronx, NY 10458-5198, or Mercy Cancer Care Unit, 1000 North Village Ave., Rockville Centre, NY 11570, appreciated.

title: Pitcher in the Rye
description: The following conversation took place between Harry Evans of Random House and J. D. Salinger. Mr. Evans was on his car phone in Manhattan when he reached the author at his New Hampshire home. The call was taped by a couple at Yaddo who heard it on a scanner that happened to pick up the cellular transmissions. The couple, who care passionately about the impact of publishing on literature, made the tape available to The New York Times.

title: Slopes Turn Gravity Into an Ally for Some
description: DURING ski season, Matt Bernaiche of Southington, a winsome 10-year-old, said he looks forward to Fridays, when he leaves school early to hit the slopes at Mount Southington. For Matt, whose cerebral palsy affects his muscle power and coordination, skiing may seem an unlikely pastime. He cannot walk unaided, and he uses an electric wheelchair to get around.

title: Beyond Pirogi In the East Village
description: CIRCA * $(rating: one star$)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, HELEN R.
description: STRAUSS-Helen R., 92, of Scottsdale, AZ. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of David and Susan. Loving grandmother of Dary Rogers. Cherished great-grandmother of Matthew and Zachary. Services will be private.

title: Hong Kong Fanfare For a Tall Ships Race
description: To celebrate its designation as the starting point for Sail Osaka '97, an international race of tall ships, Hong Kong is presenting several special events from March 22 to 28.

title: Can I Interest You in a Few Tenors?
description: WHAT The official Three Tenors sculpture, the latest addition to the merchandising monster that grew out of that ''once in a lifetime'' concert in Rome in 1990.

title: DEMOCRATS SHOW SOME FLEXIBILITY ON CAPITAL GAINS
description: After years of deriding any cuts in the capital-gains tax as a handout to country club Republicans, Democrats in Congress have softened their opposition and, in some cases, have come to support a reduction in the tax, increasing the likelihood of a compromise this year on the often bitter partisan dispute.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'POWER OF SUGGESTION'

title: Miami Loses a Big Man, but Can Knicks Win the Division?
description: The fadeaway just was not falling. Patrick Ewing could not make his signature shot, and the Knicks followed his lead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAYE, ROBERT
description: KAYE-Robert. A year ago today we said goodbye. We still love you and miss you. Love, Mom, Dad and Andy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, ROBERT WILLIAM
description: SARNOFF-Robert William. Age 78, of NYC, died Feb. 22, at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Beloved husband of Anna Moffo, brother of Edward and Thomas, father of Rosita Sarnoff, Serena Benenson and Claudia Parrot; grandfather of Adam, Toby and Felicia Jeanne Benenson. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, Feb. 26, at 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave and 65th St. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56th St, NYC 10019.

title: Widening Route 7, From Norwalk to New Milford
description: FOR some 30 years traffic congestion on Route 7, the north-south artery near Connecticut's western border, has been a motorist's nightmare.

title: The Trial That Wasn't
description: For years, James Earl Ray has asked to be tried for the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Last week, Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, echoed the call for a full trial. Mrs. King said it would be a catharsis for the nation and might shed light on unanswered questions. ''We call for the trial that never happened,'' she said. But not for Mr. Ray's reasons.

title: Jets to Begin Parcells Era With an Unusual Get-Together With Players
description: The transformation of the Jets under Bill Parcells and Bill Belichick was largely completed last week in every area except one: the players. And that, as everyone knows, is just a matter of time.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on the Bookend page on Feb. 9, ''The Road Warrior's Books on Tape,'' misstated the title of Barbara W. Tuchman's book about the collapse of the European population and society in the 14th century. It is ''A Distant Mirror.'' ''The Proud Tower'' was about Europe in the decades before World War I.

title: Axis Is Nexus For Film Makers
description: Matthew Galkin, 23 and a graduate of New York University's Film School, spent two years making a 30-minute short, ''Hello in There,'' a sendup of the classic horror film genre. He has spent the last year trying to get it some attention. First he sent it to the Sundance Film Festival in Colorado. ''Big film festivals are run like political machines,'' he said. ''It was put in a pile of 1,500 shorts they get a year.'' He heard nothing. Next he submitted it to the New Directors/New Films series at Lincoln Center. ''I haven't heard yet,'' he said.

title: Where It Pays Not to Teach
description: Federal regulators shocked health experts around the country last Monday by unveiling a plan under which they would pay hospitals in New York State not to train so many doctors. Hospitals that agree to reduce the number of doctors they churn out by 20 to 25 percent over the next 6 years will receive $400 million in special Medicare payments through the new program.

title: Average Russian Still Fears a Wider NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Burger, Burger, Burger: How a Fast Food Landmark Almost Vanished
description: ''This place is u-nique,'' said Joe Irorio, a building contractor, sitting elbow-to-elbow with other White Mana hamburger eaters. ''This is a part of Jersey City history. Dunkin' Donuts is not u-nique.''

title: The Magic of Clowns With a Serious Side
description: MYLES COHEN is one guidance counselor who knows how to handle class clowns. That's because Mr. Cohen, a counselor at Flood Middle School in Stratford, is a former clown himself.

title: Household Hints to Lighten Chores
description: MANY household and shop tasks are easier when you know a few tricks of the trade. The following is a collection of hints and tips to make workshop and household jobs easier to do.

title: On the Internet
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see Susan Spano's Frugal Traveler column ''Planning a Trip, Fingers Crossed'' (Jan. 19), because planning a trip is almost as much fun as taking it. In addition, the column is my favorite in the Travel section.

title: Drug Ties Taint 2 Mexican Governors
description: The Governor of the Mexican state that borders Arizona is collaborating with one of the world's most powerful drug traffickers, creating a haven for smugglers who transport vast quantities of narcotics into the United States, according to American officials and intelligence.

title: Ms. Schenkler-Buxbaum, Mr. Berliner
description: Lisa Schenkler-Buxbaum was married in New York last evening to Mitchell Berliner. Rabbi Camille Angel performed the ceremony at the Hudson Theater.

title: A Star System That Leaves No One in a Shadow
description: WHEN THE PAUL TAYLOR Dance Company went to India last month, it tried to expect the unexpected. The troupe brought along two understudies, who could step in if someone got sick. Likewise, in case the electricity failed during a performance, the dancers arranged to gather backstage by candlelight until power was restored. Yet none of these measures prepared the company for the acoustical glitch that it ran into at the Siri Fort Auditorium in New Delhi.

title: Who Won? Not These Guys.
description: The debate over whether Admiral Robert E. Peary or Frederick A. Cook was the first to reach the North Pole has been settled after 90 years, according to a book published last week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SABARSKY, SERGE
description: SABARSKY-Serge. A year has passed. You are still very much in our hearts and in our thoughts. We will never forget your wonderful humor. You will be a part of our family forever. We miss you. The Habers

title: County's Economy Emerging With Vigor
description: LIKE a bear rousing itself from long hibernation, Westchester appears finally to be shrugging off the effects of an extended slowdown and readying for more active days ahead. Until recently, the county was slow, along with the rest of the Northeast, to emerge from a recession that began early in the decade and seemed loath to go away.

title: Rewards and Penalties Vary in States' Welfare Programs
description: Exercising the vast discretion given to them under the new welfare law, many states are adopting stricter work requirements and shorter time limits than Congress envisioned for public assistance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGESS, LOUIS
description: BURGESS-Louis. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of The Brookdale University Hospital & Medical Center mourn the loss of Louis Burgess, Chairman of Community Board 17; a great humanitarian, a devoted friend of the hospital and a pillar in the community. Our sincere sympathy to his family. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Alvin I. Kahn, MD, Sr. Vice President Medical Affairs

title: Leonard Edelen, 59, a Runner
description: Leonard (Buddy) Edelen Jr., the first American marathoner in nearly four decades to set a world record, died of cancer in Tulsa, Okla., on Wednesday. He was 59.

title: Money, Lawyers and the First P.M.
description: A SINGLE composition is the centerpiece of a compact and dense exhibition entitled ''Among the Whores and Thieves: William Hogarth and 'The Beggar's Opera' '' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. The composition records a pivotal scene in an opera by John Gay written between 1728 and 1731. William Hogarth, visual chronicler of English life in the 18th century, painted five modest-sized versions of the scene. Two of them, plus a copy by another hand, are surrounded by prints, books and other paintings. The result is that the several paintings become more than a document of the opera. Hogarth's scheme has ramifications in several areas that encompass aspects of politics and culture.

title: A MOTHER'S NAME
description: I wish all women would keep their family names. Losing name identity when they marry is ridiculous. I'm trying to locate several women I knew years ago, and the first task is to find out what their married names are. They have ceased to exist as Mary Jones and are now Mary Unknown. A shame.

title: Probation Class Aims To Prevent Life in Crime
description: ON a recent afternoon, eight youths 14 to 21 on probation for offenses like assault, robbery or possession of drugs or weapons sat around a table at the county's Probation Department here and took part in an auction intended to keep them out of gangs.

title: New Mayor of Belgrade: A Serbian Chameleon
description: As insults thundered down from the podium in front of him, Zoran Djindjic sat impassively in the front row of the City Council chamber, waiting for the storm to blow over.

title: Finding the Comedy In Yesterday's Oddballs
description: IN 1886, A FELLOW NAMED Krafft-Ebing published a book called ''Psychopathia Sexualis.'' The volume contains a series of case studies of German people with minor and major sexual disorders. The book is rife with the assumptions of the day. Homosexuality is on an equal footing with people who eat the dead. Masturbation is the quickest route to epilepsy, nymphomania and not doing well in school. As Krafft-Ebing was a scientist, there is much measuring of heads and noting of irregular facial hair.

title: Meeting Pleases Steinbrenner and Fielder
description: George Steinbrenner is serious enough about pacifying the disgruntled Cecil Fielder, he canceled a trip to Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla., to see one of his horses, Acceptable, run today. Instead, he met with Fielder to discuss a possible contract extension.

title: Pulpit Proves He's Worthy Of the Derby
description: He comes with the churchy name of Pulpit, and he raced to stardom today in the third race of his career, winning the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park and confirming that he is indeed the leading candidate to win the Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NOMBURG, HARRY
description: NOMBURG-Harry. We love you and we all miss you. Yair and Family Vera

title: A Summer in Camelot
description: JACKIE BY JOSIE By Caroline Preston. 314 pp. New York: Scribner. $22.

title: Let the Renaissance Begin!
description: A new Federal Communications Commission regulation requires television stations, starting next fall, to broadcast at least three hours a week of educational children's programming. Reed Hundt, the F.C.C. Chairman, has spoken idealistically of a renaissance in educational TV, but one wonders: Is the industry ready to deliver? Judging by the new kids' programs offered recently at the convention of the National Association of Television Program Executives -- the premier marketplace for new shows -- it's certainly ready to deliver something. Here's a preview.

title: Istanbul
description: After John F. Kennedy Jr. married Carolyn Bessette in one of the major social events of 1996, the couple stole away for the requisite romantic honeymoon. But unlike socialites past, they did not choose Paris, a Caribbean island or a Mexican resort. Instead they flew to Istanbul, the great metropolis on the Bosporus, one of the world's most fascinating and romantic cities.

title: In Rural Southold, Preservationists as Developers
description: A Little over four years ago, Michael Croteau, a graphic designer, and his wife, Paula, left a one-bedroom Manhattan co-op to try life in this rural township on the North Fork.

title: Hot off the Flagpole
description: ''A lot of people don't have the cynicism you read about,'' says H. M. Franklin, explaining the bottomless demand for a product he helps provide: United States flags that have fluttered proudly over the U.S. Capitol for all of a minute. As Executive Officer of the Architect of the Capitol, Franklin oversees a team of six full-time workers who, year round, lower and raise the flag hundreds of times a day. The flags -- available in nylon or cotton, five sizes, with or without fringe -- are sent to constituents who request them through a congressman or senator. Customers pay not just for the flag (a top-end 8-foot-by-12-foot model costs $67), but for postage and $3.30 in flying costs. In 1995, 134,000 flags went out, and the requests keep coming.

title: When Mr. Coffee Says Hello
description: WHEN I started to use my computer and printer a couple of years ago, a pleasant, well-modulated male voice, apparently from the depths of the hard drive, would tell me when to renew the printer's paper supply, or that there was a paper jam, or that it was time to replace the ink cartridge, among other pithy remarks. Because I work alone, the occasional helpful comment initially offered a welcome break in the relative silence of my office, something akin to hearing Hal in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' But after a while, it began to sound like just another techno-gimmick.

title: Ridgely Limbocker And Charles Brode
description: Nicole Ridgely Limbocker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Derek L. Limbocker of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Edward Brode, a son of Mrs. Edward Hunter Brode of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Brode. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: MOMMY, WHAT'S A CLASSROOM?
description: It is nice to see the ranks of Yankee independence growing. Home schooling is an excellent alternative. If a child is doing fine in school, then great! But if he's not doing so fine, then take the bull by the horns and do something. You only get one go-round with your child.

title: Makeup Goes Multicultural
description: It was Monday morning at Industria, the photography studio in the West Village in Manhattan, but it felt more like a slumber party, because Bobbi Brown, a makeup artist and the author of ''Bobbi Brown Beauty'' (Harper Style), and her assistant, Cynde Watson, were working sponges and brushes over the faces of three of my friends. At fashion shows, I had noticed how Bobbi Brown -- using the same neat paint box of shades from her own line of cosmetics -- went about making up everyone from porcelain blondes to ebony goddesses. Brown agreed to let me watch her working, away from the madness of the runway, so we could talk about how various ethnic faces take to color.

title: Emerging Photographers Capture Images Radiating Power
description: Dark Images, Bright Prospects: The Survival of the Figure After World War II

title: Getting to Know You
description: When my husband changed jobs, I moved from Center City Philadelphia to suburban New Jersey. I went from living in a high-rise building to a garden-style apartment. I went from living in a city of 1.5 million people to a city of 20,000 people. I went from riding the bus or the elevated everywhere to walking everywhere (I didn't have a driver's license). I went from City Slicker to Suburban Matron.

title: No Show for the Showy: The Flower Show Is Canceled
description: After years of attending a spring flower show that became known more for commercialism than spectacular blooms, New Yorkers will have to go elsewhere this year. The Horticultural Society of New York is not going to have one -- at the Coliseum, or anywhere else within the five boroughs.

title: TRENT LOTT AND HIS FIERCE FRESHMEN
description: Some aspects of your article on Trent Lott were comforting, but I was horrified to read Senator Gordon Smith's comment that ''landlords should not be forced to rent to homosexuals.'' And Senator Sessions -- who used to think the K.K.K. was O.K. and called the N.A.A.C.P. ''un-American'' -- is not someone I would want teaching high-school history.

title: Jackson Leaves Torch in Texas
description: It would be easy to play Six Degrees of Separation with Jim Jackson, picking any subject related to the demise of the Dallas Mavericks and their once celebrated three J's.

title: Q. & A.
description: Replacing Windows In a Condo

title: Giving Terror the Silent Treatment
description: DO terrorists lose the power to terrorize when they fade from public view?

title: With Instant Landscaping, Beauty, Yes, but at a Price
description: A new house appeared down the road three years ago. It was one of those instant houses, the kind that arrives in big pieces on a couple of flatbed trucks and has curtains hanging in the windows in a matter of days.

title: Human Face Of the Garden Didn't Last
description: A FEW MONTHS AGO, I made a terrible mistake. I acknowledged the identity of the latest corporation to own Madison Square Garden.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE VERY BEST MEN. Four Who Dared: The Early Years

title: Anne Swanson, Charles Brown 3d
description: Margery Anne Swanson and Charles Gailey Brown 3d, lawyers in Washington, were married there yesterday. The Rev. William E. Wegener performed the ceremony at the Georgetown Lutheran Church.

title: Cooler Golf
description: To the Editor: The gentlemen who chose to play a round of golf in Penang (''Where Bad Golf Can Anger the Gods,'' Feb. 2) missed the mark by less than 200 miles. Because of the altitude and the favorable breezes, the golf course at Tanah Rata in the Cameron Highlands of Malaysia feels almost air-conditioned. The humidity is low and the undulating fairways and tricky greens provide a real challenge. The greens fee for 18 holes was about $8 a few years ago. If you stay at Ye Olde Smokehouse, you can walk across to the clubhouse in less than five minutes.

title: Carolyn Butts, Carl Schmalenberger
description: Carolyn Anne Butts, a press aide to the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth Messinger, was married on Friday to Carl Philip Schmalenberger, an artist at Volt Information Services, a production contractor for the Nynex Yellow Pages in Syosset, L.I. City Clerk Carlos Cuevas officiated in Ms. Messinger's office.

title: Du Pont Shuts the Door on Its Private Offices
description: WHEN Samuel L. Waltz Jr. landed a job editing a management publication for E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in 1977 he had an office that some chief executives might envy.

title: THE LITTLE RUBBER DRESS
description: While reading Lynn Hirschberg's article ''The Little Rubber Dress, Among Others'' (Feb. 2), on the designer Helmut Lang, I had a revelation.

title: 'Betrayal Trauma'
description: To the Editor:

title: The State of Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, delivered his annual State of the Borough speech Wednesday. While emphasizing the positive -- such as the strongest economic growth in downtown Brooklyn in 50 years -- Mr. Golden's review also noted several stalled initiatives and a handful of massive, unresolved projects that have the potential to significantly brighten or significantly mar the borough's future.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an essay on Jan. 12 about crime books set in Edinburgh referred incorrectly to a comment by Henry James about a work by William Roughead. A reader's letter received Jan. 23 points out that James died in 1916, before the appearance of Roughead's 1924 book, ''The Fatal Countess and Other Studies.'' James expressed his admiration of Roughead in an exchange of letters between 1913 and 1915. (This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.)

title: Rallying to Save a Legacy
description: When the late Evelina Lopez Antonetty saw desolation and emptiness replace a building that was once home to a Head Start Program where eager young scholars recited the alphabet, she gathered a small group and moved in to guard the edifice from vandals and thieves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, CHARLES GORDON
description: POST-Charles Gordon, February 18, age 95, in Poughkeepsie, New York. Retired Political Science Dept. Chairman at Vassar College. Survived by wife, Emily Dohme Post, daughters Claudia Hannah of Silver Spring, MD, Regan Peppard of Kinnelon, NJ, Antonia Fiske of Salinas, CA., Olivia Fiske of Newton, MA., and 12 grandchildren.

title: Inspirational Respiration
description: STUCK in traffic beneath the rivers, inhaling exhaust, drivers often feel as if the air in the city's vehicular tunnels has been stagnating in there for years, possibly aspirated by millions over the decades.

title: Have Mafia Movies Been Done to Death?
description: TWO MEN ARE DISCUSSING murder. They are alone in a Cadillac but not really alone: hanging over them is the spirit of a movie genre that has been done nearly to death.

title: Rituals of Identity
description: It's the first day of summer, and skinny children with jet black hair tumble down a sand dune; wearing a tattered lace dress, with a bouquet and a grinning skull mask, a little girl celebrates her first Communion; a dark-skinned boy squints mischievously, his face buried in the soft wings of a white chicken; barefoot in the Sonoran Desert, a boy balances on a cheap mountain bike while a ragged princess -- his sister? -- stands by his side. Because their lives so vividly embody the notions that preoccupy the Mexican photographer Graciela Iturbide -- the tensions between the traditional culture of Mexican villages and Northern modernity; the resilience, adaptability and capacity for happiness of Mexican communities bound by family, work and seasonal customs; the wonder and strength of Mexico's syncretic religious rituals -- images of children abound in her IMAGES OF THE SPIRIT (Aperture, $40). In these black-and-white photographs, taken over the last two decades and presented in her first major publication in the United States, still lifes are rare. Indeed, whether depicting her subjects from afar, lost in Mexico's dramatic landscapes -- like the two small human figures, one of them on crutches, walking toward an ancient temple in ''Calzada de los Muertos'' (''Pathway of the Dead'') -- or from up close (like the young woman smiling softly as she breast-feeds her baby in a hammock), Ms. Iturbide seems to favor finding beauty in the various forms of human life. Informed by the notions that haunt her, Ms. Iturbide's definition of beauty in Mexican communities is complex -- in turn violent, spiritual, joyous, tense or tender -- and it always has to do with dignity, the dignity of a ritual performed, a bond asserted, an identity worn with pride. Christine Schwartz Hartley

description: An Original Man

description: THE FRIENDS OF FREELAND By Brad Leithauser. 508 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Paradise Moves Indoors For Sporting Enthusiast
description: Anglers and hunters should find surcease from cabin fever at the 20th World Fishing & Outdoor Exposition, which opens Wednesday at the Rockland Community College Field House in Suffern, N.Y.

title: Mobile Homes Go Upscale: One Pet Per Plot, Please
description: APPARENTLY James Carville has never been to Hunter Ridge.

title: What News on the Rialto? A Theater Is Saved
description: After half a year of fighting to save their 74-year-old-movie theater, the Rialto, from being converted into stores, Westfield residents are feeling more optimistic that the 980-seat downtown landmark will not go dark.

description: Rosewood

On the Run From Ideas

title: The Mexican Drug Scandal
description: The arrest on drug trafficking charges of the general who led Mexico's antinarcotics program is shocking evidence of how difficult it will be to stem the flow of drugs from abroad. Just two months ago America's top drug fighter, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, praised his newly appointed Mexican counterpart, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, as a man of ''unquestioned integrity.'' Now General Gutierrez stands accused of accepting bribes from and collaborating with leading Mexican drug traffickers. The general's reputation for integrity stemmed from his crackdowns on the drug trade while a regional commander. Now he is suspected of ignoring his favored traffickers and moving only against their competitors.

title: Mrs. Harriman Broke Down the Barriers to Women in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shaggy Dog Story For the Gurney Set
description: AS the oldest established chronicler of the archaic ways and considerable means of the WASP set, A. R. Gurney has an assured place in the contemporary American theater. But having evaded the possibilities for depth in his serio-comic pursuits of the old boy-dining room-cocktail hour culture, Mr. Gurney has gone on to master the craft of the gimmick.

title: Regardless of Counsel, Clinton's Woes Go On
description: AS Kenneth W. Starr wavered between the Whitewater independent counsel's office and a university campus in Malibu last week, a new scandal was emerging that has compelled even some Democrats to call for yet another special prosecutor.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about New Jersey's oversight of the Prudential Insurance Company misstated the method the state used in reviewing records. In the multistate investigation, led by New Jersey, regulators focused on analyzing computer files but did not directly examine paper files. In its final report, however, the multistate task force noted that New Jersey regulators had independently reviewed 662 paper files.

title: Second Stage to Get a New Stage, More Room for Actors, and Subscribers
description: The Second Stage Theater is small (108 seats), nonprofit and packs a big wallop. In its 18 seasons, including 13 at its current location above the Promenade Theater on Broadway near 76th Street, it has won 20 Obie awards, featured actors like Dianne Wiest, Betty Buckley and Nathan Lane and showcased new works from playwrights like Tina Howe, Lanford Wilson and David Henry Hwang.

title: If Meter Is Your Metier . . .
description: Fancy yourself a Bayside bard? Does a borough so diverse inspire its residents to verse?

title: Recognizing Achievements
description: SIX Westchester residents were honored Friday night with Excellence in Enterprise awards. The awards, timed to coincide with Black History Month, recognized the achievements of blacks who might otherwise be unsung heroes in the business and professional world.

title: A MOTHER'S NAME
description: My hackles rise every time a pregnant friend tells me that her baby-to-be will carry its father's surname (Lives: ''A Mother's Name,'' by Jenny McPhee, Feb. 2). ''It's nonnegotiable,'' they often say. ''You'd understand if you had a kid.'' No, I wouldn't, and I'm tempted to get pregnant just to prove the point. Thanks to McPhee, I don't have to.

title: Snags in Parts Delivery Keep Toyotas Off Road
description: FOR Kenneth Henry, the good news and the bad news were the same: his stolen car had been recovered in New York City.

title: The Communist Dynasty Had Its Run. Now What?
description: WHEN Deng Xiaoping visited the United States in 1979, the actress Shirley MacLaine told him how impressed she had been on a visit to China during the Cultural Revolution, when Mr. Deng and countless others had been forced to toil in remote areas and ''learn from the peasants.'' The actress said she had been particularly moved by a scholar working in a field, who had described how much more fulfilling it was to grow tomatoes than to work in a university.

title: For Beth Israel, a New Automated Lab
description: Lasers were among the construction tools for a revamped laboratory space spanning two side-by-side buildings at Beth Israel Medical Center. The new facility features a futuristic blood-testing laboratory with a robotic assembly-line operation.

title: China's Rulers Face Key Test: Power of Army
description: On the seventh day after he took up the title of Commander in Chief of China's armed forces in November 1989, President Jiang Zemin went to the far western province of Xinjiang to inspect a frigid frontier post. He demanded to know why the soldiers were sleeping with only one blanket. ''Aren't they cold at night?'' he asked.

title: The Brigands of the Clams
description: THE water around the eastern edges of Jamaica Bay looked like black tea early Thursday. Nothing could be seen except the outline of an old whitewall tire. ''Looky there,'' said Carl Kirschner, a trapper and fisherman who lives on the banks near Hook Creek. ''This time of year, you ought to be able to see clear to the bottom, but you can't see nothing. The whole dang thing's poisoned.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SANE, JOHN WESLEY
description: De SANE-John Wesley, 68, of Englewood, died Friday at Englewood Hospital. He was a resident of Englewood for over 40 years. He was born in Bamburg, SC. Received his master's degree from Columbia University. A member of Community Baptist Church, 224 1st Street, Englewood, NJ. An author/educator and black history scholar. He is survived by his lovely daughter, Nicole De Sane of Englewood; one son, John De Sane, Jr., of Queens, NY; one brother, James De Sane of Bronx, NY; a host of nieces, nephews and friends. Funeral service Tuesday, February 25, 10 AM, at the church. Viewing Monday, 6-8 PM, at the church. Interment Fairlawn Memorial Cemetery, Fairlawn, NJ.

title: GOOD NEWS
description: 1. As an antidote to iffy journalistic practices, Court TV now celebrates positive ethics with an annual Integrity Day. 2. It all started during the O. J. Simpson criminal trial. The cable network inadvertently televised the image of an alternate juror, and a producer admitted the error to Judge Lance Ito, who went ballistic. 3. Steven Brill, Court TV's C.E.O., declared that ''as a company we should mark that day . . . forever.'' 4. The 1997 winner of $5,000: Emily Hiller, a reporter for a legal newspaper owned by Brill. She mistakenly wrote that an Atlanta lawyer pleaded guilty to 3 counts in a 25-count indictment. As she admitted, it was really 2 counts in a 24-count indictment. 5. Was the defense impressed? Donald F. Samuel, the defendant's lawyer, says the correction ''didn't make any difference to me.''

title: A Scorecard Doesn't Help In the Money-Fund Game
description: WHEN Strong Capital Management bailed out three of its money market funds early this month, investors had every right to be surprised.

description: Life Itself

title: Onward and Downward
description: GRAVITY, the pull of it, does not at first seem like much of a subject to celebrate, especially if the person doing the celebrating is as close to his 50th birthday as this one is. That subtle and not-so-subtle tug downward toward earth becomes clearer with each aging year, from the heavy way I get out of bed in the morning to the heavy way, 16 gravity-fighting hours later, I fall exhausted back in. Though the physics are incomprehensible to me, I understand in each joint, each bone, each muscle, that the planet does indeed exert a force on every object resting on its surface, and to wish yourself permanently free of this force is to ask for a dispensation none can grant.

description: CENTURIES AGO, IN the fabled garden cities of ancient Persia, the world's greatest books appeared. They were usually small, they were often costly beyond reckoning, and they always came in editions of one.

title: Four Girls Abducted, Raped, Murdered. A Country on Trial.
description: Seated at the dining-room table of his house in the Belgian town of Hasselt, Paul Marchal, a 42-year-old school teacher of slight build with a carefully manicured beard and wire-rimmed glasses, seems an unlikely revolutionary. For nearly two decades he has taught reading, writing, math and history to disabled children in this quiet Flemish-speaking community in Limburg, a rural province in eastern Belgium best known for its fresh air and pungent cheeses. But since August 1995, Marchal has commanded the attention of Belgium's public and, increasingly, its politicians. His declarations regularly make headlines in the national press and become the substance of debate in Parliament. He lectures the Prime Minister in public and meets with him in private. Twice now, Marchal has been called to court by Albert II, the King of Belgium. Still, Marchal prefers teaching.

title: SCIENTIST REPORTS FIRST CLONING EVER OF ADULT MAMMAL
description: In a feat that may be the one bit of genetic engineering that has been anticipated and dreaded more than any other, researchers in Britain are reporting that they have cloned an adult mammal for the first time.

description: EUPHORIA over the winter return of bald eagles to the Hudson Valley is being dampened by the birds' failure to reproduce.
