description: ASYLUM

title: Breasts as More Than Decoration
description: VIRGINIA MOORE has a sense of humor, and she is not afraid to use it. ''A lot of people think breasts are just decorative pieces attached to a woman's body,'' she said. ''But they're functional; they're there for a reason. We tell people, human milk is what you should give human babies.''

title: A Short Respite For Spring Skirts
description: Skirts appeared to be on the endangered fashion list this winter, as the popularity of pants was soaring for women of all ages. The very existence of the skirt seemed threatened, until last week's brief appearance of springlike weather showed that the short skirt is alive and well. Highlighting a long stretch of legs in light-colored stockings, the skirt can occasionally be a welcome relief from a uniform of pants.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: A new latitude
description: Those of us who work in the fashion business speak what might be called a dialect, and, like all dialects, it has its peculiarities, its idiomatic expressions that say as much about the people who use them as they do about the things they describe. Fashion models, appropriately enough, are referred to as ''girls'' -- as if youth and beauty went hand in hand, which, experience tells us, is not always the case. Those who aren't models come under the category of ''real women'' -- as if models were figments of our imaginations, which in some respects they are. Celebrities are ''personalities'' -- as if lawyers and housewives and other women without a public profile were somehow lacking in identity, which of course they are not.

title: MOMMY, WHAT'S A CLASSROOM?
description: While it seems unfortunate that Peter Kowalke, one of the young people profiled in Bill Roorbach's article ''Mommy, What's a Classroom?'' (Feb. 2), can't play high-school football (albeit with a mediocre team), he has learned an important lesson: there are some disadvantages inherent in bypassing the traditional secondary-education system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACOFF, HAROLD
description: LACOFF-Harold. Suddenly on Feb. 20, 1997, while visiting in Houston, TX. Husband of Clara, dear father of Nathan, Andrew, daughter-in-law Regina. Proud grandfather of Jason and Jacqueline. Brother of Howard, of Delray Beach, FL. Funeral Sunday, February 23 at Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd., at 10:30 AM. Shiva, 136-55 71st Rd.

title: Cornwall in the Winter
description: WE were the only people who got off the train at Liskeard. As the conductor helped tumble duffel bags into the January rain, I sensed something odd: no people, no sounds. We were in the bottom of a narrow stone pit. ''Where's the station?'' I called through what proved to be a force 9 gale.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Fashions of The Times

title: Furthering the Cause of 'New Zionism'
description: AS executive vice president of the American Society for Technion the last 12 years, Melvyn Bloom has the job of overseeing efforts to raise money on behalf of Technion, formally known as the Israel Institute of Technology.

title: Coining a Catchword
description: To the Editor:

title: Going to Extremes
description: Yesterday morning soaked the city with record-breaking warmth. But by early afternoon, storm clouds moved in, and their thunderbolts sent the giddy coatless masses back indoors. And winter, that persistent scoundrel, was expected to reappear this morning, with temperatures back in the 30's.

title: He Crossed Color Barrier, But In Another's Shadow
description: Larry Doby remembers clearly his first day in the major leagues, that day 50 years ago when he broke the color barrier in the American League. It was 11 weeks after Jackie Robinson had played his first game for the Brooklyn Dodgers in the National League. Doby remembers the excitement of that day when he became only the second black player in the major leagues -- he had hardly slept in four nights leading up to it -- and he remembers the dismay.

title: Help Getting a Mortgage
description: THE problem that had stopped Pamela Henry from buying her apartment was her bankruptcy five years ago.. She was hesitant to talk about the circumstances -- they were still too painful -- but she wanted to give a boost to the privately run nonprofit group that helped her take on the banking bureaucracy and, finally, procure a mortgage.

title: Alzheimer's Fight in Her Mother's Name
description: YASMIN AGA KHAN, who spent many summers on the East End, has devoted herself to the cure of the disease that claimed her mother, the actress Rita Hayworth. The Rita Hayworth Galas have raised $16 million for Alzheimer's research. Public awareness of Alzheimer's has increased to where there are now 221 chapters of the Alzheimer's Association and 2,000 support groups in the 50 states. (The Long Island chapter can be reached at 516-289-6335). Ms. Khan's father, Aly Aga Khan, was probably more famous as a European playboy than as spiritual leader of 15 million Ismaili Muslims. Ms. Khannow divides her time between New York and Utah where she has what she describes as a ''New Age marriage.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PATT, JESSICA EVE
description: PATT-Jessica Eve. Feb. 23, 1967-Aug. 4, 1993. On your 30th birthday. Love forever, Mom

title: The Islamist Who Runs Turkey, Delicately
description: With not a single security guard visible, could this ugly concrete building be the official residence of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, the first Islamist to lead modern Turkey? Assured by my driver that it was, I approached, rang a bell and was admitted. Inside the door I literally bumped into Erbakan as he emerged from a small elevator. We bent down to remove our shoes together.

title: Foggy Bottom Bids for Tourists
description: With all the monuments, museums and official buildings to see in Washington, the State Department has rarely rated as a tourist destination.

title: Books From The Times
description: Since May 1992, Lois Smith Brady has crashed -- her own word -- weddings for The New York Times. The results, accompanied by Edward Keating's photographs, have appeared regularly in Ms. Brady's column, Vows, in The Times on Sundays. Now she has collected some 80 favorites in VOWS: Weddings of the Nineties From The New York Times (Morrow, $23). Of weddings in the 90's Ms. Brady notes: ''Almost anything is possible and permissible these days. I've watched ceremonies in hayfields, deep forests, ski lodges and cathedrals; one in the middle of a city street; and another on a beach with barefoot bridesmaids.'' Fashions in weddings may come and go, but Ms. Brady reports a factor that has remained constant for decades: in ceremonies freelanced for the occasion by the marriagees, the poet most quoted is still Kahlil Gibran.

title: Finding Relief in the Fat Old Men of Summer
description: Those distant, shuffling footsteps are a comforting sound. From their sun-stroked day camps, the fat old men are marching back into our daydreams. David Wells (one hopes he can throw it as well as he slings it) has offered to stop drinking to reduce his gout and help the Yankees win the pennant again. What a gamer he is, willing to sacrifice for us. And why does this seem so much more endearing than the sobs of Oksana Baiul, a teen-ager who drank too much in the flush of fame and drove off the road?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINSCHMIDT, HANS J.
description: KLEINSCHMIDT-Hans J., on February 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Peter, Trude, Catherine, and Nina. Grandfather of Justin, Samuel, Benjamin, and Sarah. Survivor of the Nazi Holocaust. Service Sunday 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Toward a Visible Woman
description: Several features that appeared in Jane Shore's two previous volumes of poetry, ''The Minute Hand'' and ''Eye Level,'' also distinguish her latest one: a concern with the family and with Jewish traditions; a fondness for the miniature and the fairy tale as metaphors; an indebtedness to Elizabeth Bishop, to whom she dedicates a new poem called ''The Wrong End of the Telescope.'' But in a departure from Ms. Shore's earlier lyrics, MUSIC MINUS ONE (Picador USA, $20) is resolutely autobiographical, reaching from her 1950's New Jersey childhood through her adolescence and sexual awakening to her acknowledgment of her maturity, occasioned by her daughter's birth and her parents' deaths. This impressive sequence (which is a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle prize in poetry) imparts a sense of deepening consciousness, of shifts in perspective over time. Thus, in the beginning, we see Ms. Shore as a child, moved by Anne Frank's diary to invent a game called ''washing the streets of Holland,'' and then, in the book's final section, we find a reprise and variation: the grown woman, overcome by her visit to the Holocaust Museum, ''descending floor by floor / year by year, into history.'' Similarly, we encounter the young girl as she watches her father shave and, later, the adult opening her father's safe after his death with the combination he has taught her. In ''The Visible Woman,'' the book's last and possibly its most moving poem, Ms. Shore describes her mother's physical diminution and terminal illness as she helps her daughter to assemble a plastic model of the female body. These 31 poems all work together in a similar fashion, forming a seamless arc of personal history, both artful and accessible. Gardner McFall

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ARTS AND TECHNOLOGY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARO, CLIFFORD J.
description: KARO-Clifford J. Beloved husband of Ann. Devoted father of Jean and Daniel. Beloved brother of Alan and adored uncle. Services Monday, 10:00 A.M., at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Officer Kills Cook in a Raid On a Social Club in Queens
description: A cook at a social club in Queens was killed by the police early yesterday when he struggled with officers during a vice squad raid and then brandished a foot-long knife, the police said. He was shot once in the chest by a detective, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADDAD, BRUCE ERNEST
description: HADDAD-Bruce Ernest, 43, senior vice president-international operations for the GTE Corp and his wife, Dorothy Summers Haddad, in an airplane crash February 19 near Guatemala City airport in Guatemala. The couple, who were traveling on business, perished when the chartered jet, carrying a crew of three, crashed during its approach to the airport. The members of the crew also died. Bruce E. Haddad was a 20-year veteran of GTE, the telecommunications company, and was named senior vice president-international operations in January 1997. Prior to that appointment, he served in several key international and corporate positions, including pesident of CANTV, the Venezuelan telephone company. He was born in Princeton, NJ on October 20, 1953. His family later moved to Ormond Beach, Florida where he met his future wife at Seabreeze High School in Daytona Beach. The couple was married in 1975, the same year both graduated from Florida State University. Dorothy Summers Haddad was born in Pensacola, Florida; the family later moved to Daytona Beach. ''Bruce was not only one of the best businessmen I've ever had the pleasure to work with, but he and Dorothy also were great friends and important members of the GTE family,'' said GTE Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Charles R. Lee. ''Bruce brought extraordinary energy, intellect and creativity to all the posts he held.'' Bruce E. Haddad is survived by his parents, the Rev. Ernest and Miriam Haddad, Ormond Beach, FL; two brothers, Kenneth Haddad, St. Petersburg, FL and David Haddad, Winter Park, FL; a sister, Judith Sharpe, Ormond Beach; two nephews and three nieces. Dorothy Summers Haddad is survived by her mother, Elaine Rogers, New Smyrna Beach, FL; her father, Robert Summers, DELand, FL; a sister, Susan Summers Persis, Ormond Beach; a nephew, Alexander Clark Cone II, West Palm Beach, FL; a half-sister, Kim Summers, Sarasota, FL and a half-brother, Dray Summers, DE Land. A memorial service is scheduled for today, 4 pm, at the Ormond Beach Presbyterian Church. In lieu of other remembrances, donations may be made to the Bruce Ernest and Dorothy Summers Haddad Scholarship Fund, Seabreeze High School, 2700 North Oleander Avenue, Daytona Beach, FL 32118.

title: Caught in the Net
description: AS FRANCESCA By Martha Baer. 274 pp. New York: Broadway Books. $22.50.

title: Entering the Met Through a Side Door
description: THERE ARE BASICALLY TWO modes of entry into the Metropolitan Opera for emerging singers. One is the traditional Met debut in a major role, an exciting, high-pressure and risky rite of passage. Then there is the route taken by Christopher Schaldenbrand.

title: Board Would Trump Trump With a Historic District
description: When Michael Owen Gotkin read last month that Donald J. Trump planned to turn the once-glamorous St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South into luxury condominiums and was considering sheathing the pre-World War II masonry building in one of his signature glitzy bronze and glass facades, Mr. Gotkin's first reaction was surprise, followed by shock, followed by anger.

title: Quiet Spinoffs Talk the Loudest in Returns
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES is a spinoff that investors remember. The huge company, which makes telecommunications equipment, was severed from AT&T last year and instantly became a star.

title: From a Partnership of 'Elements' to a Show of Playfulness
description: ONCE a year, the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson departs from its schedule of group shows to focus on two Westchester artists. The spotlight is now on the painters Diane Brawarsky and Linda Nisselson, and in this review it encompasses an anthology of visual jokes -- the anthology of visual jokes hanging in the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle.

title: Dismissed Officer to Tell Story His Way
description: On his first full day as a former police officer, Francis X. Livoti ''kissed a beautiful girl,'' looked forward to his afternoon kick-boxing workout and began a whirlwind campaign to convince the world that he has been unfairly portrayed as a symbol of police brutality.

title: Pettitte's Relationship With God Comes First
description: When the persistent pain in Andy Pettitte's valuable left elbow was so excruciating, when he wondered if he had thrown his last pitch as a Yankee, when he tortured himself fretting about how he would support his family, the pitcher would retreat to a quiet place and seek solace by reading the Bible.

title: The Rehabilitation of Morning in America
description: NOTHING has so defined the American mood over the last 20 years as economic pessimism. From nearly every quarter came the message that prosperity was in decline and young people would have to adjust to a lower standard of living than their parents'. But now, all of a sudden, the last couple of decades don't look so bad. Recent economic history is being revised. And in the new version, Americans turn out to have been more prosperous than they realized. The children can relax.

title: Entrepreneurial Training for Ex-Employees
description: VITO SALVATORE has worked for large corporations ever since he graduated from Iona College with a degree in business administration 10 years ago. First for KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and most recently at Ciba's corporate offices in Ardsley as an accounting systems specialist.

title: TRENT LOTT AND HIS FIERCE FRESHMEN
description: I certainly agreed with your headline, alongside the four senators on the cover of the Magazine, which read, ''They Don't Look Fierce.'' Indeed, at first glance, I thought you were running an ad for the Hair Club for Men.

title: Accounting for Taste
description: The secret of how to stay thin is finally out. All these years it's been chalked up to will power, the ability to walk away from triple chocolate ice cream. But according to new reports presented last week at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the secret is in the tongue.

title: Regional Indian Dishes in Mount Kisco
description: IT was with happy anticipation that four years ago this village welcomed this charming little Indian restaurant. Among its high points, the Taj offers a handful of regional dishes not found elsewhere in the area, specialties of southern India -- in particular, Goa. In addition, the extensive menu carries a full complement of familiar items available in most Indian restaurants. Through all these years service has improved, and prices have held steady.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGER, DR. STUART M.
description: BERGER-Dr. Stuart M. In loving remembrance. We miss you. Your father and friends

title: DOG FIGHT
description: ''This law is a clear vendetta by the Federal Government,'' gripes Richard Avanzino (pictured left), president of the San Francisco Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Strong words, especially given that Avanzino is talking about a National Park Service ordinance that (brace yourselves, freedom lovers) prohibits unleashed dog-walking on a two-mile stretch of beach in the Golden Gate Recreational Area. The new enforcement is designed to prevent rollicking mutts from disturbing the winter habitat of a threatened shore bird, the Western Snowy Plover. It's the sort of environmental measure that Bay Area urbanites tend to cheer when applied to loggers in the Pacific Northwest -- remember the spotted owl? -- but Avanzino say this measure is cruel and unnecessary. (Arthur Feinstein, a local Audubon Society official, counters that the dog lovers are being ''a little selfish.'') Now Avanzino and ''10,000'' compatriots are threatening a mass off-leash dog walk unless the law is erased. ''We've always been a silent group, but we bark loud,'' he says. ''And if provoked, we even bite.''

title: Torre Faces Tough Choices
description: Questions about whether Wade Boggs or Charlie Hayes will start at third base for the Yankees cause the affable Joe Torre to shake his head, rub his face and respond in a diplomatic manner. The manager does not have to make a final determination for at least another month, but he is already fretting over what he said ''probably will be'' the most difficult decision of his career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUINAN, PATRICIA DAVIDSON
description: GUINAN-Patricia Davidson. February 22, 1997. 45 years of dedication to the Hearst Corporation. Devoted mother of Pamela Motley and Patricia Rushin. Loving grandmother of Christopher Rushin and Mariah Motley. Funeral service at Coster Funeral Home, Cutchogue, on Tuesday, February 25, at 11 AM. Any memorial contributions to Eastern LI Hospital, Greenport NY will be appreciated.

title: Though Poles Apart, Clinton And Lott 'Hear Each Other'
description: One is a punctilious neatnik who re-irons his newly starched shirts, runs a tight meeting and likes nothing better than a well-done deal. The other pays little attention to appearances and cannot resist an intellectual digression.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Chubb Expected To Sell Life Unit And Real Estate
description: Taking steps to concentrate on its central property and casualty insurance business, the Chubb Corporation is expected to announce in the next few days the sale of its life insurance business and the biggest portion of its commercial and residential real estate unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JANET HAYES
description: WALKER-Janet Hayes. Founder and producing director of the York Theatre Company, died February 20, 1997 after a long and valiant battle with cancer. Wife of Charles Dodsley Walker, mother of Peter Hayes Walker and Susan Walker Wyss, grandmother of Natalie Starr Wyss, Branford Hayes Walker and Camille Walker Wyss. Sister of Dr. E. Morris Hayes and Marian Hayes Miller. She was born in Shanghai, China in 1925 of missionary parents, and recieved a Master's degree in music from the New England Conservatory and a Master's degree in theatre from Hunter College. As a singer, she was an active recitalist, giving concerts in Europe and the U.S. Later she appeared as a singing actress, in a career which included roles in many Broadway shows and in regional theatres. In 1969 she founded the York Theatre Company, which became known particularly for its outstanding revivals of musicals, generating numerous awards both for the theatre and for Janet. Memorial services will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, Connecticut at 1 P.M., on Tuesday, February 25, and at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, at 1 PM on Thursday, February 27. A celebration of Janet's life in the arts will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the York Theatre Co., Inc., 619 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10019, where a memorial fund is being created in her honor.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Jan. 23, about legislative proposals to allow motorists to buy no-frills, no-fault auto insurance, misstated the position of the Consumer Federation of America on one such auto choice proposal before Congress. The federation does not support it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIKE, RAYMOND J.
description: FIKE-Raymond J. On February 22, 1997. Beloved brother of Rosemary Fike and the late Isabelle Ackerman. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), New York City, Monday 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Teacher Worries About Evaluation And Pupil's Future
description: Ted Kesler paced anxiously outside the tiny office with the gray metal door.

title: Giuliani Asks for Calm and Caution
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appealed last night to people to not draw any conclusions from the shooting, particularly as to whether terrorism was involved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAFF, JULIUS G. (''BUDDY'')
description: STAFF-Julius G. (''Buddy''). My dear friend, I will always miss you. Ruthie

title: Police Actions In Club Killing Ignite Protests
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the police detective who fatally shot a cook during a raid at a social club in Queens early Saturday had acted properly, while lawyers for the man's family accused the police of having overreacted.

title: AIDS Campaign Dropped as Religion and Advertising Clash
description: The six-word billboard copy was reviewed and debated. Kenneth Cole, the footwear designer and marketer, favored a bold, urgent plea to promote AIDS research. He did not want to give onlookers pause. He wanted to jolt them. So the final slogan read: ''Prayer Won't Cure AIDS. Research Will.''

title: Mets Look at Wilson's Son And See a Talented Enigma
description: Preston Wilson is a 22-year-old minor league outfielder with precious little chance to be on the Mets' opening day roster. But that does not mean that the son of Mookie Wilson -- and the man who inherited Darryl Strawberry's number, 18, -- is not a precious commodity in the eyes of his father's former team.

title: A big brouhaha erupts when Advertising Age takes a few shots at a Miller Lite campaign.
description: A BIG beer campaign that is stirring contentious debate has caused a rift between a hot creative agency and a leading trade publication.

title: Radcliffe Women, Once Docile, Prod Harvard Sharply on Equality of Sexes
description: The men at Harvard have always been educated to lead the world. Peggy Schmertzler recalls a different set of expectations for her and her classmates at Harvard's neighbor, Radcliffe, in the 1950's.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLUHR, BENJAMIN S.
description: FLUHR-Benjamin S. My late, great father gone 21 years today, missed and loved forever! Ellen

title: Leader Once Purged by Deng Is Barred From His Funeral
description: In death, there is forgiveness. At least that is what Zhao Ziyang, the man who could have been the leader of China today, may have hoped when he apparently petitioned President Jiang Zemin for permission to attend the memorial service for Deng Xiaoping.

title: A Window Into Schubert's Emotional Life
description: Schubert is singular among prodigies. Mozart, Mendelssohn and Saint-Saens are teen-age perfection in search of a soul: the physical and mental agility already there; arriving later, usually much later, a flexing of the spirit. Schubert, living this life cycle backward, begins with a mature soul and flails for control of it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion Page on Tuesday about the costume designer Arienne Phillips misstated the name of an organization that purchased an advertisement in Daily Variety protesting the film ''The People vs. Larry Flynt.'' It was Public Citizen, not the Hollywood Women's Political Committee.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about China's economic prospects after Deng Xiaoping's death misspelled the surname of the president of the U.S.-China Business Council. He is Robert A. Kapp, not Knapp.

title: Corrections
description: The Media column in Business Day on Feb. 3, about donations to news organizations from charitable foundations, referred incorrectly to the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit group that provides information to news organizations. It is not a subsidiary of the Joyce Foundation.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A King With Raw Energy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, KATE
description: GOODMAN-Kate. On February 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel. Devoted mother of Jacob and Howard Michael. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Robert. Funeral today, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Fort Worth Publisher Trying to Buy Paper
description: Richard L. Connor, who was dismissed as publisher of The Fort Worth Star-Telegram earlier this month after unsuccessfully negotiating to keep his job, said today he was trying to form a group to buy the newspaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: BERNSTEIN - William. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving children Sue, John, David and Lynn, Susanne, Nancy and Chris, and niece Jerri. Cherished grandfather of ten and great-grandfather of two. Services Tuesday, 2 PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Tilles Center of Performing Arts, C.W. Post Campus, Greenvale, NY 11548-0570 would be appreciated.

title: A Steamroller Amid the Gentry
description: Their landmark victory came way back in 1993 at Georgia Tech, untelevised and unnoticed inasmuch as they had already lost to Georgia State. Their big victory this year was over Stanford, but, wouldn't you know, it was a Christmas holiday thing. In Alaska. Tiny wonder then that at the same time the College of Charleston basketball team has slithered into the national consciousness for the first time in its cobblestoned history, it has been out-visibled not just by two teams from its own state, South Carolina and Clemson, reaching the top 10, but also by the trouble at the Citadel in its own city.

title: Chef Is Injured In a Shooting
description: The chef at Lundy's restaurant in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, was shot yesterday morning, apparently in a robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Gatti Fighting His Way Off the Late, Late Show
description: The excitement that he brought to his rematch with Tracy Harris Patterson early today, and the good condition of his face following his 12-round unanimous decision to retain the International Boxing Federation junior lightweight championship, indicated one thing to Arturo Gatti: he is ready for prime time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, REV. RICHARD C.
description: JOYCE-Rev. Richard C., 79. Beloved brother of Thomas and Francis. Died February 22. Mass Monday, 7:30 PM and Tuesday 10:30 AM, St. Mary's Church, Montgomery, NY. Friends may call at the Gridley-Horan Funeral Home, 39 Orchard St., Walden, NY, Monday, 2-4 PM. Burial will be in St. Mary's Cemetery, Montgomery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANKER, ALBERT
description: SHANKER-Albert, 68, President of the American Federation of Teachers, 1974-Present; President of the United Federation of Teachers, 1964-1986. Senior Vice-President, AFL-CIO Executive Council, 1973-present. Died Saturday, February 22, 1997, of complications from cancer at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, New York City. He is survived by his wife of 36 years, Edith Shanker (nee Gerber) of Mamaroneck, NY; his sister Pearl Harris of Beachwood, OH; his sons Carl Sabath of Gaithersburg, MD; Adam Shanker of Mt. Vernon, NY; Michael Shanker of Tarrytown, NY; his daughter Jennie Shanker of Philadelphia, PA; and his three grandchildren, Adrian, Jeremy, and Olivia. Private interment. Memorial services to be arranged in New York and Washington, DC. Contributions in his memory may be made to the International Rescue Committee (122 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10168) or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (attention: Development Department, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021).

title: Rangers Come Up Dry, And Drought Continues
description: Midway through tonight's game, when the Flyers were dominating the Rangers in every area except the score, a white towel fell on the ice from the New York bench.

title: INSIDE
description: Netanyahu Under Pressure

title: Noting Good Fortune, and Seeking to Share It
description: Last January the Herbert family was burned out of their home, an experience of ''nightmarish proportions,'' they wrote. Twelve months later, thankful that they had survived the disaster, they sent a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: With Cloning of a Sheep, the Ethical Ground Shifts
description: When a scientist whose goal is to turn animals into drug factories announced on Saturday in Britain that his team had cloned a sheep, the last practical barrier in reproductive technology was breached, experts say, and with a speed that few if any scientists anticipated.

title: Pistol Is Light but as Powerful as Police's
description: The handgun found next to Ali Abu Kamal on the observation deck of the Empire State Building is a powerful Italian-made weapon, capable of firing 8 to 14 quick shots, depending on the exact model, according to gun catalogues and police officials.

title: Go Slow on Myolysis
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Gambles On Staging Grammys
description: How badly does New York want the Grammys? Badly enough to kick the Knicks out of Madison Square Garden for their longest road trip this decade? Badly enough to shut down a subway line and several city blocks for part of an evening? Badly enough for the Mayor to start bashing his Grammy rival, Los Angeles, in the media? Badly enough for a major corporation to raise $1.5 million for the Grammy Host Committee and another to mount a $10 million advertising campaign? Yes, that badly.

title: Internet Advertising Growing Slowly
description: Reality check for the World Wide Web: Who is going to pay for it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, ROBERT WILLIAM
description: SARNOFF-Robert William. Age 78, of NYC, died Feb. 22, at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Beloved husband of Anna Moffo, brother of Edward and Thomas, father of Rosita Sarnoff, Serena Benenson and Claudia Parrot; grandfather of Adam, Toby and Felicia Jeanne Benenson. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, Feb. 26, at 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave and 65th St. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56th St, NYC 10019.

title: Russia's Staff of Life Is Now a Bone of Contention
description: It takes a true disaster to enrage the people of this city. Their President has hardly appeared among them in months, but nobody cares. NATO is about to sweep across the boundaries of what was once their enduring empire, yet it seems that few ordinary Russians even know that the organization exists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MERRILL J.
description: SIMON-Merrill J. We mourn his very sudden loss. He was a deeply devoted man of Israel and a special person, a loving husband to Amalia, devoted to his children and his grandchildren. We will miss Merrill very much. Ira, Risa, Andrew and Mikayla Bellach

title: Williams to Have Surgery
description: Jayson Williams has decided to schedule surgery for Monday or Tuesday to repair ligaments in his right thumb.

title: Knicks Pass a Survival Test
description: Al Davis said it best. Just win, baby. And this afternoon, although it took two overtimes, that's exactly what the Knicks did.

title: Not the Way It Used to Be
description: Is the quality of Atlantic City's tap water going downhill? After winning a national contest for the best-tasting drinking water in three of the last six years, Atlantic City did not finish in the top five at this year's competition, held Saturday in Berkeley Springs, W.Va. Dubuque, Iowa, a first-time entrant, was first in the field of 40 in the contest sponsored by Berkeley Springs' tourist office as part of its ''Festival of the Waters,'' the A.P. reported.

title: Raytheon Considers Sale of Appliance Unit
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it was considering the sale of its appliance operations, a move many investors expected in the wake of the company's pending purchases of $12.5 billion in military-contracting businesses.

title: Stocks Decline in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the end of the session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 137.55 points, or nearly three-quarters of a percent, at 18,896.99. On Friday, the Nikkei lost 17.17 points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUDAHY, JOHN J., JR. (SEAN)
description: CUDAHY-John J., Jr. (Sean), of Staten Island, on February 22, 1997, beloved husband of Kathleen Bridges, loving father of Mary Kate, beloved son of Dorothy Hayden Cudahy and the late John J. Cudahy, beloved son-in-law of Lenore and Robert Bridges, loving nephew of Catherine Gallery and James Hayden. Survived by many loving cousins and friends. Past President of County Clare Association and AOH Division 3 NY County, member 69th INF Veteran's Association. Funeral at Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, NY, Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Clare's Church, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetary. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Poof! Pulling Ratings Out of a Hat
description: A year ago, Lance Burton and his magic act gave NBC an impressive ratings lift on a Monday night, long a weak link in the ''Must see TV'' network's schedule. Next predictable step? Tonight, during a sweeps period, NBC offers Mr. Burton's ''second annual television special.'' It's called, rather grandly and misleadingly, ''Lance Burton, Master Magician: The Encounter.''

title: A Fabled View Yields To Panic and Horror
description: One moment, they were on top of the world, gazing down at New York City from the Empire State Building as the late afternoon light faded and the tall buildings at their feet began to glow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTENBERG, ANNA
description: TRACHTENBERG-Anna, 91, of Edison, on February 20, 1997. Mother of Dr. Eugene and Bernice Trachtenberg. Sister of Bertha Goodman. Grandmother of two. Great-grandmother of two. Funeral services were held Friday at the Gosselin Funeral Home in Edison, NJ. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge. Shiva will be observed at son's residence.

title: Priest Hurt During a Trick, But Won't Give Up the Magic
description: In his grand finale Saturday night before 200 Cub Scouts and their families, the Rev. Jerry Jecewicz, a professional magician and pastor of Brooklyn's Holy Spirit Church, waved his magic wand to make a live duck disappear.

title: Pulpit Is Ready to Take His Next Steps to the Derby
description: Pulpit ate his oats today and stretched his legs and seemed ready for the next landmark in his racing life, the Florida Derby, in three weeks, while his trainer basked in the rave reviews that proclaimed the colt first on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Campus Mood Is Unlike '89, But Lid Is Kept On Anyway
description: At the Triangle, the three-sided intersection on the campus of Beijing University where student posters ignited the democracy movement of 1989, there is no free space on the bulletin boards.

title: Walter Sorell, 91, Who Wrote About Dance and Culture
description: Walter Sorell, an erudite and prolific writer about dance and esthetics, died on Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 91 and had residences in Manhattan and Zurich.

title: Egyptians Find Status in Costly Cellular Phones
description: Nineteen-year-old Tammer Asaad thought he had all the right qualifications to date an 18-year-old woman who had caught his interest. He attends the expensive American University in Cairo, speaks his native Arabic with a deliberate American accent littered with English slang, dresses in costly black-black tight Levi's jeans and dances the macarena backward. She still wasn't impressed.

title: Awards Presented By 2 Groups
description: Awards for advertising and public relations have been presented by two organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, BERTHE
description: FISCHER-Berthe. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its longtime member. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, ETHEL
description: BRESSLER-Ethel, age 92. Wife of the late Isador Bressler. Mother of Joan and Dr. Waldo Greenspan. Grandmother of Jane Sims and David and Nancy Greenspan. Great-grandmother of Zachary and Emma Sims. Services 1 PM today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus.

title: Mother of Girl Missing a Year Won't Face Murder Charges
description: The mother of Justina Morales, the 8-year-old girl who the police say was beaten to death by the mother's ex-boyfriend more than a year ago, will not face murder charges in her daughter's death, an investigator said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, JOSEPHINE
description: HYMAN-Josephine. Age 92, of New York City. Widow of S. Frank Hyman. Beloved daughter of late Louis and Sophie Cohen. Devoted sister of Jeanette Goldfarb, Adele Zemansky and E. Malcolm Cohen, M.D. Survived by caring sister-inlaw Sylvia Cohen and numerous nieces and nephews. Always gracious. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetary on Sunday, February 23, in Elmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, JOYCE FIELDS
description: SIMONS-Joyce Fields. On February 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Richard Fields and the late Judith Fields Alviani. Mother-in-law of Marjorie Vandow and Joseph Alviani. Loving grandmother of Matthew and Samantha. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Monday evening 7-9 PM, with a service on Tuesday, February 25, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Punish the Batterer
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Five months after CHUCK JONES's conviction on charges of stealing footwear and intimate apparel from MARLA MAPLES TRUMP was reversed, a Criminal Court judge in Manhattan dismissed charges of aggravated harassment against him.

title: Rectifying a Legislative Blunder
description: When Representative Steven LaTourette of Ohio introduced a bill last month to repeal a section of the Kassebaum-Kennedy health insurance reform legislation enacted last year, he assumed someone would come forward to defend its purpose. He has yet to hear from anyone willing to claim authorship. The language apparently migrated from an earlier budget bill that was vetoed by President Clinton, but how it wound up in the health insurance law remains a mystery. End-of-session legislative fatigue could explain why no one seems to remember anything about it now.

title: Harassment Suit Opens
description: The Route 24 extension between Short Hills and Route 287 was finished years ago. But a sexual harassment suit stemming from a union picket at the highway construction site in 1991 is beginning a new chapter today in Superior Court.

title: Enigmas From the Clouds
description: Erick Hawkins's dances can almost always be looked at as both plotless and narrative works. Dance in general has that rich capacity for suggestion, but Hawkins takes it all a bit further. One example is ''Summer Clouds People,'' presented by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Friday night at Kaye Playhouse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DILL, DAVID
description: DILL-David. January 8, 1997. A celebration of his life will be held Monday, February 24, 1997, 5PM at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette St, NY. Donations may be made to Roswell Park Alliance Foundation, POB 631, Buffalo, NY 14240-9856. Checks should be designated ''In memory of David Dill-Pancreatic Research.'' For further information, contact 212-628-2320.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREIBLATT, BERNIECE
description: DREIBLATT-Berniece. Of Roslyn, NY, on February 22, 1997. Beloved wife of Leonard. Loving mother of Dean, Adam and Ross. Cherished grandmother of Alex, Perri and Ethan. A memorial service will be held at Sunset Chapels in Manhasset on February 25, 1997, at noon.

title: In H.M.O. Era, The House Call Is by Telephone
description: Every Tuesday, a nurse greets J. L. Atteberry, a frail 73-year-old cancer patient recovering at his home in Orangevale, Calif.

title: Clear Agreement Elusive On Fixing 737's Rudders
description: The Boeing 737 is more dangerous than other planes because of problems with its rudder, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday morning, and it could not be certified to fly under today's rules. No, the Federal Aviation Administration said that afternoon, it is as safe as any other plane and would be licensed.

title: Union Is Losing Battle With an Island Resort
description: Three years ago, the housekeepers, drivers, cooks and waiters of the Melrose Club, a luxurious private resort on South Carolina's isolated Daufuskie Island, won an epochal victory by voting to form the first trade union in Beaufort County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, WORTHINGTON
description: JOHNSON-Worthington, age 84, beloved husband of Frances Claudet Johnson, died Feb. 20, 1997. He was educated at the Choate School and Brown University and remained active in his philanthropic dedication to the Choate-Rosemary Hall School, the Fairfield Country Day School and the Wakeman Boys and Girls Club. He was a member of the Country Club of Fairfield, CT, the NY Racquet Club and the Lyford Cay Club of Nassau, the Bahamas. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his four children, Marina Sutro, Joan Stott, Margo Johnson and Worthington Johnson, Jr., and eight grandchildren. Memorial services will take place on Friday at 11 AM at the Southport, CT, Congregational Church. Donations in his memory to: Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, 385 Center St., Southport, CT 06490

title: Closure On Vince Foster
description: Kenneth Starr plans soon, I am told, to file his long-awaited report on the death of Vincent W. Foster Jr. It will conclude that the White House lawyer committed suicide.

title: Mourn Tibet, Not Deng
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparked by Pilon's Annual Goal, Islanders Stay Within Sight of Playoffs
description: They often resemble the gang that couldn't shoot straight. But the Islanders were on target enough this afternoon to put four pucks behind the rookie sensation Patrick Lalime on their way to a convincing 4-1 victory over the slumping Pittsburgh Penguins at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Overseas, Attacks on Corruption
description: Nothing makes people more furious with their leaders than corruption. Yet nothing seems harder to stop. In Pakistan, accusations of corruption have brought down Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto twice. The new Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, who was himself deposed on charges of corruption, now promises to fight it.

title: Hearing on a Freight Merger
description: The possible merger of two of the East Coast's three largest rail freight carriers -- Conrail, CSX and Norfolk Southern -- has sent tremors through the shipping industry, nowhere more so than in New Jersey, home to some of the busiest freight ports in the country, including Ports Newark and Elizabeth. Today, the Senate's and Assembly's transportation committees will hold a joint hearing on the potential impact of the merger.

title: What Is a Grammy Worth?
description: The biggest winners Wednesday when the National Academy of recording arts and Sciences hands out the Grammys may not be the musicians who give a speech, but the musicians who do what musicians do best -- perform.

title: Union Accepts a Pay Cut
description: Unlucky bettors are not the only ones losing money at New Jersey race tracks. A decline in racing receipts blamed on casino gambling has compelled the union that represents workers at state-owned horse-racing tracks to accept a 12 percent pay cut, officials said. ''We did what we had to do to save our jobs,'' said Robert Ligouri, business manager for the Sports Arena Employees Local 137. ''We negotiated out of privatization.''

title: Robert Sarnoff, 78, RCA Chairman, Dies
description: Robert W. Sarnoff, who succeeded his father as chairman of the RCA Corporation and steered it into a hodgepodge of new businesses before being removed more than 20 years ago in a ''palace revolt,'' died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Seychelles Warbler Proved Worth Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug makers test Thalidomide as a treatment for inflammations that accompany serious diseases.
description: THALIDOMIDE. The mere name conjures images of sloppy science, poor oversight of medicine and consumer betrayal. Not to mention fear -- of the unknown powers of biotechnology and the possible unforeseen long-term consequences of potent drugs.

title: Question of Succession In Union Leader's Death
description: The death of Albert Shanker, the longtime president of the American Federation of Teachers, silences one of the brashest, most persuasive and most respected voices in American education, educational leaders said yesterday.

title: 70 Years Old, and Still a New York Juror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Could Pixar Make It Without Disney?
description: When Andrew Stanton graduated from the California Institute of the Arts in 1987, he expected to struggle to make ends meet as an animator. And his expectations proved accurate for years.

title: Jefferson and Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAN, LILA
description: SWAN-Lila. On February 21. Passed away peacefully after a long illness. Loving wife of Kingsley Swan, will be remembered with love by her step-daughter Suzette McGouth, her nephew Bonzo King and cousin John Baker. Beloved daughter of the late Philip and Stella King. She will be deeply missed by her wide circle of friends. She touched many lives in an unforgettable way. Services at The Unitarian Church Of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, Thursday, February 27, 11 AM. Family will receive friends at her home after the service.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Of Youth, Childhood

title: Palestinian, 69, Carried Travel Papers and a Gun
description: When he joined scores of other tourists on the Empire State Building's 86th floor yesterday afternoon, Ali Abu Kamal, a 69-year-old Palestinian, held the road map of his last two months in America in his shirt pocket.

title: HOUSING PROJECTS IN NEW YORK CITY FACE BIG CHANGES
description: Facing stiff reductions in Federal aid, the sprawling New York City Housing Authority is exploring what was once unthinkable: turning over some of its high-rise buildings to private managers and earning more money from all its projects by sharply increasing the number of tenants with jobs, who can pay more rent.

title: Murderer's Sex Tapes Put Canadian Lawyer at Risk
description: A lawyer who withheld crucial evidence in one of Canada's most shocking murder cases is facing criminal and professional charges that have set off a debate on how far a lawyer can go to follow a client's instructions.

title: U.C.L.A. Is On Time And Target Vs. Duke
description: Duke played H-O-R-S-E today, while U.C.L.A. passed inside to its horse.

title: Shots Send Empire State Crowd Fleeing
description: A man wielding a semiautomatic handgun killed a tourist, wounded six others and then fatally shot himself in the head on the crowded 86th floor observation deck of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon. The wild shooting spree touched off panic among 90 to 100 terrified sightseers and their children, some of whom were trampled in a stampede to escape.

title: Free On-Line Time for a Price: Ads That Just Don't Go Away
description: Just a few years ago, when cyberspace was young, most on-line service providers charged their customers by the hour. These days, offering unlimited access for a set monthly price is practically a necessity for any consumer on-line business.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When PHYLLIS KARAS checked into a mountain inn in Santorini, Greece, last year, she never imagined that she would check out as the co-author of a book with blockbuster potential. Its subject: the last years of Aristotle Onassis and his relationship with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: Next Step: Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: Consultants Setting Up On the Web
description: As anyone would expect from a $25 billion industry, management consulting has a strong presence on the World Wide Web. But unlike finding, say, telephone numbers or flight schedules, finding management consulting information is not easy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERT, CECIL
description: LAMBERT-Cecil. February 24, 1972. Beloved father and grandfather. It's been 25 years and you are remembered with love each and every day. Steven, Barbara, Joseph and Corey

title: Prizing Observation More Than Confession
description: Sheryl Crow has no reason to be shy. A former backup singer, she has made two million-selling albums and won top Grammy Awards, and she has toured ceaselessly, honing her band and her songwriting. Yet at her sold-out show at Roseland on Friday night, she hung back from the audience. When someone tossed a bouquet of roses on stage, she fretted that it could have hit her in the eye. She depended on her music to carry the performance by itself, and most of the time it did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOGSDON, RICHARD H.
description: LOGSDON-Richard H. Former Director of Libraries for Columbia University. Of New York City and South Egremont, MA, died on Saturday, February 22, 1997. A Eucharistic Service will be conducted on Friday, 11 AM, at St. James Episcopal Church in Great Barrington, MA. Donations in his memory may be sent to the South Egremont Public Library, 1 Buttonball Rd., South Egremont, MA 01258; St. James Episcopal Church, 352 Main St., Great Barrington, MA 01230; or St. Peter's Church, 225 North Eighth St., Upper Sandusky, OH 43351.

title: Man Charged With Raping Date He Met From E-Mail
description: After six weeks of trading E-mail messages with a man she met on line in an Internet chat group, a 41-year-old woman from Syracuse visited New York on Friday evening to meet him. But soon after their first date began with a home-cooked dinner at the man's Greenwich Village apartment, the police said, the man raped her, beat her and held her in his apartment against her will.

title: Visions of Ballet as a Multiracial Art Have Been Slow to Spread in the U.S.
description: The pickets behind the barricades at Dance Theater of Harlem's headquarters earlier this month marched with the signs and shouted the slogans that have become familiar parts of the history of trade unionism in America. But for these striking dancers, there was a profound and poignant difference.

title: All Hail the Conquering (And Nonplused) Hero
description: Tino Martinez first noticed something strange happening to him in his hometown of Tampa last November and then it happened again while he was in New Jersey for Thanksgiving and then once more when he trekked to New York for an awards show this month. Martinez, Mr. Modest, had become Mr. Popular to legions of Yankee fans, and it shocked him.

title: Librarians Seeking a Good Book Turn to Him
description: Bill Ott wears 10 pairs of reading glasses. He may not wear them all in any one day, but at least that many pairs -- all drugstore purchases -- are sprinkled about his apartment and his office at the American Library Association headquarters in Chicago.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: From Abroad And Nearby: In Wrong Spot
description: They were European tourists enjoying the most classic New York City tourist ritual, a wind-whipped afternoon on the top of the Empire State Building. They were locals on a sunny Sunday outing with their families or shepherding out-of-town visitors on a sweep of must-see sights. They were members of an alternative rock band who had volunteered to be tour guides for some Swedish women they had met.

title: Albright Struts Across a World Stage, Radiating Star Quality
description: As she prepares for her visit to China, the last and most sensitive test of her grueling, 9-nation, 11-day tour of the world, Madeleine K. Albright shows every sign of having a wonderful time.

title: In This Game, Losing Is the Route to Success
description: THE proverbial journeyman center bid his wife and three children adieu Saturday afternoon in Phoenix, touched down in New Jersey later that night and reported to the scorer's table early in the second quarter yesterday afternoon.

title: Albert Shanker, 68, Combative Leader Who Transformed Teachers' Union, Dies
description: Albert Shanker, who rose from being a substitute mathematics teacher to become a tough, canny labor leader who in the 1960's transformed New York City's United Federation of Teachers into one of the nation's most powerful unions, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Mr. Shanker, the longtime president of the American Federation of Teachers, the parent organization of the United Federation of Teachers, was 68 and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Iona Wins Regular-Season M.A.A.C. Title
description: Mindaugas Timinskas has always played hard-nosed basketball. Today, the term took on a whole new meaning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, MURRAY S.
description: MARK-Murray S. On February 21, 1997. Beloved husband of Roslyn; father of Steven, Kim & Denis; father-in-law of Alan, Laurel and Arlene; brother of Mac and Saul; brother-in-law of Shirley, Doreen and Ethel; uncle and granduncle. Adored grandfather of Deena, Stacey, Alissa, Rebecca, Joseph, Elizabeth and Julia. Services Monday 2 PM, Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street.

title: Bridge
description: Deng Xiaoping, the ruler of modern China, who died last week, was a dedicated bridge enthusiast, willing to sit up half the night at the card table. When he was in eclipse during the Cultural Revolution, his devotion to a capitalist recreation was one of the charges brought against him.

title: Press, Politics and Consensus in New Old South
description: Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi is recuperating from a mysterious automobile crash in November and is returning to day-to-day duties. But the editor who directed the coverage of the accident and its puzzling aftermath by The Clarion-Ledger of Jackson, John D. Johnson, is out of a job and looking for work.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: E-MAIL LEADS TO ATTACK -- A woman visiting a man she met on the Internet was raped, beaten and held against his will in his Greenwich Village apartment, the police said. The man, Paul Krauth, 46, was being held on charges of rape, sodomy and sex abuse. B3.

title: Still Goofy, Still Sharp
description: Who is the real David Letterman? Here are some clues from his official video biography. Alec Baldwin, more in sorrow than in anger, reveals: ''Dave is, in fact, one of the Baldwin brothers. When we found out he was going to go into show business, we asked him if he wouldn't mind performing under a different name.'' Mia Farrow says in exasperation, ''For the thousandth time, I want to go on the record, I was never married to David Letterman.'' Throughout this deadpan spoof, which also features guests as oddly matched as Dave's mom and Howard Stern, Mr. Letterman puts on his goofiest expression, the one that says: Even if you're not a Baldwin, you might kick him out of your family. Of course that dunderheaded look works precisely because you know what a sharp comic intelligence is behind it.

title: Recalling three waves of newspaper strikes, after the devastation in Detroit.
description: THE Detroit newspaper strike that ended last week has been called the strike to end all newspaper strikes. As many as 2,000 people are out of work because of it, careers were cut short or shunted on to new, less gratifying paths, homes were forced onto the market, any sense of community and solidarity among journalists there was shattered, and for what?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUGENT, HELEN MARA
description: NUGENT-Helen Mara. Age 89. Died February 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph C. Nugent and the late John V. Mara. Loving mother of Maura Mara Concannon and the late Timothy J. Mara. Dear sister of Lillian Phelan and Jeanne Rohrs. Cherished grandmother of Christine Geithner, Kathleen Anderson and Sheila Concannon, and great-grandmother of Peter and Clare Geithner. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., on Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Chirstian Burial St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Ave at 84th St., on Tuesday, 11:15 AM. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to John V. Mara Cancer Research Unit, St. Vincent's Medical Center, 153 West 11 St., NYC 10011 or Catholic Big Sisters, 60 Lafayette St., NYC 10013.

title: Protecting Bird Habitats
description: Since 1972, environmental officials say, real estate development has gobbled up 40 percent of the wildlife habitat in the lower third of the Cape May peninsula, a main stopover and feeding point for the largest shorebird migration east of Alaska.

title: BOOKS: LIFE AT THE CROSSROADS A History of Gaza
description: LIFE AT THE CROSSROADS A History of Gaza.By Gerald Butt. 200 pages. $24.95. Rimal Publications, Scorpion Cavendish.

title: U.S. AND CHINESE SEEN NEAR A DEAL ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: After seven months of secret diplomacy, American and Chinese officials seem to be within striking distance of a breakthrough in their longstanding dispute over human rights. At issue is the fate of thousands of Chinese political and religious dissidents held in prisons, labor camps or just at home under heavy guard or surveillance.

title: Metal Detectors, Common at Other City Landmarks, Are Not Used
description: The Empire State Building, perhaps the most durable image in Manhattan's skyline, did not have what has become commonplace throughout New York City, from its most famous landmarks to its neighborhood high schools: metal detectors.

title: Fossils as the Focus of an Ethics Debate
description: Tyrannosaurus rex is causing trouble again. Only this time, as tomorrow's offering from ''Nova'' explains, it is not as predator but as the object of conflicting affections.

title: E*Trade Group To a WPP Unit
description: E*Trade Group Inc., an on-line investing company in Palo Alto, Calif., has named the San Francisco office of the J. Walter Thompson Company to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been handled in-house and fielded out on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Monday about the hostage crisis in Peru misstated the position of Pedro Fujimori, brother of President Alberto K. Fujimori. He is an adviser to the President; he is not the Foreign Minister.

title: Head of Morgan Stanley Merger Team Suffers Heart Attack
description: Robert G. Scott, the Morgan Stanley executive who is supervising his company's $10.2 billion merger with Dean Witter, Discover & Company, suffered a heart attack last week while on a family vacation in the Caribbean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: GROSSMAN - Charlotte. Loving wife of Morris. Beloved mother of Rita and Manny Roth and Harriet and Joshua Muss. Cherished grandmother of eight and greatgrandmother of twelve. Services 10 AM Monday.

title: Clinton Must Go Further to Support Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''It makes you aware that at any moment, your life can change. We had gone there on a family outing, and it turned into a nightmare.''

title: Accounts
description: * Steve Madden Ltd., Long Island City, Queens, to Hampel/Stefanides, New York, to handle advertising for the footwear maker, which had been handled by Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, OSCAR
description: GOLDMAN-Oscar. On February 22. Devoted husband of the late Mitzi Goldman. Beloved father of Naomi (Shlomo) Breines of Jerusalem and Susan (Shelly) Kramer of Queens. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be sorely missed. Shiva observed until Friday, February 28 at 144-41 69th Ave., Flushing, NY.

title: New and Improved? Not Quite
description: When President Clinton announced recently that welfare caseloads are down by 2.1 million from four years ago, he called it ''the biggest drop in welfare rolls in history.'' The President pointed to the waivers he has granted to 43 states, making it easier for them to place welfare recipients in jobs and training programs. Republican leaders gave the credit to Governors like John Engler of Michigan and Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin.

title: Family Pays Price of a Rebel's Fervor
description: Before Marxist guerrillas seized the Japanese diplomatic residence here two months ago, the large Rojas family was well-liked in the poor community of San Martin de Porres, where family members operated a candy store from their house and often helped neighbors in need.

title: Voices in Each Party Call for Special Counsel on Fund Raising
description: A rising chorus of prominent Democrats and Republicans predicted today that Attorney General Janet Reno would ultimately have no choice but to recommend the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the growing number of questionable campaign fund-raising practices by Democrats.

title: Secrecy Gives Way to Spotlight for Scientist
description: His hobby is walking in the mountains of Scotland. He relaxes with ''a good single-malt Scottish whisky,'' and enjoys the quiet of his village near Edinburgh that is ''so small you wouldn't be able to find it in an atlas.''

title: U.S. Utility Is Said to Be Near to British Deal
description: The American Electric Power Company is expected to announce as early as today that it plans to acquire Yorkshire Electricity P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Regulators Dan Quayle Could Love
description: THINK of it as one of those little inconveniences that come with driving a hearse.

title: Israeli Premier Hires a Lawyer in Appointment Scandal
description: With a police investigation into a shady political appointment burrowing ever deeper into his Government, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has hired a lawyer, and opposition politicians said they were preparing for new elections.

title: Victory Puts Villanova In a Satisfying Position
description: Before Final Four expectations led to weeks of scrutiny and criticism, before a 37-point pratfall at Kentucky turned up the volume on the talk-show complaints, the Villanova Wildcats would have nodded and smiled if presented with the following scenario:

title: Geoffrey Swaebe, 86; Former Envoy to Belgium
description: Geoffrey Swaebe, a department store executive who ran the May Company's southern California operations for 10 years and later served five years as Ambassador to Belgium under Ronald Reagan, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: A Differing View of the Spread of Technology
description: Disputing earlier conclusions that the Information Revolution is bypassing much of rural America, a new study financed by the National Science Foundation argues that information technology is becoming more and more equally distributed across the country.

title: Trade Agency Is Place to Mediate Helms-Burton
description: To the Editor:

title: Cloned Animals Offer Companies a Faster Path to New Drugs
description: Leaving aside the science fiction scenarios and ethical debates, the first products to emerge from the remarkable cloning of an adult sheep by British researchers will probably be animals that can serve as drug factories.

title: Ewing Leads Knicks' Escape From L.A.
description: The escape was not diagrammed on Coach Jeff Van Gundy's clipboard; it was rehearsed in Patrick Ewing's mind. As in old times, he would demand the basketball and his teammates would give it to him. And nothing else would matter.

title: Aldrich Ames: Brilliant or Bumbling?
description: CONFESSIONS OF A SPY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, ROBERT W.
description: SARNOFF-Robert W. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member and Officer with the title of Prior, Friar Robert W. title: Esquire Editor Resigns After Story Is Pulled
description: Saying he did so as an act of protest, the literary editor of Esquire has resigned from the magazine over the executive editor's decision to pull a work of fiction from the April issue.

title: Mexico Stages Manhunt for Its Top Ex-Prosecutor, Suspected in Body-Planting Conspiracy
description: As the Mexican law enforcement authorities struggle to recover from the arrest on drug charges of the top anti-narcotics commander, they are also engaged in a nationwide search for another man who only recently was a top official in the justice system.

title: Tuberculosis Rate Drops
description: In 1993, Newark had the second highest tuberculosis rate of any major city in the country. But since a federally financed program was started in Newark in 1994 to check the spread of the disease, new cases in the city have dropped by 37 percent, to 102 last year, according to the National Tuberculosis Center, which runs the program. Dr. Lee Reichman, the director of the center, which is based at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, told The Associated Press that the figures show the need for the Government to continue to help fight the disease. In Jersey City, Dr. Reichman said, where there was no such program until this year, tuberculosis cases climbed 28 percent from 1994 to 1996. His staff is setting up a similar program in Middlesex County, which saw a 22 percent jump in new cases last year.

title: Release the Harlem Audit
description: Harlem has a better chance for its long-awaited renaissance since Gov. George Pataki closed down the Harlem Urban Development Corporation and replaced it with a potentially more effective development agency run by the state. Founded nearly 25 years ago to spur development, the corporation had spent $100 million in public funds but left Harlem disillusioned and ravaged by urban blight.

title: Residents Make Appeal On Shoreham Tax Debt
description: Residents of the Shoreham-Wading River School District, which faces possible bankruptcy over a property tax refund due on the abandoned Shoreham nuclear plant, pleaded for relief yesterday from the Long Island Power Authority.

title: UST'S FINANCE CHIEF AND TOBACCO PRESIDENT RESIGN
description: UST Inc. said yesterday that its chief financial officer, John J. Bucchignano, and the president of its tobacco unit, Robert D. Rothenberg, had resigned because of differences over UST's direction. No successors have been named, UST, which makes Skoal and Copenhagen brands and is based in Greenwich, Conn., said in a statement. The disagreement may hinge on how to combat gains being made by private-label brands in the United States, analysts said. UST, the nation's largest maker of smokeless tobacco products, has been losing market share for years to lower-priced brands.

title: Hot Corner Heats Up Earlier Than Usual
description: Wade Boggs is sitting at his locker, gripping a baseball bat, surveying the clubhouse with his hyperactive eyes and talking baseball. It is 8:30 in the morning and Boggs is already dressed in his uniform and has already pumped coffee into a body that turns 39 years old in June. The scene looks natural.

title: U.S. to Make Water Available To Homes Near Laboratory Leak
description: Despite Federal assurances that a nuclear waste leak at the Brookhaven National Laboratory poses no threat to their drinking water, the Federal Government has agreed to connect 500 nearby homes to a public water supply.

description: Park Chung Ryul, an official with a militant leftist organization here, was awakened by a knock at 2 A.M. one day in November 1995. When he opened his door, he said, more than 10 men rushed in, forced him to kneel, flashed a warrant for his arrest and whisked him away.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES BUYING 2 MORE NEW-CAR DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it would buy new-car dealership groups in Miami and Houston for about $75 million in stock in the latest expansion of its chain of auto dealers. Republic is buying Kendall Toyota, a group of Toyota, Lexus and Kia dealerships in Miami, and Joe Myers Automotive Group, the owner of Ford, Toyota, Mitsubishi, Mazda and Kia dealerships in Houston. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and headed by H. Wayne Huizenga, entered the new-car business in December. It also owns the Autonation chain of used-car dealerships and has solid-waste landfills and an electronic-security business. Its shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $35.125.

title: AIDS Program Finds a Home
description: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey will take over a pediatric AIDS program it has jointly run since 1986 with a Newark hospital that filed for bankruptcy, officials said yesterday. The program will be relocated to University Hospital from United Hospital, which filed for bankruptcy last week and turned over its Children's Hospital to Saint Barnabas Health Care System for $13 million.

title: A Long-Secret Weapon Of Millipede Is Unveiled
description: MILLIPEDES and centipedes are the many-segmented and multilegged animals that live in rotting logs, but there is a huge difference in their strategies for survival. Centipedes are fast-moving carnivores with venom-filled jaws for killing insects, earthworms and other small prey, while the slower millipedes feed on decaying plant matter and have evolved passive defenses against insects, their chief enemies. Most millipedes, when alarmed, curl up like watch springs with their soft undersides hidden and their heads at the center of the spiral. If attacked, they emit toxic compounds like cyanide from glands on each body segment.

title: Union Has Federal Approval
description: Prosecutors asked a Federal judge in Trenton yesterday to end nearly six years of court-ordered supervision of the union local that represents more than 15,000 people who work in Atlantic City casinos. Local 54 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees International Union no longer needs court supervision, the United States Attorney's office said, because it is now free of organized crime influence.

title: TEREX PLANS TO ADD 6 SIMON ENGINEERING BUSINESSES
description: The Terex Corporation agreed yesterday to buy certain businesses of Simon Engineering P.L.C.'s Simon Access division for $90 million. The units to be sold are Simon-Telelect, Simon Aerials Inc., Simon Aerials Ltd., Simon-Cella, the Simon-R.O. Corporation and Simon Aircraft Ground Equipment. They make truck-mounted cranes and aerial work platforms. Terex, based in Westport, Conn., makes heavy-duty off-road trucks, mobile cranes and aerial work platforms. Simon is a London-based engineering, storage and equipment-making company. Shares of Terex rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $10.625.

title: Rangers Can All Shoulder the Blame
description: The Rangers are not that good or that bad. They are just an interesting, mediocre team with marquee appeal, with more sizzle than steak. With their expensive, aging and lopsided mixture of stars and grinders, they can beat the best, as they did in Colorado by a 5-2 score on Nov. 27.

title: Disney in 10-Year, 5-Film Deal With Pixar
description: The Walt Disney Company announced an unusual 10-year partnership yesterday with Pixar Animation Studios to jointly make five films in a deal that reflects the value Hollywood increasingly places on the lucrative field of animated movies.

title: Workaday World Of Stock Breeding Clones Blockbuster
description: IF Dr. Ian Wilmut of Scotland had been an American researcher trying to get a Federal grant to clone a sheep, a feat he announced on Saturday, the request would not have been approved, experts in the United States say. And not because the work was too scary or controversial. His goal is just too practical, and he comes from the wrong side of the scientific tracks.

title: A Dam Open, Grand Canyon Roars Again
description: LAST March, in a precedent-setting effort to turn back the ecological clock, Federal officials unleashed four roaring jets of white water from a Federal hydroelectric dam on the Colorado River. The objective was to mimic the annual floods that for millenniums, until the dam was built, had set the terms of life at the bottom of the Grand Canyon.

description: The Green Cross Corporation, a troubled Japanese company at the center of a big H.I.V.-tainted blood scandal, will be acquired by another pharmaceutical company, and its name will cease to exist, the companies said today.

title: Korean Air Records Its First Yearly Loss
description: Korean Air, the world's 10th-largest airline, lost money for the first time in its 34-year history last year, buffeted by rising fuel costs and the won's slump against the dollar. The airline, South Korea's flagship carrier, said yesterday that it had a net loss of 210 billion won ($244 million), in contrast to a net profit of 105.9 billion won in 1995. The loss was within analysts' expectations. Revenue for 1996 rose 8.4 percent, to 3.665 trillion won ($3.15 billion).
