description: ISRAEL-Lea. Of Newton, Ma. Formerly of Brooklyn. Wife of Nissan, mother of Elliot and David, beloved sister and grandmother.

title: Lights Are Dimmed
description: The decorative lights atop the Empire State Building were dimmed last night because of the shooting Sunday at the building's observation deck.

title: Thorn to Close Stores and Cut Jobs in Britain To Stop Slide
description: Thorn P.L.C., moving to reduce costs as its sales slump, said today that it would close 90 Radio Rentals stores and cut 360 jobs in Britain and step up promotional efforts in the United States aimed at retaining customers at its Rent-A-Center, U-Can-Rent and Remco outlets.

title: Dean Witter Layoffs Presage a Merger
description: Dean Witter, Discover and Company will soon lay off as many as 600 employees as it prepares to merge with Morgan Stanley Group Inc., Dean Witter executives said yesterday.

title: Seniors Take Joke Seriously
description: The issue the passage of a $28 million school bond referendum -- was serious. But Chuck Fest, the president of the Mount Laurel teachers' union, said yesterday that he thought he was being funny when he referred to the elderly opponents of the measure as ''old coots'' in his February newsletter. A copy wound up at a senior citizens' home, where residents did not appreciate the attempt at humor.

title: ENERGY VENTURES AGREES TO ACQUIRE TEXAS ARAI
description: The oilfield equipment concern Energy Ventures Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Texas Arai Industries, also known as TA Industries, for about $64 million in cash and debt. Houston-based TA Industries makes tubular couplings and accessories under the brand names Texas Arai and Tube Alloy. The closely held company had revenue of $80 million in 1996. Energy Ventures, also based in Houston, makes drilling tools, tubulars and production equipment. It had revenue of $478 million in 1996, and said it expected to save as much as $2 million a year after it integrated the operations of TA Industries and the Tubular Corporation of America, which it acquired in August. Shares of Energy Ventures jumped $2.25 yesterday, to $56.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGENSTERN, SHELDON
description: MORGENSTERN - Sheldon. On Feb. 22, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ada Shalit Morgenstern. Devoted brother-in-law of Martin Shalit, of NYC, and Clara Nitzberg and uncle of Laura NItzberg, both of Ann Arbor, MI. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUDAHY, JOHN J., JR. (SEAN)
description: CUDAHY-John J., Jr. (Sean), of Staten Island, on February 22, 1997, beloved husband of Kathleen Bridges, loving father of Mary Kate, beloved son of Dorothy Hayden Cudahy and the late John J. Cudahy, beloved son-in-law of Lenore and Robert Bridges, loving nephew of Catherine Gallery and James Hayden. Survived by many loving cousins and friends. Past President of County Clare Association and AOH Division 3 NY County, member 69th INF Veteran's Association. Funeral at Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, NY, Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Clare's Church, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetary. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Applied Magnetics Begins $1.76 Billion Read-Rite Bid
description: Not content to remain a spurned suitor, the Applied Magnetics Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy the rival Read-Rite Corporation for about $1.76 billion in stock in an effort to create one of the leading computer disk head suppliers in the country.

title: Cloning for Good or Evil
description: The startling news that scientists have cloned an adult sheep, producing a younger, genetically identical ''twin'' of the original, is a reminder that reproductive technologies are advancing far faster than our understanding of their ethical and social implications. Just a few years ago, researchers seemed confident that such cloning lay far in the future, giving ample time to wrestle with the consequences. Now a little-known team from Scotland has breached the barrier and entered a realm that fiction writers have long suggested is rife with potential for evil. The possibility of making carbon copies of humans is no longer quite so far-fetched.

title: Jacques Coe, 103, Dies; Oldest Active Broker
description: Jacques Coe, believed to be the nation's oldest active stockbroker, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., after a brief illness, his daughter, Jean Fink, of Scarsdale, N.Y., said. He was 103.

title: Supreme Court to Review Sharp Limits on Membership in Credit Unions
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower-court ruling that placed sharp limits on the membership of federally chartered credit unions. The Federal agency that regulates credit unions, urging the Justices to hear the appeal, warned that the decision ''threatens the survival'' of credit unions, which have millions of members throughout the country.

title: The Kings' Hall of Fame 'No-Account'
description: UNTIL this season, Pete Carril and Michael Jordan had always been on different basketball planets -- one the longtime Princeton coach in the Ivy League, the other the National Basketball Association's one and only. But when the Bulls were in Sacramento not long ago, the Kings' assistant coach met Air for the first time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about China's economic prospects after Deng Xiaoping's death misstated initial activity on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange on Thursday. The Hang Seng Index opened down, not up, in the first minutes of trading, falling nearly 1 percent from Wednesday's close before rallying to close up 2.3 percent for the day.

title: Barney's Chapter 11 Is Under Investigation
description: Barney's Inc.'s bankruptcy proceedings are the subject of a preliminary fraud inquiry by the Manhattan District Attorney, the company said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: A Fall Preview: Sleekly Feminine but Without Frills
description: If last fall was about androgyny and this spring is about femininity, then the good word for next fall is the melding of both extremes. There are still lots of pants, but there are sweater jackets and kimonos to soften the effect. And the micro-miniskirt is making a comeback, accentuating a long, lean, leggy look.

title: A Case of Rape, Memory and DNA
description: The script is not unknown to real-life television: a wrongful conviction, a long stay in prison, final exoneration. Tonight's absorbing ''Frontline'' uses such a case to inquire into the vagaries of memory and the fallibility of eyewitness testimony.

title: Reckson Associates in Deal
description: The Reckson Associates Realty Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire a 10-building portfolio of research and development and industrial space for about $21 million. The Melville-based real-estate investment trust said the properties, representing 447,000 square feet, are in Reckson's Vanderbilt Industrial Park in Hauppauge. The buildings are 85 percent leased.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an impending decision by the United States on whether to certify Mexico as cooperating in anti-drug efforts misidentified the event at which the decision is expected to be announced. It is a State Department news conference on Thursday, not an anti-drug rally.

title: Giuliani Hires Media Firm for Campaign
description: Filling the last major gap in his campaign organization, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has hired a media consultant with long experience in Republican circles for his re-election effort, aides said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBIUS, MARGARET E.
description: JACOBIUS-Margaret E., on February 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Hans Jacobius. Cherished mother of Dr. F. Michael Jacobius. Loving sister of Beatrice Herbert. Devoted grandmother of David and Daniel Jacobius. Great-grandmother of Allie and Joshua Jacobius.

description: HEYER-Paul. The New York School of Interior Design extends its sympathy to the family of Paul Heyer, our former president and professor of architecture and design. Carl A. Schwarz, Jr, Chairman Inge Heckel, President

title: But He Was a Killer
description: When Joseph Stalin died, Western newspapers carried stories about the sorrow that was supposed to have gripped the Soviet people and how they would miss him.

title: Army Knew in '91 of Chemical Weapons Dangers in Iraq
description: An internal Pentagon investigation has determined that the Central Intelligence Agency provided the Army with detailed warnings more than five years ago that American troops might have been exposed to nerve gas in the demolition of an Iraqi ammunition depot shortly after the Persian Gulf war.

title: Longtime makers of sporting goods consider the possibility that their game has passed them by.
description: WHEN the golf star Tiger Woods turned professional last year, the sports world was stunned by the estimated $60 million in endorsement contracts he secured from Nike and the Titleist unit of American Brands.

title: A Preventable Tragedy
description: Mass shootings have become a common enough part of American life that many people are inured to reports of yet another crazed gunman run amok. But when random violence occurs at a familiar site like the Empire State Building, the normal defenses break down. Everyone who has ever been there, or meant to go some day, has the same startled insight: It could have been me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, IRVING A.
description: GREENE-Irving A., on January 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Corinne Greene. Dear father of Michael and Peggy, Andrew and Barbara, and Steven. Adored grandfather of Adam, Sam and Billy.

title: Street Cleaners in Partnership Vote to Join Teamsters Union
description: Organizers with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said yesterday that more than 60 street cleaners at the Grand Central Partnership, one of New York City's best-known business improvement districts, voted on Friday to join the teamsters.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Before the calendar turns to March Madness, here is a look at some of the best coaching performances in the metropolitan New York area this season.

title: Officials Look For Any Links In Bombings In Atlanta
description: Investigators have found distinct similarities as well as some differences between the bombs planted at a gay nightclub here on Friday night and those planted last month near an abortion clinic in north Atlanta, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Gore to Speak at Memorial Service for Sagan
description: A memorial for Carl Sagan, the astrophysicist whose influence was felt in the domains of science, culture and public policy, will be held on Thursday at 4 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial donations to the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11225.

description: MAJOR-Claude, 39, of Manhattan and St. Eustache, Quebec, died Monday, February 24, 1997 after a brief illness. A native of St. Eustache, Quebec, Mr. Major graduated from the University of Quebec at Montreal with a degree in French Literature. He later attended The Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. He is survived by his mother, Carmen Major, of St. Eustache, Quebec, a brother, Michel Major, his sisterin-law Sylvie Girard, and two nephews, Marc-Andre and David Major of St. Eustache, Quebec.

title: A Hollywood Story, a Hollywood Ending
description: Mike Medavoy is, in some ways, having the last laugh.

title: Loans for Rained-Out Farms
description: Last summer's wet weather ruined crops throughout the state. But in the southwestern corner, excessive rainfall and a hailstorm on July 8 prompted the United States Department of Agriculture to declare Gloucester and Salem Counties a disaster. At least 40 farms reported losses of 50 percent or more of their vegetable and fruit crops, Gerard G. Hlubik, the agriculture credit director for the New Jersey Farm Service Agency, said.

title: European Clearance For Coke Enterprises
description: The European Commission said today that it had approved Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.'s 15-year licensing agreement with Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., allowing the United States bottler to produce and distribute Cadbury soft drinks in Britain.

title: INSIDE
description: Chemical Exposure Warning

title: CHRONICLE
description: Win a few, lose a few: the score came out just about even this week for MILOS FORMAN, the director of ''The People vs. Larry Flynt.''

title: Might as Well Be Spring
description: There was a decidedly romantic mood wafting through many spring collections, from ruffled dresses to floral print scarves to delicate sandals and evening bags with a vintage air.

title: Russia Atom Aides Buy I.B.M. Supercomputer Despite U.S. Curbs
description: In an effort to circumvent United States export controls, Russia's nuclear weapons establishment says it has obtained a powerful I.B.M. supercomputer through a European middleman.

title: Once a Trapeze Artist, Always a Heart-Stopper
description: It was the mid-1950's. I was barely in my teens. And there one day at Yankee Stadium, just a few rows away, sat Burt Lancaster, supercool in sports jacket and sunglasses, and every bit as dashing as the swashbucklers he was then playing in films like ''The Crimson Pirate.'' Flashing his famous clenched-teeth smile to awed fans, Lancaster was quite simply bigger than life. He was the very essence of what is supposed to be a movie star.

title: Vast Negligence Reported In Granting of Citizenship
description: The Clinton Administration allowed about 180,000 immigrants to become American citizens before checks for criminal records had been completed, two House Republicans said today.

title: BEC GROUP TO BUY THE EYEWEAR MAKER BOLLE FRANCE
description: The BEC Group of Rye, N.Y., said yesterday that it would buy Bolle France, the French maker of sunglasses and other eyewear, for $60 million in cash plus warrants issued to Bolle's controlling family. After it combines Bolle France with its existing sunglasses subsidiary, BEC plans to separate the business from its optical-technology unit to form a new company called Bolle Inc. The Bolle family will receive warrants to buy 2.13 million Bolle Inc. common shares. Exercising the warrants will give the family 10 percent of the new company.

title: No Headline
description: ''It made me realize that narcotics crime has reached extremely serious levels, and we are going to have to take measures never seen before in our country to stop it.''

title: 'Schindler' Sets A TV Record
description: NBC's broadcast of Steven Spielberg's Academy Award-winning film ''Schindler's List'' on Sunday night had by far the biggest audience of any nonsports program on television this season, according to overnight ratings from Nielsen Media Research.

title: A Farm That Could Sweeten a Nation's Bitter Crop
description: Hendrick Kritzinger's family has farmed the valley here for generations, using hundreds of mixed-race workers to prune and weed and spray and harvest the apple and pear orchards that have produced his substantial wealth.

title: Officer Is Not Hurt In BB Gun Shooting
description: A police officer examining a stolen or abandoned automobile in the Bronx yesterday afternoon was shot in the chest with a BB gun, the police said. The officer, who was not identified, was wearing a bullet-proof vest and was not injured.

title: Slain Girl's Mother in Plea Agreement
description: The mother of an 8-year-old girl whose slaying went undetected for more than a year, pleaded guilty to hindering prosecution yesterday and will testify against her former boyfriend in an agreement that could keep her out of prison, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Nets Begin Basking In Cathode-Ray Glow
description: To see the Nets play on network television, as they did Sunday afternoon against Boston, is to witness an occurrence as rare as an intelligent Chris Farley film. And the good news is that the game wasn't against the Knicks and it was scheduled last July, long before last week's nine-player deal with Dallas.

title: New York Study Finds Uninsured Are on the Rise
description: In a report that has implications for the entire country, researchers have found that the number of New Yorkers without health insurance has jumped in the last five years.

title: Alfonzo Spending Another Camp Living the Questions
description: Edgardo Alfonzo, at age 23, hasn't really been stuck in neutral in his Mets career. It only seems that way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, RAE FISHBERG
description: GLANTZ-Rae Fishberg, 94, at home on Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. Widow of Harry; cherished mother of Geraldine, Janice and Lois. Beloved mother-in-law of Sidney Bergman, Robert Greenstein and Arthur Rosenfeld. Adored grandmother of the late Pamela, Susan, Ivy, Tod, Felicia, Carolyn and Sara. Loving great-grandmother of eleven. Devoted sister of Marte and aunt. A woman of incomparable grace, charm, intelligence and insight. She was a natural beauty whose character was as unforgettable as her face. A member of the Fishberg-Glantz musical family, her life was a symphony of great personal accomplishment, filled with warmth, love and serenity. She will be deeply missed. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, BERTHA S.
description: NEWHOUSE-Bertha S. Died on January 23 in New York City at the age of 78. Beloved wife of Roy for over 53 years. Loving mother of Martin and Lina Wood. Devoted grandmother of Katherine, Philip, Samuel, Emma and Rebecca. Born in Mt. Vernon, New York, she lived most of her life in New York City, where she was educated and where her children were raised. She graduated from Morris High School in the Bronx, received her B.A. from Hunter College and an MS from the School of Business, Columbia University. In addition to caring for her family, she was the first woman accountant to do field work for the firm of S.D. Leidesdorf Co. and the first woman CPA in the department of Accountancy at Baruch College, CUNY, where she taught for many years and, at her retirement, was Associate Dean and Professor of Accountancy in the School of Business and Public Administration. As an officer of the Gustave Hartman YM/YWHA in Far Rockaway, she helped formulate an ongoing drug abuse discussion program. She was also founder and president of the Atlantic Shore Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, setting up the first recreation center for senior citizens in the area. In 1984, she was named as a distinguished alumna to the Hunter College Hall of Fame by the Alumni Association of Hunter College. A voracious reader, a devotee of The New York Times cross word puzzle, a woman of inspired conversation, a deeply caring friend, and a person who never lost her passionate love for the cultural life of this city, her death leaves a void that can never be filled. Funeral services will be at 10:45 a.m. on Sunday, January 26 at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., followed by burial at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York. Thereafter, her family will be at 140 Nassau Street, N.Y.

description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, proposed a commission to find a way to fix the Government's main inflation gauge today, providing possible political cover for a deal that would help balance the budget by reducing cost-of-living increases for Social Security.
