title: Bonds Slip On Caution By Investors
description: Treasury prices slipped yesterday as bond investors looked cautiously ahead to testimony this week from the Federal Reserve chairman as well as to looming supply.

title: 2 U.S. Utilities to Buy British Company for $2.4 Billion
description: Two United States utilities, the American Electric Power Company and the Public Service Company of Colorado, announced yesterday that they had agreed to acquire Yorkshire Electricity Group P.L.C. for $2.43 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINARY, JOHN S.
description: MINARY-John S., O.B.E., attorney and personal financial advisor to William S. Paley, died Tuesday, Feb. 18, after a short illness at his home in Charlottesville, VA. He was 88. Mr. Minary was born in Benton Harbor, Mich., the son of Charles K. Minary and Margaret Bowmer Minary. He was a graduate of Dartmouth, and the Minary Conference Center there was given in his honor by Mr. Paley. He was a member of the Century Association. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, two step-sons, C. Wickliffe Moorman of Virginia Beach, and Dr. J. Randall Moorman of Charlottesville, and five stepgrandchildren. The funeral was held Friday, Feb. 21 at the Wesley Memorial United Methodist Church. He was buried at the Riverview Cemetery in Charlottesville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MERRILL
description: SIMON-Merrill. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the untimely passing of our generous patron and Presidential Founder, Merrill Simon. He published many volumes through which he was helpful to the business world. His greatest achievement was, however, that he discovered his roots in his middle years and he applied himself to the Jewish heritage with such zeal and commitment that he commanded the respect of all who knew him. To his loving family, we extend sincerest condolences and with them we share many inspiring memories. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Jane Stern Lebell, President, American Friends Brig. Gen. (Res) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President, Bar-Ilan University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, PHILIP C.
description: BRODSKY-Philip C., on January 24, 1997 of cancer. Beloved and adored husband of Jeanne, cherished father and grandfather of sons Paul, Gabriel and Eugene, daughter-in-law Karen, children Nancy, Marc and Sue Lazarus and grandchildren Sascha, Kirsten, Anya, Kate, Emma, brother Nathan and sister Ruth Leopold. His elegance touched everyone. Service Sunday, January 26th at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 1:15 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Yale Drama School.

title: From Teacher to Gunman: U.S. Visit Ends in Fatal Rage
description: When he arrived in the United States last Christmas Eve, there was no indication that his journey would end in anything out of the ordinary. His family said that he wished nothing more than to find a comfortable existence for them. But what he did find, and very quickly, apparently was the exact opposite, and it ultimately transformed a teacher of English into a brazen killer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PANTELL, ROBERT E.
description: PANTELL-Robert E. Bob...my dearest friend and only brother on your first birthday (76th) without you. Wendy, David, Jon, Cathy, Aaron, Maya and Richard miss you. Resting next to beloved Astrid. Elaine Gailmor

title: New York Democrats' Disarray Mirrors Party's Ill Fortunes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, DOROTHY
description: WEINER-Dorothy, age 88, of Bronx, NY. Survived by her son Barry, her brother David, and three grandchildren: Jessica, Hallie, and Ross. Services are today, 10:00 am, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: If You Can't Remember D-Day, G.M.'s Luxury Nameplate Wants You
description: For more than 15 years now, Cadillac has watched its faithful buyers grow silver-haired and age beyond their driving years. And every few years, the General Motors division has tried to lure younger buyers with cars designed to appeal to them, instead of their parents.

title: Eurotunnel Gets Delay In Debt Repayments
description: Eurotunnel said yesterday that its creditor banks had extended until December the date at which it must resume payments on its debt. A moratorium on repayment had started on Sept. 14, 1995, and was to have expired on March 14. The English Channel tunnel company, which owes payment on $:9 billion ($14.6 billion) of debt, started to break even on an operating basis last March.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: $1.76 Billion is Offered For Computer Part Maker

title: Ancient Graves Of Armed Women Hint at Amazons
description: THE ancient Greeks could certainly tell a good yarn. Cultivating a kernel of fact, or less, they could bring forth a feast of a story to nourish imaginations down through the ages. One such tale was about a society of fierce warrior women -- the Amazons.

title: Attorney Says Union Is Free of Mob Influence
description: Prosecutors asked a Federal judge yesterday to end nearly six years of court-ordered monitoring of a union local that represents more than 15,000 people who work in Atlantic City casinos.

title: Looking for Work, Stopping to View
description: Mario Carmona had retired from his job as head of the systems department at a bank in Argentina because he craved independence. But after six years of plying his trade as a computer consultant, the money had dried up and Mr. Carmona decided to take a gamble. He would travel to New York City and look for a job with the help of his cousin.

title: President of U.S. Chamber Will Resign After 21 Years
description: Richard L. Lesher, the dean of business lobbying, who raised the profile of the United States Chamber of Commerce during his 21 years as its president, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Boston Harbor Cracks Bone And Will Not Run in Derby
description: The road to the Kentucky Derby claimed a victim today when Boston Harbor, the champion 2-year-old of last season and one of the favorites for this year's Derby, cracked a bone in his left foreleg and was removed from racing for at least four months.

title: President Asks Experts for Advice on the New Reality of Cloning
description: Reacting to what the White House called the ''very startling news'' that scientists in Scotland had successfully cloned a mammal, President Clinton today asked a Federal bioethics advisory commission to review the research implications for human beings and report to him in 90 days.

title: Showing Up Is Not Enough, One Meet Director Says
description: The pro golf tours pay prize money but no appearance fees, although nontour stops may slip a six-figure fortune to a star like Tiger Woods. The tennis tours do the same. Track and field, a poor stepchild, offers occasional prize money, but invitation meets have traditionally lured athletes with appearance fees.

title: Club Med Shares Surge On Turnaround Hopes
description: The shares of Club Mediterranee S.A. soared 21 percent yesterday amid optimism that the closing of seven unprofitable resorts and the hiring of the chief executive of Euro Disney S.A. would help earnings. Club Med said on Friday that closing 7 of its 114 villages would have an ''important positive impact.'' Investors also hailed the hiring of Philippe Bourguignon, 49, of Euro Disney to replace Serge Trigano, 50, son of its founder. Club Med's shares gained 75.5 francs yesterday, to 431 francs ($75.64), their highest since 447 francs last July.

title: Rock Band's Promise Was Bright Until Gunman Shattered Their Hope
description: Matthew Gross and Chris Burmeister were going places. They were sure of it. Gig by gig, club by club, the band they were part of, the Bushpilots, was building a following in and around New York City, drawing young people who came to dance and laugh at the group's loopy antics, which included donning Viking horns as they played a brand of progressive rock with a naughty, satirical edge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, WILLIAM
description: REISMAN-William, 95, on Feb. 24 in Vero Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Edna for 70 years; loving father of Robert and daughter-inlaw, Toby; cherished grandfather of Larry, his wife Lee, and greatgrandfather of Rhett, all of Vero Beach; and granddaughter Shari of Atlanta. Formerly of Washington Heights and owner of Style Vogues. Services in Florida.

title: Tourists See A Sad Fluke, Not a Menace
description: FORTUNATELY for those who care about this city's reputation in foreign precincts, tourists from abroad are a hardy breed, not ones to be easily deterred by bullets at the Empire State Building. While appalled by the shooting spree, Europeans in particular took it in stride yesterday as something that could have happened anywhere.

title: Thousands Join Leaders In Bidding Deng Farewell
description: In the Hall for Paying Last Respects, a room with curtains of black silk and overflowing floral baskets, China's leaders bid a last farewell to Deng Xiaoping this morning in a traditional ceremony. Then they escorted his body, draped with the red flag of the Communist Party, across town to a crematory that turned it to ashes.

title: Success in Cloning Hardly Insures Profit
description: Shares in PPL Therapeutics P.L.C. soared on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, following the news over the weekend that scientists in the tiny Scottish biotechnology company, in collaboration with researchers at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh, had successfully cloned a sheep. Its shares rose 16.4 percent yesterday, closing at $:3.875, up 52.5 pence.

title: Not Just a New Ferry Terminal, but a Fanciful One
description: Staten Island officials said yesterday that they wanted to replace the borough's aging St. George Ferry Terminal with a $100 million building, a twisting, chimerical structure that would continue to receive passengers while also housing a museum. The new building would be a striking fusion of infrastructure and culture, beckoning visitors to the southern end of New York Harbor.

title: Heads of SUNY Colleges Fight Budget Cuts Sought by Pataki
description: In an unusual plea to lawmakers, the presidents of the State University of New York's 19 major four-year colleges and universities say they cannot withstand another round of significant budget cuts, and they have appealed to the State Legislature to restore the higher-education cuts proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, SOPHIE GOLDBERG
description: MARCUS - Sophie Goldberg. Passed away Feb 24. Wife of thelate Fredric. Beloved mother of Linda Bakian and Marilyn Alper. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Joshua, Marielle, Daniel and Michael. Loving mother-in-law of Victor Bakian and the late Howard Alper. Adored sister, aunt and friend. Graveside services Linden Hill Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens, NY Wed Feb 26 at 11:15AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZBURG, JOSEPH
description: SALZBURG-Joseph. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Barbara London and Karen Beer. Loving brother of Irving. Cherished grandfather of Scott, Jill, Nicole, Debbie and Tim, Adam, and Eric. Great-grandfather of Alex Danielle. Service Tuesday, 10 AM, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPPERN, YALE W.
description: SAPPERN-Yale W. In New Haven, Ct., Feb 22, 1997. Husband of Pietrina Rizzo Sappern of 7 Melba St., Milford, Ct. He was Administrative Chief of Family Division of the Superior Court for the Judicial District of New Haven for 30 years and distinguished member of State Task Force Against Family Violence. Also survived by his mother Sally Sappern of Stamford and brother Donald Sappern of Westport. Funeral Wed 1PM at Celentano Funeral Home, 424 Elm St., New Haven, Ct.

title: Secrecy at Scholastic May Have Been in Vain
description: Activity was feverish at the New York offices of Scholastic Inc., the children's book publisher, last Thursday as the company prepared to release information that company officials knew would be taken negatively by investors.

title: Panel Pushes For Revival Of Spending On the Arts
description: A nonpartisan Presidential committee has warned that cuts in public, private and corporate spending on the arts and humanities are undermining cultural and educational institutions in the United States. In a report to be released today, the panel recommends wide-ranging measures to confront what it calls growing threats to the nation's cultural heritage.

title: Whitman Scales Back Borrowing Plan for Pension Funds
description: In the face of growing criticism over a plan to borrow $3.4 billion to help pay off the state pension system's unfunded liability, Whitman administration officials announced today that they would reduce the borrowing to $2.9 billion.

title: The Publisher of Army Times Hires Furman Selz to Sell It
description: The company that publishes Army Times, the unofficial weekly newspaper of the United States Army, is putting itself up for sale. The Army Times Publishing Company, a family-owned concern that also publishes Navy Times and Air Force Times, has hired Furman Selz Inc. to accept bids for the company, which has publications with a total circulation of 360,000 and annual sales of $50 million.

title: Evicted Family Gets Help in Avoiding Homelessness
description: Growing up in suburban Long Island, Joyce S. never lacked for anything. Her father worked hard as a machinist to provide for the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSKER, LENNIE
description: PINSKER-Lennie. Passed away at home Sunday, February 23, 1997. My loving wife of over 53 years. I love her. Cap

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Saturday headed ''The Favorite Stocks,'' listing the 15 issues with the most shareholders, provided outdated figures in some copies. BellSouth, for example, closed on Friday at 46 5/8, not at 45 5/8, and Intel closed at 146 3/8, not at 153 7/8.

title: Raising Money for Whitman
description: Fresh from a trip to California to raise money for other Republicans, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman plans to hold the first fund-raising event of her own re-election campaign tonight. More than 1,000 tickets, at $525 apiece, have been sold for the cocktail party at the Brunswick Hilton, her campaign manager, Tom Wilson, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURG, SAMSON
description: HAMBURG - Samson. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Steven and Debbi Hamburg and Marilyn and Zev Grossman. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Ilan and Michal Hamburg and Max and Rebecca Grossman. Loving brother of Ted Hamburg and Sonny Organ. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 B'way, Hewlett, L.I. Wednesday, 9:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MORRIS
description: SANDERS-Morris, 86, of Palm Beach, Florida, on January 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Toby, loving father of Carole and Jack Berger and Arthur and Dorothy Sanders. Grandfather of Jody (Bruce) Wenig, Jamie (Gary) Katz, Gerald (Brenda) Sanders and Holly Sanders. Great grandfather of Samantha, Cody, Eric, Dylann and Jacob. Services to be held Sunday, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon. Interment at Sharon Gardens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANKER, ALBERT
description: SHANKER-Albert. The members, officers and staff of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, AFL-CIO, CLC mourn the loss of Albert Shanker, an extraordinary trade union leader and a true champion of working people and their families throughout the world. Our sincere condolences go out to his family and to the members of his union. We will miss him profoundly. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, AFL-CIO, CLC Lenore Miller, President Stuart Appelbaum Secretary-Treasurer

title: Youths Charged in Killing
description: Five teen-agers from Hudson and Union Counties were charged yesterday in the December slaying of the stepmother of one of the youths, the authorities said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID MERRICK, the theatrical producer, has never been shy about trumpeting himself and, at 85, he is still at it.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Final Four Weeks, Kotite Was Lame Duck
description: Three months ago today, following the Jets' most decisive defeat of last season, Rich Kotite told the team's hierarchy that he would step down as coach when the season ended. The search for a replacement was on and it was at that moment, the team now says, that it targeted Bill Parcells, although it was not sure he would even be available.

title: All-Time Team Picked
description: Goaltender KEN DRYDEN, who played at Cornell from 1967-69, and defenseman CHRIS CHELIOS, who skated for Wisconsin in 1982 and 1983, are among 21 players who have been named to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship's all-time team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGER, PHILIP
description: TAGER-Philip, MD. Beloved husband and father died 2/23/97. Survived by wife Marcy, sons Mike, Andy, David, Geoff, and Ed and Al Blackman, daughter-in-law Lisa, grandchildren Alison and Daniel, sister-in-law Ann Kantor, and Susie and Gary Bank, and Amy and Olaf Van Genabeek. Also survived by special friend and professional colleague Bob Boyer, MD. Funeral 2/25, Wien and Wien, 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ at 1 PM. Shiva at 193 Elm St, Tenafly, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, SIDNEY
description: GARBER-Sidney. On February 24, 1997. Beloved husband of Sophie, loving father of Lynn Garber Weiden and father-in-law of Dr. Michael Weiden. Cherished grandfather of Aurora. Dear brother of Casper Garber. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGER, LILLIAN (LILA)
description: RIGER-Lillian (Lila), age 88 years, on February 24, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Martin. Beloved mother of Peter and Marcia Rochman, mother-in-law of Francine Wolf Riger and Alan Rochman. Loving grandmother of James and Gerald Riger and Jason Rochman, great-grandmother of Nicholas Riger. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel Inc., 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: W. R. GRACE FINDS BUYER FOR SPECIALTY POLYMERS UNIT
description: W. R. Grace & Company agreed yesterday to sell its Grace Specialty Polymers unit for $147 million in cash to the National Starch and Chemical Company of Bridgewater, N.J., a subsidiary of Unilever N.V. The specialty polymers business employs about 325 people and has plants in the United States, Belgium and Japan that make adhesives, coatings and films. The unit's 1996 sales were $73 million. The specialty polymers business was one of four businesses Grace said last October that it planned to sell off to invest in its core businesses. Grace, based in Boca Raton, Fla., also said yesterday that it planned to acquire Schurpack Inc., a maker of flexible food packaging in St. Joseph, Mo., with sales last year of about $20 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: His First Visit Is Likely to Be Last
description: For 10 years Hector Mendez had lived in the Bronx and, like many New Yorkers, had never set foot in the Empire State Building. It was always there, he thought, and one day when he had a day off from his job in a neighborhood bodega he would visit.

title: A Broadcaster's Brand-New Game
description: Larry Dierker could not adopt the attitude that it was just like riding a bicycle because he had never ridden this particular bicycle. But Dierker discovered a good feeling nonetheless when he dressed for his new job and didn't feel naked.

title: Ceremonies Honor Fliers Shot Down By Cuban Jets
description: Exactly one year after the Cuban Air Force shot down two airplanes belonging to a Cuban exile group based here, a memorial squadron today returned to the scene of the attack, honoring the victims without incident despite warnings from the Cuban Government.

title: The Potato Catcher Makes His Return
description: Dave Bresnahan opens the mailbox at his home in Tempe, Ariz., and occasionally finds a potato in it. Sometimes several potatoes. The potatoes have been sent to him by admirers, if you will, who request that he autograph and return them in the enclosed, self-addressed envelope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, EUGENE ''GENE''
description: WEINBERG-Eugene ''Gene'' of Pipersville, PA formerly of New York, New York, died Sunday night after a protracted illness. He was 86. Beloved husband of Emmeline Epstein Weinberg. Father of Michael and the late Alex. Grandfather of Mia Weinberg Clinton and Michael Weinberg, Jr. Great-grandfather of Keegan, Devin, Amber and Michael III. Relatives and friends are invited to his memorial service at 12:00 noon on Sunday, March 2, 1997 at the family residence at 6312 Carversville Road, Pipersville, PA. Friends are requested to make donations to their favorite charity. For information contact Reed & Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA.

title: Updating Some Kid Stuff for Serious Children
description: MICROSOFT Plus is a companion collection of programs that did not make it into Windows 95 for one reason or another, like Desktop Themes, with striking illustrations and icons; Drivespace 3, an improved compression agent, and 3D Pinball, which a couple of weeks ago I mistakenly said came with Windows 95. New this week is Microsoft Plus for Kids, with features aimed at the 3-to-12-year-old set, and an additional feature to ease parental concerns. The program should be widely available for less than $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODELL, ALLEN
description: PODELL-Allen Ph.D. Retired hospital Administrator, of Edison, NJ. Beloved husband of Selma, adored father of Brenda and Marlene, father-in-law of Dr. Armine Vafai and Mel Levy, grandfather of Jonathan and Scott. You will remain in our hearts and our thoughts. Rest in peace my darling.

title: Clinton, Despite the Controversy, Is Still on the Fund-Raising Trail
description: President Clinton was the star attraction tonight at a dinner for donors to the Democratic National Committee, each of whom had paid at least $10,000 to join the Democratic Business Council.

title: Navy Yard Seeks Growth
description: Hoping to cash in on the wave of retail development in downtown Brooklyn, directors of the Brooklyn Navy Yard industrial park said yesterday that they would seek development proposals for nine acres of the 300-acre city-owned park.

title: Sex Slayings Alarm France on the Peril of Repeat Offenders
description: The police of Boulogne-sur-Mer, a small town in northern France, ended their search on Friday for four missing young women: they found the bodies in a makeshift sandy grave on a nearby beach. The police said the young women -- two were 17 and two were 20 -- had all been raped and strangled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS DAVID
description: COHEN-Harris David. January 25, 1967-August 13, 1985. Happy 30th Birthday-wish we were celebrating together. Our memories are beautiful; our hearts are broken. Much love, Mom, Dad & Jonathan

title: Inflation Indicator Shows a Rise in Germany
description: German producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January, more than expected, and were up seven-tenths of 1 percent over the last 12 months, the Government said yesterday. Prices were unchanged in December. All of Germany's leading inflation indicators showed a pickup in price pressures last month, prompting the Bundesbank to drop hints that a further depreciation in the mark may not be ''in Germany's interest.'' The mark fell 6.5 percent against the dollar in January, pushing up the prices of imported goods.

title: Gunman Was Aided By Gap in the Laws
description: Ali Abu Kamal, the man who opened fire on the 86th-floor observation deck of the Empire State Building, was able to buy a gun in Florida by taking advantage of what the Federal Government concedes is a flaw in the enforcement of the nation's gun control laws.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One week ago, BONNIE FULLER published her first issue of Cosmopolitan magazine. Four days later she gave birth to her third child, LEILAH JONAH FULLER, who was born on Saturday. Ms. Fuller has succeeded Helen Gurley Brown as editor in chief of Cosmopolitan. Her husband, Michael Fuller, is an architect; the couple have two other children, Noah, 9, and Sofia, 6.

title: And Presto, We'll See Fewer Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Robotics Ships Modems
description: The U.S. Robotics Corporation said today that it had begun shipping new high-speed modems that allow customers to retrieve information from computer networks and the Internet at nearly double the speed of current modems.

title: What Did Asian Donors Want?
description: The question that recurs in much of the discussion of the unprecedented contributions to the Democratic National Committee from Asian sources is, ''What did these people expect in return?''

title: Madeleine Albright's Visit to China
description: The coincidence of Deng Xiaoping's death and the beginning of Bill Clinton's second term offers the hope that relations between the United States and China can be put on a more stable, productive track. Madeleine Albright made a good start in her brief visit to Beijing yesterday by talking candidly to the Chinese leadership about its continued abuse of human rights.

title: New Jersey Arts Center Names Its First Performers
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark announced an eclectic program ranging from the mainstream to the offbeat yesterday for its opening season, starting in October.

title: Accounts
description: * Anderson & Lembke, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $6 million to $8 million: Public Service Enterprise Group, Newark, as the first agency to handle its Energis Resources subsidiary, and Altec Lansing Technologies Inc., Milford, Pa., previously at Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWISON, LOUIS
description: LEWISON-Louis, 89, of Miami, FL, passed away on Friday, February 21, 1997. Mr. Lewison was a retired attorney who practiced civil law in New York City for over 40 years. For many years he was executive vice president and general counsel for the Amalgamated Mutual Casualty Co. in Queens, NY. His wife Jerry passed away in December of 1995. He is survived by his sons, Tom and Richard, daughters, Nancy, Diane, Nina, and grandchildren, Deborah, Rebecca, Jed, Emma, Lily; his sister, Helen Ostrow of Worcester, MA and his brotherin-law Boaz Brandmarker, Col., U.S.A. (Ret.) Private services were held. May his spirit be bound up in the bonds of life.

title: For Your Games, a Joystick That Pushes Back
description: A YELLOW disk on the screen is the virtual ball. A green line serves as a virtual slingshot. But when you wrap your fingers around a new kind of joystick and pick up the ''ball'' with the ''slingshot,'' this simple descendant of the game of Pong literally comes alive in your hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JUDAH
description: COHEN-Judah, M.D. A brilliant doctor, an incredible musician and my soulmate. Lila Tov Baby-Lila Tov With love, Janis, The Buber

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARASCO, ANGELINA
description: MARASCO-Angelina, on February 23, 1997. Beloved wife of Anthony. Mother of Robert Marasco and Carole Melillo. Mother-in-law of Alphonse. Grandmother of four and great-grandmother of four. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193 St, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:15 AM, St Luke's Church. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Study Faults President's Plan for Tuition Aid
description: Tax policies designed to make a college education more affordable, like those being proposed by President Clinton, might help make college more affordable for middle-income families but would not help the poor or increase overall access to higher education, according to a report being released today.

title: In Trump Revision, Highway Stays and Park Goes
description: The lambs were roaring in 1991 and the lion was bleating a bit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIMER, SOPHIE (NEE EISEMANN)
description: WERTHEIMER-Sophie (nee Eisemann). Died 2/23/97 in her 92nd year. Beloved mother of Henry Wertheimer and Ruth Rosenberg. Grandmother of four and greatgrandmother of twelve. She will be deeply missed.

title: The Gunman Premeditated The Attack, Officials Say
description: The Palestinian English teacher who unleashed a barrage of deadly gunfire Sunday on the observation deck of the Empire State Building carried out a premeditated attack, officials said yesterday, visiting the building the day before, and writing a two-and-a-half page condemnation of various governments that he carried in a pouch around his neck.

title: Deng's Smoking Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, GLADYS SHERR RITTER
description: LIVINGSTON-Gladys Sherr Ritter. With great sadness we record the passing of our beloved Gladys Livingston, a woman of style, humor and generosity. Mother of Toby and Nataly Ritter, Frances and Robert Weisman. Grandmother of Louis and Laurie, Ward and Loree and Adam Weisman; Louis, Victoria and Meridith Ritter. Great grandmother of the most precious Erin Rose. Aunt of David and Marie Ritter, Alan and Eileen Silverstein Ritter, Daniel Sherr, Irene and Leigh Breslau, Miriam and Gedaliah Wollosh. Stepmother to Peter and Ellen Livingston, Patricia and Richard Perlman. As the matriarch of our family, she has been a role model and an inspiration to many. She brought a joy and unity to her family that will endure as a living memorial. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., 10AM, Sunday, January 26, 1997. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAINES, MICHAEL CHRISTOPHER
description: GAINES-Michael Christopher, of Palisades Park, NJ on January 23, 1997. Beloved son of Nancy (nee Siegel) of Lancaster County, PA., and the late William M. Dear brother of Cathy Mifsud, wife of Dr. Stephen Mifsud, and Wendy Bucci wife of Robert Bucci. Dear uncle of Nicholas and Corey Mifsud, Patrick, Laura and Amy Bucci. Memorial service Sunday 12 Noon at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, New Jersey. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, ALAN W.
description: KATZENSTEIN-Alan W. On February 23, 1997 following a brief illness. Beloved husband of Rhoda (nee Kaplan), loving father of Paul and Ann Katzenstein, Fran Katzenstein, and Joy and Gary Levy, adoring grandfather of Sarah, Andrew, Jeffrey and Hannah. Funeral service today, February 25, 12:30 at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. Memorial donations to a charity of your choice.

title: Surprising New Particle Appears, Or on the Other Hand, Maybe Not
description: PHYSICISTS in Germany may have detected a bizarre hybrid particle called a leptoquark that, if it turns out to be real, could topple the reigning scientific model of how the world is put together.

title: Inquiry Into Gifts to Democrats Widens
description: The Justice Department today subpoenaed the records of Johnny Chung, a California businessman who gave $391,000 to the Democratic Party, and others who made large donations while seeking access to the White House, Government officials said.

title: South Korean Apologizes For Scandals
description: Seeking to salvage his final year in office, the embattled South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, apologized to the nation today for a corruption scandal that has engulfed some of his closest aides and was reported to involve his son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, MARTIN
description: ALTMAN-Martin, of NYC, in peace at home on Feb. 23, 1997. Cherished husband of Lois. Devoted father of Anita, Gary and Robert. Beloved grandfather of Matthew, Jill and Michael. President of Sarah David Altman Family Circle. Past chairman of Children & Infants Wear Division of UJA. Funeral services Feb. 25 at 11:15 AM at Riverside Chapel, NYC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to ALS Chapter of MDA, 10 E. 40th St., NYC 10016.

title: Chess
description: Joel Benjamin, a 32-year-old Manhattan grandmaster, won the 26th running of the Rilton Cup in Stockholm early this month. He tied with two other grandmasters at 7-2 in the international open Swiss-system tournament, but beat them out in tiebreak points to take the $2,400 first prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, IRENE B.
description: ROSEN-Irene B. Sister of Lillian Oxtoby and the late Alice R. Levithan. Graveside service 11 AM, Sunday, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Face-to-Face Meetings Fill In Cyberspace Gaps
description: There was chatter of virtual this and virtual that, talk of ''tele-presence'' and the diminishing need to go anywhere but on line, mention of a future in which colleagues will meet as holographic projections around computer-generated conference tables.

title: Business and Ethics Of Livestock Cloning
description: The cloning of an adult mammal gives the workaday science of livestock breeding an unaccustomed starring role in research. It was the sort of utilitarian study that would probably never have received a basic research grant.

title: O'Neill Might Not Be Ready to Go on Opening Day
description: The crowded Yankee outfield has become a questionable outfield with Manager Joe Torre expressing serious concern about Paul O'Neill's chronic left hamstring injury. Torre hinted today that O'Neill's strain might be a permanent problem and conceded that the right fielder might not be ready to play by opening day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHANON, EUNICE BLAKE
description: BOHANON-Eunice Blake. Died February 16, 1997. Widow of Paul and long time resident of East 80 St. and New London, NH. Daughter of the late James and Helen Blake of New Haven. Survived by her cousins Alfred P. Putnam, Anne Morrish, Helen Lilly and Catherine Goodrich. Contributions in her memory may made be made to the Smith College Fund.

title: Terrible Misfortune On a Chance Visit
description: Visiting New York had not been Patrick and Virginie Demange's first choice.

title: Observation Deck Draws Thousands as It Reopens
description: Tourists returned in force to the Empire State Building yesterday, drawn by brilliant sunshine and evidently undeterred either by Sunday's shooting rampage on the 86th-floor observation deck or by the beefed-up security precautions, which included newly installed, airport-style metal detectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIZER ELIAHOU, AVIVA
description: AIZER ELIAHOU-Aviva, at age 65, on January 23. Devoted and loving wife to Albert. Cherished and adored mother of Donald, Vivian, and Robert. Mother-in-law of Moshe and Bianca. Beautiful grandmother of Avi and Talia. Aviva was a beautiful flower in our lives. She will be missed, remembered and loved. Services today, 2 PM, Nassau North-Riverside Chapel, Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOEY, MARY W. (NEE NEE)
description: McGOEY-Mary W. (nee Nee). On January 22, 1997. Native of County Mayo, Ireland. Retired teacher N.Y.C. Public School System. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Maeve Scott, John, Peter, Desmond, Barry, Patrick and Bernard. Proud grandmother of Courtney, David, Kaylyn and Shannon. Reposing David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Ave), Yonkers. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30 AM Saint Paul the Apostle Church. Interment Saint Mary Cemetery (Yonkers). In lieu of flowers, kindly make donations to Burke Rehabilitation Institute, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, New York 10601.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONRADY, GEORGE
description: KONRADY-George. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George Konrady, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1982.

title: Bond Prices Edge Lower After Auction
description: Prices of Treasury securities bounced back from early lows yesterday, but investors resumed selling after results of the Treasury two-year note auction, although in line with expectations, were disappointing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JAFFIN, ALVIN. A
description: JAFFIN-Alvin. A gathering of friends and family in memory of Alvin Jaffin will be held on Saturday February 1, 1997 at 4PM in St. Paul's Chapel, 116th St between Broadway and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DANIELS, MARLENE D.
description: DANIELS-Marlene D. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, January 29, 1997, 4:30PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Seamen's Church Institute, 241 Water St, NY, NY 10038, attn, Doug Stevenson.

title: Voter Poll on Rowland Wavers on a Tax Issue
description: While 63 percent of voters say Gov. John G. Rowland is doing a good job over all, 48 percent disapprove of his handling of taxes, according to a Quinnipiac College Poll released yesterday.

title: Coffee Light
description: Move over, Leno and Letterman. Some of the cleverest ridicule of President Clinton's White House coffees for big contributors was provided last week by the people who run the Fairway supermarket at West 132d Street near the West Side Highway in Manhattan.

title: Cuba Embargo No Longer Makes Policy Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrei Sinyavsky, 71, Dies; Writer Was Sent to Gulag
description: Andrei Sinyavsky, a Russian dissident and writer whose imprisonment in the 1960's marked the end of the more liberal period after Stalin's death, died today at his home in the Paris suburb of Fontenay-aux-Roses. He was 71 and emigrated to France in 1973.

title: Loyal Ewing Has Van Gundy Clause
description: When the Knicks and Patrick Ewing sit down to discuss numbers in the off season, the franchise center has certain stipulations that will determine whether he finishes his career in New York. Amount and length of contract will be paramount, but now Ewing says there is another important factor as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEM, THERESA DE VOE
description: CREEM-Theresa De Voe, 90, widow of John J. Creem Jr. died at St. Francis Hospital after a long illness on January 23, 1997. A long time member of the Munsey Park and Sands Point Garden Clubs. She was a nationally accredited horticultural judge. She is survived by her 3 sons: Michael, Anthony and Timothy, seven grandchildren & 2 great-grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday from 3-5 PM and Monday from 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday 11 A.M., at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial donations to the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11225.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALUMINUM CO. OF AMERICA, Pittsburgh, the world's largest aluminum producer, agreed to acquire most of the assets of Inespal S.A., a Spanish state-owned aluminum producer with revenue of $1.1 billion last year. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Sugar Ray Can't Try The Marines
description: THE combination punches keep blasting Riddick Bowe. A sharp left to the midsection from the late Gen. George S. Patton. A hard right to the cranium from a clone of Snoop Doggy Dogg. And an Andrew Golota-style low blow from Donald Imus himself. And that was just 10 minutes of radio satire yesterday morning.

title: Fund Raiser Swells Whitman's Coffers
description: After spending four days last week in California raising as much as $200,000 for the New Jersey Republican State Committee, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was the host of a cocktail party tonight that was expected to raise as much as $800,000 for her re-election campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, ROBERT WILLIAM
description: SARNOFF-Robert William. Age 78, of NYC, died Feb. 22, at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Beloved husband of Anna Moffo, brother of Edward and Thomas, father of Rosita Sarnoff, Serena Benenson and Claudia Parrot; grandfather of Adam, Toby and Felicia Jeanne Benenson. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, Feb. 26, at 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave and 65th St. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56th St, NYC 10019.

title: The London Tube, in the Dumps, Could Be Put Up for Sale
description: Britain's Conservative Government today proposed selling off London's subway system, the oldest in the world and the transportation lifeline of a city built more for grace than for mobility.

title: Evolving China Merely Resembles a Dynasty
description: To the Editor:

title: Distant Hands That Provide Illegal Arms
description: A NUMBING shock hit Joan Davis when she learned about the shootings at the Empire State Building. She worked there, years ago, at an accounting firm. When horror descends on the familiar, the mind rushes to fill in the blanks.

title: In the Land of the Small It Isn't Easy Being Tall
description: A quick glance around is enough to tell the arriving visitor here that Ghana is a country designed for the abbreviated of stature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAHNESTOCK, FRANCES JEFFERY
description: FAHNESTOCK-Frances Jeffery. Of Boston, MA, January 17, 1997. Philanthropist, patroness of the arts, wife of the late Harris, Jr. J.S. Waterman & Sons Funeral Home, Boston, MA, 1-800-344-7526.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINRAUB, WILLIAM C. L.
description: WEINRAUB-William C. L. Age 49, of Norcross, GA. Beloved husband of Anita Z. Devoted father of Stephanie and brother of Jerome. Graduate of Horace Mann School, Yale University, University of Massachusetts, he was an accomplished businessman, craftsman, musician, and raconteur. His passing leaves a void in all our lives. Funeral at Riverside Chapel, Fleetwood, NY, noon Monday January 27. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla.

title: Torricelli Hires Ex-Diplomat Who Lost Security Clearance
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey has hired a former State Department official who was stripped of his highest security clearances last year because he told Mr. Torricelli of C.I.A. misconduct in Guatemala and identified one of the agency's informers there.

title: Sanofi of France Says Income Rose 11% in '96
description: Sanofi S.A., France's second-biggest drug company, said yesterday that its income rose 11 percent in 1996. The company, known for its blood-clot drug Ticlid and Yves Saint Laurent perfumes, posted a profit of 1.74 billion French francs ($307.61 million) in 1996, compared with 1.57 billion francs in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANLEY, HELEN SWENSON
description: MANLEY-Helen Swenson. At Lakewood, NJ, on January 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John Howard Manley. A longtime resident of New York, she was a valued member of the support staff of Sullivan and Cromwell, as secretary to Eustace Seligman, a prominent senior partner. Survived by her brother Victor H. Swenson, Jr., of Mantoloking, NJ, and several nieces and nephews. For information contact D'Elia Funeral Home of Lakewood, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, LOUIS SR.
description: FARKAS-Louis Sr. The President, Board of Governors, and the New York Board of Overseers, administration, faculty, staff and students of Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion record with deep sorrow the passing of Louis Farkas Sr., beloved fatherin-law of Rabbi Zahara Davidowitz-Farkas, Dean of the New York School. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his dear wife, Elizabeth, his family, Peter, Louis Jr. and Zahara. May God comfort the bereaved among them. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, President Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors Robert Heller, Chair, New York Board of Overseers

title: Museums and Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Welfare, Work and Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: A Whirl Beyond the White House for Stephanopoulos
description: Not every 36-year-old freshly arrived in Manhattan is immediately invited to dinner (and provided with a tuxedo) by Ralph Lauren, or to a lunch given by the Vogue editor Anna Wintour for Katharine Graham, or to an opening of the Byzantium exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, or to an evening of pizza with a clutch of New York intellectuals pondering the future of American labor. And, of course, not every 36-year-old new to town says he would like to run for United States Senate someday.

title: The Semiotics of Rubber Bullets in Israeli Society
description: RUBBER BULLETS

title: Where Vines Stair-Step Up the Hills
description: OVER the years, I'd tasted and enjoyed a few bottles from a California winery called Renaissance. I'd even noticed the odd appellation: North Yuba County. But I never bothered to look it up.

title: Birds Are Poisoned at a Park
description: Someone is poisoning geese and pigeons at Glen Rock Park, officials said yesterday. Since late January, officials have found 17 carcasses of Canada geese and pigeons, Peter Both, manager of the park's environmental center, said. All had been fed millet and wild sunflower seeds laced with a pesticide, he said.

title: New Agencies For 2 Accounts
description: Two advertisers have named new agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MARGUERITE (GRACIE)
description: ALLEN-Marguerite (Gracie). In order to accommodate the many friends that Grace has made over her long and fruitful life, the location and date of her memorial service has been changed to St. Bartholomew's Church at 51st Street and Park Ave on Tuesday, February 4 at 2:30pm. Howard P. Milstein Chairman Douglas Elliman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, S. MULFORD
description: COLE-S. Mulford, January 24, in the 92nd year of his extraordinary life, at home in Palm Beach, FL. So loved by his wife of 64 years, Sylvia (Peanut), daughter and sonin-law Carolyn and Fred Shulman, son and daughter-in-law, Richard and Ellen Cole, 5 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren, brother-in-law and sister-in-law Howard and Rosalie Aronson. Private graveside service on January 27. May he rest in peace.

title: Solid Profits From Retailers Spur a Late-Day Dow Rally
description: Wall Street was taken by surprise yesterday, as another late-afternoon rally lifted stock prices out of their morning slump. Aiding the rally were healthy earnings reports from Wal-Mart and Home Depot, as well as a technology comeback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDOR, EDNA (AINBINDER)
description: SIDOR-Edna (Ainbinder) of Armonk, Brooklyn and Queens, NY. Died suddenly on January 23, 1997. She was a joy and treasure who taught by example the fine art of living. She will be forever loved and missed by eight grandchildren, three children, one brother, nieces, nephews, in-laws, neighbors and the fortunate ones that she called ''friends''.

title: Devils Get Gilmour From Maple Leafs
description: The Devils traded youth today for the proven scorer who has been missing from the team for the last two years.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Feminists Deplore 'Flynt,' and Censorship, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Fish, Big Taste: The Dorade Royale Lands in New York
description: DORADE, a mouthwatering fish from the Mediterranean Sea, has captured the imaginations of European cooks for centuries. And now that a variety of dorade has become available in the New York area on a regular basis, it appears to have seduced some of Manhattan's most visible chefs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLTZMAN, HERBERT
description: HOLTZMAN-Herbert. Gone but not forgotten. Always remembered on your birthday. Phoebe and Leonard Lewin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, GLADYS SHERR RITTER
description: LIVINGSTON-Gladys Sherr Ritter. With great sadness we record the passing of our beloved Gladys Livingston, a woman of style, humor and generosity. Mother of Toby and Nataly Ritter, Frances and Robert Weisman. Grandmother of Louis and Laurie, Ward and Loree and Adam Weisman; Louis, Victoria and Meridith Ritter. Great grandmother of the most precious Erin Rose. Aunt of David and Marie Ritter, Alan and Eileen Silverstein Ritter, Daniel Sherr, Irene and Leigh Breslau, Miriam and Gedaliah Wollosh. Stepmother to Peter and Ellen Livingston, Patricia and Richard Perlman. As the matriarch of our family, she has been a role model and an inspiration to many. She brought a joy and unity to her family that will endure as a living memorial. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., 10AM, Sunday, January 26, 1997. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: New Study Faults Pentagon's Gay Policy
description: Three years after the Clinton Administration adopted a policy of ''don't ask, don't tell'' for gay men and lesbians in the military, Pentagon figures show that the number of service members discharged for homosexuality is far higher than it was before the policy went into effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENDOR, RENEE
description: SENDOR-Renee. Beloved wife of Mortimer S. Loving mother of Rabbi Meir B. and Benjamin B. Devoted grandmother of Shira, Atara, David, Noam, Julia, Adam and Willie. Dear sister of Edward Mettler. Services today at 12 Noon at ''Parkside Chapel'', 66th Avenue and Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Music in Review
description: In a Big Hall, a Big Sound,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRUCELLI, ROCCO JOSEPH II
description: PETRUCELLI-Rocco Joseph II, M.D., born on September 20, 1943, deceased Jan. 24, 1997, medical historian and author of ''Medicine, An Illustration.'' Graduate of Yale College, M.D. magna cum laude; History of Medicine, Harvard Medical School. Dr. Petrucelli received Boylston Medical Society Prize, Richard Cabot Prize and John McGovern Prize in the History of Medicine. He was a leader in the field of nephrology, Chief of Nephrology at New Rochelle Medical Center and President of End Stage Renal Network of New York State, and belonged to New York, America, and Interval Sources Nephrology. He is survived by his brother Robert Petrucelli, his niece Laura Rose and his companion Stephen Rzewuski. Visiting hours will be held at The William H. Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial in Christ Church, Rye, Tuesday 9:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Evolving China Merely Resembles a Dynasty
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Now Says It Knew Of Chemical Weapons Risk
description: The Pentagon acknowledged today for the first time that the Army blew up a sprawling ammunition depot in southern Iraq in March 1991 even though it had information at the time suggesting that the depot might contain chemical weapons.

title: Gaston Stirs Up a Storm, Not Olerud
description: John Olerud and Cito Gaston reacted with surprise today that comments by Gaston on the emotional mind-set of his former player had prompted the first Big Apple headline blizzard in Olerud's young Mets career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTOLO, VINCENETTE
description: ROTOLO-Vincenette, suddenly on 2/24/97 of Little Neck, NY. Beloved friend of Marguerite O'Connor. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Thursday and Friday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Services on Saturday 10am at the Funeral Home, with interment to follow in St. Johns Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGHIERI, MARIE. (NEE YANNERELLI)
description: BRAGHIERI-Marie. (nee Yannerelli). On January 23, 1997. Beloved wife of Martin. Loving mother of Cheryl King, Adele Brehler and Eileen Starace. Dear sister of Frances Rudzianis. Cherished grand mother of Alex, Maria, Christopher and Michael. Reposing at the Lloyd's Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave, Sat, 7-9 and Sun, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial on Mon, 9:45AM, St. Robert Bellarmine Church. Interment to follow.

title: Big Demand for Executives Last Year
description: The good times are definitely rolling for executive recruiters. But new industry statistics have a decidedly ''good news, bad news'' cast for the executives that recruiters place in jobs throughout corporate America.

title: Disney Chief Says Hiring of Ovitz Was a Mistake
description: It was a show of corporate might and razzle-dazzle, with equal parts of boastfulness and pomp, as the Walt Disney Company used its substantial skills today to entertain roughly 10,000 people gathered at a hockey arena for the annual shareholders meeting. And then Michael D. Eisner, at what should have been one of his greatest moments, deflated the excitement.

title: Drugstores May Go Public
description: Duane Reade Holding Corporation, which runs 60 discount drugstores in the New York City region, may make an initial public stock offering.

title: Pushing the Envelope On Favors for Donations
description: The picture of Democratic fund raising in 1995 and 1996 that emerged today from an avalanche of White House documents does not differ much from past practices in its basic outline. The Democrats did not invent a new system, but the documents show that, driven by President Clinton himself, they pushed the old one to the limit.

title: A Ban on Human Cloning Is Urged
description: Jumping into the debate started by the recent cloning of a sheep, a Republican State Senator said today that he wanted New York State to outlaw the cloning of human beings, even though science has yet to reach that frontier.

title: Kimberly-Clark Plans Split Of Stock and Sale of 3 Mills
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, seeking to strengthen its competitive position against its global rival the Procter & Gamble Company, announced a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday along with the sale of three pulp-paper mills.

title: Mr. Starr's Latest Stumble
description: Kenneth Starr cannot seem to get it straight that as Independent Counsel for the Whitewater investigation he should exercise good judgment and freedom from partisan ties. The latest example is his decision to accept, albeit after the investigation is over, a deanship that awaits him at Pepperdine University's new School of Public Policy.

title: UNITED AUTO BUYS DEALERSHIPS IN FLORIDA AND NEW YORK
description: United Auto Group Inc., a publicly held automobile dealership, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire nine dealerships in Florida and the New York area for $25 million in cash, $25 million in notes and about $3 million in United Auto common stock. The dealerships, which represent the Chrysler, Infiniti, Lexus, Nissan and Toyota lines, had an estimated $430 million of revenue in 1996. United Auto, which already operates 38 franchises in 7 states, could make additional payments of $4 million or more based on the performance of the dealerships and the value of the stock issued in the transaction. Separately, United Auto, which is based in New York, forecast that its first-quarter earnings would be 17 to 21 cents a share, below the consensus estimate of 25 cents a share. Following the announcements, United Auto's shares slumped $6.625, to $24.75.

title: Clinton Unveils Plan For Battle Against Drugs
description: Twice declaring that ''we know what works,'' President Clinton formally unveiled his $16 billion plan to combat drugs today, calling it ''a guide to action for the next decade,'' intended particularly to reverse rising drug use among children.

title: Yanks and Japanese Pitcher
description: Forty-eight hours before a scheduled executive council meeting, the Yankees were still trying yesterday to have Hideki Irabu declared a free agent. The Yankees sent three lawyers and two club executives to make a last-ditch effort to convince a four-man committee studying Major League Baseball's relations with Japanese baseball that they should be permitted to sign Irabu.

title: Connecticut Banks Merge
description: New England Community Bancorp said today that it had agreed to buy First Bank of West Hartford for $17 million in stock. New England, based here, had assets of $433 million as of Dec. 31, 1996. First Bank has assets of $84 million.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Metro Business column on Feb. 13 showing bankruptcy filings from 1990 to 1996 was published in error. The figures were for the nation as a whole, not for New York City. The source, the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, does not compile city figures separately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, SOPHIE GOLDBERG
description: MARCUS - Sophie Goldberg. Passed away Feb. 24. Wife of the late Fredric. Beloved mother of Linda Bakian and Marilyn Alper. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Joshua, Marielle, Daniel and Michael. Loving mother-in-law of Victor Bakian and the late Howard Alper. Adored sister, aunt and friend. Graveside services Linden Hill Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens, NY, Wed., Feb. 26 at 11:15 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGOW, ROSALIND
description: DUGOW-Rosalind. Beloved mother of Lois Neufeld and Leonard Dugow. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Matthew and Zachary. Fond mother-in-law of Victor Neufeld. Services 10 AM, Wednesday, Plaza Memorial Chapels, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Vote for Julia Child
description: To The Living Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINGLASS, MEYER F
description: STEINGLASS-Meyer F. Age 89. Of Bronx, N.Y., Westport, CT. and Manchester, N.H. passed away in peace on the morning of February 25, 1997. He spent over forty years in service to the Jewish community and Israel, with the United Palestine Appeal, United Jewish Appeal and the Israel Bond Organization, which he played a major role in forming in 1951. He retired as the Bond Organization's National Publicity Director in 1978. He was the devoted husband of his adored Mildred, who passed away in October, 1994, beloved father of Sandra and James Townsend, Edward and Claudia Steinglass and Henry and Judith Steinglass, loving grandfather of Ariel, Emily, Torrey, Julia, Sarah, Reuben, Daniel and Sabrina. Dear brother of the late Sam Steinglass and of Jack Steinglass and brother-in-law of Florence and Roselyn. His courage, wisdom, humor and gentleness will continue to nourish us. Services Thursday, February 27th, Weinstein Chapel, 1652 Central Ave, Yonkers, N.Y. 914-793-3800.

title: Of Froth, Grace and Vigor, To the Music of Delibes
description: ''La Source'' is one of George Balanchine's prettiest ballets. Its 19th- century Delibes ballet music (excerpts from ''La Source'') wafts lazily toward the ear or teases it with an oompah-oompah beat. Frothy pink tutus turn a female ensemble into Degas ballet girls; they are the cotton candy in a ballet that is otherwise sorbet.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in some editions on Monday describing the shooting on the observation deck of the Empire State Building showed the location of the gunman incorrectly. His body was found on the southeast corner of the deck, not the northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MORRIS
description: SANDERS-Morris, 86, of Palm Beach, Florida, on January 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Toby, loving father of Carole and Jack Berger and Arthur and Dorothy Sanders. Grandfather of Jody (Bruce) Wenig, Jamie (Gary) Katz, Gerald (Brenda) Sanders and Holly Sanders. Great grandfather of Samantha, Cody, Eric, Dylann and Jacob. Services to be held Sunday, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon. Interment at Sharon Gardens.

title: Guilty Plea by Ex-Executive of Archer Daniels
description: As part of an agreement to testify against fellow conspirators, a former executive with the Archer Daniels Midland Company pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiring to steal more than $300,000 from the giant grain concern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOOS, HOWARD
description: JOOS-Howard, M.D. Of Staten Island, New York, on Feb. 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Mona. Loving father of Dr. Richard Joos, Linda Sorrentino, Carole Cramer, fatherin-law of George Cramer. Also survived by eight grandchildren. For information Harmon Funeral Home, Staten Island.

title: Eating Well
description: IT was only eight years ago that oat-bran muffins were the rage. It didn't take long for the fad to fade. When people realized how much oat bran they had to eat to have any chance of reducing their risk of heart disease, they decided that one of those behemoths every morning for breakfast was more than they could tackle.

title: New Nets Starting To Click
description: The Nets are still learning to play together, but the transition is getting smoother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOUBIN, FRANCIS RENAULT
description: JOUBIN-Francis Renault. Of Toronto, Canada. On February 21, 1997. Discovered the Algoma, Canada uranium mines. 2 decades with the United Nations. Member of The Order of Canada and charter member, Canada's Mining Hall of Fame. Loving father of Marion Selig of New York, devoted grandfather of Marea Casas of Bogota and David Selig of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, PHILIP
description: DRUCKER-Philip. On January 24, 1997. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Mitchel and Harvey. Adoring grandfather of Teddy and Katie and Lee. Dear father-in-law of Susan and Jeri. Founder of Drucker Associates Real Estate Co. and co-founder of Philmar Fabrics, Inc. His wonderful, warm and charming personality drew everyone to him. His love of life was evident in everything he did. He loved to play sports, be with people and always enjoyed every moment. He had great wisdom and was a source of unlimited inspiration to his family. He will be loved constantly and always. Service Sunday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: America Online Reaches Big Marketing Deal With Tel-Save
description: America Online Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached a $100 million marketing deal with Tel-Save Holdings Inc., a reseller of long-distance telephone service.

title: For a Building A Bit Unusual, Ideas to Match
description: Two Columbus Circle, the eccentric 10-story building that was put up for sale by the city as part of the effort to redevelop the southwest corner of Central Park, has attracted seven proposals for new uses, ranging from a spiritual retreat to a complex of Spanish language radio stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDELMAN, MILTON
description: RANDELMAN-Milton, on Feb. 25 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Survived by his beloved wife Roslyn, his loving son and daughter-in-law Hal and Mary Randelman, two adored grandchildren Craig and Nicole Randelman, three devoted sisters: Jimmie Josephson, Beulah Glickman, and Evelyn Rifkin. Member of Congregation Emanu-El and the Friars Club. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday 7-9 PM, with service Thursday, 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, PAULINE (PEPPY)
description: BECKER-Pauline (Peppy). 1/18. Adored wife of the late Nat. Dearest mother of Alan and Barbie. Cherished grandmother.

title: U.P.S. Is First to Quiet Noisy Jet Engines
description: United Parcel Service said today that it had met the December 1999 Federal deadline for quieting noisy airplanes, becoming the first airline to do so.

title: DEAL BY MURDOCH FOR SATELLITE TV STARTLES INDUSTRY
description: Cable television and satellite companies around the country were roiled yesterday by the news that Rupert Murdoch had agreed to invest $1 billion in a new satellite service that could be the first full-fledged competitor to cable in its three-decade history.

title: An Abortion Rights Advocate Says He Lied About Procedure
description: A prominent member of the abortion rights movement said today that he lied in earlier statements when he said a controversial form of late-term abortion is rare and performed primarily to save the lives or fertility of women bearing severely malformed babies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX
description: TEMEL-Max. Beloved husband of Hannah (Hanka). Devoted father of David and Cory, Charles and Judy, Sofia and Jay Maisler, George and Shana. title: Port Authority Auctions Art
description: Art lovers and curiosity seekers spent $354,000 at two recent auctions of works belonging to the Port Authority, officials said yesterday.

title: GREAT WESTERN POSTPONES SHAREHOLDERS MEETING
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, the subject of a hostile $6.6 billion takeover bid from H. F. Ahmanson & Company, said yesterday that it would indefinitely postpone its annual shareholders meeting, which had been scheduled for April 22, citing ''recent and ongoing events.'' As part of its bid, Ahmanson, which is based in Irwindale, Calif., has proposed amendments to the bylaws of Great Western, which is based in Chatsworth, Calif., to provide shareholders with ''an opportunity to send the clear message to Great Western's board of directors that they support the Ahmanson merger proposal.'' The company has also said it would undertake a consent solicitation of Great Western shareholders for similar purposes.

title: New Mutual Fund Prospectus Being Prepared by the S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to extensively revise the mutual fund prospectus, the basic sales document used to detail the risks and investment style of funds, the commission's chairman said yesterday.

title: Caterpillar Acquisition
description: Caterpillar Inc. has agreed to buy most of the assets of the Swedish forest products manufacturer Skogsjan A.B. Terms were not disclosed. Caterpillar, the heavy-equipment maker based here, said Skogsjan distributed advanced forestry machines and equipment in Sweden, Norway, Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Britain.

Loving daughter of the late Wesley and Kathryn Renehan Paisley. Cherished grandmother of 15; great grandmother of 20. Contributions to St. Mary, Star of the Sea School Alumni Association, 1920 New Haven Ave, Far Rockaway, N.Y. 11691. Att: Rev. Sean G. Ogle would be appreciated.

title: MERCK SETS $5 BILLION STOCK REPURCHASE
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $5 billion of its stock on the open market. Merck, a leading drug maker, said it was completing a $3 billion buyback program announced in November 1995. Through Dec. 31, Merck spent $2.1 billion to buy 33 million shares under that program. The latest program was announced as Merck shares traded near their record of $99.875, reached on Feb. 13. The shares closed yesterday at $97.75, down 62.5 cents. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said it was also raising its quarterly dividend to 42 cents a share from 40 cents.

title: Personal Health
description: WHEN someone has a heart attack or stroke, it is common to wonder what might have set it off. Was it smoking, high cholesterol, obesity, diabetes, high blood pressure, inactivity, heredity, old age? In many instances, these cardiovascular events seem to happen out of the blue to people without any of the well-known risk factors.

title: Payton Takes a Number as Mets' Injuries Mount
description: The reverie the Mets were feeling this spring about the progress of several of their surgically repaired players burst like a balloon today when Jay Payton, their top prospect among position players, was felled by an injury to a right elbow that has already been operated on three times.

title: BANCORP HAWAII TO PAY $183 MILLION FOR CU BANCORP
description: Bancorp Hawaii Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire CU Bancorp, the holding company for California United Bank, in a deal worth about $183 million. Under the agreement, CU Bancorp shareholders will get rights to $15.34 a share in cash or Bancorp Hawaii stock. Between 60 percent and 80 percent of CU Bancorp stock will be swapped for Bancorp Hawaii stock. CU Bancorp's shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $14.375, in Nasdaq trading. Bancorp Hawaii edged up 50 cents to $45.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. CU Bancorp, based in Encino, Calif., has total assets of about $844 million. Bancorp Hawaii, of Honolulu, has 160 sites and total assets of about $14 billion.

title: Johnson Back With Parcells
description: Linebacker Pepper Johnson has agreed to terms on a two-year deal with the Jets, rejoining Coach Bill Parcells and the assistant head coach, Bill Belichick. Terms of the two-year deal were not announced by the team and were subject to Johnson's passing of a physical examination by the team early next week.

title: 'My Restless Aspiration Is to Murder'
description: Following is the text of a letter, released by City Hall yesterday, that was found on Ali Abu Kamal after his shooting rampage at the Empire State Building on Sunday. Italicized words were underlined in the English handwritten version.

title: Secretary to Mexican Patriarch Discloses Links to Drug Barons
description: The longtime private secretary to a patriarch of Mexico's governing party has told American authorities about a series of dealings between narcotics traffickers and high-ranking political leaders, including members of the family of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.

title: Pataki Signs a Bill Barring Ultimate Fighting
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today banning the competition known as ultimate fighting, in which combatants are allowed to do almost anything, short of biting and eye gouging, to beat their opponents.

title: Clinton Pressed Plan to Reward Donors
description: President Clinton two years ago personally approved a plan under which the Democratic Party rewarded some top donors and fund-raisers with meals, coffees, golf outings and morning jogs with him and with overnight stays in the Lincoln Bedroom, to ''energize'' them for the coming Presidential campaign.

title: The Drug-Certification Dance
description: This week President Clinton will decree which countries the United States deems uncooperative with American anti-drug efforts. The decision has been dominated by the question of whether Washington will be honest and deny full certification to Mexico, a close ally with a big corruption problem. The politicization of the debate is only one example of what is wrong with the whole certification process. It began in 1986 as a way to pressure supplier countries to fight drugs. It has not been successful and should be abolished.

title: City Council Gives Tattooing Its Mark of Approval
description: From beneath a black velvet top hat, a man who called himself Prince Vlad Marco smiled and rubbed a skull ring on his right hand yesterday as the New York City Council passed a bill legalizing and regulating tattooing in the city for the first time in more than 35 years.

title: Singleton Joins MSG
description: KEN SINGLETON, a Montreal Expos announcer for the last 12 years, has been hired by the MSG Network to call Yankee games this season. The cable network has been slow to hire a replacement for DAVE COHEN, whose contract was not renewed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, VALLE WEBER
description: FAY-Valle Weber. Of Rowayton, CT, who led the efforts to revitalize South Norwalk in the late 1970's and 80's, died Wednesday night in Norwalk Hospital of complications following an emergency operation. Beloved wife of Francis X. Fay, Jr. and loving mother of Valle Gaynor Blake of Brighton, MA, was 77. As Founder and President of the Norwalk Preservation Trust in 1977, Mrs. Fay arranged the educational programs and forums that redirected the focus of Norwalk's urban redevelopment from demolition to rehabilitation. Concurrently, as one of five Norwalk Redevelopment Agency Commissioners, she influenced the agency between 1978 and 1981 to adopt the rehabilitation of the Washington Street Historic District, a project that won two national awards in 1988. Mrs. Fay was one of five cited in the US Department of Interior Historic Preservation Award for the ''creative use of contemporary historic preservation techniques.'' The project was also selected and she was cited for the Downtown Development Award of the Downtown Research & Development Center of NYC, ''as a demonstration of public/private partnerships creating a vibrant downtown.'' ''Valle was the inspiration behind the city's approach to restoring the wonderful assets of South Norwalk,'' said former Mayor William A. Collins, who had appointed her to the Redevelopment Agency. ''I don't belive we could have gathered enough strength in the community to support the program without her effort.'' ''Valle was the pivotal person, and her voice was the stongest in saving the South Norwalk heritage despite the tremendous opposition at the time,'' said Rod Johnson, former Redevelopment Agency Excecutive Director. Mrs. Fay's interest in architectural antiquity had been inspired as a youngster by visits to St. Genevieve, Missouri, 60 miles south of St. Louis. Her paternal ancestors, the LaVallee family, had been among the early settlers in that first white development of Missouri (1735), and had produced three governors general of what was then known as the Louisana Territory. Mrs. Fay was Chairman of the Norwalk Green Historic Commission, Trustee and Secretary of the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum and served twelve years as a member and Vice Chairman of the Norwalk Historical Commission. Mrs. Fay had been Post Master of the Rowayton Post Office from 1961 to 1963. She had been a trainee with the Women's Air Service Pilots (WASP) during WW II. She was cited for her accomplishments in 1995 by Celebrate Women!, a Norwalk organization honoring women's achievements. Mrs. Fay was born in St. Louis on March 5, 1919, and raised in nearby Webster Groves, MO, the only child of the late John A. and Ethel Bass Weber. She was a gradaute of Mary Institute (1936) in the St. Louis area. She also attended Mills and Barnard colleges. She was predeceased in 1969 by a son, Robert E. Blake III. A memorial program will be held at 7 PM, February 2, at the Norwalk Maritime Aquarium. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Norwalk Museum, 141 East Ave., Norwalk, CT 06851, or the Norwalk Maritime Aquarium, 10 Water St, South Norwalk, CT 06854.

title: Clock Ticks Louder For Kings' Richmond
description: The best pro basketball player with the lowest national profile finished another shoot-around in another arena on another road trip in another season leading nowhere. Mitch Richmond dropped into a front-row seat under the basket for an afternoon chat yesterday at Continental Arena, still the heart and soul of a bunch of court jesters also known as the Sacramento Kings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, ROBERT K.
description: STRAUS-Robert K. formerly of New York City, died on February 24, 1997 at St Francis Hospital in Santa Barbara, CA. Straus is survived by his wife, Barbara, his daughter, Penelope More of Olema, CA and his son, Christopher Jesse of Santa Barbara. A stepson, Simon Flower, lives in Kingston, England. Penelope More is the mother of his two grandchildren, Braden More of New York City and Alexandra More of Olema, CA. Straus is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Isidor Straus. He graduated from Harvard College in 1927 and spent two years studying abroad at Trinity College, Cambridge; the Ecole des Sciences Politiques in Paris, and the Geneva School of International Relations in Switzerland. On returning to the United States, he entered and graduated from the Harvard Business School in 1931. He first worked for the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration of New York State and in Washington, DC for two New Deal agencies, the National Recovery Administration and the Resettlement Administration. Returning to New York in 1936, he was elected to the New York City Council in 1937 and served two terms. In 1942 he enlisted in the United States Army. After a year in the Pentagon, he went to London as a Military Government officer, assigned to the Civil Affairs staff at Supreme Headquarters. In 1958, he and his family moved from New York to Los Angeles, where he had purchased a bi-weekly newspaper in the San Fernando Valley. In this enterprise he, with partners, developed one of the first cold type and web offset printing businesses in California, Sun Litho, which they sold in 1980; after which Straus retired in Santa Barbara. In Santa Barbara, Straus served as a trustee of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art for a number of years. In the 1980s he and his wife established the Barbara and Robert K. Straus Thinking and Learning Center at Pace University in New York to encourage interdisciplinary education based on the work of Alfred Korzybski, the founder of the Institute of General Semantics. Straus had been interested in this approach to education and the study of decision-making for many years. He and his brother, Jack Straus, established a fund at the Harvard Business School in 1973 in memory of their father, for the same purpose. The funeral will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: A Warning As Science Catches Up On Cloning
description: ''When I found so astonishing a power placed within my hands, I hesitated a long time,'' Victor Frankenstein wrote, looking back at those innocent days before his laboratory-created man turned monstrous. ''I doubted at first whether I should attempt the creation of a being like myself or one of simpler organization.'' Well, there's his mistake; he should have started with a sheep.

description: Tony Williams, a drummer whose innovations made him one of the most influential jazz musicians of the last half-century, died on Sunday at the Seton Medical Center in Daly City, Calif. He was 51.
