title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, FRANCIS J.
description: CUNNINGHAM-Francis J. Major U.S. Army (Retired), 82 and the beloved husband of Dorothy Cunningham, died at his home in Venice, FL, on Monday, February 24, 1997. Born in Chicago, IL, October 3, 1914, Frank was the son of James Cunningham and Katherine Fitzpatrick Cunningham. He graduated from DePaul University in Chicago, and joined the Corporate Trading department of the investment banking firm of Kidder, Peabody & Co, Inc, in NY, in 1936. In June of 1942, Frank was inducted into the U.S. Army and was commissioned as a First Lieutenant at Fort Benning, GA in 1943. In World War II, he served with the 29th Infantry Regiment overseas in Iceland, Scotland, England, France, Belgium, Holland and Germany, and was wounded in the Battle of the Bulge in the Ardennes Breakthrough, for which he received the Purple Heart. He was also awarded the Legion of Merit and the Bronze Star for Bravery beyond the line of duty when he took over command of his unit after his Captain was killed on the battlefield. In the fall of 1945, Frank returned to Westport with the rank of Captain, after which he earned his Majority serving in the Army Reserves. He resumed his position with Kidder, Peabody & Co, Inc, in 1945 and was made a Senior Partner of that firm in February 1952. After serving as a member of the Board of Governors of the National Association of Security Dealers (NASD) from 1969 to 1971, he became Vice Chairman in 1971. He also served on the Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC) until his retirement from Kidder, Peabody & Co Inc, in 1972. During the 27 years he lived in Westport, Frank was active in forming the Saugatuck Fathers' Club for which he served as President for many years. He was also President of the Compo Beach Improvement Association. For the last 20 years of his residence in Westport, he headed the planning and directing of the Memorial Day parade, serving several times as Grand Marshall. After moving to Venice, Fl in 1975, Frank and Dorothy enjoyed playing golf at the Lake Venice Golf Club and the Buck Hill Falls Golf Club for over 20 years. In addition to his wife, Dorothy, Frank is survived by a brother, Bernard J. Cunningham, of River Forest, IL, three daughters; Sheila Perry of Amsterdam, NY, Gail Cunningham Coen of Westport, CT, Blithe Dotson of Newtown, CT, five grandsons, three granddaughters and one great-grandson. He is also survived by his first wife, Toni Cunningham of Westport, from whom he was divorced in 1973. He was predeceased by a sister, Mary Morrison, and a brother, James William Cunningham. For information Harding Lewis Funeral Home Westport, CT, Burial will be in Willowbrook Cemetery in Westport. There will be no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Primeco Switches To Richards Group
description: Primeco Personal Communications L.P. in Westlake, Tex., a national wireless communications services company, said yesterday that it had named the Richards Group in Dallas to handle the creative and account planning portions of its account on a trial basis, as well as to handle media buying permanently. All aspects of the account, with billings estimated at $35 million to $50 million, had been handled by Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Primeco had dismissed Angotti, Hedge in December after 10 months on the account. Primeco is an alliance of Airtouch Communications, Bell Atlantic, Nynex and U S West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEGON, IRA R.
description: LEGON-Ira R. on January 22, 1997, in Asheville, North Carolina. He was the former president of S. Appel and Company, the preeminent manufacturer of custom tailored uniforms in the United States. In his position, he was devoted to the success and prosperity of the uniform industry, of which he and his family were such a large part. He served as the president of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers and Distributors and was a member of its board of directors from 1977-1983. He was also the president of the Uniform Manufacturers Exchange for 25 years. He was an accomplished jazz pianist who adored music together with the friends with whom he made such precious melodies. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Sissel; his adoring children, Judson, Todd, and Suzanne; his cherished granddaughter, Rachel Rose; and his beloved brother, Allan.

description: He has not fought in six years. He is 40 years old. And Sugar Ray Leonard insists that his cash flow is fine, that nobody needs to show him the money.

title: Reclaiming the Hudson
description: Measured against other great cities of the world, New York has done a poor job of opening up its extensive marine environment to its citizens. Years of highway development and unimaginative leadership have denied New Yorkers easy access to the Hudson, one of the nation's premier rivers. So when an opportunity comes along to improve the waterfront, New York's political leaders should seize it, however much it pinches their budgets.

description: HOURIGAN-SMITH-Mary (nee Mary Ellen Hourigan). Died March 31, 1996. Services were held at English Bros. Funeral Home, 2203 Ave Z, Bklyn, N.Y. 11235. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: VW Says Income Doubled Last Year
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday in a preliminary report that its net income surged to 678 million marks ($401 million) in 1996, more than double the 336 million marks posted in 1995. Sales rose to 100.1 billion marks, compared with 88.1 billion marks a year earlier.

title: Tokyo to Propose Repeal Of Holding Company Ban
description: The governing coalition of Japan said today that it would move to repeal the nation's 50-year-old ban on holding companies, giving Japan's plan for financial deregulation its biggest boost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, JACQUES
description: COE-Jacques. The entire partnership of Cowen & Company mourns the passing of our longtime friend and eminent colleague, Jacques Coe, 103. Widely recognized as the oldest active broker on Wall Street, Jacques joined Cowen & Company in 1964 as a limited partner. He epitomized an exceptional standard of service and integrity in the financial services industry and will be missed by all who knew and worked with him. Jacques will be remembered for his consummate professionalism, keen market insight, vibrant personality and sense of humor. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Coe family. As Jacques was a founder of the American Chess Association, and past president of the Manhattan Chess Club, contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Chess-in-the-Schools, The American Chess Center, 353 West 46th St., NYC 10036. Memorial service will be held Sunday, March 2nd, 11:30AM, at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, NYC.

title: Bondholders Win a Round At Marvel
description: Score one for the bondholders in the fight over Marvel Entertainment. But the final victor remains unclear.

title: In wake of brief American Airlines strike, some second thoughts about consolidators' tickets.
description: THE short-lived American Airlines strike caused plenty of confusion but relatively little disruption among travelers, yet it is already generating some second thoughts among the growing number of business travelers.

title: Centennial Technologies Soars Though Delisting Is Next Week
description: Looking for a bullish story? How about this one: a company's chief executive is in jail, charged with falsifying its books. The stock is scheduled to be kicked off the New York Stock Exchange next Monday. And in two days, on phenomenal volume, the share price rises to $14.75 from $2.50.

title: New Tenants for a Popular Silicon Alley Building
description: In July 1995, amid much hoopla, the Rudin Management Company renamed a nearly 400,000-square-foot office building at 55 Broad Street the New York Information Technology Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, EUGENE ''GENE''
description: WEINBERG-Eugene ''Gene'' of Pipersville, PA formerly of New York, New York, died Sunday night after a protracted illness. He was 86. Beloved husband of Emmeline Epstein Weinberg. Father of Michael and the late Alex. Grandfather of Mia Weinberg Clinton and Michael Weinberg, Jr. Great-grandfather of Keegan, Devin, Amber and Michael III. Relatives and friends are invited to his memorial service at 12:00 noon on Sunday, March 2, 1997 at the family residence at 6312 Carversville Road, Pipersville, PA. Friends are requested to make donations to their favorite charity. For information contact Reed & Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA.

title: In Washington, Saudis Try to Ease Tensions on Bombing Inquiry
description: A senior delegation from Saudi Arabia, led by King Fahd's brother, began four days of talks with the Clinton Administration today, trying to repair a serious breach in relations caused by Saudi Arabia's investigation into the terrorist bombing that killed 19 American airmen in Dhahran last June.

title: Mexico Says Critical Report On Drugs Would Hurt Ties
description: Mexico warned today that any move by the United States to downgrade this country's standing as a partner in the effort to fight narcotics smuggling would jeopardize Mexico's future cooperation in the drug war.

title: No Headline
description: ''Ready to start overnights right away.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, RAE FISHBERG
description: GLANTZ-Rae Fishberg, 94, at home on Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. Widow of Harry; cherished mother of Geraldine, Janice and Lois. Beloved mother-in-law of Sidney Bergman, Robert Greenstein and Arthur Rosenfeld. Adored grandmother of the late Pamela, Susan, Ivy, Tod, Felicia, Carolyn and Sara. Loving great-grandmother of eleven. Devoted sister of Marte and aunt. A woman of incomparable grace, charm, intelligence and insight. She was a natural beauty whose character was as unforgettable as her face. A member of the Fishberg-Glantz musical family, her life was a symphony of great personal accomplishment, filled with warmth, love and serenity. She will be deeply missed. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, LOTTE
description: FRIEDLANDER-Lotte. On January 25, 1997. She is survived by a son Tomas, and granddaughters Jill Goroff and Amy Friedlander, as well as three great-grandchildren. She was 92 years old and lived life to the fullest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMONT, ROSE
description: LAMONT-Rose. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Rose Lamont, associated with The Times from 1923, until retiring in 1970.

title: New tourism ads try to show the French are fun after all.
description: THE French are coming.

title: Violence in Muslim Area In Western China Kills 2
description: At least one and perhaps two bombs exploded on buses today in the capital of China's westernmost province of Xinjiang, where Muslim separatists have rioted against Chinese rule. Two people were killed and dozens were wounded.

title: Internet Newsletter Writer Settles Charges
description: The author of several popular Internet newsletters on investing settled Federal charges yesterday that he had misled investors by making false claims about several companies and by failing to disclose that he was getting paid to promote more than 150 stocks.

title: Florida Man Put Bomb at Peres Speech, Police Say
description: The authorities in Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday charged an Orthodox Jew with planting a bomb at a Conservative Jewish synagogue on Feb. 13 only hours before Shimon Peres, the former Prime Minister of Israel, spoke to 1,500 people there.

title: Calls for Stricter Gun Control Laws Increase in Aftermath of Shooting
description: The chorus of public leaders and private individuals calling for stricter gun control laws after the Empire State Building shootings grew louder yesterday, as Clinton Administration officials began a review of Federal gun control policies and the relatives of a Montclair, N.J., man who was critically injured pleaded for tougher regulations and enforcement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAM, ANNA P.
description: BRAM-Anna P. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of our esteemed colleague, Anna P. Bram. An ardent Zionist, and devoted to Hadassah, Anna was beloved by Hadassah chapters in both Philadelphia and Southern California for her warmth, leadership and humor. She will be missed. May her memory be for a blessing. Marlene E. Post National President Beth Wohlgelernter National Executive Director

title: Polka: So Cheerful, So Competitive
description: Lenny Gomulka is heading to New York City to attend the Grammy Award ceremonies, hoping to finally strike gold on his seventh nomination.

title: A Step Too Far
description: ''There is no reason in principle why you couldn't do it.'' That's what Dr. Ian Wilmut, a Scottish embryologist, said of the prospect of cloning a human. But, said this man who had just successfully cloned a sheep, ''All of us would find that offensive.''

title: Evolving China Merely Resembles a Dynasty
description: To the Editor:

title: Cone to Get The Start On April 1, Torre Says
description: The Yankees performed a dress rehearsal for their spring training opener today at Legends Field before a sparse crowd under gray skies. It was a lazy atmosphere for the intrasquad game, but David Cone did not mind. He had a baseball and a mound, so he had a pitching laboratory to create in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, MAY W.
description: HARTMAN-May W., 97. Widow of Judge Gustave Hartman. Mother of the late Kenneth Hartman. She is survived by daughter Alicia Ashe, grandchildren Theodore, Andrew and Catherine Hartman and her daughter-in-law Polly Hartman, many nieces and nephews. She was the Founder of the Gustave Hartman YM-YWHA and for 25 years she was President of the Gustave Hartman Home for Children. Mrs. Hartman annually presented its world-famous All Star Shows in Madison Square Garden. She was active in many other philanthropies and the recipient of numerous awards and testimonials. She was an author and speaker. In lieu of flowers the family suggests contributions to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, Feb. 27, at 1:30PM.

title: Airport Buses to Go Private
description: In a move that will save the state nearly $5 million but may increase fares, directors of New Jersey Transit voted yesterday to let a private bus service take over the route between the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan and Newark International Airport, starting in April. By agreeing to pay $16 million over five years for the right to operate the route, the Olympia Trails Bus Company would become the only bus company offering service between Manhattan and Newark Airport.

title: Theater in Review
description: Powerless to Stop

title: Lott Joins Call For an Outside Investigation
description: Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, called today for appointment of an outside counsel to investigate President Clinton's campaign fund raising and said that if one was appointed, Republicans in Congress might abandon or sharply curtail their investigation into the fund raising.

title: $1.7 Billion Loss For Matsushita
description: Joining financial companies in reporting damage from Japan's debt crisis, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that it expected to lose as much as 204 billion yen, or $1.7 billion, from bad loans it made to real estate developers.

title: As Deng Joins the Immortals, Jiang Vows to Keep the Faith
description: As the center of this city came to a brief halt today, President Jiang Zemin delivered a final eulogy to Deng Xiaoping before 10,000 Communist Party faithful in the Great Hall of the People on Tiananmen Square. He promised to continue Mr. Deng's policies and invoked his own links to the legacy of Mr. Deng and Mao.

title: Nassau Comptroller Cites Continued Drop in Deficit
description: Nassau County had a deficit of $1.5 million last year out of a budget of $2.103 billion, Comptroller Fred Parola said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Clear Channel Agrees to Buy Eller Media
description: In a side step out of its core radio business, Clear Channel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Eller Media Corporation, a closely held outdoor advertising company, for $1.15 billion in cash and stock.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

description: WHEATLEY-Virginia Garling, February 17 in Richmond, VA, a longtime resident of Long Island and advocate for retarded children and the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Surviving are her husband, Dr. George M. Wheatley, and 4 children, Andrew T. Callan, Jr., John G. Callan, Douglas S. Callan, and Jean C. Baxter; 4 stepchildren, George M. Wheatley, Jr., Mary Ellen Rausch, Sarah G. Nichols, and William Bradford Wheatley; 20 grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children in Old Brookville, NY or North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Derails
description: Four cars of a freight train derailed on the Long Island Rail Road tracks near Hicksville, L.I., last night, disrupting rail traffic after 9:05 P.M., railroad officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, JAMES W.
description: AUSTIN-James W. Of Delray Beach, FL, on Wednesday, January 8. Cherished companion of Judy. Beloved friend of Ann and Susan, Ronald and Rob, adored Opa of Alissa, Sasha and Claire. Dearest Jim, we are proud to have been your family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUILE, DICKSON B.
description: GUILE-Dickson B., age 75, of Stuart, Florida. Died on Tuesday, February 25 at Martin Memorial Medical Center, Stuart. He was born and grew up in Rockville Centre, NY and was a longtime resident of Huntington, NY and moved to Stuart from Amityville, NY. He was graduated from Southside High School, Rockville Centre, Phillips Exeter Academy, and Princeton University, class of 1943. His entire business career was in textiles. At the time of his retirement in 1985, he was executive vice president of Greenwood Mills Marketing Company. In World War II he served as an officer in the field artillery in Europe. He was an arbitrator for the American Arbitration Society, a member of the Technical Advisory Committee of the American Textile Manufacturers Association, and was active in other textile oriented activities. He was an active volunteer for the Martin County unit of the American Cancer Society and a member of the Cocoanut Point Yacht Club. He was a past secretary and president of the class of '43 Princeton University and remained active in class affairs. He is survived by his wife Helen of Stuart, five children: Susan Souder of Gaithersburg, MD, Nancy Guile of St. Michaels, MD, Dickson B. Guile of Stuart, Leslie Puglisi of Parkland, FL, Keith S. Guile of Durham, NC, 11 grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Memorial services will be held 10:00 AM Friday, February 28th, at First Presbyterian Church, Stuart. Interment will be private at Forest Hills Memorial Park in Palm City. For information Forest Hills Funeral Home in Palm City. Memorial contributions may be made to the Martin County Chapter of the American Cancer Society, 1695 S.E. Indian Street, Stuart, Florida 34997.

title: Victim's Parents to Sue Iran
description: The parents of a Brandeis University junior from West Orange who was killed in a terrorist bombing in the Gaza Strip in 1995 said yesterday that they would file a Federal lawsuit today seeking $150 million in damages from Iran. Stephen and Rosalyn Flatow said that Iran sponsored the suicide bomber who drove his car into a public bus in April 1995, killing Alisa Flatow, 20, and seven Israeli soldiers.

title: Albright Comes Home
description: ''I'm deeply hurt that people think I'm lying,'' said Madeleine Albright yesterday afternoon, an hour after her plane touched down in Washington, bringing her home from her 11-day international tour. ''I have never been secretive about anything in my life. If a shrink wanted to deal with me, it would be primarily about the fact I talk too much.''

title: $12 Million Face Lift For Bloomingdale's
description: For the first time since the 1970's, the interior of Bloomingdale's flagship store, on Lexington Avenue at 59th Street, is getting a major make-over.

title: EMI Reports Drop In 9-Month Profit
description: The EMI Group, the British music company, said yesterday that the strong pound and weak holiday sales reduced nine-month pretax profit by 6.1 percent, though a promising fourth-quarter release schedule might bolster full-year earnings. Pretax profit before a one-time gain from asset sales declined to $:293.3 million ($478.6 million) in the nine months ended Dec. 31 from $:312.4 million a year earlier.

title: Parlez-Vous U.S.A.?
description: The frigate U.S.S. Carr pulled into Casablanca harbor last week and the U.S. Embassy held a reception on board, replete with Budweiser and chicken fingers, for local dignitaries. I dropped by and was soon conversing with a senior Moroccan official. Sporting a tailored suit and speaking elegant French, he explained why he was sending his two children to the American school in Casablanca, and not to the French schools where he was educated. ''Two reasons,'' he said. ''First, in the world we are going into if you don't speak English, you're illiterate. Second, the French system teaches you how to be an administrator. The American system teaches you how to survive on your own. That's what I want my kids to know.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, ETHEL

The account had been at Anderson & Lembke in San Francisco, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

description: Three undercover Israeli soldiers, evidently on a stakeout in this Palestinian village, shot and beat several residents today, killing one and wounding three, witnesses said.

title: Martin Slate, 51, Director of Federal Pension Benefit Agency
description: Martin Slate, the executive director of the Government corporation that insures the pensions of 41 million Americans and a civil servant repeatedly honored for innovative solutions to regulatory problems, died on Sunday night, the White House announced yesterday. He was 51.

description: With the support of 11 Republicans, some of them strongly opposed to abortion, the Senate today approved a Clinton Administration-backed resolution to speed up the release of money for family-planning programs overseas.

title: Internet Comes to Rescue: Web Site for Devil Dogs
description: For six months, Claude Dauman operated a Web site on the Internet that had a great appeal to many former East Coast residents: He sold Ring Dings, Devil Dogs, Yodels and Yankee Doodles, gooey chocolate snacks that are made in New Jersey and distributed mostly in the Northeast.

title: Remember the Neediest
description: A family burned out of its home is given help to avoid living in the street. A single mother receives money for food and shelter so that her child does not have to go into foster care. A onetime drug addict receives money for clothing so he can train for a job. These and other stories have stirred readers to respond generously to The New York Times Neediest Cases appeal for 1996-97, which ends Friday.

title: New Report Indicates Consumers Remain Optimistic on Economy
description: Americans' confidence in the economy remained extremely high this month, a report by the Conference Board showed.

title: New York Is What's Cooking in London
description: LONDON has become a restaurant boomtown. And one of the hot new spots is Nobu, a branch of the New York restaurant, which opened last week in a sleek space at the Metropolitan Hotel, 19 Old Park Lane. Nobu is owned by Robert De Niro; Drew Nieporent; Nobuyuki Matsuhisa, the chef, and Christina Ong, the hotel's owner. It offers typical Nobu food like shrimp tempura rolls and sashimi with warm sesame oil. Nobu follows Vong from New York to London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPIN, EARL
description: CHAPIN-Earl, on January 21, 1997 in Greenfield, MA. Beloved husband of Lynne Rudie, father of Kenneth (and Ellen), Paul (and Janice), Julia (and Alcides Filho), grandfather of Sarah, Matthew and Sarah, Godfather of Ingrid Rudie. Earl had a long and illustrious career as a french horn player, performing with the Casals Festival Orchestra in Puerto Rico, the Mostly Mozart Festival, Music from Marlboro, the 92nd Street Y Chamber Orchestra, and numerous chamber music groups, symphony, ballet, opera and theatrical orchestras, and recordings. When his health began to fail, he retired from music and moved from New York City to the Berkshires, where he gave much of his time to community endeavors, nature restoration projects, and his friends. There is no planned funeral service, but his friends will gather on Groundhog Day in the Berkshires to celebrate his life. For information, please call Abba Bogin at 212-663-4198.

title: Eating Tuna on the Ginza Without Ever Leaving Home
description: Americans never thought much about buckwheat noodles until Japanese food became fashionable. Since then, we haven't been able to get enough of them. The Japanese make soup with soba noodles or with udon noodles. Most supermarkets place soba and udon noodles on shelves beside Italian pasta. Italians have buckwheat noodles, too, called pizzoccheri. But you have to shop at an Italian market to find them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUSSE, ALEX
description: BUSSE-Alex. January 26, 1995 And tomorrow the sun will shine again And along the path that I shall take it will unite us, lucky ones, once again.

Sayres, Jr of East Haddam, CT., and 4 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held February 15 at 11:00 AM at The First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Nature Conservancy, 55 High Street, Middletown, CT. 06457 or to The Country School, 341 Opening Hill Road, Madison, CT. 06443.

title: Nationwide Terrorist Alert Leads to Two Innocent Men
description: For a time on Monday, they seemed to be the two most wanted men in America. The F.B.I. put out a ''terrorist threat advisory'' and released a composite sketch to the police and news organizations nationwide. The men were traveling in a rented U-Haul truck that might contain the makings of a massive bomb, the agency warned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, WILLIAM P
description: KELLY-William P, on February 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Dolores A. (nee Marlin) of Cherry Hill, NJ. Age 76. Loving father of Claudia Seaver of Ketchikan, AK and William G. Kelly of Cherry Hill. Devoted grandfather of Sean and Ryan Seaver both of Ketchikan, AK. Dear brother of James Kelly of Englewood, FL and a nephew George Togliatti of Las Vegas, NV. Viewing Thursday evening 7 to 9 pm in the Schetter Funeral Home, 304 W Rt 70, Cherry Hill, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10am in St. Pius X RC Church, Cherry Hill. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Cherry Hill. The family requests in lieu of flowers that contributions in his memory be made to the American Cancer Society, 410 White Horse Pike, Haddon Heights, NJ 08035.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, HOWARD WEAVER, JR.
description: McCALL-Howard Weaver, Jr., of Darien, CT, died at his home on February 24, 1997. Born in Chattanooga in 1907 and graduate of the University of Virginia, he retired as President of the Chemical Bank in 1972. He is survived by his wife, Jane, three children, Nancy Watson, Howard, III, Jane Politi, and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Noroton Presbyterian Chapel, 2011 Post Rd, Darien, Fri, Feb 28, 1997, 2:30 pm. Donations may be made in his memory to The American Parkinson's Association, 1250 Hylan Blvd, Staten Island, NY 10305-1946, or Mid-Fairfield Hospice, 112 Main St, Norwalk, CT 06851.

title: A Mayor Who's Intent On Keeping His Job
description: The nicely barbed Australian documentary ''Rats in the Ranks'' may be local in outlook, but it illustrates a universal political maxim: watch your back. Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson, the husband-and-wife team who produced and directed this film, have made the most of their extraordinary access to political infighting in a small municipality outside Sydney. In the process of showing exactly how Leichhardt (pop. 60,000) selects its mayor, they prove that it's a small world after all.

title: 'They Used to Call Me Oprah's Boyfriend'
description: HE looked and talked as if he had just stepped out of one of those glossy photos in Fortune or Forbes of perfectly pressed, unflappable corporate types. And as he glided into Nobu, the post-modern Japanese restaurant in lower Manhattan that is a daily destination for perfectly pressed, unflappable corporate types, Stedman Graham was all facts and figures.

title: Gruntal Executives to Lead Leveraged Buyout of Firm
description: Restless to pursue growth more aggressively, Robert P. Rittereiser, the chairman of Gruntal & Company, said yesterday that he was leading a group of senior managers in a leveraged buyout of the firm worth $235 million.

title: THERAGENICS IN MARKETING DEAL WITH JOHNSON & JOHNSON
description: The stock of the Theragenics Corporation jumped 40 percent yesterday after the company said it would give Johnson & Johnson the worldwide rights to market its Theraseed product for treating prostate cancer. Under the agreement, Theragenics, which is based in Norcross, Ga., will continue to manufacture and distribute the device, and Johnson & Johnson, of New Brunswick, N.J., will invest $5 million in Theragenics. Theragenics said the agreement is for seven years, with three-year extensions contingent on certain performance criteria. Theraseed is an implant that releases doses of radiation to destroy tumors. The device has been used in the United States since 1987. Theragenics' stock was up $7.375, at $25.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: F.B.I. Lab's Role in Impeachment Reviewed
description: A Justice Department investigation into complaints about the Federal Bureau of Investigation's crime laboratory has found evidence that the bureau may have provided misleading testimony about the results of forensic tests used in impeachment proceedings against a Federal judge, for his role in a bribery scheme.

title: An Author and Explorer in the World of Children
description: It was a quiet, gray winter afternoon, when only an occasional passing car or rustle of underbrush broke the silence of the surrounding pines, and Robert Coles was standing at his front door, pleading gently with his black spaniel to stop barking at the newly arrived guests.

title: 2 Democrats Say Mexico Is No U.S. Ally In Drug War
description: Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill objected today to the prospect that the Clinton Administration might certify Mexico as an ally in the war on illegal drugs as pressure to decertify Mexico grew. And even some senior Administration officials acknowledged that drug corruption had become so endemic throughout the ranks of Mexican law enforcement as to make cooperation difficult if not impossible.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHNNIE L. COCHRAN JR. has held forth in courtrooms and on television, and now he is about to acquire a new platform: the schoolroom.

title: Giant Food Stores Goes to Gray Kirk
description: Giant Food Stores Inc. in Carlisle, Pa., a unit of Royal Ahold of the Netherlands, which operates the Edwards, Giant and Martins supermarket chains, has named Gray Kirk VanSant in Baltimore to handle its consolidated account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

title: ENERGY COMPANIES DECLINE TO COMMENT ON SALE REPORT
description: The Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation and Total S.A. declined to comment yesterday on a report that they were in talks on a sale of Total's North American unit. The report in The Wall Street Journal said Ultramar, a refiner and owner of gas stations and convenience stores, was expected to pay $400 million and assume $430 million in debt to buy Total Petroleum (North America) Ltd., which is based in Denver. Ultramar, of Greenwich, Conn., said it would not comment on speculation. Total S.A. of France said it was considering merging its United States refining business with another company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODFRIED, RITA (NEE MARKS)
description: GODFRIED-Rita (nee Marks), of Suffern, N.Y. and Hollywood, FL., on 1/18/97. Devoted wife for 54 years of Abraham. Loving mother of Lois Bashoff. Cherished grandmother of Marilyn and Evan. Sister of Lillian Parmer and Ted Marks. Funeral service 1/20/97 Cedar Park Cemetery. Donations Hospice of Rockland County.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROOKS, B.
description: BROOKS-B. Rest peacefully in the knowledge your success as a role model and moral compass are embodied in the wonderful man you raised. A Loving Friend

description: GIORDANO-Antonio. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Antonio Giordano, associated with The Times from 1964, until retiring in 1992.

title: New York's Drug Court
description: To the Editor:

description: ZUCKERMAN-Joan, on January 24, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Robert Zuckerman. Dear mother of Donald and Donna, Barry and Roberta. Adored grandmother of Ethan, Elizabeth and Adam. Services Monday January 27, 10 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Read This Democrat's Lips
description: Representative Robert E. Andrews pledged yesterday to refrain from raising taxes for his entire term if he is elected governor. The promise came in response to a reporter's question and was not elaborated upon. But Pat Politano, a spokesman for Mr. Andrews, a Democrat of Haddon Heights, said afterward, ''Rob made a pledge he intends to keep.''

title: Study Cloning, Don't Ban It
description: In ''Songs of Innocence,'' William Blake asked, ''Little Lamb, who made thee?'' The answer for Dolly the sheep is Dr. Ian Wilmut and his colleagues at the Roslin Institute near Edinburgh. Dolly, as the world now knows, is a clone, a duplicate of one genetic parent. Her birth marks a milestone in our ability to engineer animals for food and medicine. It also signals that humans can, in principle, be cloned, too. That prospect troubles many people, but they ought not be too concerned about it at the moment.

title: Soybeans Hit 5-Month High As Global Demand Is Strong
description: Soybean prices rallied to five-month highs yesterday as strong exports and increased demand from domestic processors threaten to erode lean reserves in the United States.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Absence of Foreign Guests Shows Beijing's Attitude
description: When the Great Hall of the People filled with 10,000 people today for the memorial service for Deng Xiaoping, there were no foreign faces in the crowd.

title: Michael Jackson as Potent Aphrodisiac
description: ''Booty Call,'' Hollywood's first condom comedy, may also be the first movie whose main characters practically mummify themselves in plastic wrap. Bunz (Jamie Foxx), a streetwise young Lothario, and his best friend, Rushon (Tommy Davidson), have been ordered by their dates, Lysterine (Vivica A. Fox) and Nikki (Tamala Jones) to use plastic wrap if they expect to perform oral sex. Bunz is so eager that he promptly swathes his head with the stuff and almost smothers.

title: Democratic Strategists Took a Lesson From Republicans
description: The files of Harold M. Ickes show that the Democrats stole a page from the opposition's playbook by offering access to President Clinton and the White House in an effort to attract campaign money.

Artaserse, and her son, Peter, Jr. Funeral services Tuesday, 10:30 AM from the Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, Clifton and 11:00 AM at St. Philip the Apostle R.C. Church, Clifton. Visiting Sunday and Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: VISHAY OFFERS TO ACQUIRE GENERAL INSTRUMENT DIVISION
description: Vishay Intertechnology Inc. said yesterday that it had made a bid for the semiconductor division of the General Instrument Corporation, becoming the second company to seek the division. Neither General Instrument nor Vishay, an electrical component maker in Malvern, Pa., would disclose the bid price. The division has sales of about $360 million. General Instrument is also talking to Taiwan's Liton Group about selling the semiconductor division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBTUCH, DAVID
description: GELBTUCH-David. We extend our Kos Tanchumim to Benjamin Gelbtuch on the loss of his beloved father, David Gelbtuch. Benjamin, along with his wife Hadassa, are Golden Founders of the Hospital, benefactors of the Woman and Infant Center and long-time supporters of our Annual Dinner and Concert Sponsorship campaign. They have shown an extraordinary commitment to bringing compassionate healing to the people of Jerusalem. This outstanding expression of tzedakah and chesed, as demonstrated by their devotion to Torat Yisrael, Am Yisrael, and Eretz Yisrael, emulates the example set by Benjamin's father, who was a kind, gentle and loving man to all who knew him. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee of the Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Charles H. Bendheim, President Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Sidney G. Adler, Treasurer Lee Weinbach, Secretary International Board of Governors Menno Ratzker, Chairman Morris Talansky, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZBURG, JOE
description: SALZBURG-Joe. Our heartfelt sympathy to all his family. We will always remember Joe as a kind, warm, concerned human being who had a real zest for living and a tremendous love for his family. Donna and Philip

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIRESTONE, HENRY
description: FIRESTONE-Henry, of Evanston, IL and Bay Harbor, FL, died on February 20 in Miami, FL. Born January 13, 1917, in New York City, Mr. Firestone was a graduate of New York University and its Law School. Mr. Firestone served under General George S. Patton's Tank Division in Europe, participated in the Normandy Invasion, and rose to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He served as Military Governor of Bremen, Germany, during its occupation by the Allies. For fifty years, Mr. Firestone was active in New York City's Garment Center. Mr. Firestone is survived by two sons, H. Barney Firestone, (Lynne) of Evanston, IL and Jeffrey R. Firestone, of Bay Harbor, FL, and two grandsons, David Graham Firestone and Stephen Evan Firestone, both of Evanston. He is also survived by two brothers, Dr. Milton W. Firestone, of the Bronx, NY and Bernard W. Firestone, of Miami, FL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Cradle Society, 2049 Ridge Avenue, Evanston, IL 60201 or the National Stroke Association, 96 Inverness Dr East, Englewood, CO 80112.

title: Cuba Embargo No Longer Makes Policy Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Age Limits Set for Two Jobs
description: No one over the age of 35 can become a police officer or firefighter in New Jersey, and people in both occupations must retire when they reach 65, State Attorney General Peter G. Verniero said in an opinion issued yesterday. About 95 police officers and firefighters will be forced to retire in the next three months, he said.

title: Knicks Go South When Life Gets Tough Out West
description: The Knicks resembled a bunch of compulsive gamblers. They were up and down, and when it mattered most, they simply could not walk away from the table. They threw away everything. A hard-earned lead. Their poise. And, perhaps the most crucial game of their road trip.

title: Brooklyn Gas in Belfast
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that it would pay $75 million for a 24.5 interest in two natural gas concerns in Northern Ireland that are owned by BG P.L.C., formerly known as British Gas.

title: Judge Madeleine Albright by What She Believes
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Babies Eat Less Fat?
description: WHILE mothers and pediatricians have long considered a chubby baby a healthy baby, researchers in Finland are starting to look at just how much fat an infant needs in its diet and concluding that it might not be as much as many experts have thought.

title: With Iran's Aid, Guerrillas Gain Against Israelis
description: Apparently with help from the Iranian Government, the main guerrilla group waging a campaign against Israeli forces in southern Lebanon has made important gains in recent months in intelligence, weapons and tactics, Western diplomats and other experts here say.

title: 30 Brokers Fined In Test Fraud
description: Thirty of 53 brokers charged in the biggest case ever of brokerage licensing-test fraud were fined as much as $20,000 each yesterday after pleading guilty to felony charges of attempted forgery.

title: Correction: A Pork and Beans Stew
description: A recipe in the Plain and Simple column on Feb. 12 for a pork and beans dish that is more like a stew than a casserole and can be prepared in 20 minutes omitted instructions about draining and adding tomatoes. Here is a corrected version:

title: Ruling Ended Use of Race to Redraw Districts
description: Drawing districts dominated by black or Hispanic voters to insure they have a chance to elect candidates of their choice was a main remedy used to broaden minority participation in electoral politics under the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN INC. (PNU,N)
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc., the American-Swedish drug company, said yesterday that its earnings rose in the fourth quarter, though it warned that a stronger dollar and higher-than-expected costs for introducing new drugs could crimp 1997 results.

title: Journalists Prepare to Take On Serb President
description: Olja Beckovic, one of Serbia's brightest journalists, was back at work today after a forced interlude, drawing up a list of guests for the comeback of her popular television program and thinking again about the sharp questions she would put to fractious politicians.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARKIN, JUKI
description: ARKIN-Juki. March 26, 1933 - January 27, 1996. Dearest Juki Aba, every day you are in our thoughts. We miss you and your funny ways. We'll always love you. Jonathan and Helene Sara

title: Huskies End at 27-0 And Keep Promises
description: Good basketball teams focus on the present, not the future, and the Connecticut women are certainly a good team, ranked first in the nation for the last 10 weeks. But they can be forgiven for sneaking a few thoughts about last year before they routed Syracuse, 86-52, tonight and completed a perfect regular season of 27-0.

Donations funding the creation of a memorial ''Michael's Chair'' can be made to SIT, 115 Bank Street, #

title: 'Annie' Replaces Its 12-Year-Old Star
description: The producers of ''Annie'' have replaced the 12-year-old star, Joanna Pacitti, with an understudy, Brittny Kissinger, who is 8. Miss Pacitti had been playing the title role during the show's pre-Broadway tour, which began in Houston in November. ''Annie'' is scheduled to begin performances on March 14 at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: Abortion-Rights Backers Defend Stance on Late-Term Procedure
description: Advocates for the abortion-rights movement today dismissed the contention by a member of the movement that they had all knowingly misled the public about the circumstances and frequency of a particular late-term abortion procedure.

title: More Gun Control Isn't Answer to Shooting
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping-Cart Solution
description: So many Jersey City residents take shopping carts home from supermarkets and then abandon them that the authorities in November set aside a lot for abandoned carts, and 400 carts are stored there now, said a spokesman for Mayor Bret Schundler. Last night, the City Council voted 8 to 0 to authorize the Department of Public Works to begin charging a $5 daily storage fee for store owners who want to retrieve their carts. The measure would also allow the department to auction off unclaimed carts to grocers and scrap-metal dealers, said the spokesman, Tom Gallagher. The idea is to encourage store owners to take measures to protect their carts, he said. TERRY PRISTIN

description: KNOX-Samuel Doughty, 86, of Stonington, CT., retired VP of RH Macy Corporation, former resident of Glen Ridge, NJ. Survived by his wife, Katherine (McLean) Knox; a son, H. title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Lawmakers Approve Bill Allowing City to Borrow
description: Just months before New York City would have hit a borrowing limit preventing it from spending billions of dollars on school construction and other projects, the State Legislature yesterday passed a bill allowing the city to get around the law that set the debt ceiling.

title: Empire State Gunman Gave No Hint of Anger, His Hosts Say
description: Late on the afternoon of Dec. 31, Ali Abu Kamal showed up at the Saudi Mission to the United Nations and said he was looking for Taysir H. Badanoro, a high school friend from the Middle East whom he had not seen in more than 30 years.

title: Too Close to the Bone
description: Using machines to get meat off the bones of cow carcasses may be faster than doing it by hand, but it is not necessarily safer. A recent U.S. Department of Agriculture study showed that pieces of bone, bone marrow and spinal cord sometimes get into the meat, raising the possibility of health hazards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, EDWARD SHELDON
description: STEWART-Edward Sheldon, age 91, died January 21 after a long illness. Survived by wife of 43 years, Shirley, sister, Beatrice (Babbie), children Helen, Sheldon (Shelley), Anthony (Tony) and Francesca (Francie), 7 grandchildren (Shellie, Scott, Sean, Michael, Jenny, Peter and Jaryn), 2 great grandchildren (Krysta and Justin), their spouses, and close companions. His eldest son, Edward (Ned) died last October. He was a happy man who enjoyed every minute of his life. We will miss him.

title: NOVELL INC. (NOVL, NNM)
description: Novell Inc. said yesterday that its earnings fell 20 percent in the fiscal first quarter, falling below analysts' expectations as sales slowed in Europe and Japan.

title: Dr. Frankenstein's Furniture Makes House Calls
description: IN these days of managed care and malpractice fever, furniture from the time of house calls, ether and laudanum is making its way into the living rooms, dining rooms and bedrooms of America. Shops and flea markets around the country are asylums for collections of medical storage cabinets, steel shelving, surgical lamps, operating tables, hospital chairs and instrument sterilizers.

title: A Pair of Muses, Above It All
description: ''YOU can shower naked out of doors in total privacy,'' promised the fashion illustrator Ruben Toledo. And he does. Neighboring skyscrapers and passing falcons notwithstanding, Mr. Toledo and his wife, the fashion designer Isabel Toledo, have created a reclusive world in the theatrical, high-ceilinged penthouse loft they share atop a 19th-century building on Broadway south of Herald Square.

title: Evidence Of a Planet Is Inaccurate, Scientist Says
description: A Canadian astronomer has challenged evidence for the existence of the first planet reported found around another Sun-like star, saying the phenomenon observed 16 months ago is actually caused by the star's own pulsations, not the gravitational effects of an unseen planetary companion.

title: France Blasts European Parliament for Attacking Immigration Bill
description: France, which has spent heavily over the years to make sure the European Parliament stays in France, bitterly attacked it today for criticizing a French bill to crack down on illegal immigration.

title: Gifts Lag as Campaign Reaches Its Final Days
description: Tomorrow marks the end of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's 85th annual appeal. With $4,738,756.96 recorded to date, the fund remains about $77,000 behind last year's total, which was the second best in the fund's history.

title: Claims and counterclaims fly as two giants battle for supremacy in the antihistamine market.
description: HAY FEVER season may be months away, but claims and counterclaims have been flying between the makers of the top two brands of prescription antihistamines, Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc. and the Schering-Plough Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: ''Jesus Christ doesn't want his followers to be angry with anyone. Being in prison a long time made me learn patience and some English.''
