Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Abraham Sinnreich, M.D., Pres.

title: Job Insecurity of Workers Is a Big Factor in Fed Policy
description: For months now, the Federal Reserve has been poised to raise interest rates, but has held off. Why?

title: REGAL-BELOIT TO BUY MARATHON ELECTRIC FOR $240 MILLION
description: The Regal-Beloit Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Marathon Electric Manufacturing Corporation of Wausau, Wis., for $240 million in cash. Marathon Electric is a private manufacturer of electric motors, generators and related products and had 1996 revenue of $245 million. Regal-Beloit, based in Beloit, Wis., is a supplier of power transmission equipment and cutting tools. Its stock closed yesterday at $20.875 a share, up 12.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Storm Takes to Boards To Hold Off Seton Hall
description: Close games have been St. John's specialty this season. But it has only been recently that the Red Storm has been winning them.

title: Out of the Past, A Modern Vision
description: EVEN to fans of American modern furniture, Edward Wormley (1907-1995) is not exactly a household name. But a retrospective of his work, ''Edward Wormley: The Other Face of Modernism,'' should help remedy that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTTON, AUBREY WHITELEY
description: DUTTON-Aubrey Whiteley, age 86, of Brooklyn, NY, on January 25, 1997, in Allentown, Pennsylvania. Born on August 23, 1910 to Lawrence Amor Dutton and Eunice Holt (Whiteley) Dutton at Twin Oaks, Delaware County, Pennsylvania, on a farm owned by the Dutton famly since 1682. Resident of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn since 1916. Graduate of P.S. 99, James Madison High School and Pratt Institute, Class of 1932. Artist and cartoonist whose work appeared in The Saturday Evening Post, Colliers Magazine and other national publications and whose paintings hang in homes and offices all along the Eastern Seaboard, but his greatest role in this life was as the totally devoted and loving husband of fifty-two years of his wife, Ruth M. Dutton (nee Andorfer) and as the extraordinarily caring and nurturing father and best friend of his son, Richard L. Dutton, of West Orange, New Jersey, and his daughter, Barbara L. Dutton, of Allentown, Pennsylvania, by whom he will be greatly missed. He was also loyal and unselfish in his concern for his other relatives and his many longtime friends. Funeral arrangements handled by Horace Schantz Funeral Home, Emmaus, PA; memorial service at later date to be announced. Contributions in his memory to Kings Highway United Methodist Church, Brooklyn, New York, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BITTKER, ANNE S.
description: BITTKER-Anne S. Of New Haven, Ct., died in her sleep on Feb 2, 1997 at the Connecticut Hospice of Branford, Ct. She graduated from the Horace Mann School for Girls in New York City and Connecticut College for Women. She was active in many New Haven civic and charitable organizations, including the League of Women Voters, the Friends of the New Haven Library and the Fair Haven Soup Kitchen. She is survived by her husband, Boris I. Bittker, by her two children Susan of Edinburgh, Scotland and Daniel of San Francisco, by her sister Margaret S. Kahn of Chicago and her brother, Carl Stern of Lynchburg, Va. Memorial contributions may be made to the Friends of the New Haven Public Library, 133 Elm St., New Haven 06510 or to Connecticut Hospice, 61 Burban Drive, Branford, Ct 06405. There will be a Memorial Gathering at the New Haven Lawn Club on Saturday, March 22 at 2:30 PM.

title: Family Calls for Help to Find Student
description: Friends and strangers alike answered the pleas of a young man's father yesterday and began searching Manhattan streets, stopping in homeless shelters, riding subways and papering bus stops with fliers in the hope of finding a Fordham University student who disappeared after wandering away from a bar on the Upper East Side 10 days ago.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about new disclosures of official corruption in Mexico misstated the given name of the Governor of Sonora. He is Manlio Fabio Beltrones, not Mario.

title: Jokes Come Easily; Worries About Consequences Soon Follow
description: First came a fusillade of humor, a rat-a-tat-tat of cleverness worthy of Letterman and Leno.

title: New Financial Chief Appointed at RJR
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it had named David B. Rickard chief financial officer, replacing Robert S. Roath, who is retiring early.

title: Knicks Scramble Out of Jam In Overtime
description: One moment the game was slipping through their fingers. The next moment Patrick Ewing, Coach Jeff Van Gundy and Charles Oakley were bumping chests and celebrating a stirring survival encounter on the road.

title: Investors Fear a Fast-Food Price-Cut War
description: Wall Street was hardly enthused yesterday by the McDonald's Corporation's plan to cut the price of its Big Mac sandwich sharply as a way of bringing in more customers and increasing sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DYKE, FRANK
description: VAN DYKE-Frank. The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York mourn the passing of former Board Member and member Frank Van Dyke. Mr. Van Dyke's dedication to children and the issues they face in NYC made him an especially valuable and impassioned advocate on their behalf. Edythe First, Chairman Martha Olson, President Gail Nayowith, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, ROBERT K.
description: STRAUS-Robert K. The Trustees and members of the Institute of General Semantics mourn the death of their former President and longtime supporter. His leadership was fundamental to the growth of the Institute. He will be sorely missed.

title: Ion Cioaba, 62, of Romania, Self-Styled King of All Gypsies
description: Ion Cioaba, who proclaimed himself King of All Gypsies Everywhere but wielded most of his meager influence as a political gadfly in his native Romania, died on Sunday at a hospital in Bucharest. He was 62 and reportedly died of a heart attack.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Suspension by Crew
description: An appeals court has overturned Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's suspension of the District 12 School Board in the Bronx. In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected the basis for Dr. Crew's action in suspending the board last Aug. 20.

title: Surgery for U.S. Player
description: As the United States prepares for the final round of qualifying for the 1998 soccer World Cup in France, the team will be without forward JOE-MAX MOORE for six to eight weeks, officials said yesterday. Moore left training camp in Miami to undergo surgery in Boston for what was described as a chronic abdominal-groin injury.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DANIELS, MARLENE D.
description: DANIELS-Marlene D. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, January 29, 1997, 4:30PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Seamen's Church Institute, 241 Water St, NY, NY 10038, attn, Doug Stevenson.

title: Big Night for Love Songs at the Garden
description: Love songs reigned at the 39th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, held last night at Madison Square Garden and telecast by CBS.

title: New Directors at Regional Theaters Find Scrounging for Money Is Part of the Job
description: When Douglas C. Wager announced in November that he would step down in 1998 as artistic director of the Arena Stage in Washington, he left its board of trustees on unfamiliar ground. Never before in its 47-year history has the Arena, one of the nation's first regional theaters, had to look outside its own family for a leader.

title: Defense Motion Denied In Oklahoma City Case
description: The Federal judge hearing the Oklahoma City bombing case in Denver yesterday denied a motion by defense lawyers that he hold a pretrial hearing to determine the admissibility of scientific evidence processed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Steinbrenner a Meddler, Torre Says in His Book
description: Joe Torre indicates in an autobiography to be published next month that the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, was more meddlesome during the 1996 season than the manager had previously revealed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: After Greenspan Warning, Dow Closes Down 55.03

title: Republicans' Budget Amendment Is Headed for Defeat in the Senate
description: Republican hopes for a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution were crushed today when Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the last senator to state a position, announced that he would vote against the measure.

title: 3Com Plans To Acquire U.S. Robotics
description: The 3Com Corporation said today that it would acquire the U.S. Robotics Corporation in a $6.6 billion stock swap that would create the second-largest computer networking company.

title: EXXON STOCK TO SPLIT 2 FOR 1 AFTER 33% RISE IN 13 MONTHS
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would split its stock 2 for 1 effective March 14, with new shares distributed beginning on April 11. Exxon's share price has risen 33 percent in the last 13 months. Exxon, which is based in Irving, Tex., has 1.24 billion shares outstanding. ''A lower share price should contribute to an increase in the shareholder base and improve market liquidity,'' said Ed Burwell, a spokesman for the company. Shares of Exxon fell $1.375, to $102.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PATRICIA SCHROEDER, who left the House of Representatives in January after 12 terms, has a new job. She has been named the president and chief executive of the Association of American Publishers, the trade group for the book publishing industry. She is to take over on June 1, when she finishes teaching at Princeton University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETL, JOHN
description: BRETL-John of Barrington, RI. Our friend, a gentleman for all seasons. Successful investment banker, accomplished artisan and sailor. His analytic mind, intellectual curiosity, keen eye and love of perfection were apparent in all he undertook. We will remember his love of family, warmth, wit, and calm and his quest, always, for excellence. His counsel will be missed and we offer sincere condolences to his beloved wife, Valerie, and family. Mitchell Gibbons-Neff family Andrew Lawrence family Morris Propp family

title: Social Security Proposal Doesn't Spread Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSLANDER, LOUIS
description: AUSLANDER-Louis. The faculty, students and staff of The Graduate School and University Center of The City University of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Louis Auslander, Distinguished Professor of Mathematics and Computer Science and faculty member since 1971. We extend our most sincere condolences to his family. Frances Degen Horowitz President

title: Southern Monuments
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, IRVING A., D.D.S.
description: GERBER-Irving A., D.D.S. A man of accomplishment and good humor, who excelled at everything he attempted-dentistry, musicianship, athletics and most of all fatherhood. Beloved husband of the late Paula, father of Marc and Terry, grandfather of Lauren Partridge and Michelle Gerber, greatgrandfather of Alexandra Partridge. Services to be held at Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, 11 AM, Monday, January 27.

title: Art in a New Frame: Internet Exhibition
description: Ada Web, an on-line site dedicated to original art and produced in New York, is one of four sites being considered for an on-line collection of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, RITA C.
description: LEWIS-Rita C. on Tuesday, February 25, 1997 of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved wife of Milton F. Lewis, devoted mother of Patricia A. Lewis, Maureen W. Corbett and Vincent J. Lewis. Loving grandmother of four grandchildren. Funeral Saturday 9 AM from the Volk-Leber Funeral Home of Teaneck, 789 Teaneck Road. A Mass of Christian Burial will be at 10 AM from Holy Trinity R.C. Church. Interment following, St. Joseph's Cemetery, Hackensack, NJ. Memorial donations can be made in lieu of flowers to: Our Lady of Victories Homes of Charity, 780 Ridge Road, Lackawanna, NY 14218 or Immaculate Conception Seminary, 400 So. Orange Avenue, So. Orange, NJ 07079. Visiting Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLAHER, JOHN PATRICK
description: KELLAHER-John Patrick. January 25, 1997. Loving companion of Laura Prato. Loving brother of Kathryn Miller and Anne Kellaher. Loving uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., today, Monday, 2:305 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church.

title: 2 Agencies Get Samsung Work
description: The Samsung Group in Seoul, South Korea, said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationships with the Arnell Group in New York and Cheil Communications in Seoul, by naming those agencies to share responsibilities in developing worldwide branding strategy. Billings have not been determined.

title: Ordonez Will Sit Out a Few Days to Rest His Arm
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine had just learned some good news about Jay Payton's injured elbow and decided to add his opinion that it is better to talk about elbows than shoulders, because shoulder injuries are invariably more serious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNES, FRANK P.
description: BARNES-Frank P. Husband of Dorothy. Son of the late Doris Plummer Barnes, former Senator, U.S. Territory, Alaska, and the late Frank Scott Barnes, proprietor Salmon Canneries in Alaska, passed away February 21, 1997. Father of Margaret A. Barnes of NYC. He was a graduate of Stanford University School of Engineering. He was a resident of NYC for the past 34 years. Mr. Barnes was a senior vice president of telecommunications for ITT of New York and retired in 1979. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Workfare Is a Job With Rights Like Any Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMPERIO, CULLINAN, ANNE M., PH.D.
description: IMPERIO-CULLINAN-Anne M., Ph.D. Director of Fordham University Counseling Centers. On January 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Thomas. Loving mother of John and William. Daughter of Grace Imperio and sister of Leonard Imperio, both of the Bronx. Reposing Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY (one block north of Tuckahoe Road), on Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Fordham University Chapel (Rose Hill Campus, Bronx). In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Cabrini Hospice, New York, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERSON, BEATRICE (BILLIE)
description: MERSON-Beatrice (Billie), 80 years old, died February 26, 1997two days short of 60th wedding anniversary. Formerly of Bronxville, New York, she recently moved to Goshen, NY. Former proprieter of BAM Liquors of Mt. Vernon, NY, she is survived by husband, Carl, two daughters, Ann Bialek and Miriam Shapiro, 11 grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her son, Robert. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York, on February 27 at 1 PM.

title: 2 Flight 007 Settlements
description: The families of two New Jersey residents who were killed in 1983 when a Korean Air Lines jet was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane will receive a total of $4.3 million in a settlement with the airline, lawyers said yesterday.

title: More Gun Control Isn't Answer to Shooting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JANSON, RICHARD W. (RICK)
description: JANSON-Richard W. (Rick) Feb. 27, 1946 to Dec. 20, 1987. ''Here's looking at you, kid.'' Love always, Frank Nash

title: Robert Kenneth Straus, 91, Heir Who Served in Agencies
description: Robert Kenneth Straus, a member of one of New York's leading merchant families who turned instead to government service, publishing and, most recently, founded a center for the support of analytical thought in decision-making, died on Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. A former resident of New York and San Francisco, he was 91 and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: Life With Father: Incestuous and Soul-Deadening
description: THE KISS

title: Expanding The Trite To Reveal New Poetry
description: ''Eventide,'' the startling new work with which the Paul Taylor Dance Company opened a new season on Tuesday night, is about love and life. No subject could seem more trite, and it is a measure of Mr. Taylor's greatness as a choreographer that he explores this theme with such depth and poignancy.

title: Ruben Rivera's Injury Worse; Surgery Likely
description: Ruben Rivera was slumped on a couch in a storage room next to Joe Torre's office, with a baseball cap pulled down tight over his moist eyes and a glum expression on his face. Rivera, the Yankees' elite prospect, had just been informed he would not play baseball for at least three months because of impending arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder. He did not have to utter a syllable to express his dejection.

title: Will a New Frogdesigner Make Frankfurt Chirp?
description: FROGDESIGN, the design princes of Silicon Valley, will open a New York office. And they have persuaded Tucker Viemeister, one of the founders of Smart Design, the New York industrial design firm, to head it. Call it a case of like (the company that helped create the user-friendly Apple computer) meeting like (the man whose team devised Good Grips housewares, with their ergonomic handles).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEWETT, NANCY R. (TUCKY)
description: JEWETT-Nancy R. (Tucky). Age 54, of New York City and Lyme, CT., of cancer on February 25, 1997. Wife of Jonathan. Mother of Brooke, Lindsay and Ian. Memorial Service Saturday, March 8th at 11:30AM at Old Lyme Congregational Church, Old Lyme, CT. She was actively involved with the Conservatory Garden in Central Park, and the inspiration for her family's garden in Lyme. Gifts in her memory may be made to Wave Hill Inc., 675 West 252 St., Bronx, NY 10471 where she volunteered her time and energy for many years.

title: Gilmour Ignites Devils' Offense In a Hot Debut
description: The Devils could not have asked for a more awe-inspiring debut by a player. There was Doug Gilmour, newly arrived from the Toronto Maple Leafs, skating at center, skating on wing.

title: Cable System Is Sabotaged
description: Saboteurs disrupted the cable television system of T.C.I. of Northern New Jersey Tuesday night by slicing through four distribution wires at the company's main signal-processing facility, the police in Pompton Lakes said. Service to 22,000 homes was knocked out for more than nine hours, David Capo, a spokesman for T.C.I., said. Other homes lost transmissions for about three hours. The company serves 215,000 homes in 53 towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, DONALD
description: BEER-Donald, age 61, of Princeton, New Jersey. Husband of Nancy. Father of Frederick, Cyrus and Catherine, brother of Andrew Beer and Marguerite Platt. Service at Trinity Church, Princeton, 12:00 Saturday, February 1.

title: Scanning the Web: When Home Sites Are Worth a Click
description: TAKE away the glossy paper and lavish images that have long been key components of home-design magazines, and you may well ask what is left.

title: Mortician Charged in Thefts
description: A Whippany mortician stole more than $50,000 from 10 clients who paid for their funerals in advance, according to a complaint filed Tuesday with the New Jersey Board of Mortuary Science. The State Attorney General's office said that L. Richard Smaldone, 52, the owner of Braviak Funeral Home, placed the money he received between July 1994 and October 1996 into his own business account rather than into interest-bearing funeral trusts on behalf of his clients, as state law requires.

title: Crime in Region Is Dropping, But Some Pockets Defy Trend
description: Serious crime in the ring of cities and suburbs around New York City has fallen to its lowest level since at least 1980, an analysis of data for the last 16 years shows. But it has not dropped nearly as far as it has in New York City, and it appears to be rising again in a few of the region's most troubled urban areas and the fastest growing suburbs.

title: CPC TO SPIN OFF ITS CORN-REFINING OPERATIONS
description: CPC International Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its corn-refining business and focus on its food brands. Terms of the spinoff to shareholders, expected to be completed by the end of the year, were not disclosed. The maker of Hellmann's mayonnaise and Skippy peanut butter said it might make an initial public offering of stock in the company before the spinoff. Shares of CPC rose $2.75, to $84.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. CPC, which is based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., plans to spin off its corn-refining operations in the United States, Canada, Latin America, Asia and Africa and a joint venture in Mexico. Sales from those operations were $1.5 billion in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAN, CATHERINE (NEE DWYER)
description: HOLLAN-Catherine (nee Dwyer), age 91, February 22, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John, dear sister of James, Thomas and Margaret Gordon, all deceased. Survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial is on Wednesday, March 5, at 10 AM at St. Joseph's RC Church in Garden City, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, New York 11792.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DEBORAH SANDERS
description: LEWIS-Deborah Sanders, on January 25, 1997 at home in Darien, CT. Loving mother of Rebecca Anne and Jesse Austin Lewis. Sister of Dona, Mrs. Alexander Y.P. Garnett, also of Darien, and the late Susan Sanders Henck and infant daughter, Katie. Daughter of Durward and Anne Sanders of NYC. Memorial services will be at St. Jame's Church, 865 Madison Ave., NYC on Thursday, January 30 at 4 PM and at St. Luke's Church, Darien, CT on Saturday, February 1 at 11 AM. Contributions may be sent to the Deborah Sanders Lewis Trust Fund at Lafayette American Bank, 20 West Ave., PO Box 1265, Darien, CT 06820; Attn: Mr. Robert A. Locke.

title: Frankel Assignment From Oldsmobile
description: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had named Frankel & Company in Chicago as its first national promotional marketing agency of record. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: Mr. Torricelli's Turnaround
description: Senator Robert Torricelli of New Jersey swallowed an embarrassing campaign promise yesterday and vowed to vote against the ill-conceived balanced-budget amendment. His no vote will effectively bury the amendment for the foreseeable future. Had Mr. Torricelli decided to vote yes, the amendment would probably have carried the Senate and moved on to a closely divided House.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX
description: TEMEL-Max. The directors and staff of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York extend sincerest condolences to Board Member Charles Temel on the death of his beloved father. May Charles and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Philip Schatten, President David Mann, Executive Vice President Stephen A. Kramer, Chairman of the Board

title: When Money Counts
description: LET'S face it: a hook is a compromise. But it can be an interesting compromise between an out-of-control pileup on a chair and a well-organized closet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, HELEN
description: BECK - Helen. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Helen Beck. Her deep devotion to the Jewish heritage will be missed by our synagogue family. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her loving family. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Jack B. Levitt, President

title: Helmets Lagging Behind In Gaining Acceptance
description: Chip Carey, a winter-resort executive and father of a ski racer, was doing it all at age 50: mountain biking, kayaking, sailboarding, snowmobiling, motorcycling, playing hockey, and, oh yes, skiing.

title: Enron Utility Merger Approved In Move to Expand Nationwide
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved the Enron Corporation's $3.2 billion purchase of the Portland General Corporation yesterday, using for the first time a procedure intended to speed up the glacial pace of adjudicating utility mergers.

title: Mercer County Weighs In
description: In the gubernatorial primary, State Senator James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge won the endorsement yesterday of the chairman of the Mercer County Democratic Party Chairman, leaving only Atlantic, Passaic and Essex County leaders undecided. ''It was a tough decision,'' said Alan Karcher, the Mercer chairman. Mr. Karcher, a former Assembly speaker, employed Mr. McGreevey as an aide in the early 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUG, PAUL L.
description: KRUG-Paul L., 83, of Boynton Beach, Florida, passed away on February 25, 1997. Mr. Krug was an executive with the Krug Baking Company of New York and H.D. Catty Company in Connecticut. He was a graduate of Canterbury School, New Milford, CT and Yale University 1936. Mr. Krug is survived by his beloved wife, Ella Galvin Krug; loving father of Pamela K. Boalt, Karen Krug, Sueanne Miller, Judith McLean, Paul Jr., John and Peter; fifteen grandchildren and five great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Maryknoll Fathers, Maryknoll, NY 10545 or to Alzheimer's Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONICK, BEVERLY
description: RONICK-Beverly. My loving soulmate, David, Susan, and Rick's ''Mom'', Brian, Alex, and Erin's ''Ganma'', you dedicated your life to making our world a good and happy one. You exceeded your goals. We'll be together always. The family will receive friends at 142 East 71st Street on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Ave., c/o Beverly Ronick Memorial Cancer Research Fund.

title: Some EU Countries Fear Effects of Fiscal Dumping : Europe Struggles With Tax Policy
description: BRUSSELS  For the economically depressed region of Liege in eastern Belgium, the factory making balloon catheters for angioplasties was a ray of hope in an otherwise bleak landscape, providing 200 jobs in an industry with a bright future.

title: Devils Deal, One Banner At a Time
description: JUST a little more. That's what the New Jersey Devils were looking for Tuesday when they traded young talent to Toronto to get Doug Gilmour and Dave Ellett. Just two old hands who could make the Devils better -- right here, right now, which is all that matters in sport.

title: Swiss to Share Control of Holocaust Fund With Jewish Groups
description: After 18 months of tortuous and sometimes secret negotiations that flared into public bitterness, the Swiss Government agreed today to share control of a Holocaust memorial fund with leading Jewish groups. The fund was set up after criticism of Switzerland's financial dealings with Nazi Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, SIDNEY
description: GARBER-Sidney. He will be sorely missed, but long remembered. In lieu of flowers, send donations to The Foundation for the Jewish Community. The Silvermans

title: Files Detail Big Effort to Raise Money
description: On May 3, 1994, President Clinton sat down with some of his closest advisers to talk about the never-ending campaign to raise more money.

title: Making a Star of Key's Spangled Banner
description: How do you clean a huge old piece of cloth that is a national symbol, the subject of the anthem that is sung, if with some difficulty, by every American?

title: Court Outlaws New York District Drawn Up to Aid Hispanic Voters
description: A Federal court declared yesterday that the mostly Hispanic 12th Congressional District in New York City was unconstitutional because race and ethnicity were the dominant factors used to draw it. The ruling is expected to lead to new boundaries for many of the city's 14 Congressional districts, forcing some incumbents to defend their seats in the next election in unfamiliar neighborhoods.

title: For a Moody Poet of Folk, an Unmournful Tribute
description: Sunday's tribute at the Bottom Line to Townes Van Zandt, the influential Texas singer and songwriter who died of a heart attack on Jan. 1, was powerful and moving. But it wasn't any more powerful or moving than Mr. Van Zandt's own performances.

title: Ann Taylor on the Move
description: Ann Taylor will be relocating an East Side Manhattan store and opening a new one in the Flatiron district. The women's apparel maker has leased 5,900 square feet at 850 Third Avenue, at 52d Street, and will relocate the store it has had for more than 10 years in 8,000 square feet at 805 Third Avenue, at 50th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, HYMAN
description: SPECTOR-Hyman. Fine artist. Survived by his wife, Shirley, daughters, Susan and Karen and grandsons, Jason and Nicholas. For information contact Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 E, Paramus, NJ.

title: More Gun Control Isn't Answer to Shooting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLABMAN, SOL., A.K.A. STEPHEN GRAY
description: GLABMAN-Sol., a.k.a. Stephen Gray, age 75, on Feb. 23. Beloved husband of Thea, loving father of Jonathan, brother of the late Bernice Epstein and brother-in-law of Rabbi Gilbert Epstein. Actor, then business representative for Actors' Equity Association, 1966-1987. Interment was private. Donations may be made to The American Heart Association or the Actors' Fund. ''Now cracks a noble heart.''

title: Immigration's Automation Plan Criticized
description: A $2.2 billion project to automate many of the Immigration and Naturalization Service's most important tasks, including airport inspections and tracking illegal immigrants, is in trouble, the Justice Department's inspector general said today.

title: U.S. Officials Dispute Police About Failure To Find Bomb
description: The State Department and police officials in Jacksonville, Fla., traded accusations yesterday about who was responsible for not finding a crude pipe bomb that was planted in a Jacksonville synagogue only hours before former Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel gave a speech there on Feb. 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MARGUERITE (GRACIE)
description: ALLEN-Marguerite (Gracie). In order to accommodate the many friends that Grace has made over her long and fruitful life, the location and date of her memorial service has been changed to St. Bartholomew's Church at 51st Street and Park Ave on Tuesday, February 4 at 2:30pm. Howard P. Milstein Chairman Douglas Elliman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNECKE, JOSEPH F.
description: WARNECKE-Joseph F. On Feb. 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Ann (daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C.S. Radford, Jr. of Louisville, KY). Loving son of Edward and Ellen. Brother of the late Teresa and James. Reposing Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 Street, NYC on Thurs. Visiting hrs 5-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM, Sacred Hearts Church, 307 E. 33 St, N.Y. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul and the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX.

title: Greenspan Speaks and Stocks Plunge
description: Alan Greenspan rattled the markets yesterday. Within 10 minutes of the Federal Reserve chairman's Senate testimony yesterday morning, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 102 points, before a partial recovery to close down 55.03 points at 6,983.18. Interestingly, that one-day loss mirrored the one that occurred the day after Mr. Greenspan's now much-quoted ''irrational exuberance'' remark last December.

title: Cal Abrams, Part of Lore Of Dodgers, Is Dead at 72
description: Cal Abrams, a Brooklyn Dodger outfielder whose otherwise ordinary career was punctuated by an extraordinary moment underlining the Brooklyn fans' lament, ''Wait Till Next Year,'' died on Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 72.

title: Better Than Steel King
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPP, BERTHA
description: RAPP-Bertha. On January 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Emanuel Rapp. Loving mother of Shelley and Jay Friedland, Marion and Louis Sanders. Adored Nanny to Amy and Robert Fisher, Erica Friedland and Charles Sanders. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary last Thursday about President Jiang Zemin of China referred incorrectly to the education of his predecessors as the country's paramount leader. He is not the first with a college degree; Sun Yat-sen, who ruled Nationalist China from 1921-25, had a medical degree.

title: Board Seems to Clear Way for School Repairs
description: A vote by the Board of Education last night appeared to clear the way, after long delays, for the spending of $1.4 billion over the next four years on badly needed school repairs.

title: Comparative Shopping
description: To The Home Section:

title: 'Wondrous Bugs' and Fantasy Landscapes at Flower Shows
description: THE conjurers of spring will crack the back of winter this Sunday as the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society opens its annual Philadelphia Flower Show, 10 acres of fantasy landscapes and amateur exhibits entitled ''The Great Exchange: People, Places and Plants,'' at the Pennsylvania Convention Center, at 12th and Arch Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, SOPHIE
description: ORENSTEIN-Sophie. A woman of grace and dignity. Beloved mother of Melvin, David and Michael. Adored mother-in-law of Martha, Jeanie and Barbara. Grandmother of Jeffrey, Richard, Geri, Pamela, Elizabeth, Heather, Sarah and Hope. Great-grandmother of Abraham. Funeral service, Monday, 12:30 PM, Boulevard West, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: China Press Now Lacks Tea Leaves
description: On Red Star Lane, a narrow alleyway in downtown Beijing where tiny stalls compete for space to sell fruit, comic books, socks and newspapers, it was the newspapers that sold swiftly this afternoon.

title: Korean Chip Makers See Profits Plunge
description: The Samsung Electronics Company and two other leading South Korean computer chip producers reported 90 percent plunges in profits in 1996, staving off losses only by changing their accounting methods. Computer chips are Korea's largest single export item.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, LILLIAN
description: HAMBURGER-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Loving mother of Michael and Andrea, Richard and Lisa. Cherished sister of Dora Portnick and Rivi Wasserman. Adored grandmother of David, Gillian, Adam and Amanda. Funeral services today, 10 AM, at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I. J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: Building Trouble in Jerusalem
description: Pressed by right-wing parties in his governing coalition, Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has authorized work to go forward on a long-debated new housing project for Jews in Har Homa, a highly sensitive area of Jerusalem. In doing so he has ignored American counsel for delay and the strong objections of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was not exactly a private moment when JAMES BROWN, the Godfather of Soul, proposed to ROLONDA WATTS during a taping of her talk show, ''Rolonda,'' on Tuesday.

title: INSIDE
description: Renewal Eludes Economy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANKER, ALBERT
description: SHANKER-Albert. The officers, members and staff of the Jewish Labor Committee mourn the death of Albert Shanker, President of the American Federation of Teachers, longtime activist in the free trade union movement nationally and in New York City. A dedicated leader of our organization, he served as Secretary of the JLC for more than two decades. His lifelong commitment to working men and women, his steadfast opposition to prejudice and oppression, leave a legacy for us all. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Edith, children Adam, Carl, Jennie and Michael, and to his entire family and colleagues. He will be deeply missed. May his memory be a blessing. Lenore Miller, President Michael S. Perry, Exec. Director Jewish Labor Committee

title: Pop, Rock, Jazz and More: Winners of the 1997 Grammy Awards
description: Single Record: Eric Clapton, ''Change the World''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, PERCY
description: KATZ-Percy. Of Greenwich, CT, on January 24, at the Greenwich Hospital. Husband of the late Blanche Landau Katz, with whom he will be buried in Scottsdale, AZ. Father of Gerald Katz of Pound Ridge, NY, and Lawrence Katz of Scottsdale, AZ. Brother of Estelle Glass and Frances Cohen, both of New York City. Grandfather of Benjamin, Andrew, and Jed Katz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMLIN, KATE LINCOLN
description: HAMLIN-Kate Lincoln. Age 23. Beloved daughter of Suzanne and Ned Hamlin, and sister of Nathaniel. Died at home Feb. 22, 1997. Donations in her memory may be sent to the St. Ann's School Scholarship Fund, Brooklyn, NY.

title: A Clinton Friend and Former Official Survives to Fight New Political Battles
description: In his three decades in the thick of Democratic Party politics, Harold M. Ickes has always been the keeper of secrets, a man who took good notes and no prisoners, who lost his share of battles and lived to fight the next war.

title: Building to Learn In Mexico
description: FOR the last three years, 30 architecture students at the University of Washington in Seattle have wintered in Mexico, not sunbathing and snorkeling, but building a school of poured concrete, with a pergola colonnade that will soon be covered with bougainvillea (below right).

title: McDonald's To Cut Prices To Stem Slide In U.S. Market
description: The McDonald's Corporation, frustrated by steady market share gains by its leading rivals in the United States, plans to strike back with some of its steepest discounts ever, raising the possibility of a fast-food price war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINGLASS, MEYER
description: STEINGLASS-Meyer. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn the passing of Meyer Steinglass, National Publicity Director from the program's inception in 1951 until 1978. A master in the art of communications, he created a magnificent campaign that defined Israel's economy needs clearly and persuasively and inspired a worldwide audience to invest in her growth and development. The legacy of his labors is a thriving nation that has benefitted from the purchase of $17 billion in State of Israel securities. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Gideon Patt, President

title: The Call of Duty
description: Any mention these days of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and Richard Jewell inevitably raises eyebrows and the question of whether we plan to settle Mr. Jewell's libel lawsuit against the newspapers and some of our reporters and editors.

title: Turkish Poet Is Lauded, but Stays Exiled in Death
description: As Turkey settles into what is likely to be an extended confrontation between secular and pro-Islamic forces, symbols take on exaggerated political importance for both sides.

title: Navy Blames Air Controller in F-16 Encounter
description: A Navy admiral today acknowledged responsibility for the close encounter earlier this month between an F-16 fighter jet and a civilian airliner off the coast of New Jersey, telling a House subcommittee that the military's air traffic controller had not followed proper procedures.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SEARCH FOR STUDENT -- The father of a Fordham University student who has been missing for more than a week implored people to search for his son. B3.

title: Koreans Divided on Leader's Apology
description: South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, appears to have won sympathy from the public by apologizing for a scandal that has engulfed his administration. But he has still not fully put the affair behind him, according to political experts and the results of opinion polls made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, ARTHUR, M.D.
description: ROBINSON-Arthur, M.D., January 25, 1997 of Amityville, N.Y., formerly of Ozone Park, N.Y. Beloved husband of Gladys Robinson, devoted brother-in-law of Irene Robinson and Dorothy Stagg. Loving uncle of Barbara and Ronald Robinson, Joyce and Gerald Robinson, Elizabeth and Alan Shulman, Ruth and Michael Orange, Karen and Kennedy White and John Ritter. He was a loving husband as well as a caring physician for over 50 years. He gave of himself as both physician and friend and was loved by all for his warmth and caring nature. Services will be today at 2:15 PM at the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUTER, JAMES B.J.
description: SOUTER-James B.J. In loving memory. Born in Aberdeen, Scotland, October 10, 1923. Died in peace at home on February 11th in Scotrun, PA. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Gray Souter. Beloved brother of Sheena and John Klenert. Memorial service will take place Tuesday, March 4, 11:30 AM at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55th Street, New York City. Burial will be at Maple Grove Cemetery, Queens. Memorial contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Publicis/Bloom Promotes 2 in Dallas
description: The Publicis/Bloom unit of Publicis S.A. yesterday named Steve Price, 45, president and chief operating officer of the Dallas office for the last three years, and Seth Werner, 42, vice chairman and executive creative director for the last decade, to head the Dallas office as co-chairmen and co-chief executives. They assume responsibilities from Paul MacMahon, 51, who previously announced that he would retire at the end of the month. The company said there were no immediate plans for successors to Mr. Price and Mr. Werner.

title: Why Play a Numbers Game?
description: If the number is accurate, leave it alone. If it's understated, fix it; if it's overstated, fix it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, WILFRED R.
description: O'CONNOR-Wilfred R. Judge of the Civil Court, former Director of the Legal Aid Society's Prison Legal Assistants' Program, and former Associate Attorney-In-Charge at the Queens Supreme Court Branch of the Legal Aid Society, on January 23, 1997 at Calvary Hospital. The Board, members and staff of the New York State Defenders Association mourn his death. He was a founding member of our association, who served with distinction as President (1978-1989), and brought us into the spirit by which he lived - pure devotion to the belief that everyone, including the disadvantaged, have a right to the equal protection of the law. Our friend Bill will be greatly missed and we extend to his family our prayers and deep sympathy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ALEXANDER E.
description: ROSENTHAL - Alexander E. Daughters of Miriam Center/The Gallen Institute notes with profound sorrow the passing of friend and benefactor Alexander E. Rosenthal on Tuesday, February 25. Recently named an honorary president, Alexander Rosenthal was involved with the center for half a century. He was president of the facility from 1972 to 1976 and served on many committees including chairing the Investment Committee, co-chairing the Nominations Committee, treasurer of the Daughters of Miriam Foundation, senior vice president of the Brawer Building Association and a member of the Executive and Development Committees. A dedicated champion of the aged and steadfast supporter of the center, Alexander Rosenthal leaves a legacy of years of service to the elderly of the Jewish community. The Board of Trustees & the entire Daughters of Miriam family extend their most heartfelt condolences to Lorraine, Richard and his grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDELMAN, MILTON
description: RANDELMAN-Milton. Milton, we will always remember the happy times our families enjoyed together. We will miss you. Zelinka and Greenman Families

title: New TV Magazine. New Band. New Fuhrman?
description: Sunday brings the debut of yet another weekly prime-time news magazine, this one on CNN, in collaboration with Time magazine. It's called ''Impact'' and Bernard Shaw delivers the come-ons.

title: Recalling Grandma Prisbrey
description: To The Home Section:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant and Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOXENBAUM, HARRY
description: BOXENBAUM-Harry, 88, of Hollywood, FL, January 24, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Irene (Bermack) and the late Sylvia (Cohen). Loving father of Bernie and Gloria, Betty and Mel Saler. Dear grandfather of Abby and Dr. Jonathan Rubin, Steven Boxenbaum, Diane Bader, Karen and Dr. Eric Fisher, David Bader. Great grandfather of seven. Services Monday 12 noon, Sunset Chapel, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY.

title: A Forgotten Architect
description: To The Home Section:

title: Xerox Chief Meets Analysts And Promises '97 Profit Rise
description: At their first big meeting with Wall Street analysts in more than two years, the Xerox Corporation's chairman, Paul A. Allaire, and other top executives yesterday promised a double-digit earnings increase on single-digit sales growth this year as a result of lower costs and a much quicker flow of products to the marketplace.

title: Bringing Up Baby in a Don't-Touch-That World
description: ON a recent rainy Friday, Alyzza Oser, 33, a real estate broker and lawyer with a cheerful, easy manner, was waiting for the babyproofer to arrive at her spacious duplex apartment on West 54th Street. Samantha, her pretty 9-month-old daughter, who has active little hands and a raging curiosity, was sitting in the living room, playing with her mother's briefcase.

title: Reno Resists Pressure for Special Prosecutor
description: Despite growing political pressure from some members of Congress, Attorney General Janet Reno today reaffirmed her position that an independent counsel to investigate the fund-raising practices of the Democrats was unnecessary.

title: Before the First Bell Rings, the Jabbing Begins
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho has always found it difficult to keep quiet, or to keep still.

title: New Report Dulls Shine Of Economy In New York
description: Despite indicators of a renaissance in New York City, from a falling crime rate to a surging payout of bonuses on Wall Street and a rising tide of tourists, the city's overall economic performance lagged far behind the rest of the nation in 1996, a city report said yesterday.

title: GREENSPAN WARNS AGAIN THAT STOCKS MAY BE TOO HIGH
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, bluntly warned investors today that stock prices might be unsustainably high. And he suggested that despite the economy's basic health, the time might be drawing near when the central bank would have to raise interest rates to head off inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVARD, REV. ROBERT J.
description: RIVARD-Rev. Robert J. The Vincentian Community announces the death of Father Rivard, C.M. on February 25, 1997. Survived by his loving sisters, Rita Flood, Beatrice Kelley, and Annette Potena, all of Medway Massachusetts; also 2 nieces. Family will receive friends at St. John's University, Vincentian Residence, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica Thursday 7-9 P.M. and Friday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass will be celebrated on campus at St. John's University Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes on Saturday, March 1, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. John's University Band will be greatly appreciated.

title: Prices Tumble On Testimony By Greenspan
description: Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, after traders took Senate testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to mean that a Fed tightening was probable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINRAUB, WILLIAM C. L.
description: WEINRAUB-William C. L. Age 49, of Norcross, GA. Beloved husband of Anita Z. Devoted father of Stephanie and brother of Jerome. Graduate of Horace Mann School, Yale University, University of Massachusetts, he was an accomplished businessman, craftsman, musician, and raconteur. His passing leaves a void in all our lives. Funeral at Riverside Chapel, Fleetwood, NY, noon Monday January 27. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla.

title: Bridge
description: Mel Colchamiro of Merrick, the 1996 Long Island Player of the Year, is trying to add to a string of recent successes at the Long Island Spring Regionals this week.

title: People
description: * Timothy R. Volk, executive vice president and marketing services director at KSV Communicators, Burlington, Vt., was promoted to president, succeeding Linda Kelliher, who continues as chairwoman.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: When Tomatoes Are Not Red

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday with the obituary of Mr. Jiang's predecessor, Deng Xiaoping, misstated the year in which Mr. Deng was shown reviewing troops in Beijing. It was 1984, not 1985.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DROOZ, RICHARD B
description: DROOZ-Richard B. The Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourns the passing of its longtime member and cherished colleague, and extends its deepest sympathy to his family. Harvey B. Bezahler, M.D., Pres Charles Goodstein, M.D., Secy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, EUGENE ''GENE''
description: WEINBERG-Eugene ''Gene'' of Pipersville, PA formerly of New York, New York, died Sunday night after a protracted illness. He was 86. Beloved husband of Emmeline Epstein Weinberg. Father of Michael and the late Alex. Grandfather of Mia Weinberg Clinton and Michael Weinberg, Jr. Great-grandfather of Keegan, Devin, Amber and Michael III. Relatives and friends are invited to his memorial service at 12:00 noon on Sunday, March 2, 1997 at the family residence at 6312 Carversville Road, Pipersville, PA. Friends are requested to make donations to their favorite charity. For information contact Reed & Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA.

title: Clonalities
description: Two centuries ago, when William Blake posed the question ''Little lamb, who made thee?'' the answer the mystic poet gave seemed obvious: the same gentle God who fathered Jesus made, and blessed, the lamb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, EDNA R.
description: LEVIN-Edna R. Formerly of Mahopac, NY. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Levin. Devoted mother of Sally Shakun and Kenneth D. Levin. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 2.7% on Nasdaq
description: ''Atmel has been a favorite of short-sellers for the last two or three years, because people expected Intel and Advanced Micro to hand their hat to them,'' James L. Barlage, an analyst at Smith Barney, said. ''But the company has continued to report strong results. The fundamental weakness the shorts expected never did occur.''

title: Student's Death Widens Protests in Kenya
description: For a fourth straight day, thousands of students marched through the streets of this East African capital today in a widening campus revolt over the mysterious death of a student leader last weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IAMS, SAMUEL H. (JACK)
Events: Shows and Talks on Design
description: Ceramics and Jewelry

title: Surprises for everyone in a new analysis of affirmative action.
description: WITH California's initiative against affirmative action, Proposition 209, on the books and other states pondering rollbacks in their own affirmative action programs for public higher education, you'd think policy makers clearly understand the consequences of the contemplated changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEXTON, DANIEL V.
description: SEXTON-Daniel V., on Feb. 25, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Rita (nee Ryan). Loving father of Rita Dodge, Patrick, Jane Mackay, Daniel J., Robert and Thomas. Brother of Eileen Graham and Raymond. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Funeral from Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, Inc., 36-46 Bell Blvd., Bayside, NY, on Saturday. Mass of Christian Burial at Sacred Heart R.C. Church at 9:45 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOERSHEIM, OTTO, M.D.
description: FLOERSHEIM-Otto, M.D. Age 100. Loving husband of the late Cornelia. Adored father of Gabriella. Devoted grandfather of Stephen, Anita and Miriam; and great grandfather of Allison. Services 1PM at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76 Road) Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, HOWARD, JR.
description: McCALL-Howard, Jr. We at NYU Medical Center mourn the loss of a dear friend and devoted Life Trustee & former Vice Chairman of our Board of Trustees, Howard McCall, Jr. He was an outstanding and highly respected trustee who was a remarkable individual. He was dedicated to pursue excellence in medical education, research and patient care. Always a gentleman, he convinced others by wise persuasion. His wisdom was recognized by all his colleagues and friends. His humor was unique & always contributed to the analysis of a critical situation. We will miss him. We extend our sympathy to his spouse Jane, his daughters: Jane Politi and Nancy Watson, his son, Howard III, and his four grandchildren. Laurence A. Tisch, Chairman, NYU Board of Trustees L. Jay Oliva, Ph.D., President, New York University Thomas S. Murphy, Chairman of the Board, NYU Medical Center Saul J. Farber, M.D., MACP Provost and Dean, New York University Medical Center and School of Medicine

title: Sales to SFX Broadcasting
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. has agreed to buy radio station WRFX-FM in Charlotte, N.C., from EZ Communications Inc. for $20 million and the radio station WDSY-FM in Pittsburgh. SFX Broadcasting, which is based in New York, said that it was buying WDSY-FM from Secret Communications. The acquisition also includes the John Boy and Billy Syndication Network, whose morning show is heard on 37 radio stations. EZ Communications is based in Fairfax, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOWITZ, ALBERT M.
description: ARONOWITZ-Albert M. The attorneys and staff of the law firm of Aronowitz and Singer mourn the loss of Albert M. Aronowitz, Esq. He was a kind and gentle man and a father figure to us all. For almost 60 years he was a devoted lawyer, diligently representing his clients with skill and compassion. Our condolences to daughters Susan and Judy, and all eight grandchildren. Services 12:15 PM, Monday, January 27, 1997, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: House Votes to Restore Aviation Excise Taxes
description: The House voted today to renew five excise taxes that support the Airport Trust Fund, including the 10 percent surcharge on domestic airline tickets, in an effort to avert a cash crunch in aviation capital programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPOVIC, NENAD
description: POPOVIC-Nenad, on February 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Tatyana. Loving father of Sanya PopovicBogdanich & Gina Goldhammer. Cherished grandfather of Dimitri Bogdanich. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Frontier Theatre and Film Inc., Yugoslavia Project, 233 East 69th Street, Apt. 7G, New York, New York 10021.

title: Stocks And Socks
description: When you become a stockholder in a company, you begin to notice all kinds of things. Michael Eisner's socks, for instance.

title: LAIDLAW TO RECORD $550 MILLION GAIN IN 2D QUARTER
description: Laidlaw Inc. said yesterday that it would record a second-quarter gain of $550 million, or $1.75 a share, because of the sale of its Canadian and United States trash-handling operations to Allied Waste Industries of Scottsdale, Ariz. The $1.6 billion sale, which was completed on Dec. 30, was one of a series of moves intended to return Laidlaw to its transportation roots. Laidlaw, based in Burlington, Ontario, is the largest school bus operator in North America. Laidlaw also said it would reduce its earnings for the quarter by $133 million, or 42 cents a share, for charges related to the $1 billion sale of its hazardous-waste disposal business to Rollins Environmental Services Inc.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Over New Planetarium
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday cleared the way for construction of a new planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, dismissing lawsuits by neighborhood groups opposed to the project.

title: Alzheimer's Homes Open
description: Three boarding homes for people with Alzheimer's disease have opened in Bergen County in the past year and eight more are planned, according to the Northern New Jersey Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. Some Bergen County residents have complained that people with Alzheimer's disease can be found wandering in the neighborhood unsupervised and pose a danger to themselves and others.

title: Seeing Fashion In an Old Light
description: SOFTLY glowing lanterns are the ancient, indigenous lights of Asia. And Calvin Tsao and Zack McKown, architects in Manhattan and Singapore, have given them a voluptuous twist in the modern interior of Joyce Bangkok, a clothing and furnishings store in Thailand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, SOPHIE
description: MARCUS-Sophie. The Board and staff of Camp Isabella Freedman profoundly mourn the passing of Sophie Marcus, the beloved mother of Marilyn Marcus Alper, President of our Board. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family.

title: An Oddly Shaped District Clearly Based on Race
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling by a three-judge Federal panel in Brooklyn that the 12th Congressional District in New York City is unconstitutional. The referees mentioned in the decision are three experts appointed by a state court to develop a plan for Congressional redistricting in 1992. Prof. Alan Gartner was retained to draw the districts.

title: President Defends His Role In Raising Campaign Funds
description: Bombarded with Republican calls for the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Democratic campaign finances, President Clinton said today that there was no ''legal issue'' raised by newly released White House documents detailing his involvement in soliciting money.

title: Some Help In Running A Business Nearly Solo
description: It was Saturday afternoon, and Randy, from Aberdeen, Wash., wanted to talk business with Mitch Schlimer, a New York radio host.

title: Mexican Denies Links To Drug Traffickers
description: The patriarch of one of Mexico's leading political families said today that he had never had ties to drug traffickers and denied that a woman who raised narcotics accusations against him was his personal secretary.

title: CARGILL TO SELL LIQUID-FEED UNIT TO E D & F MAN GROUP
description: Cargill Inc. agreed yesterday to sell a unit that makes molasses-based liquid animal feed to E D & F Man Group P.L.C. for $48.5 million, allowing Cargill to focus on dry feed and grain and oilseed processing. Under the agreement, Cargill will sell its liquid-feed product lines and plants in the United States, Britain, Italy and the Philippines to E D & F, the commodities trading company, which is based in London. The agreement excludes four United States facilities that also make other Cargill products. Cargill, based in Minnetonka, Minn., is the largest closely held company in the United States.

title: Gulf War Panel Will Investigate Warning Lapse
description: President Clinton today ordered an investigation of newly disclosed evidence that American soldiers who blew up an Iraqi ammunition depot in 1991 were not warned about intelligence reports suggesting that chemical weapons might have been stored there.

title: Moynihan, in Gesture, Cancels Fund Raiser for Re-election
description: In a gesture of support for campaign-finance reform, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, today canceled a fund-raising ''birthday bash'' that was to have opened his re-election campaign.

title: Workfare Is a Job With Rights Like Any Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Indians Plan to Endure as Players Go
description: Just because Carlos Baerga was traded last summer, Albert Belle left as a free agent this winter and Kenny Lofton has already said he will be a free agent next winter, the Cleveland Indians are not about to pronounce their grand experiment a failure. On the contrary, John Hart, the architect of the signing scheme, has proclaimed it an unqualified success.

title: Class-action lawsuits by investors are not turning out exactly as Congress planned.
description: A YEAR after Congress altered the rules under which investors can sue companies for securities fraud, the world of class-action lawsuits has indeed changed -- though not necessarily in the ways lawmakers intended.

title: A Warning Investors Have Ignored Before
description: When the Federal Reserve speaks of overvalued stocks, investors usually don't listen. Or at least they don't do so for long. Only later do they regret that decision.

title: Campaign and Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, SIDNEY W., JR.
description: DEAN-Sidney W., Jr. The family and friends of Sidney W. Dean, Jr., will always remember him with love as father, friend, mentor and exemplar of a life well lived. He departed this life January 24, at his home in Greenwich Village, age 91. A lifelong champion of civil liberties, active in the Democratic Party and ADA, he was also active in community affairs and served over 30 years as trustee of the City Club of New York. His longtime friend and fellow City Club trustee Joel Harnett praised Sidney's ''almost religious respect for the First Amendment.'' A memorial service will be held Sunday, February 2, time and location to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAMARA, SR. LORETTA, M.S.C.
description: PALAMARA-Sr. Loretta, M.S.C. Executive Administration and the Board of Trustees of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Sr. Loretta. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to her mother, Rose Palamara; her sisters, Mickie DiMatteo and Sr. Regina Palamara, M.S.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOL, FLORENCE
description: SOKOL-Florence, on Feb. 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late David R. Sokol. Loving mother of Ellyn Goode and Andrew L. Sokol. Cherished sisters of Rose Weinstock, Violet Miller, Gertrude Schwinger and Edith Ertrachter. In lieu of flowers please make donations to your favorite charity. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: U.S. Acts to Simplify Labels on Medicine
description: The Government proposed today that labels on nonprescription drugs be simplified, a step the Secretary of Health and Human Services said would help ''anyone who ever takes a pain reliever, cough syrup or any of the thousands of other over-the-counter items on the market.''

title: Workfare Is a Job With Rights Like Any Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Foundation Pushes Robinson's Legacy
description: Rachel Robinson cannot fail to move an audience when she talks about the 425 past and present Jackie Robinson Scholars who have earned $20,000 college scholarships from the foundation she started after her husband died in 1972.

title: Jewish Housing for East Jerusalem Approved
description: The Israeli Government today approved the development of a large new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem, drawing a chorus of Arab and international denunciation and defying warnings that the move could provoke a new wave of Palestinian rage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIGERS, ALICE J.
description: ELLIGERS-Alice J., 93, on February 11, 1997 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Mother of Patricia J. Abbo. Grandmother of Gigi Abbo, Suzanne Abbo and Marisa Quintero.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Hockey East Commissioner

title: Well, You See, Doctor, Someone's Stolen Dad's Argyle Socks
description: Dr. Block, the ego-shredding psychiatrist in John Patrick Shanley's ''Psychopathia Sexualis,'' which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club, doesn't actually eat his patients. But that little detail aside, he is probably the best (and certainly the funniest) argument for avoiding analysts' couches since Hannibal Lecter, the cannibal shrink, chewed his way through ''The Silence of the Lambs.''

title: PHILIP MORRIS TO SPLIT STOCK 3 FOR 1 AND BUY BACK SHARES
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it would split its stock 3 for 1 and buy back $8 billion in shares over the next three years, causing the company's stock price to reach a record during trading. The company makes Marlboro cigarettes, Kraft cheese and Miller beer. The new buyback plan comes after a $6 billion, three-year repurchase program scheduled to be completed by the end of March. Stock in Philip Morris rose 59 percent last year, raising expectations of a stock split. The stock price has tripled in four years. Shares of Philip Morris rose 25 cents yesterday, to $133.50, in trading of almost 5.7 million shares. Earlier, the stock touched a record high of $136.75.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: THERMADYNE HOLDINGS CORP., St. Louis, said it would sell its wear-resistant metals business, which has annual sales of $97 million, to concentrate on welding and cutting operations and to improve its balance sheet.

title: Carnegie's Charity Aimed to Uphold Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about a British Government plan to privatize the London Underground, comparing the sizes of London's and New York's subway systems, misstated the size of New York's in some editions. The New York system has 238 miles of routes; 714 is the figure for miles of track, with every route having at least two tracks.

title: The File on President Clinton
description: Having turned the White House residential quarters into a Democratic contributors' playground and sleepover camp, President Clinton now tells us that the Lincoln Bedroom was not for sale and no one was actually promised anything in return for money. That may be so, but the image of guests racing in and out of White House bedrooms like something out of a Feydeau farce makes it clearer than ever that Mr. Clinton was presiding over an operation that was out of control and demeaning to the government.

title: Music Industry Celebrates, And New York Joins In
description: The 39th annual Grammy Awards came to New York last night, and it did not take long to distinguish the event from the version of the awards ceremony often held in Los Angeles. While there was plenty of black-tie and evening gown glitz, there was also the inevitable traffic jam as limousines crowded along Seventh Avenue at Madison Square Garden in hopeless limo-lock.

title: U.S. Growth Spurs Prudential of Britain
description: The Prudential Corporation, Britain's largest life insurer, said yesterday that its 1996 operating profit rose 8.6 percent, as the strong performance from its United States life unit, Jackson National, offset the start-up costs of its new banking division. The insurer said that operating profit rose to $:873 million, or $1.4 billion, from $:804 million a year earlier, meeting analyst forecasts.

title: Workfare Is a Job With Rights Like Any Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Shedding State Companies, If Sometimes Reluctantly
description: For men who defended the repression of blacks and secret wars in Africa by declaring that they were holding back Communism, the old white rulers of this country created a surprisingly socialist state. A startling 50 percent of South Africa's fixed assets are in government hands.

title: Space Station Faces a Delay Over Russia's Lack of Money
description: The start of construction of the international space station will probably be delayed until next year because of trouble Russia is having in financing its share of the project, the head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, BENJAMIN WALTER
description: FREEMAN-Benjamin Walter, at age 86 on January 25, 1997 in Margate, FL after a long illness. Beloved husband of Claire for 57 beautiful years, father of Debra and Barry Goldman, and Lynn and David Pravda, doting and loving grandfather to Lisa, Heather, and William Goldman, and Jacqueline and Douglas Pravda, brother of Paul Freeman and the late Lilyan Donner Kaplan. A kind and generous man who will be missed by all who knew him personally, as an attorney or in business (Atlas Corrugated Case Co.). Services at Riverside, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY today at 1:15 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Parkinson's Disease Association or the charity of your choice will be appreciated.

title: Smuggled Chinese Immigrants Released From Prison
description: Smiling shyly and blinking up into a gray sky, the last 39 Chinese immigrants held in a county prison here were released today, three years and eight months after they swam ashore to New York from a shipwrecked smuggler's vessel, the Golden Venture. They left carrying small cloth bags with their few possessions but no clear word on whether they will be granted permanent asylum in the United States.

title: Italian Dressing
description: Mondo Inc., the parent company, based in Florence, Italy, for the Mondo di Marco, Pronto Uomo, M.D.M. and Linea Uomo men's wear lines, is moving its New York headquarters down the block from 37 West 57th Street to the Crown Building, 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street.

description: Let other college basketball programs operate like superstores. St. Joseph's runs an endearing five and dime. The Hawks are ranked nationally for the first time in 24 years and are soaring on the updraft of March Madness for the first time in more than a decade.

title: Coffee Prices Close Higher As Colombia Trims Forecast
description: Coffee prices surged yesterday after Colombian growers lowered their forecast for this year's crop by 5.5 percent. Colombia is the second-largest coffee producer after Brazil.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SARAH FERGUSON, the Duchess of York, has moved back in with Prince Andrew, but she will be staying in the servants' quarters, a newspaper reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Styles pages on Sunday about sculptures of the Three Tenors misstated the rights held by the New York company Arcaseum. It holds rights to the sculptures and products derived from them, not to all Three Tenors merchandise.

title: Bail Revoked for Felon Who Visited White House
description: A Federal judge has revoked the bail of Eric Wynn, a twice-convicted felon who was reported to have attended a White House coffee for large contributors to the Democratic National Committee.

title: Stock Funds Still Register Big Inflows
description: Mutual funds got off to a bigger start this year than ever before, a mutual fund trade group reported yesterday, in contrast to its earlier estimates that last month's cash flows had fallen short of the record set one year ago.

title: Dancing the Balanced-Budget Waltz
description: In 1986, a proposed constitutional amendment to balance the budget fell one vote short in the Senate. The House rejected it by seven votes in 1990 and nine votes in 1992. In 1994, it lost by four votes in the Senate and 12 in the House. The measure fell one vote shy in the Senate in 1995, and last year it lost there by three votes.

title: As Law Takes Effect, Irish Embrace Divorce at Arm's Length
description: Jennifer Gibney is one of the tens of thousands of Irish men and women whose marriages have broken down in recent decades, but whose hopes are rising because of Ireland's first law permitting divorce, which went into effect today.

title: MANAGERS AT LESLIE'S POOLMART TO BUY COMPANY
description: The swimming pool supplies retailer Leslie's Poolmart of Chatsworth, Calif., said yesterday that its board had approved an agreement under which an investment group involving the company's management would buy Leslie's for about $109 million. The management team will pay $14.50 a share for Leslie's 6.55 million common shares and another 960,000 shares that are subject to employee and director stock options. The offer was made by a partnership called Hancock Park Associates 2, which includes Leslie's officers, and Leonard Green & Partners, an investment firm in Los Angeles. Leslie's stock rose 68.75 cents, to $13.6875 a share in Nasdaq trading.

Burial in Saint Thomas, Virgin Islands. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory made to a charity of your choice.

title: Mets Aim To Outwait Whatever Ails Them
description: Joe McIlvaine, surrounded by the walking wounded at the Mets' camp, had his fingers crossed instead of on the panic button today.

title: Kwan Has Fallen, but She Can Get Up
description: At stake is an obscure title, a tidy $50,000 prize, and Michelle Kwan's damaged reputation. Repairs on that last but definitely not least component of this champions-only weekend skatefest are already under way.

description: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

title: CAMCO EXPANDS OILFIELD SERVICES WITH ACQUISITION
description: Camco International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Production Operators Corporation for $575 million in stock, adding natural gas compression to Camco's line of oilfield equipment and services. Based on yesterday's closing price, the offer is worth $54.44 a share to stockholders of Production Operators, which is based in Houston. Camco, also based in Houston, will exchange 1.3 newly issued shares for each share of Production Operators. The acquisition was announced after the stock market closed. Production Operators shares fell 25 cents, to $45.50, in Nasdaq trading, while Camco fell $1.375, to $41.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bonds Extend Losses to 4th Day on Fear of Rate Increase
description: Bonds extended their losing streak to four consecutive days yesterday as a stronger-than-expected report on orders for durable goods in January intensified investors' concerns that the Federal Reserve would push up interest rates.

title: JAMES RIVER WILL SELL TIMBERLANDS TO JOHN HANCOCK UNIT
description: The James River Corporation, a paper and packaging concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell about 95,000 acres of timberlands in Alabama and Mississippi to an investment unit of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston for $110 million. James River also signed a long-term wood supply agreement with the John Hancock unit, Hancock Timber Resource Group, under which James River will have cutting rights on the lands. James River expects to use proceeds from the sale to pay down debt. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of James River gained $1, to $33 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSETTI, ROY
description: ROSSETTI-Roy, 64, passed away on February 26, 1997. Born in New York to a family coming from Siena, Italy, Mr. Roy Rossetti served as Executive Secretary of the Italy America Chamber of Commerce for twelve years, until 1995, working with six different presidents, thus becoming a focal point amongst the business community that lives and operates in this area, trading between Italy and the U.S. Hard working, loyal and imaginative, Mr. Rossetti carried out the activities of the Chamber, initiating and cultivating business and commercial contacts both in Italy and the United States. He proved to be instrumental in shaping the guidelines of the Chamber and creating new programs aimed to its improvement and development. His leading presence in the Chamber assured the continuity of the commercial bonds between the two countries and was therfore of key importance. It is also thanks to him that the Italy-America Chamber of Commerce, the first Chamber in this country linking Italy and the United States, founded in 1887, is the main point of reference for business men of the two countries. For all these reasons the President of the Republic of Italy, Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, bestowed upon him the honorific title of Commendatore in the Order of Merit of the Republic of Italy. Mr. Rossetti is survived by his beloved wife, Paola, daughter Claudia, along with relatives and numerous friends. Services to be held in Miami on February 28, 1997, Van Orsdel Funeral Chapel (305) 446-4412. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that in his memory contributions be made to the American Italian Foundation for Cancer Research (212) 628-9090. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date.

title: Mixing Business With Music And Moves
description: David Dorfman Dance, which opened a weeklong season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, offered as much for the mind as the eyes. Mr. Dorfman, who comes from Chicago, became a dancer after earning a bachelor's degree in business administration, which may account for the interestingly distant perspective he brings to dance. He is also a musician and an athlete. And all of this came together in a program of three new and recent works that suggested new artistic growth. Everything -- wryness of tone, drama and athletic and dance movement -- blended inextricably in work with a decidedly new look.

Our deepest love and sympathy to Audrey Brown Kastan (her niece) and Peter L. Kastan, and all fellow mourners. David and Susan Kastan John Kastan and Janice Eidus

title: Turning People Into Product
description: The disclosure that scientists had cloned several sheep -- including a handsome ewe named Dolly -- surprised much of the world but not those who follow these things closely. Embryologists feigned surprise, but those who had already experimented with human embryos must surely have expected this. The science-fiction writers, meanwhile, took the news of the cloning completely in stride. They have long assumed that synthetic life would one day be common.

title: Paribas of France Returns to Profitability
description: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas S.A., the French financial-services company, returned to profitability in 1996 as strong banking and investment revenues offset a surge in charges. The company reported a net profit of 4.35 billion francs ($763 million) in 1996, recovering from a loss of 3.99 billion ($700 million) a year earlier.

description: At the height of the Democrats' fund-raising frenzy last summer, the chairman of the Clinton-Gore campaign organized a White House coffee that was explicitly intended to bring in $500,000 from 10 wealthy Texans.

He was 82.
