title: Sunday in the Park With Fred: Visualizing Olmsted's Legacy
description: ''VIEWING OLMSTED'' is superbly timed. Many architects and planners today are looking for ways to reinforce the identity of the city in an overwhelmingly suburban age. No figure in American architectural history has more to offer them than Frederick Law Olmsted, the leader of the 19th-century parks movement. Unfortunately, ''Viewing Olmsted'' is not the Olmsted show we've been waiting for. Beautifully executed but narrowly focused, the show perpetuates the standard, truncated view of Olmsted as a visual artist in the picturesque tradition. If he is to receive the honor that is his due, it will come in the form of uncompromising challenges to that convention.

title: A Wall Street Deal Called a Tax Dodge
description: A corporate financing maneuver that had exploded in popularity in the last month has been banned by the I.R.S., which called it a tax dodge that threatened a major loss of revenue for the Treasury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COE, JACQUES
description: COE-Jacques. The entire partnership of Cowen & Company mourns the passing of our longtime friend and eminent colleague, Jacques Coe, 103. Widely recognized as the oldest active broker on Wall Street, Jacques joined Cowen & Company in 1964 as a limited partner. He epitomized an exceptional standard of service and integrity in the financial services industry and will be missed by all who knew and worked with him. Jacques will be remembered for his consummate professionalism, keen market insight, vibrant personality and sense of humor. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Coe family. As Jacques was a founder of the American Chess Association, and past president of the Manhattan Chess Club, contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Chess-in-the-Schools, The American Chess Center, 353 West 46th St., NYC 10036. Memorial service will be held Sunday, March 2nd, 11:30AM, at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, NYC.

As part of its agreement with the developer, Kajima International, the state, which owns the land, agreed to move Route 120, which now bisects the site.

title: Mecke Retires With Injury
description: Mecke, the horse who won $2.4 million as one of the more durable and exciting closers of his generation, was suddenly retired today after his handlers detected a deterioration in the lower joint of his right foreleg.

title: Radon Testing Bill Passed
description: In 1994, the Department of Environmental Protection found high levels of radon in nearly half the child care centers in Hunterdon County and asked lawmakers to mandate radon testing in day care centers statewide. Yesterday, the Legislature fulfilled the request, passing a bill requiring the state's 3,016 day care centers to test every five years for radon, an odorless gas that is the second-leading cause of lung cancer in the country, after smoking.

title: Bridgestone's Profits Rose Nearly 30% in '96
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, the world's largest maker of tires, said yesterday that its profit on worldwide operations rose 29.9 percent in 1996 to a record 70.3 billion yen ($576 million), amid steady growth and the dollar's gains. The figure fell short of Bridgestone's forecast of 73 billion yen ($597 million) because of a $10 million depreciation for good will in its operations in the United States, the company said. Bridgestone is based in Tokyo.

title: Could Jordan Be Cloned? Not Exactly
description: NOW that there is a sheep named Dolly, the possibility suddenly exists that the most coveted and most expensive free agent in pro football, pro basketball, baseball, hockey and any other sport might be the same person: Dr. Ian Wilmut.

title: $25 and Under
description: If you're hungry for beef and plenty of it, you may be looking for a place like 18 de Julio, a Uruguayan grill in Jackson Heights, Queens, a neighborhood that is home to many South American grills.

title: Inside Art
description: Art on the Move

title: Dada Dearest: An Artist Alone With Her Calling
description: IN 1939, Hannah Hoch moved into a former guardhouse on a defunct airfield in the remote Berlin suburb of Heiligensee, ''the ideal place to sink into oblivion,'' she said. She needed to sink into oblivion, as a Dadaist who didn't flee Nazi Germany. Fortunately, she survived the war there, stashing away not just her own work but also irreplaceable Dada documents. She spent the rest of her life quietly working in that house, emerging from her oblivion during her last decades to get a measure of belated renown, which has only grown since her death in 1978, at 88. Now more than 100 of her photomontages are in a fine show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: THERMO FIBERTEK TO BUY BLACK CLAWSON FOR $110 MILLION
description: Thermo Fibertek Inc. said yesterday that it intends to buy the Black Clawson Company's paper stock-preparation business for $110 million in cash and assumed debt. Black Clawson, a subsidiary of Landegger Industries, makes equipment used to process fiber into ''brown paper,'' used for corrugated boxes. The privately held company is based in Middletown, Ohio. Thermo Fibertek, of Waltham, Mass., is a subsidiary of the Thermo Electron Corporation.

title: Tattooing May Be Regulated
description: Although they use needles that can spread disease if not properly sterilized, tattoo parlors have never been regulated in New Jersey. That may change: yesterday, the Assembly passed a bill putting tattoo and body-piercing parlors under the jurisdiction of the Public Health Council, which enforces the state sanitary code and health standards. The bill now goes to the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCE, MARK E.
description: SPENCE-Mark E. January 23, 1997. Services were private, but his family will be accepting visitors at his apartment on February 1 from 1-4 P.M.

title: Home Video
description: Attention Shoppers!

title: MITSUBISHI BUYS REMAINING SHARES OF ROCKEFELLER GROUP
description: The Mitsubishi Estate Company, a Japanese real state company, said yesterday that it had bought all the shares in the Rockefeller Group Inc. that it did not already own. Mitsubishi said it bought a 20 percent stake of the American real estate developer for $151 million from the Rockefeller Family Trust. The Rockefeller Group owns all of the Time-Life building and 55 percent of the McGraw-Hill building. Its 80 subsidiaries include the Rockefeller Center Management Corporation, the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation and Radio City Music Hall Production Inc., an event planning company. Rockefeller Group has no stake in Rockefeller Center.

title: One Is Killed as School Van Crushes Car
description: As a light rain fell on the Harlem River Drive yesterday morning, a school van carrying six high school students to a yeshiva skidded along a stretch of slick road, jumped a guardrail, then crushed an oncoming car, killing the driver of the van.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Dead-Fit Beauty'

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: CENTENNIAL SHARES PLUNGE AFTER TRADING RESUMES
description: Shares of Centennial Technologies plunged 76 percent yesterday after trading of the stock, which had been halted since Tuesday, resumed. The company said it had falsely reported earnings of $12.1 million in the last three and a half years while actually losing money. Shares fell $11.25, to $3.50, on trading of almost 11.2 million shares. The computer equipment maker said it will report ''material losses'' for the last 14 quarters because of sales reversals, inventory write-offs and investment write-downs. Last week Centennial announced that it had reported fictitious earnings of $10.8 million for all of the 1996 fiscal year and the first two quarters of the 1997 fiscal year. According to new findings, earnings for fiscal 1994 and 1995 were also fictitious. Centennial, based in Billerica, Mass., manufactures equipment for computer applications.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 7 about the safe destruction of chemical weapons referred incorrectly to experiments conducted by Teledyne-Commodore, LLC. The company has used a chemical bath to destroy the explosive components of an M-55 rocket and the chemical agents in such rockets, but not to destroy the rocket itself.

title: Judge Tells Hempstead To Prepare Voting Plan
description: A Federal judge yesterday directed lawyers for the Town of Hempstead, L.I., to return to court on May 16 with a plan to divide the town into six electoral districts to replace the current system of electing members of the Town Board at large.

title: Mexico Drug War Exposes U.S. Intelligence Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREEN, WILMA
description: GREEN-Wilma February 28, 1989 Remembering. MY GREAT LADY

title: Scalping Law Is Backed
description: The state's 18-month experiment in legalized ticket scalping still has two months to go, but yesterday the Assembly voted to make it permanent. The 1995 law allowing brokers to charge market value for tickets to concerts and sports events has increased competition, supporters say. The Division of Consumer Affairs said that the number of ticket brokers has risen to 50 from 10 since the law passed, while complaints against them have fallen by half.

title: Cloning Breeds Loathing and Fascination : The Trouble With Dolly
description: From physicians to theologians to politicians to ethicists, the world reacted with brooding and soul-searching Thursday to the advent of Dolly, the cloned sheep from Scotland.

title: Dollar Drops to Lowest Point In Four Weeks Against Yen
description: The dollar fell to a four-week low against the yen yesterday on growing expectations that Japanese companies and investors would sell dollars to bring yen home before March 31, the end of the fiscal year.

title: Art in Review
description: Karl Blossfeldt

title: Expanding Children's Health Care
description: Paula Lincoln of Rockland, Mass., lost her teaching job and her health insurance two years ago, but her sons, Christopher and Jeffrey, still get checkups and shots at a dollar a visit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mutual Funds Strong; Stock Prices Tumble

title: Legal Bills Mushrooming
description: The legal bills facing President Clinton and his wife have grown to more than $2 million. Officials of their legal defense fund say contributions slowed to a trickle over the last six months, and the fund is charging $2 for lists of donors. Page A26.

title: New York's Chancellor Seeking Wider Access to Gifted Program
description: Saying many minority and immigrant students are being shut out of programs for gifted children in New York City's schools, Chancellor Rudy Crew is proposing major changes in how local districts run the programs and choose students for them.

title: Health Care Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOESEL, PEGGY LYON
description: BOESEL-Peggy Lyon. Died in Anaheim, CA. Formerly of Winter Park, FL. Survived by two sons, Barry L. Boesel of Anaheim, CA, and David C. Boesel of Winter Park, FL, and 2 brothers William W. Lyon of Del Ray Beach FL, & Peter B. Lyon of Tuftonboro, NH.

title: Renault Plans to Close Belgian Plant in July
description: Renault S.A. said yesterday that it would close its Belgian car-making operations and report a ''very significant loss'' for 1996, its first in 10 years. Speculation about a 1996 loss was stirred on Feb. 14 when Renault, France's second-largest car maker, after Peugeot S.A., reported a decline in 1996 sales and said its operating loss last year was ''considerably'' higher than expected. The company has refused to comment on reports that the loss could be as much as 5 billion francs ($877 million). It had profit of 2.14 billion francs ($375 million) in 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about the problems affecting regional theaters referred incorrectly to the tenure of Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Mr. Brown's replacement, Douglas Hughes, does not take over as artistic director until July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVARD, REV. ROBERT J.
description: RIVARD-Rev. Robert J. The Vincentian Community announces the death of Father Rivard, C.M. on February 25, 1997. Survived by his loving sisters, Rita Flood, Beatrice Kelley, and Annette Potena, all of Medway Massachusetts; also 2 nieces. Family will receive friends at St. John's University, Vincentian Residence, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica Thursday 7-9 P.M. and Friday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass will be celebrated on campus at St. John's University Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes on Saturday, March 1, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. John's University Band will be greatly appreciated.

title: Sagan Is Remembered at Service As Scholar With Faith in Science
description: Carl Sagan, the astronomer, was remembered yesterday as a Brooklyn boy whose wondrous curiosity about the universe fueled a lifelong passion for science.

title: Uneasy Riders, With Plenty to Fear
description: America as imagined by Peter Bratt in his surreal, politically charged road movie, ''Follow Me Home,'' is no shining misty-eyed melting pot of rainbow-colored dreams and compassionate helping hands. If you are of Chicano, black or American Indian descent, you are fair game for any itchy-fingered redneck with a gun once you stray across the boundaries of your urban neighborhood. Nebraska is portrayed as a particularly dicey state in which to get lost if your skin is brown, black or red.

title: Cuomo Says HUD Needs Added $5.6 Billion for Subsidies
description: Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo told a House subcommittee today that the agency needed an additional $5.6 billion in 1998 to avert the ''greatest crisis HUD has ever faced,'' the possibility that millions of people would become homeless if they lost their housing subsidies.

title: Computers and Education
description: It is not enough, computer specialists say, for New York City businesses to provide schools with computers and fancy gadgets. They must also train students and develop long-term relationships with educators.

title: Bill Would Forbid Visitors To Buy or Carry Gun in U.S.
description: Reacting to Sunday's shootings at the Empire State Building, Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Richard J. Durbin of Illinois introduced legislation today to prohibit foreign visitors to the United States from buying or carrying firearms.

title: The Hunger Of the Hunt For a Man
description: ''Hysterical Blindness'' is a tale of suburban ennui that could have been just another slice-of-life comedy about the search for love and meaning in the land of malls. But the writing, direction and acting display such authority and sensitivity that they raise the work above the commonplace.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, an auto parts concern, said it would sell its warehouse distribution operations in Britain, the Netherlands and Portugal to Partco Group P.L.C. for $168 million.

title: The market struggles with 3Com's bid for U.S. Robotics.
description: THE market gave the 3Com Corporation's proposed $7.3 billion takeover of the U.S. Robotics Corporation a skeptical reception yesterday, sending shares of both companies lower. The skepticism of investors and industry analysts focused on two issues. The deal, they say, does not appear to give 3Com a large new advantage in its battle with the No. 1 computer networking company, Cisco Systems Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYER, JACK
description: DYER-Jack, died in a tragic accident, Sunday, January 26, 1997. Adored and cherished by his wife Carolyn Abrams-Dyer. Father of Julia & Michael Dyer. Stepfather of Ali Frankel. Son of Cissy Brown and Adair Dyer. Stepson of Susan Dyer. Son-in-law of Bobbie Abrams. Brother of Gretchen, Julia and Stephen Dyer. Brotherin-law of Alan and Laura Abrams and Elizabeth Abrams. We all loved him so-services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGGERMAN, KENNETH M. JR
description: SEGGERMAN-Kenneth M. Jr, in New York City on Feb. 27. Son of the late Kenneth M. and Sarah G.A. Seggerman. Survived by his children Kenneth, Tobias, Sarah and Victoria, 3 granddaughters & his brothers Harry and Frederick. Funeral service will be held at St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, 71st Street, on Monday, March 3, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Princeton University Class of 1947 Scholarship Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPORT, ROBERT
description: RAPPORT-Robert. Beloved husband of Muriel, loving father of Paul (Carole) Rapport, Joanne Fischer and Andrew (Mindy) Reade, adoring grandfather of Michael, Matthew, Anne, David, Michelle, Jeffrey, Sydney and Melissa. Graveside services on Tuesday, 2 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. For information call Weinstein-West End Chapel (1-800-452-9597).

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BOYCOTT ENDS -- The boycott of Citarella, the fish and butcher shop, is over. After six months, residents of the traditionally liberal Upper West Side no longer must choose between crossing a picket line and denying themselves prickly sea urchins and other favorites. B2.

title: American Express Names Apparent Successor to Chief
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had appointed Kenneth I. Chenault, a smooth, 16-year veteran of the company, as its president and No. 2 executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DROOZ, RICHARD, M.D.
description: DROOZ-Richard, M.D. Passed on Friday, January 24th. Survived by his beloved wife, Miriam. Dr. Drooz, psychoanalyst and psychiatrist, will be remembered for his brilliance as an academician, clinician, teacher, mentor, and for his kind, generous spirit. He will be greatly missed. Neither he nor his words of wisdom will ever be forgotten. Marla F. Wald, M.D. Chevy Chase, Md.

title: No Surgery for Stanley
description: Boston Red Sox catcher MIKE STANLEY won't require surgery on his spine, the team said yesterday. Stanley, 33, underwent a repeat magnetic resonance imaging test last week, which revealed shrinkage of a herniated disc in his lower neck.

title: Al Pacino as Gangster, A Guy Who's Not Wise
description: There's a great little moment in the gangster film ''Donnie Brasco'' that shows Al Pacino preparing to meet the Godfather. Fine, we've seen that before. But this Mr. Pacino is different: aging, weary, drab, down on his luck though desperately eager to please. Trying to put his best foot forward, he stands dutifully amid a crowd of low-level Mafiosi. The boss walks by without giving him a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JOSEPH D.
description: GREENBERG-Joseph D., 71, Jan. 26, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Shirley A. Greenberg. Loving father of Lawrence, Edward, Francine and Susan. Cherished grandfather of nine. Interment at Eternal Light, Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: Big Rebound For Durables; Gain is 3.6%
description: Orders to factories in the United States for big-ticket goods rebounded in January, rising a larger-than-expected 3.6 percent and setting the stage for continued economic growth.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: That Thing You Do!

title: Defense Company Charged
description: Defective parts sold by a Paterson defense contractor hampered the operation of the jet-landing systems used on half of the Navy's aircraft carriers, Federal prosecutors charged yesterday. David Grimaldi Jr. and his company, the Grimco Pneumatic Corporation, made shoddy parts for the cable systems that snare jets when they land to slow them down, then submitted fake inspection records, according to a six-count indictment.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, SIDNEY W. JR.
description: DEAN-Sidney W. Jr. The trustees and members of The City Club mourn the death of Sidney. He will be remembered as one of the Club's most outstanding trustees. During his nearly four decades of service, Sidyey served as both President and Chair. We will miss him. The Board of Trustees The City Club of New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEMEL, MAX
description: TEMEL-Max. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York extends heartfelt condolences to our esteemed board member, Charles Temel on the passing of his father. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Martin S. Begun, President Michael S. Miller, Executive Director

title: New York Can't Afford Riverfront Park Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYER, PAUL
description: HEYER-Paul. Architect (AIA, RIBA); former President of The New York School of Interior Design, New York; Dean Emeritus and holder of the first endowed chair in architecture at that school; former Dean of the School of Architecture at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York; teacher, lecturer, author of numerous books and articles on architecture and design, including ''Architects on Architecture,'' considered to be one of the pre-eminant books on American architecture. Graduate of the Brighton School of Art, Michigan State and Harvard. On February 22, 1997 at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. Survived by his beloved mother, Ivy Winter Heyer and his cousins, Diane Duca of Norwalk, Connecticut and John Winter of Crawley, Great Britain. Funeral services are private. Memorial service to be held at a later date announced in The New York Times.

title: Howard and Hamilton Cut In Jets' Salary-Saving Move
description: Having been a member of Bill Parcells's Giants Super Bowl championship teams does not guarantee a place with Parcells now that he is the Jets' coach. Nose tackle Erik Howard can attest to that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, JOSHUA
description: LEIBOWITZ-Joshua. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue is shaken by the tragic death of a promising young man whom we watched grow up. We reach out in love to Ruth and Morty and the bereaved family. Would that words could heal broken hearts. Hamakom yenachem etchem.

title: New Fleisher Program
description: The pianist Leon Fleisher has changed his program for a concert tomorrow night with the New Philharmonic of New Jersey. Mr. Fleisher, who is recovering from a chronic hand disability, is to perform Mozart's Concerto No. 12 in A (K. 414), instead of Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Concerto. The rest of the program at the Community Theater in Morristown, to be conducted by Leon Hyman, is unchanged.

title: Town Rejects Female Officer
description: What town would turn down a $375,000 Federal grant to hire five new police officers? South Hackensack might, and the reason, Police Chief Joseph Brown said, is that one of the officers would be a woman. Christine Guthrie, who holds a bachelor's degree in criminal justice, is at the top of the eligibility list and would have to be the first officer hired under the grant, the A.P. reported. But Chief Brown and a township committeeman say other officials do not want to hire her because she is a woman. Mayor Arlene Garris and other officials said the problem was one of finances: The grant money will run dry, and the township would have to pay the officers' salaries. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Immigration to France Unchanged in 20 Years
description: PARIS  Despite the fury of a debate over a tougher immigration law for France, official figures released Thursday showed that the number of foreigners legally migrating to France declined by 40 percent between 1992 and 1995, and that the proportion of immigrants in the population has remained the same for 20 years.

title: Ruling Says Only Padres Can Negotiate for Irabu
description: Barring a deal between the Yankees and the San Diego Padres, neither George Steinbrenner nor Hideki Irabu will get his wish. Major League Baseball's executive council ruled today at a meeting in Chicago that Irabu, a highly regarded Japanese pitcher, was under reserve to the Chiba Lotte Marines of Japan's Pacific League, and the Marines have given negotiating rights only to the Padres.

title: Arafat and His Foes Seek Common Palestinian Ground
description: Islamic and leftist Palestinian groups opposed to Yasir Arafat's self-rule accords with Israel joined his supporters today in a ''national dialogue'' conference headed by Mr. Arafat to plan strategy for negotiations with the Israelis on a final peace settlement.

title: Seduction, A Skill That Gets Results
description: Mira Nair's voluptuously pretty ''Kama Sutra'' follows Maya (Indira Varma), a 16th-century Indian Cosmo girl, as she learns the ways of love.

title: Intrigue Amid Lonely Vistas of Snow
description: ''Smilla's Sense of Snow'' has a heroine whose mother was killed by a walrus, one small sign of the chilly exoticism that made Peter Hoeg's mystery novel such a huge, unlikely popular success. Mr. Hoeg's tale of Arctic intrigue moved from urbane Copenhagen to remote regions of Greenland with scientific concentration and with a snappish main character who enjoyed quoting Euclid and philosophizing about snow.

title: Campaign Reform Made Whole
description: The recent revelations about fund-raising abuses by President Clinton's re-election campaign and by both national party committees have given Congress plenty of reasons to reform the system.

title: Counting the Blessings of a Mayor Who Makes Blessings Count
description: As of this week, the re-election team is finally in place; the headquarters is open; even the Web site is almost ready. With 36 weeks left before the voting, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's professional staff of pollsters and marketing experts is finally assembled and ready to go.

title: If Everyone Writes Standards, Who Will Teach?
description: To the Editor:

title: Newly Popular Corporate Investment Banned as Tax Dodge
description: The Government banned a corporate financing maneuver today that had exploded in popularity in the last month, calling it a tax dodge that threatened a major loss of revenue for the Treasury.

title: In a Hot One, Duke Wears Down Maryland
description: Cameron Indoor Stadium, which lacks air conditioning, can be stifling on a mildly warm winter evening. On a day when temperatures reached the low 80's and had barely declined by game time, the 1940-vintage building was a virtual sweatbox tonight.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Courage Under Fire

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinians Join Forces

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENZER, DR. SEYMOUR
description: TENZER-Dr. Seymour, 81, of Coconut Creek on February 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Fleet). Loving father of Robert, Wendy (Jack) Weisblat, Lisa (Larry) Sporn, and the late Steven. Adored grandfather of Caryn, Michelle, Sean, and Melissa. Graveside services are today at 11AM, the Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, NY. In lieu of offerings donations to the American Kidney Foundation would be appreciated. For further information call the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 6701 West Commercial Boulevard, Tamarac, Florida, 800-758-1151.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBBINS, JEAN M.H.
description: DOBBINS-Jean M.H. Born on October 30th, 1947. Graduated from Rowan College 1969. Former officer of Irving Trust Company. Most recently employed by the National Audubon Society. Wife of David, daughter of Marie and the late Charles Harrahill, and sister of Eileen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with service Saturday, 11:30 AM. Interment private.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: A New Show Full of Plots and Types
description: Fans of ''Homicide'' are in for a rude shock. For six weeks, the slot that usually belongs to one of the best dramas on television (Friday night at 10 on NBC) will be filled by a new show that ranks as one of the worst.

title: SUMMIT BANCORP-COLLECTIVE BANCORP DEAL SEEN
description: Summit Bancorp has agreed to buy Collective Bancorp Inc. for an estimated $856 million in stock, a person familiar with the agreement said yesterday. Collective, based in Egg Harbor City, N.J., has 82 branches, about 50 of which are in southern New Jersey. Spokesmen for the two companies would not confirm the report. Summit, based in Akron, Ohio, has agreed to pay roughly $42 worth of its stock in a tax-free swap for each Collective share, the person familiar with the situation said. Collective has about 20.39 million shares outstanding. Collective shares rose $3.875, to $42, before trading was halted. Summit shares fell $1.75, to $47.50.

title: Steinbrenner Softens And Might Extend Fielder's Contract
description: Suddenly, George Steinbrenner has decided that Cecil Fielder is priceless to the Yankees. Suddenly, Steinbrenner is maneuvering to make the cranky Yankee the happy Yankee. Suddenly, the owner is serious about giving a three-year contract extension to the player who still has a trade request on the table.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, DANIEL
description: GROSS-Daniel. Dearest Dan, two years seem like two weeks. We love you and miss you terribly. Sandy and Gary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAKAKJIAN, BECKMANN, MARY E.
description: TAKAKJIAN - BECKMANN - Mary E., age 72 of Boca Raton, FL, died Saturday, Jan. 25, 1997 at Imperial Point Medical Center in Ft. Lauderdale. Mrs. Beckmann was formerly of Park Slope, Brooklyn, NY, where she served 26 years as Executive Secretary with New Court Securities and successor firm, Rothschild, Inc. She is survived by her husband, Allan G. Beckman, and a brother, Dr. M.J. Takakjian of Los Angeles; also survived by two nephews, a niece and three step-grandchildren. Friends will be received on Tuesday from 2-4 and 6-8 PM at the Babione Funeral Home in Boca Raton, FL. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday at 11:00 AM with the Rev. Anthony Osimo officiating at Babione Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, SOPHIE
description: ORENSTEIN-Sophie. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to her family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi Jeffrey Scherr, President.

title: A Surprise, and Then a Collection
description: AS part of the decor of their Chicago apartment in the 1930's, Florene and Samuel Marx hung a very good Rouault reproduction on the wall. Surprised when visitors mistook it for an original, they decided to go for the real. Their first venture was Braque's ''Yellow Tablecloth'' (1935), which attracted them at Golden Gate Exposition in San Francisco in 1939. They went on, as a team, to develop one of the finest small collections of modern French masters in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, NORMA
description: COHN-Norma. The Auxiliary of North Shore University Hospital mourns the passing of its member and gratefully recognizes her caring commitment to the hospital. She will be sorely missed. Hilary Chilton, Auxiliary President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOWITZ, ALBERT
description: ARONOWITZ-Albert. The East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue sorrowfully records the loss of its esteemed and beloved congregant. Our deepest sympathy to his family. Reuven Siegel, Rabbi Daniel Hirtenstein, President Lawrence E. Levine, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUDO, SAM
description: PLUDO-Sam, on January 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Edna. Devoted father of Penny, Michael and Joy. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Joshua and Chad. Services Tuesday 12 noon at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Knicks Low On Gas As Trip Nears End
description: The point guard's left wrist is sprained, the shooting guard's pride is wounded, and the bags under the coach's eyes cannot fit in the overhead compartment.

title: Restaurants
description: La Grenouille is the most frustrating restaurant in New York.

title: Isis Cites Promising Results in Drug for Crohn's Disease
description: In the first clinical tests indicating that a biotechnology known as antisense may have broad therapeutic effects in humans, Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that its antisense drug for Crohn's disease, an inflammatory bowel condition, had shown promising results.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN HOSPITALITY AGREES TO BUY 5 HOTELS
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire five hotels for $104.5 million. The hotels, which have a total of 1,593 rooms, are the Sheraton Park Place Hotel and the Hotel Luxeford Suites, both in Minneapolis; the Hyatt Regency in Tampa, Fla., and a Holiday Inn and Ramada Inn in San Francisco. Patriot American is a hotel real estate investment trust based in Dallas. The company said the Doubletree Corporation, a hotel management company based in Phoenix, would co-invest 10 percent of the purchase price of the Minneapolis hotels and would manage those properties.

title: Mexico Drug War Exposes U.S. Intelligence Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, W. HOFFMAN
description: BENJAMIN-W. Hoffman, 87, of Garrison, NY and NYC, in peace at home on February 20th. Devoted husband to Joan Ellett. Loving father to Beverley Goodwin, John Bigelow and Nathaniel Prime. Six grandchildren and five siblings and many others will miss his love and charity. Funeral services Saturday, March 1st, 2 PM, St. Philips Church, Garrison. In lieu of flowers: Hospice of Putnam, 43 Kensico Drive, Mount Kisco, NY 10549.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Desperately Seeking Space

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACTER, BARBARA CAMERON
description: SCHACTER-Barbara Cameron on January 26, 1997. A beautiful person both inside and out, who touched everyone in her own very special way. A devoted and wonderful friend who will live on not only in my heart, but also in the hearts of all those who knew and loved her. Barbara, I will miss you and I will always love you. Gail Jeffee Cohen

title: Art in Review
description: Collier Schorr

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DEBORAH SANDERS
description: LEWIS-Deborah Sanders, on January 25, 1997 at home in Darien, CT. Loving mother of Rebecca Anne and Jesse Austin Lewis. Sister of Dona, Mrs. Alexander Y.P. Garnett, also of Darien, and the late Susan Sanders Henck and infant daughter, Katie. Daughter of Durward and Anne Sanders of NYC. Memorial services will be at St. Jame's Church, 865 Madison Ave., NYC on Thursday, January 30 at 4 PM and at St. Luke's Church, Darien, CT on Saturday, February 1 at 11 AM. Contributions may be sent to the Deborah Sanders Lewis Trust Fund at Lafayette American Bank, 20 West Ave., PO Box 1265, Darien, CT 06820; Attn: Mr. Robert A. Locke.

title: A Discovery Puts Humans In Siberia Ages Ago
description: Scientists dating stone tools found in northern Siberia have made the surprising discovery that primitive humans were there as early as 300,000 years ago, much earlier than archeologists had thought that human ancestors who evolved in the warmth of Africa could have survived the rigors of subarctic living.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, BERTHA S.
description: NEWHOUSE-Bertha S. I wish to express our faculty's sadness on the occasion of the death of our long time and esteemed colleague, Bertha S. Newhouse. Her illustrious career ending as a Professor of Accounting began in 1946 and lasted until her retirement in 1985. She was the first woman CPA to teach in the School, to reach the rank of full professor in accountancy, and to serve as associate dean in the School of Business. We who knew her remember her as a dedicated colleague and friend. We offer our condolences to her beloved husband Roy Newhouse, her children Lina and Martin and her five grandchildren. Sidney I. Lirtzman, Dean Baruch School of Business Baruch College, CUNY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANKER, ALBERT
description: SHANKER-Albert. The officers and members of the United Federation of Teachers mourn the loss of the revered and beloved leader & early organizer of their union, Albert Shanker, 68, Feb. 22. An indefatigable fighter for the dignity of all of us who teach children, he inspired us to the causes of improving our schools & working for a more just & democratic world where quality education is the key to equal opportunity for all. Throughout his life, Al Shanker never hesitated to act according to his beliefs, whether or not they conformed to what was popular at the moment. He was a staunch champion of human rights in totalitarian countries, civil rights in the U.S., the rights of workers everywhere and the rights of students to safer schools and more rigorous academic standards. His contributions to education and labor are unsurpassed, and he leaves us a legacy that will surely continue to guide us in our personal & professional lives. The 125,000 members of the United Federation of Teachers join their colleagues nationwide in extending our heartfelt sympathies to the Shanker family, his wife Eadie, his children, Carl, Michael, Jennie and Adam and his three grandchildren, all of whom sacrificed precious time with him so that he could lead and inspire us with his personal humanity, ringing oratory and prescient vision. For that we are grateful. Sandra Feldman, Tom Pappas, Harriet Merchant, Randi Weingarten, Phyllis Wallach, Carmen Alvarez, Frank Carrucci, Ronald Jones, Richard Miller, David Sherman, John Soldini.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRKWOOD, WILLIAM C.
description: KIRKWOOD-William C. The Board of trustees, medical board, administrative staff and employees of New York Methodist Hospital mourn the loss of our beloved vice chairman and treasurer, William C. Kirkwood. A member of the board since 1978, Bill's association with the Hospital actually dated back much farther; he was born at the Hospital. He became vice chairman of the board in 1982 and served on the Executive Committee, chaired the Finance and Budget Committee and was a member of many other board committees. In honor of his many contributions, the board of trustees had voted to rename our West Pavilion the William C. Kirkwood Pavilion at its January 1997 meeting. We are deeply saddened that Bill will not be with us at the dedication ceremony. Those of us who were privileged to know Bill Kirkwood will miss his warmth, his friendship and his gentle sense of humor. Those who worked closely with him will miss his untiring dedication and his intelligent, wise and perceptive counsel. All of us at New York Methodist Hospital express heartfelt condolences to Bill's wife, Gladys and to his son, daughter-inlaw and grandchildren.

title: NHP RECEIVES NEW PURCHASE OFFER, FROM INSIGNIA
description: NHP Inc. said yesterday that it had received a letter from Insignia Financial Group Inc. saying it was prepared to buy NHP, an apartment property manager, for $24 a share in cash and stock, or about $308 million. A week ago, the Apartment Investment and Management Company offered to buy NHP for about $23 a share. NHP's two largest shareholders have already agreed to sell their 55 percent stake to Apartment Investment. NHP, based in Vienna, Va., said it was prepared to evaluate any offer it receives. NHP's shares rose $1.25, to $24.75, in Nasdaq trading. NHP is the second-largest apartment property manager in the United States, providing services for 133,000 apartments. Only Insignia, with about 287,000 apartments, is bigger.

title: Separating the Varied Colors Within the Voice of the Violin
description: The violinist Joseph Silverstein, in his all-Schubert concert with Lee Luvisi at the piano on Tuesday night, seemed to be visiting from another age. He walked onto the Alice Tully Hall stage and stayed there throughout the whole first half of his program (three relatively early sonatinas): there was no going off and returning between pieces to milk the applause and establish a high-strung character. Nor did Mr. Silverstein, conductor of the Utah Symphony and former concertmaster of the Boston Symphony, make any kind of a splash with his playing. He performed as if for friends at home.

title: Why Were They Shot?
description: Eighteen-year-old Robert Reynoso is in constant, searing pain at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital from a bullet wound in his chest. Breathing and swallowing are extremely difficult. He frequently goes into extended, agonizing fits of coughing. Sometimes his overall discomfort is so great that he will turn to a visitor and whisper, ''I just want to die.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBEN, MILES H.
description: ALBEN-Miles H., 97, in Los Angeles where he lived for the past six years, now reunited with his wife of 68 years, Sylvia, who passed away in April of 1996. He will be remembered by son Russ of Los Angeles, daughter Rhoda Alben-Aronson of Riverdale, New York and five grandchildren: Seth Aronson and Ted Alben of Los Angeles, Dr. Daniel Aronson of Lutherville, MD, Nancy Torellas of Manhattan, and Alex Alben of Mercer Island, WA. Miles took pride in eight great grandchildren: Brandon, Cameron, and Sutton Aronson of Los Angeles, Joshua & Rebecca Aronson of Lutherville, Rachel Alben of Charlottesville and Emily and Jeremy Alben of Mercer Island. An Attorney, he was respected as an authority in Real Estate matters in the Motion Picture industry in a thirty-five year career as General Counsel for Warner Brothers Pictures in New York starting in 1928. He was an industry pioneer in the introduction of Employee Benefits in the early thirties. An active supporter of Jewish Community causes, he was the founding President of the Cinema Lodge of B'Nai Brith and organizer of a group that helped escapees from Nazi Germany in 1932. With an encyclopedic knowledge and a photographic memory, he was a leading figure in Anti-Trust Litigation activities of the Movie industry in the 1940s. His lifelong commitment to the importance of higher education led him to establish the Midwood High School Scholarship Fund, making it possible for many gifted students to accept academic scholarships which they may have otherwise had to forego because they lacked minimal funds for travel, clothing, and books. He retired in 1968 as a Vice-President of the Stanley Warner Corporation, the company that assumed management of the 400 Warner Brothers Theaters he had worked with for decades. Burial at New Mount Carmel Cemetery in New York, on Friday.

title: Fewer Doctors, Lower Medicare Costs
description: Hospital officials outside New York are reacting with jealousy, even rage, to the Clinton Administration's plan to pay New York hospitals hundreds of millions of dollars to train fewer physicians over the next six years. But the anger is misplaced. The plan is an innovative way to bring Medicare costs under control and, in the process, better match the nation's supply of physicians with patient needs. Rather than griping that they have been left out, teaching hospitals in Boston, Los Angeles and other training centers ought to root for New York's success in the hope that what is good for New York will soon become policy everywhere else.

title: Wise Warnings to Giddy Investors
description: That latest warning from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that stock prices might be unsustainably high is rooted in a statistical dilemma. The economy -- jobs, production and income -- has been growing at a steady but unexciting pace. Yet stock prices, which should be tied to the growth of corporate earnings, are soaring to breathtaking levels. The rosy scenario is that investors are betting correctly that earnings growth will rise further, justifying high stock prices. The ominous scenario is that stock prices will prove irrationally high, collapse and drag consumer spending and the economy down with them.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Heart Foundation.

title: Salomon Official Chosen for Board of Regents
description: The leaders of the Democratic-controlled Assembly have nominated Harold O. Levy, a vice president and counsel at Salomon Brothers in Manhattan, to fill a vacancy on the State Board of Regents, all but assuring his appointment by the Legislature early next month.

title: In China's Far West, Tensions With Ethnic Muslims Boil Over in Riots and Bombings
description: As Muslim ethnic minorities chafe under Chinese rule, a simmering revolt and seething ethnic conflict have turned much of western China into a heavily armed garrison ready to crush sporadic, spontaneous and seemingly futile acts of rebellion.

title: Broadcast Industry Defends Its TV Rating System
description: Seeking to head off calls for requiring more detailed labeling of violent and sexually explicit television programming, the broadcast industry defended the current ratings system today and pleaded for more time to let it work.

title: Police Remove Encampment Of Homeless
description: The police vans and bulldozers arrived in the rain just before 10 P.M. Wednesday at Manhattan's last large homeless encampment. Carrying flashlights and axes, officers pounded on the plywood doors covering the old Penn Central coal bins under West 66th Street near the Hudson River, rousing the few remaining inhabitants.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAN JANSEN, the speed skater who won a gold medal in the 1994 Olympics after failing in his quest in 1988 when his sister died on the day of a race, has filed for divorce from his wife, ROBIN JANSEN.

title: Art in Review
description: Suzy Frelinghuysen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSTEIN, ISABEL META
description: WOLFSTEIN-Isabel Meta on February 27, 1997, age 95, born in Cincinatti, Ohio. Survived by her niece Ann W. Golden of Rydal, Pennsylvania and nephew Dr. Ralph Wolfstein of Los Angeles, California. Also survived by 4 grand-nieces and nephews and 3 great grandnieces and nephews. Services private in Cincinatti, Ohio.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Someone Else With My Fingerprints'

title: Southern Jewish Angst as One-Liners
description: ALFRED UHRY'S ''Last Night of Ballyhoo,'' a comic drama about intra ethnic Jewish prejudice in Atlanta, is set in 1939, and it often feels as if it had been written then. If your mind wanders during the production (and it might), you may find yourself thinking of an alternative cast of actors, all long dead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, JEROME H.
description: TEITELBAUM-Jerome H. 3655 days. I love and miss you and Mother always. Andrew

title: Annual Charity Drive Winding Up With Second-Highest Total
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund closes its 85th annual appeal today a nose ahead of last year's total, guaranteeing the second-best finish in the charity drive's history. Donations postmarked by midnight tonight will be counted toward this year's fund, leaving hope that the fund may yet break the $5 million mark.

title: Clinton Defense Fund Is Shrinking Rapidly
description: President Clinton and his wife have fallen so deeply into debt from their growing legal bills -- now topping $2 million -- that the legal defense fund they established to pay for their Whitewater expenses today charged reporters $2 for lists of donors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, STELLA (BROWNIE)
description: KAUFMAN-Stella (Brownie). A beautiful, talented and loving woman who enhanced our lives by knowing her. She made a profound impact on us as a caring relative and good friend. We feel blessed to have been given the gift of Brownie's love and friendship. She will be dearly remembered and profoundly missed. Dr. and Mrs. Morton Rosenbluth and Family

title: Gifted Programs' Criteria Vary Widely
description: Selection criteria for gifted programs in New York City vary widely from district to district, with schools and districts starting their programs at different ages and using different methods to test children's abilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, HERMAN
description: LIPPMAN-Herman, 89, formerly of Belle Harbor, died in Tamarac, FL. Beloved husband of Ida, father of Jack Lippman, the late Sheila Sohn, and Carol Lippman. Grandfather of Susan, Steven, Bonnie, Alan, Sharon, Linda and Naomi. Great grandfather of ten. Graveside services Tues Jan 28 Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY 1pm.

title: Group to Buy A BBC Network
description: A group led by the Castle Tower Corporation, a television antenna manager, and Telediffusion de France won a bid to buy the British Broadcasting Corporation's transmission network for $:200 million ($326 million), the British Government said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANDS, ABRAHAM M., M.D.
description: SANDS-Abraham M., M.D. 1/28/07-7/26/86. Happy Birthday, Poppa dear. We still miss you. Love Edith, Penny and John.

title: Winners of the 1997 Grammy Awards
description: Here are the winners of the Grammy Awards presented Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Triton Energy Settles Indonesia Bribery Case for $300,000
description: The Triton Energy Corporation, an international oil and gas development company based in Dallas, agreed yesterday to pay $300,000 to settle Federal charges stemming from bribes that a subsidiary paid to Indonesian Government officials in 1989 and 1990.

title: Strong Finish By St. John's Is a Big Boost For Tourney
description: St. John's victory over Seton Hall Wednesday wrapped up the 10th seeding in the Big East tournament for the Red Storm and enhanced the team's chances of reaching a post-season tournament.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of the 1997 Grammy Awards in some copies yesterday misidentified the winner for album notes. The Grammy went to George Avakian, Bill Kirchner, Bob Belden and Phil Schaap for ''The Complete Columbia Studio Recordings'' (Miles Davis and Gil Evans), not to Will Friedwald for ''The Complete Capitol Singles Collection'' (Frank Sinatra). A corrected listing appears today on page C26.

title: Icahn Ends RJR Nabisco Proxy Fight
description: Taking Wall Street by surprise, the financier Carl C. Icahn announced yesterday that he had sold his 7.3 percent stake in the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation for $732 million, making a profit estimated at no less than $100 million and ending his 17-month challenge to force a spinoff of the company's food business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNBERG, ANNA
description: GRUNBERG-Anna, of Hallandale, FL. and NY died February 26, 1997. Devoted mother of Rodica Eliash and Irving Grunberg. Darling grandmother and greatmother. Services at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street, today at 11 A.M.

title: Earnings at Gap Rose 11% in 4th Quarter
description: Gap Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose nearly 11 percent in its fourth quarter, with Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy stores all showing increased profitability.

title: Art in Review
description: Barry LeVa

title: Women and minorities are courted by auto makers, which now recognize their buying power.
description: AUTO makers, the nation's biggest advertisers, are stepping up marketing efforts aimed at women and minorities, who account for a rising share of car buyers.

title: French Luxury Hotel Planned for West Side of Manhattan
description: Accor, the giant French hotelier, plans to build a 27-story, 400-room luxury hotel on the rarest of all commodities in Manhattan, a vacant lot, on West 44th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, GERALD
description: MARKS-Gerald, January 27, 1997. The Board of Directors of the New York Sheet Music Society mourns the loss of our gentle, devoted member. Gerald, one of the last Tin Pan Alley giants, composer of ''All of Me,'' ''Is It True What They Say About Dixie,'' and 400 other songs will be missed, admired and remembered. He is survived by a niece, Harriet Bloomberg, 400 songs and thousands of friends and admirers. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers a donation to the Gerald and Edna Marks Award Fund or the New York Sheet Music Society at P.O. Box 354, Hewlett, NY 11557 will be appreciated.

title: LEADERS IN SENATE DEMAND F.B.I. FILES ON C.I.A. NOMINEE
description: The chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today that unless he received all of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's files on Anthony Lake, President Clinton's nominee as Director of Central Intelligence, he would not hold confirmation hearings for Mr. Lake.

title: No Money? No Problem! It's All Free
description: ''NEW YORK is too expensive.'' So goes the mantra of the Manhattan tourist. To this complaint, penny-pinching New Yorkers often respond, ''You just have to live here long enough to know where to go.''

title: Series of Lawsuits on Tobacco Are Subjects of Split Decisions
description: It was a day of good news, bad news, and no news for combatants in the tobacco wars.

title: Where Art Thou, Decorum?
description: Whoops! As even casual followers of the B-movie spoofs from Troma Entertainment must be aware, none of this scrappy little company's films would be complete without a brightly hued regurgitation or two, or three, or four, usually in colors like green and purple. And in ''Tromeo and Juliet,'' a deliriously grossed-out parody of Shakespeare, Juliet, a porn mogul's vegetarian daughter, goes to great lengths to empty the iron stomach of her fiance, a nerdy billionaire meat packer whom her family is forcing her to marry.

title: Ex-G.I. at Fort Bragg Is Convicted in Killing of 2 Blacks
description: A jury convicted a white former Army private today on murder charges in the shooting deaths of a black couple in this Army town near Fort Bragg in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIGH, CHARLES R., JR.
description: SLIGH-Charles R., Jr. The Directors and Staff of the Deafness Research Foundation note with sorrow the passing on January 25th in Delray Beach, Fl, of its former Chairman, benefactor and loyal friend. Mr. Sligh was former Chairman of the Sligh Furniture Co. of Grand Rapids, MI and former President of the Natioanl Association of Manufacturers. He will be greatly missed. We extend our sympathies to his widow and his family. Collette Ramsey-Baker, Founder, DRF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, BERNARD
description: OPPENHEIMER-Bernard. on January 27, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Alice (Lizzi) and Ruth. Loving father of Linda and Alan Greengrass. Devoted grandfather of Andrew and David. Services Wednesday, 12:30PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAUMBURG, ELSA S.
description: NAUMBURG-Elsa S. On Jan 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Frederic. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Jan 29, 1997 at 11am

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDLER, ADOLPH
description: HENDLER-Adolph, January 26, 1997. Friend, companion and devoted husband of Stella Dratler. Loving father of Roberta (Stephan Melnick), adoring grandfather of Lauren, caring uncle to niece Louise Dratler. Adolph earned the respect of the entire graphic arts industry as teacher, lecturer, consultant. Died peacefully at home.

title: Suspense-Filled Puzzle Draped in a Dark Mood
description: A sullen young roustabout slumped outside a diner off a desert highway near Las Vegas is approached by a well-dressed older man with bags under his eyes and a poker face who offers to buy him coffee. Suspicious but hungry, the young man, John (John C. Reilly) accepts, and over breakfast, Sydney (Philip Baker Hall), the grimly formal stranger who accosted him, poses a question, ''If I were to give you $50, what would you do with it?''

title: MacLean's Memorable Day . . . And Night
description: John MacLean, the career scoring leader for the Devils, spent most of Wednesday night at a hospital in Livingston, N.J., awaiting the birth of his first child. After a brief nap this afternoon, he came to Continental Arena tonight and celebrated the birth of his son, John, at 12:40 A.M. today by scoring on a rare penalty shot to lead the Devils to a 4-1 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: By Belittling Russia's Military, Ex-General Tries to Save It
description: Russia's Defense Ministers have rarely hesitated to tout their nation's military power. But Igor N. Rodionov has taken a decidedly different approach.

title: Confidence Is Expressed On Drawing New District
description: One day after a three-judge Federal panel invalidated the boundaries of the largely Hispanic 12th Congressional District, Democratic elected officials predicted that they could redraw it without affecting the lines of at least half of the 14 city-based districts or endangering the re-election prospects of incumbents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VENETIOU, JAMES JOHN
description: VENETIOU-James John. March 1, 1996. Memorial service on the 1st anniversary will be held at St. Catherine's and St. George, 22-28 33rd St., Astoria, Sunday, March 2, at 10 A.M. Your beloved memory will remain with us forever. Love, Bud, Irene, family and friends here and in Greece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JANE CARTER
description: JOHNSON-Jane Carter, on Tuesday, February 25, 1997, in NYC. Alumna of Chatham Hall. Leaves behind Valerie Westheimer.

title: If Groundhogs Were Boastful: 'I Hate to Say I Told You So'
description: Punxsutawney Phil was one laid-back groundhog yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, RUTH
description: LONDON-Ruth. Peacefully died January 26, 1997. Loving mother of Roberta Martell and Sheila Mandell; grandma of Troy, Philip, Elyse and Peter; sister of Shirley Rubinstein and sister-in-law of Martha Walter; and dear aunt, great-aunt, cousin and friend, who fought against injustice and worked for peace and union rights. She will be missed, remembered and loved. Friends and family may call at 2630 Cropsey Avenue, Apartment L5, Brooklyn, NY, on Sunday, February 2, 1997, 2-5 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, SAM
description: FRIEDLANDER-Sam. July 2, 1911 to January 28, 1995. Remembered always. Ruth

title: National Tests Show Students Have Improved in Math
description: In a generally encouraging sign of progress in American education, the latest report from the only national assessment of educational achievement shows steady and significant progress in mathematics test results by the nation's fourth-, eighth-, and 12th-grade students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNIN, MOREY
description: BUNIN-Morey, Feb. 26, at home in Woodstock. Master puppeteer; creator of ''Foodini the Great''; inventor of Aniforms, a live cartoon process. His work is in the Museum of Radio and Television. He brought joy to millions, and was deeply loved and will be missed. Survived by his wife, Charlotte; children David, Erica, Reada; grandchildren Alex, Jennifer, Emily, Michael, Damian. Memorial March 2, 4 P.M., at the home of David and Rachel Bunin, 9 Poplar Street, Dumont, NJ.

title: Vienna Philharmonic Lets Women Join in Harmony
description: The Vienna Philharmonic, a proud bastion of male musicians since its founding 155 years ago during the gilded days of the Hapsburg empire, bowed to the modern world today and agreed to admit women as full members.

title: Forgotten Wanderer, Back From Oblivion
description: THE American landscape painter Louis Remy Mignot (1831-1870) is barely a footnote in surveys of American art. He was thoroughly schooled, had artist friends in high places and earned good press in his day. But after he died suddenly of smallpox at age 39, he was largely forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIB, CARROLL INGALLS
description: LEIB-Carroll Ingalls. Died suddenly on Thursday, January 23, 1997. Loving mother of Eric Leib and Cara Leib of New York City. Dear sister of Melville Ezra Ingalls IV of Key Largo, FL. Services private. Burial will take place in Cincinnati, OH. A memorial service in New York City will be announced at a later date.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Nobody would have called the old La Caridad, an Upper West Side institution that has been feeding the neighborhood for more than 20 years, charming.

title: Too Much Fun At the Kremlin: Aides Lose Jobs
description: As President Boris N. Yeltsin himself can attest, vodka and the Kremlin usually mix. But after a celebratory party in the Kremlin got drunkenly out of hand this month, the President's personal photographer and several senior members of the presidential security service were dismissed.

title: Plastic Surgeon Is Convicted Of Disguising Wanted Man
description: Despite a jolt when the star witness could not identify the accused in court, a Philadelphia plastic surgeon was today convicted of helping a wanted drug lord elude the police by surgically transforming his face and fingerprints.
